title: Japan Vehicle Exports
description: Japanese auto makers exported 9.1 percent fewer cars, trucks and buses in January than they did a year earlier, largely because the yen's rise against the dollar shrank shipments to the United States, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. Exports to the United States dropped by 19.4 percent, to 199,904 units. Japanese companies exported a total 524,785 units in January.

title: Legal Adviser Leaves a Trail of Furious Debate
description: His legal theories on the interpretation of treaties have overshadowed the Senate debate over the new missile accord. He is the State Department's point man contesting the move by Congress to close the Washington office of the Palestine Liberation Organization. And his legal rationale for the American bombing raids on Libya in 1986 still stirs debate.

title: Bank-Report Rule Change
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has decided to require that banks give depositors easier and faster access to their call reports, the statements of financial condition that banks file with the agency.

title: British Trade Deficit
description: Britain said today that its current account deficit for January widened to a record $:905 million, or about $1.6 billion. The results came as a surprise to analysts, who expected the figures for the current account, which includes services and overseas investment earnings as well as merchandise trade, to be closer to the revised shortfall of $:401 million in December.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Feb. 8 with an article about exhibitions dealing with the architecture firm of McKim, Mead & White carried an incorrect order, provided by the New-York Historical Society, for the identities of the men shown. From the left were William Rutherford Mead, Charles Follen McKim and Stanford White.

title: Trump Bows Out
description: Donald Trump announced yesterday that he would no longer have anything to do with trying to find a buyer for the New England Patriots.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 7 percent stock dividend paid in December 1987. Year-ago periods include a net gain of $334,274 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: The Dance: Melanie Stewart Troupe
description: ALTHOUGH Melanie Stewart had ideas for several different kinds of dances, she failed to find kinetic images to express them in the program that Melanie Stewart Dance, her company from Philadelphia, offered Saturday night at the Horace Mann Theater as part of the Morningside Dance Festival of Columbia University Teachers College. It was an evening of blurred choreography.

title: 2 Decades of Decline Chronicled by Kerner Follow-Up Report
description: In the 20 years since the Kerner commission described a nation racially divided, life for inner city blacks has worsened as the races have grown further apart socially and economically, according to scholars who gathered here this weekend to follow up the original report.

title: Dawkins Announces Race for Senate
description: Pete Dawkins, a retired Army general and former West Point football star, formally announced his candidacy today for the Republican nomination to oppose Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, in November.

title: Gooden Takes Center Stage
description: The Mets staged their first full workout of spring training today and delivered some theater to their new audience on Florida's Gold Coast. Dwight Gooden pitched batting practice for the first time and fired the heater past sluggers like Gary Carter and Darryl Strawberry.

title: Yanks Happy With Meulens
description: Every day, the rows of seats begin to fill in the early morning, before the players even arrive.

title: VIRATEX INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $856,000.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Includes a credit of $4.7 million from an adjustment to the LIFO reserve, compared to a credit of $1.7 million a year ago. c-Includes a charge of $9 million from the LIFO reserve, compared to a charge of $8.4 million last year. The effective tax rate in the latest year was 40.8 percent, compared with 45.8 percent in the prior year.

title: Tax Appeal by Lawyers Dismissed
description: The Supreme Court today rejected an appeal by lawyers in the Washington office of a New York City law firm of a decision that New York State and New York City can tax a portion of their partnership income even though they do not live or work there.

title: Dole Chides Bush on Panama Crisis
description: Senator Bob Dole today introduced the Panamanian crisis into the Republican Presidential campaign, seeking to turn the turmoil in that country against Vice President Bush and his appointed role in charge of anti-narcotics efforts.

title: Brain-Deficient Baby Dies at Loma Linda
description: An 8-day-old baby girl born with almost no brain died one day after she was taken off a respirator used to preserve her organs for transplant, hospital officials said today.

title: Advertising; Myers's Rum Tests Videos In Nightclubs
description: WELL aware of the impact that motion and music can add to pictures and color in promotions, the House of Seagram since December has been testing video advertising for its Myers's Rum.

title: Lawyer Held In Contempt At Mob Trial
description: A prominent lawyer and his law firm were held in contempt of court today for defying a judge's order to defend a reputed organized-crime leader whose own attorney had become ill during a 15-month-old trial.

title: Democrats Turn Up Volume in Debate
description: With the Southern primaries only eight days away, the leading Democratic Presidential candidates turned up the volume of their debate, clashing repeatedly here tonight on a wide range of issues and seeking to strike patriotic and nationalist chords.

title: Food and Brain: Psychiatrists Explore Use of Nutrients in Treating Disorders
description: LINKS between compounds in the food people eat and the levels of certain chemicals in their brains are leading some psychiatric researchers to suggest that nutritional supplements might be used as psychiatric drugs.

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter and year results are after pretax charges of $65,908,000, including $62,685,000 of restructuring costs.

title: Arizona Senate Begins Impeachment Trial of Mecham
description: The Arizona Senate began hearing evidence here today against Gov. Evan Mecham in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years.

title: 2 in Manhattan School Are Top Science Winners
description: Two seniors at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan took the two highest honors today in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, the prestigious nationwide competition for teen-age students of science.

title: Solomon, British Pianist, 85, Dies
description: Solomon Cutner, a British pianist known to the musical public as Solomon and greatly admired for his immaculate, stately renditions of works by Schubert, Beethoven and others, died on Feb. 2 in London. He was 85 years old.

title: Why Testing Tots Is a Wrong Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Peugeot Incentive
description: Peugeot Motors of America Inc. said it was offering $3,000 toward the purchase of a new car to those who trade in Peugeot models that they have owned for at least four months. The company said the offer was intended to increase the resale value of its cars, whose prices have been raised as a result of the weakening of the dollar.

title: Sale by Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation has completed the sale of a timber subsidiary to Sierra Pacific Industries of Redding, Calif., for $460 million. The two companies had announced their agreement Oct. 12 on the sale of the Santa Fe Pacific Timber Company, which owns and manages about 520,000 acres of timberland in Northern California. The sale nearly completes Santa Fe's restructuring program, leaving only one non-core business for sale, the Black Mesa pipeline.

title: Tribes Seek Settlement For Land Lost to a Dam
description: The fertile bottom lands of the Missouri River where the Arikara, Hidatsa and Mandan Indians thrived for seven centuries are gone forever, buried beneath the waters of Lake Sakakawea.

title: Hart Ruled Off Ballot In New York Primary
description: Gary Hart's stumbling Presidential campaign was dealt a major setback today when the New York Board of Elections ruled that he had failed to qualify for the state's Democratic primary ballot.

title: Tax Watch; Is It a Business Or a Tax Shelter?
description: WHAT is the difference between a business and a tax shelter?

title: E.P.A. Surveys Asbestos in Buildings
description: More than 500,000 office buildings, apartment houses, stores and other public and commercial buildings contain potentially dangerous loose asbestos in deteriorating condition, the Environmental Protection Agency reported today.

title: Elated Calgary Turns to Job Of Maintaining New Stature
description: The XV Olympic Winter Games are over, and now Calgary can take a deep breath, relax and enjoy the rewards.

title: Pickens Bidding for Homestake
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, offered nearly $2 billion today to acquire the Homestake Mining Company, one of the nation's largest gold producers.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Market Place;
The Obsession With Takeovers
description: LEAD: IN recent weeks, the stock market has been almost obsessed with takeover stocks, those of both real and rumored deals. ''Stories are dominating the market,'' said Steven A. Kroll, president of Hutton Asset Management, a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. that manages $23 billion in mutual fund assets.

title: HENLEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized and unrealized investment losses totaling $112 million and $102 million, respectively, and higher interest expense related to additional borrowings for the acquisition of 15.1 million shares of Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corp. common stock, common stock repurchases and other investments. c-Includes $286 million of pretax restructuring charges related to writedowns and asset revaluations, partially offset by a $35 million pretax gain on the sale of a minority interest.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Disappearing Debates
description: The Bush camp says the Vice President plans no further debates with his competitors for the Republican Presidential nomination. That's smart; he feels confident again about his prospects and doesn't want to risk a knockout blow. But such a blow is surely unlikely, to judge by the debates in Atlanta last weekend. The debaters, Republican and Democratic alike, have fallen into ruts.

title: Recital: Arleen Auger Sings
description: PERHAPS the only unkind words one could venture against Arleen Auger's recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday night is to note her lack of hotbloodedness - the kind of biting abandon Donizetti asks for in songs like ''La Zingara.'' Miss Auger's soprano technique and her musicality is so suffused with elegance, in other words, that shedding it seems impossible.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter loss was primarily attributable to continued poor refining margins experienced throughout the United States, and to start-up costs associated with the establishment of the company's new crude oil blending operation in the San Joaquin Valley Area of California.

title: Royal Couple Captivate Los Angeles
description: When the Duke and Duchess of York plunged their forks into a crepinette of salmon and whitefish in champagne chervil sauce at 8:32 P.M. Sunday, two years of planning were triumphantly over.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Archbishop Tutu was arrested along with two dozen other church leaders when they marched toward the South African Parliament in Cape Town to protest the banning of 17 anti-apartheid groups last week. Page A1

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss on investments of $3,057,000 for the quarter; the year includes capital gains of $8,283,000. c-Net income and includes capital gains of $2,019,000 for the quarter; the year includes capital gains of $13,170,000. The company said its previously announced $22,600,000 net-of-tax charge against 1987 fourth quarter earnings contributed substantially to the loss. The charge resulted primarily from the termination of financing agreements with the career general agency field force and a restructuring at the company. Included in the fourth-quarter charge was $3.1 million related to the discontinuation of a portion of the company's individual health insurance line of business and the cancellation of a small employer group health case at the unit. The company also noted that annual and fourth-quarter losses included operating losses from individual and group health insurance lines which worsened throughout 1987 and deteriorated significantly during the fourth quarter.

title: Gene I. Sogioka, 73; Painted Camp Scenes
description: Gene Isao Sogioka, a watercolorist who painted scenes of daily life in an Arizona internment camp where he and other Americans of Japanese descent were held during World War II, died of cancer of the larynx on Feb. 21 at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Security Pacific To Buy Hibernia
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding concern, agreed to acquire San Francisco-based Hibernia Bank for $160 million, or about one and a half times its book value. Hibernia was put on the auction block by its parent, Hong Kong-based First Pacific Holdings Ltd., last summer. But after the October stock market crash First Pacific said it was no longer actively seeking a buyer.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $4,000 and a credit of $100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the company's share of a partially owned unit's extraordinary item. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,869,000 for the quarter and $1,738,000 for the year, and a gain of $617,000 from a share in the partially owned unit's for both the quarter and year. The company said the latest fourth quarter also includes a charge of $1,734,000 from a reserve established for unrealized losses on the marketable securities portfolio.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
10,000 at Slain Officer's Mass Display Resolve
description: In a turnout that veteran officers said was the largest they had seen at a police funeral, more than 10,000 policemen today mourned one of their own who was shot last week while guarding a narcotics witness in Queens.

title: Advertising; Frances Denney Buys New York Showroom
description: The Frances Denney Companies, Lynchburg, Va., makers and marketers of fragrances, cosmetics and skin-care products for the well-off, has acquired the New York Showroom, a direct response company in Greenwich, Conn., that specializes in selling through television and cable. It was a cash deal and no further details were given.

title: SEACOAST SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: There are no share earnings for the year-ago periods because the company converted from mutual to stock form in March 1987.

title: A Pistol Shot in the Nation's Ear
description: A commission on riots! A national day of prayer! People hooted at Lyndon Johnson's response to the long hot summer of 1967. He would have done better, a cynic said, to appoint a commission on prayer and declare a national day of riot. After all, study commissions are just devices to buy time till the problem cools.

title: REX NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
2 White Police Officers Charged With Racially Motivated Assault
description: Two white New York City police officers were indicted yesterday on charges that while off-duty in October 1986 they assaulted two black men in a racially motivated street fight in midtown Manhattan.

title: TV Review; 'To Hear A Pin Drop,' On 13
description: YOU don't have to visit a disco and stand by a loudspeaker to impair your hearing; everyday life may do the same thing. Unwanted noise in an urban environment can create a new kind of pollution. ''Innovation,'' on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight, explains how; it also explains what technology can do about it.

title: WIDESPREAD FRAUD REPORTED IN CHINA
description: More than $48 million allocated to alleviate poverty in China has been embezzled or misappropriated by local officials, the country's leading newspaper reported today.

title: RED LION INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-to-date represents April 14 to Dec. 31; the company has no comparative figures because it commenced operations on April 14, 1987.

title: Gay Men's Chorus Doesn't Sing for Gays Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Abrahamson, Bowdoin Professor, 82
description: Albert Abrahamson, the George Lincoln Skolfield Jr. Professor of Economics emeritus and former dean of Bowdoin College, died Feb. 14 at the Falmouth Convalescent Center in Falmouth, Me. He was 82 years old.

title: HOME FREE VILLAGE RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Colorado's High-Oxygen Fuel Test Runs Smoothly
description: Colorado's first experiment with high-oxygen fuels ended today without the epidemic of clogged fuel injectors and stalled cars predicted by opponents of the smog-control program.

title: Learning to Govern the Bill Bradley Way
description: It seems very long ago that a 34-year-old former basketball star named Bill Bradley began a second career as a New Jersey politician.

title: Rebel Rivalry Is Hampering Afghan Talks
description: The war in Afghanistan has produced at least two factions of guerrilla leaders - Islamic fundamentalists and traditional leaders with tribal and village constituencies - whose clash of ideologies and ambitions is hampering negotiations for a Soviet troop withdrawal and an eventual peace.

title: Back in Board Rooms, Out on the Town
description: The dress is back. Oh, some women have always worn them. But not since the ubiquitous Courreges shift of the 60's has the dress made such a strong fashion statement.

title: DRESS BARN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Merger by Holmes a Court
description: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier, today announced a plan to merge his two leading companies after clearing the decks two weeks ago with huge write-offs of losses in the stock market.

title: New Tools Are Aiding Excavation Of Sites
description: Archeologists may be inspired by lofty dreams of a major find, but their days in the field are often more prosaic: as they excavate, they must record by hand the mountain of detail they unearth, in a tedious, time-consuming and error-prone process.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
S-K-I- LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings were affected by continuing restructuring charges.

title: Israel Considers Barring the Press From Arab Areas Hit by Turmoil
description: Israeli officials, stung by foreign television footage showing four soldiers beating two captive Palestinians, are considering banning journalists from areas of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Rewards Are Few For Race-Walker
description: Maryanne Torrellas will go to Indianapolis in mid-July to compete in the United States Olympic trials. But for the 29-year-old from Clinton, Conn., who led all women this winter in Mobil Grand Prix indoor points, a victory there will not mean a trip to the Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Penney to Sell Its Midtown Skyscraper
description: Declaring that it did not want to be in the real-estate business, the J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would sell its skyscraper headquarters in midtown Manhattan as part of its previously announced relocation to Dallas.

title: GOLDOME BANK FOR SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The bank converted to stock ownership in August.

title: Porter Scores 22 for St. John's
description: St. John's kept its hopes for a post-season tournament bid alive tonight.

title: Islanders Multiply, And So Do Options
description: Bill Torrey, the general manager of the Islanders, stood with Al Arbour, his director of player personnel, and laughed at the incongruity of things. The calendar insisted it was February, but the scene in front of them looked an awful lot like late summer.

title: A Revival to Rival a Premiere
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will present a new piece by Mr. Cunningham during its New York season, which opens tonight at the Joyce Theater. There will also be a New York premiere. But for many people, the major event of the season is the single performance, tonight, of ''RainForest.'' Last performed in New York in 1978, the dance is vividly remembered as a work of special sensuousness and atmosphere created by a choreographer whose expression of passion and sensuality was usually far more implicit.

title: KEY RATES
MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $1.4 million and $3.7 million from the repurchase of long-term debt for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; both periods include a pre-tax charge of about $600,000, taken in the second quarter, of about $600,000 for proxy contest costs.

title: New Arms Agency Chief Is Delayed by Helms
description: President Reagan's choice to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency will not be able to assume his post for at least another month because of recent objections raised by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

title: Problems Seen in Children With Transplanted Hearts
description: There are signs that children who receive heart transplants develop atherosclerosis, a transplant surgeon says. He says the children also seem to have a worse survival rate than adults given new hearts.

title: PROSPECT PARK SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are not available for the 9 months and year-ago periods because the company had not yet converted to stock form.

title: Stage: Korder's 'Boys' Life'
description: AS we all know well by now, the modern American man is a wonderful creature - caring, open, sensitive, a boon not only to his buddies but also to the emancipated women he formerly treated like chattel. Or so we are to believe from the past decade's worth of confessional books, magazine columns and daytime talk shows in which man after man has bravely, even tearfully, come forth to testify that, yes, guys have feelings, too, and can cook quiche as well as eat it.

title: How Creditworthy Is the World Bank?
description: LEAD: The World Bank, originally established to help reconstruct postwar Europe, and a major source of development aid to third world governments, is now creating a new role for itself: that of central manager and negotiator in the continuing ''third world debt crisis.''

title: A Strike in Panama Has Limited Effect
description: A general strike called to protest the ouster of President Eric Arturo Delvalle last week met with limited success here today, amid what organizers of the action described as a campaign of official intimidation against them.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the LIFO method of inventory valuation hurt earnings in the latest quarter and year. The company also said it had a pretax LIFO charge of $5,420,000, compared with a pretax credit of $2,489,000 a year ago. For the year, the company said its pretax LIFO charge was $8,051,000, compared with a $142,000 charge the prior year. The company also said an accounting change resulted in a pretax credit of $1,115,000 for the latest quarter, and $4,715,000 for the year.

title: Wage Freeze in Norway
description: Norway's Government proposed a temporary wage freeze today. A permanent plan to control the nation's 8.7 percent inflation is expected in two weeks.

title: Vincenzo Celli, 87, A Dancer, Teacher And Choreographer
description: Vincenzo Celli, a former principal dancer and choreographer at La Scala Opera House in Milan and a dance teacher whose pupils included Alicia Markova and Jerome Robbins, died Sunday at Greenwich Hospital after a heart attack. He was 87 years old.

title: Patterns; Anne-Marie Schiro
description: New Cardin Beachhead

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 102, Bulls 101: Gerald Henderson's driving layup at the buzzer last night snapped the 76ers' five-game losing streak. After Michael Jordan's free throw gave visiting Chicago a 101-100 lead with 59 seconds left, each team missed opportunities to score. With four seconds remaining, the Bulls' Horace Grant missed two free throws. Philadelphia's Mike Gminski grabbed the rebound and the 76ers called a timeout. The clock, however, still read four seconds, prompting Coach Doug Collins of Chicago to protest at the scorer's table. After taking another time out, Henderson took the inbounds pass from Cliff Robinson and drove for the winner. (AP) Mavericks 123, Nuggets 96: In Dallas, Roy Tarpley scored 6 points during a 16-3 fourth-quarter spurt to help Dallas to a club-record ninth straight victory. Rolando Blackman also had 6 points during the streak, which pushed Dallas from an 85-85 tie to a 103-88 lead.(AP) N.H.L. Canadiens 2, Nordiques 1: Montreal, playing on the road, held on to defeat Quebec behind the goaltending of Brian Hayward, who made 39 saves. Quebec's Gaetan Duchesne appeared to have scored the tying goal with one second to play but it was disallowed by Referee Don Koharski, who ruled that the Nordiques' Paul Gillis interfered with Hayward.(AP) TENNIS Graf Easy Victor: Steffi Graf of West Germany glided to a first-round victory last night, defeating Cammy MacGregor, 6-1, 6-2, at the Lynda Carter Maybelline U.S. Women's Hardcourt Championships in San Antonio. Graf needed only 49 minutes to win. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD 2 Freshmen Set Marks: Two freshmen, Germaine Johnson of White Plains (N.Y.) High School and Bryan Spoonire of Asbury Park (N.J.) High School registered sparkling performances last night at the Eastern States Boys Interscholastic indoor track and field championships at Princeton. Johnson won the triple jump at 45 feet 10 inches, a New York state freshman record. Spoonire was first in the two-mile run in 9 minutes 33.37 seconds, a New Jersey state freshman mark.

title: Bankers and Terrorists
description: Bankers have been accused of many things over the years, but a lawmaker from Wisconsin has come up a new charge: legislative terrorism.

title: DATAPOINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,152,000 for the quarter and $1,639,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after tax credits of $244,000 and $577,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the latest fourth quarter share earnings were less than one cent a share. Year-ago quarter and 6-month both include $56.8 million of special restructuring charges.

title: Q&A
description: Q. When a near-sighted person holds a mirror up close, why are distant objects reflected in it still blurry? A. The viewer is not actually seeing the distant object as if it were brought closehand by the mirror, explained Clint Hatchett, an astronomer who is astronomical writer/producer at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium in New York.

title: Advertising; Y.&R., Northwestern Team Up for Seminar
description: It is not surprising that Young & Rubicam is teaming up with Northwestern University to present a three-day working conference for senior executives entitled, ''Managing Communications for the Changing Marketplace.'' Not only is Y.&R. the nation's largest agency, but it also has subsidiaries in each of the fields that the session will cover: advertising, promotion, direct marketing, public relations and design.

title: Negative Campaign Spots Move to the Southern Airwaves
description: The negative television advertising that has been the hallmark of the Presidential race has moved South.

title: Ousted Panamanian in Counterattack
description: Supporters of Eric Arturo Delvalle said here today that he had issued orders from hiding in Panama that were intended to create a cash flow crisis for the Panamanian Government.

title: For Drugs: A Monroe Doctrine
description: The headlines send new shivers over drugs: The growing influence of the narcotraficantes in Panama and other Latin American capitals translates directly into the cold-blooded killing of Edward Byrne, a young New York police officer on a Queens street taken over by crack dealers.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $136,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $491,000 on the sale of those operations.

title: Takeover Action Buoys Stock Market
description: Wall Street's focus on real and rumored takeover deals helped lift the stock market yesterday, analysts said.

title: ABC's Olympic Coverage Wins Gold in Ratings
description: SOMEWHERE between Dr. Ruth's benevolent warning on pre-ski lovemaking to the sad look on Debi Thomas's face for being only the world's third-best figure-skater, ABC broke new ground in Olympics coverage. It also set some sort of record with its uncanny ability to switch to a commercial just when a hockey player felt like scoring a goal. Whether it was a financial success depends on one's values and what sort of bookkeeping procedures one uses.

title: RULING IS SOUGHT ON P.L.O.'s MISSION
description: The Arab nations asked the General Assembly today to seek a World Court ruling on the American attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission.

title: In Respect To Jackson Voters
description: For two days, the South was a political supermarket, with all the goods neatly spread out, available for comparison shopping.

title: Cougar Research in Florida
description: Five wild cougars from Texas will be released in a forest in northeastern Florida to see if the closely related but endangered Florida panther can survive there, wildlife officials have announced.

title: Recital: Abbey Simon
description: FOR better and for worse, Abbey Simon has remained throughout his long career just on the edge of the artistic spotlight, maintaining on the basis of reliable readings of the standard piano repertory a reputation unaffected by shifting musical tastes. Mr. Simon plays in a fluid, polished, self-effacing way, and his performances can be counted on to provide at least reasonable satisfaction and pleasure. They fall into no particular interpretative camp but pursue their own sensible, straightforward path.

title: Anesthesia Linked to Trembling
description: Post-operative trembling results from the use of anesthetics, not from decreased body temperature, as had been assumed, according to a new study.

title: European Nations Reaffirm Backing for Latin Peace Plan
description: The European Community reaffirmed its support for the Central American peace plan today and said outside interference must cease in order to end the region's wars.

title: McNally Unit Acquired By Simon & Schuster
description: Simon & Schuster has acquired a number of Rand McNally's travel books and related operations, including Rand McNally's campground directories and national park guides.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a pretax charge of $3.5 million, or 34 cents a share after tax, from the consolidation of the company's electronic systems and microwave systems units.

title: Stefania Toczyska's Operatic Odyssey
description: Some singers simply happen. Stefania Toczyska - enjoying current success as Marfa in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Khovanshchina'' - did not grow up to be one nor does she act like a singer today. No piano lessons as a child in her native Poland, no stage mother, no burning ambition for the theater. Miss Toczyska sang with her mother and grandmother around the house and at mass.

title: Four Years After Crisis, Fsk University Thrives
description: Enrollment is up and the debt is down at Fisk University, where only a few years ago students shivered in unheated dormitories because the historically black private institution could not pay its gas bill.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Chess: Seirawan Presses Too Hard In Crucial Loss to Speelman
description: The results of the preliminary round in the world championship candidates' matches in Saint John, New Brunswick, were: Nigel Short (Britain)....3 1/2 Gyula Sax (Hungary)....1 1/2 Jan Timman (Netherlands)....3 1/2 Valery Salov (Soviet Union)....2 1/2 Lajos Portisch (Hungary)....3 1/2 Rafael Vaganian (Soviet Union)....2 1/2 Jonathan Speelman (Britain)....4

title: Plan Offered In Debt Crisis
description: An important business leader today called for an international agency to buy $250 billion of debt from 17 debtor countries at a discount.

title: WAVETECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest quarter includes the results of Applied Environmental Technology Inc., acquired in October.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: BISCAYNE HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $440,000 and $2,558,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $264,000 for the quarter and $1,619,000 for the year, and the also includes a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $87,000.

title: Bond Prices Retain Early Gains
description: Bond prices moved narrowly higher in light trading yesterday despite small gains in commodity prices and a big jump in the stock market, developments that have made credit market participants edgy in the past.

title: Plessey Venture
description: The Plessey Company and the General Electric Company P.L.C., two of Britain's biggest electronics concerns, said they had agreed to form a telecommunications group. GEC Plessey Telecommunications will dominate the industry in Britain and will supply products to government and commercial customers globally, they said. The venture, approved last month by the Government, will have revenues of almost $:1.2 billion, or about $2.1 billion, and net assets of $:428 million, or $757 million, Plessey said.

title: Emergency Called in Senegal in Unrest Over Vote
description: President Abdou Diouf declared a state of emergency in Dakar today as supporters of a defeated rival who denounced Sunday's presidential election as a fraud battled the police.

title: Elmar Oliveira
description: The violinist Elmar Oliveira is to appear with the Syracuse Symphony in the New York premiere of a work by Ezra Laderman, on March 13 at 3 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The new work, Concerto for Violin and Cello, was composed by Mr. Laderman for Mr. Oliveira and the cellist Nathaniel Rosen. The symphony, to be conducted by Kazuyoshi Akiyama, will also perform Dvorak's Carnival Overture and Rachmaninoff's Symphony No. 2. Information: 247-7800.

title: Grand Jury Selected in Brawley Case
description: Three months after a black teen-ager, Tawana Brawley, says she was abducted and sexually assaulted by six white men, a new grand jury was empaneled here today by the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, to try to settle the furor that has surrounded the case.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AFA Financial, Cleveland, an investment manager, elected James M. Mendell president and chief executive.

title: EIL INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Look at Amiga 500
description: TWO and a half years ago, there was the Amiga 1000, a most innovative machine that left such computers as the Commodore 64, the older Ataris, Apple IIe and even I.B.M. far behind. Its color, graphics and sound capabilities were unexcelled and it was as easy to use as the Macintosh.

title: New Opera, in Concert
description: ''Dream Beach,'' a new opera in three acts for two singers and ensemble, will be given a concert performance on March 20 at the Green Auditorium of the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, 40 West 68th Street. The opera, by Michael Sahl and Howard Pflanzer, deals with a woman on a beach and a man on a train and their subsequent encounter. The performance is to begin at 2 P.M. Admission is free; suggested contribution is $5, or $1 for the elderly.

title: Defense in Chambers Case Suggests Key Witness Lied
description: The defense attorney for Robert E. Chambers Jr. confronted the prosecution's key witness yesterday and angrily suggested that the witness, a forensic medical expert, had lied under oath and changed his medical opinion of how Jennifer Levin died.

title: Surprise Macy Offer Tops Canadian Bid For Federated Stores
description: In a surprise bid to compete with the Campeau Corporation, R. H. Macy & Company yesterday offered more than $6.6 billion in cash and stock to acquire Federated Department Stores.

title: Ancient Tree Yields Secrets Of Potent Healing Substance
description: IN what could be a step toward testing a folk remedy for modern medical use, chemists at Harvard University have succeeded in synthesizing the potent substance responsible for the ancient ginkgo tree's enduring reputation as the source of varied healing powers.

title: 9 Get Corporate Conscience Awards
description: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization, has awarded its second annual America's Corporate Conscience Awards to nine corporations that it feels exemplify corporate social responsibility.

title: U.S. Plans Wide Use of Credit Cards
description: The Federal Government is going for the plastic.

title: Preston Tisch Rejoins Loews
description: Preston Robert Tisch, who is finishing up his stint as Postmaster General, will return to the Loews Corporation as president and co-chief executive with his brother, Laurence A. Tisch, the company said yesterday.

title: Curb Congress by Line-Item Veto; Pork Allowance
description: To the Editor:

title: CAPE TOWN POLICE ARREST CLERGYMEN AT PROTEST MARCH
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu and two dozen other church leaders were arrested today when they marched in Cape Town to protest the banning of 17 anti-apartheid groups last week.

title: MOUNTAINEER BANKSHARES OF WEST VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year's decreased earnings reflect expenses related to the merger of four banks during the year, and operating losses incurred at its newly chartered bank in Jefferson County, which completed its first full year of operation. The company also said 1987 net was also affected by expenses related to opening two new branches, trading account losses sustained during the second quarter, and the impact of the alternative minimum tax during the period.

title: Bokassa Execution Commuted to Life Term
description: President Andre Kolingba today commuted the death sentence of the deposed emperor, Jean-Bedel Bokassa, reducing it to life imprisonment in solitary confinement.

title: Bridge: Administrators of Events Often Given Little Credit
description: The hard-working administrators who prepare the conditions of contest for sporting and recreational events almost invariably do their work well and receive little credit. But they are under fire on the rare occasions in which unexpected circumstances produce a bizarre effect.

title: Our Rites of Election Through English Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1988
description: Companies

title: C-TEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $15,000 and a loss of $1,529,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and a loss of $1,364,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $501,000 and $1,620,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: By Design; Keeping Up With the Upkeep
description: Keeping fashionable clothes in tiptop shape is a nuisance. Nobody has much time for the upkeep needed between stops at the dry cleaner and the shoe-repair shop. Here are some gadgets that make maintenance fairly easy.

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beep, Beep
description: Senators may find their switchboards lighting up with more calls than usual today. The message: ''Don't bug me!''

title: Conrail Names Official As Crane's Successor
description: Conrail yesterday designated Richard D. Sanborn Jr., a railroad executive from outside the company, as the next person to run the large Northeast freight line.

title: Boat Carrying Aliens Sinks Off Puerto Rico
description: A small boat said to be carrying about 40 illegal aliens from the Dominican Republic sank in rough seas just off the west coast of Puerto Rico, but a survivor said today he believed most made it to shore.

title: CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes losses from a unit's interest in a hotel partnership of $716,000 and $2,143,000 for the quarter and the year, respectively. c-Includes losses of $389,000 for the quarter and $1,349,000 for the year from the hotel partnership, and the year also includes a pretax writedown of $14,600,000 of oil and gas property costs.

title: Group Positive on Economy
description: The October stock market plunge will contribute to a significant slowdown in economic growth this year, but the country should be able to avoid a recession, an organization of economists for top United States corporations predicted today.

title: Sides Shift In Belgian Takeover
description: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti set out in a new direction today in his battle for Societe Generale de Belgique, forming a holding company with two former Belgian adversaries.

title: U.S. Delays Brazil Action
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was postponing the imposition of $105 million in retaliatory sanctions against exports from Brazil, citing a new Brazilian law that may ease barriers against sales of American computers.

title: The Mysterious Mr. Hong
description: NOW the Olympic stage moves to Seoul, South Korea, with its political turmoil and the threat of terrorists from the People's Republic of Korea, less than 30 miles away.

title: Close Vote Expected Today On Senate Panel's Bank Bill
description: Senator William Proxmire will give Congress its first opportunity on Tuesday to test whether it has the will to change a 55-year-old law that separates the securities industry from commercial banking.

title:
Careers;
Lobbying: A Growing, Varied Field
description: LEAD: WHEN James H. Webb Jr. resigned as Secretary of the Navy last week because of a dispute over the proposed military budget, President Reagan replaced him with William L. Ball 3d, who had been the chief lobbyist for both the State Department and the White House. The move is an example of the increasing role of lobbyists in and out of the Government.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Deal For Retailer
description: Moving to ward off a takeover attack by the Haft family, the Stop and Shop Companies said yesterday that it had accepted a $1.2 billion buyout offer from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big New York merchant bank.

title: Eastern U.S. Is Warned About Big Earthquakes
description: THE next catastrophic American earthquake could well strike not in California but in the densely populated, highly industrialized and poorly prepared eastern United States, many geologists now believe.

title: Court Delays Banks' Powers
description: A Federal appeals court agreed yesterday to delay its ruling allowing commercial banks to add limited investment banking powers. The decision by the United

title: Diagnostek Deal
description: Diagnostek Inc., a small company that operates diagnostic imaging centers, said it had acquired Health Care Services Inc., one of the nation's largest mail service pharmacies. Health Care Services, based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., had been privately owned and family managed. The company earned about $1 million on $53 million in sales in the year ended March 31, 1987. Diagnostek, based in Albuquerque, N.M., intends to pay $250,000 in cash, $1.1 million in stock and an unspecified amount based on future profits.

title: Baghdad and Teheran Exchange Missile Attacks
description: Iraq said today that it had retaliated for predawn missile attacks on Baghdad by firing long-range rockets into the heart of Teheran. Iran reported 16 people killed in the bombing of a hospital by warplanes.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $75,000 and $278,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $1,058,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year. c-Net income d-Includes net of $20,000 and a loss of $198,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. The latest quarter and year both include a pretax charge of $2,619,000 for a planned major change in the company's Cybex Back Systems' computerization.

title: Jakarta Journal; A Colonial Legacy Comes Back, but Not to Haunt
description: In Southeast Asia, where Western empires once collided in the race for spices and straits, most independent nations seem perenially sensitive about their colonial legacies.

title: Porter Testifies
description: Kevin Porter, a former Auburn football star, testified yesterday at the misdemeanor commercial bribery trial of the former Atlanta sports agent Jim Abernethy that he got a $2,000 bonus and $900 in cash delivered in envelopes after signing with Abernethy last August.

title: Marcos Meets Aquino Envoys
description: The Government said today that it had sent representatives to talk with former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who has praised the Aquino Government and said he is ready to negotiate his return to the Philippines.

title: Stage: 'Tapman,' With Moses Gunn
description: ''TAPMAN,'' the title character in Karen Jones-Meadows's new play, is not, as one might expect, a tapdancer. He is instead a legendary blues musician who has reached the end of the line - a familiar archetype from fiction as well as fact. In this case, however, we know he is legendary only because other characters tell us so. The play (at the Hudson Guild Theater) is itself filled with inconsistencies.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pension Rise Is Voted in Albany in Rebuff to Koch
description: The State Legislature, with some angry words for Mayor Koch, passed a bill tonight to increase pensions for retired New York State and City workers.

title: G.M. Unit to Buy Control of Mtech
description: Mcorp, the Dallas-based bank holding company, said it had agreed to sell its 80.1 percent interest in the Mtech Corporation for about $281 million in cash and securities to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation. Mtech is a provider of data processing and electronic-funds transfer services.

title: ROCKY MOUNTAIN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $6,824 for the quarter and $71,062 for the 9 months. The company said the year-ago figures include the results of HSD Inc., acquired in October 1987 on a pooling of interests basis.

title: Winning Start for Leetch
description: Brian Leetch's parents were in Calgary, Alberta, through the weekend, which was hardly tragic but still a lesson in the risks of great expectations. Because of hotel reservations made in anticipation of the United States Olympic hockey team's advancing to the medal round, they were prevented from traveling to New York for their son's debut with the Rangers last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Hockey Notebook; Shakier Harvard Still First
description: This was the season that some team - St. Lawrence, in the opinion of many coaches in October - would pass by Harvard to the top of the ECAC Hockey league. But in 132 games, that failed to happen.

title: CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $204,000 and $275,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: Results for the latest year include charges of $2.5 million related to changes in the estimated useful lives of property, equipment and intangible assets. The company said that non-cash accruals for estimated losses expected to be incurred on its insurance liability deductibles totaled $1.1 million.

title: STARPOINTE SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the year includes tax credits of $525,000. Share earnings for year-ago period are not available because the bank converted to stock form in October 1986.

title: FOSTER WHEELER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes approximately $13,900,000 resulting from the settlement of several of the corporation's pension plans. c-Net income d-Restated by approximately $1,507,000 for the quarter and $3,919,000 for the year. The company said in the latest fourth quarter the corporation recorded a provision of $18,800,000 for anticipated losses on restructuring of certain subsidiary operations and dispositon of properties no longer used in its businesses. The restructuring cost is estimated at $14,000,000 (after tax) or 40 cents a share. The 1987 and 1986 quarter results are unaudited.

title: 'I Am Flying': Hurricane Carter Rejoices in Freedom
description: After almost 20 years of protesting his innocence from grim prison confines, yesterday Rubin (Hurricane) Carter celebrated the dismissal of triple-murder charges against him amid the elegance of the Plaza Hotel.

title: College Basketball; Tillmon Sparks Hoyas
description: Mark Tillmon scored 17 points in the second half tonight, including 7 in the final three minutes, as Georgetown handed Providence its fifth straight Big East loss, 73-63.

title: Mother and a Daughter, 9, Slain
description: A 26-year-old woman and her 9-year-old daughter were found slain, apparently strangled, in the woman's Bronx apartment yesterday.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Show Drop
description: The prices that farmers got for raw products in February declined an average of eight-tenths of 1 percent from January's prices but were still 6.6 percent above those a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Jordan Hints That Palestinians' Role May Be Obstacle for Shultz Peace Plan
description: The problem of how Palestinians would be represented in a peace negotiation emerged today as another possible obstacle to Secretary of State George P. Shultz's efforts to get Arab-Israeli talks under way.

title: 2 Boys, Left by Parents, Die in Newark Fire
description: Two young brothers died this morning when fire broke out in an apartment where they were left alone with a 12-month-old sister, the authorities said. The girl was seriously injured.

title: Cold Water and Fish
description: The most productive fisheries are found in colder areas of the world's oceans, places like the Grand Banks off Newfoundland and the Bering Sea, and a University of Georgia ecologist may have discovered the reason.

title: Curb Congress by Line-Item Veto
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Arditti Quartet In a Modern Program
description: SINCE there were no premieres on the Arditti String Quartet's New York debut program Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, one might reverse the usual focus of contemporary music discussion and consider the performers before the composers. That is not the way the quartet conducts its affairs, but the most immediate and most lasting impression from this bill of Oliver Lake, Brian Ferneyhough, Gyorgy Ligeti, Elliott Carter and Iannis Xenakis was of the four performers' stunning virtuosity and exciting musical grasp. It is not easy to recall a more impressive evening of quartet playing, in whatever repertory.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OCCIDENTAL NEBRASKA SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Drilling Activity Grows
description: The number of oil and gas rigs working in the United States increased by five last week, to a total of 983, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year ago the rig count was 801.

title: Americans Measure Their Performance
description: If Dan Jansen is correct, the United States team at the XV Winter Olympic Games did just fine. More than 130 athletes competed in medal sports, and all of them, Jansen said, tried their hardest.

title: Raiders Hire Shanahan
description: Mike Shanahan, the assistant coach credited with tailoring the Denver Broncos' offense to fit the talents of the quarterback John Elway, was named head coach of the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday.

title: Farm Value Up In the Midwest
description: The value of Middle Western farmland is up about 7 percent from 1986 levels, but still is little more than half the level it had reached seven years ago, a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago has found.

title: Robbery Suspect Is Found Dead In Holding Cell
description: A suspect in an attempted robbery in a Brooklyn bakery plant where employees scuffled with him died early yesterday in police custody, about six hours after his arrest.

title: Arbitrager May Have Bail Posted
description: Lawyers for John A. Mulheren Jr., the Wall Street trader arrested 12 days ago on charges of illegal possession of weapons, are expected to seek to post bail for him at a hearing in New Jersey this morning, legal sources close to his case said late yesterday.

title: Sears Restructures
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company plans a management overhaul in its retail division, but will not disclose yet what the restructuring will include. Philo Holland, national public affairs manager, said Sears Merchandise Group officials would meet with employees in Chicago this week to discuss the restructuring. Mr. Holland said he could neither confirm nor deny a report today in Crain's Chicago Business that the nation's largest retailer planned to transform its 27 merchandise buying groups into independent business units and lay off some headquarters employees.

title: DATA ARE ELUSIVE ON THE HOMELESS
description: In debating the problems of homeless Americans, the candidates for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination have addressed an issue on which there are few firm statistics or undisputed facts.

title: Dr. Paul Ramsey, 74, a Professor At Princeton for 4 Decades, Dies
description: Dr. Paul Ramsey, a professor of religion at Princeton University for nearly 40 years and a widely recognized authority on medical ethics, died of a heart attack early yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: A Case For Flip-Flops
description: What's wrong with a Presidential candidate changing his position - though his opponents call it ''flip-flopping'' - in order to improve his chances of winning?

title: Israel's Peace Marchers Struggle Against Occupation, and Apathy
description: Against a blustering wind and all the odds, a group of Israelis - Arabs and Jews - has embarked on a march to Jerusalem to strike a blow for peace.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Will Rule on U.S. Drug-Testing Program
description: Entering a major civil liberties dispute, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of the Reagan Administration's drug-testing program for Customs Service employees seeking certain promotions.

title: Clause in Texaco Pact Is Questioned
description: Lawyers for shareholders of Texaco Inc. yesterday questioned a key figure in the company's settlement with the Pennzoil Company on why the plan to bring Texaco out of bankruptcy protects the company's officers from lawsuits charging mismanagement.

title: Soviet Opponents Mere Pretenders
description: There was talk of defection, deportation and importation, and debate over whether genuine amateurs still have a chance at being competitive in international hockey.

title: Laser Treatment May Spread Wart Virus
description: ONE of the most popular means of treating warts is to burn the growths with a laser beam, but scientists have documented a little-known hazard in this seemingly safe and simple treatment.

title: Jersey Democrats Plan a Slate for Bradley
description: A group of New Jersey Democratic leaders announced plans today to run an uncommitted slate of candidates in the New Jersey Presidential primary June 7 ''to put as much voting strength as possible into the hands of Senator Bill Bradley.''

title: Goodyear Aerospace Cited By U.S. in Overcharging
description: The Federal Government charged yesterday that the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Loral Corporation, had overcharged for making certain products used in Army and Navy bombers.

title: 'Le Schweitzer' Still Inspires Deep Loyalty
description: A YOUNG man deftly guided his dugout canoe to a bank of the Ogooue River and then sprang ashore.

title: Circle K Will Acquire 473 7-Eleven Stores
description: The Southland Corporation said today that it would sell 473 of its 7-Eleven stores to its chief competitor, the Circle K Corporation, for more than $147 million to help finance the Thompson family's leveraged buyout of Southland.

title: North Star Roster Increases by 3
description: The Minnesota North Stars signed two players from the Canadian Olympic hockey team today and acquired John Barrett, a defenseman, from the Washington Capitals for future considerations.

title: Fidelity Investments to Lay Off 800
description: Fidelity Investments announced today that it was laying off about 800 people, or 10.5 percent of its employees, as a result of declining mutual fund sales and lower sales of Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: William D. Seidler, 67, Nabisco Legal Counsel
description: William Dickson Seidler, a lawyer and senior vice president of law for International Nabisco Brands Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Merger of 7-Up And Dr Pepper
description: The boards at holding companies for Dr Pepper and Seven-Up have tentatively agreed to merge the privately held soft-drink companies, it was announced today. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Maxxam Will Buy Kaisertech Stake
description: Maxxam Group Inc., a holding company controlled by the Houston financier Charles E. Hurwitz, said it had agreed to buy from the British investor Alan E. Clore his stock and options on preferred shares in Kaisertech Ltd. for about $190 million. In addition, Maxxam said it was negotiating to pay $12 a share for 2.8 million more shares of the Oakland-based aluminum producer from a group headed by Mr. Clore, Kaisertech's chairman.

title: Surge in Platinum Sparks A Rally in Precious Metals
description: Precious metals futures soared yesterday after a dramatic late rally caused frenzied buying among the large number of traders who had been betting on a decline in the prices of gold, silver and especially platinum in recent weeks.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss of $66,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Media General Is Sent Unwanted Merger Bid
description: In a puzzling takeover bid, Barris Industries and Giant Group Ltd. proposed a $1.7 billion merger with Media General Inc.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Schembechler Says No
description: Bo Schembechler, the Michigan football coach, yesterday rejected an offer to become the school's athletic director, electing to remain in the job he has held since 1969. Michigan is trying to replacem Don Canham, who has announced plans to retire.

title: William G. Braude, Rabbi in Providence, 80
description: Rabbi William G. Braude, for 40 years a rabbi at Congregation Sons of Israel and David, Temple Beth-El in Providence, R.I., died Thursday at his home in Providence after a series of strokes. He was 80 years old.

title: The Rise of the Religious Right
description: LEAD: The scene, not too hard to imagine, is at the Republican National Convention in steamy New Orleans this August.

title: Baltic Journal; Archives Offers the Global Picture
description: Except for a distant silo, the low modern building is the only break on the long prairie horizon. But here, 20 miles northeast of Sioux Falls, in what can seem the middle of nowhere, the Federal Government is selling pictures of everywhere.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LAST CRUSADE. The War on Consumption 1862-1954. By Mark Caldwell. 336 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $22.50.

title: Magnetic Cyclotron Is Tested
description: THE highest-energy cyclotron accelerator ever built began operation last week at Michigan State University, and its operators predicted that the machine would produce a host of discoveries.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Included an unrealized loss in its investment portfolio of $19.4 million. c-Net income

title: Soviet Reports a Major Oil Center In Azerbaijan Is Shaken by Riots
description: The Soviet Union reported today that a major oil and natural gas center was shaken Sunday by rioting apparently related to recent nationalist unrest.

title: Former Officer Gets Jail Term In Drug Payoff
description: Despite a tearful appeal to a judge for a chance ''to begin my life again,'' a former New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to 1 to 4 years in prison for taking a $500 payoff from an undercover investigator posing as a drug dealer.

title: Sunken Barge Recovered, Averting a Disaster
description: A salvage crew has raised an upside-down barge a month after it sank and spilled about 70,000 gallons of heavy bunker oil in inland waters.

title: INSIDE
description: Panama Strike Falters A general strike called to protest the ouster of the Panamanian President met with limited success. Page A3. Stormy Legal Advice From Libya raids to ''Star Wars,'' the rationale came from a man of controversy. Washington Talk, Page A14. A Young Life in the Projects Mark Jenkins, 15, is living a life the Kerner commission warned about 20 years ago - separate and unequal.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,255,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter, and a gain on the sale of discontinued operations of $1,624,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $460,000 and $11,334,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses on the sale of discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $4,960,000 for the year.

title: Ruling Clears a Psychiatrist Of Liability in Maine Slaying
description: A psychiatrist who failed to commit a mentally ill man cannot be held negligent because the man killed a woman three days later, the Maine Supreme Court ruled today.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge from the reversal of tax credits of $23,000. c-Net income and includes tax credits of $1,000 and $58,000.

title: Reed to Make Debut Tonight
description: The New Jersey Nets' official announcement of their new coach was greeted enthusiastically by the state's senior United States Senator.

title: Mrs. Reagan Assails Drug Users
description: Nancy Reagan opened a conference on drug abuse today by saying that any user of illicit drugs is an ''accomplice to murder.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Cablesystems Corp., Beverly, Mass., completed its previously announced merger with Continental Cablevision Inc.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Morton Lowenstein has been named executive vice president at Young & Rubicam New York.

title: Mikhail Naimy Is Dead; Lebanese Poet Was 98
description: Mikhail Naimy, a Lebanese poet and philosopher, died in East Beirut on Sunday after developing pneumonia, his relatives said today. He was 98 years old.

title: Small-Town Trend Fading
description: They were once small and quaint, the Olympic Winter Games, staged in areas known predominantly for their ski slopes, places like Chamonix, France; St. Moritz, Switzerland, Cortina d' Ampezzo, Italy, and Squaw Valley, Calif. Even Lake Placid, N.Y., gave the 1980 Games a small-town flavor.

title: Syria Calls Shultz Plan a 'Fig Leaf' for Israeli Aims
description: Syria has expressed disappointment with Secretary of State George P. Shultz's Middle East mission, asserting that Washington's ideas for peace in the region are a ''fig leaf'' to keep the Palestinians ''under Israeli hegemony.''

title: Minority Officials Seek Revised Board of Estimate
description: A group of current and former black and Hispanic officials, including several United States Representatives, urged yesterday that the powerful New York City Board of Estimate be retained, although not in its current form.

title: Exhibition Shows the Silents as Anything But
description: The exhibition that opens today at Lincoln Center is a reflective survey of some of the most flamboyantly overstated productions ever to catch the public eye. It is called ''Epics and Icons of the Silent Film Era,'' and it will be found, trumpeting the glories of the golden silents, in the second-floor Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

title: Concert: Early Music
description: IT will be interesting to see what becomes of ''early music,'' as it used to be defined, now that the avant-garde of that movement has invaded the mainstream classical and early Romantic repertory. New York's Ensemble for Early Music does not, to all appearances, have any imminent designs upon the symphonies of Beethoven or the operas of Donizetti; Saturday's concert in Alice Tully Hall showed the group still concerned with lute, citole, gittern, shawm, pipe-and-tabor, recorders, and music of centuries before the 15th. It was sparsely attended and most affectionately applauded; pre-Baroque music may well be left behind in the agreeable ghetto it occupied before Christopher Hogwood became a star.

title: NASA Buying a Boeing To Carry Space Shuttles
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that it would acquire a Boeing 747-100 jetliner to use as a second transporter to carry shuttles piggyback from landing sites back to the launching center here.

title: Europeans Take Heart
description: The European Community's Washington office says it is encouraged by the results of a Gallup Poll it has just commissioned showing that four out of five Americans give a ''very favorable'' rating to Western Europe - higher than for Japan, but lower than for Canada.

title: Growing a Wrong Virus
description: NEW research on an AIDS-like disease in cats suggests that scientists growing AIDS viruses in the laboratory for study may end up with only variants that do not cause the disease.

title: New Flu Variant Found in 41 States
description: Most of this winter's outbreaks of flu have resulted from a new variant of influenza virus similar to one that was discovered in Sichuan, China, last April. The virus caused an outbreak on a ship cruising between China and Korea in October. Similar viruses also turned up last fall in Wisconsin, Minnesota and upstate New York, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Our Towns; Where the Rich Find Comfort In Each Other
description: ''Excuse me,'' said Anne Watkins ($3 million lottery winner, 1983). ''I have to go pick up the $13 million man.'' Joe Moore (actually, $13.7 million, 1985) had just arrived at the train station and was waiting for a ride to the Millionaire Circle Club. Ms. Watkins figured she would save him taking a cab.

title: Jupiter's Spot: A Cosmic Whirlpool
description: A SPINNING tub of water has convinced experts on chaotic systems that they have figured out one of the Solar System's most baffling landmarks, the Great Red Spot of Jupiter.

title: 'Separate and Unequal': a View From the Bottom
description: Like a war veteran's reminder of old battles, Mark Jenkins's left arm aches in cold weather just below the shoulder, where a bullet lodged when it shattered the bone last winter.

title: Dreaming Up a 'Nightmare' for TV
description: Freddy Krueger is a child killer who slashed and gashed his way to box-office glory in the film ''Nightmare on Elm Street'' and in two sequels. Now, perhaps inevitably, the character will have his own weekly television show, to be syndicated to stations across the country this fall.

title: Dow Advances 48.41 To Finish at 2,071.62
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved sharply higher yesterday in a broad advance that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest point since the October market collapse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not defying, we are obeying, and we are going to obey God every day.'' - Archbishop Desmond Tutu, on march protestingSouth Africa's ban on anti-apartheid groups. [ A1:6. ]

title: Chinese Optimistic About 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Recital: Marianne Schroeder, Pianist
description: MARIANNE SCHROEDER, a Swiss pianist who specializes in new music, made a powerful case for nine recent works in a Sunday-evening recital at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street. Connecting several of the stylistically diverse works was a concern with sonic afterimages - the thinning sound of a densely harmonized chord, or even an emphatically thwacked single note, as its overtones fade away.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Roper Chief to Add Title In Whirlpool Purchase
description: LEAD: Robert E. Cook, the president and chief executive of the Roper Corporation, which manufactures kitchen ranges and outdoor power equipment, will continue in his post and add the title of vice president of the Whirlpool Corporation, the company in Benton Harbor, Mich., which announced yesterday that it would buy Roper for $37.50 a share, or about $350 million.

title: New York City Has Been Making Major Strides as a Landlord
description: To the Editor:

title: Bids on Debt Called Poor
description: Mexico, which had hoped for $10 billion in bids at Friday's debt-for-bonds auction, received a disappointing $6 billion to $7 billion in bids from foreign banks, Japanese bankers said today.

title: Transit Officer, 28, Indicted In Assault at an IRT Station
description: A 28-year-old transit police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he punched a man in the face in a subway stairwell in East Harlem and then had the man arrested on spurious charges.

title: Dr. Moe Frankel, 76, Economics Educator
description: Dr. Moe Frankel, retired president of the Joint Council on Economic Education, died of pancreatic cancer Saturday at his home in Madison. Conn. He was 76 years old.

title: But Can You Say It in 1's and O's?
description: IN the nightmare I'm back at the University of Mars and the final exam in computer science starts in 20 seconds. But there must be some mistake! I'm a poetry major and I've never been in this class before. Suddenly the professor appears: It's Art Fleming, and I'm in Jeopardy.

title: Amnesty Sale: The Medium Is the Tortilla
description: With top officers wearing sombreros, immigration floats in Chinese New Year parades, fliers placed in packages of tortillas, free videotapes and other novel tactics, immigration officials are laboring to increase turnout as the nation's amnesty program for illegal aliens enters its last 10 weeks.

title: Payment by IU
description: The IU International Corporation disclosed today that it had paid $14.5 million in fees and expenses to a management group led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation after the group's $21.50-a-share tender offer was terminated. The $650 million Dean Witter Capital offer was ended after the IU board withdrew its recommendation that shareholders tender their shares to the group, because of a $22-a-share bid by Neoax Inc. IU, the diversified services concern based in Philadelphia, has tried to fend off Neoax and said last week that it was continuing to explore alternatives to the hostile bid from the Stamford, Conn., concern.

title: Pillsbury Returning to an Old Recipe
description: Three years ago, William H. Spoor, the Pillsbury Company chief legendary for his brusque management style, retired earlier than expected. He handed over the Minneapolis food and restaurant company to John M. Stafford, an affable, soft-spoken executive who was expected to soothe frayed nerves and make the company even more profitable.

title: GWC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mexico to Freeze Peso And Prices for March
description: As part of a program to control Mexico's 177 percent inflation rate, the Mexican Government announced today that it would maintain the value of the peso against the dollar and freeze Government-controlled prices during March.

title: Kuenn's Funeral Set for Thursday
description: Harvey Kuenn, the former manager of the Milwaukee Brewers who died Sunday at the age of 57, suffered a heart attack, the club said today.

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by about $249,000 due to discontinuation of all products of Boat Sentry Inc. and Lakontek Inc.

title: Weinberger to Law Firm
description: Less than four months after resigning as Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger has returned to private law practice. Mr. Weinberger, 70 years old, is joining the international law firm of Rogers & Wells, which is headed by another former Washington Cabinet member, William P. Rogers, who was Secretary of State in President Nixon's first term. Mr. Weinberger, who will be based in Washington, will specialize in international law and international finance. Immediately before becoming Defense Secretary, Mr. Weinberger was senior vice president and general counsel of the Bechtel Corporation.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Results for the year-ago first quarter are restated.

title: New Tricks for Old Workhorse Computers
description: TRADITIONALLY, computers have been serial beasts, executing a task one step at a time. But few care to wait while a computer finishes a job. So as the quest for faster computers intensifies, serialism is steadily giving way to parallelism on many fronts.

title: G.M. to Stop Building Pontiac Fiero
description: Production of the Pontiac Fiero, a car hailed for its innovative design and manufacturing process when it was introduced in 1983, will stop at the end of the current model year, the General Motors Corporation said today.

title: Brooklyn Double Murder: Mental Patient and a Flawed System
description: After waiting more than 13 hours for a bed on an overcrowded psychiatric ward at Kings County Hospital last month, Nick Gavrilou told his doctors that he had made up the story he had been telling about stabbing someone, and was ready to go home. The doctors agreed. Eleven days later, as neighbors listened in horror behind their locked doors, the police said, Mr. Gavrilou, 37 years old, stabbed his elderly parents to death in their apartment on East Ninth Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, cutting his father's throat and piercing his mother's heart with a kitchen knife.

title: Devils Overpowered; Islanders Prevail; Islanders 2, Blues 0
description: Bill Smith, a man with a reputation as an aggressive and often irascible goaltender, is proving to be a more than a tough labor negotiator, too.

title: Small-Property Owners in Manhattan Find Situation Worsening
description: To the Editor:

title: GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $156,000 for the quarter and $479,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes net of $632,000 for the quarter and a loss of $4,054,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: ALASKA BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the decline in earnings is attributed to the unprecedented decline in the Alaskan economy as a result of the fall of oil prices in 1986.

title: THE SOURCES OF DRUGS
description: Major drug-producing countries that have diplomatic relations with the United States and the estimated amount of drugs, in metric tons, produced in each country. Increases in Thailand are a function of changes in methodology and improvements in data, and may not indicate increased production. Maps are not to scale.

title: HALL, FRANK B & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $15,216,000 and $17,761,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $8,985,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Massimo Calabresi, 84, Yale Medical Professor
description: Dr. Massimo E. Calabresi, clinical professor emeritus of medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine, died Sunday at his home in New Haven after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dance: DanceArt Troupe, From Boston
description: IT was easy to be puzzled by Benita Bike's DanceArt Company. This troupe from Boston, which appeared Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, offered tiny dances that stopped almost as soon as they started. Some contained vivid images. But the brevity of the dances occasionally made one want to say, ''How's that again?'' And a few, though short, trailed off after strong beginnings.

title: FIRST SERVICE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock form in August 1986.

title: Bond Prices Steady in Listless Day
description: Bond prices were little changed yesterday, as dealers struggled through another listless session. For the most part, traders shrugged off new economic data, even though the reports offered scant evidence of strength.

title: Bridge: Is That Player an Expert? Just Watch and Find Out
description: If you know that a partnership consists of one expert and one relative novice but do not know which is which, watching a single deal should provide the answer. Follow the play of the diagramed deal from the Greater New York Bridge Association's Pro-Am event last Friday and decide which category South belongs in.

title: Date for Decision In Soccer Shifted
