description: The announcement of whether Brazil, Morocco or the United States will be awarded the 1994 World Cup soccer finals has been postponed by four days to July 4, the Federation Internationale de Football Association said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Volcker's Future
description: Seven months since leaving the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve, Paul A. Volcker may have decided on another job, back at his alma mater. It appears that he will be joining the Princeton University faculty as a professor of public policy.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $147,000 and $3,239,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year, respectively; an after-tax non-cash charge of $26.2 million to reduce the carrying amount of the company's portfolio of marketable equity securities to market and an after-tax provision of $11.3 million on sale of the company's investment in CJI Industries for both periods. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $647,000 for both periods and also includes a charge of $1,271,000 and $33,983,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Food Notes
description: Dining for a Cause

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pistons 117, Hawks 104: The Pistons scored the road victory despite a 50-point performance by Atlanta's Dominique Wilkins.

title: Sale of Stake In Kaisertech
description: Jefferies & Company Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell 1.4 million shares of Kaisertech Ltd. stock to the Maxxam Group Inc. for $12 a share, or $16.8 million.

title: RIVERSIDE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; ABP Group Sees Growth In the Sun
description: THE ABP Group of New York, Dallas, Montreal and Toronto seems to have all the accouterments of a mega-agency except billings. The giants bill in the billions of dollars, but ABP's total is around $60 million.

title: Is Holding Back Pupils a Policy of Abject Failure?
description: The contentious debate over requiring elementary school pupils to repeat a grade they have failed has flared again after a Chicago principal's decision last week to demote 250 children in the middle of the school year because of poor scores on reading tests.

title: Stage: 'Cocktail Party' By the Cocteau Troupe
description: CAN a play whose heroine is crucified by cannibals and devoured by ants be a real comedy? As the production of T. S. Eliot's ''Cocktail Party'' by the Jean Cocteau Repertory at the Bouwerie Lane Theater reminds one, the play is definitely a comedy and, after 39 years, still resilient. It helps a lot that Celia Copplestone's grisly demise is thousands of miles off stage, of course. Still, one cannot help wondering whether she should not have resisted the temptations of virtue in the wilds and sought salvation by sin in tired London.

title: Stage: 'The Boob Story'
description: AS Jane Gennaro's one-woman show, ''The Boob Story,'' opens, an eerily caressing recorded voice advertises the female body, using the vocabulary of fashion design to describe its components as parts of a wardrobe in which the hands and fingers are accessories. Out of this ingenious conceit, the writer, comedian and radio personality has constructed a cautionary seriocomic monologue about breast fetishism in America and the perils of getting too much of what one wants.

title: John Kenny, 88, Dies; Founded High School
description: John B. Kenny, co-founder and principal of the High School of Art and Design, formerly the New York School of Industrial Art, died Thursday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Jackson Sets Sights on White Vote
description: Jesse Jackson came home today with the hope, bordering on conviction, that the South his generation helped change forever will judge him not by the color of his skin but by the content of his message.

title: LEADING INDICATORS: COMPONENT ANALYSIS
description: Components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change in January.

title: KEY RATES
LOWRANCE ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: OMNICOM GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net of $1,383,000 from various nonrecurring items, including gains realized on the sale of investments of certain minority interests in international affiliates, partially offset by costs incurred s a result of the company's consolidation programs. c-Includes nonrecurring restructuring expenses of $5,948,000 before tax benefit for eliminating duplicate facilities and staff. d-Net loss and includes nonrecurring provisions for merger and restructuring expenses of $40,292,000 before tax benefit. Revenue represents commissions and fees.

title: Grocery Chain In Buyout Talks
description: Boys Markets Inc., a supermarket chain in Los Angeles that went public last year, said it was negotiating with an unidentified party about being acquired for $12.50 a share, or $125 million. The chain was acquired in April 1986 for $83 million from the founding Goldstein family by Riordan, Freeman & Spogli, a Los Angeles buyout firm.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ABB Composites Inc., Irvine, Calif., an Asea Brown Boveri subsidiary that makes fiber-reinforced plastic products, appointed Rolf R. Berglund president.

title: Ferrer Urges Bronx Housing Renewal
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, delivering his State of the Borough report. He urged spending $100 million in state and city housing funds to rehabilitate 31 abandoned city-owned buildings along the Cross Bronx Expressway. Mr. Ferrer said the effort would provide homes for 1,500 families and help counteract the negative image of the Bronx held by motorists who use the expressway. (NYT/John Sotomayor)

title: Kelly Has His Eyes on Home
description: The gold chain that hangs around Roberto Kelly's neck is a constant reminder of home. He touched it this morning and wondered aloud about his daughter - her name, Charlene, is written in script on the chain - and his wife, who are home in Panama City, Panama, where Kelly was born and where he still lives during the off season.

title: BANK OF INDUSTRY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cairo Journal; Now, After 4,600 Years, Time Adds a New Scar
description: A chunk fell off the Sphinx the other day, and stirred more than just the dust in which it landed.

title: Cheers, Feast For Doberman's Heroic Exploit
description: A Doberman pinscher, Gridiron's Air Coryell, named after Don Coryell, the former coach of the National Football League's San Diego Chargers, is America's dog hero of the year.

title: DOWNEY DESIGNS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $58,000 and $110,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings include pro forma income taxes for a subsidiary previously taxed as an S Corporation.

title: Memory Chip Pressure Is On
description: The Government is putting pressure on American semiconductor companies to re-enter the computer memory chip business, which they all but abandoned to the Japanese.

title: The Yawning Abyss Chasm of Cable TV
description: LEAD: Americans sometimes take their country for granted, sneering at its spacious skies and purple mountains' majesty. Then they go visit some perfectly horrible place like East Germany where they don't even have amber waves of grain, and come back with a new appreciation of the good old U.S.A.

title: Problems for 2 New York Wineries
description: TWO major wineries in the Finger Lakes region of New York have suffered reverses.

title: Potvin's Garden Finale
description: The Islanders' Denis Potvin returns tonight to perhaps the most difficult building he has visited in his National Hockey League career. Barring an encounter in the playoffs, this evening's game against the Rangers will be Potvin's final appearance at Madison Square Garden. The 34-year-old defenseman, one of the most accomplished in the game's history, is retiring at the end of the season.

title: Marcum Dismissed
description: Bob Marcum, athletic director at the University of South Carolina since 1982, was dismissed yesterday after a five-member task force investigating drug testing of athletes at the university found that no random testing had been done since the spring of 1986. The university president, James Holderman, said at a news conference that the team physician, Dr. Paul Akers, had also been dropped. Holderman also said that the task force had found at least one player who tested positive for drugs three times but was not discharged. Under the school's drug-testing program, an athlete who tests positive three times for drugs is to be dropped from a team. The president said he has appointed Johnny Gregory as a consultant to him on athletic affairs. Marcum, who once was athletic director at Kansas, said he would comment on the dismissal in a few days.

title: PIEDMONT MINING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a tax credit of $63,000 and $198,000.

title: Metromedia Raises Its Stake in Orion
description: The Metromedia Company has increased its stake in the common stock of the Orion Pictures Corporation to 39.5 percent, from 30.9 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Metromedia said it received Federal clearance last Thursday to lift its stake in Orion, the New York-based producer of movies and television programs, to as much as 49.9 percent.

title: In 'S.,' Updike Tries the Woman's Viewpoint
description: In John Updike's eyes, there is a permanent twinkle. He had come to the offices of his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf, to talk about his new novel, ''S.,'' which has just reached the bookstores. ''S.'' is a departure for Mr. Updike, an epistolary novel told through letters written and tapes recorded by Sarah P. Worth, a 42-year-old Massachusetts woman who leaves her wealthy home and wealthy physician husband to live on the Arizona ashram of the guru Shri Arhat Mindadali.

title: About New York; Child Essayists Walk a Mile In Koch's Shoes
description: Joel Fram, who owns Eeyore's Books for Children, says it is ''bunny eat bunny'' in his business, meaning it's competitive. A guy has to keep on top of things, has to keep his clientele happy. One of the ways Mr. Fram achieves this is by dreaming up writing contests. His latest is called, ''If I Were Mayor of New York: Here's What I'd Do to Improve the City. . . .''

title: Books of The Times
description: LULU INCOGNITO. By Raymond Kennedy. 305 pages. Vintage Contemporaries. $7.95.

title: U.S. PLANS RELIEF OF UP TO $7 BILLION IN BAD FARM DEBT
description: The Farmers Home Administration, the nation's second-largest farm lending institution, said today that it was drafting new rules to relieve farmers of the burden of up to $7 billion in debts.

title: FIRST SAVINGS BANK (NORTH CAROLINA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted to stock ownership on Jan. 22.

title: Witt-Thomas a TV Hit
description: More than 60 million people - the largest Saturday night television audience since the broadcast of ''Roots'' in 1977 - watched Katarina Witt and Debi Thomas duel for the Olympic gold medal in figure skating.

title: PO FOLKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $284,000 and $869,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Public Library Should Be a Refuge for Children; An Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: Scaasi: From Bright Into White
description: ARNOLD SCAASI is aware that the fashion mood of the moment tilts more to razzle-dazzle than to sobriety. Somberness was certainly not what he had in mind when he designed his spring and summer couture collection, which was shown this week in his salon in New York.

title: Court Upholds Ruling Against Racial Quotas for Starrett City
description: A divided Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn must end its use of ''rigid racial quotas'' even if they were intended to promote integration.

title: At NATO Parley, Reagan Reassures
description: Asserting that military resolve had produced a treaty to dismantle medium-range missiles, President Reagan declared today that the United States would never sacrifice allied interests to get an arms accord with the Soviet Union.

title: Commissioner Chosen for Suffolk's Troubled Police Department
description: Daniel P. Guido, who assumed control of the Police Department in Stamford, Conn., only eight months ago, was selected today to lead the troubled Suffolk County Police Department.

title: Student Convicted In a Friend's Slaying
description: A 17-year-old honor student and computer enthusiast was convicted yesterday in the killing of a longtime friend during a quarrel over an $85 printer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY The Government's main forecasting index was revised upward for December, avoiding the three consecutive monthly declines that are viewed as a signal of an imminent recession. The index fell 0.6 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected. But private forecasters said they still expected the economy to expand, though sluggishly, in the next few months. [ Page A1. ] Spending for construction fell 2.9 percent in January, the Government reported. It was the biggest drop in 10 months. [ D4. ] Farmers would be relieved of up to $7 billion in bad debts under new rules being drafted by the Farmers Home Administration. The action could help keep 100,000 farmers in business. [ A1. ] The Reagan Administration is applauding new Fed policies disclosed last week. [ D2. ] COMPANIES A J. P. Stevens management group sweetened its buyout bid for the huge textile producer to $55 a share, or about $880 million, only to see West Point-Pepperell, also a major textile producer, emerge several hours later with a $56-a-share bid. [ D1. ] The Macy offer for Federated is no better than Campeau's, investors seem to agree. Campeau is expected to carve up much of Federated if its bid wins, while an R. H. Macy-Federated combination would create the nation's biggest chain of fashion-oriented department stores. [ D1. ] The chairman of GAF offered to buy the company for $51 a share, or $1.4 billion, but all seven of GAF's independent directors said Samuel J. Heyman's revised offer was not high enough. They have asked Salomon Brothers to seek a higher bidder. [ D1. ] Pillsbury stock soared, then fell after the new chief executive said he had no plans to try to sell the Burger King chain. [ D2. ] G.M. will halt production of the Pontiac Fiero, a car once hailed for its innovative design and manufacturing process. [ D5. ] Desert Partners made a hostile bid for USG of $42 a share, or $1.9 billion. USG is the nation's largest gypsum producer. [ D5. ] Kodak is offering $1.1 billion of 10-year notes, and proceeds may be used partly for the acquisition of Sterling Drug. [ D17. ] Maxxam is closer to its Kaisertech goal of a 32 percent voting interest after another stock-purchase deal. [ D5. ] MARKETS The Wall Street speculator arrested on weapons charges was released but immediately arrested on related charges. [ D1. ] Stock prices slipped, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at 2,070.46, 1.16 points below its post-collapse high. [ D8. ] Bond prices were little changed as traders shrugged off new economic data that offered scant evidence of strength. [ D17. ] The dollar fell marginally and gold prices dropped to $430.45 an ounce, down 15 cents. [ D16. ] Prices of oil futures continued to drop amid confusion on whether exporting countries were offering deep discounts. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL A Soviet-American meeting on business deals is off, at Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request, and many experts are puzzled. [ D1. ] Airbus Industrie was urged by four nations to step up talks with McDonnell Douglas. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY Wall Street will invest in computer technology in two key ways, despite delays caused by the market collapse. [ D6. ] Programmers have begun to focus on parallelism in the everyday computer world, and ''anti-noise'' machines that can sharply lower sound levels are being used in new ways. Advances. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Frequent fliers may face action by the I.R.S. as criticism of the airline programs increases. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Investors say they are not yet ready to jump back into the market despite recent gains. And that sentiment, some strategists say, is what is needed for the rally to continue. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Washington Talk: The Presidency; Tapes Offer a Rare Glimpse of the Private F.D.R.
description: The day was Oct. 4, 1940, and Franklin D. Roosevelt was at his desk in the Oval Office, talking on the telephone to Cordell Hull, his Secretary of State, about a press interview with the Japanese Prime Minister.

title: AMERECO ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results are on a pro-forma basis. The company said share earnings for both years were less than one cent a share. The company said it recently had its initial public offering.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest results included those of Curacare Inc., acquired last October.

title: AMERIANA SAVINGS BANK OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago share earnings are unavailable because the bank converted to stock ownership in Feb. 1987.

title: No Quick Arrests Seen In Police Officer's Killing
description: Despite what he termed ''potentially fertile leads,'' the Police Department's Chief of Detectives said yesterday that no arrests were imminent in the slaying of a rookie officer in Queens last Friday.

title: INSIDE
description: Candidates' Game Plans

title: Market Place; Money Managers Still on Sidelines
description: ALTHOUGH the Dow Jones industrial average was a steady gainer in February and climbed nearly 50 points on Monday, investors say they are not about to jump back into the stock market. And that sentiment, some strategists assert, is what is needed for the rally to continue.

title: Advertising; 3 Medical Publications Acquired by Medcom
description: Robert J. Krefting, former president of CBS Magazines, and Hershel B. Sarbin, former president of Ziff-Davis Publishing, are now the principals in Medcom Partners, which has acquired Hospimedica and Labmedica magazines from Techcom Inc. of Westport, Conn., and Medical Week, a newsletter, from Medical Week Associates, also of Westport.

title: Stage: Innaurato's 'Magda and Callas,' in Philadelphia
description: With ''Magda and Callas,'' at the Philadelphia Festival Theater for New Plays, Albert Innaurato returns to South Philadelphia for a story dealing with such favorite subjects as grand opera, passion and motherhood. In a neighboring backyard can be heard the lingering laughter of ''Gemini'' (the playwright's long-running Broadway comedy) but in the world of the La Selva family, there is a definite strain of solemnity beneath the jocularity. Unfortunately, ''Magda and Callas'' is neither as funny nor as serious as it intends to be.

title: Jazz: Sandke Quartet
description: THE songs and styles of the 1930's and 40's are familiar fare at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street. But they are being played with fresh flair since the Jordan Sandke quartet and the singer Judy Niemack opened a five-week engagement there on Monday.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A View of Capital
description: Playboy magazine's attitude toward women in the nation's capital has been evolving in the last dozen years. A 1976 issue was billed ''The Girls of Washington.'' Four years later a similar collection was titled ''Women of the U.S. Government.'' This summer, the magazine plans to display 12 models called the ''Women of Washington.''

title: CARDIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said it changed to an Oct. 31 from an April 30 year-end last year.

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL REALTY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After gains on the sale of property of $6,279,000 for the latest year and $3,038,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Knicks Win Again At Home, of Course
description: The Knicks had been behind by 20 points in the third quarter, and the Indiana Pacers were slicing through their trapping defense time and again. But with 35 seconds left in the game last night, the Knicks were ahead.

title: Weaker Dollar Fails to Bring A Jump in U.S. Sales in Japan
description: The weak dollar has helped to make American products much more competitive in many markets around the world. But defying predictions, it has not brought about a significant increase in sales in Japan.

title: Shultz Ends Mideast Tour Upbeat but Empty-Handed
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his swing through the Middle East today without the general accord he had sought on principles of negotiation but with enough encouragement from the parties to lean toward a return trip at the end of the week.

title: Hacking Back the Trade Bill Weeds
description: What the House and Senate passed separately added up to 2,000 pages of trouble. The trade bill, it's called, but anti-trade is more like it. Now the conference committees charged with reconciling the two versions have, encouragingly, started to hack away much of the blatant special-interest mischief. The conferees' tentative agreement sets a welcome tone and gives promise that nuisance provisions won't slip through unnoticed. But there's hard bargaining ahead to insure that the final bill is not destructively protectionist.

title: Devils Overpowered; Islanders Prevail; Capitals 5, Devils 3
description: Two goals by Bob Gould 16 seconds apart early in the second period tonight led the Washington Capitals to a 5-3 triumph over the Devils, who have never won in 20 games at Capital Centre.

title: Airbus Urged to Press Its McDonnell Talks
description: The transportation ministers of France, West Germany, Britain and Spain today called on Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, to step up its discussions with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to help establish a cooperative agreement between the two rivals.

title: Restroom Search
description: To The Living Section:

title: Hammer Begins a Drive to Raise $1 Billion a Year to Fight Cancer
description: A new campaign to raise a billion dollars more a year for cancer research was announced yesterday by Dr. Armand Hammer, the industrialist and philanthropist.

title: Henry S. Bloch, 72, An Investment Banker
description: Henry Simon Bloch, managing director of E. M. Warburg Pincus & Company, investment bankers, and adjunct professor emeritus at Columbia University, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: CONSOL ENERGY PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes losses from the hotel partnership of $1,235,000 and $3,626,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from the hotel partnership of $774,000 for the quarter and $2,367,000 for the year.

title: Reed Sees Nets Romp in Debut
description: ''How do you feel? Are you a little nervous?''

title: Head of Business Lobby Forms His Own Firm
description: William Lilley 3d, the former CBS executive who has spent the last 18 months in Washington as head of a business lobbying group, announced yesterday that he was forming his own Washington-based concern to provide policy analysis, lobbying and communications services to corporate clients.

title: Oil Drops Amid Confusion On Pricing by Exporters
description: Prices of crude oil and byproducts resumed their decline yesterday amid confusing new reports about deep price discounting by some major oil-exporting countries.

title: HOME NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split paid in June 1987.

title: 22 Varieties on the Half Shell
description: THIS guide to oysters of the United States and Canada is adapted, with permission, from ''Oysters: A Connoisseur's Guide and Cookbook'' by Lonnie Williams and Karen Warner, published last year by 101 Productions in San Francisco (cloth, $16.95; paper, $10.95).

title: Small-Property Owners in Manhattan Find Situation Worsening; Cut the Red Tape
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Lawyer Balks At Taking Defense
description: A Federal judge yesterday held a Miami lawyer in contempt and fined him for refusing to represent a defendant in a 15-month racketeering trial here.

title: In Storm's Eye, a Race Of Cup Design
description: The time was June 1987. Andrew Johns, an eager young attorney working for Michael Fay of New Zealand, was looking for answers from the San Diego Yacht Club. What were the conditions going to be for the next America's Cup match? His boss wanted to know.

title: Japanese Unemployment
description: Unemployment in Japan fell to a seasonally adjusted 2.7 percent in January from 3 percent a year earlier, but it was up one-tenth percentage point from the previous month, the Government said today. The number of job holders rose in the 12-month period by 1.12 million, or 1.9 percent, to 58.28 million. Employment surged in the second half of 1987 as the Japanese economy recovered from the yen's higher value.

title: Pepperell Tops a New Stevens Bid
description: In the opening round of a takeover battle, a management group at J. P. Stevens & Company sweetened its buyout bid for the huge textile producer yesterday, only to see West Point-Pepperell Inc. emerge with an even higher offer.

title: Advertising; Omnicom Group's Net Soared in 1987 Quarter
description: The net income of the Omnicom Group, the holding company of both BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham, more than doubled in the fourth quarter of 1987 from the period a year ago.

title: AMERICAN CLAIMS EVALUATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Does Tumult Imperil Gorbachev's Goals? Some U.S. Views
description: Despite the challenge to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's authority posed by the current unrest among Soviet ethnic minorities, the consensus among United States Government experts is that he and his policies of change have not yet been seriously endangered.

title: CA BLOCKERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: This development stage company began operations on Oct. 23, 1986.

title: Natural Instincts
description: To The Living Section:

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes report in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described Cotton Inc.'s appointment of J. Nicholas Hahn. He was named president and chief executive.

title: Black Official Faults Tactics Of Sharpton
description: A black Assemblyman today accused one of Tawana Brawley's advisers of ''tactics that encourage race war'' and ''cavalier use of words like 'racism' and 'fascism.' ''

title: FBX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Former Agent Is Convicted
description: Jim Abernethy, a former sports agent from Atlanta, was found guilty of a misdemeanor tampering charge tonight and received the maximum sentence of a year in jail and a $2,000 fine.

title: Desert Partners Makes Hostile Bid for USG
description: After failing to negotiate a friendly merger with the USG Corporation, a partnership controlled by the Texas oilmen Jack E. Brown and Cyril Wagner Jr. today made a hostile tender offer of $42 a share, or $1.9 billion, for the nation's largest gypsum producer.

title: Would Nunn Win on Super Tuesday?
description: ''You can gather up your Confederate money, because the South will rise again!''

title: 'Carrie' Churns Toward U.S.
description: It certainly sounds Bardic enough for the Royal Shakespeare Company's imprimatur, from the first-act bloodletting to the finale's mutual murder of mother and daughter. But, more crassly, is it Broadway?

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Culture and Rocks
description: It appears Washington will go to considerable lengths to prove it has become culturally sophisticated city.

title: MONTCLAIR SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in March 1987. The bank announced that a plan to reorganize the bank into a holding company structure will be presented for stockholder approval at the April 26 annual meeting.

title: Victory on a Foul
description: Julie Krone, who is involved in a race with Patty Cooksey for most career victories by a woman jockey, picked up her 1,200th triumph Monday night at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N.J., in an unusual fashion. In the featured eighth race, Krone's horse, Explodom, had a head advantage over Flying Daisey as the horses neared the finish line when the opposing jockey, Armando Marquez, reached out with his left hand and grabbed Explodom's reins from Krone's right hand. After Explodom quickly pulled up, Flying Daisey crossed the finish line first, but was disqualified because of Marquez's foul. Explodom was moved up, and the victory put Krone within three victories of Cooksey, who on Sunday became the women's leader with two victories that moved her total beyond the 1,202 that Patti Barton had before she retired in 1984.

title: Troops Raid Panama Radio Station and Seize Ex-Candidate; Strike Gains
description: Heavily armed paramilitary forces burst into a radio station here this afternoon, beating a former presidential candidate badly before seizing him and 10 other people and forcing the station off the air.

title: Pillsbury to Keep Burger King, Despite Rumors
description: The Pillsbury Company's stock soared early today in anticipation that the Minneapolis company's new top officer would announce dramatic plans like the sale of the Burger King chain. But the shares fell back when he said he had no such intentions.

title: INTERNATIONAL POWER MAHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WESTERN HEALTH PLANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bilingual Education Survives in California
description: A year ago, advocates of English as California's official language were cheering their landslide victory in a statewide vote on the issue. They looked forward to ending the state's bilingual education program.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Jose Mesa, pitcher. HOUSTON (NL) - Signed Billy Hatcher, outfielder, and Jim Deshaies, Jeff Heathcock, Manny Hernandez and Charlie Kerfeld, pitchers, to one-year contracts. Signed Hal Lanier, manager to a contract extension through the 1989 season. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed Danny Tartabull, outfielder, to a one-year contract. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Bill Wegman and Chuck Crim, pitchers, and Steve Stanicek, outfielder, to one-year contracts. MINNESOTA (AL) - Signed Doug Baker, shortstop, to a one-year contract. MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Andres Galarraga, first baseman; Jeff Parrett, pitcher, and Ron Shepard, outfielder, to one-year contracts. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed Rey Quinones, shortstop, and Harold Reynolds, second baseman, to one-year contracts. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Rob Ducey, outfielder; Manny Lee, infielder; Jeff Musselman and Jose Nunez, pitchers, to one-year contracts. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed John Russell, catcher, and Bob Scanlan, pitcher, to one-year contracts. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed Greg Mathews and Joe Magrane, pitchers; Mike Laga, first baseman, and Tim Jones, shortstop, to one-year contracts. BASKETBALL ATLANTA (NBA) - Announced that Jon Koncak, center, will miss the remainder of the season because of injury. ROCHESTER (CBA) - Dismissed Bill Klucas, head coach and general manager. COLLEGES ABILENE CHRISTIAN - Announced the resignation of Mike Martin, basketball coach. BROWN - Announced that Herb Hammond, hockey coach, had resigned but will remain with the school as assistant to the athletic director for event management. SOUTH CAROLINA - Dismissed Bob Marcum athletic director. Relieved Dr. Paul Akers, team physician, of his duties and started termination proceedings. URBANA - Named Doug Sams football coach. HOCKEY BOSTON (NHL) - Signed Bob Joyce, left wing, to a multiyear contract. RANGERS (NHL) - Signed Tony Granato, right wing-center, and assigned him to Colorado of the International League. Sent Jeff Brubaker, left wing, to Colorado. WASHINGTON (NHL) - Traded John Barrett, defenseman, to the Minnesota North Stars for future considerations.

title: Debates Are Cancelled For Want of Debaters
description: The League of Women Voters said tonight that it was canceling the Republican and Democratic Presidential debates that were to be held here Sunday because some candidates would not participate.

title: Economic Scene; Frequent Fliers: Will I.R.S. Act?
description: IS Uncle Sam planning to take the ''free'' out of frequent flier awards?

title: Mets' Miller in a Utility Role
description: If you ask Keith Miller why he drove 1,000 miles in the middle of December, two months early for spring training, even before the Mets' new stadium here was completed, he says with absolute logic: ''The years pass. I wanted to get going.'' Keith Miller is a 24-year-old rookie, and he wanted to get going because he had no job on a team loaded with stars. Also, because six people on the Mets outrank him in the three positions he plays.

title: CIRCLE EXPRESS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest year includes a pretax loss on investments of $1,18,000.

title: ASHTON-TATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Lessons
description: On a sand and gravel road, a stone's throw from where a winter sea breaks hard against the rocks, the past lives. It is a white one-room schoolhouse with seven students and a teacher who makes her way to class along an icy path through a dark pine woods.

title: Iraqi Missile Attacks on Iran: A New Twist to the Old War
description: Iran and Iraq bombarded each other's capitals with missiles today, continuing a dramatic escalation of attacks on cities.

title: Southern Democrats Go Home Again
description: Nancy McCoy has not backed a Democratic Presidential candidate since Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964, but next Tuesday, she says, she will vote in the Texas Democratic primary.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: In the latest year, the costing of inventories under the LIFO method reduced net income by 5 cents a share, in the prior year by 1 cent a share.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $179,000 for the quarter and $226,000 for the 6 months.

title: 'Complete Silence Is the Best Thing'
description: Following are excerpts from tape recordings of remarks by Franklin D. Roosevelt, recorded in the White House:

title: Film: 'A Jumpin' Night' of Klezmer
description: IN case the proclaimed revival of klezmer has somehow passed you by, you can catch up with the catchy music at ''A Jumpin' Night in the Garden of Eden.'' Klezmer (the word comes from the Hebrew for musical instruments) had its origins in the Middle Ages and was popular in the shtetls of Eastern Europe. Itinerant bands of fiddlers, horn blowers and drummers were hired by Polish aristocrats to play their lively mishmash of Hebraic melodies and folk airs from every country where Jews had found themselves. Those poor Jews, a notch above beggars, must have had rhythm.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Commerce Choice
description: W. Allen Moore, a former chief counsel and staff director of the Senate Commerce Committee, has apparently won out in the hot competition to become Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration, replacing S. Bruce Smart Jr., who resigned last week. The decision is expected to be announced soon, Administration sources said.

title: Abused Youth Is Flown Home To Zimbabwe
description: The 9-year-old son of a Zimbabwean diplomat was flown home to Zimbabwe Sunday night, ending a legal battle that began in December when the boy's father was charged with brutally beating him at the family's house in Queens.

title: Voter Surveys Approved
description: A Federal judge gave the three major television networks the go-ahead today to take polls at Georgia voting places during the Presidential primaries next week. CBS, NBC and ABC had sued state and Fulton County election officials to stop enforcement of a 1985 law prohibiting public opinion surveys within 250 feet of a polling place. The ruling will allow poll takers to be stationed within 25 feet of the door.

title: Open Hearings Against Judges Urged by Panel
description: Disciplinary hearings against judges in New York State should be opened to the public, the state commission that oversees judicial conduct recommended today.

title: A New Chief For Britoil
description: The British Petroleum Company said on Monday that it intends to name John Saint as chief executive of Britoil P.L.C. as soon as B.P. completes its acquisition of the company. The British Government has given B.P. permission to acquire Britoil.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Corruption of government officials and law enforcement officers, bribery, trafficker intimidation and violence, and the stark fact that nations are outmanned, outgunned and outspent by narcotics traffickers, continue to undermine global efforts to stop narcotics production and trafficking.'' - The State Department's annual report on narcotics. [ A1:6. ]

title: FIRST WOMEN'S BANK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The bank said its loss for 1987 is after a provision for loan losses of $1,941,000 and a charge of $250,000 for the settlement of a claim with the U.S. Treasury Dept. The bank also said that as of Dec. 31, 1987, its non-performing loans totaled only $144,000.

title: Gorbachev Delays Meeting With U.S. Business Leaders
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has asked to postpone a long-scheduled meeting in Moscow this month in which possible business deals were to be discussed with more than 500 American corporate leaders and Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., according to American and Soviet officials. It was unclear when the meeting might be rescheduled.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,679,000 and $5,711,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a $12,670,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $3,374,000. c-Net income d-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $474,000 and $11,302,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; an extraordinary gain of $6,455,000 for the quarter; the year includes a gain of $12,828,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations; a $40,054,000 tax credit and a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $1,787,000.

title: DIMENSIONAL MEDICINE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Profit for World Bank
description: The World Bank, the third world's main source of loans, today reported a $679 million profit for the last half of 1987, up from $655 million a year before. The bank borrows at low interest because its funds are guaranteed by the 152 member governments.

title: Public Education: A State-by-State Review
To Plug the Social Work Drain
description: In the battles to erase poverty's terrible consequences, those on the front lines are apt to be social workers. Yet low salaries are forcing professionals who staff voluntary human services agencies to flee the field by the thousands. Interface, a group that analyzes public policy issues in New York, offers some imaginative ways to lure them back.

title: Smoke Clears And Trains Are Cleaner
description: Two weeks after smoking was banned on the Long Island and Metro-North Commuter Railroads, officials say, the cars are cleaner.

title: Pretoria's Move Challenges the U.S.
description: LEAD: Seeking to guarantee the survival of apartheid into the 21st century, the South African Government last week effectively banned 17 organizations, including the two-million-member United Democratic Front, that have been leading the struggle against apartheid. The Government has simultaneously imposed crippling restrictions on South Africa's largest labor federation, the Congress of South African Trade

title: Eugene H. Remmer, 64, Founder of Chemtex
description: Eugene H. Remmer, the founder and chairman of Chemtex Inc., an engineering company that specialized in the export of technology to developing countries, died of cancer Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: PLEXUS RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Girl Attacked by Ants Dies
description: A 16-month-old girl bitten last week by a swarm of ants has died, a hospital spokeswoman said today. The girl, Tiffany Cheatham, died Monday night at Sacred Heart Hospital here, said the spokeswoman, Kathy Musial. Tiffany was taken to the hospital on Feb. 23 after a playful dog pushed her into an ant hill near her Florida Panhandle home in Navarre, 20 miles from Pensacola. Ann Papadelias, another hospital spokeswoman, said she suspected the girl was attacked by fire ants.

title: Inland Steel Sets Closing of 4 Mills
description: The Inland Steel Company said it planned to close four mills at its Indiana Harbor Works plant in East Chicago, Ind., in 90 days, but that it was willing to ''discuss the proposal or to receive any alternatives to the proposed course of action.' At issue is Inland's proposal to separate its bar and structural steel business and then begin a $100 million modernization.

title: COMMUNITY BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the earnings decline to a pretax non-recurring charge to earnings of approximately $543,000 taken in the latest quarter resulting from problems that developed in a data processing conversion.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: REMEMBERING THE MOVIE MATRON

title: Britain to Sell Its Rover Stake
description: British Aerospace P.L.C., the country's biggest aircraft manufacturer, will make an exclusive bid for the state-owned car maker Rover Group P.L.C. in an effort to prevent a foreign takeover, the Government announced today.

title: Determined Bidders for Federated; Canada Rebuff Led Campeau Chief to U.S.
description: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail. But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy & Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation. Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers have signed Tony Granato, a member of the United States Olympic hockey team. Granato, a 23-year-old right wing who played at the University of Wisconsin, scored a goal and had seven assists in the United States' six games in Calgary, Alberta. . . . Mary Decker Slaney has entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon for the first time, organizers of the 10-kilometer race announced yesterday. The race will be run in Central Park on June 4. . . . Torn ligaments in the right knee will cause the Atlanta Hawks' reserve center Jon Koncak to miss the rest of the season. Koncak was injured Feb. 12 in Detroit when he collided with a teammate, Cliff Levingston. . . . Larry Smith, who went on the Golden State injured list for the fourth time this season, probably will miss the remainder of the Warriors' season because of a torn thigh muscle. The team rebound leader in each of his seven National Basketball Association seasons, Smith had played in only 20 games this season. . . . Danny Tartabull, who said Monday night that he wanted the Kansas City Royals to trade him, ended his holdout yesterday and signed a one-year contract.

title: Founder of Moog Inc. Starts New Company
description: William C. Moog, the 72-year-old entrepreneur and engineer, has left the industrial company he founded in 1951 to concentrate on developing new suspension technology for autos.

title: Sports of The Times; An Ode to Calgary
description: THE last day has been crossed off the Olympic calendar, and by now, the bones of the Winter Games have just about been picked clean. It seems so long ago, but this all began Feb. 8, on a flight from New York to Chicago, the first leg of a journey to Calgary that only a travel agent unaware that the shortest distance between two points is a straight line would have booked. That particular flight was canceled, of course.

title: Bush Defends Efforts to Intercept Drugs, but He Concedes Difficulty
description: Speaking in a region favored by drug smugglers, Vice President Bush declared today that despite Reagan Administration efforts the United States still had ''porous borders and shorelines.''

title: Question for Indonesia: Who Will Be No. 2?
description: An assembly created to elect the next President and Vice President of Indonesia opened an 11-day session here today with a subdued ceremony, but amid lively public speculation over who will fill the second-highest position.

title: Real Estate; Development Ideas Sought In New York
description: THE largest solicitation of commercial and industrial development proposals in the 22-year history of the New York City Public Development Corporation was announced yesterday by the agency's president, James P. Stuckey.

title: U.S. Struggles With Plan to Monitor Arms Treaty
description: Though both the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to try to speed work on a new strategic arms reduction treaty, the Reagan Administration is still struggling to define a plan for monitoring the pact, according to Government experts.

title: Music: A Bernstein Celebration
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN will not reach 70 for six months, but his friends and admirers could not wait. They held a party for him on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall, where ''A Leonard Bernstein Song Celebration'' was presented by Composers' Showcase. The music was all by Mr. Bernstein, a sampling of his output during nearly half a century of composing for the voice. The two-dozen numbers ranged widely in weight and pretensions, from ''I Hate Music'' (No. 3 in the 1943 cycle of ''Five Kid Songs'') to Dede's Aria from the 1983 opera ''A Quiet Place.''

title: Wine Talk
description: A HORIZONTAL tasting has nothing to do with the posture of the tasters. It is a sampling of many wines from one vintage. A vertical tasting, on the other hand, is a tasting of one wine from many vintages.

title: FIRST BANC SECURITIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Monday about Ann B. Wrobleski, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, misidentified her alma mater. It is Stephens College in Columbia, Mo.

title: Eastman Kodak Is Offering $1.1 Billion of Notes at Par
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is offering $1.1 billion of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Proceeds from the note sale, the underwriters said, may be used for various corporate purposes, including Kodak's planned acquisition of Sterling Drug Inc. Originally Kodak had planned to sell about $750 million of notes.

title: IMMUCELL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MORTGAGE & REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Saturn Hiring Begins
description: The General Motors Corporation's new car division has begun recruiting the first 3,000 workers for its Spring Hill, Tenn., factory, the Saturn Corporation said today. The plant will begin producing Saturn vehicles in the summer of 1990 for the 1991 model year.

title: FORD CANADA CO OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1.6 million for the quarter and a special charge of $40.2 million for the year. The company said the charge in 1987 was from the restructuring of its involvement in South Africa. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: G.O.P SEES DEFEAT ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: Furious over procedures set by the Democratic leadership for a House vote on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, Republicans today all but conceded defeat in their efforts to win passage of a rival aid package.

title: 6 Free Agents to Stay Put
description: Six of the seven beneficiaries of an arbitrator's ruling in Conspiracy Case I ended their period of no-risk free agency today by opting to stay with their teams. Kirk Gibson was the only player to change teams.

title: GATEWAY COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Dukakis and Bush Win Vermont
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis easily won the Vermont Democratic Presidential primary today, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson the runner-up. Vice President Bush defeated Senator Bob Dole in the Republican race.

title: Pleasant Landing
description: Saying he would not let failure go to his head, Eddie (The Eagle) Edwards, the ski jumper, arrived home from Calgary with the rest of the British team yesterday and got off the plane last - his final standing in the two ski jumps during the Olympic Winter Games. Surrounded by policemen at Heathrow Airport outside London, Edwards said: ''Nothing's going to change. I've made it, I've made it to the Olympics. That's all I cared about.'' A gala reception is planned for tomorrow in Cheltenham, his hometown, which is 90 miles northwest of London.

title: People Goes Feelbad
description: People was my favorite magazine. It made me feel good even through the feelgood Reagan years when all instinct screamed that anybody who really believed it was morning in America was either very rich or too dumb to tell time without a digital watch.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of 9 cents a share and 15 cents a share for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: WORKINGMENS CO-OPERATIVE BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $404,000. Year-ago share earnings are not available because the company went public in April 1987.

title: Public Library Should Be a Refuge for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Revision of Economic Index Dims Specter of an Imminent Recession
description: The Government today revised upward the December figure for its principal economic-forecasting index, ending a string of three consecutive monthly declines, which is sometimes considered a signal of an imminent recession. It also reported that the figure fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected.

title: U.S. Backs Panamanian's Tactic And Weighs Canal Funds Cutoff
description: With the backing of the Reagan Administration, political opponents of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today presented a campaign of economic warfare intended to create a cash flow crisis for Panama.

title: Old-Timers Are Shut Out
description: For the first time since 1956, the Veterans Committee failed to elect anyone to the Baseball Hall of Fame. Today, the committee again passed up such former stars as Phil Rizzuto, Leo Durocher, Joe Gordon and Gil Hodges.

title: EATING OUT: With Garrison Keillor; Where Are The Smelts of Yesteryear?
description: GARRISON KEILLOR is not easy to camouflage in a crowd, especially when it's a soigne group of evening revelers at the newly renovated Rainbow Room atop Rockefeller Center.

title: Announcement Of Computer Due
description: Apple Computer Inc. and Texas Instruments Inc. will announce on Thursday a specially configured version of the Macintosh II personal computer for artificial intelligence applications, industry sources said today. The machine will include a microprocessor designed to run LISP, a computer language used in artificial intelligence development, and is expected to be sold by Texas Instruments for less than $20,000.

title: 2 Officials Praise New Fed Policy
description: The Reagan Administration, which has blamed Federal Reserve policies of last year for much of the slowing of the election-year economy, today applauded the new policies that Fed officials disclosed last week.

title: Senators Discuss Bank Bill
description: The Senate Banking Committee adjourned this evening without taking substantive action on a bill sponsored by Senator William Proxmire, its chairman, to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 and in the process increase the power of commercial banks to engage in activities that were previously restricted to the securities industry.

title: Portugal Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Microwave Cooking
description: GOOD salads can be among the more pleasant parts of dieting, with only two problems: dressings tend to be very fattening, and making special ones is time consuming. That presents a difficulty, because it is a good idea when dieting to spend as little time as possible amid temptation in the kitchen. The microwave oven can help by making dressings quick to do.

title: Piano: Jodie Gelbogis Recital
description: MOST debut artists play to forlorn rows of empty seats, but Jodie Gelbogis enjoys a following that packed Weill Recital Hall to overflowing for her piano recital Sunday afternoon. To judge by intermission talk, the audience still represented the traditional components (family, friends, congregation), but the scale was unusual.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall
description: Interest rates fell for the second straight week at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper yesterday at an average rate of 6.5188 percent, down from 6.567 percent last week, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 6.525 percent, down from 6.6226 percent.

title: CYCLOPS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $30,918,000 for the quarter and $34,467,000 for the year. The company said it was formed last June 30 from the steel products and non-residential construction businesses of Cyclops Corp. and the steel fabrication and components businesses of Alleghany Corp. The company did not provide year- ago comparisions, since it was newly structured last June 30.

title: U.S. FINDS OUTPUT OF DRUGS IN WORLD GROWING SHARPLY
description: The State Department reported today that production of coca, marijuana and opium poppies in most drug-producing countries had grown substantially in the last year and that it was beyond the ability of any single government to control.

title: Eating Well
description: DON'T think of spa food as diet food; think of it as a new kind of cuisine. That is the suggestion of one of the most skillful creators of spa food, Christian Chavanne, the new chef at the Golden Door in Escondido, Calif.

title: Gretzky Tops Assist Record
description: Wayne Gretzky got his record-breaking 1,050th career assist and Esa Tikkanen helped set up three goals tonight night, pacing the Edmonton Oilers to a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings. Gretzky's record point, breaking the assist of 1,049 set by Gordie Howe, came at 12 minutes 44 seconds of the opening period.

title: G.M. to Sell Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation has agreed to sell its Fairfield automobile parts stamping plant to Cynba International Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Cynba, headed by an automotive executive, Anthony Barclae, would continue operating the plant, G.M. officials said.

title: Prominent U.S. Jews, Visiting Israel, Voice Unease
description: This is the time of year when, by recent tradition, the leaders of American Jewish organizations meet with the leaders of Israel to cement and renew a bond. This year, more than usual, the occasion is shot through with unease and worries framed in terms of war and peace and morality.

title: Hamlet In Central America
description: To intervene or not to intervene? That really isn't the question. The litany enshrining non-intervention as a principle of Western Hemisphere relations arose from the U.S. dispatch of armed force and gunboat diplomacy, and on that level the taboo is clear enough.

title: Amid Hopes, Green Starts as Chancellor
description: Dr. Richard R. Green took over as New York City's Schools Chancellor yesterday amid high hopes that the man who had dramatically improved public education in Minneapolis could do the same for New York.

title: Dow Declines 1.16 in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday in slow, virtually featureless trading.

title: 76th Appeal for the Neediest Receives Highest Donation Total
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has finished its 76th annual appeal with the highest total of contributions in its history - $3,764,546.04 from 14,121 donors.

title: Those Oysters From Bays You've Never Heard Of
description: LEAD: JUST when you thought you'd finally mastered the differences between a Belon and a bluepoint, a slew of new oysters have begun showing up on New York menus. The dizzying array includes Kumamotos, Quilcenes, Hog Island Sweetwaters, Olympias, Westcott Bay Petites, Minterbrooks, Kent Islands, Pine Islands, Caraquets, Golden Mantles and Willapa

title: Securities Firms Streamlining Computer Systems Despite the Crash
description: JOHN J. MURPHY, the manager of Paine Webber Inc.'s consumer market systems, originally expected to spend last Oct. 20 proposing to a management committee that the aging stock quotation machines used by Paine Webber's 4,000 brokers be replaced with personal computer-based work stations tied to powerful minicomputers. That presentation, like many others on Wall Street, was called off on Oct. 19 as the stock market went into its nose dive.

title: Speculator Is Released and Then Arrested
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., the Wall Street speculator arrested last month on state charges of illegal possession of weapons, was released from a county jail in Freehold, N.J., today but immediately arrested by Federal authorities on related charges.

title: In 'Babette,' A Great Feast For the Palate And the Eye
description: COMING to neighborhood theaters, and some 500 restaurants nationwide, is ''Babette's Feast,'' the movie and the meal.

title: In Queens, A Farewell With Love
description: She loves them, the elderly people know, and they love her.

title: College Basketball; Syracuse Sets Back Villanova by 71-69
description: Rony Seikaly scored on a reverse layup with 1 minute 25 seconds to play tonight as No. 12 Syracuse edged Villanova, 71-69, in a Big East Conference game.

title: Aquino Indicates Conditions For an End to Marcos Exile
description: After initial contacts with former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, President Corazon C. Aquino said today that Mr. Marcos cannot return before he gives back the billions of dollars he is believed to have stolen from the Philippines.

title: Even Those Who Serve Must Audition for the Part
description: AFTER 10 years of pursuing a career in movie acting, Ryan Sands has learned to take show business in stride. But when he decided late to look for a job as a waiter in the fall of 1987, he was rattled.

description: Year-ago quarter includes one- month of operations of Allied Uniking, acquired Nov. 30, 1986.

title: Jersey Judge Declines to Order AIDS Tests
description: In the first case to be heard under a local ordinance requiring AIDS testing of anyone convicted of prostitution or of soliciting, a Municipal Court judge said that he did not have the power to order the tests because there were no enforcement provisions in the law.

description: The featured speaker at the annual conference of the National Association of Independent Schools last week was Governor Kean, a favorite of educators because of his long outspoken support.

title: Makers Display New Computers
description: Three companies have introduced new high-powered computers. Apollo Computer Inc. of Chelmsford, Mass., has a work station for engineers with supercomputer power that is priced from $69,900 to $130,000.

description: * Archer-Daniels-Midland Inc., Decatur, Ill., which processes agricultural commodities, has agreed to buy CLC of America Inc., St. Louis, a barge line, for about $60 million.

Campaign Trail
description: Left? Right!

title: Robertson Seeks to Withdraw Libel Lawsuit
description: Pat Robertson announced today that he was seeking to withdraw his $35 million libel suit against Paul N. McCloskey Jr., the former California Congressman who accused him of using his father's influence to avoid combat in Korea.

title: British Mail Carries Mark, 'Jesus Is Alive!'
description: The Post Office today began postmarking nearly all letters mailed in Britain with the words ''Jesus Is Alive!'' as part of a private arrangement financed by an evangelist.

title: Coaches Help Authors Talk Well to Sell Well
description: Marilyn Greene expects to be on television often this summer, so on this blustery winter day she was being put through her paces. ''When you sit, put your fanny back, cross your legs and incline forward into the camera,'' her speech coach, Dorothy Sarnoff, told her. ''Think of the 10 most hostile questions you do not want to be asked, and be ready to answer them succinctly with a smile on your face.''

title: Script Writers' Talks Go On
description: Negotiators reported no progress today in resolving three primary issues in a 21-hour session on a contract for 9,000 movie and television script writers.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Racial Tension at Dartmouth As Teacher and Paper Clash
description: A dispute between a black professor and a right-wing student newspaper has erupted anew, fueling racial tension at Dartmouth College and leaving four students facing disciplinary charges.

title: Court Rules In Belgium
description: A Brussels appeals court today approved Societe Generale de Belgique's plan to increase its capital by 40 percent to weaken the stake of the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, but left it to a higher court to give the final word on the issue.

description: To the Editor:

description: b-Net income

description: The chairman of the Senate panel investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d's financial disclosures today asked the Federal ethics office to determine whether Mr. Meese had complied with regulations on conflict of interest in his personal investments.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary income of 4 cents a share in both the quarter and year. c-Includes extraordinary income of 8 cents a share and 22 cents a share in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: GAF Seeks Alternative to Heyman Bid
description: Samuel J. Heyman, the chairman of the GAF Corporation, offered to buy the company yesterday for $51 a share, or $1.4 billion, in cash and securities.

title: Lebanon Kidnappers Release 2 U.N. Refugee Aid Workers
description: Two Scandinavians serving with the United Nations relief agency who were kidnapped in southern Lebanon last month were freed unharmed today, the United Nations announced here.

CAYUGA SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loan loss provision of $214,000. c-Net income and includes gains of $304,000 on securities transactions for the quarter; the year includes an extraordinary gain of $670,000, or 89 cents a share. The company said the loss in the latest year was a result of a $2,167,000 provision for market depreciation on certain U.S. Treasury and mortgage- backed securities during the first and second quarters of 1987.

title: Determined Bidders for Federated; One Success After Another for Macy Head
description: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail. But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy & Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation. Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

title: Southwest Chief Journal; For Train Passengers, A Seminar on Indians
description: Crossing a landscape of vast and haunting beauty as it hurries from Los Angeles to Chicago, the Southwest Chief looks like any of the remaining transcontinental passenger trains. But twice a week, along the 160-mile stretch from Gallup, N.M., to Albuquerque, the train becomes a speeding mini-seminar on Indian America.

title: TV Review; The Met Opera's 'Tales of Hoffmann'
description: FORMERLY ''Live From the Met,'' when at least some broadcasts were indeed transmitted live from the Lincoln Center stage, ''The Metropolitan Opera Presents'' continues its current television season this evening at 8 on Channel 13 with still another lavish production from this year's repertory. Last month, it was Franco Zeffirelli's ''Turandot.'' Tonight, it's Otto Schenk's ''Tales of Hoffmann,'' a production of the Offenbach work that was first introduced in 1982. This performance was taped on Jan. 8.

title: De Gustibus; What's American Depends on the Cook
description: REMEMBER when restaurant food meant French, Italian or Chinese? Everything else was what you ate at home. And whatever you ate at home was called home cooking. It probably had an exotic accent if your parents were first-generation Americans, but it took a long time for those exotic ingredients to make their way into mainstream cooking.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in Living on Feb. 10 misidentified the owner of Frieda's Finest, a marketer of unusual produce in Los Angeles. She is Frieda Caplan.

title: Public Library Should Be a Refuge for Children; Regulars in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: For Heidegger, Nazism Was Great Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo; 2 Steady Courses to Super Tuesday
description: With all the uproar over candidates' changing their images, styles, strategies and deeply held beliefs, one of the striking facts about the 1988 Presidential campaign is that two of the strongest candidates are coming to next Tuesday's big array of primaries with almost exactly the same strategies that their campaigns outlined last spring.

title: Harvard Study In Soviet Is Set
description: Two professors at the Harvard Business School have received permission from the Soviet Union to conduct a comprehensive study of management procedures at two Soviet industrial sites.

title: The Pop Life
description: Robert Plant Evolving

title: Soviet Says It Used Troops to Quell Riots in South
description: Military forces were called in to quell rioting in a southern Soviet city Sunday and have remained there to enforce a nighttime curfew, the Government said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
description: International A3-12

title: Construction Spending Declines
description: Construction spending fell 2.9 percent in January, the biggest decline in 10 months, reflecting widespread weakness in all sectors of the building industry, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Justices Back U.S. Deportation Stand
description: The Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 today that the Government has broad latitude to refuse to reopen deportation cases to hear belated assertions by aliens that they would be persecuted if returned to the home country.

title: You Can't Stand the Noise? Get an Anti-Noise Machine
description: HIGH school physics students learn that matter is composed of waves - light waves, electromagnetic waves, sound waves -and that if two trains of waves are exactly out of phase and collide head-on they can cancel each other. Engineers have toyed with the possibility of blanking out noise by bombarding offensive sound waves with their exact opposites, or anti-noise. But generating effective anti-noise has been difficult because it required too much electronic signal processing.

title: Pretoria May Ban Foreign Funds for Rights Groups
description: The South African Government continued its nationwide crackdown on anti-apartheid groups today by proposing legislation to block foreign financing of political groups and individuals.

title: COUNTY SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chambers Prosecution Rests After Slaying Is Re-enacted
description: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. after a heated and dramatic court session in which the jury saw two subtly different re-enactments of how Jennifer Levin might have died.

title: An Operation For The Sphinx
description: Experts started work today to see if they could repair the damage to the Sphinx.

title: FRAMINGHAM SAVINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring pretax special distribution of $1.1 million. The bank converted to a stock form of ownership from mutual ownership in October 1987.

title: Maureen Roach, Guidance Counselor, 56
description: Maureen Roach, a former teacher and guidance counselor, died of cancer Feb. 21 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FIRST FEDERAL OF ALABAMA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are not available; the company went public Dec. 17, 1986.

title: Moslems to Expand Anti-Drug Patrols
description: A Moslem leader who won praise and community support when he led volunteers from his Brooklyn mosque against drugs said yesterday that the anti-drug patrol in Bedford-Stuyvesant would be expanded.

title: Mecham Is Called Victim of Political Persecution
description: In a combative opening statement, Evan Mecham's lawyers today began defending the Governor in his impeachment trial here by charging that he was the victim of political persecution.

title: Blacks-Indians Alliance Has Deep Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Life in the 30's
description: I WAS walking on the East Side of Manhattan one afternoon when I saw a woman in slacks and a turtleneck standing outside the front door of a lovely old house. I immediately crossed the street. Anyone watching would have thought I was going out of my way to avoid someone I knew and disliked. The truth was I was going out of my way to avoid someone I didn't know, but worshipped. I was afraid the woman in the doorway was Katharine Hepburn, and I was afraid to set eyes on her.

title: 7.95% Offering By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $1 billion of new 4-year, 11-month debentures through various dealers. With a coupon of 7.95 percent, the issue is priced at par. The top yield is 34 basis points more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $306,000 from sale of land. c-After a loss of $1,332,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Ancient Redwoods Fall to a Wall Street Takeover
description: Thousands of redwood trees are being felled along California's wild northern coast in an environmental drama that is arousing high emotions and demonstrating how decisions on Wall Street can affect people, communities and natural resources far away.

title: Boxing Notebook; First Step Into Rahway Ring for Ayala
description: Tony Ayala, the former junior-middleweight contender now incarcerated at Rahway (N.J.) State Prison, is due back in the ring again.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for 12mo to Jan 31
description: The company said results for the 1987 periods are restated to reflect the effects of a change in accounting standards concerning computation of a loss on abandonment and disallowance of plant costs.

title: About Education
description: Prof. Lee S. Shulman, who may be in the process of revolutionizing testing in America, likes to tell this story. A man asks his neighbor to return a pot he had lent him some weeks ago. The neighbor replies angrily: ''In the first place, I never borrowed the pot. In the second place, it was cracked when I borrowed it. And finally, I returned it a long time ago.''

title: Joe Besser, 80, od rhw 3 Stooges
description: Joe Besser, a comedian who was one of the later members of the Three Stooges and played the whining brat Stinky in the Abbott and Costello television show, was found dead in his home today. He was 80 years old and had been ill for six months, said his press agent of 15 years, Jeff Lenburg.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: IN recent months I have been surprised at how often cabbage, long scorned as a second-class vegetable, has appeared on the menus of some of the finest and most luxurious restaurants, both in this country and in France. Now cabbage is being stuffed with foie gras or with fish and truffles.

title: BERKLEY, W R CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $192,000 and a gain of $905,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both on investments, and the year also includes a tax credit of $4,181,000. c-Includes gains on investments of $267,000 for the quarter and $1,203,000 for the year, and tax credits of $4,350,000 and $8,650,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The P.L.O., No and Yes
description: The bottom may be about to fall out of the assumption that underlies Middle East peace negotiations. The assumption has been that Palestinians would sit at the peace talks as part of the Jordanian delegation, and that the parties thus could sidestep direct dealings with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Now Jordan seems to say that it will not press for a delegation including Palestinians, and that the P.L.O. is free to make its own way.

title: Opera: Change in 'Siegfried'
description: SINCE Peter Hofmann withdrew from the title part of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Siegfried,'' the Met has been dividing up the performances among substitutes. Wolfgang Neumann got the premiere and several subsequent evenings. But Toni Kramer, who had been scheduled to sing a couple of performances anyway, is doing four of them, including the broadcast and the one Monday night, in a cast otherwise comprising singers who have been reviewed in their parts.

title: A Bit of Old New York On a Japanese Skyline
description: IN August, the people of Nagoya, Japan, will have a glimpse of New York architecture without having to leave town. In fact, once Sekitei Plaza is finished, the neo-classical building with cornices, moldings and columns would look at home in lower Manhattan. But Nagoya?

title: National Ski Patrol Celebrates 50 Years
description: SKIERS generally take it for granted that if they're hurt on the ski slopes, someone wearing a parka with a large gold cross on the back will be along to transport them safely to the bottom of the mountain. That good samaritan is a member of the National Ski Patrol, which on March 7 will be 50 years old.

title: Health; New Studies Report Health Dangers Of Repressing Emotional Turmoil

title: Nuclear Plant Release
description: A ''puff'' of tritium escaped from the Department of Energy's Savannah River plant Tuesday, officials said. They said the release from the plant that makes materials used in the production of nuclear weapons did not pose a hazard to the public. The release of 20,000 curies of tritium, a radioactive isotope of hydrogen, was described as a puff that lasted less than a minute.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
New President Chosen At McDonnell Douglas
description: Gerald A. Johnston, a top manager of a McDonnell Douglas Corporation unit that has recently won a number of important space contracts, was selected president of the company yesterday in a move that surprised some analysts.

description: b-Includes for the quarter an operating loss in the company's Zayre Stores division of $16,781,000, the result of the division's disappointing sales and reduced merchandise margins; the year includes a gain of $20,536,000 representing the cumulative affect of a change in inventory accounting and also includes a gain of $89.6 million from the sale of a minority interest in TJX Cos. c-Includes a charge of $3,432,000 from the early extingishment of debt. The company said the loss in its Zayre Stores division for the year was $13,885,000.

title: Far Right Gains in South Africa
description: The far-right Conservative Party scored a decisive victory Wednesday night in two by-elections in Transvaal Province.

description: The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission took issue today with another key Federal regulator over whether margin, or down payment, requirements on stock-index futures need to be increased.

title: Better U.S. Accounting Will Increase Confidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Aide Held In Theft of Items In an Apartment
description: An investigator in the Queens Public Administrator's office was indicted yesterday after authorities said he stole valuables from the home of a man he believed had died without a will.

title: Higher Sales Buoy Atari's Results
description: The Atari Corporation today reported operating gains for the fourth quarter and all of 1987 as sales increased. The computer maker was hampered, however, by a write-down related to Atari's October acquisition of the Federated Group, a troubled electronics retailer.

title: Jazz: Paul Bley Quartet
description: THE pianist Paul Bley revels in vagueness: at the first set Tuesday at Sweet Basil, leading a quartet, he opened several tunes without a melody; time floated in and out, solo orders were called out in the middle of compositions. All this caused apprehension, as if the relationship between the audience and the band members mirrored an uncertain relationship between two friends. The rules had changed, and every step was a new one.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Offering Of $425 Million in Securities
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $425 million in mortgage securities through a real estate mortgage investment conduit, commonly referred to as a Remic.

title: The Dance: 'Labor Of Love'
description: THE mood was lighthearted when Gail Donnenfeld and Rocky Bornstein presented their works on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church. But the two choreographers had more on their minds than simple, spirited fun.

title: Metro Datelines; Explosives Dropped On Tug From Bridge
description: Two mock grenades filled with explosives were dropped off the Queensboro Bridge onto a tugboat, and flares were fired at another tug early yesterday in the latest incidents stemming from a strike by a union of tug and barge crewmen, the police said.

description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company will pay $39 million to clean up ditches, lagoons and other groundwater sites contaminated by hazardous waste that seeped from its Chamber Works plant here, a company official said. The cleanup, part of an administrative consent order with the state Department of Environmental Protection, was described as the largest settlement by one company for one location in the United States.
