description: The Detroit Tigers said today they planned no disciplinary action against Willie Hernandez, their relief pitcher, for dumping a bucket of ice water on a sportswriter today.

title: Treasury Bonds Rise Moderately
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted moderate gains yesterday in trading marked by sharp changes in market sentiment throughout the day. Meanwhile, Treasury bill rates were slightly lower, reflecting a continued easing of short-term credit conditions.

title: U.N. Plans Observers for Afghan Peace
description: The United Nations has drawn up plans to send a small military observer force to Afghanistan next May to monitor a peace agreement that would provide for the withdrawal of Soviet troops, a senior United Nations official said today.

title: The Problem With New York's Coliseum Deal
description: To the Editor:

The company converted to stock form of ownership in November 1986; per-share data are not applicable for the 1986 periods.

title: Chicago Journal; It's Pure Poetry, for Cheers or Jeers
description: A rather serious-looking poet is reciting a wrenching piece about the nothingness of being, or perhaps the being of nothingness. The audience is not moved. In fact, a few people are booing.

title: Different Site, Same Result for Devils and Capitals
description: The Devils came up with another incomplete performance and another loss tonight, their fifth in the last six games.

title: Forstmann Little Bids $883 Million for AFG
description: Forstmann Little & Company, a New York firm known mainly for its leveraged buyouts, made an unsolicited all-cash offer today for AFG Industries, a glass manufacturer in Irvine, Calif., that could exceed a $33 a share, or $883 million.

title: Seat-Belt Misuse Cuts Effectiveness, Report Says
description: While the increasing use of lap-shoulder belts in automobiles is saving hundreds of lives, the belts are often misused in ways that reduce their effectiveness, according to a Federal study.

title: The Drug Flames Rise Higher
description: The State Department's annual report on narcotics worldwide is certain to arouse Congress, but for the wrong reasons. Everyone is coming to recognize the report's blunt finding that production, consumption and trafficking now blaze out of control, beyond the ability of any single government to suppress. Drug racketeers like Colombia's Medellin cartel use their billions to corrupt and even take over Western Hemisphere governments.

title: XIOX CORP reports earnings for
New York Schools Chief Proposes 11-Month Year to Ease Crowding
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green, proposed yesterday that the public schools offer classes 11 months a year to relieve overcrowding and improve education.

title: Schoolboy Playoffs Reach Quarterfinals
description: While the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association boys' basketball quarterfinals are moving smoothly into second gear like a fine European sports car, the Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinals are sputtering along like an old jalopy in serious need of a tune-up.

title: Belgium Cuts Key Rates
description: Belgium's central bank announced cuts today in two key interest rates to reflect the strength of the Belgian franc and international trends. The bank said it would lower the discount rate to 6.5 percent from 6.75 percent and the Lombard rate to 6.75 percent from 7 percent, effective Thursday. The discount rate is the interest the central bank charges to member banks. The Lombard rate is interest charged on central bank loans that use securities as collateral.

title: EXECUTIVE
description: * American Medical Buildings Inc., Milwaukee, which develops, designs and manages the construction of medical buildings and clinics, said James R. Germain had resigned as chief financial officer to pursue other interests.

title: 'Sewer Wars'
description: Some might call it ''sewer wars.'' Last year President Reagan vetoed legislation to provide $2.4 billion a year for building sewage treatment facilities, asserting that it was too much money. Congress promptly and overwhelmingly overrode the veto.

title: HERS
description: ''I WANT us to be like a family,'' said the creative director interviewing me for a job in advertising. I began to sweat, and it wasn't just the usual interview anxiety. The word family does not evoke pleasant memories, reassurance or a sense of security in me. He continued, ''I like people to think of this company as home.''

title: Artists, Newly Militant, Fight for Their Rights
description: Painters, sculptors, musicians, film makers, writers, composers and other artists are increasingly speaking out, organizing and lobbying for artists' rights.

title: Correction
description: The Sounds Around Town column in Weekend last Friday misstated the status of the Women of the Calabash.

title: Suddenly It's Chartreuse, Again
description: CALL it lime green, pistachio, Day-Glo yellow, citrus green, acid green, neon green, pea soup or granny apple, but please don't call it chartreuse.

title: For a Friend, Lawmaker Bars Aid to Jamaica
description: A portion of United States aid to Jamaica is being blocked because of a property dispute between the Jamaican Government and a Congressman's friend, the Congressman said today.

title: NUTMEG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: Year-ago fourth quarter and year net were restated for adoption of FAS No. 96, accounting for income taxes; the effect was to increase the fourth- quarter net by $30,000 and the year net by $101,000.

title: Judge Rebukes Church Members Over Child Labor
description: A Federal judge has declared members of a church in contempt of court for employing children as young as 9 years old on construction projects in violation of labor laws.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Eden Prairie, Minn.;
Growth and Conservation
description: LEAD: THIS fast-growing suburb of Minneapolis, which is trying to balance development with conservation, is getting a 490-unit rental apartment project.

title: Brazil Leader's Move to Rule Longer Spurs a Crisis
description: In a last-ditch effort to prolong his term in office, President Jose Sarney has mounted a series of fierce attacks on a Constitutional Assembly that is preparing to call Brazil's first direct Presidential elections in almost three decades.

title: Fund Senate Campaigns? No Lowell P. Weicker; Lowell P. Weicker is Republican Senator from Connecticut.
description: For the eighth time, an all-time record, legislation to federally fund Senate campaigns has come to the floor but not to a final vote. Despite the filibuster, the majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, promises to repeat the exercise. If he does, constitutional principle, not a selfish desire to line politicians' pockets, will be at stake. While such a bill would give the appearance of reform, it would in fact restrict the public's ability to participate in the election process.

title: Advertising; Magazine's New Study Of Affluence
description: TOWN & COUNTRY magazine has always had an affinity for the affluent, and the feeling is obviously mutual.

title: Court Adds Hurdle to Suing Localities for Officials' Acts
description: The Supreme Court, splintering in three directions with no majority opinion, today made it harder for victims of unconstitutional actions by local officials to win damages from local governments.

title: TRANSFORM LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago fourth quarter revenue figure excludes revenue of $1,124,649 from discontinued operations.

title: Sotheby's to Sell Estate Of Clare Boothe Luce
description: The estate of Clare Boothe Luce is to be auctioned by Sotheby's in a series of sales from mid-April through June.

title: Tourism Rises in Britain
description: A record number of foreign tourists, 15.6 million, spent a record amount of money, about $11 billion, in Britain last year, the Government said today.

title: Under 400 Square Feet, Every Inch Must Count
description: MYRNA ROSEN remembers exactly how she felt the moment she and her husband, Hy, first laid eyes on their East Side condominium - all 309 square feet of it.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL BANKING COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Interstate
description: The First Interstate Bancorp yesterday priced $100 million in 8 3/4 percent notes due in 1995 at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Noncallable for five years, the notes at pricing were yielding about 87-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are rated Aa-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

title: More Missiles Fall on Baghdad and Teheran
description: Iraq and Iran battered each other's capitals with long-range missiles for a third day today, and Iraq fired rockets into Qum, seat of the Iranian religious hierarchy.

title: Advertising; Scott Paper to Shift Most U.S. Accounts
description: The Scott Paper Company is dropping the J. Walter Thompson Company as an agency for its United States consumer products business after 60 years and also shifting all but one product from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn in the United States. None of this will cause major hardship because most of the brands do not have an ad budget for 1988.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ed Roman, 57, Basketball Player In City College's Two-Title Season
description: Ed Roman, who led the 1949-50 City College basketball team to victory in two championship tournaments and was later involved in a conspiracy to fix games, died of leukemia Tuesday at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 57 years old.

title: U.S. to Let Bristol-Myers Market AIDS Drug
description: The Federal Government has said it intends to give exclusive marketing rights for an experimental AIDS drug to the Bristol-Myers Company.

title: Caring for Wood Used in the Kitchen
description: LEAD: Caring for wooden kitchen accessories - antique bowls and new or old butcher block and cutting boards - is simple and straightforward. The main caveat: If you want to use the object or surface for food preparation, be sure it has not been treated with any chemicals that could taint what you eat.

title: Davis Jury, in 8th Day, Lacks Verdict
description: The jury in the trial of Larry Davis, who is accused of the execution-style murders of four suspected drug dealers in the South Bronx, concluded its eighth day of deliberations last night without reaching a verdict.

title: Greenspan's Budget Ideas
description: The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told Congress today that it should consider trimming entitlement programs, including Social Security, as it searches for ways to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: I.B.M. in Europe
description: The International Business Machines Corporation expects sales in Europe to grow about 10 percent this year after a disappointing 1986 and flat 1987, Michael Armstrong, chairman of the company's European operations, said.

title: Select Debut Series
description: An appearance by the mezzo-soprano Mimi Lerner will open the Select Debut series at 8 P.M. Monday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Ms. Lerner has performed with opera companies in Europe and the United States, among them the New York City Opera and the Netherlands Opera. Warren Jones will accompany her on piano in works by Ravel, Poulenc, Barber, Ives, Hoiby and Bolcom. Tickets are $10. The debut series will run through March 28. Information: 840-2824.

title: BUEHLER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $63,000 and $1,365,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Bratislava Journal; Much Ado About Brown Coal on the Blue Danube
description: They call it Corn Island, a verdant oval embraced by the Danube and an appendix, the Little Danube, that part, meander quietly, then rejoin some 45 miles downstream on the Hungarian border.

title: Metro Matters; What's Behind The Resistance In Brawley Case?
description: ''You know what Tawana Brawley wants now?'' C. Vernon Mason, her attorney, said. ''To be a lawyer. You know what she wants to do with her law degree? Become a prosecutor.''

title: Polish Party Asserts It Sought to Prevent Purge of Jews in '68
description: The Polish Communist Party formally acknowledged today that an anti-Semitic campaign drove thousands of Jews from the country in 1968, but the party did not accept full responsibility for it.

title: ARBOR DRUGS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
4 Among 20: Key States Poised for Super Tuesday; Texas: Democrats Close, But Not Republicans
description: On Tuesday primaries and caucuses will be held in 20 states and American Samoa, more jurisdictions than have ever picked Presidential nominating convention delegates in a single day. Most will be elected in the Southern and border states whose politicians organized the event and called it Super Tuesday.

title: 10 ASPIRIN MAKERS TO HALT AD CLAIM
description: Ten major U.S. aspirin manufacturers have agreed to drop advertising claims that taking aspirin regularly reduces the risk of a first heart attack in the general population.

title: New York Cops Make Solid Citizens
description: Governor Cuomo rightly believes New York City would be better protected if police officers and firefighters lived where they serve. He therefore presses for a sensible law requiring that newly hired police and fire personnel reside in the city.

title: Errors Continue to Plague U S Sprint's Billing System
description: Despite the efforts of Robert H. Snedaker, U S Sprint's new president, the nation's third-largest long-distance telephone company is still plagued with problems in billing its customers.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Campeau Bid Revives Retail Fight
description: The battle for Federated Department Stores Inc. heated up again late yesterday when the Campeau Corporation, seemingly thwarted by R. H. Macy & Company, again revised its bid for the giant retailer.

title: 52 Charged in Poaching Case
description: An investigation has led to the arrest of 52 people suspected of operating a $100 million poaching ring that dealt in tiger, bear, sea lion and rhinoceros parts, state officials announced Tuesday. Twenty-three other people in Southern California are expected to be charged as a result of a 23-month investigation by the California Department of Fish and Game. Chuck Monroe, a regional game warden chief, said 74 misdemeanor complaints were filed against the 52 defendants.

title: Goetz Gets $140,550 From Father's Estate
description: Bernhard H. Goetz has inherited $140,550 from his father's estate, but he faces huge legal bills, one of his lawyers has said.

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL TO UPSET A LIMIT ON U.S. RIGHTS LAW
description: Despite the threat of a veto from President Reagan, the House of Representatives tonight approved a bill overturning the effects of a 1984 Supreme Court decision that limited the application of civil rights laws.

title: Moslem Leader Wins $369,000 Religion Prize
description: The Templeton Prize, a $369,000 award to encourage progress in religion, was awarded yesterday to Dr. Inamullah Khan, a proponent of Islamic unity who has helped bring together world religious leaders.

title: Advertising; Poppe Tyson Names New Chief Executive
description: Poppe Tyson, a subsidiary of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt with offices in New York and Union, N.J., has promoted Fergus O'Daly, 44-year-old president and creative director, to chief executive. The title was formerly held by Ron Vrba, 54, who is chairman.

title: Passport Seizure Ordered by U.S. For Illicit Drugs
description: The head of the Customs Service said today that agents would begin seizing the passports of Americans who tried to re-enter the country with any illicit drugs.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: New York City Schools Lose Fast Way to Hire Teachers
description: The company that tests as many as 1,000 applicants a year for teaching jobs in New York City's public schools said yesterday that the Board of Education could no longer use its tests because of a state law that does not meet the company's guidelines on determining who passes.

title: College Basketball; Another Upset for Seton Hall
description: Mark Bryant had 23 points and 13 rebounds, and Ramon Ramos converted a 3-point play in the last minute Wednesday night as Seton Hall beat Pitt, 83-79. The victory was Seton Hall's second over the Panthers this season.

title: Volcker, the Deal-Making Professor
description: Paul A. Volcker, the former Federal Reserve chairman, yesterday solved the riddle of where he would go next by announcing that he would split his time between Wall Street and academia.

title: Denver Mayor Orders Work Crews Studied
description: Mayor Federico Pena has ordered an investigation into reports that street crews spend more time eating and reading than working.

title: TV Review; 'Voices and Visions,' On Poets
description: REACHING the sixth of its 13 essays on modern American poets, ''Voices and Visions'' this week deals with a man who, in many respects, is the most intriguing of the lot. ''William Carlos Williams,'' produced and written by Jill Janows, can be seen at 10 this evening on Channel 13.

title: Yields Are Down a Bit
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds showed small declines for the week ended yesterday.

title: Navistar Outlook
description: The Navistar International Corporation, the truck manufacturer that returned to profitability in 1987 after a string of losses, said it hopes for a small increase in profits this year despite the rising cost of steel and labor. Neil Springer, chairman of the Navistar International Transportation Corporation, the Chicago-based company's chief operating unit, said plans were under way to expand its trucking and parts businesses with acquisitions in related industries. But Mr. Springer conceded to financial analysts in Los Angeles that Navistar, the former International Harvester Corporation, faces numerous difficulties, including litigation and high borrowing costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1988
description: Companies

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $384,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn., said it had completed its acquisition of E-II Holdings Inc.

title: Icahn Said To Discuss Texaco Bid
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor and chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., has been conducting talks with Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British conglomerate, about making a friendly offer to acquire Texaco Inc., Wall Street professionals said last night.

title: Candidates Can Land on TV Just by Landing
description: In the frenzied campaign for the multiple primaries and caucuses next Tuesday, Presidential aspirants are engaged in the frequent-flyer version of whistle stop campaigning. They jet from airport to airport in the hope that their mere presence will get them on the local evening news programs. It almost always works. On a single day this week, Tuesday, news coverage by television stations in four Super Tuesday states reflected the candidates' itineraries. Even a 30-minute stop at the airport in Fort Myers, Fla., was enough to get Pat Robertson a minute on two local stations hungering for live candidates. The Local Priorities

title:
Market Place;
Ideas for Picking Stocks in Europe
description: LEAD: IT has perhaps never been easier for Americans to invest in foreign stocks, either directly or through various ''country funds.'' But that does not mean they should.

title: Shell Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named
description: John F. Bookout will retire as president and chief executive of the Shell Oil Company on June 30, to be replaced by Frank H. Richardson, executive vice president, products, the company announced yesterday.

title: RARE WHALE TYPE DECLINES IN SURVEY
description: A record low number of right whales, the rarest of the large whale species, were sighted last month in an annual survey conducted by the New England Aquarium in the whales' usual wintering grounds off the Georgia and Florida coast.

title: Talking Deals; Media General: An Oddball Script
description: BURT SUGARMAN is the Hollywood producer who has brought forth such entertainment oddites as ''The Gong Show'' and ''The Dating Game.'' Now, he is the protagonist in a simmering corporate takeover battle that is about as far-fetched as anything the entertainment world can dream up.

title: MCA 'Poison Pill'
description: In an apparent effort to block a takeover threat posed by the developer Donald J. Trump, MCA Inc. tightened the trigger on its takeover defense, making it effective if any shareholder acquires 10 percent of its stock. The original plan, which was adopted last July, would have taken effect when a 20 percent stake was acquired. The poison pill is intended to make an acquisition prohibitively expensive.

title: Voting Act Is Upheld For Judicial Elections
description: A Federal appeals court, ruling that the Voting Rights Act of 1965 applies to election of judges as well as of legislators and executives, has revived a lawsuit aimed at creating a black-majority district for the election of Louisiana Supreme Court justices.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Upheaval at Mortgage Insurers
description: The private mortgage insurance business, which for decades has been a virtual money machine, is now running up losses at an alarming rate.

title: PETROLEUM HEAT & POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1987 profits were hurt in part by the timing of the acquisition of Whale Oil Co., which resulted in Petroleum Heat & Power absorbing normal non-heating period losses without the benefit of the first quarter heating periof profits. The company also attributed improved revenue to its continued acquisition of retail heating oil distributorships.

title: AMERICAN WOODMARK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Jean Le Poulain, Actor, Dies at 63; Director of the Comedie Francaise
description: Jean Le Poulain, one of France's most respected actors and the administrative director of the world-famous Comedie-Francaise, died of a heart attack at his home Tuesday night. He was 63 years old.

title: Homes Sales Plunged 9% in January
description: Sales of new single-family houses fell by 9 percent in January, to their lowest level in more than five years, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: ALTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: b-Includes a gain of $274,000 from the disposition of the company's Puerto Rican facility for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: This Is the Year to Kill the Wicks Law
description: Over the next decade, New York City plans to spend $16 billion on major capital construction projects. Count at least $1.6 billion as needless waste. The reason? The state Wicks Law, which bars use of a general contractor on public construction jobs. Common sense cries out for repeal of this weight around the taxpayer's neck. Legislators who resist repeal invite being held regularly and repeatedly accountable for the waste.

title: Dallas Bank's Deposits Fall
description: First Republicbank Dallas lost more than 8 percent of its deposits as customers withdrew $599 million in one week last month amid speculation about the financial health of its parent company, regulators said.

title: Frank E. Brown Dies; Archeologist Was 79
description: Frank E. Brown, an archeologist and former director of the American Academy in Rome, died of a stroke Sunday at the Lely Palms Health Care Center in Naples, Fla., where he had lived for the last year. He was 79 years old.

title: Sandinistas Call for Ouster Of Mediator in Peace Talks
description: The Sandinista Government said tonight that it was ready to hold high-level talks inside Nicaragua next week with leaders of United States-backed contra guerrillas.

title: Reflections on Golfers' Riches
description: No golfer on the PGA Tour has a more aggressive and exciting style of play than Lanny Wadkins does when he is within reach of a victory. The 38-year-old Texan wishes more of the young players would try harder to win - the way he has always played the game.

title: TRANS-NATIONAL LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chrysler Outlines Europe Sales Plan
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the No. 3 car maker in the United States, said it hoped to become the leading seller of American cars in Europe. ''We aim to sell 5,000 to 10,000 cars in Europe this year and 10,000 to 20,000 Jeeps,'' Michael Hammes, vice president of international operations, said at a news conference on the eve of the 58th Geneva International Motor Show.

title: Calendar: Antiques, Appraisals, Design
description: Antiques Show

title: West Point-Pepperell Head Carries the Family Torch
description: As the sixth member of his family to run West Point-Pepperell Inc., Joseph L. Lanier Jr.'s roots go deep in the textile town of West Point, Ga., and in Lanett, Ala., just across the state line.

title: ACCEPTANCE INSUARANCE HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $150,636 and $59,627 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes realized investment gains of $3,126 for the quarter and $39,601 for the year, and tax credits of $9,000 and $729,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: CSC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $640,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $2,568,000 for the year.

title: Strike in Panama Halts Most Activity in Capital
description: Normal activity was paralyzed here today in the third day of a general strike called by opponents of this country's de facto ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported.

title: Summer Programs for a Disabled Child
description: One morning last summer, a teen-ager from New York climbed onto a sailboard at Camp Wapanacki, a camp for the blind in Hardwick, Vt. Although he had never tried it before, he was sailing by afternoon.

title: Legislator Seeks to Oust Leader of Black Caucus
description: A State Senator from Brooklyn has begun a campaign to oust Assemblyman Roger L. Green as chairman of the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus, charging that the caucus has not been effective in advancing the interests of minority groups.

title: Pagliarulo Insists On Pride and Heart
description: By the end of last season, as September was turning to October and the Yankees had settled hopelessly into fourth place, Mike Pagliarulo kept playing every day in pain. He could not fully straighten his right arm nor could he make throws from third base without discomfort.

title: Hunt for Officer's Killers Is Focused on 4 Suspects
description: Detectives hunting the killers of a rookie police officer in Queens are focusing on four suspects believed to have been in the ''execution team's'' car, officials close to the investigation said last night.

title: Action Planned On Farm Debt
description: The Government's chief farm lending agency said today that it would begin restructuring up to $6.6 billion of delinquent farm debt in July.

title: TV Writers Vote for Strike
description: Movie and television scriptwriters voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike, a spokeswoman said today.

title: Metro Atlantic Tournament; Very Bizarre Finish Wins for St. Peter's
description: Willie Haynes hit two technical foul shots that were awarded when opposing players and their coach ran onto the court with two seconds left to give St. Peter's the 63-60 victory over Fairfield tonight.

title: Jazz; Randy Weston at Davis Hall
description: THE great jazz pianist Randy Weston opened his concert at Davis Hall Saturday night with a majestic, improvised solo. Chords peeped out from under rumbling ostinatos. Thelonious Monk-ish whole-tone flurries and brilliantly colored Ellingtonian note clusters added decoration. Walking bass lines anchored cascading washes of notes, and Mr. Weston's tone, warm and big, kept the music sympathetic.

title: F.A.A. Chief Rules on Exit Closings on Jetliners
description: An effort to close off two of the 10 doors on Boeing 747 jumbo jets operated in the United States was apparently scuttled today by the head of the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: More Regulation of Medical Testing Is Sought
description: Inadequate Federal and state regulation of medical laboratories is allowing an unacceptable level of inaccurate testing, the chairman of a House panel said today.

title: Sports People; Golden Opportunity
description: Yvonne van Gennip, the 23-year-old Dutch speed skater who set two world records and won three gold medals in the Olympics, recevied a hero's welcome when she returned to her Haarlem home from Calgary yesterday. A crowd estimated at 60,000, about half the city's population, jammed Market Square as van Gennip rode in an open car to City Hall in a celebration. . . . A coach from the Rumanian Olympic team met with immigration officers at an undisclosed location yesterday after appealing for asylum in Canada. ''He's in a secluded place, a safe place with security,'' said Gerry Maffre, an immigration spokesman in Ottawa. The coach has not been identified publicly, but Olympic sources and Canadian news media named him as Dumitru Focseneanu, the bobsled coach.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it took special pretax charges of about $600,000 in the latest fourth quarter.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect the 5-for-4 stock split distributed Oct. 30.

title: In Swedish Silver, Simplicity Is a Virtue
description: From tankards to beakers and flower-topped tureens, from pear-shaped coffeepots to streamlined modern boxes, Swedish silver has had a history ofsimplicity.

title: BRITISH PLAN LAWS TO END ULSTER BIAS
description: The British Government today outlined its plans for legislation to combat job discrimination against Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland.

title: GAINSCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $1,000 for the quarter and $30,000 for the year. c-After gains of $50,000 and $174,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: 4 Among 20: Key States Poised for Super Tuesday; Missouri: Gephardt Receives A Hero's Welcome
description: On Tuesday primaries and caucuses will be held in 20 states and American Samoa, more jurisdictions than have ever picked Presidential nominating convention delegates in a single day. Most will be elected in the Southern and border states whose politicians organized the event and called it Super Tuesday.

title: Chambers Witnesses Attack Prosecution's Account of Slaying
description: Lawyers for Robert E. Chambers Jr. began their defense yesterday by attacking two of the prosecution's main arguments: That Mr. Chambers punched Jennifer Levin in the face, injuring his right hand, and that he then strangled her with her blouse.

title: Abrams Ends Contract Approval for Indicted Company
description: The New York State Attorney General's office said yesterday that it had withdrawn approval for a $57.6 million highway construction contract in Queens after it learned that a state agency had negotiated confidential provisions with a company under indictment for bid-rigging.

title: Sears Group To Undergo Revamping
description: Responding to fierce competition from specialty stores and discounters, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, today announced plans for a major restructuring of its merchandise group.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Jerome Katz, 75, Dies; International Lawyer
description: Jerome Katz, a lawyer who specialized in international cases, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Israeli TV's Editing Brings Harsh Questions
description: The Israeli television's handling of CBS News footage showing Israeli soldiers beating Palestinians has raised new questions about Israeli coverage of the violence in the occupied territories.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Chicago; Costly Homes For Bucktown
description: A CHICAGO builder has turned to an unlikely neighborhood on the Near North Side of the city for a development of higher-priced single-family homes.

title: Yeutter Warns Korea on Trade
description: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that if South Korea and other Asian nations did not end what he called unfair trading practices, they would face retaliation and curbs on their exports.

title: Bridge: At Age of 95, Jay Feigus Still Brings Home Titles
description: There is one notable bridge personality who ought to be in the Guinness Book of World Records in one category, and has a good claim in another.

title: Apple Buying Software Unit
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the Network Innovations Corporation, its first acquisition of another computer technology company.

title: Violence and Strike Threaten Bangladesh Vote
description: Paramilitary and police forces patrolled the capital today to quell scattered violence, including bombings, as a general strike intended to disrupt elections Thursday began.

title: UNITED DOMINION REALTY TRUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $41,000 and $56,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $188,000.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said the year-ago first quarter revenue included the sale of a T series supercomputer.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Upholds Move To Retry Gene Gotti
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a brother of John Gotti, the reputed crime boss, and two co-defendants can be tried a second time on drug and racketeering charges.

title: ACC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $654,480 related to the elimination of costs associated with double payment of certain state gross revenue taxes.

title: 4 Among 20: Key States Poised for Super Tuesday; Florida: Bush and Dukakis Seen as Holding Lead
description: On Tuesday primaries and caucuses will be held in 20 states and American Samoa, more jurisdictions than have ever picked Presidential nominating convention delegates in a single day. Most will be elected in the Southern and border states whose politicians organized the event and called it Super Tuesday.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $190,500 for the latest quarter and $123,500 for the year-earlier period.

title: Grammy Awards Honor U2
description: ''Honest music,'' said Bono Vox of U2, won two top Grammy awards for the Irish rock band and its album, ''The Joshua Tree.'' At the 30th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, telecast live last night from Radio City Music Hall after six years of broadcasts from Los Angeles, U2 won album of the year and best rock performance by a duo or group. On stage, Mr. Vox mentioned his political concerns over South Africa; backstage, he insisted, ''We're slipstream, not mainstream.''

title: Rangers Take Fourth Straight
description: Some 24 days ago, the Rangers returned home, clinging to the knowledge that for the next three weeks and 11 games they would have to venture no farther than New Jersey. The extended stay was perhaps their last chance at moving anywhere in the standing.

title: Concert: New Music
description: THERE was little joy to be had in Merkin Concert Hall Monday evening at Speculum Musicae's third concert of the season. This ensemble is an indispensable figure on the new-music scene in New York, but its programs are not always chosen with sufficient discrimination, and the latest installment had more than its share of dreariness. The fitful jazziness of Stefan Wolpe's 38-year-old Quartet for Trumpet, Tenor Saxophone, Percussion and Piano made some effect, and might have made more in a defter, softer performance than the Speculum players gave it; Anthony Davis and Joseph Passaro were visually impressive and rhythmically vital in Mr. Davis's droning ''Behind the Rock'' for percussion and piano, but little else gave satisfaction.

title: Mansfield Returns
description: Mike Mansfield, currently the longest serving United States ambassador, returned to his post in Tokyo Tuesday after undergoing heart bypass surgery in Washington two months ago.

title: COMMUNITY SHARES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $2.8 million and $8.4 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, in reserves for probable losses on loans and real estate, and the quarter also includes $3.4 million in charges related to the closing of a mortgage banking subsidiary.

title: PENALTY DEBATED IN SWAGGART CASE
description: Leaders of the Assemblies of God in Louisiana have rejected a request by national officials of the church to toughen the sanctions they recommended against the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, according to a church official.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its fourth quarter results were down as a result of continued reductions in grade at its principal mining properties, coupled with an acceleration of exploration outlays during the latter portion of the year.

title: Sports People; License Revoked
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board has revoked the license of Steve Adika, a jockeys' agent, for illegally intercepting the simulcast signal that is beamed to offtrack betting parlors. The board said that Adika intercepted the signal in 1986 and that he has since tried again by offering a bribe to a technician employed in the simulcasting operation. Adika denied any wrongdoing and said he would appeal.

title: Ivo Duchacek, 75, Broadcaster
description: Ivo D. Duchacek, a member of Czechoslovakia's Parliament who fled in 1948 when the Communists took power and later became a professor of political science at City College, died of cancer of the pharynx Tuesday at his home in Kent, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: Plan to Bar CD Piracy Is Called Inadequate
description: A system designed by CBS Records to prevent the recording of compact disks onto digital tape is inadequate, a Government agency has reported after a five-month test.

title: AGS to Acquire C3
description: AGS Computers Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire C3 Inc., a computer systems integration company based in Herndon, Va., for $15.75 a share, or about $157.5 million. C3 designs, assembles and maintains computer systems to solve the automation needs of the Federal Government. AGS, based in Mountainside, N.J., is involved in computer automation of telecommunication and computer systems.

title: Jazz: Harry Connick Jr.
description: HARRY CONNICK JR., a 20-year-old pianist and singer from New Orleans, is one of those blazing young musical talents that one hopes do not become stunted by too great an early success and too much lionization.

title: Advertising; International Magazine Aims at Broadcasters
description: Act III Publishing, which has a number of business magazines in the media field, has entered into a joint venture with Telso Communications of Britain, and together they have produced Television Business International, a very selective magazine for top executives in broadcasting and production.

title: Pilots Practice for Persian Gulf Strikes
description: To train for an air strike near the Persian Gulf, the two F-15 Eagle fighters streaked toward the target low to the ground, slipped over a ridge and up a valley, then climbed through clouds into the sun to protect the attack force behind them against hostile planes.

title: Focus on War Crimes Architects, Not Waldheim; Austria and Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Just the President
description: President Reagan's relationship to reality has always been tenuous. Everyone knows his habit of inventing facts and uttering fantasies as if they had really happened. He believes what he wants to believe.

title: Sign of Collapse Leads to Closing Of Queens Road
description: A section of the Van Wyck Expressway, in Flushing, Queens, was closed yesterday morning by the authorities because they feared severe structural damage might cause the roadway to collapse.

title: ELXSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring gains of $2.3 million and $5.5 million for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss The company said the latest fourth quarter share earnings are less than one cent a share.

title: U.S.-Japan Talk On Auto Parts
description: Manufacturers of American auto parts are meeting with executives of 11 Japanese car companies in an effort to whittle away at a large trade deficit between the two countries in the auto parts industry.

title: Dow Gains Just 0.83 After Blue-Chip Selloff
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved broadly yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average managed to eke out only a fractional gain.

title: Health; Trip Across Adolescence Is Just as Risky as Ever
description: Despite revolutionary progress in preventing and treating life-threatening infections through immunization and antibiotics, teen-agers today are as likely to get sick and die before reaching their 20's as they were in the 1940's and 1950's. Only the causes of death and disability have changed dramatically, shifting from traditional medical problems to health effects stemming more from social causes.

title: NATO SHIFTS STAND ON ARMS IN EUROPE
description: A summit gathering of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization approved a new approach today to conventional arms negotiations, calling on the Warsaw Pact to make huge reductions in its tanks and artillery.

title: Strawberry Is Fined Again
description: Gary Carter was named co-captain of the Mets today so he could help Keith Hernandez maintain discipline among their teammates. And he didn't have to wait long for his first challenge: Darryl Strawberry was late for work and was fined by Manager Dave Johnson, who has fined and even benched Strawberry for the same offense in the past.

title: Unlikely Pair Behind Dog-Track Star
description: On Friday night in the 14th race at Hollywood Greyhound Track, the Priest and the Prosecutor will be pulling for the Pope. Therein lies a tale that could happen only in Miami, by way of Ireland.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Meadville, Pa.; Conversions Bring Hope
description: THE rehabilitation of a huge manufacturing plant outside this city of 15,500 in northwest Pennsylvania is the centerpiece of an effort to attract businesses to the area, which has been hit hard by plant closings and layoffs.

title: A Movie Spoofs Moving
description: FOR the screenwriter Andy Breckman, moving day became a real-life nightmare and the inspiration for a film. The result - ''Moving'' - opens tomorrow, starring Richard Pryor.

title: How to Approach Third World Debt
description: LEAD: Privatization of foreign policy - from Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North to John K. Singlaub, a retired Army general - has been a hallmark of the Reagan Administration. In keeping with this tradition, we now have a privatized approach to the third world debt crisis: Let the banks handle the mess.

title: New Measures Taken to Aid Mental Wards
description: Amid warnings that the mental health system in New York City is moving toward collapse, state officials announced emergency steps yesterday to relieve overcrowding in municipal psychiatric wards.

title: 8 Art Galleries Facing Fines For Failure to Post Price List
description: In the first day of a two-day sweep of art galleries, the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs issued citations to at least eight galleries yesterday for failure to conspicuously display a price list of the works of art for sale, department officials said.

title: ATARI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $13,277,000. c-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $11,047,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $19,466,000 for the year. The company said the latest period results include operations of Federated Group Inc., acquired Oct. 4; net sales of Federated for the latest quarter and year were $130,564,000. Pretax loss from Federated included in Atari's results was $8,268,000.

title: Robertson Is Victor in Alaska
description: Pat Robertson won nearly half the delegates in Alaska's Republican precinct caucuses, with Vice President Bush a distant second, state party officials announced today.

title: VHC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes for the quarter a provision of about $530,000 for estimated costs of the environmental clean-up resulting from the sale of Maul Technology's Melville, N.J., plant last year; the year includes a tax benefit of $850,000. c-Includes tax benefits of $378,000 and $715,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The 1986 results include operating results of Maul Technology from the acquisition date of Feb. 21, 1986.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $161,000. c-Includes tax credits of $897,925 and $1,306,860 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: WINSTON FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After non-recurring after-tax charges of $3,000 and $624,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, related to the prepayment of loans. Year-ago figures include the results of the Winston Furniture predecessor division, acquired in March 1986, and the Lyon-Shaw wrought iron division acquired as of November 1986, as if both transactions had taken place at the beginning of the year.

title: Renewable Notes From CIT Group
description: CIT Group Holdings Inc., a unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, is offering $500 million worth of floating-rate renewable notes with a final maturity in 1998 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said costs associated with restructuring of the company contributed to the losses.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,100,000 and $2,300,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Earnings for full-year 1986 include a net gain of $5,164,000, or $1.82 a share, from the termintion of the company's defined benefit pension plan and the cost of a related special contribution to the company's ESOP.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: John Kruk, the first baseman for the San Diego Padres, has reached an agreement in principle on a two-year contract. Kruk, 27 years old, batted .313 in 138 games last season and hit 20 home runs with 91 runs batted in. . . . Bruce Sutter threw batting practice for five minutes during the Atlanta Braves' workout yesterday, and Manager Chuck Tanner said the right-hander's work was encouraging. Sutter has not pitched in nearly two full seasons after three arm operations. . . . Andrew Toney, a Philadelphia 76ers guard, who has been plagued by chronic foot problems for the past three seasons, was placed on the injured list yesterday.

title: ACTION AUTO RENTAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thomas Vezzetti, 59, Hoboken Mayor, Dies
description: Mayor Thomas Vezzetti, who fought against the ''gentrification'' of this Hudson River city, died early today of a heart attack. He was 59 years old.

title: GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Jan 3
description: b-After a gain of $46,957,000 related to financial restructuring. c-After a gain of $6,776,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. The company did not provide separate results for the latest fourth quarter ended Jan. 3; however, the company said it took a charge of about $10 million in the quarter, of which $8.5 million was related to realignment of operations, primarily in Europe.

title: Alcoholic Absentee Wins as Court Rules He Had a Handicap
description: Clarence Ferguson, who drank a pint of gin a day and was dismissed from his job after missing a total of 14 months of work in three years, has won a suit based on a law that requires counseling for handicapped Federal workers.

title: CBS News Says Team Broke Rule
description: The CBS News journalists who recorded dramatic scenes of Israeli soldiers beating two Arab captives in the occupied West Bank last week violated company rules by giving unedited videotape footage to the Israeli Army, network officials said yesterday. But they said the journalists had made ''an innocent mistake'' and would not be reprimanded.

title: Cabaret: Jimmy Rogers
description: OF all the blues musicians to come out of the active Chicago scene of the late 40's and early 50's, the guitarist and singer Jimmy Rogers is the most soft-spoken. Though he works with typical electric blues groups, his records show him using a shiny jump and rhythm-and-blues feel. And when he sings, instead of using a bleak Mississippi cry to break through the din of the instruments, he sings with a warm, rounded voice that implies friendliness.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: American medicine is increasingly worried about the health of the nation's 30 million teen-agers, the only age group that has not experienced any improvement in health status in the last three decades.

title: U.N. Resumes Aid to Refugees in Lebanon
description: A United Nations relief agency resumed the delivery of food and medical supplies to Palestinian refugees in Lebanon today, a day after two of its workers were freed by kidnappers.

title: Sports People; Knicks Sign Scurry
description: Carey Scurry, a 6-foot-7-inch forward, signed a 10-day contract with the Knicks yesterday. Scurry, a 1985 second-round draft choice by the Utah Jazz, played at Alexander Hamilton High School in Brooklyn and at Long Island University. The Knicks placed Rick Carlisle on the injured list.

title: U.S. ASKING BANKS NOT TO SEND FUNDS TO NORIEGA REGIME
description: The State Department has prepared a document advising a group of New York banks not to disburse any Panamanian Government funds to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega because he is not the lawful head of the country, department officials said today.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a cumulative effect of an accounting change of $2,800,000. c-Reflects a special charge for restructuring certain operations which adversely affected the fourth quarter operating income by $4,800,000, or $2,600,000 after tax. d-Net loss and includes a special charge made in the first quarter of $5,500,000 for a doubtful account. The effect after taxes amounted to $2,700,000, or 20 cents a share.

title: U.S. Factory Orders Dipped 0.6% in January
description: The Commerce Department said today that orders to the nation's factories for manufactured goods fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, the first decline in five months, but private economists said the setback was not serious.

title: ALTAI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Health; Debate Grows on Standards for Certifying Fitness Instructors
description: Injuries, from shin splints to heart attacks, are prompting new demands from within and outside the fitness industry for the establishment of minimum standards for fitness and aerobics instructors. But there is little agreement about what those standards should be, and who should establish and enforce them.

title: Palestinian Fights Palestinian After Rumor of Collaboration
description: Between impassioned telephone calls to plead a case that might bring a beating or death, the Palestinian lit one cigarette after another in his office here today and said that, yes, he was very nervous.

title: Robertson Says He'd Be Satisfied With 2d Place in South Carolina
description: Pat Robertson, who had thrown down the gauntlet to Vice President Bush and vowed, ''I will beat you in South Carolina,'' plucked it back up from the Carolina clay today and suggested he would be satisfied with second place.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes extraordinary losses of $10,000 and $1,100,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Trial Set in Killing of 16
description: A man accused of killing 16 people, including 14 members of his own family, is competent to stand trial, a judge has ruled in setting a May 9 trial date. The man, R. Gene Simmons, 47 years old, surrendered to the police Dec. 28 after a shooting spree left two former co-workers dead and led to the discovery of the bodies of his wife; four daughters; three sons; two spouses of his children; three grandchilden and a child who officials say he fathered by his oldest daughter. 30

title: CAMBRIDGE MEDICAL TECHOLOGY reports earnings for
Army Told to Stop Drug Tests on Employees
description: A Federal district judge ordered the Army on Tuesday to stop random tests of 9,400 civilian employees for drug use on the ground that the tests were an unreasonable search prohibited by the Constitution.

title: FRONTIER INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment loses of $114,000 and $56,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes investment gains of $116,000 for the quarter and $133,000 for the year.

title: Mecham Aide Testifies at Impeachment Trial
description: Gov. Evan Mecham's former security chief, testifying in the Governor's impeachment trial, said today that he considered a reported death threat against a grand jury witness to be a potential felony and that he personally told Mr. Mecham so.

title: GENTEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Panamanian Government accounts should not be disbursed by New York banks to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, because he is not the lawful head of the country, the State Department said. The action in effect would freeze about $50 million in assets. Page A1

title: Tax Cuts in Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary, Piers Jacobs, cut taxes on corporate profits and personal income in the 1988-89 budget released today. Corporate taxes fell to 17 percent from 18 percent in the British colony, and the personal income tax base rate was reduced by one percentage point, to 15.5 percent. Mr. Jacobs announced slight increases in indirect taxes on cigarettes, liquor and cosmetics.

title: Second Generation Highchairs
description: WHEN Sjaak van der Vooren, a Dutch designer, learned that his wife was pregnant, he started working on a highchair with his partner, Rene van de Beek.

title: AMERICAN CONSUMER PRODCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Many-Tentacled Agency Lights Up 75 Candles
description: It is called the Government's biggest conglomerate because it charts the seas, predicts the weather, counts the population, commercializes space, analyzes economic trends, promotes minority business, grants patents, sets standards of measurement, runs the world's biggest depository for technical information and acts as the nation's traffic cop for imports and exports.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ADOLESCENCE is marked by battles over power and control. It is a time of physiological stress as your child copes with what seems like a conquering army of hormones. It's also a time of emotional stress as he tries to adjust to the new demands made by family and school. That combination can test the mettle of even the most resilient parents.

title: Dance: Merce Cunningham's 'RainForest'
description: ''RAINFOREST,'' with choreography by Merce Cunningham, electronic score by David Tudor and silver pillows by Andy Warhol, is a wonderful artifact of the 1960's, one that tells us how much fun we are missing in the 1980's.

title: Tapestries Warm Up Modern Buildings
description: HAND-WOVEN tapestries, the decorative wall hangings traditionally associated with medieval and Renaissance castles, are now showing up on the walls of corporate headquarters, banks and hotels.

title: Utility Stock Sale
description: The Western Massachusetts Electric Company, a subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, is offering $53.5 million in preferred stock through Salomon Brothers Inc. The financing is part of a program to help lower the utility's borrowing costs. The initial annual dividend rate on the preferred stock is 6.375 percent and is effective for 62 days. The rate then will be reset every 49 days based on an auction.

title: Sports of The Times; The Captain to the Rescue
description: WILLIS REED made a joke, one of several Tuesday night.

title: Soviet Reports Deaths in Rioting; Unofficial Toll in Azerbaijan Is 17
description: A Soviet spokesman said today that an unspecified number of people were killed in nationalist rioting Sunday in the southern Soviet city of Sumgait.

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Undirty Dozen
description: It is the most unassailable, respectable, bipartisan, perfectly balanced and universally welcomed idea to come to fruition in years.

title:
FOCUS: Resorts;
A White Mountains Comeback
description: LEAD: AT the turn of the century, this northwest New Hampshire village had 30 hotels, three railroad stations and four golf courses. Its pollen-free air, clean water and panoramic views of Mount Washington and the nearby Green Mountains of Vermont attracted thousands of tourists.

title: Minority Students End Protest at Hampshire
description: A group of minority students ended a nine-day occupation of a dormitory office at Hampshire College today after administrators signed a 16-point agreement aimed at encouraging racial harmony.

title: WETTERAU PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represents rental income. For the period from May 11, 1987, the date the company commenced operations, through Dec. 31, 1987, Wetterau Properties had net of $408,000, or 33 cents a share, on rental income of $1,156,000.

title: Stage: Zaks Directs Shue's 'Wenceslas Square'
description: IN his tender production of Larry Shue's sketchy play ''Wenceslas Square'' at the Public Theater, Jerry Zaks offers more evidence of why he is the outstanding director of comedy in the American theater today. Should that judgment sound recklessly sweeping, let me add that with Mr. Zaks one can use the word ''comedy'' in the broadest sense. He is equally adept at caustic absurdist comedy (''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You''), at heartbreaking absurdist comedy (''The House of Blue Leaves''), at period farce (''The Front Page'') and at musical comedy (''Anything Goes''). His staging of Mr. Shue's popular exercise in Mad-magazine-style silliness, ''The Foreigner,'' was also a model of its kind, even if one felt (as I did) that the script was far from a consistent laugh riot.

title: Stage: Sendup of Musicals
description: ''THE LAST MUSICAL COMEDY,'' Tony Lang and Arthur Siegel's lighter-than-air sendup of 1950's musicals about New York City, is set ''roughly 30 years before 'Cats,' '' according to a program note, and is dedicated to George Abbott, the writer and director who helped steer ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Damn Yankees'' to Broadway glory in those innocent palmy days.

title: Tisch May Buy Patriots
description: Preston Robert Tisch, who has just retired as Postmaster General, may wind up with an organization that usually works only on Sundays - the New England Patriots.

title: Jets Seeking Direction After Changes
description: Twenty years after their Super Bowl season, the Jets appear to be light years from winning another title.

title: Rock: Bosho, a Band
description: KUMIKO KIMOTO'S percussion setup - gongs, cymbal, cowbell, tambourine, Roto-tom tunable drum, electronic sound generator and a hubcap - just about summed up the music of Bosho, the six-piece band that performed Monday at Dance Theater Workshop. Bosho sets in motion Western and Eastern, new-fangled and down-home sounds, layering them into crafty, off-center funk.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The door chime in our house is in the entrance foyer, and I can't hear it when I am working in the basement. Can I install a second chime that will sound at the same time the upstairs one does? A. Yes. Run a three-conductor cable (or three wires) from the existing chime to the new one so that one wire connects each terminal on the old chime with the matching terminal on the new chime. In other words, connect the ones marked R, F and T or Trans to the same ones on the new unit. You may also need a larger transformer, as the old one may not be powerful enough to operate two sets of chimes. Q. The house we recently purchased has hardwood floors under the carpet. The floors are not very large and I am fairly handy, so I was thinking about sanding and refinishing the floors myself. Is this a project that can be done yourself, or should a professional be called in? A. If you do the job yourself you will have to rent a drum-type floor sander, plus a smaller disk sander for the edges. Handling these machines properly does take a bit of practice to avoid gouging the floors, but many amateurs do the job.

title: Legislator Reprimanded For Remark
description: The State House of Representatives put to rest today an issue that had nagged at the General Assembly for the last month, accepting a delicately worded report that mildly reprimands one of its members for referring to homosexuals as ''lollipops.''

title: Policewoman Seized By U.S. Drug Agents In a Big Heroin Raid
description: A New York City police officer was among 32 people arrested yesterday in Brooklyn as Federal agents broke up a heroin ring that had sales of up to $2 million a month, authorities said.

title: Senate in Albany Proposes Bonds For Roads Be Backed by Surplus
description: Leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate proposed a $3 billion bond issue today to pay for improvements to New York's roads and bridges over four years.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items.(Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Advertising; Shandwick Acquisitions
description: Shandwick P.L.C., the British public relations giant that is buying up firms worldwide and owns eight in the United States alone, announced two more acquisitions yesterday. They are the International Public Relations Company, its first purchase in Japan, and the McCann Consultancy, a London subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Battling Apartheid
description: The latest crackdown by South Africa's Government on a range of anti-apartheid groups may lend impetus to a drive in Congress for further sanctions against Pretoria.

title: U.N. VOTE OPPOSES U.S. ON P.L.O. ISSUE
description: The General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to take action against the United States in the World Court over an attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's mission here.

description: b-Includes a gain of $17,675,000 for both the quarter and year from the sale of real estate. c-Includes gains of $309,000 and $1,848,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, boht from the sale of real estate.

title: REALTY SOUTH INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year shae earnings were affected by the dilutive effect of stock warrants. As previously announced, 1987 results were affected by non-cash charges, primarily for depreciation and amortization expenses, and payment of the full advisory company fee which was deferred partially in 1986.

title: The Stage: 'Childhood'
description: AS we are told too often, ''deep pain'' infects a Brooklyn household in ''A Subject of Childhood,'' a new play by Loren-Paul Caplin at the WPA Theater. A 3-year-old boy's playmate has died in a mysterious tumble down a staircase, and the 3-year-old's father and stepmother are trying to decide if the death was an accident or homicide. In other words, is the child a ''bad seed'' or are the parents indulging in theatrics? Enter a concerned family counselor (Novella Nelson) to lead them, as she says pretentiously, ''to confront your own dragons.''

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Sports People; Foul Play
description: When two jockeys are thundering toward the finish line in one of those neck-and-neck duels, the will to win can sometimes get so intense that it's all a jockey can do to keep himself from reaching over and yanking on his rival's reins. For one jockey, it seems, the impulse proved irresistable. That, in the view of racing officials, was exactly what happened in the eighth race at Garden State Park Monday night when Armando Marquez found himself coming down to the wire with Julie Krone right by his side and threatening to beat him across the line. As it happened, Marquez did hold off Krone's challenge, but after reviewing the finish, the judges decided he hadn't done it in a very sporting way and placed Krone first. They said that just before the finish Marquez had grabbed her reins, slowing her charge. At a hearing later, Marquez, a 22-year-old Panamanian who lives in Philadelphia, said that his hands had accidentally become entangled in his rival's reins. The stewards didn't buy it. They gave him a six-month suspension.

title: BALDWIN PIANO & ORGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $125,000 and $371,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, because of a change to the LIFO method of valuing inventory. c-Adjusted to exclude an after-tax gain of $768,000, or 23 cents a share, resulting from the sale of the company's German subsidiary in June 1986.

description: BUZ VAULTZ'S work is all over town: in the A.T.&T. building in midtown, the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan and the Stage Deli on Seventh Avenue. Mr. Vaultz, a glass etcher, does many smaller jobs as well.

description: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Chicago, which became an agency of the James B. Beam Distilling Company, Deerfield, Ill., last fall, has now been assigned its Windsor Canadian whisky, which bills an estimated $6 million.

description: Six Navy parachutists slid down a pole protruding from an airplane, deployed their chutes and glided to the ground today as the space agency tested the second of two escape systems for the space shuttle.

title: Settling on a New HOme For the Folk Art Museum
description: THE Museum of American Folk Art, which has been without a permanent home for a year and a half, will soon have a place to call its own.

Krishna Group Named In a Child Abuse Case
description: Children at a Hare Krishna commune have been subjected to sexual abuse and forced into communal marriages, according a court petition filed by a former sect member seeking custody of her children.

title: Why the Home-as-Castle Isn't What It Used to Be
description: SIPPING white wine at the start of the evening, Ettore Sottsass toyed with the idea of the home as castle, and found it hopelessly obsolete.

title: AGOURON PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Backup for Tubbs
description: If Tony Tubbs has a change of heart and decides not to fight Mike Tyson on March 21 in Tokyo, the show will go on with Jose Ribalta as a substitute. According to Bill Cayton, Tyson's co-manager, Ribalta is being paid ''not quite six figures'' to go to Japan as a backup to Tubbs, who in December 1986 pulled out of a heavyweight title fight against Tim Witherspoon. In 1986, before Tyson became champion, he stopped Ribalta in the last round of a 10-rounder.

title: Music: Opera Parodies
description: NOT everyone responds with equal enthusiasm to the prospect of grown men dressed up as women and singing opera arias and scenes in falsetto with campy inflections and explicit homosexual innuendo.

title: A Rare Ellington Work Is Revived
description: Shortly before Duke Ellington died on May 24, 1974, at age 75, he and Maurice Peress revised the ending of ''Black, Brown and Beige,'' Ellington's longest - and seldom heard -composition. Tonight, Mr. Peress will lead the American Jazz Orchestra in the first performance of that work to incorporate the composer's final revisions. It will also be a re-creation of the work's premiere at Carnegie Hall in 1943.

title: Cliches of the Month, and Era
description: It has been a big season for jump-starts, which, this being winter, is reasonable enough for the literal kind. ''Jump-start'' is a perfectly straightforward way to describe the transfusion of juice, via jumper cables, from a car that's already running to one whose battery has gone dead overnight.

title: Restoring The Glitter And Sheen Of Jewelry
description: A LITTLE bit of jewelry care goes a long way toward enhancing the brilliance of gemstones, pearls and precious metals. It also safeguards their worth.

title: Troubled City Now Facing Criminal Charges
description: The city of East St. Louis, the first municipality in Illinois accused of criminal violations of state law, pleaded not guilty today to charges that it is endangering its police officers with inadequate equipment.

title: Cleveland Strike Goes On
description: Classes resumed today for some high school seniors as a teachers' strike entered its seventh day. The 5,093 members of the Cleveland Teachers Union struck Thursday in a contract dispute with the school board. The district has nearly 73,000 students.

title: German Output Up 2.2%
description: West German industrial production rose 2.2 percent in January from December, the Economics Ministry said today. The ministry adjusted December's increase to three-tenths of a percent after previously reporting a seasonally adjusted gain of five-tenths of a percent.

description: Faced with sluggish local demand for condominium apartments, Manhattan developers are turning to Japan to try to find investors interested in owning a few rooms 8,000 miles away in New York.

description: It now appears likely the Senate will begin debating the new treaty eliminating medium and shorter range nuclear weapons without the participation of Senator Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, who played a key role in framing the issues for that debate.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Even the desire to do good, which I know is at the heart of this bill, must be seen in light of the unintended consequences our best-intentioned legislation sometimes has.'' - Representative Bob Michel, in debate on civil rights bill.

title: Gephardt Presses Double Theme: Nationalism and Economic Worry
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt stood in the rain outside a Ford plant in Louisville today and spoke once again of an America under siege: beset by unfair foreign competition and misled by politicians attached to the status quo.
