description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation is offering $96.9 million in second-resolution bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which made a successful competitive bid.

title: Senate Panel Approves Banking Bill
description: After a marathon negotiating session, the Senate Banking Committee overwhelmingly approved a compromise bill that would give banks large new powers to underwrite securities but would place limits on their further expansion into the sale of insurance.

title: Nureyev in Los Angeles
description: Rudolf Nureyev is to perform as a guest artist with American Ballet Theater on March 17, 18 and 19 during the company's season at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Mr. Nureyev, who celebrates his 50th birthday on March 17, is to dance Albrecht in ''Giselle.'' Ballet Theater remains in Los Angeles through March 20 and then opens a six-week spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House in New York City on April 18.

title: New Postmaster General
description: Anthony M. Frank, a San Francisco banker, took office Tuesday as head of the United States Postal Service. He is the fourth Postmaster General in four years. Mr. Frank succeeds Preston R. Tisch, a New York businessman who had held the post since Aug. 6, 1986. Mr. Tisch replaced Albert V. Casey, who held the job for seven months. Mr. Casey succeeded Paul N. Carlin, who served from January 1985 to January 1986.

title: Shocker: Nets Win in Boston
description: The Nets won their second straight game under Coach Willis Reed tonight, and it came in the most improbable of settings: Boston Garden.

title: Piano: Aldo Mancinelli In Recital
description: ALDO MANCINELLI devoted the first half of his piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday evening to Brahms's big F minor sonata, and tackled it whole: One sensed an awareness of the broad scope that informed each contributing episode. It was an authentic experience of the piece, even though the tone grew rather hard and worked sounding in sustained loud passages.

title: Metro Datelines; Jersey Denies Parole In '64 Police Killings
description: The State Parole Board refused yesterday to release Thomas Trantino, imprisoned since 1964 for the slaying of two Lodi police officers, and ordered that he serve at least three more years before being considered for parole again.

title: IPL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $115,000 and $690,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $78,000 for the quarter and $337,000 for the year.

title: Tv Set Learns A New Step
description: SOMEDAY, if Brian Addison Elliott has his way, there will be a television set that walks and responds to the viewer's voice.

title: Eviction Empties Motel Where Dr. King Died
description: Four sheriff's deputies today evicted the last resident of the Lorraine Motel, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated 20 years ago.

title: Focus on War Crimes Architects, Not Waldheim; Ardent Supporters
description: To the Editor:

title: In Two Cities, Shows of Spring Flowers
description: FORGET the grim grays of winter: spring is here. Or so gardeners can pretend as they immerse themselves in the flower shows that arrive as the daylight hours lengthen.

title: City Opera: 'Music Man'
description: PROBABLY no musical comedy of the 1950's more perfectly epitomizes American small-town nostalgia during the Eisenhower era than ''The Music Man,'' by Meredith Willson. Set in 1912, the show, which trounced ''West Side Story'' in the 1957 Tony Awards, brought a mixture of John Philip Sousa-style razzle-dazzle and George M. Cohan blarney back to Broadway, where it ran for 1,375 performances. At its emotional center loomed Robert Preston's mammoth performance as the charming swindler Harold Hill, who cons the small Iowa town of River City into buying instruments and costumes for a children's marching band that he promises to lead, although he has no musical training or experience.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After equity in net earnings of spunoff subsidiary of $14,963,000 and $14,424,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also is after a charge of $1,116,000 for an accounting change.

title: Reagan Backs Return Trip by Shultz to Mideast for Peace Mission
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz got President Reagan's approval today to devote two more days to his peace mission in the Middle East, beginning Thursday, when he will return to region.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: CHRONIC mildew on walls and ceilings, peeling paint that exposes bare material underneath (not just earlier coats of finish), sweating window panes and crumbling plaster: these problems frequently are signs of indoor condensation. Most often this condensation - water in household air changing from vapor to liquid -occurs in winter. But it can crop up anytime.

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Layoffs Planned By Campbell Soup
description: The Campbell Soup Company said that it would lay off 460 workers at a Chicago plant and that it intended to save $10 million by trimming its white-collar work force. The company said it had begun a hiring freeze and early retirement programs, and a spokesman said additional layoffs might be made.

title: KEY RATES
4 Among 20: Key States Poised for Super Tuesday; North Carolina: Dole and Gore Face Uphill Battle
description: On Tuesday primaries and caucuses will be held in 20 states and American Samoa, more jurisdictions than have ever picked Presidential nominating convention delegates in a single day. Most will be elected in the Southern and border states whose politicians organized the event and called it Super Tuesday.

title: How $8 Million Was Won and Lost
description: Don't look for Ozar Hatorah in the Manhattan telephone book. Nor, until last week, could one obtain a listing of the world headquarters of the educational organization by dialing Manhattan information.

title: Sports People; Basketball Honors
description: Two basketball players from New York City have been named by Parade magazine as among the top 12 high school players in the country. Kenny Anderson of Archbishop Molloy in Queens and Malik Sealy of St. Nicholas of Tolentine of the Bronx were named to the first team of the magazine's all-America squad. Another Molloy player, Robert Werdann, was named to the second team, and Chris McRae of Brooklyn Tech was a third team selection.

title: Man With AIDS Virus Cleared in Blood Sales
description: A man who tested positive for the AIDS virus was acquitted today of two counts of attempted poisoning for selling his tainted blood to a blood bank.

title: Excerpts From Speech By Schools Chancellor
description: Following are excerpts from the speech yesterday by Dr. Richard R. Green at his inauguration as New York City Schools Chancellor:

title: Villa-Lobos Program
description: The Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, is presenting ''An Evening of Villa-Lobos'' at 8 tonight. Featured on the program is an aria from the Brazilian composer's opera ''Yerma'' and other vocal and chamber works. The performers include Alfred Heller, pianist; Debra Mitchell, soprano, and Jue Yao, violinist. Tickets are $10. Information: 427-5103 or 249-8950.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Congressman's move to withhold some American aid from Jamaica because of a land dispute involving a friend misstated a State Department official's objections to the move. The official said the Congressman's friend, John W. Rollins, had not sued the Jamaican Government to recover the disputed property; he did not say Mr. Rollins had lost such a lawsuit.

title: Washington Talk: The Commerce Department; Did Japanese Lobbyists Scuttle Top Appointment?
description: Have lobbyists for the Japanese construction industry killed the promotion of a tough negotiator who was up for a top post in the Commerce Department?

title: KEY RATES
Robertson Promises Not to Impose His Religious Views on Americans
description: Concerned by skepticism about his commitment to separation of church and state, the former evangelist Pat Robertson said in a statewide 30-minute television address today that he neither desired nor sought to impose his religious views on the people of America.

title: ARIZONA INSTRUMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $32,340 from a change in accounting method.

title: Film: From Italy, 'Traffic Jam'
description: ''TRAFFIC JAM,'' Luigi Comencini's 1978 Italian film, begins as if it were going to be a light-hearted, satirical variation on Jean-Luc Godard's apocalyptic classic, ''Weekend.'' Instead it becomes a very heavy, rather literal forecast of the decline and fall of capitalism through gridlock.

title: 'Admission' Charge For Wrestling Fans
description: PAY-PER-VIEW has a cash-register ring to it for promoters, and a sinister sound to people who believe television airwaves should be forever free. But paying for a sports event has become a part of the living-room landscape.

title: Matthews Retires
description: Saying he was not interested in a second-string role, Gary Matthews, the 37-year-old outfielder who in 16 major league seasons compiled a .281 batting average with 234 home runs and 978 runs batted in, announced his retirement as a player yesterday. Matthews, who picked up the 2,000th hit of his career last Aug. 4 while with the Seattle Mariners, won the National League rookie of the year award in 1973 with San Francisco. He spent five seasons with the Giants, four with the Atlanta Braves, three with the Philadelphia Phillies and three and a half with the Chicago Cubs, who traded him to Seattle in the middle of last season. Matthews has decided to take a job with the Sheridan Broadcasting Network's major league baseball radio show, which is based in Pittsburgh.

title: Chrysler to Keep Acustar But Plants Will Be Dropped
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would not sell Acustar Inc., its parts-making operation, but that it would sell or close four of the subsidiary's plants, affecting about 2,000 workers.

title: 80-Plane USAir Deal For Boeing
description: USAir Inc. said yesterday that it had ordered 50 Boeing 737 jets and taken options on 30 more in the biggest plane order in its history, one that could total about $2.4 billion if all options are exercised.

title: CONTROL MATERIALS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $902,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Dance: Premiere of Merce Cunningham's 'Carousal'
description: THE New York premiere of Merce Cunningham's tantalizing ''Carousal'' and the season's first performances of ''Locale'' and ''Quartet'' made up Wednesday night's program by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

title: Women's History Month Celebrated
description: March is observed as Women's History Month across the nation. In New York City, it is a time for examining women's lives and celebrating their experiences in events throughout the five boroughs. Many of the events are free. Some are open to women only. The range is wide, in entertainment alone this weekend, from reggae music to Bach and from feisty Lower East Side performance art to a show about a 19th-century feminist writer.

title: RICHMOND HILL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $487,000 for the quarter; the year includes an extraordinary credit of $4,052,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,513,000 and $5,387,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The bank did not disclose share earnings for full years 1987 and 1986.

title: WPP GROUP PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Each ADR represents two ordinary shares. The company said directors are recommending a final dividend for 1987 of 4.9 pence, making a total for the year of 6.4 pence, double the 1986 level. The company completed the acquisition of JWT Group, Inc. on July 14, 1987. The company said that during 1987 the revenue of the JWT Group increased to $700 million from $645 million in 1986. In terms of billings, although J. Walter Thompson Co. lost a total of about $450 million in 1987, while it gained more than $330 million. The net loss of $120 million represents only 2 percent of the group's pro- forma revenue of almost $900 million, assuming 15 percent agency commission.

title: Looking South: The Impact of Turnout
Touring America by Subway
description: AIRLINES and travel agents are wont to advertise their wondrously inexpensive getaways to the beaches of California and Hawaii, the mountains of Colorado and Montana, or the urban delights of Chicago and New Orleans - but the best bargain tour of the United States can be taken with only a handful of subway tokens and a hearty dose of imagination.

title: Series of 4 Asian Films
description: A four-week series of four influential Asian films begins today at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, in its Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium. The screenings, which are presented by Columbia University and the Asia Society, are to be Fridays at 3 and 7 P.M., with speakers after the later shows. Today's film is ''Seven Samurai'' (1954), Akira Kurosawa's Japanese western about a 16th-century village that hires warriors to fight off bandits; the speaker is Andrew Sarris, film critic for The Village Voice.

title: Lilco Rejects A Bid to Delay Annual Meeting
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today refused to postpone its annual meeting in May, a postponement that state officials had said was crucial to continue negotiations on avoiding a possible public takeover of the utility.

title: Film: 'And God Created Woman'
description: THERE are few real constants in this world, but surely Roger Vadim's gift for girl-watching looked like one of them. So it's sad to see Mr. Vadim's lecherous eye let him down. Whatever it was that possessed him to remake his 1957 ''And God Created Woman,'' the film that launched Brigitte Bardot, it was not the discovery of a voluptuous and comparably kittenish new star. Mr. Vadim's leading lady this time is the thoroughly ordinary Rebecca De Mornay, who has all the self-interest her role requires but little of the sex appeal.

title: Roll-Call in House Defeating Plan Providing Aid to Contras
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 216 to 208 today by which the House of Representatives defeated a plan to provide $30.8 million in food, clothing and medical aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the aid package. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 203 Democrats and 5 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 45 Democrats and 171 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Committee Assails Nuclear Agency
description: Congressmen accused the leadership of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission again today of lax enforcement of safety standards for the nuclear power industry.

title: Bush and Dole Campaign Aides Differ Sharply in Mood and Consistency; Serenity Atop Bush Campaign
description: Some Presidential candidates have made major shifts in their key advisers, but Vice President Bush has made virtually none.

title: Raising Minimum Wage Increases Employment
description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret C. Braun, 74; Served on Staff of U.N.
description: Margaret Cunningham Braun, a member of the United Nations international staff for 28 years, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 74 years old. In the early 1940's, she was a staff member of the United Nations Information Office, an intergovernmental agency that helped prepare for the founding conference of the United Nations in San Francisco in 1945. During her career, she helped organize the United Nations' documentation service and then became a writer-researcher.

title: Disguised Tamil Rebels Kill 15
description: Tamil rebels in Sri Lankan Army uniforms shot to death nine children and six adults Wednesday in an attack on homes of ethnic Sinhalese, a senior military officer said today.

title: Cuomo Asks Return of 2-Way Toll For Trucks on Verrazano Bridge
description: Hoping to ease traffic jams, cut pollution and gain at least $3 million in lost revenue, Governor Cuomo today proposed reinstating two-way tolls for trucks crossing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: The Republican Presidential candidate Pat Robertson has called his motion to abandon his libel case against Paul N. McCloskey Jr. ''one of the most unfair choices I have ever had to make.'' The trial was to begin Super Tuesday, he noted, and there was no way he could seek vindication and the White House simultaneously.

title: Gretzky's Influence
description: Joey Ferras, a senior center for the Plattsburgh State hockey team in upstate New York, comes from Brantford, Ontario, the hometown of Wayne Gretzky. With a goal and two assists in a 7-5 loss to Oswego State on Wednesday night, Ferras became college hockey's leading scorer at all levels, running his total to 355 points. He had been tied at 352 points with Dave Lair, who finished his career at Oswego in 1983.

title: Fairfield Protest Denied
description: The Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference denied a protest by Fairfield University yesterday after its basketball team lost by 63-60 to St. Peter's in the first round of the conference tournament Wednesday night in Jersey City.

title: A Trade Gain In Electronics
description: The United States continued to import more electronics than it exported last year, but exports grew at the fastest pace since 1980, the Electronic Industries Association said today.

title: Joke Turns Sour
description: Kirk Gibson, who signed with Los Angeles as a free agent after 10 years in the Detroit organization, angrily left Holman Stadium in Vero Beach, Fla., and didn't play in the Dodgers' exhibition game against the Chunichi Dragons yesterday after he was victimized by a practical joke. It would have been his first game as a Dodger. Somebody apparently put eye black, which is used to protect players' eyes from sunlight, into Gibson's cap. When he discovered the black substance on his forehead, he got angry, went to the clubhouse, got dressed and left, according to reporters at the game. Gibson wouldn't comment. . . . Willie Hernandez, the Tigers' relief pitcher, has aplogized to Mitch Albom, a columnist for The Detroit Free Press, for dumping a bucket of ice water on him in the clubhouse Wednesday. Hernandez has blamed Albom for turning Detroit fans against him. ''I feel pretty bad about it,'' Hernandez said. ''A lot of people make mistakes. I believe I made a good mistake.''

title: Nuclear Deterrence Affirmed by Reagan
description: A two-day summit gathering of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here was meant to have turned the alliance toward the future, to the shifting arms control agenda and to the challenges posed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: TORONTO DOMINION BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan losses. Assets at Jan. 31 are $57.75 billion vs. $52.79 billion. Figures are in Canadian funds. Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The bank said lower first-quarter earnings were mainly the result of sharply reduced returns on investments and higher expenses. It said it estimates that its 1988 loan losses will be $150 million, which does not include ant increase in prudential reserves on loans to less developed countries.

title: Mexico Accepts $3.67 Billion In Debt Exchange for Bonds
description: Mexico said today that it had accepted $3.67 billion in bids from foreign banks in its innovative program to swap debt for bonds. The figure was slightly more than a third of what Mexico was hoping to receive.

title: Quisenberry Faces a Bullpen Showdown
description: The so-called lifetime contract the Kansas City Royals gave Dan Quisenberry three years ago did not guarantee the relief pitcher a job with the team for life, so this spring he is pitching for just that: his life with the Royals.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on Feb. 25, about a ruling on a Manhattan dentist who refused to treat a patient with AIDS, misidentified the dentist.

title: Robert J. Dawson, Direct-Mail Consultant, 53
description: Robert J. Dawson, a direct-mail consultant, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 53 years old. He was a former president of the Life Circulation Company, a subsidiary of Time Inc. At his death, he was president of Dearfield Associates, a direct-mail consulting company, in Greenwich and Phoenix.

title: Panama Runs Into a Cash Crisis, Forcing Banks to Limit Dealings
description: Fears that the United States Government and American banks plan to freeze all payments to the Panamanian Government caused a severe cash shortage here today. The central bank was unable to meet some obligations, and leading commercial banks were forced to limit withdrawals and other transactions.

title: IU Drafts a Plan To Counter Neoax
description: Neoax Inc. said that it had been informed by the IU International Corporation that the IU board was meeting to consider a new recapitalization plan to defeat Neoax's $22-a-share hostile bid. The plan calls for selling all of its assets other than its environmental services unit for $460 million to a management group led by the Dean Witter Capital Corporation. Under this proposal, detailed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, IU would then pay its shareholders a special cash dividend of $19.50 a share.

title: Art: Versailles Palace In Swedish Perspective
description: ''VERSAILLES: The View From Sweden'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum is on more than one count a remarkable exhibition. Made up entirely of drawings from Swedish sources, it looks good, it isn't too big, it is very amusing and it is consistently instructive. We see great architecture and great gardens as they were set down on paper by the people who designed them, but we also get to read the small print of history.

title: Film: Turner in 'Switching Channels'
description: SOME eccentric inspirations are better than others. In its own day, the idea of the safety pin sounded crazy as well as dangerous. There were also people who groaned when Howard Hawks decided to remake ''The Front Page'' with Rosalind Russell as Hildy Johnson. Not only did Hawks change Hildy from a man into a woman, but he introduced a love-hate sexual relationship between Hildy, the star reporter of Chicago yellow journalism in the 1920's, and Hildy's manic, unscrupulous editor, Walter Burns.

title: Helen M. Brady Aeder, Mutual Fund Analyst, 54
description: Helen M. Brady Aeder, a mutual fund analyst, died of renal cancer Tuesday in Palisades General Hospital in North Bergen, N.J. She was 54 years old and lived in West New York, N.J.

title: NEW KABUL OFFER IN AFGHAN PARLEY
description: The Communist-backed Kabul Government made a new offer at the Afghanistan peace talks here today, apparently leaving Pakistan's conditions for the makeup of a government after a Soviet withdrawal the major remaining obstacle at the negotiations.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Schenley Industries to Grey Advertising for Lillet, an imported French aperitif.

title: Physician Retracts Diagnosis
description: The doctor for three brothers who were ostracized in their hometown because they had been exposed to the AIDS virus has retracted his diagnosis of the oldest boy.

title: Aon Buyback
description: W. Clement Stone and his wife, Jessie, agreed to sell 1.4 million shares of stock in the Aon Corporation back to the company for $25.95 a share. The $36.3 million transaction, agreed to Wednesday, was disclosed just days after the Alberto-Culver Company announced it had repurchased 866,802 of its shares from Mr. Stone for $20.5 million. Mr. Stone, chairman of Aon, an insurance holding company, indicated the sale of Aon stock was made due to ''reasons related to our own personal financial planning.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not going to sink any more money down a washtub of malfeasance, misfeasance and nonfeasance.'' - Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio, on contra aid. [ A4:5. ]

title: Ernst & Whinney Acquires McLean
description: Ernst & Whinney, the international accounting and consulting firm, said it had acquired the McLean Group Inc., a management and computer-systems consulting firm specializing in banks and brokerages.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are unavailable because the partnership was formed in December 1986.

title: West German Freed in Beirut After 5 Weeks
description: A West German engineer who was kidnapped here five weeks ago was freed today.

title: Productivity Gain for 1987 Set at 0.9% After Revision
description: The nation's nonfarm productivity improved last year by nine-tenths of 1 percent, just half as much as in 1986, despite revised figures showing higher output in the fourth quarter, the Government said today.

title: HAWKEYE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,446,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss Results for 1986 are restated to reflect a reconsolidation of five bank units designated for sale but not sold. Hawkeye said its problems loans were reduced 49 percent in 1987.

title: Macy Plans Legal Step In Bidding
description: In an intensifying struggle to win Federated Department Stores Inc., R. H. Macy & Company is expected to contest the legality of the Campeau Corporation's latest tender offer for the giant retailer.

title: Volatile Mix of Empire and Glasnost
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of loosening controls, applauded by the West, creates inevitable complications. These have never been more apparent than now, in Armenian and Azerbaijani protests. Moscow's looser grip gives the more than 100 Soviet ethnic groups room to stretch. But the stretching will not come without pain - for the ethnic groups as well as the Soviet leaders who must fashion a response. When that response includes force, as it has and will, there will be complications for U.S. policy makers, too.

title: BP AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $30,000,000.

title: 13 Are Reported Killed In Bangladesh Voting
description: Rival party workers fighting with guns, knives and bombs killed 13 people and wounded scores of others in Bangladesh during elections today, police officials said, but Home Minister M.A. Matin put the death toll at five.

title: INVENTION DESIGN ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a reserve of $100,000 representing anticipated losses on the sale or disposition of assets no longer required at the company's Torrance, Calif. facility.

title: Green, Installed, Appeals for Help
description: Dr. Richard R. Green, formally installed yesterday as New York City Schools Chancellor at a colorful ceremony marked by pomp and humor, appealed to state, city, union and school officials to assist him in a collective effort to improve the schools.

title: INVESTORS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Books of The Times
description: THE YEAR OF THE BARRICADES. A Journey Through 1968. by David Caute.

title: Arizona Senate Rejects Charge of Misconduct
description: The Arizona Senate today rejected an attempt by lawyers for Gov. Evan Mecham to introduce evidence at his impeachment trial about the sex life of a key witness.

title: Dining Out Guide: 3-Star, Varied Cuisine
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. The date of original publication is listed after the phone number. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. THE FOUR SEASONS, 99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - (Nov. 22, 1985) For more than a quarter century, this venerable institution has pampered the elite and has managed to maintain standards of food quality and service that are paragons of the industry. The menu changes daily, but you might start with a terrine of pike and salmon; duck livers with apples and Calvados, or stuffed cabbage with pheasant. Entree options are duck au poivre; snapper baked in sea salt and pepper with two sauces; veal cutlet with ginger, and double lamb chops. Entrees $34 to $42.50. Pool Room: Fridays, noon to 2 P.M. and 5 to 11:15 P.M.; Saturdays. 5 to 11:15 P.M.; closed Sundays. GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL, 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - (Oct. 4, 1985) The spacious and comfortable multi-tier dining room has a post-modern decor with pink marble bar, tall columns and parachute shades. The cooking approach is contemporary and frequently freewheeling, and the dishes are dazzling but rarely incongruent. You may be hard pressed to choose from the alluring appetizers: goat cheese ravioli with pancetta, tomato, shallots and an herbed chicken broth; squab salad with couscous, croutons and a curried vinaigrette, and a salad of curly, sharp Italian lettuce with Roquefort croutons and Caesar vinaigrette. Among the regular entrees are grilled salmon and artichokes a la grecque with spinach, tomato, olive oil, garlic and eggplant; grilled rack of lamb with flageolets, mustard and roasted garlic custard, and thin sliced venison with sauteed green apples, red onion compote and poivrade. Entrees $23 to $26. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11:30 P.M. Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5:30 to 10 P.M. HATSUHANA, 17 East 48th Street (355-3345) - (Feb. 21, 1986) Cheerful dining rooms on two levels, each with elongated sushi bars flanked by rows of simple wooden tables, provide a suitable stage for the colorful production put on by the personable sushi chefs at this high-ranked Japanese restaurant. The menu is extensive, and with fish as fresh as this, some of the least elaborate presentations are the most appealing. Sushi and sashimi are the highlights of the menu, and a good way to get acquainted is to order the Hatsuhana special, which includes both raw fish specialties and tempura and grilled skewered fish. If you are feeling experimental, sample the tiny fried Japanese crabs. All the grilled teriyaki-style fish are highly recommended. Dinner entrees $18 to $29. Fridays, 11:45 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. and 5:30 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 10 P.M. MITSUKOSHI, 461 Park Avenue, at 57th Street (935-6444) - (March 8, 1985) This comfortable restaurant below a porcelain and pottery shop of the same name has three seating areas: the over-illuminated main dining room, the sushi bar and the private tatami rooms with a sunken well under the table. Excellent sushi and sashimi are available and it is fun to have them at the sushi bar; the basic platter is a vivid palette of contrasting tastes and textures - tuna rolls, tuna sashimi, salmon, salmon caviar roll, fluke, shrimp and a triangle of Japanese omelet, which should be eaten last. Other selections are dictated by market availability - from lightly smoked eel to a luxurious quail egg and sea urchin combination and wondrously sweet baby Gulf shrimp. Entrees $15 to $25. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M. RIVER CAFE, 1 Water Street, Brooklyn (718-522-5200) - (July 25, 1986) With its stunning views of Manhattan and the East River, this restaurant would cause a slight rush of pulse in even the most jaded New Yorker. Besides the atmosphere, the kitchen offers some of the most provocative food to be found in the city. To start, you may choose from smoked salmon; sauteed quail and quail ravioli in soy and mushroom consomme, or chilled duck foie gras with dressed lentils and endive puree. Entree options are pan-roasted squab with corn risotto and confit of dates; salmon seared with ginger and cracked pepper with burgundy butter, salsify and leeks, and calf's liver with smoked kidneys and eggplant confit. You might want to save room for the parfait of banana praline and coffee with milk chocolate sauce. Dinner prix fixe $52. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 7 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 3 P.M. and 7 P.M. to midnight. HUBERTS, which received a 3-star rating on April 26, 1985, has closed at its previous address and plans to reopen on March 15 at 575 Park Avenue, at 63d Street. The number for information and reservations is 826-5911. What the star rating means, page C26.

title: Two Doctors Charged In Sick-Leave Scheme
description: Two Manhattan doctors were arrested and charged with illegally selling disability certificates to undercover agents of the Transit Authority, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday.

title: Carriers Improve Record
description: On-time peformance by the nation's major airlines improved slightly in January, but 3 of every 10 flights were still at least 15 minutes late, according to the Department of Transportation.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Parks and Football
description: The national parks have often been used as political footballs and they are now being kicked around by Paul G. Kirk Jr., chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel.

title: Bush and Dole Campaign Aides Differ Sharply in Mood and Consistency; Tension Seen in Senator's Staff
description: At a meeting at Senator Bob Dole's Presidental headquarters the other morning, the deputy campaign chairman, Bernard M. Windon, called the staff together and spoke quietly.

title: ISS INTERNATIONAL SERVICE SYSTEM (DANISH, CO)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CLUE IN THE SPREAD OF AIDS VIRUS SEEN
description: The AIDS virus has been found to infect the lining of the cervix, which may help explain how the disease spreads in sexual activity and childbirth, according to a study made public today.

title: Seton Hall Gains In Women's Play
description: Seton Hall used a 19-5 spurt early in the second half tonight to overcome a 6-point deficit and defeat Georgetown, 72-63, in the first round of the Big East Conference women's tournament at Pitt.

title: AMERICAN VANGUARD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest fourth quarter includes a special after-tax gain of $192,000, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of air-quality emission credits and a one-time charge of $96,000 from the writedown of a special project.

title: Trial Set in Killing of 16
description: A man accused of killing 16 people, including 14 members of his own family, is competent to stand trial, a judge has ruled in setting a May 9 trial date. The man, R. Gene Simmons, 47 years old, surrendered to the police Dec. 28 after a shooting spree left two former co-workers dead and led to the discovery of the bodies of his wife; four daughters; three sons; two spouses of his children; three grandchilden and a child who officials say he fathered by his oldest daughter.

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Drops 7.80, to 2,063.49
description: LEAD: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday, as takeover activity continued to be the dominant theme on Wall Street.

title: Advertising; Taylor Studies Three Agencies
description: W. A. Taylor & Company, which markets alcoholic beverages, has narrowed the field of competitors for its advertising business down to three agencies: Waring & LaRosa, part of the Omnicom Group; Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, part of the WCRS Group, and the William Esty Company, part of Saatchi & Saatchi. Taylor's current agency is J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Canter Achenbaum Associates is managing the competition.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO TAKE NORIEGA FOES' CUE
description: As the Reagan Administration continued to support the economic campaign against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama, American officials acknowledged today that they were following rather than leading the effort.

title: Irish Music
description: The Egan Family - Seamus on wooden flute, tenor banjo, mandolin and uileann pipes; Siobhan on flute and fiddle and Roryann on tin whistle and button accordion - is to play Irish traditional music tomorrow at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Magazine Is Ordered to Pay $9.4 Million for Killer's Ad
description: A jury today ordered Soldier of Fortune magazine to pay $9.4 million in damages to the family of a woman whose husband hired her killer through a classified advertisement in the magazine.

title: Advertising; Insert on Nynex Unit To Aid Recognition
description: Since its subsidiaries operate telephone systems in the Northeast, Nynex can't fail to be well known in that region. But elsewhere, except in the scattered locations where it also publishes Yellow Pages directories, Nynex is relatively unknown. This situation does not please the operators of the Atlanta-based Nynex Business Centers, 81 of which are spread out around the country offering a variety of computers, peripherals and software.

title: TEVA PHAMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its fiscal year has been changed to coincide with the calendar year in accordance with recent Israeli legislation; Teva's fiscal year previously ended on March 31. Share earnings are per ADR.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 8
description: b-Net loss

title: Wholesale Club Venture by K Mart Is Seen
description: The K Mart Corporation today will announce its entry into the field of wholesale clubs through a joint venture with SHV Holdings, a Dutch company, people close to the big American retail chain said.

title: Larry Davis Cleared In the 1986 Slayings Of 4 Drug Suspects
description: After presenting a defense based almost entirely on the assertion that he had been framed by the authorities, Larry Davis was acquitted of all charges last night in the murder of four suspected drug dealers 16 months ago in the South Bronx.

title: Electric Voltage Dips As a Fire Breaks Out At a Con Ed Station
description: Electrical voltage dipped throughout New York City and Westchester County yesterday afternoon as a fire of unknown origin heavily damaged a Consolidated Edison transmission station in Yonkers and two power lines there failed.

title: Hamlet Journal; In Indiana, 640 Cases of Championship Fever
description: ''Can you just imagine it?'' asked Perry Watkins, the town barber, as he paused over Duck Awald's forelock and stared wistfully out the window of his shop. ''A little school from a town like this, where half the stores are boarded up and half the people gone - state basketball champions of Indiana.''

title: Managua Journal; Lifelong Rebel Is Home, Unarmed but Unbowed
description: Because Fernando Chamorro Rappaccioli has spent his life immersed in conspiracies and uprisings, it is more than a bit incongruous to find him sitting quietly behind a desk in Managua.

title: Group Offers $45 a Share for Koppers
description: In a surprise takeover bid that is expected to escalate quickly, Beazer P.L.C., a British construction company, offered yesterday to pay $1.1 billion in cash for the slightly more than 92 percent of the Koppers Company that it does not already own.

title: Thomas W. Melham, Insurance Executive, 86
description: Thomas W. Melham, an insurance executive who served in the 1950's as Imperial Potentate of the Ancient Arabic Order of Nobles of the Mystic Shrine of North America, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Fort Salonga, L.I. He was 86 years old.

title: Cats, in All Their Glory, On Display at the Garden
description: Since the stars of this show would be hard pressed to have anything more articulate to say than a particularly expressive meow or soulful purr, Vicky Markstein, the co-producer of New York's fourth International Cat Show, offered to speak for the 1,000 or so feline attendees of this weekend's extravaganza at Madison Square Garden.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Film: Haunted 'Prison'
description: ''PRISON'' has a generic, low-budget name, and for once you can judge a movie by its title. This prison-drama-meets-ghost-story, which opens today at the Criterion and Movie Center 5, turns out to be an object lesson in how cheaply and badly a film can be made.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; WPP Profits Are Hailed By Analysts
description: BRITAIN'S WPP Group, which after a fight acquired the JWT Group for $566 million last year, issued an annual financial statement yesterday that has surprised and pleased Wall Street analysts.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Horse Racing Notebook; Derby Favorites Get an Early Rehearsal
description: Ten colts were entered this morning for the $500,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park Saturday, which looks like the most significant Kentucky Derby prep to be contested so early in the season since 1984.

title: State Report Says Koch Overestimated Revenue
description: The New York State Comptroller, in a twist on the prevailing criticism of the Koch administration's spending plan for fiscal year 1989, said yesterday that the Mayor had overestimated by as much as $125 million the tax revenue New York City will receive next year.

title: Peru Sentences Guerrillas
description: Two leftist guerrillas have been sentenced to 25 years in prison for assassinating an admiral who was president of a Peruvian state bank, a court spokesman said today. He said Maria Saire Heredia and Pablo Efrain Jorge Morales, members of the Shining Path guerrilla group, were found guilty Wednesday of killing Adm. Geronimo Cafferata.

title: Manhattan Cable To Carry Bravo
description: Manhattan Cable TV, pressed by a citizens' lawsuit to add more pay-television channels, will offer Bravo, the movie and performing-arts service, beginning in May.

title: What Balanchine Thought of Soviet Hospitality
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball Family Goes to the Hoop
description: Grace Paterno pauses to reminisce and the memories come bouncing forward. Basketballs being dribbled in the hallway, chest passes off the wall, more uniforms churning in the washing machine than she can remember and three-on-three games in the backyard.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: An Unfamiliar Tale

title: All of China Keeps The Same Time
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage
description: A Bilingual Brecht Package

title: INDEPTH DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a development stage company.

title: New York Tests a Boot Camp for Inmates
description: At precisely 5:30 A.M. today, a bugle blared reveille, and 32 Sixth Platoon men leaped from their bunks.

title: Setbacks for Artificial Intelligence
description: A major retrenchment is occurring in the artificial intelligence industry, dashing the hopes of many companies that thought they would prosper by providing the technology to make computers ''think.''

title: Music: Chamber Orchestra of Europe
description: IN prospect, the program by the Chamber Orchestra of Europe at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening looked unusually appetizing. The group, formed in 1981, was appearing under the baton of its artistic director, Claudio Abbado, whose appearances in New York are rare enough to insure expectations of quality music making. For a soloist, there was Maurizio Pollini, taking on the Schumann Piano Concerto, a high-Romantic work that one does not automatically think of in connection with this precisionist and intellectual. And, in a gesture not commonly made by touring conductors, Mr. Abbado introduced a work by a young composer relatively unknown in this country, Wolfgang Rihm.

title: Dismissed Aide Issues Comment
description: Bob Marcum, the athletic director at the University of South Carolina until he was dismissed Tuesday, said he discovered only last week that the school's drug-testing program was ineffective.

title: U.S.-Built Vehicle Sales Surged in Late February
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose 25 percent in late February from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Concert for Children
description: Rosenshontz, a musical duo comprised of Gary Rosen and Bill Shontz, is to present a special concert for children tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Manhattan Center High School, 116th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive. Youngsters in the audience will be able to participate in a program of original songs that deal with issues dear to children, such as eating vegetables, parting with one's security blanket and refusing to go to sleep. Tickets are $6 and $8. Information: 873-1222.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1988
description: COMPANIES Macy is expected to contest the legality of Campeau's latest tender offer for Federated Department Stores. The Macy strategy apparently will be to contend that the offer represents a new bid, not an amended proposal, and that it violates Federal laws and a Delaware anti-takeover statute. [ Page D1. ] A $1.1 billion bid for Koppers was made by Beazer, a British construction company. Koppers is a Pittsburgh-based road builder and manufacturer of construction materials. The offer was for $45 a share. Kopper's shares rose to $51.75, up $6.625. [ D1. ] Chrysler will not sell Acustar Inc., its parts-making unit, but will sell or close four plants, affecting about 2,000 workers. A sale had been strongly opposed by Chrysler's unions. [ D1. ] A new cable entertainment service is planned by Ted Turner, who has gained tentative approval of the plan from a number of cable operators. The eventual goal would be to provide original productions for cable. [ D1. ] USAir ordered 50 Boeing 737 jets and took options on 30 more in a deal that could total $2.4 billion. [ D4. ] K Mart is expected to announce its entry into wholesale clubs through a joint venture with SHV, a Dutch company. [ D4. ] Batus sweetened its tender offer for Farmers Group to $63 a share, or $4.5 billion. [ D4. ] Leading airlines raised fares for the second time in two weeks, reflecting unexpected strength in winter traffic. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY Retailers reported unexpectedly slow sales for February, with a number of large chains posting declines for stores open more than a year. Analysts, while noting that the comparison was with a relatively strong February last year, still expressed concern. [ D1. ] Vehicle sales rose 25 percent in late February. For the month, sales of domestic vehicles were 15.9 percent higher, while sales of imported vehicles fell 4.4 percent. Detroit's heavy discounting received most of the credit for the strong results. [ D5. ] A Senate panel's compromise on a landmark banking bill is expected to help secure its passage in the full Senate this spring. But strong opposition is likely in the House. [ D2. ] The Fed's chairman advocated two changes in the tax system. Alan Greenspan told Congress that he favored the imposition of consumption taxes and a reduction in the capital gains tax. [ D5. ] Nonfarm productivity improved last year by 0.9 percent, just half as much as in 1986, according to revised figures. [ D5. ] MARKETS The stock market had a mixed day, dominated by takeover activity. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.80 points, to 2,063.49, but other indexes had gains. [ D8. ] Bond prices were little changed in light activity as many traders waited for fresh data on the economy. [ D15. ] The dollar held steady in trading described as the lightest in more than a year. Gold fell to $428.20 an ounce, down $2.05, in New York. [ D16. ] Cattle futures were down amid reports of a packinghouse closing. [ D16. ] The New York Stock Exchange named a new president, Richard A. Grasso, who has been in charge of automated trading. The current president, Robert J. Birnbaum, is retiring. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL Mexico accepted $3.67 billion in bids from foreign banks in its innovative program to swap debt for bonds. [ D5. ] Chip makers are pressing for more sanctions against Japan. An industry group said sales of American computer chips in Japan last year fell $200 million short of agreed-upon levels. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Cutting the budget deficit must remain the top item on the agenda in Washington. One forecast sees Federal debt reaching $2.8 trillion in fiscal 1989. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Suppliers of temporary employees are enjoying a surge in demand fed by the corporate-restructuring trend. Analysts find the sector attractive, especially since the companies are emphasizing the filling of professional positions. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Never the Twain?
description: It looks as if Congress will be out on the town March 16, with Democrats and Republicans heading in different directions.

title: Crafts Market
description: An array of crafts, from gold jewelry to woven goods, is to be available the next two weekends at Columbia University, Ferris Booth Hall, Broadway and West 115th Street. Sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance, the annual crafts market features more than 125 exhibitors. Hours are today 2 to 8 P.M.; tomorrow 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is $4. Information: 866-2239.

title: Episcopal Women Seek Bishop Posts
description: Even while the Church of England remains deeply torn over whether to ordain women as priests, its sister Episcopal Church in the United States is moving toward the consecration of women priests as bishops.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 5, Maple Leafs 3: Reed Larson converted a pass from Geoff Courtnall with 2 minutes 15 seconds left to snap a 3-3 tie in Boston. Larson's goal came 38 seconds after Gary Leeman tied the score for the Maple Leafs, tapping in Tom Fergus's rebound. Cam Neely scored into an empty net with 6 seconds left. The game marked the pro debut of Craig Janney of the United States Olympic team. Janney, a center, took a shift for Boston during the first two periods. (AP) Red Wings 6, North Stars 3: Adam Oates and Bob Probert each scored twice to lead the Red Wings in Detroit. Oates's first goal, with 2:51 remaining in the first period, gave Detroit a 3-1 lead. He added a power-play goal at 5:36 of the second period before Probert scored twice in 13 seconds on the power play midway through the period. (AP) GOLF Two Tie for Lead: Hollis Stacy and Marci Bozarth both shot four-under-par 68's yesterday to share the first-round lead in the $300,000 Women's Kemper Open in Princeville, Hawaii. Light winds led to low scores at the 6,210-yard Mirage Princeville Ocean and Lakes course on the island of Kauai. (AP) Moody Shoots a 64: Orville Moody, putting with deadly accuracy, shot a 64 to take the first-round lead in the $350,000 Vintage Invitational senior tournament in Indian Wells, Calif. Moody, 55, set a course record on the Vintage Club's 6,240-yard, par-72 Desert Course. Gene Littler shot a 67 to tie for second place with Dale Douglass and Al Geiberger. (AP) SCHOOL BASKETBALL Molloy and Hayes Advance: Archbishop Molloy and Cardinal Hayes, the teams that made it to the final of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association tournament last year, both won quarterfinal games at Fordham last night. Molloy (22-2), the defending champion, routed Rice of Manhattan, 96-48, ending the Raiders' season at 16-10. Kenny Anderson had 31 points, 9 steals and 4 assists for Molloy. Hayes (17-10) defeated Xaverian of Brooklyn (15-9) by 68-64. N.B.A. Bulls 97, 76ers 93: Michael Jordan, who scored 36 points, hit a driving layup with 1:13 remaining, then added four free throws for the Bulls last night in Chicago. It was the 76ers' 19th consecutive road loss. Charles Barkley led the 76ers with 32 points and 18 rebounds. (AP)

title: A Baroque Premiere
description: ''Susanna,'' an oratorio by the Italian Baroque composer Alessandro Stradella, is to be given its belated New York premiere 4 P.M. Sunday at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. Offered as part of the Music Before 1800 series, the performance features Margery Daley, a soprano, in the title role. The supporting cast includes Marion Beckenstein, soprano; Jennifer Lane, mezzo-soprano; Michael Brown, tenor, and Robert Kuehn, baritone. The singers are to be accompanied by two violinists, Benjamin Hudson and Jorie Garrigue, and a gambist, Rosamund Morely. Louise Basbas is to direct the work from the organ. Tickets are $9. Information: 666-0675.

title: Murder for Thrill Described at a Trial
description: A 15-year-old defendant on trial here for murder is said to have killed a classmate for a thrill, then showed the corpse to friends who stayed mum about the killing for weeks.

title: Steven Lubin: A Man of Many Modes and Pianos
description: It is perhaps a little easy, at this advanced point in the progress of the early-instrument movement, to forget the practical difficulties it involves for a keyboard player. Steven Lubin, best known as a fortepianist, would be game in theory for the idea of playing his Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin on three different period pianos tomorrow night at the 92d Street Y. But it's easier proposed than tried.

title: Nuclear Plant Closings Could Cost $1 Trillion
description: To the Editor:

title: Contras Insist Cardinal Continue Role in Talks
description: Contra leaders said today that they would insist that Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate continue to play a role in their talks with the Sandinista Government.

title: AIDS Fight: Public Data Or Secret?
description: When a 26-year-old man died in a respirator fire two weeks ago at New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital, the hospital announced he was an AIDS patient, making public the confidential information that had not even been disclosed to his family.

title: PRECISION AEROTECH reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a $176,000 extraordinary charge.

title: Early Celtic Rule in Scandinavia Doubtful
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL U.S. FUNDS NOW HALTED
description: The House of Representatives today unexpectedly defeated a Democratic plan to provide $30.8 million in food, clothing and medical aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. The vote was 216 to 208.

title: 25 Trampled in China
description: Twenty-five people were trampled to death in two Chinese cities, and at least 220 others were injured during celebrations Wednesday of the Lantern Festival. Eighteen people were crushed to death in Xining, capital of Qinghai province, when 100,000 people who turned out to watch a lantern procession panicked, the official New China News Agency said today. Seven people were trampled to death in Lankao county, Henan province, as a crowd of 20,000 dispersed after watching a fireworks show, it said.

title: Mortgage Unit Leaders To Join Blackstone
description: In another example of the unsettled state of Wall Street, the heads of mortgage securities at two large brokerage firms said yesterday that they were leaving to form a venture with a small investment banking ''boutique.''

title: Chancellor Green's Good Fight
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Richard Green, marched to the stage at Erasmus Hall High School yesterday accompanied by six kindergarten students, members of the high school graduating class of the year 2000.

title: PIEDMONT FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 5, 1988.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $365,000 from a writeoff related to redemption of subordinated debt and prepayment penalties on Federal home loan bank advances. c-Net loss d-Includes a charge of $196,000 from redemption of subordinated debt and prepayment penalties.

title: Chairman Sued By Kaisertech
description: In its second lawsuit this week against its own chairman, Kaisertech Ltd. today sought the resignation of Alan E. Clore and charged that he had breached his contract with the company.

title: George V. Horton, 76, Country-Music Singer
description: George Vaughn Horton, a country-music songwriter and performer, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in New Port Richey, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: British-Soviet Contract
description: A British engineering contractor, Simon-Carves Ltd., has signed a contract for $:246 million, or $435 million, to build a plant for making nonstrategic computers in the Soviet Union, British diplomats said today. Each year the plant will be able to turn out 25,000 programmable logic controllers - devices that control conditions like assembly line production.

title: Bond Prices Are Little Changed
description: Note and bond prices were little changed yesterday and remained near their highest levels of the year.

title: Topics of The Times; The President's Line-Item Bluff
description: In his State of the Union address, President Reagan complained about Congressmen who subordinated fiscal policy to politics by inserting extravagant pet projects into the budget - like cranberry and crawfish and wildflower research. Then he challenged them: ''In 30 days, I will send back to you, as recisions, those items which, if I had the authority to line them out, I would do so.''

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Arnett Cobb

title: Where Politicians Feed
description: To the Editor:

title: Expect a Super Tuesday Muddle
description: LEAD: Unanticipated consequences often wreck reforms. This means that Super Tuesday, which was established with the best of intentions, may not turn out so super.

title: Advertising; Ted Chin to Handle Work for Irving Units
description: The Irving Bank Corporation has called on Ted Chin & Company to handle the creation of advertising and collateral material for four of its divisions. The budget is about $2 million.

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results for 1987 include Space- Co. which was acquired in Dec. 1986.

title: Restaurants
description: RICHARD KRAUSE, a tall, reedy Californian, looks more like a bass player for the Grateful Dead circa 1970 than a leading New York chef. An alumnus of Spago in Los Angeles, he made his mark here at Batons, which closed last fall, before opening his own place, called Melrose, last October. After an early shakedown period, both the light salubrious food and the service have improved markedly.

title: Musica Sacra
description: Musica Sacra, under the direction of Richard Westenberg, is to perform Mozart's ''Coronation'' Mass, Verdi's ''Four Sacred Pieces,'' Giovanni Gabrielli's ''In Ecclesiis'' and motets by Richard Strauss at Avery Fisher Hall at 7:30 tonight. Soloists in the Mozart and Strauss works are Rebecca Copley, soprano; Catherine Robbin, mezzo-soprano; Jon Humphrey, tenor, and Kevin McMillan, baritone. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: 874-6770.

title: ALFIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $1,567,000 for the quarter and $2,422,000 for the 6 months.

title: Senate Votes for Limits On Polygraph Testing
description: The Senate today approved a bill that would sharply limit the use of polygraphs to screen job applicants or to test employees in private industry. The vote was 69 to 27.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Figures are in Canadian funds. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect a change in accounting for loan losses. The company said the provision for loan losses in the first quarter was $112 million, down from a restated $136 million a year earlier. It said the 1988 charge includes a general provision for possible future losses but did not indicate the size of the provision. The company also said non-accrual loans totaled $1.9 billion at Jan. 31, a decrease of $360 million from a year earlier and a continued reduction in non-accrual loans is expected through the rest of the year. The bank said its non-interest income was up 15 percent to $246.7 million in the latest quarter from a year earlier due to good performance from its investment banking, foreign exchange and crdit card operations.

title: English Concert
description: The English Concert, which performs on original instruments, is to play works by Haydn, Mozart and C. P. E. Bach at Avery Fisher Hall at 7:30 P.M. Sunday. Trevor Pinnock, the group's director, is to be the soloist in C. P. E. Bach's Concerto for Harpsichord in G (W. 43, No. 5), and Simon Standage is to be the soloist in the Mozart Violin Concerto in G (K. 216). Also on the program are Haydn's Symphonies 38 and 59. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: 874-6770.

title: Economic Scene; Budget Gap Still At Top of Agenda
description: THE top item on the economic agenda confronting Congress and the Presidential candidates remains the Federal budget deficit and how to cut it. The deficit, according to a revised forecast of the Congressional Budget Office to be presented today, will rise to $180 billion in fiscal year 1989 from $157 billion in the current fiscal year. That would increase Federal debt to nearly $2.8 trillion, from $1 trillion eight years ago.

title: College Basketball; Missouri Upsets Oklahoma by 93-90
description: Derrick Chievous had 35 points and 18 rebounds, and Doug Smith broke an 88-88 overtime tie with a slam dunk tonight as Missouri beat fourth-ranked Oklahoma, 93-90, in overtime in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: Middleweights Are Picture of Disdain
description: Late last month Iran Barkley, who will fight Michael Olajide on Sunday at the Felt Forum, bumped into his opponent.

title: U.S. SUSPENDS PLAN TO CUT OFF FUNDS FOR ABORTION TIES
description: The Reagan Administration today suspended its effort to prevent federally financed family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions.

title: PACIFIC NUCLEAR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Revenue
description: b-Net loss

title: Hilton Inquiries
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said it had received unsolicited inquiries about the possible acquisition of its 50 percent interest in Hilton Hawaiian Village, a 22-acre, 2,524-room Waikiki Beach property. The company declined to identify the prospective buyer, but said the suggested $1 billion price was within range of other transactions on comparable properties in Hawaii.

title: AMERICAN TRAVELLERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mets' Fragile Pitchers Pass Their First Test
description: The Mets tested two of the biggest question marks on their pitching staff today, and came up with a couple of small exclamation points.

title: 44 Slain in Sikh-Hindu Violence
description: At least 32 people were killed and 25 wounded when gunmen attacked a village crowd celebrating a Hindu festival in the Punjab Thursday night, the state government said today. Another 12 people were killed in separate incidents Wednesday night.

title: Amid Ghost of His Glory, Hart Says He's Not a Joke
description: Gary Hart's mouth was a thin line of embarrassment as he listened to Scott Hodes, a Chicago lawyer and loyal supporter, argue over a late dinner at an Italian restaurant that the only way to save his campaign was to confront the public's doubts ''head on.''

title: Expert Analyzes Mark Found on Levin's Neck
description: A mark on Jennifer Levin's neck was left by an object ''identical to or similar to'' the face of Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s wristwatch, an expert on analyzing photographs testified yesterday.

title: Road Runners Race
description: Central Park is to be the site for two races Sunday morning sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. At 9:30, a one-quarter mile race for those 2 to 6 years old is to begin at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue. At 10, a five-mile race for men is to begin at the same location, followed at 10:15 by the start of a five-mile race for women. Runners must register at the New York Road Runners Club, 9 East 89th Street; fees range according to age from $5 to $12. Information: 860-4455.

title: Two Chinese Leaders Are at Odds Over Economy
description: Two senior Chinese leaders are struggling over control of fundamental economic policies, diplomats and other foreign specialists here say.

title: A Cappella Groups
description: Betty and the Bobs, two a cappella vocal groups, are to perform Sunday at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Double bills begin at 8 and 11 P.M. tickets are $12.50.

title: Iran and Iraq Report More Missile Attacks
description: Iran and Iraq continued their missile attacks on each other's capital for a fourth day today, according to official reports from the two countries.

title: The Law; Ethics Peril for Lawyer: Seeing a Trial as Drama
description: When Roswell Gilbert pumped two bullets into the brain of his ailing wife of 51 years, Emily, he saw it as an act of mercy. The prosecutor saw it as calculated murder. So did the jury.

title: TV Weekend; Hardy Tale on 'Masterpiece Theater'
description: WITH public television in a pledge period, ''Masterpiece Theater'' has found a self-contained production that, with an intermission for money pitches, fits neatly into a two-hour slot this Sunday evening. ''Day After the Fair,'' produced by Louis Marks for the BBC in association with the Arts & Entertainment Network, gets under way at 9:05 P.M. on Channel 13.

description: b-Net loss

How Southern Democrats View Jackson
METEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects a $767,565 unrealized loss on the company's investment portfolio and a $415,547 write-off of goodwill and intangible assets relating to the company's transformer products segments. c-Net income

title: When Basketball Resembles Hockey
description: BIG East officials expressed such concern about the recent number of brawls in their games that they convened an emergency meeting to extinguish the blaze.

title: TGI Friday Chief Quits To Find His Own Chain
description: J. Michael Jenkins thinks the time is right for acquiring a restaurant chain, and he is leaving his posts as president and chief executive of TGI Friday's Inc. to find one.

title: Nicklaus Finds Trade-In Is a Good Deal
description: Although he calls himself an ''old traditionalist,'' Jack Nicklaus broke with his old ways today and played a competitive round of golf using a metal driver.

title: Professor Is Charged With Lying For Maker of Birth Control Device
description: A Northwestern University professor was indicted today on charges of perjury and obstructing justice in his testimony for the maker of the Dalkon Shield birth-control device.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
CO-OPERATIVE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $1,666,000 from the sale of mortgage servicing rights. c-Includes a net gain of $836,000 from the sale of a branch office.

title: Auctions
description: Jack and Belle Linsky's wide-ranging art collection - Old Master paintings, Renaissance bronzes and jewelry, French 18th-century furniture and European porcelain figures -was thought to have been thoroughly documented in their lifetimes. The couple, who were partners in what Mrs. Linsky used to describe as ''our stationery business'' - it included Swingline, the manufacturer of staplers that they sold to American Brands for $210 million in 1970 - concentrated on buying period works for more than 40 years. In 1982, two years after her husband's death, Mrs. Linsky donated the bulk of their collection, about $60 million worth, to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it is on view in its own galleries.

title: DRUG TESTS SOUGHT FOR AIRLINE JOBS
description: The Transportation Department today proposeda wide range of drug tests for more than a half million airline employees, from pilots to mechanics, although officials acknowledged they had no clear evidence of a drug problem in the industry.

title: A Big Weekend For the Big East
description: As Seton Hall ran out the final seconds of its upset victory in Pittsburgh Wednesday night, Jim Boeheim, the Syracuse head coach, stared at his television set, first in disbelief, then in amazement.

title: G.E. Shows Lower Profit
description: The General Electric Company, the nation's largest producer of electrical equipment, said in its 1987 annual report released this week that it earned $398 million, or 44 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987, compared with $730 million, or 80 cents a share, a year earlier. Earnings for the quarter had not previously been disclosed.

title: 2 Held in Execution-Style Slaying Of Officer Outside Queens House
description: Two men have been arrested and will be charged in connection with the execution-style killing of a rookie police officer early last Friday, the authorities announced late last night.

title: DIVERSIFIED RETAIL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $48,806 gain from the sale of a store.

title: Franco Scalamandre, 89, Leader In Making of Decorative Textiles
description: Franco Scalamandre, a co-founder of Scalamandre Inc., one of the nation's most prestigious manufacturers and distributors of decorative textiles, trimmings, carpeting and wall coverings, died Tuesday at his home in Plandome Manor, L.I., after a long illness. He was 89 years old. Mr. Scalamandre, a leader in historical textile reproductions, developed his interest in restoration projects for more than half a century.

title: White House Chooses Chef From Within
description: The White House has selected its new executive chef, the first to have been promoted from within the ranks of the kitchen staff, according to Gary Walters, chief usher.

title: Bank Bill Compromise Seen Aiding Prospects
description: The willingness of the 18 Senate Banking Committee members to agree to a compromise package in approving a landmark banking bill on Wednesday night will go a long way toward securing passage in the full Senate this spring, Senators and Banking Committee aides said today.

title: Diet Candy Seeking Name
description: The manufacturer of the diet candy Ayds is seeking a new name for its product because publicity about the deadly disease AIDS is hurting sales, the chairman said today.

title: PANCRETEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Final Say Over Films At Issue
description: The film makers Steven Spielberg and George Lucas asked a skeptical Senate panel today to give artists final rights over their works, including the unapproved coloring of classic motion pictures.

title: Dollar Stable in Light Day While Gold Shows Decline
description: The dollar was little changed against major currencies yesterday, and trading activity was the lightest in more than a year, according to some dealers.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said general and administrative expenses for the latest and third quarter increased due to professional fees and other expenses relating to litigation and proxy contests involving the company's 40 percent owned subsidary, Direct Action Marketing Inc., and the SEC investigation involving prior management's financial and accounting controls. The company also said it recorded an additional loss of $271,000 in the quarter in connection with the disposition of assets.

title: Batus Bid for Farmers Raised to $63 a Share
description: Rebuffed in its first attempt to acquire Farmers Group Inc., Batus Inc. sweetened its tender offer today to $63 a share, or a total of about $4.5 billion, for the nation's seventh-largest insurance holding company. Batus's original offer was $60 a share.

title: Piano Recital
description: Marilyn Crispell is to play a piano recital tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (662-2133). Admission is free.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter results were affected by a donation of about $118,000 of several slow moving products to a charitable organization.

title: Film: 'Girl From Hunan'
description: ''GIRL FROM HUNAN,'' one of the first films from China to receive commercial release in this country, is a plea for the rights of women as reflected in the sad consequences of the arranged marriage of a peasant girl, Xiao Xiao, 12, and a 2-year-old boy, Chun Guan.

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS ASSOC (HOUSTON) reports earnings for
description: b-Net income For the latest second quarter, the company provided $43.7 million in reserves for possible losses on loans, accrued interest, real estate investments, and other receivables; a year earlier the company had reserve provisions of $38 million. For the first six months of fiscal 1988, the company had $62.3 million in reserve provisions, compared to $43.8 million a year earlier. Total loss provisions at Dec. 31, 1987, were $179 million.

title: Shultz's Handicap: No Meetings With Palestinians
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has been handicapped in his search for an Arab-Israeli negotiating formula by his inability to meet with Palestinian leaders.

title: Belgium Bidder Must List Allies
description: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti must identify his allies before Government regulators will allow an extension of his offer for Societe Generale de Belgique S.A., Belgium's biggest holding company, a banking commission official said today.

title: Art: 3 Shows at Brooklyn Museum
description: DESPITE its relatively low profile among New York City's leading art institutions, the Brooklyn Museum remains conspicuously active. Three diverse shows have recently been mounted by the ambitious institution, which at the same time is organizing a tremendous expansion. Starting next Friday, master plans by the five finalists who competed to redesign the museum will be publicly displayed for the first time. The jury's choice, a team headed by Arata Isozaki and James Stewart Polshek, is already plotting the first phase - renovation of the old west wing - in an effort intended eventually to double the institution's current size.

title: 3 Whites Seized In Bronx Attack On Some Blacks
description: Three white men, apparently angered during an exchange with a black prostitute, beat the woman with a baseball bat early yesterday and then randomly attacked black people in the West Farms section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: Contra Aid: Ups and Downs in Congress
description: The House rejection of a contra aid plan yesterday continued a fluctuating pattern of Congressional support for such assistance. The fiscal-year figures below do not include money from other sources - for example, from a contingency fund, from third countries, or from the Iran-contra arms sales. 1982: $19 million (covert)

title: SYSTEM SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflects a change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Korea's Trade Surplus
description: South Korea's trade surplus more than tripled in February from a year earlier on the strength of exports, the Government reported this week. It said that last month's surplus rose to $524 million from $158 million in the 1987 period. The surplus for the first two months of this year rose to $810 million from $683 million, it said. In 1987, South Korea posted a trade surplus of $6.26 billion.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''I DON'T believe it - there he is!'' gasped the beefy, assiduously coiffed businessman as he walked toward the bar, gawking, open jawed, like a 10-year-old watching a flying saucer approach his bedroom.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Eugene H. O'Sullivan has joined McCann-Erickson's New York agency as executive vice president, deputy general manager.

title: Unity Stressed at NATO Summit But Tough Issues Are Unresolved
description: The Western allies issued a broad statement of unity today at the close of a two-day summit conference, but tough decisions, including a timetable for modernizing short-range nuclear weapons, remained unresolved.

title: LIFELINE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $142,000. c-Net loss and includes pretax charges of $230,000 for termination costs, $460,000 for inventory excess and valuation allowances, and $200,000 for warranty provisions. d-Includes a tax credit of $83,000.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized gains of $14,431,000 for the quarter and $97,478,000 for the year. c-Includes realized gains of $93,957,000 and $139,224,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The latest quarter also includes pretax foreign exchange losses of $426,000 and the year includes pretax foreign exchange gains of $2,548,000. Year-ago quarter and year includes pretax foreign exchange gains of $1,357,000 and $1,093,000, respectively. The company said operating results for the 1987 fourth quarter included a ''fresh start'' tax benefit, which reduced the provision for income taxes by about $33 million; included in the full-year 1987, was a similar benefit of $110 million, or 67 cents a share.

title: Dr. Beverly Smith, 92; Helped Found Hospital
description: Dr. Beverly Chew Smith, a general surgeon and a founder of Doctors Hospital, died of a heart ailment Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
New Zealand Deal
description: New Zealand's largest company bought the Government's 70 percent stake in a local oil and gas explorer and distributor for about $528 million, the State-Owned Enterprises Minister, Richard Prebble, announced. Fletcher Challenge Ltd. will pay the same per-share price for the Government's stake in the Petroleum Corporation of New Zealand as British Gas earlier offered. The Government terminated the previous agreement to sell the stake in the company, known as Petrocorp, when it objected to conditions sought by the British Gas Corporation.

title: Kentucky Reprimanded
description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation of the basketball program at the University of Kentucky, started by a series of newspaper articles, produced no proof of wrongdoing, according to David Berst, the N.C.A.A. director of enforcement. In the official finding the Committee on Infractions released yesterday, Kentucky was reprimanded for not fully cooperating with the long investigation and was ordered to monitor athletic expenditures and report their results to the N.C.A.A. for the next three years. The Lexington Herald-Leader won a Pulitzer prize for investigative journalism in 1986 for its stories detailing corruption in the Kentucky program. The newspaper articles quoted former players as saying that Kentucky recruits received cash, clothing and other gifts dating to the early 1970's. ''Out of 33 individuals quoted in the articles, 32 told us they were either misquoted or quoted out of context,'' Berst said. Berst said his requests to examine the newspaper's tapes or notes or to interview the reporters were denied. The newspaper's editor, John S. Carroll, said: ''We're not an arm of the N.C.A.A. or any other organization. If we have materials that deserve to be read, it will be read by our readers.''

title: Henryk Szeryng, Violinist, Dies; Player in Romantic Style Was 69
