description: Henryk Szeryng, one of the more elegant representatives of a now fading school of Romantic violin playing, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday in Kassel, West Germany. Mr. Szeryng was en route to Brussels for a concert celebrating the current NATO conference and for an appearance at an AIDS benefit. He was 69 years old.

title: LaFontaine to Rest
description: Pat LaFontaine, the leading scorer for the Islanders this season, did not practice yesterday and is listed as doubtful for the team's games tomorrow and Sunday. LaFontaine, whose streak of 161 consecutive games ended Wednesday night when he sat out the 3-1 loss to the Rangers, has been hampered by a sore right knee that was bruised in a game against the Vancouver Canucks nine days ago. . . . The Rangers, who lost Norm Maciver to a shoulder dislocation in the game against the Islanders, are expected to replace him with Jari Gronstrand in games against Buffalo and Hartford this weekend. Gronstrand missed the last several weeks with sprained ligaments in his knee. . . . Steve Yzerman, leading scorer of the Detroit Red Wings, won't require surgery to repair a severed knee ligament, but will miss the rest of the regular season and likely the playoffs.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Eric Bell and John Habyan, pitchers, and Fritsroy Marsham, third baseman. Signed Bob Gibson, pitcher, to a minor league contract. Named Jim Simpson play-by-play announcer. BOSTON (AL) - Signed Steve Curry and Steve Ellsworth, pitchers, and Angel Gonzalez, infielder. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Kal Daniels, outfielder, and Rob Murphy and Jose Rijo, pitchers, to one-year contracts. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed B. J. Surhoff, catcher. YANKEES (AL) - Signed Lee Guetterman, pitcher, and Jay Buhner, outfielder. BASKETBALL L.A. CLIPPERS (NBA) - Placed Joe Wolf, forward, on the injured list. PHILADELPHIA (NBA) - Signed David Henderson, guard, to a 10-day contract. PORTLAND (NBA) - Activated Steve Johnson, center, from the injured list. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Signed Scott Leach, linebacker. HOCKEY EDMONTON (NHL) - Signed Grant Fuhr, goaltender, and Randy Gregg, defenseman, to multiyear contracts. MINNESOTA (NHL) - Recalled Chris Pryor and Jay Caulfield, defensemen, from Kalamazoo of the International Hockey League. Assigned Manny Viveiros, defensemen, to Kalamazoo. DEVILS (NHL) - Assigned Chris Terreri, goaltender, and Murray Brumwell, defenseman, to Utica of the American Hockey League. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Recalled Robert Dirk, defenseman, from Peoria of the International Hockey League. VANCOUVER (NHL) - Named Mike Murphy assistant coach. Assigned Dave Lowry, forward, to Fredericton of the American Hockey League. COLLEGES FLORIDA - Announced that Tony Williams, forward, had been removed from the basketball team for the rest of the season because he has not fully recovered from a preseason injury. KENT STATE - Named Jack Sells defensive back coach, Doug Klein quarterback coach, and Bob Stoops inside linebacker coach. MARQUETTE - Announced that it is joining the Midwestern Collegiate Conference effective September 1. WEDNESDAY BASEBALL METS (NL) - Signed Len Dykstra and Mark Carreon, outfielders; Kevin Elster, shortstop; Jose Roman, Randy Myers, and Jack Savage, pitchers and Darren Reed, catcher, to one-year contracts. Renewed the contracts of Gene Walter, pitcher, and Randy Milligan, first baseman. Fined Darryl Strawberry, outfielder, $100 for reporting late for a workout. Named Gary Carter co-captain.

title: The Secret Treaty
description: Why does it take the Reagan Administration so long to learn terribly important lessons? It is a puzzlement.

title: Looking Foolish on the P.L.O.
description: Pandering to Israel's supposed interests, Congress ordered the Justice Department to shut down the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission at the United Nations. This move showed contempt for international law and American ideals of free speech, and Congress now reaps the humiliating rewards.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CROP GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 418 money market mutual funds decreased $1.51 billion, to $278.51 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $1.28 billion, to $81.74 billion. Assets of the 208 general-purpose funds were up $230.5 million, to $81.67 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds decreased $457.8 million, to $115.1 billion.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Liliane Montevecchi

title: Cuomo's Health Chief: Innovation and Influence
description: How out of place David Axelrod seems in the halls of the State Capitol.

title: Topics of The Times; Monumental Indifference
description: For more than a million sunrises, the Egyptian sphinx has guarded the Pharaohs' mysteries with implacable calm. Nothing has shattered its unblinking meditation; a cannonball fired by Napoleon's army only broke its nose.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $600,000. c-Includes tax benefits of $166,000 and $1,865,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: UNITED COASTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a capital loss of $171,840 and $97,952 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a capital gain of $1,010.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY BOURKE-WHITE PHOTOS

title: Sewall Wright, 98, Who Formed Mathematical Basis for Evolution
description: Sewall Wright, a geneticist who was widely regarded as the foremost American evolutionary theorist of the 20th century, died of complications yesterday after suffering a hip fracture Sunday in Madison, Wis., where he lived. He was 98 years old. Dr. Wright, an avid walker, suffered the injury when he slipped on the ice near his apartment. He died at Meriter-Madison General Hospital.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Retaliation
description: Late last year, Congress banned Japanese companies from partipating in new American public works contracts.

title: AIDS PANEL BACKS WIDE DRIVE IN U.S.
description: The President's AIDS Commission today approved a wide-ranging set of recommendations that call for a $2 billion-a-year national effort to expand drug treatment programs and other health services to combat the AIDS epidemic.

title: Film: 'House on Carroll St.'
description: ''THE HOUSE ON CARROLL STREET'' unfolds in a beautiful, clean city, a place of safe subways and balmy summer breezes, a peaceful, romantic urban landscape bathed in warm golden light. This place, strange and delightful as it may seem, is in fact New York. But the city's appearance (which is made spectacularly lovely by Michael Ballhaus's magical cinematography) is deceptive, for the time is 1951. The political climate is as sinister as the physical setting is serene.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest year includes charges totaling $17,889,000, net of tax benefits, from restructuring costs and expenses connected with discontinued operations. Most of the charges were recorded in the fourth quarter. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split on Nov. 23.

title: A Two-Way Street
description: Leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are on the right track in switching their emphasis in conventional arms negotiations from troops to weapons. But negotiations are always a two-way street and it's not clear what kind of ''balance'' NATO leaders want and what they'll be willing to pay for it.

title: In Hebron, a Knifing and Then Purim
description: The knifing of a Jewish teen-ager was followed today by a Purim carnival parade in this city of 70,000 Palestinians encircling 40 Jewish families. The events produced a confrontation of faiths and visions so raw it almost hurt to witness them.

title: 3 Dropouts Look Kindly on Process That Dashed Hopes for Presidency
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. said he should have started his failed campaign for President five or six years sooner. Pete du Pont insisted he ''wouldn't change'' the primary system that made him an early casualty. Bruce Babbitt remembered the New Hampshire voter who supported him because he had properly used the word ''oxymoron.''

title: Stake in Christie's Bought by Phillips
description: Phillips Son & Neale, a London auction house, said it had acquired a 5 percent stake in the much larger Christie's. The auction house bought 1.6 million shares from a Kuwaiti investor, the Al Futtooh Investment Company.

title: Butler Is Seeking Larger Bear Stake
description: A group led by the New York-based Butler Capital Corporation, an investment banking firm, is asking Federal antitrust regulators for permission to increase its holdings in Big Bear Inc. to up to 25 percent from 8.8 percent. Butler has said previously that it was considering a merger with Big Bear.

title: New York City Ought to Have a Museum Pass
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole and Gore Gain Campaign Backing From Three Leaders
description: Senator Bob Dole gained an endorsement yesterday from Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, while Senator Albert Gore Jr. won backing from a Governor and a Governor-elect.

title: PROFIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 31
U2 Wins Top Grammy Prize
description: ''Honest music,'' said Bono Vox of U2, won two top Grammy Awards for the Irish rock band and its album, ''The Joshua Tree.'' At the 30th annual Grammy Awards ceremony, telecast live from Radio City Music Hall Wednesday night after six years of broadcasts from Los Angeles, U2 won album of the year and best rock performance by a duo or group. Onstage, Bono Vox mentioned his political concerns over South Africa; backstage, he insisted, ''We're slipstream, not mainstream.''

title: Charles Feinberg, 88, A Whitman Collector
description: Charles E. Feinberg, a book and manuscript collector who specialized in the works of Walt Whitman, died Tuesday of heart failure at Mt. Sinai Hospital in Miami. He was 88 years old and maintained residences in Detroit and Florida.

title: Spotlighting the Stars Of New York Cabaret
description: ACROSS New York this evening, as stage lights dim on the first night of the first weekend of Cabaret Month, the mood of the city's nightlife should be unusually buoyant. Because of the recent overturning of a law forbidding clubs without cabaret licenses to have more than three musicians (including a singer) onstage together, many clubs will have more musicians than they could have had a year or even two months ago. For musicians, the change in the law means more work for more players, while cabaret patrons will be rewarded with more music and fuller shows for their money.

title:
About Real Estate;
Astoria Housing Features a River View
description: LEAD: Despite its broad view of Manhattan, the waterfront in Astoria, Queens, has not attracted much residential construction because of its industrial character.

title: James Webb In Contract For Novel
description: James Webb, who resigned recently as Secretary of the Navy, signed a contract with Random House yesterday for a novel that he expects to complete in about 18 months.

title: Art: Five Sculptures By Richard Deacon
description: RICHARD DEACON'S second solo show at the Marian Goodman Gallery offers New Yorkers the best evidence yet why this 38-year-old Briton is one of the best sculptors around. The five very different works, all at the same time eminently reasonable and wildly enigmatic, give a clear sense what this artist's seductive and demanding sculpture is about.

title: Tolleson's Job Slips Away
description: The mornings begin to blend into one another down here. Players - from veterans to rookies hoping to make a lasting impression - follow identical routines: they arrive as the sun is still rising, change into their uniforms, read the local newspaper, pour themselves cups of coffee. Every day at the same time, they gather on the outfield grass to stretch and to work.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1988
description: International A3-11

title: 6 Violin Styles
description: Masters of the Folk Violin is to present six violinists in traditional styles - Cajun music from Michael Doucet, jazz from Claude Williams, Irish music from Seamus Connolly, bluegrass music from Kenny Baker, Cape Breton music from Joe Cormier, country music from Alison Krauss - tomorrow at 8 at Julia Richman High School, 317 East 67th Street. Tickets are $8 in advance, $10 at the door; information, (718) 343-1431 or (718) 392-0053.

title: ESI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $213,809. The latest quarter and year include results for Contempri Homes Inc. and Supreme-Jannell, acquired Dec. 30, 1986 and July 23, 1987, respectively. Share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in November.

title: Market Place; Temporary Help In Great Demand
description: THE wave of corporate takeovers and restructurings, along with other business trends, is fattening the coffers of the nation's suppliers of temporary employees, according to people familiar with the temporary-help industry.

title: New Big Board Official Versed in Automation
description: Richard A. Grasso, a man instrumental in improving the back office operations of the New York Stock Exchange, was named yesterday as the exchange's next president, replacing Robert J. Birnbaum, who is retiring. The appointment becomes effective on June 2.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a suit by a group of homosexual Catholics against trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan misidentified the law under which the group, Dignity, contends its rights have been violated. It is Section 1983 of Title 42 of the United States Code, which was enacted shortly after the Civil War.

title: A Black Woman Is Sworn In As Justice in Pennsylvania
description: Juanita Kidd Stout was sworn in today as a Justice of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, becoming the first black woman in the nation to sit on a state's highest court.

title: INTELLIGENT ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Officials Criticize Soviet On Verification Negotiations
description: The United States criticized the Soviet Union today for refusing to engage in detailed talks on verification issues for a treaty to reduce long-range arms.

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $3.6 million and $6.4 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from merger-related expenses. c-Includes a gain of $991,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PLASMA-TERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $401,000 and $260,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: GREASE MONKEY HOLDING CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss The company said it restated prior year's earnings to reflect a change in the method for accounting for area development fees.

title: 2 Tax System Changes Favored by Greenspan
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, spoke out today in favor of making two contentious changes in the tax system - the imposition of consumption taxes and a reduction in the capital gains tax.

title: Study of AIDS Patients Finds No New Infectious Pathways
description: A study of 2,059 AIDS patients who appeared to have become infected from unknown sources has found no new pathways for the spread of the deadly disease, Federal researchers have reported.

title: Bridge: Computer Company Drew An Expert Field to Taiwan
description: World championships apart, tournaments that bring together expert teams from many parts of the world are, for economic reasons, a rarity.

title: U.S. Wine Export Spurt
description: Soaring sales to Japan and Britain helped to send total United States wine exports in 1987 to 11.87 million gallons, up 64 percent from the previous year, the Wine Institute, a trade group, has reported. The dollar's decline was the main cause, the institute said Wednesday. United States exports totaled $60.8 million in 1987, up from $34.8 million the year before.

title: U.S. Agency Head Says He Will Resign For Private Reasons
description: The head of the General Services Administration, Terence C. Golden, said late yesterday he planned to resign on March 18.

title: Film: 'Babette's Feast'
description: ''Babettes's Feast'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times Oct. 1, 1987. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said it had received a $112 million order from Transavia Airlines of the Netherlands for four 737-300 jetliners for delivery in 1989 and 1990.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dean Witter Reynolds (Canada) Inc., Toronto, which is affiliated with the Sears Financial Network in the United States, appointed Peter K. Lundgren executive vice president and director of retail sales, marketing and training.

title: Brain Graft Seeks to Relieve Huntington Disease Patient
description: Doctors have removed an adrenal gland from a 41-year-old man and grafted it into his brain in an attempt to relieve symptoms of Huntington's disease, a fatal brain disorder.

title: INSIDE
description: Polygraph Limits Voted The Senate voted to limit the use of polygraphs in screening job applicants or testing employees. Page A21. Schools Chief Inaugurated Dr. Richard R. Green appealed for support to help him turn the New York City Schools around. Page B1.

title: FINAL DECISION DUE IN SWAGGART CASE
description: National officials of the Assemblies of God, unable to agree with Louisiana leaders of the pentecostal denomination on a punishment for the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart, have passed the case to an appeals body for the final decision.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from favorable settlement of lawsuits of $2.7 million for the quarter and $11 million for the year. c-Net loss

title: Welfare Isn't A Way Of Life
description: The number 19 recently became more than a number to me for reasons that are both different and related.

title: Chip Group Urges Japan Sanctions
description: American semiconductor manufacturers are pressing for additional sanctions against Japan, contending that their Japanese sales at the end of last year were $200 million less than they should have been under an 18-month-old pact.

title: The Law; Law Firms, Too, Hire Lawyers by the Hour
description: The demand may not be what it could be, but as Lesley Friedman found last fall when she started her agency to provide lawyers for temporary assignment to law firms, the supply is there.

title: Candidates' TV Ads Produce Shifts in South, Survey Finds
description: The final days of campaigning for the Southern Presidential contests next Tuesday are producing some dramatic shifts in voter sentiment, largely because of television commercials, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After pretax gain of $2.7 million from sale of Broad Street property for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $419,000 on the exchange of shares for debentures and other exchanges. c-Net loss includes a loss of $115,000 from adjustment of a tax credit. d-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $8,096,000 from tax credits and a pretax gain of $17.2 million from the sale of a foreign subsidiary.

title: Art: The Taut Paintings Of Philip Pearlstein
description: IT may be difficult to like Philip Pearlstein's paintings, with their perpetual rearrangements of inert, expressionless and usually female nudes. Still, it is also difficult not to respect them. This mixed response, a dilemma of sorts, has never been clearer than it is at the artist's current exhibition of new paintings at Hirschl & Adler Modern. However, it has never seemed easier to resolve. One of his most impressive to date, this show lays out the complexity and ambition of Mr. Pearlstein's undertaking with unusual force.

title: Goalie Joins Devils on Decline
description: The Devils were totally dispirited after their 6-1 loss to Washington Wednesday night. It was their second loss in two nights to the Capitals and the fifth in their last six games, making New Jersey the front-runner to be the first team eliminated from a playoff spot in the Patrick Division.

title: Toyota to Export Wente Bros. Wine
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said that its United States unit would enter the wine exporting business. Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. said it would ship California wine made by the Wente Brothers vineyard to Japan. The first sale of 29,000 bottles went to Japan Railways Tokai Inc. The wine will be used in meal service aboard trains in Japan.

title: New Cable Programming Backed
description: Ted Turner, chairman of the Turner Broadcasting System, announced yesterday that a number of major cable television operators had tentatively approved the creation of a new basic cable service offering entertainment programming.

title: Foe Seeks to Revive Suit
description: An attorney for Mr. Swaggart argued in a state appeals court here today that Mr. Swagaart and his colleagues had been bound by church rules and the Bible to spread their accusations of adultery against a rival evangelist, Marvin Gorman.

title: Our Towns; To Be Elderly And Unwanted In Mohegan Lake
description: This is the shameful story of how a respected local nonprofit group has tried to winterize four summer cottages to house eight elderly poor people - and how neighbors and town officials have fought them so that the case has dragged on three years. It's a good story to know the next time someone asks how a wealthy suburban county like Westchester could have one of the worst homeless problems in America.

title: Edwards Goes Home
description: Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards, the British rookie ski jumper who pursued mediocrity at the XV Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, last month, returned yesterday to a hero's welcome in a motorcade in his hometown of Cheltenham, England. ''I'm not letting this go to my head,'' he said. ''I'm determined to keep my feet on the ground. Except when I'm ski-jumping, of course.''

title: CHARLOTTE CHARLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AFG Stock Jumps To $37 a Share
description: AFG Industries' shares jumped sharply today as the glassmaker found itself holding competing bids from its chairman and a group of outsiders, both of whom are trying to take the company private. With more than 2.1 million shares traded, AFG's shares climbed $4.75, to $37, on the New York Stock Exchange. It was among the Big Board's biggest gainers and most heavily traded issues.

title: Reed Works Magic for Nets
description: It was not easy to get through by phone to the New Jersey Nets' offices yesterday at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. A ''please hold'' greeted most callers to the home of the team with a 14-42 record.

title: AIDS Patients Are Found to Have an Extremely High Suicide Rate
description: AIDS patients are committing suicide at a far higher rate than the general population, and at a higher rate even than among people with other fatal diseases, according to a new study of patients in New York City.

title: Art People
description: Japanese Influence

title: Unemployment: The Biggest States
description: Civilian unemployment in January and February. Figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: Flaws Found in Shuttle Safety Study
description: The space agency has many groups assigned to assess the safety of launching space shuttles, but its efforts are fragmented and lack objective measures for evaluating the hazards, a National Research Council panel said in a report made public today.

title: Southland Sells Reddy Ice Unit
description: The Southland Corporation said it had sold its Reddy Ice subsidiary to the Kaminski-Engles Capital Corporation, an investment firm, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Reddy Ice is a major producer of fragmentary ice and operates seven plants in Texas, Florida and Nevada.

title: MECHAM TRIAL TOLD OF AIDE'S THREAT
description: An official told Gov. Evan Mecham's impeachment trial today that when she tried to tell an aide to Mr. Mecham about a death threat it was dismissed as ''just a bunch of hot air.''

title: Piano: Mark Anderson
description: Mark Anderson, an American pianist now completing his studies in Manchester, England, chose a conservative but technically demanding program for his New York debut Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Technically, he was up to the challenge, and he sailed through four Scarlatti sonatas, Beethoven's Sonata in C minor (Op. 111), Brahms's Sonata in F minor (Op. 5) and five Debussy preludes with astonishing fluidity and finger power.

title: CHANCELLOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW HIRINGS PUSH THE JOBLESS RATE TO AN 8 1/2-YEAR LOW
description: More than half a million new jobs were created last month and the nation's unemployment rate eased one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent, the lowest level in eight and a half years.

title: Tribute to Howser
description: Dick Howser's name and likeness became a permanent part of Florida State University's baseball heritage yesterday as the school began a scholarship program and named its baseball complex in Tallahassee in Howser's memory. The Kansas City Royals, whom Howser guided to a World Series championship in 1985, joined in the festivities as Dick Howser Stadium was officially dedicated in honor of the former major league player and manager who died of brain cancer last June at the age of 50. A new $175,000 scoreboard carrying Howser's name and a bronze bust were commemorated during a half-hour dedication ceremony. Bernard Sliger, the president of Florida State, announced plans to endow a $650,000 project to finance the school's 13 baseball scholarships, which will be awarded in the future as Dick Howser championship scholarships. Howser was an all-America player for Florida State in 1957.

title: South Carolina Votes Today In Test of Bush's Momentum
description: Three contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination crisscrossed the state today, striving to pull their campaigns out of the doldrums in time for the South Carolina primary on Saturday and the Republican balloting in 17 other states on Tuesday.

title: Progress at Greek-Turkish Talks
description: The Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey continued a month-old effort to move toward reconciliation today by agreeing to set up committees to deal with two contentious questions: people declared missing after the fighting in Cyprus in 1974, and military flights in airspace claimed by the other.

title: Israel Curbs Coverage of the West Bank
description: Israel sought for the first time today to close the entire occupied West Bank to journalists, but a military spokesman denied that the move represented new restrictions on coverage.

title: Twain Exonerated
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income d-After gains from discontinued operations of $4,000 and $266,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $530,000 for the quarter and a gain of $7,346,000 for the year both from the disposal of discontinued operations. The latest year is after a third quarter aftertax writedown of $1.2 million from ''the space works'' multimedia project.

title: Rhoden Enjoys Spring Debut
description: On any other day, Rick Rhoden would have spent the afternoon boasting about his hitting. But today, after he pitched for the first time in almost six months and tested his right shoulder, he hardly seemed concerned about Manager Billy Martin's successful experiment batting him second in the lineup.

title: Newtown Advances
description: Fred Smith, a 6-foot-9-inch senior, snatched the rebound of a teammate's shot and scored a game-winning lay-in with 2 seconds left in overtime yesterday to give Newtown a 56-55 victory over Springfield Gardens in a Public Schools Athletic League quarterfinal playoff game at John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens. It was Newtown's 25th consecutive victory of the season and gave the team a berth in the semifinals March 13 at Brandeis. Springfield Gardens, the defending P.S.A.L. champion, finished with a 20-5 record. The victory made Newtown the Queens borough champion.

title: Congested And Achy? It's Not Flu
description: A high fever lasting several days, accompanied by a variety of other symptoms, has been sending people in the New York metropolitan area home from work and school in droves.

title: Sandinistas Go on the Political Offensive
description: With social tensions increasing in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government is striking back against growing pressure for another round of political concessions.

title:
Your Money;
Financial Vows In Remarriages
description: LEAD: Financial factors must play a part in the planning of any marriage, but there are special considerations for divorced and widowed people who intend to marry again.

title: No Clowning, Please
description: One day after he walked off the field and called his teammates clowns for playing a practical joke on him, Kirk Gibson, the new millionaire with the Los Angeles Dodgers after nine years in Detroit, returned to the outfield yesterday for an exhibition game against the Minnesota Twins. Gibson was about to make his debut in Dodger blue Thursday in Vero Beach, Fla., when he discovered that someone had smeared eye black inside his cap and that it had rubbed off on his head. Yesterday, before starting in left field and batting third, he questioned his teammates' dedication. ''I told Tommy Lasorda that now I can understand why the Dodgers finished fifth the past two seasons,'' Gibson told The Ann Arbor (Mich.) News. ''They have their priorities wrong.'' Lasorda said the matter had been resolved following a meeting with Gibson, who signed a $4.5 million contract as a free agent in January. The manager also said the players had agreed to lighten up on their lighter moments.

title: Doral Lead Is Kept By Bobby Wadkins
description: When Chip Beck won the Los Angeles Open last Sunday for his first victory in the 10 years he has been on the PGA Tour, Bobby Wadkins became the only golfer to have earned more than $1 million on the Tour without a single victory.

title: New York Is Readying Effort to Gain Control of Lilco
description: The Long Island Power Authority, the state agency considering a takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, said today that it was preparing to begin taking the steps necessary to win control of the utility.

title: Arbitrager Is Accused Of Boesky Death Threat
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., once one of Wall Street's leading arbitrage specialists, threatened to kill Ivan F. Boesky and another witness in an investigation after an employee from Mr. Mulheren's firm was subpoenaed by a grand jury, a Federal prosecutor asserted yesterday.

title: KEY RATES
ENGINEERED SUPPORT SYSFTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: General Services Chief to Quit
description: The head of the General Services Administration, Terence C. Golden, said Thursday that he planned to resign on March 18.

title: Data on Jobless Fail to Relieve Koch's Gloom
description: Despite data showing unemployment in the New York region at its lowest level in almost 18 years, Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the consequences of the stock market plunge in October might yet undermine the city's economy.

title: ECOGEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Minority Contractors Protest Rule That Gives Women Similar Status
description: A new Federal regulation that classifies women as members of a minority group in the awarding of highway construction contracts has touched off a bitter protest here and threatens to pit women against minority contractors nationwide.

title: Jazz: Wayne Shorter Band
description: If anyone can turn jazz-rock into personal, volatile music, Wayne Shorter can. The saxophonist and composer has brought a new quintet to the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, where he's appearing through tomorrow. The other groups Mr. Shorter has led since he left Weather Report in 1985 have simply supplied a beat and crescendos behind his incandescent solos, but his current quintet promises to join Mr. Shorter's forays as well as support them.

title: Woman Hurt in Fall As She Flees a Blaze
description: A woman fell five stories yesterday while trying to escape an apartment fire that the authorities said was set by a man who had argued with her roommate.

title: COMPRESSION LABS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $668,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $132,000 for the year.

title: 3 Quit a U.S. Panel in Protest
description: Three prominent conservatives have resigned from the Reagan Administration's Panel on Teen Pregnancy Prevention, charging that it is doing more to promote teen-age sex than prevent it.

title: Jury in Chambers Trial Inspects Site of Killing
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. went to Central Park yesterday for a cold and muddy tour through the trees just off the East Drive, where Jennifer Levin's body was found. They stayed about eight minutes before returning to their buses.

title: GUIDEPOST
description: Mortgage Shopping As spring approaches, the start of the home-buying season begins. Just in time, mortgage rates have been dropping. A fixed-rate 30-year mortgage is lower than last years' high of about 11.25 percent, while an adjustable-rate mortgage is down from about 8.25 percent. Adjustable rates are attractive to first-time home buyers as well as trade-up buyers because of the initial low rate. But many lenders have recently tightened requirements for first-time borrowers if they have less than 20 percent to put down. In that case, the borrower has to qualify on the basis of his or her ability to pay the higher second-year interest rate. Listed are the most common types of mortgages and average rates. Fees and points vary according to the lender. Type of mortgage End of February January Fixed rate 30 years 9.75% 10.25% 15 years 9.50 10.00 Adjustable rate Adjusted every year; usually has a one-year treasury bill as a base, with a 2 percent annual cap and 6 percent lifetime cap 7.50 7.75 Convertible-adjustable: An adjustable rate with a one-time conversion to a fixed rate. 7.50 7.75 (Source: Federal National Mortgage Association)

title: Robertson Allowed to Drop Libel Suit if He Pays Defense Court Costs
description: A Federal district judge agreed today to allow Pat Robertson to drop his libel suit against Paul N. McCloskey Jr., a former California Congressman, if the Republican Presidential candidate agreed to pay Mr. McCloskey's court costs.

title: Care of Mental Patients Challenged in Lawsuit
description: As an emergency program to relieve overcrowding in New York City psychiatric wards got under way, an advocacy group filed a lawsuit yesterday charging that city hospitals were illegally turning away hundreds of other mentally ill people.

title: Yankees and Mets Planning to Meet
description: The Yankees and the Mets, who last December began discussing the possibility of a preseason exhibition series in New York, are drawing closer to an agreement and could begin playing each other next year. They have not met since 1985.

title: Gephardt Ads Accuse Dukakis of 'Tricks'
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, stung by advertising that lists his corporate contributors, today began running a commercial that accused Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of ''dirty tricks.''

title: Some See Bungling on Morgan Bond Plan, But Others Call It a Guide to Future Moves
description: Although many bankers are blaming the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the United States Treasury for bungling a novel plan to cut Mexico's foreign debt, even most critics agree that the move was a bold attempt to help solve the third-world debt crisis that has plagued the world economy for much of this decade.

title: BURGER KING INVESTORS MASER L P reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Offer for Weak Rover: What's the Allure?
description: As acquisition candidates go, the Rover Group P.L.C., Britain's largest auto maker, is hardly a prize.

title: J. Saunders Redding, 81, Is Dead; Pioneer Black Ivy League Teacher
description: J. Saunders Redding, a historian who is believed to have been the first black to teach at an Ivy League institution, died of heart failure Wednesday at his home in Ithaca, N. Y. He was 81 years old.

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for 16wks to Jan 2
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $293,000 for both the 16 weeks and 52 weeks.

title: Lewis B. Cuyler, 85, Ex-Banking Executive
description: Lewis B. Cuyler, retired senior vice president and director of personnel relations for the First National City Bank, now Citibank, died of congestive heart failure and kidney failure on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: An Injudicious Choice for Judge
description: In its twilight months, the Reagan Administration has nominated for the prestigious U.S. Court of Appeals on the West Coast a California lawyer named Bernard Siegan, a man distinguished for his extreme conservatism. Legally speaking, he is so far out that Robert Bork, who was rejected for the Supreme Court for being out of the mainstream, calls some of his ideas ''revolutionary.'' Senate Democrats are right to subject the Siegan nomination to exacting scrutiny.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of two suspects in the killing of a New York City police officer gave an incorrect address in some copies for the house where the men were picked up. It is 93-08 209th Street in Queens Village.

title: Insider Charges Settled by 2
description: Two employees of a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., the oil services company, this week settled civil charges that they illegally purchased stock in the Texas International Company in 1985 while possessing inside information about the discovery of a major oilfield in Egypt by Texas International.

title:
Patents;
A Spacecraft Oriented to Earth or Sun
description: LEAD: Space industries of Webster, Tex., received a patent this week for a spacecraft operable in two alternative flight modes, with its position oriented toward either the earth or the sun. Patent 4,728,061 was granted to Maxime A. Faget, president and chief executive, Caldwell C. Johnson, chief of design, and David J.

title: DAHLBERG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: BANKS IN PANAMA ORDERED TO CLOSE
description: The Panamanian Government today ordered all banks here to close ''until the supply of dollar bills can be regularized.'' The move was intended to avoid a run on deposits that would force banks into insolvency and touch off a general financial collapse.

title: The Job Picture
BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1988
description: The Economy

title: A Car Theft Suspect Is Killed by an Officer
description: A South Orange police officer, clinging to the hood of a moving car that was reportedly being stolen, shot and killed the teen-age driver yesterday by firing through the windshield, authorities said.

title: Tektronix Plans To Lay Off 1,000
description: Tektronix Inc. said it would lay off about 1,000 employees as part of a restructuring that might result in a third-quarter loss. Tektronix, which makes electronic instruments and computer graphics equipment, said the layoffs were necessary because expenses have been outpacing revenue growth. Tektronix said that 300 workers would be laid off today and that the layoffs would be complete by May 28, the end of its fiscal year. Tektronix employs about 16,900 workers.

title: Upjohn-Chugai Joint Venture
description: The Upjohn Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent with the Chugai Pharmaceutical Company of Tokyo to form a joint venture that would develop and market drugs.

title: BEAR AUTOMOTIVE SERVICE EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $64,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net income and includes tax benefits of $231,000 and $1,212,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $67,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: K Mart to Acquire 51% of Makro Inc.
description: The K Mart Corporation, as expected, said it would enter the warehouse membership store business. K Mart, the nation's second-largest retailer, will acquire 51 percent of Makro Inc., a United States subsidiary of the Dutch company SHV Holdings. SHV will continue to hold the remaining 49 percent of Makro, K Mart said.

title: LAWRENCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $512,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $464,000 and $455,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Fund to Help Libraries Get Public TV Classics
description: Chicago's wealthy MacArthur Foundation is providing $4.5 million to put Alistair Cooke's 13-part ''America'' series and 19 other public television classics on the shelves of 4,000 public libraries across the country next month for use by borrowers.

title: No Need to Extend Amnesty for Aliens
description: To the Editor:

title: 22 on Commuter Plane Die in Crash Near Paris
description: A twin-engine commuter plane flying from eastern France to Paris crashed near the capital this morning while waiting to land, killing all 22 people aboard, aviation authorities said.

title: Screenwriting Doesn't Stop With the Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz: American Orchestra
description: After two years of struggle, financially and musically, the American Jazz Orchestra began its third season on Thursday evening at Cooper Union with a concert that was its finest realization so far of its intention to make performances of classic jazz a vital, living experience rather than copies of old records.

title: Ellery Queen's 'Double Lives'
description: Walking through the exhibition of the Ellery Queen documents that opened to the public last week in the rare book and manuscript hall of Butler Library at Columbia University, a visitor can envision a large part of the history of the modern detective story - from policiers to political thrillers. The show leaves the strong impression that the American detective story has made as original a contribution to the literary arts as the American musical comedy has made to the Western theater.

title: Baseball by the Boardwalk
description: George Brett couldn't resist it. ''I saw the thing go around a hundred times a day,'' he said. ''I had to go on it. I'm glad I got it out of the way. It's scary. That thing flies.'' Brett, the Kansas City Royals' fearsome first baseman, was talking about the Hurricane, the roller coaster at the amusement park that is the Boardwalk part of Boardwalk and Baseball. The major league side of the Baseball part of the unusual entertainment pairing opened today with the Royals' 9-7 exhibition loss to the Houston Astros.

title: As Warning Labels Multiply, Messages Are Often Ignored
description: Warnings, disclaimers and disclosure statements surround the American consumer.

title: Coping: With a Consumer Problem
description: Robert J. Pearl, a lawyer in Rochester, ordered a tennis racquet from a mail-order company. The day before he was to play in a tournament, the racquet had not arrived, so Mr. Pearl bought one at a local store. When the racquet he had ordered was delivered, he returned it. But the company refused to send him a refund, insisting that it had fulfilled its obligations.

title: Fear of Shelters Sends Many to Streets
description: With a pint of vodka in his jacket pocket, Robert Meade prepared to bed down for the night next to the 24-hour teller machines of a bank on Lexington Avenue near 54th Street.

title: Embroidery of Greece On Display in Astoria
description: An exhibition and display of embroidery by artisans from Greece and Cyprus is to open a four-part series dedicated to the folklore of the area at 3 P.M. tomorrow at the Hellenic Cultural Center of the Greek Archdiocese, 27-09 Crescent Street, Astoria, Queens. The demonstration is free and is to be given in English and Greek.

title: INTEGRATED GENERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $52,910 for the latest first quarter and $137,338 for the year-ago period.

title: Jackson Leads Knicks in Overtime
description: More heroics by Mark Jackson settled a battle of streaks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Spain Curbs Public Smoking; Health Warnings Are Ordered
description: Spain, a country with one of Europe's heaviest concentrations of smokers, today banned smoking in most public places, prohibited tobacco sales to those under 16 years old and ordered the placement of health warnings on cigarette packages and vending machines.

title: Film: 'Moving,' With Richard Pryor
description: Richard Pryor has been given the full Bill Cosby treatment for his role in ''Moving,'' complete with charming family, fancy sweaters and brand-new Saab. Mr. Pryor plays Arlo Pear, a mass transit engineer who has been living in suburban splendor in New Jersey when a career change makes it necessary for him to relocate to Idaho. Nominally a comedy, this is in fact a horror story chronicling the hellish things that befall the Pear family's possessions en route, and documenting the general trauma of being uprooted.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
About New York; At 76, Alumna Is What's New On Campus
description: One nasty afternoon this week, 30 or 40 students who have been thinking about careers came in from a rain that blew across the city horizontally, shook off their slickers and assembled in an overheated room at New York University to hear the remarks of a 76-year-old businesswoman. The woman, May Gruber, had, among other achievements, taken a company with $12 million in annual sales in 1963 and more than trebled the gross.

title: Swedish Group Is Singular In Ability to Switch Partners
description: Three decades ago, the top-ranked American team was highly flexible. Its players could change partnerships freely, an advantage when an individual was tired, sick or unavailable. That flexibility disappeared around the world when more sophisticated bidding methods made their appearance, but there is one country that is an exception.

title: G.M.'s Rebates
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had added two cars to its buyer incentive program, which has been extended by a month, to March 31. The Oldsmobile 88 model will carry a sales rebate of $750 and the Ninety-Eight model $1,000.

title: The Republicans Cut Off the Contras
description: The House vote Thursday against all further aid to the Nicaraguan rebels was a mistake. House Speaker Wright's plan for non-military funds would have kept the contras afloat while supporting the Central American peace talks. But the Reagan Administration and Republican legislators seemed more interested in gaining a campaign issue against the Democrats than in serious negotiations - or helping the contras.

title:
Patents;
Westinghouse Patents On Nuclear Equipment
description: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received eight patents this week relating to nuclear power equipment that it is producing for the world market.

title: BRING ON THE HIPPOS
description: Gulfstream Park will briefly change from a hippodrome to a hippo hippodrome this morning.

title: In Wilds of Manila, a Hunt for Lost Treasure
description: Looking like a diminutive Indiana Jones in his broad-brimmed hat, Charles McDougald sat at a dimly lit folding table inside an old Spanish dungeon and talked of buried treasure.

title: Salerno-Sonnenberg Ill
description: Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, the violinist, has canceled her performance tonight at 8 o'clock with the Solisti New York Chamber Orchestra at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Ms. Salerno-Sonnenberg, who has tendinitis, will be replaced by Joseph Swensen. The program remains unchanged.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $927,000 from the sale of Culp's industrial fabrics division.

title: Wigglesworth Birthday
description: To mark Frank Wigglesworth's 70th birthday, which was Thursday, a program of the composer's music is to be offered at 3 P.M. today at the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street. The composer is to be at a reception afterward. The program includes two new works, ''Autumn Songs'' and a string trio, as well as an earlier trio, ''Lake Music'' for flute, and a choral work, ''Short Mass Without Credo.'' The performers include Deborah Parker, soprano; Andrew Bolotowsky, flutist; the New Trio d'Anches, and the choir of Corpus Christi Church, directed by Louise Basbas. Admission is free. Information: 741-5600.

title: NORTHWEST CITED BY F.A.A. ON SAFETY
description: Federal inspectors charged Northwest Airlines yesterday with breaking numerous safety rules or guidelines, including those governing compliance with maintenance requirements, limiting postponement of repairs and setting maximum duty times for pilots.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Doctor Is Sentenced In Medicaid Fraud
description: A doctor was ordered yesterday to pay back $178,000 from a Medicaid fraud in which she filed for bills and prescriptions issued by a former messenger working as a doctor, a prosecutor said.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $1,818,000 charge from the early repayment of debt.

title: 5 Senators to Offer a Contra Aid Plan
description: A bipartisan group of Senators who support aid to the Nicaraguan rebels said today that they would try to fashion their own assistance package by building on elements of the $30.8 million rebel aid plan defeated by the House on Thursday.

title: Wicks Is Aiming Past Her Statistics
description: It took 2,512 points, 1,293 rebounds and four years of patience. But Sue Wicks of Rutgers has finally achieved status as the premier player in women's college basketball. Still, Wicks fears that she will not be remembered.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment losses of $8,341,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $4,286,000 for the year, and extraordinary credits of $77,000 and $510,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes investment gains of $18,561,000 for the quarter and $25,620,000 for the year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: With Marvin Powell in retirement after undergoing several knee operations, George Martin of the Giants was selected yesterday to succeed him as president of the National Football League Players Association. Martin, a defensive end with 13 years of N.F.L. experience and seven years of service as the Giants' player representative, was elected during the second day of a three-day meeting of the union's player representatives in Washington. . . . Trade talks between the Jets and the Indianapolis Colts have broken off after Russell Carter, a Jets cornerback, failed a physical examination, according to Jim Irsay, the Colts' general manager. Carter, the Jets' first-round pick in 1984, did not pass a physical by Indianapolis because of a previously dislocated shoulder, Irsay said. . . . Robert Tisch, the former Postmaster General, said yesterday he was hoping that his plans to buy the New England Patriots and keep them in New England could be realized by Wednesday, four days before National Football League owners begin their meetings in Phoeniz. . . . The appeal of a six-month suspension for Armando Marquez, a jockey at Garden State Park, has been denied by the New Jersey Racing Commission. Marquez drew the stiff penalty Wednesday after grabbing the reins of Julie Krone near the finish line of the eighth race Monday night and preventing her horse from winning.

title: Santiago Is Signed
description: A day after Oakland's Mark McGwire, the American League rookie of the year in 1987, signed a one-year contract worth at least $260,000, Benito Santiago, the National League's top rookie, signed a one-year contract worth $175,000. The San Diego Padres catcher, who hit safely in 34 consecutive games last season, nearly tripled his 1987 salary of $63,500.

title: Pop: Michael Jackson At Madison Sq. Garden
description: For years, the title of ''the hardest working man in show business'' has been claimed by the great soul singer James Brown. But after watching Michael Jackson's bravura two-hour show on Thursday at Madison Square Garden, where he performed a benefit for the United Negro College Fund, one wondered if perhaps that sobriquet didn't belong to pop music's lanky 29-year-old Peter Pan, a man who has the gift of appearing to be earthbound only at his own whim.

title: U.S. INSISTS SOVIET STOP SENDING ARMS TO AFGHAN REGIME
description: The United States said today that it would not end aid to the Afghan guerrillas unless Moscow agreed to stop sending military supplies to the Afghan Government.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about Garrison Keillor misidentified the distributor of his radio show, ''A Prairie Home Companion.'' The show, which was produced by Minnesota Public Radio, is distributed by American Public Radio.

title:
Patents;
A Lighted Fishing Lure
description: LEAD: An electronically lighted fishing lure was patented this week by Michael Garr of Jericho, L.I. Patent 4,727,674 discloses that the lure is battery-operated and transmits light through fiber optics. Different angles of light are said to attract different species. The lure will be available from the Husky Lure Corporation in New York City.

title: 3 White Officers Are Charged With Murder in a Texas Jail
description: Three white law-enforcement officers were charged with murder today in the death of a black Louisiana truck driver who was under arrest.

title: Nancy Reagan Defends Her Decision to Have Mastectomy
description: Nancy Reagan, who had a mastectomy last October, said in an interview prepared for broadcast last night on ABC's ''20/20'' that, despite widespread criticism, she felt she had made the right choice in having her whole breast removed, rather than just the malignant lump.

title: Soviet Reports Deaths of 31 in Azerbaijan Rioting
description: The Government said today that 31 people were killed Sunday in nationalist rioting in the southern Soviet city of Sumgait.

title: Congress vs. the War on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Along the Way to 1997, New Voices Are Heard
description: When Britain released a long-awaited policy paper on the future of Hong Kong's government recently, pro-democracy groups were so angered by the limited measures it outlined that they called for a mass protest.

title: Mets Look for a New Stopper
description: Now that the Mets won't have Jesse Orosco to kick around anymore, who will take the heat when the game is on the line? Roger McDowell, who wasn't so sharp last year after surgery to repair a hernia, and Randy Myers, who was a rookie with a losing record.

title: DOW CUTS BIG EARLY LOSS, ENDS DOWN 5.63
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average trimming large early losses to close at 2,057.86, a decline of 5.63 points. Indexes that track smaller stocks were up, however.

title: Ernest L. Cuneo, 82; Owned News Service
description: Ernest L. Cuneo, lawyer, writer and former owner of the North American Newspaper Alliance, died Tuesday at the National Hospital for Orthopedics and Rehabilitation in Washington after a heart attack. He was 82 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tiny Indiana School A Step Closer to Fame
description: The Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School in tiny Hamlet, Ind., kept up their winning ways tonight with a 59-54 victory over neighboring North Judson High, moving a step nearer the regional basketball tournament.

title: Media General Rebuffs Sugarman
description: Media General Inc. rejected a $1.75 billion buyout proposal from the television producer Burt Sugarman. The company's president, James S. Evans, said the Bryan family, which founded Media General and owns controlling interest, had decided the offer was unacceptable.

title: The Dance: 'Inlets 2,' by Cunningham
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company looked beautiful on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater. One thing that made it so was the way its members paid attention to stillness as well as motion.

title: HARCOURT BRACE JOVANOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,605,000 and $16,795,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; a gain of $136,959,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and year; extraordinary charges of $65,000 and $11,231,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an accounting change gain of $18,306,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $2,659,000 for the quarter and $10,484,000 for the year. The company noted that in 1987 it took a pretax charge of $15,543,000 for the relocation of its insurance operations from Battle Creek, Mich. to its headquarters building in Orlando, Fla. The company also noted that in 1987 it charged to income $98,947,000 of expenses relating to its recapitalization plan.

title: CALPROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of 8 cents a share.

title: Morphine as Good as Heroin for Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15.

title: Shultz, Ending Mideast Mission, Gives Leaders Letters on U.S. Plan
description: Ending his peace mission to the Middle East, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had delivered letters containing the American negotiating plan to the leaders of Israel, Jordan, Syria and Egypt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is ridiculous to consider white women as minorities in the same way that blacks and Hispanics and other ethnic groups are minorities. When I was a kid, water fountains were labeled 'white' and 'colored.' They were not labeled 'white,' 'colored' and 'women.' '' - Ralph C. Thomas 3d, executive director of the National Association of Minority Contractors. [ 6:2. ]

title: Decker Tops Standard's New Offer
description: A billion-dollar seesaw battle for American Standard Inc. continued to escalate yesterday as the Black & Decker Corporation outbid the company's latest proposal to remain independent.

title: Taking the Edge Off
description: With more than two weeks left before he defends his world heavyweight boxing crown against Tony Tubbs in Tokyo March 21, Mike Tyson has apparently reached peak form -and his handlers are not happy. Yesterday, Kevin Rooney, his trainer, cut short a scheduled 10-round sparring session in Tokyo at the end of the sixth round even though the champion protested by saying, ''I can spar 20 more rounds now.'' Rooney said that Tyson ''was too good and too sharp,'' and added, ''He's already near top shape, but we still have nearly 20 days before the title match, so I stopped it.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Lyons P.L.C., London, a spirits, food and retail concern, said it had completed its $572 million acquisition of the 49 percent of Hiram Walker-Gooderham & Worts Ltd. that it did not already own from Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.

title: The Dance: 'Rock With Me'
description: Mary Bruce Blackburn has created a dance of memorable sweetness and imagination in ''Rock With Me,'' performed on Wednesday in the Morningside Dance Festival's Choreographers Showcase Two at the Horace Mann Theater at Columbia University's Teachers College. She has, for one thing, set the dance to a very appealing score that includes gospel song by the Whitesburg Baptist pre-school choir, the Spencer Family and Sweet Honey in the Rock. And the Kentucky-born choreographer alludes to the weave of vocal lines in this smooth-flowing suite of dances. But she complements the music's rich texture with simple movement that is at one with the quiet innocence and idealism of the songs.

title: Harmonica: Bonfiglio
description: Musicality sometimes manifests itself in odd ways. For Robert Bonfiglio, its outlet is the harmonica, and Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall he offered an entertaining display of what he and his instrument can do.

title: Building-Collapse Case Sent to Justice Dept.
description: The Labor Department asked the Justice Department today to consider prosecuting a Texas contractor in the collapse last April of a high-rise complex being built in Bridgeport, Conn., a Labor Department spokesman said today.

title: Hula Hoop Is Coming Around Again
description: The Hula Hoop is making a comeback -both among grown-ups whose last hoop was probably chewed up by the family dog a quarter-century ago and among children who are discovering that toys do not have to have microchips to be fun.

title: COMET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Shallow Thinking on Public Pay
description: Governor Cuomo of New York doesn't believe high state officials deserve high salaries, himself included. He offers stinging criticism of the salaries paid to a few top executives of public agencies like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Battery Park City Authority and the Urban Development Corporation. Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority, for example, earns $170,000 a year.

title: Bonds Fall Sharply on Job Report
description: Bond prices tumbled yesterday after the Labor Department reported an unexpectedly large increase in the nation's employment for February.

title: 102 Degrees in The Night
description: It is 3:15 in the morning, and I have just been roused out of bed to announce there will be no column in this space today. Since I'm nothing but hired help around here, I keep my thoughts to myself, but that doesn't mean I can't try to put a little fire in the old fellow once in awhile.

title: Along the Amazon, Conservation of Fish Could Be Harmful
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Paraphernalia Is Seized in 4 Raids
description: Customs agents and other law-enforcement officers seized $2 million worth of drug paraphernalia in four raids in New York and New Jersey, officials announced yesterday.

title: Marcus Christ, 87, Ex-Presiding Justice Of New York Court
description: Marcus G. Christ, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court's Second Judicial Department, died yesteday at his home in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing 3 Swiss Women Hurt: Heavy snowfall and poor visibility caused crashes yesterday that led to season-ending injuries for Maria Walliser, Vreni Schneider and Beatrice Gafner of Switzerland and forced postponement of a World Cup downhill race in Aspen, Colo. Walliser, the defending World Cup overall champion; Schneider, the double Olympic gold medalist, and Gafner will miss the rest of the World Cup season with knee injuries, according to a physician for the Swiss team. Eleven skiers had made it out of the start house when the snow worsened and the race was stopped.(AP) College Basketball Penn 85, Cornell 79: Tyrone Pitts and Walt Frazier Jr. each scored 22 points last night for Penn, spoiling a Big Red chance to win the Ivy League championship. Cornell, 11-2 in the conference, will play at Princeton tonight. Cornell can clinch the title by beating Princeton, or if second-place Dartmouth, which beat Brown last night, 94-73, loses at Yale. Dartmouth is 10-3 in the league. (AP) N.B.A. Celtics 121, Clippers 90: Larry Bird scored 32 points as Boston ended a three-game losing streak and handed Los Angeles its 21st consecutive loss on the road. The Celtics played their second consecutive game without Kevin McHale, who has a strained knee.(AP) Bullets 95, Pacers 88: Moses Malone scored 27 points and Washington used a 13-point run late in the fourth quarter. Indiana was led by John Long with 14 points.(AP) College Hockey Harvard 5, R.P.I. 4: C. J. Young scored three goals as Harvard won the first game of an ECAC Hockey playoff series. The first of Young's goals came in the second minute of play. When the first period ended, the Crimson was ahead, 3-0. The Harvard lead went to 4-0 in the second period before Bruce Coles made the first goal for R.P.I. The teams will play in Cambridge, Mass., again tonight. Harvard, seeded first, needs a second victory or a tie to win this quarterfinal series. If R.P.I. wins, a 10-minute mini-game will follow and then, if necessary, a shootout. In other games, second-seeded St. Lawrence defeated Princeton, 5-1; sixth-seeded Clarkson upset Cornell, 4-3, and fourth-seeded Vermont beat Colgate, 8-0. The same opponents will play again tomorrow. The quarterfinal winners will advance to the finale at Boston Garden March 11-12. N.H.L. Capitals 6, Nordiques 2: Mike Ridley scored twice as Washington won for the 10th time in 11 games since the All-Star Game break, rallying from a 2-0 deficit last night in Landover, Md., to beat Quebec(AP) 5 Assists for Gretzky: Glenn Anderson scored four goals and Wayne Gretzky had five assists as Edmonton routed Philadelphia, 7-4. In the first period Gretzky set up Edmonton's four goals, all on power plays. Anderson, who scored once in the first period, connected three straight times, all from the slot, in a 3:12 span early in the second period. He had 11 shots on goal in the first two periods. The Flyers played without eight injured regulars, including Mark Howe, Rick Tocchet, Dave Poulin and Brad Marsh.(AP) Tennis Graf vs. Maleeva: Steffi Graf of West Germany and Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria advanced to the final of the United States women's hard-court championships in San Antonio by rallying to victories yesterday. The top-seeded Graf defeated third-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-7, 6-1, 6-1. Maleeva, seeded fourth, beat second-seeded Helena Sukova, 6-3, 6-7, 6-4.(AP)

title: Let's Purify New York's Campaign Financing
description: In the 70's, the Government, rocked by the Watergate scandal, enacted laws setting contribution and expenditure limits for Presidential campaigns. Voters, eager to wrest control of elections from those wealthy enough to contribute millions to slush funds, gave overwhelming support to laws limiting individual contributions to $1,000 for each Presidential primary and general election campaign.

title: 45 E.M.S. Workers Are Dismissed
description: The Koch administration dismissed 45 provisional employees of the New York City Emergency Medical Service last night after a one-day job action in which almost half the technicians and paramedics who were scheduled for duty called in sick during two shifts.

title: Pop: Angela Strehli
description: Angela Strehli opened the first set of a variety show from Austin, Texas, at the Lone Star Cafe on Wednesday with unpretentious blues. She's an impressive, unfrenetic singer, and she sounds like a country singer shouting the blues - comfortable and relaxed.

title: Customers of Jersey Power To See 2% Increase in Rates
description: Electric rates for the 820,000 customers of Jersey Central Power and Light Company will rise as high as 2 1/2 percent, the state Board of Public Utilities announced today.

title: Campeau, May in Deal on Federated
description: The Macy-Campeau tussle for Federated Department Stores Inc. continued yesterday, while one of the rivals took steps to cash in.

title: Greater Acceptance of Homosexuals Is Only a Pleasant Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Sides Split on Impact of Davis Verdict
description: The Bronx District Attorney and a lawyer for Larry Davis differed sharply yesterday on whether Mr. Davis's acquittal Thursday night in a quadruple-homicide case would help him at his next trial, at which he faces nine counts of attempted murder stemming from a shoot-out with the police.

title: Ashkenazy Cancels Recital
description: Vladimir Ashkenazy's piano recital on Thursday at Carnegie Hall has been canceled and will not be rescheduled. Mr. Ashkenazy's management said he is indisposed. Requests for refunds on tickets will be accepted until April 11. Refund requests for tickets purchased through Carnegiecharge should be mailed to Carnegiecharge, Carnegie Hall, 881 Seventh Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019; refunds for tickets purchased from the box office can be obtained at the hall from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Philip Alston Jr., 76, A Former Ambassador
description: Philip Henry Alston Jr., a confidant of former President Jimmy Carter and a former Ambassador to Australia, died Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Congress vs. the War on Abortion To Save Women's Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1988
description: International 3-5, 28 Demanding a halt to Soviet aid to the Afghan Government, the United States said it would not stop sending aid to Afghan rebels until Moscow agreed to stop helping the Kabul regime. The position could become a complication in talks on a withdrawal of Soviet troops. Page 1 Panama ordered all banks to close ''until the supply of dollar bills can be regularized.'' The move was intended to avoid a run on deposits that would force banks into insolvency and trigger a general financial collapse. 1 A treasure hunt in the Philippines has aroused controversy and speculation. Government officials say they are skeptical, but will be happy to accept their share if any treasure is unearthed. 1 A new package of aid for the contras will be fashioned by a bipartisan group of five Senators by building on elements of the $30.8 million plan defeated by the House on Thursday. 3 Ending his Middle East trip, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he had delivered letters containing the American negotiating plan to the leaders of Israel, Jordan, Syria and Egypt. 5 Israel sought to bar journalists from the entire occupied West Bank for the first time. The Israeli move was imposed under longstanding rules permitting army officers to declare any area a closed military zone. 5 News analysis: A Mexican bond swap was a bold attempt to solve the third-world debt crisis, critics agree. But many bankers are accusing Morgan Guaranty Trust and the United States Treasury of bungling the plan. 35 Soviet Union riots killed 31 people in the southern Soviet city of Sumgait, Moscow reported. The press agency Tass said members of various nationalities, including women and old men, were among the victims. 28 Sandinistas go on the political offensive 3 Hong Kong journal: Demands for democracy 4 Mediator reports major gains at Afghan talks 4 Kissinger urged Israel to ban TV reports of unrest 5 NATIONAL 6-8, 32-33, 50 The U.S unemployment rate eased one-tenth of a point in February to 5.6 percent, the lowest level in eight and a half years, the Labor Department reported. 1 A Federal law on women contractors that classifies them as minority-group members in the awarding of highway construction bids has triggered a bitter protest in Chicago and threatens to pit women against racial minorities. 1 Warning labels have proliferated on various products. But there is little evidence that they have much effect on consumers' behavior, or that they reduce the liability risks or insurance premiums for businesses. 1 An increase in postage rates that would raise the cost of a first-class stamp to 25 cents from 22 cents was approved by by a Presidential advisory panel. The United States Postal Service is expected to accept the recommendations. 6 The hazards of space flight have been assessed by many groups in the space agency, but the agency's efforts are fragmented and lack objective measures for evaluating the risks, a new report said. 32 Nancy Reagan's mastectomy lat October was discussed by the First Lady in an interview. Mrs. Reagan said that she made the right choice in having her whole breast removed, rather than just the lump. Her decision has been widely criticized. 6 A meeting on racism at Dartmouth ended a week of anti-racism events at the college, where a disciplinary hearing is to be held today for four white students accused of harassing a black professor. 7 Northwest Airlines faulted on safety 6 Arizona aide tells about threat 50 Politics 8 Are there any issues out there? The 1988 Presidential campaign has produced few that seperate the candidates. A New York Times/CBS News survey suggests how little the candidates' own messages have penetrated with some voters. 8 Vice President Bush led the polls in South Carolina as his three Republican rivals spent the day crisscrossing the state in search of support in the last primary leading up to Super Tuesday. 8 Robertson may drop libel suit 8 REGIONAL 29-32 Unemployment in the New York area fell last month to the lowest level in almost 18 years. But Mayor Koch warned that consequences of the October stock-market collapse might yet undermine the city's economy. 1 Two more men were arrested in the slaying of a rookie New York City police officer who was guarding the South Jamaica, Queens, home of a man who had complained about drug dealing in his neighborhood. 1 Two other suspects in the shooting, Todd Scott and Scott Cobb, apparently have managed to swagger through the criminal justice system like they do the streets of southeast Queens, where the police say they are low-level dealers. 31 45 E.M.S. workers were dismissed by the Koch administration after a one-day job action in which almost half the technicians and paramedics who were scheduled for duty called in sick during two shifts. 29 A lawyer for Larry Davis and the Bronx District Attorney differed sharply on whether Mr. Davis's acquittal in the slayings of four suspected drug dealers would help him at his next trial, where he faces charges stemming from a shoot-out with the police. 31 The Long Island Power Authority, the state agency considering a takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, said that it would soon begin taking the steps necessary to win control of the utility. 29 Many people live on the streets in New York City because they decide to avoid the shelter network. The decision is complex, according to interviews with homeless people and their advocates. 29 In a lawsuit over psychiatric wards, an advocacy group contends that New York City hospitals were illegally turning away mentally ill people. The suit came as an emergency program to relieve overcrowding at psychiatric wards began. 30 Flu-like symptoms hit many 30 Jurors in the Chambers murder trial visited Central Park 31

title: Bush Looking Ahead to Dukakis and, Over His Shoulder, Back at Dole
description: For a moment this week, Vice President Bush sounded as though he was not running against Senator Bob Dole and Pat Robertson but against Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: Small Opera Groups in Labor Dispute
description: A struggle between New York's small opera companies and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians may soon change the face of the city's fringe operatic activity. Most of the companies have operated for years without union contracts, but several have been unionized over the past three seasons and three more are targets of a current organizing campaign.

title: Wide Increase in Postal Rates Proposed
description: A Presidential advisory panel today recommended increasing the cost of mailing a first-class letter by 3 cents, to 25 cents. The United States Postal Service's Board of Governors is expected to accept the recommendation.

title: Dartmouth Ends Week of Rallies In Effort to Curb Campus Racism
description: An open meeting on campus racism today brought to a close a week of anti-racism rallies, marches and forums at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., where a disciplinary hearing is to be held Saturday for four white students accused of harassing a black professor.

title: Rattlesnake Bites Handler
description: A reptile expert who was bitten by his own rattlesnake was in guarded condition today at St. Joseph's Medical Center here, a hospital spokesman said. The man, Albert Kilian of Stamford, was taken to the hospital Thursday night after being bitten at his home, officials said. The Stamford police picked up a special serum at Norwalk Hospital to treat Mr. Kilian, a breeder of snakes and lizards. Brian Ward, a spokesman for St. Joseph's, said he did not know the circumstances surrounding the bite.

title: AMERICAN BARRICK REOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary items. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said on March 3, 1988, the Bank of Canada noon rate for U.S. dollars was Canadian dollars $1.2534.

title: The Revenge of Paper
description: LEAD: Bad news for trees. Information technology was supposed to let us taper off paper. But we emphatically have not. The paperless office, the bookless library, the printless newspaper, the cashless, checkless society - all have gone the way of the Empire State Building's dirigible mooring, the backyard helipad, the nuclear-powered convertible and the vitamin-pill dinner.

title: Mexican Buyout Of Boys Markets
description: The American Breco Corporation, a company controlled by the Brenner family of Mexico, agreed to acquire Boys Markets Inc. for $12.50 a share, or $131 million, the grocery chain said. The chain's management will participate in the buyout. Boys Markets had been acquired two years ago for $83 million by Riordan, Freeman & Spogli, a leveraged buyout group.

title: Investment Firm Seen In Offering
description: For nearly two years the stock of Morgan Stanley & Company has made the firm's 160 managing directors rich - but only on paper. That will soon change. Within the next few months the firm's insiders could cash in shares worth hundreds of millions of dollars in a secondary stock offering.

title: Insurance Rates Rouse Drivers to Protest Ways to Cut The Premiums
description: Automobile insurance rates are rising sharply across the country, continuing a five-year trend. In a few states premiums for private passenger cars are increasing so fast that the public is protesting vocally and sometimes dramatically.

title: Corrections
description: A heading in the Metro Datelines column on Thursday misstated the year in which two police officers were slain by Thomas Trantino in Lodi, N.J. The murders occurred on Aug. 26, 1963.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ENSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
