description: b-Includes an accounting adjustment gain of $868,000. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $342,000 and $1,175,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Banker May Join Fed Board
description: Frederick Heldring, chairman and chief executive of the Philadelphia National Bank and vice chairman of its parent, the Corestates Financial Corporation, is a leading candidate for a seat on the board of governors of the Federal Reserve, Government officials said today.

title: Kissinger Urged Ban on TV Reports
description: Henry A. Kissinger has privately urged that Israel bar television cameras and reporters from the occupied territories as part of its effort to put down violent protests.

title: Futility at the National Cancer Institute
description: LEAD: The National Cancer Institute recently announced a ''large scale evaluation'' virtually predestined to ineffectiveness. The institute admirably intends to investigate whether an association exists between higher incidences of leukemia, or ''clusters'' among residents, 100 nuclear power plants around the country and low-dose radiation.

title: Iran and Iraq Fire Missiles For the 5th Day at Capitals
description: Iran and Iraq mounted new missile attacks at each other today in a long-range rocket duel, which has lasted five days and killed scores of people.

title: Cabaret: Amy Coleman in Beatles Songs
description: One measure of the staying power of the Beatles' music is the amazing adaptability of the Lennon and McCartney song catalogue. In their original versions of songs like ''Yes It Is,'' ''If I Fell,'' ''I'll Be Back'' and ''Run for Your Life,'' to name several of the songs that Amy Coleman covers in her revue of Beatles songs, ''Face to the Wall,'' the Fab Four evoked a winsomely witty romantic ambiance. When telling a girl, ''You'd better run for your life,'' the Beatles offered the challenge as a whimsical boast not meant to be taken literally.

title: U.S. Supported Dollar Heavily in Quarter
description: The Reagan Administration, which assumed a staunch laissez-faire attitude toward exchange rate policy when the dollar was stronger earlier this decade, has proved to be no different from its predecessor during times of dollar weakness.

title: 2 Seen as Favored For Regents Posts
description: A Staten Island surgeon and a retired executive for the Eastman Kodak Company are likely to be elected to two vacant seats on the state Board of Regents, officials in the State Legislature said yesterday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Candidates, Voters and Issues a Puzzle, Poll Finds
description: Are there any issues out there?

title: CBS Is Sued Over Bonuses
description: A group of executives of the former CBS Record Group filed suit this week in New York State Supreme Court for $1.5 million in lost pay and $3 million in punitive damages.

title: IU and Neoax Discuss $670 Million Merger
description: The IU International Corporation, which has sought to elude a takeover by Neoax Inc., said today that it was negotiating with Neoax to be acquired for $670 million.

title: Afghan Talks' Mediator Sees Main Issues Settled
description: The mediator in the Afghan peace talks said today that the two sides had removed all significant obstacles to an agreement ending the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan and that country's eight-year-old civil war.

title: Phillips Collection Wins Grant for Renovations
description: The Phillips Collection in Washington is the recipient of a $750,000 challenge grant from the Kresge Foundation of Troy, Mich. The money is to be used for the renovation of the Phillips Collection annex, which will include additional gallery and storage space and conservation facilities. The annex is expected to be completed early next year.

title: American Volunteer Is Seized By the Nicaraguan Guerrillas
description: An American volunteer was among a group of people taken captive Tuesday by contras in a northern village, associates of the volunteer said today.

title: Felons' Swagger: Look at 2 Suspects
description: Todd Scott and Scott Cobb, two of the four men arrested in the slaying of a New York City police officer, are convicted felons who have managed to swagger through the criminal justice system like they do the drug-infested streets of southeast Queens, where police sources say they are low-level dealers.

title: Brazil in Bank Debt Accord
description: Brazil and its commercial-bank creditors have agreed on a plan to stretch out repayment of $62 billion of bank debt over 20 years, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Strauss and Lewis Head Panel
description: Robert Strauss, the Washington lawyer, and former Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis were selected today as co-chairmen of a Congressional commission created to find ways to balance the budget.

title: Morton Fearey, Lawyer, 75
description: Morton Fearey, a retired partner in the law firm of Davis, Polk, Wardwell, died of heart failure Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan and Edgartown, Mass.

title: Former Connecticut Banker Indicted on Insider Charges
description: Two Federal grand juries, one in Boston and the other in New Haven, indicted the former chairman of a Connecticut savings bank today on charges of insider trading, perjury and other offenses in connection with a stock trading investigation of the bank's merger with a Maine savings bank in 1986.

title:
Patents;
Artificial Blood Vessels
description: LEAD: A process for making small artificial blood vessels and other tubular organs has been patented for the Research Corporation of New York. Patent 4,728,328 was granted this week to Dr. Howard C. Hughes and Jacob T. Kissinger of Penn State's medical center in Hershey, Pa. The invention is described as a breakthrough in the design of replacements for small veins and arteries with flexibility similar to that of the human blood vessels.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
INSIDE
description: Soviet Puts Riot Toll at 31

title: S.E.C. Backs Banking Bill
description: After winning concessions from Federal banking regulators, the Securities and Exchange Commission has voted unanimously to support Congressional efforts to modify or repeal the Glass-Steagall Act, the law that maintains a barrier between banks and the securities business.

title: Extension for Reardon
description: Jeff Reardon, the relief pitcher whose 31 saves helped Minnesota to the American League pennant and then victory in the World Series last year, has agreed to a one-year contract extension for 1989 that will pay him $1.15 million, with incentives that could be worth an extra $250,000. This season he will earn $850,000, the same as in 1987. ''My family likes it here, I like it here and we went all the way,'' he said. ''You always want to come back and try to do it again.''

title: In Search of a Faith
description: WOMEN AND CHILDREN FIRST. By Francine Prose. 229 pages. Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: Drug Enforcement Role For Military Is Opposed
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci said today that he would strongly oppose any effort to create an active law-enforcement role for the military in the campaign against drugs.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Franco Scalamandre yesterday gave an incorrect time and place for a memorial service to be held on March 12. It will be at 10 A.M. at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: HOOPER HOLMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rangers in a Fog In Loss to Buffalo
description: The foghorn, which this year replaced the scoring siren at the Memorial Auditorium, sounded three times for the home team in the first period tonight. But what should have been ample warning for the Rangers was instead a painful and repeated reminder of an impending disaster.

title: 2 More Arrests in Officer's Death
description: Two more men were arrested yesterday in the execution-style slaying last week of a rookie New York City police officer.

title: 2 From British Charity Are Sought in Lebanon
description: A British official of a private charity organization and his Syrian assistant are missing in the southern Lebanese port of Sidon and may have been kidnapped, the police said today.

title: DETREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest year includes a gain of $457,074, or 29 cents a share, to reflect reduced tax rates under the 1986 Tax Reform Act. The adjustment has been retroactively included in the first quarter, 1987 operating results.

title:
Patents;
Machine Controlled By Operator's Jaw
description: LEAD: A machine controller to be activated by the operator's jaw was patented this week. Patent 4,728,812 was granted for the oral machine controller to Paul S. Sheriff of Honolulu and Randal J. York of Plymouth, Minn.

title: Hoyas Need 2 Overtimes for Victory
description: Georgetown ended Seton Hall's five-game winning streak this afternoon, but it took two overtimes, an outstanding effort by Jaren Jackson and perhaps the Hoyas' best game of the season to do it.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: SHAPING POLITICAL CONSCIOUSNESS: The Language of Politics in America From McKinley to Reagan. By David Green. (Cornell University, $29.95.) Language, as David Green observes, can be both a tool and a weapon. In politics, it is mainly the latter. Political labels such as ''liberal,'' ''progressive'' and ''conservative'' are elastic; adroitly used, they can serve disparate purposes and influence the ethos of an age while camouflaging underlying disharmonies of thought and emotion.

title: POSTINGS: Bobbies at the Towers; London Terrace
description: The sponsors of the Towers at London Terrace in the Chelsea section of Manhattan are thinking of outfitting their doormen as turn-of-the-century English bobbies to recreate the atmosphere of the London Terrace apartment community when it opened in 1931. The lobby fashion statement is a small part of a large noneviction cooperative conversion.

title: Perspectives on Crafts
description: AS AN art form and a subject for analysis and study, contemporary crafts are gaining interest.

title: Q&A
description: Touring Japan Question:We would like a guided tour of five or six days, by coach or bullet train, of the main island of Japan from Tokyo at the end of April. Where can we find out about such tours? - S. S., Bethesda, Md. Answer:Japan's well-developed tourist industry offers many opportunities for tours on the island of Honshu and elsewhere. However, the tour companies' programs, of one to several days, do not attempt to cover the whole of the 800-mile-long, diversified island on one trip. The visitor should study the bus and train tours available and perhaps fit two or three of them together. An alternative is to take a tour that concentrates on one area of Honshu, like Tohoku, the northeastern district, or the Inland Sea section. Another option is to buy a seven-day rail pass, which could be used for swift, independent travel around the island on bullet trains, with travelers booking their own accommodations.

title: To Sit, to Sleep Perchance to Clap
description: THERE was once a Broadway play called ''Subways Are for Sleeping.'' Given the crime rate, I doubt that's true anymore. The updated version, Fairfield County-style, would be ''Theaters Are for Sleeping.''

title: Two Offerings Of Gilbert and Sullivan
description: TWO of the best Gilbert and Sullivan operas are coming to Connecticut this week, with four performances of ''Iolanthe'' in Hartford and six performances of ''The Yeomen of the Guard'' in Simsbury.

title: Japan's Kodo: Drum-Playing From the Heart
description: LEAD: Winding down a three-month tour of the United States, the Japanese performing troupe Kodo will bring its vibrant drumming to Manhattan's City Center beginning Tuesday for a six-day engagement. Opening night will feature the veteran American percussionist Max Roach playing a new work entitled ''Macrame.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Rutgers Leasing Its Land to a Developer
description: LEAD: JOINING the band of higher-education institutions across the country that have entered the real estate business, Rutgers University plans to lease to a developer a total of 335 surplus acres at two of its central New Jersey campuses.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. May Admit Armenians

title: A Mix of Media In a Unified Show of New Works
description: MUSEUMGOERS interested in stretching their horizons might venture south to the Delaware Art Museum here, where the 26th Contemporary Crafts Exhibition is installed in a spacious new wing.

title: Music: Auvergne Group
description: THE French in the postwar era have been carefully establishing a series of musical ensembles that both serve and reflect the country's different regions. One is the Chamber Orchestra of the Auvergne. It was formed in 1981, and Jean-Jacques Kantorow has been its conductor for the last three years. The orchestra -about 20 strong - came to New York Thursday night with a concert at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: FLOWER SHOW

title: FICTION
description: ZIONS CAUSE (1920-1950). By Jim Peyton. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $14.95.) It's odd to read a book and think it would make a handful of one-acters, but this first novel by a retired Kentucky teacher talks itself into the notion pretty quick. ''Zions Cause'' is an anecdotal tale of a Kentucky hamlet over 30 years. But the real story is about time and mortality, human failing and strength. The residents of Zion are kissing kin to those in Grover's Corners, N.H., and Winesburg, Ohio: scandal and idiosyncrasy flourish here as thick as weeds. These Bible-quoters and churchgoers are afflicted with weak consciences and strong wills - and too often predictably so. But the elegiac voice of the narrator, Jim, a reflective loner who has grown up and become a lawyer by the end of the book, is sure. A man digs a deep hole in the ground and sits in it to the amazement of his neighbors (''It beat anything I ever saw,'' says Jim's guardian; ''it was maybe like death, if death is, as it says somewhere, a place of utter peace''); an angry man so short he has to look up to his 10-year-old son tries to catch an enormous fish with his hands and encounters fate (''He had gone to meet it, leaving that boy on the bank to wait alone through the long, uneasy silence stretching on and on above the water motionless as a dirty windowpane until that parted scum, like man's last and ultimate sheet, met and covered it''). When his narrator falls in love, however, the author stumbles into a swamp of cliches. Still, it's not surprising that several of Jim Peyton's plays have been produced on television and the stage. Mr. Peyton doesn't write so much for the eye as for the ear.

title: PING-PONG, BOX LUNCHES AND THE MUSE: A COLONIST AT MACDOWELL
description: Up here at the MacDowell Colony in Peterborough, N.H., home of the true blue ice, we skidded one recent evening from our studios in the woods to the lounge in Colony Hall. By the great stone hearth, beneath the high beamed ceiling, between the stout clapboard walls, within the encircling calm of towering pines, beyond which stretch meadows, hillocks, more towering pines, we raised a glass on the 80th anniversary of his death to Edward MacDowell: composer, benefactor, granddaddy of all we survey.

title: HOSPITALS AND NURSING
description: From the point of view of a registered nurse, the article ''A Great Hospital in Crisis'' (by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman, Jan. 24) was very interesting, especially for what it did not say. Poor nursing care is cited again and again as a major problem. However, only one nurse is quoted in your article, and she is a supervisor. It is presumed that doctors and supervisors can speak for the bedside nurses.

title: A Duesenberg Could Also Be a Doozie of an Investment
description: When the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, collectible car owners, auctioneers and others with a financial stake wondered about the fallout in their market. ''I was biting my fingernails for a while,'' said Brian Jackson, co-owner of the Barrett Jackson Auction Company. Almost immediately, however, values of many collectible cars increased. ''We saw prices go up 15 percent in one week,'' said Mr. Kruse of Kruse International.

title: Damascus Has Both Praise And Criticism for U.S. Effort
description: The Syrian Government, in its first official comment on the Middle East peace proposals submitted by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Friday, said today that Washington was trying to put ''an American stamp'' on what is meant to be an international effort.

title: Lisa Crosby, Consultant, and Mark Dixon Are Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter of Alcantara in Port Washington, L.I., Lisa Anne Crosby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Crosby of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Mark Edward Dixon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Dixon of Herndon, Va. Msgr. Walter Simmons performed the ceremony.

title: Kissinger Disputing a Report
description: Henry A. Kissinger yesterday disputed the accuracy of some of the remarks attributed to him in a report in The New York Times on his statements to a group of prominent American Jews last month.

title: A New Television Section
description: Television, a new section with program highlights, an alphabetical directory of the week's movies on television and expanded broadcast and cable schedules designed for quick reference, begins today.

title: Julia H. Mills and Andrew S. Levine, An Executive, Are to Marry in June
description: Julia Holbrook Mills, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Mills of Greenwich, Conn., and Andrew Seth Levine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Levine of Pikesville, Md., and Palm Beach, Fla., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents have announced.

title: Canisius Player Dies During Game
description: Jeff Taggart, a junior guard for Canisius, suffered a fatal seizure tonight while sitting on the bench during the game with Niagara, a 71-60 loss. The Erie County Medical Examiners office said Taggart was dead on arrival at Sheehan Emergency Hospital.

title: Cuts Hurt Coast Guard
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of a $103 million cut in the Coast Guard's budget, a number of stations on or near Long Island are reducing services or are being closed. Among those being closed is the Coast Guard station on Block Island, placing an added burden on the Star Island station in Montauk.

title: This Time, the Germans Are Sold on Detente
description: DETENTE - a French word once distinctly malodorous in the United States - is breaking out again, and Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are responsible, or at least presiding over the process. In Western Europe, not all the allies are wholeheartedly enthusiastic by Detente II.

title: Golden Years Spent Under Golden Arches
description: THE television commercial is poignant: an elderly man anxiously arrives for his first day of work at a McDonald's restaurant, spends a pleasant afternoon serving customers and mingling with his teen-age colleagues, and returns home with a beaming smile. ''I don't know how they ever got along without me,'' he tells his wife.

title: An Example of Tax Swapping
description: Tax swaps may be used for stocks, mutual funds, bonds, unit trusts and other investments to take a tax loss in one year but to maintain a similar investment in a portfolio. Other advantages might be to upgrade portfolio quality, increase yield or change maturities. Here's an example of a municipal bond swap. title: Strategies For Dealing With Teen-Age Suicide
description: SUICIDE is a somber and persistent fact. Tragic whenever it occurs, suicide is especially potent when an adolescent is the victim.

title:
ART;
Max Coyer's Subjective Journey
description: LEAD: IN a brief but prolific painting career, 34-year-old Max Coyer has developed an approach for which the term ''synthetic'' is the most appropriate description. Although his work is not directly imitative of past styles, his subject matter and technique reflect preoccupations drawn from an appreciation of art history and the realization that art itself can be a valid area of investigation for the contemporary painter.

title: Gibbs Looks Not for Love But Respect for the I.R.S.
description: Lawrence B. Gibbs is a friendly Texan who admits he has an image problem. Now in his second year as Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, he is struggling to change the culture of an agency that too often, he says, is seen as the enemy of the people, somewhat slipshod, inaccurate and rude.

title: Queens Judge Leaves Child-Molestation Case
description: Acceding to the request of the Queens District Attorney, a State Supreme Court Justice has removed himself from a child molestation case in which he had proposed that the defendant be sentenced to give lectures on pedophilia rather than to jail.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: It was good that we did not expect to win many medals. It was bad that we were not surprised. ED SCHULTZ Secaucus, N.J.

title: Shingle Siding Repair
description: WINTER winds, coupled with freezing and thawing over several months, can wreak havoc with a home's exterior. Although early spring is usually too soon to repair shingled roofs (not only do icy surfaces still make such work dangerous, but also the ground may be too soggy to support ladders), you can get a head start on outdoor maintenance by repairing shingle siding.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Guilford, Conn. $259,000 719 Nut Plains Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; attic fan, 2-horse barn, 1 acre; taxes $2,402. Lincolndale, N.Y. $339,900 Green Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 7-year-old brick/frame contemporary; eat-in kitchen, Jacuzzi, woodstove, 1 acre; taxes $4,506. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J. $159,900 28-30 Laurel Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old split level; 2-zone heat, rec room, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,315. title: Centac's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Pick A Bucket Shop In London
description: It was Saturday morning, and though most of the tiny offices in the big Regent Street building were closed, Iain Carstairs, who owns Orion Travel, was seated behind his sleek wooden desk in his tiny travel agency, manning the telephone. ''A lot of people walk in or call up and ask what's cheap at the moment,'' he said, sifting through a pile of travel brochures.

title: A Call to Arms for Detroit Free Press
description: This city, which has had its share of letdowns in recent years, is bracing for another. The morning newspaper, The Free Press, may be shut down, and much of the state seems to be rising up to try to save it.

title: Maybe Minor Composers Aren't So Minor After All
description: The London Piano School. How many know what that means, much less the composers who were part of it? Who, even in a lifetime of concert going, has ever heard a piece of music by Thomas Busby? John Burton? Cipriani Potter? Ferdinand Ries? William Thomas Best? The once-famous William Sterndale Bennett? Edmund Thomas Chipp?

title: IN SEARCH OF GEORGE BUSH
description: A CRACKLING FIRE warmed the White House office of the Vice President this raw winter day, complementing the deep wood tones, the rich Oriental rugs and the family photographs. Sprawled in a chair, George Bush contemplated a question: How would his leadership differ from that of his chief rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Senator Robert J. Dole of Kansas?

title: The 'Princeton Corridor': Development Gone Wild
description: Princeton, if you believe the real-estate developers, now begins at New Brunswick and ends at Trenton. Along Route 1 heading south from New Brunswick there is a development called Princeton Park and another called Princeton Gates, not to mention Princeton Oaks, Princeton Meadows, Princeton Green, and on and on.

title: Republicans Fear Effect Of a Veto of Rights Bill
description: Republican leaders are urging President Reagan to sign a major civil rights bill that has overwhelmingly passed both houses of Congress, fearing that a veto would damage their party's political prospects in an election year, Senator Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, expressed that view in a letter to Mr. Reagan this week. Warning the President that he would vote to override any veto, he wrote, ''I implore you to sign this bill.''

title: 19 Killed in Sri Lanka Attack
description: A Tamil rebel mine killed 19 Sri Lankans and wounded 17 today in the Trincomalee district, military officials said.

title:
THE NATION: 14 on Trial;
Judging the Danger on The Right Fringe
description: LEAD: A CENTURY ago, Federal Judge Isaac C. Parker presided over trials in Fort Smith, Ark., and sent 79 men to the gallows in an attempt to bring law and government to the frontier. Today, a portrait of the legendary ''Hanging Judge'' looks down upon 14 white supremacists on trial in United States District Court, charged with conspiring to overthrow the Government by force or to murder its officials, including a Federal judge.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
For East Hampton, New Period Houses
description: LEAD: WHEN Norman Judelson, a White Plains builder, acquired two three-acre parcels on Main Street in the heart of East Hampton village, it was clear that to build anything other than traditional houses on the site would be, as he put it, ''criminal.''

title: THE GENOME PROJECT
description: I find it hard to determine which is worse, the human genome project financed by the Federal Government or the human genome project sponsored by Walter Gilbert's Genome Corporation (''The Genome Project,'' by Robert Kanigel, Dec. 13).

title: Olympic Creed Taken to Heart
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lisa Jean Moulton To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Moulton of Norwich, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Jean Moulton to James Bradford Straus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Straus of Rye, N.Y. The couple plan a June wedding.

title: Volleyball at Center
description: IT may not be Madison Square Garden, but the Westchester County Center has recently become home to a professional sports team.

title: Poll Shows Southern Support for Import Limits
description: A large majority of Southerners favor legislation limiting imports, although they realize that such measures might cause other countries to retaliate against American products, according to a poll released today.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Branford
description: IN 1644, a fishing and farming community known as Totoket was renamed Branford, after a town in England. Tightly controlled by a puritanical wing of the Congregational Church, the new town almost collapsed in 1660 when half the population, led by their minister, left in a religious dispute with the more liberal parishioners.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING
description: THIS IS CER-TAINLY a case of a fashion that's caught on. In their recent collections, many leading designers in Paris, London and New York fell for flowers, using all sorts of blooms - especially roses - as motifs for printed fabrics and accessories.

title: Is Integrity Always Worth It?
description: IN a few days my daughter will be 22 years old. It's hard to believe that I have been somebody's mother for 22 years when I barely feel grown-up myself. She was the first of four, the one I practiced on, and the one who is still teaching me the art of motherhood.

title: NATO Holds Firm
description: Euphemisms and platitudes suitable for sampler embroidery have so overcome NATO discourse that the straight message scarcely gets through.

title: NONFICTION
description: MANHATTAN WATER-BOUND: Planning and Developing Manhattan's Waterfront From the Seventeenth Century to the Present. By Ann L. Buttenwieser. (New York University, $35.) At first glance, the photograph on the jacket of ''Manhattan Water-Bound'' seems at odds with the title. Why would a book about the waterfront feature an aerial view dominated less by the water than by the land? It requires a closer look (as do many of the maps in the book) to get the point: unbeknown to most Manhattanites, their waterfront, however underused, is never far away, and one of the last great hopes for opening it to the public lies in the vacant West Side tract (prominent in the jacket photograph) where Donald Trump hopes to build Trump City. This book by Ann L. Buttenwieser, an urban planner, takes a scholarly look at waterfront development in America. Focusing on Manhattan, she traces the historic clash between commerce and recreation as government officials and private developers expanded the borough's borders into surrounding rivers to accommodate growing population and industry. Even with the public's recent rediscovery of the waterfront, she cautions that much of Manhattan will continue to be bound more by a wall of concrete than by water if many pending plans for residential and commercial projects are approved. ''Manhattan Water-Bound,'' heavily annotated and sprinkled with anecdotes, provides a valuable perspective on current development.

title: 52-Story Tower in TriBeCa Faces Opposition
description: Plans for a 52-story luxury apartment tower near City Hall have startled and angered some neighbors, but the proposal apparently conforms to zoning rules and is not subject to prolonged review - or bargaining.

title: A BOMB TICKS IN PAKISTAN
description: ARSHAD Z. PERVEZ, A DARK-HAIRED, PAKISTANI-BORN Canadian fond of polyester suits and known by the nickname Archie, hurried into the bar of Toronto's Hilton Harbour Castle hotel, fretting about the traffic. He was late for a rendezvous with John R. New, a balding middle-aged American who Pervez thought was a steel salesman. Nursing their Johnnie Walkers, the two men settled down to discuss their illicit export deal.

title: Fordham Advances To Final
description: The second life granted St. Peter's College by Fairfield Coach Mitch Buonaguro's premature victory dance Wednesday night ended abruptly today. The Peacocks were beaten in the final minute by Fordham, 53-52, in one semifinal of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference Tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Wrong Suspect Settles His Case for $55,000
description: Terry Dean Rogan, who had arrested five times in Michigan and Texas for crimes he did not commit, has settled a lawsuit against the City of Los Angeles for failing to remove his name from a crime computer's file.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: For 16 days I have given new meaning to the term couch potato so I feel qualified to comment. The good: the gutsy Jamaican bobsled team; Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards, and the wonder and glory of it all. The bad: one minute of hockey and three minutes of commercials; the up-close-and-personal segments (with the exception of Alberto Tomba in his skivvies). Let's have more competition and less color. ANGELA STEWART Fairfield, Conn.

title: Prague Seizes 13 Dissidents Before a Catholic Pilgrimage
description: The Communist authorities rounded up human rights advocates on the eve of a Catholic pilgrimage aimed at pressing for greater religious freedom in Czechoslovakia, dissidents said today.

title: Islanders Collapse In the Final Period
description: Two goals nine seconds apart in the third period this afternoon sparked the Penguins to an 8-3 victory over the Islanders, who collapsed at the Civic Arena.

title: Leslie Rhett Plans to Wed
description: Leslie Carrere Rhett and Leonard Hearne Armistead 3d, a son of Mrs. Jack C. Massey of Nashville and the late Mr. Armistead Jr., plan to marry in May, the future bride's father, Harry M. Rhett Jr. of Huntsville, Ala., has announced.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have two doors in my house that seem to gradually close by themselves and will not stay fully open. Is there a simple solution to this problem?

title: STREETSCAPES: Spuyten Duyvil Swing Bridge; Restoring a Link In the City's Lifeline
description: SINCE trains stopped running across it in 1982, the Spuyten Duyvil swing bridge has been stuck in the open position, like a faucet that cannot be turned off.

title: Slap Shot: Who Has The Best?
description: On a particularly eventful morning, chairs would be splintered, windows shattered, and traffic outside brought to an abrupt halt. Although they were hardly a rival for the civic disorder that would wrack Chicago a decade later, Bobby Hull remembers his demonstrations of the late 1950's as possessing an element of anarchy, a sense of revolution.

title: STATE-OF-THE-ART FOUL UP
description: WILD BLUE YONDER Money, Politics, and the B-1 Bomber. By Nick Kotz. Illustrated. 313 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: The Short and Limited Life of Central America's Peace Plan
description: THE presidents of the five main Central American countries have yet to carry out the peace plan they signed seven months ago - and it looks as if they never will. But even if the treaty dies a slow death, it may manage to have a few lasting effects.

title: Alan D. Morris Is Wed To Bonnie L. Rothman
description: The marriage of Bonnie Lynne Rothman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Rothman of Haverford, Pa., to Alan David Morris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Morris of Freeport, L.I., took place last evening at the College of Physicians and Surgeons in Philadelphia. Rabbi Henry Morris, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: A Duet for Diplomats Hits Some Strained Notes
description: ''A Walk in the Woods'' arrives on Broadway with theatrical credentials extending from a stage reading at the Eugene O'Neill Playwrights Conference to productions at the Yale Repertory Theater and the La Jolla Playhouse in California. The Lee Blessing play should have been well groomed for New York; that it is not can be attributed to the current production rather than to the play, although the director, Des McAnuff, remains the same.

title:
WORKS IN PROGRESS;
Glass Act
description: LEAD: ''THEY HAVE TORSOS AND AP-pendages, there's an area in each that seems clearly delineated as 'the head,' '' says Howard Ben Tre, of the sculptures he's preparing for a new show opening April 28 at the Charles Cowles Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan. Up to seven feet high, the show's 13 pieces - two are shown at right, in the artist's Providence, R.I., studio - were begun a year ago.

title: 'THEY SENT US TO BE TARGETS'
description: U.S. MARINES IN LEBANON 1982-1984 By Benis M. Frank. Illustrated. 196 pp. Washington: History and Museums Division, Headquarters, United States Marine Corps/ Government Printing Office. Paper, $10.

title:
FOCUS: Resorts;
Discovered Hideaway Growing
description: LEAD: FOR almost a century, wealthy Southerners from Charleston, Savannah, Atlanta, New Orleans and other cities have traveled in the summer to this small mountain town in North Carolina for its cool climate and carefree way of life.

title: Salvador Candidate Is Suspected In Misuse of $2 Million in U.S. Aid
description: A prominent candidate of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Christian Democratic Party has been told by American and Salvadoran officials that he is a subject of an investigation into the misuse of as much as $2 million of American aid, according to Salvadoran and American officials.

title: POSTINGS: Leasing a Course; No Handicap
description: Only 15 to 20 percent of people who buy homes in golf-course communities play golf, according to an informal study by Steven M. Stollman, who, along with brothers Carey and David, is developing the Fairways at Chanticlair in Colchester, Conn. The planned 246-condominium complex off Old Hebron Road, midway between Hartford and New London, will be clustered behind a nine-hole golf course.

title: Wedding Planned By Annick Finlan
description: The engagement of Annick Finlan to William P. Tavoulareas Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Tavoulareas of Sands Point, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Finlan of Whitegate, Cheshire, England. A September wedding in New York is planned.

title: Ruling Party Is Declared the Winner in Bangladesh
description: Bangladesh's ruling Jatiya party today was declared the overwhelming winner of elections that were marred by violence, but the opposition renewed its pledge to topple President H. M. Ershad.

title: Medical Help
description: To the Editor: In ''Insuring Against a Medical Crisis'' (Practical Traveler, Dec. 27), there was an incomplete description regarding memberships and duration of coverage with our company, WorldCare Travel Assistance. In addition to coverage ranging from 8 days ($38) to 90 days ($115), we offer six-month coverage ($155) and coverage for a full 365 days ($200).

title: Your Chances Of an Audit
description: The percentage of individual 1986 returns audited, by income level and by district. The district fluctuations may reflect varying income levels to some extent.

title: Lucinda Alpert and Dodd Grande, Engineer, Wed
description: At the Harvard Club in Boston, Lucinda Jean Alpert, a daughter of Mrs. Malcolm C. Green of Boston and East Hebron, N.H., and Leonard Alpert of Sacramento, Calif., was married yesterday to Dodd Harrison Grande, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Grande of Des Moines, Wash. The ceremony was performed by Richard Alpert, an uncle of the bride, who is known as Baba Ram Dass, the Hindu spiritual leader of the Hanumam Temple in Taos, N.M.

title: Deborah Mullin, Actress, Weds Anthony Lembeck
description: Deborah Mullin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Mullin of Chicago, was married there last night to Anthony Jon Lembeck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lembeck of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi William Frankel officiated at the Standard Club.

title: We Have Met the Enemy in the War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: An Influx of New Money Revs Up the Market
description: At least 300,000 people in the United States collect old cars for love or money or both. And while the number of collectors is increasing by 5 to 10 percent a year, the real growth in the collectible car market is measured in dollars. This year, participants estimate that up to $500 million will change hands at auctions and private sales.

title: LET'S GO TO THE VIDEOTAPE, TOLSTOY
description: After watching the Super Bowl on television, I realized that what modern fiction needs is instant replay. Instant replay is more than a video technique: it's an epiphany, the moment of truth caught, held and made accessible. Until the 20th century, people had only one look, but art is so ambiguous now that the single look won't do. The single look is what Willem de Kooning called ''a slipping glimpse.'' Even Baudelaire said, ''I have seen everything twice,'' but we don't know how he did it.

title: Recorder: Michala Petri In Recital
description: MICHALA PETRI would clearly like to establish the recorder as a modern concert instrument, and to that end she is devoting herself not only to the voluminous and popular Baroque literature, but to reviving 19th-century scores and commissioning new ones. At Weill Recital Hall Friday evening, Miss Petri, with her mother, Hanne Petri, at the harpsichord, covered all those bases, and was a personable, persuasive advocate for her instrument.

title:
GARDENING;
Garden Color Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: LEAD: ENGLISH gardeners have long made it a practice to avoid shocking color combinations. The writer Vita Sackville-West probably developed it to the highest level at Sissinghurst, where her monochromatic gardens still exist today.

title: The Top Amateur
description: There are 10 finalists, including such luminaries as David Robinson, the former Navy basketball star, and the noted gymnast, Scott Johnson, but when the Sullivan Award is presented to the nation's top amateur athlete in Indianapolis tomorrow night, the betting would have to be on Greg Foster. That's partly because Foster, who became the world's top-rated 110-meter hurdler last year, had a dazzling season, winning the at the world championships in Rome and establishing two world marks and two American records. It's also partly because track and field athletes have won the award 34 times in 58 years.

title: A Worksheet to Estimate Taxable Income
description: Going through the worksheet will help you determine which records you need to gather up and organize for tax preparation, as well as give you a ball-park figure on taxable income and help you see where you may want to make adjustments this year. Enter losses as a negative number. Gross Income 1987 1988 Estimate Wages $

title: REALISTIC GOALS IN SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: Leslie Pihas's article ''Choices Both Great and Small'' [ Opinion Page, Jan. 10 ] underlines the problems parents have to deal with when their handicapped youngsters reach the age of 21.

title: The Theme Is War at 2 Theaters
description: IN ITS pursuit of out-of-the-way plays, which is just what makes the company distinctive, the Penguin Repertory can go wildly astray.

title: A NEW ECONOMICS ON WALL STREET
description: On Wall Street, data-watching was always a favorite sport among economists, but not as much as it is today. Hand-holding of clients was always important; now, it can dominate an economist's working day. The principal task used to be the quarterly forecast. Now, the horizon can be as short as a few days - and sometimes less. Once, economists were gurus. Today, they are greeted with a skepticism they are among the first to concede they deserve.

title: Fringe Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Garden Color Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: LEAD: ENGLISH gardeners have long made it a practice to avoid shocking color combinations. The writer Vita Sackville-West probably developed it to the highest level at Sissinghurst, where her monochromatic gardens still exist today.

title: TALKING: Violations; Enforcing Rules in a Conversion
description: UNTIL recently, tenants in a building undergoing conversion in New York State could rest assured that any code violations or other dangerous conditions would be cleared up prior to closing.

title: Brooklyn Woman Delivers Her Own Baby
description: A 22-year-old Brooklyn woman delivered her own baby yesterday morning, following instructions provided by technician.

title: Natalie Combemale to Wed W. P. Matt
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of Winthrop, Me., and New York of the engagement of their daughter Natalie Stanbury Combemale to William Poole Matt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Matt 2d of Utica, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Silver Spring, Md.;
Day Care Clinches a Deal
description: LEAD: IN an unusual swap, the Montgomery County Planning Board has agreed to give a developer 250,000 square feet of space beyond the 325,000 square feet it approved for a downtown regional mall in return for a pledge to help plan, build and operate a 140-child day-care center on county-owned land nearby.

title: A Singing Doctor Works the Land Between Ridicule And Reverence for Nashville
description: Country music is easy to come by in Europe and in the British Isles. There is local imitation country music; you can hear it sung in Danish in trucker bars in Jutland, for example. There is imported mainstream American country: Willie Nelson will play Wembley Stadium here in April.

title: Green Grass Of Home
description: Who stole the strawberries? Who put the eye-black in Kirk Gibson's cap? Who threw the overalls in Mrs. Murphy's chowder? Why did Willie Hernandez throw more cold water on a columnist than he does on opposing rallies for months at a time?

title: THE MEDICAL NAME FOR SORROW
description: SAFETY PATROL By Michael Martone. 128 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $14.95.

title: Tough Treatment For Tax Breaks
description: Everyone is in favor of closing up loopholes in the tax law - a loophole, after all, is something the other guy is wriggling through to avoid taxes. And the Congressional tax writers did just that in the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tightening deductions and taxing income that was previously exempt. That was how they kept the law ''revenue neutral'' while lowering marginal tax rates. But just in case they overzealously included one or two of your own legitimate tax breaks with the loopholes, here is how current law treats the following subjects: Fringe Benefits

title: Mastermind Sought in Officer's Killing
description: With the arraignment yesterday of the fourth suspect in the slaying of a rookie New York City police officer, investigators turned to what they believe is the more difficult task of compiling enough evidence to arrest whoever ordered his execution.

title: Miss Lachapelle to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Lachapelle of Massapequa, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marianne Lachapelle, to Peter Sherman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Sherman of Potomac, Md. Miss Lachapelle, a registered nurse at the Washington Hospital Center, is studying for a master's degree in exercise physiology at George Washington University. Her fiance, a lawyer, is a regulatory analyst at the Science Applications International Corporation in McLean, Va.

title: Hard-Won Lessons In Local Politics
description: A LOCAL election in a small village on Long Island would seem to be very different from a national election, but actually they have a lot in common.

title: GOOD AND EVIL
description: MATEWAN Starring Chris Cooper (in photo), Will Oldham, Mary McDonnell, Kevin Tighe, Nancy Mette, Bob Gunton, David Strathairn, Josh Mostel, James Earl Jones. Directed by John Sayles. 1987. Lorimar Home Video. 132 minutes. $79.95. Rated PG-13.

title: KEY WORDS, PROBLEM WORDS, WORDS I LOVE
description: In 1968 and 1969, ''The Joke'' was translated into all the Western languages. But what surprises!

title: Hamilton College Appoints Historian as 17th President
description: Hamilton College of Clinton, N.Y., named Harry C. Payne its 17th president yesterday.

title: HOSPITALS AND NURSING
description: I have recently moved to New York from Seattle, where I worked for 10 years as a nurse in an intensive-care unit. In an I.C.U., many things can change rapidly without warning. Where I come from, the nurse is trained in managing emergencies as they arise. You know what to do, and can act quickly. In many of the hospitals I have worked in here, the nurse is not allowed to treat a patient before notifying the physician. In the time it takes to do this, it may be too late. The patient may arrest. I have seen patients die because of this.

title: Glimmerings Of Irish Hero For the British
description: A tiny part of the British public claimed a blow for free expression as they gathered here to view some forbidden glimmerings of Michael Collins, the Irishman who led the rebel war against Britain almost seven decades ago.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 6, 1988
In India, a Boom in Private Security Agencies
description: Private security agencies, which provide guards, security systems and investigators for industrial and individual use, have become big business in India because of growing wealth, greater business competition and the fear of terrorism in the Punjab.

title: 18 Youths Seized in Moscow After a Fierce Street Battle
description: Hundreds of Moscow youths battled each other with sticks and iron bars in a street fight last month and 18 people were arrested, the police said today.

title: Kodak Pays the Price for Change
description: In January, the Eastman Kodak Company announced a new product called Create-a-Print that would enable anyone with a color negative to walk into a photoprocessing lab, sit at a computer terminal and design a cropped or enlarged print. Amid the hoopla - and criticism - over Kodak's $5.1 billion acquisition of the Sterling Drug Company later that month, the new product went virtually unnoticed. But in a sense, Create-a-Print is more symbolic of the changes at Kodak than is its gargantuan acquisition.

title: Bloated Budgets Conceal School Basics
description: I HAVE been trying to figure out whether the annual school budget is a sacred cow. That's why I decided to go to the recent hearing and sit in the auditorium amid the rest of the .002 percent of the town population that attends such stuff.

description: Blanche Du Bois first appeared to Tennessee Williams as an image: a woman sitting in a chair in the moonlight, waiting for a man to show up. Though she grew to be the heroine of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' she never stopped waiting for men to save her.

title: Soviet Is Added To Baseball Group
description: The executive committee of the International Baseball Association has approved an application from the Soviet Union to become the association's 65th member.

title: Here I Sit, No Warts at All
description: HIS BACK WAS TO the wall in New Hampshire. Hot-eyed pollsters were tracking voters through the snow to detect the impact of the ''Iowa bounce,'' the term for the influence of one state's results on the next state's election. The trend-happy media were headlining ''Dole on a Roll,'' suggesting momentum growing for the campaign of Bob Dole, a phrase based on a crapshooter's run of luck, and not a new heroic sandwich.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A Special Silver Dollar from Canada
description: LEAD: SINCE 1971, the Royal Canadian Mint has issued silver dollars as collector's items, changing their designs every year and selling them at a premium. The coins' silver content is 50 percent and they do not have circulating counterparts.

title: Few but Sturdy Threads Tie New South to the Old
description: ''TELL about the South. What's it like there. What do they do there. Why do they live there. Why do they live at all,'' asked a Harvard student in William Faulkner's ''Absalom, Absalom!'' questioning his Mississippi roommate about the enigmas of a violent and defensive region.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. Is Getting Stuck With a Glut of Repossessed Houses
description: When a foreclosed home falls into the hands of the Federal Housing Administration, ''we try to get it back on the market within 14 days,'' said James C. Nestler, the deputy assistant secretary for single-family housing, says. The Federal National Mortgage Association, in contrast, does everything it can not to sell. ''If there's any way to keep a mortgage and a house together, we do it,'' Bonnie O'Dell, a Fannie Mae spokesman, said.

title: A Checklist of the Itemized Deductions Now Allowed Taxpayers
description: Limitations are being phased in, so careful taxpayers may want to change the structure of their finances in the coming year to be in the best possible shape for 1988 returns. MORTGAGE INTEREST Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Mortgage interest on only a principal or second home is fully deductible, if the mortgage does not exceed the lower of the home's purchase price and improvement costs (subject to limitations) or its fair market value. Interest on debt incurred prior to Aug. 16, 1986, is not subject to the purchase price limitation. Interest on a mortgage that exceeds the cost but not the fair market value is deductible if the proceeds are used for educational or medical expenses. Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: For debt incurred after Oct. 13, 1987, a deduction will be allowed for: Interest on debt used to acquire or improve a principal or second home to the extent this combined debt does not exceed $1 million; and other mortgage interest on a principal or second home to the extent the mortgage does not exceed $100,000. The loan proceeds may be used for any purpose. OTHER PERSONAL INTEREST Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Only 65 percent is deductible Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Deductible portion drops to 40 percent in 1988, 20 percent in 1989 and 10 percent in 1990; no deductions after 1990. INVESTMENT INTEREST Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Generally deductible to the extent of net investment income + $10,000, excluding long-term capital gains Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deductible to the extent of net investment income, including all gains regardless of holding period Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 REAL AND PERSONAL PROPERTY TAXES; STATE AND LOCAL INCOME TAXES Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Deductible SALES TAXES Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Not deductible Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Not deductible MEDICAL EXPENSES Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible above 5 percent of adjusted gross income Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deductible above 7.5 percent of adjusted gross income Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 CHARITABLE CONTRIBUTIONS Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible for both itemizers and nonitemizers Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deductible only for itemizers Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 MOVING EXPENSES Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible for both itemizers and nonitemizers Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deductible only for itemizers Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 MISCELLANEOUS EXPENSES Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Unreimbursed employee business expenses and other miscellaneous deductions, such as tax-preparation fees and investment advisory fees, are limited to those exceeding 2 percent of adjusted gross income. Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 BUSINESS ENTERTAINMENT EXPENSES AND MEALS Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Fully deductible Law Affecting 1987 Returns: 80 percent deductible; qualified convention meals allowed in full Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987, except the convention meal exception expires after 1988 BUSINESS USE OF HOME Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Deduction for qualified business use of home was limited to gross income from activity, reduced by interest and taxes related to business portion of home. Disallowed deductions due to limitation could not be carried forward. Law Affecting 1987 Returns: Deduction for qualified business use of home limited to gross income from activity, reduced by interest and taxes related to business portion of home, and further reduced by all other non-home office expenses of business. Disallowed deductions resulting from the limitation are carried forward to later years. Law Affecting Post-1987 Returns: Unchanged from 1987 DEPRECIATION Law Affecting 1986 Returns: Accelerated cost recovery system provided write-offs under five classes of assets for 3- , 5- , 10- , 15- and 19-year property. Expensing in lieu of cost recovery allowances was limited to $5,000. Law Affecting 1987 Returns: New system expands to six classes of personal property and two classes of real property. The most significant change is straight-line depreciation is instituted for real property, 27.5 years for residential property and 31.5 years for commercial realty.

title: Super Tuesday Warps Race to Succeed Stennis
description: The Democratic Party's effort to unite the voting power of Southern states in a swelling Super Tuesday chorus has produced some confusing political dynamics in the Mississippi contest to pick a successor to Senator John C. Stennis.

title: A CURRICULUM OF MISFORTUNE
description: LEAD: RETURNING A Spiritual Journey. By Dan Wakefield. 250 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Democratic Challenge To DioGuardi Begins
description: DEMOCRATIC efforts to recapture the 20th Congressional District seat held by Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi entered a new phase last week when Dennis Mehiel, a 45-year-old North Castle businessman, was the first to announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the seat.

title: POSTINGS: Jamaica Mall; Gertz Redux
description: Where the Gertz Department Store failed, sponsors hope the Gertz Mall will succeed. The new shopping center in the Jamaica section of Queens will open on Saturday with 76 stores and seven food outlets in the basement and first floor of what once was one of the largest department stores in New York. The original Gertz store closed in 1980, and the new mall will not have a large anchor tenant. Jerry Gertz, vice president of STREG Inc. - a play on the family name - said the 100,000-square-foot Art-Deco mall will instead rely on local stores such as Audio Express and smaller chain outlets such as Fayva shoes, Sterling Optical and Hallmark Cards.

title: Mourners for I.R.A. Member Clash With Police in Ulster
description: Policemen and mourners scuffled today during a funeral procession for an Irish Republican Army member who was one of two men killed when they accidentally detonated a bomb they were installing in a van, the police said.

title: The Bite of the '87 Revenue Act
description: As individuals prepared to cope this tax season with the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the end of the year saw yet a new tax law take effect - the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1987.

title: More Than Ever, Africa Prefers One-Party Rule
description: THE arrests and unrest last week in the wake of Senegal's elections were another reminder of the continuing decline of Western-style democracy in Africa. Nearly three decades after the wave of decolonization, 38 of 45 sub-Saharan states have single- or no-party systems. Only a half dozen operating under majority rule - Senegal, Gambia, Botswana, Madagascar, Sudan and Mauritius -allow more than one party.

title: Profiles: How Some Are Getting Their Financial Houses in Order  A Young Family
description: Altagracia R. Coleman, who had combined a sales career with being a wife and mother, took a leave of absence of more than a year to be with her three children. Then, in 1984 she returned to work after she and her husband, Richard, realized that her salary was needed to meet the family's expenses.

description: To the Editor:

description: Mario Garcia came to the airport rally here as much out of curiosity as conviction. But after Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts finished a speech that alternated between English and Spanish, Mr. Garcia broke into an enthusiastic chant of ''Viva, Mike; viva, Mike.''

title: New Challenge to Board of Examiners
description: CRITICS of New York City's schools, led by the Educational Priorities Panel, a civic watchdog organization, have once again called for the abolition of the city's Board of Examiners, which licenses teachers and principals for city schools.

title: For Latin America, It's the Decade of Unsupportable Debt
description: IN hindsight, the early days of Latin America's debt crisis were adventurous as government officials, foreign bankers and international experts stepped gingerly into the unknown, aware only that one false move - a moment of panic or an act of despair - could bring chaos to the international monetary system.

title: HOW MUCH FOR THAT TURKEY IN THE RAFTER?
description: What do you call a group of turkeys? The question was asked in your Jan. 31 Long Island Journal. The answer clearly is a rafter of turkeys. Everybody knows that; everybody, that is, who regularly consults Christopher Leahy's ''Birdwatcher's Companion'' or has thrilled to James Lipton's collective noun musings in ''An Exaltation of Larks.''

WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
AIDS Testing

description: Tracy Stephanie Hurlbut and Jeffrey Stuart Sonn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Sonn of Tarrytown, N.Y., plan to marry in October, the future bride's mother, Dorothy Kruse of Burlington, Wis., has announced. Ms. Hurlbut, also a daughter of the late Donovan W. title: Cindy Still to Wed Niles A. Howard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Still of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Washington, Iowa, have announced the engagement of their daughter Cindy Jo Still to Niles Ainsworth Howard, a son of Mrs. Leon Earl Howard of Clinton, N.C., and the late Mr. Howard.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: LISBON
description: Without a doubt Lisbon is one of the more relaxed cities of the world. It has a genuine joie de vivre that does not seemed forced as in some cities, and hustling-turned-hassling seems to be at a minimum.

title: FICTION
description: THE PALACE. By Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $18.95.) If you're a squat pudgy sexist approaching middle age with little to look forward to and less to forget, Paul Erdman's sixth novel is a fairy tale written for you. It's about Danny Lehman's conversion from a nebbish in Philly to a wheeler-dealer in Vegas. At the start, he owns a shabby coin shop and whoops it up with bowling and bagels. Then, in a hop, a skip and a jump, he builds a bullion empire that out-Deaks Deak International, takes a pair of hoods to the cleaners after laundering their money, picks up a couple of casinos (the Palace is one of them), and even gets involved in a leveraged buy out. By the end, he has amassed almost as much money as a Hunt brother could lose, and left every woman around him weak-kneed. He's not much to look at but, as a stewardess observes in Mr. Erdman's embarrassing prose, ''he would be one hell of a lot of fun in the sack.'' Needless to say, Danny isn't exactly Gloria Steinem's idea of Mr. Right. Or Horatio Alger's. What's the secret of his success? Good financial advisers: a bartender, a Hollywood sharpie and a six-foot prostitute with a heart of gold. So the plot is far-fetched, but who wants reality? If you have enough reality in your life, ''The Palace'' isn't exactly the worst way to escape. It certainly beats tequila or television. But Danny wouldn't be caught dead reading it. ''After all, you could hardly make any money while reading, could you?'' he asks. ''So why waste the time?''

title: Indiana School Wins Again
description: The Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School in tiny Hamlet, Ind., kept up their winning ways Friday night with a 59-54 victory over neighboring North Judson High, moving a step nearer the regional basketball tournament. With a record of 21 victories and 1 defeat, the school has 9 of the 20 male seniors on the varsity team. A crowd of 3,200 attended the Friday night game, with a big contingent traveling from Hamlet, population 640.

title: Hundreds of Marchers Clash With Police at Seoul Campus
description: Hundreds of protesters demanding the release of political prisoners today threw rocks and firebombs at policemen, who responded by firing tear gas to disperse the crowd.

Constantine of Greenwich, Conn., and Rick Allen Beispel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Beispel of New York, were married yesterday at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn. The Rev. title: WHY SINGERS DON'T SET RECORDS

Liddle of Riverside, Calif., who writes to ask, ''Since track and field and swimming records fall all the time, why shouldn't singers improve?'' In a postscript, Mr. Liddle notes, ''Of course, I recall Salvatore Baccaloni as Leporello and E. Pinza as the Don. . .''
