description: Hamburger Hill Starring Anthony Barrile, Michael Patrick Boatman, Don Cheadle, Michael Dolan, Don James, Dylan McDermott, Courtney Vance, Tegan West. Directed by John Irvin. 1987. Vestron Video. 109 minutes. $89.98. Rated R.

title: Three Examples of the 'Kiddie Tax'
description: Each case assumes a child under age 14 with $3,000 of interest income. Andy Betty Chris Earned income $0 $1,000 $600 Itemized deductions 0 0 800* Total unearned income 3,000 3,000 3,000 Standard deduction 500 500** N/A Directly connected itemized deductions N/A N/A 600* Taxable unearned income 2,500 2,500 2,400 Unearned income taxable at child's rate 500 500 500 Earned income taxable at child's rate 0 500 400 Net unearned income taxed at parents' rate $2,000 $2,000 $1,900 * $600 of the $800 in itemized deductions is directly connected to the production of unearned income and therefore reduces it; the other $200 is taken against the child's earned income. ** Generally, the child's deduction would be $1,000, but only $500 may be used against unearned income. The remaining $500 is used against the child's earned income. (Source: Coopers & Lybrand)

title: Profiles: How Some Are Getting Their Financial Houses in Order  A Young Investor
description: Four years ago William J. Boyko left his native West Germany to take a job at his company's United States subsidiary. A marketing manager for Rohm Tech Inc. of Malden, Mass., Mr. Boyko is in charge of selling chemicals to the leather and fur industries and earns, he says, a ''decent'' salary.

title: 'I'm an Ambassador for Connecticut'
description: ANN SULLIVAN acts as the eyes and ears of Connecticut in the nation's capital.

title: Covering Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: The Modern Prepares for the 21st Century
description: The recent move by the Museum of Modern Art in appointing Kirk Varnedoe, age 42, to succeed William Rubin, age 60, as head of its department of painting and sculpture, marks a major generational shift. With the world's greatest assemblage of 20th-century masterworks and a long roster of illustrious exhibitions to its credit, the department is the museum's biggest, its best funded and its most powerful esthetic presence. Mr. Varnedoe, a respected art historian and exhibition organizer, is ambitious, energetic and keen for new approaches. In the post - held before him by such distinguished scholar-showmen as the museum's founding director Alfred Barr, Mr. Rubin and, for a brief period, James Thrall Soby and James Johnson Sweeney - he becomes the Modern's most prominent spokesman, with a significant influence on its artistic policies.

title: VAMPIRES AND THE LANDED GENTRY
description: BLOOD AND WATER And Other Tales. By Patrick McGrath. 192 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $15.95.

title: After 1988, Higher Rates?
description: WASHINGTON

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
MILAN SETTLES DOWN
description: LEAD: DON'T LOOK FOR ABERRATIONS in the ready-to-wear collections for fall and winter that will be revealed this week in Milan. Although many designers flirted with dangerously short hemlines for summer, they have returned to a more reasonable shortness, most often just above the knee, for autumn.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Erie, Pa.; New Life On the Shore
description: REDEVELOPMENT along Lake Erie's shore here in northwestern Pennsylvania is finally taking shape after several years of planning. By far the largest project, Perry's Landing, a $120 million, 90-acre mixed-used commercial and residential development, is under construction on Presque Isle Bay with 180 new boat slips set to be ready in April.

title: Program Is Helping Elderly to Cope With Crime in a Massachusetts City
description: A network of services for elderly crime victims here in this western Massachusetts city and the rest of Hampden County has encouraged the elderly to report crimes against them to the police, officials say.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS: Rising Caseload;
Child Abuse Victims Face System Made For Adults
description: LEAD: A SHARP rise in reported cases of child abuse is straining a legal system that is already ill-equipped to handle the problems of child victims and witnesses.

title: Prospects; How The Networks Line Up
description: Television's broadcast networks are facing intense competition from cable TV, independent stations and each other. The Olympics and the Presidential elections should make 1988 a good year. But not all analysts agree. What will 1988 be like for the networks? Daniel B. Burke President and chief operating officer, Capital Cities/ABC Inc.

title:
ANTIQUES;
102 Dealers To Display Antiques In Wilton
description: LEAD: WHEN the Wilton Historical Society held its first antiques show in the spring of 1967, it was a casual outdoor fund-raiser much akin to a flea market. Since then, the event has become an annual tradition, changing and growing year by year into one of the most extensive and prestigious shows in the Northeast.

title: 'Serenading Louie' at Hartford Stage
description: IN any terrain, from a seedy hotel lobby (''The Hot l Baltimore'') to a gazebo on a moonlit night in Lebanon, Mo. (''Talley's Folly''), where souls are painfully bared, one has come to expect, in the plays of Lanford Wilson, the temperance of compassion and lyricism.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: ABC should be fined for false advertising. Instead of airing the Olympics, the network aired various advertisements with infrequent interruptions for Olympic sports activities. More time was spent on airing advertisements than on hockey during the Canada-Czechoslovakia game. S. E. WARD Stratford, Conn.

title: Gorbachev Is Feeling the Heat From the South
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV begins his fourth year as Soviet leader this week probably worried less about the state of the economy than the stability of the state.

title: New York Reinstates Worker Hospitalized Before a Job Action
description: An Emergency Medical Services worker who was injured in the line of duty was reinstated yesterday, a day after the Koch administration mistakenly dismissed her for taking part in a sickout.

title: Therapists Say Heterosexual AIDS Is 'Rampant'
description: Countering a wide range of scientific studies and the judgments of virtually all top AIDS experts, Dr. William H. Masters and Virginia E. Johnson contend that the AIDS virus is ''now running rampant'' among heterosexuals in the United States.

title: Liza Parker to Marry Frank Migliorelli
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ashton Parker to Frank Angelo Migliorelli has been announced by Eleanor W. Shakin of New York and Sherman, Conn., and Peter J. Parker of Philadelphia, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Migliorelli of Pelham Manor and Red Hook, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Cynthia McKay To Marry July 9
description: Mrs. William C. McKay of Rye, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter Cynthia B. McKay to James Beckett Meeker, a son of Mrs. Oivind Lorentzen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Robert DeWitt Clinton Meeker. The couple plan to marry July 9.

title: Changing Times Dilute Church Group's Power
description: The Council of Churches of New York City, once the premier Protestant voice in the city, recently moved out of its spacious suite of offices on Riverside Drive and squeezed its operation into four tiny rooms in the tower of Riverside Church.

title: The Pentagon Needs Less High Tech
description: America spends too much for its military and receives too little for its money. The military consumes 6.7 percent of gross national product and 32 percent of America's research and development expenditures. Germany spends 3.1 percent of G.N.P. and employs 6 percent of its R.&D. talent in the service of its defense; Japan spends even less. These countries correspondingly spend 50 percent more of their G.N.P. on commercial R.&D. than we do. This contrast partly explains America's competitiveness predicament.

title: White Plains Adopts School Plan
description: LEAD: BEGINNING with the class entering kindergarten in September next year, parents in White Plains will select which of five public elementary schools their children will attend. Whether they get their first choice of school will depend largely on whether the racial and ethnic mix of students in that particular grade conforms to new school district guidelines.

title:
WINE;
The 'Boutique Bottles': Ventures in Quality
description: LEAD: WHILE Gallo continues to sell more than a million cases of wine a week, most critics contend that many of the best California bottles hail from very small establishments, commonly referred to as ''boutiques.'' Lacking the financial clout to begin major advertising or public-relations campaigns, the boutiques depend primarily on word of mouth and winning awards to encourage sales.

title: From Pool to Pool, Condo to Farm
description: With a reach from Key West to Seattle, from the civil servants of the northern Virginia suburbs to the farm workers of the Rio Grande Valley, Super Tuesday is not a moonlight and magnolia primary.

title:
ART;
Taking a Stand on Social Issues
description: LEAD: SOCIAL issues have had a secondary role in art for most of this century, an era when arrangements of line and color were considered sufficient to evoke a satisfying response.

title: On 'Serious Money'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. NUCLEAR UNIT ASSAILED BY STAFF
description: Members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission staff say their superiors have tried to discredit a Justice Department investigation of the Tennessee Valley Authority's top nuclear power manager.

title: City Finally Focusing on Its Sluggish Rights Panel
description: WHEN a Mayoral task force issued a stinging critique of New York City's Human Rights Commission last month, saying it took years to handle complaints that should be resolved in months, few were surprised.

title: Riker Hill: What Is Fair to Artists and the County?
description: WINDS of change, stirred up by a new political administration, have shaken the tranquillity of artists working in studios at Riker Hill Art Park here.

title: Prince Charles Assesses the Castles of Pittsburgh
description: Prince Charles, whose criticisms of postwar British architecture and planning have made him his own country's most celebrated architecture critic, took his crusade to the United States today for the first time and expanded his target accordingly.

title: Official Offers Advice on Eviction Rights
description: ''DON'T GO'' is the advice that William M. Connolly, director of the Division of Housing and Development at the state's Department of Community Affairs, has for tenants who receive oral orders from city officials to leave their homes within 48 hours.

title: Colorful Baskets Embody American Indian Culture
description: While Andy Warhol was forward-looking in the realms of art and film, he also took a keen interest in things of the past. This facet of the late artist's enthusiasms can be seen in the collection of artifacts from his estate that will be auctioned at Sotheby's in a 10-day sale running from April 23 through May 3 - a sprawling 2,526 lots, spelled out in a six-part catalogue that costs $95.

title: One Man's Treasures Are His Wife's Junk
description: IT was not the first time my wife, quite rightly perhaps, tried to get me to throw my old gym shorts into the trash. They are tattered, old, ugly, made for a person 35 pounds lighter than myself, and would be rejected from most rag bags. I, however, refuse to dispose of them, for purely sentimental reasons. They are one of those things I have grown quite attached to.

title:
GARDENING;
Simple Tests Reveal the Soil's Status
description: LEAD: GARDENERS are seldom able to start out with the kind of good soil they read about. Most of them try to make do with what they have, but part of the ethic of good gardening is making the soil better. Soil tests are an intelligent first step to take toward this goal.

title: The Oslo Philharmonic Has Come a Long Way
description: Although experiments have shown that orchestras cannot often get along without conductors, it is an open secret that they cannot always get along with them, either. Some of the tensions are undoubtedly rooted in the same problems that crop up between any group of employees and management, yet the results achieved in performance seem less dependent on personal relations between players and conductor than on artistic rapport combined with mutual respect.

title: Ives's Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: SIGHT LINES. By Arlene Croce. (Knopf, $19.95.) Arlene Croce is the most cogent of dance critics. Her lucid and nimble style targets the reader who can take a reference to Eddie Murphy in one sentence and ''Giselle'' in the next. She has been writing for The New Yorker for the past 15 years, and ''Sight Lines'' is her third book of collected reviews. It chronicles the period from 1981 to 1987. This was an odd and, in many respects, a bleak time, with the death of George Balanchine in 1983, a lack of innovative choreography and the decline of the international stars who had made dance so exciting in the 70's. If this collection does not have the power of her first or second, it is because by and large what Ms. Croce got to see was not so compelling. And when she disapproves she can be downright nasty, as in her appraisal of a short male dancer at the New York City Ballet whose outstretched leg had the impact of a ''fully extended finger.'' She goes straight for the jugular when something strikes her as false - Pina Bausch makes women ''look worse on the stage than any misogynist ever has'' -but at times her enthusiasms for some post-modern choreographers slip the leash and run wild. Her writing, though, is often poetic: ''The waltz, with its three-beat phrase, makes a drama of balance. Weight is continually suspended, as if it could somehow be abolished, leaving us free to float. The tango, in four beats, offers no such incentive to keep moving. As an image of destiny, it is tragic rather than poignant, a dance in which we confront our mortality, luxuriate in it, but do not transcend it.''

title: Wadkins Retains Two-Shot Lead
description: Bobby Wadkins, who has made over $1 million but has not won a tournament in 14 years on the PGA Tour, is in good position to gain his first Tour victory Sunday.

title: Baby Boomers Reshaping The Housing Market
description: JUST as they have for the last 15 years, members of the postwar baby-boom generation, by the strength of their numbers, are again reshaping the housing market to fit their own needs.

title: Waste-Site Panel at Crossroad
description: LEAD: THE state's Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission will decide this spring whether to pursue legal changes that could dramatically alter where and how such facilities are situated in New Jersey.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Ah, Sweet Mystery of Oscar

title: Blunting a Poison Pen in Bensonhurst
description: LAWN ornaments of the Madonna alternate with dragon-vase window dressings on Bay 20th Street. The neat row of homes belonging to Italian and Asian families near Brooklyn's south shore is typical of Bensonhurst, a largely Italian and Jewish community with few blacks that is seeking to acclimate itself to ethnic and racial diversity.

title: 'Marigold, Jigsaw Girl': Growing Up in Pieces
description: WITHOUT occasional new material to challenge them, actors and directors can lose their creative edge and audience interest can atrophy. Consequently, it is always exciting when a theater takes a chance and presents new work.

title: Stalin's Killerati
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Concert 'Firsts' Are Scheduled
description: ''BEAUTY in music is too often confused with something that lets the ears lie back in an easy chair,'' wrote Charles Ives, the pioneering American composer. Ives also noted that ''music (and all art, like all life) must be a part of the great organic flow, onward and always upward, or become soft in muscles and spirit, and die.''

title: Q and A
description: Undercutting Renters

title: PERSPECTIVES: Landmarking; Agency's Permit Procedures Put to Test
description: THE executors of the estate of the late Dorothy Valentine Smith had a rude surprise last September. They applied to the New York City Buildings Department for a permit to demolish two modest vacant houses on the North Shore of Staten Island. The houses occupy a small portion of two acres that are valuable for commercial and residential development.

title: Righting English Becomes Easier
description: There is a thing called the idiocy factor, and it crops up frequently in business letters. ''Dear Valued Customer,'' a letter might begin. ''Thank you for your odor. Unfortunately the shipment of widgets were delayed, and the warehouse doesn't have anymore in stock at this point in time. My partner and myself send our apology. We are all ready working to get some more, and we intend to, without farther delay, send them to you. Sincerely, John Q. Bigshot.''

title: Putting the Squeeze on Panama's Economy
description: WHEN General Manuel Antonio Noriega refused the blandishments of the Reagan Administration last December to step aside as the de facto head of the Panamanian Government, American strategy makers suddenly found themselves without a strategy.

title: Book Birds of Spring
description: Impatient New Yorkers who see spring in the first signs of snowdrops or hear it in the early pipings of finches can head to 42d Street to see a wonderful aviary.

title: Piano: Jorge Bolet
description: SOMETIMES frustratingly complacent, the music world is occasionally jarred by a strange and heartening twist of fate. Consider, for instance, what has happened lately to Jorge Bolet. For decades, the pianist's career progressed at what might be called a respectable trot, never sprinting despite the combination of good looks and swift fingers that this artist possessed. Then a few years ago the Cuban-born musician, already in his 70s, made a series of Liszt recordings and gave several recitals of Romantic favorites that brought him widespread praise and newfound popularity. There was nothing strikingly different about these performances from what Mr. Bolet had been doing all along on stage, and yet suddenly - rather inexplicably -the pianist found himself with more concert dates than ever.

title: Weather's Fine for Ferry Service
description: FRED HALL'S tastes about winter weather are strange but understandable. Like most people, he revels in sunny days in the summer. But in the winter, he is happiest if it is snowing, raining or sleeting.

title: Towns Facing Bigger Bills for Trash
description: DRAMATIC price increases at the two trash-to-energy plants in the state have many towns wondering whether they have underestimated costs for the six plants in the planning stage.

title: Mountain Bikers Face Limits in Central Park
description: Clad in colorful jerseys, tight black pants and shiny helmets, dozens of mountain bikers have invaded the hills of Central Park in the last year.

title: Louvre Pyramid Is Unveiled
description: Parisians got their first official look today at a modernistic and gigantic glass pyramid set amid the ancient stone courtyards of the Louvre.

title: Raise $16 Billion in Alcohol and Tobacco Taxes
description: To the Editor:
