description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Modern Bill by Gerard Schwarz
description: IF there was a conclusion to be drawn from Gerard Schwarz's Music Today program Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, it was that contemporary composers have slowly found their way out of the woods: The earliest work offered, Harrison Birtwistle's ''World Is Discovered'' (1961), was virtually impenetrable, while the latest, Richard Danielpour's ''First Light'' (1988), was instantly accessible. Between them, works by Alberto Ginastera and George Perle charted a path toward clarity of expression.

title: NAILING DOWN THE TRIP'S COSTS
description: THE deterioration of the value of the dollar against many foreign currencies is causing a lot of people to rethink their plans for travel abroad this year. Some, with the encouragement of their travel agents, are looking over the maps of Eastern Europe.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: Good: the mirth of Eddie (the Eagle) Edwards. Bad: the involvement of George Steinbrenner. ROBERT JAMES Clifton, N.J.

title: Caroline Herbert Weds J. D. Lewis
description: Caroline Alice Herbert, a daughter of Col. Morris Joseph Herbert, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Herbert of Highland Falls, N.Y., and Joseph Donald Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Lewis of Woodmere, L.I., were married last evening at the Jewish Chapel at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y. Rabbi Kenneth J. Leinwand, an assistant chaplain at the academy, performed the ceremony.

title: Purdue Beats Michigan To Clinch Big Ten Title
description: Melvin McCants scored a career-high 24 points, including three crucial free throws in the closing minutes, as Purdue survived frigid shooting down the stretch to defeat Michigan, 80-67.

title: BORN OF THE SUN
description: WHERE YA GOIN'? OUT. WHATCHA gonna do? Nuttin.

title: Grumman, We Need Leadership
description: FOR the Grumman Corporation, it all started in a small rented garage in Baldwin, building floats for Navy seaplanes. Today it is difficult to believe that even Leroy Grumman, engineer, entrepreneur and aviation innovator, would recognize this multibillion dollar giant of a company.

title: Museums Are Where Cultures Go to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate Over A Canadian Bill of Rights
description: AMBIVALENCE toward a neighbor that is 10 times larger in population and economic strength has been a perennial feature of Canadian life. Lately, the strains of admiration and resentment have been in the forefront of public debate, with those who look south for social and economic models increasingly at odds with those who warn of creeping ''Americanization.''

title: Strategies for the Dollar-Wise
description: >Despite all of the dollar's gyrations over the last year, American travelers should not be disheartened -traveling in many countries costs only slightly more than it did a year ago, and in many places Americans will find it costs less.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Thoughts Tossing in a Hammock In anthropology now, says Clifford Geertz, there's ''a pervasive nervousness about the whole business of claiming to explain enigmatical others.'' This is from his ''Works and Lives: the Anthropologist as Author'' (Stanford University).

title: Body and Mind; The New Marital Therapy
description: HOW LOVE'S SWEET song has changed. Just a decade ago it was marked by bold discordancies and feisty lyrics: alternate life styles, swinging, open marriage. All those are gone now, and the new lyrics sound remarkably old: constancy, stability, tradition.

title: Warehousing
description: To the Editor:

title: MASTERING THE DARK FOREST
description: THE LIFE OF EMILY CARR By Paula Blanchard. Illustrated. 331 pp. Seattle: The University of Washington Press. $19.95.

title: Miss Cabana Wed to J. A. DePasquale
description: In the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, Elizabeth Ann Cabana, a daughter of Oliver F. Cabana of Buffalo and Margaret Cabana of Kenmore, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Anthony DePasquale, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Anthony DePasquale of Wethersfield, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla. The Rev. Thomas A. Nielson performed the ceremony.

title: Hospitals, Citing AIDS, Seek Higher Fees
description: LEAD: HOSPITALS are asking the state to allow them to raise patient fees because the costs of caring for AIDS patients and buying disposable clothing and equipment has become a significant expense.

title: Aiding U.S. Olympic Team May Bring Gold to N.H.L., Too
description: Last month, the United States hockey team gave the Olympic tournament some of its most compelling moments in 7-5 losses to Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.

title: WHEN FAST IS FAST ENOUGH
description: A colleague here in the office just handed me ''Sometimes, Fast Isn't Fast Enough'' by Janice Hecht (Opinion page, Feb. 14) as I was waiting for my laser printer to print.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: What was good in the Olympics? Hockey without goons. HAROLD SCHLOSSBERG Brooklyn

title: ELITIST DISTINCTIONS
description: In her letter to the editor (Feb. 7), Natania Rosenfeld complains bitterly and cogently about the ''elitism'' of Allan Bloom's views in his book ''The Closing of the American Mind.'' Yet her complaint is exactly what Mr. Bloom is talking about -the American desire to ''democratize'' art and literature so that ''elitist'' distinctions of quality are banished. Some artists are better than others, and somebody needs to say so. Is it elitist to think - and say - that Shakespeare is better than Neil Simon, that Mozart is better than Neil Diamond?

title: Investors Face Myriad Choices Under New Law
description: ''The best investment is land, because they ain't making anymore of it.'' - Will Rogers

title: Design in Barcelona: Gaudi and Gris
description: ONE of the great pleasures of visiting Barcelona is discovering the city's rich heritage of turn-of-the-century architecture. The l'Eixample quarter is filled with Modernist buildings by three important Catalan architects of the period, Lluis Domenech i Muntaner, Josep Puig i Cadafalch and the city's beloved Antonio Gaudi, whose Parc Guell and monumental unfinished cathedral, the Sagrada Familia, attract as many visitors as the Picasso museum.

title: Wachtler Supports A Nonpartisan Vote To Re-elect Judges
description: The Chief Judge of New York State, Sol Wachtler, bowing to what he called the political realities in Albany, has endorsed a proposal to replace the partisan re-election process for sitting judges with a nonpartisan retention election.

title: The Artists of Staten Island
description: FROM a developer's point of view, Snug Harbor is one that got away. An enclave of 19th-century buildings -some are Greek Revival in style - it is set on 75 acres and might have become a high-rise heaven if preservation groups and the people of Staten Island had not pressured the City of New York to buy it.

title: Fame for Cawley
description: Winning Wimbledon may not guarantee election to the International Tennis Hall of Fame, but winning twice helps, especially if the victories were eyebrow-raising upsets nine years apart. That, anyway - plus a string of other major championships - was the formula followed by the hall's newest recruit, Evonne Goolagong Cawley, who has become the 147th person and the 36th woman elected to the shrine in Newport, R.I.

title: Bathing Suits, Alas! That Time Again
description: THE season is upon us. Crocuses are baring their tender shoots in the rock garden. Heavy woolens have hit the 50-percent-off rack in the stores. Winter is on the wane. I'm talking bathing suits.

title: THE OBSERVATION TOWER
description: LEAD: THE most-celebrated bat-wielder to come out of East Side High School in Paterson is not its principal, Joe Clark, but an alumnus, Larry Doby.

title: SENATORS CRITICIZE SHAMIR'S POSITION ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: Thirty United States Senators, including many of Israel's staunchest supporters, have written a letter criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud party, suggesting they may be obstructing efforts to reach a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: A Daughter's Spirited Feline Legacy
description: THE small, pointed face with its wide-apart green eyes stared down at us from the topmost shelf of the city apartment. Tiger-striped, an Egyptian statue come to life, this was our introduction to our daughter Lisa's newly adopted kitten, Ziggy.

title: Eagles in Comeback in the County Area
description: LEAD: AMERICA'S national bird, the bald eagle, though still endangered in New York, has been seen in record numbers this winter in the Westchester area and in other parts of the state, according to local and state authorities who have recently completed the mid-February bald eagle counts.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
At the Wall: I Remember, I Remember
description: LEAD: NOT LONG ago, while walking from the Washington Monument to the Lincoln Memorial on a family visit to the capital, I caught a fleeting glimpse of a swiftly approaching hooded assailant.

title: AN EERIE TALE OF CIVILIZATION AND THE JUNGLE
description: In ''Juan Darien,'' by the Uru-guayan short-story writer Horacio Quiroga, a woman's compassion transforms an orphaned tiger cub into a child.

title: Vivienne Barr to Wed Perry Howard Braun
description: The engagement of Vivienne Hanna Barr to Perry Howard Braun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman L. Braun of Highland Park, Ill., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Charles E. Barr of New York. The couple plan to marry in the fall.

title: Pop: Brazil's Roberto Carlos In Love Songs and Stories
description: TWELVE string players, three keyboardists, two guitarists, one bassist, three background singers, two drummers, and six horns helped the Brazilian singer Roberto Carlos charm the sold-out crowd at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Carlos, looking healthy and tan in a white suit with sleeves rolled up, acts the repentant playboy who has found the power of true love - his songs leap all the way from phrases like ''I want you to be my love'' to ''What will be with you?''

title: Mush From the Office Seekers
description: Amid the din of the Presidential debates and the rambling reflections that are conveyed to the public in 20 to 30 second whiffs across the TV screen, a rather odd conclusion is born. It is this: Only rarely has any candidate publicly confronted the challenges, changes and dangers that the 41st President will surely have to deal with.

title: Wild Tulips Flower Early in the Spring
description: FINISH dormant pruning and spraying. Check flower borders and young shrubs; push back into the ground, gently, any that have had their roots heaved by frosts. Indoors transplant annual seedlings that have developed their second pair of true leaves; plant seed of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants indoors. The First Tulips

title: Slow Progress On Takeover Irks Lilco Opponents
description: FOR several months now, officials involved in the fight over the future of the Long Island Lighting Company and its Shoreham nuclear power plant have predicted that a resolution to the enormously complicated issue would come ''in a couple of weeks.''

title: THE GUIDE
description: GAELIC FESTIVAL Step-dancing demonstrations, pipe bands, Irish coffee and speeches by Westchester officials of Irish extraction are on the bill for the Gaelic Feis, or festival, scheduled from 6 to 10 P.M. Friday and from noon to 10 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday. It is to take place under a 60-by-100-foot heated tent on Glen Island in New Rochelle, in observance of the city's tricentennial and the 125th birthday of the Irish Benevolent Society, a charitable organization in the city.

title: REGENTS CONSIDER HOMELESS PROBLEM
description: The New York State Education Department is considering regulations that would settle the issue of who is responsible for educating homeless children in the state by letting parents choose their children's school district.

title: Prohibition's Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis Seaton, 81, Dies; G.M. Labor Specialist
description: Louis G. Seaton, chief bargainer for the General Motors Corporation in the early years of contract negotiations with the United Automobile Workers, died Thursday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. Mr. Seaton, who suffered a stroke four days earlier, was 81 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Vermont Indians In Rights Battle
description: FOR nine years, the Abenaki Indians of Vermont have been trying to get the state to prosecute them for fishing and hunting without licenses. Their wish may be granted soon. So far they have succeeded only in getting summonses three times. Twice the state, unprepared to argue its case, declined to prosecute.

title: Retirement Plans Require An Ever-Earlier Look
description: ''The days dwindle down to a precious few.'' - ''September Song'' (Copyright 1938, By Maxwell Anderson and Kurt Weill, ASCAP)

title: LET'S MAKE A DEAL
description: Patricia Volk's ''wish list'' to improve her life in New York City was amusing (''Let's Make a Deal,'' Feb. 7). Of course, if she, like NBC, employed 4,000 people (half of whom are New Yorkers) and were willing to invest $1.5 billion to renovate her facilities, we'd be glad to assist her.

title: 15 Crimean Tatars Detained During a Protest in Moscow
description: The police detained 15 Crimean Tatars today after members of the ethnic group held up a banner demanding the right to live in their homeland, a dissident said.

title: Japanese Are Special Types, They Explain
description: TSUTOMU HATA has earned a lasting entry in the lore of United States-Japan relations with a recent discourse on why his country could not accept more imports of American beef. Japanese are incapable of eating much beef, said Mr. Hata, a former agriculture minister who had gone to Washington as his Government's point man on this issue. Japanese, he explained, have longer intestines than other people.

title: Few Olympic Medals? Who Cares?
description: LEAD: Before the Winter Olympics fade from memory, if they haven't already, we Americans have to face some cold facts. We simply can't dominate the world, on or off the slopes, the way we used to or would like to. That's the way it is, like it or lump it. Most of us will lump it, since we've never been particularly good losers.

title: CULTURAL FESTIVAL WITH SOVIET SAVED
description: An American-Soviet cultural exchange jeopardized by financial problems has been rescued by more money from the state of Massachusetts and the last-minute lobbying of Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have two doors in my house that seem to gradually close by themselves and will not stay fully open. Is there a simple solution to this problem?

title: Review of Jersey City Police Is Joined by the State
description: The State Attorney General's office has joined a review of the Jersey City Police Department, which was rocked recently by the suicide of its chief and has been accused of racism and brutality by the city's Indian and Hispanic communities.

title: Experience is The Source For Writers
description: A PRESTON woman described the difficult birth of her son in a car, when the baby was deprived of oxygen for several minutes. A man from Old Lyme wrote of his boyhood summers by the shore, when his family slept in a large tent and ''had a porcelain flush toilet in its own little tent.''

title: Correction
description: A report in The Week in Review on Jan. 24 about Israeli reactions to the conflict on the West Bank misspelled the name of an Arab member of the Israeli Parliament who said there was ''real opportunity'' in the situation. The correct spelling is Abed Darawshe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 6, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FAST LANES, by Jayne Anne Phillips. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $5.95.) Unlike the selections in her first collection of short fiction, ''Black Tickets,'' many of these stories of dispossessed drifters are unfocused and even a bit cliched, Jay McInerney said here last year. But in the best of them, such as ''Bluegill,'' in which a young woman engages in a monologue with her unborn child, ''events have a dreamlike inevitability.'' THE SECRET HOUSE: 24 Hours in the Strange and Unexpected World in Which We Spend Our Nights and Days, by David Bodanis. (Touchstone/Simon & Schus-ter, $9.95.) Viewed microscopically, the author shows, even the most suburban home teems with disgusting creatures, such as the 2 million mites that inhabit a typical double bed, living on tiny flakes of skin. Yet a penicillin mold on a slice of Cheddar cheese (pictured) can appear as beautiful as some imagined extraterrestrial garden. In 1986, K. C. Cole said in The Times that this picture-filled book is ''nothing short of astounding.'' It ''zooms in relentlessly on the mundane matters of modern life, proving once again that the difference between the ordinary and the exotic is only your point of view.'' FAMILY RESEMBLANCES, by Lowry Pei. (Vintage, $6.95.) Exiled for a summer with her eccentric young aunt, a 15-year-old girl learns that love stories don't often have happy endings. Lowry Pei's ''clean, limpid, almost translucent prose renders the perfect plot . . . all but invisible,'' Lee Smith said here in 1986, ''as small events build to genuine suspense.'' KAISHA: The Japanese Corporation, by James C. Abegglen and George Stalk Jr. (Basic, $12.95.) After working in Tokyo, the authors conclude that it is not Zenlike management styles that have led to Japanese corporate success but sheer aggressiveness. In 1985, our reviewer, Nicholas D. Kristof, praised the authors for going beyond ''dark conspiracy theories or giddy paeans.'' ''Like most things created in Japan, this book is sturdy, well designed and a good buy.'' SUMMERTIME, by Maureen McCoy. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $6.95.) The mother, wife and daughter of a man dying of leukemia spend a summer awaiting the inevitable. Last year, Emily Listfield said here that the novel ''has a cumulative power, and in the end an overriding optimism - reasoned, sanded down by the necessary compromises, but optimism nonetheless - that is moving.'' MORTAL SPLENDOR: The American Empire in Transition, by Walter Russell Mead. (Houghton Mifflin, $9.95.) By extending the liberal vision and insisting on decent working conditions for third world laborers, the author argues, the United States would not only be morally right but would also serve its own economic interest. This book ''should be required study for Democratic Presidential candidates and their staffs,'' Randall Rothenberg said here last year. A WORLD OF LOVE, by Elizabeth Bowen. (Penguin, $5.95.) With the careful prose that is her trademark, Elizabeth Bowen tells what happens when an Irish girl discovers a batch of old love letters in a run-down country house. ''Miss Bowen's powers are at their summit,'' A. S. Morris said here in 1955. ''She is interested in the outward and unexceptional as it must, if carefully observed, illuminate the hidden and particular.'' HEALTH AND HEALING, by Andrew Weil. (Houghton Mifflin, $8.95.) After studying a range of alternative therapies, a Harvard-trained physician concluded that most important to success is that patient and practitioner have faith in the cure. In 1984, our reviewer, Gerald Weissmann, said the ''amiable, open-minded guide [ is ] sympathetic, but not uncritical.'' HEARTBREAK HOTEL, by Gabrielle Burton. (Penguin, 6.95.) The residents of the Heartbreak Hotel in Buffalo work at the Museum of the Revolution, which displays miniskirts, Barbie dolls and other examples of sexist oppression. ''Reading this novel is like watching a boisterous, surrealistic three-ring circus on the theme of being a woman in America,'' Brett Harvey said here in 1986. ''Women readers in particular will roar and cringe with recognition, and many will be swept up in Gabrielle Burton's triumphant vision.'' TONE DEAF AND ALL THUMBS? An Invitation to Music-Making, by Frank R. Wilson. (Vintage, $6.95.) Using his expertise as a neurologist and late-blooming amateur pianist, Frank R. Wilson analyzes the brain and the muscular system and explores the biology of timing, rhythm and tempo, concluding that it is never too late to learn. In 1986, our reviewer, Robert J. Lurtsema, said the book was obscure in places but, on balance, ''thought-provoking and valuable to both the novice and the accomplished musician.'' REINDEER MOON, by Elizabeth Marshall Thomas. (Pocket Books, $4.50.) Written by an anthropologist, this first novel tells of an adolescent girl's life in a Siberian clan 20,000 years ago. Last year, our reviewer, Gay Andrews Dillin, called the book ''entrancing.'' It ''illuminates our path back into the distant past, allowing us to see it with new understanding.'' WOMEN OF THE LEFT BANK: Paris, 1900-1940, by Shari Benstock. (University of Texas, $12.95.) Reversing what has been conventionally accepted as foreground and background, Shari Benstock argues that Gertrude Stein, Alice B. Toklas, Jean Rhys, Djuna Barnes and other members of their Parisian literary community were as important to the development of modern literature as T. S. Eliot, James Joyce and Ezra Pound. ''Modernism as we will understand it for a long time to come will be defined by [ this ] book,'' one reviewer said in 1987.

title: Palestinian Radicals in Syria See Return of Power
description: The uprising in the Israeli occupied West Bank and Gaza has revived the hopes of militant Palestinian organizations here that they can restore their old influence after years of obscure existence and internal discord.

title: Only Coed Schooling Can Prepare Women for the Real World
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexandra Roosevelt Wed To Dr. Ronald W. Dworkin
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Alexandra Roosevelt, a daughter of Mrs. Quentin Roosevelt of Oyster Bay and the late Mr. Roosevelt, was married yesterday to Dr. Ronald William Dworkin, a son of Alyse S. Dworkin and Dr. David Dworkin, both of Long Beach, Calif.

title: Street Fashion; Svelte Waistlines of Winter '88
description: THE waist, which is normally found somewhere beneath several layers of wool, down or fur at this time of year, has come out in the cold this winter. Yes, it's right there as plain as day, smack-dab in the middle of those hourglass-shaped jackets, short coats and sweaters that are hot this season.

title: Lawrence C. Liebers Marries Karen Bitar
description: Karen Yasmine Bitar, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samir Bitar of Brooklyn, was married last night to Lawrence Charles Liebers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Liebers, also of Brooklyn. Judge Neil J. Firetog of New York City Criminal Court in Brooklyn performed the ceremony aboard the Princess, a motor yacht, in New York Harbor.

title: Gore and Dukakis Defeat Gephardt in Wyoming's Caucuses
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts fought to a standstill in Wyoming's Democratic Presidential caucuses yesterday while the state's Republicans were dividing their delegates between Vice President Bush and Senator Bob Dole, Mr. Gore and Mr. Dukakis each won enough representatives to the state convention to earn at least four delegates to the Democratic National Convention in Atlanta. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri earned three delegates. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois and Gary Hart did not qualify for any delegates.

title: Everett C. Sherbourne, Banker, 80
description: Everett C. Sherbourne, a former chairman of City Federal Savings Bank in Bedminister, N.J., died Thursday at his home in Westfield, N.J., after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: A GENUINE POWER COUPLE
description: THE DOLES Unlimited Partners. By Bob Dole and Elizabeth Dole with Richard Norton Smith. Illustrated. 287 pp. New York: Simon & Shuster. $19.95.

title: 'School Daze' Days
description: To the Editor:

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LIBERTYVILLE, ILL.;
Crusading for Open Space
description: LEAD: THE great-grandson of a settler, F. T. Graham, is on a crusade against development in this township, which is in the path of growth in the expanding Chicago metropolitan region.

title: For Some, 'Simplification' Becomes Complication
description: ''This is the most unkindest cut of all.'' - William Shakespeare

title: For African Island Nation, Foreign Aid Is a Lifeline
description: Anchored in the rich fishing waters of the Gulf of Guinea, the African archipelago of Sao Tome e Principe was shaken in 1981 by food riots. The new Government could no longer afford to import dried fish.

title: Timeless Truths of the Dutch Landscape
description: It is not often in first youth that people fall in love with Dutch 17th-century landscape painting. At 18 or 20, we prefer wilder shores and a more ecstatic mode of expression. Rare is the young person who would pass up a Provencal landscape by van Gogh or a Fauve harbor scene by Matisse or Derain in favor of rutted flatlands, blasted trees and tumbledown cottages by painters whose names we cannot pronounce, let along remember. We think of Dutch landscape painting as amiable, pedestrian and - dare we say it? Yes, of course, we do - just a little bit dull.

title: Fur Coat 'Throwaways' Attract New Customers
description: The 37-year-old investment banker was shopping for a used fur coat recently at a thrift shop in Manhattan. The owner of three furs, she wanted another. She decided to buy it second hand, she said, because of the collapse of the stock market in October and an uncertain economy.

title: Move by Iranian Sows Confusion On a Cease-Fire
description: An unsigned statement, handed privately by an Iranian diplomat to the United Nations Security Council this week, has prompted widespread confusion over whether Iran is ready to end its war with Iraq.

title: Pears Are a Perfect Way to Cap a Meal
description: PEARS make delicious desserts, raw or cooked. A plain ripe pear is a perfect end to a meal, when served with a piece of Roquefort cheese and a glass of Sauterne - or with Stilton and port.

title: Portuguese Fare, at a Price
description: IT is ironic that as the State Department is reporting that, with the exception of Greece, dining out in Portugal is less expensive than anywhere in Western Europe, dining at Stamford's new Portuguese restaurant, Pearl of the Atlantic, is one of the more expensive experiences in Fairfield County.

title: Mothers Behind Bars
description: LEAD: DARLENE, 27 years old, and her daughter, Crystal, 4, were having a talk.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: On Maine Lake, Icemen Practice a Dying Craft
description: Just as they have for the last 90 years, the icemen came to Bald Mountain Camps on Mooselookmeguntic Lake here in western Maine.

title: Friends of Israel
description: All of us who have felt an emotional link to Israel since the moment the state was born in 1948 now face fundamental questions. Do we believe that Israel's safety lies in holding on to the West Bank and Gaza? Or would it be wiser for Israel to seek an accommodation with the Palestinians, an exchange of land for peace?

title: High Season for the Sugarhouses
description: MAPLE SYRUP, the authentic, old-fashioned pancake and waffle topping, is beginning to boil in the state's sugarhouses. But cold weather threatens to limit production, no syrup was carried over from last year, a complicated problem of ''maple decline'' is emerging, and prices for local syrup will be at least as high as last year's, maybe even higher.

title: Suspect Seen as Man Seeking Promotion
description: New details emerged yesterday about Philip Copeland, who the police believe was the messenger between an imprisoned drug dealer and the three other men accused of murdering Officer Edward Byrne.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: The good: seeing Midori Ito of Japan and Elizabeth Manley of Canada skating for the love of their sport; seeing the Jamaican bobsled team; seeing the firefighter from the Bronx and his luge; seeing Team USA giving the Soviet professionals all they could handle in hockey, and seeing Eric Flaim and Bonnie Blair.

title: Star Vehicles Sometimes Get Detoured
description: Although at times the small screen seems to be overflowing with young marrieds, adorable children and teen-age heartthrobs, television is in many ways proving a boon to what might diplomatically be called the ''veteran performer.'' This is the actor who once may have enjoyed considerable success in television and/or films but now, having reached a ''certain age'' or run into a luckless stretch of unemployment, finds decent job offers more and more scarce. Show business still is, and no doubt always will be, a tough game, but television has brightened the picture considerably as far as seasoned talent is concerned.

title: Making Way for Ducklings, in Bronze
description: Alongside a cobblestone pathway in the Boston Public Garden is a slightly larger-than-life bronze sculpture of a mallard followed by eight ducklings. The sculpture is frequently patted and hugged by children who recognize the duck family as the one made famous by Robert McCloskey's award-winning 1941 book ''Make Way for Ducklings.''

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If I had to go away on vacation and come back in 1990, I'd put all my money in bonds. '' Michael Aronstein, president, Comstock Partners, a money management firm.

title: A CUT LEMON DOESN'T TURN BROWN
description: FREE RADICAL Albert Szent-Gyorgyi and The Battle Over Vitamin C. By Ralph W. Moss. Preface by Studs Terkel. Illustrated. 316 pp. New York: Paragon House Publishers. $22.95.

title: Mouseketeers '88: Taps and Twinkle
description: The first run of the program ended almost 30 years ago, but none of the 9- to 14-year-olds missed a beat when the casting director asked them to sing the theme song.

title: Devil Scorers Save Burke in Overtime
description: The Devils were inspiring today as they beat the Boston Bruins, 7-6, on a goal by Andy Brickley 47 seconds into overtime.

title: Employing a Little Deductive Reasoning
description: The audit. The dreaded Internal Revenue Service audit. This year, more than two million Americans will learn firsthand what the word means, when their tax returns are selected for examination. While some of these returns will be chosen randomly, the vast majority will have raised some red flag that triggered an audit - failing to report income, for instance, or claiming unusual or outsized deductions.

title: Flying Courier Class: How to Save a Bundle With Someone Else's
description: I never thought I would make it to China. Every time I heard stories from friends and colleagues about their journeys to Asia, I was envious. A figure of between $3,000 and $4,000 a person was usually mentioned, a cost that seemed prohibitive to me.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of protests that it could cause the death of marine animals, the 1988 National Balloon Launch-Student Weather Experiment may be the last such event, according to John M. Fowler, director of the Maryland-based organization that is sponsoring the project.

title: Off to See The Wizard By Balloon
description: UNGODLY hours, says my friend Nestor, are so called because the sacred among us prefer to spend them silently worshiping our pillows. We are grateful to leave the opaque stillness of ungodly hours to the profane: paper carriers, fishermen, sanitation workers, Jane Pauley, and a dangerously proliferating number of hot-air balloonists.

title: Stalin's KIllerati
description: To the Editor:

title: Krone Wins One And Ties Record
description: Julie Krone scored one victory from seven mounts at Aqueduct yesterday to tie Patricia Cooksey for most career victories by a female jockey with 1,203. Krone, a 24-year-old rider from Michigan, scored aboard Seattle Knight in the fifth race. She brought Seattle Knight from last place in a field of eight allowance runners to win the six-furlong event by 1 1/4 lengths. It is only a question of time before Krone surpasses Cooksey, who is scheduled to undergo surgery on her left knee on Monday. She suffered ligament damage when she was thrown from her mount during pre-race saddling at Turfway Park in Kentucky on Feb. 17. Depending on the extent of the injury, Cooksey will be unable to compete for anywhere from one to four months. Cooksey recently broke Patti Barton's career record total for female riders of 1,202.

title: Opponents of Airport Expansion Press for Alternative Proposal
description: LEAD: OPPONENTS of the county's $25.6 million plan to expand passenger services at its 44-year-old airport will meet with County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and members of the Board of Legislators Thursday to urge consideration of an alternative proposal that, they contend, would be both smaller and less costly.

title: Olympic Springboard
description: More than a single race will be on the line for Rod Dixon and Gianni Poli today when they head a strong field for the third running of the Los Angeles Marathon. The runners, both former winners of the New York City Marathon, are hoping to use a victory in Los Angeles as a springboard to the Olympics. For Dixon, the race is an official part of the New Zealand Olympic trials, but for Poli the situation is less clear-cut. Although it would not gain him an automatic bid, he hopes a good showing will persuade Italian athletic officials to name him to the Olympic team.

title:
GARDENING;
Garden Color Is in the Eye of the Beholder
description: LEAD: ENGLISH gardeners have long made it a practice to avoid shocking color combinations. The writer Vita Sackville-West probably developed it to the highest level at Sissinghurst, where her monochromatic gardens still exist today.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo Fan Harks Back To '52 Letter
description: Sometimes these governors who say they are not running for President have a way of changing their minds. And no one knows that better than Robert F. Rothschild.

title: No Gold Medal Is No Disgrace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: England
description: To the Editor: Returning from a recent trip to England, I found I had lost one of the 11 rolls of films I had taken. It was only after having the rolls developed that I realized the missing roll contained all the photos I had taken at Stonehenge.

title: A New Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Listings of cultural events and radio highlights, formerly in The Guide, are in the Arts and Leisure section.

title: Dance: Montreal Group Makes U.S. Debut
description: FOUR choreographers presented five works Friday night in the United States debut of Montreal Danse. The group is a year-old Canadian company that does not rely on a single resident choreographer but that invites several who are based in Montreal to create its repertory.

title: Beth J. Pearlstein to Marry Lawrence Tofel, a Lawyer
description: The engagement of Beth Janet Pearlstein to Lawrence Edward Tofel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Tofel of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Pearlstein of Bridgewater, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title:
FILLING OUT THE FORMS;
Get Your Money's Worth From the Tax Preparer
description: LEAD: This tax season, Americans will find the task of filing a tax return more dreadful than ever, according to tax professionals. Even middle-income taxpayers who take such commonplace deductions as those for interest payments or contributions to an Individual Retirement Account will need to report additional financial information on complicated new forms, as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: DEAL WITH DEMOCRATS ON HELP FOR VETERANS
description: As a veteran of the Korean War and a colonel in the United States Army Reserve, I read with especial interest the Jan. 24 article ''Nassau Presses for V.A. Unit.'' The concerns of Nassau County veterans are very much my concerns.

title: Stalin's Killerati
description: To the Editor:

title: Custody Battle May Set Precedent
description: A MAN who wants custody of his two children while awaiting trial on charges of strangling his wife, the children's mother, on Long Island and dumping her body in a ditch is stretching child custody law to previously untried limits. The case is prompting family-law experts to argue that natural parents may not be the best caretakers of their children in situations involving domestic violence.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: GLORIA & JOE. By Axel Madsen. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) By the time Gloria Swanson met Joseph P. Kennedy over lunch at the Savoy Plaza Hotel in New York in 1927, the reigning movie queen had broken with Paramount Pictures and become her own producer as a member of the new United Artists group.

title: Religion Prize Sponsor Jarred by Bias Charges
description: Sir John Templeton, sponsor of the $369,000 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, has expressed surprise at charges that this year's prize winner was associated with anti-Semitic and anti-Israel causes.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: The shameless commercialism of the Games as presented by ABC, was the worst part of the Olympics. Apparently the Games exist for the coverage; the Games are not covered. What was once sport is now more about hamburgers and diet soda. Too few gold medals means lower revenues from sponsors. Of course this trend can't be allowed to continue. Solution? Bring in George Steinbrenner. Even while our athletes are competing and performing with desire, character and dignity they are criticized for not being good enough to have their faces put on cereal boxes.

title: Miss Alexander, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Cynthia Anne Alexander, an associate in the Atlanta law firm of Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan, and James Messer Ruedin Jr., a vice president of the Protect-a-Board division of Star Paper Tube in Austell, Ga., plan to marry in July. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Henry R. Alexander of Wellesley, Mass., parents of the future bride. Mr. Ruedin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruedin of Statesville, N.C.

title: REPEAT CAESAREANS AREN'T ALWAYS ESSENTIAL
description: While it is true that some women choose repeat Caesarean birth out of ignorance [ Long Island Journal, Jan. 24 ] , from my own experience I believe it is more common that women are not told by their physicians that vaginal delivery after Caesarean birth is feasible.

title: The Dreaded Check-Clearing Bottleneck
description: The young couple thought they had it all figured out. They had sold their co-op and were closing on a Monday. On the following Friday, they planned to close on their new home. They asked the buyer of the co-op to furnish a certified check at the first closing, assuming that the funds would then be available for the second.

title: St. John's Loses Fight-Marred Game
description: St. John's hopes of gaining a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament bid were weakened considerably tonight when the Redmen lost, 90-81, to Providence in a game marred by a melee involving St. John's players and Providence fans.

title: Serious Food With a Sense of Fun
description: SEA CLIFF'S Cafe Harlequin is a lighthearted, classy restaurant with a sense of fun. Outside, white lights twinkle a welcome. Within, a baby grand piano and a flamboyant rope wall hanging greet the diners. Birds of paradise and other exotic flora are dramatically arrayed on the mirror-backed bar. Walls are covered with bold, exciting French posters, ponderous in dimension but light in spirit.

title: CRIME
description: In DOWNRIVER (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95), Loren D. Estleman is back where he belongs, with his tough private eye Amos Walker. The eighth in this Detroit series, the book bears a slight resemblance to Robert B. Parker's Spenser mysteries: Spenser works with a lethal black man named Hawk, and Walker now has an equivalent of Hawk on his side - a black giant named Richard DeVries, just released after 20 years in prison, and somebody you most definitely do not want to mess around with. Walker may be as big and as tough as they come. DeVries is bigger and tougher.

title: A Soviet Foot In U.S. Market
description: SEEKING to emulate the success of Japanese and Korean car makers, the Soviet Union moved last year to penetrate the heavy-machinery market in the United States.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Barrington, R.I.;
30-Acre Project For the Elderly
description: LEAD: THE Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island plans to build a $40 million continuing health-care community for elderly residents that it says will be the first of its kind in the state.

title: AMONG THE GOLDEN BOUGHS
description: LEAD: J. G. FRAZER His Life and Work. By Robert Ackerman. Illustrated. 348 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $39.95.

title: CLARE BOOTHE LUCE IS REMEMBERED
description: Sylvia Morris makes so much of her intimacy with Clare Boothe Luce that I am surprised she could have missed the grace of Mrs. Luce's last dinner party. The evening should have elicited more from Mrs. Morris than a comment on Mrs. Luce's silver wig, her infirmity and the observation that ''this is no party, but a wake.'' It was a far more tender finale than that.

title: Miss Chanin Wed To an Executive
description: The marriage of Nancy Chanin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcy Chanin of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., to Andrew Sneider, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Sneider of Miami, took place last evening at the Carlyle in New York. Rabbi Richard Jacobs, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: A Record Inmate Level As New Board Meets
description: A NEWLY empowered Criminal Justice Advisory Board held its first meeting in White Plains last week as the county's inmate population reached its highest level ever.

title: 'Corrupt and Content'
description: To the Editor:

title: FICTION
description: CATAMOUNT BRIDGE. By Don Metz. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) In Don Metz's first novel, the Vietnam War is an ominous backdrop to a family drama set in northern Vermont. Its central conflict is between Bodie Woodard, a shy, sensitive introvert who opposes the war, and his twin brother, Harmon, a swaggering macho go-getter who supports it. As Harmon gears up to go fight and Bodie struggles to decide whether to flee to Canada, Harmon's sweet-natured wife, Darlene, prepares to deliver a child that Harmon suspects is really Bodie's. Acting as a kind of barnyard chorus to the present-tense narration is the twins' grandfather Leon, a seventh-generation farmer who delivers soliloquies to his dead wife in a kind of rustic prose poetry. One of Leon's fingers has been lost to a pulpwood saw, but his others have ''chopped and tinkered and mended, planted, reaped and brought into being the web of life around him.'' Harmon and Bodie, both master carpenters, are also menders and fixers, and their work processes are meticulously described, often as displacements of terrible events and emotions. Mr. Metz, an architect who lives in New Hampshire, captures these simple people and their remote environment with loving care, from details like the smell of Leon's chewing gum to a lyric vision of little girls sprinkling fireflies from Mason jars. The brief Vietnam scenes are harrowing, communicating directly the tragic sense of waste that is implied elsewhere in the novel. The problem with ''Catamount Bridge,'' though, is that Mr. Metz tends to explain his own symbols and symmetries, as well as set up characters who too neatly embody virtues, types and political opinions. His prose is admirably clear, but it's also a bit too tidy and schematic to deliver the power it systematically accumulates.

title: Albums Will Help to Keep Track
description: EVERY year at this time, camera manufacturers bring forth their newest creations in a flurry of press releases, press luncheons and pressing of the flesh. The occasion: the Photo Marketing Association trade show, held this year in Chicago. It is a time when just about any news is better than no news.

title: You Needn't Face It Alone: A Guide to the Tax Guides
description: Taking control of your tax situation involves a lot more than filling out the forms, or gathering up folders of last year's records to drop by the accountant's office. Actually, financial planning is an ongoing, year-round affair, and for those who spend an hour or two a week monitoring their finances - checking whether their portfolios are meeting expectations and how their household budgets are shaping up - income-tax preparation is a relatively effortless exercise.

title: Reminiscences of World War II
description: IN its pursuit of out-of-the-way plays, which is just what makes the company distinctive, Penguin Repertory can go wildly astray, and so it has with ''Waiting for the Parade'' by John Murrell, which was produced Off Off Broadway in 1981.

title: IN PERSONAL ADS, BEAUTY IS HOW ONE SEES IT
description: It is usually those who are physically unattractive who bemoan the fact that physical beauty is valued. It is those who cannot make it financially who scorn the rich.

title: BLACKS IN BRITAIN, 1942
description: WHEN JIM CROW MET JOHN BULL Black American Soldiers in World War II Britain. By Graham Smith. 265 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: Headliners; Net Gain
description: If there is a coaching equivalent of a slam dunk, Willis Reed made one last week. Tuesday, in their first game under Reed, the New Jersey Nets beat the Los Angeles Clippers by 29 points. Nice, but no big surprise: The Clippers currently have the worst record in the National Basketball Association. But the Nets, who have the second worst record, then faced the Boston Celtics, who have one of the best N.B.A. records. The Nets won by 10 points. It was a promising start for Reed's second stint as an N.B.A. head coach. Reed was a star center for the New York Knicks, and was the Knicks' coach 10 years ago for one disappointing season. When the opportunity with the Nets arose, said Reed, ''everyone thought I was taking a bad job. But after the first two games, it's been pretty good.''

title: Stalin's KIllerati
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Swiss Takes First: Brigitte Oertli, in the absence of her three injured Swiss teammates, yesterday won the weather-delayed women's World Cup downhill race in Aspen, Colo., and moved into first place in the overall standings. The Swiss have won all seven downhill races this season. Oertli, silver medalist in both the downhill and combined at the Winter Olympics, was clocked in 1 minute 22.83 seconds down a course that was icier than on Friday, when the race was stopped. It was Oertli's first downhill triumph in seven seasons of World Cup racing. Regine Moesenlechner of West Germany was second in 1:23.06. Heidi Zeller of Switzerland placed third in 1:23.21.(AP) Speed Skating Jansen Wins in Norway: Dan Jansen of the United States, who fell twice during the Olympics, and Jan Ykema, the Dutch runner-up, both beat Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany, the Olympic champion, in a 500-meter World Cup sprint race in Savalen, Norway. The national NTB news agency reported that Jansen won in 37.68 seconds with Ykema second in 37.72, and Mey third in 38.08. Nick Thometz of the United States was fourth in 38.11. Ykema won the 1,000 meters event in 1:17.82 seconds with Jansen second in 1:17.94 and Thometz third in 1:18.36.(AP) Track and Field Swede Takes High Jump: Patrik Sjoeberg of Sweden soared 7 feet 10 inches to win the high jump at the European indoor championships in Budapest. On the opening day of the two-day meet, Sjoeberg beat Carlo Thraenhardt of West Germany, who took away the Swede's world record two weeks ago with a jump of 7 feet 11 1/4 inches. The Olympic champion, Dietmar Mogenburg of West Germany, was second with 7-9 1/4, while Thraenhardt settled for third at 7-8 1/2. Frans Maas of the Netherlands scored an upset victory in the long jump by leaping 26-5 1/2. In the 60-meter dash, Linford Christie won in 6.57 seconds. East Germany's powerful team won two of the six titles at stake on the opening day. Heike Drechsler of East Germany beat her meet record by leaping 23-11 1/2 in the long jump while her teammate, Cornelia Oschkenat, missed the world record by 3-hundredths of a second as she clocked 7.77 seconds in the 60-meter hurdles. (AP) Halpin Wins Weight Throw: Gary Halpin of Manhattan College successfully defended his 35-pound weight throw title as the 67th IC4A Championships opened at Princeton. Halpin's winning throw was 65-5. Ray Humphrey of Georgetown upset favored D. D. Manns of James Madison, the defending champion, in the long jump, winning by 3 1/2 inches with a leap of 25-6 1/4. Tennis Graf Tops Maleeva: Steffi Graf lived up to her No. 1 ranking, defeating Katerina Maleeva, 6-4, 6-1, to win the $200,000 United States Women's Hardcourt Championships in San Antonio. The West German collected a $40,000 check after the hour-long match in which she extended her undefeated series of matches to 26, last losing to Martina Navratilova in the finals of last year's United States Open. (AP) Boxing Kalambay Retains Title: Sambu Kalambay retained his World Boxing Association middleweight title with a unanimous 12-round decision over Mike McCallum in Pesaro, Italy. It was the first defeat in 33 professional fights for McCallum, who vacated his W.B.A. junior middleweight crown to move up in weight.(AP) Women's Basketball Rutgers Is Upset: Tanya Garner scored a career-high 22 points last night to lead Penn State (18-11, 11-7) to an 82-69 victory over seventh-ranked Rutgers. The Lady Knights, which had won 15 straight games, fell to 23-4 over all and 17-1 in the Atlantic 10 Conference. Sue Wicks led Rutgers with 26 points and 14 rebounds.(AP) N.B.A. Bullets 101, Pistons 97: Moses Malone scored 11 of his 21 points in the fourth quarter as the Bullets won their sixth straight. The Pistons made just 16 of 42 shots in the first half and turned the ball over 10 times.(AP) Bulls 100, Clippers 76: Michael Jordan scored his 21 points in 27 minutes, and the Bulls held Los Angeles to 55 points in the first three quarters. The Clippers lost their 22d consecutive road game, fourth straight over all and 28th in their last 32 games.(AP) Rockets 105, Kings 94:Akeem Olajuwon had 24 points and 13 rebounds for the Rockets. The Kings, who lost for the 11th consecutive time in The Summit, outscored Houston, 16-2, in a fourth-quarter surge, but the Rockets held on.(AP) N.H.L. Jets 10, Maple Leafs 1: Paul MacLean scored three goals and Dale Hawerchuk added two goals and four assists. Hawerchuk's 6 points tied the Jets' single-game record he shared with two other players. Hawerchuk also scored 6 points against the Leafs on Dec. 14, 1983.(AP) Flames 7, Oilers 4: Mike Bullard scored two power-play goals for the Flames. Craig Simpson had two goals for Edmonton, which fell 3 points behind the first-place Flames in the Smythe Division race. Referee Bob Myers handed out 206 minutes in penalties, including six game misconducts.(AP)

title:
DINING OUT;
A New Life for an Old Inn
description: LEAD: OPENING and operating a restaurant is a difficult enough job for a seasoned professional with years of experience. However, when a young man barely out of his teens and with little experience in the world of restaurants, turns an old Sussex County inn that was hardly more than a beer-and-shot place into a restaurant as charming as the Inn at Stillwater, then he's already won part of the battle.

title: Nothing's More Russian Than Scriabin
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FAMILY ATTRACTIONS. By Judith Freeman. (Viking, $16.95.) We may witness death in Judith Freeman's first collection of short stories, as well as illness, painful memories and bickering, yet ''Family Attractions'' nonetheless celebrates moments of feeling and connection. In the title story, for example, an aging stepfather takes his newly acquired 9-year-old daughters not to the Hollywood Wax Museum or the Cabrillo Marine Museum but on a boating picnic, and they appreciate his teasing, accept his caring.

title: Shareholders of Texas Bank Accept $1.5 Billion Bailout
description: Shareholders of First City Bancorporation of Texas have approved a $1.5 billion restructuring plan, the second largest federally assisted bailout of a United States bank.

title: Restoring a Morgan: A Year's Wait and a $25,000 Bill
description: What do you do when you're late for the 1988 Rose Parade in Pasadena, Calif. because your $6 million 1931 Bugatti won't start? George Crocker, who runs a classic car museum in Michigan, encountered that problem as he was preparing to drive the prized vehicle, which belongs to Thomas Monaghan, owner of the Domino's pizza chain and the Detroit Tigers.

title: Stalin's KIllerati
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann G. Schaumberger, A Lawyer, Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman Schaumberger of Douglaston, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Gail Schaumberger, to Steven Nicokiris, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Nicokiris of Pompano Beach, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: CUTTING CORNERS
description: FOR YEARS, I WAS A ''pe-riphery shopper,'' buying only fresh produce, meat and dairy products that lined market walls. Occasionally, I navigated up and down the aisles displaying staples and frozen foods, adding imported canned tomatoes, orange juice concentrate and ice cream to my basket. But I was convinced that just about anything made from scratch was best. In recent years, however, I've relaxed a bit, and have discovered a good number of excellent convenience foods that, when combined with fresh foods, do not compromise the quality of a dish. They simply make the cooking process easier and quicker. Furthermore, some vegetables and fruits that are flash-frozen at the peak of their season are far more flavorful - and less expensive -than fresh but out-of-season produce. Fresh green peas, for example, are often mealy, waxy and almost devoid of flavor in all but a few short weeks in summer. Willa Gelber, a partner with her husband-chef, Karl Dauner, in Custom Cuisine, a Manhattan catering firm, uses tiny frozen peas and kernels of corn to add color and flavor to a rich risotto served with a stuffed capon breast. Chasing down costly out-of-season ingredients simply does not make good business sense, she says.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BARRINGTON, R.I.;
30-Acre Project For the Elderly
description: LEAD: ThE Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island plans to build a $40 million continuing health-care community for elderly residents that it says will be the first of its kind in the state.

title: EUROPE'S CULTURAL CALENDAR
description: The cultural highlights in Europe this spring and summer range from two new festivals in London to a new museum in Haarlem, the Netherlands, to an exhibition in Venice about the Phoenicians. This listing was compiled by Carol Plum based on reports from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Bonn, Rome and Madrid. A guide to music festivals will be published May 1. Local telephone numbers are listed; dialing codes, used to reach those numbers from outside the local area, are in parentheses. Omit the zero if you are calling from outside the country (in the case of Spain omit the 9); the procedure in France is different and is explained under that country's heading. All dollar figures are approximate, subject to changes in exchange rates. BRITAIN A new play by Tom Stoppard, ''Hapgood,'' opens at the Aldwych Theater in London on March 8. The play is a comedy involving spies. The cast includes Felicity Kendal, Nigel Hawthorne and Roger Rees; Peter Wood is the director. Aldwych Theater, Aldwych, London WC2B 4DF; box office (01) 836-6404. Tickets from $16 to $26. ''Armada 1588-1988'' will open at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich April 20 and continue to Sept. 4. The exhibit will celebrate the 400th anniversary of the defeat of the Spanish Armada and will look at it in the context of the political and religious struggles of 16th-century Europe. Items on display will include paintings, engravings, maps, charts, guns, drawings, manuscripts, sculpture and jewelry. National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, London SE10 9NF. Open Monday to Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 2 P.M. to 6 P.M. Admission $2.70. The first End Games Festival, celebrating accomplishments from late in artists' lives, will be held in London April 21 to July 4. Events include music, with more than 40 concerts ranging from chamber music to symphonies; theater, including Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline,'' ''The Winter's Tale'' and ''The Tempest''; some 21 films, with the work of Chaplin, Hitchcock, Bergman and Kurosawa; and art, including shows of Matisse and Giacometti. Participating institutions include the National Theater, Royal Festival Hall, Hayward Gallery, National Film Theater, Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Rooms. Further information: ''End Games Festival'' Box Office, Royal Festival Hall, South Bank, London SE1 8XX; box office (01) 928-3191. Admission $18 at the National Theater and the Cottlesloe; $5.85 at the National Film Theater; $5.40 at the Hayward Gallery; concert prices range from $6.30 to $36. The Festival of London, also new this year, will open July 23 at Alexandra Palace and Park six miles north of central London, and run through Aug. 7. Opening festivities include an 18th-century masked ball, fireworks and an ox roasting with dancing and entertainment July 22. Events include a parade with 33 of London's boroughs taking part; Roman chariot racing; circus, open-air and traveling theater companies, movies, opera, art, sports events, a vintage car parade, dance, crafts, an Elizabethan village with archery, falconry and jousting. The Festival of London, 22 Seymour Mews, London W1H 9PF; 935-5591. Admission to daytime events will be by one, two or three vouchers, with a book of 20 vouchers costing $9. Evening events will have separate entrance fees; prices have not yet been set. Nearest Underground station: Wood Green on the Victoria line. Alexandra Palace can also be reached by train from Kings Cross station. Courtesy buses will take visitors to the exhibition site from the subway and railway station. ''Late Picasso,'' an exhibition of work from the artist's last 20 years, will be held at the Tate Gallery in London from June 23 to Sept. 18. Items on display will include paintings, sculpture, drawings and prints. This is the same show that is at the Pompidou Center in Paris through May. Tate Gallery, Millbank; recorded information 821-7128. Open 10 A.M. to 5:50 P.M. Monday through Saturday; 2 to 5:50 P.M. Sunday. Admission $5.50. Moscow Classical Ballet will perform ''Swan Lake'' at the London Coliseum from July 25 to 30. The production is a British-Soviet effort, with dancers from the Bolshoi and British staging and design. Earlier in the month the London Festival Ballet will perform another version of ''Swan Lake,'' with choreography by Natalia Makarova. Other programs in the season, from July 12 to 23, include ''Carmen,'' ''The Kingdom of Shades'' from ''La Bayadere,'' ''Bolero,'' ''Onegin,'' ''Petrushka,'' ''Sphinx'' and ''Etude'' with choreography by Harald Lander of Denmark. London Coliseum, St. Martin's Lane, London WC2N 4ES; box office (01) 240-5258; recorded information 836-7666. Tickets for the London Festival Ballet range from $6.30 to $35. Prices for the Moscow Ballet will be set at the end of March. An exhibition of 20th-century French photography, ''Art or Nature,'' will be held at the Barbican Art Gallery in London May 12 to July 17. Photographers represented include Man Ray, Latigue, Kertesz, Puyo and Brassai. The Barbican Art Gallery, Barbican Center, Silk Street, London EC2; 638-4141. Open 10 A.M to 6:45 P.M. Monday through Saturday; noon to 5:45 P.M. Sunday. Admission $5.40. The Royal Shakespeare Company will begin its spring season in Stratford-on-Avon March 30, ending Sept. 24. The Royal Shakespeare Theater will open April 7 with ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' with Robert Demeger and Julia Ford. Other presentations include ''Macbeth,'' with Miles Anderson and Duncan Bell, beginning April 28, and ''The Tempest,'' with Duncan Bell and Melanie Thaw, from July 6. The season ends with the ''Henry VI'' cycle and Richard III. The Swan Theater will offer four Restoration plays: ''The Constant Couple,'' starting March 30, ''The Plain Dealer,'' beginning April 20, ''Man of Mode,'' from July 6 and ''Restoration,'' from Sept. 7. Three new plays will have their premieres at the Other Place: ''Across Oka'' by Robert Holman opens April 13; ''The Love of the Nightingale'' by Timberlake Wertenbaker and ''Campesinos'' by Nick Darke open later in the season. Shakespeare's ''King John'' will be presented beginning May 4. For further information for all Stratford performances: Box Office, Royal Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-on-Avon, Warwicks. CV37 6BB; box office (0789) 295623. Tickets at the Royal Shakespeare Theater range from $6.30 to $49.50; at the Swan from $5.40; all seats at the Other Place are $13.50. Hay Festival of Literature and the Arts in Hay, Wales, will run from May 27 to 30. This year, the centenary of T. S. Eliot's birth and the bicentenary of Lord Byron's birth, will be celebrated with lectures and readings from the poets' works. Also scheduled are performances of ''Beowulf'' with Julian Glover, lectures and discussions with poets and writers of their recent work, music, including Benjamin Britten's opera ''Noye's Fludde,'' and exhibitions of sculpture, watercolors and photography. Hay Festival of Literature and the Arts, Council Chamber, Hay, Wales, HR3 5BX; (0497) 820-509. Admission $4 to $15. The Mystery Plays will be presented at the York Festival from June 10 to July 10. The plays will be performed in the Museum Gardens against the ruins of St. Mary's Abbey every night except Mondays at 7:45 P.M. through July 3. Other events in York include concerts, street and square theater, a regatta and carnival, cabaret, fairs and art shows. York Festival and Mystery Plays, 1 Newgate, York, Yorkshire YO1 2LA; (0904) 610-800 or through Edwards & Edwards, 1 Times Square Plaza, New York, N.Y. 10036; 212-944-0290. Admission $10.80 to $15.30. Several sports events are scheduled for the months ahead. The Derby horse-race meeting at Epsom, south of London, runs from from June 1 to June 4, with the Derby on June 1, the Coronation Cup on June 2 and the Oaks on June 4. Epsom Derby Racecourse, Epsom, Surrey, KT1B 5NJ; (03727) 26311. Grandstand admission $27; reserved seat $60. The Henley Royal Regatta takes place from June 29 to July 3. Henley Royal Regatta, Regatta Headquarters, Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire RG9 2LY; (0491) 572-153. Admission $16 Wednesday, $23 Thursday, $34 Friday, $38 Saturday and $34.20 Sunday. The All-England Lawn Tennis Championships at Wimbledon run from June 20 to July 3. Tickets are difficult to come by, but for $9 a visitor can watch matches on all the outside courts. Tickets for Center Court, Court 1 and Court 2 are very scarce. A possible source is Keith Prowse in New York, 212-398-1430. All-England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club, Wimbledon, London SW19 5AE; (01) 946-2244.

title: 'Off-Stage' Series Of Performing Artists
description: The dancer Sean Lavery, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, the pianist Vladimir Feltsman and the conductor Gerard Scwarz will be guest stars at the four programs in the 'Lincoln Center Off-Stage' series that is to start March 28.

title: For Nomadic Rodeo Cowboys, a Few Dollars More
description: LEAD: Kyle Whiting, a 26-year-old cowboy, pulled into an Astrodome parking lot two weeks ago for the start of the Houston rodeo shortly before his event, the bull ride. He had just completed a six-hour drive from Baton Rouge, La., and tomorrow he would drive to Tucson, Ariz., and another rodeo.

title: U.S. Is Red-Faced on Issue of Aid to the Irish
description: ''As you get closer to St. Patrick's Day, Irish Americans get greener and greener,'' said Representative Brian J. Donnelly. He was explaining why several Congressmen of Irish lineage were angered by a State Department official's remark that Ireland ''ranks down the list'' of foreign aid priorities.

title: Manila Arrests 31 Suspects
description: The police raided a Communist hide-out two blocks from the police headquarters today and arrested 31 people suspected of plotting attacks in the capital.

title: A BROTHER'S DREAMS
description: The decision to submit ''A Brother's Dreams'' to your magazine was not an easy one for me to make. Even after the piece appeared, I worried about whether I had done the right thing. However, the overwhelming response from friends and many strangers from around the country has vanquished any doubt I had. In fact, the response I've received from your readership has only convinced me of our society's strong, though sometimes silent, desire to confront issues surrounding the mentally ill in an open-minded and compassionate manner. PAUL ARONOWITZ Cleveland Heights, Ohio

title: Scouting New Dancers: What Are the Criteria?
description: Every time the curtain rises on the Merce Cunningham Dance Company - which is celebrating its 35th anniversary with a season that runs through March 27 at the Joyce Theater - audiences see a troupe of 14 nimble dancers. All are obviously talented. Yet, the inquisitive dance-goer may wonder how and why Mr. Cunningham chose these particular performers for his company.

title: Gore Finds Northern Cash on Route South to Super Tuesday
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who is counting on Southern voters Tuesday to give him the lift his Presidential campaign needs, saw none of them Friday.

title: TWO PALESTINIANS KILLED BY ISRAELIS
description: Israeli soldiers shot to death two more Palestinians today in continued widespread unrest in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Article 993688 -- No Title
description: The five-year-old Lucille P. Markey Charitable Trust has awarded $25.5 million to seven universities and medical institutions.

title: Sunday Observer; No More Mr. Nice Guy
description: FOR SEVERAL weeks now I have been depressed by the thought that we can no longer have mean Presidents. This became apparent after the hysteria known as the New Hampshire primary, when many news people said Senator Robert Dole was afflicted with ''a mean streak'' that would hurt his campaign.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: TRAINSONG. By Jan Kerouac. (Holt, $15.95.) It's hard to create a realistic image of a dead father you barely knew, and harder yet when your dad was Jack Kerouac. Jan Kerouac's ''Trainsong,'' an autobiographical novel that picks up where her first book, ''Baby Driver,'' left off, is haunted by the ghost of her father, who died when she was a teen-ager and whom she met only twice.

title: DATA BANK: MARCH 6, 1988
QUEENS JUDGE IS INVESTIGATED
description: The Queens District Attorney's office is investigating allegations that a State Supreme Court justice paid bribes to Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President, for supporting her judicial nomination, the authorities said yesterday.

title: About Men; The Art of Losing
description: THE SCORE GOES TO 3-0, then to 5-0, then on to 8-0, the ball wildly ricocheting out of the corners of the court and away from my ineffectually flailing swings and tardy bursts of mock speed. As the score piles up in my friend Bruce's favor, I feel a kind of serene apathy come over me vis-a-vis pursuing this small, thwacked piece of black rub-ber around this claustrophobic arena. With the liberating flash of near-epiphany, a sense of game-threatening relief floods over me as I confront the irrefutable fact of my emotion: I simply don't care.

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: He is swaddled in down and curled up inside his tent, talking in a muffled voice, straining to find the words that will explain to a stranger wht happened to him in Vietman. He isn't very good at it at first. His account is formal, official: ''From February to November 1966, I served with Charlie Company, Second 503d Airborne Infantry, the 173d Airborne Brigade. I was 17 when I joined the Army. I was 18 when I fought in Vietnam.'' Pausing, he looks out beyond the tent flap. After a day's hike through the New Hampshire forest, our group has stopped for the night in this place, a slope dense with pine trees. In the dark, the snow, falling steadily, is visible only in the beams of our flashlights and the melting, glowing haze of our campfire. ''I am very proud of the fact that I fought with the 173d Airborne,'' he says. ''We were involved in heavy combat. I felt very fortunate to escape with my life. But looking back now, it seems that I had to shut down a lot of my personal feelings.''

title: Roughing It in Style in Mexico
description: THIRTY-FIVE miles south of the high-rises of Cancun is a luxury resort made of canvas and sand. It's a full-service establishment - only your bed is in a tent and your tent, a stone's throw from the Mexican Caribbean, is in a secluded, sandy grove of tropical trees and shrubs. Operated by an American family, the resort offers maid service, real beds, excellent food and a full bar open all day long, a resident masseuse and hot tub.

title: ABORTION RULE IRKS COUNTY AGENCIES
description: OFFICIALS at the two county health departments on Long Island say that new Federal regulations prohibiting any mention of abortion in clinics that receive Federal funds will discriminate against poor women, interfere with their right to manage their pregnancies and hamper doctors and counselers.

title: Whose Binge?
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Aftermath Of a Bus Tragedy
description: ON FIRST seeing the battered bus, one rescuer said it looked as if it had been filleted. A boulder weighing several tons, dislodged by a Colorado state road crew, had thundered down a Rocky Mountain slope and crashed into the tourist vehicle 60 miles northwest of Denver. Six people were killed instantly, one died later, 21 were injured. Only six tourists were not hurt.

title: Mets Open New Site With Loss
description: The Mets transplanted a bit of the Big Apple to the Gold Coast of Florida today after training for 26 years on the Gulf Coast. And they were welcomed to their new springtime home by cheering crowds, spouting sprinklers and wide-ranging predictions that this was the year the Mets would rise again.

title: FUELED BY THE WEAKER DOLLAR, CLASSICS GO ABROAD
description: For years, car collectors in the United States used the strong dollar to buy classic European cars at bargain prices. That trend reversed a couple of years back.

title: New York State Income Tax Rates Cut
description: The rates will be lowered over a five-year period, and at the same time larger standard deductions will be phased in, as shown below. The top marginal rates will apply to most taxpayers; the 1987 threshold is $14,000 for single persons and $23,300 for married couples filing jointly. Years Top Single Head of Married Married Marginal Household Filing Jointly Filing Rate and Separately Surviving Spouse 1987 8.75% $3,600 $4,600 $5,300 $2,650 1988 8.375% 5,000 6,000 8,500 4,250 1989 7.875% 6,000 7,000 9,500 4,750 1990 7.375% 6,750 8,750 11,250 5,625 After 1990 7.0% 7,500 10,500 13,000 6,500 Source: Grant Thornton

title: THE REGION: The Dawkins Challenge; 2 American Dreams Are On Display in Jersey Race
description: TWO of America's favorite kinds of success stories will be on view in the New Jersey campaign for the United States Senate this year.

title: Stage: The Dancing Feet Of Michael Jackson
description: THERE is no way to separate Michael Jackson the singer from Michael Jackson the dancer, as his new show proves again.

title: Memories of War
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: Sally Gross
description: SALLY GROSS has labored long and persuasively in dance, but she is surprisingly little known among dancegoers. She is also a choreographer with a sharp sense of visual effect, one who can indicate complex atmospheres and personal histories with the most minimal of brush strokes and the simplest of props. So it was good to see her performing on the stage of the Equitable Center auditorium, a pretty, comfortable and generally well-appointed new theater that is a good deal more formal a theatrical space than the ones in which Ms. Gross usually performs. And it was good to see her uncompromising work honored on Thursday as the inaugural program of ''Equinox,'' an imaginative six-performance series of dance, music, video and performance art to be presented by the Whitney Museum of American Art at the Equitable Center through April 21.

title: Fay to Visit California
description: The New Zealand challenger, Michael Fay, is going to be in California for a speaking engagement this week, and before he returns home, officials of Sail America, which is managing the defense of the America's Cup for the San Diego Yacht Club, hope he will accept some proposals to change the race format. Speaking for Sail America, Becky Heyl said the syndicate wanted to start the races Sept. 3 rather than Sept. 15, to change the competition from a three-of-five-race to a four-of-seven-race series and to use an eight-leg rather than a three-leg course.

title: Rivalry Aside, 6 Balkan Lands Meet and Agree
description: The meeting of six Balkan Foreign Ministers in Belgrade last week is being widely praised for bringing together representatives of countries burdened by historic rivalries and for producing several bilateral agreements.

title: STRIKES CHALLENGE PORTUGAL'S LEADER
description: A rash of strikes in Portugal since the beginning of the year represents the first serious test for the Government of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva and his promise of political stability.

title: Abigail Robinson And Law Student To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John R. Robinson of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Phipps Robinson, to Thomas Bowers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bowers of Greenwich. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Two Biographers Put Film Idols in Sharper Focus
description: ''She can talk about Bogart the man, which helps us understand Bogart the actor, which in turns help us understand Bogart the myth.''

description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 18 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.)
