How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 3 3 4 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society recalled by a woman who married into it. 4 6 17 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 5 4 43 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 6 10 3 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 7 5 15 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 8 7 39 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 9 13 32 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 10 9 7 N CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 11 * 12 32 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 12 1 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 13 8 6 DETOUR, by Cheryl Crane with Cliff Jahr. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) Lana Turner's daughter recalls the circumstances under which she killed her mother's gangster boyfriend 30 years ago. 14 2 DONNIE BRASCO, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (New American Library, $18.95.) A former F.B.I. agent tells of his five years posing as a mobster to discover Mafia secrets. 15 2 SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE, by William Greider. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A history of the Federal Reserve, with special attention to the years when Paul Volcker was chairman (1979-87). Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 5 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 2 2 35 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 5 3 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK AND EASY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library, $17.95.) Dishes that can be prepared in less than an hour. 4 4 130 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 3 15 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE IMMORTAL BARTFUSS, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) An extraordinary adventure in character portrayal by the distinguished Israeli novelist; Bartfuss, a Holocaust survivor, is an awesomely interior figure, alienated from the universe; his slightest acts are seen as feats of heroism. A SAND COUNTY ALMANAC: And Sketches Here and There, by Aldo Leopold. (Oxford University, $17.95.) A centenary edition of the classic collection of essays, sketches and enlightened reflections on nature by the influential conservationist. MAN WITH A GUN, by Robert Daley. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Mr. Daley's hero, a newly coined deputy police commissioner, finds himself on the wrong side of the law in this carefully designed, socially conscious thriller. UNCOVERING SOVIET DISASTERS: Exploring the Limits of Glasnost, by James E. Oberg. (Random House, $19.95.) The author, an experienced technology sleuth, inspects the record of calamity and censorship; he finds things looking up, slightly. COMPLICITY, by Elizabeth Cooke. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) A handsomely constructed first novel about three generations of New England women and a family legacy of deceit and denial. THE RACE TO FASHODA: European Colonialism and African Resistance in the Scramble for Africa, by David Levering Lewis. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $24.95.) The struggle for ascendancy in the Nile Valley in the late 1800's, with a cast rich in shrewdness, scheming, fatuity and looniness, both African and European. FROZEN MUSIC, by Francis King. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Short and thoroughly packed, this novel returns a father and son to India where they play out a psychological drama of past versus present.

title:
DINING OUT;
Indian Cuisine Back in Montrose
description: LEAD: CLOSED first for six months because of fire and then more recently for 10 months to correct a drainage problem, India House is ready again to satisfy cravings for Indian food in a section of the county somewhat poor in interesting culinary fare.

title: Plan to Drill for Oil Unsettles Los Angeles Politics
description: Motorists on the Pacific Coast Highway below the scrub-covered bluffs of the Pacific Palisades scarcely glance at the green plywood fence next to the defunct Sunspot Motel. But what is happening behind it may well recast the political future of this city, the second largest in America.

title: Inter-German Tourism Is Up
description: About 230,000 West German tourists visited East Germany last year, an increase of 10 percent and the first noticeable increase since 1984, the Bonn Government said today. East Germany's Communist Government has recently loosened restrictions on foreign travel, allowing five million citizens to visit West Germany in 1987.

title: Music the Old-Fashioned Way
description: LEAD: AS far as Barbara Kupferberg and Ken Andresen are concerned, there's never too much Baroque music or too many early-music ensembles. And because the two musicians - she's a pianist and sometimes harpsichordist; he's a trombonist whose real instrumental passion is the recorder -are in a position to do something about it, they have.

title: Washington Loosens Grip on Indebted Farms
description: SINCE 1981, when the most recent farm crisis began, no issue in American agriculture has generated more fury than the raw, desperate struggle between debt-burdened farmers and their lenders. The disorienting fear that any day could bring a foreclosure notice has scarred hundreds of thousands of farm families and left a trail of blood and tears across rural America.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Darcy J. Hammerman Weds Allen B. Dalton
description: The marriage of Darcy Jill Hammerman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hammerman of New York, to Allen Bruce Dalton took place last evening at the Concord Hotel in Kiamesha Lake, N.Y. Rabbis Seymour Nulman and Jonah Weinberg officiated. The bridegroom is the son of Theodore Dalton and Kate Mandel, both of Liberty, N.Y.

title: A Bit of Madison Avenue in the County
description: DESPITE the current trend in the advertising industry toward global companies, bigger does not necessarily mean better. That is the contention of alumni of some of the largest advertising agencies in the country who have left Madison Avenue to set up small, entrepreneurial advertising firms in the county.

title: A Voice of Dissent Ruffles Indonesian Politics
description: The decision this week by a small political organization to field its own vice presidential candidate rather than support the nominee of President Suharto created an unexpected crisis for the country's ruling party.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: LEAD: ALL THE SMALL POEMS By Valerie Worth. Illustrated by Natalie Babbitt. 173 pp. New York: A Sunburst Book/ Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Paper, $3.50. (Ages 5 and up)

title: Choosing the Lowest Cost Interest After Taxes
description: The table below shows the net present value of after-tax interest and closing costs on a $10,000 loan taken out in 1987. It assumes a 10 percent discount rate and nondeductible closing costs of $400 and $200 on second mortgages and home equity loans respectively with closing costs amortized over the life of the loan. title: Abu Nidal Group Said to Hold Briton and Syrian
description: A kidnapped British relief official and his Syrian aide are in the hands of the Palestinian guerrilla group led by Abu Nidal, security officials said today.

title: Arms Makers Get Aid on Diversifying
description: LEAD: WITH the boom years of extravagant military spending apparently ending, lawmakers from areas like Long Island and Connecticut, where billions of weapons dollars mean thousands of jobs, are looking for a way to soften the blow of future cutbacks.

title: ALL'S FARE IN FLYING TRANS-ATLANTIC
description: Just a few years ago, deciding how much to spend for a plane ticket to Europe came down to whether one flew first class, economy - or not at all. Not today. The trans-Atlantic traveler is now faced with a confusing array of options. ''There have never been as many fares before,'' said Phil Davidoff, the vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents.

title:
ANTIQUES;
'B & B' Weekends Offer Dividends
description: LEAD: AN OPPORTUNITY to get away without actually going away is the special lure this month of a number of bed-and-breakfast establishments.

title: Corsica
description: To the Editor: In writing about Corsica (Travel, Dec. 27), James M. Markham mentions that the island has a ''terrible secret'' - the terrorist movement aimed at wrenching independence from France.

title: Volunteers Help Children And Jailed Mothers Unite
description: TRACY, as I'll call her, is 11 years old and lives in New York City. My husband, David, and I are retired, and we live in Katonah. We met Tracy through the Summer Program at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, the state's maximum-security prison for women. Tracy's mother is a prisoner in it.

title: Yankees Watch As Clark Runs For the First Time
description: It might have been the most anticipated run to first base since the start of spring training.

title: A la Carte
description: LONG ISLANDERS' long love affair with pasta is taking a new turn. An innovative breed of restaurant highlighting pasta is enlivening the Long Island dining scene. Typical are three charming storefronts that have opened within the last year: Main Street Pasta in Smithtown, Casa Di Pasta in Huntington and Pastas Cafe in Manhasset.

title: Covering Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Cites Gains In Toxic Waste Cleanup
description: New York is working to clean up 293 hazardous waste disposal sites as part of a $4 billion program to rid the state of dangerous dumping grounds by the year 2000, the Department of Environmental Conservation reported this week.

title: CLARE BOOTHE LUCE IS REMEMBERED
description: Sylvia Jukes Morris's research into the life and times of the fascinating Clare Boothe Luce was both honest and gentle (''In Search of Clare Boothe Luce,'' Jan. 31).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think some of the candidates are envious of me rather than the other way around.'' - Jimmy Carter, returning from a ski trip. [ 36:6. ]

title: Getting Your Act Together For 6 Key Planning Areas
description: If ever taxes were to be an integral component of financial planning, it is 1988. For this is the year that most elements of the 1986 tax law - the most sweeping revision of the nation's tax code - take full effect. In developing tax strategies for future years, of course, individuals will also want to consider recent changes in the economy and financial markets.

title: Lincoln High Advances
description: Lincoln High School of Brooklyn (23-0) got a game-high 26 points from Norman Marbury, a sophomore, on the way to a 76-71 victory over Grady of Brooklyn (18-7) yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Section A quarterfinal game at Canarsie High School in Brooklyn. Lincoln will face Newtown (25-0), which defeated Springfield Gardens, 56-55, in overtime Friday, next Sunday in a semifinal at Brandeis High School in Manhattan. Leroy Fludd scored 15 points and Darryl Williams and Mike Spencer had 10 each for the winners. Effram Whitehead's 18 points paced Grady.

title: Susan Agoston Weds
description: Susan Lillian Agoston, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Agoston of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Harold Robert Goldstein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Goldstein of Scarsdale. Cantor Raymond Smolover officiated at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. Until recently, the bride taught at the New York Restaurant School. Mr. Goldstein is a senior vice president of institutional sales and trading of Shearson Lehman Hutton in Chicago.

title: Entries Drop for Florida Race
description: The annual Southern Ocean Racing Conference is having its second lean year in a row. Last year, organizers for the yacht-racing series off the Florida coast blamed the America's Cup in Australia for a poor turnout. This year, they cite the stock market crash last October.

title: Claudine S. Puglisi Is Wed To Thomas Leland Cagwin
description: At St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, Claudine Suzanne Puglisi and Thomas Leland Cagwin were married yesterday by the Rev. Martin Geraghty.

title: Notebook; Twins Think They Still Have Winning Formula for Pitching
description: As World Series champions, the Minnesota Twins have a spring corps of pitchers that more closely resembles the tired, the poor and the huddled masses that Emma Lazarus had in mind when she wrote the words that adorn the base of the Statue of Liberty.

title:
INVESTING;
Institutions Nibble at Technology Stocks
description: LEAD: Technology stocks were pariahs after last October's crash. Individual and institutional investors could not sell these volatile stocks fast enough in their rush to the safety of Treasury bills.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FROM THE CHAMBER

title: Bush Takes Resounding Victory In First of the Southern Primaries
description: Vice President Bush won a resounding victory today in South Carolina's Republican primary, setting the stage for what his opponents concede may approach a sweep of the 17 Republican contests scheduled for Tuesday.

title: VERBATIM: Leaving It Here
description: 'Where I'm going, they have no pockets, no places to put the stocks and bonds. I'd like to give something back, to give the people of the city some housing, which I think they desperately need.'

title: New Issue Honors an American Sportsman
description: KNUTE Rockne, one of the legends of college football, will be honored Wednesday in Notre Dame, Ind. with the release of a 22-cents United States stamp. As part of the American Sports commemorative series, the stamp will be released where Rockne was head football coach for 13 years.

title: Miss Gyftopoulos To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Elias P. Gyftopoulos of Lincoln, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Vasso Gyftopoulos to Hugh J. Kelly 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly Jr. of Weston, Mass.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; New 2-Family Houses Fill Growing Need
description: WITH the prices of land and single-family houses continuing to soar, some Westchester builders are turning to the Cinderella of the housing market, the two-family house, and finding eager buyers.

title: For Foul Weather Or Fair
description: HANDBAGS, totes and suitcases ($130 to $380) designed to take foul weather by storm are among the 400 stylish accessories that Frances Patiky Stein, left, recently brought from Europe to show to store buyers.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: A gold medal goes to the opening ceremony which was moving and awe-inspiring. Gold medals also go to Midori Ito of Japan and Elizabeth Manley of Canada for their performances during the freestyle finale of the figure skating event. They brought excitement to what turned out to be boring and uninspiring performances by the supposed stars of this contest: Debi Thomas and Katarina Witt.

title: One Big Family's Adoption Service
description: When an adoptive parent calls Susan or Hector Badeau for advice, the couple can speak from experience.

title: Archdiocese Aids Pupils With Divorced Parents
description: CATHOLIC schools are giving students of divorced parents places and times to express their feelings.

title: Orosco Is the Prankster
description: Jesse Orosco has been identified as the prankster who daubed some eye black inside Kirk Gibson's baseball cap, prompting Gibson to leave the Dodgers' training camp in anger Thursday.

title: 'Niner' Edged by 32-1 Shot in Florida Derby
description: Randy Romero learned last month how tough it is to run down Forty Niner. In the Fountain of Youth Stakes Feb. 15, the jockey spent almost the entire race unsuccessfully battling to get a colt named Notebook to edge past Forty Niner, only to fall a nose short at the finish line.

title:
ART;
Some Surprises in Mt. Vernon
description: LEAD: MARION STRAW, the director of the AC-BAW Gallery in Mount Vernon, boasts a little when telling you that this storefront space (AC-BAW stands for the Association of Community-Based Artists in Westchester) beat out the Los Angeles County Museum of Art for a chance to exhibit an important collection of African-American art, the Barnett-Aden Collection from

title: Concert: Musica Sacra
description: A SOLID, broadly phrased rendition of Verdi's beautiful collection of late choral pieces, the ''Quattro Pezzi Sacri'' formed the satisfying conclusion of a Musica Sacra concert Friday evening that had not begun promisingly. The program also included Gabrieli's ''In Eclesiis,'' Mozart's ''Coronation Mass'' and the ''German Motets'' of Richard Strauss, and it might have been a better idea to offer just Mozart and Verdi.

title: The I.R.S. and You: Closer Than Ever Before
description: ''In this world nothing is certain except death and taxes.'' - Benjamin Franklin

title: Cleveland
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Cleveland'' (Travel, Jan. 3) needs some filling in. If the Stouffer Tower City Plaza Hotel is found wanting, there are three fine large hotels in downtown Cleveland, all within easy walking distance of both the Convention Center and the Galleria: the Holiday Inn Lakeside, the Hollenden and the Bond Court Hotel. The restaurant section neglects three outstanding restaurants: Sammy's in the Flats, Giovanni's in suburban Beachwood and the Baricelli Inn in Little Italy. Finally, Cleveland is one of the few American cities with direct inexpensive rail service from its airport to downtown. LEONARD H. MANHEIM Garden City, L.I.

title: U.S. Planning for Armenian Refugees
description: Reagan Administration officials report a sharp increase in the number of Armenians trying to leave the Soviet Union, and the State Department has drafted a proposal to admit 12,000 of them to the United States as refugees.

title: THE K.G.B. AND ME
description: I'VE NEVER MET VIKTOR M. CHEBRIKOV, the head of the K.G.B., but after living in Moscow for two and a half years I can't help feeling we're well acquainted. Every time I see his somber visage in newspapers and on television I think about the dozens of times the K.G.B. has intruded in my life.

title: More Laurels for An Ex-Californian
description: IT is doubtful whether one bridge player in a hundred could answer either of the following questions: Who is the most successful tournament player in the past year? Or in the past four years?

title: Jessica Einstein Marries George Couri in Florida
description: Jessica Einstein and George Couri were married yesterday at St. Gregory's Episcopal Church in Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Paul Schneirla, a priest of the Antiochian Orthodox Church, performed the ceremony.

title: ENDLESS FEAR AND ENDLESS HATE?
description: THE YELLOW WIND By David Grossman. Translated by Haim Watzman. 216 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Helen Hill Engaged to John D. Lobrano
description: Helen Margaret Hill, a buyer for the British Isles Buying Agency in London, and John D. Lobrano, an associate in the London office of the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, plan to marry April 30.

title: Seeking Testimony in Pipeline Case: Immunity Given to a Secretive Swiss
description: James C. McKay, the special prosecutor investigating Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, has given immunity from prosecution to Bruce Rappaport, the Swiss business executive who was at the center of a Mideast pipeline project, according to people familiar with the inquiry.

title: Getting a Ticket When the Car's at Home
description: NEW YORK license plate VBL 853 is no longer in use.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Costs Increase 16.5% in U.S. for Business Travel

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: CELTIC FOLK MUSIC Just in time for St. Patrick's Day, the Boys of the Lough will bring the folk music of Ireland, Scotland and Northumberland to Englewood Friday and North Branch Saturday.

title: The Deal Makers Set a Fast Pace
description: Bidders were busy in their most-active week since the October market crash. Besides three big new deals, new suitors and revised bids emerged to complicate several previously announced takeover situations. The battle for Federated Department Stores was the most dramatic. What had finally looked like a done deal with the Campeau Corporation fell apart when R.H. Macy made an offer of$6.2 billion. Then, hours after Macy and Federated signed an apparently definitive agreement, Campeau announced it was not giving up and revised its bid, essentially matching the value of Macy's offer but providing more cash. Campeau also said that, if it does acquire Federated, it would be selling two chains - Filene's based in Boston and Foley's in Houston - to May Department stores for $1.5 billion.

title: Bishop Brooke Mosley, 72, Dies; Ex-Head of Theological Seminary
description: Bishop J. Brooke Mosley Jr., a former president of the Union Theological Seminary, died of a heart attack Friday in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan as he was preparing to board a train to his home in Philadelphia. He was 72 years old.

title: New Brunswick Evictions Raise Protests and Questions
description: LIKE a military task force, members of protest groups, using cars and walkie-talkies, fanned out across this city, looking for Michael Gupco, the local Construction Code enforcement official.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have two doors in my house that seem to gradually close by themselves and will not stay fully open. Is there a simple solution to this problem?

title: Special Today; Your Taxes: A Financial Planning Guide, Section 3A
description: For many, financial planning is more complex than ever, and the tax bill will be higher under the new laws.

title: For the Newly Poor, The Word Is Retrofit
description: Ah, the palmy days of the 10-franc, 2,000-lira dollar.

title: A GOOD TIME WAS HAD BY SOME
description: Oscar Wilde once wrote, ''There is only one thing in the world worse than being talked about, and that is not being talked about.'' In OSCAR WILDE'S LONDON: A Scrapbook of Vices and Virtues, 1880-1900 (Anchor/Doubleday, $24.95), an engaging social history of late Victorian London, Wolf Von Eckardt, Sander L. Gilman and J. Edward Chamberlin talk at length about Wilde, though always in the context of the city where he lived. (Mr. Von Eckardt and Mr. Gilman are the authors of ''Bertolt Brecht's Berlin,'' and Mr. Chamberlin has written another book on Wilde and his times, ''Ripe Was the Drowsy Hour.'') Fin de siecle London, they tell us, was a time of startling contrasts. While William Morris was espousing the virtues of hand craftsmanship, new technology was bringing the city its first telephones and electric lights. And though a third of the working-class population lived in abject poverty, wealthy West Enders - Wilde among them - enjoyed the opulence of London's yearly social season. Opium dens, public houses, child pornography and prostitution flourished side by side with the temperance societies and child-rescue leagues that opposed them. The authors' inclusion of diary excerpts and period journalism lends an immediacy to this portrait of an era caught between romanticism and change, decadence and social reform. They discuss everything from Victorian art to the changing map of London and the resurgent interest in the occult. If at times they are guilty of highlighting the sensational, the wealth of extraordinary photographs, illustrations, cartoons and paintings they provide more than compensates. This is a colorful, highly readable account of an age of contradictions not unlike our own.

title: A New Ambiance For Home Music
description: Listeners who like multidirectional loudspeakers are usually quite vocal about their preference, extolling the spacious sound typical of such designs. Yet for all their enthusiasm, these listeners remain a minority, and multidirectional speakers are therefore relatively rare and frequently expensive. Modestly priced and musically competent additions to this group are doubly welcome.

title: Rockland Votes to Withdraw From M.T.A.
description: Saying it has been paying too much for rail service, the Rockland County Legislature voted unanimously last week to withdraw from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The move, which requires the County Executive's approval, would take effect Jan. 1, 1989.

title: Attacks Reported in Namibia
description: Namibian guerrillas said today they had killed 11 South African soldiers and attacked a South African military base in separate clashes on March 3 and March 4 in the northern part of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.

title: State Seeks Ways to Pay Local Bills
description: THE state commission studying taxes and spending wants the state to assume some expenses paid by counties and municipalities.

title: A Political Song That Casts Its Vote For the Money
description: What's the most offensive music video clip ever? For me, one candidate reigns supreme: the clip for Michael Jackson's current single, ''Man in the Mirror.'' It's not the kind of video that brings down the wrath of fundamentalists and would-be censors; there's not a whiff of sex, no blood and little violence. Mr. Jackson doesn't show up in it, either. The clip, which just entered MTV's Top 20, is simply a smoothly edited, slightly tricked-up montage of news footage. But it demonstrates remarkable -I'd say monumental - gall, insensitivity and megalomania.

title: Why the Game Is Like Mathematics or Music
description: CHESS is one of the three principal human activities - mathematics and music are the others - in which youth can shine. Not only do these fields produce child prodigies, but the general level of development in them is also by far greatest in adolescence.

title: For Willingboro, a Modest Tricentennial Celebration
description: LEAD: THIS Burlington County township will be 300 years old this year, and Mayor Jim Ayers, who is planning a celebration, says:

title: CLARE BOOTHE LUCE IS REMEMBERED
description: I had an opportunity to interview Mrs. Luce in 1975, when she came to South Hadley, Mass., to receive an honorary degree from Mount Holyoke College.

title: Plan to Revive Pleasure Beach
description: AS do many other longtime residents of Bridgeport, Joseph D'Amicol has fond memories of Pleasure Beach from the 1920's to the 50's, when it was one of the best-known amusement parks in New England.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 25 in some copies of the Travel section today, about air fares, describes Air France's service between New York and Paris incompletely. The line offers first-class service, at a round-trip fare of $3,670.

title: Expanded Right to Medicaid Shatters the Link to Welfare
description: Through a series of small steps over the last three years, Congress has dramatically expanded Medicaid, the health program for the poor, extending coverage to several million children, elderly people and pregnant women.

title: Hats, Hats Hats: 150 Ways to Cover a Head
description: LEAD: ON the night of her 27th birthday, Roxanne Faber-Savage moped about the march of time. ''I was depressed,'' she said. ''Then I started playing with a party hat, and then I started making party hats. That's the form it took.''

title: Headliners; Unacceptable Loss
description: They waved goodbye to Mr. Nice Guy at the Pillsbury Company last week, and welcomed back William H. Spoor as chairman, chief executive officer and president. Mr. Spoor, now 65 years old, earned a reputation for brusque management while presiding over a 12-year period of rapid growth at Pillsbury, but took an early retirement in 1985. He was replaced by John M. Stafford, then a 48-year-old executive whose affable manner was expected to result in a calmer executive corps and higher profits. But Mr. Stafford, who resigned last week, was not up to making the necessary tough decisions, according to Wall Street analysts, and in 1987 he presided over the company's first earnings decline in 16 years. Said one analyst, ''Bill Spoor will put something in motion very quickly.''

title: Concert: Tennstedt Leads Beethoven and Mozart
description: KLAUS TENNSTEDT, the East German conductor now active in the West, once addressed himself to a broad range of music, including the contemporary. But now he is an unashamed keeper of the standard repertory flame. Wednesday night, he led the first of five Mozart and Beethoven concerts with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, the Beethoven being the ''Eroica'' Symphony, which will be repeated as the second half of an all-Beethoven program next week.

title: A BROTHER'S DREAMS
description: One of my parents' most valuable gifts to me was the understanding that my eldest sister's ''illness'' was nothing of which to be ashamed (About Men: ''A Brother's Dreams,'' by Paul Aronowitz, Jan. 24). Consequently, I have always told my friends of her diagnosis of schizophrenia. However, until recently, I had never heard of anyone who shared my experience.

title: TAKEN FOR A BEAST IN THE JUNGLE
description: STRANGER IN THE FOREST On Foot Across Borneo. By Eric Hansen. Illustrated. 286 pp. Boston: A Yolla Bolly Press Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: POSTINGS: The Kings of Flatbush; Movie Palace for Sale
description: Photographs, blueprints and publicity posters from the Loew's Kings Theater will be displayed at the Urban Center of the Municipal Art Society on Madison Avenue at 50th Street from Friday to April 26. The exhibit is intended to generate interest in the Brooklyn movie palace, which has been silent for a decade. Show hours are Monday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Profiles: How Some Are Getting Their Financial Houses in Order  A Retired Couple
description: Between 1985 and 1987, Louis G. Boli, 69 years old, a retired aerospace engineer from Santa Barbara, Calif., and an otherwise very private person, took on the Federal Government in a test case concerning the Government's right to tax Social security benefits of retirees who also receive substantial tax-free income from municipal bonds, a change that took effect in 1984.

title: Among Arabs, Bitter Views of the West
description: HIS parents' dinner guests were a little startled here last Thursday, when 10-year-old Zaher Yaghi broke into their conversation to proclaim that Secretary of State George Shultz is ''against peace and the Palestinians.''

title: NONFICTION
description: ASSATA: An Autobiography. By Assata Shakur. (Lawrence Hill, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $9.95.) Assata Shakur is something of a folk hero to a number of blacks, even those who would not follow a revolutionary to the next block. She is Assata to them and to her fellow activists of the 1970's, a woman whose worst crime may have been being black and militant. But she remains JoAnne Chesimard to law-enforcement officials, a convicted cop killer, a prison escapee and a fugitive. In this deftly written book of autobiography and poetry, Ms. Shakur, now 40 years old and living in Cuba, traces her transformation from a carefree middle-class girl in Queens to a revolutionary woman who would not shy away from violence but who says she did not commit the crimes with which she was charged in the 1970's. ''Before i was ten, i could recognize a Van Gogh on sight, and i knew what cubism, surrealism, and abstract expressionism were,'' she writes. By her early 20's she was equally a connoisseur of jails: ''They have a smell unlike any smell on earth. Like blood and sweat and feet and open sores and, if misery has a smell, like misery.'' The book's abrupt shifts in time can annoy after a while, as can the liberties she takes with spelling - ''court,'' ''America'' and ''Rockefeller,'' for example, become ''kourt,'' ''amerika'' and ''Rockafella.'' But, all in all, the author provides a spellbinding tale that evokes mixed feelings in the way the autobiographies of Malcolm X, Sonny Carson and Claude Brown did in years past.

title: Financial Woes Follow Swaggart Confession of Sin
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart's public admission of sin and the allegations of sexual misconduct on his part have caused a sharp drop in donations, forcing his ministry to lay off 100 workers and halt construction work, a Swaggart spokesman says.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: Best was the spirit, grace and camaraderie of the athletes. Worst was the obsession ABC had with the U.S.A.'s lack of medals. DINAH KROSNICK New York

title:
MUSIC;
New Philharmonic to Make Debut
description: LEAD: THE Philharmonic Orchestra of New Jersey, created a year ago to offer professional experience to recent conservatory graduates, will make its formal concert debut Saturday at 8 P.M.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DOUBLE WHAMMY. By Carl Hiaasen. (Putnam, $16.95.) Who would ever have thought there was so much fun to be found on the professional bass fishing circuit? Carl Hiaasen has tapped into this hitherto undiscovered literary gold mine and come up with a tale that tells us everything we never knew about a unique brand of American sportsman, and everything we suspected about television evangelists, good ole boys and the rape of Florida.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Foreign Tenants; Landlords Loath to Let to Governmental Agencies
description: DIPLOMATS from around the globe gathered a few days ago in an office building across from the United Nations to consider the problems of leasing office space in Manhattan.

title: Michelle Latta Marries Charles Hoefer
description: Michelle Elaine Latta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Alan Latta of Guilford, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles William Hoefer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Hoefer of Juno Beach, Fla., and Charlestown, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro performed the ceremony at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: STAFFORD SPRINGS;
For Police Officer, Job Is Worth More Than $100,000
description: LEAD: IF the six-man police department in the borough of Stafford Springs is disbanded this year, Officer Paul Bradman stands to earn $100,000 in severance pay.

title: Article 989588 -- No Title
description: Legislation to raise the Federal minimum wage from $3.35 an hour to $4.65 over the next three years has won approval from the House Education and Labor Subcommittee on Labor Standards. The vote, which came Thursday and sent the bill to the full committee for consideration next week, was 6 to 3, with all Democrats in favor and all Republicans opposed.

title: Headliners; Great Expectations
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the industrialist, has begun a recruitment campaign for what he calls a ''war on cancer.''

title: Carmel Snow Wilson, a Photographer, To Wed Brett D. Fromson, a Reporter
description: The engagement of Carmel Snow Wilson to Brett Duval Fromson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard A. Fromson of Weston, Conn., and Hartford, has been announced by R. Thornton Wilson of New York, father of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Movie Targets London Slums
description: LEAD: Sitting in a location bus that was serving as a dining hall during nighttime filming outside a rough South London housing project, the actors and crew of ''For Queen and Country'' were startled to see a ragtag group of kids run up and spit at the bus windows as they ate their dinner. The considerable hostility that this production encountered during several weeks of filming this winter in some of London's bleakest neighborhoods was ironic, given that the movie aims to spotlight the horrendous conditions of the urban poor living in Margaret Thatcher's

title: Parole-Curb Bill Gaining Support
description: A PROPOSED law that would eliminate parole for anyone convicted of willfully killing a law-enforcement officer is gaining support in Trenton, even though some legislators and the Attorney General, fearing inmate violence, initially objected to it.

title: Cashing In On the Retin-A Clamor
description: IT'S A MIRACLE, REALLY,'' said the woman behind the Estee Lauder cosmetics counter at Macy's. ''Future Perfect has Retin-A in it.''

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: HIGH DEFINITION TELEVISION;
Let's Not Lose Another Market to Japan
description: LEAD: The United States must not miss out on taking the lead in another new technology - high definition television. HD TV is video with the clarity and sharpness of film. The advance that HD TV represents over standard television is comparable to the improvement in picture quality that came with advances in color television.

title: New York's Poorest Women Offered More AIDS Services
description: In a sharp change of policy brought about by alarming new statistics, tens of thousands of New York's poorest women will soon have easy access to counseling and testing for the AIDS virus.

title: Feiner Decision on Homeless Puts Him on Unfamiliar Ground
description: LEAD: IT was a predicament that Paul J. Feiner would have liked to have avoided.

title: Iran Reports Downing 3 Jets As Iraq Continues City Raids
description: Iran said it shot down three enemy jets today as Iraq followed up missile strikes on Teheran with bombing sorties over other centers.

title: Hospitals Are Studying Cogeneration of Power
description: MORE than a dozen hospitals are considering building plants to generate electricity. One expects to start next summer.

title: Three Stooges Remembered, With Pies in Face
description: Brad Sloat couldn't remember what numbers were stitched to the backs of the football uniforms worn by the Three Stooges in one of their movies. So he got a pie in the face. But he wasn't taking anything off the pie thrower; he sent it flying right back. A group of kids joined in, hurling handfuls of whipped cream all over the Quality Inn meeting room. Sound like a meeting that got a little out of hand?

title: The Military Budget Helps the Economy
description: Stan C. Pace, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's second largest defense contractor, recently spoke with Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman about spending on the military and America's industrial competitiveness. The following are excerpts from that conversation.

title: The Essence Of Hungary's Cuisine: Paprika
description: PAPRIKA is to the entrees and main dishes of Hungary what whipped cream is to its desserts and pastries: it is theoretically possible to do without, but on the evidence of many a meal in homes and restaurants, the dominant hue of the first and second courses is rosy more often than not, and what follows is likely to be hiding under a billow of white.

title: Roundtable: Taxpayers In For a Rude Awakening
description: What does the new era in taxes - lower rates but fewer deductions - mean to individuals, both in terms of filing 1987 returns and in longer-term financial planning? How should people structure their finances, save for retirement or fund the children's education? How will investments be affected by the new tax laws? Two members of The New York Times staff, Gary Klott and Jan M. Rosen, discussed these and related questions with three experts: George E.L. Barbee, executive director of the Consumer Financial Institute, a division of Price Waterhouse; Albert B. Ellentuck, senior partner, Laventhol & Horwath, and Gerald G. Portney, principal, Peat Marwick Main & Co.

title: FOR WOMEN LAWYERS, AN UPHILL STRUGGLE
description: ON A JANUARY AFTERNOON, Peggy L. Kerr, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, in New York City, is thumbing through a stack of briefs and motions. A veteran of many takeover battles, she is fighting for the life of Computervision Corporation, trying to hit on the winning argument that will fend off a $434-million tender offer by a rival, Prime Computer Inc. Computervision must respond to Prime's tender offer within 10 days. ''Have you read the proposed resolutions?'' she hurriedly asks a colleague.

title: LET'S MAKE A DEAL
description: I enjoyed Patricia Volk's article. Five years ago, I had to move from Manhattan to New Jersey. At the time, I thought it was the end of the world.

title: Indy-Car Teams Cannot Hibernate
description: The Indy-car season doesn't open until April 10 in Phoenix, but the top teams in the series have been testing their 1988 cars almost since the last race of the 1987 season in Miami more than three months ago. Drivers and team owners say that the lonely, sometimes dangerous work of testing new equipment over the winter is one of the keys to success when the season begins.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: It is difficult to judge the Olympics because of the determined interference of the television coverage. We seemed to see far more of ABC's commentators than the Olympic events. Is there no way to shut these people up? CLARENCE FISHER Jr. New York

title: Partnership Swells 'High Tide'
description: Lilli is a loser who has landed in Eden. But in this case, Eden is not exactly Paradise - it's a patch of land on the Australian coast that cradles a dingy caravan park filled with squatty trailers. Indeed, its only Edenic quality is a breathtaking view of the percolating surf and the gloriously rugged beach.

title: Shultz and Aides Return With Hope for Mideast
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his Middle East staff returned to Washington today confident that they had injected a new diplomatic option into the grinding violence of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: Question of the Week; WHAT WAS GOOD AND BAD IN THE OLYMPICS?
description: The bad news is it happened. The good news is it is over. PAT SHANLEY Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Somers Reading
description: LEAD: Eager to participate in the community life of its new home area, the Pepsico company last fall awarded a $33,000 matching grant to the Somers Historical Society toward the publication of ''Somers - Its People and Places.'' Now the 250-page volume is available to subscribers for $22 plus a $3 handling charge, if mailed on or before March 15, or $27 plus $3 handling charge if sent after that date.

title: KNEE-SLAPPER
description: THE EGG AND I Starring Claudette Colbert (in photo), Fred MacMurray (in photo), Marjorie Main, Percy Kilbride, Louise Allbritton. 1947. Kartes Video Communications. 108 minutes. $19.95.

title: Ann Morris Colin, Freelance Writer, Wed to an Editor
description: The wedding of Ann Morris Colin, a daughter of Cynthia Green Colin and Justin Colin, both of New York, to Peter Herbst, a son of Eugenia V. Herbst of New York and the late Frank F. Herbst, took place yesterday at the Executive Tower in the Equitable Building in Manhattan.

title: Lesley Gordon to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Gordon of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter Lesley Jill Gordon to David Alan Hakim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Selwynn S. Hakim of Lido Beach, L.I. Ms. Gordon and her fiance graduated from the State University College at Potsdam, N.Y. She is a sales coordinator for the Freed, Crown Lee Publishing Company, and he is the sales manager for the Alfred Publishing Company, both in Van Nuys, Calif.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Feb. 7 about European travel packages misstated Alitalia Airlines' rate for six nights at the Nord Hotel in Rome. It is $299.

title: U.S. Seeks to Free Schools From Court Supervision
description: The Justice Department has begun a review of 300 Federal school desegregation cases and is seeking to release 17 Georgia school districts from court supervision.

title: Outdoors; The Latest Trend in Shotguns
description: Although most American shotgun users have long favored automatics or repeaters, increasing numbers of them are going for something classier.

title: Purim and Other Parties
description: Ball on the East River March 6 - The Park East Synagogue Young Couples will hold its second annual Gala Purim Masquerade Ball at the Water Club, at 30th Street and the East River. The evening's theme will be the 1950's, reflected in the dinner, music, decor and entertainment. Cocktails at 6:30. Tickets for the event, which benefits the synagogue, $125, from 212-737-6900. Purim at the Waldorf March 7 - A Beaux-Arts masked ball, to celebrate Purim and to benefit the Jewish Museum, will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. An original play, known as a Purimspiele, will be performed by Daniel Schorr, the radio and television commentator, and the Golden Peacock Players. Cocktails at 6:30, to be followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $350, or $65 for the 9 P.M. admission to entertainment and dancing only, from 212-860-1882. The Greening of Israel March 8 - The Jewish National Fund's Tree of Life Award will be given to Peter S. Kalikow, the real-estate developer, for his contributions to forestry programs in Israel. A black-tie dinner-dance starts with cocktails at 6 at the Marriott Marquis. Tickets, $500, from 212-737-7441. Sondheim Redux March 9 - Stephen Sondheim's ''Little Night Music'' will be back in town for nine performances by the Opera Ensemble of New York, 45 East 81st Street. The 7 P.M. opening performance will be a benefit for the ensemble, which does its own interpretations of musical theater. A reception at the Whitney Museum of American Art follows. Tickets, $100, from 212-288-1485. Urban Rejuvenation March 10 - The New York Landmarks Conservancy is dedicated to promoting the re-use of architecturally and historically significant buildings in the city. An offshoot of the conservancy, the City Ventures Fund, seeks to involve low- and moderate-income families in that endeavor. Paine Webber, a backer of the project, is holding a 6 to 8 P.M. reception benefit and preview of a photography exhibition, ''Reweaving the Urban Fabric,'' at its gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas (51st Street). Tickets, $35, from 212-995-5260 or at the door. Michael Jackson Here! March 10 - Michael Jackson will be honored at a fund-raising dinner on the anniversary of the United Negro College Fund, which since 1944 has raised $400 million. Liza Minelli, Whitney Houston and Quincy Jones are some other performers expected at the black-tie benefit at the Sheraton Centre. Cocktails at 6. Tickets, $500 and $1,000, from 212-234-2331. 'Bachelor Bid' on L.I. March 11 - The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation will benefit from a ''Bachelor Bid'' in which women may bid for dates with 35 bachelors, ranging from 23 to 56 years old and representing most of the professions. Before they go on the block, the bachelors may be appraised at a cocktail party starting at 7 P.M. at the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale, adjacent to the Nassau Coliseum. Tickets, $25 from 516-746-0080 or $30 at the door. Hepburns Honored March 14 - Working with Margaret Sanger when she founded Planned Parenthood in 1916 was the late Katharine Houghton Hepburn, whose daughter, the actress, has continued to support the family-planning service through the decades. Miss Hepburn is expected to attend a black-tie benefit for Planned Parenthood at which the Katharine Houghton Hepburn Fund will be established to provide funds ''for the battle to retain reproductive freedom.'' Cocktails at 6:30 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria will be followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment. Tickets, $500 and $1,000, from 212-614-0400. Movie Premiere March 14 - The film ''Dominick and Eugene'' will premiere at the Sutton Theater, at 57th Street and Third Avenue, at 7:30. After the show, there will be Champagne and dessert at the Drake Hotel. The evening benefits Very Special Arts, an international organization that seeks to provide opportunities in the arts for the disabled. Tickets, $100, or $25 for the movie alone, from 212-753-4178. Dance Benefit March 15 - The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will open its 20th anniversary season at the City Center with a benefit performance of the premiere of Mr. Lubovitch's ''Musette'' as well as his ''Of My Soul'' and ''Concerto Six Twenty-Two.'' The 7:30 P.M. performance and a Champagne buffet and dance afterward at ''21'' will help pay for a health insurance plan for the dancers. Tickets, $250, from 212-242-0633.

title: GOLDEN MOUNTAIN WAS GREATLY EXAGGERATED
description: THE NEW CHINATOWN By Peter Kwong. 198 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $18.95. BITTER MELON Stories From the Last Rural Chinese Town in America. By Jeff Gillenkirk and James Motlow. Illustrated. 142 pp. Seattle: University of Washington Press. Cloth, $35. Paper, $19.95. THE CHINESE LAUNDRYMAN A Study of Social Isolation. By Paul C. P. Siu. Edited by John Kuo Wei Tchen. Maps and tables. 311 pp. New York: New York University Press. Cloth, $47.50. Paper, $11.95.

title: Soviet Reports an Arms Buildup by Afghan Rebels
description: The Soviet Union charged today that Afghan insurgents are moving large quantities of arms and ammunition into Afghanistan in the midst of negotiations seeking an end to the country's civil war.

title: Miss Wallace, Lawyer, To Marry Fred Cooper
description: Nancy C. Wallace and Fred Allen Cooper, a son of Mrs. Louis Cooper of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Cooper, plan to marry in April, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leveritt A. Wallace of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced.

title: 'Workingman's' Team Inspires Loyalty of Fans
description: WEARING a red, white and blue New Haven Nighthawks booster cap, Jerry Lim was truly in his element.

title: CHILDREN WHO WILL NOT SPEAK
description: LEAD: JUST ANOTHER KID By Torey L. Hayden. 318 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: REED'S NETS WIN AGAIN
description: The Willis Reed coaching magic continued tonight. For the third straight game, the Nets, the owners of the worst record in the National Basketball Association when Reed was named coach last Monday, won, giving them three straight victories for the first time this season.

title: 3 'Blessed' by Their Adversity
description: At the memorial service, his Board of Education colleagues spoke of how Ed Roman dealt with ''children who had more problems than they had solutions for.'' Of how this ''gentle giant'' of a man with a Ph.D. in adolescent psychology ''gave us his sense of excellence: always do the best you can.'' Of how ''he was the righteous of the righteous.'' And earlier, Floyd Layne, now the City College basketball coach, stood before 250 mourners and remembered when Ed Roman was his teammate on the 1949-50 C.C.N.Y. team that won both the National Collegiate Athletic Association and National Invitation Tournament titles.

title: Debate Grows on Working Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: LARRY YABLON, a senior at Oceanside High School, began working 16 hours a week in a local delicatessen when he was in the 10th grade. Then, last year, his time behind the counter doubled.

title: Police Station Is Hit in Rioting in Tibet
description: Rioting broke out in Lhasa today, and a police station was attacked as a Buddhist festival drew to a close in the Tibetan capital, according to the official New China News Agency.

title: VATICAN EXPECTS RECORD '88 DEFICIT
description: The Vatican said today that it expects a record budget deficit of $61.8 million this year, although income from contributions has increased.

title: New Trial for McLain
description: A judge in Florida has set Sept. 7 as the starting date of a new trial for Denny McLain on charges of racketeering related to drug dealings. McLain, a former two-time Cy Young Award winner and the last major leaguer to win 30 games in a season, was convicted of the charges in 1986, but the conviction was overturned last year by an appeals court.

title: Release of Financier Delayed
description: A Federal magistrate yesterday ordered the release of John A. Mulheren, the Wall Street speculator accused of threatening Ivan F. Boesky and another witness, but the order was stayed by a Federal judge.

title: Four Experts Assess How Much You Can Reasonably Deduct
description: While cautioning that everyone's return must be considered individually, four experts found the following deductions reasonable for the family situations described. This is not to warn taxpayers away from taking larger deductions if they are entitled to them and have adequate records. Nor should anyone with smaller actual deductions beef them up. The experts are: Jacob R. Brandzel, national tax partner, Laventhol & Horwath; Jerry K. Brockett, senior tax manager, Seidman & Seidman/BDO; David J. Silverman, enrolled agent in private practice, and Stephen L. Mason, tax attorney, Kane, Kessler, Proujansky, Preiss & Nurnberg. Single, No Children, Rents Apartment Brandzel Brockett Silverman Mason Gross Income $40,000 $40,000 $40,000 $40,000 Less 401(k) contributions

title: Legislators Weigh Raceway Proposal
description: LEAD: A MOVE to establish a separate off-track betting region for Westchester, which was blocked by the County Board of Legislators five years ago, has been revived.

title: BLACK IS WHITE AND HE IS SHE
description: THE STORY OF MY WIFE The Reminiscences of Captain Storr. By Milan Fust. Translated by Ivan Sanders. Preface by George Konrad. 336 pp. New York: PAJ Publications. $18.95.

title: Ten Months Left to Fight Drugs
description: Why won't the United States fight back?

description: What was good and bad in the Olympics? Who can really say. The home viewer couldn't tell you because he did not see most of the events.
