title: Correction
description: A caption on Jan. 24 about Sigmund Freud and six colleagues dated the photograph incorrectly. The picture, which appeared with an article on 1930's intellectuals and Stalin's secret police, was taken in 1922.

title: The Challenge This Year: Keeping Your Balance
description: ''And if I laugh at any mortal thing, 'Tis that I may not weep.'' - Lord Byron

title: Duquesne Suspends Tuition Prepayment Plan
description: Duquesne University in Pittsburgh, which attracted national attention when it instituted a plan for prepayment of tuition at a child's birth, has been forced to suspend the program because of changing economic conditions.

title: Local Red Cross Marks 90th Year
description: LEAD: IT was in 1898 - during the Spanish-American War - that the first meeting of a Red Cross Society in Westchester took place, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Marquand of New Castle.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: BROKEN GROUND. By John Keeble. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The construction of a top-secret detention facility in the desert of southeastern Oregon is the focal point of this engrossing novel by the author of ''Yellowfish.'' Its hero, a Portland engineer named Hank Lafleur, is maneuvered into supervising the project by the manipulations of his ailing father's business partner.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Walks in the Woods
description: International negotiators, even Soviet and American negotiators, sometimes develop a curious consanguinity, a common impulse to reach agreement even where it runs against their governments' policies. At times, they explore possibilities for compromise that exceed their instructions, and conspire to sell their joint product to their respective capitals.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Check In and Play Through

title: Two Tenor Men Come In From the Cold
description: Halfway through his solo on Harold Arlen's ''I've Got the World on a String,'' the late tenor saxophonist Ike Quebec dramatically exhales three descending, screaming sighs. Following 16 bars of jeweled and carefully controlled be-bop, the swing-style eruption is a wonderful, startling surprise: Mr. Quebec is playing with the rules of jazz, taking them into his fist and molding them into a way of playing that suits his imagination. In retrospect, his stylistic freedom sounds utterly contemporary; it was, to a certain extent, also his undoing.

title: Next Week; Do Mets And Yanks Need More Pitching?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Rangers Misfire At a Key Moment
description: When he collected the puck tonight, Ulf Dahlen immediately understood the significance of what he was about to do. There were 15 minutes left in the third period, there was some room to the far side, and there was a chance to put away the game against the Whalers.

title: Defending Morgan
description: To the Editor:

title: On State Returns, New York Makes Major Revisions
description: ''Anyone has a right to do anything the law does not say is wrong.'' - J. Pierpoint Morgan

title: WHEN ARTISTS GET LOST IN A LABRINTH OF CONTEXT
description: The Musee D'Orsay may be only a little more than a year old, but it is already the most controversial museum built in this decade. It includes almost every form of visual expression in France between 1848 and 1914. The great Realist, Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings that were in the Louvre and the Jeu de Paume are here. So are Salon favorites. So are the decorative arts. So are some of the most urgent questions that can be raised about the presentation and interpretation of art.

title: FILLING OUT THE FORMS
description: Whether you plan to have your return prepared professionally or to do it yourself, walking through a return prepared by top professionals can be helpful, both in terms of getting records organized for this year's filing and in planning tax strategies for future years. Pamela Pecarich, tax partner, and Steven Woolf, Robin Cornelius and Jeffrey Hillier, tax managers for Coopers & Lybrand in Washington, prepared a sample return for a two-income New York couple. Key points of the return are explained in the accompanying commentary, and particular attention is given to areas where the new tax laws call for changes in planning or treatment. Filling Out the 1040

title: Our Worst Shortage Is of Integrity
description: AMERICA has survived many shortages in its proud history. From a scarcity of manufacturing facilities in Colonial times to oil embargoes in the 1970's, it has emerged to push toward the technological horizons.

title: CAMPAIGN SCHISMS WORRY THE G.O.P.
description: The Republican Party's search for a successor to Ronald Reagan, whose landslide victories stirred the party's hopes for a national realignment under Republicans, has turned into a campaign so rough that some party leaders are worrying that they may lose the White House and many other offices this fall.

title: The Cheerful Trudge Of a World Book
description: Judye Suttenberg admits she's one of those mothers who bought her children absolutely everything. Back in the late 1960's, she got the World Book for her three daughters when they barely knew who Howdy Doody was. Why isn't everyone like that? She can't understand it.

title: Global and Satirical Images in two Silvermine Shows
description: LATE last year, the Silvermine Guild Arts Center created a stir by giving birth, at the age of 65, to a second gallery -not at its compound in New Canaan but in downtown Stamford. What's more, the center did the deed at the new Metro Center hard by the new Stamford Transportation Center that used to be the plain old Stamford Railroad Station.

title: Pacific Group Recruit
description: Tom Robbins was senior vice president, corporate communications, for Backer Spielvogel Bates for two weeks. He then fell prey to the siren song of a pair of public relations people who had their own booming four-year-old firm in San Francisco. So now Tom Robbins, longtime public relations man for J. Walter Thompson in New York, is an associate at the Pacific Group. That firm's owners, Betsy Dixon and DeeAnn Gunn, had worked with Mr. Robbins for three years at J.W.T. Public Relations, San Francisco.

title: When It Comes to Population, More Isn't Better; No Room for Edisons
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $2,742,784 from settlement of a patent rights dispute. c-Net loss

title: Japanese Know-How for New York City
description: Tokyo and New York have been sister cities since 1960 but little more than good will came of it until 1986. Then, New York sent officials on visits to Tokyo, funded by the United States-Japan Foundation and managed by the Fund for the City of New York. The visits proved so fruitful that the fund now hopes to continue the exchanges.

title: RITZY'S, G D INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POP RADIO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $76,410 charge for the amortization of debt discount.

title: NEGLIGENCE IS SEEN IN PARTS OF CANAL CEDED TO PANAMA
description: The Panamanian Government has been mismanaging sections of the former Panama Canal Zone and installations important to the canal that have already been handed over by the United States, according to Panamanian employees of the canal and shipping industry experts here.

title: VICTORIA FINANCIAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: R. Baumfeld, 84, Dies; Architect and Planner
description: Rudi Baumfeld, an architect who designed the first two-level enclosed shopping mall built in the United States, Southdale in Minneapolis, died of congestive heart failure on Feb. 20 in Los Angeles. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Television; Hepburn as a Novelist and an Embattled Patrician
description: It's Katharine Hepburn all right. Playing a novelist named Laura Lansing, she has had her morning run and swim, and now she's on the phone talking to Yves Saint Laurent - in French. Then, pedaling on her stationary bicycle, she's told that her new book, ''Penthouse Paradise,'' isn't selling, and that her publisher is reluctant to go on to another novel. Furious, she wails: ''I'm chopped liver. I'm down the drain. I'm out with the garbage.'' Hardly. It's still Katharine Hepburn.

title: LAWYER AND A FELLOW OF HARVARD
description: William L. Marbury, a prominent Maryland lawyer who represented his boyhood friend, Alger Hiss, in the early stages of Mr. Hiss's libel suit against Whittaker Chambers, died Saturday after a heart attack in his Baltimore home. He was 86 years old.

title: Fresh Research Tells Asthmatics To Stay Active
description: FOR generations, people with asthma have been treated as invalids. They have been told to avoid exercise because it would induce attacks of their disease. A vicious circle was set up: the less they exercised, the less exertion it took to bring on an attack of coughing, constricted bronchial passages and difficulty breathing.

title: Farmers Irked by New Rules Restricting Drivers of Trucks
description: A farmer in Alexandria, Mo., would not be able to send his teen-age son to pick up a load of fertilizer a mile away in Keokuk, Iowa. A woman in Kalvesta, Kan., would need a commercial driver's license to ferry fuel across a state highway to her husband's tractor.

title: Back From the Brink: The Baltimore Symphony
description: As recently as three seasons ago, the Baltimore Symphony was one of the most seriously endangered of America's orchestras, with a deficit of $2.3 million and every prospect of sinking more than $1 million deeper into the hole each year.

title: Proudfoot Print Effort
description: Doremus & Company, the Omnicom Group unit that quietly became agency for the Alexander Proudfoot Company, management consultants, will be popping a new national campaign for it soon. The ads, with the theme line ''The Power of Productivity,'' will be running in Forbes; Fortune; The Wall Street Journal, which breaks the campaign tomorrow; Barron's, and the Harvard Business Review.

title: Market Place; Stevens as Focus Of a Long Battle
description: The battle for J. P. Stevens & Company, the giant textile producer, could prove to be complex and lengthy. Already there are two bids on the table: one from management and the other from West Point-Pepperell Inc., a major textile and apparel company. And analysts believe another bid is possible.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Surakarta Journal; A Sovereign of Surrealism and the Unseen Spirits
description: As a youth he was a rebel. All he wanted from life was the freedom to paint abstract and Surrealist art. But Sujiwo Kusumo was dealt another fate: on his shoulders fell a Javanese kingship.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Let There Be Flowers
description: Next month, when the capital is awash in the colors of tulips, daffodils and blossoming trees, Lady Bird Johnson will return for what is being called ''A Jubilee Celebration'' in her honor. As chairwoman of the First Lady's Committee for a More Beautiful Capital back in 1964, Mrs. Johnson is credited with mobilizing the forces that have turned Washington's boulevards, squares, traffic circles, parks and public places into a flowering wonderland.

title: U.S. Helicopters Come Under Fire in the Gulf
description: American helicopters on a reconnaissance mission in the Persian Gulf came under heavy machine-gun fire today from an oil platform and from several boats in the central part of the waterway, American officials said.

title: SHAMIR FOILS VOTE ON U.S. PEACE PLAN
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today blocked an attempt by his rival, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, to force a Cabinet vote on the new peace initiative brought by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: Navy Limits Role of Workers In Washington State's Vote
description: Republican and Democratic leaders are protesting a decision by the Navy to bar civilian shipyard employees from participating in the state's Presidential caucuses Tuesday.

title: His Record of Success Is Sure, But Boeheim Is Still a Mystery
description: NO sooner had Jim Boeheim walked into the lobby of a local televison station last week than a man wearing an Orangeman cap bounced over and cheerfully thrust out his hand. ''Good win over Villanova the other night, coach,'' he said. Boeheim smiled weakly and nodded.

title: La Prensa: Gadfly of the Sandinista Regime
description: Early every afternoon, as the first copies of the opposition newspaper La Prensa roll off the presses, Nicaraguans are treated to a new round of vitriol aimed at the Sandinista Government.

title: OUTDOORS: A LURE FOR ANGLERS WHO DON'T MIND COLD
description: THE middle of winter is not exactly regarded as a prime time for dry-fly fishing, but anglers made desperate by cabin fever might consider trying an imitation of a winter stonefly on trout streams that remain legally open. Streams that come to mind are the ''no kill'' sections of the Beaverkill and the Willowemoc in the Catskills and the Housatonic in Connecticut.

title: CHANDLER INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Soviet Reports Riot at Embassy in Iran
description: Iranian rioters attacked the Soviet Embassy in Teheran today, flinging rocks and firebombs and trying to break into the compound, the official Tass press agency reported tonight.

title: People
description: * Robert Cox is joining Hal Riney & Partners, New York, as senior vice president, executive creative director.

title: Mets Have a Tough Call at 2d
description: Rain fell on the Mets today, washing out their game with the Boston Red Sox and a matchup of Dwight Gooden and Roger Clemens. It also washed out another round in the only fight for a full-time job: the confrontation at second base between Wally Backman and Tim Teufel.

title: Folk Singers in Concert
description: Holly Near and Charlie King, the folk singers, are to appear with other performers in a concert tonight at 7:30 at Symphony Space, 95th Street and Broadway. The event is to raise money for humanitarian aid to Central America. Tickets are $15. Information: 864-5400.

title: ARGENTINA STILL CAN'T CARRY DEBTS
description: Although a recent round of negotiations in Washington produced $550 million in new financing for Argentina, economic officials here say a major crisis in servicing the country's $54 billion foreign debt is still looming.

title: Bethlehem Steel Bonus
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said Friday that it would distribute $48 million in cash and stock among 24,000 employees because their wage and benefit concessions helped Bethlehem record its first profitable year since 1981. By April 15, the workers are to receive cash payments averaging $500. Also, convertible preference stock worth an estimated $1,500 will be credited to each worker in an employee stock ownership trust.

title: Big East Penalizes Jayson Williams
description: Jayson Williams, St. John's 6-foot-7-inch sophomore center, yesterday became the first player suspended under the Big East's anti-fighting legislation.

title: Review/Music; Rostropovich in New Work From Land He Left Behind
description: Glasnostic doings on Long Island Saturday night: Rodion Shchedrin -secretary of the powerful Union of Soviet Composers - has written music for his country's most prominent musical dissenter, Mstislav Rostropovich. Mr. Rostropovich and his American orchestra, the National Symphony, played the piece - called ''Stykhira'' - at a Friends of the Arts concert at the Tilles Center, on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, in Greenvale.

title: Demise Of the Fundies
description: South Carolina, where firebrand orators a century ago led the nation into bloody civil war, assured the Union this weekend that the proud Palmetto State is a land of good sense.

title: Foreign Cars Assaulted
description: Vandals punctured tires on about 60 foreign cars at O'Hare International Airport last week, the authorities said. Ismael Hernandez, a garage supervisor, said Saturday that vandals roamed the parking deck's fourth level Tuesday and slit the tires on Mercedes-Benzes, Jaguars, BMWs and Volvos. Two American cars were also damaged. Mr. Hernandez said the owners of the cars got one bit of good news. ''We didn't charge them for parking,'' he said.

title: Elise Weissman Wed To Robert P. LeBow
description: Elise Michele Weissman, a daughter of Lester Weissman of Las Vegas, Nev., and the late Larraine Weissman, was married yesterday to Robert Philip LeBow, the son of Mrs. Daniel J. Greenberg of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi George Stern officiated at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton.

title: East Germany Is Said to Bar Faithful From Church Rites
description: Uniformed and plainclothes security forces prevented Christian worshipers from gathering for a church service today, detaining several people, a West German radio station reported.

title: The Los Angeles Life, but on New York Time
description: They may live by the edge of the Pacific Ocean or in the shadow of the San Gabriel Mountains, but a small army of Los Angeles residents march to the temporal rhythms of New York.

title: ANTONOVICH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly MEETING OF STATES PARTIES TO CONVENTION ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council SPECIAL COMMISSION ON U.N. STRUCTURE IN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC FIELDS - 10 A.M. WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
President Is Named At Gibraltar Financial
description: James N. Thayer has spent more than three decades in accounting jobs for insurers, investment bankers and aerospace manufacturers. Last week, his career path took another turn when the financially troubled Gibraltar Financial Corporation selected Mr. Thayer as its president and chief executive.

title: I.R.A. Demand Slows And Caution Prevails
description: In a savings climate clouded by changes in the Federal tax law and uncertainties about the stock market, the business of Individual Retirement Accounts is shifting gears. Fewer people are opening accounts, and those who do show a preference for investments that have historically been safe and stable.

title: Swaggart Makes TV Appearance, Saying He'll Tell His Sin Someday
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart returned to his television program today and told his followers that he would tell them someday about the unspecified sin to which he has confessed.

title: La Salle Faces True Test in Final
description: La Salle's domination of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference will be tested tonight by the team that perhaps poses the most matchup problems for the Explorers: the Fordham Rams.

title: Tugboat Workers' Strike Drags On
description: Even in the worst of times - when decks are icy, seas are rolling and a thousand feet of thigh-thick hawser line must be drawn and coiled - Hank Beattie and Patrick Branley are wedded to their work.

title: Islanders, Hrudey Check Nordiques, 2-0
description: Denis Potvin and Brent Sutter scored goals today and Kelly Hrudey got his third shutout of the season as the Islanders beat the Quebec Nordiques, 2-0.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 6, 1988: TUESDAY Household Intl Inc Roper Corp (Del) Oklahoma Gas & Elec Wrigley (Wm) Jr WEDNESDAY NICOR Inc Wallace Computer Svcs Southn NE Telecommun West Co THURSDAY Centel Corp Lincoln Natl Corp Hancock Fabrics Wal-Mart Stores Idaho Power FRIDAY Helmerich & Payne

title: INSIDE
description: Russians Attacked in Iran Iranians attacked the Soviet Embassy in Teheran, throwing rocks and firebombs and trying to break into the compound, Tass said. Page A3. A Harsh Nicaraguan Critic The Government hoped the paper La Prensa would support compromise after its forced closure, but it has been an unrelenting critic. Page A6. From Public to Private A Presidential panel says air traffic control, postal services and other Government functions should be entrusted to private business. Page A12. Murdoch Years at Post End Rupert Murdoch's sale of The New York Post, which is final today, appears to mark the greatest failure in a career of successes. Page B1.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: No Headline
description: Treasury auctions this week are limited to the bill market, with new three-month and six-month issues to be sold today, followed by a 12-month issue on Thursday.

title: BLYTH HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Indoor Lacrosse; Saints Advance To Final
description: The New Jersey Saints hung on until the end tonight and beat the Philadelphia Wings, 12-10, in a Major Indoor Lacrosse League semifinal playoff game before 4,118 spectators at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Paul Boubal, Cafe Owner, 80
description: Paul Boubal, former proprietor of the Cafe de Flore, a favorite haunt of French philosophers, writers and poets, has died, the management announced Saturday. He was 80 years old.

title: Review/Television; Manilow Blends 50's With 80's in a Special
description: Barry Manilow still sells records and still does major tours, but the pop singer seems to have reached a pivotal point in his career. Going are the soaring ballads with their soupy crescendos that seduced the hearts of teeny-boppers throughout the world. In his last couple of albums, Mr. Manilow has been reaching out to different sounds and styles, tapping especially the American heritage of jazz and Latin music. The change is evident in tonight's special at 10 on Channel 2, ''Barry Manilow: Big Fun on Swing Street.''

title: Holy Part of Greece Arrives In Queens in Orthodox Icon
description: The two youngsters stood in a crush of people at Ditmas Avenue and 31st Street in Astoria, Queens, yesterday, arguing over which direction Greece was from where they stood.

title: Pakistanis Hold Line In Afghan Peace Talks
description: Pakistan appeared to be sticking to its tough line in the Afghan peace talks tonight when its chief negotiator returned here after consultations in Islamabad over the weekend.

title: The Pentagon's Grand Illusion
description: The Pentagon is mortgaging its present to its future. Even the reduced budget prepared last month by Frank Carlucci, the new Secretary of Defense, fails to address the choice former Secretary Weinberger so long postponed: The new weapons being planned for the future cannot be afforded without severely undermining military preparedness today. In failing to postpone the costly new generation of planes and ships and nuclear forces, Mr. Carlucci has bucked a critical choice onto his successor.

title: A Museum Taking Shape To Tell the Holocaust Story
description: One of the museum's designers once described their task as the creation of an institution ''charged with telling what cannot be told, showing what cannot be shown, sharing what cannot be shared.''

title: Alysheba Wins Santa Anita
description: Alysheba evened the score with his archrival, Ferdinand, in the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap today, and in the process righted a few expensive wrongs suffered by Jack Van Berg at the hands of Charlie Whittingham.

title: DAVE WINFIELD'S REBUTTAL
description: Through the years, whenever Dave Winfield was asked for his reaction to having been stung by another of George Steinbrenner's tirades, the Yankee outfielder would invariably shake his head.

title: APPLIED DATA COMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Weighty Commitment
description: At 330 pounds and with a body-fat content of 22 percent, Kevin Duckworth didn't exactly possess the physique scouts in the National Basketball Association look for when he was a senior at Eastern Illinois.

title: Export-Import Bank Allows Loan Guarantees to Be Sold
description: The United States Export-Import Bank will allow its loan guarantees to be sold on secondary markets and to be used to support bond issues by state-owned and private foreign companies, a senior bank official said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Calet, Hirsh Campaign For K Mart Blue Denim
description: Another television advertising effort breaking Wednesday is coming from K Mart, the country's largest discounter. It will be promoting the chain's private-label blue-denim outfits for girls with a clever commercial by Calet, Hirsch & Spector.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Interpreting Economic Signs
description: Rarely, if ever, have prospects for the nation's economy been scrutinized so closely as they have since October's stock market plunge. Yet rarely has it been harder, given the contradictory mixture of recent statistics, to draw conclusions with confidence.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Pitt Tops Syracuse By 85-84
description: Pittsburgh survived a late Syracuse surge today to capture the Big East regular-season title with an 85-84 victory.

title: CAREPLUS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $2.7 million in non-operating charges, which itself includes a $2.2 million provision for losses taken in connection with the termination of the proposed Professional Care Inc. acquisition. The year loss also includes reserves and disallowances of about $860,000 related to unsettled medicare part a receivables associated with the company's certified nursing businesses. c-Net income

title: Portrait of 2 Southern Electorates
The Figures Don't Lie: Hollywood's Audience Is Older and Pickier
description: What many people in Hollywood have suspected for the last two years is now official: adults are going to the movies.

title: 4 Are Convicted of Selling Heroin To an Organized-Crime Informer
description: A jury convicted four men yesterday of selling heroin to a major mob informer who later refused to cooperate with the prosecution.

title: APPLIED SPECTRUM TECHNOLOIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Race Crash Kills 16 in Argentina
description: A race car plunged into a crowd of spectators after one of its tires exploded today, killing at least 16 persons and injuring more than a dozen others, the police said.

title: Olajide Is Stopped By Barkley in Fifth
description: The plan for Michael Olajide Jr. was to get by Iran Barkley and then take a long rest. Olajide, you see, has been feeling weary lately in the gym.

title: F.A.A. Spokesman Resigning; Discord in Agency Is Cited
description: The chief spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration is leaving after three months on the job because of an apparent conflict with his superiors at the Transportation Department, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Consider the Stepchild
description: To the Editor:

title: Electoral Integrity vs. Free Speech
description: The startling surge in expenditures by candidates for public office presents a fundamental challenge to the integrity of the electoral process. Spending increases have been staggering. Total spending in the 1984 Presidential primaries was $104 million. The current crop of Presidential contenders spent more than $87 million even before the New Hampshire primary. And yet, in recent days, when Bruce Babbitt, Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Pete du Pont withdrew from the race, each cited inadequate finances. As the pundit Will Rogers observed, ''Politics has got so expensive that it takes a great deal of money even to get beat with.''

title: Soviet Meeting Is Rescheduled
description: A meeting in Moscow in which business deals are to be discussed with more than 500 American corporate leaders has been rescheduled, according to Tass, the Soviet Government's official news agency. In a statement yesterday, Tass said that a session of the Soviet-American Commission on Trade and an annual meeting of the American-Soviet Trade and Economic Council would be held in Moscow during the week of April 11. No further explanation was given. On March 1 American and

title: Britain's FKB Group Makes 4 Acquisitions
description: THE FKB Group, a British concern little known by American marketers, has suddenly exploded onto the scene with the announcement that it is acquiring four United States marketing and sales promotion companies, all of which will continue to operate under their old names and managements.

title: Oust the P.L.O.'s Mission at the U.N.
description: Should the mission of the Palestine Liberation Organization to the United Nations remain on American soil? That is for the American people to decide, and Congress has decided that it should not. But the real question is: Should the P.L.O. be in the United Nations in the first place?

title: Paper Industry Sees Another Record Year
description: The trade association for American paper companies predicts that the industry is headed for another record year as a result of increased demand and the dollar's weakness againstmajor currencies, which has stimulated exports.

title: Soviet Reporter in New York Finds It's a Driver's Delight
description: A Soviet journalist has reported that New York City streets are better marked, that there is more faith in motorists' good sense and that the traffic police are more courteous, helpful and tactful than back home.

title: Don't Let the Boat People Drown
description: LEAD: Headlines like ''Vietnamese boat people pushed back to sea'' and ''Refugee boat rammed and sunk -many feared drowned'' recall the tragic flood of refugees out of Vietnam in the late 1970's. Unfortunately, the problem has once again become critical.

title: Senator D'Amato's Duty
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato, a supporter of Bob Dole for President, professes outrage at the rigging of the rules for New York's April 19 Presidential primary to favor George Bush. The reformist rhetoric is welcome; the question is whether the Republican Senator cares enough to press Republicans in Albany to reform the election law.

title: Bailout Voted By First City
description: Shareholders approved on Friday A. Robert Abboud's $1.5 billion plan to rescue First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc.

title: Purchasers Find Ongoing Sluggishness
description: For the second month in a row, the growth rate of the nation's economy slowed in February, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.

title: Novel Technique Shows Japanese Outpace Americans in Innovation
description: Starting more than a decade ago, Japan has been achieving a level of innovation greater than that of the United States, according to conclusions based on an experimental technique for analyzing the quality of patents.

title: OPEC Rate Up in Month
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have increased production, oil analysts said today.

title: Frustrated Dole Struggles to Find Weapon That Will Weaken Bush
description: After two grueling months on the road, a weary Bob Dole came to this resort town last night to spend Sunday morning soaking up some sun near his beachfront apartment. The dismal weather, which kept the candidate indoors, matched the mood within the Kansan's Presidential campaign.

title: New York Audit Finds Idle Cabs Flouting Rules
description: More than 20 percent of New York City's 11,787 medallion cabs sit idle in garages every day in violation of the Taxi and Limousine Commission's rules, City Comptroller's office estimated in an audit report released yesterday.

title: MDC ASSET INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it had no significant operations during 1986.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: An obituary last month of Bob O'Farrell, the former St. Louis Cardinal catcher, reported that he ended the 1926 World Series by throwing out Babe Ruth of the Yankees attempting to steal second base. What were the circumstances of such a bizarre Series-ending play? How many stolen bases did Ruth have in his career?

title: Merillat Assignment
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss has been assigned the consumer broadcast advertising by Merillat Industries, a subsidiary of Masco and a maker of cabinets for rooms of all persuasions. The budget was not disclosed and the print ads will continue to come from Creative House Advertising in Farmington Hill, Mich.

title: Offshore Quake Jolts Alaska; Hundreds Evacuated Briefly
description: A major earthquake struck Alaska today, shaking buildings and triggering a tsunami warning that led to the brief evacuation of hundreds of people. No damage or injuries were reported.

title: Nancy Dolgin Wed to Bruce D. Judson
description: Nancy Gayle Dolgin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Dolgin of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Bruce David Judson, a son of Betty Judson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Morris L. Judson. Rabbi Myron Fenster and Cantor Albert Albrecht officiated at the Water's Edge restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: In Victory, Bush Seems Beneficiary of a Legacy
description: South Carolina still loves President Reagan, and most of the state's Republicans see Vice President Bush as Mr. Reagan's rightful heir.

title: Review/Dance; Mixing Baby Dolls and Tarzan and Gore and Grins
description: Dancenoise roared into Performance Space 122 Saturday night with ''Half a Brain,'' and along with the din came clutter and fun.

title: Corrections
description: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Thursday described an aspect of Burt Sugarman's proposal for Media General incorrectly. He would try to gain three seats on Media General's board through a proxy solicitation, not through his $1.7 billion offer for the company.

title: Alamo Film Is Under Hispanic Siege
description: Remember the Alamo? It's under siege again, in a manner of speaking, with the legend that intertwines history and myth being attacked as racist and insulting to Hispanic-Americans.

title: From Flights of Fancy to Grim Reality: New Facets of Cezanne in His Drawings
description: The show is one of scratches and scribbles, of deft touches and muscular curls, of grocery lists and ink stains, of tentative tappings and of boldly finished works of art.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Consumer Borrowing... Jan. Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Producer Prices... Feb. Retail Sales... Feb.

title: BIO-VASCULAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $74,306.

title: At Age 34, Brett of the Royals Has a Few Points to Prove
description: The rib injury was bad enough; freakish, it happened in only the 10th game of the season. The knee injury, though, totally devastated him. He was playing in only his third game after returning from the rib injury and all he did was throw home. Not to mention that he tore the ligament on his 34th birthday. Happy birthday, George.

title: Letter From 30 Senators to Shultz on Mideast
description: Following is the text of a letter to Secretary of State George P. Shultz from 30 Senators on reaction in the Middle East to his proposal for peace talks. The letter was made public Saturday.

title: Kinney's 'Right Shoe' From HBM Creamer
description: As its first effort for Kinney Shoe, HBM/Creamer, Boston, has come up with a bouncy, competitive TV campaign that compares its leather footware with unnamed others to get across a quality and value story. The comparison is literally done on the hoof, with young, energetic women each wearing one of the ''others'' on their left foot, allowing for the new, rife-with-double-meaning theme line: ''Kinney. We only sell the right shoe.''

title: Official at Commerce Picked for No. 2 Job
description: President Reagan has announced his intention to nominate Donna Frame Tuttle as Deputy Secretary of Commerce, succeeding Clarence J. Brown in the department's second-highest post.

title: Cocoa Prices At 5-Year Low
description: World cocoa prices slipped to the lowest levels in more than five years Friday as the International Cocoa Organization reported little progress toward propping up prices in talks between producing and consuming nations.

title: When It Comes to Population, More Isn't Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Zoning Plan Means Towers on 5th Ave. and Danger to the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: School Track; Meet Continues Search for Sponsor
description: A high school track meet that has helped generate more than $3 million in college scholarships since its inception in 1984 is in danger of being canceled next year because of insufficient financing.

title: Murdoch's Post: Futile Battle or Missed Opportunity?
description: When Rupert Murdoch ends his 11 years as owner of The New York Post, the moment will mark, perhaps, the greatest failure in a career of stunning successes.

title: Devils Top Flyers And Move Into 4th
description: The Devils are back in the playoff race again after posting their second victory in 24 hours against a team with a superior record.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1988
description: International A3-9

title: SUPER TUESDAY COUNTRY: A POLITICAL ROAD MAP
description: Primaries and caucuses to be held tomorrow in 20 states and American Samoa will determine almost a third of the delegates to the Republican and Democratic conventions. Most of the voting will take place in Southern and border states whose politicians organized Super Tuesday as a way of increasing their influence. Voting rules vary from state to state. Registered independents can vote in either primary in Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and in the Republican primary in North Carolina. Asterisks denote states where any voter can vote in either party's primary. The outlook given for each state is based on local polls and politicians' judgments. In general, they expect Vice President Bush to win a majority of the delegates at stake Tuesday, but the Democratic outlook is uncertain. Democrats in American Samoa will caucus to elect six delegates to cast a total of three votes at the national convention in Atlanta. DEMOCRATS * 1,307 delegate votes at stake * 30% of total convention vote of 4,162 * Needed to nominate: 2,082 votes REPUBLICANS * 753 delegate votes at stake * 33% of total convention vote of 2,277 * Needed to nominate: 1,139 Presidential vote: Vote in 1984 ALABAMA primary* Delegates at stake: 56 for Democrats, 38 for Republicans

title: U.S. TO CUT BACK WORKER SURVEYS
description: Despite protests from Mayor Koch and other officials, the Federal Government plans to reduce the size of its monthly employment survey in New York City, thus sharply limiting its ability to track employment trends among black, Hispanic, teen-age and other workers.

title: AGS Founder Is Closer To Billion-Dollar Goal
description: The goal of Lawrence J. Schoenberg, chairman and chief executive of AGS Computers Inc., is to make his company a $1 billion enterprise by the beginning of the 1990's.

title: DERBY HOPEFULS ON THE MOVE
description: If this were last year or next year, Brian's Time and Forty Niner would be heading for a dramatic rematch in Florida in a few weeks. But because this is a year of turmoil in Florida racing, the two colts must find other ways to get ready for the Kentucky Derby on May 7. In fact, they are about to be evicted from their stables here.

title: Japan Increases Its Reserves
description: Japan became the world's biggest holder of currency reserves last year, gaining an equivalent of $32 billion, for a total of $81.1 billion, the International Monetary Fund said today.

title: HUNTER-MELNOR reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: Baryshnikov to Dance In U.S.-Soviet Festival
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov has announced that he will perform in ''Hommage a Plisetskaya,'' a tribute to the Soviet prima ballerina Maya Plisetskaya, on March 27 at the Wang Center in Boston. The gala, which also features dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, is part of Making Music Together, a three-week festival of new Russian music and dance that opens on Friday.

title: SAGE DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $141,000 and $217,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After tax benefits of $198,000 for the quarter and $336,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sharpton Says Informant Told Him of Cult Link in Brawley Case
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that a white man came to him and to lawyers for Tawana Brawley three weeks ago with information about a white racist cult, which the man said was responsible for an abduction and sexual assault on the 16-year-old black girl.

title: Washington Talk; PANEL ON AIDS TURNS VOICES OF CRITICISM INTO SONGS OF PRAISE
description: President Reagan's AIDS Commission, once derided by critics as incompetent, poorly managed and biased toward a right-wing agenda, has suddenly emerged as a bold, decisive champion of Government spending to help the victims of the disease.

title: Determined Grapplers
description: Misha Dichter and his wife, Cipa, are a world-renowned team of concert pianists. Their 14-year-old son, Sasha, who is a fine pianist himself, has enjoyed a different type of success. He is a member of the Dalton High School wrestling team.

title: WILEY, JOHN & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,105,000, or 26 cents a share, on the sale of land. Results for the year-ago quarter and 9-month were restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 87, Employers' Accounting for Pensions.

title: Barnyard Insult Hurled at Kings
description: A Los Angeles Kings hockey fan was arrested after a live chicken dressed in the team's colors was tossed onto the ice during a game at the Forum Saturday night.

title: Reed's First Lesson: How to Have Fun
description: The New Jersey Nets have won three consecutive games since Willis Reed became their coach. The major change, according to Otis Birdsong, is that the team is relaxed and enjoying the game again.

title: Metro Matters; Crack Dealers Rewriting Rules Among Criminals
description: The Queens crack wars that claimed the life of Police Officer Edward Byrne reflect an ominous development - one that, in part, represents the other side of law enforcement's success in disrupting the Mafia.

title: Robertson Stumps in Dallas
description: Pat Robertson, the former television minister, took his Presidential campaign into the churches of Dallas today, quoting Scripture to exhort the religious to go to the polls on Tuesday.

title: South Carolina Result Sets Stage For a Bush Showdown With Dole
description: With the campaigns of Pat Robertson and Representative Jack F. Kemp flattened by their showings in the South Carolina primary, Republicans looked today toward Tuesday's unprecedented number of primaries as a chance for Vice President Bush to take a wide lead.

title: New President Protested at School for Deaf
description: The trustees of Gallaudet University, the world's only university for the deaf, today rejected two deaf candidates to be the college's next president, triggering renewed protests by hundreds of students.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Canisius Player Had Heart Defect
description: Jeff Taggart, the Canisius College basketball player who died after suffering a seizure during a game Saturday night against Niagara, had an enlarged heart, according to preliminary medical reports.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Steiner Retires By Taking a Title: Roswitha Steiner of Austria, in the final event of her nine-year career, captured the last World Cup women's slalom race of the season yesterday and clinched the 1987-88 slalom title. The 24-year-old Steiner, who retires with eight World Cup race victories and two slalom crowns, outdueled Corinne Schmidhauser of Switzerland in a treacherous competition that saw most of the other favorites fall in the first run. Schmidhauser, who was initially awarded second place, was disqualified for missing a gate in the second heat. The disqualification gave Austria a sweep of the top three places. Steiner was only third-fastest in the second run with a time of 37.45 seconds. But with the second- and third-place finishers in the initial heat falling in the second run, she had a cushion to work with. Steiner finished with an aggregate time of 1 minute 16.42 seconds. Her teammates, Anita Wachter and Monika Maierhofer, finished second and third, respectively, in 1:17.05 and 17.32. Steiner's victory was worth 25 points, and vaulted her from fifth in the slalom standing to first with 87 points. The previous standing leader, Vreni Schneider of Switzerland, with 80 points, was sidelined for the season on Friday after suffering a knee injury in an aborted downhill race.(AP) Horse Racing King's Swan Rules: King's Swan took the lead from Matthews Keep in the stretch yesterday and went on to a five-length victory in the $110,000 Grey Lag Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. King's Swan, ridden by Jose Santos, carried the high weight of 130 pounds. Palace March was runner-up ahead of Matthews Keep and Mr. Classic. It was the fourth consecutive victory for King's Swan. He had won the Stymie, Assault and Aqueduct handicaps in his three previous starts. The 8-year-old gelding went a mile and one-eighth on the fast track in 1:50 3/5 to earn $66,000 for Alvin Akman. He paid $3.80 for $2 to win as the favorite. Track and Field West German Loses Medal: Carlo Thraenhardt of West Germany, holder of the world indoor high-jump record, was stripped yesterday of a bronze medal won Saturday at the European indoor track and field championships in Budapest, for leaving the arena without permission. The decision to throw out Thraenhardt's third-place finish followed a protest by the Rumanian team immediately after the high-jump competition Saturday at Budapest Sports Hall. Yesterday's ruling gave Sorin Matei of Rumania the bronze medal. Matei jumped 7 feet 8 1/2 inches, as Thraenhardt did, but took one jump more than the West German to clear that height. The event was won by Patrik Sjoeberg of Sweden, the defending titleholder, with 7-10. The Olympic champion Dietmar Mogenburg of West Germany took the silver. After exceeding the 30-second regulation during his first attempt at 7-6 1/2 Saturday, Thraenhardt, who holds the world indoor record of 7-11 1/4, packed his gear and stormed out of the arena without authority when the jump was disallowed by the judges. He explained that his concentration had been disturbed by a clash on the track during a men's 3,000-meter race, and also said he was impeded by one of the high-jump officials. Thraenhardt agreed to return to the competition after consultation with his coach. In competition yesterday, Linford Christie of Britain failed in his attempt to become the first man to win the 60-meter and 200-meter double at these championships, which date to 1970. Christie finished third behind Nikolay Razgonov of the Soviet Union and Nikolay Antonov of Bulgaria. (AP) Ski Jumping Nykaenen Sweeps: Matti Nykaenen of Finland completed a weekend sweep when he captured the 90-meter hill jump yesterday at the annual Lahti Ski Games in Finland. Nykaenen, who won three gold medals at the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, had finished first in the 70-meter hill event Saturday. Yesterday, Nykaenen jumped 111 meters and 103 meters, which gave him 208.4 points, compared with 205.5 points for Jan Boklov of Sweden. With his two victories over the weekend, Nykaenen amassed 50 World Cup points to increase his lead to more than 100 points over Pavel Ploc of Yugoslavia.(AP) Speed Skating Title for Flaim: Eric Flaim of the United States was declared the winner of the world men's speed-skating championships at Alma Ata in the Soviet Union yesterday after finishing fourth in a 10,000-meter race, which was won by the Dutch skater Leo Visser, the Tass press agency reported. Another American skater, Dave Silk, had won the 1,500-meter race earlier in the day, but fell during the final event and finished in 11th place. Silk was third in the overall standing, and Visser was second. (AP) A First and 3 Seconds for Jansen: Dan Jansen of the United States won one race and was runner-up in three others at Savalen, Norway, to top the World Cup point standing after a weekend speed-skating sprint meet. Jansen is in first in the 500-meter standing with 177 points. He is followed by the Olympic champion, Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany, who has 175, and Jan Ykema of the Netherlands with 152 points. Jansen also leads in the 1,000-meter standing with 102 points, 2 ahead of Ykema and 4 ahead of Nick Thometz of the United States. Jansen won the first 500-meter race on Saturday in 37.68 seconds. Ykema won the second 500-meter race yesterday in 37.86, followed by Jansen in 37.91, Thometz in 37.97 and Mey in 38.05. Thometz won yesterday's 1,000-meter race in 1 minute 17.49 seconds followed by Jansen in 1:17.74 and Ykema in 1:17.76. Ykema won the first 1,000-meter race on Saturday in 1:17.82, followed by Jansen in 1:17.94 and Thometz in third place in 1:18.36.(AP) Road Running Five-Mile Run to McKenzie: Mark McKenzie of Scotch Church, N.Y., who covered the course in 25 minutes 33 seconds, won the New York Road Runners Club's 27th annual Bob Preston Memorial five-mile run in Central Park yesterday. Katharine Young of the Atlanta Track Club won the women's title in 29:57. Auto Racing 3d Straight for Bonnett: Neil Bonnett took the lead 20 laps from the finish and charged to his third victory in as many weeks, taking yesterday's Goodwrench 500 Nascar stock-car race at the North Carolina Motor Speedway in Rockingham. Bonnett won a Winston Cup event two weeks ago in Richmond, Va., and followed that with a triumph last Sunday in an all-star race in Australia. Lake Speed was second yesterday, and Sterling Marlin barely held off Alan Kulwicki to take third. (AP) Marathon Record Set in Los Angeles: Martin Mondragon of Mexico broke away in the last mile to win the Los Angeles Marathon yesterday in a record-breaking time of 2 hours 10 minutes 19 seconds. Mondragon, competing as part of Mexico's Olympic trials, broke the course record of 2:12:59 set in 1986 by Ric Sayer of Ashland, Ore. Blanca Jaime of Mexico City won the women's competition in 2:36:10. (AP) Show Jumping Best Wins on Santos: Greg Best of Flemington, N.J., and Santos, an 11-year-old German-bred gelding, won the Cadillac Grand Prix of Palm Beach yesterday at the Palm Beach (Fla.) Polo Club. Twelve of 50 entries qualified for a timed jumpoff by riding without penalty over the 17-jump 579-yard first-round course. The United States Olympic veteran Michael Matz of Collegeville, Pa., took an early jumpoff lead on Chef, finishing the six-jump 293-yard jumpoff course in 34.091 seconds. Matz's lead held for eight rides until Louis Jacobs of East Aurora, N.Y., rode without a fault on Manuel in 33.426 seconds to take the lead. The final entry was Best, the 1987 champion, who rode Santos to a clean ride in 32.473 seconds. It was Best's sixth career grand-prix victory and his first on Santos.

description: A heavily armed man walked into a crowded church today and opened fire, killing one person and injuring four others before he was subdued by church members, the authorities said.

Politicians Are Fair Game
description: Did you hear the one about George Bush? If you were watching late-night television last month, you probably heard a lot more jokes aimed at the Vice President than any jokes aimed at other Presidential candidate.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Feb. 10 gave incorrect quantities for nutrients in some fruits and vegetables. Oranges contain about 30 micrograms of folacin; bananas, 5 milligrams of niacin and 19 micrograms of folacin. A 3 1/2-ounce portion of broccoli has 71 micrograms of folacin; a similar portion of turnip greens has 194 micrograms.

title: German Anti-Nuclear Rally
description: Nearly 10,000 people protested West Germany's nuclear power industry on Saturday in rallies in Frankfurt and at the site of a proposed nuclear waste disposal plant in Gorleben, a village in the state of Lower Saxony.

title: Boxer's Drug Test Is Called Positive
description: Urine samples taken from Bernardo Pinango of Venezuela after he won the World Boxing Association superbantamweight title Feb. 27 tested positive for cocaine, a boxing official has announced.

description: b-Includes tax loss carryforwards of $236,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said there are no per share earnings because the bank converted to stock ownership in July 1987.

title: London Expected to Proceed With Maneuvers in Falklands
description: Despite the protests of several Latin American nations, the British are expected to go forward Monday with military maneuvers in the Falkland Islands. The islands were the focus of a 74-day war in 1982 between Britain and Argentina.

title: Justice, at Last, on Grove City
description: From the day four years ago when a Supreme Court decision crippled enforcement of important antidiscrimination laws, a broad coalition of civil rights groups has worked to restore them. Now, by convincing margins, Congress has passed an act that would do just that. President Reagan, brimming with misinformation about the bill, says he will veto it. That would be foolish and wrong.

title: CRENSHAW POSTS 66 FOR ONE-SHOT VICTORY
description: Ben Crenshaw, whose superb iron shots today matched his always deadly putting, hit an excellent 8-iron of 150 yards just 18 feet short of the final hole. He rolled in the birdie putt to win the $1 million Doral Ryder Open by a single shot over Mark McCumber and Chip Beck.

title: U.S. PRESSING KOREANS ON TRADE
description: South Korea is suddenly on the trade firing line, with Washington aiming at Seoul the kind of criticism usually reserved for Tokyo.

title: Couple Hunts a Rare Breed: American Giraffe
description: Because she waged a nine-year battle to block the construction of a nuclear power plant in Oklahoma, Carrie Barefoot Dickerson recently became a Giraffe. So did Jerilyn Brusseau, who runs a family cafe and bakery north of Seattle, for starting an exchange program between Soviet and American chefs, farmers and ''people who feel passionate about food.''

title: Wheels Under the Influence
description: A man who rode his motorized wheelchair into the path of a police car has been charged with driving under the influence of alcohol. James L. (Ironside) High, 29 years old, of Gallatin, was arrested Friday, said the assistant police chief, Wayne Brooks. He was not struck.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes a tax benefit of $600,000. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3 percent stock dividend distributed Jan. 4.

title: UNSIGHTLY CAMPAIGN
description: Nobody can accuse Syracuse fans of being sore losers, but a lot of them have been in an ugly mood since they discovered that their football team, previously invincible in 1987, wasn't good enough to beat Auburn in the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Day.

title: Catching Up

McIntosh's Prospect Heights team overcame a 4-point halftime deficit to defeat Julia Richman, 102-87, giving it a 19-3 record and a berth in Saturday's citywide Final Four.

title: Financial Times Seeks Its Own Pace
description: The Financial Times, Britain's salmon-pink business daily, has just marked its centenary with a $100,000 banquet, testimonials from a bevy of knights and peers, and a door-stopper of an official history that runs 543 pages. Indeed, there has been much to celebrate at a paper that began as a few-page handout and whose first editor was described as having ''no notion of writing and poorly educated.''

title: Lisa H. Clayman Marries Richard Lebowitz on L.I.

description: Seven months after Congress approved a $10.8 billion rescue of the nation's savings and loan insurance system, the industry, regulators and financial experts are formulating contingency plans for a second bailout, which many predict will come out of taxpayer dollars.

description: ''The United States is Israel's greatest and most loyal friend.

description: The General Electric Company offered yesterday to buy the Roper Corporation for $45 a share, or about $405 million, even though Roper had announced last week that it had agreed to support a bid of $37.50 a share, or $350 million, by the Whirlpool Corporation.

description: Take a rape, two varieties of incest and a case of adultery, one parricide and four other murders, a dead baby, a homosexual affair, a couple of what may be epileptic seizures and a con game, mix with five uninterestingly peculiar people and, as ''Stealing Heaven'' demonstrates, you have one excruciating evening.

title: Review/Recital; From Fortepiano to Piano
description: Steven Lubin's fortepiano sounded so delicate in the acoustically dry auditorium of the 92d Street Y Saturday evening that it might seem preposterous to suggest that he was playing it too loudly, but that was occasionally the case. In three works of Mozart -the Sonata in F (K. 332), the Adagio in B (K. 540) and the familiar variations on ''Ah, vous dirais-je, maman,'' - he played with incisiveness and character, relishing the advantages of the light Viennese keyboard tone and action that Mozart knew and bringing out the vigor that is sometimes missed when this music is adapted to a powerful modern grand.

description: Neoax Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the IU International Corporation for about $670 million.

The book has been chosen as a summer split main selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

While rock, funk and dance music support the record business -and have made American music the world's music - the Grammys pretend that refined, innocuous pop is the jewel in the crown.

Klein, a partner in the certified public accounting firm of Reffsin, Delle Fave & Company in Jericho, L.I., were married yesterday at their home in Jericho. Rabbi Philip Bentley officiated. The bride, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Rosoff of Manhasset Hills, L.I., graduated summa cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and received a medical degree from Harvard University. Her father is a psychiatrist.

title: 2 Paths To Yank Jobs
description: When their work was done today, Richard Dotson and Scott Nielsen returned to the visitors' clubhouse at Miami Stadium, toweled themselves off and began to pack their bags. Their day had been confined to a few innings of pitching in an afternoon exhibition against the Baltimore Orioles, and now they sat by themselves, seeming lost in their private moments.

title: Don't Let N.I.H. Go The Way of A.T.&T.
description: To the Editor:

title: Madagascar Frees 245
description: A special court in Madagascar has ordered the release of 245 people held in detention since 1985 in connection with riots by kung-fu enthusiasts the previous year. Radio Madagascar said the court issued sentences that ranged up to two years in jail, but because the prisoners had been in detention longer than that, the effect was to free them. The kung-fu movement, which practices martial arts, was banned after enthusiasts and jobless youths rioted in 1984. Troops were later used to round up kung-fu enthusiasts in an effort to stem a crime wave.

title: STRIKE ANNOUNCED BY WRITERS FOR TV
description: Movie and television scriptwriters called a strike for Monday after rejecting what producers called a final contract offer, union officials said today.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $430,649 from an accounting change for both the quarter and year.

title: JACK HENRY & ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 2 American Senators Dispute Criticism of Shamir
description: United States Senators expressed disagreement today with a letter signed by 30 of their colleagues criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, suggesting he was obstructing peace efforts.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: GOLF;
Varied Routes To Mastering A Big Drive
description: LEAD: EVERY golfer's idol is James Braid, the turn-of-the-century Scotsman who went to bed one evening a short hitter and woke up the next day a long hitter. No one ever learned his secret, but all golfers live in the hope of having such a midsummer night's dream.

title: New Zealanders Reveal Their Hull
description: The hull of New Zealand, the America's Cup challenger, was unveiled today, measuring 27 meters, or about 88 1/2 feet. Wings protrude from each side of the hull, giving the boat an extreme beam of 7.9 meters.

title: Washington Talk: Urban Planning and Preservation; Tempers Are Rising Over Capital's Skyline
description: One of this city's most jealously guarded treasures is its low-lying skyline, pierced by the 555-foot obelisk of the Washington Monument and the 300-foot dome of the Capitol.

title: PLAYERS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $10,700 from reversal of a tax credit.

title: SADDLING UP THE SYNTHETIC WAY
description: A well-worn leather English saddle that is supple after years of horseback riding is treasured among equestrians. Breaking in the saddle, as well as soaping and oiling it, are as much a part of riding as learning to canter.

title: Fliers Sweat and Fret For Triple-Mileage Deal
description: Joe Dulle, the president of a group of retail stores in Texas whose headquarters is in Fort Worth, often drives to visit his store in San Antonio. If he flies, he normally takes a commuter airline that goes out of a nearby airport.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about the search for a sponsor for a scholastic track meet misidentified the president of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress. He is Tracy Sundlun.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on the Washington Talk page last Wednesday described early sound recordings of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, made with a concealed device in the Oval Office in 1940.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: MCA Sets Defense To Protect Shares
description: MCA Inc., the large entertainment company, has agreed to sell its 48 percent stake in the Cineplex Odeon Corporation back to the Toronto-based theater chain, should MCA become the object of a hostile takeover attempt, to keep its shares out of unfriendly hands. The announcement comes after Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, received Federal antitrust clearance to purchase up to 25 percent of MCA's outstanding shares.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $8,495,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $31,362,000 for the quarter and $28,563,000 for the year, and the year also includes a $33.9 million after-tax loss related to the sale of its container leasing business. The company said its 1987 earnings benefited from a significant reduction in interest expense, from $35 million in 1986 to $26 million in 1987, and continued reduction in administrative cost levels.

title: The Sun Nears a Period of Intense Activity
description: A STEEP and surprisingly early increase in magnetic disturbances on the Sun in the last few months may herald a cycle of exceptionally intense solar radiation, and astronomers have warned that satellites in low orbits could face premature destruction as a result.

title: 200 Bumped by Eastern Air; Irate Man Is Held in Assault
description: A crowd of 200 Eastern Airlines passengers who were bumped from New York-bound flights Sunday angrily confronted ticket agents, and one man was arrested for assaulting police officers, the authorities said.

title: Soviet Verification Proposal
description: Soviet negotiators presented draft proposals at the Geneva arms talks today on how to verify a new treaty reducing long-range arms, Administration officials said. American officials assailed the Soviet Union last week for failing to present such proposals. American officials said the Soviet draft proposals did not appear to contain any surprising new suggestions. But they said the presentation of the proposals was an important procedural step.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax investment gain of $1.9 million and $4.9 million for the latest and prior years, respectively. The company said earnings are restated to reflect a change in accounting methods.

title: Chess: A Neat Tactical Twist Wins For Benjamin in Saint John
description: Joel Benjamin of Brooklyn surpassed 74 entrants to win the first prize, $10,000 (Canadian), in the International Open Tournament 1 in Saint John, New Brunswick. The 23-year-old grandmaster won five games and drew four to achieve his winning 7-2 score in the nine-round Swiss-system event.

title: Soviet Offers Measures To End Iran-Iraq War
description: The Soviet delegate proposed several Security Council measures today to end the Iran-Iraq war, including the appointment of a special representative to negotiate with both sides and a resolution calling for an end to missile attacks on civilians.

title: James Peter Davis, Retired Archbishop, 83
description: James Peter Davis, Archbishop of Santa Fe from 1964 to 1974, died Friday. He was 83 years old.

title: Salerno Prosecutors End Summation
description: Two prosecutors completed a summation yesterday that accused Anthony (Fat Tony) Salerno and 10 other men of carrying out a wide range of racketeering activities of the Genovese crime family.

title: Soviet TV to Carry Met 'Ariadne,' Live
description: The Metropolitan Opera's matinee performance on Saturday of Richard Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' will be telecast live to the Soviet Union, the company announced yesterday.

title: Bond Prices Dip in Light Trading
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly in light trading yesterday as speculators and investors waited for more information about the economy.

title: 6 Bids Cited For Unit of Federated
description: Federated Department Stores has received six bids for its Ralphs Supermarkets division, its only food operation, the Campeau Corporation said in an amended offering statement yesterday.

title: Essay Attacks Orders To Protect the Unborn
description: Physicians concerned for the unborn should not turn to the courts to force pregnant women to undergo Caesarean sections, drug abuse treatment or other procedures, two medical researchers argue.

title: Nancy Marie Ferguson, Professor of Drama, 89
description: Nancy Marie Ferguson, a longtime professor of speech and drama at Hunter College, died of uterine cancer on March 1 at New York Hospital. She was 89 years old.

title: Montgomery Ward Is Sold
description: A group led by Montgomery Ward's management agreed to buy the revitalized retailer from Mobil in a deal valued at $3.8 billion. Page D1.

title: WORLDS OF WONDER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $63,661,000 and $93,411,000 for product price reductions and excess materials for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income

title: Superconductors: Scientists Hail Latest Materials
description: WITH the discovery of a yet another kind of superconductor, a distant cousin of the materials found in the breakthroughs of the last year, research on superconductivity has suddenly passed a new milestone.

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Jurors Picked in Biaggi's Wedtech Trial
description: Jury selection began yesterday in the Federal trial of Representative Mario Biaggi, his son and five others who are charged with turning the Wedtech Corporation into a center of criminal racketeering that paid millions of dollars in bribes to win military contracts.

title: SCRIPPS HOWARD BROADCASTNG reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net charges of $17.3 million for the writedown of intangible assets, $3.6 million for settlement payments in certain litigation and net gains totaling $20.7 million from the sale of investments. c-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $10 million. d-Net income

title: Warner and Lorimar in 'Early' Talks
description: Warner Communications Inc. and the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation said yesterday that they had begun ''very, very early'' merger discussions over the weekend.

title: 4 Girls Hurt in Random Attacks
description: Four girls ranging in age from 12 to 17 years old have been injured, one critically, in separate random attacks in the South Bronx by a man wielding a blunt instrument, the police said yesterday.

title: Brazil Finance Chief Shakes Up Economic Team
description: Brazil's new finance minister, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, announced today a shake-up in his top economic team, including a new chief negotiator for this country's foreign debt.

title: Robert E. Link, Educator, 72
description: Robert E. Link, who taught at Brooklyn College for 39 years, died of cancer of the kidney and liver yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Long Beach, L.I.

title: La Salle Captures M.A.A.C. Tourney
description: It came as no surprise that La Salle, a team that did not lose in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference all season, defeated Fordham, 79-70, tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena for the conference tournament championship.

title: Fight for Roper Reflects Shift in Appliance Field
description: The takeover contest between two archrivals, General Electric and Whirlpool, for the Roper Corporation, a maker of kitchen ranges and riding lawn mowers, reflects the changes in strategy and the consolidation under way in the maturing home-appliance business, analysts said today.

title: By Design; Evolution of Shoulder Pads
description: Shoulder pads have been squaring off shoulders and boosting fashions for at least 10 years. The fact that the pads, especially the outsize ones, tend to slip and slide around has not diminished their popularity. Women have just learned to tug and shove them back into place.

title: Families of 4 Astronauts Received $7.7 Million in Shuttle Settlement
description: The families of four space shuttle astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster received a total of $7.7 million worth of long-term tax-free annuities from the Federal Government and the rocket manufacturer blamed for the accident, documents released today by the Justice Department show.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss of $4,700,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Low-Cost Amiga
description: THE Amiga 500, as mentioned here last week, is an exciting machine, a home computer with capabilities in graphics and sound that only a few years ago would have cost thousands of dollars more, and in many cases still do. It comes with 512,000 characters of internal memory, expandable to a million, and a built-in 880,000-character disk drive.

title: Blues Acquire Hull
description: The St. Louis Blues, approaching the Stanley Cup playoffs with a fear that they lacked scoring power, traded two of their top defensive players yesterday to acquire Brett Hull, a rookie scoring ace from the Calgary Flames. The Blues gave up Rob Ramage, a defenseman who has been named an All-Star four times, and Rick Wamsley, a goaltender with a 3.40 goals-against average, to obtain Hull and Steve Bozek, a left wing. Brett Hull, the 23-year-old son of Bobby Hull, has 26 goals and 24 assists, the third best scoring total among rookies this season, in 52 games at right wing for Calgary.

title: Coniston Rejection Urged by Gillette
description: The Gillette Company urged its shareholders to reject an attempt by Coniston Partners to oust four company directors at its annual meeting in April. Colman M. Mockler Jr., Gillette's chairman and chief executive, said that Coniston intended to sell or dismantle Gillette if it succeeded in a hostile takeover.

title: Increase in Oil Use Seen
description: Oil consumption in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries is expected to grow by 1 percent, or about 300,000 barrels a day, over 1987 levels, the International Energy Agency said. In its latest monthly report, the agency projected average world consumption, excluding the centrally planned economies, at between 49 and 49.5 million barrels a day in 1988, with non-O.E.C.D. consumption at about 13.2 million.

title: Wohl's Accusation Is Denied by Nets
description: The Nets today vehemently denied recent comments by Dave Wohl, the team's former head coach, that the team's management knew of Orlando Woolridge's use of drugs as early as last fall.

title: Paine Webber Group Names New President
description: Donald E. Nickelson was named president of Paine Webber Group Inc. yesterday, succeeding Donald B. Marron, who remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Hough Called for 9 Balks
description: Charlie Hough, the Texas Rangers' knuckleballer, committed nine balks in four innings today as umpires set out to enforce a full set position this season.

title: Our Towns; Getting in Shape For Russian Test In Body Building
description: Last year George Allen, chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness, said American children were in terrible shape and most would not pass a fitness test given in Russian schools. ''I took it personally - I teach phys ed,'' said Lenny Saunders of Valley View Elementary School. ''I don't know where all these people get off saying Americans are fat and weak. My kids take it personal, too.''

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes results of companies acquired during the latest third quarter that have been accounted for on a pooling of interest basis; previously reported results for the 6 months ended Oct. 31, 1987, have accordingly been restated.

title: Heiress Wins Church Campus
description: An heiress who won a $6.6 million judgment against her church last year won the 69-acre Bible Speaks campus in Lenox today with a $3.23 million bid in an auction supervised by the Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: Far From View, a Race On Track to Leadership
description: A political race is shaping up in the House of Representatives that will test the mettle of one of its most visible Democrats and the stomach of the rank and file for the grueling campaigns that are becoming the norm for leadership positions. It is the contest for chairmanship of the House Democratic Caucus.

title: Robertson's Libel Case Ends
description: A Federal judge today dismissed Pat Robertson's $35 million libel suit against a former Congressman after the former religious broadcaster agreed to pay court fees.

title: A Crystal Ball
description: The conductor Andre Kostelanetz was on the mark 50 years ago when he made a prediction on what would remain two of the most enduring American musical compositions.

title: Dow, in a Lackluster Session, Loses 1.49
description: Demand for stocks involved in acquisitions provided a little spurt yesterday to a mostly lackluster market. With the London and Tokyo markets weaker, stocks were somewhat on the defensive when the New York market opened and remained under light pressure during the session.

title: Wells Fargo Defendant Is Released on Bail
description: The 31-month, pre-trial detention of a defendant in the Wells Fargo robbery case ended today after a judge freed him on $1 million bail.

title: Sex Researchers Defend AIDS Book Against Wide Criticism
description: Defending themselves against a chorus of criticism about their methods and conclusions, the authors of a new book on AIDS charged yesterday that Government health officials had understated the threat posed by AIDS to the general population to avoid causing alarm.

title: Divine, Transvestite Film Actor, Found Dead in Hollywood at 42
description: Divine, the 300-pound transvestite star of ''Pink Flamingos,'' ''Hairspray'' and other John Waters films, was found dead yesterday morning in his room at the Regency Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. He was 42 years old.

title: Fort Smith Journal; As Things Look Up, the People Look Homeward
description: To the rest of the country, the people of western Arkansas and their cousins just across the Arkansas River in Oklahoma may still seem to be the folk of John Steinbeck stories and Woody Guthrie songs, the so-called Arkies and Okies who fled as dust bowl refugees to the fields and factories of California five decades ago.

title: Turkish Avalanche Kills 19
description: An avalanche hit a small village near the Iranian border, killing 19 people and injuring 8 others, the Anatolia news agency said today.

title: Discarded Hearts May Yield Clues to Disease
description: FROM hearts discarded after transplant operations, a Bronx scientist hopes to find clues to explain why many people succumb to heart disease and others do not.

title: Expert Disputes Theory of Levin's Death
description: A forensic expert testified yesterday that Jennifer Levin was killed when her neck was compressed by a chokehold applied from behind, not by a frontal strangulation, The witness, testifying for the defense in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., also said Miss Levin did not appear to have been beaten before her death.

title: Methane Up Sharply; Ozone Impact Studied
description: A sharp increase in methane gas in the atmosphere since 1978 will probably make the earth warmer and may worsen seasonal losses of protective ozone over Antarctica, scientists say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said it had received a $60 million order for a Boeing 767-200 jet from Britannia Airways Ltd.

title: A Republican Voice
description: Robert H. Michel gets a lot of voice practice as the House minority leader, but beyond that he has a reputation as an excellent singer.

title: 113 Officers To Fight Drugs At Queens Site
description: A stepped-up drug-enforcement program, including the addition of more than 100 police officers, will begin in a square-mile area of South Jamaica, Queens, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: U.S. COURT EXTENDS PANAMA BANK CURB
description: The financial battle against the Panamanian regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega continued in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday as a judge extended a restraining order preventing two banks from transferring money to the national bank of Panama.

title: A Canterbury Tale: Cleaning Up Chaucer for a New Tourist Shrine
description: When April with its sweet lucre beckons the enterprising Englishman to woo anew the credit-carded hordes of modern pilgrims, it will be Chaucer himself whom the newest shrine extols, with his ''Canterbury Tales'' related in audio-visual extracts.
