title: HARNISCHFEGER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,050,000 and $2,960,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: President 'Welcomes' Senators' Israel Note
description: The White House spoke favorably today of the letter sent by 30 senators criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel for opposing the trading of territory for peace.

title: Emil A. Schmidlin, 81, New Jersey Architect
description: Emil A. Schmidlin, an architect, died of heart failure Friday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: British Amend Account of Killing of 3 in Gibraltar
description: Correcting initial reports on the police killing of three unarmed Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar, the British Government announced today that no terrorist bomb had been found at the scene.

title: Candidates Attack on Eve of Biggest Day
description: In what amounts to the first-ever regional primary, voters across the South on Tuesday could give Vice President Bush a long lead in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination and narrow the field in the Democratic contest.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Giants acquired Robert Abraham, a linebacker, on waivers from the Houston Oilers yesterday. Abraham spent last season on injured reserve with hamstring and groin injuries. A third-round draft choice of the Oilers in 1982 out of North Carolina State, Abraham had been a key part of the Houston defense in each of the four previous seasons. . . . Mike Sherrard, the Dallas Cowboys' wide receiver who missed the 1987 season with a broken right leg, refractured the leg while running on the beach in the Los Angeles area. He is expected to miss the Cowboys' four preseason games. . . . Roger Craig, the San Francisco Giants' manager, will undergo arthroscopic surgery to repair a knee injury aggravated while demonstrating a pick-off move at the club's camp in Scottsdale, Ariz. He is expected to miss two days of camp. . . Gary Garner, the Drake basketball coach, was dismissed yesterday, two days after his team ended the season with its sixth consecutive loss and a 14-14 record. . . . Danny Manning of Kansas and Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, the nation's leading scorer, head the United States Basketball Writers Association's all-America team. Gary Grant of Michigan, J. R. Reid of North Carolina and Sean Elliott of Arizona were also selected.

title: Use Tainted Cash To Pay Lawyers?
description: LEAD: No constitutional provision permits lawyers to share in the ill-gotten gains of the criminal defendants they represent. That simple, straight forward proposition should be self-evident.

title: Review/Dance; From Gambia, Steps Set to Lilting Music
description: The National Cultural Theater and Dance Company of Gambia, which appeared on Friday at Town Hall, is a likable group whose performing of traditional music and dance has the air of being both contemporary and of another time. It performed at less than full strength in terms of the number of company members. The Fulani acrobatic dancers, whose men move in a way that approximates our own break-dancing, were among those who were unable to join the national tour. That was a pity, but the program's small scale provided a charming intimacy that might otherwise have been lost.

title: NATO's Smiling Summiteers
description: NATO leaders left Brussels happy last week, and not surprisingly. They heartily endorsed the Euromissile treaty, reaffirmed the U.S. commitment and welcomed efforts at European defense cooperation. They also avoided details on all the hard questions: conventional arms talks, modernization of battlefield nuclear missiles, strategy and burden-sharing. But as soon as the next Soviet-American summit session passes in the spring, the leaders would do well to get down to these questions.

title: Pakistani Arms Dealers Hail God and the AK-47
description: Haji Baz Gul, the owner of Arms Store No. 1 in Darra Adam Khel, an hour's drive south of here, said he was not worried about peace breaking out in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Umpire Awaiting Her Call From Majors
description: The umpire at first base this afternoon in the Mets' 5-3 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers was Pam Postema, who said that she didn't particularly want to make history as much as she wanted to make the umpiring staff in the National League.

title: Market Place; Settlement Hopes Buoying Polaroid
description: RUMORS of a larger-than-expected lawsuit settlement have sent shares of Polaroid soaring in the last week. Yesterday, the stock, one of the most active on the New York Stock Exchange, closed at $36, up $2.25, on a volume of more than 2.2 million shares. Last week, the Activity in the stock has been fueled by rumors that John W. Kluge, chairman of Metromedia, was a heavy buyer in recent days. Mr. Kluge, who is traveling, was unavailable for comment. The rumors that he was buying even touched off speculation of a possible takeover attempt, although there was nothing to indicate such a move was in the offing.

title: Democrats in a Quandary
description: The 2,000 Democrats who recently crowded into a state fairgrounds building for North Carolina's Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner seemed mostly concerned with getting fed. It wasn't easy since all of them had to stand in one interminable line to be served a dubious piece of fried chicken.

title: Computers From Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation will introduce several large multiprocessor computers Tuesday for the mainframe market now dominated by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: The Preachers and the Bully Pulpit
description: Super Tuesday, here at last, turns out to be both more and less than its inventors intended. Geographically, it's more than a Southern regional primary. It's a far-flung event with caucuses and elections from Hawaii to Massachusetts. Politically, it may be a bust for the Democrats. Instead of shoring up support among Southern whites, it may turn many into crossover voters, more interested in the race on the Republican side.

title: UNITED BRANDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,906,000 from the exchange of debt. c-Includes a pretax gain of about $15 million from the termination of a pension plan.

title: Movie and TV Writers, Rejecting 'Final' Offer, Take to Picket Lines
description: More than 2,000 writers clogged the sidewalks in front of the 20th Century-Fox studios this morning on the first day of a strike against movie and television producers by the Writers Guild of America.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Thomas International Enterprises, Pensacola, Fla., to Bruce Novograd Advertising for a group of skin care products.

title: Pennsylvania Electric Executive Retires After Atom Plant Closing
description: LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company said yesterday that its chairman would retire next month, just over a year after Federal regulators closed one of its nuclear power plants because operators had been found sleeping on the job.

title: Customers Groan as Postal Service Is Cut
description: In the wake of a tightening of postal services, residents and businesses throughout the New York metropolitan region are struggling to adapt to fewer window hours in post office branches and the end of all Sunday mail collection and sorting.

title: Italian Seeks New Support Special to The New York Times
description: Carlo deBenedetti disclosed today that two of Europe's biggest industrial enterprises, N.V. Philips of the Netherlands and Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, were negotiating to join the Italian entrepreneur in his battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique.

title: Albany Leader Opposes Cuomo On Scholarships
description: The State Senate majority leader today condemned Governor Cuomo's proposal for Liberty Scholarships for college-bound students from poor families but left open the possibility that some kind of new scholarship program might be approved if Mr. Cuomo agreed to sweeten existing tuition assistance grants.

title: Exotic G.O.P. Calculus
description: In the Republican contest, a competing calculus of expectations has developed among the candidates' camps. Bush campaign officials say that winning 400 delegates would give the Vice President an insurmountable lead; this really means they expect to get more. Mr. Bush's foes say the Vice President must get 500 delegates to score a knockout, hoping they can score against inflated expectations.

title: College for Deaf Is Shut by Protest Over President
description: Gallaudet University, the nation's only college exclusively for the deaf, was shut down today and classes were suspended indefinitely after hundreds of students, faculty members and alumni blocked entrances to the campus to protest the selection of a president who is not hearing impaired.

title: New Light On Old Idea At Kennedy
description: Kennedy International Airport is installing the latest technology to help guide planes on the ground - traffic lights.

title: Budd to Run
description: Some African nations have threatened to boycott the world cross-country championships if Zola Budd, the South African athlete who became a British subject in 1983, is permitted to run. But two officials of international track said yesterday that Budd has been cleared to compete for Britain in the championships on March 26 in Auckland, New Zealand. Primo Nebiolo, the president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, and John Holt, the group's general secretary, said in London that no pressure was applied to British officials to withdraw Budd from the meet. ''We would never dream of putting any pressure on a member country to withdraw an eligible athlete,'' Holt said. Nebiolo said that the I.A.A.F. rules permit Budd to run and that ''the New Zealand authorities must let her enter the country.''

title: The U.S. Poet Laureate In the Role of Performer
description: The poet laureate of the United States does not have a lot of mandatory duties to perform, but one that seems to be evolving is reading his works in front of official Washington and just plain fans of poetry and literature. It is a job he started out enduring and has come to enjoy.

title: Nets' Streak Ends After 3 Victories
description: Thurl Bailey and Karl Malone scored 21 points each and Bobby Hansen added 20 as the Utah Jazz won their fifth straight game, defeating the Nets by 105-81 tonight.

title: Morong Journal; They Train to Become as American as They Look
description: Chieu Hang Cuc Nguyen, whose American father left her behind in Vietnam when she was 3 years old, knows she will do well in the United States because, she said, she is bold and outspoken like an American, even though she still does not speak English.

title: Former Doctor Is Sentenced
description: The man whose attempted murder conviction led to the book and television movie ''Deadly Intentions'' was sentenced to 15 years in prison today on Federal marijuana and weapons charges.

title: Dallas Selling Water Bonds
description: The City of Dallas is offering about $230 million of water and sewer refunding bonds through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Yields range from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1989 to 7 percent in 1998 and 7.50 percent in 2003 and 2004.

title: Judge Lets 'Baby Bells' Offer Some Information Services
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the regional Bell telephone companies could offer such information services as electronic mail and voice messaging. But he continued his restriction against the seven companies providing the content for the information services and offering electronic Yellow Pages.

title: Business and Health; Early Retirement: A Surprising Cost
description: COST-CONSCIOUS corporations that seek to induce employees to take early retirement by offering them continued health-care benefits as part of a compensation package are discovering that the health care can become unexpectedly expensive over time.

title: Outpatient Strategy Fails to Cut Health Costs
description: A vigorous effort by health insurers and employers to hold down medical bills by encouraging people to seek outpatient treatment has backfired in several ways.

title: ROBINS, A H co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an accrual of $1.75 billion for Dalkon Shield claims and related expenses, and a charge of $44.2 million for Chapter 11 bankruptcy costs, litigation expense and settlements. c-Net income The company said the $1.75 billion accrual is the difference between the $2.3 billion provided for claimants in the company's fifth amended reorganization plan and the balance of $548 million that remains from a Dalkon Shield reserve established by the company in 1984.

title: An Average Reader Finishes This Article In About 2 1/2 Minutes
description: How much time does an average taxpayer spend filling out Form 1040? The Internal Revenue Service knows, but it does not want to remind the public right on the form.

title: Girl Mimicking Movie Scene Is Struck and Killed by Train
description: A 15-year-old girl who was acting out a scene from the movie ''Stand By Me'' was struck and killed when she misjudged the speed of an oncoming freight train and stepped into its path, the authorities said today.

title: A Whodunit Goes Askew
description: THIS was not just the customary denial, written on official stationery by the team publicist. The management of the New Jersey Nets went to more elaborate measures yesterday -holding a news conference at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena - to adamantly deny that it covered up or ignored Orlando Woolridge's drug problem. Instead of providing answers, however, it only raised more questions.

title: Politics and Corruption: Schools Under Siege in Jersey City
description: To state education officials, the school system in this bastion of bare-knuckle politics and cronyism is one of the worst in New Jersey.

title: Iran-Contra Inquiry
description: The independent counsel investigating the Iran-contra affair, Lawrence E. Walsh, is believed to be preparing for imminent indictments. Yesterday, he summoned the widow of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, before the grand jury.

title: A Job for Susan B.
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvador Ruling Party To Dismiss Candidates
description: Leading officials of the ruling Christian Democratic Party in El Salvador said today that a party member suspected of misuse of American funds would be dropped as a candidate from this month's election.

title: Jackson Gets 33 To Spur Knicks
description: Many in the capacity crowd of 19,591 were drawn to Madison Square Garden last night by Michael Jordan, but the fans walked away talking about Mark Jackson.

title: For Israeli Arabs, a Question of Divided Loyalties
description: Lubna Daroushe came home from class one day, her father said, and told him she was not proud of him anymore.

title: Advertising; Gannett Is Acquiring Subways Advertising
description: The Gannett Company is about to become the owner of New York Subways Advertising, which will be run by its Gannett Outdoor division. The division, operating in 11 states and Canada, is already North America's largest outdoor company.

title: Williams Court Date Off
description: Jayson Williams, St. John's sophomore center, will not be required to appear in Providence District Court today for arraignment on assault charges stemming from an incident Saturday night during the Redmen's game with Providence.

title: Heinz Profits Increase 22%
description: The giant food maker H. J. Heinz Company today reported a 22 percent increase in third-quarter earnings, attributing the improvement to a higher sales volume, acquisitions and the beneficial effects of a cheaper dollar.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an accounting change gain of $487,000. The company said the year-earlier fourth quarter net amounted to $1,102,000, or 18 cents a share, pro forma, assuming retroactive application of a new method of accounting for the cost of merchandise inventory. The company also said the pro forma net assuming the new method of accounting for the cost of merchandise inventory, amounted to $4,150,000, or 69 cents a share, compared with $2,089,000, or 35 cents a share.

title: Moog a Bruin
description: Andy Moog, the goalie who was a holdout with the Edmonton Oilers, has been acquired by the Boston Bruins in exchange for Geoff Courtnall, a left wing, Bill Ranford, a goalie, and future considerations. Harry Sinden, general manager of the Bruins, said that Moog signed a multiyear contract and was expected to be in uniform tonight in Detroit for the game against the Red Wings. Moog, 28, played five full seasons and parts of two others with the Oilers. He was a member of this year's Canadian Olympic team.

title: Captive Condor Lays a Fertile Egg
description: The first California condor egg produced by a captive breeding pair is fertile, and a chick should emerge in less than two months, San Diego Wild Animal Park officials said today.

title: Gooden's Start Is Uneven One
description: Dwight Gooden pitched three fairly ragged innings in his first start of the exhibition season today, giving up eight hits and five runs to the Los Angeles Dodgers. But he said not to worry, ''it's too early, it's still too early.''

title: Shearson Hires Leading Broker
description: In the latest outbreak of hostilities between Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., Shearson said yesterday that it had snared Dean Witter's top producing broker, Andrew Cooper 3d.

title: VESTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $10,528,000 and $25,290,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and includes a tax credit of $180,000 and $9,683,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A Queens Boy, 7, Is Run Over And Killed by His School Bus
description: A 7-year-old boy was fatally injured yesterday when he fell beneath the rear wheels of a school bus that had just dropped him off near his home in Queens, the police said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Five Assists for Gretzky: Wayne Gretzky assisted on five consecutive goals, two by Craig Simpson, as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Jets, 6-0, last night at Winnipeg. Grant Fuhr, the Oiler goaltender, made 21 saves for his fourth shutout of the season and had an assist. Gretzky started weaving his magic in the second period at the Oilers struck for four goals, including Simpson's 48th and 49th of the season. Esa Tikkanen, Craig MacTavish, Mark Messier and Jari Kurri, on a power play, also beat the Jets' goalie, Daniel Berthiaume. The Jets had a three-game winning streak snapped. They are in third place in the Smythe Division with 71 points, behind the Flames (85) and Oilers (84).(AP) Penguins 5, Flames 4: The road victory by Pittsburgh moved the Penguins into a fourth-place tie with the Devils and 1 point ahead of the Rangers in the battle for the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division. Dan Quinn scored three goals and Mario Lemieux one as Pittsburgh opened a 4-0 lead.(AP) SKIING West German Is First: Christine Meier of West Germay overtook Mateja Svet of Yugoslavia and captured her first World Cup victory yesterday in a women's giant slalom in Aspen, Colo. Meier, 22, stood just one-hundredth of a second behind Svet, the first-run leader, with both well ahead of the rest of the field. Meier posted the fourth-fastest second run of 1 minute 10.81 seconds for a two-run aggregate of 2:23.16. Svet's second run was the 12th fastest, and she finished fourth. Blanca Fernandez Ochoa of Spain finished second, Ulrike Maier of Austria was third and Tamara McKinney of Olympic Valley, Calif., was fifth.(AP) TENNIS Yugoslav Wins in Upset: Monica Seles, a 14-year-old amateur from Yugoslavia playing in her first pro tournament, beat Helen Kelesi of Canada, ranked No. 31 in the world, 7-6, 6-3, yesterday in the opening round of the Virginia Slims of Florida at Boca Raton. Seles, an eighth-grader, will get a sterner test tonight when she plays Chris Evert. ''I was scared before the match and didn't stop being nervous until I was ahead, 3-0, in the second set,'' Seles said. Using a two-handed forehand and backhand, Seles played mostly from the baseline but showed promise of a good volley. (AP) Gomez Rallies to Gain: Fifth-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador saved 2 match points in the second set and defeated Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina, 1-6, 7-6, 6-2, in the first round of the DuPont Classic in Orlando, Fla. Gomez, ranked No. 11 in the world, double-faulted twice at 5-6 in the second set to give the unseeded Bengoechea his second match point. But Gomez drilled three consecutive service winners to force a tiebreaker, which he won easily. In another match, Andre Chesnokov of the Soviet Union defeated John Frawley of Australia, 6-3, 6-1.(AP)

title: Florida Crime Rate Up 6.3%: Rise in Use of Drugs Blamed
description: More than one million serious crimes were reported in Florida last year, a record number attributed in part to the spread of drugs, the commissioner of the State Department of Law Enforcement said today.

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $564,000 tax credit and $1,612,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and after a $1,050,000 tax credit and $15,220,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Advertising; Psychology Today in Transition
description: OWEN LIPSTEIN and T. George Harris, the founders and owners of American Health magazine, said yesterday that they had agreed to acquire 90 percent of Psychology Today from the American Psychological Association.

title: HIGH COURT ORDERS FULLER DISCLOSURE FOR MERGER TALKS
description: The Supreme Court today significantly expanded the obligations of public companies and their managers to disclose preliminary merger negotiations to the public.

title: Region in Brain Is Linked to Obsessive Disorder
description: SCIENTISTS have found important new clues to the brain chemistry and anatomy of one of the most serious, puzzling and difficult forms of mental illness, obsessive-compulsive disorder.

title: E.P.A. Joining Environmentalists In Seeking Stronger Pesticide Law
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and national environmental organizations, often polarized over legislative issues, are now calling for amendments to strengthen the Federal pesticide control law.

title: Fanny Kemble Not a Yankee Abolitionist
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., appointed Bonnie Stedt senior vice president, human resources.

title: Democrats Fight Several Wars As Bush Foes Battle to Survive
description: The Democrats fight a multi-front war today for the right to stay in the long march to their national convention, but on the Republican side, Vice President Bush will be trying to bury all his opponents.

title: Article 601688 -- No Title
description: In a move that signals the successful turnaround of one of the nation's oldest and largest retailers, Montgomery Ward & Company will be bought from the Mobil Corporation in a leveraged buyout valued at $3.8 billion.

title: Renaissance Paintings Damaged In Milan
description: About 20 Renaissance paintings, including a masterpiece by Piero della Francesca, were damaged during a malfunction of the heating and humidity systems at the Brera Gallery in Milan, museum officials said today.

title: Program Finds Path Through the Tax Code
description: SINCE the people we call at the Internal Revenue Service for advice on our taxes are wrong at least 25 percent of the time, by their own admission, those of us who take on our own tax preparation are thus on our annual journey to the heart of darkness.

title: Church Officials Join U.S. in Promoting Amnesty
description: With only 58 days left before the yearlong amnesty program for illegal aliens expires, leaders of the Roman Catholic Church today joined with Federal immigration officials here to urge all those eligible to take advantage of the program before it is too late.

title: Floral Therapy for Flu
description: If the New York Flower Show is any guide, this is the year to learn how to pronounce ''gazebo'' (with a long ''e''). It is also the year to learn to spell ''ranunculus,'' a kind of upscale buttercup. And the year to quit cutting back the hollyhocks. The show, which runs through March 13, is rich in all three.

title: London Stock Official Quits
description: Sir Nicholas Goodison said today that he would surrender his position as chairman of the London Stock Exchange at the end of the year and not stand for re-election.

title: Korean Car Exports Up
description: South Korea's three auto makers reported today that their combined exports soared 97.4 percent in February, to 49,879 cars, from 25,270 in the same month last year. Officials said that the February shipments were mostly passenger cars and that more than 90 percent of them were to the United States and Canada. The Hyundai Motor Company topped the list with 33,803 autos, followed by the Kia Motors Corporation with 10,360 and Daewoo Motor with 5,716. No statistics for a year earlier were given.

title: Carrying, Like Touching, Is Beneficial to Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: Stone Slab in Mexico Reveals Ancient Writing System
description: AN ancient carved stone monument pulled from a river near the Gulf Coast of Veracruz gives evidence of a previously unknown system of hieroglyphics that flourished in the New World by the second century A.D.

title: The Budget Makes Refugee Choices Necessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Researchers Find Link Between Endometriosis And Bone Deterioration
description: NEW findings on the immune system are leading to unexpected insights into the causes and consequences of endometriosis, a mysterious affliction of millions of women.

title: Review/Recital; 1700's Glimpsed in 7 Rare Piano Works
description: Ian Hobson, a highly regarded young British pianist with an ear for the unusual, is devoting three recitals this season to a series called ''The London Piano School, 1766-1860.'' Drawing on Nicholas Temperley's recently published collection of music by composers working in London at the time the piano supplanted the harpsichord, Mr. Hobson began his series Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, offering works that are rarities to even the most obsessive of piano mavens, with several real gems among them.

title: Pickens's Bid Is Spurned
description: The board of the Homestake Mining Company has unanimously rejected a $1.9 billion takeover offer from Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil and gas company headed by T. Boone Pickens. The San Francisco-based gold producer said that its financial adviser, the First Boston Corporation, had determined that the offer, for $20 a share, was inadequate. It also said that its directors had determined that Homestake should remain an independent, publicly traded company.

title: Philippine Insurgents Kill 9
description: Communist guerrillas ambushed a vehicle near Subic Bay on Sunday, killing three civilians and six Filipino sailors assigned to the United States-run naval base, the military said today. The sailors - and the civilians, who were hitchhikers - were traveling from Subic to Manila when the rebels attacked near Hermosa, 40 miles west of Manila.

title: Moore McCormack Spurns Hostile Bid
description: The board of Moore McCormack Resources Inc. has rejected a $177 milllion hostile bid from Southdown Inc. as ''grossly inadequate.'' The concrete concern, based in Stamford, Conn., said it was investigating several options, including an acquisition of its own, to avoid a takeover.

title: Pirelli Bids To Acquire Firestone
description: Heating up the competition to acquire the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Pirelli S.p.A., the giant Italian tire maker, announced a $58-a-share, $1.86 billion tender offer yesterday.

title: Bridge: Retirement From the Game Bolsters Expert's Reputation
description: Few players retire from the game and then find that their reputation is growing. This has happened to Paul Lewis, a New York City bridge expert who temporarily put the game aside in 1985 when he married and moved to Irvington, N.Y. But since his namesake, Paul Lewis of Las Vegas, has had numerous successes, ''some people,'' he said, ''still think I just moved West.''

title: John, 44, Thinks Like 24
description: There have been 27 springs before this one. Tommy John does not clearly recollect them all, but he can still remember, with some clarity, certain moments: the managers, the teammates, workouts, drills.

title: STRUTHERS WELLS CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,513,642 from disposal of discontinued operations and a gainb of $7,616,468. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $6,201,895 from discontinued operations, a loss of $8,556,975 from disposal of discontinued operations, and a gain of $131,545.

title: Review/Television; Orbison Is Still Around and Rocking
description: Roy Orbison is not your average rocker. He was born in Wink, Texas, and he's over 40, well over 40, even older than Mick Jagger. He made his rockabilly debut on Sun Records in 1956 with ''Ooby Dooby.'' He hit his stride as a Nashville songwriter and performer for Monument Records in the 1960's. He still wears tinted glasses and an odd helmet of jet-black hair. His performing style is strait laced. No shaking and rattling here.

title: Mathilde Pincus Dies; Music Supervisor, 71
description: Mathilde Pincus, a leading music-preparation supervisor for the New York theater, died on Saturday in Dania, Fla., after a brief illness. She was 71 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Dania.

title: Talks on Grain Delayed
description: United States-Soviet trade talks on grain, set to begin on Friday in Vienna, have been delayed, United States officials said today. The Soviet Union asked that the negotiations be delayed because of logistical difficulties, the officials said.

title: KEY RATES
Experts Issue Warning About Dengue Fever
description: THE number of cases of dengue fever, a temporarily incapacitating disease spread by mosquitos, is increasing in warm regions of the Caribbean and Latin America, according to United States health specialists, who have called for more vigorous control of the insects throughout the hemisphere.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consumer Debt Rose 36% in January
description: Consumers took on more installment debt in January than in any month since September, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: The Budget Makes Refugee Choices Necessary; Thai Brutality
description: To the Editor:

title: Noriega's Opponents Set Up a Coalition
description: Major opposition political parties and civic groups announced today that they were joining with the deposed President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, to form a ''government of national reconciliation'' in place of the regime dominated by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Abbott Wins Sullivan
description: Jim Abbott, a pitcher who was born without a right hand, was named the 58th winner of the Sullivan Award last night as the nation's top amateur athlete. Abbott, 20 years old, is from Flint, Mich., and plays for the University of Michigan. He led Team USA last summer with an 8-1 record and a 1.70 earned run average as it won a silver medal in the Pan American Games. As a sophomore at Michigan last year, he started 15 games and finished the season with an 11-3 record. He was also named the 1987 winner of the Golden Spikes Award as the country's outstanding amateur baseball player. Abbott, the first baseball player to receive the Sullivan Award, was selected from a group of finalists that included Greg Foster, the world champion in the hurdles, and David Robinson, the former Navy basketball player. ''It's just incredible,'' Abbott said of his selection, announced at an awards dinner in Indianapolis. ''I just thought I was coming here for a dinner and to meet some of these other athletes.'' Abbott was drafted by the Toronto Blue Jays before deciding to attend Michigan. ''Receiving this makes everything worthwhile,'' he said. The Blue Jays made a very enticing offer, he said, ''but I always wanted to go to college at Michigan.''

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain on the sale of property of $1,175,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Books of The Times; South African Singer's Life: Trials and Triumphs
description: Makeba: My Story - By Miriam Makeba with James Hall. 249 pages. New American Library. Illustrated. $18.95.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized losses on investment of $568,000 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $6,930,000 for the year. c-After realized investment gains of $73,000 and $6,253,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a loss of $5,180,000 for the quarter and net of $9,214,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: The Election Process; Super Tuesday Offers A Muddled Experiment
description: Super Tuesday, the day designed to restore the South to the dominant role it once played in the Democratic party, hasn't even happened yet, and already they're calling it an idea whose time is past.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 7
description: Latest third quarter comprises the 16 weeks ended Feb. 7, while the year- ago third quarter comprises the 16 weeks ended Jan. 31. Latest 9 months are the 40 weeks ended Feb. 7, while the year-ago 9 months are the 40 weeks ended Jan. 31. Sales figures are those of all franchised and company-owned restaurants.

title: Metro Datelines; Teen-Ager Arrested After Shooting Spree
description: A youth who had been suspended from school apparently drank whisky and beer and went on a shooting spree that held the police at bay for more than 4 1/2 hours, the authorities said yesterday.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1 million. Year-ago results include the Viskase operation acquired in February 1986, and Filmco operation acquired in December 1986. The company said results for 1987 include both operations for the full year.

title: The Shot That Reigns Over the Rim
description: Sometime during the game Wednesday night against the Knicks, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers will take a pass near the basket, fake to his left, swing to his right and shoot the most potent and feared shot in the history of basketball.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''She won't listen to us and if we can't have a deaf president, we won't listen to her.'' Kim Harris, a Gallaudet University student. [ A20:6. ]

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council MEETS ON SOUTH AFRICA - 11 A.M. General Assembly MEETING OF STATES PARTIES TO CONVENTION ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council SPECIAL COMMISSION ON U.N. STRUCTURE IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M. WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Waldheim Pressed on Case of British P.O.W.'s
description: President Kurt Waldheim of Austria has admitted that he knew that Allied commandos were being interrogated by his German Army unit and that some were sent off for execution in violation of the Geneva Convention on treatment of prisoners of war.

title: Careers; The Difficult Search for Chief Executives
description: WHEN John M. Stafford abruptly resigned last week after three years as chief executive of the Pillsbury Company, the former chairman, William H. Spoor, emerged from retirement to take the top post and select another chief executive.

title: No Suicide for Israel
description: It happens to everybody from time to time. We believe certain things about a matter of important controversy and we say them. But when we hear the same points made by others, we become queasy and know something is wrong or missing.

title: Israel Must Not Wait For November Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys and Japanese
description: Lallation it's called, the difficulty Asians have in pronouncing ''L'' and ''R'' in English. For years it prompted adolescent jokes about ''flied lice'' and ''I went to U.C.R.A.'' The wisecracks have waned as Japan has given America lessons in quality and industry. No one is heard to mock the Honda Acula or the Sony Warkman. Yet the stereotyping is back, in different form, on NBC.

title: U.S. and British Producers Start Fund for New Plays
description: Two British and two American theater producers - including Jujamcyn Theaters Inc., the smallest of Broadway's three theater-owning groups - have announced the creation of the International Theater Development Fund to develop new work for the London and New York theater as well as for touring-circuit theaters in both countries.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Max L. Heine on Feb. 17 incorrectly described his role in founding the Mutual Shares Corporation. Mr. Heine founded the securities corporation in 1949 with Joseph C. Galdi.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1988
description: The Economy

title: The Budget Makes Refugee Choices Necessary; Cruel Trade-Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Season for Suspicious New Jobs
description: When a new Administration comes to town, it is usually dismayed to discover that it can make only a relatively small number of political appointments.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $39,819,000 from the sale of International Hydron Corp. and a gain of $11,925,000, mostly from a tax credit for the quarter; the year included income from discontinued operations of $45,685,000 and an extraordinary gain of $12,150,000, mostly from tax credits. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $196,000 for the quarter and $2,423,000 for the year. The company said the revenue increase for the latest fourth quarter and year was primarily attributable to the acquisition of General Physics Corp. on Dec. 31, 1986.

title: HEINZ, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
Corrections
description: An on article Saturday about voter reaction to the issue positions taken by Presidential candidates misstated the number of registered voters in Southern and border states interviewed in a New York Times/CBS News Poll. It was 1,724, not 1,666.

title: Latin Loan Agency's New Chief
description: Among the nearly three million Uruguayans the prevailing view is that an accident of birth is the only thing keeping Enrique Iglesias from being their next elected President.

title: Submachine Guns and Unpredictability Are Hallmarks of Crack's Violence
description: Crack has brought a new level of drug violence to New York and several other American cities, and law-enforcement officials say they now fear that many of the unstated codes of the street - restraints that often protected the police, drug agents and witnesses from attack - may be starting to disappear.

title: Fashion; Milan: It's Long, Short or Pants
description: Forget about childlike, playful and giddy. Those were last season's fashion words. The new clothes are grown-up, sophisticated and sober.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Administration Begins Talks On New Contra Aid Package
description: The Reagan Administration is working with key lawmakers from both parties to fashion a new proposal for aiding the Nicaraguan rebels, the White House said today.

title: Supreme Court Roundup Justices to Rule on Curb Of Obcenity Book Sales
description: The Supreme Court said today that it would decide whether the First Amendment bars state and Federal governments from using racketeering laws to close down bookstores selling any quantity of sexually explicit materials a judge considers obscene.

title: Capital Plan Set by Shoney's
description: Shoney's Inc., a leading operator and franchiser of restaurants in the East, said yesterday that its board had approved a $730 million recapitalization plan to ''help shareholders better realize the potential value of the company's stock.''

title: Texaco Plan Draws Icahn
description: Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider, said yesterday that he would probably vote his 14.8 percent stake in Texaco Inc. in favor of the company's plan to come out of bankruptcy, despite his displeasure with many aspects of it.

title: Antibody May Help Pinpoint Blood Clots
description: Doctors are hoping that by injecting a radioactive, genetically engineered antibody into a patient's bloodstream, they can can improve detection of blood clots.

title: Doing More for Reverse-Direction Commuters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bankrupt Farmers Lose High Court Case
description: The Supreme Court today ruled, by 8 to 0, that Federal bankruptcy law did not allow financially troubled farmers to avoid foreclosure and keep their farms by promising to continue operating them and making payments on their loans.

title: Program in Texas Helps Hispanic Mothers Discover Their Children and Themselves
description: Teaching mothers how to teach their children is the goal of Avance, a program here for low-income Mexican-American women with children under 4.

title: Two Ohio Utilities Offering $877 Million in Lease Bonds
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and the Toledo Edison Company are offering $877 million of secured lease obligation bonds through a special-purpose financing company called the CTC Mansfield Funding Corporation.

title: Publishing; Nonfiction Can Be Best Seller
description: The best-seller list is top-heavy with books that were published with plenty of fanfare and huge first printings, but the nonfiction list continues to serve up surprises.

title: Peter Martin, 65, Dies; Founder of a Bookshop
description: Peter Martin, who in 1964 founded the New Yorker Bookshop, an Upper West Side institution that closed for economic reasons in 1982, died of emphysema in San Francisco last Thursday. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. Rig Count Declines
description: The number of oil and gas rigs working in the United States decreased by five last week, to a total of 978, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. The total reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday. A year ago, the rig count was 766, Baker Hughes said.

title: College Hockey Notebook; Road to Final a 3-Way Route
description: College hockey officials are of different minds as to a fair format for tournaments, and as a result three different procedures were tried this season in the four Division I leagues.

title: Cat-Scratch Germ Isolated
description: The bacterium that causes infection in humans scratched by cats has been isolated and grown in the laboratory, researchers at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington reported in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Simon Discounts Being No.2
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, who is pinning his remaining Presidential hopes on next week's Illinois Democratic primary, says he would rather remain in the Senate than settle for second best. While campaigning Sunday in the Chicago area, Mr. Simon said he saw the Vice Presidency as largely a ceremonial post. ''That is not something that interests me,'' he said. ''My interests are in public policy.''

title: Rangers Wary of Rematch
description: For Michel Bergeron, the day was altogether ordinary, which meant his pulse rate was anything but. There were roster realignments to explain, injury reports to update, trade rumors to deny. Cigarette in one hand, a cup of coffee in the other, he juggled all the the issues yesterday and prepared to return to his office.

title: Family Support Efforts Aim To Mend Two Generations
description: Larry Keane is far too tall for the child-sized chairs in the playroom, but he sits quietly, beaming at the back of his son's head as Kevin, 4, finishes a wooden puzzle and proudly hands it to the nursery aide at the family drop-in center in Baltimore's bleak Cherry Hill housing project.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Alan Alexander has been elected a senior vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide, Chicago.

title: INSIDE
description: Panama Coalition Set Up Panamanian opposition parties and civic groups joined the deposed President in a ''government of national reconciliation.'' Page A3. Training to Be American A cultural orientation course at a camp in the Philippines is preparing young Vietnamese-Americans for life in the United States. Page A4.

title: Two Face Disbarment or Jail in Bar-Exam Switch
description: A woman already licensed to practice law took the bar exam for a second time in 1985, posing as her husband. She now faces disbarment, and he may go to jail.

title: Advertising; Alba Waldensian Focuses on Underwear
description: Down in Valdese, N.C., the people who run Alba Waldensian Inc. are having very big throughts about their future in the apparel business. They want to do with women's panties in supermarkets and drug chains what Hanes Hosiery did with L'Eggs pantyhose: sell them where such products have generally never been sold.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Held in Attack And Stabbing of Boy
description: A man was arrested yesterday after he showed up at a state police barracks with a 12-year-old boy who had been stabbed 13 times and sexually assaulted, the authorities said.

title: U.S. Assailed on Freer Farm Trade
description: A high-level United States trade mission clashed sharply with senior European officials today over the Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate all subsidies from world agricultural trade by the year 2000, including those paid to American farmers.

title: Rockwell Pleas Entered
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a former manager and a suspended employee pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here to 24 charges stemming from a reported scheme to double-bill the Government on a navigational satellite system in 1982. The company also pleaded not guilty to a criminal contempt charge involving reported violations of a 1982 injunction, which prohibited Rockwell from submitting false or fraudulent claims. A trial date of May 3 was set.

title: Mergers Group Official Quits Post at Shearson
description: In a sign of serious strains at the senior levels of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., Stephen Waters, co-head of the firm's mergers and acquisition department, resigned abruptly yesterday, Shearson executives said.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Dow Corning Officer Due to Add Chief's Job
description: LEAD: Lawrence A. Reed, president of the Dow Corning Corporation, the world's largest producer of silicone products, has been nominated to the additional post of chief executive.

title: U.S. Demands an Accounting by U.N. Agency
description: The United States has demanded that the chief of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, Edouard Saouma, respond to numerous allegations of improper management practices, including the distribution of jobs and contracts to guarantee political support.

title: His Heart's in Minnesota
description: You can take the boy out of Minnesota, it would seem, but you can't take the Minnesota out of the boy - at least not in the case of Garrison Keillor, the creator and former host of the ''Prairie Home Companion'' radio show.

title: 2 Workers Held Hostage in Hospital by a Prisoner
description: A prisoner being treated at a Manhattan hospital held two workers hostage early yesterday after ripping out a section of his bed, beating a police officer with it, and then fleeing with the officer's gun, the authorities said.

title: Curbing Cremation Fuel Need
description: The depletion of forests in many less developed nations has prompted warnings that shortages of wood for fuel and timber will further impoverish the people and damage the environment. India is seeking to reduce one source of demand for wood by promoting fuel-efficient cremation, a shift that can help save both forests and money.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are rainbows round and often double? A. The most common rainbows form when sunlight enters raindrops, according to Dr. William Gutsch, chairman of the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium. The drops act like prisms and disperse the sun's light into the familiar spectrum of colors: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo and violet.

title: 6 KILLED AS ARABS HIJACK ISRAELI BUS
description: Three Palestinian guerrillas hijacked an Israeli bus today, killing one hostage before they and two Israeli women died in a blaze of gunfire as troops stormed the bus.

title: David Bradley, 70, Longtime Executive At Missouri Papers
description: David R. Bradley, chairman of the St. Joseph News-Press and Gazette Company in Missouri, died Sunday of complications after heart surgery at St. Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Mo. He was 70 years old and lived in St. Joseph.

title: I.M.F. Studying Plan To Ease Debt Burden
description: The International Monetary Fund would play a major role in facilitating debt relief for third-world countries under a plan put forward by Arjun Sengupta of India, one of the fund's 22 executive directors.

title: Fashion; Patterns
description: From Europe to U.S.

title: Enough Hatred
description: LEAD: ''Hate,'' my grandfather Mohandas K. Gandhi told me, ''will only make you miserable. It is a word you must try to omit from your vocabulary.'' This was in 1946 when I was 12 and had just fought with a close friend. It was much later that I understood the importance of this message.

title: Refund to Lift Morgan's Net
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that its net income for the first quarter would be bolstered by $43 million as the result of a Federal income tax refund stemming from the New York City debt crisis in 1976.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 An Israeli bus was hijacked by Palestinian guerrillas, who killed one hostage before they and two Israeli women died in gunfire as troops stormed the bus. A group within the Palestine Liberation Organization took responsibility. Page A1

title: False Alarms About AIDS
description: The cover of this week's Newsweek features the rumpled sheets of an empty double bed. That's the teaser for a rumpled, alarming article: it implies that the AIDS virus can be spread by casual contact, declares the risk of being infected by a blood transfusion to be seven times greater than the best current estimates, and warns that the epidemic among heterosexuals ''will now begin to escalate at a frightening pace.''

title: U.N. Is Pressed to Cite Cuba for Rights Abuses
description: An American drive to have Cuba cited for violating its citizens' human rights is dominating a meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission for the second year in a row, diplomats say.

title: DOME PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $83 million. The company said results include writedowns of the value of energy assets of $346 million in the latest year, compared with $2.08 billion in the prior year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lawsuit Seeks End to Religious Aid Abroad
description: A civil liberties group is pressing a lawsuit to end all United States aid to religious schools abroad, even though Congress eliminated the $8 million program that spurred the action.

title: MECHAM IS ACCUSED BY POLICE OFFICIAL
description: Arizona's top police official testified at the impeachment trial of Gov. Evan Mecham today that he realized almost immediately that Mr. Mecham had committed a crime in ordering him not to cooperate in an investigation of a purported death threat.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $10 million charge from valuation of oil and gas properties for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $1,120,606 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,633,106 for the quarter and $82,714,884 for the year, and included charges of $36.4 million from valuation of oil and gas properties, a $45 million gain from settlement of a contract dispute and a $7 million provision for potential liabilities, all for the quarter.

title: Review/Concert; Schuller Conducts His Own Composition
description: The American Composers Orchestra did valuable service at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon with clear, seemingly well-rehearsed performances of four substantial works, each new to this city. In one instance it was service and then some, for the first movement of Gunther Schuller's Viola Concerto suffered a mishap and was repeated. That move provoked mildly annoyed intermission conversation among some composers in the audience: flawed performances are common, repeats are an enviable luxury, and in this case the beneficiary was also the bestower, since Mr. Schuller was the afternoon's conductor.

title: Review/Television; 'Whale Rescue,' Escape And a Happy Ending
description: ''Nova'' presents a story with a happy ending tonight: three young whales go home. Viewers may not be moved to cheers or tears, although certainly they will be pleased. The program, ''Whale Rescue,'' on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight, is about a narrow escape.

title: South Africa Envoy Arrested
description: A South African diplomat was cited for assault today after his car struck a protester and a police officer outside a radio station where he had been interviewed, the police said. Police Chief John Race said the man, identified as Duke Kent Brown, the South African vice consul in New York, was arrested after fleeing the scene. Mr. Brown was charged with simple assault, released on his own recognizance and ordered to appear in court in April. The protester was said to have suffered bruises. It was not immediately clear whether Mr. Brown had diplomatic immunity. Chief Race said that police officials who queried the State Department were told ''to treat this case like any other.''

title: College Basketball; Rutgers Pounded By Rhode Island
description: Tom Garrick scored a record-breaking 50 points, including 32 in the first half, to lead Rhode Island to a 104-73 rout of Rutgers tonight in an Atlantic 10 Conference Tournament quarterfinal game.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Sports People column last Friday about an investigation into basketball at the University of Kentucky misstated the outcome. A university report to the National Collegiate Athletic Association acknowledged violations and identified the corrective and disciplinary actions to be taken.

title: John W. Miller, Importer, 65
description: John W. Miller, president of Miller-Rogaska Inc., an importer of crystal, died of heart failure Friday in John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Atlantis, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Russell Is Removed As Coach of Kings
description: Bill Russell was removed as coach of the Sacramento Kings today and was transfered to a front-office job. He was replaced by Jerry Reynolds, an assistant coach.

title: Senator Wants Answers
description: Senator Strom Thurmond has asked the White House for a detailed explanation of the procedures followed in selecting a new Under Secretary for International Trade at the Commerce Department.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Stanlake Samkange, Zimbabwe Politician, 65
description: Stanlake Samkange, an author and politician who fought for independence for Zimbabwe, died of heart and lung ailments Sunday after a long illness, his widow said. He was 65.

title: Manila Accused of Rights Abuses
description: Amnesty International today accused the Philippine Government and Government-backed forces of carrying out unlawful killings, including mutilations and a beheading, in the name of preventing an insurgency.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $237,009 and a credit of $313,995 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from retirement of debt.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge form the reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $22,000. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $13,000 and $131,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago results are reclassified to conform to current year classification.

title: CRAFTMATIC-CONTOUR INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESTO-TEX reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $283,436 tax credit. The company said the primary reason for the 1987 loss was the fact that in 1986 it sold about 84 percent of the water dispensing machines it had previously owned and the income from such nonrecurring sales resulted in a net profit of approximately $675,000.

title: For Women in the Law, Still a Long Way to Go
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL MINISTERS SEEK MEETINGS TO AVERT COLLAPSE IN PRICES
description: A sharp drop in crude oil prices in recent weeks has prompted oil ministers around the world to call for emergency meetings aimed at preventing a recurrence of the 1986 price collapse.

title: 3 Ex-Detectives Held in Charity Fraud
description: Three former detectives for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office have been charged with illegally soliciting millions of dollars from businesses through a fraudulent police charity they set up 10 years ago, the Manhattan District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: LANDS' END reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said its fiscal 1988 net income was affected by an accounting change, which resulted in a reduction of deferred income tax liability and an increase in net income of $685,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Education; Another Club at Yale Plans to Admit Women
description: Scroll & Key, one of the most prestigious of Yale University's exclusive undergraduate clubs, will accept women as members next year, according to members. The move will end the club's 145-year year existence as an all-male institution.

title: Savings Bond Sales Rise
description: Sales of United States savings bonds increased for the sixth consecutive month in February, rising 2 percent, to $658 million, the Government reported today. The Treasury Department said that sales in February had been $13 million higher than in January and had been 2 percent above the level of a year ago, when sales were $646 million. With the inclusion of interest earnings, the value of outstanding bonds rose by $1 billion, to $103.24 billion, 10 percent higher than a year ago. Since November 1982, savings bonds held five years or longer have earned market-based interest rates. The current rate, in effect until May 1, is 7.17 percent.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Includes losses of $8,001,000 and $9,379,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses of $432,000 for the quarter and $3,602,000 for the year. The company said the latest fourth quarter loss due mainly to three factors- a charge of about $7.4 million related to the proposed sale of the company's unprofitable TCS Process Systems business; $3.3 million of cost overruns on custom military power supplies and other conversion products, as well as $2.8 million of inventory writedowns and contingency reserves.

title: Shortsighted to Drill for Oil in a Wildlife Refuge; A Bad Energy Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Protest by the Deaf Is Widening
description: The stormy effort by students, faculty members and alumni to win appointment of a deaf president for the nation's only university for the hearing-impaired appeared today to be turning into an expression of the frustrations of deaf people all over the United States.

title: Grandson of Salomon Founder Guilty in Shooting
description: Arthur K. Salomon, a grandson of a founder of the Salomon Brothers investment banking firm, pleaded guilty today to first-degree assault in the shooting of a 19-year-old motorist on the Hutchinson River Parkway last June.

title: ECOLOGY & ENVIRONMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Algerian Gas for Britain
description: Sonatrach, the Algerian state energy company, will sign a three-year contract soon to sell liquefied natural gas to British Gas P.L.C., the official press agency announced today.

title: Test Screenings of New Movies Put Demographics Over Creativity
description: The day after ''Made in Heaven'' was screened for a preview audience, the film's director, Alan Rudolph, faced researchers, marketing people and production executives from Lorimar Motion Pictures, who came armed with test results. The audience - chosen by sex, age and movie-going interests - had been confused, the data said, while watching Timothy Hutton and Kelly McGillis as lovers who meet in heaven and who must rediscover each other on Earth.

title: Super Tuesday: The Candidates Speak
description: ''I'm going to be the next President.'' - Vice President Bush

title: Noriega Aide Says U.S. Plans Invasion
description: The Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega charged today that American military maneuvers now being conducted here violate the Panama Canal treaties and are ''a prelude to a military invasion of Panama.''

title: Gold Trader Is Elected As Comex Chairman
description: The members of the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday elected as chairman a rough-and-tumble gold trader, John H. Hanemann, clearing the way for a new round of merger talks for the troubled futures and options market.

title: Sports People; Marino Steady Patient
description: One day after being released from Pembroke Pines General Hospital in Florida after tests for a stomach disorder he suffered last Saturday, Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins headed for California and another knee operation yesterday. Dr. Richard Steadman is to perform arthroscopic surgery in Lake Tahoe, on Marino's left knee, the quarterback's fourth such operation in five years.

title: Israel Deserves Better From Its Friends
description: LEAD: In a letter to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, 30 of Israel's best friends in the United States Senate have criticized Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir for his unwillingness to announce his negotiating position before negotiations have begun. The White House welcomed the letter. It is unclear what is behind this attempt to weaken Israel's position in negotiations that will deal with

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest full- year included a pre-tax gain of $323,000 from the sale of a building.

title: NORTHERN AIR FREIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEITEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $44,023 from discontinued operations and a loss of $25,959 from the disposal of a subsidiary for both periods; the year also includes an extraordinary gain of $115,697 from the early repayment of debt. c-Net loss

title: WHOLESALE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
WINE TALK
description: THERE was a time when French-American hybrid meant a kind of grape, a cross between an elegant European variety and a rugged American variety, meant to withstand North American winters. It still means that, but these days French and American vintners are crossing a lot more than grapes.

title: Market Place; Merger Potential In Appliance Field
description: MERGERS have become the name of the game for the home appliance industry, and the number of players seems likely to shrink again shortly. Then, too, quite apart from domestic deals already on the table, some Wall Street analysts suspect that foreign companies might emerge as buyers eager to tap into the United States market, which represents 25 percent of global appliance sales.

title: Ohio Law on Takeovers Is Challenged by Pirelli
description: Seeking to eliminate any legal obstacles to its bid to acquire the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, Pirelli S.p.A., the large Italian tire manufacturer, yesterday sought a temporary restraining order declaring an Ohio takeover law unconstitutional.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the latest quarter includes results for Plessey Peripheral Systems subsidiaries acquired at the close of the company's latest fiscal year. The company also said its results for the latest quarter continued to be affected by expenses related to the consolidation of the two companies.

title: Bonn Growth Slowed in '87
description: The West German economy, Western Europe's biggest, grew by 1.7 percent in 1987, well below the 2.5 percent achieved in 1986, the Federal Statistics Office reported today.

title: Kaisertech Block Sold to Maxxam
description: Maxxam Group Inc., which last week agreed to buy big blocks of Kaisertech Ltd.'s stock from the British investor Alan E. Clore and from Jefferies & Company, has negotiated the purchase of another 1.4 million share block from the Jamie Securities Company and two other entities for $16.8 million, a spokesman said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1988
description: International

title: Coup Attempt in Sao Tome In West Africa Is Put Down
description: Authorities in the West African island nation of Sao Tome and Principe crushed an attempted coup today, killing 2 of the 40 insurgents who tried to seize the police headquarters, a Portuguese radio station reported.

title: Metro Datelines; Look-Alike House Must Get New Plans
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the impoundment of all ''infringing copies'' of architectural plans used by a couple to build an expensive home nearly identical to one on the same street in Scarsdale.

title: Hope for Black Farmers in New Rules
description: New farm lending rules that become effective next June could slow the long decline in the number of black farmers in the South, according to Federal officials and community leaders.

title: Palestinians Free Relief Workers
description: A radical Palestinian guerrilla group today released two representatives of a British relief agency after detaining them for five days in the Lebanese southern port of Sidon.

title: FAIRMOUNT CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pension expense of $107,900 in compliance with FASB No. 87.

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $3,503,000. c-Net loss and after a tax credit of $3,038,000. The latest year's net from operations included a pre-tax gain of $67 million on the sale of its Chibougamau mining properties. All figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Women Still Finding Bias in Engineering
description: AS an engineer working in the aerospace industry, LuAnne J. Beckley encountered one prospective employer who wanted her to agree not to have children. Rockwell International, where she took a job, assigned her to an all-male laboratory with no women's restroom, a problem that was corrected only after she complained to management.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Business Week's Business Information Program to Sader & Associates for advertising and direct marketing.

title: To Protect the Theaters' Soul
description: Should Broadway's great old theaters be given landmark status? The Board of Estimate ought to give an answer from ''Evita'' - a ''qualified yes.''

title: Despite Losses, Gephardt Vows to Persist
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt acknowledged today that his losses in primaries across the South were a severe blow to his campaign. He said his main problem had been a lack of adequate funds to get his message out.

title: Surgery for Justice O'Connor
description: Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court had her appendix removed Monday night at Bethesda Naval Hospital and was in good condition today, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Stanford Enriches Its 'Core'
description: Who controls a university's curriculum and what should a required ''core'' curriculum contain? These questions continue to roil Stanford University. A faculty-student task force recommends broadening a required program on Western civilization. It wants to incorporate material on the contributions of women and minority members, and thus has ignited far-flung controversy.

title: INSIDE
description: China Assures U.S. on Iran

title: Sports People; Whalers Get Brodeur
description: In a swap of goaltenders, the Hartford Whalers acquired Richard Brodeur, a 35-year-old veteran of 16 big league pro seasons - 7 in the World Hockey Association and 9 in the N.H.L. - from the Vancouver Canucks. The Whalers gave up 29-year-old Steve Weeks, who had a 42-33-14 record in four seasons with the Rangers before joining Hartford for the 1984-85 season. Brodeur is the last player from the opening W.H.A. season, 1972-73, still in the N.H.L.

title: ARCO-Tricentrol
description: ARCO said it was starting a tender offer for all American depositary receipts of Tricentrol P.L.C. at $7.10 each. The company said the offer was not conditioned on the receipt of any minimum number of A.D.R.'s, each of which represents two Tricentrol ordinary shares. ARCO said the offer was part of its previously announced plan to acquire all shares of Tricentrol, a small British oil company. ARCO, the oil exploration and refining company based in Los Angeles, said there are about 977,283 Tricentrol A.D.R.'s outstanding.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Illegal Arms Deal Trial Opens in District Court
description: The lawyer for a New York arms dealer asserted yesterday that his client, acting on behalf of American intelligence officials, had tried in 1982 and 1983 to purchase two Soviet tanks from Polish generals.

title: Rangers Win After 3 Early Goals
description: The last 15 minutes of the third period were filled with fights and fouls, bad goals and regrettable mistakes. For the Rangers, none of those 15 minutes were elegant at all. Luckily, not a one of them mattered in the least.

title: Reapportionment Panel Should Be Created Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Balk, and Minis Fade
description: Just a year ago, fashion designers declared that short skirts were back and that no woman should even think of covering her knees. Now, in a remarkably speedy turnabout, they are showing some longer styles for fall and extolling the virtues of variety, including pants.

title: Special Inspection Ordered for Commuter Airlines
description: Disturbed by seven air crashes that killed 56 people in the last four months, the Federal Aviation Administration today ordered a special yearlong inspection of commuter airlines.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RAYONIER TIMBERLANDS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PEN/Faulkner Group Lists Award Nominees
description: The nominees for the eighth annual PEN/Faulkner Award for the best American fiction of 1987 were announced yesterday.

title: Don Redden, Basketball Player, 24
description: Don Redden, a member of the 1985-86 Louisiana State University basketball team, which went to the semifinals of the national championship tournament, died today at Baton Rouge General Hospital. He was 24 years old.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 7
description: b-After a pre-tax loss of $2.2 million on its corporate cash investment program due to the stock market crash last October. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $394,000 for the 16 weeks and $1,622,000 for the 40 weeks. Year-ago results were restated for comparative purposes to conform to 52-week accounting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 A sharp drop in crude oil prices in recent weeks has prompted oil ministers around the world to call for emergency meetings aimed at preventing a recurrence of the 1986 price collapse. Page A1

title: BEAUTY LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 9-month net are pro forma. The latest quarter and 9-month include results of Stance Industries Inc., acquired in November. The company said it had non-recurring expenses related to centralizing control of warehousing, distribution and administration, which should be completed in the current quarter.

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend issued in July 1987.

title: Cuomo Says G.O.P. Seeks To Overspend on Programs
description: Saying that Republicans in the State Senate ''have always been the big spenders,'' Governor Cuomo charged today that Senate Republicans were pressing for almost $2 billion worth of programs the state cannot afford.

title: PRATT HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $72,000 and $1,927,000 from early retirement of debt. c-Includes an extraordinary charge of $755,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $3,388,000 for the year. d-Net income

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ameron Inc., Monterey Park, Calif., a maker of construction products, basic steel products and protective coatings and liners, said it had repurchased 911,400 common shares, or about 18.6 percent, from Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd. for $36 a share, a total of $32.8 million.

title: Providence, R.I.
description: ETHNIC roots run deep in this city of 157,000. That is why Providence takes its Ma-and-Pa bakeries seriously and why first-rate Portuguese sweet bread, Jewish rye, crusty Italian white, Lebanese pita and now Bagelbread are all available here.

title: Soviet Armenians Mourn Their Dead
description: Tens of thousands of Armenians held a silent march and vigil in the Armenian capital of Yerevan this afternoon in memory of those slain in the recent rampages in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, according to Armenians and Westerners who were present.

title: Time To Speak To Israel
description: The old children's taunt goes, ''Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me.'' It applies to Israel, the other way around. It has been the words, and the pictures, of young Palestinians defying the Israeli Army after 20 years of occupation, with no end in sight, that are bringing the region to a new sense of urgent crisis.

title: Suspect Is Sought in Bludgeoning Of Four Girls in Bronx Buildings
description: The police are searching for a man who they say attacked four Bronx girls since Friday by striking them in the head with a blunt instrument, possibly a hammer.

title: California Jury Is Told Defendant Admitted Slaying Journalist
description: A prosecutor told a jury today that the former member of a Taiwanese criminal gang accused of murdering a Chinese-American journalist more than three years ago had admitted committing the crime ''all over the world.''

title: A Baffled Brokaw Sees Ratings Slip
description: Last summer, NBC News filled its airwaves with promotions calling its ''Nightly News'' broadcast with the anchor Tom Brokaw as ''clearly America's news,'' hoping to capitalize on Mr. Brokaw's yearlong surge to the top in the ratings, largely at the expense of Dan Rather and the ''CBS Evening News.''

title: Shortsighted to Drill for Oil in a Wildlife Refuge
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW DRUG IS CITED ON COMBATING AIDS
description: Imreg, Inc., a small biotechnology company, announced today that one of its drugs had reduced the progression to full-fledged AIDS in patients who have early symptoms of the disease.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Deficit . . .
description: When will the Republican Presidential candidates raise taxes? Never! When will the Democratic candidates? Only ''as a last resort.'' When will Congress? Certainly not in this election year. To hear these politicians talk, you'd think the issue was dead in the water. But it's not. Fortunately, if the candidates don't dare face it responsibly, others will.

title: CCR VIDEO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $108,640.

title: Italian Fashion: Trousers a Diversion
description: Trousers are sweeping like a tidal wave through the fall and winter fashion openings, in an effort to divert attention from skirts and their lengths. This is inevitable at a time of hemline unrest, designers say.

title: Merrill Official Plans to Quit
description: Robert F. Mancuso, a senior Merrill Lynch & Company executive who founded the firm's leveraged buyout business seven years ago, plans to resign. Confirming Wall Street rumors of his departure, Mr. Mancuso said that he intends either to set up his own business to provide financial advice in leveraged buyouts or to join a small firm. He thus joins a growing exodus of senior Wall Street deal makers from the large firms they helped to build.

title: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mamet's 'Speed-the-Plow' Set to Open on Broadway
description: The executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, Bernard Gersten, announced yesterday that David Mamet's new play, ''Speed-the-Plow,'' starring Joe Mantegna, Madonna and Ron Silver, will bypass the Mitzi E. Newhouse, where it was scheduled to begin performances at the end of the month, and open at the Royale May 3, after previews beginning April 9.

title: A Car Bomb Is Found in Spain Near Gibraltar
description: The Spanish police found an explosives-laden car Tuesday that was thought to be linked to three members of the Irish Republican Army who were shot dead in Gibraltar by British commandos, officials said.

title: Advertising; Expo Looks At Prospects For Research
description: THE major acquisitions and mergers involving advertising agencies and media organizations are over for a while, according to Joseph E. Laird Jr., a senior analyst for the investment firm of Hambrecht & Quist Inc.

title: ROCKY MOUNT UNDERGARMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes unusual litigation and settlement costs totaling $1,237,000. c-Included $173,000 in unusual litigation costs for the quarter and year; the year also included tax benefits of $922,000.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK & TRUST NORTH PALM BEACH reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,375,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: KEY RATES
Review/Television; 'Inside Soviet Circus,' Dedicated Performers
description: ''Inside the Soviet Circus'' shows a lot of inside but not enough circus. The National Geographic Special, on Channel 21 at 8 o'clock tonight (and on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow), doesn't look at Soviet circus life so much as canonize it. It suggests that clowns, jugglers and aerialists pursue a sacred calling.

title: Sorting Facts In Food Ads
