description: THE burning political question in the world of nutrition has nothing to do with Presidential primaries.

title: Betty Throne-Holst, Foundation Aide, 61
description: Betty Throne-Holst, founder and president of the Swedish chapter of the African Medical and Research Foundation, died of intestinal cancer March 1 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Anne Dunlap Winkler, Decorator, 91
description: Anne Dunlap Winkler, an interior designer, died Sunday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 91 years old.

title: New Digital Computers Will Challenge I.B.M
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation introduced several mainframe computers today in another challenge to the International Business Machines Corporation, the industry leader.

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $268,000 on investment of surplus cash in adjustable rate preferred stock funds.

title: BASE TEN SYTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Perdue Lets a Title Go But Is Not Bowing Out
description: Think of Perdue Farms and you think of the chicken entrepreneur Frank Perdue and the advertisements in which he promotes his chickens. But there are other executives down on the farm in Salisbury, Md., and one of them is succeeding Mr. Perdue as chief executive.

title: Metro Datelines; M.T.A Smoking Ban Is Upheld by Judge
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was within its rights when it banned smoking on its commuter railroads.

title: U.S. and Japan Talks Fail
description: Discussions between the United States and Japan over participation by American companies in Japanese construction projects ended in failure today.

title: New York Bids for Welfare Hotel, a Symbol of Homeless Plight
description: New York City announced plans yesterday to buy and shut down the Holland Hotel, a midtown welfare hotel that has become a symbol of the plight of homeless families in the city. The city wants to renovate and convert the hotel to a residence for homeless people who are elderly or mentally ill.

title: 3-Way Muddle; Primary Vote Leaves Many Questions But No Clear Leader for Democrats
description: Among the Democrats this year, there is a palpable hunger for an ''electable'' candidate. The party has captured the White House only once in the last 20 years, and now it is presented with what looks like a rich opportunity, with the conclusion of the Reagan era. So a big question after

title: 60-MINUET GOURMET
description: RECENTLY I took a casual inventory of the various foods that have been prepared for this column to determine the one most commonly used. It turned out to be, of course, chicken breasts, which, for a variety of reasons, are a great choice for cooking in less than an hour.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Guemes Island Journal; Will Seaweed Farming Mean Paradise Lost or Kept?
description: Mention sushi in this pocket of paradise and you'll probably be run off the island. The raw fish, a much-maligned food of the stylish moderns, is wrapped in seaweed, which the Japanese called nori. Now plans are under way to make Guemes Island the nori capital of the Western Hemisphere by establishing a 700-acre seaweed farm here, Farming, in this part of the world, has clearly changed: salmon are raised in pens and seaweed is grown in underwater nets suspended from floats in saltwater ranches, dried and then processed into thin sheets of edible wrapping. Considering sea farming an industry with a future, the State of Washington has spent millions of dollars promoting aquaculture.

title: Tyson's Impact Powerful in Japan
description: Mike Tyson has come to Japan, where people keep touching his hair.

title: Advertising; David Deutsch Named To Handle Innervision
description: David Deutsch Associates has become the creative-only agency for Innervision Inc., a new company that will make and import health and beauty aids.

title: Michelin Guide's '88 Ratings
description: The 1988 Guide Michelin for France has awarded its highest rating to the Paris restaurant L'Ambroisie, the only restaurant to be added to the three-star category this year.

title: FORSTMANN & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes charges of $421,000 and $555,000 from the early retirement of debt for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Transfers Begin To Police Unit In Queens Area
description: The Police Department began reassigning narcotics officers yesterday to the new, 118-member Tactical Narcotics Team that will try to rid southeast Queens of its growing drug trade.

title: COLONIAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HESSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEQUEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said year-ago revenue included the sale of certain assets of a discontinued product line.

title: Green Wins Third Term As Albany Caucus Head
description: Assemblyman Roger L. Green won a third one-year term as head of the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus tonight after a State Senator who was running against him withdrew from the race in a closed-door meeting.

title: Review/Concert; In London, a Weekend of Berlioz as Berlioz Heard It
description: The increasingly less aptly named early-music movement broke fresh ground over the weekend, with period-instrument performances by Roger Norrington and his London Classical Players of Berlioz's ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and ''Romeo et Juliette'' at Queen Elizabeth Hall.

title: Ruling Expands Bank's Liability In Employee Discrimination Case
description: A Federal administrative law judge ruled today that a Chicago bank that had been found to have discriminated against female and minority employees might owe millions more in back pay in the case, the biggest of its kind.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $10 million writedown of an investment in an affiliate for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $1,120,606 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,633,106 for the quarter and $82,714,884 for the year, and included a $36.4 million writedown of an investment in an affiliate, a $45 million gain from settlement of a contract dispute and a $7 million provision for potential liabilities, all for the quarter. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Williams Case Off Until April
description: A District Court judge today put off a court appearance for Jayson Williams, the St. John's sophomore center, until April 7.

title: Education; Lessons
description: They meant no indictment. ''We do not assert that American 17-year-olds are stupid, that . . . they are short on savvy, creativity or energy,'' said educational researchers Diane Ravitch and Chester E. Finn Jr. in ''What Do Our 17-year-olds Know?'', their report on history and literature tests given in 1986 to almost 8,000 high school students nationwide.

title: CARRINGTON LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Minnesota Yields At 6.10% to 7.30%
description: Minnesota is offering $184.3 million of general obligation bonds with yields ranging from 6.10 percent in 1996 to 7.05 percent in 2002 and 7.30 percent in 2006 and 2007, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: Education; From Shakespeare to Hansberry to Cafeteria Post
description: The waxed floor of Room 108L glistens from the morning light. Vacant student desks are marshaled like a platoon set for a parade. Chris Ask is already at his desk going through trial runs with the tape recorder and phonograph that will be vital to the day's lessons.

title: Advertising; Money Names New Publisher
description: William S. Myers has been named publisher of Money magazine, replacing William M. Kelly Jr., who is retiring after 34 years with Time Inc.

title: Martin Herzer Is Dead; Stage Manager Was 45
description: Martin Herzer, a production stage manager who worked on many of the most successful Broadway shows of the last decade, died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: ATTICO FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest periods' results include an income tax credit of $2,227,000 for the quarter and $6,002,000 for the year, which Atico said resulted primarily from the reduction of deferred tax liability related to gains in the company's equity securities portfolio. The latest fourth quarter and year results also include the July 31 acquisition of Pan-American Mortgage Corp., and the Aug. 31 acquisition of 93 percent of the common stock of Intercontinental Bank.

title: Review/Television; In Series, Culture Shock For Amish
description: Deciding to go all the way with ''family entertainment'' on Wednesday evenings, NBC is rolling the dice on a new series called ''Aaron's Way,'' which, at 8 P.M., will precede ''Highway to Heaven'' and ''thirtysomething.'' The new show is being given a special two-hour ''preview'' tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: RAUCH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Revival for Makers of Classic Toys
description: Stung by its failure to continue churning out blockbuster hits like the Cabbage Patch kids and the Teddy Ruxpin talking bear, the toy industry is shifting back to basics. Classics like building blocks, trains and cars are regaining popularity and some middle-tier companies best known for their old favorites are enjoying a renaissance.

title: Arthur N. Seiff, 86; Won Free Press Case
description: Arthur N. Seiff, a trial lawyer, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan while he was working on legal papers. He was 86 years old.

title: Boston Hermit Is Discovered Dead After Resisting Efforts to Aid Him
description: Bill Britt, a homeless man who gained national attention for his refusal to leave his lean-to on state-owned land here, was found dead Monday, the police said. He was 52.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News report in Business Day yesterday misstated the total value of Southdown Inc.'s hostile takeover offer for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. Southdown has offered to pay $31 a share for the 8.8 million Moore McCormack common shares outstanding, $51.77 for each $3.6875 preferred share and $1,174 for each $1,000 face amount of 7 1/4 percent subordinated convertible debentures due 2012. Southdown values its bid at $391 million.

title: Costs of New Submarines Rise
description: An effort to upgrade future Los Angeles-class attack submarines has generated delays at shipyards and contract overruns totaling $1.3 billion, the Navy said today.

title: Sports People; Wieland Hits Tape
description: Bob Wieland, who lost both legs during the Vietnam War, crossed the finish line yesterday morning and completed the Los Angeles Marathon, which he started last Saturday. Wieland covered the 26-mile-385-yard course in about 74 1/2 hours, using his powerful arms to push himself along. He bettered his 1987 time by 18 hours.

title: Will He Run? Secret Is Kept By Mitterrand
description: On a quiet curving street between the Pont d'Alma and the Eiffel Tower, President Francois Mitterrand's campaign headquarters is ready. A sign on the brick facade of 7 avenue Franco-Russe says that a school has moved from the four-story building to another address.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shutting the Door on the Poor
description: We have been bombarded with images of the homeless, wrapped in tattered blankets, sitting on steaming grates across from the White House. This rightly disturbs us. All too often, however, we ignore the complex substance that underlies these images. Budget numbers may not make good television copy, but if we consider only the homeless person and not the reason for his homelessness, we cannot solve the problem.

title: Suit Charges Bias in Foster-Care Rules for Aliens
description: New York City and the Legal Aid Society sued the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday, contending that alien children who are in foster care have little chance to become legal residents of the United States.

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $23,000 on investments for the quarter and a $381,000 investment gain for the year, and a $28,000 reversal of a tax benefit for the quarter and a tax benefit of $264,000 for the year. c-Includes investment gains of $437,000 and $822,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax benefit of $68,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $222,000 for the year.

title: HAMPTONS BANCSHARES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
For Katharine Hepburn, Her Mother's Crusade
description: NEARLY 70 years ago, a determined suffragist known as Mrs. Thomas Hepburn heard Margaret Sanger speak on the need for birth control; the message changed her life. Mrs. Hepburn, the wife of a prominent Connecticut doctor, decided that women needed birth control even more than they needed the vote.

title: Levallois Journal; Valiant Little Companion of the Road, Au Revoir!
description: It looks like a cross between a frog and a camel, and it is about as aerodynamic as an aardvark, but Citroen's Deux Chevaux model has long been treasured by French car lovers.

title: COCA MINES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $54,700. c-Net loss

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Abram Hails Israeli 'Restraint'
description: The head of a delegation of American Jews that returned over the weekend from Israel said yesterday that Israel was ''trying to handle a difficult situation with care and circumspection'' in its occupied territories and blamed ''Arab intransigence'' for the deadlock in peace talks.

title: Review/Opera; First 'Cosi' of Metropolitan Season
description: The ragged edges of stage business and musical ensemble in ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera Monday evening will probably smooth themselves out in later performances. It may be, too, that the singers will find their way to a feeling, thinking exploration of Mozart's six characters and the funny, sad, searing, bewildering situation they get themselves into. They make a strong cast vocally, about as strong, on the whole, as one opera house could reasonably hope to assemble today. So their first performance together gave pleasure. But it did not satisfy.

title: Rose Likes Mets and Giants
description: The art of predicting division winners, Pete Rose said today, really isn't an art at all. It's a matter of mathematics.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Dow Rises 24.70 in Broad-Based Advance
description: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 24.70 points to close at 2,081.07.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS LEAD
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Albert Gore Jr. divided the biggest one-day harvest of national convention delegates of this election year yesterday.

title: College Tournaments; West Virginia Falls To Rhode Island
description: Carlton Owens scored 25 points and Kenny Green scored on a dunk with j1 minute 24 seconds remaining to insure Rhode Island's 65-63 victory over West Virginia tonight in an Atlantic 10 semifinal.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: Lovett at Bottom Line

title: 2 Albany Newspapers Are Planning a Merger
description: The publisher of The Knickerbocker News, Albany's afternoon newspaper, announced today that it would be merged with The Albany Times Union to form a larger, all-day newspaper.

title: Bridge: Two Players at Same Table Had a Reason to Bid Eight
description: Something patently illegal was seriously debated early in this century: Can players bid eight if they choose?

title: Rates End Session Little Changed
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday after Treasury bond prices recovered from midday losses of about half a point.

title: PRICE/STERN/SLOAN PUBLISHER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Racial Puzzle For Cuomo; Some Blacks Criticize Him on Brawley Case
description: Governor Cuomo's handling of the Tawana Brawley case is being criticized by some of New York City's leading black political figures, who say Mr. Cuomo lent legitimacy to the Rev. Al Sharpton and thereby undermined his own efforts to resolve the case.

title: ARTISTIC GREETINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fremont Insurance
description: The Fremont General Corporation, which had been trying to shed its property and casualty insurance business since suffering losses beginning in 1986, said that 10 managers and the unit's chief executive, David L. Mc Intyre, had agreed to buy the Fremont Insurance Group for $82 million in cash, notes and preferred stock. Since discontinuing some unprofitable reinsurance lines, the insurer's operations include coverage for workers' compensation and medical malpractice in California and rein-surance for catastrophes in London. The company, based in Santa Monica, Calif., has $600 million in assets and earned $18.6 million in 1987. The rein-surance business had losses of $31.4 million last year.

title: New Interest in Mediterranean Food: Rich Cuisine on a Clear Conscience
description: LEAD: THOSE bountiful gushes of straw-gold olive oil, those smells of basil and rosemary perfuming the thick New York air, those heaps of couscous that threaten to block traffic at major intersections: these are sure signs of another food trend under way in New York and, to an extent, elsewhere.

title: Rights Aide Held in Atlanta
description: Hosea Williams, a City Councilman active in the civil rights movement, was charged Sunday with carrying an unlicensed pistol when security officers at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport found a gun in his briefcase. Mr. Williams ''said he had been cleaning his car out and put it in his briefcase but forgot to leave it in his house,'' a police sergeant said. The police did not say whether the .38-caliber pistol was loaded. The charge is a misdemeanor.

title: Bonds Offered for Prisons And Criminal Justice Center
description: Tax-exempt bonds to finance prisons in New York State and a criminal justice center in Philadelphia were offered yesterday. Principal and interest payments on both issues were insured, raising their credit ratings to the highest triple-A level.

title: Dart Withdraws Stop and Shop Bid
description: The Dart Group Corporation said it would not extend its $37-a-share offer to purchase the Stop and Shop Companies, which owns supermarkets, discount stores and other retail outlets in the Northeast. Stop and Shop accepted a $44-a-share offer, worth a total of $1.2 billion, from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big New York investment firm.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In France, A Fondness For Homey Classics
description: BENEATH the lofty toques of most haute cuisine chefs in France is a humble bistro cook, or so it seemed on a recent trip through Paris and Burgundy, with stops at 20 or so restaurants. Everywhere, chefs and restaurateurs were talking about a rekindled interest in ingenuous home cooking, rhapsodizing over boeuf bourguignonne and coq au vin with a fervor once reserved for the latest nouvelle cuisine flourish.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year losses include a gain of $577,000 from the sale of the company's Chicago warehouse and distribution facility.

title: Channing's 2 Views of Marriage
description: Onstage she is the picture of defeat: her body obscured in a shapeless housedress of indeterminate color, her hair like straw, Susan is trapped in a loveless marriage to a priggish vicar, taunted by a spiteful sister-in-law who has moved in for good, and tortured by the rejection of her only child, who joined a cult and hasn't spoken to her in two years. A woman whose entire existence is defined by her roles as wife and mother, Susan finds her life intolerable.

title: T CELL SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Standard To Talk To Decker
description: American Standard Inc. said today that it would negotiate with the Black & Decker Corporation, which has made a hostile $2.26 billion tender offer, and also with other potential buyers.

title: FILTERNEK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain on an accounting change of $260,000.

title: WEBB INVESTMENT, DEL E CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Right Way to Purge the Teamsters
description: LEAD: The Justice Department is expected to seek a court-ordered trusteeship of the nation's largest union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. While the Government surely can prove that the union and more than 100 affiliates are dominated by organized crime, trusteeship is senseless and bound to fail.

title: Sampling Vintages That Have Aged Well
description: ADMIRERS of rare old premium California chardonnays will soon find a bonanza at the River Cafe, a Brooklyn restaurant on the East River with a spectacular view of lower Manhattan.

title: 'To Burke' Isn't Better Than 'to Disappear'
description: To the Editor:

title: From Milk Co-op for Poor, A New Hope for Housing
description: Late last summer, eight low-income families renovating an abandoned building in Brooklyn found themselves in a jam. Money from a state grant was late, and the families owed a total of $4,500 to an insurance company and an electrician.

title: Samuel Lewis Cohen, Physician, 91
description: Dr. Samuel Lewis Cohen, a Manhattan internist, died of heart failure Monday at Doctors Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 6 percent stock dividend paid in November 1987. The company said its latest second quarter was adversely affected by costs associated with a major restructuring program, consolidation of industries, delays in planned new products and the loss of a distribution account in the company's aviation products subsidiary.

title: IGI INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $156,098 and a tax credit of $271,537.

title: Austria Fouling Hungary's Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: New Zealand Asks to Delay Cup Racing
description: In a surprise move, Michael Fay, the New Zealand merchant banker, has offered to postpone the America's Cup regatta scheduled for September until 1989 in order to give other challengers an opportunity to race.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Gore's Unorthodox Strategy Seen As Vindicated on Super Tuesday
description: For the campaign of Senator Albert Gore Jr., Super Tuesday was the vindication of an unorthodox and often questioned strategy.

title: Women Lead Palestinian Protests; 2 More Are Killed
description: Security forces fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse marching Palestinian women today, witnesses said, as widespread violence continued in Israel's occupied territories.

title: NBC Plans to Take Tougher Approach
description: THERE will be no Olympic-sized hugs by NBC interviewers in Seoul, South Korea, during the Summer Games.

title: BOYS MARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $449,000 due to damages sustained in an earthquake. The company said prior year results were not available; the first quarter of 1986 was a predecessor company.

title: Pasqua Starting Anew With White Sox
description: When he finally walked onto the field today, Dan Pasqua looked across the grass at Payne Park and saw familiar faces. For three summers, he played in New York alongside Don Mattingly and Mike Pagliarulo and Dave Winfield. But unlike them, he was a star who never did much more than flicker.

title: Tourism Up in O.E.C.D.
description: Tourism flourished in major industrial countries last year, tentatively topping the record set in 1985, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. Real tourist trade earnings (allowing for inflation and exchange rate fluctuations) climbed 6 percent in the 24-nation O.E.C.D., compared with the 1986 rise of three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Boxing Notebook; Nevada Leads Way in AIDS Testing for Fighters
description: The fear of AIDS has sometimes led to extreme measures - the attempt, for example, to keep a child with the disease out of school. Such actions have been fought by civil libertarians, who have sought to protect the rights of AIDS victims.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are on the verge of a meltdown.'' Bryan Jacoboski, an oil analyst. [ D7:5. ]

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Islanders Prevail In Midst of Fighting
description: Derek King has not often felt comfortable in his Islander jersey because, in the three seasons since the team drafted him, he has not often worn it.

title: RUNAWAY IN G.O.P.
description: Vice President Bush took a long stride toward the Republican Presidential nomination yesterday by sweeping all 16 primaries at stake.

title: Amid Its Success, Big East Struggles With Surly Image
description: It's difficult, at times, to remember that the Big East, with all of its accomplishments, is only nine years old. And sometimes it seems as if the conference is made up of 9-year-olds.

title: JAMES MADISON & CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Return to the Land of the Gipper
description: Ronald Reagan played football in college. Then he played a football player in a movie. In some ways he has been playing the player, if not the game itself, ever since.

title: 2d U.S. Appeals Court Hears Japanese Internment Lawsuit
description: A second Federal appeals court here heard arguments today in the case of 120,000 Japanese-Americans who were held in prison camps in World War II.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Villa Iacocca

title: Appeals Court Backs G.M. on X-Car Safety
description: Three Federal appellate judges today upheld a lower court's finding that there was no evidence that the General Motors Corporation knowingly sold 1.1 million 1980 X-cars with brake defects.

title: Who May Cry for Tibet?
description: When Tibetans rose in protest against Chinese repression last fall, Congress condemned China for human rights failures. Beijing in turn condemned the U.S. for meddling. Now new protests shake Lhasa just as the Chinese Foreign Minister visits Washington to discuss ever-stronger bilateral relations. A reminder, however diplomatic, is in order: For Americans, human rights are as much a part of foreign policy as economics.

title: KRELITZ INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HYPONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said it had pretax unrealized losses on investment of about $12,646,000 in the latest year, most of it in the fourth quarter.

title: COMTECH TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,682,000 from the gain on an exchange offer for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After gains of $468,000 and $581,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: STEEL OF WEST VIRGINIA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $227,000 from early repayment of debt. Year-ago figures are pro forma because the company went public in October 1987.

title: Gap Inc. to Cut Growth Of Banana Republic Unit
description: The Gap Inc. says it will scale back expansion of its trendy Banana Republic Travel and Safari Clothing Company.

title: AMBASSADOR FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $35,690. c-Net income

title: COMMUNICATION CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and full-year results include two months of the operation of Intercomp Wire & Cable, acquired last September.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose for the first time in three weeks at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.5941 percent, up from 6.5188 percent last week.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $172,935 and a loss of $659,009 for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary gains of $1,525,470 for the quarter and $3,009,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $18,472,636 for the quarter and $28,856,423 for the year.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $239,000 from the early repayment of debt. c-Net income and the year includes a tax credit of $598,000. The prior year also included a pretax gain of $24,541,000 from the sale of properties.

title: Sports People; Islanders Trade Dineen
description: With the National Hockey League's trading deadline ending yesterday, the three metropolitan area teams were involved in only minor deals in their drives for the playoffs. In a move to go with younger players, though, the Islanders traded two defensemen with experience who might have helped them. They sent Gord Dineen to the Minnesota North Stars for a minor league defenseman, Chris Pryor, and they sent Brian Curran to the Toronto Maple Leafs for a sixth-round selection in the 1988 draft. Dineen, who has been with the team for five seasons, had 4 goals and 12 assists in 57 games this season. Curran had only 1 goal in 20 games as he missed 26 games because of injuries that included a broken jaw. The Islanders said Pryor would remain with Minnesota's minor league affiliate in Kalamazoo, Mich., and join the Islanders next season. . . . The Rangers sent Jim Pavese, a defenseman, to the Detroit Red Wings for future considerations. Pavese was obtained from St. Louis Oct. 23 for a fourth-round choice in the 1988 draft. Pavese played 18 games for the Rangers and had 2 assists. . . . The Devils, who were expected to make at least one deal involving one of their six goaltenders, instead sent Steve Tsujiura, a minor league center, to Boston for future considerations.

title: Former Indian Leader Sentenced to Probation
description: Dennis Banks, a former leader of the American Indian Movement, was sentenced Monday to five years' probation for illegally possessing dynamite.

title: Pennsylvania Power Offering
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering $125 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds, due in 1998, at a price of 99.68 to yield 9.30 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: UNITED FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIONEER FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $144,000 from investments for the quarter; the year includes a gain of $527,000 from investments. c-Includes a gain of $34,000 and $860,000 from investments for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Samuel R. Donnellon, Civil Engineer, 103
description: Samuel R. Donnellon, a civil engineer, died of heart failure Feb. 26 at Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital. He was 103 years old and lived in Lake Wales.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column is moving to The Home Section, where it will appear starting March 24.

title: Something For the Populus
description: This is Popular Request Day. Accordingly, the election returns will not (by popular request) be analyzed, or even hereafter mentioned in this space. Instead, we shall attempt to give the people (''populus'') what they want.

title: Tibet Unrest: Fears Return; Display of Tolerance Fails to Win Hearts
description: The details emerging about the violent anti-Chinese demonstrations Saturday in Tibet leave little doubt that Beijing's attempt to court Tibetans through a display of greater tolerance has won neither their loyalty nor acceptance of the Chinese presence.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Correll, Minn.
description: LEAD: SMOKED pheasant and country sausage from Big Stone County are being offered at a special price this month by the county's only mail-order food operation, the Prairie Gourmet. To Minnesotans, Big Stone County means granite and pheasants. Granite is in such abundance here (hence the county's name) and is of such high quality that it is shipped as far as Italy.

title: Advertising; Beech-Nut Nutrition Hires Makovsky & Co.
description: After all the bad publicity it received for selling phony apple juice for infants, Beech-Nut Nutrition has retained the public relations firm Makovsky & Company for a national program.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Sampson
description: In order to allow doctors to examine and perhaps remove cartilage from his right knee, damaged in a game against the Knicks Feb. 26, Ralph Sampson of the Golden State Warriors will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville and may miss the remainder of the National Basketball Association season. The surgery will be performed by Dr. Frank McCue, who performed a similar operation on Sampson's left knee a year ago. Since he was ac-quired in a trade with the Houston Rockets Dec. 12, the 7-foot-4-inch cen-ter has averaged 15.4 points, 10 re-bounds, 2.9 assists, 1.9 blocked shots.

title: CHARTWELL GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $129,000 and an extraordinary gain of $309,000 on extinguishment of debt for both the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $209,000 for the quarter and $243,000 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary gain of $600,000 from a tax benefit.

title: Tandon Sells Disk Drive Unit
description: The Tandon Corporation said it had sold the disk drive business on which the company was founded to the Western Digital Corporation for $49 million in cash and other considerations. Western Digital, of Irvine, Calif., a leading maker of computer storage, communications, video controller and logic-processing units, will also assume about $28 million in Tandon liabilities.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $851,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $2,077,000 for the year, and gains of $1.4 million and $6.1 million for the quarter and year, respectively, from property transactions. c-Includes a charge of $739,000 for the quarter, and the year incldes a gain on the extinguishment of debt of $17,894,000 and a $17,893,000 tax credit.

title: Soviet Will Tax Private Incomes On Scaled Basis
description: The Soviet Union is preparing to introduce a progressive income tax on individuals to curb the growing wealth of private business ventures, Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced in remarks published today.

title: Pound's Strong Gains Reflect Hot Economy
description: The recent calm in the foreign exchange markets has been shattered this week not by one of the world's three major currencies - the American dollar, the German mark and the Japanese yen - but by the second-tier British pound.

title: Foreigner Phobia
description: While Government officials and business executives are generally enthusiastic about foreign investment, the man in the street is not nearly as sanguine, according to a new poll.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PRINCEVILLE DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $181,496 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $251,910 from discontinued operations. The company noted that the unusual litigation and other expenses of $3,361,000 incurred in connection with an unsolicited takeover attempt in 1986 was the primary reason for the loss in that year.

title: Books of The Times; Epic America in a Woman's Quest
description: Dalva: By Jim Harrison. 324 pages. E. P. Dutton/ Seymour Lawrence. $18.95.

title: Chevron in Talks On Soviet Venture
description: The Chevron Corporation is talking with the Soviet Union about creating a joint venture in the petroleum business, a Chevron spokesman said. Chevron officials have repeatedly visited the Soviet Union in recent months to discuss business opportunities. On Friday, Nikolai Lemayev, the Soviet Minister of Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Industries, had discussions with Chevron officials in San Francisco.

title: Woman, 27, Fatally Stabbed In Hallway at Brooklyn Home
description: A 27-year-old woman was stabbed to death in the first-floor hallway of an apartment building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night, the police reported.

title: Macy Begins Its $6.1 Billion Federated Bid
description: R.H. Macy & Company began its $6.1 billion tender offer for Federated Department Stores yesterday. It also filed its expected lawsuit against the Campeau Corporation, seeking to postpone next Tuesday's expiration of Campeau's competing offer.

title: Sallie Mae Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association offered $500 million of 8.20 percent notes, due in 1993, through various securities dealers. The Sallie Mae notes, due in five years and two months, were offered at a price of 100 and yield about 37-hundredths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.

title: Lost Drivers Get Some Help
description: When you're lost in the Silicon Valley, there's no need to do something so low tech as to look at a map. The Navigation Technologies Corporation, a start-up based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has created a small computer that tells you where to go and how to get there by the most efficient route.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $58,000 and $47,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes losses from discontinued operations of $709,000 and $602,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary credit of $607,000.

title: Chicago
description: CHICAGO used to be a beer-with-brawny-food town. That changed in the 70's: singles bars and restaurant chains overtook the neighborhood tavern, and megabreweries swamped the beer market.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Hawks 143, Suns 113: Dominique Wilkins scored 41 points to lead the Hawks last night. Wilkins hit a half-court shot at the halftime buzzer, then sank another 3-pointer to open the second half and stake the Hawks to a 78-64 lead. A season-high point total allowed Atlanta to snap a three-game slump at home. Glenn Rivers had 19 assists for Atlanta, including a club-record 16 in the first half. Mark West led Phoenix with 23 points. (AP) Pacers 117, Pistons 104: Steve Stipanovich and Reggie Miller each scored 22 points as Indiana snapped a four-game losing streak. Vern Fleming had a triple-double of 18 points, 13 assists and 10 rebounds as the Pacers stopped the visiting Pistons' seven-game winning streak. Dennis Rodman led Detroit with 21 points. A scuffle between Stipanovich and Detroit's Bill Laimbeer resulted in a double technical with 8:08 remaining in the first half. Laimbeer appeared to get poked in the eye during the shoving match. Laimbeer then had to be restrained by a teammate, Rick Mahorn, from going after a referee.(AP) Trail Blazers 112, Mavericks 110: Jerome Kersey scored 33 points, and Clyde Drexler had 31 to help Portland win its sixth straight. Dallas, at home, had a chance to force an overtime, but Rolando Blackman missed on a drive to the basket with two seconds left.(AP) Bucks 119, Spurs 101: Terry Cummings scored 27 points, and Randy Breuer added 23 to lead Milwaukee to its ninth victory in the last 12 games. Paul Pressey scored 18 points and Ricky Pierce 17 for Milwaukee, which handed San Antonio its fifth consecutive road loss. The Spurs are 4-22 away from home this season. Alvin Robertson led the Spurs with 23 points.(AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 6, Whalers 4: Marc Fortier scored the first two goals of his National Hockey League career and Jeff Jackson also scored two goals last night to lead the Nordiques at home. The Nordiques, who are battling the Whalers for the final playoff spot in the Adams Division, moved within 3 points of Hartford. (AP) Red Wings 2, Bruins 0: Lee Norwood and Shawn Burr scored, and Glen Hanlon recorded his fourth shutout of the season in the home victory. The Red Wings played one man short for five minutes late in opening period and early in the second. Following a fight between Joe Kocur and Boston's Jay Miller, Kocur received a 10-minute match penalty because he was wearing tape on his hand. A league rule requires a match penalty if a player wearing tape injures an opponent during an altercation. Miller was cut in the fight.(AP) Tennis Pate Upsets Connors: Unseeded David Pate upset Jimmy Connors, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the $415,000 Du Pont Classic tournament in Orlando, Fla. Pate is ranked 20th in the world, Connors fifth. ''I used to idolize him,'' Pate said. ''It's hard to play someone you used to ballboy for.'' In another upset, Dan Cassidy, ranked 119th in the world, upset Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, seeded seventh, 6-0, 7-6.(AP) Graf Gains: Extending her winning streak to 27 matches, Steffi Graf beat Lisa Bonder, 6-1, 6-1, in 46 minutes in the second round of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Florida, at Boca Raton. Pam Shriver, seeded third, Raffaella Reggi of Italy, seeded eighth, and Nathalie Tauziat of France, seeded ninth, also advanced to the third round. (AP)

title: Whirlpool Pursues Deal With Roper
description: The Whirlpool Corporation indicated that it would try to complete its acquisition of the Roper Corporation despite the existence of a higher bid by the General Electric Company. The company issued a statement saying that it ''remains firmly committed to effecting the agreed upon transaction'' with Roper. Last month Roper agreed to be acquired by Whirlpool for $37.50 a share.

title: Sports People; Bird and Parish Out
description: Two members of the Boston front line, the forward Larry Bird and the center, Robert Parish, are expected to miss the Celtics' game tonight against San Antonio with injuries that could keep them sidelined longer. Bird has a fractured eye socket and a swollen left eye, and Parish is bothered by a recurrence of back problems. Both were hurt Sunday in a 127-98 victory over Cleveland.

title: Sports of The Times; Whose Fans Lead in the Lout Rankings?
description: IT has always been a matter of perverse civic pride that the absolute best and the absolute worst sports fans resided in New York. Sometimes they even resided in the same building, like hockey fans who levitated the Rangers into the Stanley Cup semifinals of 1986, while a few cretins chanted ''Get a Porsche'' at the Philadelphia goalies, referring to Pelle Lindbergh's death in a car crash.

title: U.S. Drops Banker Fine
description: The Comptroller of the Currency has dismissed proposed civil penalties against a former Michigan bank chairman accused of misusing bank funds.

title: Correction
description: The ''60-Minute Gourmet'' column in The Living Section on Feb. 24 omitted an instruction for an ingredient in sauerkraut with pork chops. The ingredient, apple cubes, should be added in step 6. along with the wine, bay leaf and thyme.

description: The United States and Britain vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have imposed an oil embargo and other sanctions against South Africa for its imposition of restrictions on 17 anti-apartheid groups.

title: Black Politicians Pressure Rodino to Retire
description: For 40 years, Peter W. Rodino Jr. has represented New Jersey's 10th District in Congress, earning a reputation as a civil-rights advocate as far back as 1957. But today the man who was floor manager for the 1966 Civil Rights Bill and who wrote the 1982 Voting Rights Act Extension is under pressure to retire, so that New Jersey can elect its first black Representative.

description: Rutgers University extended a campus-wide ban today on drinking at parties and formed a committee to study fraternities and sororities after the alcohol-related death of a student last month.

title: New York To Join Hollywood Strike
description: The movie industry settled down today to what everyone expects will be a long and bitter strike by 9,000 film and television writers. A spokesman for the eastern branch of the Writers Guild of America said that the first picketing in New York would take place Wednesday from noon to 2 P.M. outside the MGM Building at 1350 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Boston
description: IN this city, the name Legal has been associated for years with fresh and basically unadorned seafood. So it came as no small surprise to Boston restaurant patrons when the Legal Sea Foods restaurant chain announced last December that it would introduce exotic Chinese preparations to its already extensive menu.

Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, has been elected chairman of the board of the National Book Awards, effective May 1. He succeeds Lawrence Hughes, chairman of the Hearst Trade Book Group, whose year-long term as chairman expires at the end of April but who will remain a member of the board of directors.

description: Top executives of the Exxon Corporation told Wall Street analysts yesterday that they believed oil prices would average about $18 a barrel for the next few years despite the recent decline.

description: FOR several decades, milk producers have been packaging milk that stays fresh in sterile containers for about six months without refrigeration. Pending approval from the Food and Drug Administration, an over-the-counter formulation of Syntex's Naprosyn, the most widely prescribed anti-inflammatory drug used to treat arthritis in the United States, may be among the joint venture's products.

description: In a four-hour debate punctuated by unusually strong complaints about the state's school system, the Legislature today elected a Staten Island surgeon and a retired Eastman Kodak executive to the Board of Regents.

description: The Sandinista Government today canceled a negotiating session with contra representatives that was planned for Wednesday. The contras had earlier announced they would not attend.

Sonya Selby-Wright, a television producer, said her mother used to eat orchids. I used to eat honeysuckle, not to mention an occasional crystallized violet or rose petal.

description: Like a biblical prophet, it could be said that Sergei L. Petrov is a photographer not without honor, save in his own country. His pictures are displayed and published in the West, but he cannot find employment as a photographer in his own land.

title: Sports People; Renewal Likely
description: Officials at Seton Hall University have scheduled a news conference today and are expected to announce that P. J. Carlesimo will be retained as the school's head basketball coach. Carlesimo, who has guided Seton Hall to its first winning season in seven years, is expected to sign a four-year contract. The team's 20-11 record is the best in 32 years. Earlier this season, Carlesimo, whose teams had won 55 games and lost 88 in five previous seasons, seemed in danger of being dismmissed. But the Pirates began win-ning regularly and defeated Pitts-burgh, the Big East champion. twice.

title: About New York; Hunting Clues To Winter's End In Central Park
description: Word raced through the staff meetings in Central Park a couple of days back: snowdrops (galanthus nivalis) had been spotted blooming in the Conservatory Garden. It wasn't long after that Sarah Price, the curator, discovered a crocus near the women's room. Glory be! Could winter's back be broken? You should live so long. But just as sappy lovers have been known to mewl in parting, ''We'll always have Paris,'' the temporarily thawed tenant of this town will always have this week's flirtation with warmth. Only last minute stays of execution could feel as good as yesterday. (If you were not in shadow. Let's not lose our heads. It's not exactly time to spray for fruit flies yet.) ''It's a little bit early,'' Lorraine Devens said as she swung into a green (green!) Parks Department truck, one of those square-shouldered things named after a horse or an American Indian. ''But we'll see.'' Ms. Devens had given in to supplications from a man with thin blood who desperately sought the scantest sign of spring. Was there not, in fact, the hint of a sun's kiss upon her very cheek? She said she had been on holiday where you get that way, alas.

title: Martin Longstreth, 43, Exchange Chairman
description: Martin L. Longstreth Jr., chairman of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange since 1984, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Oreland, Pa. He was 43 years old.

title: Economic Scene; Faulty U.S. Logic In Cocaine Policy
description: CONGRESS and the Reagan Administration may be confounded by evidence of rising cocaine production and smuggling. But it comes as no surprise to the handful of economists who study the markets for illicit drugs that the Federal war on cocaine is being lost. They contend that relative simple economic analysis shows that the war is being fought on the wrong fronts with the wrong weapons. As they see it, the dramatic measures of progress on the battlefield - plants burned, powder seized - are virtually irrelevant to the long-term prospects for victory.

title: Inquiry Into Denver Jet Crash Looks at Possible Ice Buildup
description: A Continental Airlines jet that crashed in Denver last November, killing 28 people, waited 24 minutes in a snowstorm between de-icing and takeoff while other aircraft were taking off only 15 minutes after de-icing, an investigator said today.

title: LaRouche Lawyers Seek F.B.I. Files
description: Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and six of his followers, who are charged in a fraud conspiracy, are expected to be told at a hearing Wednesday whether the Government will turn over Federal documents their lawyers said could be grounds for dismissal of the case.

title: China's Surplus Workers
description: China has 20 million surplus workers in its work force of 132 million, the official China Daily said today. However, it added, there are manpower shortages in work requiring heavy labor.

title: Another Strawberry Strikeout
description: TWO weeks after Davey Johnson fined Darryl Strawberry $250 for arriving late for batting practice in Chicago last season, the Mets' right fielder finally apologized to the Mets' manager. And when somebody mentioned that to Davey Johnson in his Shea Stadium office a few days later, he glanced at the ceiling and shook his head. ''Wonders never cease,'' he said. And as the Mets continue to discover to their dismay, the wonders of Darryl Strawberry never cease. Just when it seems that maybe their 26-year-old slugger is maturing as the 1988 season approaches, he shows that he's still capable of embarrassing himself. In a verbal strafing of the Mets' clubhouse that will appear in the upcoming issue of Esquire magazine, Straw identifies Davey Johnson, Keith Hernandez, Gary Carter, Lenny Dystra and Wally Backman as the primary culprits for last year's second-place finish. But he chose to ignore Dwight Gooden's nine-week absence for drug rehab. And perhaps out of modesty, he never mentioned his own negative contributions.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Celtics 119, Spurs 118: Dennis Johnson hit two free throws to put Boston ahead with 15 seconds left and then blocked Jon Sundvold's shot with two seconds remaining last night to lead the Celtics at home. Johnson scored Boston's last 6 points after San Antonio used a 10-point run to take a 116-113 lead with 1:31 left. Johnson scored two baskets to put the Celtics ahead, 117-116, with 56 seconds left. Mike Mitchell, who led San Antonio with 20 points, then made a jumper to give the Spurs a 118-117 lead with 37 seconds remaining. Then Johnson was fouled by Frank Brickowski after grabbing an offensive rebound and sank the winning points. Larry Bird, playing for the first time with goggles to protect a fractured left eye socket, led Boston with 36 points. The Celtics established a league mark by attempting 21 3-point field goals. They hit six of them. (AP) Pistons 103, Jazz, 98: Bill Laimbeer scored 21 of his 27 points in the first half as the Pistons, playing at home, snapped Utah's five-game winning streak. (AP) Cavaliers 117, Bucks 91: Ron Harper scored 23 points as the Cavaliers ended a six-game losing streak by topping the injury-riddled Bucks. Cleveland scored the final 7 points of the second quarter to take a 56-44 lead. The visiting Bucks never got closer than 9 after that.(AP) Bullets 115, Suns 111: Moses Malone scored 8 of his 24 points in the final four minutes as the Bullets rallied for their seventh straight victory. The Bullets' streak is their longest since November 1984. Washington, which led, 91-77, after three quarters, trailed by 100-97 with 4:29 left. John Williams's layup cut the lead to 1 point and Malone hit two free throws to put the Bullets ahead to stay.(AP) N.H.L. Whalers 5, Kings 4: Ray Ferraro scored his second goal of the game with 6 minutes 13 seconds remaining last night to lead Hartford at home. Paul MacDermid added a goal and two assists as the Whalers swept the season series from the Kings. The victory moved the Whalers 5 points ahead of idle Quebec in the battle for the final playoff berth in the Adams Division. (AP) TENNIS Wilander, Becker Upset: Jay Berger ousted top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden yesterday, 6-0, 7-5, and Boris Becker and Andres Gomez were also eliminated in second-round matches of the Du Pont Classic, at Orlando, Fla. Amos Mansdorf of Israel beat the fourth-seeded Becker, of West Germany, 6-4, 6-4, and Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union rallied to eliminate the fifth-seeded Gomez, of Ecuador, 3-6, 6-1, 6-3. ''I wasn't psyched in the beginning,'' said Wilander, who was playing in his first tournament since winning the Australian Open. ''I got going a bit in the second set, but Jay got tough and played really well.''(AP) Graf Advances: Steffi Graf had trouble with her serve, but the top-seeded West German swept past Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-2, 6-1, to reach the quarterfinals of the Virginia Slims tournament in Boca Raton, Fla. Earlier, Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina, seeded fourth, beat Wendy Turnbull of Australia, 6-1, 6-1. (AP)

title: Advertising; People
description: * Daisy Exposito has been appointed senior vice president at Young & Rubicam New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1988
description: International A3-12

title: S.E.C., in Filing, Challenges New York Takeover Law
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission submitted a friend-of-the-court brief in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday arguing that New York State's anti-takeover law is unconstitutional.

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The company said the latest 6-month includes a charge of $1.3 million from an unfavorable judgement in litigation. Year-ago second quarter and 6-month are restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: VULCAN PACKAGING reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Writers Union Strikes Oscars Show
description: Union television writers have halted work on the script for next month's Academy Awards ceremony, and CBS shelved two new shows as a result of the strike by the Writers Guild of America.

title: Mets Meet on Criticism by Strawberry
description: Dave Johnson tried to contain the latest war of words engulfing the Mets when he closed the locker room door today, called a team meeting and ordered his players to quit sniping at one another.

title: Koch Says He Would Like to Have Black or Hispanic Running Mates
description: Mayor Koch, seeking to defuse what he predicts will be a significant challenge to his re-election bid next year, says he would like to campaign with black and Hispanic running mates.

title: The House Call Makes a Comeback With New Concept of Team Care
description: The medical house call, once considered a relic of a simpler past, is making a comeback, according to many doctors and home care specialists.

title: Army, Bell Helicopter Said to Settle
description: Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. has agreed to return $90 million to the Government to settle allegations that it fraudulently overcharged the Army on helicopter spare parts, Pentagon sources said tonight.

title: WILTON ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL OPEC is studying a plan to reduce oil output by 5 percent, several officials of the organization said. The proposal is intended to address the slide in oil prices, which have recently fallen to $13 to $14 a barrel, from OPEC's official price of $18. Non-OPEC oil producers met in London. Egypt's oil minister, who arranged the talks, said the group would like to work with OPEC to reduce production and bolster prices. [ Page D1. ] Treasury Secretary Baker said Japan might be asked to pay a far greater share for its national security. Mr. Baker's comments were the first indication that ''burden sharing'' has become a major economic issue for the Administration. [ D1. ] COMPANIES United Artists Communications and United Cable will merge in a cash-and-stock transaction valued at about $1.6 billion. The complex deal will create the nation's third-largest cable company. Tele-Communications, the largest cable company, will own about 52 percent of the new company. [ D1. ] Bell Helicopter has agreed to return $90 million to the U.S. Government to settle allegations that it fraudulently overcharged the Army, Pentagon sources said. Six jurors are trying to put a price on the life of a man who, some say, might have become chairman of I.B.M. Lawyers for the estate of Philip D. Estridge, who died in a 1985 plane crash, have asked Delta for $25 million. [ D2. ] Grumman will reduce its Long Island work force by 2,300, laying off 600 workers. Grumman, one of the nation's biggest military contractors, is Long Island's largest employer. [ B3. ] Campeau's bid for Federated could end, or gain impetus, at a Federal court hearing in Manhattan next week. [ D4. ] Unisys struck deals with A.T.&T. and Sun Microsystems aimed at improving its competitive position among the growing number of computer makers using the Unix operating system. [ D4. ] Texaco is concluding negotiations to borrow $3 billion from a consortium of banks, so as to emerge from bankruptcy. [ D4. ] THE ECONOMY Mortgage interest rates registered their sharpest decline since 1986, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said. Rates fell for the fourth month in a row, with fixed-rate mortgages of 15 years and longer averaging 10.50 percent. [ D6. ] The S.E.C. asked a Federal court to overturn New York's anti-takeover law, arguing that the statute unconstitutionally interfered with the rights of stockholders to determine the fate of their companies and interfered with interstate commerce. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices were mixed, with smaller issues again doing relatively better than blue chips. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,074.27, down 6.80 points. [ D6. ] Bond traders and investors remained on the sidelines, in the third consecutive day of listless activity with no substantial change in interest rates. [ D12. ] Yields were down slightly on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D15. ] The dollar was mostly higher but world markets remained focused on the surging pound. Gold rose 45 cents in New York, to $436.15 an ounce. [ D14. ] Copper futures settled at their highest levels in three weeks on signs of tightening supplies and rising demand. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The junk bond market is showing strong signs of a revival, raising the prospect that the high-yield securities could become the fuel in a growing flurry of mergers and buyouts. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Earnings estimates are being trimmed for Digital Equipment, but many computer analysts view the stock favorably. The company, whose mid-size Vax computers have been well received, announced earlier this week that it would challenge I.B.M.'s mainframes. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: A Nephew of Former Leader Breaks Ranks With Noriega
description: A nephew of the former Panamanian military leader, Omar Torrijos Herrera, said today that he had broken with the Government and accused it of plunging Panama into a crisis.

title: ACCEL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $101,000 for both the quarter and year, capital losses of $8,000 for the quarter, and the year includes gains of $2,107,000 from stock transactions of an unconsolidated subsidiary and realized gains on investments of $690,000. c-Includes realized gains on investments of $310,000 and $1,777,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Case Heard on Death of an I.B.M. Official
description: In a small Federal courtroom in lower Manhattan, six jurors are trying to put a price on the life of a man who, some say, might have become chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Chinatown Day Center: A Haven for 80, but 500 Must Wait
description: AFTER nap time and snack time, it was story time at the Garment Industry Day Care Center of Chinatown. The children squirmed and looked serious as the teacher began to read the adventures of Detective Mickey Mouse. Finally, when Goofy came into the story, there was silence and a galaxy of gap-toothed smiles.

title: Currents; When Inspiration strikes Twice
description: A. GF Furniture Systems' 40/4 chair, designed by David Rowland and introduced in 1965.

title: John Cullen Dies at 86; Ex-Investment Banker
description: John L. Cullen, a retired investment banker, died of cardiac arrest Saturday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Cost of Clean Air Bill Assailed
description: A bill revising the Clean Air Act would be likely to cost the economy $32 billion and 300,000 to 600,000 manufacturing jobs, a business group told a Congressional committee today.

title: Rachel Carson's Legacy
description: SHORTLY after World War II, when my life as a young gardener began, another war broke out, and I do not mean the cold war or the one in Korea. Most American gardeners, my parents included, eagerly enlisted in an army that had powerful new weapons.

title: Temple Captures Atlantic 10 Title
description: Tim Perry's 3-point play with 3 minutes 44 seconds left helped turn back a Rhode Island comeback as Temple scored a 68-63 victory tonight to capture the Atlantic 10 tournament title.

title: A New Director at Modern as Fashion Plate
description: It's a rare event in the art world that can still evoke a double take. But it happened last Sunday morning when Kirk Varnedoe, soon to become the director of the painting and sculpture department at the Museum of Modern Art, appeared in a full-page ad for Barneys New York on page 13 of The New York Times Magazine.

title: 2 MORE ARE KILLED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Two Palestinians were shot and killed today, one by a Jewish settler, as the Palestinian revolt in the occupied territories entered its fourth month, according to Palestinian reports and to other accounts.

title: Migration to America 33,000 Years Ago Hinted
description: Radiocarbon dating of charcoal found with ancient stone tools in southern Chile has bolstered the argument of some experts that humans lived in the Americas 33,000 years ago, much earlier than is generally accepted, anthropologists reported yesterday.

title: Nuclear Agency Officials Defend Reactor Security
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has yet to require the utility industry to install the same security against terrorist bombings that is provided members of Congress at the Capitol, a House subcommittee was told today.

title: LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes non-recurring credit of $5,035,000, or 26 cents a share, from the elimination of an estimated liability for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a non-recurring charge of $1,690,000 from the early repayment of a bank term loan.

title: HORBECK OFFSHORE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Unisys Obtains Pacts For Unix Capabilities
description: The Unisys Corporation yesterday announced technology pacts with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Sun Microsystems Inc. aimed at improving its competitive position among the growing number of computer makers using A.T.&T.'s Unix operating system.

title: SYNERCOM TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and includes a $29,000 tax credit.

title: Texaco Nears $3 Billion Loan
description: Texaco Inc. is concluding negotiations with a consortium of 20 to 30 banks to borrow the $3 billion that it says it needs to come out of bankruptcy, the company said yesterday.

title: College Basketball; F.D.U. Gains Metro Conference Final
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University moved a step closer to a National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament berth tonight, but only after surviving a melee at halftime and a late scare from Long Island University.
