title: Market Place; Digital Equipment Is Still a Favorite
description: ALTHOUGH earnings estimates are being trimmed for the Digital Equipment Corporation - a spectacular performer in the closing years of the bull market - many computer analysts view the stock favorably.

title: Mobil Plans to Sell Additional Assets
description: The Mobil Corporation said it expects to get another $500 million from asset sales in 1988 in addition to the $1.5 billion in cash it will receive from its deal to sell the Montgomery Ward retailing business. Mobil's president, Richard Tucker, told securities analysts that the additional $500 million would come from the sale of ''dribs and drabs'' in the company. He would not elaborate.

title: SUMMA MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $5.4 million gain on the sale of pharmacy assets; the company did not give share earnings for the latest quarter. c-Net loss

title: Bridge: Contract May Be a Puzzle, Even With 4 Hands Visible
description: One of the principal challenges of bridge is to find the best contract for you and your partner without being able to see the other hands. The challenge would be trivial if you could see all 52 cards. True or false?

title: A Big, Quiet Rally in Small Stocks
description: Huge corporate takeovers have grabbed the stock market's spotlight since January. But these splashy moves have overshadowed a quiet and powerful rally in small stocks.

title: Chip Indicator Is Up Again
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to improve in February, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported their third consecutive month with more than $1 billion in orders, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry

title: IVERSON TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.M.F. Loan to Sri Lanka
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $343 million loan to help with economic reform in Sri Lanka. The I.M.F. said that, of the total, $194 million would be available over the next three years, of which $61 million could be drawn immediately.

title: Nello Santi, an Italian Maestro 'Discovered' at 56
description: Opera singers are rarely eager to let on that they read the papers, but the baritone Sherrill Milnes, just once, couldn't resist asking a critic about a review - and it wasn't even about him. ''Are you the one,'' he wanted to know, ''who finally gave Nello Santi a good review?''

title: Austria Asks: Accomplice of Nazis, or Victim?
description: At the center of an exhibition that opens Thursday in the Vienna City hall is a wooden platform that the contemporary Austrian is encouraged to mount to look out over a broad tree-lined lane leading to the ornate Burgtheater.

title: A Plea to Slow Down
description: The heads of two of South Korea's biggest business concerns, Samsung and Daewoo, which rank among the largest companies in the world, visited Washington this week with a message of caution for American business and Government leaders:

title: Kurt Kiesinger, 60's Bonn Leader And Former Nazi, Is Dead at 83
description: Kurt Georg Kiesinger, the third Chancellor of West Germany, died of heart failure yesterday in the university hospital in Tubingen. He was 83 years old.

title: Jock Semple, Marathon Official
description: John Duncan (Jock) Semple, who was involved wih the Boston Marathon for six decades but will always be remembered for chasing down a woman who entered illegally in 1967, died today. He was 84 years old.

title: Banks Tread Cautiously On Panamanian Debts
description: Banks around the world that have lent money to Panama are trying to avoid taking sides in the political battle over who represents the Government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If someone had told me 23 years ago when we walked across that bridge - I couldn't register and vote in Alabama; my mother and father couldn't vote in 1965 - if someone had told me I would have the opportunity to vote for a black man for President, I would have said, 'You're out of your mind.' '' - Representative John Lewis of Georgia. [ A1:5. ]

title: TRANS-INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net investment income of $905,583 for the quarter and year. c-Included net investment income of $511,566 for the quarter and year. d-Net loss

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $35,000 and $79,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 20.

title: Lois 8Wilson, Actress Of Stage, Television And Silent-Film Era
description: Lois Wilson, an actress who appeared in more than 100 early films including the 1923 Western epic ''The Covered Wagon,'' died of pneumonia on March 3 at Riverside Hospital for Skilled Care. She was 93 years old.

title: LABATT, JOHN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: End of the Case Is 'Imminent,' Judge Tells Chambers Jurors
description: The judge in the murder case of Robert E. Chambers Jr. told the jury yesterday that the end of the trial was ''imminent'' after nearly 10 weeks of testimony and that the defense could complete its case as early as today.

title: Advertising; The Circus Is Coming, The Circus Is Coming
description: In marvelously capitalistic fashion, the Moscow Circus on its next North American tour will be sponsored by Snuggle Fabric Softener from Lever Brothers.

title: SHAMIR SAYS NOTE BY SENATORS STIRS QUESTIONS ON U.S.
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel replied with astonishment today to a letter signed by 30 United States senators criticizing him for rejecting an exchange of ''territory for peace'' on the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He said the letter raised questions about the American commitment to the Camp David accords of 1978.

title: UNITIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
From Fiber and Smudges, Questions in Brawley Case
description: New details in the Tawana Brawley case - cotton-like wadding, smudged gloves, traces of drugs and heat turned up in a vacant apartment - have raised fresh questions about the teen-ager's sketchy account of abduction and sexual abuse by a group of white men in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., last November.

title: CHARIOT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago figures are restated to retroactively include the results of an acquired company.

title: INSIDE
description: A New Capital for Japan?

title: The Delegates Count
Officer in Haiti Indicted By U.S. on Drug Counts
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Haitian Army officer who witnesses say allowed drug traffickers to use his private landing strip for cocaine shipments bound for the United States.

title: Swedish Merger For $983 Million
description: The Swedish forestry company Stora Kopparbergs Bergslags A.B. will merge with Swedish Match A.B. in a deal valued at $983 million for Swedish Match's owners. Both Stora and Swedish Match, which a year ago bought Wilkinson Sword from Allegheny International Inc. of Pittsburgh, are part of the group controlled by Sweden's influential Wallenberg family. The family's head, Peter Wallenberg, said he was supporting the bid, making its acceptance certain.

title: Super Tuesday Primaries: The Results
description: The table below gives results of the primary elections for President held Tuesday in 16 states. The columns indicate the vote for each candidate, his percentage of the total, the delegates won, and the percentage of the total delegates. Where total delegates in a state do not add to 100 percent, the preference of one or more delegates has not been determined.

title: DYNASCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $224,000 and $68,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain on the disposition of the discontinued operations of $1,538,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and a loss of $15,000 for the year. The company said the financial statements have been restated to reflect discontinued operations of the company's industrial segment.

title: U.S. Informs China High-Tech Exports Could Be Widened
description: The Reagan Administration is considering relaxing restrictions on the export of high technology to China after determining that China is no longer selling Silkworm missiles to Iran, Administration officials said today.

title: Afghanistan Faces Massive Return of Refugees; 'The Great Game'
description: To the Editor:

title: STEVENS GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago full year results are pro forma and adjusted to reflect the acquisition of Hamilton Tool Co., which was acquired on Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Metro Datelines column on Saturday about the sentencing of a doctor, Nirmal Kade, in a Medicaid fraud case misstated the address of the Brooklyn clinic where she practiced. The clinic, the Fulton Medical and Dental Clinic, is at 1204 Fulton Street.

title: Ex-Mecham Aide Tells State Senate of Threat
description: A former top aide to Gov. Evan Mecham testified today that she called a newspaper after she was told that a state official had threatened her life because she thought she would be safer if she made the matter public.

title: Afghanistan Faces Massive Return of Refugees; Trouble in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis and Iranians Continue Missile Attacks on Capitals
description: Missiles exploded in Baghdad and Teheran today, the 10th day of missile attacks on civilian targets in Iran and Iraq that have killed or wounded hundreds of people.

title: Review/Orchestra; Baltimore Symphony In Premiere
description: In a splendid, sweeping performance by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, John Harbison's First Symphony made a bold and stirring impression at its New York premiere on Monday evening in Carnegie Hall.

title: STERNER LIGHTING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No. 2 Purdue Is Upset
description: Jerry Francis scored 14 points, including 6 in an 11-2 spurt that turned the game round in the second half, as Ohio State upset No. 2 Purdue, 71-60, in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: SYMBION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring costs of $732,000 related to the company's response to a tender offer from Warburg, Pincus Capital Co.

title: Art Finds a Way at Soviet-American Festival
description: If language were the only obstacle, the Soviet-American cultural exchange Making Music Together would be a model international effort.

title: Medical-Test Pioneer Hails Growth in Field
description: William C. O'Neil Jr.'s industry -medical testing - has grown dramatically in the last decade, and so has International Clinical Laboratories Inc., the company he heads.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ADVANCED CIRCUITS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Net income c-Includes a gain for both the quarter and 6 months of $1,737,000.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Royal Dutch's share earnings for the latest periods were $3.62 a share for the quarter and $11.31 for the year, compared with $2.30 a share and $8.65 a share, for the same year-ago periods, respectively. Shell Transport's share earnings for the 1987 periods were $1.98 a share for the quarter and $6.24 a share for the year, compared with $1.38 a share and $4.78 a share for the year-ago quarter and year, respectively. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Melanoma Victims Often Slow to Act
description: The early signs of malignant melanoma are too often unrecognized or ignored by doctors and patients until it is too late for treatment, a new study indicates.

title: Home Truths, Hard Truths
description: The Palestinian terrorist attack on an Israeli bus deepens one's sense of foreboding for the Middle East. How can we hope for a negotiated way out of the conflict when the P.L.O. uses the tactic of murderous assault on civilians?

title: Armed Against Birds, Bomber Set for Duty
description: The first B-1B bomber to be strengthened against damage by birds was cleared for flight training today, allowing the Air Force to fly a low-altitude training mission for the first time in more than five months.

title: PERPETUAL SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,631,000 which included a prepayment penalty of $307,000 on borrowings and a gain of $1,938,000 on early retirement of debt. The latest quarter net also included a gain on the sale of the Washington Building in Washington, D.C., of $39,407,000. This gain was partially offset by the impact of writing down the value of several of the bank's non- performing assets and increasing the provision for possible losses. The bank also said it provided $4.5 million to its reserve for possible losses.

title: Tuesday's Crossover Voters
description: Eight of the Southern and border states allow voters to cast ballots in either party's primary, regardless of their party registration. The states are Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Mississippi, Missouri, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia.

title: Two Organ Premieres
description: The organist Leonard Raver will play the world premieres of David Diamond's Symphony for Organ and Gardner Read's ''Phantasmagoria'' for organ and English horn, Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. Thomas Stacy will be the horn soloist for the latter work. Also on the program are Louis Marchand's ''Dialogue sur les Grands Jeux,'' Bach's Fantasia and Fugue in G minor, the Liszt Prelude and Fugue on B-A-C-H and Persichetti's Prelude and Toccata (Op. 144).

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $188,000 and a gain of $12,949,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, both on the disposal of discontinued operations, and the year also includes income from discontinued operations of $320,000. c-Net loss d-After a gain of $3,456,000 for the quarter and income of $5,071,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said 1986 results include an unusual after-tax charge of $34,774,000 from a writedown of non- current assets.

title: DEMOCRATS THINK TUESDAY'S RESULTS MEAN A LONG RACE
description: A three-way dead heat in the Super Tuesday primaries and caucuses almost certainly foretells a four-month struggle for the Democratic Presidential nomination, party leaders agreed yesterday.

title: Savings Unit Loan Pledge
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board issued a long-expected resolution today to reassure uneasy Wall Street securities firms that have lent funds to the Financial Corporation of America's ailing savings unit, the American Savings and Loan Association.

title: Japanese to Buy U.S. Grain Hauler
description: C.Itoh & Company and the National Federation of Agriculture Cooperative Associations will join forces to buy the Consolidated Grain and Barge Company, an American grain transporter based in St. Louis, C. Itoh officials said. They said they expect to sign an agreement to buy Consolidated Grain and Barge, which has 30 elevators and 650 barges along the Mississippi River, late next month. Terms have not yet been worked out. The acquisition of the American grain transport company should help to stabilize agricultural supplies and improve the quality of goods sold in Japan, the officials said. Consolidated handles around five million metric tons of corn, soybean and sorghum a year.

title: Times Plans a New Edition in San Francisco
description: A newly designed edition of The New York Times, with a new daily section called The Living Arts, is to be introduced in the San Francisco area starting April 4, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, has announced.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $4 million from an accounting change. The revenue figures for the year- ago periods have been restated.

title: Detecting Pneumonia Easier
description: A rare, deadly form of pneumonia that is a common affliction of AIDS patients can be more easily detected by using a new method of analyzing a patient's lung fluid, researchers have reported.

title: Books of The Times; The Allure of Elephants, In Their Grace and Folly
description: Elephant Memories: Thirteen Years in the Life of an Elephant Family. By Cynthia Moss. Illustrated. 336 pages. William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

description: LIKE most architects and industrial designers, Stefano Carmi is particularly aware of the design of everyday items. Neckties, for example.

title: After Super Tuesday; Turnout in South Seen As Boon for the G.O.P.
description: The crumbling remnants of the solid Democratic South were dealt another blow in Tuesday's primaries, when hundreds of thousands more people voted in Republican primaries than had ever done so before.

description: John A. Mulheren, the major arbitrager who is accused of threatening Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted insider trader, remained at the Metropolitan Correctional Center last night, awaiting an appeals court hearing this morning on whether he can be transferred to the private Carrier Foundation, a clinic in Belle Mead, N.J., as desired by his family. Late yesterday, Robert

title: Safe-Sex Version of a Pornographic Film
description: When Elisa Florez was studying political science at Georgetown University in 1984 she did not know what AIDS was.

title: Firefighters Battle Law Requiring New Licensing
description: Firefighters across the country are incensed about a Federal law that could require them to obtain commercial licenses if they wanted to continue to drive fire vehicles.

title: Atlantic Air Traffic Gain
description: More than 25.8 million passengers flew across the North Atlantic in 1987, a 21.7 percent rise from the previous year, the International Air Transport Association said today. David Kyd, a spokesman for the Geneva-based association, said that the number of North Atlantic passengers in 1986 totaled only 21.1 million as Americans stayed away from Europe because of the dollar's weakness, fear of terrorism and concern about the fallout from the Chernobyl accident.

title: A Rude Awakening for Some Contest 'Winners'
description: Believing they had won a $2 million sweepstakes offered by a California mail-order company, Kathy and Dale Work bought a pickup truck and a new car and were about to quit their jobs. Then they learned they hadn't won a thing.

title: Phoenix Journal; Her Life's Work (Not So Oddly) Is Matching Shoes With Feet
description: Jeanne Sallman's ranch house here is stuffed with boxes of shoes - anything from a skinhead's black leather stomping fantasy to a disco dancer's Day-Glo chartreuse pump.

title: What the Market Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Desert Partners' Bid Is Rejected
description: The board of directors of the USG Corporation has rejected a hostile takeover bid of $42 a share, or $1.9 billion, from Desert Partners L.P., as ''wholly inadequate'' and ''coercive.''

title: Peremptory Challenges By Defense Are Upheld
description: A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that judges cannot bar defense lawyers from excluding potential jurors on the basis of race, sex, religion or national origin.

title: Nothing Is Easy for Rangers' Patrick
description: James Patrick might have guessed it wasn't going to be as easy as it looked. The New Jersey goal was empty, the path to it clear, the chances for the Ranger defenseman's second goal of the night apparently excellent. Patrick, who never put the puck in the net, would eventually be credited with the goal anyway, thereby providing the Rangers with their final score in a 7-4 pounding of the Devils at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.

title: EVEREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the second quarter earnings reflect the December 1987 acquisition of Abaton Technology Corp.

title: Supporter of LaRouche Wins Democratic Post in Houston
description: Local Democratic leaders here spent the day trying to explain how a supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the extremist politician, was elected Tuesday as chairman of the Harris County Democratic Party.

title: 5 Rockettes Sue Show Over Use of Name
description: The producers say ''Can-Can.'' The Rockettes - the real Rockettes, not the phony ones - say ''Can't, can't,'' and they're suing to press the point.

title: Advertising; Britain's No. 1 Shop Created: BSB/Dorland
description: SAATCHI & SAATCHI is merging the Backer Spielvogel Bates and Dorland Advertising offices in London to form BSB/Dorland. This creates the biggest ad agency in Britain, with annual billings of some $500 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Monday about legislation to permit the building of a new Federal judiciary building taller than the District of Columbia's 80-foot limit described the hearing procedure incorrectly. The Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works sent notices that its Subcommittee on Water Resources, Transportation and Infrastructure would hold a hearing Feb. 3.

title: First Ladies Step Further Out of Shadows
description: In her husband's Presidency, Nancy Reagan has received her share of scrutiny, analysis, criticism and praise, along with President Reagan.

title: Investors Remain on the Sidelines
description: Bond traders and investors remained on the sidelines yesterday, resulting in the third consecutive day of listless activity with no substantial change in interest rates.

title: One Man's Crusade Against Lawn Darts
description: David Snow vividly remembers the day last April when a stray lawn dart struck his 7-year-old daughter in the head as she played with her dolls in the front yard of his house.

title: MAGMA POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $321,000 for the quarter and $1,447,000 for the year. c-Net loss and after tax loss carryforwards of $210,000 for the quarter and $591,000 for the year.

title: 5% Output Cut Studied By OPEC
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is studying a plan to reduce its oil output about 5 percent, equivalent to 850,000 barrels a day for all its members with the exception of Iraq, several OPEC officials said today.

MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Disney Files Suits Against 15 Stores
description: Turning up the heat on retailers of counterfeit goods, the Walt Disney Company said it had filed a lawsuit in Federal court in New York against 15 independent New York variety stores that the company accused of selling toy Mickey Mouse telephones imported from Taiwan last year.

The latest year also includes the following pretax items: net gains from transactions involving Medirace Plc totaling $1,118,006, a loss from amortization of intangibles of $155,000, and a gain of $60,500 representing net interest and investment income. Latest year figures reflect the restatement of third quarter results involving a $480,000 writedown in connection with Medirace holdings and due to a SEC ruling.

title: Mortgage Rates Off Sharply; Decline Is Fourth in a Row
description: Interest rates on mortgage commitments dropped for the fourth consecutive month and registered the sharpest decline since 1986, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: Finding the Work
description: THESE stores carry furniture by artisans of the Southwest:

title: America Turns Left
description: With no dominant or polarizing personality on the political scene - no Roosevelt or Eisenhower, no Nixon or Reagan -we should not be asking ourselves ''Who is winning?'' so much as ''What is winning?'' To help us see what direction America is taking, let us use the prism of the losers.

title: Killing of I.R.A. Suspects Angers Thatcher Critics
description: Critics of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher are demanding an inquiry into the fatal shooting of three Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar, contending that the episode had created fresh martyrs for the Irish Republican Army.

title: 100 Yank Games to Cable
description: SportsChannel, the cable-television company, announced yesterday that it will show 100 Yankee games this season. WPIX, Channel 11, will carry only 40 Yankee games. Fans without a SportsChannel subscription could feel the pinch in the pennant run in September, when SportsChannel has 21 Yankee games to WPIX's 4.

title: Computer Concern to Sign Metrotech Lease
description: The Securities Industry Automation Corporation is to sign lease agreements today for space in Metrotech, a huge development planned for downtown Brooklyn.

title: Jets Trade Bennett
description: The Jets traded Barry Bennett, the 32-year-old defensive lineman, to the Los Angeles Raiders yesterday for an undisclosed draft choice. Bennett was one of five players 30 years old or older whom the Jets cut recently. He had been on recallable waivers since then, and when the Raiders picked him off the waiver wire, the Jets simply recalled him. That allowed the club to work out a deal with Los Angeles. Joe Klecko, the nose tackle who had also been cut by the Jets, was released outright yesterday. He is still being considered by other teams. The Jets had no word on whether any teams had expressed interest in the other dropped players: Joe Fields, Dave Jennings and Gordon King.

title: Review/Music; Sinfonova, Bostonians Who Play With Elan
description: Musical groups with distinct personalities aren't that common today, but the Sinfonova Chamber Orchestra - which came from Boston for a Carnegie Hall concert Sunday night - does seem to have its own voice. The real speaker is apparently the group's conductor, Aram Gharabekian, who worships at the altars of forward melodic movement and beautiful sound.

title: Utilities Are Directed to Seek Bids From Small Companies
description: In an effort to reduce the cost of electricity, New York's Public Service Commission decided today that utilities will have to allow small, independent power companies to bid to supply them with electricity.

title: Review/Oratorio
description: How ironic that Alessandro Stradella, one of music history's more rakish figures, should have composed a magnificent oratorio on the folly of injudicious lust barely a year before he was assassinated in consequence of an adulterous liaison.

title: Expert Advice
description: According to Postmaster J. Robert Tracey of Morristown, N.J., a higher-than-normal number of postal carriers slipped and fell on ice this winter. The solution? Enter Randy Velischek, defenseman for the Devils. Velischek will speak at the Morristown post office from 8 A.M. to 10 A.M. on Tuesday to tell carriers how to avoid trips, slips and falls on ice. Carriers from other post offices and the public are invited.(AP)

title: Reward for Carlesimo
description: P. J. Carlesimo, Seton Hall's head basketball coach, received a new five-year contract yesterday after guiding the Pirates to their best season in 32 years. The signing ended months of speculation on whether Carlesimo would be back. He compiled a 54-92 mark in his previous five seasons at Seton Hall and may have saved his job with this season's 20-11 record and an 8-8 Big East mark. The Pirates will meet Georgetown in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament tomorrow and appear in line for their first bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. ''I'm happy,'' said Carlesimo. ''I like it here. I like the Big East. I didn't, to be perfectly candid, think I wouldn't be here. I'm not being smart. I am very appreciative.'' Salary figures were not disclosed, but Carlesimo said his pay would be commensurate with that of other Big East coaches. Carlesimo reportedly made $50,000 this season, about half of what other Big East coaches make.(AP)

title: 2 Cable Companies Set $1.6 Billion Merger
description: United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation said yesterday that they would merge, creating the nation's third-largest cable company. Analysts valued the complex cash-and-stock transaction at about $1.6 billion.

title: National Service, From the Bottom Up
description: Despite the virtual certainty of a Presidential veto, national youth service has become a hardy legislative perennial in Washington. At least seven bills dealing with the issue have bloomed again in the current Congress. While all have merit, national service may be best achieved from the bottom up rather than the top down.

title: An Old Pro
description: Seventy-year-old Joe Redington, the second-oldest musher in the field, is leading the Iditarod sled-dog race, a grueling 1,150-mile course from Anchorage to Nome, Alaska. He dashed out of the checkpoint at McGrath yesterday saying, ''I feel like an old fox being chased by 50 young hounds.'' Redington left the town on the Kuskokwim River after staying just over four hours to feed and rest his 14 dogs. He is known as the Father of the Iditarod, a race he helped create 16 years ago but has never won. Redington arrived in McGrath, 410 miles into the race, about four hours ahead of Herbie Nayokpuk. Behind them were Jan Masek of Anchorage in third, and Joe Garnie of Teller in fourth. Redington, Nayokpuk and Garnie took their layovers early in the race. That turned out to be a successful strategy, because a pack of about 20 leading mushers later bogged down in new snow. As those mushers took their 24-hour layover at the Rohn Roadhouse, they watched helplessly as Redington, Nayokpuk and Garnie sailed past on the smooth trail the former leaders had packed.(AP)

title: Talking Deals; Signs of Revival For Junk Bonds
description: WHEN the stock market crashed in October, many on Wall Street expected takeover activity to stall, largely because junk bonds, those speculative high-yield securities that backed many deals, became too costly to issue. Fearful of a recession, investors demanded, and got, a higher return for accepting the securities' greater risk.

title: Take the Postal Service Out of the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Mansouri Offered Post At San Francisco Opera
description: Lotfi Mansouri, the Iranian-born head of the Canadian Opera in Toronto, has been offered the job of general director of the San Francisco Opera.

title: Metro Matters; Woman Boards Bus and Is Stuck In a Legal Jam
description: On Oct. 13, 1976, Roslyn Marinoff boarded the M-10 bus on West Broadway to return home from lunch at the World Trade Center. Instead, she was taken for a ride that hasn't ended yet.

title: 17 DIE IN COLLISION OF ARMY COPTERS
description: Two Army helicopters collided on a training missing Tuesday night, killing all 17 soldiers aboard, the Army said.

description: b-After tax credits of $660,800 for the quarter and $2,110,000 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $295,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: Parent & Child
description: A CHILD must accomplish four tasks when a friend or family member dies: understand the nature of death and why this one occurred; grieve for the dead person; commemorate that person, and go on with his life. His success at coping with these tasks will be based, in part, on how his parents introduce him to death. By understanding how children at different ages comprehend and deal with the death of someone they love, parents can help ease their fears and reduce their confusion.

title: Small Hospitals Vie to Offer Heart Surgery
description: Heart surgery, once the province of major medical centers, is spawning a competitive struggle among smaller hospitals in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, according to hospital executives and state health officials.

title: Linoleum: Would You Believe It's Coming Back?
description: HIGH in the Hollywood Hills, where the terra cotta and the travertine reign, Johanna Went, a performance artist, and her husband, Stuart Cornfeld, a movie producer, have enacted a deeply rooted, dimly remembered American domestic ritual. They have installed linoleum.

title: Contras Say They'll Free Captured American
description: Nicaraguan rebels who have held an American volunteer for eight days say they are ready to release him, but will continue to capture foreigners they find in war zones.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $398,651,000 from the retroactive effect of an accounting change for both the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Eugene Lynn, Investment Banker, 77
description: Eugene Lynn, a partner in the investment banking firm of Wertheim & Company, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Police Charge 5 at Princeton in Drinking Spree
description: Five Princeton University students were charged today with serving alcohol to minors during campus parties that resulted in 36 people being taken to the hospital for drinking too much.

title: Stocks End Session Mixed; Dow Falls 6.80
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with smaller issues again doing relatively better than blue chips.

title: Birthday Party
description: This year marks the 75th anniversary of the Department of Labor, and eight former Labor Secretaries will be in Washington today to be honored by its current Secretary, Ann Dore McLaughlin, and more than 2,000 Government, industry and labor leaders.

title: Lendl Injured
description: Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked tennis player, has withdrawn from the Lipton International Players Championship, which begins Monday in Key Biscayne, Fla., because of a stress fracture in his right foot. Lendl, who said he expected to be out of action for four to six weeks, has been getting treatment for what he thought was a bruised right big toe. But X-rays taken Tuesday determined that he has a stress fracture of a bone. ''I don't know what to say except that I'm not happy I won't be able to play,'' Lendl said. Three of the top five men will miss the Lipton tournament: Pat Cash of Australia, who is No. 2 (Achilles' tendon), Stefan Edberg of Sweden, No. 3 (bronchial virus) and Boris Becker of West Germany, No. 4 (he said he doesn't like the tournament).(AP)

title: QUIPP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Ruling Seen for Campeau
description: A Federal court hearing in Manhattan next week may either end the Campeau Corporation's seven-week-old campaign to acquire Federated Department Stores Inc. or give new impetus to the effort, which is competing with an offer by R. H. Macy & Company.

title: French Trade Deficit
description: The French current account balance of payments swung back into a deficit in 1987 after achieving its first surplus for seven years in 1986, the Finance Ministry said today. The current account, which measures not only trade in goods and services but also such invisible items as bank transfers, fell to a deficit of 27.2 billion francs, or about $4.9 billion, in 1987 from a surplus of 20.2 billion francs the previous year.

title: A Political Calendar

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $3,655,000. The company said comparative results for the year-ago fourth quarter are not available because of accounting factors connected with a change in fiscal year to a calendar year from April 30 that was effective Dec. 31, 1986. The company also said the loss is primarily due to a decline in market value of its equity securities portfolio as a result of the October market crash.

title: San Diego Club to Weigh '89 Cup Race
description: The board of directors of the San Diego Yacht Club plans to meet tonight to discuss a proposal by Michael Fay of New Zealand to postpone his challenge for the America's Cup until May 1989 in order to allow other nations to join.

title: F.B.I. Files Surrendered to LaRouche Defense
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation files declassified today quoted three intelligence operatives as saying they had been directed by high-level officials of the bureau and the Central Intelligence Agency to infiltrate the political organizations of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. Excerpts from the files, surrendered to defense lawyers in the fraud and conspiracy trial of Mr. LaRouche, six of his aides and five of his political groups, showed that one of the three operatives refused to discuss his dealings related to Mr. LaRouche with low-level bureau officials. The operative, Sgt. Maj. Fred Lewis of the Army, said he had been instructed by ranking officials at the agencies not to do so, the files showed.

title: Mathematics Expert May Soon Resolve A 350-Year Problem
description: One of the most notorious unsolved problems of mathematics, a 350-year-old conjecture known as Fermat's Last Theorem, may be close to succumbing to a new line of attack, mathematicians said yesterday.

title: Scientists Report Advances In Vaccine Against Malaria
description: Scientists have reported an important advance in the long, frustrating search for a vaccine against malaria, one of the world's major killers.

title: After Super Tuesday; Dukakis Funds Mount As His Rivals Face Bills
description: Michael S. Dukakis's formidable money machine continues to roll on, giving the Massachusetts Governor an undisputed edge in resources as the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination moves north. His rivals, meanwhile, are struggling to pay their bills from the television advertising in Tuesday's contests.

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Maurice Wahl, Judge, 86
description: Maurice Wahl, a retired New York City Civil Court judge, died of cancer Feb. 18 while visiting his daughter in Eugene, Ore. He was 86 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Forstmann Little
description: Forstmann Little & Company, the investment firm that specializes in buyouts, announced that some of its affiliates plan to divest themselves of four units with the help of Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm. The units, which have total annual sales of $500 million, are American Electric of Memphis, a unit of FL Industries; Reznor, of Mercer, Pa., another FL division; Janitrol Aero, a division of the FL Aerospace Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, and the Management Services Corporation of Oklahoma City, a unit of Lear Siegler Holdings.

title: RESDEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter net equals less than 1 cent a share after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Offending Food Bags Pulled
description: Meadowdale Foods, owner of Great Scott Supermarkets Inc., has removed frozen food bags that offended an Asian-American group, American Citizens for Justice. The bags, which bear a caricature of a child with slanted eyes and prominent teeth, have the words, ''Coolee bag for your purchases of ice cream and frozen foods.'' Unskilled Asians who worked on American railroads in the 19th century were called coolies. Raymond Gomez, a spokesman for the bag maker, said the character was intended to be an Eskimo.

title: Black & Decker Shuns Bid Talks
description: The Black & Decker Corporation said it would not take part in talks about a cease-fire in its $2 billion hostile takeover attack on American Standard Inc. On Tuesday American Standard proposed an agreement under which it would provide Black & Decker with non-public information. But Black & Decker said the arrangement would have prohibited additional action to pursue its $73-a-share bid for the New York-based plumbing and air-conditioning maker. Nolan D. Archibald, Black & Decker chairman and chief executive, called the conditions of the proposal ''excessively restrictive and totally unacceptable.''

description: Bears danced, a juggler juggled and an unlikely triumvirate of American producers and a Soviet circus impresario announced yesterday at Radio City Music Hall that the Moscow Circus would make its first North American tour in 10 years.

description: Paul Evans took a sip of beer and considered a question about his interest in becoming an athletic director.

description: HE lobbies of Manhattan's luxury apartment buildings are considered plum assignments in the interior decorating trade: walk-through showcases for designers' work that are seen daily by residents and guests.

description: In the aftermath of his huge victories Tuesday, Vice President Bush said today that he would begin tailoring his campaign message to reach beyond Republican primary voters.

description: A Federal appeals court upheld a contempt citation against a prominent New Jersey lawyer and his firm today for refusing to defend an accused mobster whose previous lawyer became seriously ill.

title: Bill to Provide AIDS Caution For Partners
description: A bill to let doctors warn sexual partners of AIDS patients that they may have been infected - even if the patients object to the disclosure - was introduced today by a bipartisan group of legislators in the Assembly and the State Senate.

title: Afghan Expects No Pact by Deadline
description: The Afghan Foreign Minister warned today that an Afghan peace agreement appears unlikely by the March 15 deadline suggested by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Review/Violin; Bach to Sibelius to Faure
description: If Joshua Bell develops into the art-ist his best work suggested at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening, he will satisfy some wants that are mostly given short shrift in today's violin playing. In the first half of the recital, he distinguished himself mostly by being tasteful and expert. He did not employ a thick, hectic vibrato; he did not saw at the allegros in his Mozart (K. 454) and Faure (Op. 13) sonatas; he did not let the sweet quality of his tone turn thin or raspy.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Malaysian Politician Freed
description: A regional court today freed a leading opposition politician who had been imprisoned without trial since Oct. 27. The politician, Karpal Singh, was released in Ipoh, 120 miles north of Kuala Lumpur, after he won a lawsuit charging wrongful arrest. Mr. Karpal is a member of Parliament and the Vice President of the opposition Democratic Action Party. He was 1 of 119 people seized by the Government during a political crackdown on the opposition between October and December.

title: Benjamin Minifie, Outspoken Cleric, Is Dead at Age 77
description: The Rev. Benjamin Minifie, rector of Grace Church from 1960 until 1975 and an outspoken Protestant Episcopal cleric on many public issues, died of heart failure Tuesday at his retirement home in Newport, R.I. He was 77 years old.

title: Wachtler Asks for 17 Criminal Court Judges
description: The state's Chief Judge said today that drug arrests in New York City had increased so rapidly - by 65 percent over two years - that its courts were on the verge of crisis and needed 17 more judges.

title: Grumman Says It Will Reduce Jobs by 2,300
description: The Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest private employer, said today that it would reduce its Long Island work force by 2,300 jobs, including the layoff of 600 employees.

title: Hers
description: THE first time I flew on an airplane, I was 20 years old and all the flight attendants looked about my age. The last time I flew, I was 40 and again the flight attendants, or at least some of them, looked my age. In 20 years, we had all come a long way.

title: Koch and Probation System Faulted in Officer's Death
description: The head of the New York City probation officers union suggested yesterday that the failure of the city's probation system had helped bring about the murder of a police officer.

title: After Super Tuesday; Judge's Vote Comment Draws Formal Protest
description: A formal complaint has been filed against an Illinois appellate judge for saying that South Side residents who failed to vote for Mayor Harold Washington ''ought to be hung.''

title: Baker Is Weighing a Shift In Military Costs to Japanese
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d raised the possibility today that President Reagan would ask Japan to pay a far greater share for its national security that is now provided by the United States.

title: Winds Flip a Small Airplane Piloted by Ex-Secretary Clark
description: William P. Clark Jr., a former Interior Secretary in the Reagan Administration, was hospitalized after erratic winds flipped his plane as he tried to take off from his private airstrip Monday.

title: Personal Health
description: When sexual intercourse causes pain instead of pleasure, the effects on the partners and the relationship can be devastating. The partner who is in pain is likely to avoid sexual activity, and the other partner is likely to feel guilty and reluctant to inflict pain by attempting intercourse. Both partners may end up frustrated and resentful as well as confused when an activity purported to bring joy to so many turns out to be so discomforting for them.

title: Review/Television; Sleuthing Duo and Murder in Church in 'Mystery!
description: This being a pledge week, Channel 13 is tailoring its schedule to researcher specifications. The prime-time emphasis is being placed on presumably more popular programming that might encourage viewers to become paying subscribers. So tonight the fine but relatively demanding poetry series ''Voices and Visions'' has been shunted to midnight. Emily Dickinson is the subject of this week's essay. Meanwhile, ''Mystery!,'' normally seen Saturdays on Channel 13, is being pushed up to this evening, weighing in at 9:40 with not one but two hourlong episodes of another ''Inspector Morse'' story. As it happens, this one, entitled ''Service of All the Dead,'' is another nifty addition to the series.

title: Review/Television; Coverage of Super Tuesday: Bad Calls and Bush 'Blowouts'
description: The coverage wasn't exciting, but it was responsible. Tuesday night and yesterday morning, we could almost hear anchors and correspondents think out loud. How should they treat the Rev. Jesse Jackson? Was Vice President Bush a poor candidate? Had Senator Albert Gore become a contender? Consensus seemed to form only on the question about Mr. Jackson. Everyone treated him carefully.

title: Text of Shultz Letter to Israeli Prime Minister
description: Following is the text of the letter that Secretary of State George P. Shultz wrote last week to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel outlining the American peace proposal. A similar letter was sent to King Hussein of Jordan.

title: Military Seen As Still Behind Panama Chief
description: The Panama Defense Forces, which are the key to the political crisis in Panama, remain solidly behind their chief, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, according to American military and civilian officials here and in that country.

title: Nanne Promoted
description: Lou Nanne, who said in January he would resign as general manager of the Minnesota North Stars because he was worried about his health, was named president of the team yesterday. He will also serve as president of the Met Center, the cdub's home arena.(AP) ,

Gorbachev marks his third anniversary as General Secretary of the Soviet Union. His efforts to restructure the country economically (perestroika) and to bring fresh thinking to foreign and military affairs have created powerful countervailing forces.

description: JACQUES GRANGE, speaking from his office in Paris, had trouble putting himself in a trans-Atlantic frame of mind.

title: Review/Dance; Kenneth King Interprets Myths
description: Kenneth King's dances have often combined scientific speculation with science-fiction. Their content has been cryptic, and their choreography has been liquid.

title: New Furniture from the Old Southwest
description: LEAD: IN adobe studios scattered throughout Santa Fe, N.M., in villages tucked into the Sangre de Cristo Mountains and in tin-roofed workshops high on the Taos plateau, young artists and artisans are fashioning furniture that reflects their hybrid Indian-Hispanic-Anglo culture, but with a contemporary twist.

title: Cuba Economy Shrank in 1987
description: Cuba's economy shrank 3.5 percent in 1987 after expanding an average 7.2 percent a year during the 1981-85 period, according to a confidential report by the central bank. It grew 1.4 percent in 1986. The decline of Cuba's gross social product (the Communist equivalent of gross national product) confirmed that 1987 was a very difficult year for the Cuban economy. The report, however, said the results were ''considered favorable because 1987 was one of the worst years the country had had to face as a result of adverse weather conditions, the sustained slide of the dollar and the drastic decrease in imports from free-convertible currency areas.''

title: TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $105,000 for the quarter and $321,000 for the year. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $80,000. d-Net loss

title: Review/Theater; Image vs. Reality for a Vietnam Veteran
description: Life is viewed in a mirror in ''A Circle on the Cross,'' but we are never certain that the images represent anything real in front of the mirror. The people in Thomas Cadwaleder Jones's play at the Open Eye: New Stagings are palpable enough, but, as Mr. Jones peels away our illusions about their lives - or is he masking reality with illusions? - we begin to doubt the meaning of every line and action.

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an unrealized market value loss of $884,000 on the company's marketable securities portfolio. c-Net income Year-ago results are restated.

title: AMERICAN COLLOID reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $492,000 to cover the unreserved portion of the recent tax settlement with the Montana department of revenue.

title: 3CI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income from discontinued operations.

title: SOONER DEFENSE OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $28,500 and $150,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Puerto Cisnes Journal; Among the Daunting Vistas, a Dauntless Mayor
description: ''You didn't expect to find such an entertaining mayor here,'' declared the woman who rules Puerto Cisnes, population 1,098.

title: Luncheon Guests at Sardi's Were Definitely Top Dog
description: Two top dogs lunched at Sardi's yesterday, but though the restaurant had spare tables, they weren't given seats.

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Justice in the Brawley Case
description: Judging from the acrimony between Tawana Brawley's lawyers and Governor Cuomo of New York, one could conclude that personality conflicts are responsible for the intransigence that has prevented a thorough investigation and possible prosecution. Yet a more basic issue separates the parties and must be addressed before any reconciliation can take place.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that during the fourth quarter of 1987, it purchased certain assets of J.M. Aleander & Co., a fabric converter and supplier, and that last month it acquired the Bloomsburg, Pa., business.

title: Indian Sikhs Install Leader
description: Sikh gunmen killed eight people in Punjab state today shortly after a high priest freed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi was made head of India's Sikhs. The priest, Jasbir Singh Rode, urged Sikhs to continue the struggle for freedom, but he avoided mention of the independent homeland for which extremists are fighting. He was freed as a peace overture to the militants.

title: HEALTH: Ophthalmology; Zinc Shows Promise In Slowing Disease That Causes Blindness
description: Eye doctors are both excited and cautious about a new report suggesting that zinc may halt the progress of macular degeneration, a leading cause of loss of vision and blindness in older people that has so far been untreatable.

title: In Japan, Wondering About a Capital
description: For 1,074 years Japan sank its imperial roots in Kyoto, a city of graceful temples and soothing gardens. Then, in 1868, the national center was moved to Tokyo.

title: Australia Loan to China
description: Australia has agreed to lend China 200 million Australian dollars, or about $145 million, in low-interest funds for trade-related projects, an Australian Government minister said today. Industry Minister John Button said that terms for the three-year loan had not been set but that the rate would be well below commercial levels. Australian companies will have priority in participating in Chinese projects using the funds.

title: Nets' Defense Sinks Clippers
description: John Bagley scored 10 of his 24 points in the final six minutes, and the Nets limited Los Angeles to 32 points in the second half tonight in a 97-93 victory over the Clippers.

title: Blacks, Years After Selma, Share in Jackson's Victory
description: Twenty-three years ago this week, demonstrators marching for the right of black people to vote were turned back at the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., by policemen with dogs and cattle prods.

title: Rescue Coordinator Testifies In Continental Crash Hearing
description: The effort to save victims of a Continental Airlines crash went well even though radio batteries failed, pens would not write and rescuers were not dressed for the cold, the rescue coordinator testified today.

title: The Art of Reweaving
description: YOU knew it would happen.

title: Government Gives Private Sector A Chance to Run Medicare Plans
description: Thousands of retired clothing workers will participate in an experimental program in which their union's welfare fund will manage the retirees' health care using Medicare funds.

title: The Shock of Super Tuesday
description: Super Tuesday turned out to be a shock.

title: Yields Post Small Drop
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were down slightly for the week ended yesterday.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest year was attributable to advertising costs of $2,022,412, compared with $546,294 in fiscal 1986.

title: Soviet and U.S. TV To Carry Youth Summit
description: A ''youth summit'' of American and Soviet teen-agers exchanging information about various aspects of their daily lives will be broadcast live by satellite tomorrow in the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: New York's Secondhand Bookshops Are an Endangered Species
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptians Claim Lost King Tut Treasures
description: The Egyptian Government is seeking to reclaim a trove of more than 300 artifacts found in the ancestral home of the British nobleman who financed the excavation of the tomb of King Tutankhamun in 1922.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rysanek to Appear In 'Die Walkure' at Met
description: Leonie Rysanek will sing the role of Sieglinde in ''Die Walkure'' at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday evening and in the matinee performance of March 19, which will be broadcast live on WQXR (1560 AM, 96.3 FM).

title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS FORM TV NETWORK
description: An interfaith coalition of mainstream religious groups have taken a lesson from television evangelists: use television but handle it with care.

title: Portrait of the Super Tuesday Electorate
7 Die in Arizona Road Crash
description: A man driving a motor home hit a tractor-trailer rig Monday, causing a four-vehicle crash and fire that killed him, his wife and their four grandchildren, officials said. Also killed was a woman driving a pilot truck behind the tractor-trailer on the narrow, twisting section of U.S. 93 near this remote community in western Arizona, the authorities said.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a loss of $706,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the loss on discontinued operations represents a charge in the quarter ended Oct. 31, 1986 relating to excess crude oil sales prices under the Department of Energy's former oil and gas subsidiary.

title: After Super Tuesday; Hart to Meet Reporters; May Be Quitting Race
description: Gary Hart canceled travel plans today and scheduled a news conference for Friday morning, when he may abandon his race for the Democratic Presidential nomination a second time.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Drops Pizza Inn Job
description: Pizzas and burgers don't mix, at least not on the same agency's client list.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KEY RATES
An American Ritual Sold by the Foot
description: REAL linoleum, made from linseed oil, wood dust, cork and resins, has not been manufactured in the United States for over 10 years. But some distributors import linoleum from Europe in styles from purely durable to high-tech chic. American manufacturers are keeping up by making new vinyl tiles and sheets with brick, floral and marbleized motifs that recall the old look.

title: A Steam Engine From China
description: A tourist rail line based here is going to the Far East to find a new steam locomotive. The Valley Railroad plans to spend about $300,000 on a new locomotive from China, where 70 percent of the locomotives are run by steam because of that country's scarcity of oil and surfeit of coal. It is cheaper to go there for the engine than to have one custom-built in the United States or rebuild an old one, railroad officials said.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $340,100 for the latest year and $323,600 for the year-earlier period. The company said the average shares outstanding in the latest fourth quarter reflect the maximum number of equivalent shares that could be issued relating to a $20,250,000 private placement of class A shares in October.

title: Brooklyn's Big Garden Is Growing Bigger
description: The Brooklyn Botanic Garden will display today the completed first phase of a $25 million expansion project that more than doubles the space for public exhibits and greenhouse plantings.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $22,517 reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and a tax credit of $46,184 for the year. The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend to be issued March 15, 1988.

title: F.A.A. Is Criticized Over Security at Airports
description: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley today chastised the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to ''strictly enforce security requirements'' at airports.

title: Lakers Put End To Knick Streak
description: The Knicks' 13-game Madison Square Garden winning streak ended last night, but it took the powerful Los Angeles Lakers, the best team in the league, to accomplish the feat, 104-99.

title: Hungary, Suzuki Discuss Venture
description: Hungary is holding talks with the Suzuki Motor Company and other Japanese companies to set up its first car assembly plant in a joint venture worth 10 billion forints, or about $210 million, the Hungarian press agency said. The assembly of 50,000 Suzuki Alto mini-cars annually could begin in two years, the press agency said.

title: Joyce Brown Panhandles Again
description: Joyce Brown, the former homeless woman who challenged the Koch administration's efforts to hospitalize her against her will, held a news conference yesterday to confirm reports that she had returned to the streets for three afternoons of panhandling.

title: Deaths Are Reported In an Air Hijacking In the Soviet Union
description: An Aeroflot flight attendant and three passengers were killed Tuesday when a group of ''armed criminals'' tried to hijack a Soviet passenger airliner and force it to leave the country, the Soviet press agency Tass reported tonight.

title: Defense Says Florida Is Hasty in Moving to Execute Convict
description: A new death warrant giving seven days to prepare a new appeal shows that Florida is moving too quickly to execute Willie Jasper Darden, whose case has drawn international attention, his lawyers said today.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its results in the latest 6 months were affected by an unrealized loss of $316,000 in securities as well as a charge of $250,000 as a result of a loss by Movie Star Inc., in which the company has an interest.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Reagan Invokes Rockne to Encourage Optimism
description: President Reagan made an emotional journey here today to the University of Notre Dame, scene of one of his most memorable films, ''Knute Rockne -All American.''

title: Calendar: From Ceramics to Stichery
description: Judaic Needlework Class

title: A School for the Amateur Builder
description: LEAD: JOHN CONNELL is a charismatic leader who runs a subversive school in the Green Mountains at Warren, Vt.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net of $39,000 for the quarter and a loss of $519,000 for the year both from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $161,000 and $464,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Head of Shoney's Sees An Industry Slowdown
description: LEAD: J. Mitchell Boyd, the vice chairman and chief executive of Shoney's Inc., entered the company's restaurant business the easy way, as a management trainee, but proved himself the hard way, as an entrepreneur.

title: Tidy City Is Paramount For Jakarta's Governor
description: The new Governor of the city of Jakarta, a national capital territory that is a little (but only a little) like the District of Columbia, has spent most of his first six months in office getting the bad news.

title: Home Improvement
description: MUCH ordinary furniture made during this century, and even some fine furniture, is fastened with dowels: cylindrical wooden pegs that function like nails or screws but are held in place by glue. When installed expertly, dowels create a joint tat is usually stronger and longer lasting than one with metal fasteners. However, once loosened - by age or mishandling of the article - they may break.

title: After Super Tuesday; 3 Democratic Leaders Stump in Illinois
description: The three Democratic Presidential candidates anointed as leaders by Tuesday's primaries campaigned yesterday in the mills and factories of Illinois as their struggle moved to the nation's industrial heartland.

title: Currents; Clear the Coffee Table, Here Comes a Textbook
description: JOHN PILE described the genesis of his book ''Interior Design'' as ''slow and painful.'' Nevertheless, Mr. Pile, an interior designer and teacher at Pratt Institute, has written a book that is a refreshing anomaly in design textbooks. It is informative without being dull, and would be as suitable on a coffee table as on a designer's bookshelf.

title: After Super Tuesday; Bush is Odds-On Favorite
description: Vice President Bush's triumph in all 16 republican primaries Tuesday makes him the favorite to with the Presidency, at odds of 4 to 9, a bookmaker, William Hill, said here today.

title: Benjamin Borsody, 87, An Innovator in Radio
description: Benjamin Frank Borsody, a construction engineer and innovator in radio systems design, died Sunday at the Kensington Manor Nursing Home in Sarasota, Fla., after a series of strokes. He was 87 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Q&A
description: Q.I find it difficult to apply paint or varnish to knobs without getting it all over my hands, and I always miss some spots. Is there a simple trick to solve this problem?

title: Advertising; Raisin Sales Respond To 'Grapevine' Spots
description: Those hip raisins who ''got it from the grapevine'' for the California Raisin Advisory Board have not only charmed TV viewers but have also increased the sales of raisins. And that, after all, is the bottom line.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes unrealized losses in equity investments of $1,399,000 and $3,346,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The company said the prior year includes results of Greenwich Mills Company, acquired Dec. 30, 1986.

title: Architecture Director Named at the Modern
description: Stuart Wrede, an architect with wide experience as a teacher and museum curator, has been named director of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, the museum announced yesterday.

title: In Milan, Eclectic Collections
description: Fashion is in a state of flux, which adds a certain zest to the fall and winter showings here. It is impossible to know for sure what shapes, lengths or even moods designers will emphasize. ''I guess it will end up being a wardrobe of fashion: skirts of any length, plus pants,'' said Kalman Ruttenstein, the senior vice president for fashion direction at Bloomingdale's.

title: Robert Livingston, 83, An Actor in 100 Films
description: Robert Livingston, an actor who played the Lone Ranger and was in many Hollywood westerns, died Monday of emphysema at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 83 years old.

title: Global Fight in the Tire Industry
description: The battle between Pirelli S.p.A. of Italy and the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan over the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company is not simply another takeover contest. It is a struggle for supremacy, if not survival, in the emerging global market for tires.

title: Review/Piano; Maurizio Pollini Unearths Little-Known Beethoven
description: Beethoven is perhaps our best-known composer; also the one whose music we know the least. He wrote 32 piano sonatas, for example; and from the early Opus 2, No. 3 - wonderfully original, totally assured - to the mystical C minor Sonata (Op. 111), the progress of a creative mind is spread out before us. Is it a conspiracy among performers or only an attempt to make a buck with proven merchandise that keeps so many of these pieces from public view? We hear repeatedly Opus 10, No. 3 from the early works, the ''name'' sonatas - the ''Pathetique,'' ''Les Adieux,'' ''Appassionata,'' ''Moonlight,'' ''Waldstein'' - and then the late pieces (except the ''Hammerklavier,'' which is too difficult to play and too complex for the casual listener).

title: The Cost of Sales Calls In Europe Is Surveyed
description: McGraw-Hill is always doing research on how much average sales calls cost in hopes that publishing that figure will lead manufacturers to use advertising in McGraw-Hill publications to augment such calls.

title: Macy's Plans for Federated
description: R. H. Macy & Company said it would divest Federated Department Stores Inc. of all its non-department store divisions and certain other assets within a year of a Macy's-Federated merger and would expect net proceeds from the sales of about $2.9 billion, according to documents filed by Macy with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Economic Scene; Is 'Conventional Wisdom' Wise?
description: THE term ''the conventional wisdom'' has become so much a part of the language that people forget that the phrase was coined by John Kenneth Galbraith just 30 years ago in ''The Affluent Society.''

title: Contras Agree to Talks On Sandinistas' Terms
description: Contra leaders, reversing their position, said today that they were willing to negotiate with the Sandinista Government under conditions proposed by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra.

title: SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $16,000.

title: STEP-SAVER DATA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Carter Example
description: Albert Gore of Tennessee, winner of Democratic primaries in five states forming a belt across the midriff of the South, has followed the Jimmy Carter example to put himself solidly in contention for his party's 1988 Presidential nomination.

title: Because Jews Are Not a Nation of Terrorists; What Kissinger Said
description: To the Editor:

title: In Vanguard of Do-It-Yourself Law Movement
description: In an airy, converted clock factory in an old industrial area here, a group of refugees from the practice of law are merrily but purposefully trying to demolish the legal profession.

title: Head of College For Deaf Quits After Protests
description: Elisabeth Ann Zinser, the newly appointed president of Gallaudet University, the nation's only institution of higher learning for the deaf, resigned early today in the face of mass protests by students and faculty members who had demanded a leader who is hearing-impaired.

title: Heart Disease Found in Redden
description: The deputy coroner confirmed that heart disease killed Don Redden, the former Louisiana State basketball player who was buried here today near the grave of Pete Maravich, the former L.S.U. star who died last Jan. 5 at 40 years old.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and the quarter is after a $20,000,000 pretax charge for the restructuring of operations.

title: U.S. SCALES BACK PLAN FOR BURIAL OF ATOMIC WASTE
description: The Department of Energy said today that it would sharply reduce the amount of radioactive material it plans to bury in the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository because of water leaks.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Frontier Letters

title: Review/Theater; Danner and Quinn In a New 'Streetcar'
description: ''We've had this date with each other from the beginning,'' says Stanley Kowalski to his sister-in-law, Blanche DuBois, just before he sweeps her away to bed in ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' That line -wholly in character for Stanley and yet a classic expression of tragedy's inexorable pull - sets off what is still among the most shocking acts of human destruction the American stage has known. In the collision of Stanley, the working-class stiff, and Blanche, the frayed Southern belle, Tennessee Williams gave life to forces that run far deeper than his play's specific place (New Orleans) and sociological context (the postwar 1940's). ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' is not a morality tale about a brutal man victimizing a frail woman but a terrifying plunge into the madness that afflicts anyone, male or female, brute or sensitive, who submits to his own personal executioner - the passion so incendiary that it consumes the self.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $16.4 million from redemption of high-cost debt for the quarter and year.

title: Japan's Press Says Voting Dealt Blow to Protectionism >
description: Japan's highly influential press today welcomed the results in the American Presidential primaries and caucuses held Tuesday as a blow against American protectionism and thus a small victory for the Japanese.

title: A Correction
description: Because of an error by the authors, the ''first major United States bank to actually charge off some third world debt from its books'' was mis-identified in an article March 3 by Robin Broad and John Cavanagh. The proper institution is the First Na-tional Bank of Boston.

title: Writers' Talks Halted
description: Scriptwriters and producers meeting under the guidance of a Federal mediator broke off talks Thursday on ending a four-day strike, the executive director of the Writers Guild of America-East reported. The official, Mona Mangan, was at the talks with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers in Los Angeles. No date has been set for further talks. The union struck Sunday, demanding an increase in residuals from movies and television shows distributed in foreign countries.

title: Age No Object
description: Matt Dunigan's first day in his new career as a player in the Montreal Expos' farm system raised an old question in West Palm Beach, Fla. The question concerned the age of Dunigan, a former Edmonton Eskimos quarterback who abandoned the Canadian Football League and signed a minor league contract as an outfielder with the Expos on Wednesday. The Expos issued a news release stating that last year's outstanding offensive C.F.L. player was 25 years old. C.F.L. news media guides and city records in Lakewood, Ohio, where Dunigan was born, show his birthdate as Dec. 6, 1960, which would make him 27. Dunigan insisted he was 25. ''I was born in 1962,'' said Dunigan, a former Louisiana Tech University quarterback who led the Eskimos to the Grey Cup. ''Either way, I feel like I'm 21. If it doesn't bother the Expos, it doesn't bother me.'' Dan Duquette, the Expos' farm director, said Dunigan's age wasn't a factor. ''Whether he's 27 or 25, we would have signed him,'' Duquette said.

title: Review: New Directors/New Films; 'Who Killed Vincent Chin?': Answer Is Complex
description: On a hot summer night in 1982, Vincent Chin, a young, thoroughly assimilated Chinese-American, was having a night out with his pals (white), celebrating the last days of his bachelorhood at a Detroit topless bar called the Fancy Pants. In the course of the evening, Mr. Chin got into a scuffle with another customer, Ron Ebens, an unemployed auto worker. Mr. Ebens and Michael Nitz, his stepson, left the Fancy Pants.

title: Dartmouth Punishes Four as Harassers of Professor
description: Four students at Dartmouth College charged by the school with harassing a black music professor have been given penalties ranging from probation to suspension, the college announced today.

title: Opposition Parties in Seoul Fail in Effort for Unification
description: An effort to forge a united opposition to the Government of President Roh Tae Woo collapsed Wednesday.

title: Our Towns; Where Students Make the Grade And $25 a Week
description: Last Friday after third-period remedial math class, the teacher, Lynn Prestia, handed out paychecks to three of her Red Bank High students. To earn the money, they had attended class for five straight days, were on time, did the homework and brought their supplies. Travis Patton had two perfect weeks. At $5 a day, he earned $50 for being good.

title: Andy Gibb, 30, Singer in 70's, Dies in Britain
description: Andy Gibb, a teen-idol pop singer in the late 1970's and the younger brother of the three members of the Bee Gees, died Friday in Oxfordshire, England, after being hospitalized for stomach pains. Spokesmen at John Radcliffe Hospital declined to give the cause of death. He was 30 years old.

title: New President Picked By Columbia Savings
description: Lawrence K. Fish found his calling as an international banker only after spending a year on a fellowship visiting 20 countries. Deciding, in effect, to become an expatriate, he forsook his training as a journalist and returned to Brazil, where he eventually went to work for the Bank of Boston.

title: Skitch Henderson
description: Skitch Henderson will conduct the New York Pops in a concert celebrating movie music tonight at 8 o'clock at Carnegie Hall. The singer Donna Theodore and the actress Jane Powell, who starred in such films as ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers'' and ''Royal Wedding,'' will be guests. Tickets, at $30, $27.50, $22.50, $20 and $14, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

description: b-Net loss c-Includes a loss of $706,000 from discontinued operations. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain equal to 2 cents a share.

title: MEYER, FRED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,530,000.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Business Day on Wednesday about the Tandon Corporation misstated the revenues of its disk drive unit. For the nine months ended in September, the unit had sales of $90 million. The report also inaccurately described Tandon's personal computer business. The company has been making personal computers since 1984.

title: Debentures From Masco Industries
description: Masco Industries is offering $300 million in 10 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 1995 at 99.358, to yield 10.13 percent, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The size of the issue was increased from $250 million.
