title: Review/Film; Animated Black Comedy About Courage as the World Ends
description: James and Hilda Bloggs are living out their golden years in a modest, immaculately tidy cottage in a remote part of Sussex. James and Hilda are a staunch, lower-middle-class English couple, backbone-of-the-nation types whose faith in the future has remained undiminished since they stood up to the Jerries in 1940.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Videos Bring Fly-Fishing Adventures Into Home
description: THIS is the season when the fly fisherman, who has the bucks and the spare time, slips away to some tropical or semitropical isle for a week of casting on the shimmering flats for such species as bonefish, tarpon and permit.

title: Departure Under a Cloud
description: Costa Rican Ambassador Guido Fernandez, regarded in some quarters as one of the most effective ambassadors in Washington for his efforts to promote the President Oscar Arias Sanchez's Central American peace plan, left the United States Thursday to become Costa Rica's Minister of Information. But a small cloud hangs over his departture.

title: Islander Tribute to Bossy
description: He has been unable to play hockey this season, but before tonight's game, Mike Bossy received a tribute from the Islanders for the nine 50-goal seasons he has given them.

title: Kemp Bows Out But Drops Hint On No. 2 Spot
description: With grace and a suggestion that he was available for the Vice-Presidential spot, Representative Jack F. Kemp withdrew from the Republican Presidential race today. He promised teary supporters that there was ''no way'' this would be his final bid for the White House.

title: Bronx Resident Dies After Being Arrested By 6 Police Officers
description: A Bronx man died yesterday after being arrested and restrained by six police officers responding to a report that he was attacking his wife, the police said.

title: Amid Avowals of Love, Bursts of Hate
description: To Dwell in Peace: An Autobiography By Daniel Berrigan. 356 pages. Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Islanders Beaten On Late Score
description: The Nordiques grew bolder as the game wore on and they noticed they could create chaos in the Islander zone without any confrontations.

title: Former Chief of Staff Testifies for Mecham
description: Gov. Evan Mecham's last chief of staff testified today that he would not have responded as the Governor did to reports that another Mecham aide had threatened a grand jury witness.

title: Co-op Owners Trapped By Credit Union Scandal
description: When George Kowalczyk bought his co-op in Brooklyn almost four years ago the investment seemed like a prudent one: a roomy studio apartment in a four-story, turn-of-the-century building in Park Slope bordered by landmark blocks, near good transportation and shopping and verdant Prospect Park.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $386,000 for the quarter and year; the year also included a gain of $1,552,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Emblem Is A-OK!
description: First there was a slashed red circle to indicate ''no left turn.'' Then came the international ''no smoking'' message. Now there is a worldwide design to promote security for American children overseas.

title: TRUSTCOMPANY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET WON'T END AFGHAN ARMS AID
description: A senior Soviet official declared today that Moscow would not cease arming the Kabul Government as part of an agreement for an Afghan cease-fire. The Reagan Administration has demanded an arms cutoff as part of any peace settlement.

title: Maxxam Opposes Kaisertech Pact
description: Maxxam Group Inc., which controls the equivalent of 32 percent of Kaisertech Ltd., has filed a suit in state court in Delaware seeking to end a standstill agreement between the two companies. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Maxxam said it has sued because Kaisertech had ''induced Maxxam's consent to the standstill agreement by fraud.''

title: DENNING MOBIL ROBOTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is in the development stage.

title: The Icy Nightmare of '88
description: The Weather Bureau forecast fresh-to-brisk winds and fair weather for the Northeast on March 11, 1888, followed by rain. Rain it did, in torrents. Then shortly past midnight the rain turned to snow, with fierce winds, and it snowed for most of three days. Unheralded, it was a storm to make history - the Blizzard of '88.

title: Soviet Reports 9 Died in Hijacking of Jet by Family
description: A woman led at least three of her seven sons - jazz musicians who hid weapons in their instrument cases - in the hijacking of a Soviet airliner Wednesday in which nine people were killed, official accounts said today, The mother and sons were among 11 members of the same family who boarded the flight in the Siberian city of Irkutsk, apparently hoping they could force the crew to take them to London instead of Leningrad, the plane's final destination, according to the accounts. The reports indicated that the Government's handling of the hijacking, including an armed assault to free the passengers at an airfield near Leningrad, was inadequately planned and contributed to the death toll.

title: Manufacturers Hanover Sees No Dividend Cut
description: Long the target of rumors that it would be forced to cut its dividend, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday laid out the reasons it believes that move would be unnecessary.

title: Man About House
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; Arab and Jew in the Winds of Hate
description: ''Jew-hater!'' the man screamed at the occupant of a car on Jaffa Road, the main thoroughfare in West Jerusalem. ''Nazi!''

title: Coniston Fights For Gillette Sale
description: Coniston Partners confirmed that it would actively seek offers to sell or break up the Gillette Company if it gains representation on the company's board. The New York investment partnership formally began a proxy fight today to win four board seats at Gillette's annual meeting in April.

title: Young Dreamers Can't Resist Capital's Magnet
description: From across the country and from distant parts of the world, tens of thousands of young people throng here to study.

title: On Mended Knee
description: Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback voted the outstanding player in the Super Bowl, will be released Friday from a Birmingham, Ala., hospital following a knee operation. According to Donnie Tuck, director of public relations for the Redskins, Williams underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday on his left knee, which was injured in the first quarter of Super Bowl XXII in San Diego. Dr. James Andrews, who has performed two other knee operations on Williams, said the quarterback ''is already experiencing increased range of motion.'' Redskins officials said Williams will recuperate for about two weeks before undergoing rehabilitation at Redskin Park.

title: HEALTHCO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,205,000 from restructuring costs for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a gain of $440,000 on prepayment of debt, a gain of $12,761,000 on sale of a unit's common stock and income of $3,050,000 from a unit.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE ART OF COLLECTING

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $60,000 and $1,208,000 from the sale of securities for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also includes a $1,935,000 writeoff of prepaid FSLIC insurance premiums, and a loss of $672,000 from a flood loss at Precision Steel. c-Includes gains of $2,140,000 and $4,590,000 from the sale of securities for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: 2 Canucks Suspended
description: Two days after Vancouver lost to the Islanders in a game marked by fights, the defenseman Dave Richter and Coach Bob McCammon of the Canucks were suspended yesterday by the National Hockey League. Richter was suspended for 10 games without pay, the balance of Vancouver's regular-season schedule, which will end April 1. McCammon was suspended for five games and was fined $1,000. The Vancouver team was fined $10,000. Richter received an automatic one-game suspension after being assessed his third game-misconduct penalty of the season during the incident at the end of the second period. He apparently left the penalty box area to engage in a fight that involved the Islanders' goaltender, Billy Smith. The Islanders won, 7-4, to extend Vancouver's losing streak to eight games during McCammon's first season as coach.

title: U.N. to Study Rights in Cuba; U.S. Sees Diplomatic Victor
description: The Reagan Administration claimed a diplomatic victory tonight after the United Nations Human Rights Commission unanimously agreed to accept an invitation from Havana to investigate human rights in Cuba.

title: Trouble for Skier
description: Bill Johnson, the 1984 Olympic gold medalist in downhill skiing who has struggled to recover from knee and back surgery this season, has been temporarily suspended from the United States Ski Team for races in Beaver Creek, Colo., this weekend. The action could result in Johnson's being dropped from the team because he must pick up points in the remaining races this season to maintain his B-team ranking. According to Harald Schoenhaar, Alpine director of the team, ''Billy didn't give us a whole lot of options. At Whistler Mountain last weekend, he had a shouting match with one of the coaches. Let's say that he didn't exactly use elegant language. I understand he hit the coach on the shinbone with a ski pole. It's the same coach he had a shoving match with last fall. He also hasn't been participating in meetings.'' Johnson, whose best finish this year was 33d, was not available for comment. ''I haven't seen him here,'' Schoenhaar said. ''He's not staying with the team.''

title: Top Catholic Rivals in Final
description: When Tolentine and Molloy met in the semifinal round of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association playoffs last year, the 6,000-seat Alumni Hall at St. John's was sold out. When they met this season, Molloy's 1,100-seat gym was filled. The same will probably be true at 8 P.M. tomorrow, when they will meet in the C.H.S.A.A. championship at Fordham's 3,100-seat Rose Hill Gymnasium.

title: Advertising; Nostalgia Highlights Sugar Drive
description: THE suppliers of the nation's refined sugar, which have been hit by both changing industrial and consumer uses, are going to try to win back consumers with an adroit use of nostalgia.

title: Trio in Debut at Y
description: The Fisk Karr Lewis Trio - a new ensemble featuring Eliot Fisk, guitarist; Gary Karr, double bassist, and Harmon Lewis, harpsichordist - is to make its New York debut tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The Baroque program features solo and ensemble works by Quantz, Torelli, Soler, Telemann, Bach and Rameau. Tickets are $10 to $7.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Blue Jay Fielders Feel Out of Place
description: Nobody asked Jesse Barfield, but he doesn't like the move, either. He just hasn't been as vocal about it as George Bell and Lloyd Moseby.

description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $94.2 million and $87.3 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary charges from the purchase and redemption of debt of $12.6 million for the quarter and $32.3 million for the year. There were no extraordinary items in the latest periods.

title: In Praise of the Genetic Throw of the Dice

title: Dining Out Guide: Historic New York
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHELSEA CENTRAL, 227 10th Avenue, between 23d and 24th Streets (620-0230) - **(July 17, 1987). In 1750, the grandfather of Clement Clarke Moore, author of ''A Visit From St. Nicholas,'' bought farmland west of Eighth Avenue and named the estate Chelsea. Chelsea Central offers a handsome turn-of-the-century atmosphere and a menu the establishment calls American bistro. An eclectic composition of grilled entrees along with pastas and seafood are available. Winners include wood-grilled chicken, bouillabaisse (a Friday special) and grilled salmon. Recently added to the menu are medallions of lobster with grilled monkfish, and pan-seared coho salmon with lobster sausage. Lunch entrees $7 to $12; dinner $12 to $26. Lunch: Fridays and Saturdays 11:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M.; Sunday brunch same time. Dinner: 6 P.M. to midnight Fridays and Saturdays, until 11 P.M. Sundays. PETER LUGER, 178 Broadway, Williamsburg, Brooklyn (718-387-7400) -

title: Girl Called 5th Victim Of Hammer Attacker
description: A 15-year-old Bronx girl who was hit on the head last week by a man wielding a blunt object, possibly a hammer, is considered the fifth victim of the same attacker, the police said yesterday.

description: The company said LIFO charges were $1,614,000 for 1987, compared with $1,094,000 for the prior year.

description: Bill Moyers and Channel 13 plan to start a new, nightly public affairs program for the national Public Broadcasting Service next fall, according to officials at the station.

title: Yonkers Seeks to End Pact on Housing Ruling
description: Yonkers officials yesterday sought a Federal judge's release from their commitment not to appeal his housing-discrimination ruling to the United States Supreme Court and to allow them to make other changes in a recent agreement to desegregate the city's neighborhoods.

Shultz, Seeing Arab 'Time Bomb,' Urges Israelis to Rethink Borders
description: Pressing his campaign for Arab-Israeli peace talks, Secretary of State George P. Shultz today urged Israel to rethink its concept of defense and to address the ''ticking demographic time bomb'' of an Arab population under occupation.

title: Alice Lightner Hopf, Author, 83
description: Alice Lightner Hopf, a naturalist and the author of many books for children, died Feb. 3 at her Bucks County home in Upper Black Eddy, Pa. She was 83 years old.

description: b-Net loss

title: Connecticut Gains in Tourney
description: A year ago, Connecticut's Cliff Robinson and Phil Gamble were home in Storrs, watching their teammates lose, 61-59, to Boston College in the elimination game of the Big East Conference tournament.

title: Study Sees Bias in New York Teacher Exams
description: The tests New York City uses to license public school teachers are discriminatory, and the city should rely instead on a state-mandated test already in use, a Columbia Law School panel has recommended.

description: b-Net loss

Market Place; Analysts' View Of Oil Companies
description: SELECTIVE ''buy'' recommendations for oil stocks, which have enjoyed a mini-rally in recent months, are the order of the day on Wall Street. Analysts attribute part of this group's improvement to the expectation that crude oil prices will climb during the second half of 1988.

title: Bridge: A Celebrated New York Club Has Moved to a New Home
description: One of New York City's oldest and most celebrated clubs is the Mayfair, which has had many homes in the past half century. Its newest, as of yesterday, is at 51 East 25th Street.

title: Joint Agency Idea Attacked
description: The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission reiterated her position today that the agency should remain independent from the Securities and Exchange Commission. She also urged better coordination between the two regulatory agencies.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes gains of $341,145 and $480,412 from the sale of land for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Who's Living Up to the Arias Plan?
description: Nicaragua has gone further in complying with the Arias peace plan than Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. However tardily and grudgingly, the Sandinistas are negotiating directly with their sworn enemies, the contras. There's more diversity of published and spoken opinion in Managua than in those other three ostensibly democratic countries. Sure, the Sandinistas don't like democracy one bit and have harassed and jailed political opponents. But opposition figures are not murdered with impunity, as they are, shamefully, in El Salvador, Guatemala and Honduras.

title: McDonnell and Lockheed Talk
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had held exploratory subcontracting talks with the Lockheed Corporation and several other companies on producing its new commercial aircraft line.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Moscow on Wednesday about a new Soviet income tax misstated the number of employees in Soviet cooperatives.

title: Women's History Celebrated With Plays, Politics and Art
description: Here is a sampling of some of the New York events celebrating Women's History Month. Many other events will take place throughout the rest of March, most of them listed in the Women's History Month Calendar, an exhaustive free listing coordinated by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women.

title: CBS Is Said to Be Replacing Its Political Coverage Chief
description: Richard M. Cohen, a CBS News producer whose maverick actions sometimes provoked the ire of CBS management, has been told that he will be replaced as head of the network's political coverage.

title: Layoffs at Case IH
description: Tenneco Inc.'s Case IH subsidiary said it planned to cut employment worldwide during 1988 by about 3,000 workers, or 10 percent. The agricultural and construction equipment producer said the reductions, affecting all areas of the company, would take place in the next few months. ''Employment will be reduced through hourly and salaried layoffs, retirements, attrition, termination of temporary employees, a hiring freeze and improved manufacturing and staff productivity,'' Case said.

title: Big East Tournament; Parity May Emerge as Champion
description: Many reasonable observers think that this year's Big East Conference tournament is anyone's tournament, that any of six teams could wind up in Sunday's championship game. Pitt is the regular-season champion, Syracuse is right on the Panthers' heels, Seton Hall is on a roll, and Georgetown is ever Georgetown.

title: Mrs. Reagan Has Skin Patch Scraped From Her Upper Lip
description: A dermatologist removed a small patch of skin from Nancy Reagan's upper lip and tests show it to be noncancerous, her spokeswoman said today.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: On the List, Awaiting a Call for a Transplant
description: In a cluster of garden apartments here, almost 200 people from across the country wait, hoping the heart or liver or kidney that they need will be found in time.

title: New Meese Link to Pipeline Payment Is Reported
description: A $150,000 payment from Bruce Rappaport, a Swiss businessman, to his American lawyer for work on an Iraqi pipeline project was deposited into a stock trading account that made investments for several people, including Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, according to people familiar with the transaction.

title: Japanese Surplus in Trade With U.S. Shrinks by 14.4%
description: Japan's unadjusted trade surplus with the United States shrank 14.4 percent in February as imports from the United States reached record levels, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Milton Galamison, Leader in a Dispute Over the Schools, 65
description: The Rev. Milton A. Galamison, a Brooklyn pastor for four decades who was a major figure in the dispute over decentralizing the New York City schools in the 1960's, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 65 years old. Mr. Galamison, who wore a dashiki as he picketed construction sites to obtain more jobs for his fellow blacks and who led school boycotts to urge better education for minority-group children, served briefly as vice president of the New York City Board of Education.

title: SILVER KING MINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Old Soldier Mobilizes A Gray-Haired Army
description: Old soldiers never die, they just fade away, the refrain goes, but not according to Richard G. Stilwell, the retired Army general.

title: Restaurants
description: JOHN CLANCY no longer owns John Clancy's restaurant. His former chef, Sam Rubin, does - although Mr. Rubin is no longer chef. That job is handled by a capable young woman named Melissa Lord. If this is getting confusing, don't worry, the important news is that seven-year-old John Clancy's, the handsome all-seafood restaurant in Greenwich Village, is as good as ever, turning out some of the freshest and most arresting grilled fish in town.

title: A Cappella Choir
description: The King's Singers, an a cappella choir of seven male voices based at King's College, Cambridge, is to sing works from around the world, Sunday at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The program includes ''Scenes in America Deserta'' by the British composer John McCabe; a setting of the Lamentations of Jeremiah by the 17th-century Mexican composer Juan Gutierrez de Padilla; Dvorak's settings of Lithuanian folk songs, and two groups of American works -folk-song settings, and choral versions of works by Paul Simon. Tickets are $17.50. Information: 874-6770.

title: 'Brassai/Picasso' Show, Photos From '32 to '44
description: ''Brassai/Picasso,'' a collection of 33 black-and-white photographs of Picasso by the printmaker Brassai, will go on display today in the gallery of the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, 22 East 60th Street. The photos, made between 1932 and 1944, are on loan from the Picasso Museum in Paris and will remain on view until April 23.

title: KAY JEWELERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Because Jews Are Not a Nation of Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

description: Companies

title: CITIZENS SECURITY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a realized loss of $15,481 for the quarter and realized gains of $82,345 for the year. Year-ago results are not available because the company went public in December 1986.

title: The Verdict Is Libel, and the Trend Is Up
description: News organizations are losing more libel trials than they were earlier in the decade, according to a new study by the Libel Defense Resource Center.

title: Hans A. Panofsky, 70, Scientist
description: Hans A. Panofsky, an atmospheric scientist who taught at Pennsylvania State University for 30 years and who was credited with several advances in the study of meteorology, died of a cerebral hemorrhage after a heart attack on Feb. 28 in San Diego, where he lived. He was 70 years old.

title: Ear Retrieved and Restored
description: Doctors have reattached a 2-year-old boy's ear after retrieving it from the stomach of one of three pit bulls that mauled him. The boy, Chris Graham, was attacked by the dogs at his grandparents' farm on Tuesday, officials said.

title: Colt to Go Private for $660 Million
description: Colt Industries said yesterday that its directors had approved a $660 million buyout led by senior management and a Morgan Stanley & Company investor group.

title: Iraq Offers Cease-Fire in 'War of the Cities'
description: As missile attacks continued in the Persian Gulf war, Iraq offered today to halt the 11-day-old ''war of the cities'' with Iran Friday as long as Iraq fires the last shot.

title: Robertson Pares His Campaign
description: Pat Robertson brought a stripped-down Presidential campaign to Illinois today, vowing to stay in the race for the 1988 Republican nomination but virtually announcing a renewed candidacy for 1992.

title: Seagram to Buy Tropicana Products
description: Faced with a steady cooling in America's love affair with Scotch whisky and other so-called brown goods, the Seagram Company Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Tropicana Products Inc., makers of Tropicana orange juice, for $1.2 billion from the Beatrice Company.

title: Kansas City Journal; The Eyes That Can See the Ill Wind
description: The sounds still echo across 41 years. A tornado decimated Worth, a village of 200 people in northwest Missouri, killing 20 of Edward Ferguson's friends and neighbors. ''What I remember most was the weeping and wailing,'' Mr. Ferguson said the other day. ''And I remember thinking that there must be some way of warning people that a storm of this type is coming.''

title: The Wake-Up Alarm
description: At last, the danger of AIDS to heterosexuals in the United States has exploded into public debate.

title: Review/Art; An Unfamiliar Cezanne In the Basel Sketchbooks
description: Perhaps the most striking aspect of ''Paul Cezanne: The Basel Sketchbooks,'' a small exhibition now on view at the Museum of Modern Art, is that we learn little about this extraordinary artist's works on canvas. Or rather, we learn about them only obliquely. It is not the early modernist landscape and still-life painter one encounters here, but another, less familiar, Cezanne.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Farmers Rejects Batus Proposal
description: Farmers Group Inc. said that it had rejected as inadequate Batus Inc.'s unsolicited offer of $63 a share, or $4.35 billion, and that the company had held exploratory talks with an unspecified third party about a leveraged buyout.

title: U.S. Bonds Fall a Bit in Light Day
description: Treasury bond prices fell modestly yesterday, in reaction to higher prices for oil and gold.

title: OSBORN COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 KILLED IN CRASH OF A CARGO PLANE
description: A cargo plane that had just taken off from a Detroit airport crashed into a residential area today, striking a garage and a house, officials said. The pilot and a couple in the house were killed.

title: N.C.A.A. to Ban Fighters
description: If a player throws a punch during a national tournament game, he will be subject to immediate suspension, Dick Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said today.

title: Media General: A New Attack
description: Burt Sugarman, chairman of Barris Industries and Giant Group Ltd., mounted a new attack yesterday in his quest to take over Media General Inc.

Charles Escapes Injury; Avalanche Kills Friend
description: Prince Charles escaped injury today when an avalanche struck while he was skiing. A close friend was killed and another skier was injured.

title: Glenn Cunningham Dies
description: Glenn Cunningham, who dominated the mile at Madison Square Garden in the 1930's dies at 78 years of age. An obituary appears on Page D18.

title: New-Fashioned Films From Novice Directors
description: THE artist David Hockney peers down at a 17th-century Chinese scroll unrolled before him, depicting the emperor's voyage on the Grand Canal. As he leads us through the 72-foot-long painting, picking out bonsai-tree merchants and monks with begging bowls, he meditates about ways of seeing - including how the camera frame defines our vision in the very film we're watching.

title: Hamilton Grange, Once Moved, Still Handsome
description: To the Editor:

title: Horse Racing Notebook; Horses Can Stay at Hialeah
description: Forty Niner and Brian's Time, the early favorites for the Kentucky Derby on May 7, will not be thrown into the streets of Hialeah, Fla., next Tuesday, after all. John Brunetti, Hialeah's principal owner, has relented, deciding not to shut down the track's stable area. He has agreed to keep it open until April 1. That will give the colts another two weeks to train in the mild Florida weather before Brian's Time heads to New York and Forty Niner goes to Kentucky for their final Derby preparations.

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Electronic Associates said it settled with five electrical utilities on their claims resulting from agreements reached in 1984. The company also said the settlement, for $1.7 million in cash and 10- year warrants for purchase of 300,000 shares of Electronic Associates common stock at $6 a share, was recorded in the latest year.

title: A 12-Hour Marathon Of Porter Melodies
description: FOR millions of people, the name Cole Porter is synonymous with ultra-sophisticated love songs like ''Night and Day,'' ''I Get a Kick Out of You,'' and ''What Is This Thing Called Love?,'' songs that examine passion with a jeweler's eye and a wry, incisive wit. But Porter connoisseurs, of which there are a growing number, are just as likely to dote on brilliant obscurities like ''The Tale of the Oyster,'' a parody of a Schubert song that was dropped from the 1929 show ''Fifty Million Frenchmen'' after one critic found its lyric to be in bad taste.

title: NEW LINE CINEMA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Dance; Cunningham Spirit At Heart of Premiere
description: What is the point, some might ask while looking at Merce Cunningham's dances of non sequiturs. There is never a destination in view; one hardly knows - given the potentially interchangeable passages of dancing and the variation in sound scores from performance to performance -when a Cunningham premiere will end. Like a painting, it is ''finished'' when its creator decides.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Flyers 5, Capitals 2: Brian Propp scored two goals last night as Philadelphia broke Washington's five-game winning streak with a victory at home. The triumph moved the Flyers back into first place in the Patrick Division. The Flyers, who began play tied with the Islanders a point behind Washington, broke a three-game losing streak and also celebrated the return of Tim Kerr, who made his first appearance since last April 24. Kerr, a center, had been sidelined by a shoulder injury that required five operations. Propp's second goal came at 8 minutes 28 seconds of the final period on a power play and gave the Flyers a 4-2 lead. He fired a slap shot past Clint Malarchuk, the Capitals' goalie, from the right faceoff circle.(AP) Kings 3, Bruins 3: Bernie Nicholls scored his second goal of the game on a power play with five seconds remaining in the third period to give Los Angeles the tie in Boston. The Bruins had taken a 3-2 lead just 54 seconds earlier when Bob Joyce, who played on the Canadaian Olympic team, tipped in Glen Wesley's shot from the point for his third National Hockey League goal. Boston held a 2-1 lead after the first period, but Nicholls tied the score 2-2 at 15:25 when he interecepted a clearing pass and fired the puck into an open net with Reggie Lemelin, the Boston goalie, out of position. The point for the tie gave Los Angeles a 7-point lead over the Vancouver Canucks in the race for the fourth and final playoff berth in the Smythe Division. Boston is second in the Adams Division, 6 points behind the Montreal Canadiens. (AP) Red Wings 5, Canucks 2: Dave Barr scored twice to lead Detroit handed the visiting Canucks a record-tying ninth consecutive loss. The Canucks' losing streak tied a club mark initially set in 1975 and matched in 1984. Rick Zombo, a Detroit defenseman, scored his second goal of the season 36 seconds into the final period to snap a 2-2 tie as the Red Wings ran their unbeaten N.H.L. streak to six games. Vancouver played without Coach Bob McCammon, who was given a five-game suspension by league officials following an incident in a game earlier this week against the Islanders. Vancouver's David Bruce scored late in the second period to tie the score but Zombo took a pass from Gerard Gallant inside the Vancouver blue line and fired a slap shot past Steve Weeks, the goalie, to put Detroit ahead to stay. Jeff Sharples and Barr added goals 2:11 apart later in the period. It was Weeks's debut with Vancouver since he was acquired from Hartford earlier this week.(AP) CYCLING American Wins Third Leg: Andy Hampsten of the United States broke away from a small group in the final kilometers yesterday to win the third leg of the Paris-Nice race, beating Sean Kelly of Ireland by 27 seconds. Sean Yates of Britain held the overall lead of the race, which ends Sunday. Hampsten, riding for La Vie Clair, finished fourth in the Tour de France in 1986 but switched to the American team 7-Eleven last year and dropped out of the top rankings, although he did win the last two Tours of Switzerland.(AP) NORDIC SKIING Utah Strengthens Lead: Utah, bolstered by a strong performance from its men's cross-country team, widened its lead over Vermont yesterday at the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship in Hancock, Vt. Per Jakobsen of Colorado won the race in 34 minutes 18.4 seconds. But three Utah skiers placed in the top 10 to give the Utes 331 total points to Vermont's 299 after two days of the four-day competition. Utah and Wyoming tied for first in men's cross-country. In the women's race, Utah placed second to Vermont. Brenda White of Vermont, an Alpine skier who switched to cross-country, won the women's 10-kilometer race in 27:12.9.(AP) Double Victory for Norway: Norwegians scored a double biathlon triumph yesterday when Elin Kristiansen won the women's 10-kilometer individual event and Gisle Fenne won the men's 20-kilometer event at the World Cup races in Holmenkollen, Norway. Kristiansen, 19 years old, runner-up in the world championships in France a week ago, shot clean and beat the World Cup leader, Nedezda Alekseyeva of Bulgaria, by 46.8 seconds. Despite two misses on targets, and two minutes added to his racing time, Fenne was so fast that he beat Sergei Antonov of the Soviet Union by 1.2 seconds. It was Fenne's first World Cup victory. Frank-Peter Roetsch of East Germany, a double Olympic champion, and Valery Medvedtsev, who won a silver medal for the Soviet Union, were not entered. (AP) TENNIS Evert and Shriver Advance: Second-seeded Chris Evert and third-seeded Pam Shriver won third-round matches last night to enter the quarterfinals of the $300,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tournament in Boca Raton. Evert stopped Peanut Louie Harper of San Francisco, 6-1, 6-3 in 62 minutes. Shriver needed only 54 minutes to eliminate Nicole Provis of Australia, 6-4, 6-0. In afternoon matches, 11th-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami upset fifth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2, and Pascale Paradis eliminated eighth-seeded Raffaella Reggi of Italy, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2.(AP) HORSE RACING Lay Down Wins by Half a Length: Lay Down raced to a half-length victory yesterday in the $35,000 allowance feature at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old colt by Spectacular Bid and Impish stalked the leaders through the first seven furlongs, swung wide to take the lead entering the stretch and then maintained a slim advantage the rest of the way. Lay Down went the mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:47 to reach the wire ahead of French Connector. The victory was the fourth in six career starts for Lay Down, who earned $21,000 and returned $2.80 for $2 to win as the favorite in the field of six.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON U.N. CHARTER- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Working Group on International Standards of Accounting and Reporting - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Chrysler Financial To Offer Notes
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, the financing subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, will offer $500 million in medium-term notes, probably this week, and plans additional debt issues in Europe soon.

title: SOUTHEASTERN MICHIGAN GAS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gain Made on Down's Disease
description: Researchers have found a gene that produces a brain protein from a region of the human chromosome that is responsible for Down's syndrome, the most common form of mental retardation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Chrysler Corp. said it would consider resuming vehicle production in Europe if its new trans-Atlantic marketing drive leads to several years of rising sales. Chrysler expects to be selling cars and Jeeps in Europe at the rate of 25,000 a year by the end of 1988.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Apollo Stompers

title: Waldheim Apologizes for War Crimes by Austrians
description: President Kurt Waldheim publicly apologized today on behalf of his country for Nazi crimes committed by Austrians.

title: Robert S. Liebert, 58, Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Robert S. Liebert, a psychiatrist and author, died Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived and practiced in Manhattan.

title: Bonfire in Bronx!!! Wolfe Catches Flak!!!
description: He held on for dear life, as if a tornado were going to rise up at any moment and blow them out of the proper groove and -back to the Bronx! - ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' Tom Wolfe (1987)

title: ART PEOPLE
description: The Condo Technique

title: 2 Bombs Taken to School
description: A seventh-grader was expelled and a classmate was suspended for 30 days for making at least three bombs and taking them to school, reportedly to get revenge on a teacher, officials said today. The Boone County Board of Education took the action against the unidentified boys after hearings on March 1 and 2, school officials said.

title: Hofstra Ensemble
description: The American Chamber Ensemble, a resident performing group at Hofstra University, is to present a program of music by Long Island composers at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street, Sunday at 3 P.M. The ensemble, joined by Stanley Drucker, the principal clarinetist of the New York Philharmonic, will give the New York premiere of Elie Siegmeister's ''Prelude, Blues and Finale'' for two clarinets and piano. Also featured are David Hollister's ''Tributaries'' for clarinet and piano; Judith Lang Zaimont's ''From the Great Land: Woman's Songs'' for mezzo-soprano, clarinet, piano and Eskimo drum, and Irwin Swack's ''Profiles'' for violin, cello and clarinet. Tickets are $10, or $5 for students. Information: 841-9633 or (516) 541-9090.

title: SIGMA DESIGNS reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
About Real Estate; Tuxedo, N.Y., Enters Subdivision Era
description: Tuxedo, a 46-square-mile community of 3,800 residents and 1,500 homes, lies in New York's Orange County not far from the border with New Jersey's Passaic County.

title: A Democracy With Ever Fewer Voters?
description: The news media blitz of Super Tuesday's caucuses and primaries underscored a remarkable, though largely unnoted, fact: Politics, increasingly, is purely a spectator sport.

title: At the Movies
description: A Fresh 'Cookie'

title: New York Panel to Urge Broader Role for Teachers
description: A task force appointed by the State Education Commissioner is expected to recommend that schools throughout New York be restructured to give teachers a greater decision-making role in areas ranging from textbook selection to hiring practices.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
U.S.F.L. Loses Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court in New York yesterday upheld a 1986 verdict that effectively ended the existence of the United States Football League.

title: Review/Film; Rob Lowe and Meg Tilly Team in a 'Masquerade'
description: The makers of ''Masquerade'' had a great idea: put Rob Lowe in Top-Siders. As the golden-boy skipper of a racing yacht anchored off the Hamptons, Mr. Lowe has an appeal he never manifested in earlier, sulkier post-adolescent roles. This time, Mr. Lowe has the more interesting job of playing Tim Whalan, whose good looks, good manners and racing record make him very much in demand, especially among those Hamptons residents who know about his other, less obvious talents. In Tim's case, still waters definitely run deep.

title: Officer Accused of Supplying Guns and Badges to a Robber
description: A police officer was arrested yesterday and accused of being involved with another policeman in supplying police shields, guns and walkie-talkies to at least one other man who used them to impersonate a police officer in a Bronx robbery.

title: Southdown Lifts Offer To Moore McCormack
description: Southdown Inc., the Houston-based cement manufacturer, increased its bid for Moore McCormack Resources Inc., the Stamford, Conn., cement manufacturer, to $35 a common share from $31 a share, raising the total value of the deal to $450 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let us not give rise to the impression that we had nothing to do with this. Obviously there is no collective guilt. Nevertheless, as head of state of the Republic of Austria, I wish to apologize for Nazi crimes committed by Austrians.'' - President Kurt Waldheim. [ A3:3. ]

title: Conference Tournaments; Fairleigh Dickinson Wins And Gains an N.C.A.A. Berth
description: E.C.A.C. METRO

title: Gwynn May Need Surgery
description: Tony Gwynn, the Padres outfielder who batted .370 and won his second National League batting title last season, will return to San Diego so that doctors can examine his injured left index finger. He will probably undergo surgery Friday, and, according to the team trainer, Dick Den, he will be sidelined from four to six weeks. The Padres will open their season in three and a half weeks.

title: Mullin Helps Warriors Top Nets, 128-112
description: Chris Mullin scored 26 points, and Steve Harris, a reserve guard, had a 24 tonight for the Golden State Warriors, who snapped an eight-game losing streak with a 128-112 victory over the Nets.

title: 2 Accounts This Week For Traham, Burden
description: So far this has been a memorable week for Traham, Burden & Charles of Baltimore. It has picked up two nice accounts.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Weekend; 'Bacall on Bogart,' Profile of the Ultimate Tough Guy
description: Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall met each other in 1944. He was in his mid-40's; she was 19. The star and the starlet had been signed to make ''To Have and Have Not,'' the first of their four movies together. They were married in 1945. He died in 1957.

title: Panel told Cleanup of Weapon Plants May Cost $100 Billion
description: Cleaning up the Energy Department's nuclear weapons production plants may cost as much as $100 billion and will pose a major challenge for the Federal Government, a House panel was told today.

title: Jersey Examines Drinking On Its College Campuses
description: The New Jersey Chancellor of Higher Education said today that he would convene a meeting of student and fraternity leaders across the state to re-examine the role of student organizations in the wake of the death of a Rutgers University freshman during a fraternity initiation party.

title: Scientists, Using Mirrors, Match Energy Intensity of Sun's Surface
description: In a development promising major advances in space communications, lasers and the processing of materials, scientists at the University of Chicago have concentrated the sun's energy at 60,000 times its normal intensity on earth, exceeding the previous record by more than three times.

title: A Test of Change Explodes in Soviet
description: Two years ago Igor Muradyan, a young economist living in Yerevan, joined a small group of Armenian intellectuals for what they took to be an exercise in democracy.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allen Group Inc., Melville, L.I., a maker of automotive diagnostic equipment and parts for the automotive supply market, said the board had accepted the resignation of Walter B. Kissinger as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Kissinger will remain a director and serve as a consultant to the company.

title: AMVESTORS FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment losses of $152,000 and $806,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $235,000. c-Includes realized investment gains of $6,000 for the quarter and $721,000 for the year, and tax credits of $102,000 and $257,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Reagan Considering Measures to Weaken Panamanian Leader
description: President Reagan and his senior advisers today considered a range of sanctions for the United States to impose to worsen a crippling cash flow crisis for the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama.

title: Feeling Safe
description: ''Semper Paratus - Always Ready'' is the motto of the United States Coast Guard. And so, there they were, 28 active duty Guardsmen and 13 reservists, protecting the Kansas coast of the Missouri River ''against any possible threat of terrorism,'' according to the service's Reservist issue for March.

title: CASTLE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,980,474.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Wednesday from Managua, Nicaragua, reported the abandonment of efforts to convene talks this week between the Sandinista Government and its guerrilla opponents. The Government dropped the plan after the contras said they would not attend, and each side accused the other of bad faith. The headline said, ''Sandinistas Call Off Contra Meeting.'' In fairness, it should have reported the collapse of the negotiation plan without attributing it to either side.

title: Armani an Anchor in a Time of Fashion Flux
description: Giorgio Armani provided a soothing, reassuring conclusion to the fall and winter fashion openings here. In showings Wednesday night and tonight, each for 500 people in the theater of his headquarters on the Via Borgonuovo, he showed short hemlines and gently shaped clothes. His sure hand dissipated some of the confusion about the new fashion scene. His proportions worked.

title: 48.24 DROP PUTS DOW AT 2,026,03
description: LEAD: Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 48.24 points to close at 2,026.03. That was the Dow's third-biggest point drop of the year.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Feb. 24 about the Equitable Gas Company misstated the size of its advertising budget for 1988. It is $750,000, a company spokesman said.

title: At The Bar
description: Complaints about incompetent lawyers and frivolous litigation are perennial. But they reached a peak in the early 1980's, with the nation's top lawyer, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, leading the assault. Indeed, along with his attacks on advertising by lawyers and his scuffles with television photographers, Chief Justice Burger's acidic comments on silly lawsuits were as much a ritual at bar gatherings as cocktail parties.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Ray Hayward and David Masters, pitchers, and Rick Wilkins and Bill Bathe, catchers, to the minor league camp for reassignment. COLLEGES ALABAMA - Reinstated Joe King, tackle. ARIZONA STATE - Announced that the contract of Clyde Duncan, track coach, would not be renewed. COLUMBIA - Promoted Pat O'Leary to full-time linebacker coach. FLORIDA - Named Charlie Strong outside-linebacker coach. RUTGERS - Named Mark Tracey wrestling coach. SLIPPERY ROCK - Named Tom Herman defensive coordinator. FOOTBALL NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Waived Larry Linne, wide receiver. SAN FRANCISCO (NFC) - Signed Steve Apke and Jon Cox, linebackers; Dale Dawson, kicker; Mario Perry and Scott Eccles, tight ends; Alfred Jenkins, quarterback; Marion Knight, defensive end; Paul O'Connor, guard; Eric Richardson, wide receiver, and Bruce Tiller, wide receiver-defensive back. HOCKEY ISLANDERS (NHL) - Recalled Chris Pryor, defenseman, from Kalamazoo of the International Hockey League. OLYMPICS 1992 WINTER OLYMPICS ORGAN-IZING COMMITTEE - Named Jean-Claude Killy co-president.

title: Review/Film; 'Vice Versa,' A Comedy
description: Luck doesn't get any worse than it has for ''Vice Versa,'' the twin of an identically plotted film released only a few months previously. Originality isn't a factor for either this or ''Like Father, Like Son,'' since they both owe a good deal to the earlier ''Freaky Friday,'' but timeliness undoubtedly is.

title: PICK 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Norway's Statoil in Red
description: Norway's state oil company, Statoil, today reported a record loss of $300 million for 1987, in contrast to 1986's profit of $180 million. The loss was caused by cost overruns in the expansion of the Mongstad refinery.

title: Glenn Cunningham, 78, Premier Miler of 1930's
description: Glenn Cunningham, a former world-record holder in the mile run who in 1979 was named the greatest track performer in the history of Madison Square Garden, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Menifee, Ark. He was 78 years old. According to Robert Mitchell, the Conway County Coroner, Mr. Cunningham was found dead in his pickup truck near his farm for exotic animals.

title: Jamie Subpoenas Reported; Trader Is Released to Clinic
description: As many as a dozen more subpoenas have been sent by the United States Attorney to current and former employees of Jamie Securities, the investment firm run by John A. Mulheren Jr., according to Wall Street professionals with knowledge of the Government investigation.

title: The Anschluss
description: LEAD: Exactly 50 years ago, the Anschluss - ''union'' in the German language - made Austria part of the Third Reich. Within hours, it transformed me along with all Jews in its reach. The event has three dimensions in my mind, each distinct from the others.

title: Lorimar Overture By Davis
description: The Lorimar Telepictures Corporation, which is already in preliminary discussions about a possible merger with Warner Communications Inc., said yesterday that Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, had asked for a meeting to discuss a possible sale of the company for $17 a share in cash.

title: Search for New Oil Is Growing
description: The price of oil has fallen by a sharp $3 a barrel in recent weeks, and some analysts predict that it could go lower by summer. But the major American oil companies, believing that the price drop is transitory, are significantly increasing their spending to find new oil and gas.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 420 money market mutual funds increased $1.41 billion, to $280.06 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds increased $423.7 million, to $82.17 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were down $306.5 million, to $81.5 billion. The 97 broker-dealer funds increased $1.29 billion, to $116.39 billion.

title: Blue Wave Band
description: Jean-Paul Bourelly, a guitarist, leads his Blue Wave band, with Daniel Ponce as guest percussionist, tomorrow at 8 and 10 P.M. at Jazztrack, 27 Barrow Street (645-2387). Admission is $12.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The New Jesse Jackson
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who came out of Super Tuesday a certifiably mainstream candidate, really is different this year. Four years ago, such a showing would likely have provoked him to an indignant denunciation of the disparity between his popular vote and the delegates he earned. This year, Mr. Jackson reacted with almost introspective humility.

title: Cardigan Bay Dies at 31
description: Cardigan Bay, a pacer from New Zealand who in 1968 became the first horse in harness racing history to win $1 million in purses, died peacefully in his sleep at the age of 31 last Friday on Puketutu Island off Auckland, New Zealand.

title: Dallas Pastor Warned His Wife
description: A former minister left two telephone messages for his wife the night she was choked nearly to death, describing his whereabouts in detail and warning her to lock the garage door, according to tape recordings released today Walker Railey, who was senior pastor of the United Methodist Church of Dallas at the time of the attack, told the police he found his wife, Margaret, unconscious on the floor of the garage at their home April 22. She had been choked with a cord and remains in a coma.

title: Fraud Arrest Is Linked to Murder of a Millionaire
description: An associate of Irwin Schiff, a millionaire businessman who was slain last August, was arrested yesterday on charges that he and Mr. Schiff defrauded finance companies of $29 million in loans. As a result, the authorities said, an arrest in Mr. Schiff's murder may be imminent.

title: Defense Rests In Chambers Case
description: The defense rested yesterday in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., and court officials said the case would probably go to the jury next week.

title: Soprano in Recital
description: Carol Donn Trainor, a soprano who sang at the New York City Opera and toured the Far East with the U.S.O. more than 20 years ago, will sing works by Scarlatti, Mozart, Richard Strauss, Schubert, Dvorak, Rimsky-Korsakov and Hugo Wolf in a recital Sunday at 2 P.M. at Weill Recital Hall. Her accompanist will be Oksana Protenic. Tickets, at $10, or $7 for students and the elderly, are available at the Carnegie Hall box office. They will go on sale at the Weill box office one hour before the performance. Information: 247-7800.

title: Boy, 15, Is Convicted of Murder for Thrill
description: A 15-year-old boy who beat a classmate to death with a baseball bat because he wanted to know what it was like to kill someone was convicted of murder today and sentenced to life in prison.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on March 3 about tapestries misidentified the site where a weaving in the ''Microchip'' series by Joyce Crain is displayed. It is at the Lafarge Corporation in Reston, Va. Another tapestry in the series is at Automatic Data Processing in Dayton, N.J.

title: Man, 80, Killed In Hit-Run
description: An 80-year-old man was struck by a car and killed in a hit-and-run accident in the Fort Washington section of Manhattan last night, the police said. The victim, Allen Grayson, of 539 West 179th Street, was crossing Fort Washington Avenue near 179th Street at 7:15 P.M. when he was struck by a white Datsun whose driver drove north on Fort Washington Avenue, Park, N.J., according to Sgt. John Clifford, a police spokesman. The police found the car shortly afterward at 190th Street and Amsterday Avenue and arrested Joseph Zimmerman, 22, of Elmwood Park, N.J. Mr. Zimmerman was charged with leaving the scene of an accident.

title: McGuigan to Return
description: Barry McGuigan of Northern Ireland won the world featherweight championship from Eusebio Pedroza on June 8, 1985. He defended it twice, then lost a controversial decision to Stevie Cruz in Las Vegas, Nev., on June 23, 1986. He has not fought since. McGuigan, 27 years old, plans to make his comeback April 20 in London as a superfeatherweight against one of three opponents - Francisco Tomas Cruz of Brazil, Gerome Porras of Puerto Rico, or Tommie Cordova of the United States. If McGuigan wins, he would fight again within five weeks, followed by a shot at a second world title in July, according to his manager, Frank Warren. ''If I'm not happy with my buildup, preparation and performance, I won't waste anyone's time by going for the world title,'' McGuigan said. ''I want to be as good as before. I want to be world champion again. But I don't intend to fool anyone and I certainly don't need the money.''

title: Caernarvon Journal; Firebrands vs. Linguists In Land of the Griffins
description: The fervid movement to keep Wales Welsh has slipped into extremism, with arsonists torching scores of vacation homes of prosperous Thatcherite newcomers from the Welshman's ancient source of worry, adjacent England.

title: Wang Expects Smaller Profits
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it expected third-quarter earnings and revenues to fall, and its stock dropped sharply as analysts lowered their earnings estimates for the maker of minicomputers and office work stations.

title: U.S. Says Haitian Officer Aided Drug Smuggling
description: United States officials charged today that an influential Haitian Army officer provided a ''secure airstrip'' for smuggling cocaine through Haiti to the United States.

title: LIPOSOME CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest periods included a gain of $625,000 from the sale of an investment in a joint venture.

title: H&H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a special charge of $667,000 related to the June trial of a class action lawsuit. c-Net loss d-Includes a special charge of $1,600,000 related to the writedown of certain rental tools.

title: Yank Has Influential Friends
description: On the day he became a Yankee last season, Randy Velarde wore a look of wonder, not unlike that of a 5-year-old walking into kindergarten for the first time. But in the seven months that have since passed -from last August to this spring training camp - Velarde has grown from innocence.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Liz Magnes's Jazz

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $314,000 from discontinued operations and the disposal of a segment. c-Net income and after income of $3,194,000 for the quarter and $5,331,000 for the year from discontinued operations and the disposal of a segment.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes capital gains of $3,370,000 and $17,510,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $174,000 for the quarter and $302,000 for the year. c-Includes capital gains of $2,955,000 for the quarter and $10,881,000 for the year, and tax credits of $570,000 and $18,101,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-earlier share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1987.

title: The World Bank Remains Financially Strong
description: To the Editor:

title: On Finding the U.S.P.
description: When the 10 members of the newly created international management committee of Backer Spielvogel Bates, including David Beecroft from far-off Hong Kong, come to town on May 16 for their first meeting, they will hear from a fellow member, William M. Backer, deputy chairman and worldwide creative head, who will instruct them on how to judge advertising and how to find the unique selling proposition, or U.S.P., according to Mr. Backer. That just shows that old Ted Bates genes are alive and well in the new body.

title: Presidio Oil Makes Hostile Sabine Bid
description: The Presidio Oil Company, an oil and gas concern based in Englewood, Colo., began a hostile tender offer of $20 a share, or $256 million, for the Sabine Corporation. Presidio also plans a proxy contest to gain control of the board of the Dallas oil and gas exploration and production concern, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Presidio told the S.E.C. that it would finance its hostile bid through a $275 million credit agreement with the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: K Mart Net Increases 12.7%
description: The K Mart Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of its latest fiscal year rose 12.7 percent on a 7.2 percent increase in sales.

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a deduction of $2,212,250 for net unrealized losses in the company's investment portfolio. The company said the latest year and prior year revenue includes gains on sale of securities of $2,584,331 and $207,270, respectively.

title: Forstmann Drops Plan for AFG Bid
description: After reviewing confidential financial information, Forstmann Little & Company said it was dropping its plan to submit a competing tender offer for AFG Industries, which earlier this month accepted a $940 million buyout bid from its chairman. A spokesman for Forstmann Little declined to elaborate. The decision came a week after Forstmann announced its intent to pay more than $33 a share for the glass maker, which is the price of the management offer. Shares of AFG, based in Irvine, Calif., plunged $5 today, to $31.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Review/Film; 'Off Limits,' a Thriller
description: The story is nothing out of the ordinary: two tough-talking, super-macho detectives are put on the trail of a serial killer, a sadomasochist who has been murdering prostitutes and is sure to do it again. But the setting raises the ante, since it is the turbulent, troubled Saigon of 1968 in which ''Off Limits'' unfolds. Here things automatically become more dangerous and perverse; here certain unavoidable ironies are built into the situation. By rights, ''Off Limits'' should never have been as conventional as it turns out to be.

title: SATELLITE INFORMATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; Sly, Sardonic Feminism From a West German
description: Rosemarie Trockel's exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, the latest in the ''Projects'' series, offers the first extended look at the work of a European artist who has attracted a great deal of interest on this side of the Atlantic. This look, which consists of three walls full of small, delicate drawings made between 1982 and 1987, and two examples of recent sculpture, is somewhat surprising. Miss Trockel is best known here for tough machine-knit paintings that are frequently filed under Neo-Geo. The work at the Modern emphasizes a Neo-Expressionist side of the West German artist's sensibility that is more accessible, but also more conventional.

title: Recital Is Canceled
description: The joint recital by the violinist Shlomo Mintz and the pianist Yefim Bronfman that was scheduled for Sunday at 3 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall has been canceled. Mr. Mintz has the flu. The concert will not be rescheduled. Refunds are available by mail or in person at the Fisher Hall box office.

title: GENESEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Where Two Can Dine for Under $50
description: DINNER for two in the average New York restaurant has broken the three-digit barrier, and with a little imagination when it comes to wine, the damages could easily surpass $150. Add to that expense drinks before dinner, miscellaneous service tips, the coat check fees, cab fare, maybe a baby sitter and a trip to the dry cleaner afterward to get that chocolate stain out of your new silk tie, and you may resort to looting the Christmas Club account to pay for the singular luxury of dining out in the big city.

title: BELL COPTER AND ARMY SETTLE CASE
description: The Army and Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. have settled a four-year dispute over accusations that the Army was fraudulently overcharged for helicopter spare parts. The Army said today that Bell had agreed to pay the Government about $88 million.

title: Coach of the Year: 'We'
description: P. J. CARLESIMO believes in ''we.'' He believes in it so much that ''we'' were named Big East coach of the year yesterday, ''we'' received a five-year extension worth as much as $1 million from Seton Hall University on Wednesday, and ''we'' have a chance against Georgetown this afternoon.

title: MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-After a loss of $827,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income and after a gain of $776,000 from a tax benefit.

title: Doubts Increase on Need For Early Mammogram
description: A new report on the value of mammograms to detect breast cancer questions whether they are worth the expense in women under 50 years old who have no symptoms and who are at low risk for the disease.

title: NATIONAL MEDIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: IMMUNOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Rivals Switch Emphasis to Electability
description: With the great battle for the South behind them and Illinois's rich cache of delegates in front of them, the remaining candidates for President today began looking toward the general election in November and at who had the best chance of winning then.

title: Officer's Father Thanks Public For Outpouring
description: The father of Edward Byrne, the rookie police officer killed while guarding a witness in a narcotics case, yesterday thanked ''the people from all over country,'' including President Reagan, ''whose messages of support and sorrow sustained us during this time of personal tragedy.''

title: ON STAGE
description: If Rumor Were All

title: Federal-City Effort Attacks Violent Brooklyn Drug Ring
description: One of the largest and most violent drug rings operating in Brooklyn has been smashed with the arrest of the group's leader and five major associates, Federal and city law-enforcement officials said yesterday. Another associate is being sought.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LESLIE FAY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes non-recurring credit of $5,035,000, or 26 cents a share, from the elimination of an estimated liability for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a non-recurring charge of $1,690,000 from the early repayment of a bank term loan. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
description: b-Includes a gain of $426,302 from an accounting change.

title: CABOT MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
WOLVERINE EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $193,000 and $88,561,000 from debt restructuring for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss The year-ago periods were restated.

title: This Drive Carried As If It Had Wings
description: A sea gull took off with a couple of golf balls today during the first round of the Honda Classic, causing Brad Faxon to wonder if nature's creatures just don't like him.

title: S.I. Boy, 10, Is Shot As 3 Play With Guns
description: A 10-year-old Staten Island boy was shot and critically wounded yesterday morning as he and two other boys were examining three guns in a playground.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Met Feels 2 Kinds of Pain Double Pain for Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry sat sullenly in front of his locker today with a strained hamstring muscle and a severely bruised ego, and admitted, ''It's a hurting situation.''

title: HE CANCELS TV ADS
description: Senator Bob Dole tonight canceled his television advertisements for the Illinois primary. Several top aides urged him to concede the state, and thus almost certainly the Republican Presidential nomination, to Vice President Bush.

title: INDONESIAN LEADER SEEKS TO BAR VOTE
description: President Suharto, who was elected to a fifth five-year term in office Thursday, has asked that a vote for Vice President be canceled.

title: Review: New Directors/New Films; 'Wedding in Galilee,' Palestinian Village Tensions
description: ''Wedding in Galilee'' cannot help but seem exotic to Western eyes, as it lures us into a ritual wedding feast in a Palestinian village in Israel. Michel Khleifi, a writer and director who was born and raised in Nazareth and now lives in Brussels, relies on a wandering, Eastern-style narrative to depict Palestinian traditions threatened by 20th-century inroads.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LEGEND has it that Marco Polo packed his saddle bags with pasta from China in the 13th century and carried it back to Italy, where it became a national dish. Be that true or not - I find it difficult to believe that he didn't polish it off en route - pasta of all sorts has never ceased to be popular in China. A variety of intriguing Chinese pasta dishes can be sampled at the new David K's Cafe, a casual, comfortable spot that is one of the better bargains on the East Side.

title: Largest Initial Offering Set By Massachusetts Financial
description: The Massachusetts Financial Services Company, the Boston-based investment advisory firm, has arranged to sell $2 billion worth of stock in a new bond fund that would be the largest initial public offering of shares ever arranged.

title: They Do Us Proud
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Harvard Says No to Teacher's Tenure
description: Derek Bok, president of Harvard University, refused today to grant tenure to an assistant law professor associated with an ideology challenging the traditional view of the law.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $468,000.

title: Suffolk Suit Accuses Lilco Of Lying
description: Suffolk County's civil suit against the Long Island Lighting Company accuses the utility of repeatedly lying to and filing false documents with regulatory commissions in its efforts to complete its Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: 3 White Men in Bronx Arraigned In Assaults That Injured 5 Blacks
description: Three white men were arraigned yesterday on attempted murder charges in random attacks on blacks in the Bronx that the police said followed a black prostitute's rejection of their offers. The authorities have described the incident as racially motivated.

title: ROSE'S STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Included a gain of $2,422,000 from the sale of real estate. Operating results for the latest fourth quarter included a LIFO charge of $4 million, which included a $2.1 million adjustment related to the first three quarters. There was a LIFO charge of $6 million for all of 1987, and $1,220,000 for 1986.

title: MIDDLEBY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Talley Plans to Retain McMullen's Chairman
description: John J. McMullen has made a career of sports and business since he retired from the Navy as a captain in 1954.

title: Jim Hall Quartet
description: The jazz guitarist Jim Hall is to lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Biaggi Accused of Greed By Wedtech Prosecutor
description: Representative Mario Biaggi was accused by a Government prosecutor yesterday of demanding millions of dollars in bribes for helping a South Bronx company win military contracts.

title: Swaggarts Appeal for Funds
description: The Jimmy Swaggart Ministries will begin a nationally televised appeal for money on Saturday in which the evangelist's family pleads that ''everything could be finished'' unless contributions pick up.

title: INSIDE
description: Theaters as Landmarks

title: Speaker Seeking To Trim Power Of School Board
description: The Speaker of the New York State Assembly said yesterday that he would push legislation to reduce the power of members of the New York City Board of Education by stripping them of their salaries and perquisites.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ben Feliciano, a jockey at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore, was fined $300 yesterday after Zeus Belle, a filly he was riding, was blinded in the right eye on Monday. Feliciano's whip broke the plastic cup of the horse's blinkers, damaging the horse's eye with splinters. Zeus Belle, who finished third, will probably continue racing whether or not she undergoes surgery to save the eye. . . . Ralph Sampson, the center for the Golden State Warriors, underwent surgery on his right knee yesterday in Charlottesville, Va., and will remain at the University of Virginia until he rejoins his teammates when they play the Rockets tomorrow in Houston. Sampson who had three floating bodies removed from his knee, is not expected to play again this season. . . . Gary Halpin, a senior at Manhattan College, won the 35-pound weight throw at the National Collegiate Athletic Association Indoor Track and Field Championships in Oklahoma City with a throw of 68 feet 3 inches, a personal best. . . . Bernie Nicholls, a center for the Los Angeles Kings, has been suspended for five games because of a match penalty he received in a March 9 game against Hartford. Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president, said in a statement that Nicholls ''deliberately swung his stick at his opponent'' and that Nicholls admitted it was in retaliation for a check earlier in the game. (AP)

title: Morris E. Kaufman, 50, a Mortgage Banker
description: Morris Enouch Kaufman, co-founder and chairman of American Mortgage Banking Ltd., died of heart failure March 5 at his home in Floral Park, Queens. He was 50 years old.

title: Demonstrations by the Deaf Bring A Resignation but Not Yet a Truce
description: The new president of Gallaudet University, the nation's only college for the deaf, resigned early today in response to protests by students and faculty because she was not deaf.

title: Review/Television; Michael Jackson Profile on Cable Shows His Star Quality as a Child
description: Michael Jackson may have lost out on the top laurels at the recent Grammy Awards, but he still was the indisputable star of the show. Glancing over my shoulder during his sensational ''Man in the Mirror'' production number, I caught the members of Ireland's U2 group, which did win several top awards, watching the stage with unabashed respect and admiration.

title: Tables Curtailed
description: Futures and options tables reflect trading only up to 1 P.M. because of a power failure. Settlement prices unavailable.

title: Drug Found to Reduce Pain In Circumcision of Newborns
description: A local anesthetic provides a safe and effective way to reduce the distress of circumcision of infant boys, a new study has shown.

title: U.A.W. and Chrysler Agree to Early Talks
description: The United Automobile Workers has agreed to early contract talks with Chrysler Corporation, the union's president, Owen F. Bieber, says.

title: Article 131888 -- No Title
description: The British financier Lord Spens was released on bail of $925,000 today and ordered to surrender his passport as a result of four charges connected with the 1986 takeover of a whisky company by the British-Irish brewer Guinness P.L.C.

title: Official Predicts Lower Limit on Drug in Pork
description: The Food and Drug Administration will lower the permissible level of a widely used animal drug in American pork because the drug has been found to cause cancer in mice, an official at the agency says.

title: Jersey Commission Proposes Major Shift in Tax Burden
description: A commission on state taxes and spending approved recommendations today to help cut property taxes while easing the burden on lower-income families by raising taxes on those earning more than $50,000 a year.

title: Big East; PIRATES TURN BACK HOYAS AND MOVE INTO SEMIFINALS
description: There has been jubilation at Seton Hall over the last few days: the basketball coach signed a new contract on Wednesday, and won the Big East coach-of-the-year award on Thursday. But Seton Hall players knew yesterday that it would take more than momentum and optimism to beat Georgetown in the Big East tournament.

title: The Gore Foreign Policy 'Difference': Generally Less Liberal Than Rivals
description: In his bid for the Presidency, Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee has relied on a strategy that emphasizes the conservative side of his record to set himself apart from the rest of the Democratic field and to support his contention that he has the best chance of being elected.

title: Seattle Bids To Make Old Rails New Trails
description: When the Burlington Northern Railroad confirmed last month that it had sold parts of this city's popular bicycling and jogging trail to a wealthy real estate developer, some critics said it was as if the Space Needle had gone condo.

title: 2 Tiny Bullet Wounds Found
description: An undertaker found two bullet wounds in the body of a 58-year-man thought by authorities to have died a natural death on March 9 in his Greenwich Village apartment. The death of John Hunter of 52 Carmine Street was ruled a homicide yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner after X-rays confirmed that there were very small bullet wounds to the scalp and groin, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Raymond O'Donnell.

title: Review/Jazz; Detroit Musicians Imported
description: New York doesn't have an exclusive on first-rate young jazz musicians. To record an album next week for Nonesuch Records, Geri Allen, a keyboardist, has imported a singer and a half-dozen instrumentalists from Detroit, and she's warming them up - and introducing them to New York listeners - with a four-night stand through tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street at Mulberry Street.

title: Steve Mills, Comedian In Vaudeville Days, 92
description: Steve Mills, one of the last of the vaudeville comedians who worked with the Shubert organization in the 1930's and 1940's, died Wednesday at his home. He was 92 years old.

title: For Soviet Emigres, Family Visits Still Difficult
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18.

title: Suzanne Lee Bricker Bride Of William Joseph Sullivan
description: Suzanne Lee Bricker and William Joseph Sullivan were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. William D. Roberts.

title: New York Area Retail Sales Dip
description: A number of leading retailers had an average decline in sales of 1.6 percent in the New York metropolitan area in February, compared with the same month of 1987. The retailers' stores in New York City, however, had an average gain of 2.5 percent.

title: Toni Bodini, Restaurateur, Is Married to Jean Goutal
description: Toni Allen Bodini and Jean Goutal, partners in the Tapis Rouge restaurant in New York, were married Wednesday at the Manhattan home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Hamilton Kramer, by the Rev. David Cockcroft, a Presbyterian minister.

title: About New York; Where Is Romeo In This World Of Hip-Hop?
description: A couple of fellows from the Royal Shakespeare Company have been in town for a fortnight trying to show students from 45 schools that the Bard was user friendly, not impenetrable. All this week the two gentlemen of London have focused on Verona, the setting of ''The Tragedy of Romeo and Juliet,'' and ninth graders who cast a less than enthusiastic eye on the work at the outset have come away thinking it didn't hurt so much after all.

title: ISRAELI REJECTS SHULTZ PLAN
description: Two days before his departure on a crucial visit to Washington, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today sharply criticized the newest United States proposals for a Mideast peace settlement.

title: Time Up for Pound Note
description: The British Treasury withdrew the pound banknote from service today, nearly 200 years after introducing it to conserve gold. Pound coins, introduced in 1983, will replace the notes, which were first printed in 1797. The notes will no longer be accepted as legal tender in shops but can still be exchanged at banks. Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduced the pound note when he feared that an invasion by Napoleon was imminent.

title: Italy's Leader Resigns Amid Rift on Nuclear Plant
