description: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned tonight after his Government split apart over a decision to resume the construction of a nuclear power plant. It was the third time that Mr. Goria had quit since taking office almost eight months ago, but this time his departure seemed final.

title: American Brands
description: American Brands Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn., said it had decided to dispose of three additional subsidiaries of its recently acquired E-II Holdings Inc.: the Culligan International Company, the Samsonite Corporation and most of the Samsonite Furniture Company. American Brands said it would retain the Vogel Peterson division of Samsonite Furniture. The company, which completed the acquisition of E-II on Feb. 29, had previously announced it would sell several of E-II's specialty food businesses, including Lowrey's Meat Specialties Inc., Aunt Nellie's Farm Kitchen Inc., Martha White Foods Inc., Beatreme Food Ingredients Inc., Pet Specialties Inc. and Frozen Food Specialties Inc.

title: Iran and Iraq Call a Halt to Missile Strikes on Cities
description: After 12 days and hundreds of casualties, Iran and Iraq stopped missile attacks on each other's cities this afternoon. But each side threatened to resume the strikes if the other broke the unofficial truce.

title: Young (63) Jack Lemmon Gets Film Institute Award
description: The American Film Institute gave its 16th annual Life Achievement Award to Jack Lemmon at a fund-raising dinner Thursday night. Mr. Lemmon was praised for his decency, dedication and how good he looks in women's clothes.

title: Syracuse Wins
description: In Jim O'Brien's estimation, Boston College did not have many options. The Eagles could have attempted to fly with Syracuse, and the game would have probably been over at halftime. So with apologies, O'Brien chose to have his team hold the basketball yesterday for as long as the rules allowed, hoping to frustrate the Orangemen, perhaps even lull them into a false sense of security.

title: Petra T. Shattuck, 46, Lawyer and Professor
description: Petra Tolle Shattuck, a lawyer who specialized in the legal status of American Indians and who taught civil liberties and American constitutional law at the City University of New York, died Wednesday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage a week ago. She was 46 years old.

title: Amid Despair, She Tries to Bring Hope
description: For 31 years, Margit Homs has been braiding the hair of other people's children, helping them with their homework, teaching them to tie their shoes.

title:
Patents;
New Cathode Tube
description: LEAD: An improved cathode ray tube was patented this week for the Zenith Electronics Corporation. Patent 4,730,143 was awarded to James R. Fendley, a staff engineer. The tube has a flat tension mask supported directly by the face plate. The improved tube is being used in computer monitors.

title: New York State Courts More Open Than Ever
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: March 12, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6, 32 Robert McFarlane pleaded guilty to four misdemeanor counts of withholding evidence from Congress. The former national security adviser agreed to be a prosecution witness in the Iran-contra criminal investigation. Page 1 Israel's Prime Minister criticized the newest U.S. plan for a Middle East peace settlement. Yitzhak Shamir sharply renounced the plan two days before leaving on a crucial visit to Washington. 1 Yasir Arafat demanded a direct role for the P.L.O. in any international conference on the Middle East and rejected a U.S. proposal for indirect representation through a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation. 1 The P.L.O.'s observer mission to the United Nations must close within 10 days or the U.S. will go to Federal Court to close it, the Reagan Administration said in a letter to the P.L.O.'s chief observer. 4 New economic sanctions on Panama were imposed by President Reagan in the latest move in an effort to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. The steps include withholding a payment of nearly $7 million. 1 The lack of cash in Panama is strangling the country's economy. One week after Gen. Noriega ordered all banks closed, businesses and individuals are scrambling to survive. Some workers are paid in food. 6 Concern for Lisbon's slums is growing. Government officials hope membership in the European Community will mean money for redevelopment of neighborhoods like Alfama, the oldest part of a city that is showing its age. 4 Afghan refugees in Hangu, Pakistan, are uncertain when they will be able to return home, but are ready. They are skeptical about the Soviet Union's withdrawing its troops soon. 3 Ortega says contras come to talks weakened by Congress 3 Iran and Iraq call a halt to missile strikes on cities 3 Waldheim silent as Austria marks Nazi takeover 4 Suharto rebuffs challenge over choice for vice president 5 Italy's Prime Minister resigns in rift over nuclear plant 32 NATIONAL 7-10, 36 A severe shortage of memory chips is hurting computer sales and placing new strains on the semiconductor trade agreement between the U.S. and Japan. Prices for memory chips have doubled or tripled. 1 Gallaudet's president resigned in response to protests by students at the university for the deaf. The protesters, seeking a deaf president, say they will continue their demonstrations despite the resignation of Elisabeth Ann Zinser. 1 Producer prices declined in February. Retail sales continued to show scarcely any adverse effect from last fall's stock market plunge. The Government data caused bond prices to rally, driving interest rates down. 1 Tiny traces of cocaine were found in the body of an airline captain who was among nine people killed in the crash of a commuter airliner near Durango, Colo., on Jan. 19, the National Transportation Safety Board said. 7 Seattle bids to make old rails new trails 7 Blizzard sweeps northern plains 9 Judge delays LaRouche trial as U.S. searches for records 9 U.S. finds no evidence of chemical dumping after oil spill 9 Mecham trial told of Godly guidance 10 F.D.A. official sees lower limit for drug given pigs 36 Drug found to cut circumcision pain 36 World Health Organization plans AIDS survey 36 Politics 8-9 Bob Dole plans a final appeal to Illinois voters in a television address tonight. He acknowledged that advisershad urged him to quit the Republican Presidential race and and that losing next Tuesday's primary could mean the end of his candidacy. 1 Gary Hart ended his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He announced his second withdrawl from the 1988 race without the anger and defiance with which he stepped out of the campaign last May. 1

title: Cocaine Traces Are Found In Pilot Who Died in Crash
description: Evidence of cocaine use was found in the body of an airline captain who was among nine people killed in the crash of a commuter airliner near Durango, Colo., on Jan. l9, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: The Blizzard That Spawned 100 Years of Memories
description: One hundred years ago this weekend, New York City's most dramatic snowstorm, the Blizzard of '88, burst upon a New York that had been basking in a warming sun that seemed to be a curtain raiser for the spring that would be official 10 days later. The blizzard began as rain that turned into snow late Sunday, March 11. Winds up to 85 miles an hour blew the 21-inch snowfall into drifts that towered 20 feet in many places. Hundreds were frozen under snowbanks.

title: Two Teen-Agers Held in Slaying Of Hasidic Jew
description: Two youths were charged yesterday in the slaying of a Hasidic Jew on a street corner in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn last Dec. 25, the police said.

title: On Foreign Trade
description: To Keep Our Wealth From Flowing Out

title: New Howard Beach Trial Will Have Two Juries
description: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case ruled yesterday that the seven remaining defendants will have a single trial with two juries.

title: Review/Theater; IN REVIVAL OF 'NIGHT MUSIC,' AN IDEALIZED OLD WORLD
description: Every element of ''A Little Night Music,'' from the waltz tempos of Stephen Sondheim's thrilling score to the graceful pirouettes of Hugh Wheeler's dialogue, is infused with a delicate three-quarter-time pulse.

title: Dow Up 8.95, but Has 22.88 Loss for Week
description: LEAD: A late rally allowed the stock market to end the week on a positive note yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,034.98, up 8.95 points.

title: A Correction
description: The photograph used to illustrate yesterday's editorial on the Blizzard of 1888 was misidentified. It was supplied to The Times 30 years ago by a photo archive as having been taken in the famous blizzard. It turns out to be a poor reproduction of Alfred Stieglitz's ''Winter - Fifth Avenue,'' taken in 1892.

title: U.S. to Close P.L.O. Mission
description: The Reagan Administration said the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it. Page 4.

title: Jazz Musicians Honor Max Gordon, Impresario And Father Figure
description: As Bobby Short pounded out ''Happy Birthday'' on the small platform stage of the Village Vanguard early Thursday evening, some 200 guests joined voices to celebrate the 85th birthday, two days early, of the veteran jazz impresario Max Gordon.

title:
Your Money;
Caution Advised On Bankruptcy
description: LEAD: Filing for personal bankruptcy is often the only way to solve some debt problems. But lawyers and credit counselors warn that bankruptcy has serious consequences and they urge people to consider it only as a last resort.

title: J.P. MEI, 76, CHINATOWN LEADER
description: Joseph P. C. Mei, a former president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Society, died of a heart attack on March 3 at his home in Chinatown. He was 76 years old.

title: Europe's Loss No Gain for Detroit
description: The weak dollar that has caused the price of luxury European cars to soar and their sales to plunge in the United States would seem to create a golden opportunity for domestic car makers. But for reasons ranging from lack of production capacity to unpopular models, they seem unable to expand their share of the potentially lucrative market for cars that go for $20,000 and up.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Broaden Its Sterling Drug Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its investigation of suspected insider trading in the securities of Sterling Drug Inc., issuing nearly two dozen subpoenas to arbitragers who bought the securities while the merger was being planned or negotiated, a number of Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

title: Hart, Conceding People Decided, Quits Again
description: The anger and defiance that marked Gary Hart's first withdrawal from the 1988 Presidential race last May were gone today as he withdrew a second time.

title: Profit Condemned
description: To the Editor:

title: Raids by Housing Inspectors Anger Jersey Neighborhood
description: When city officials, acting on a tip, found that illegal immigrants were crowding into houses in a poor neighborhood here, they began a campaign to crack down on building-code violations.

title: Chinese Balance Sheet Is Decidedly Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: Before the Blooms, a Little Shopping
description: It's still a bit early to go outdoors and begin planting, although by this time of year the urge is there. It's not too soon, however, to do some shopping. Browsing in gardening catalogues and centers will turn up new products to help with spring cleanup and get plants off to a healthy start, even potted ones on a city windowsill.

title: Impressive Neck
description: Mike Tyson, the world heavyweight champion, and Tony Tubbs, the man who will challenge for his title later this month, passed their physical examinations yesterday and were declared fit for the bout March 21 at the Tokyo Dome. They took their exams at the Jikei Medical College Hospital, where the champion's neck was measured at 20.1 inches against 17.3 inches for Tubbs. ''I was most impressed with Tyson's thick neck,'' Dr. Takashi Suzuki said. ''With it, he receives very little damage to the brain when he receives punches.'' Tubbs, though, was found to have a reach that exceeded Tyson's by 10 inches. (AP)

title:
Patents;
Methods for Identifying Liquid Compounds
description: LEAD: Liquid chemical compounds are identified and their molecular structure indicated by procedures patented this week for the Research Corporation of New York. Marvin L. Vestal and Calvin R. Blakley, who conducted the research at the University of Houston, were awarded patent 4,730,111. Mr. Vestal is one of the founders of Vestec Inc., which was established to develop the invention.

title: Beecham Drug: Positive Tests
description: A study of Enimase, a drug made by Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain to treat heart disease has shown positive results, the medical journal Lancet reported yesterday. But analysts said that sales of tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, the genetically engineered drug made by Genentech Inc. for the treatment of heart attacks, are unlikely to be affected before 1990.

title: Paine Webber Is Censured
description: Paine Webber Inc. was censured today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for defrauding its customers on coupons of the brokerage's ''stripped'' Treasury bonds between January 1984 and July 1985. A source close to the investigation put the amount of the fraud at $200,000.

title: Ski Delivery, No Waiting
description: A thought for spring skiers and other travelers: Let someone else haul your gear.

title: Albany Faces Up to Campaign Reform
description: The New York State Assembly's approval of a campaign finance reform bill leaves State Senate Republicans with no place to hide. For years, they have quietly killed similar bills in the adjournment rush. Not this year.

title: U.S. Withholds a Canal Payment In New Steps to Oust Panamanian
description: President Reagan imposed new economic sanctions on Panama today, saying the United States would not conduct ''business as usual'' until Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler, relinquished power and left the country.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about recommendations of a New York State education task force misidentified a co-chairman. He is Dr. Edward J. Mortola, current Chancellor of Pace University.

title: ECONOMIC DATA BUOY BOND PRICES
description: Bond prices rose yesterday, buoyed by new indications of modest economic growth and continued low inflation. But bond dealers cautioned that most of the day's gains reflected purchases by those who had previously sold Treasury issues short rather than buying by retail investors.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day last Saturday with an article about the Rover Group inaccurately described the Range-Rover, a four-wheel-drive, four-door vehicle intended for highway and off-the-road driving. It is sold worldwide, not just in the United States.

title: P.L.O. Told to Shut Mission in 10 Days
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the Palestine Liberation Organization must shut its observer mission to the United Nations within 10 days or the United States would take action in Federal court to close it.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amerifirst Federal Savings and Loan Association, Miami, said it had received inquiries about a merger.

title: Review/Film; 'Call Me Madame,' a Documentary On Effects of a Sex Change at Age 55
description: At the age of 55, Jean-Pierre Voidies had a sex-change operation. He had been a political activist, poet, novelist, husband of the bird-like Huguette Voidies and the father of one son, Jean-Noel. By his own account, Mr. Voidies was a member of the Underground during the Nazi occupation of France and was tortured by the Gestapo.

title: Bassist and Dancers
description: Reggie Workman, a bassist, will lead a quintet and the Maya Milenovic dancers will perform at 8 P.M. tonight at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133). Admission is free.

title: State Raises Drinking Age
description: Wyoming today became the last state to raise its minimum drinking age to 21. Gov. Mike Sullivan signed into law a bill raising the age from 19 effective July 1. The bill had stalled for years in the state Legislature over what its opponents called Federal blackmail. Wyoming stood to lose $8.2 million in Federal highway funds immediately if the increase were not in place by July and the Government would have continued to withhold funds until the state adopted the increase.

title: 28 THEATERS ARE APPROVED AS LANDMARKS
description: The New York City Board of Estimate, in a major victory for preservationists and the Koch administration, unanimously approved landmark status early yesterday for 28 Broadway theaters that have been home to some of the greatest moments in American stage history.

title: Review/Dance; 3 Choreographers Show Off Modern Dance From Japan
description: Modern dance would appear to be alive but not too well in Japan, to judge by a program presented on Tuesday evening at the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of the Asia Society. The three dances on the program, produced by the Contemporary Dance Association of Japan and presented by Asia Society, did suggest that there is some very good dance training to be had in Japan and that the Butoh style is not the only kind of modern dance in Japan these days. But the academic quality of the dances shown, all of them created by choreographers attached to institutions, made this a disappointing evening.

title: Nets Fined $25,000 in Woolridge Case
description: Commissioner David Stern of the National Basketball Association fined the Nets $25,000 yesterday for failing to tell the league about an incident in a hotel room in training camp last fall involving the Nets' forward, Orlando Woolridge, who is now in drug rehabilitation.

title: Bridge; Player With 2-Suiter Made Rare Retreat to No-Trump
description: Two or three times in a bridge lifetime a player can expect to pick up a complete two-suiter, with seven cards in one suit and six in another. In this rare situation he usually finds himself fighting his opponents and his partner for the right to be the declarer with one of his suits as trump.

title: A Challenge to Suharto Ends in 'Consensus'
description: President Suharto's nominee for Vice President was elected by acclamation today after the reluctant, last-minute withdrawal of the only other contender.

title: Merrill K. Riddick, 93; Politician and Aviator
description: Merrill K. Riddick, who campaigned for President three times as the candidate of the Puritan Ethic and Epic, Magnetohydrodynamics and Prohibition Party, died here Wednesday of cancer. He was 93 years old.

title: Hope for America's Black 'Boat People'
description: LEAD: Around graduation time, newspapers blossom with headlines about children of Vietnamese boat people who rise from destitution to the top of their classes. These heartwarming stories echo other reports of Asian-American students running away with academic honors and science prizes in breathtaking numbers.

title: JACKSON EDGES OUT DUKAKIS IN ALASKA
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson won nearly 35 percent of the delegates selected at Alaska Democratic Party precinct caucuses, narrowly edging out Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who took 31 percent, party officials announced today.

title: New York City Environmentalism, Made Easier
description: LEAD: In New York City, the environmental impact statement has been converted to an everything impact statement. This transformation is defeating its central purpose, and is rapidly supplanting established planning processes.

title: Jack Bennett, 86, Dies; Government Economist
description: Andrew Jackson Bennett, an economist who advised the United States military government in Germany after World War II, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 86 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

title: Pham Hung, 75, Prime Minister Of Vietnam and Early Rebel, Dies
description: Pham Hung, the Prime Minister of Vietnam, died of a heart attack Thursday. He was 75 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about the Guide Michelin gave an incorrect address for the Traveller's Bookstore. It is at 22 West 52d Street in Manhattan.

title: Convictions of 4 Are Upheld In New Bedford Rape Case
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in a decision Thursday, upheld the convictions of four men who raped a woman on a barroom table in New Bedford in 1983, rejecting defense arguments about the fairness of the 1984 trial in Bristol Superior Court.

title:
Patents;
Linear Predictors
description: LEAD: The National Security Agency, in Fort Meade, Md., which protects Government communications and produces foreign intelligence information, received a patent this week for what are called linear predictors. The predictors forecast subsequent values of a signal or process and are described as useful in such applications as speech processing.

title: Jackson the Favorite in South Carolina
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today left the next major campaign battleground, Illinois, where the primary will be held Tuesday, for a day of stumping across South Carolina to nail down what seems to be a solid lead here for the state's Democratic caucuses Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're hanging by our fingernails.'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ 1:3. ]

title: Arab Stresses P.L.O. Role
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has rejected Secretary of State George P. Shultz's approach to an international conference on the Middle East and insisted that the P.L.O. must be fully represented at any such talks.

title: Review/Concert; A Modern Recasting of Old Japan's Rituals By Kodo, the Percussion and Dance Group
description: Music demands muscle - one fact it's impossible to forget during a concert by Kodo, the 10-man, two-woman Japanese percussion-and-dance group that's appearing through Sunday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Traditional rituals recast as theater and contemporary thoughts about ancient instruments both figure in Kodo's performance, which includes ancient and modern compositions. Yet with tense, angular postures, with stylized, frozen gestures and, in one playful piece, with animal-like scampering and slithering, Kodo reminds its audience, above all, that its music is a matter of flesh and blood, wood and stretched skin. The gestures are nearly as absorbing as Kodo's perfectly calibrated noise.

title: The Prosecutor's Inquiry: 4 Major Targets
description: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to reach a decision soon about whether to bring indictments against four prominent subjects of his investigation. Here are descriptions of their roles in the affair: JOHN M. POINDEXTER Vice admiral and national security adviser from December 1985 to November 1986, when he was allowed to resign. Took complete responsibility for authorizing diversion of Iran arms sale proceeds to the contras. Now retired. OLIVER L. NORTH Marine lieutenant colonel who coordinated dealings with Iran and the contras while on the National Security Council staff. Dismissed from the staff in November 1986. Testified before Congress that all his activities had been approved by superiors. Currently a project officer for plans with the Marine Corps. RICHARD V. SECORD Retired Air Force major general hired by Colonel North to direct the arms sales and covert support of the contras. Denied before Congress that he had been motivated by any desire to profit from the transaction, but other testimony before Congressional investigators indicated that some proceeds were put to personal use. ALBERT HAKIM Iranian-American business partner of General Secord. Middleman for the financial transactions of the Iran arms sale as well as delivery of supplies to the contras. Congressional investigations showed that large profits were produced by the arrangement, in which Mr. Hakim played a large part in setting up Swiss bank accounts.

title:
Patents;
A Training System For Airborne Warfare
description: LEAD: An airborne, laser electronic warfare training system has been invented for Teledyne Industries of Huntsville, Ala. Robert L. Reagan, a staff member, and Theodore Nietzold, a former employee, were granted patent 4,729,737 this week.

title: KEY RATES
Wilkins Scores 40 for Hawks
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 40 points tonight, including 5 during a 17-10 spurt over the last 5 minutes 30 seconds, as the Atlanta Hawks beat the Knicks, 122-115.

title: David F. Cavers Dies; Legal Scholar Was 85
description: David F. Cavers, retired Fessenden Professor of Law at the Harvard Law School, died of prostate cancer at his home in Cambridge, Mass., on March 4. He was 85 years old. Professor Cavers taught at the law school from 1946 until 1969 and was its first associate dean. He was a specialist in the field of conflicts of law, the process of resolving conflicts between the laws of different jurisdictions. His writings on the subject over a period of 50 years were collected in ''Choice of Law,'' published by Duke University Press in 1985.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 12, 1988
description: The Economy

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in Weekend yesterday in the Sounds Around Town column misstated the location for performances by John Wallowitch and Bertram Ross. They are at Danny's Skylight Room, 346 West 46th Street.

title: Koppers Sues Beazer, Shearson
description: The Koppers Company filed a lawsuit in United States District Court here charging Beazer P.L.C. and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. with violations of Federal securities laws in their proposed takeover of Koppers. The group led by Beazer, a British construction concern, and including Shearson as both adviser and participant, made a tender offer for Koppers at $45 a share, or $1.27 billion.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: Federated Delays 'Poison Pill' Plan
description: Federated Department Stores said that its board had postponed putting into effect the rights plan attached to Federated's common shares until next Friday or later. The shareholder rights plan, sometimes referred to as a ''poison pill,'' would allow shareholders to buy new Federated shares at a 50 percent discount if another company acquired 30 percent of the company. The result would be to dilute the shares held by the acquirer so that it could not gain a controlling interest in Federated.

title: Revenue Gain Doubted In Bush's Tax Proposal
description: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office cast doubt today as to whether cutting the capital gains tax - one of Vice President Bush's important campaign promises - would raise Government revenues.

title: Pitt Finishes Well
description: To a certain extent, the Big East tournament is like starting over for Pitt. Three months have been condensed into one long weekend in New York, a game of roulette, really, in which the Panthers are trying to reaffirm that they are the class of the conference. The regular-season championship they won last Sunday in Syracuse will have to be savored at a later date.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Business People column on Monday about Donna Frame Tuttle, the nominee for Deputy Secretary of Commerce, misstated her college graduation year.

title: Cup Offer Runs Aground
description: The board of directors of the San Diego Yacht Club, defender of the America's Cup, said today that it would be willing to negotiate on a New Zealand challenger's compromise offer calling for a 1989 multinational regatta in waters off San Diego. But Michael Fay, who made the proposal, later refused to meet with the defenders.

title: Santa Fe Special Dividend
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said today that it would immediately begin to distribute the remaining $5-a-share debt portion of its $30 special dividend after a Delaware court denied the Henley Group's motion for a preliminary injunction to halt the distribution.

title: 'Allah Will Call,' Afghan Refugees Say
description: In a dozen mud hut camps along both sides of the road between this nondescript market town and the even smaller village of Thal, 40 miles nearer the Afghan border, 150,000 refugees are waiting.

title: Crowd Control
description: If you think everything that happens on a professional wrestling card has been rehearsed several times, check with Martin Gallagher, 28 years old, of Watertown, N.Y., a 6-foot, 200-pound construction worker. Gallagher went to a wrestling match at Watertown High School Wednesday night and began heckling 212-pound David Sammartino, the son of Bruno Sammartino, a former World Wrestling Federation champion. Sammartino, after losing his match, was heading for the dressing room when he suddenly lunged at Gallagher, who was still heckling. ''I thought it was just part of the deal,'' Gallagher said. ''I thought he was going to come and point at me. But he was for real when he came at me and grabbed me by the back of the hair and threw me out of the chair.'' Gallagher, who suffered several bruises, pressed harassment charges against the wrestler. Sammartino was released on $100 bail pending an April 4 court appearance.(AP)

title: G.S.A. Is Extending Phone Contract Bids
description: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it would extend the deadline for submitting bids for contracts to build the Government's new telecommunications system to allow the U S Sprint Communications Corporation more time to prepare its bid.

title: Review/Film; THE 'PEACE RUN,' A PUNGENT LOOK AT POLAND
description: ''The Great Race'' is a metaphor for Poland in the 1950's - and possibly in 1988, too. Feliks Falk's screenplay centers on a ''Peace Run'' by model factory workers, high-producing farmers and zealous activists, thoroughly manipulated by Communist Party bureaucrats. The director, Jerzy Domaradzki, does not spare the satire. The sadly humorous movie, made in 1981 but held back under Poland's martial law, can be seen at New Directors/New Films tonight at 8:30 and tomorrow at 1 P.M.

title: U.N.L.V. Is Surprised By Cal-Irvine
description: Pacific Coast

title: Gooden Relaxes And Is Impressive
description: Dwight Gooden buzzed four vintage innings against the Atlanta Braves today in his second start of the spring, and said later that part of the credit should go to Sandy Koufax.

title: This Article Is About a Snow Job
description: It was the mildest winter in 17 years. New Yorkers had faith in the March 11, 1888, forecast that ''slightly warmer weather would be followed by rain.''

title: Let the Candidates Speak Up About Space
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
A Method To Evaluate Hyperactivity
description: LEAD: An apparatus that is used to evaluate hyperactivity and inattention was patented this week by Michael Gordon, a clinical psychologist. The inventor is president of Gordon Systems of DeWitt, N.Y.

title: Koch Proposals to Convert 2 Buildings to Shelters Are Rejected
description: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday rejected plans to convert two vacant commercial buildings into homeless shelters, a major setback to a Koch administration plan to provide housing for the homeless.

title: U.S. REBUTS RUMORS OF POISON DUMPING
description: No evidence has been found to substantiate suspicions that hazardous chemicals might have been dumped into the Ohio River under the cover of a huge oil spill in January, an environmental official said Thursday.

title: CLIFF SPECK'S UNIFORM
description: Dale Murphy stepped into the batter's box for the Braves as a new pitcher was brought in, and just as Murphy was taking his practice cuts and getting all loose and warm and comfy, he heard the announcement:

title: Reagan Is Optimistic on Trade Bill
description: President Reagan, who has persistently threatened to veto a comprehensive trade bill that is approaching final passage in Congress, said today that the lawmakers had thrown ''overboard many objectionable provisions.''

title: As Tickets Pile Up, 500,000 Scoff
description: Half a million New Yorkers routinely ignore summonses for minor offenses each year - from illegal parking to littering -despite aggressive campaigns by city agencies to find them and make it easier to pay fines, city officials say.

title: 'Shalom '88'
description: Israel's 40th anniversary will be celebrated at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, this weekend with a program of contemporary Israeli music and dance called ''Shalom '88.'' A company of 40 young Israeli performers - including such stars as Boaz Sharabi, Yaffa Yarkoni and Amalia Izhak - will provide a sampler of Israel's many ethnic cultures. Performances are at 8:30 tonight and 3 and 7 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $15 to $27.50. Information: 840-2824 or 564-8038.

title: Firestone Meeting Sought by Pirelli
description: Pirelli S.p.A., the giant Italian tire maker that made a $1.86 billion takeover bid for the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, asked Firestone officials yesterday to meet with them before taking a position on the week-old offer.

title: Redmen Suffer Late Collapse
description: St. John's seemed on the verge of righting all the wrongs of its season last night.

title: Balance of Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Man Arrested in Loan Fraud Is Said to Be U.S. Informant
description: An associate of Irwin Schiff, the enigmatic millionaire businessman who was slain last summer, was a ''cooperating Federal informant'' when he was arrested by the Manhattan District Attorney's office Thursday, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Milt Jackson and Trio
description: Milt Jackson, a vibraphonist, is appearing with a trio led by Monty Alexander on piano tonight and tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. with a 1:30 A.M. show tonight; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $10 charge at the bar.

title: Lupu and Philharmonic
description: Radu Lupu will be the soloist with the New York Philharmonic in the Beethoven Third Piano Concerto at 8 P.M. tonight. The performance, which will be conducted by Klaus Tennstedt, will include Beethoven's Symphony No. 3 (''Eroica''). Tickets are $35 to $7.50. Information: 580-8700.

title: World Health Group Plans Survey To Help Understand AIDS Spread
description: People in dozens of countries will be asked how they make love, how often and with whom in a World Health Organization survey intended to help understand and curb the spread of AIDS, an official has said.

title: Pope Continues the Theology of Egalitarianism
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; John Berryman's Pain and Sense of Mortality
description: We Dream of Honour John Berryman's Letters to His Mother By John Berryman Edited by Richard J. Kelly. Illustrated. 405 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50.

title: LAROUCHE TRIAL DELAYED AS JUDGE ORDERS SEARCH OF FEDERAL RECORDS
description: The judge in the fraud trial of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. today delayed a resumption of testimony pending searches of Government records for any evidence suggesting infiltration of the political extremist's organizations by Federal agents.

title: Righetti Still Not on Track
description: Every spring, it's the same old thing: one bad game follows another, and Dave Righetti can neither explain his troubles nor find an answer to them.

title: Dispel This Banking Myth
description: Could this finally be the year for modernizing Depression-era regulation of financial services?

title: Producer Price Index Dipped in February As Retail Sales Rose
description: In a pair of largely reassuring reports on the economy, the Government said today that prices at the producer level declined in February while retail sales continued to show scarcely any adverse effect from last fall's stock market plunge.

title: Flxible Bus Fiasco
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisbon Journal; In Old Section of City, A Ghetto With a View
description: The Alfama district is Lisbon's slum by the sea, along the banks of the Tagus River where it widens to enter the Atlantic.

title: Guidepost
description: Staying Dry Spring showers bring out raincoats and umbrellas. But which ones will keep you driest? While raindrops roll off water-repellent fabric in a light rain, the material won't prevent a soaking in a downpour. Water-repellent material is better at keeping raindrops out of the fibers. Waterproof gear like slickers and rubber boots is coated or laminated to provide complete protection. Rainwear can have its resistance restored by most dry cleaners. Treatment for a cotton trench coat, for example, costs $9.50 to $12 in New York City. Clothing made of untreated fibers may also be treated for rain, either by a dry cleaner or at home with a fluorocarbon- or silicone-based spray. Here is a guide to how some garments stand up to showers. Fabric Degree of water resistance Trench coat Cotton (latex coated) Water resistant Lightweight shell Nylon Water resistant Olefin Water repellent Slicker Rubberized cotton Waterproof Gore-Tex Waterproof Umbrella Cotton Water repellent Nylon Water resistant Polyester Waterproof (Sources: Clothing and Textile Department, University of North Carolina at Greensboro; American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists in Research Triangle Park, N.C.)

title: Queens Slaying Parallels Death Of Officer, 22
description: Jury selection began yesterday in Queens in the murder case of a Jamaica man who, according to court records, drove up to a man in a parked car, got out and shot him in the head three times.

title: Output Cut At OPEC Less Likely
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seem to have abandoned a proposal to reduce production by about 5 percent because of fears that any sacrifices in output would simply turn a larger share of the market over to non-OPEC oil producers.

title: Mauch Is Ailing
description: Manager Gene Mauch of the California Angels has left the team's spring training camp in Mesa, Ariz., for unspecified health reasons, the team announced yesterday. He is scheduled to undergo an examination Monday in Palm Springs, Calif. The Angels hold the latter part of their spring training in Palm Springs, and Mauch owns a home in nearby Rancho Mirage. Mauch, 62 years old, said he had not been feeling well for some time. ''I'm going to find out if this is how you're supposed to feel when you're 62,'' Mauch told a reporter. ''I'm going to get after it and get it taken care of.'' The Angels said that Cookie Rojas, an advance scout for the Angels, would be interim manager. Mauch has managed 26 seasons in the major leagues, the longest among active managers. (AP)

title: MECHAM TRIAL TOLD OF GODLY GUIDANCE
description: Gov. Evan Mecham believed he was ''divinely guided'' in making executive decisions, one of his closest aides testified Friday at the Governor's impeachment trial.

title: Miss Dempsey Weds B. J. Charendoff
description: Pamela Lawrence Dempsey, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Bruce Jay Charendoff, an associate at the Hartford law firm of Shipman & Goodwin, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. The Rev. Henry Fehren, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Harold Swiss officiated.

title: Utah Rejects Textbook Ban
description: The Utah Textbook Commission has rejected an Indian request that grade schools remove a book containing stories by Washington Irving and John Smith that depict Indians as blood-thirsty savages.

title: More People Seek 'a Pill for Every Ill'
description: Every day before she sets off to work, Roberta Berk, a 48-year-old commodities broker, takes one aspirin, 500 milligrams of vitamin C, 1,000 milligrams of calcium, an antihistamine tablet and powdered fiber in water.

title: Murray Rimmer, Hospital Administrator, 54
description: Murray Rimmer, administrator of Gracie Square Hospital, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens.

title: Gunmen in Sri Lanka Kill 17 in Bus Attack
description: Masked gunmen attacked a bus in Sri Lanka today, killing at least 17 passengers, mostly ethnic Tamils, the police said.

title: Lilco Takes Write-Down
description: The Long Island Lighting Company, as expected, said today that it would take a $1.35 billion write-down related to its investments in three nuclear plants. Lilco also announced that its earnings in 1987 fell by 14.8 percent, to $269.9 million, or $1.72 a share, from $316.7 million, or $2.13 a share, the year before. Revenues rose 6 percent, to $2.1 billion from $1.98 billion.

title: In Cash Squeeze, Panamanians Switch to Barter
description: It was payday today at the Acsesa automobile repair shop here, but instead of receiving checks or cash, the 90 mechanics and drivers stood in line as a fellow employee doled out payment in food.

title: Shortage of Memory Chips Has Industry Scrambling
description: A severe shortage of computer memory chips is hurting the sales of computers and placing new strains on the semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan, an agreement that some executives blame for the shortage.

title: Promises by Texaco's Creditors
description: Texaco's creditors sought to induce management to settle the company's dispute with the Pennzoil Company by offering top executives protection from lawsuits by shareholders.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about Brooklyn co-op owners whose building is threatened with seizure by the Federal Government in the Hyfin Credit Union scandal incompletely identified a mortgage lender. It is the Dime Savings Bank of Williamsburg.

title: JAIL TERMS SET FOR FRAUD ON TAX SHELTERS
description: Charles A. Atkins, who was convicted in what the Government has called the largest case of tax-shelter fraud ever brought to court, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail, followed by four years of community service. Two co-defendants received lesser sentences.

title: Three Men on An Eagle
description: From time to time when the Romans couldn't decide which of three leaders they wanted to rule they simply fudged the whole problem by putting all three in office.

title: Beirut Weekly Says Captors Plan to Free Marine Hostage
description: The weekly Beirut magazine Al Shiraa said today that the captors of an American Marine officer have promised to free him but have set no date.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Harvard Is Upset: Clarkson upset first-seeded Harvard, 6-4, in a ECAC Hockey tournament semifinal last night after St. Lawrence defeated Vermont, 4-2, at Boston Garden.

title: Apres Ski
description: After the United States Ski Team failed to win a medal and placed no higher than ninth at the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, it came as no surprise when Harald Schoenhaar, the team's Alpine director, announced yesterday in Vail, Colo., that he had given his resignation to the board of directors. Schoenhaar, a native of West Germany who has been associated with the team for 14 years, said he hoped to devote more time to private pursuits. ''I'm 47,'' he said. ''I want a more quiet life. I want time to play more golf and to fly an airplane. The ski team needs a long-term commitment, and I can't go on for four more years. That's for sure.'' Schoenhaar was head coach of the men from 1976 to 1980. John McMurtry, the former coach of the women's team who has been serving as development director, is a likely successor to Schoenhaar.(AP)

title: DOLE WILL MAKE LAST-DITCH EFFORT IN TELEVISION TALK
description: Saying ''we're hanging by our fingernails,'' Bob Dole announced today that he planned a final appeal over Illinois television Saturday night in an effort to salvage his Presidential campaign.

title: Review/Opera; Janacek Rarity, 'House of the Dead,' in Paris
description: Leos Janacek's operas have been performed less frequently in Paris than in most major Western cities, but when the Paris Opera set about rectifying that omission, it did so in flamboyant style. Instead of producing just one opera, there were two, and they were presented within the context of a two-month Janacek festival.

title: Review/Jazz; Jim Hall, Intense Guitarist
description: ''Cross Court,'' the second composition played by the guitarist Jim Hall at Sweet Basil on Tuesday, opened with a stop-time section. Usually, the blank spaces of a stop-time break provoke a soloist, as if competing with Charlie Parker's famous outburst on ''A Night in Tunisia,'' to gush music. Mr. Hall carefully chose a few notes instead, one after another, and placed them with the care of someone setting an elegant table.

title: Ortega Says Congress Hurt the Contras
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra says he thinks contra leaders will come to the negotiating table this month in ''a position of weakness'' because of the recent Congressional vote cutting off aid to their movement.

title: McFARLANE ADMITS WITHHOLDING DATA ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's former national security adviser, pleaded guilty today to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress and agreed to serve as a prosecution witness in the criminal investigation of the Iran-contra affair.

title: SOMBER AUSTRIA MARKS DAY OF NAZI TAKEOVER
description: Urging his countrymen to learn from their past for the sake of their future, Chancellor Franz Vranitzky led Austrians through a day of somber ceremonies and events marking the 50th anniversary of Austria's willing absorption by Nazi Germany.

title: COPING: With an Aging Pet
description: The dog that frisked its way through so many years of your life is not eager to play anymore. And the cat seems to spend more time than ever sleeping.

title: New York's Bridges Are Falling Down
description: New York City is a clump of islands joined to mainland America only at the Bronx. The 76 bridges that lace it together, and the 2,000-plus that span rail lines and roadways, are lifelines. Yet New Yorkers take these vital links for granted. Almost all the bridges are victims of deferred maintenance. The City Council and State Legislature therefore ought to welcome a city proposal for a Bridge Maintenance and Reconstruction Authority.

title: Book on the AIDS Quilt
description: On May 11, Pocket Books will publish ''The Quilt: Stories from the Names Project,'' with a foreword by Elizabeth Taylor, national chairman of the American Foundation for AIDS Research. The Names Project Quilt - the national AIDS memorial, which weighs about 3 1/2 tons and is the size of two football fields - contains more than 3,000 individual panels, each depicting the name of someone who has died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The panels were created by friends, parents, lovers, siblings and co-workers. Profits from the sale of the hard-cover book will go to the Names Project for continung community service projects.

title: ENERGY AT ESTEE LAUDER
description: In her Jan. 17 letter to the editor, in response to Lisa Belkin's article ''The Makeover at Estee Lauder,'' (Nov. 29), Phyllis Kraemer really did miss the point. Age is not the question. Vitality is. At Estee Lauder, we are trying to inject a bit more energy and vitality into our approach. We have never targeted our marketing to a specific age group - at either end of the spectrum - nor do we plan to at this time. We appreciate all of our customers, regardless of age. LEONARD A. LAUDER New York, N.Y.

title: Agency Helps Disabled Map Out Their Vacations
description: LEAD: LOIS BONANNI of Armonk treasures the photographs she receives from around the world. The pictures were taken during trips that Mrs. Bonanni, a travel agent, had arranged to Europe or Hawaii or Israel. Interspersed among the typical scenes of beaches, monuments and smiling tourists are other features - wheelchairs and special vans for the disabled, guides and other aids for the blind.

title: TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING
description: May I clarify my position on man's ''minimal daily requirement'' for exercise (Body and Mind: ''Too Much of a Good Thing,'' by Morton Hunt, Feb. 7)? I agree with the American College of Sports Medicine recommendation of 20-30 minutes of aerobic exercise three times a week, which was mentioned in your article. But recent data suggest strongly that this is a minimum requirement. Optimal health benefits require, I believe, three times more exercise. And though there is no evidence that more than three hours of aerobic exertion weekly is beneficial for health and longevity, there is certainly no evidence that additional exercise is harmful. In fact, many people find very high exercise levels to be personally rewarding. A recent book written by myself and Steven Levisohn, ''The Athlete Within: A Personal Guide to Total Fitness'' (Little, Brown & Company, 1987) explains what exercise is best.

title: Explosion Halts Train Service
description: An electrical transformer seven stories beneath Grand Central Terminal exploded at 11:56 A.M. yesterday, cutting off power to Metro-North and Amtrak lines and suspending passenger service in both directions for more than an hour, according to New York City Fire Department and Metro-North officials.

title: Report Finds Ecuador Rights Abuses Rose Sharply
description: An American human rights organization said today that torture, extrajudicial killings and other human rights abuses have increased alarmingly in Ecuador over the last three years.

title: JACKSON WINS EASILY IN SOUTH CROLINA CAUCUSES By RICHARD L. BERKE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson scored an overwhelming victory in the Democratic caucuses today in South Carolina, his native state, showing far greater support for his Presidential campaign than when he won in 1984.

title: Loyal Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Name-Dropping?
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of North Tarrytown, once called Beekmantown after an early settler, will vote in Tuesday's village elections on whether to change the community's name to Sleepy Hollow.

title: A Center for the Art of Embroidery
description: IN China, a place where taxes were once paid in bolts of silk and decorative needlework ranked among the most highly esteemed art forms, the ancient crafts of sericulture and embroidery are as firmly entrenched in national tradition as the daily bowl of rice.

title: But Will It Play in Podolia? Nowadays, Yes
description: On the second stage of the venerated Maly Theater here, James, Mary, Edmund and Jamie Tyrone are trying to untangle their hatreds and groping to save one another in Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PLACE MAKERS: Creating Public Art That Tells You Where You Are. By Ronald Lee Fleming and Renata von Tscharner with George Melrod and Beverlee Seronick Barnes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $14.95.) Both halves of the seemingly straightforward expression ''public art'' have become increasingly problematic.

title: Charm Fades for Americans Living in Canal Zone
description: With tensions here running high, the Administrator of the Panama Canal met last week with American residents of the former Canal Zone to discuss emergency evacuation plans. But the meeting had to be adjourned after the headquarters of the Canal Commission received a bomb threat.

title: Tv Changes Bar Patterns
description: TAVERNS aren't what they used to be, because when television came in, conversation went out.

title: SIDS: 'We Don't Know Why Your Baby Died'
description: LEAD: IT STRIKES about 130 families in New Jersey each year - always without warning, usually in the winter between midnight and 8 A.M.

title: THE NATION: The Amnesty Gamble; Immigration Law's Impact Still Tough To Measure
description: IT was called a corpse that would not die, the immigration legislation that finally became law in 1986 after a year-to-year Congressional marathon.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VISIT BY JUDY CHICAGO ''The Dinner Party,'' a sculpture by Judy Chicago that was first exhibited in 1979 at the San Francisco Museum of Fine Art, was a room-sized chez d'oeuvre that incorporated the needlework and china-painting of 39 women and took five years to complete.

title: German Outpost Of Education
description: WHEN Japan recently announced plans to place its first American-Japanese high school in Harrison, it became the second foreign government to claim educational territory in Westchester.

title: 2 Retirement Seminars Set
description: LEAD: NO ONE knows exactly how many New Jersey businesses have pre-retirement planning programs.

title: What's the Rush? Take an Elephant
description: IF anticipation is the better part of travel, it would seem reasonable that travelers for pleasure should avoid high speed.

title: Away With Those 'Cool Blues'
description: I wouldn't have believed it if I hadn't tried it myself, but Kodak's new Ektachrome 100 Plus Professional slide film has a quality few films of its type can match: truly neutral shadow tones.

title: Protectionist Mood Is Diminishing in Trade Bill Negotiations
description: THE votes of 13 million Americans last week increased the chances that a nonprotectionist trade bill will be be signed into law this year after months of acrimonious deadlock.

title: Bologna
description: To the Editor: My wife and I were particularly pleased with the article ''Scholarly and Epicurean Bologna'' by William Weaver (Travel, June 29, 1986), which we saved. Recently en route from Venice to Florence, we stopped for the night. The Accademia hotel was exactly as described: clean, friendly and inexpensive. Our meal at Diana was excellent and typically Bolognese: risotto, bollita misto and the finest gelato we've ever had. IRA G. BARROWS Newtown, Pa.

title:
ART;
Yale Show Traces the Ties of Early Photography and the West
description: LEAD: ONE of the most resonant chapters in American history is the post-Civil War era. From combat, tight struggle often typified as brother against brother, the attention of the nation turned to the wide open spaces of the West.

title: Reagan Files Appeal of Order Barring U.S. Abortion Rules
description: The Reagan Administration has appealed a Federal judge's order overturning regulations that would have cut off Federal financing to family planning clinics that offer abortion counseling.

title: Correction
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section today and a listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide give outdated theater information for ''Stand and Deliver.'' It opens on Friday at the National Twin, the Plaza, Loews 84th Street Six and the Art Greenwich Twin.

title: The Tough Road of Black Women
description: Feminism has done many use-ful things, one of which is to discover and reframe the achievements of female authors and artists of the past.

title: New Flu Strain in U.S. Extends Suffering Season
description: More cases of influenza, coming later in the flu season, have recently been reported around the country, but Federal and state health officials say there is no cause for national alarm.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: With the addition of Jack Clark, the Yanks have the strongest lineup in baseball. With the addition of Santana at shortstop and Roberto Kelley at center field, the Yanks have a very solid defense. Do they need more pitching? Even adequate pitching will enable the Yanks to capture the '88 World Series. And believe it or not, their pitching is better than adequate. (See Rhoden, Dotson, Candelaria, Leiter, rookie of the year '88, and Righetti.) The Mets? Who cares? MARTY FRIEDMAN New York

title: Supertitles: The Eyes Have It
description: Religion used to be the topic that well-bred people did not bring up in polite company. Now it is supertitles. The rapid spread of captioned opera and the surprisingly enthusiastic acceptance of the device, on this continent and in Europe, has served to inflame both advocates and opponents. When it appeared that supertitling might be a fad, jeered today and gone tomorrow, the rhetoric remained fairly rational. Now, however, the debate can take on the angry tone of editorials, pro or contra, about the death penalty.

title: U.S. Aide and South African to Meet on Angola
description: A senior State Department official will meet South Africa's Foreign Minister next week at an undisclosed site in Europe to press an American initiative for peace in southern Africa, the State Department said today.

title: THE LURE OF THE POLITICAL ROAD
description: A PRESIDENTIAL campaign is a moveable feast: sandwiches on the plane, a Budweiser and chocolate chip cookies in the office, hors d'oeuvres sneaked at a fund-raiser. Lunch is nice, but there is often something more important going on.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 13, 1988
Dangerous Paris-Dakar Race Is Endangered
description: More than a month after the first cars and motorcycles roared out of the Sahara to complete the 10th Paris-to-Dakar rally, the dust has yet to settle on the world's longest and toughest motor race.

title: Still Struggling
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTING: Choir School Site; Offices by Macklowe
description: On one of the most built-up streets in Manhattan, Sheldon Werdiger, the project manager for 125 West 55th Street, speaks of creating a park feeling. Though the 23-story office building being developed there by the Harry Macklowe Real Estate Company has two of New York's tallest new buildings as neighbors, it is near a mid-block public plaza and will yield to small plazas of its own on both 55th and 56th Streets. Moreover, the building's blue-green glass sheathing may give it a pastoral sheen.

title: The River of Grass Seen From a Tram
description: EVEN on one of those raw, blustery days that bedevil the winter visitor to Florida, there are no vacant seats on the tram tour that explores the Everglades at Shark Valley. Thirty miles west of Miami, along the well-traveled Tamiami Trail, Shark Valley is the most accessible of the three entrances to Everglades National Park, the one closest to south Florida's booming resort communities. It is also the best area for viewing the park's interior, a swampy, sawgrass prairie dotted by occasional islands of trees - a different world from the junglelike hummocks and mangrove swamps that characterize the Everglades' coastal regions.

title: Iris B. Krasnow Is Wed To Charles Anthony 3d
description: Iris Bessie Krasnow, a feature writer for United Press International in Washington, and Charles Edward Anthony 3d, an architect in Washington, were married last evening in Chicago. Rabbi Roy Furman performed the ceremony at the Standard Club.

title: 'There Has to Be Accountability'
description: GERALD N. TIROZZI was named State Commissioner of Education on April 26, 1983. It was a memorable date in American education, for it was also on this day that the National Commission on Excellence in Education released its famous report, ''A Nation at Risk,'' calling for the reform of American public schools.

title: Bill Would Restrict Canoeing
description: LEAD: A PROPOSED amendment to the Town of Smithtown's statutes would make most of the modern-day canoeists who have grown used to paddling the Nissequogue River's tidal swirls as much of a memory as the Indians who once silently plied the same waters.

title: Totalitarianism, Indoors and Out
description: Since ''The Case of Herman the Stoker'' makes some effort to penetrate the mind of its subject, a lot of it is about firewood. Leszek Wosiewicz's short film includes the information that birch logs are good for keeping bad thoughts away and for making a person ready to work. Maple, on the other hand, produces a more dynamic state of mind.

title: The Word From Sheboygan: Our Wurst Is Best
description: FANS of the radio show ''A Prairie Home Companion'' learned that travelers in Minnesota could blend with the natives by using a few key Midwesternisms: phrases like ''Cold enough for you?'' and ''You bet.''In Sheboygan, Wis., one phrase will suffice: ''Double brat with with the works, please.''

title: A Eulogy For Winter
description: THOUGH the admission still sends a chill through me, I must say I am going to miss winter.

title: FROM THE CAULDRON OF LITERATURE: AN EXILE'S JOURNAL
description: Witold Gombrowicz was born into a family of Polish gentry in 1904. He completed his law studies in Warsaw and studied philosophy and economics in Paris, but abandoned a legal career when he made his literary debut with a collection of short stories, ''Memoir From Adolescence,'' in 1933. ''Ferdydurke,'' a novel, and ''Yvonne, Princess of Burgundy,'' a play, followed in 1938. From the beginning, Gombrowicz overturned realistic form and assumed the role of a provocateur. In a highly idiosyncratic style, which combined almost surrealistic deformations with sly humor, his early works explored his preoccupations with spontaneous authenticity - which he associated with youth - and satirized the conventions into which people mutually force each other in the ''interhuman church'' of the adult world.

title: LITTLE NELL, OR VIRTUE REWARDED
description: THE HEARTS AND LIVES OF MEN By Fay Weldon. 357 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: POSTING: No-Smoking Law; Lobbies, Too
description: New city restrictions on smoking in offices and restaurants that go into effect on April 6 will also apply to common areas of apartment buildings with 10 or more units. Moreover, no-smoking areas will have to be designated with signs.

title: Pilot Shortage Is Cited in Flight Cancellations
description: Eastern Airlines, embroiled in labor problems, says it has been forced to cancel numerous flights because of a shortage of pilots.

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: A Walk in the City; TOKYO PRESENT MEETS TOKYO PAST
description: The busiest part of Omote-Sando, Tokyo's grand boulevard of past and present, begins at the designer Hanae Mori's sleek glass headquarters and ends with the majestic shrine to the Emperor Meiji, under whose reign Japan opened its doors to the West. In between lies one of the city's pleasantest avenues, a place to sample some of its trendiest boutiques, fastest food and most traditional monuments.

title: Selling Amtrak Will Not Improve IT
description: IT'S THAT time of year again.

title: The Illusion of Aces
description: FOR a quarter of a century, the International Bridge Press Association has given awards annually to the best-played hand and the best-bid hand. There was not, however, a comparable award for the best-defended hand. Last year this gap was remedied, and there is now a Precision Award for the best defense of the year.

title: Garbage In, Garbage Out
description: AT home, from Monday through Friday, my wife and I threw away the following: Six pounds of newspapers Fifteen paper napkins Two empty boxes of cream cheese and two pieces of the foil that wraps the cream cheese One coffee filter and coffee grounds Six used tea bags (herb tea) The rinds from five grapefruits and four oranges The peel of a banana Four eggshells An empty cardboard box of raisins An empty package of chocolate chip cookies Two empty orange juice cartons One empty milk carton One cardboard cereal box with its plastic liner Three empty cans of vegetables One empty vitamin bottle One empty cardboard spaghetti box One empty jar of spaghetti sauce Several pieces of tinfoil Several pieces of wax paper Assorted food scraps Two steel wool soap pads Twelve cotton swabs One cardboard toilet-paper roll and wrapping Some dead leaves from our house plants A bouquet of flowers One old nine-volt battery One cardboard and plastic battery package Four and a half pounds of glossy magazines and mail-order catalogues and about one pound (mostly paper) of envelopes, junk mail, subscription requests and advertisements that we received in the mail. Then the stuff we threw away our stuff in: One plastic one-gallon storage bag and a tie Three plastic 13-gallon garbage bags and ties Four large paper bags from the grocery store. It was a pretty normal week of garbage disposal for us. We threw away the same kinds of things we've been throwing away for years and the same kinds of things we imagine we will dispose of in the future (although we are expecting to add diapers to this list in May). Most people probably throw away the same sort of things as we do, although certainly in different amounts. So this is what the residents of Long Island are contributing to the landfills in Wisconsin and other states to which our refuse is trucked. Which leads me to four questions: Why isn't there any national, state or local system for recycling most of the trash? Why are so many unrecyclable materials permitted? Why are products packaged in a way that creates unnecessary junk? When are we going to wake up?

title: Plansky 3-Pointer Wins for Villanova
description: In January, a few days before Villanova's opening conference game this season, Coach Rollie Massimino sat in a deserted Villanova locker room, stewing about the predictions that the Wildcats would finish near last place in the Big East.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DETOUR: A Hollywood Story. By Cheryl Crane with Cliff Jahr. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) There's at least one good thing about living at the center of a Hollywood scandal - when you decide to write your memoirs, you're a hot property. In ''Detour'' Cheryl Crane tells, in an implausibly detailed reconstruction, the story of her life as Lana Turner's daughter.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: The Mets' starting pitchers, barring injuries, should be the best in baseball. But they could use more strength in the bullpen. Do the Yanks need more pitching? Who cares? FRANK STOCKWELL New York

title: Headliners; Cupboard Bared
description: Second only to the excitement when the fifth Earl of Carnarvon helped open King Tutankhamen's tomb in 1922 was the fanfare last week when the seventh Earl of Carnarvon disclosed what he had found when a butler helped him open one of his grandfather's closets last fall.

title: New Police Bias-Crime Rules in Effect
description: ALTHOUGH New Jersey's first official statistics on crimes of racial, religious and ethnic bias will not be available until next year, local police departments must now follow standards for handling those incidents and reporting them to the State Police.

title: Billiards and Redfish In the Everglades
description: THERE is no other way to get blackened redfish as fresh as the ones making their way on a waiter's tray across the wide, screened veranda of the Rod and Gun Club this evening. The table of four awaiting the treat, men and women in slacks and shorts, sipping cocktails under the paddle fans and watching the sun set over the mangroves of the Barron River, caught the redfish earlier in the day. They were cooked to order at this century-old fishing, hunting and nature lover's resort in Everglades City, the only town to survive, and even prosper, in the wilds of south Florida's vast Everglades country.

title: TALKING: Ministorage; Squeezed? Rent the Solution
description: GREAT-GRANDMA probably never thought twice about piling her roomy attic or basement with the flotsam and jetsam of her family's life.

title: HOME FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: I returned from a trip to Leningrad and Moscow recently, and was writing letters to my new Russian friends on the flight home when I came across Bill Keller's article. I began to tremble as I looked at the boyish face and the military uniform on the cover of the magazine. Only four days before, I had met a Russian veteran of the Afghan conflict.

title: DEFYING THE YAPPING ESTABLISHMENT
description: UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK The Life Story of Christopher Nolan. By Christopher Nolan. 163 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $16.95.

title: Audrey Wolff, a Teacher, to Wed S. R. Winkelman
description: The engagement of Audrey Sharon Wolff to Stephen Ray Winkelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Winkelman of Scottsdale, Ariz., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Wolff of New York, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Susan C. Kearns To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. Kearns of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan C. Kearns to Michael R. Alderman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce Alderman of Towson, Md.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A Mime-Dance-Noh Synthesis
description: LEAD: TO WATCH Yass Hakoshima perform is to be captured and captivated by a synthesis of modern dance, traditional mime and elements of Japanese Noh theater.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Bastion of Biddy Ball IF the Olympics left you yearning for a winning American team, meet the Hempstead Salvation Army biddy basketball team.

title: Greece Ceases Preparations To Upgrade Ties With Israel
description: The Greek Government has suspended preparations to upgrade relations with Israel because of Israel's conduct with the Palestinians in the occupied territories, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said on Friday.

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: A Walk in the City; THE PIQUANT FLAVOR OF AN AMAZON PORT
description: Conventional wisdom has it that Portugal's Renaissance seafarers had a gift for staking out handsome vantage points; witness the splendid bays they picked for Rio de Janeiro and Salvador.

title: Trying to Move A Wall of Art
description: IT IS infinitely simpler to commission a work of art than it is to remove one after it has been installed, the Federal Government is learning.

title: OH MY CRACKING PISTONS!
description: It's comforting to know that I'm not the only one giving up the thrill of a Porsche. I plunked down $25,000 three years ago, roared away from the dealership and promptly skidded 180 degrees into a snowbank. ''You need a set of four all-weather tires with rims,'' said the dealer. ''They will run about $2,500.''

title: 7 Players, 5 Spots, and Questions for Red Sox
description: Perhaps the most trite expression in baseball is ''you can never have enough pitching.'' In the Boston Red Sox camp, they have a variation on that theme: you can never have enough outfielders.

title: Shipmates by Choice and Chance
description: As the harbor of Monte Carlo came in sight, our eyes sought out and found the sleekest of sleek white vessels, quiet at her moorings. ''She's beautiful,'' I said, meaning it. Our cab-driver, a native of Nice, agreed with me. ''Oui, monsieur, but that sheep belongs to a Greek gentleman. Your sheep is over there.''

title: Rebecca G. White To Marry in July
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Mattocks White Jr. of Manchester, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Gilman White to Christopher Wood Dilworth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Warden Dilworth of Groton, Mass.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
And Now, the 'Drop-Dead' Dress
description: LEAD: MARCH comes in like a lion for one reason. It collides with women searching for the ''drop-dead'' dress for spring parties and weddings. (Or any affair where the stamp on the invitation matches the tablecloths at the dinner.) And what is a ''drop-dead'' dress? Any gown that warrants losing one-fifth of your total body weight to get into.

title: TOLENTINE BEATS MOLLOY FOR TITLE, 70-65
description: Malik Sealy scored a game-high 26 points and grabbed 10 rebounds last night as St. Nicholas of Tolentine defeated Archbishop Molloy, 70-65, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship at Fordham University in the Bronx.

title: Syria Rejects U.S. Plan for Peace in Mideast
description: Syria today termed unacceptable an American proposal for an Arab-Israeli peace settlement submitted last week to Arab and Israeli leaders by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PLIMPTON BENEFIT TALK George Plimpton will give a talk titled ''An Amateur Among the Pros'' at 4 P.M. today in Kings Chapel of the Hackley School in Tarrytown.

title: Lisa Claudy, Yale Graduate Student, Plans to Wed Charles M. Fleischman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Claudy of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Joan Marshall Claudy, to Charles Mark Fleischman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Fleischman of Washington. The wedding is to be June 18.

title: FRENCH PLAYS FIND A SO-HO HOME
description: The existence of a New York-based performance company being subsidized by a foreign government may sound insidious, but the French-sponsored UBU Repertory Theater's sole objective is ''a collaboration between people of different cultures,'' according to its founder and artistic director, Francoise Kourilsky.

title: Airport X-Rays
description: To the Editor: Although I hate to disagree with a professional filmmaker, I must take exception to Mel London's remarks (Letters on Travel, Jan. 24) regarding lead pouches to protect film from airport X-rays. I had two such bags and watched the monitor screen with concern as they passed through the ''safe'' minidose machines at Ben Gurion International Airport (Israel) and Heathrow Airport (London) recently. In both cases, the X-rays penetrated the bags, showing my film neatly stacked in rows.

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time; THE THING FROM THE BRINY DEEP
description: Travel serendipity? Because I grew up among life scientists, my most vivid images of the unexpected tend to be biological. But which to choose? Should it be the toucans glimpsed while up to my knees in mud beside Lake Catamaco in Mexico? The fire ants I sat down on by mistake in the Galapagos? Or the popular hole in a wooden wall in the rudimentary zoo of Kabul, Afghanistan, on the other side of which was a single elephant eye, looking back out?

title: Wedding in April For Miss Rambo
description: Louise de Clercq Rambo, a personal fashion adviser at Lord & Taylor in New York, plans to be married April 30 to Anthony Lane Adams, a managing director of the QSR Capital Corporation, an investment counseling concern in New York.

title: I Know How the Rangers Can Win It All
description: These are soul-searching times for the Rangers. They have not won the National Hockey League's greatest prize, the Stanley Cup, since 1940, when people thought the N.H.L. was just another program in Roosevelt's National Recovery Act. Forty-seven years going on 48, and folks still call it a ''jinx.'' Cute. Twenty-five seasons without a championship is a jinx. Even 30. Forty-eight straight snake-eyes deserves a gold Mickey Mouse watch with the inscription, ''Keep your day job.''

title: Mattingly Hoping To Avoid Slow Start
description: When he talks about hitting, he is talking about the thing that matters most to him on a professional level. He speaks almost nonstop about the subject, pausing only momentarily to take a breath, and then continuing.

title: Paper Mill Offering British Sex Farce
description: FOR YEARS, Tony Randall has spoken, with customary eloquence and elegance, of the need for New York-based classical repertory theater.

title: Russia's Old and Rival Capitals
description: WITH JUST FOUR WORDS - ''LOVED LENINGRAD, hated Moscow'' - first-time visitors to the Soviet Union have been summing up their feelings ever since Intourist hung up its shingle. The twofold reaction is visceral, irrepressible and virtually universal. In Leningrad, visitors feel bouyant, alert and subtly flattered. ''All this is for me?'' they ask themselves. In Moscow, by contrast, they feel baffled, pushed around, disoriented and unloved. They are quite right, too. Initially, Moscow is hard to decipher and hard to take, whereas Leningrad comes on like a beautiful woman who has been waiting for us all her life.

title: From Carburetors to Arias: A Tenor Is Born
description: LEAD: BEFORE the curtain goes up Friday night on the first opera produced in 25 years at the Shubert Theater in New Haven, ticket sales will determine whether opera has a future in that city.

title: Labor of Play: A Brobdinagian Chess Set
description: DAVID C. ANDERSON looked over the wooden chess set he was making. ''I'll have to rent a truck to transport this,'' he said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: The Loss of Affordable Housing
description: AT A recent tenant-organization meeting in West New York, on Hudson County's ''Gold Coast,'' several hundred people were asked:

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: The Mets: Blue Cross-Blue Shield.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Dover, Del.
description: GOV. MICHAEL N. CASTLE of Delaware is trying to bring stronger state control to real estate development with a package of land-use and related highway legislation.

title: THE EDUCATION OF A CONCERTGOER
description: STRONG ON MUSIC The New York Music Scene in the Days of George Templeton Strong, 1836-1875. Volume One: Resonances, 1836-1850. By Vera Brodsky Lawrence. Illustrated. 686 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $85.

title: Laura Rankin to Wed David William Stokes
description: The engagement of Laura Combs Rankin to David William Stokes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter McCook Stokes of Blue Bell, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Robert Rankin of Tenafly, N.J. Miss Rankin and her fiance, graduates of Hartwick College, plan to marry in September.

title: Nuclear Plant Shuts Down
description: The Millstone 1 nuclear power plant shut down automatically at 5:45 A.M. today when a water feed pump lost power, a Northeast Utilities spokesman, Anthony Nericcio, said. The plant will be put back into service when the cause of the power interruption is determined and any problems corrected, he said.

title: Will Lower Unemployment Fuel Inflation?
description: Unemployment has fallen to 5.6 percent, the lowest rate in 8 1/2 years. Will increased tightness in the labor market push up inflation? The Phillips curve - an economic relationship which shows that inflation grows as unemployment shrinks, and vice versa - would suggest the answer is yes. But most economists say the curve is not an accurate guide. BARRY BLUESTONE Professor of political economy, University of Massachussets at Boston.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock. The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this. This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it. How do I get this cover plate off?

title: Debuts; A Pianist, a Flutist and Three Singers in Recitals
description: Richard Fields

title: South Africa Bans New Anti-Apartheid Group
description: The South African Government today banned a new church-led anti-apartheid movement headed by Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu.

title: 'Blood Knot,' About Apartheid
