description: IT'S a rare day when problems arising from South Africa's policy of apartheid fail to make news. But even the most detailed report cannot examine the emotional, soul-searing effects of apartheid on the people living the headlines. Communicating the secrets of the human heart is the job of literature and the arts, and the South African playwright Athol Fugard's drama ''The Blood Knot'' is a case in point.

title: New York Lobbyists Spent $17 Million in '87
description: Lobbyists spent a record $17.9 million last year wooing state legislators, Cuomo administration officials and others in state government, according to a new report.

title: Kate Benton Engaged To James F. Doughan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Benton of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Kate Benton to James Francis Doughan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Francis Doughan of Apple Valley, Minn. An August wedding is planned.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Waltham, Mass.;
A 'New World' On Route 128
description: LEAD: THE vitality of the commercial hotel market along Route 128, Boston's high-technology beltway, is reflected in the $52 million Vista International-Waltham Hotel being built here.

title: ANARCHY IN SPACE
description: AMAZON WOMEN ON THE MOON Starring Steve Forrest, Michelle Pfeiffer, Joey Travolta, Ed Begley Jr., Matt Adler, Ralph Bellamy, David Alan Grier, Carrie Fisher, Rosanna Arquette, Steve Guttenberg, Archie Hahn. Directed by Joe Dante, Carl Gottlieb, Peter Horton, Robert K. Weiss, John Landis. 1987. MCA Home Video. 85 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: FICTION
description: DAN YACK. By Blaise Cendrars. Translated by Nina Rootes. (Michael Kesend, $15.95.) Dan Yack is Blaise Cendrars' Paul Bunyan. Without ox or ax, he strides larger than life through the pages of this thoroughly sophisticated tall tale. Drunk as a skunk or inaugurating a commercial utopia in the South Shetlands, Dan Yack - '' 'The millionaire?' 'The famous hell-raiser?' 'The beautiful Hedwiga's lover?' 'The very same' '' - cuts a lanky, flamboyant figure of formidable mental and financial resources. A fair-haired Englishman with a taste for liqueur brandy and gramophone records, Yack, monocle aglitter, is a kind of demonized Lord Peter Wimsey run amok on a gigantic scale. Sozzled, he proposes esthetic adventure to a trio of artists in St. Petersburg; sober, he waits out the south polar summer alone on iron rations of plum pudding and whisky (the latter strictly for washing). In this first American appearance of Blaise Cendrars' 1927 novel, published on the 100th anniversary of his birth, the French avant-garde master chronicles his outrageous brainchild in a style that mirrors Yack's extremes of fortune, studded with exclamation points and awash with verbal effervescence, a dizzying soar and plunge of mood. Cendrars' extravagance, like Yack's, is shrewd: no detail seems too lavish when the subject is ice sculpture in the Antarctic waste or the nonpareil mechanical orchestra of stuffed cats that churns and carols for the enraptured Yack in a Chilean bar. And Nina Rootes, translating with verve and a rollicking vocabulary, keeps breathless pace with this grand gallop.

title: The Rink Trump Didn't Fix
description: New York City's bungled renovation of the Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park became a national symbol of government inefficiency. The rink finally reopened for skating last year, but only after Donald Trump, the real estate developer, took charge of the repairs.

title: Back North, Dukakis Kicks Up Heels
description: After the moussaka and the stuffed grape leaves, after the squid and the wine and the Greek coffee, they pushed back the tables at the Greek Islands Restaurant Friday night and they turned up the bouzouki music. And Michael S. Dukakis began to dance.

title: Shaking Off the 'Federal Plantation' Image
description: A FEW years ago, just as Benjamin F. Payton, 55, was getting the feel of the president's chair that Booker T. Washington occupied a century ago at Tuskegee Institute, he was invited to accompany Vice President Bush as an educational adviser on an official tour of Africa.

title: Ambassador Lodge Regrets
description: To the Editor:

title: PATIENTS FACING INCREASED COSTS AT NURSING HOMES
description: The Reagan Administration has issued a new rule that it says will probably increase the costs of nursing home care for hundreds of thousands of low-income people who are elderly or disabled.

title: OPTIMISM AGAINST ODDS
description: This is the Middle East peace plan timetable proposed by Secretary of State Shultz to a number of heads of state; it has received little support. April 1988 - International conference would convene with Israel, Syria, Egypt, a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, Britain, France. Conference would have continuing role but could not veto or impose settlement. May 1, 1988 - Israel and ''each of its neighbors'' would begin six months of negotiations on an interim phase of self-administration for Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, including election of administrative council by Palestinians. December 1988 - Talks, to last one year, would begin between Israel and a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation on the final status of occupied territories. An interim phase of self-administration would not go into effect until these talks had begun. December 1989 - Talks on the final status of occupied territories would conclude. December 1991 - Earliest possible effective date for agreement on the final status of occupied territories.

title: 3d Suspect Questioned in Brooklyn Slaying
description: A third teen-ager was being questioned yesterday as a suspect in the fatal stabbing of a postal worker on a corner in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn on Dec. 25, the police said.

title: Of Ives, Music and Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Passaic Basin Gets Flood-Alert System
description: THE completion of a massive new flood-warning system for the Passaic River Basin is expected to be announced here Tuesday by the National Weather Service.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Boxing Whitaker Loses Title Bid: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title yesterday in Paris with a controversial split decision over Pernell Whitaker of the United States. Whitaker, who won a gold medal at the 1984 Olympics, appeared to have an easy time from the start and was peppering the champion with right jabs throughout the fight. He moved easily out of trouble but was missing combinations late in the fight after suffering an injury to his left hand in the middle rounds. Although Ramirez kept trying to come in, he failed to score often and Whitaker was able to stay out of trouble most of the way. There were no knockdowns. Judge Harry Gibbs of Britain scored the fight 117-113 in favor of Whitaker, which was in line with the way most people at ringside saw it. But Newton Campos of Brazil had it 118-113 for Ramirez, and Louis Michel of France scored it 116-115 in Ramirez's favor. Whitaker lost for the first time in 16 fights since turning pro in November 1984. Ramirez improved his record to 101-6.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins Lose: Marc Habscheid and Dave Gagner each scored two goals and Dave Archibald had the go-ahead score yesterday as the Minnesota North Stars ended their seven-game losing streak by beating the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-3, in Bloomington, Minn.(AP) Skiing Another Victory for Mueller: Peter Mueller of Switzerland won a World Cup downhill race in Beaver Creek, Colo., yesterday. The 30-year-old Mueller, in his 12th season of World Cup racing, recorded his second downhill victory of the season and the 17th of his career. Eight victories have come in the United States or Canada, including five in Colorado.(AP) Figini Closing In on Title: In Rossland, British Columbia, Michela Figini of Switzerland continued her domination of Red Mountain, gaining her third World Cup downhill victory of the season yesterday. The triumph all but clinched the World Cup downhill title for the former Olympic champion.(AP) Track and Field McRae Wins 55-Meter Dash Again: Lee McRae of the Pitt won the men's 55-meter dash for the third consecutive year in the N.C.A.A. indoor track and field championships last night in Oklahoma City. Carlette Guidry, a Texas freshman, won her second event of the meet. McRae, the 1987 World University Games and Pan American Games 100-meter gold medalist, took the sprint in 6.07 seconds. Guidry, who won the long jump Friday night, took the women's 55-meter race in 6.72 seconds.(AP) Scholastic Record in 600 Meters: Ian Jones, a senior at Nazareth High School in Brooklyn, posted a national indoor scholastic record for 600 meters yesterday when he won the event in 1 minute 20.34 seconds at the New York State boys and girls indoor championships at Cornell. Jones lowered the former mark of 1:20.56 set by Errington Lindo of Jefferson High in Brooklyn in 1986. Derrick Atkins of Malverne, L.I., at 1:20.45, was second, also under the national record. Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn set a national mark in the 3,200-meter relay in 9:09.18, 2 seconds under the record. Sharon Moore, won the girls' 600-meter run in 1:33.18, ran an anchor leg of 2:11.4 in the relay. Tennis Soviet Player Wins Tournament: Andrei Chesnokov became the first Soviet player to win a men's professional tournament in the United States in 14 years as he beat Miloslav Mecir, 7-6, 6-1, in the final of the Du Pont Classic in Orlando, Fla., yesterday. Chesnokov's victory was the first by a Soviet player in an American men's professional tournament since August 1974, when Alex Metreveli won the Eastern Open in New Jersey.(AP) Sabatini Gains First Victory Over Evert: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina beat Chris Evert for the first time, and Steffi Graf won a third-set tiebreaker to beat Pam Shriver in yesterday's semifinals of the Virginia Slims of Florida tournament in Boca Raton. The 17-year-old Sabatini won, 6-1, 7-5. Evert had beaten Sabatini in their five previous meetings dating to 1985. Graf needed 2 hours 50 minutes to beat Shriver, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6.(AP) Speed Skating Kania Captures Two Races: Karin Enke Kania of East Germany, who won two silver medals and one bronze in the Calgary Olympics, won the 500- and 3,000-meter races at the world speed-skating championships in Skien, Norway.(AP) Jansen Wins 1,000 Meters: Dan Jansen, who fell twice in the Winter Olympics, took the 1,000-meter competition at a World Cup event yesterday in Inzell, West Germany.(AP) Women's Basketball Milestone for Texas Coach: Coach Jody Conradt of the University of Texas yesterday became only the second women's basketball coach to notch 500 victories as Texas defeated Texas Tech, 88-61, in the final of the Southwest Conference Classic. Conradt has 500 victories and 115 losses in 19 seasons, the last 12 at Texas. Conradt's achievement followed that of the Fresno State coach, Bob Spencer, who recorded victory No. 500 earlier this month.(AP) Sled Dog Racing Redington Loses Iditarod Lead: After pacing the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race for more than 400 miles, 70-year-old Joe Redington lost the lead yesterday to Martin Buser as the leaders raced down the frozen Yukon River in Alaska. Buser, who moved to Alaska from Switzerland in 1979, left Galena at 8:21 A.M. local time, an hour ahead of Redington. Buser arrived at Nulato, 52 miles downstream, at 2:36 P.M. Redington arrived an hour later. Nulato, at the junction of the Nulato and Yukon Rivers, is 400 miles from the finish in Nome.(AP) Fencing Another Title for Columbia: Bob Cottingham and Chris Reohr were undefeated in 13 saber bouts as Columbia registered 100 victories to win the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championship for the third straight year yesterday at Levien Gymnasium on the Columbia campus.

title: Miriam A. Leventhal Weds Roger Widmann
description: Miriam Ann Leventhal, a second-year law student at Yale University, and Roger Franklin Widmann, a third-year medical student at Yale, were married last evening in Morristown, N.J. Rabbi Z. David Levy performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Or.

title: Guarneri Quartet in Montclair
description: LEAD: THE Guarneri Quartet will make its only New Jersey appearance this season when it joins forces with the New Jersey Chamber Music Society next Sunday in a concert at Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Avenue, Montclair.

title: Environment Gains As a Political Factor
description: THE issue that could dominate the 1989 race for Governor surfaced in a poll released this month. It showed that state residents were becoming worried about the effects of growth and development on their personal lives.

title: New Book Says Pentagon Failed to Inform Congress of Secret Units
description: The Pentagon set up several highly secret units in the early 1980's that carried out operations that in some cases were not disclosed to Congress or to appropriate senior officials in the military and intelligence agencies, according to a forthcoming book.

title: Problem Youths Learn How to Succeed in Business
description: Vincent Wilkins reached deep into the pocket of his blue jeans and pulled out his business card.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock. The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this. This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it. How do I get this cover plate off?

title: An Uneasy Alliance in Smokestack U.S.A.
description: THEY make motors here at the General Electric Company's aging plants on Taylor Street and on Broadway, and they want to keep making them. They like to say that they are the best motor makers in the world.

title: R.I. Nooter Weds Barbara Reichart
description: Barbara Ellen Reichart, a certified financial planner who is a sales assistant with Alex. Brown & Sons in Washington, and Robert Ingram Nooter, an assistant director of national affairs for the American Farm Bureau Federation in Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Harley Bender performed the ceremony at St. Paul's United Methodist Church in Chesapeake, Va.

title: Headliners; Message Heard
description: With a week of campus demonstrations, students at Gallaudet University in Washington, the nation's only institution of higher learning for the deaf, made it clear how important it was to them to have an administrator who shared their handicap. By week's end, they were on their way to achieving that goal. Dr. Elisabeth Ann Zinser, whose appointment as president last Sunday sparked the protests, announced her resignation on Friday. The protesters had demanded that Dr. Zinser, who is not deaf, be replaced by someone who was hearing-impaired. Dr. Zinser, formerly a vice president at the University of North Carolina, said she had learned ''how deeply some see the social stature of deaf persons reflected in the presidency of this university,'' and hoped her departure would ''pave the way'' for the selection of Gallaudet's first hearing-impaired president in its 124-year history.

title: Alan H. Howard Married To Carole Jean Freedman
description: Carole Jean Freedman, an officer in commercial lending at the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Alan Hugh Howard, an associate in investment banking at the First Boston Corporation in New York, were married last evening at the Pierre by Rabbi Burt A. Siegel.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock. The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this. This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it. How do I get this cover plate off?

title: Political Notes; Being at Odds With Leaders May Aid Koch
description: Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic chairman, has joined the list of Democratic county leaders at odds with Mayor Koch - a political development that is unusual but less significant than it would have been when political ''bosses'' were really bosses.

title: Pee Wee Russell Stomp Next Sunday at Rutgers
description: DESPITE mailing lists in the thousands and heavy advertising and promotion, most of New York's concert halls frequently are less than full.

title: REAGAN'S BUREAUCRATS
description: In Phillip Longman's article, Edwin Feulner, president of the Heritage Foundation, says that he observed the late Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige's enthusiasm for David Stockman's budget-cutting proposals in 1981. But, ''within two years, he [ Baldrige ] was fighting for every 35 cents and trying to get more,'' having become Commerce's spokesman ''instead of the President's representative to Commerce.''

title: Mozambique Wins a Skirmish on Health Care
description: In a country of miseries where the odds are stacked against survival, people in this capital city are molding a fragile success story by knocking on doors.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Recycling; Putting Vacant Buildings Into Service
description: OVER a period of at least 10 years, New Yorkers have grown accustomed to hearing that the inventory of city-owned tax-foreclosed buildings is increasing. More housing units seemed to be coming into city ownership than going out as decent, improved housing.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: RAPTURE. By Thomas Tessier. (Atheneum, $20.95.) ''Things happen because they have to,'' reasons Jeff Lisker, the psychotic protagonist of Thomas Tessier's new suspense novel. What has to happen for Jeff is the attainment of one Georgianne Slaton Corcoran, a woman who has fascinated the 38-year-old California businessman since their high school days.

title: Thousands Protest Outside Waldheim's Office
description: Thousands of protesters gathered outside the offices of President Kurt Waldheim today, urging him to resign, as they invoked the memory of the victims of Nazism 50 years after Hitler's troops marched into Austria.

title: Should the Prince Send Modernism to the Tower?
description: Last weekend, when Prince Charles gave the concluding address at an international conference of architects in Pittsburgh, he confirmed to an American audience what the British have known for some time now - that he does not think much of modern architecture and planning, and is prepared to be outspoken, even blunt, about it. ''In the United States and United Kingdom we have had 40 years of practice at urban design and comprehensive planning and development,'' the Prince said. ''The results have been pretty disastrous.''

title: Jackson Wins South Carolina
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson easily won the Democratic precinct caucuses in the state where he was born. Page 28.

title: There's Nothing Monolithic About Evangelical Politics
description: WHEN the National Association of Evangelicals met here last week, chagrin over the Jimmy Swaggart scandal ran far ahead of Presidential politics in the minds of the delegates. In some ways, it was characteristic of evangelicalism that the health of the church should take priority over matters of state. Yet it could easily have been otherwise.

title: Devils Defeat Flyers Again
description: The Flyers are virtually assured one of the four playoff spots in the Patrick Division and the team they would probably like to avoid in the opening round is the Devils.

title: The Miami Area
description: To the Editor: Having spent many family vacations in Miami Beach while growing up, I want to thank you for your Miami spread (Travel, Feb. 7). While all three articles were great, I most enjoyed Michael Connor's on Miami Beach's Art Deco Historic District. Yet, I found it amazing that he never mentioned that this colorful neighborhood has always been known by the name South Beach.

title: Minority Jobs Gain, State Aides Report
description: LEAD: GOVERNMENT officials are saying that employment opportunities for minorities have been rising in the state ever since New Jersey started outpacing the nation in job growth in the wake of the 1982 recession.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Manchester, N.H.;
A 'Village' To House 6,000
description: LEAD: OFF a narrow two-lane road near Manchester's northwest boundary, a developer is building what he says will be its largest single residential complex.

title: Army Unit Taps Open Secrets of Soviet
description: For two years, the Army has been operating a small research unit with an unusual mission - delving into the inner workings of Soviet military power by relying solely on publicly available sources.

title: Q and A
description: Surcharge for Repairs

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: ANIMAL IMAGES

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: A Walk in the City; ETERNAL ROME: A VIEW FROM ON HIGH
description: The Via di Santa Sabina runs for only a few hundred yards across Rome's Aventine Hill, but it is one of those magic places where this city reminds visitors that there are more than 2,000 years of history here -all intertwined. It is a green, normally quiet spot where that thought can be allowed to spur fantasy.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: BRUSSELS
description: Brussels seems to affect different people in different ways. Emily Bronte and Baudelaire hated it, Victor Hugo and Cocteau adored it, Lord Byron was impressed by the parks. Marx and Engels read the tentative chapters of the ''Communist Manifesto'' to Brussels workingmen, Verlaine shot Rimbaud after a lovers' spat in the narrow street that runs by the Hotel Amigo, Emily's sister Charlotte wrote her last novel, ''Villette,'' with Brussels as the setting. The city like a whited sepulcher, in Joseph Conrad's ''Heart of Darkness,'' is Brussels.

title: Sindelar Birdies 18th and Gains One-Shot Lead
description: Joey Sindelar, who has a string of 11 consecutive sub-par rounds on the PGA Tour, sank an 8-foot birdie putt at the 18th hole today, and a few minutes later was in the lead by one shot after three rounds of the Honda Classic.

title: Closed Lanes and Other Trouble Sites
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Transportation has identified the following sites as work areas that may cause traffic congestion. Where lane closings are limited to weekdays or off-peak hours, it is indicated.

title: Paul Ying Lee Is Wed To Johanna Lawrence
description: The Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Johanna Clune Lawrence, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Stanton Lawrence of Port Washington, L.I., to Paul Ying Lee, the son of Dr. Catherine So of Buffalo and the late Dr. Joseph C. Lee. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Prague and East Berlin See Reform as Fine - For Moscow
description: IN East Germany and Czechoslovakia, where opposition politics has long been dormant, signs of life are stirring. The activities of small East German ecology and human rights groups have grown so extensive that the Government cracked down in January, rounding up more than 100 activists and expelling some of the leaders to West Germany.

title: Correction
description: An article on Feb. 7 about corporate efforts to register voters gave an incorrect location for the headquarters of the Nationwide Insurance Company. It is in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Sexism: the Sequel
description: To the Editors:

title: Dole Makes Plea in Half-Hour TV Ad
description: Senator Bob Dole staked his fading Presidential candidacy tonight on a a televised speech that was marred by technical mishaps.

title: CITY CENTERS
description: LONDON: The Swiss Ice Cream Garden, Swiss Center, Leicester Square (telephone: 734 1291). Open noon until 10 P.M.; no alcohol. The Coupe Swiss Baby - vanilla and strawberry ice cream with fresh strawberries, fresh whipped cream and strawberry sauce, about $6 (computed as one pound sterling - $1.80). FLORENCE: Rivoire, Piazza della Signoria 5r (214412). Open 8 A.M. to midnight, closed Tuesdays. Spremuta di limone (fresh-squeezed lemonade): about $2.50 at the bar, about $5 at a table (computed as 1,240 lire - $1).

title: A Maze of Boulevards and Byways
description: ROAD MAPS ARE DESIGNED to take your from point A, to point B, but mazes are designed to get you lost. Consider the above, as round as the world, and as full of distractions. Get out your pencil and start at the top - you may choose your own entrance - and find your way back to the adjacent exit.

title: Hope in a Bottle: The Billion-Dollar Baldness Race
description: PEDDLERS have been seeking baldness cures about as long as alchemists tried to turn base metals into gold. But while the alchemists gave up some time ago, the anti-baldness forces now seem to be hitting their stride.

title: A Checklist for Buying Raw Land
description: JAMES LLAMAS, a New York City resident, has been spending his weekends lately looking for land upstate. The venture is partly personal and partly for profit. He and his fiancee are seeking a parcel they can divide and sell, using the proceeds to finance the building of a vacation home on the portion that they would keep.

title: Dethrone the Emperors of Trash
description: Big plastic bags of trash line New York's downtown sidewalks every day, waiting for commercial carters. Meanwhile, scavengers tear them open looking for returnable bottles. Garbage-combers scatter scraps. Rats dart out, scratching for food. Here is the domain of the Emperors of Trash.

title: DiffJrent Stories, but All Ending in Heartbreak
description: LEAD: ONE by one, the parents told their stories, speaking of Stephen, Meredith, Joyce, Kali, James, Brett and Anthony - babies they had loved for so short a time but whom they would never forget.

title: To Mr. Gorbachev: Stop Sending Arms
description: The following letter has been directed to the Soviet Union through diplomatic channels.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY

title: Volunteerism Finds New Adherents in New York
description: At the age of 26, Paul Rice had a rewarding career as a New York City architect, with time for friends, music and skiing, but he sensed that his life needed another dimension. He began calling hospitals and offering to be a volunteer.

title: THE WORLD: Occupied Territories; Uprising by the Palestinians Is Not a Made-for-TV Movie
description: THE 4,000 residents of this tiny Arab village in the West Bank mountains say they have held some 20 demonstrations since the Palestinian uprisings began last Dec. 9. The village's Israeli-appointed leaders have all resigned and its youth have broken apart one of the ancient stone terraces on the hillside sloping down from Mazraa Sharqiya in order to build a series of roadblocks at the entrance to the town. Two of the village's residents have been killed, one shot by soldiers, another by a Jewish settler. When an American reporter walked into the hamlet last week, he found scores of people, young and old, congratulating a teen-ager who had been grazed by an Israeli bullet that left an inch-long hole in his shirt sleeve. What is noteworthy is that television cameras have not recorded any of this. The uprising here began without television, it widened without television, and now it is part of local legend without television.

title: BUY THAT! SELL THIS! GET ME OUT OF HERE!
description: TRADING UP By Nancy Bazelon Goldstone. 262 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Elissa Ann Von Heill, a Bank Official, Is Married to George
description: Elissa Ann Von Heill, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Von Heill of Syosset, L.I., and Dunewood, Fire Island, L.I., was married yesterday to George Hartwell Hylton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Hylton of Danville, Va. The Rev. J. Douglas Ousley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation in Manhattan.

title: Computer Viruses
description: To the Editor:

title: Children Of the Divorced: Children in Need
description: I AM writing about a fixed fight.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Making a Go of That 'Handyman Special'
description: LEAD: TWO years after purchasing their house on Old Post Drive in Hauppauge, Debbie and William Ahrens are still living with plaster dust.

title: How Doctors Judge Peers Is Challenged
description: Hardly anyone in this coastal town regretted the departure of Dr. Timothy A. Patrick - not his relatives and friends, not his former patients, certainly not his former colleagues.

title: OPEC's Plan Runs Into a Snag
description: OPEC apparently dropped plans to cut oil production. Officials said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had studied a plan to reduce oil output by 5 percent in hopes of raising sagging prices. But it reportedly abandoned the proposal because of fears that any cuts in output would be made up by non-OPEC producers. OPEC prices have declined in the past two weeks to around $14 a barrel, well below OPEC's official goal of $18. But the price of the American benchmark crude oil, West Texas Intermediate, rose $1 last week, to over $16 a barrel, because of hopes of lower OPEC output.

title: Amy Joy Bermant To Wed a Teacher
description: Amy Joy Bermant, the promotions associate at Conde Nast's Traveler magazine in New York, and Eliot Weiss, a mathematics teacher at the Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, plan to be married June 5.

title: Mr. Shamir's Mistakes
description: Thirty United States senators wrote to Secretary of State Shultz to support his Middle East peace plan and to criticize Prime Minister Shamir for rejecting the heart of the plan - land for peace. The Israeli leader replies that he is ''astonished'' by the letter and that the only valid part of the Shultz plan is the Secretary's signature.

title: Body and Mind; Laughter and Hope
description: THE ERNEST young psychiatrist recalled his patient sadly:

title: THIRD-COMMANDMENT BLUES
description: Mr. Bush is indeed off the hook, but not because he used the adjectival form of the expression, as Mr. Safire indicated. Mr. Bush is off the hook because he was never on it. The Third Commandment, many believe, has nothing to do with minor swearing; it refers, rather, to lying under oath - to perjury, not profanity. If this is so, then the commandment wasn't broken and Mr. Bush can rest easy. JAY STOLAR Marietta, Ga.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE LADY'S CHAIR AND THE OTTOMAN Written and illustrated by Noel Tennyson. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 8)

title: Sophisticated Traveler/Magazine, Part 2
description: Crossroads of Spring: grand boulevards and rustic byways.

title:
FIVE PLACES TO MEET THE WORLD;
The Kurfurstendamm
description: LEAD: I recently returned to West Berlin after a few years away; and if only to heck out how the place had changed, I went to the Kurfurstendamm, walking a mile or so along the south side of the street and returning on the north before settling into a chair at an outdoor cafe to watch the passers-b. The experience reminded me that one of the key pleasures of city living is the pleasure of watching people, a variety of people.

title: For Deaf, Gallaudet Was Just a Start
description: The protests at Gallaudet University, the nation's only liberal arts college for the deaf, represent the blossoming of a new civil rights movement, deliberately patterned on the black civil rights actions of the 1960's, according to deaf people and advocates for the handicapped.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Streetscapes article on Feb. 21 incorrectly stated that the building at 503 Fifth Avenue had been emptied of tenants and not since relet. There are three ground-floor tenants - Picadilly and Showplace I, both clothing stores, and Showcase Sports, selling athletic clothes and shoes.

title: Knicks Blow Big Lead But Defeat Jazz, 108-105
description: After squadering a 21-point second-quarter lead, the Knicks had to stage some last-minute heroics last night before beating the the Utah Jazz, 108-105, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Florida Inmate Faces His Seventh Date With Executioner
description: In an apricot-colored concrete holding cell at the Florida State Prison here, it takes six minutes for guards to free Willie Jasper Darden from the chains that girdle his body. It is routine procedure for an inmate marched down from death row to see a lawyer or a member of the press and Mr. Darden, 54 years old, knows the routine well.

title: SWIFT TO ALOHA PROSPECTOR
description: Aloha Prospector, who beat the highly regarded Tejano in California last month, posted a similar front-running 2 3/4-length victory yesterday to win the $141,000 Swift Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct.

title: Just Around the Corner, A Storeful of Sympathy
description: At the Answer Shops/House of Spiritual Knowledge, a tiny cluttered store wedged between a barber shop and a check-cashing stand on Girard Avenue, people come to buy candy, tea and cigarettes. The answers are free.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Their resignation will leave a big and dangerous vacuum.

title: AIDS VIRUS-CARRIERS FACING DIM FUTURE
description: A study of gay men in San Francisco has provided new evidence of the dire medical prospects for carriers of the AIDS virus, indicating that half will develop AIDS and another 25 percent will develop AIDS-related complex within about nine years of infection.

title: REAGAN'S BUREAUCRATES
description: I attended Dartmouth during the heyday of these young conservatives' efforts on The Dartmouth Review. The editors of The Review wrote malicious and self-serving journalism. The newspaper, which had no association with the college, represented the viewpoints of some old, conservative alumni and a small minority (10 percent) of students. The mainstream students laughed at The Review and its staff, parodying editor Dinesh D'Souza as Distort De'Newsa.

title:
TELEVISION;
Hunting Wildlife With a Movie Camera
description: LEAD: At one time or another almost everyone has sat in a comfortable armchair and watched wonders of the natural world: the hatching of an alligator, a polar bear cub's first timid venture out of its dark den onto the frozen white tundra. What television viewers rarely see are the film makers who captured these moments: Alan Degen, who crawled on his belly through swamp ooze to the giant alligator nest, or Hugh Miles, who managed to find the bears' den after weeks of searching and mishap in the

title: Incentives Are Sound Strategy
description: Since its revival under Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler Corporation has been closely identified with incentive programs. Despite the problems others cite with this approach, Chrysler has continued to use it. Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, talked with Bud Liebler, director of marketing services of the Chrysler Motors Corporation.

title: Bad News Gives a Better Chance
description: South Africa's ban on news coverage of violent repression, especially by television, has worked in a sense. There is no longer a steaming head of outrage in the U.S. and Western Europe, or demands for greater outside pressure on the regime.

title: Incident on the Road From Jerusalem to Hebron
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Stafford Plans To Marry May 14
description: Dr. Susan Stafford, a partner in Concord (Mass.) Radiologists, and Dr. David Stark, an associate professor of radiology at the Harvard Medical School, plan to be married May 14.

title: British-Irish Violence Is 'Appallingly Normal'
description: ''THEY are the murderers!'' the Conservatives shouted from their majority benches in the House of Commons, furious once more at the evidence of Irish rebellion. They were contradicting one of the few members willing to rise and question the manner in which three unarmed Irish rebels were shot to death by British anti-terrorist agents in Gibraltar last weekend as they plotted to devastate a public square with 200 pounds of plastic explosives.

title: BANGS AND WHIMPERS: NOVELISTS AT ARMAGEDDON
description: LEAD: Faced with extinction, we imagine reprieve.

title: HARVARD WINS THIRD PLACE
description: Harvard played to win tonight and also to impress a selection committee. The Crimson beat Vermont, 7-1, in the consolation game of the ECAC Hockey Tournament at the Boston Garden to capture third place and perhaps something more.

title: Susan L. Alfin to Wed Michael T. F. Johnson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Alfin of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lisa Alfin, to Michael Thomas Finley Johnson, a son of Mrs. John H. Hapeman of New Boston, N.H., and Gardiner Porter Johnson of Dallas.

title: Accord Clears Way to Give River New Look
description: The Pigeon River, which is the color of coffee after passing through this city, may be improved to the shade of weak tea within three years as a result of an agreement this week among two states and this region's largest employer.

title: In Montauk, Conservation, Not Campers
description: WHEN the 557-acre wilderness of hickory and oak trees in Montauk called Hither Woods opens to the public, possibly this spring, there will be no restrooms, campsites or refreshment stands.

title: ''Yellow Fever'' to Visit Purchase
description: SAM SHIKAZE, private eye, is expected to stop off in Purchase next Sunday. And the search for the missing Cherry Blossom Queen will be on.

title: Katonah Gallery Gets Its First Director
description: SOMETIMES the Katonah Gallery gets called the Katonah Museum. It is an understandable mistake, because although it is run mainly by volunteers the place seems like a museum with its well-researched and professionally installed shows.

title: Exploring Twin Cities By Canal Boat
description: WE had to board Paradise before 6 P.M., but we just could not find it. Paradise is the name of the new tourist boat that runs overnight between Suzhou and Hangzhou along the Grand Canal. Paradise is also the name that Chinese give to the twin cities of Suzhou and Hangzhou, linked in an ancient Chinese saying that Marco Polo elaborated on when he told the West of the fabulous cities of the East: ''In heaven, paradise; on earth, Suzhou and Hangzhou.''

title: Celebrating The Great Blizzard
description: LEAD: EDITH PERRY wasn't planning anything special today - she said she would just sit in her Bronxville home and relax. That is what she did 100 years ago in Fairhaven, N.J., when the snow fell and fell, eventually piling high enough to cover the first floor of her house.

title: Controlling Development
description: GOV. MICHAEL N. CASTLE of Delaware is trying to bring stronger state control to real estate development with a package of land-use and related highway legislation.

title: Helping Make Relocation a Good Move
description: CONVINCING an employee in the Atlanta area to trade the spacious family homestead for one that is half the size and twice the price in the Westchester area is a hard sell. Companies find that disparate living costs are a major concern of employees who resist relocation.

title: Welcome, Pirates, to Saturday
description: The last eight years were difficult for the Seton Hall basketball team.

title: Vegetables and Pasta: Seductive, Simple
description: THE official beginning of spring is a week away. But the markets have begun to display their springtime finery. Appetites whetted by the arrival of spring insist on asparagus. Bunches of asparagus have made their appearance with prices at less than $2 a pound. Artichokes and herbs also have irresistible seasonal appeal. Many of these ingredients can combine with fresh pasta to make seductive or sprightly first courses or main dishes.

title: WHEN EATING IS ALL THAT MATTERS
description: MY NAME IS CAROLINE By Caroline Adams Miller. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York: Doubleday. $17.95.

title: Bush Basks As Dukakis Strives to Break Away
description: SUPER Tuesday, the nation's first experiment with a megaprimary, didn't exactly work out as its Southern Democratic sponsors had planned, in that it produced a surge in participation in the Republican contests, and a muddle, rather than a clear front-runner with a conservative bent, for the Democrats.

title: Sexism: the Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth I. Bushkin Is Wed to Marc D. Schnitzer
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ida Bushkin, an account executive in the women's sportswear division of Liz Claiborne Inc. in New York, to Marc David Schnitzer, an assistant vice president of the Related Capital Corporation in New York, took place last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky, assisted by Cantor William Wolff, performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LONG DISTANCES. By Fabienne Marsh. (Summit, $17.95.) Both Michael Hammond, a poet and Columbia University English professor, and his wife, Kate, who makes television documentaries, are good-looking, cultured, well traveled and irresistible to the opposite sex. After 14 years of marriage and two splendid children, they still adore each other.

title: Harsh Truth For Parents: It's Never Over
description: CONTRARY to public opinion, life is not easier when children grow up.

title: Street Fashion; Preppy Look With a Downtown Twist
description: A LOT of young men about town have been cleaning up their act lately, shying away from the black-leather rock-and-roller look so popular in the last fashion millennium (about a month ago on regulation calendars) in favor of tweedy checks and plaids. Subdued silk ties, striped shirts, comfy cardigan sweaters, baggy trousers and slicked-down hairdos are getting their share of attention, too.

title: New Jersey Guide
description: THE IRISH ARE COMING As a child, Eamon Kelly heard his father and his father's friends spin wonderful yarns while they sat around a peat fire. On Thursday, Mr. Kelly, now an actor with the Abbey Theater in Dublin, will be at Seton Hall University in South Orange to honor St. Patrick with an evening of tall Irish tales.

title: LUBOVITCH SETS HIS OWN TEMPO
description: Dressed in black, always dressed in black to make himself less visible, Lar Lubovitch is obsessed with focusing the stage lights during a rehearsal of his new dance, ''Musette.'' The choreographer knows exactly what he wants: no abrasive edges around the spots, but a smooth transition from the hot patch on center stage where his dancers stand basking to a dim gray area on the sidelines.

title: Food; The Farmers' Banquet
description: SOMETIMES I AM SURPRISED THAT the French have cookbooks at all. For even though the written word is sacrosanct in France, all one has to do is walk out the door and, inevitably, the subject of food comes up. Before you know it, you're jotting down recipes for the cheesemonger's favorite potato gratin, the hairdresser's grandmother's version of creme caramel, the dry cleaner's apple tart and the farmer's wife's cheesecake.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE DRAWER opened grudgingly, making cobwebs billow. Through the age-warped glass and the leaves plastered against the panes, a pale shaft of dust slanted neatly into the drawer. It was empty except for an impressive collection of rodent droppings and a knife. Earl's knife. I didn't reach for it immediately.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: A Troubled Urban Mall; Rouse Makes Plans for the South Street Seaport
description: THE Rouse Company is planning extensive marketing and design changes for the South Street Seaport, a five-year-old urban mall that has failed to find its niche within the cutthroat retail marketplace of Manhattan.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Art Pottery at the Newark Museum
description: LEAD: THE Newark Museum's decorative arts collection began in 1911 with a Persian antelope tile donated by Dr. Henry Chapman Mercer, a ceramist of rare and eccentric accomplishment whose home and pottery works, along with the remarkable museum he founded in Doylestown, Pa., are open to the public.

title: Italy Enacts Seat-Belt Law
description: Parliament has approved a law requiring the installation and wearing of seat belts, bringing Italy into line with the rest of Western Europe. ''From today on we are more European,'' said Antonio Testa, the president of the Chamber of Deputies' transport commission, after approval of the law Thursday. The law requires all cars registered in the last 10 years to be equipped with seat belts in the front seats by March 1989. By September 1989, drivers and front-seat passengers will be required to wear them.

title: At the End, We Ask the Unanswerable Questions All Over Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Sentence in Pentagon Fraud
description: A former high-ranking official at the Defense Personnel Support Center here was sentenced Thursday to 10 years in prison for taking bribes in the awarding of clothing contracts. Frank Coccia, 55 years old, who supervised the award of $1.3 million in contracts a year when he was head of the Clothing and Textile Directorate, had pleaded guilty to taking part from 1976 to 1986 in a kickback scheme that involved at least 9 companies and 15 people.

title: Marjori Gill, Social Worker, Weds Andrew L. Schecter
description: Marjori Joy Gill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph L. Gill of New York, was married last evening to Andrew Lawrence Schecter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Schecter of Brooklyn. Rabbi Martin J. Zion officiated at Temple Israel of the City of New York in Manhattan.

title: Anne R. Dowden to Marry Franz Colloredo-Mansfeld
description: The engagement of Anne Robertson Dowden to Franz Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald Smith Dowden of Islip, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Colloredo-Mansfeld of Hamilton, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: Log Homes Market Grows
description: SALES of the log cabin, one of the oldest and most durable forms of American homes, are making a comeback in the Northwest, spurred in part by demand in Japan and Taiwan.

title: Focusing on Pro Hockey, and How It Oughta Be
description: By nature hockey tends to be a bit more hot-headed than, let us say, chess. But harsher penalties and an injection of guts into N.H.L. leadership might help restore the attraction of the game to those of us whose taste is slightly above that of female mud wrestling.

title: Institute Proposed On Lyme Disease
description: LEAD: EFFORTS to combat Lyme disease took on new urgency recently when the State Assembly's Health Committee made public a report that called the illness ''a clear and present danger'' and called for the creation of a $1.7 million tick-borne disease institute.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bloomsbury $159,000 39 West Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; fireplace in living room, 2 porches, full finished basement; taxes $2,097. Jackson $245,000 120 Fish Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 8-year-old custom-built ranch; eat-in kitchen, deck, pool; taxes $1,070. Lake Hopatcong $183,000 23 Crescent Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old ranch; w/w carpeting, screened porch, fireplace, attached garage; taxes $2,726. Livingston $162,500 10 Midway Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, dining room, full basement; taxes $2,186. Short Hills $314,000 4 Inverness Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old split level; 2-car attached garage, c/a, fireplace; taxes $4,866. Woodbridge $157,000 119 Grove Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 19-year-old colonial; front porch, hardwood floors, fireplace; taxes $1,857. OTHER AREAS Brookhaven, L.I. $95,000 148 Beaver Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 60-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,260. White Plains, N.Y. $273,000 25 Coolidge Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 49-year-old brick/frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, screened terrace; walk to school; taxes $1,733. Danbury, Conn. $222,000 18 Westwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old raised ranch; screened porch, electric security system, 1.1 acres; taxes, $2,178.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: Yankee pitching needs an owner who knows how to develop good young pitchers within the farm system instead of wasting time on annual shopping trips to baseball's overpriced free-agent market. Taking time to develop talent instead of going for the quick fix - Candelarias, Niekros, et al., will pay off in the long run. Go back to Florida, George. JERRY TOUVAL Great Falls, Va.

title: Pakistani Aides Foil Attempt To Hijack a Domestic Flight
description: Two provincial government officials traveling on a Pakistan International Airlines jet subdued a man who shot a guard and was trying to hijack the plane today, Pakistani officials and the national press agency reported.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
For Art's Sake
description: LEAD: Do you think today's colleges are filled with future Yuppies, majoring in business, then making a run for the money or an M.B.A.? Perhaps a visit to the Purchase campus of the State University of New York is due. There, amid the art, drama and music programs for which the college is noted, is a class so esoteric it could make the other courses seem downright mundane.

title: Pamela R. Akers And K. A. Sjodin Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Pamela Renee Akers to Kevin Andrew Sjodin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton F. Sjodin of Fairfield, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John F. Akers of Westport, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., parents of the bride-to-be. An October wedding is planned.

title: Elaine La Roche Weds a Geologist
description: At the Union Club in New York last evening, Marie-Elaine La Roche, a managing director of Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, was married to Dr. Peter Richard Donovan, an exploration geologist with the United Nations Development Program. The Rev. John D. Twiname, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Brooklyn Man Given Prison Term For a 'Racially Motivated' Slaying
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man has been sentenced to 15 years to life in prison for what the authorities have called the ''racially motivated murder'' of a black Coney Island supermarket clerk.

title: State Report Criticizes Reliability of Utility
description: THE average Connecticut resident had a power failure every 5.6 months in 1986, as against one every 8.7 months in the period from 1982 to 1985, according to a draft of a state report on Northeast Utilities.

title: 'Give Us Your Money or Give Us Your Influence'
description: MORGAN STATE, a cultural and educational oasis amid Baltimore's inner-city bleakness, is borrowing heavily from techniques of Madison Avenue and Hollywood to promote its resurgence.

title: Taxpayers Warned on Overpaying
description: A SPOKESMAN at the New Jersey headquarters of the Internal Revenue Service here says that ''New Jersey taxpayers are losing considerable sums of money in overpayments due to an oversight stemming from changes in the new income-tax law.''

title: STREETSCAPES: West 80th Street Day Care Center; A Bright Hope for Children Giving Way to Office Condo
description: THE physical reminder of a dream that blazed briefly, but died stands vacant and grimy today on West 80th Street, waiting for a new incarnation.

title: DATA ON SMOKING REVEALED AT TRIAL
description: For six weeks, lawyers in Federal District Court here have been presenting jurors with internal tobacco industry documents in an effort to show how some cigarette companies tried to mislead the public about the health risks of smoking.

title: Soviet Has Joined Little League Inc.
description: The Soviet Union has accepted an invitation to join Little League Baseball, the organization announced today.

title: Symphony Hits High Notes With Singles in Stamford
description: BACH for single people will be the Stamford Symphony program on Friday at the Stamford Sheraton.

title: THIRD-COMMANDMENT BLUES
description: Beyond my belief that the absence of conversational profanity usually indicates that the speaker is capable of saying what's on his mind without resorting to tribal conventions, I have no particular interest in who does or does not break the Third Commandment (On Language: ''Falling in Love With Luv,'' by William Safire, Feb. 14). However, I find William Safire's proclamation about George Bush's utterings puzzling.

title: Focusing on Pro Hockey, and How It Oughta Be
description: The column on Feb. 26 was great. I just hope John Ziegler receives more like it.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: SOME members of the State Planning Commission have proposed a change in the draft of the State Development and Redevelopment Plan.

title: MUSIC
description: BACH, Beethoven, Brahms, Mozart, Schubert and other classical friends are well represented in the county this week, so lovers of the musical tried and true have an abundance of choices ahead.

title: N.F.L. OWNERS WILL BE FACING A CROWDED AGENDA
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle, more than 200 National Football League executives, and virtually all the league's coaches will have little time to explore the grounds of their hotel, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, when the league's annual meeting starts today in Phoenix.

title:
DINING OUT;
New Japanese Spot in Hartsdale
description: LEAD: THOSE who shop at Marshall's, Service Merchandise or the handful of other stores in this shopping mall on upper Central Avenue might have noticed that the unprepossessing B. J. Kirby's restaurant has had a face-lifting and a name change. This erstwhile coffee shop and barbecue spot that only dabbled in Japanese cuisine by offering teriyaki chicken and beef has been transformed into one of the best Japanese restaurants in the area.

title: Correction
description: The Pop View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday incorrectly described the uses of proceeds from Michael Jackson's ''Man in the Mirror'' recording. A spokesman for Mr. Jackson says that indeed a part of the royalties from the 7-inch and 12-inch singles of ''Man in the Mirror'' will be donated to charity, benefiting Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, a camp for children with cancer.

title: Hunters Upsetting Residents at Shore
description: LEAD: THOSE who buy a home or a getaway cottage along the beach gaze at Long Island Sound, enjoy cool breezes and dig clams in summer. By early fall, they have almost total privacy, but by late fall and winter, they can wake up to the gunshots of hunters less than a football field away.

title: JEAN-PAUL SARTRE, CAPITALIST
description: THE INTELLECTUAL ENTERPRISE Sartre and Les Temps Modernes. By Anna Boschetti. Translated by Richard C. McCleary. 279 pp. Evanston, Ill.: Northwestern University Press. Cloth, $42.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: LETTERS FROM THE ASHRAM
description: S. By John Updike. 279 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Musicians From Hofstra Spread the L.I. Word
description: LEAD: MUSICALLY, there may be not be a ''Long Island sound,'' but there are musicians and composers from Long Island. And this afternoon, in what the American Chamber Ensemble of Hofstra University considers a kind of informational, cultural exchange, both journey across the East River for an outing at Cami Hall in

title: Richard C. Adams; Inventor, 76
description: Richard Croxton Adams, who invented the paint roller 48 years ago, died Wednesday in La Mesa, Calif. He was 76 years old.

title: RED BRICK AND BROWNSTONE: A LITERARY TOUR OF GRAMERCY PARK
description: In 1831, a lawyer and real estate developer named Samuel Ruggles created the neighborhood of Gramercy Park. Ruggles was a major figure in Manhattan's cultural and physical development in the 19th century and when he mapped out the graceful Manhattan square and its surrounding streets, he hoped to create a bastion of civility and serenity that would calm the spirit after a day in the harsher world ''outside.'' To a remarkable extent this serenity endures, so that even today Gramercy Park resounds softly with what a former resident, Henry James, called, ''the incomparable tone of time.''

title: WHEN THE PUTTING GOES BAD
description: ON A BRIGHT WINTER DAY with the temperature stuck at around 40 and the ground still heavily patched with snow, Tom Watson stands in the center of a very empty Kansas City Country Club, lofting nine-iron shots at a practice green.

title: FACTS WITHIN FRAMES
description: GARRY WINOGRAND NEVER CARED for moderation. For him, to be a photographer was to see pictures everywhere, in everything. It was normal for him to shoot several rolls of film before lunch, or during lunch, every day. And he wasn't just behind in developing and editing his work, as all photographers are. ''It's hopeless,'' he would say, laughing, when asked about his backlog.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: Representative Dean A. Gallo, Republican of Parsippany, will be the sponsor of a second small-business export-opportunity conference to be held May 13 at the Holiday Inn in Livingston.

title: 52 Bald Eagles Counted, A 58 Percent Increase
description: CONSERVATIONISTS say they are encouraged by a recent survey that found 19 more bald eagles in the state.

title: Love and Murder Among the Chimps
description: EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS OF THE MOON Chimpanzee Society in the African Rain Forest. By Michael P. Ghiglieri. Maps and tables. 315 pp. New York: The Free Press. $22.50.

title: Woman Takes Post as Head Of Police Complaint Board
description: An official who has presided over nearly 300 Police Department disciplinary cases has taken office as head of the department's Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: About Men; The 7-Month Itch
description: AS A RULE OF thumb, a man has as many barbers in his lifetime as he has affairs. This includes one-cut visits as well as liaisons that go on for years. The similarities between the two relationships extend to the sensitive courtship, or tryout, period, the growing intimacy and fear of intimacy, the meetings that result in complete satisfaction and those that disappoint a little or a lot, and ultimately - and perhaps inevitably - the guilt at the end.

title: THE WEDDING
description: As a road representative for a large manufacturer of wedding gowns, I am in the bridal business. Norma Kamali, Mary McFadden, Carolina Herrera and Oscar de la Renta are all fine designers, but they are nothing more than part-timers in the bridal business. The mainstays in this business are the bridal-wear designers whose gowns cost between $500 and $600. Most women could never afford a Bill Blass mother-of-the-bride dress. The groom and male attendants rent tuxedos for about $70.

title: McFarlane's Plea
description: 'I believe strongly that throughout, my actions were motivated by what I believed was in the best foreign policy interests of the United States.'

title: Westchester Life
description: A Pennysaver by another name would attract more readers. So reasoned Stephen A. Traube, the 45-year-old president of The New Pennysaver Group Inc. in Elmsford, when he changed the name of 13 of his community Pennysavers to Westchester Life and began adding local news and syndicated editorial features to the weekly giveaway.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FLAMES. By June Oldham. (Virago/Random House, Paper, $6.95.) June Oldham charts the ups and downs of marriage between different social classes in her first novel for adults. As its heroine, Stella, prepares for her father's funeral, she sifts through her childhood memories, trying to make sense of her parents' failed marriage.

title: West European Rocket Puts 2 Satellites Into Orbit
description: The European Space Agency's Ariane 3 rocket, in a mission affirming its role as the West's only active commercial satellite launcher, lifted off Friday night and placed French and American communications satellites into orbit.

title: A CURSE ON WOODROW WILSON
description: ALICE ROOSEVELT LONGWORTH By Carol Felsenthal. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Mamaroneck, N.Y. $250,000 1203 Keeler Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 80-year-old Victorian; eat-in kitchen, family room, deck; taxes $2,200. Peekskill, N.Y. $312,500 22 Smith Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 95-year-old frame colonial; pool, guest cottage, playroom, 1.9 acre; taxes $7,582. White Plains, N.Y. $273,000 25 Coolidge Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 49-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, screened terrace; taxes $1,733. Danbury, Conn. $222,000 18 Westwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old raised ranch; screened porch, electric security system, 1.1 acres; taxes, $2,178. Glastonbury, Conn. $329,000 9 Hawthorne Mead 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; 2-car garage, gas water heater, wood lot, 1 acre; taxes not yet available. Portland, Conn. $185,000 107 William Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old raised ranch; hilltop setting, electric heat, 0.75 acre; taxes, $2,185. OTHER AREAS Mineola, L.I. $225,000 17 Wisteria Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old brick colonial; fireplace, family room, 1-car attached garage; taxes $2,600. Southold, L.I. $242,000 Sunset Lane 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; deck, private beach; taxes $1,400. Livingston, N.J. $162,500 10 Midway Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, dining room, full basement; taxes $2,186.

title: Focusing on Pro Hockey, and How It Oughta Be
description: Dave Anderson did himself proud with his open letter to the ceremonial leader of the National Hockey League. Watching the young United States team push the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia to the limit in brilliantly, cleanly played games was something to behold. All those newspaper critics who lamented the results lost sight of the bigger story: that Olympic hockey was hockey ''as it oughta be'' as opposed to the sickening goonery of the N.H.L.

title: DAVID HWANG: RIDING ON THE HYPHEN
description: IN THE ETHNIC COMMUNITIES that spawned them, artists who manage to cross over into the mainstream from Harlem or Watts or Chinatown east or west call the journey ''riding on the hyphen.'' Pop musicians like Mexican-American Ricardo Valenzuela, who as Ritchie Valens topped the charts in the 1950's with ''La Bamba,'' were among the first. Today's crossover stars include the black American film maker Spike Lee, whose vaguely anarchist dispatches from the city (''She's Gotta Have It'') and the campus (''School Daze'') are propelled by a savvy populist energy.

title: Melinda R. Jackson Marries
description: Melinda Roosevelt Jackson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Jackson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and a great-granddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, was married yesterday to Michael Philip Kessler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael Kessler of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Sharami Kerr performed the interfaith ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Book Row Is Gone, But Used Bookshops Aren't
description: In the 1950's, it took Paul A. Solano a week to stroll the six blocks from Union Square to Astor Place in Manhattan, a corridor of three dozen shops selling used books. Now, Mr. Solano, a bibliophile who started a used bookstore of his own in Morningside Heights, walks the same distance in just 10 minutes, a little more if he stops to reminisce.

title: Young, Irish and Illegal on L.I.
description: LEAD: PATRICK and Jeremy came to the United States a year and a half ago with intentions of breaking the law. Both are illegal aliens who live on Long Island.

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time; AT HOME WITH LASSIE AND HER ILK
description: They run daylong, the competitors from Jedburgh and Craigielands and Potburn and Mayshiels and threescore other Scottish map dots. Late and just now unlost - we nearly haven't come at all, what with the wee directions provided in the Edinburgh newspaper's notice of this event and then one of those travel-weary ''Should we or shouldn't we?'' colloquies about the uncertainties of aiming a rented car and our mortal selves down the left side of the road into the back lanes of the Pentland Hills - my wife, Carol, and I arrive as the entrant from Shoestanes Farm is gliding around the green course, a sleek speck in pursuit of four larger specks.

title:
GARDENING;
Gray Foliage for Contrast and Variety
description: LEAD: THERE is an increasing interest in using plants with gray foliage in flower gardens.

title:
GARDENING;
Gray Foliage for Contrast and Variety
description: LEAD: THERE is an increasing interest in using plants with gray foliage in flower gardens.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: The Mets shouldn't have any problems with their pitching staff. Doc should be in top form along with Bob Ojeda back in starting rotation. They have an excellent starting lineup in hitters. They shall win the East.

title: Next Week; How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Housing Concerns Land In Legislature's Court
description: LEAD: FINDING the housing problem has moved to its court, the General Assembly's Housing Select Committee is holding hearings on more than 30 proposals.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Pound Ridge
description: LEAD: PEOPLE settle in Pound Ridge, says Lucille D. Corda, a 22-year resident, because of its ''vistas and shrubbery and trees and winding country roads.'' It is, she says, ''truly God's country.''

title: POSTING: A Brooklyn Phoenix; Fort Greene Condominium
description: At 2:30 A.M. on Jan. 15, 1987, Leon Golomb saw a fire raging through the old Roanoke apartment house at 69 South Oxford Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. ''By the time I looked out the window, the flames were already roaring through the roof,'' said Mr. Golomb, who lives across the street in a brownstone. Three buildings abutting the stone-and-brick apartment house were either destroyed or damaged. ''Fortunately for us the wind was going in the other direction,'' he said. No one was hurt in the fire.

title: For a Few Thais, Their Home Is Their Castle
description: Bangkok, a city with no discernible zoning laws or limits to the imagination of developers, is about to take domestic architecture to new heights: the parapets of a castle.

title: Tracking Balmier Rates in the Rockies
description: AT ski areas throughout the West, the arrival of spring brings sun, shorter lift lines, a boisterous mood in the apres-ski lounge and, in most cases, discounted hotel and lift rates. Spring skiing can stretch into the summer at a few resorts, with slopes staying open into June. At others, mid-April signals the end of the season. In either case, the weather will determine just how long the trails remain skiiable.

title: THE NATION - Q. & A.: Brig. Gen. Myrna Hennrich Williamson; 'Committed, Mission-Oriented Team Players'
description: ARMY Brigadier General Myrna Hennrich Williamson is the services' senior female officer, outside the nurse corps whose officers traditionally are women. Commissioned in 1960, General Williamson has served as a company commander, commander of a military police training battalion, brigade commander and commanding general of the Third Reserve Officer Training Corps Region, with headquarters at Fort Riley, Kan. General Williamson, who is 51 years old, is now Deputy Director of Military Personnel on the Army staff in the Pentagon. She was interviewed by Richard Halloran, a military correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: Now When I Was Your Age...
description: DO you want to hit the boredom nerve of any child alive? Just remark how much tougher you had it when you were a kid.

title: China's Waters And Mountains Of Eternity
description: The river forms a green gauze belt, the mountains are like jade hairpins. - Han Yu, a Tang dynasty poet

title: AIDING ART AND CHILDREN
description: Time to Create

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE World Wrestling Federation, saying it was ''shocked and appalled,'' has suspended David Sammartino for an incident with a ringside fan following a match in Watertown, N.Y., last week. The federation said that Sammartino, son of Bruno Sammartino, assaulted Martin Gallagher, a 200-pound construction worker who heckled him after David lost his match at Watertown High School Wednesday. . . . Even though his team was eliminated from the Southeastern Conference tournament Friday night, Don DeVoe's contract as head coach of the University of Tennessee basketball team has been extended for two years, through the 1990-91 season. DeVoe's teams have a 185-125 record at Tennessee, including 16-12 this season, and have appeared in five National Collegiate Athletic Association tournaments and two National Invitation Tournaments. . . . Larry Farmer wasn't so fortunate. His Weber State team was eliminated from the Big Sky tournament Thursday and Farmer was dropped the next day as head coach after seasons of 7-22 and 9-21. Farmer is a former player and coach for U.C.L.A.(AP)

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: Mets: No, if the number of healthy pitchers does not exceed the number on the disabled list.

title: DR. KRIM'S CRUSADE
description: I am flattered that you considered my life's story worthy of attention (''Dr. Krim's Crusade,'' by George Johnson, Feb. 14). However, I worry about a conclusion to which the article may have led readers, namely that interferon research has been a disappointment to me and to others in the field.

title: Sports of The Times; Measuring How Far the Knicks Have Come
description: NOW that the Knicks are alive again, so are the scalpers on the sidewalks outside Madison Square Garden.

title: Record Notes; CD's Get Older, and Cheaper
description: Never in memory has the classical-record marketplace been as confusing as it is right now, thanks to the compact disk and the increasing competition engendered by an explosion in the number of plants capable of manufacturing them.

title: When a Building Owner Goes Too Far
description: ONE day in 1984, said Alice Carey, she walked into the lobby of 155 East 52d Street in Manhattan and overheard some ''some really tough-looking guys, like gangsters'' telling the doorman that the building had been sold and that that staff no longer had jobs.

title: Fray at Southampton P.T.A.
description: HOW to divide jurisdiction over children's education between the home and the school is in dispute in Southampton, where parents say they are being stifled by school officials and teachers say they are being assailed by overzealous parents.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Housing Tax Credits: A Limited Impact
description: LEAD: A FEDERAL program introduced 14 months ago aimed at producing rental dwellings for low-income families through housing tax credits has had a limited effect in New Jersey and in the nation.

title: Jackee Jacknowitz to Wed
description: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] of Plainview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jackee Ann Jacknowitz, to Tod Buckvar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Buckvar of Woodbury, L.I. Miss Jacknowitz is studying for a master's degree in elementary education at Adelphi University. Her fiance is president of Buck Realty, a commercial brokerage in Hicksville, L.I., and of Buckvar Development, a commercial land developer in Hicksville.

title: Correction
description: An article last week about air fares described British Airways' service between New York and London incompletely. The airline also offers nonrefundable APEX tickets, at a round-trip fare of $398 until April 2; from April 3 to May 31, the fare is $558 midweek and $608 on weekends. Tickets must be purchased 30 days in advance. A minimum stay of 7 days and a maximum of 21 are required.

title: Political Memo; Gore Fine-Tunes Hart Strategy of '84
description: In the Democratic race for President, the story line keeps changing as new characters keep pushing into the center of the action. The latest one to do so is Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee.

title: Ozark Lollygagging
description: A SMART VISITOR to London starts in scruffy Hackney or Wapping to better aprreciate Knightsbridge and Westminster. On the same theory, a traveler might start in Branson, Mo., or get a better perspective on the Ozark Mountains.

title: THE VOYEUR IN THE MIRROR
description: FRYE STREET & ENVIRONS The Collected Works of Marita Bonner. Edited By Joyce Flynn and Joyce Occomy Strictlin. 286 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $18.95.

title: Review/Dance; FERNANDO BUJONES IN ALL-SCANDINAVIAN PROGRAM
description: The Boston Ballet has packaged some well-known ingredients for this weekend with novel touches, and has succeeded in making the familiar look fresh and lively, even passionate.

title: A Focus on Homeless Children
description: LEAD: EVERY weekday, from 8:30 A.M. to 1 P.M., the ground floor of the Sharing Community in downtown Yonkers is the site of frenetic activity, as the Homeless Services Network operates a center for homeless children and their families.

title: South Africa's Economy Faces an Unsteady Future
description: ALONG the undulating highway that leads southwest from this city, a traveler passes through countryside made lush by summer rains. It is a place of farms and fruit stalls, but on the hillsides back from the road stand the sentinels of a harsher world - the towers of concrete and steel atop South Africa's richest gold field.

title:
MUSIC;
DEAD 50 YEARS, AND STILL A '10'
description: LEAD: ''Even if Ravel refuses the Legion of Honor, his music accepts it for him,'' wrote Erik Satie in a typically spiteful moment. Satie may have had his joke, but considering Maurice Ravel's popularity 50 years after his death, he has had the last laugh. Ravel, composer of ''La Valse,'' of ''Ma Mere l'Oye,'' of the ubiquitous (and, to some, the notorious) ''Bolero,'' died on Dec.

title: Correction
description: A review of self-help products last Sunday in Your Taxes, section 13, incorrectly listed the computers on which ''J. K. Lasser's Your Income Tax'' will operate. The software is available for personal computers made by the International Business Machines Corporation and compatible models.

title: Romare Bearden, Collagist and Painter, Dies at 75
description: Romare Bearden, a painter who artistically manipulated pieces of photographs and colored paper and became the nation's foremost collagist, died Saturday after suffering a stroke in New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in lower Manhattan and St. Martin.

title: Review/Architecture; THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM COMPETITION
description: The Brooklyn Museum is one of the great incomplete buildings of New York, the same symbol of unfulfilled dreams for its borough that the Cathedral of St. John the Divine is for Manhattan. The cathedral, of course, resumed building a few years ago, and recently the Brooklyn Museum announced the same intention - to complete its monumental structure within our time.

title: Arena Stampede Kills More Than 80 in Nepal
description: More than 80 people were killed and hundreds were injured today when soccer fans were trampled in a stampede to get out of a hailstorm, witnesses and hospital sources said.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE WOMAN OF THE PHARISEES, by Francois Mauriac. Translated by Gerard Hopkins. (Carrol & Graf, $8.95.) In this novel, Francois Mauriac, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1952, tells the story of Brigitte, who forces her religion on unwitting members of a Bordeaux community, sowing tragedy in their lives. Beside Mauriac, ''Gide seems artful and barren . . . Malraux harsh and narrow, Sartre ephemeral,'' Frederic Prokosch said here in 1946. Mauriac's ''style seems a little arid but . . . fulfills its function with precision, coolness, economy.'' CHURCHILL & ROOSEVELT: THE COMPLETE CORRESPONDENCE, edited by Warren F. Kimball. (Princeton University, 3 volumes boxed, $65.) By arranging, annotating and introducing the approximately 2,000 messages exchanged by Winston Churchill and Franklin Roosevelt, the Rutgers historian Warren F. Kimball shows that their relationship wasn't always as amiable as it seemed. ''The publication now of the complete correspondence does a great service in removing some of the gloss from the legends,'' Alistair Horne said here in 1984. ''Altogether the three vast volumes read like a skillful and compelling history of World War II - as indeed they are.'' ALEXANDER'S BRIDGE, by Willa Cather. (Meridian/ New American Library, $4.95.) Bartley Alexander, a renowned builder of bridges, is at the peak of his career -and in the midst of a marriage - when his first sweetheart, a beautiful Irish actress, re-enters the scene. When this first novel by a little-known author named Willa Cather was published in 1912, a reviewer in The Times recognized her special talent for ''catching and describing in terse, refined phrase the salient features of personality.'' The same publisher has gathered more of Cather's early work in a volume called WILLA CATHER: 24 Stories ($5.95). VISIONS AND NIGHTMARES: America After Reagan, by Robert Lekachman. (Collier/Macmillan, $9.95.) Even when President Reagan is long gone from the White House, free-market philosophy will reign, writes Robert Lekachman, predicting more privatization, militarization and dismantling of the welfare state. While our reviewer, Michael C. Janeway, said last year that the prose can be annoyingly polemical, ''when backed by fact and figure, [ the book is ] an intelligently passionate brief against the Reagan Administration.'' MARYA: A Life, by Joyce Carol Oates. (Berkley, $3.95.) A young woman tries to overcome a troubled childhood with the single-minded pursuit of academic perfection. In 1986, Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times that the novel is ''a fresh departure for Miss Oates -quieter, more controlled and realistic, and personal to the point of suggesting autobiography.'' HERE LIES: An Autobiography, by Eric Ambler. (Mysterious Press, $8.95.) Eric Ambler's autobiography begins like an Eric Ambler novel: with an ominous car accident and a bout with amnesia. While the rest of the book is written in a more conventional manner, it is ''far from . . . commonplace,'' The Times's John Gross said in 1986. ''Mr. Ambler turns out to write as well about domesticities as he does about exotic intrigue.'' THE INVISIBLE BAR: The Woman Lawyer in America, 1638 to the Present, by Karen Berger Morello. (Beacon, $10.95.) By the turn of the century, half of all lawyers in the United States may be women, the author writes, yet it wasn't until 1950 that Harvard Law School admitted female students. In 1986, Rita E. Hauser said here that the ''well-researched'' book is an ''important history.'' ''Many women attorneys were crusaders for the poor and needy. . . . They were among the earliest public interest lawyers the nation knew.'' OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/ New American Library, $4.95.) Alex Delaware, the psychologist hero of Jonathan Kellerman's previous two mysteries, receives a disturbing late-night call from a brilliant young patient he hasn't seen for five years. ''Mr. Kellerman is one of the ablest mystery writers to have emerged in recent years,'' John Gross said in The Times last year.
