'' 'Over the Edge' is as sleek and high-powered a performance as its predecessors.'' FARTHER AFIELD: A Gardener's Excursions, by Allen Lacy. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) Allen Lacy is a professor of philosophy who writes about gardening. When this second collection of essays was published last year, our reviewer, Susan Brownmiller, said Mr. Lacy is ''among that admirable elite who elevate the pleasant pastime of writing personally and with firm opinions about their private gardens into something that approaches literature.'' THE MACHIAVELLIANS: Defenders of Freedom, by James Burnham. (Regnery Gateway/Kampmann, $7.95.) The problem with democracy, James Burnham wrote, is that there is no such thing as majority rule; a powerful elite is, by necessity, always in control. In 1943, one reviewer said Mr. Burnham ''brings to the consideration of the eternal problem of power in society a mind like a surgeon's scalpel. . . . Timid readers may be shocked.'' FLESH AND BLOOD, by C. K. Williams. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $8.95.) When C. K. Williams's fifth collection of poems, each consisting of eight long lines, was published in 1987, our reviewer, Edward Hirsch, compared them to John Berryman's ''Dream Songs'' and Robert Lowell's ''Notebooks.'' ''Many of his poems present single extended moments intently observed: a girl with an artificial hand stepping onto the subway or a bum scribbling into a battered notebook in the public library. Others are like miniature short stories, sudden fictions.''

title: In Montreal, A New Electricity Is in the Air
description: Dance-theater is a term used lately to cover a multitude of sins, and it is one that has particular appeal to the burgeoning experimental dance scene in Montreal. In the late 1970's, West German choreographers called their work dance-theater -Pina Bausch made the label famous - and it became applicable thereafter to Japan's Butoh dance and to work, such as Maguy Marin's, that grew out of the French dance explosion. Like the dance boom in France, the ferment of dance creativity that now exists in Montreal is roughly 10 years old.

title: In This Year's Movies, Baby Knows Best
description: Men and women do not fall in love with each other in the movies anymore. They fall in love with babies. Babies are the new lovers - unpredictable, uncontrollable, impossible and irresistible.

title: He Challenges A Privileged Point of View
description: The only work in Dennis Adams's show at the Nature Morte Gallery (through March 27) is a wall piece called ''Falling Water.''

title: HIS DAYS AT BLACK ROCK
description: Despite the ubiquity of their work, most graphic designers tend to remain anonymous. DORFSMAN & CBS (American Showcase, $49.95) attempts to change all that. The authors, Dick Hess and Marion Muller, review the life and work of Lou Dorfsman, CBS Inc.'s vice president and creative director for advertising and design. Though relatively unknown outside the field, Mr. Dorfsman is something of a legend among design aficionados. Under the enlightened aegis of CBS executives, most notably Frank Stanton, president emeritus of CBS Inc., Mr. Dorfsman took a fledgling operation and made it look classy. Over a career that has spanned 40 years, his reach, mostly behind the scenes, extended to advertisements and annual reports to the now-famous CBS typefaces. Under his direction, everything the corporation touched took on a distinctive CBS look, from the wall clocks at Black Rock to the salt and pepper packets in the company cafeteria. Unfortunately, ''Dorfsman & CBS'' suffers from a testimonial-dinner tone. (Mr. Hess is a graphic designer, and Mrs. Muller, according to the jacket, is a ''longtime friend and occasional collaborator with Lou Dorfsman.'') Do we really need to know how wonderful Mr. Dorfsman's children are? Nevertheless, the authors tell us a lot about Mr. Dorfsman and help explain just what it is corporate designers do. Leafing through this abundantly illustrated book, one is struck by the fact that television nurtured one of print's most innovative graphic designers.

title: A Critic's Quandary: What's Authentic?
description: For the past few months I've been enjoying an album as exotically euphonious as the name of the Indonesian singer who made it: Idjah Hadidjah. ''Tonggeret'' (Nonesuch 79173 LP, cassette and CD) is a compilation of Ms. Hadidjah's recordings from 1979 to 1986. As a listener, I can bask in the way it sounds: the serene counterpoint that issues from resonant gongs, a fiddle-like instrument called a rebab, tinkling ''keyed metallophones'' and Ms. Hadidjah's gentle, firm, intricately controlled voice, which has a throaty quality I haven't heard in much Asian singing. Sometimes there's a salvo of drumming or a wry male voice answering Ms. Hadidjah, and I can nearly hum the recurring, almost catchy melodies, although they're in non-Western tunings. But as a critic, I'm in a quandary.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Beverly Hills Cop II Starring Eddie Murphy, Judge Reinhold, John Ashton, Ronny Cox. Directed by Tony Scott. 1987. Paramount Home Video. 102 minutes. $89.95. Rated R. Some violence, strong language.

title: What Goes Around Comes Around
description: ''Gone the way of the Hula-Hoop'' has become a vivid way of saying ''passe.'' Now the phrase itself may be that. Hula-Hoop sales topped two million last year and will exceed that this year. Hula-Hoops are back.

title: Mary Abele Plans to Wed Michael Makurat in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Abele of Baldwin and Southold, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Elizabeth Abele to Michael D. Makurat, the son of Mrs. Thomas M. Makurat of Harwich, Mass., and the late Mr. Makurat. The couple plan to be married April 30.

title: DATA BANK: March 13, 1988
Margaret Mary Peters To Wed Scott Nedrow
description: Mr and Mrs. William Henry Peters of Bay Head. N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Mary Peters to Scott Allen Nedrow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Nedrow of Donora, Pa. The wedding is to be in July.

title: ON A BIG SCALE
description: CIVILIZATION Directed by Thomas H. Ince. Video Yesteryear. 102 minutes. $29.95.

title: Safe Flying On the Ground
description: ONE way to deal with a fear of flying is to shrug it off, perhaps by wearing a Survive! T-shirt. This new line comes from United Stars of America, a division of J. G. Hook. The shirts, in eye-popping black, orange and white, are emblazoned with bold graphics inspired by the emergency-procedure diagrams in airplane seat pockets. One depicts a plane with its exit doors marked. The shirt at left shows an open parachute. Others depict figures lowering their heads to their knees in the crash position. The T-shirts are packaged in air-sickness bags carrying the Survive! logo. The oversize shirts are $18 at Macy's and at the Cockpit, 595 Broadway (between Houston and Prince Streets).

title: The Impropriety of Hugging a Mike
description: When you watch pop singers in a nightclub or on television, you usually see them hugging and kissing the microphone. Such passionate gestures toward the hardware are meant to underline the performer's capacity for emotional abandon, but they are not likely to produce good sound. In fact, the hand-held mike subjected to these dramatic antics is usually supplemented by another microphone, known as the body mike, sequestered in the singer's clothes to yield an acceptable sound balance - and the output of nearby stage microphones is also blended in.

title: Compromise Is Offered on Japan Nuclear Pact
description: To ease Congressional concerns over a nuclear agreement with Japan, the Reagan Administration has developed a plan to fly plutonium from Europe to Japan in a polar route that would not cross American and Canadian territory.

title: A New York Officer Is Seized On Assault in Massachusetts
description: A New York City police officer was arrested early yesterday at a Sharon, Mass., motel on assault charges, according to the New York police.

title: Jail Overcrowding Tests the Ingenuity of City and State
description: LAST month's uprising in New York City's Rikers Island jail complex, in which 550 inmates seized control of 12 dormitories for three and a half hours, sounded yet another warning about the dangers of jail and prison crowding. Yet at both the city and state levels, the government response so far has amounted to chronic crisis management.

title: Rare Material From Radio Comes to CD
description: All over Europe, state radio stations have been busily recording and, often, producing major concert and operatic performances for decades. There is a lively network of collectors of such materials, usually broken down by specialty (in other words, opera collectors live in a separate world from chamber-music collectors, and so forth). And such material is often worth collecting: most of the great musical artists of this century have been captured by radio tape recorders, often in spontaneous live situtations far removed from the clinical exactness of their studio recordings, and frequently in combinations never preserved in formal recording sessions.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: WEST TO EDEN by Gloria Goldreich. Macmillan Publishing Company. 418 pages. $18.95.

title: Parents Fight Tracking's End
description: LEAD: PARENTS and teachers in the Lawrence School District who have been fighting a plan to end tracking, the grouping of students by ability, have forced the postponement of the proposal. The school district will delay the planned elimination of tracking for sixth graders in September as it continues to discuss the idea.

title:
GARDENING;
Gray Foliage for Contrast and Variety
description: LEAD: THERE is an increasing interest in using plants with gray foliage in flower gardens.

title: Fishermen's Group Faces Loss of Dock
description: LEAD: THE Shinnecock area is the most productive fishing port in New York and, according to the Suffolk County Cooperative Extension, a major reason is the Shinnecock Fishermen's Cooperative. But that could change. The lease on the dock the group has used since it was formed in March 1985 expires tomorrow, and attempts to obtain another one have been unsuccessful.

title: Headliners; Account Unsettled
description: When 7-year-old Ronald DeSillers Jr. of Miami died last April in Pittsburgh while awaiting a fourth liver transplant, he had received about a half million dollars from sympathizers around the country, including President Reagan. The boy's mother, Maria DeSillers, created a foundation to help other children in need of transplants.

title: State Premiere for a Musical for Children
description: History will repeat itself next Sunday in Westport, when Heida Hermanns presides over the state premiere of ''Let's Build a Town,'' Paul Hindemith's musical play for children.

title: Keep Up the Fight on All-Terrain Vehicles
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark's Ark Is Coming Down
description: KEA'S ARK, the controversial hand-built vessel that stood in the parking lot of a Baptist church here and was envisioned as a land-based ark and urban museum, is slowly being dismantled.

title: Cast of 'Sarafina!' Evokes Their Lives In South Africa
description: None of them had ever seen her before. But they knew her face from old photgraphs on faded album jackets and her voice, of course, from worn, scratchy recordings.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Saving Trees
description: LEAD: Going on the theory that those who use the grounds at Lyndhurst should help preserve them, the Westchester Kennel Club is sponsoring a five-year ''Save the Trees'' program at the former Jay Gould estate in Tarrytown.

title: Costly Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Faulted on Latin Arms
description: Oscar Arias Sanchez, President of Costa Rica and winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for the regional peace plan that bears his name, has written a letter to Mikhail S. Gorbachev asking him to end the supply of Soviet arms to Central America.

title: Covering Panel Edges
description: MANUFACTURED wood paneling, particularly plywood and particle board, has revolutionized carpentry and woodworking. However, one drawback is inherent in working with these materials, and that is covering their edges. This is necessary both for a finished appearance and to protect the wood from moisture.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Selling Preactical Elightenment; EST Leaders Recharge the Batteries of a New Clientele
description: WHEN Woody Allen complained in the film ''Manhattan'' that his neurotic wife had left him to join EST, he could hardly have chosen a more evocative symbol for the self-help movement of the 1970's. Known for grueling sessions in which hundreds of people paid hundreds of dollars each to subject themselves to hour upon hour of verbal abuse, tedium and other means of ''personal transformation,'' EST became one of the most notorious - and least understood - examples of a loose-knit industry offering transcendence for sale.

title: Welcome the Children, Gay or Straight
description: AT a recent business lunch, one of the men spoke of his son coming home from college with a girlfriend. He thought he was prepared for that, but found he wasn't. Whereupon one of the women at lunch quipped, ''Just be glad he didn't come home with a boy.''

title:
TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time;
TREKKING IN SEARCH OF FIDDLEHEADS
description: LEAD: Last spring, in Vermont, having dinner at a friend's house, I was served a vegetable I'd never had before: fiddleheads - the young, unfurling fronds of a fern. I tried to compare them to things I knew - brussels sprouts, for instance. But the taste eluded me, and like anything elusive it intrigued me.

title: And Now, 640 Cases Of Disappointment
description: For the Bobcats of Oregon-Davis High School, and the fans who had backed them, it took less than two minutes yesterday to end - at least for this season - the dream of becoming an Indiana basketball legend.

title: A Palestinian University
description: To the Editor:

title: Connections to the Past, Ties to the Future
description: RECENTLY I went to the Museum of the Diaspora in Tel Aviv. I had been told that in addition to the exhibits and dioramas, it had a computer there that I would be able to use to get data about my family in Europe. That excited me. I would soon become a grandmother, and I imagined getting some kernel of information that I might be able to pass on to my grandchild.

title: Israel's Army Battles Arabs And an Image
description: The Israeli Defense Force, the citizen army that has seemed to many Israelis the finest expression of their nation's modern spirit, is facing a difficult and divisive battle as it struggles to suppress Palestinian protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Military Women: Increasingly Indispensable
description: THE role of women in the United States armed forces has expanded so swiftly over the last 15 years that today almost no duty but direct combat is closed to them. More than in any other nation, by far, a woman in an American uniform has an integral place in military service.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE LEFT COAST OF PARADISE: California and the American Heart. By Judith Moore. (Soho Press, $17.95.) Some six years ago Judith Moore left her husband and grown children in Washington State to start over as a writer in California - the place where ''you could be what you said you were.'' Now comes her first book, a curious, eclectic grab bag of sketches, interviews and reminiscences.

title:
INVESTING;
When Stockbrokers Try Too Hard
description: LEAD: THE small investor had rarely heard from his stockbroker, because he used his account mainly as a money market fund and for checking. Even during the 1982-87 bull market, when just about any idea might have turned to gold, the account executive called only when there was a problem, usually a bounced check.

title: New York Regents Investigate Board Member
description: The New York State Board of Regents has begun an investigation of a board member and a State Education Department employee who wrote a guidebook intended to help students pass a new Regents-required examination.

title: Musical Comedy It Ain't
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; 'In' Housing: Barn Homes, Brand New
description: CONVERTING an old barn into a home has been a fond fantasy, and for some people a realized dream, for decades. In Connecticut, where so many farms have been plowed under to make way for housing developments and shopping centers, barns are scarce, and, of course, they aren't being built any more. Or are they?

title: Speaking of Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD CASES MAKE GOOD STORIES
description: BAD ACTS AND GUILTY MINDS Conundrums of the Criminal Law. By Leo Katz. 343 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $14.95.

title: Jackson's Success Earns the Trust Of Many Who Once Feared Him
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's emergence as a major force in the Democratic Party is being greeted as an opportunity and a breakthrough by many of the same Democrats who a year ago were terrified by the idea.

title: U.S. Asserts Soviet Shifts Nuclear Subs to Europe
description: The Soviet Union has recently stopped sending Yankee nuclear missile submarines to patrol off the Atlantic coast of the United States, diverting them to European waters instead, according to the United States Director of Naval Intelligence.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: They don't need more pitching, they need better pitching. JIM STAGNO Massapequa, L.I.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: HONOLULU;
Ala Moana Gets Bigger
description: LEAD: EXTENSIVE renovations are under way at Ala Moana Center, a regional shopping center and major visitor attraction, in hopes of bolstering sales.

title: New Data Show Sharp Impact of Crash
description: STATISTICS compiled by Manhattan apartment brokers are beginning to reflect the fear and hesitation that all but the most affluent buyers felt after the stock market crash last October.

title: Vetting VCR's: Three That Stand Out
description: With more than 40 brands of video cassette recorders eager to catch the eye of American viewers, home video has become one of the most grossly oversupplied areas of consumer goods. Predictably, this abundance includes an ample share of ''me-too'' products. Many are clones masquerading under different corporate nameplates.

title: In Pressing Noriega, U.S. Is Playing a Risky Game
description: WHEN many of Panama's 60,000 retirees took to the streets last week after the banks here could not cash their pension checks, they expressed their contempt for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the country's military leader, with a sardonic variation on a slogan long heard throughout Latin America. ''Noriega go home! Noriega go home!'' they chanted.

title: Home Offices
description: To the Editor:

title: With an Election Over, Bangladesh Looks to the Next
description: No sooner did the Government party win an overwhelming victory in parliamentary elections earlier this month than talk began about dissolving the body and holding a new vote next fall.

title: 'PARKWAY FOLLIES' GETS TWO REVIEWS
description: Joel R. Jacobson's Feb. 21 article, ''The Parkway Follies, Starring Tom Kean,'' parallels the Governor's actions concerning the Hackensack Water Company's watershed land development in Bergen County.

title: Sexism: the Sequel
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie J. Glick Marries Dr. Michael Goldberg
description: Leslie Janice Glick, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Glick of Liberty, N.Y., and Dr. Michael Goldberg, the son of Rosalie Goldberg of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Max Goldberg, were married last evening. Rabbi David Gorelik officiated aboard the Empress, a yacht, at Pier 62 on the Hudson River at 23d Street.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: National Parks To Charge Fees In 16 Areas

title: Harbor Views at an Amiable Inn
description: NEAR the reception desk of Danfords Inn in Port Jefferson is a picture of George Washington. Under it, in a spidery 18th-century hand, is the message, ''I never slept here.'' George wouldn't lie. In spite of its Colonial look, Danfords Inn is a 1980's creation.

title: Court Backs Reagan on Funds
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the Reagan Administration's refusal to release $180 million in revenue-sharing funds that had been withheld two years ago under the deficit-reduction law.

title: Arafat on Peace
description: We asked Yasir Arafat whether the Palestine Liberation Organization was prepared to make peace with Israel. ''Yes,'' he said. ''Definitely.'' If there was an agreement, did he visualize a Palestinian state living in peace with Israel next door?

title: A Cozy Setting for French Cuisine
description: IN recent months, Fairfield County has been blessed with the opening of several fine restaurants. Now add L'Hotellerie des Bois (Little Hotel in the Woods) in West Redding to the growing list.

title: Currency Debasement It Was Then and Is Now
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORY OUT OF CHAOS
description: REVOLUTIONARY MEXICO The Coming and Process of the Mexican Revolution. By John Mason Hart. Illustrated. 478 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $35.

title: SAVING THE SOUND: THE STEPS TAKEN
description: While the Jan. 31 article ''A New Commitment to Save the Sound'' describes a recently initiated Assembly task force committed to working on cleaning up Long Island Sound, it did not mention efforts already taken by the State Legislature.

title: POSTING: 700 Jersey Acres; New Frontier
description: The empty tract on which the 150 to 200 homes of Deerfield will be built is outside the most established residential areas of New Jersey but centered among them. Bergen County is off to the north, Cherry Hill is well to the south, Princeton University is west and Asbury Park is east. The site, once farms and woodlands, is at the intersection of Middlesex, Mercer and Monmouth Counties and Monroe and Millstone townships. Even the road it is on, east-west Route 33, connects points in New Jersey, not New York City and Philadelphia.

title: Among Arabs in U.S., New Dreams
description: The pews are crowded these days in the Arab mosques and churches of Little Palestine here, and prominent local Palestinian-Americans have been meeting to talk about the rioting now entering its fourth month in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RADICAL CITIZENSHIP: The New American Activism. By David Bouchier. (Schocken, $19.95.) The abiding legacy of the 1960's is the existence of millions of Americans who still feel a loyalty to the values of social change articulated and fought for through the mass movements of that decade. Today, most of those people are invisible to one another - nurturing their ideals, but finding no political frame in which to channel their energies.

title: Reining In Longshore Union
description: AS A UNION with a reputation for muscle, the International Longshoremen's Union has had vigorous views not only on labor matters, but also on foreign affairs. Now it may be having second thoughts about ranging too far afield.

title: Eagles Are Helped by Their Foe, Man
description: Jack Swedberg, who can hold a young eagle to his chest as gently as if it were his grandchild, once said, ''To find eagles, you have to find people, then proceed in the opposite direction.''

title: Miss Gibson Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Gibson of New York and Bogota, Colombia, have announced the engagement of their daughter Alanna Christina Gibson to Timothy Edward Cronin, the son of Donald R. Cronin of Hillsdale and Bay Head, N.J., and the late Alice Fischer Cronin.

title: 2 Arrested in 21 Robberies
description: The arrest of two men is believed to have solved 21 bank robberies committed in the area in the last two months, the police say. Coincidentally, the two were arrested Thursday, although the police say the two carried out the robberies individually. Mark MacAdoo, 22 years old, was arrested in connection with 10 robberies in which the bandit escaped on a motorcycle with a total of about $6,000, the police said. Howard Bonner, 59, was arrested in connection with 11 robberies in which about $20,000 was taken, officers said.

title: Why Auto Rebates Don't Really Help
description: FOR several years now, American automobile manufacturers have been using sales incentive and rebate programs to increase the sales of selected models. The effect of these programs is so large that total consumer spending is substantially affected when the incentive programs end.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
PARIS LOOKS TOWARD FALL
description: LEAD: A return to a more graphic silhouette is expected this week when the influential Paris designers show their ready-to-wear collections for fall and winter. The umbrella description for these new clothes seems to be ''proportion,'' a word that also serves to shelter that troublesome issue of skirt length.

title: The Raiders Make It Harder to Compete
description: A leading Brazilian manufacturer recently offered me an outsider's perspective. ''Industrial strength depends on manufacturing strength,'' he said. ''But like past industrial giants that have faltered and fallen, you're losing the ability to make things.''

title: 'Something's Afoot' Spoofs Agatha Christie
description: SINCE the whodunits of Agatha Christie are a proven box office draw in small theaters, it follows that a fledgling company would dig up a musicalized mystery spoof that acknowledges its inspiration in a big second-act number with the lyric: ''I owe it all to Agatha Christie.''

title: Leicester Square
description: Every big town has, or should have, its place to meet - the place that everyone knows and that is accepted as the hub of focus of the city. In New York it's Times Square, or possible Rockefeller Center. In San Francisco, Union Square. In Florence, the Piazza della Signoria; in Venice, the Campanile in the Piazza San Marco. For anyone who is young in Paris - or for anyone who ever was young in Paris - it's ''Meet me at the fountain in Place St.-Michel.'' I can't seriously imagine anyone agreeing to meet at the Eiffel Tower, or in the Place de La Concorde. We'll leave out my own big town, Los Angeles; it's been described as a collection of suburbs in search of a city, and it has no center.

title: HOME FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: As a Vietnam veteran, I particularly related to Bill Keller's article ''Home From Afghanistan'' (Feb. 14). I saw the faces of the men in my platoon in paratrooper Aleksandr Simonov's face. He says, ''. . . every night, I dream of my fellow soldiers.'' I do the same thing, even after so many years.

title: WHAT'S THE MATTER WITH EDDIE?
description: PRISONER'S DILEMMA By Richard Powers. 348 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow. $19.95.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS: Brawley Case Options; Can the Prosecutor Pierce the Silence?
description: IT is not unusual for prosecutors to come across crime victims or eyewitnesses who are reluctant to get involved because they are afraid of retaliation or so shattered by their experience that they are unable to assist in an investigation. But few such instances are as intractable as the case of Tawana Brawley.

title:
DINING OUT;
First West Orange, Now Millburn
description: LEAD: ''Knock three times and ask for Sergio.''

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending Feb. 27 MANHATTAN Chelsea $335,000 322 West 22d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. duplex co-op; dining area, fireplace; maintenance $530, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Murray Hill $550,000 630 First Avenue (37th St.) (Manhattan Place) 2-bedroom, 3-bath, condo in a 3-year-old building; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area; common charge $560, taxes $200 (Broker: Thompson Realty) Upper East Side $625,000 605 Park Avenue (65th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, terrace; maintenance $1,728, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sotheby's International Realty) Upper West Side $400,000 895 West End Avenue (104th St.) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,550-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, maid's room; maintenance $740, 35% tax-deductible (Broker: Joan Schlank Real Estate) Upper West Side $555,000 355 Riverside Drive (106th St.) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,800-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, Hudson River view; maintenance $1,250, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Corcoran Group) BRONX Allerton $150,000 2717 Pearsall Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, brick house, dining room, finished basement, 1-car garage, 21- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $943 (Broker: Tryax Realty) Riverdale $130,000 4555 Henry Hudson Parkway (Briar Oaks) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area; maintenance $631, includes gas and electricity, 44% tax-deductible (Broker: Stephen Eldridge Realty) BROOKLYN Canarsie $150,900 1002 East 93d Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, frame house; dining room, large kitchen, 24- by 144-ft. lot; taxes $660 (Broker: Fogarty Real Estate) Flatlands $245,000 1005 East 38th Street 2-family, detached house; 6 bedrooms, 2 baths in primary duplex; 4 bedrooms, 1 bath in other; dining room, large kitchen in each; 2 bedroom, 1 bath courtesy suite in basement; 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $985 (Broker: Dwork & Korn) Park Slope $176,000 3259 6th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; dining area, large kitchen, original moldings; maintenance $300, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: F.J. Kazeroid Realty Group) QUEENS Forest Hills $255,000 110-11 Queens Boulevard (Kennedy House) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, terrace, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $989, 48% tax-deductible (Broker: M.J. Raynes) Jackson Heights $380,000 32-10 86th Street 3-family, semi-attached, brick house; 4 bedrooms in second floor unit; 3 bedrooms on first; 2 bedrooms in basement; 1 bath, dining room in each; 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,800 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) STATEN ISLAND Travis $170,000 60 Roswell Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached, frame ranch; large kitchen, full basement, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,146 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty) Willowbrook $190,000 404 Harold Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, Colonial; dining room, sun room, family room, 30- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate)

title: DEALING WITH GORBACHEV
description: SINCE COMING TO power three years ago as General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has captured the imagination of many in the West with a personal style that is refreshingly different from that of his predecessors. If we mistake a change in style of leadership for a change in Soviet international goals, Gorbachev may capture the rest of the West as well.

title: THE MIAMI AREA
description: To the Editor: Acknowledgements are in order for Jon Nordheimer, Michael Cannon and Bryan Miller for their upbeat reports on the Miami area.

title: Patricia O'Connor to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. O'Connor of Carmel, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Mary O'Connor, to Dr. Greenfield Sluder, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John C. Sluder of Armonk, N.Y. The future bride is an assistant professor of biological sciences at Wellesley College. Dr. Sluder is a staff scientist at the Worcester (Mass.) Foundation for Experimental Biology. They plan to marry in May.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: It Only Hurts When I Talk The unspeakable nature of concentration camps leaves Aharon Appelfeld's characters with a permanent distrust of speech. This conversation between two camp survivors is from ''The Immortal Bartfuss'' (Weidenfeld & Nicolson). ''Will you let me say something personal?'' ''I'm listening.''

title: Legislators Weigh Insurance Pool
description: LEAD: THE county's local governments would be able to form an insurance pool for their employees' health coverage under a proposal that has been sent to the Board of Legislators.

title: Adelphi Celebrates St. Denis Legacy
description: LEAD: IN 1961, Ruth St. Denis, the woman who had helped transform modern dance into an international art and established at Adelphi University the first independent dance department at an American liberal arts university, returned to the campus at the age of 84.

title: BEST SELLERS: MARCH 13, 1988
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 19 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 2 2 38 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 3 3 16 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates havoc. 4 9 15 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga. 5 8 33 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 6 5 21 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 7 * 11 4 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 11 1 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrageur's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 12 12 7 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) The death of a distinguished biologist leads to discoveries about medical science's mysteries. 13 14 11 WINTER, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $19.95.) Blackford Oakes in charge of a secret operation involving Fidel Castro. 15 1 THE PALACE, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 2 6 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 3 3 5 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society recalled by a woman who married into it. 4 4 18 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 5 5 44 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 6 6 4 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 7 12 2 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 8 10 8 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 9 * 7 16 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 10 11 33 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 11 14 3 DONNIE BRASCO, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (New American Library, $18.95.) A former F.B.I. agent tells of his five years posing as a mobster to discover Mafia secrets. 12 9 33 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.)
