The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 2 2 36 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 3 4 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK AND EASY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library, $17.95.) Dishes that can be prepared in less than an hour. 4 4 131 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 16 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE YELLOW WIND, by David Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.95.) The painful, disturbing record of seven weeks spent interviewing in the West Bank by a young Israeli novelist, who found the Palestinians he talked to dreaming only of return, totally unreconciled to coexistence with Israel. BLOOD AND WATER: And Other Tales, by Patrick McGrath. (Poseidon, $15.95.) Thirteen Gothic tales, set in England, New York and elsewhere, told in a rich, soupy, ornate, deliberately literary style that recalls a gentler, more easily scared era. FREE RADICAL: Albert Szent-Gyorgyi and the Battle Over Vitamin C, by Ralph W. Moss. (Paragon House, $22.95.) The life of the bumptious, iconoclastic, self-promoting Hungarian Nobel laureate, told with sympathy but not with credulity. STRANGER IN THE FOREST: On Foot Across Borneo, by Eric Hansen. (Yolla Bolly/Houghton Mifflin, $17.95.) Improbable places still exist, giving room for improbable acts; this account by an invincibly innocent American nomad has plenty of both. SAFETY PATROL, by Michael Martone. (Johns Hopkins University, $14.95.) An honest, intelligent collection of short stories about introspective loners, full of good craftsmanship. JUST ANOTHER KID, by Torey L. Hayden. (Putnam, $17.95.) This animated case history records a year in the life of a teacher of disturbed children; it argues by example that sensitivity, good will and hard work can still make a difference. THE IMMORTAL BARTFUSS, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) An extraordinary adventure in character portrayal by the distinguished Israeli novelist; Bartfuss, a Holocaust survivor, is an awesomely interior figure, alienated from the universe; his slightest acts are seen as feats of heroism.

title: Shift of AIDS Center Forced in Queens
description: Neighborhood opposition is forcing the only center in Queens for people with AIDS to move its counseling services, and the uproar has led to a discrimination complaint against two neighborhood groups and an assemblyman.

title: Yonkers Group Finds Taiwan Encouraging On Subway Bid
description: A DELEGATION of Yonkers officials learned quickly when they got to Taiwan this month why the capital, Taipei, needed a subway system. They found the burgeoning city of 2.5 million suffering from severe traffic congestion.

title: Elderly Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time; AMAZEMENT UNDER THE MIDNIGHT SUN
description: I am not often in exactly the right place at the right time, unless you consider it lucky to be near Cape Hatteras during a hurricane or on the subway when there's a derailment. But sometimes I believe that I have only myself to blame for certain travel mishaps. After all, I did pack a flashlight for Fairbanks during the summer solstice, and I didn't pack any mosquito repellent.

title: Elizabeth Noone to Wed S. T. Merrick
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Michael F. Noone Jr. of Alexandria, Va., of the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Noone to Samuel Thompson Merrick, a son of Mrs. Charles Nelson Gregg Jr. of McLean, Va., and Dr. John Vaughan Merrick 4th of Puyallup, Wash.

title: WONK MEETS SNOB
description: ARTS AND SCIENCES A Seventies Seduction. By Thomas Mallon. 210 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: Issues Muted In Three Races For Assembly
description: ABOUT 150,000 Long Islanders are eligible to vote in three Assembly contests Tuesday, an unusually busy special election.

title: Breast Cancer Rate: Puzzle for L.I.
description: LEAD: CONSISTENTLY high incidence and mortality rates for breast cancer on Long Island are continuing to puzzle Nassau and Suffolk County health officials. They hope that a major study conducted between 1984 and 1986 will reveal new clues about why the disease is so prevalent in the region.

title: Deborah V. Davis, Medical Student, To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton M. Davis of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah V. Davis to Thomas Eliot Ascheim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Ascheim of New York and Old Chatham, N.Y. A June wedding is planned. Miss Davis, who graduated from the Brearley School and cum laude from Wellesley College, is a second-year medical student at New York University. Her father, an architect, is president of Dayton Metal Products in the Bronx. Her mother, Joanne Victorsohn Davis, is a calligrapher and a partner in Programme Associates, planners of corporate events.

title: OH MY CRACKING PISTONS!
description: Funny, isn't it, that only dumb people who get smart are news. People who were smart all along are not news.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''People are getting back to breakeven, and they say, 'Get me out.' This is a humongous resistance level.''

title: Practical Traveler; Getting to the Airport
description: WHEN friends came home from Greece, they had made no plans for getting out of Kennedy International Airport and traveling home to the suburbs in Bergen County, N.J. They piled into a metered medallion cab and across New York City they went, over two bridges and home to the tune of $100, including the tip.

title: Don't Underestimate Bush
description: LEAD: The idea seems to be emerging that the Democrats should rejoice that the ''beatable'' Republican candidate, George Bush, buried Bob Dole in the South. As vulnerable as Mr. Bush may appear, however, the question remains whether any Democratic survivor of Super Tuesday can defeat him.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Cigarette Gambit Backfires

title: Police Rescue Woman, Held In Trunk of a Car for 3 Days
description: A 73-year-old woman was found alive in the trunk of her car today, after being locked in it for three days, according to the state police.

title: D. K. Shuffman Plans To Wed Linda Blough
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Blough of Lafayette Hill, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter Linda Jill Blough to David Kenneth Shuffman, the son of Rose Shuffman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Oscar Shuffman. The couple plan to marry April 17.

title: Battling to Save Maine's Wild Lands
description: At the age of 71, James T. Bryan is waging a private battle to protect a pristine lake in northeastern Maine from those who would strip the forest of treesand build houses along the shore.

title: Far From the Shopping Malls, Farm Life Is the Good Life
description: REBECCA GRAY once won a prize for an essay she wrote about her favorite thing to do: working on her family's farm.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: WHEN she saunters down the runway, showing off the new collections of such designers as Geoffrey Beene, Adolfo, Oscar de la Renta and Carolina Herrera, Liz Lee Fabiaschi looks as if she hasn't had a decent meal in several months. In fact, according to most people's definition of a decent meal, she probably hasn't. Ms. Lee is a careful and disciplined eater. Most of the time.

title: Sacred And Ancestral Ground
description: LEAD: THERE IS GREAT GOOD IN RETURNING TO A landscape that has had extraordinary meaning in one's life. It happens that we return to such places in our minds irrestibly. There are certain villages and towns, mountains and plains that, having seen them, lived in them, even for a day, we keep forevcer in the mind's eye.

title: Shawn Lester Plans to Wed Stephen Carl Swett in June
description: The engagement of Shawn Avery Lester to Stephen Carl Swett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Swett of Summit, N.J., has been announced by Miss Lester's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan A. Lester of Avon, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: A Strong Comeback From the Brink of Bankruptcy
description: ''THE best is yet to come,'' the voice on the television intones solemnly, as the prime time commercials on Nashville's stations focus on the likenesses of W. E. B. DuBois and Roland Hayes that gaze solemnly over the reading rooms of Fisk University's library.

title: The Ride May Be Over For Carousel in Baldwin
description: LEAD: FOR almost 50 years, Nunley's Carousel on Sunrise Highway in Baldwin has been the place to take the children for a merry-go-round ride on the colorful wooden horses that rise and fall on brass rods to the music of a military band organ. But now the four-acre property has a buyer who plans to demolish the carousel building and rezone some of the land behind the building for commercial purposes.

title: Aliens on the East End
description: RICHARD BERRYMAN, chief legalization officer for the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Long Island branch office, realizes there is a problem. Not more than 12 people from the whole South Fork of Long Island have applied for amnesty since last May 5, when the new law went into effect. But any tourist visiting a Montauk restaurant or seaside hotel knows there are large number of foreign nationals working on the East End.

title: Why Fast Food Has Slowed Down
description: BURGER, chicken or pizza? Eat at the restaurant or take it home? Drive to get it, or have it delivered? Decisions, decisions. They may be insignificant for consumers, but they are make-or-break ones for the nearly 130,000 fast-food outlets that dot the country. The recent top-management shakeup at the Pillsbury Company put the spotlight on troubles at its Burger King subsidiary, but if misery likes company, then Burger King must be a happy place: For all the purveyors of fast food, with the exception of giant McDonald's Corporation and tiny White Castle Systems Inc., are crashing into the law of supply and demand. Simply stated, there are just too many fast-food outlets around. It is not that Americans have soured on fast food. In fact, they spent $55.7 billion on it last year alone. But after double-digit sales growth into the early 1980's, the pace has slowed. The market has become oversaturated at a time when food and labor costs are rising. And, despite all of the advertising aimed at differentiating products, customers - at least those who are not diehard McDonald's or White Castle loyalists - do not seem to care which ones they go to. ''Nowadays, a driver won't even make a U-turn to go to a different fast-food outlet,'' said Malcolm M. Knapp, who owns a market research firm in New York that specializes in the food-service industry.

title: Special for Spring
description: LAST call to complete and mail nursery/seed catalogue orders; some sources have run out of stock of first choices and substitutions are being made, when requested. Continue transplanting indoor seedlings of vegetables and annuals to individual pots. Check house plants for mealybugs, aphids and white flies; control, if found. Start using water-soluble fertilizers on house plants as the growing season is renewing with longer daylight hours. Crocus

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: In the Right Place at the Right Time; WHERE A MONSTER LEARNED MANNERS
description: When monsters stop eating people there is cause for festivity.

title: Cuomo's Plan For Fiber Cable
description: GOVERNOR Cuomo had a vision in January 1986: ''a revolutionary fiber-optic telecommunications cable'' along the entire 559-mile Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Such a cable carries messages on beams of laser light at tremendous speed, and the Governor said it would ''dramatically improve the state's communications'' and ''attract high-tech industry and jobs to New York.''

title: Homeless Find Humanity at Private Shelters
description: At nearly 10 P.M., the bell finally rang and 10 neatly dressed homeless men stepped off a city bus and in the side door of the B'nai Jeshurun Synagogue on West 89th Street for a home-style meal and a bed for the night.

title: TIPS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: A Walk in the City; BOMBAY'S TAWDRY, BEJEWELED STRAND
description: The scent of salt spray, spices, sewage and humanity along Marine Drive in Bombay captures everything pestilential and magnificent about India's busiest city. At night, the Drive comes to life with a string of lights known as the Queen's Necklace - magical, lively, yet somehow serene.

title: Bid for a Bear
description: IN a move rarely seen in the National Football League these days, the Washington Redskins have made a five-year, $6 million offer to Wilber Marshall, the linebacker for the Chicago Bears who became a free agent when his contract expired Feb. 1. Now the Bears must decide whether they will match the offer or let Marshall move on.

title: Q&A
description: Phantom Tours Question:Having seen ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' and currently planning a trip to Paris, I wonder whether it is possible to take backstage tours of the Paris Opera House. - W. H. B., New York, N.Y. Answer:Backstage tours are available twice a month, but arranging one with an English-speaking guide requires making an appointment a month in advance. The regular tours are held on the first and third Tuesday each month. Participants assemble at the Opera's main entrance at 1 P.M. The visits, led by professional guides, are organized by Les Monuments Historiques de Paris (telephone, 48.87.24.14), an agency of the Ministry of Culture. They cost $8 a person, last about an hour and a half and generally take in the attic, the caves and the small underground lake across which, in the story, the Phantom lures the singer Christine to his secret lair. Visitors wanting a backstage tour with an English-speaking guide must call the monuments office to schedule a visit. These tours cost a total of $92 for any number of people up to 30.

title: 'Something's Afoot' Musical in Fairfield
description: SINCE the whodunits of Agatha Christie are a proven box office draw in small theaters, it follows that a fledgling company would dig up a musicalized mystery spoof that acknowledges its inspiration in a big second-act number with the lyric: ''I owe it all to Agatha Christie.''

title: Correction
description: A report last Sunday about the engagement of Nancy C. Wallace to Fred Allen Cooper referred incorrectly to Miss Wallace's parents. They are Leveritt A. Wallace of

title: A STERLING GALLERY OF SLEUTHS
description: The return this week of ''Rumpole of the Bailey,'' cheery news in itself, is a reminder that ''Mystery!,'' the popular public-television series that first brought us Horace Rumpole in February 1980, is now in its ninth season. Between Rumpole and Rumpole, we have met 13 other sleuths, including such addictions as Lord Peter Wimsey, Miss Marple, Chief Inspector Dalgliesh and, of course, Sherlock Holmes. Mobil Corporation has lately announced that it is continuing its support for ''Mystery!'' (as well as ''Masterpiece Theater'') through 1993.

title: Bernard Rudofsky, 82, Architect And 'Outspoken' Social Analyst
description: Bernard Rudofsky, the provocative architect and social commentator whose books and museum exhibitions influenced not only his profession but fashion, interior design, urban planning and food, died of cancer yesterday at New York University Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: An Unwanted Child Grows Up, And Now Everyone Loves It
description: We will hear about The Road to Kansas City until we have memorized every turn. Late this afternoon, the selection and seeding of the 64 teams for the 50th National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, a process that once consisted of a few telephone calls, will again be presented live on network television. The information will be placed in brackets to be instantly and passionately analyzed. The brackets will be used to help produce America's stamp of significance, the office pool.

title: Lotus 1-2-3 Faces Up to the Upstarts
description: AFTER years of unquestioned dominance in the PC arena, Lotus 1-2-3 is suddenly facing serious challenges from a host of new spreadsheets. The upstarts are faster, prettier and better suited for today's more powerful computers. To counter, Lotus is putting the finishing touches on a couple of new versions of 1-2-3, its first major overhaul in a long time.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: DO THE METS AND YANKS NEED MORE PITCHING?
description: What the Yanks' pitching needs is the Mets' pitching staff. What the Mets' pitchers need are the Yankee hitters. TONY MARSHALL New York

title: A Grandmother's Gift of Selfless Love
description: THE swollen veins in her fingers rose even more as she tightened her grip on the pen. I sat across from her at the kitchen table. I watched her, felt her silence.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE VIXEN. By Mao Dun. (Panda Books/China Books & Periodicals, Paper, $6.95.) When the great satirist Lu Xun died in 1936, Mao Dun stepped into his shoes as the leading figure among left-wing Chinese writers. But he never quite achieved the status of his mentor, chiefly because his output as a writer lacked the biting power of Lu Xun's work, which had delighted readers with its thinly veiled assaults on a corrupt society.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: Paul Delaney's article ''Aboard the Andalusian Express'' (Travel, Jan. 17) painted a wonderful picture of Spanish rail life. While I found Spain fascinating, my bizarre encounter last July on a night train traveling from Barcelona to Madrid fits much better under Isabel Soto's accompanying ''Note of Caution.''

title: Counseling to Ease Grief of Pet Loss
description: THE death of a pet can be tantamount to the death of a family member, but owners are often surprised when they ''overreact'' to the pet's death, according to Patricia Gallagher of Stamford, a counselor.

title: River Vigil Ends as Ice Breaks Up
description: SPRING, as measured in the town of Kent, is here. It arrived at 7:34 P.M. last Monday, when the thick mantle of ice covering the Housatonic River broke.

title:
GARDENING;
An Update on New Herbs to Grow
description: LEAD: RESPONDING to the gardener's renewed interest in herbs, commercial growers and seed producers are discovering new varieties and rediscovering old ones. This year, for example, three new varieties of basil are taking a bow.

title: Towns Scrambling To Acquire Open Space
description: LEAD: FACED with surging development, spiraling real estate values and shrinking Federal dollars for land conservation, towns throughout Connecticut have begun to spend unprecedented amounts of their own money to purchase open space.

title: 'PARKWAY FOLLIES' GETS TWO REVIEWS
description: My recent position on the Garden State Parkway toll increase has apparently provided for Joel Jacobson a golden opportunity to vent his spleen.

title: F.A.A. Criticized on Aircraft Noise
description: ALTHOUGH Federal aviation officials say that new routes for aircraft using Newark International Airport will not mean more noise for people below the flight paths, lawmakers from northern New Jersey vow to fight the changes anyway.

title: Dr. Wright Weds A Sales Engineer
description: Dr. Elizabeth McRae Wright and Timothy Michael Hazel were married yesterday at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Arthur F. McNulty performed the ceremony.

title: Stacy B. Weiss Is Wed To Ronald Scheinberg
description: The marriage of Stacy Beth Weiss, the senior manager of the education department at Sotheby's in New York, to Ronald Scheinberg, an associate at the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, took place last night at the Harvard Club in New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein performed the ceremony.

title: Too Tall Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Film; For Elisabeth Welch, Life Is a Dark Cafe
description: ''Keeping Love Alive'' is a high-spirited, graceful performance by -and a suitably unfancified hommage to - Elisabeth Welch, the great American star of cabaret and musical comedy who, like Josephine Baker, Mabel Mercer and Ada (Bricktop) Smith, had to be recognized abroad to be recognized at home.

title: THE WEDDING
description: Your ''traditional celebration with modern twists'' accurately reflects the tastes of the 1988 bride. Whether lavish or simple, the trend is toward a traditional wedding. Thank you for the refreshing and informative piece. M.TRACEY WARE Bridal Consultant Laura Ashley Inc. New York, N.Y.

title: Syracuse Rallies Into Final
description: Rony Seikaly was in another world, Derrick Coleman was in a funk and Seton Hall was on the verge of chasing Syracuse out of Madison Square Garden and the Big East Conference Tournament.

title: A Furnished Time Machine
description: SUMMER may be fine for visiting drafty British country houses and walking the length and breadth of their gardens. But during the perennial spring drizzle, one seeks the cozier atmosphere of drawing rooms in town. Also, in only visiting stately aristocratic homes, one neglects the equally rich heritage of the frequently more stylish rooms of merchants' houses.

title: Lieutenant Myers Becomes a Bride
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Amherst, Mass., Second Lieut. Susan Annabel Myers, U.S.A.F., a satellite-operations officer at the Consolidated Space Operations Center at Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, was married yesterday to G. Victor Treyz, a doctoral candidate in solid-state science and engineering at Columbia University. The Rev. James H. Clark performed the ceremony.

title: Colorado's Late Skiers Get a Touch of the Sun
description: APRIL in Colorado is indeed the cruelest month, dumping snow on lilacs at altitudes as low as 5,000 feet, sometimes burying the entire bush higher up. This seeming endlessness of high-country winter is hard on would-be gardeners and tennis players, but not so hard on skiers, who may still enjoy the lingering snow, as well as April's longer days and higher temperatures.

title: THE WEDDING
description: That was quite a Valentine's Day message you sent to women in your ''created scenario'' of a ''modern'' wedding (''The Wedding,'' Feb. 14).

title: Focusing on Pro Hockey, and How It Oughta Be
description: Dave Anderson's open letter to John Ziegler, president of the National Hockey League (''Hockey the Way It Oughta Be,'' The New York Times, Feb. 26), focuses on a need of long standing: attention to the utter lack of management and guts in the N.H.L. to keep a premier sport from losing its tradition, its skills and its wonder to those who watch.

title: A Bridge To Elderly In Nursing Homes
description: LEAD: RITA ABOULASIA of New Rochelle has worked for almost four years as an ombudsman at the United Home for Hebrew Aged there. One of 38 ombudsmen in the county who work at 29 different facilities, Mrs. Aboulasia said of her volunteer work:

title: Oklahoma Tops Missouri To Gain Final
description: Stacy King converted a 3-point play in the closing seconds and finished with 35 points today as Oklahoma turned back a furious Missouri rally for a 102-99 victory in a semifinal game of the Big Eight tournament. The Sooners (29-3) moved into the final on Sunday against Kansas State.

title: Designer With an Affinity for the Past
description: The first academy award for costume design was given, in 1948, to Dorothy Jeakins for ''Joan of Arc.'' If years are locomotives, then 1948 is 40 stations down a twisted track, a world that only exists in memory and old snapshots. But there are survivors. ''Joan of Arc'' was her first screen credit as a costume designer. Forty years later, at the age of 74, Ms. Jeakins has been nominated for ''The Dead,'' John Huston's last movie.

title: Baby Thrown Out Window; Mother Is Held
description: A woman alledgedly hurled her weeping 2-month-old son from a third-floor window in the Bronx yesterday, but the baby's fall was broken by an overhang above the entrance to the building, the police said.

title: Out on the 4-x-4 Frontier
description: FEW would quibble with the notion that Jeep wrote the book on four-wheel drive, and the company, now owned by Chrysler, goes merrily on its way with the latest plaudits from 4-Wheel & Off-Road magazine, which has voted Jeep its 4-x-4 of the year.

title: MERELY DISTINGUISHED, NEVER GREAT
description: PERFECT PITCH A Life Story. By Nicolas Slonimsky. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95.

title: Review/Concert; MUSICIANS COME IN FROM THE COLD WAR
description: The host cedes to his guests; thus the Making Music Together festival began tonight with Soviet music for American audiences. It will continue this way for the next three weeks as a visiting contingent of 285 musicians, dancers, composers, singers, poets and critics mingle with their American counterparts in a cultural exchange being transacted all over this city. The roles are to be reversed when the event moves to the Soviet Union next year.

title: Museums Add Touch of Fun To Learning
description: ON a recent Saturday, dozens of children crowded inside a barn at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center to watch five day-old lambs nestle by their mother's side.

title: Swedish Silver: Sophisticated Simplicity
description: Shimmering Swedish silver masterpieces -powerful forms embellished sparingly with boldly crafted flourishes - fill two galleries at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street. The 81 tankards, tureens, platters and coffee pots selected for ''The Triumph of Simplicity: 350 Years of Swedish Silver'' are from the collections of the Nationalmuseum in Stockholm and the Swedish royal family. They demonstrate how deep are the roots of today's starkly robust Swedish style - commonly seen in such designs as vacuum cleaners and crystal vases. The exhibition remains through June 5.

title: REAGAN'S BUREAUCRATS
description: I wish to take exception to the notion that Reagan political appointees have been exhibiting a disdain for Government service (''Reagan's Disappearing Bureaucrats,'' by Phillip Longman, Feb. 14).

title: Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing in Colombia
description: Bombs exploded outside the opposition newspaper El Colombiano Thursday night, killing a man in the street and slightly wounding 10 others. The newspaper's director, Juan Gomez Martinez, is a candidate for mayor of Medellin, the country's second biggest city, in municipal elections next Sunday. Five months ago, he was the target of a kidnapping attempt by drug traffickers fighting possible extradition to the United States for trial on drug charges.

title: Kathanne Wray, A Banker, Weds R.E. Fowler 3d
description: Kathanne Elizabeth Wray, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robert Wray of Greenfield and North Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Edward Fowler 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fowler Jr. of Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Franklin Darling performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Greenfield.

title: GETTING AWAY FROM DADDY
description: THE RIGHT THING TO DO By Josephine Gattuso Hendin. 211 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $16.95.

title: The Columbia Literary History
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday Observer; Farewell, Friend . . .
description: WHEN I TOLD the Editor I just had to get rid of the Sunday Observer, he wept. Blotting his tears, I was touched until he said, ''Look, the market's collapsed, I'm under pressure to cut the budget, so there's no way I can raise you more than $2.25 a week.''

title: Ah, Spring. Ah, Balloons. Bang!
description: Acquiring the helium balloon, a delightful rite of spring, also holds the potential for childhood tragedy. Not that parents don't try to avert disaster. No sooner is a balloon obtained than the lecture begins: ''Now, I'm tying this to your wrist so that you won't lose it. Remember, if you take it off, it will go up in the air. I can't get it back. And hold it down low. If it hits a tree or anything sharp, it will pop. And we won't be able to get another one.''

title: INSIDE
description: Meeting on South Africa

title: RANGERS' GRIP CAN'T BE BROKEN
description: The Rangers, who are locked in a prolonged struggle for the playoffs, spent the final minutes of the game tonight fighting for oxygen. As they sat in the satisfied silence of the locker room, their chests gradually stopped heaving.

title: Agency Selects Chairman
description: The Rev. Thomas F. Pike, rector of Calvary and St. George's Episcopal Church in Manhattan, has been elected chairman of the Partnership for the Homeless, a private group that operates a network of shelters in churches and synagogues throughout New York City. The partnership also elected as vice chairman Leonard Harris, recently retired director of corporate relations for The New York Times Company.

title: NONFICTION
description: FORTY-EIGHT MINUTES: A Night in the Life of the NBA. By Bob Ryan and Terry Pluto. (Macmillan, $16.95.) So much happens in even five minutes of a professional basketball game. The clock ticks while players execute complex moves planned during a hurried timeout. Arms and legs move nonstop on the hardwood court. Steals, fakes, whistles and slam dunks. It goes so fast that you can never see everything. To capture all the drama of one 48-minute basketball game, the sportswriters Bob Ryan and Terry Pluto break down, play by play, the Jan. 16, 1987, duel between the Boston Celtics and the Cleveland Cavaliers. The Cavaliers, a rebuilding team led by rookies, had come to Boston after losing seven of their last eight games, while the then world champion Celtics had won 53 of their last 54 games at home. Another Boston Garden sellout crowd expected an easy Celtics victory. Instead, the fans got a thriller. Beyond the plays and calls, Mr. Ryan and Mr. Pluto explain both teams' roles in the history of the National Basketball Association and explore the coaching and business sides of the sport. They reveal through excellent interviews the thoughts and feelings of the players. There is also a worthwhile discussion of whether the Celtics organization deserves the reputation it has among some people for having ''pandered to the bigots who happened to be basketball fans'' by acquiring so many white players in a predominantly black league. ''Forty-eight Minutes'' is like an exciting game - but it's more thought-provoking.

title: Islanders Waste A Shot At First
description: The Islanders, adrift in pre-playoff limbo and unable to play well enough to escape third place, have a harsh opinion of themselves.

title: Ben Yehuda Street
description: THE LAST TIME I WAS IN JERUSALEM, white-hot midsummer, a poet friend suggested that I meet her at a cafe on Ben Yehuda Street. I was astonished. There are a few leafy garden spots to which visitors tend to be taken again and again by their eager hosts - I usually pretend, out of politeness, that I haven't been to any of them yet, so that my current hosts can surprise me. I'd have expected her to name such a graden oasis, not the tourist-clogged and teeming Ben Yehuda. ''Oh,'' she reassured me, ''there are a couple of cafes right in the middle of it all where everybody goes. The writers and artists sit in one, the politicians and jounalists sit in another. We notice each other, but we don't pay any attention to the tourists.'' Give the eyeball-to-eyeball intensity of Israeli conversation, that wasn't hard to believe.

title: Miss Trowbridge to Wed Peter Parent
description: The engagement of Kimberly Trowbridge to Peter Arthur Parent, a vice president of Lazard Freres & Company in New York, has been announced by Nancey H. Trowbridge of Southport, Conn., and Alexander B. Trowbridge of Washington, parents of the bride-to-be. A September wedding is planned.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: LUCK OF THE IRISH The Irish are not being ignored this St. Patrick's Day, as special programming essentially turns the celebration into St. Patrick's Week. Things get under way today with a touch of the offbeat, a Culinary Tour of the Emerald Isle during the weekly brunch at the New York Institute of Technology's Culinary Arts Center. From 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., for $24 a person, diners may partake of traditional Irish fare, along with the customary haute cuisine. The center is on the college's Central Islip campus. Reservations, at 348-3232, are required.

title: 'Glamour and Mousiness'
description: LEAD: GEORGE BALANCHINE Ballet Master. By Richard Buckle with John Taras. Illustrated. 409 pp. New York: Random House. $29.95.

title: Can U.S. Persuade Shamir to Yield on an Issue of Security?
description: WHEN Secretary of State George P. Shultz set out last month to promote an ambitious plan for Arab-Israeli peace negotiations, his strategy seemed to be aimed primarily at Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: Oaxaca
description: To the Editor: Although Betty Freudenheim's article on wall hangings from Oaxaca (Travel, Jan. 10) is informative, I am concerned about the remark of the United States Consul in Oaxaca: ''You never pay too little. They know what the bottom price is.'' It would have been more appropriate to advise Americans not to worry about paying too much. The Mexican weaver is a hard-working craftsman whose standard of living is low. Although the American tourist may not feel rich in his own country, his possessions and his ability to travel make him enormously wealthy compared to the average Mexican. Tourists should not be overly concerned about the rock-bottom price. Let us share our good fortune and express our respect for Mexican handicrafts. LUCY FEIN Durham, N.C.

title:
DEALING WITH GORBACHEV;
6 WAYS TO COMPETE WITH THE U.S.S.R.
description: LEAD: EVEN IF AGREEMENTS ARE worked out on issues such as nuclear-arms control, the United States and the Soviet Union will still be in conflict on others, such as the future of Europe and regional conflicts in the third world. To compete effectively, the United States must develop six key capabilities:

title: Au Printemps, Au Marche
description: WEEKS BEFORE WINTER OFFICIALLY submits to spring, the signs are there. From Brittany's port of Erquy to the bustling riverside quays of Lyons, from Nice's sun-kissed Cours Saleya to the sunrise tuna auction in St.-Jean-de-Luz, one's senses are alerted to the change of season. Already, plump melons from Cavailon, tiny peas from Barbentane, strawberries from just north of Marseilles, peaches from Salon-de-Provence, cherries from Ceret, have begun to trickle into market stalls. Truck farmers are smiling once again, now that their rich soil has been warmed by the sun to produce the primeurs - the freshest, youngest dandelion greens and tender mache, the finger-sized carrots, the potatoes no bigger than golf balls, the precocious radishes planted, it seems, just days before.

title: For Suharto, A Whisper Of Defiance
description: PRESIDENT SUHARTO told Indonesians two weeks ago that ''very dynamic changes have taken place in our society'' that have brought ''new potentials, new aspirations and new hopes.'' By Friday, when Mr. Suharto was sworn in for his fifth five-year term, Indonesians were demonstrating, unexpectedly and not to his liking, how right he was.

title: New Zealand Cup Proposal Rejected
description: The San Diego Yacht Club yesterday rejected a proposal by Michael Fay, chairman of New Zealand's America's Cup challenge, to postpone the yachting series until next year so that other challengers could join in a sailoff.

title: Salvador Rebels Reported to Plan Big Campaign
description: A batch of documents reported to have been captured from Marxist guerrillas here indicate that the rebels are planning a major political and military offensive over the next 10 months, according to Salvadoran officials and several foreign diplomats.

title: The Mets Take Part In a New Migration
description: Officials of the Mets acknowledged today that they had asked for and received substantial real-estate inducements to move their spring training operations here after 26 years on Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: N.H.L. Kills a Penalty
description: ONE game after Bob McCammon began serving a five-game suspension, the National Hockey League has rescinded the suspension and a $1,000 fine levied against the Vancouver coach in the aftermath of a brawl between the Canucks and Islanders last Tuesday. But the league increased the Canucks' team fine from $10,000 to $25,000 and upheld the 10-game suspension of Dave Richter, a Vancouver defenseman.

title: Overbooking
description: To the Editor: Anyone who has ever been bumped from an overbooked flight knows only too well how infuriating that experience can be. But air travelers should know that being bumped can also be something like winning a lottery.

title: Two Roads Through West Cork
description: BY EARLY VICTORIAN DAYS, English tourists were at last venturing into Ireland. One of the first recorded uses of the word ''tourism,'' in fact, occurs in Thackeray's ''Irish Sketch Book of 1842.''

title: An Expert On Work By Mother
description: LEAD: EVEN though she is much in demand as a speaker during Women's History Month, Ruth Schwartz Cowan, the author of ''More Work for Mother,'' a pioneering study of housework and technology, would be just as happy if there were no need for such an observance; or, for that matter, for women's studies, which she directs at the State University of New York at Stony

title: Traffic and History Cross At Bedford's Village Green
description: LEAD: IN 1681, a year after Bedford was founded, the town's leaders set aside a three-acre ''common'' for communal cattle pasturing. Over the years, some of the town's most important buildings - from a courthouse to a schoolhouse - were established around that tract of land, which became the center of the tightly clustered community's attention.

title: Murray C. Weiss, 64, Journalist
description: Murray C. Weiss, who was editor of The International Herald Tribune for 13 years, died yesterday from complications after a stroke at Arlington Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 64 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: State Weighs Open-Choice Schooling
description: THE state's Department of Education is beginning a broad-based inquiry into the feasibility of allowing New Jersey parents to choose the public schools their children attend.

title: Iraq Says It Hit Tanker And Iranian Oil Station
description: Iraq said today that its jets attacked a tanker in the Persian Gulf and an oil pumping station on the Iranian mainland, indicating renewed hostilities against economic targets in the Persian Gulf war. The raids came a day after both sides called a halt in the missile strikes on each other's cities.

title:
GARDENING;
Gray Foliage for Contrast and Variety
description: LEAD: THERE is an increasing interest in using plants with gray foliage in flower gardens.

title: Focusing on Pro Hockey, and How It Oughta Be
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Famous Collection to Be Auctioned
description: LEAD: THE sale of United States coins from the famous Norweb Collection will resume this month in New York City. A two-session auction will take place March 24 and 25 at the Vista International Hotel in conjunction with the Metropolitan New York Numismatic Convention. Both sessions will start at 7 P.M. The hotel is located at 3 World Trade

title: The Piazza della Signoria
description: To trave, as we did, from Venice direct to Florence is to experience the Time Machine at its most devastating. Venice, still recognizably the city of Canaletto and Guardi, is the world's largest pedestrian precinct; Florence is a gigantic toyshop with malignant, destructive boys in little vehicles tearing up and down the aisles, bent on raising havoc. In Venice the loudest noise we heard was that of the pigeons eating themselves silly in the Piazza San Marco; in Florence there is hardly a moment's relief from the hideous clamor of the internal-comustion engine in one or another of its forms.

title: Pakistani to Confer on Aiding Afghan Peace Talks
description: A senior Pakistani representative at the Afghan peace talks here will go home this weekend to consult his Government on moves to break the deadlock, according to officials involved in the talks.

title: When The Message Becomes Meaningless
description: ''ARE you the station that gives twice as much weather?

title: Schoolgirls Honored
description: AMONG the players named to the first team of Parade Magazine's 12th annual All-America High School Girl's Basketball Team is Tammi Reiss of Eldred Central School in the southern Catskills. And with good reason. Earlier this month, the 5-foot-6-inch Reiss became the top-scoring female high school player in New York State. Her 2,705 points broke the career record of 2,704 held by Katrina Springer of Broad Albion High in Amsterdam, N.Y. Yesterday, Reiss added 36 points to her state record, which she will carry with her to the University of Virginia next fall.

title: Why Do Players Lose the Inspired Momentum?
description: USUALLY a skillfully played victory over a great player will provide the winner with enough inspiration to carry him through to an excellent result in the competition. But apparently not always.

title:
FIVE PLACES TO MEET THE WORLD;
The Chao Phraya
description: LEAD: When Joseph Conrad visited Bangkok's Oriental Hotel, it was twin-storied and pillared, facing alwn leading to a jetty on the Chao Phraya River, beside the landing of the East Asiatic Company. Today the Oriental has grown to a complex of modern slabs that almost engulf the old hostelry. But a Lord Jim's Restaurant, an Author's Wing and an Author's Lounge remain to commemorate Conrad and the other scribblers -among them Somerset Maugham, Noel Coward and Graham Greene - who have stayed in this crossroad of Eastern Asia.

title: A TOP GUN FOR TAXPAYERS: Rubin Gorewitz, C.P.A.; 8,000 New Battles at the 1040 Corral
description: ''AIIYIIYII!'' Rubin Gorewitz said. ''This is so stupid! You look one place and it says check Document 872. You get there and it says check Section 469. That tells you to go to Clause 609A. And then the clause is 3,000 pages long.''

title: THE REGION: Rent Control Review; Landlords Are Trying A New Tack in Their Push For Deregulation
description: WHILE no one would say it is easy to find an apartment in New York City, landlords are saying there are some statistical grounds for easing rent regulation at least a bit. When the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee starts its triennial hearings on the rent laws tomorrow, the landlords will try to make their case for wresting about 72,500 units that rent for $750 a month or more -most of them in Manhattan - from city protection.

title: FICTION
description: AFOOT IN A FIELD OF MEN. By Pat Ellis Taylor. (Atlantic Monthly Press, Paper, $6.95.) A fashionable piece of fiction about a lazy bunch of downside Dallas eccentrics, ''Afoot in a Field of Men'' is narrated by a character with the same name as the author (hmmm . . .) who wants ''to figure out how to make a living doing nothing.'' Presented as interrelated short stories, this collection should probably be billed as a novel, except the reader might then expect something in the way of structure or plot. As it is, the divorced narrator lives with her lover and grown son in a series of dumpy east Dallas apartments. In her well-intentioned and responsible effort to do nothing, the narrator, Pat, who also writes and clings to credentials as a ''sometimes somewhat of a female folklore scholar,'' becomes an office temp and then works in a bookstore (as does the real-life writer Pat). The people she meets on these jobs make great copy. Except for Leo the lover, who is not so interesting - so Pat the author packs him off to Galveston. Whereupon good-natured and generous Pat the narrator gets a new roommate named Pauline, a neighbor who's about to be evicted with her three children and two dogs. There is mild substance abuse, as well as babies and dogs who have frequent accidents on the floor. Mostly, however, there are kids everywhere (Pat's two others have also arrived). Eventually our cheerful narrator is taken aback by the throngs: ''Even in the Bible story . . . the multitude didn't just decide to move in and stay.'' She may not have a sense of purpose, but Pat (author or narrator, take your pick) makes a stab at turning a sense of humor into an acceptable substitute.

title: PALESTINIANS QUIT THE POLICE FORCE IN OCCUPIED AREAS
description: Palestinians working for the Israeli police in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip were resigning from their jobs tonight amid predictions that the entire 1,000-member Palestinian force would quit by Sunday. Police officials said almost 500 had already resigned in a dramatic protest that began Friday.

title: U.S. Fears China Will Widen Arms Sales to Iran
description: American intelligence agencies are watching anxiously to see whether China's recent pledges to end deliveries of Silkworm anti-ship missiles to Iran will be expanded to include a cutoff of anticipated sales of several other types of weapons.

title: Robin Isabel Riley to Wed John Christopher Ahrens
description: The engagement of Robin Isabel Riley to John Christopher Ahrens, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Charles Ahrens of Toledo, Ohio, has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Isabel Cooper Riley of Manhasset, L.I. A May 14 wedding is planned.

title: A Promenade In Monte Carlo
description: IN MONTE CARLO, THERE'S THE OLD, THE NEW and the newly old. The newly old buildings are the newest, as seen in the still-unfinished Metropole Hotel, which is being rebuilt in the style of the Belle Epoque, with pillars, marble floors and ''riotous over-decoration,'' as one Monacan lovingly described it. The truly old, which is Monte Carlo's claim to a place in architectural history, is exactly the same - except it is genuine. the Casino was built in 1878, as was the Opera House, known as the Salle Garnier after Charles Garnier, who designed it as a smaller version of his Paris Opera House.

title: Heavy Metal
description: IT IS THE LARGEST ATRIUM IN Washington. Its Corinthian columns, 75 feet high, 8 feet in diameter, are the world's biggest. The Pension Building in Judiciary Square was erected between 1882 and 1887 with a dual purpose - to house the offices of the Federal Government's pension bureau and to serve as a setting for large gatherings. By the 1960's, however, it had outlived its usefulness and was threatened with razing. Then, in 1980, Congress established it as the site of the National Building Museum, and when renovation is completed this fall, galleries and museum offices will fill two of the four floors that line the perimeter of the massive central hall.

title: OH MY CRACKING PISTONS!
description: I laughed all the way through Fred Halliday's essay ''Oh My Cracking Pistons!'' (Feb. 14). I had kept an MG on the road for almost 10 years - with similar experiences. I, too, learned to keep a ''winter rat'' sitting in the driveway, just in case!

title: Cezanne's Sketchbooks: Secrets and Surprises
description: The quietest exhibition of the current season to date in the New York museums may well turn out to be the most important one. It is ''Paul Cezanne: the Basel Sketchbooks,'' and it can be seen through June 5 at the Museum of Modern Art. The 114 drawings in the show are from the hand of one of the greatest artists who ever lived, and they range in date from his student days to the final phase of his career. How could we not assign a very high place to a show that takes us into the intimacy of Cezanne as he probes the very nature of representation and the extent to which deep feelings can be released in the act of drawing?

title: Car Rental
description: To the Editor: I'm writing to tell you about a small-scale scam recently perpetrated on me in Hawaii by Dollar Rent-a-Car.

title: Ms. Higgs to Wed Robert A. Morin
description: Mr. and Mrs. John H. Higgs of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Forbush Higgs to Robert Alan Morin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Morin of Forest Hills, Queens. The wedding is to be late next summer.

title:
DANCE;
When Balachine Brought Ballet to Hollywood
description: LEAD: In 1937, Vera Zorina was the toast of London. The glamorous 20-year-old soloist from the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo had just made a hit in the Rodgers and Hart musical ''On Your Toes,'' and the movie producer Samuel Goldwyn got wind of it. He invited her to Hollywood to star in his film extravaganza ''The Goldwyn Follies,'' for which he had already sought out George Balanchine, also a hot property, to choreograph the ballet sequences.

title: 'WHY ARE YOU NOT SINGING?'
description: RED STAR OVER TIBET By Dawa Norbu. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Envoy Press/Apt Books. $25. THE TIBET GUIDE By Stephen Batchelor. Illustrated. 466 pp. Newburyport, Mass.: Wisdom Publications. Paper, $26.95.

title: Peter Elder; Accounting Executive, 64
description: Peter Elder, a former partner of Peat Marwick Main & Company, the accounting concern, died of cancer Thursday at Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: Queens Area Seeks Renewal From New Mall
description: A 20-year effort to revitalize the business district of Jamaica, Queens, took a step forward yesterday as a newly renovated retail complex, the Gertz Mall, was dedicated.

title: Justice Can Sometimes Be Blind to Needs of the Community
description: ''THE stretching of the Constitution to override local authority undermines communities' rights to self-government and leaves citizens in a perpetual state of uncertainty as to what the Constitution will suddenly turn out to require or prohibit.''

title: Jamaica
description: To the Editor: On a recent vacation trip to Jamaica, my wife, daughter and I were impressed with the beautiful beaches, the courteous maids and the efficient waiters, but we had some unpleasant experiences as well.

title: Expressiveness And Expressionism
description: WORKS by Jay Milder, the Expressionist painter, are on view at Gallery Jupiter in Little Silver, and Sy Kattelson, an expressive photographer, is having a 40-year retrospective at the Jersey City Museum.

title: Critic of Israel Stirs Political Furor in Canada
description: A political storm developed in Canada today over a strong criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian unrest in the West Bank and Gaza Strip voiced by Joe Clark, the Secretary of State for External Affairs.

title: NONFICTION
description: FOR LUST OF KNOWING: Memoirs of an Intelligence Officer. By Archie Roosevelt. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) Archibald (Archie) Roosevelt Jr., grandson of Theodore Roosevelt, knew everybody. Even though he came from the Long Island rather than the Hudson Valley squirearchy, he maintained fairly good relations with Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. Wherever he went during his impressive career - the United States Army, the State Department and various embassies in the Middle East, the Central Intelligence Agency (from 1951 to 1974), the Chase Manhattan Bank - his name opened doors. A scholar and linguist, he became fluent in Arabic. He made himself invaluable as a translator and then as a political interpreter. The strongest part of this memoir comes near the end when he offers his opinion of American foreign policy. In an important statement, Mr. Roosevelt writes: ''The distinction between Communists and the nationalist extremists has not always been understood by the 'wise men' of Washington.'' About the fall of the Shah of Iran he has this to say: ''If, in the beginning, the Shah had shown the ruthlessness of his predecessors -Darius the Great, Genghis Khan, Reza Shah - the Iranian masses would have bared their necks, and prostrated themselves before the Great Khan.'' Mr. Roosevelt also clams up. Abiding by C.I.A. rules, he tells us: ''I cannot give the exact nature of these assignments nor their time frame, nor do I wish to do so. . . .'' Fortunately, the Freedom of Information Act has enabled others to learn at least some of what should be public knowledge, including mistakes in policy.

title: TOWN WINS FIGHT TO SAVE A BRIDGE
description: Residents of this tiny village in the hills of northwest Massachusetts have won their fight with the state to save their 98-year-old iron bridge.

title: A Baltimorean Battles Bunkum
description: John Waters, Baltimore's new-est sage and the city's only full-time, live-in movie maker, loves Grace Metalious, fresh desk blotters, Glenn Gould, candy-filled bullets (''seven to a pack, 59 cents''), Pia Zadora, Flannery O'Connor and the films of Randall Kleiser (''Blue Lagoon,'' among others). He hates slobbering dogs met in elevators (''Every time you make direct eye contact with these creatures, your I.Q. drops 10 points''), Hermann Hesse, ''The African Queen,'' ''people who ostentatiously hold their ears in New York subways,'' and iceberg lettuce (''the polyester of greens'').

title: Artists of the High Plains
description: Hard by the Indian hunting grounds, religious sites and battlefields of Montana and northern Wyoming, the traveler can find rich collections of the arts and artifacts of the area. The region holds a number of museums where fragments of American Indian history and culture have been preserved. But few collections are as successful - or as elclectic - as those of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyo. This rambling museum, named for the Pony Express rider-turnedshowman William F. Cody (Buffalo Bill), is a short drive from the eastern boundary of Yellowstone National Park. The center also contains the Whitney Gallery of Western Art (established by Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney on land donatged by his mother), the Winchester Arms Museum and the Plains Indian Museum).

title: 'Best Small House of 1988' Rises, Right Before Westporters' Eyes
description: FOR months, motorists on Wilton Road in Westport have been charting the progress of a small house being built near the Saugatuck River, less than a quarter-mile from the business center.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I am trying to repair a loose door lock. The bolts holding the inside plate and the body of the lock in place need tightening, but I can't get at them because there is a decorative plate or cover over this. This plate is not held on by screws, and I can't figure how to remove it. How do I get this cover plate off?

title: Interpex '88 Will Open In New York City
description: THE multi-faceted appeal of stamp collecting will be on display at Interpex '88, the annual show staged by the American Stamp Dealers' Association. It attracts dealers and collectors from around the world.

title: How Currents Of Art, Revolution And Culture Took Russia's Jews On Fateful Paths
description: The scene is a room in Odessa. Five literary men face the camera - all seated, all formally attired in the fashion of 1913. The two on the far left and the far right are unfamiliar names today, but the trio in the middle remain celebrated figures wherever modern Jewish culture is studied. In the very center sits Simon Dubnow, the foremost Jewish historian of his era. The round-faced man on his right, one hand thrust under his lapel, is the poet Chaim Nachman Bialik; the man with a trim snow-white beard on his left, head held quizzically to one side, is the storyteller Mendele Mokher Sforim.

description: UNTIL recently colleges that cater to black students were flailing to stay afloat in the mainstream of higher education. Hit by a tidal wave of competition from predominantly white institutions during the 1960's, several weaker schools have repeatedly come close to going under.

description: To the Editor: As a cataloger of art owned by the University of Illinois, I wish to correct a letter (Travel, Jan. 24) on the Swedish sculptor Carl Milles and his work at the university's Robert Allerton Park.

title: Laura Pine Dickey Weds
description: At St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., Laura Pine Dickey, the daughter of Mrs. William Burton Dickey of Riverside and the late Mr. Dickey, was married yesterday to Stephen Walker Walt, the son of Norman Walt of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Herbert Krohn of Marco Island, Fla. The Rev. Gilbert D'Souza officiated. Mrs. Walt is an executive secretary at the Xerox Credit Corporation in Stamford, Conn. Her husband is a computer programmer at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: On Language; Phantom of the Phrases
description: HIGH UP IN THE SCENERY of language, in his lair among old mental sets, lurks the Phantom of the Phrases, ready to hurl down a chandelier on some speaker who dares cross his purposes.

title: Trying to Make a First Punch Count
description: The Army, which has a decidely mixed record in the first battle of a war, has started training generals to win that vital fight if the United States goes to war again.

title: Clay: A Medium and a Tool for Education
description: ''I LOVE ceramics,'' Robin Silberberg, a high school junior, said as she patiently sanded a leather-hard, three-foot-tall coiled urn.

title:
Focus: Boston;
Rundown Reborn
description: LEAD: COLUMBIA POINT, a 1,500-unit public housing project, developed a reputation nationally over the years as a center of crime and decay. It was built 30 years ago on what was then a deserted peninsula in Boston Harbor. An elevated highway walled it off from the rest of the city.

title: Reflections From a High Window
description: LEAD: FOR ME, TRAVEL CAN NEVER BE a vaguely courted experience, but must move my life with it. As it has moved both my own emigre forbears and those travelers who have most moved me: Goethe on his Italian journeys, Chateaubriand shunting between revolutionary France and the plains of the American Indians on his quest for the Northwest Passage -or even the Marquis de Vogue, calibrating all

title: Wendy Nelles Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mark Nelles of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Beth Nelles to Daniel Adam Picard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Picard of Newton Centre, Mass. Ms. Nelles, a graduate of Franklin and Marshall College, is a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at the State University at Albany. Her fiance, a fourth-year student at the Albany Medical College of Union University, graduated from Tufts University.

title:
INVESTING;
The Allure of Building Materials
description: LEAD: WHEN investors talk about buying hard assets, they don't usually mean cement. But maybe they should. Companies that produce cement, concrete, gypsum and other building materials have been swept up in Wall Street's takeover frenzy. Moore McCormack Resources, the USG Corporation and the Koppers Company have all been targets.

title: A Cliche That Impacts? Try 'State of the Art'

title: Agent Faces Drug Charge
description: A Federal Drug Enforcement Agency officer was arrested Saturday in a city police antidrug operation, the police said. The agent, Ray Murray, 34 years old, of Atlanta, was charged with possession of marijuana after his arrest by officers watching an area of known drug activity shortly before 1 P.M.

title: Europe's Big 1992 Goal: Truly Common Market
description: Alain Madelin, as France's Minister for Industry, has pushed French industry to prepare itself for 1992 - the deadline that the 12 nations in the European Community have set for creating a truly common market by eliminating their internal commercial, financial and customs barriers.

title: U.S. Shift Is Shrugged Off in China
description: China and the American business executives who sell to it have mostly shrugged off the Reagan Administration's decision on Wednesday to resume liberalizing controls on high-technology exports to China.

title: Tracking an Atlantic Weather Puzzle
description: Carl Kreitzberg knew by lunchtime on Jan. 25 that a winter storm was developing in the Atlantic off the Virginia capes. That was easy enough to tell from radar and satellite images.

title: Speedy Twosomes
description: Cross-country runners they're not, but if professional golfers seem swifter these days, it's no illusion. As a result of a recent PGA rules change, touring pros are getting around the course as much as 30 percent faster than before.

title: Review/Concert; An All-Beethoven Evening By Lupu and Philharmonic
description: Klaus Tennstedt's performance of the ''Eroica'' Symphony with the New York Philharmonic, reviewed last week in these pages, is being repeated in the current group of subscription concerts with a new companion work, Beethoven's Third Piano Concerto. Radu Lupu is the soloist. At Friday evening's performance, he played with a big tone to match the orchestra's, aggressive but rarely harsh, and with full technical command.

title: A Reversal for Texas Air; Decision on Transfer of Eastern's Shuttle Could Make It Harder to Shuffle Assets
description: Since Frank Lorenzo acquired Eastern Air Lines Inc. in 1986, he has warned that unless its unions, particularly the machinists, make major concessions on wages and work rules, large parts of the airline could be sold or spun off as subsidiaries.

title: Mets' 'Superiority' Tested by Carindals

Recently, John McNamara, the manager of the team, addressed his players in their training camp in Winter Haven, Fla., and gave them some bad news: no more golf bags on road trips.

So it should come as no surprise that various Swedish and Swedish-American interests are planning an array of celebrations in Delaware and in southern New Jersey, which the settlers colonized a few years later.

description: The Coca-Cola Company, maker of that most American of products, earned more money from soft drinks in Japan last year than it did at home - despite a record year in the United States.

description: About a quarter of Vienna's 6,000 Jews crowded into their oldest synagogue today to commemorate the suffering inflicted on their families a half-century ago.

Is that the league high?

description: Iowa, Texas, Auburn and Tennessee, the defending national champion, today were made the four top-seeded teams for the seventh National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I women's basketball tournament.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 14, 1988
description: COMPANIES A rescue plan for First City Bancorporation of Texas is in jeopardy because creditors have balked at its provisions. Federal agencies are weighing alternative moves. [ Page D1. ] Hachette of France offered $415 million for Grolier, a major American educational publisher. The bid has a per-share value of $21, a substantial increase from the $15.875 at which the stock was trading when the market closed Friday. [ D1. ] A G.S.A. employee made tape recordings of phone conversations in which an official of a regional Bell phone company told the employee that an agency official had given A.T.& T.'s secret bid information to competitors for the Government phone contract. [ D1. ] The U.S. reversed its milder assessment of damage by Toshiba Machine to national security that was caused by the company's sales of advanced submarine technology to the Soviet Union. [ D1. ] Campeau will extend its tender offer for shares of Federated to Friday at midnight, individuals close to Campeau said. [ D2. ] American Standard voted to remove its ''poison pill'' provision if an unwanted suitor accumulates more than half of its stock. [ D2. ] THE ECONOMY Some U.S. corporations are vigorously lobbying against a bill passed by the House that would require foreign investors in the U.S. to disclose their identity and holdings. The companies fear retaliatory measures against their overseas operations. [ D2. ] Stalwarts of American business have agreed to a Soviet request to give marketing pointers to Soviet managers. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT China and American businesses that trade with it shrugged off the decision by the U.S. to consider loosening some export licensing controls for goods bound for China. [ D4. ] Government officials in Spain want to encourage bank mergers because the nation apparently has too many banks. [ D10. ] Some economists fear that Tokyo's market is climbing too fast as the stock exchange nears its pre-crash highs. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Much ''stock parking'' is as harmful as jaywalking, according to some traders and lawyers. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Stocks of The Gap and The Limited are on the bargain counter, but some brokerages view them with caution. Market Place. [ D6. ] Investors and traders have been content to stand by and watch the seesawing of economic signals. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Bid for Rover Proceeding
description: Price appears to be the only thing standing in the way of British Aerospace P.L.C.'s surprise bid to take over Britain's state-owned car manufacturer, Rover.

title: Drive on Alien Law Stepped Up as Response Lags
description: After Mass, the Rev. Octavio Cisneros moved outdoors to greet Spanish-speaking parishioners and urged them to take advantage of the new immigration law permitting many unauthorized aliens to apply for residency before May 4.

title: Red Wings Sweep Islanders
description: Nothing good happened on the ice for the Islanders tonight during their game against the Red Wings, and after they had lost, 5-1, they barricaded themselves in their locker room at their coach's request for hockey's version of a soul-searching.

title: Review/Piano; Chopin, Bartok And Beethoven In Chen Recital
description: Hung-Kuan Chen made it clear in the first few bars of his piano recital Tuesday evening at the 92d Street Y that he would play his Beethoven with unusual concentration and command of rhythm. The E flat sonata, (Op. 27 No. 1), was very impressive for security at top speed in the finale and for evenly weighted, thoughtful chording in the slow movements. Bartok's ''Out of Doors'' suite was even better: a wonderfully precise realization of pictorial details was combined with a strong sense of overall shape and enough virtuosity to make some things that are often merely noisy sound quite exciting.

title: Gain Reported On Japan Issue
description: Japan and the United States agreed Friday to restart talks on the opening of the Japanese construction market to American companies, the Kyodo News Service said.

description: When he was in New York last Tuesday, Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, who pleaded guilty on Friday to withholding information from Congress, stopped to consult with an old friend who knows something about special prosecutors and the ways of Washington. He was Richard M. Nixon.

title: For Mexico's Rulers, Victory Is Not Enough
description: Six days a week, Carlos Salinas de Gortari heads out on the campaign trail to crisscross Mexico by train, bus and helicopter, shake the hands of poor peasants, middle-class housewives and factory workers, confer with local political bosses and spend millions of dollars, all part of his effort to be elected President of Mexico in July.

title: Psychologists Take Seat On Little League Bench
description: For six years, Mike Salogub has been his Little League team's manager, teacher, baby sitter, disciplinarian and chauffeur. Now Mr. Salogub is adding team psychologist to his list of duties.

title: Critic's Notebook; Has Stanley Kowalski Become an Unactable Role?
description: From the moment Tennessee Williams wrote the final line of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' the role of Stanley Kowalski has been the most difficult to cast in the modern repertory.

title: South Africa - a Lebanon?
description: Black South Africans have exercised the most remarkable patience in pressing for their human rights.

title: AEP INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Dutchess Prosecutor Vows Brawley Case Slander Suit
description: Lawyers for Tawana Brawley, without citing evidence, yesterday accused a Dutchess County assistant prosecutor of being ''one of the attackers'' of the black teen-ager. Last night, the prosecutor, expressing outrage, said through his attorney that he would sue the Brawley lawyers for slander.

title: Jean Levitan Married To Stephen Bernstein
description: The marriage of Jean Elizabeth Levitan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Levitan of New York, to Stephen Jay Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bernstein of Elkins Park, Pa., took place yesterday at Hebrew Union College in New York. Rabbi Lawrence W. Raphael performed the ceremony.

title: Market Place; Outlook for Gap And The Limited
description: ALTHOUGH many stocks have rallied in recent months, two specialty apparel issues once tagged as Wall Street favorites - The Gap Inc. and The Limited Inc. - are selling at prices near their sharply depressed levels of last October. The two issues may be on the bargain counter, but both rate no better than a cautious ''hold'' recommendation at some brokerage houses.

title: Nets Are Beaten By SuperSonics
description: Tom Chambers scored 19 of his 25 points on perfect third-quarter shooting tonight as the Seattle SuperSonics defeated the Nets, 115-102.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $181,000.

title: SCHOOL FOR DEAF PICKS DEAF CHIEF
description: The trustees of Gallaudet University, the nation's only institution of higher learning for the hearing impaired, bowed tonight to demands of protesters by choosing a deaf person as its next president.

title: Exterminator Is a Pest, Goldin Says in an Audit
description: If a New York City audit is any indication, an exterminator hired by the city might as well have fought cockroaches by speaking sternly to them and ordering them to go their room.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Theater; Reluctant Envoy's Tale: Porter's 'Leave It to Me!'
description: Equity Library Theater's 50th anniversary production of ''Leave It to Me!'' is billed as the first American revival of the Cole Porter musical. Unfortunately, the reasons for that neglect are self-evident. Despite promises, this is not one of Porter's wittier scores, and the book by Bella and Samuel Spewack is only glancing in its attempt to be comic about global politics.
