description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 13, 1988: MONDAY Affil Publications Franklin Resources Interco Inc TUESDAY CPC Intl House of Fabrics Federal Paper Board Upjohn Co WEDNESDAY American Tel & Tel Northwestern Steel & Wire Carolina Pwr & Lt Oxford First Corp DCNY Corp Rochester G & E Fairchild Indus St Joseph Lt & Pwr Keystone International Service Corp Intl MacNeal-Schwendler Transco Energy National Serv Indus THURSDAY Air Products & Chem Southern Cal Edison Federal Signal Transamerica Corp Russ Togs FRIDAY CP National Knight-Ridder Equitable Resources Southeast Banking

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $807,784 for the quarter and $807,794 for the year, and tax credits of $3,200,000 and $5,700,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $538,364 and $743,909 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a tax credit of $1,215,000 for both periods.

title: South Africa Clerics Defy Threats With Services Against Crackdown
description: Striking a new note of militancy, South African church leaders today dismissed the latest Government threats to silence them and held defiant and well-attended protest services around the country to reiterate their support for civil disobedience.

title: David L. Stitzer Is Wed To Leah C. Schoenberg
description: Leah Chana Schoenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Schoenberg of Miami, was married yesterday to David Lee Stitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Stitzer of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Yisroel Schorr officated at the Bais Yaakov girls' yeshiva in Monsey, N.Y.

title: Richard C. Maier Weds Debra Ann Silverman
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Debra Ann Silverman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mathew Silverman of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Charles Maier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Maier of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: Presidio Oil's Head Buys Companies in Bad Times
description: George P. Giard Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Presidio Oil Company, says he is employing the J. Paul Getty strategy of buying up oil businesses during bad times.

title: Advertising; The Editor of Boating Becomes Publisher, Too
description: Diamandis Communications has bestowed the additional title of publisher on G. Douglas Schryver, editor of Boating magazine, which was acquired from Ziff-Davis in 1985. The former publisher, J. Samuel Huey, 36 years old, is back at Ziff-Davis as associate publisher of PC magazine.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Cablevision-SCI Talks
description: The Cablevision Corporation, the Long Island-based cable company, is in preliminary negotiations to acquire the cable assets of SCI Holdings, according to several well-placed industry sources. Cablevision executives declined to comment. It was not clear Friday how such a deal would be financed and whether it might ultimately involve other companies. SCI Holdings is the name given after Storer Communications was acquired by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts, the leveraged buyout firm. It is the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, with 1.5 million subscribers. Cablevision, with 1.05 million subscribers, is 10th-largest cable operator.

title: Meese Predicts He Won't Be Indicted Over Pipeline
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that he did not expect to be indicted by a Federal grand jury investigating his ties to a proposed $1 billion Iraqi pipeline project and insisted that he would not resign.

title: Chaney's Playbook: His Life
description: AFTER defeating Rhode Island in Morgantown, W. Va., last Wednesday night and hoisting the Atlantic 10 Conference tournament trophy high, after clipping the nets and insuring their No. 1 ranking among the 64 teams clawing this week for college basketball's biggest prize, the Temple Owls boarded a chartered bus for Pittsburgh, from where they would fly to Philadelphia the following morning.

title: Opposition Mounting To Disclosure Proposal
description: Fearful of retaliation abroad, some major American corporations are vigorously lobbying against a bill that was passed by the House that would require foreign investors in the United States to disclose their identity and holdings.

title: For Arabs, 'Uprising' Takes an Economic Toll
description: The Palestinian police officer rose this morning, packed his dark blue Israeli uniform in a plastic bag, went to his precinct next to the Church of the Nativity here and resigned.

title: Conservative Judaism Faults Fundamentalism
description: In the first statement of principles in its 143-year history, the Conservative movement of Judaism resoundingly rejects fundamentalism - be it Christian, Moslem or Jewish - and steers a moderate course that favors loyalty to tradition ''without resigning from the 20th century.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Senators and the rest of them give themselves raises, but they don't do nothing for guys like us here.'' - Ben Guttierez, a Chicago voter. [ A1:5. ]

title: 'Exuberance' Wins Aqueduct Sprint
description: Cagey Exuberance finally proved herself the queen of Aqueduct's winter sprinters by reversing recent defeats to Bishop's Delight and Spring Beauty with a definitive victory yesterday in the $69,500 Correction Handicap.

title: Olympic Notebook; War Doesn't Deter Iraqis and Iranians
description: Despite the recent intensity of their war, which has continued for more than seven years, Iraq and Iran still intend to participate in the Seoul Olympics later this year.

title: Home Care: Unsung and Underpaid
description: When Gwendolyn Rosemond testified at a public hearing last spring on the ''Plight of the Home Care Worker,'' she brought along living proof to document the value of her work - her client of nearly nine years, Mary Dunn.

title: Extend One-Way Toll To East River Bridges
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A table on the Education page on March 2 incorrectly listed North Carolina's rank in average teacher salary. The average salary, $22,775, ranked 30th in the country.

title: Delegate Selection Begins
description: North Dakota Democrats today began the two-week process of picking the delegates who will attend the state convention. Democrats in the state hold 53 district conventions between Sunday and March 27 to select delegates to the state convention in Fargo. Convention-goers will cast their ballots for a Presidential nominee April 16. Delegates to the national convention will be chosen based on their Presidential preference.

title: Soviet Nationalities Seeking More Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Changes Its Stance On Damage by Toshiba
description: For the second time in a month, the Reagan Administration has sharply reversed its assessment of how much United States security was damaged by the Toshiba Machine Corporation's sale of advanced submarine technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Review/Music; Ensemble That Offers Only the Truly Early
description: Anthony Rooley's English vocal ensemble, the Consort of Musicke, has been around since 1969 and performs ''early music'' that really is early, meaning Baroque and before, rather than more recent forays into Romantic music. In the course of its nearly 20-year existence, the group has made many fine recordings and produced a host of early-music singers who have gone on to solo careers, Emmy Kirkby chief among them.

title: A Tough Battle In Orange Juice
description: One beverage business in which the Coca-Cola Company is being bruised is orange juice.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After a gain from an accounting change of $5,355,000. The latest first quarter operating loss included a loss on the sales of securities of $235,000, compared with a gain of $743,000 on the sales of securities for the year-ago period. Other income in 1987 included a pre- tax profit of $2,382,000, or 18 cents a share, on the settlement of an insurance claim arising from a fire loss in a foreign branch in the first quarter of that year.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $420,000 from extinguishment of debt. c-Net income The company said the latest 6-month loss is after a pre-tax charge of $1,325,000 as a result of the failure Johnson & Johnson to make its scheduled payments to the company. The charge includes about $75,000 of legal fees and the related litigation costs in connection with legal proceedings filed against Johnson & Johnson.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Is Fatally Shot On a Street Corner
description: A 24-year-old man was shot and killed on the corner of Vermont Street and Pitkin Avenue in the East New York section of Brooklyn shortly after noon yesterday, the police said.

title: Art Gallery Owners Are Mixed on Law About Posting Prices, but Browsers Like It
description: ''The sale of a painting is always subject to negotiation,'' Rachel Adler said the other day. ''The dealer and the client discuss a painting on all levels, including its monetary value, and when they reach a price it's an agreement reached between two consenting adults. I don't think one of those people needs to be protected by a great city ordinance.''

title: Simon Seems at Home in Last Stand
description: Senator Paul Simon, as ebullient as ever on the campaign trail, gives no public signs that he thinks his home state's primary on Tuesday may very well be the end of the line for his Presidential campaign.

title: SPORTMAN'S GUIDE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $248,965 from a change in accounting method. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $180,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net income

title: Ryan's Flame Burns Eternal
description: THE Houston Astros were playing an exhibition game at Osceola County Stadium in this central Florida city, about 15 minutes south of Disney World, but Nolan Ryan, not much younger than Mickey Mouse but certainly as eternal, was on the other side of the spring training complex. He was in the Astros' clubhouse, relaxing in front of his locker, finished with his work for the day, and talking.

title: Brush Fire Contained in Texas
description: Firefighters worked today to extinguish smoldering hot spots after a brush fire that charred hundreds of square miles of West Texas prairie.

title: This Bud's for You
description: The dormant dragon of Iran-contra, which the nation puts out of its mind for months at a time, roused itself last week to breathe fire at the Reagan Administration.

title: BRIDGFORD FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in January.

title: Advertising; Actors in Commercials Plan Strike Over Cable
description: The talent unions whose members act in most television commercials voted last week to strike against the advertising industry next Monday because of an impasse over their demand for improved payments for reuse of commercials on cable TV.

title: Nepalese Look for Survivors Of Stampede at Soccer Game
description: Hundreds of Nepalese crowded hospitals today looking for relatives after a hailstorm caused a stampede at a soccer stadium, killing about 90 people and injuring dozens.

title: Topics of The Times; Special Vote, Special Candidate
description: Voters in Suffolk County's 10th Election District have a chance to send an unusually well-qualified candidate to the State Assembly. She is Elizabeth Hubbard, a Democrat running in Tuesday's special election to fill the seat vacated by Toni Rettaliata, a Republican who was elected Town Supervisor of Huntington last November.

title: SHAMIR'S HARD LINE GETS WIDE SUPPORT
description: Tens of thousands of Israelis demonstrated in Tel Aviv tonight in support of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's rejection of the newest United States proposal for a Middle East peace settlement.

title: Topics of The Times; Not-So-Flexible Flyer
description: One recent Saturday a friend bought her toddler a shiny red bicycle with streamers hanging from the handlebars and a Clarabelle the Clown sort of horn - it was just like the trike she herself had ridden as a child. But the woman then found that everyone in the neighborhood had a plastic contraption called a Big Wheel, as ugly as it is practical. The new trike rider couldn't go as fast or cut corners as well as the big wheelers, and came home in tears.

title: Metro Datelines; Body of a woman Is Found on Shoreline
description: The body of an unidentified woman was found on Staten Island's northern shoreline shortly before 11 A.M. yesterday, the police said.

title: Theaters as Landmarks: Who Likes the Ruling, Who Doesn't, and Why
description: It had been nearly six years to the day since a giant steel-jawed backhoe named Godzilla ate through the eastern wall of the Morosco Theater as hundreds of onlookers, many of them weeping, witnessed the end of an era on Broadway and the begining of a revolution.

description: Residents of this city 50 miles south of San Francisco are turning on their radio these days and being reassured that San Jose is a nice place to live.

description: b-Includes $1,506,000 in tax loss carryforwards attributable to Barber- Greene Co. prior to its acquisition by Astec.

title: AIDS, Like a Roof, Is Realtors' Concern
description: Realtors in Texas have been advised to tell a prospective homebuyer if a house for sale has been occupied by a person with AIDS.

title: Jackson's Triumph in South Carolina Illustrates Dramatic Change Since Vote in '84
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's dramatic sweep in this state's Democratic Presidential caucuses provided a vivid demonstration of the growth in his political support since 1984.

description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $107,000 for the quarter and $260,000 for the year. The 1986 results are restated to reflect the inclusion of the company's finance subsidiary on a consolidated basis. The company said in 1986 it changed its year-end to Dec. 31, from Nov. 30, making 1986 a 13-month period.

title: Review/Dance; Janice Brenner and the Use of Limits
description: On Thursday night, Janis Brenner was most powerful as a dancer and a choreographer when she allowed herself to be restricted. She demonstrated this with particular effectiveness in ''Phases of 30 Part I: Guilt,'' a solo on the program that Janis Brenner and Dancers offered at the Nikolais-Louis Choreospace.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New Zealand North America, a subsidiary of Bank of New Zealand in Wellington, named Laurence L. Siegel senior vice president, planning and administration, North America, and manager of the New York branch; Douglas A. Rettew, senior vice president, corporate, North America, and John J. Hanly, senior vice president, treasury, North America.

title: Washington Talk: U.S.-Soviet Relations; 2 Military Chiefs Set for Blind Date
description: It is the diplomatic equivalent of a blind date - their friends think the two might have something in common, but nobody is so brash as to say they'll truly hit it off.

title: In the Philippines, Nothing Has Improved
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Event Is Almost Rained Out But Knockout Teams Persist
description: There is no recorded case of a major bridge event being rained out, but it nearly happened Saturday at the Adria Motor Inn in Bayside, Queens. When the evening session of grand national knockout play was about to start, water began pouring out of the ceiling. Players and officials hurriedly moved tables and chairs to another area, averting the need for a complete change of venue Saturday night.

title: 30 on Ferry Drown in India
description: Thirty people drowned when a ferry overturned on a reservoir in central India, the Press Trust of India reported today. The report on Friday's accident said 10 others were rescued by villagers living near the Rihand reservoir in Madhya Pradesh state.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 3, Bruins 0: Steve Leach and Greg Adams scored first-period goals and Pete Peeters stopped 42 shots last night as Washington won in Boston. It was the third time in five games that the Bruins were shut out. Peeters, a former Bruin who leads the league in goals-against average, made several outstanding saves in posting his second shutout of the season. With the victory, Washington, which is 7-2 in its last nine road games, took over first place in the Patrick Division.(AP) Blackhawks 5, Flyers 4: Dirk Graham scored one minute into overtime to give Chicago the victory. Graham snapped in a shot from the top of the right face-off circle for his 19th goal of the season. The loss knocked the Flyers out of first place in the Patrick Division as Washington beat Boston. The Blackhawks rallied from a 4-1 deficit to tie the score, 4-4, at the 6:19 mark of the final period on a goal by Bob Murray. (AP) Penguins 5, Jets 4: Dan Quinn scored two goals, including the winner on a power play, while Rob Brown and Mario Lemieux picked up 4 points each for Pittsburgh. The victory, in Winnipeg, gives the Penguins 67 points, tying them with the Devils 1 point behind the Rangers in the battle for the final Patrick Division playoff berth.(AP) SKIING Figini Closer to Overall Title: Michela Figini of Switzerland won a World Cup super giant slalom in Rossland, British Columbia, yesterday to wrap up the seasonal title in that discipline and move closer to the women's overall championship. With two races remaining - a downhill and giant slalom in Saalbach, Austria - Figini has a 24-point lead in the downhill and a 15-point lead in the overall standing. Brigitte Oertli, 10th in yesterday's super giant slalom, trails Figini for those titles.(AP) French Medalist Wins: Franck Piccard of France won a men's World Cup super giant slalom yesterday in Beaver Creek, Colo., by 22-hundredths of a second over Markus Wasmeier of West Germany. Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg was third. (AP) Nordic Relay to Swedes: Sweden, anchored by Gunde Svan, its four-time Olympic champion, coasted to victory by 1 minute 9.6 seconds over Norway in the men's 40-kilometer freestyle relay in Falun, Sweden, yesterday. By so doing, Sweden clinched its fifth straight World Cup relay title. The Norwegian women also made it five in a row, winning the 20-kilometer freestyle relay after taking the lead on the next-to-last lap. (AP) SLED DOG RACING 70-Year-Old Sledder Leads: Joe Redington regained a slim lead in the Iditarod Trail race as the front-runners reached the last checkpoint on the Yukon River. The 70-year-old Redington checked into Kaltag, Alaska, at 12:35 A.M., local time, yesterday with only nine dogs. He was followed 23 minutes later by Martin Buser of Big Lake, with 13 dogs. Susan Butcher, the defending champion, arrived at the tiny village at 2:28 A.M., also with 13 dogs. From Kaltag, 798 miles from the race's starting line in Anchorage, the mushers turn west toward the coast. (AP) SPEED SKATING Mey Defeats Jansen: Uwe-Jens Mey of East Germany defeated Dan Jansen of the United States yesterday in Inzell, West Germany, and clinched the World Cup title in the 500-meter event. Mey skated the distance in 37.48 seconds, besting his winning time of 38.12 from Saturday. Jansen came in second yesterday with a time of 37.85. Mey won the season-long World Cup title with a total of 225 points to Jansen's 221. Jansen won the World Cup title in the 1,000 meters by 124-123 over a fellow American, Nick Thometz. Andre Hoffmann of East Germany won the World Cup title in the 1,500 meters with 101 points to 90 for Michael Hadschieff of Austria. Tomas Gustafson of Sweden won the World Cup title in the 5,000-meter event with 114 points. (AP) Kania All-Round Champion: Karin Kania of East Germany won her fifth all-round world championship at Skein, Norway, yesterday. Kania beat Yvonne van Gennip of the Netherlands, who won three Olympic gold medals, in three of the four scheduled races. The Dutch champion was runner-up over all. (AP) ROAD RACING Petersen First: Pat Petersen of Lake Ronkonkoma, L.I., in a tune-up for the Olympic Marathon Trials on April 24 in Jersey City, set a meet record of 1 hour 3 minutes 56 seconds in winning the Brooklyn Half Marathon yesterday. A field of 1,861 competed in the 13.1-mile race that finished at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The 28-year-old Petersen led from start to finish in scoring a 500-yard victory over Dan Schlessinger of New York, who crossed the finish line in 1:05.39. Doreen Ennis-Schwarz of the Warren Street A.C. of Jersey City was the women's gold medalist in 1:15.53. FENCING Saber Title Defended: Bob Cottingham of Columbia, an all-American from West Orange, N.J., won seven bouts yesterday to successfully defend his saber title in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association individual championships at Columbia's Levien Gymnasium. Ivan Fernandez-Madrid, a Columbia junior, earned a gold medal in foil with seven victories. James O'Neill of Harvard, who won a fence-off among Jon Normile of Columbia and Charles Melcher of Yale, captured the epee crown.

title: At Gatherings in U.S., Each Side Ponders Events
description: Far from the stones, bullets and tear gas that have brought turmoil to Palestinians and Israelis in the Gaza Stip and the West Bank, advocates of both sides rallied peaceably and separately today.

title: Bid to Save Texas Bank Is Imperiled
description: A rescue plan for Houston's First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc., one of the nation's largest banking organizations, is in jeopardy and without quick action the bank could fail.

title: Avery Okin Wed To Ms. Saltzman
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Lynn Suzan Saltzman, a senior associate at the New York law firm of Mandell & Mandell, was married yesterday to Avery Eli Okin, the executive director of the Brooklyn Bar Association. Rabbi Stanley Platek performed the ceremony.

title: Liverpool Streak Reaches 28 Games
description: Peter Beardsley's goal on a penalty shot sparked a three-goal second half for Liverpool as the English League First Division soccer leader defeated Manchester City, 4-0, today to reach the semifinals of the F.A. Cup.

description: LEAD: The Government has offered to grant political asylum, under certain conditions, to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military ruler, officials said today.

description: Iraq fired a missile at Teheran today and Iran vowed to retaliate, raising fears of a resumption of attacks on each other's cities after a two-day truce.

Brasilia Journal; Brazil's Professor-Politician: He Stoops to Kisses
description: When Fernando Henrique Cardoso was campaigning on a social democratic ticket to become Mayor of Sao Paulo three years ago, friends recall, he was visibly uncomfortable when handed grimy babies to kiss on visits to shantytowns.

title: Mayoral Outbursts: If Koch Is Mellowing, It's Hard to See
description: One morning last week, after a few rare days of quiet on the mayoral wing at City Hall, a reporter asked Mayor Koch for an explanation. He looked a bit puzzled, then promised that he soon would raise his ''decibel level.'' As if there were any doubt that he will. Mr. Koch has never been known for his tranquillity. But lately there have been so many mayoral outbursts and he has had such tempestuous dealings with so many people whose cooperation he and his city need that it is now noteworthy if the 63-year-old Mayor is not arguing with someone about something.

They said the move would take the pressure off a Federal judge who is scheduled to hear arguments today on issues in the complex takeover struggle.

description: In this West African city where Edwardian-era lanterns illuminate sandy streets and ceiling fans gather dust at the airport, language is a good indicator of change.

description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, rejecting the advice of some close advisers, vowed today to remain in the Republican Presidential race after the Illinois primary on Tuesday and remain ''active all the way.''

title: Conference Championships; Arizona Captures Pacific-10 Crown
description: Sean Elliott scored 17 of his 20 points in the first half today and Anthony Cook had 17 of his 19 in the second half as Arizona beat Oregon State, 93-67, in the championship game of the Pacific-10 Conference tournament.

title: Temple Seeded First
description: Temple, the nation's top-ranked team, was seeded first yesterday in the East Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament. The Owls (29-1), the Atlantic 10 Conference champions, will open play against Lehigh (21-9), the East Coast Conference champion, on Friday night at Hartford.

title: Review/Concert; Trio Plays Baroque Works
description: Some contrabass players have so facile a command of the upper positions that it costs them little effort to play music written essentially in the range of the cello. It can be an impressive feat, but unsuccessful attempts can be painful, as Gary Karr unfortunately showed Saturday night at the 92d Street Y. In Baroque duos and trios with Eliot Fisk, guitarist, and Harmon Lewis, harpsichordist, Mr. Karr was almost constantly a little way, and occasionally a long way, out of tune.

title: Syracuse Gets Villanova on the Run to Win Big East
description: Jim Boeheim sat in the Syracuse locker room after Saturday's semifinal victory over Seton Hall lamenting the fact that it was March and his team, despite all of his screaming, still had not hit that elusive top gear.

title: Rest and a Careful Exercise Plan Can Help Relieve Low Back Pain
description: ONE of life's most common ailments is low back pain.

title: Outdoors: Twilight Awakening
description: THE newly revised edition of Jim Bashline's ''Night Fishing for Trout'' (Willow Creek Press) has reminded me that one of the graying angler's traits is to slide away from various fishing techniques that delighted him in earlier years.

title: The Strawberry Festival
description: SOME speculate that Darryl Strawberry made the recently published uncomplimentary remarks about a few of his co-workers on the Mets, including Davey Johnson, the manager, because he was trying to get traded. That would mean relinquishing his spot in right field in Shea Stadium. If that's the case, then he certainly does not want it to be Strawberry's field forever.

title: Murdoch and His Options: Can He Retrieve The Post?
description: In his contract to sell The New York Post last month, Rupert Murdoch retained the right to make the first offer for the paper if its new owner, the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow, should decide to sell.

title: Review/Television; 'Eisenhower and Lutz,' A New Comedy on Law
description: It is not the world's most inviting title. ''Eisenhower and Lutz'' sounds suspiciously like still another police romp. But the new series, having an unusual debut on CBS this evening, is a comedy, and it turns out that the title is part of the joke. Created by Allan Burns for MTM Productions, ''Eisenhower and Lutz'' is an offbeat sitcom. What's more, it's very funny.

title: Review/Dance; 3 Cunningham Works Span Third of a Century
description: Three choreographically first-rate works by Merce Cunningham were offered by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater. The oldest dated to 1953; the newest was created only last year. All testified to Mr. Cunningham's ability to devise stage pictures.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $584,881.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS MASTER LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $3,525,000 and $4,015,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the net from discontinued operations of $4,015,000 includes a gain of $3,495,000 on sale of discontinued operations. The company changed to a calendar year from March 31 year coincident with coversion to a Master Limited Partnership; year-ago results are for the three and 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Business and the Law; Is 'Stock Parking' Like Jaywalking?
description: A JUDGE in Washington is expected to decide shortly whether Marc Belzberg and a company he controls, the First Cities Financial Corporation, failed illegally to disclose ownership of stock in a company they sought to take over.

title: QUIPP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Discussions Of Phone Bid Were Taped
description: An employee of the General Services Administration made tape recordings of phone conversations in which an official of a regional Bell phone company told the employee that a G.S.A. official had leaked secret bid information about Government phone contracts.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
FOR BETTER LIVING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Briefing; Catching a Spy
description: It wasn't exactly a case of setting a spy to catch a spy, but in his about-to-be-published autobiography, Stanislav Levchenko, a former KGB officer, discloses that the Justice Department employed him as a consultant in its prosecution two years ago of Jerry Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman who was later convicted of passing highly classified military information to the Soviet Union.

title: O'BRIEN ENERGY SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said unearned advances received from HBO by Mercury-Douglas Films, the company's feature production partnership with entities controlled by Michael Douglas, are recognized as revenue in accordance with the percentage of completion method of accounting. The company said implementation of this method will require it to restate results for the second and third quarters of it's year ended Nov. 30, 1987.

title: Inquiries Put Assembly Races on L.I. in the Spotlight
description: Like the Iowa caucuses, Tuesday's special election on Long Island has been subjected to a degree of attention far out of proportion to the few thousand ballots likely to be cast for three State Assembly seats.

title: Rangers' Patrick To Miss 3 Weeks
description: Phil Esposito, his graying hair splayed wildly, his growing stomach somehow restrained beneath a uniform, backed into the low slot. He turned, twisted, got his stick on the puck and lifted it high into Bob Froese's goal.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Ferry Leads Duke Past North Carolina
description: For almost 35 minutes, Duke and North Carolina battled to a virtual draw in the final of the Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament today. Then Danny Ferry, the Duke forward who is the league's player of the year, and the Blue Devils' suffocating defense seized control, giving Duke a 65-61 victory, its second league title in the last three seasons. Ferry was the most valuable player in the tourney.

title: Metro Matters; Does a Charter Affect the Public? Yes, No, Maybe
description: A chance confrontation between Mayor Koch and Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, provided an intriguing parable about changing the City Charter.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Is Found Dead On Railroad Tracks
description: A Somerville man apparently hit by a late-night train was found dead on the tracks, the authorities said.

title: DURAMED PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EMPI INC reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENVIRONMENTAL POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Democrats Seek to Seize Initiative on Drug Issue
description: With the fall elections less than eight months away, Democrats on Capitol Hill are trying to seize the initiative on the drug issue, which has been identified for years with President Reagan and his wife, Nancy.

title: Guetterman Wants to Start
description: The pitcher says one thing; the manager says another. The pitcher believes he has done enough to warrant consideration as a starter; the manager thinks that middle relief may be the right place.

title: Small Movements for Bond Yields
description: While economic statistics have moved from signs of strength to weakness like a playground seesaw, investors and traders have been content to stand by idly and watch bond yields move in a very narrow range.

title: New York Stumbles Into the Pension Pit
description: Pushed by government employee unions, New York State and its local governments are stumbling into fiscal danger. The Legislature and Governor Cuomo are going along with a new pension supplementation bill that not only helps older, needy retirees but extends its largesse to younger ones who do not need it.

title: St. Lawrence Draws Praise
description: After St. Lawrence smothered Clarkson to win the 27th ECAC Hockey tournament at the Boston Garden Saturday night, Scotty Whitelaw paid the Saints a compliment.

title: RB&W CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and the quarter is after a charge of $60,000 from a reversal of a tax credit.

title: Review/Music; Cabaret Singers Recall The Style of Cole Porter
description: The packed and ecstatic 12-hour Cole Porter celebration at Symphony Space on Saturday held a little bit of pleasure for almost everybody. Mr. Porter, who moved pop songs to a more sophisticated musical and emotional level, was represented by a flock of cabaret singers, Porter experts reminiscing, celluloid memories (by which Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers made an appearance), Bobby Short and an orchestra playing original scores from Porter's early Broadway plays. Oddly, the jazz world, which has done so much to popularize Porter's compositions internationally, wasn't represented.

title: THE FITNESS CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest 6 months included provisions for a loss on disposition of assets of $263,262. The period also included conditional provisions for non-recurring professional and equipment lease payments and a facility lease cancellation charge totaling $205,000.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
RESORTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $4.3 million for the quarter and $6.6 million for the year. c-Net loss and the quarter is after a charge of $5.2 million from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward.

title: Cultures Blend and Shake in Miami Conga Line
description: When tens of thousands of Miamians formed the world's longest conga line this afternoon, the symbolism of the act transcended the stated goal: entering the Guinness Book of Records.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about Mediterranean food misidentified a restaurant. It is the Medhattan Cafe at Third Avenue and 81st Street, not the Manhattan Cafe.

title: Litton Chief Expected To Add Chairman Post
description: Orion L. Hoch, a physicist and electrical engineer who left Litton Industries to revive an ailing semiconductor company, is expected to be elected Litton's chairman on March 31.

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Remains of Mengele Rest Uneasily in Brazil
description: A quiet institution in the heart of Sao Paulo is troubled by a skeleton in its closet, that of Josef Mengele, the Nazi extermination camp doctor.

title: NASA Plans New Site To Build Shuttle Rocket
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is to announce in two weeks a plan to build a new facility to make booster rockets for the space shuttle in the 1990's, as part of a plan that could give the Government a far larger role in the fabrication of the rockets.

title: Review/Opera; U.S.-Soviet Portrayal Of Gogol's 'Dead Souls'
description: Novels help us see, like eyeglasses through which people and places are made clearer. Opera has weaker vision. It thrives on caricature, making its subjects bigger, grander, even nobler, while not necessarily observing the specifics of their nature.

title: Hard Training Can Counteract Effects of Aging
description: FIFTEEN years after runners took their first baby steps toward improved health and fitness, the running movement is on the brink of catching a compelling second wind. Runners over 40, average joggers and top-notch competitors are discovering new opportunities in the masters age group, and learning that as midlife athletes they are able to repel the limitations associated with growing older.

title: Directors Guild Honors Bertolucci for 'Emperor'
description: Bernardo Bertolucci became the front-runner for the director's Oscar when he won the Directors Guild of America award for his opulent epic, ''The Last Emperor,'' on Saturday night.

title: Biden Enters Hospital Over Possibility of Clot
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., who underwent brain surgery a month ago to repair an aneurysm, checked into Walter Reed Army Medical Center tonight so doctors could see if he is suffering from a blood clot in his leg, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Nina L. Leon Is Wed To Michael E. Olney
description: Nina L. Leon, an assistant treasurer and financial data analyst at J. P. Morgan & Company, and Michael E. Olney, a lawyer for Merrill Lynch & Company, were married yesterday at Temple Gates of Prayer in Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Gerald Skolnick officiated.

title: 2 Kohl-Gorbachev Meetings
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will visit Moscow this autumn and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will travel to Bonn in the first half of next year, West Germany and the Soviet Union said today, confirming a thaw in relations.

title: Why Protect Uranium?
description: The American uranium industry has a big problem. Sales are far below figures projected in the 1970's because nuclear power development has stalled. What's more, a growing share of future demand is likely to be filled by lower-cost Canadian and Australian producers.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INSIDE
description: A Noriega Asylum Offer Spain offers asylum with conditions to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military ruler. Page A3. Setback for Texas Bank Creditors balked at a plan to rescue Houston's First City Bancorporation, but depositors would be protected even if it fails. Page D1. Middle Road in Judaism Conservative Jews have issued their first statement of principles in 143 years, steering a course between tradition and modernism. Page A14.

title: Don't Cast a Giant Shadow Over the Battery
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; The Division of a Family and of Its Fortune
description: House of Dreams The Bingham Family of Louisville By Marie Brenner Illustrated. 452 pages. Random House. $19.95.

title: Harrison D. Horblit, Textile Executive, 75
description: Harrison D. Horblit, a former textile executive, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: P.S.A.L. Playoffs; Stevenson to Meet Lincoln in Final
description: There was as much intensity, talent, pride, desire and good basketball in yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League semifinals as there was in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship game Saturday night. But there was a world of difference in the way the games were showcased.

title: Advertising; Low-Keyed Fragrance Ads on TV
description: HOW novel it will be to see television commercials for a fragrance that are neither suggestive nor bizarre but instead show ordinary attractive women in recognizable life situations.

title: U.S. to Push Marketing in Moscow
description: Stalwarts of American business have agreed to a Soviet request to give marketing pointers to Soviet managers of newly restructured ministries, foreign-trade organizations and state enterprises, American officials reported today.

title: Minimal Treasury Auctions This Week
description: The only Treasury financings scheduled this week are today's auctions of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $630,264 from the sale of a pipeline for the latest quarter; the year-ago quarter includes a pre-tax loss of $65,583 for start-up costs of various acquisitions.

title: 3 Shows Look at Role Of Jews in Soviet Culture
description: The role Jews have played in the cultural history of the Soviet Union is the subject of exhbitions of paintings and photographs at the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Henry Steven Florsheim Weds Doe Cohn in Omaha
description: The marriage of Doris Marie Cohn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Cohn of Omaha, to Henry Steven Florsheim, the executive producer of ''Eyewitness News'' at WABC-TV in New York, took place yesterday at Temple Israel in Omaha. Rabbi Sidney H. Brooks officated.

title: Spain's Banks Seek Efficiency
description: For Spain's Socialist Government and business leaders the problem is clear: There are too many banks employing too many people.

title: Canada Jobless Rate Dip
description: Canada's jobless rate fell below 8 percent in February, the Government reported Friday, providing further indication that the nation's economy is growing rapidly.

title: Sindelar Birdies His Way To Title
description: Joey Sindelar birdied three holes on the back nine today and made it into the clubhouse just before total darkness early this evening to win the $700,000 Honda Classic by two shots over three others.

title: Bookstore Behemoths Trade Quips
description: With nearly 2,000 stores in their two chains, Waldenbooks and B. Dalton are the undisputed behemoths of books. While each chain has undoubtedly felt the hot breath of the other on its neck, outwardly, at least, they have generally treated each other with studied indifference. Recently, however, their competition has taken on a dimension that is anything but bookish, causing amusement among publishers.

title: Knicks Make Roster Changes
description: The Knicks signed Cedric Toney, a 6-foot-2-inch point guard, and placed Pat Cummings on the injured list yesterday with a sprained right ankle.

title: NATIONAL INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PHP HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-After tax credits of $164,000 for the quarter and $311,000 for the 9 months.

title: French Satellite Enters Orbit
description: A French telecommunications satellite launched by a West European Ariane rocket on Friday was moved into its prearranged orbit around the earth today, the Government said.

title: Where the Political Vista Is Not of the White House
description: ''Gore?'' the hard hat asked, working on his shot of whisky and his short beer. ''You mean Dore, the Republican?''

title: Burma Rebels Find a Cause In Autonomy
description: From all the remote and exotic corners of Burma, the leaders of nine ethnic minorities at war with the Rangoon Government came here this weekend to plead publicly for international help against Southeast Asia's most durable dictator.

title: Robbery Suspect Towed by Police
description: A man who said he had AIDS and threatened to bite the police officers who arrested him for robbery in mid-Manhattan yesterday was placed alone in a patrol car and towed to a police station, the authorities said.

title: VOICEMAIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Rob-ert D. McFarlanes's plea of guilty ot four misdemeanor counts of with-holding information about the Nicaraguan rebels from Congress characterized his plea incorrectly in one paragraph and a later passage. The charges to which Mr. McFarlane, a former national security adviser, pleaded guilty said that he had withheld material information, but they did not charge that he made false statements.

title: Curbing the Sexploitation Industry
description: I can't even count the times in the last three years, since I began to express my concern about violence and sexuality in rock music, that I have been called a prude, a censor, a music hater, even a book burner. So let me be perfectly clear: I detest censorship. I'm not advocating censorship but rather a candid and vigorous debate about the dangers posed for our children by what I call the ''exploitation industry.''

title: Stringing In a New Direction
description: When Madeline Hauptman was a graduate student in mathematics at the University of Pennsylvania, she was taught to examine the way objects are made. She looked at her tennis racquet and wondered why the strings were in a horizontal and vertical weave. The snowshoes on the wall in her apartment were strung in a third, diagonal direction.

description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $232,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Includes a $31,000 tax benefit.

title: Gary M. Baker Married To Deborah Beth Siegel
description: Deborah Beth Siegel, a daughter of Edythe Siegel of Stamford, Conn., and the late Herman Max Siegel, was married yesterday to Gary Mitchell Baker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Baker of New York. Rabbis Elan Adler and Gedalya Glatt officiated at Congregation Agudath Sholom in Stamford.

title: SIGNAL APPAREL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the 1986 figures reflect a change in the method of accounting for pension costs.

title: Lotfi Mansouri to Direct San Francisco Opera
description: The board of the San Francisco Opera has announced that Lotfi Mansouri, the head of the Canadian Opera in Toronto, has accepted the job of general director of the opera here.

title: 2 Worlds Coexist, Warily, in a Prison Town
description: This is a prison town. The prison came first.

title: PARADISE FRUIT CO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Donors Describe Raising Money For Campaigns
description: Some of New York City's major campaign contributors - the faces behind the dollars - gave a rare glimpse under oath yesterday of why they donate, the pressure they receive from politicians, the ''loans'' that are not repaid and how they make end runs around state campaign-financing limits.

title: US FACILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Television; 2 Series Put the Less Prominent in Prime Time
description: Hispanic people and the elderly, not among the more overexposed groups on prime-time television, are suddenly popping up in two weekly series making their debuts on CBS this evening. ''Trial and Error,'' at 8 o'clock, is about two Mexican-American roommates in Los Angeles. ''Coming of Age,'' at 9, offers a former airline pilot and his wife, still only 60ish, who decide to move to a retirement community in Arizona. First returns indicate the retired folks may have more prime-time staying power than the Latinos.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 29
description: b-Reflects a decrease in net of $43,741,076, or 78 cents a share, resulting from the December 1986 provision for the coal mining operations refund.

title: CHARTER ONE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $569,000 and $2,337,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a charge of $1,492,000 from early retirement of FHLB advances. c-Includes tax credits of $236,000 for the quarter and $1,040,000 for the year, and the year also includes a charge of $722,000 from early retirement of FHLB advances.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Show me a country without nationalist problems, and I will move there right away.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev [ A1:1. ]

title: Yankee Rookie Shows Promise
description: The home run that Jay Buhner hit against the Expos Sunday afternoon in West Palm Beach seemed to carry into the clouds. It finally settled over the fence in center field, well beyond the 400-foot marker and well past the shrubs that border the chain-link fence. It was the kind of home run that big-league ballplayers glow about in the clubhouse when their work is done.

title: Not Only Heidegger
description: To the Editor:

title: Firestone Doubtful on Bridgestone
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said tonight that it did not expect to complete its agreement to sell most of its tire operations to the Bridgestone Corporation because of the unsolicited $1.8 billion buyout offer from the Pirelli Group.

title: A Greenspan's Choice
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board has offered Congress what might be called a ''Greenspan's choice'' for reducing the budget deficit: Raise taxes or reduce spending on entitlement programs like Social Security.

title: CONSOLIDATED HYDRO reports earnings for
description: b-After a non-recurring charge of $420,000 primarily related to the writeoff of expenses associated with the company's withdrawal of its proposed convertible exchangeable preferred stock offering.

title: Hugh Wolfe Frank, Nuremberg Interpreter, 75
description: Hugh Wolfe Frank, chief interpreter at the Nuremberg war crimes trials, was found dead Thursday, the police said. He was 75 years old.

title: Review/Film; 'Big Parade,' Celebration By the Chinese Military
description: From the impressive overhead shots of troops assembling for a march-past in Beijing's huge central square on the 35th anniversary of the People's Republic of China, in October 1984, to the final slow-motion close-ups of them parading, the camera of Zhang Yimou commands ''The Big Parade.'' The Chinese movie, directed by Chen Kaige and on view tonight at 6 o'clock and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films festival, holds you by its photography even as you may be getting a bit restless at the Chinese version of the good old American boot-camp movie.

title: William McFarlane, Disk Jockey, 26
description: William (Spanky) McFarlane, a disk jockey at WHTZ radio (Z-100) in New York City, died Thursday at Kings Highway Hospital in Brooklyn of cardiac arrest. He was 26 years old.

title: Film Company Set By United Artists
description: United Artists Communications Inc., which operates movie theaters and a cable television company, has formed Corsair Pictures, a New York based company. ''Corsair will finance modestly budgeted, independently made films,'' said Frank Perry, who will head the company.

title: Bush Bests Democrats in Polls
description: Vice President Bush holds big leads over the Rev. Jesse Jackson or Albert Gore Jr. but only a narrow edge over Michael S. Dukakis in possible general election matchups, according to polls conducted for Time and Newsweek magazines.

title: Top U.S. Target In Heroin Trade Seized at Hotel
description: Federal agents, using a ruse to lure him to the United States, have arrested a fugitive Chinese businessmen described as the Drug Enforcement Administration's most-wanted heroin trafficker.

title: Corrections
description: The New York Stock Exchange table in Business Day on Friday reported an inaccurate price for the Minnesota Power and Light Company. The company's stock sold for $24.125 at the close of trading Thursday, unchanged for the day.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL POWER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knicks Struggle to Score Victory
description: The Knicks' halftime statistics looked like a mess last night. Mark Jackson was shooting 1 for 8 from the field, Patrick Ewing was 2 for 10 and the Knicks as a team were shooting 33 percent. As they left the floor trailing, 56-41, the Madison Square Garden crowd, which has become accustomed to seeing them win at home, booed them loudly.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Feb 29
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: RUDY'S RESTAURANT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
