title: Judge Can Hear a Suit in Spite of Her Husband's Indictment
description: A New York State judge whose husband was indicted after an investigation initiated by lawyers for New York City can preside over a negligence case in which the city is a defendant, the Appellate Division has ruled.

title: Rodino Says He Will Retire In January
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee since 1973, yesterday announced his intention to retire from Congress in January after 40 years.

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Concessions Are Hinted In First City's Rescue
description: A. Robert Abboud indicated yesterday that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the investor group that he heads might make concessions to creditors of the First City Bancorporation of Houston to save a $1.47 billion rescue plan for the deeply troubled banking company.

title: Fashion; Patterns
description: Old Company, New Look

title: FIRST REGIONAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: Proposal to Eliminate the Board of Estimate Is Said to Gain
description: The chairman, secretary and staff of the Charter Revision Commission favor a proposal for overhauling New York City's government that would abolish the Board of Estimate and redistribute its vast powers, according to several Commission members and elected officials.

title: Searle Documents Unsealed; Early IUD Worry Is Implied
description: A Federal district judge has unsealed several hundred internal documents from G. D. Searle & Company suggesting that the company had safety concerns about its Copper-7 contraceptive device even before it went on the market in 1974.

title: Reagan to Seek New Contra Aid Vote This Week
description: President Reagan said today that he will seek a vote this week on a new contra aid package and expressed irritation with intelligence assessments that the Nicaraguan rebels are within weeks of extinction as a result of a congressional cutoff of American assistance.

title: Repaired State Plane Again Forced to Land
description: An aging state airplane that recently was refurbished at a cost of $628,000 malfunctioned again today, this time as it carried New York Assembly Speaker Mel Miller on a flight from New York City to Albany.

title: CONTINENTAL GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings have been omitted since the capitalization of the company in prior periods was not comparable.

title: Market Place; Year-End in Japan Could Affect U.S.
description: AN accounting deadline halfway around the globe could put added pressure on financial markets in the United States in coming weeks.

title: COOPER LASERSONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $786,000 for the latest quarter and $428,000 for the year- earlier period, and the latest quarter also includes a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $2,216,000.

title: Savings and Loan Shut
description: Federal regulators closed the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Paducah, Ky., today and transferred its insured deposits to the Security Trust Federal Savings and Loan Association in Oak Ridge, Tenn. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it closed First Federal because it was insolvent and had liabilities of $167.9 million and assets of $130 million. The institution's problems were attributed to high-risk loans, many of which were in the Houston area.

title: Scientists to Seek 'Shadow Bands' During a Total Eclipse of the Sun
description: AS a total eclipse of the sun sweeps across the Pacific Ocean Saturday, astronomers aboard two cruise ships will try to record images of ''shadow bands,'' a phenomenon that has often been reported during eclipses but never photographed.

title: Redmen's Foes Got Them In
description: When St. John's squandered an 8-point lead against Villanova last Friday and lost in the quarterfinal round of the Big East tournament, it seemed likely that the Redmen were headed for the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Mowers Replace Feed Grain in New Suburb
description: Not so long ago, Poor Richard's Book Shop on Route 202 did a brisk business in romances and books on gardening and farming, crocheting and knitting. Few customers paid attention to the best-seller list.

title: A Vietnam Veteran Who Said He'd Kill Again Is Executed
description: Wayne Robert Felde, who had pleaded with a jury to sentence him to death to keep him from killing again, was executed in the electric chair early today for the 1978 slaying of a rookie policeman.

title: In Sri Lanka, Fears That the Worst Isn't Over
description: Eleven villagers were reported killed today in the latest flare-up of tit-for-tat attacks that have raised fears of a resurgence of ethnic violence here.

title: DOCKERS ON STRIKE IN PANAMA PORTS, SEEKING BACK PAY
description: Dock workers at Panama's three major commercial ports went on strike today after the cash-starved Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega failed to pay them, and the police fired tear gas at hundreds of teachers who had gathered at the Ministry of Education to demand wages due them.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $11,250,000 for the quarter and $15,200,000 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $550,000 from debt retirement. c-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $750,000 and $1,350,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary charges from debt retirement of $125,000 for the quarter and $8,000,000 for the year. The company said declined in the market value of the company's investment portfolio and the discontinuance of its commercial curtain wall operations were major contributing factors to the company's 1987 loss. The company also said realized and unrealized losses on investment securities in 1987 were $23.3 million, compared with a net gain of $18.9 million in the prior year.

title: Studies Document Allergies Both Dangerous and Rare
description: Deer can make hunters sneeze, cockroaches often prompt asthmatics to wheeze and exercise can send joggers into shock, according to researchers who study little-known but potentially deadly allergies.

title: Pickens Withdraws Offer for Homestake
description: The Mesa Limited Partnership's second foray into the gold mining industry ended today when the concern, controlled by the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, withdrew its $1.9 billion offer for the Homestake Mining Company.

title: Ply-Gem Sets Pact
description: Ply-Gem Industries has agreed to acquire Wolverine Technologies Inc. for $60.8 million. Ply-Gem, a New York-based maker of home improvement products, will pay $18.50 a share for the almost 3.3 million shares of common stock in Wolverine, which manufactures vinyl siding and windows. Ply-Gem, had revenues of $313 million in 1987, while Wolverine reported revenues of $111 million.

title: CBS Drops Outspoken News Official
description: Several members of the CBS News political team gathered last weekend for a farewell dinner, one they hadn't expected so soon, this being only the middle of the Presidential campaign.

title: F-16 Crash Kills Norwegian
description: An American-made F-16 jet crashed into a mountain today in northern Norway during an eight-nation NATO exercise, killing the Norwegian pilot, according to the Allied Press Information Center. The cause of the crash was not known.

title: Citicorp Note Yield Is 8.15%
description: An offering of $250 million of three-year senior notes from Citicorp was priced yesterday at 99.932 to yield 8.15 percent, 75 basis points over the yield on three-year Treasury notes. The notes, which mature

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Our Towns; Meals on Wheels And a Side Order Of Devotion
description: When Mabel Gates and Hilton Wilson are delivering for Meals on Wheels, they're not kidding around. ''We're very fast,'' said Mrs. Gates. ''We get here early, we leave early, and we're good deliverers.''

title: More Teen-Agers Take Their Babies to School
description: If a 13-year-old girl with an 8-month-old daughter can be considered lucky, Angela Lopez may qualify.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it has more than $200 million in tax credits which can be used to reduce future tax liabilities. The company said that more than 40 percent of the latest quarter loss was due to reserves established and charges taken related to reducing significantly the cost of business, modifying the company's distribution system and contracting certain product lines to assure greater operating efficiency in 1988.

title: South African Assails Key Angola Peace Proposal
description: The Reagan Administration's seven-year effort to forge a peace settlement in southern Africa ran into new obstacles here today when a South African official called a key proposal vague and lacking in detail.

title: TRANS WORLD MUSIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Desert Partners
description: A partnership led by the Texas oilmen Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown is soliciting proxies to elect six nominees to the USG Corporation's 15-member board. Desert Partners L.P. is seeking to gain control of the nation's largest gypsum producer. USG's directors will be elected at the Chicago-based company's annual meeting on May 11. The partnership's offer of $42 a share 21.5 million shares, or about 41 percent of the company, expires on March 28.

title: Joseph J. Roberto, Architect, 79
description: Joseph J. Roberto, a former architect for New York University, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: Political Marketing; Rivals' Ads Take a Friendlier Tone in Illinois Race
description: After the bloody advertising battles of earlier contests, the electronic hawking of Presidential candidates for the Illinois primaries has taken on a decidedly friendlier tone.

title: FIRST CAPITAL HOLDINGS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said it adopted FASB No. 96 and No. 97 in 1987; results for 1986 have been restated to reflect the adoptions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Panama dock workers went on strike after the cash-starved Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega failed to pay them, and the police fired tear gas at hundreds of teachers who had gathered at the Ministry of Education demanding wages. Page A1

title: Whirlpool Opposes G.E.-Roper Talks
description: The Whirlpool Corporation has continued to oppose a meeting between the Roper Corporation, the appliance manufacturer that has accepted its acquisition offer of $37.50 a share, and the General Electric Company, which has since offered a counterbid of $45 a share. According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last week, Roper asked to meet with G.E., which said any exchange of information could occur only after Whirlpool consented in writing.

title: Lilly Oraflex Fund Urged
description: Some 100 members of Britain's Parliament took the unusual step today of asking Eli Lilly & Company, the United States drug concern, to create a trust fund to pay British claims for injuries tied to Oraflex, the company's arthritis treatment.

title: Chrysler Unit's Auto Loans Back $753 Million Offering
description: In one of the largest offerings of asset-backed debt sales of the year, the Chrysler Financial Corporation yesterday offered $753 million of debt securities backed by car loans through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Regan Criticizes Cuomo's Budget As Overly Rosy
description: The New York State Comptroller said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget was based on an overly optimistic economic forecast and could result in a shortfall of up to $800 million.

title: Gorbachev Puts Blame for Strife On Predecessors
description: Arriving in a nation that has long experienced intense ethnic friction, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today attributed the strife in the southern Soviet republics to years of neglect by earlier Soviet leaders.

title: A Neglected Civilization Gets Its Due in Venice
description: The Palazzo Grassi museum has opened what it calls the largest exhibition ever dedicated to the Phoenicians, presenting these ancient people as a remarkable civilization that embraced the Mediterranean's varied cultural currents.

title: Gaza Strip Under Curfew
description: Israel imposed a nightly curfew on the entire Gaza Strip after the resignation of hundreds of Palestinian policemen there. Page A6.

title: Bonds Mark Time on a Quiet Day
description: Bond prices were little changed in dull, trackless trading yesterday.

title: Effort Disclosed to Improve Armor on Tank
description: The Army disclosed today that under a classified program to improve the armor of its main battle tank, the M-1A1 Abrams, it was starting to build the tank with depleted uranium in the armor plating.

title: Panama Canal's Fragile Prospects
description: Since 1914, the Panama Canal has been one of the main arteries of international trade, providing cheap and efficient service to shippers. But basic questions have emerged about the canal's role in the future, quite apart from the political crisis that has rocked Panama since last June.

title: Biaggi Lawyer Cites Wedtech Corruption
description: The defense attorney for Representative Mario Biaggi said yesterday that the Wedtech Corporation ''corrupted an entire Administration,'' paying for the influence of Washington officials with direct links to President Reagan and those who awarded military contracts to the South Bronx company.

title: Fromme Is Guilty of Escape
description: A Federal court jury today found Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life sentence for trying to assassinate President Ford in 1975, guilty of escape. She had pleaded not guilty but, acting as her own lawyer, she said in her summation, ''I'm guilty as charged.'' Miss Fromme, 39 years old, a disciple of the mass murderer Charles Manson, escaped Dec. 23 from the Federal prison at Alderson, and was captured nearby two days later.

title: Genetic Engineers Prepare to Create Brand New Proteins
description: WITH the first products of genetic engineering starting to reach the marketplace, scientists are now preparing for what is expected to be the next big step in the biotechnology revolution: the creation of complex new compounds that are custom-designed to meet human needs.

title: Macy Increases Cash Part of Offer
description: R. H. Macy & Company yesterday increased the cash front end of its takeover offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. by $200 million, to $77.35 a share, from $74.50 for 80 percent of Federated's stock.

title: Review/Dance; Plan K's Belgian Experimentalism
description: A lot of money seems to have gone into ''If Pyramids Were Square,'' presented by Plan K, the Belgian experimentalist theater group, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday.

title: Lead Underwriters For V.A. Loan Sale
description: Salomon Brothers and the First Boston Corporation were named co-lead managing underwriters for a proposed sale of home loans by the Veterans Administration later this year.

title: Bridge; Four Surviving Teams in a Key New York Tourney Are to Fight For National Playoff Rights
description: Four teams survive in the New York Grand National Team Championships and will compete April 27 and 28 for the right to advance to playoffs at the national level. The pairing by captains will be: Jim Becker, Manhattan, vs. David Berkowitz, Old Tappan, N.J.; Alan Sontag, Manhattan, vs. Ira Ewen, Brooklyn.

title: Martin H. Smith, 50, Dean of Music School
description: Martin H. Smith, a pianist and the dean of faculty and students at the Manhattan School of Music, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Friday at Harlem Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 18 Are Arrested By Task Force On Its First Day
description: The New York City Police Department's new 118-member Tactical Narcotics Team took to the streets of South Jamaica, Queens, for the first time yesterday, and by evening had made 18 arrests in a buy-and-bust operation in an expanded 1.6-square-mile section.

title: MOORE MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a net physical inventory adjustment of $400,000, or 14 cents a share, arising from problems with modifications made in early 1987 to the company's computerized inventory system.

title: General Signal To Buy GCA
description: The General Signal Corporation has agreed to acquire the GCA Corporation, the troubled manufacturer of equipment used to make semiconductors, for between $75 million and $80 million. General Signal, a big electronics concern, said it would pay off GCA's debts and swap a fraction of its shares for each of GCA's nearly 9.5 million outstanding common shares.

title: Brewers Switch
description: Tom Trebelhorn, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, officially announced today that Paul Molitor and Jim Gantner would switch positions.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results include operations of acquired companies from their effective dates of acquisition; Cherokee International Inc., acquired Nov. 1, 1986; Pasar Inc., acquired Dec. 1, 1986; and Flexstar Inc., acquired Oct. 1, 1986.

title: MERCURY ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
Mexican Sailors Arrested in U.S.
description: Four Mexican military men armed with automatic rifles were arrested in the United States after they were spotted on a beach questioning picnickers.

title: Pakistan Avalanche Kills 24
description: An avalanche struck a remote village in northern Pakistan, killing 24 people, the official press agency said today. The agency said the avalanche hit Korak in the Pakistani portion of the Himalayan state of Kashmir on Friday night.

title: Protest That Turned Campus for the Deaf Around
description: The United States has seen its full share of campus protests, particularly over the last 25 years.

title: WORLDWIDE COMPUTER SERVCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Bold, New Stroke In the Racquet War
description: One of the great pleasures in the world of sport is the feeling in the pit of a batter's stomach at the moment he hits a high, hard one exactly right. There is a similar visceral echo when a golf swing really clicks, and tennis players experience it when they connect with perfect ground strokes, sending shock waves of satisfaction through their bodies.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Centel Corp., Chicago, has reached an agreement to acquire the majority interest in seven cellular mobile communications systems in four states from United Telespectrum Inc.

title: Grolier's Chief Faces Flurry of Merger Talk
description: Robert B. Clarke brought a failing Grolier Inc. back to financial health, and now that the encyclopedia company is in good shape, he has a new concern - heavy takeover interest.

title: Global Defeat of Polio Is Feasible, Experts Say
description: A campaign to eradicate polio, which remains a crippler and killer in many developing countries, gained new impetus this weekend at a global meeting on child health.

title: Military Has Plans for Space Station
description: The Defense Department has several experiments it would like to conduct on board a small, no-frills private space station, a major part of which the the Government has agreed to lease. The small station is scheduled to be carried aloft by the space shuttle in the early 1990's.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.M.E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., a supplier of videotape post-production services, elected Gary Costanzo executive vice president, administration, and Martin Katz chief financial officer.

title: Advertising; Meredith Is Planning To Acquire Craftways
description: The Meredith Corporation, a multi-media communications conglomerate whose flagship publication is Better Homes and Gardens, has announced its intention to acquire the Craftways Corporation of Richmond, Calif.

title: Guatemala Better Off Than Its Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A drawing with the Fitness column of SportsMonday this week depicted the Pelvic Tilt incorrectly. The excercise is done this way: Lying on the back, bend the knees, with feet flat on the floor and hands at sides. Press the small of the back against the floor.

title: Salary Lineups
description: The 1988 salaries of the Mets and the Yankees, including some players who will be on the disabled list or in the minor leagues when the season begins. Asterisks indicate players who will have different salaries if they play in the minor leagues. $ METS YANKEES Gary Carter $2,198,572 Don Mattingly $2,000,000 Keith Hernandez 1,850,000 Dave Winfield 1,958,652 Dwight Gooden 1,400,000 Rickey Henderson 1,770,000 Darryl Strawberry 1,320,000 Jack Clark 1,500,000 Ron Darling 1,000,000 Dave Righetti 1,300,000 Kevin McReynolds 975,000 Rick Rhoden 900,000 Mookie Wilson 900,000 Willie Randolph 875,000 Bob Ojeda 725,000 Richard Dotson 850,000 Howard Johnson 695,000 Ron Guidry 825,000 Wally Backman 650,000 John Candelaria 700,000 Roger McDowell 615,000 Tim Stoddard 650,000 Sid Fernandez 580,000 Gary Ward 625,000 Tim Teufel 537,500 Don Slaught 531,500 Lee Mazzilli 350,000 Mike Pagliarulo 500,000 Len Dykstra 305,000 Claudell Washington 480,000 Rick Aguilera 295,000 Charles Hudson 450,000 Bill Almon 250,000 Rafael Santana 425,000 Terry Leach 190,000 Wayne Tolleson 410,000 Dave Magadan 112,500 Cecilio Guante 380,000 Gene Walter* 111,600 Tommy John 375,000 Randy Myers 108,000 Jose Cruz 350,000 David Cone* 92,500 Rick Cerone 300,000 Barry Lyons* 90,000 Jerry Royster 275,000 John Gibbons* 75,000 Neil Allen 250,000 Phil Lombardi* 72,000 Bobby Meacham 212,500 Keith Miller* 70,000 Pat Clements 205,000 Kevin Elster* 69,000 Pete Filson 150,000 Gregg Jefferies* 62,500 Lee Guetterman 137,500 Jack Savage* 62,500 Joel Skinner* 110,000 Steve Frey* 62,500 Steve Shields* 110,000 Mike Kinnunen* 70,000 Al Leiter* 67,000 Roberto Kelly* 67,000 Jay Buhner* 67,000

title: UNION EXPERIMENT PROVOKES A FIGHT
description: An experiment in changing seniority rules at a General Motors plant here has degenerated into bitterness and recriminations, pitting young workers against older colleagues.

title: Joseph Sylvester, Former Jockey, 77
description: Joseph Sylvester, who rode seven winning horses on an eight-race card at Ravenna (Ohio) Race Track on Oct. 18, 1930, died of heart failure Saturday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid Feb. 22.

title: The Election Process; Old-Style Convention Prescribed by Minow
description: None of the Presidential candidates, says Newton N. Minow, ''utters a word that lifts your heart, and the system we're using to choose among them is a serious mistake that's steadily getting worse.''

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a loss of $220,000 for the quarter and a gain of $386,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations, and a gain of $1,999,000 from disposition of Medical Supply Co. for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $521,000 and $921,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Advertising; New York Post To Lois Pitts
description: Lois Pitts Gershon Pon/ GGK, which probably has as much experience in media advertising as any other general agency in New York, has received the account of the recently acquired New York Post.

title: AMCAST INDUSTRIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WESTERBEKE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a gain of $6.4 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Treaty On Ozone Is Backed In Senate
description: The Senate voted unanimously today to approve ratification of a historic international agreement to limit global use of chemicals that are believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield. The vote was 83 to 0. With today's vote, which had been expected, the United States became the first major user and producer of chlorofluorocarbons to approve an international agreement that would first freeze and then roll back their consumption and production.

title: City Steps Up Fight for $4 Million In Back Rent From Port Authority
description: Charging the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey with violating a contract and neglecting the New York side of the harbor, city officials yesterday took the first steps toward suing the agency for nearly $4 million.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter and 9 months include a charge of $201,839 from a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service on the company's taxes for fiscal 1980 through 1984.

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREHOUSE reports earnings for 16wks to Jan 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits from repayment of debt and tax credits of $3,484,000 for the 16 weeks and $3,661,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: PRESIDENT RESIGNS AT U. OF MINNESOTA
description: The president of the University of Minnesota has resigned amid controversy about the $1.5 million renovation of his official residence and the $200,000 renovation of his campus office.

title: Official Quits Shearson Post
description: The flight of senior investment bankers from large Wall Street firms continued yesterday with the resignation of Henry Lentz Jr. from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Charter Medical Price is Increased
description: The Charter Medical Corporation said that the price of a buyout offer by the WAF Acquisition Corporation had been increased. The price is now $30.25 in cash and $7 in principal amount of junior subordinated debentures due in the year 2000 for each share of Charter's class A and class B stocks. WAF's original offer had been for $28 in cash and $5 in debentures.

title: The Deficit: Still No. 1 Problem
description: President Reagan's budget, issued several weeks ago, projected a steadily declining Federal deficit, one that would fall to a mere $39 billion by 1993 even with no further spending cuts or tax increases. In effect, he is saying that the deficit problem has been solved, that we do not need a tax increase, that all we need now is the patience to let the medicine work.

title: French Satellite Enters Orbit
description: A French telecommunications satellite launched by a West European Ariane rocket on Friday was moved into its prearranged orbit around the earth Sunday, the Government said.

title: Chambers Judge Lists Ways Jury Could Vote to Convict
description: The judge in the trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. announced yesterday, over prosecution objections, that the jury would be allowed to consider a low-level felony alternative to the murder charges against Mr. Chambers when deliberations begin in the case.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $474,000 on land sale. The company noted that earnings for the latest 6-month benefitted by the lower effective income tax rates as provided by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

title: Yale to Test Fetal Tissue Use
description: Scientists at Yale University are planning to transplant brain cells from aborted fetuses into patients with Parkinson's Disease in an effort to find a treatment for the crippling disease.

title: A Barrier Is Overcome for Computer Speed
description: A TEAM of computer scientists has developed a new method of breaking down complex scientific problems into tiny pieces, letting an array of 1,024 separate processors compete with much more expensive supercomputers.

title: Careers; Need Grows For Physical Therapists
description: REPRESENTATIVES of 100 hospitals and health care organizations from many parts of the country met recently at New York University to talk about job openings with 250 seniors from such schools as Columbia University, Ithaca College, Russell Sage College and the University of Scranton who are about to become physical therapists.

title: American Standard Expects A Bid of $2.4 Billion or More
description: American Standard Inc. told a Federal district judge in an affidavit and by telephone yesterday that it expected to receive a bid for the company of at least $2.4 billion in cash by tomorrow, individuals close to the deal said last night.

title: Wear and Tear to Trucks
description: When truck drivers leave their diesel engines idling to keep the engines and fuel warm or to heat or cool the cab, they can be shortening the life of the truck engine by 6 to 12 months, according to a study by Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois.

title: Masters Describes Effort to Block AIDS Virus
description: Dr. William H. Masters, the human sexuality researcher and co-author of a new book asserting that AIDS poses a far greater threat to heterosexuals than most experts believe, said today that he had tried to raise funds to develop a product for enhancing spermicides' ability to kill the AIDS virus.

title: New Drug Dissolves Heart Clots, Saving Lives
description: A NEW drug has joined the ranks of clot-dissolving substances that can save the lives of many heart attack patients. In a British study, patients taking the drug Eminase after a heart attack were only about half as likely to die than patients who received a placebo, an inert substance. The findings were reported this week in the journal Lancet.

title: John L. Cotsworth, Executive, 73
description: John L. Cotsworth, retired president and chairman of the board of the Berry Steel Company of Edison, N.J., died of a heart attack March 7 while vacationing in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 4 from Hebron, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, incorrectly described the aftermath of riots there in 1929. Although dozens of Jews were killed or wounded in the riots, a Jewish community remained in Hebron until 1936, when further unrest prompted the British authorities to evacuate Jews from the city.

title: Erased Files Get New Life
description: YOU think you're saving that important file, but you accidentally erase it instead. If you haven't done this yet, you will. Woe, despair and anguish follow. Life loses its meaning, birds cease to sing, flowers wilt and children and pets seek hiding places.

title: Retain the Instant Replay
description: THE ball. Without it, a National Football League team can't score. If a bad call by an official deprives a team of the ball, that one call could affect the entire flow of the game, perhaps unjustly.

title: NATIONAL TRANSACTION NETORK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $127,229 from forgiveness of debt. The company had no revenue in 1986.

title: MEMORY SCIENCES reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Advertising; Ogilvy Turns Out Ads For Ford in U.S. Market
description: Although Ogilvy & Mather serves the Ford Motor Company in several countries abroad, the first advertising it has done for Ford in the United States is just beginning to appear in print and on TV.

title: New Program to Combat Child Abuse
description: Citing a recent sharp increase in reported child abuse and neglect in New York City and the nation, two private organizations announced a strategy yesterday to help police departments respond to the problem.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on the sale of investments of $887,000.

title: Colombian Voting Marred by Political Killings
description: Planned as a way of enticing leftist guerrillas to abandon decades of insurgency and accept the rules of democracy, Colombia's first municipal elections have instead been overshadowed by extremist violence and marked by abstentionism.

title: Airbus Charges U.S. Aids Rivals
description: Europe's Airbus consortium has begun a counteroffensive against United States charges that it is unfairly subsidized and is asserting that rival American aircraft makers get billions from Washington.

title: Pharmacy Concern And National Data
description: Medco Containment Services Inc., a mail-order pharmacy company based in Elmwood Park, N.J., said it had agreed to acquire the National Data Corporation, a financial services company based in Atlanta. Medco will issue 26.9 million new shares, to be exchanged at a 2.3-for-1 ratio, for the 11.7 million outstanding shares of National Data.

title: SHAMIR DECLARES GOAL OF UPRISING IS DEATH OF ISRAEL
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said tonight that the rioting by Palestinians in the occupied territories was not a demonstration of civil disobedience but a war, waged not merely against the Israeli occupation but ''against Israelis, against the existence of the State of Israel.''

title: The Endless Brawley Case
description: The case of Tawana Brawley has become a festering social wound. Without the alleged victim's cooperation, it may never be healed, but it can at least be treated, with an assiduous grand jury investigation. The public is entitled to justice, too, and to official closure of a case that has won national attention and continues to torment race relations.

title: With Clock Running Out for Reagan, Meese Is Football in Political Clashes
description: Last week, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary Committee about his department's budget for the coming year. Then the panel canceled the session, saying it conflicted with a heavy load of Presidential primaries.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,569,000 from a litigation award. The latest quarter and year includes interest income relating to litigation of $398,000 and $1,515,000, respectively. The year-ago quarter and year includes charges of $113,000 and $691,000, respectively, relating to litigation.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $10.9 million and $34.8 million for the quarter and year, respectively, and losses from early repayment of debt, legal fees and the cancellation of an employee stock plan of $31 million for the quarter and $40.8 million for the year. The company said the latest year is restated to reflect change in accounting rules.

title: New York City's Shameful Infant-Mortality Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COGNITIVE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the latest quarter and year losses include losses of $1,738,000 and $1,863,000, respectively, from unauthorized and fraudulent trading in speculative securities by the company's former chief financial officer.

title: Jordan Said to Prepare Response to U.S. Plan
description: Jordan has prepared a response to Secretary of State George P. Shultz's peace proposal and is seeking Syrian and Palestinian support for its position, according to senior Arab diplomats here.

title: Two Editorial Editors Shifting Posts at Times
description: Robert B. Semple Jr., editor of the Op-Ed page at The New York Times for the last six years, has been appointed associate editorial page editor, effective June 1. The appointment was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, the editorial page editor, who supervises both pages.

title: MAYS, J W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $424,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the quarter also includes a credit of $493,000 from leased termination at the company's Fishkill property. c-After a tax credit of $1,879,000 for both the quarter and 6 months, and the quarter also includes a gain of $4,307,180 for the sale of the company's leasehold of the Glenn Oaks store. Year-ago sales include sales in the Glenn Oaks store; the company discontinued operations in that unit Jan. 17, 1987. Sales also include leased departments.

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $60,500. c-Net loss

title: An Industry Where U.S. Prospers
description: Every hour here, 9 furnaces and 500 miles of pipe and tubing produce a half-million pounds of petrochemicals at one of the newest and largest such plants in the world. Cain Chemical Inc., which bought the 14-acre complex last year, only wishes it could make more.

title: Nets Test Lakers, for a Half
description: Byron Scott scored 21 points and Mychal Thompson added 10 of his 16 points in the fourth quarter tonight as the Los Angeles Lakers snapped a two-game losing streak with a 115-105 victory over the Nets.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Clyde Drexler of the Portland Trail Blazers was named the N.B.A. player of the week for the period ending Sunday. He averaged 28.7 points, 6.6 rebounds, 5.8 assists and 3 steals as the Blazers won all three of their games and extended their winning streak to eight games. . . . Coach Jimmy Johnson of the University of Miami, who led the Hurricanes to the national collegiate football championship last season, has agreed to a two-year contract extension through the 1992 season. His teams have a 41-8 record since 1984 and are 33-3 in the last three seasons. . . . Danny Manning of Kansas was named by The Associated Press to its all-America basketball team for the second consecutive year. He was joined by two other seniors, Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, the highest scoring Division I player in 11 years, and Gary Grant of Michigan. In addition, Sean Elliott, an Arizona junior, and J. R. Reid, a sophomore at North Carolina, were named. The team was selected by a panel of 20 sportswriters. . . . The Washington Redskins announced that their special teams' coach, Paul Lanham, will become a permanent member of the coaching staff. Lanham coached for the Redskins from 1973-1977, but left to coach for the Los Angeles Rams, where he stayed from 1978-1982. He also worked as a receivers' coach with the Detroit Lions in 1985.

title: 3 Held Hostage by Gunman In a Coin Laundry in Harlem
description: A gunman continued to hold three people hostage in the back room of a coin laundry in Harlem early this morning, apparently after a failed robbery attempt, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 15, 1988
description: The Economy

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL PRODUCTIONS - Named Mike Kostel director of baseball programming; Rich Domich director of special programming, and Tim Roberts director of operations. FOOTBALL WASHINGTON (NFC) - Announced that Paul Lanham, special teams' coach, will become a permanent member of the staff.

title: Rebels Raid Train in Uganda; At Least 5 People Are Killed
description: Rebels derailed and ransacked a passenger train, killing at least five people, a Government newspaper reported today.

title: Lawsuit Settled
description: A $2.3 million lawsuit against Cory Snyder, filed by a mother and daughter from Rochester, N.Y., has been settled out of court.

title: Review of Crash Data Is Planned
description: Two months after a Presidential task force issued recommendations on how to prevent another stock market crash, the White House is planning to form another group to draft its final, official position, White House aides said today.

title: Northeastern Captures Title
description: Northeastern beat Maine, the nation's top-ranked team, to win the Hockey East championship tonight, and the winning goal came from an unlikely hero.

title: Baseball Can't Settle on Rules
description: With the start of the baseball season three weeks away, the proposed rule changes involving balks and the strike zone remain in limbo. In the latest move in negotiations between the rules committee and the Players Association, the association has asked the committee to reconsider its rejection of the union's proposal that the new rules be implemented on a one-year trial basis.

title: Trade Bill Shift Is Asked
description: Senate conferees formally asked their House counterparts to drop the Gephardt amendment from the trade bill under discussion.

title: 3 Democrats Vie for Illinois Votes Today
description: Two homestate politicians, Senator Paul Simon and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, competed with a political outsider, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, for the ethnic and racial loyalties of Illinois Democrats in the final hours before Tuesday's Presidential primary.

title: Good Ways and Bad to Fight Drugs
description: T.N.T. and the death penalty: those are New York's reactions to the drug-related murder of a young police officer. T.N.T., short for a new police offensive, makes sense as long as it receives sustained official support. But the death penalty campaign perpetrates a fraud. Both responses apply in any city bedeviled by drugs.

title: John Holmes, 43, Dies; Was Star of Sex Films
description: John Holmes, who made hundreds of sexually explicit films during a career spanning two decades, died Saturday night at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Sepulveda, according to his manager, William Amerson. He was 43 years old and was reported to have had AIDS.

title: A Life Con Brio: Celebrating Cecil Beaton
description: They came to see Edith Sitwell receiving breakfast in a grandly canopied bed, Twiggy dancing on furniture, Johnny Weissmuller stretched seductively on sand in the briefest of loincloths, Elsa Maxwell in a ''social dictator'' crown, a 1941 fashion model posing in a bomb-damaged London building, Frederick Ashton in drag and an abundance of mirror reflections of Cecil Beaton - photographer of the famous and fashionable, designer and writer.

title: N.F.L. Sorts Out Its Hodgepodge
description: A new football, a new instant-replay gimmick, a new jacket and even a new city were offered to the National Football League's owners today as they opened their annual meetings.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,295,000.

title: Moon Watchers
description: The United States Naval Observatory is recruiting volunteers to gaze at the moon on July 14 in this country, Canada, the Caribbean and Central America. The aim is to help astronomers construct a model for lunar visibility predictions.

title: Review/Television; 'Tanner '88: For Real,' a Campaign
description: Jack Tanner campaigns again tonight. His television ads have paid off; the Presidential candidate created by Garry Trudeau and Robert Altman is now a contender. Moreover, he is assured of a Home Box Office series. Part two in the series, ''Tanner '88: For Real,'' will be shown on the pay-cable network at 10 o'clock.

title: Rig Count Off in Week
description: The number of oil and gas rigs exploring for oil in the United States fell by 32 last week, to 946, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago, the number stood at 761.

title: Bulgarian Free Zones
description: Bulgaria has established two duty-free zones to ''encourage economic cooperation'' between Bulgarian and foreign companies, the state-run press agency reported today. It said the zones had been set up in Rousse and Vidin to offer areas where ''economic activities can be carried out'' without duties or taxes. The report did not say when the duty-free zones had been established or provide further details.

title: Inventories Rise 0.4% As Increase Slows
description: Business inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January, less than half the increase of the previous month, as a rebound in car sales helped to reduce a huge backlog of unsold cars.

title: Lots of Guys at Farrell's Don't Vote
description: LEAD: The end of the Reagan era is still many months away, but already there are warning signs among ordinary people that we are moving deeper into a ''big sleep'' period in American politics. These are the people whose world is never invaded by the television cameras that routinely court the opinions of

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Tie Ends Canadiens' Winning Streak: A power-play goal by Chris Chelios, a defenseman, early in the third period allowed Montreal to salvage a 2-2 tie at Bloomington, Minn., with the North Stars. Montreal entered with a 10-game winning streak, longest in the league this season. Minnesota, with the worst record in the league, earned its third point in two games after losing its previous seven games. Brian Bellows scored both North Star goals. (AP) HORSE RACING Cordero Rides Three Winners: Angel Cordero rode his third winner of the day when he guided Notches Trace, the favorite, to a front-running 2 3/4-length victory yesterday in the $47,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 4 years old and up at Aqueduct. It was the sixth victory in 28 starts for Notches Trace, who covered a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:44 2/5 to earn $28,200 for Warren W. Rosenthal. Notches Trace, coupled with Split Sentence, returned $2.60 for $2 to win. TENNIS Wilander and Noah Advance: Top-seeded Mats Wilander, sixth-seeded Yannick Noah and ninth-seeded Andre Agassi advanced yesterday to the second round of the $2.1 million Lipton International Players Championships at Key Biscayne, Fla. Two seeded women, Lori McNeil and Catarina Lindqvist, were eliminated. Wilander swept past Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico, 6-3, 6-2, 7-5. Noah struggled before eliminating Paul Chambelin of Toledo, Ohio, 2-6, 6-1, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2. The 17-year-old Agassi of Las Vegas, Nev., beat Jeremy Bates of Britain, 6-2, 6-1, 6-0. In women's singles, McNeil, seeded seventh, committed 53 unforced errors in losing to Federica Bonsignori of Italy, 6-2, 6-4. Lindqvist of Sweden, seeded 14th, lost to Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia, 2-6, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) SLED DOG RACING Redington Loses Lead Again: Joe Redington, the 70-year-old founder of the 1,150-mile Iditarod Trail race, lost the lead again when two other teams beat him to the Bering Sea coast after battling wind and drifting snow during the night. Martin Buser arrived at Unalakleet at 5:49 A.M., local time, with 13 dogs in harness. Susan Butcher, the defending champion, pulled in at 5:57 A.M. with 12 dogs. Redington arrived in Unalakleet at 6:42 A.M. with nine dogs. Unalakleet is 889 miles from the race's start in Anchorage, and 269 miles from the finish in Nome. The next checkpoint is Shaktolik, 40 miles up the trail.(AP)

title: Tenant Selection Must Not Be Based on Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Cement Maker Rejects Offer
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. today rejected a $308.3 million tender offer by a rival cement maker, Southdown Inc., and said it was talking with unidentified third parties about a possible leveraged buyout.

title: Crude Oil Prices in the U.S. Decline Below $16 a Barrel
description: Crude oil prices again fell below $16 a barrel in domestic trading yesterday, after slipping well under $15 in London dealings earlier.

title: France Acts In Takeovers
description: France will tighten laws on corporate takeovers in response to a continuing wave of hostile bids, Finance Minister Edouard Balladur said today. He told a news conference that he would require anyone buying more than 10 percent of a company to dislose his final intentions.

title: President Pleads for More Money For Anti-Missile Shield in Space
description: President Reagan pleaded with critics on Capitol Hill today to support an increase in funds for his proposed missile shield based in space.

title: Indonesian Moslems Search for a Middle Way
description: For Moslem intellectuals in Indonesia, the world's most populous Islamic nation, these are uncomfortable but challenging times.

title: Son Of Poland
description: Almost a month ago a statement was issued that will be discussed for years. It could influence the way people all over the world think and act. It makes moral judgments about the great nations that are seen by Western diplomats as a stunning, unexpected boon for the Soviet Union.

title: Husky Presses for Texaco Canada
description: In a proposal that would make Li Ka-shing, the Hong Kong real estate investor, a major player in Canada's oil and gas industry, Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said today that it would press forward with proposals for a takeover of Texaco Canada Ltd., the Canadian unit of financially troubled Texaco Inc.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said last year's first quarter ended Feb. 1.

title: Brokerage Is Suspended
description: The brokerage house Louis Baudouin S.A. was suspended today from doing business on the Paris Bourse, the first such action at the exchange, the French stockbrokers' association said.

title: Chess; Nigel Short Sweeps Hastings Against Strong Competition
description: The 63d running of the traditional Hastings International Tournament in England was won by Nigel Short. The 22-year-old British grandmaster scored 9-5 to top one of the strongest fields ever assembled for this event.

title: Odyssey Bid For Stevens Is Supported
description: Spurning a higher bid, a committee of outside directors of J.P. Stevens & Company said yesterday that they had approved a buyout offer of $61.50 a share for the large textile producer.

title: On China's Southern Coast, Dramatic Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: The Ides of Marx
description: Old joke in Eastern Europe: Q. What is the difference, comrade, between Communism and capitalism? A. Under capitalism, man exploits man. Under Communism, the situation is reversed. As if to illustrate, Mikhail Gorbachev now promises a radical new reform to the toiling Soviet masses: the progressive income tax. Americans toiling over Form 1040 are unlikely to chuckle. The Soviet leader's avowed reason for introducing individual incomes taxes is to reward ''honest work and initiative, but not the kind in evidence at some cooperatives which take advantage of shortages and engage in open money grubbing.'' This is what Sovietologists call Aesopian language, something like the Reagan Administration calling tax increases ''revenue enhancement.''

title: Art Museum Bond Issue Approved in Massachusetts
description: The Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, which is to be the largest museum of contemporary art in the world when completed, yesterday won passage in the Massachusetts Legislature of a $35 million appropriations bill.

title: Legal-Tax-Evasion Ad Deceptive and in Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Joseph T. Sternaman, Pioneer Quarterback, 88
description: Joseph T. Sternaman, the first quarterback of the Chicago Bears, died last Thursday at the age of 88.

title: California Hospital Accepts 4th Brain-Absent Baby
description: Loma Linda Medical Center said has accepted a fourth baby born with most of his brain missing in the hope that his organs can be preserved for transplant. The baby was placed on a respirator, hospital officials said today. ''His parents want to donate their baby's organs when brain death occurs,'' said Anita Rockwell, the hospital spokeswoman.

title: Doctors and Patients Take AIDS Drug Trial Into Their Own Hands
description: A GROWING number of New York patients and their doctors are beginning to test possible AIDS treatments under a novel community-based approach to drug trials.

title: Books of The Times; A Life of Malice Practiced on Principle
description: Alice Roosevelt Longworth By Carol Felsenthal Illustrated. 320 pages. G. P Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: Rose Hits Mets With Advice
description: Pete Rose, approaching his 47th birthday and his fourth full season as a manager, offered some advice today to the Mets or any other team aiming to dominate baseball, ''You take things for granted, you finish second.''

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Backs Ozone Treaty An accord to limit global use of chemicals thought to destroy the earth's ozone shield won the Senate's approval. Science Times, page C2. New Look at the Markets The White House may form a new group to draft its final position on the stock market's collapse. Page D1. In a Flash, Housing They move in secret, at night, like guerrillas. Their battleground is downtown Atlanta. Their goal, to shelter the city's homeless. They are the Mad Housers. Page A16.

title: Just Like the Movie
description: Life imitates art, also in Washington. In the movie ''Broadcast News,'' Holly Hunter, who has been nominated for an Academy Award for her portrayal of a television news producer, attends the annual White House Correspondents Association dinner.

title: Police Upset With Meese Gun Stance
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has found himself at odds with some traditional allies, groups representing law-enforcement officers, over legislation designed to curb the manufacture of plastic guns.

title: GENCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,000,000 for the latest quarter and $6,000,000 for the year- earlier period. Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect discontinued operations and a 3-for-1 stock split in December 1987. The company also said the latest quarter's net from discontinued operations includes a gain of $5,000,000 from the Dec. 8 sale of RKO Pictures.

title: Zola Budd's Eligibility
description: The international governing body of track and field yesterday called for Zola Budd to withdraw from international running competitions, including the world cross-country championships at Auckland, New Zealand, on March 26, until the South African-born runner's eligibility can be guaranteed. The International Amateur Athletic Federation said it had asked the British track federations to seek her withdrawl so that the I.A.A.F. council could examine allegations brought by the Supreme Council for Sport in Africa that Budd participated in two South African meets in 1987. The I.A.A.F. council is scheduled to meet in London April 15-16. Budd, who obtained a British passport in 1984 that allowed her to compete for that country in the Olympic Summer Games and other international events, has won the women's world cross-country title twice.

title: KEY RATES
ALPHA 1 BIOMEDICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $412,000.

title: Oscar for a Lawyer?
description: Jonathan Weisgall, a Washington lawyer, has an unusual feather in his cap. A film he helped produce has received a nomination for an Oscar.

title: Paul McDonald Fye, Oceanographic Expert
description: Paul McDonald Fye, who led the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution nearly 20 years, died Friday at his home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Cortege for I.R.A. Members Attacked on Trip to Belfast
description: A funeral procession bearing the bodies of three I.R.A. guerrillas slain in Gibraltar was pelted with rocks and bottles by jeering loyalists as it made its way here early this morning.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pakistan Pressed to Accept Terms for Afghan Accord
description: On the eve of Moscow's deadline for a peace agreement in Afghanistan, pressure is building on Pakistan to accept an accord that would lead to the withdrawal of the Soviet forces fighting there.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Robert H. Spofford has been promoted to executive vice president, director of client services, at BBDO Los Angeles.

title: Lawrence Hill, 75, Longtime Publisher And Book Salesman
description: Lawrence Hill, a book publisher and book salesman for 46 years, died of emphysema Monday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old. A resident of Westport, he had been hospitalized for six weeks.

title: TEMPO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $2,035,000 from the sale of seven cable television systems.

title: On Primary Day in Chicago, Lowly Race Is a Main Event
description: In Tuesday's primary, it isn't just the dreams of Bob Dole and Paul Simon and the other Presidential candidates that are at stake. That's almost secondary, for many voters here, to the election's impact on Jane M. Byrne, Edward R. Vrdolyak and Aurelia Pucinski.

title: U.S. Starting Seizures Of Citizens' Passports
description: The United States on Tuesday will begin to seize the passports of Americans re-entering the country with illicit drugs despite warnings by legal experts that the action would pose constitutional problems.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $19,806,000 for the latest year and $150,897,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Bass Group Trims Stake in Church's
description: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Texas has lowered its stake in Church's Fried Chicken Inc. to 2.7 percent, from 8.2 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group gave no reason for the sale.

title: High Court Rejects Stay for Florida Inmate
description: The United States Supreme Court refused early today to halt the execution at dawn of Willie Jasper Darden, whose case has become the focus of an international campaign against the death penalty.

title: Software for the Amiga
description: IF you buy an I.B.M.-compatible computer, you can be confident that there is a rich variety of software in a wide range of prices. Even if you buy, say, a Commodore 64, you know the machine has been around so long that a daunting collection of programs is available.

title: Review/Film; Japanese Psychotic Gets His Wish: Return to Jail
description: The New Directors/New Films festival is presenting a number of unconventional documentaries, but none as alarming and significantly lunatic as ''The Emperor's Naked Army Marches On,'' conceived by Shohei Imamura (''Vengeance Is Mine'') and directed by Kazuo Hara as his first feature.

title: Sedgwick Group Picks Outsider as Likely Heir
description: David Rowland has been named group chief executive of the Sedgwick Group P.L.C., Britain's largest independent insurance broker, effective immediately. The appointment puts him in line to take over as Sedgwick's chairman when Carel Mosselmans retires after the company's annual meeting in April 1989.

title: Chipping Away the Layers of Lies
description: The Iran-contra scandal consisted of monumental misjudgments and arrogant illegality, varnished over with half-truths and full-scale lies. Investigations last year brought out some of the truth. Now, a guilty plea starts to bring out some of the crimes.

title: Arthur F. Sampson Is Dead at 61; Led G.S.A. Under Nixon and Ford
description: Arthur Francis Sampson, who led the General Services Administration for three years in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, died Sunday. He was 61 years old and lived in Falls Chuurch, Va.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Air Fares Rise for Many Travelers As Big Carriers Dominate Market
description: The full coach fares paid by travelers who cannot make plans far ahead are going up sharply today on many routes, and many discount fares are ending.

title: Ambitious Project Will Buy Land To Preserve the Connecticut River
description: THE Connecticut River meanders from a tiny lake near the Canadian border to the Long Island Sound, carving out an often pristine valley of forests, grasslands and tidal marshes that shelter a panoply of plants and animals.

title: Brutal Drug Gangs Wage War Of Terror in Upper Manhattan
description: Young and violent drug gangs, in brutal territorial battles and in calculated campaigns to terrorize neighborhoods, are believed to be responsible for as many as 523 slayings in upper Manhattan in the last five years, according to law-enforcement authorities.

title: S.&P. Plans to Restructure 4 Sectors of 500-Stock Index
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it would restructure the four broad sector indexes that make up its widely followed 500-stock index.

title: ENTIRE GAZA STRIP PUT UNDER CURFEW
description: The Israeli authorities imposed a nightly curfew on the entire Gaza Strip tonight after the resignation of hundreds of Palestinian policemen there.

title: Fashion; For British Designers, Different Drummers
description: Jean Muir, who first became known back in the glory days of the 1960's, and Anouska Hempel, the interior designer who started making dresses just two years ago, presented the most satisfying collections in the fall and winter showings that started here Friday and ended today.

title: KEY RATES
Albany Patroons Take a Shot At History, and the N.B.A.
description: LEAD: The Washington Avenue Armory in downtown Albany is an unlikely palace of dreams. It is a century-old, red-brick building, squat and unimpressive on the outside, drafty and dusty within.

title: U.S. Davis Cup Team
description: Andre Agassi and Jay Berger, newcomers to Davis Cup competition, will join Ken Flach and Robert Seguso on the United States team that will play Peru in Lima, April 8-10, in the quarterfinal round of the American Zone competition.

title: Bakker Returns to Pulpit
description: A year after he stepped down from his PTL television ministry because of a sex scandal, Jim Bakker returned to the pulpit at a trailer park in California. Tammy Faye Bakker introduced her husband to 225 retirees at a Sunday service in Niland, Calif., according to a report in today's Charlotte Observer. ''This has been a long, hard year for us,'' Mrs. Bakker said.

title: CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Health Chief Sees Obstacle to AIDS-Needle Plan
description: Unless criminal-justice officials drop their objections to an experimental plan that aims to curb the spread of AIDS by giving needles to drug addicts in New York City, the plan cannot work, the State Health Commissioner said today.

title: Governor's Swearing In Is Modest Affair for Louisiana
description: Charles E. (Buddy) Roemer 3d was inaugurated as Governor today in a setting positively spartan in comparison with the style and flamboyance associated with his predecessor, Edwin Edwards.

title: PIEMONTE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Q&A
description: Q. Do people who have been blind since birth dream in images as seeing people do? A. Researchers generally agree that people born blind are entirely lacking in visual imagery in their dreams.

description: Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

description: b-After a $627,000 loss on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said its results for the latest quarter and year were lower than expected because it was required to defer a pretax gain of $6,250,000 related to the sale of a 50 percent stake in the Vidalia Hydroelectric facility to Dominion Resources Inc.

title: Its Image Sullied, Ulster Loyalist Force Ousts Chief
description: The shadowy cabal that runs Northern Ireland's loyalist paramilitary underworld emerged briefly today to explain why it had to depose ''the wee man,'' its longtime leader.

title: I.R.S. Review Of Penalties
description: The Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service said today that the agency was reviewing its tax penalties to try to make them fairer and less complicated.

title: Irving Younger, Lawyer, 55, Dies; Judge, Law Professor and Author
description: Irving Younger, a leading scholar on trial techniques, died of pancreatic cancer Sunday at the University of Minnesota Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 55 years old.

title: Arrests in India on Eve Of a Nationwide Strike
description: Widespread arrests were reported today as the authorities moved to block a nationwide anti-Government strike scheduled for Tuesday.

title: 'Ivan' Trial Heard Hamburg Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: FCS LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed $103,000 of the latest quarter loss to currency translation effects. The additonal amount of the loss was caused by adjustments relative to its French subsidiary's reorganization plan.

title: Suspicion Stalls Japanese Project
description: For more than two years Japan has tried to launch an ambitious and expensive program in which American, European and Japanese scientists would pool their knowledge to explore the deepest secrets of biological science.

description: WASHINGTON

title: Fashion; By Design; The Enduring Chanel Look
description: The Chanel look comes and goes as a major fashion influence, and it is coming again for fall.

title: Niamey Journal; Wary Niger Wonders: Why Is Qaddafi Smiling?
description: A milelong American-built airstrip in the Sahara and an $8 million Libyan People's Bureau rising in this capital symbolize new jockeying for influence in Niger, West Africa's largest nation.

title: Patrick B. Northup, Lawyer, Dies
description: Patrick B. Northup, a deputy chief in the United States Attorney's office in Brooklyn who handled several complex and celebrated cases, died of cancer Sunday at University Hospital. He was 34 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dow Advances 15.09 Amid Light Trading
description: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday in a late rally amid the lightest trading since Dec. 29. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was only 131.9 million shares, down from 200 million on Friday.

title: Thomas Riggs Cox, Bank President, 99
description: Thomas Riggs Cox, retired president and former chairman of the board of Broadway Savings Bank, died yesterday at Lake Wales (Fla.) Hospital Extended Care Facility, after a brief illness. He was 99 years old and lived in Lake Wales.

title: Advertising; More Staff Reductions Anticipated
description: WHEN the questioner got to his feet the other morning to ask a dais full of top ad executives about the agency personnel cutbacks during 1987 that led to 5,000 to 6,000 jobs lost in the New York market, he probably anticipated some sympathetic response.

title: Atlanta Journal; Raising the Roof To Aid the Homeless
description: During the week they are architects, industrial designers and bank employees, indistinguishable from thousands of other affluent, educated young people who stream into this city in pursuit of careers.

title: Federico Sisneros, 93; Longtime Park Ranger
description: Federico Sisneros, the National Park Service's oldest ranger, died of heart failure Saturday. He was 93 years old.

title: GUNDLE ENVIRONMENTAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for the fourth quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1986, are on a pro- forma basis. The company went through a leveraged buyout in August 1986 and an initial public offering in December 1986. Results for 1986 are therefore not comparable to same periods for the year.

title: Nicaragua Reports Offensive
description: Nicaragua said tonight that it had mounted a major offensive against rebel forces in northern Nicaragua.

title: OPTEK TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $32,285 for the latest first quarter and $81,913 for the year-ago period.

title: LOS ANGELES BARS ALL-YEAR SCHOOL
description: A plan to put the entire Los Angeles school system on a year-round calendar that drew national attention when it was approved last October has been withdrawn by the Superintendent of Schools.

title: Reagan in Appeal to Pretoria
description: President Reagan, in an unusual appeal, urged South Africa today to grant clemency to six blacks convicted of complicity in a 1984 mob killing. The inmates, five men and one woman who are called the ''Sharpeville Six,'' are scheduled to be hanged on Friday.

title: Doctors Urge Campaign Against AIDS Quackery
description: Acknowledging a growing sense of urgency, top Federal health officials sought today to enroll health care professionals and educators in a stepped-up drive against medical fraud at a time when fear of AIDS is providing a rising number of prospective victims.

title: Reliance on Temporary Jobs Hints at Economic Fragility
description: One of the hallmarks of the current economic recovery, now in its sixth year, has been the creation of 10 million jobs.

title: Shultz and Shamir Deadlock
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir differed on peace talks. Page A6. Study Backs Ozone Fears

title: New Catalogue Item: Custom-Made Genes
description: A SMALL company here has begun a new high-tech catalogue business, selling custom genes to pharmaceutical companies that lack the time, manpower or expertise to generate their own. The company, British Bio-technology Ltd., a spinoff of G. D. Searle, sold its first genes last July.

title: Shoney's South Has Higher Bid
description: A management group led by Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd., a venture capital unit of Citicorp, has raised its offer to take Shoney's South Inc. private in a leveraged buyout for $14 a share, or about $95.2 million. In a letter dated Friday to

title: Texas Bank Is Seeking F.D.I.C. Aid
description: Besieged by negative news reports and rising depositor withdrawals, the First Republicbank Corporation entered direct talks today to seek aid from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to prevent its failure.

title: CONSOLIDATED STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Ex-Retailer to Return To the Work He Missed
description: Bernard H. Newberg, once a president of Bonwit Teller in New York, has returned to the retail business, this time in Norman, Okla.

description: b-Net loss

The Pop Life
description: Garfunkel Returns

title: Corrections
description: A report yesterday in the Science Watch column of Science Times about the military use of a small space station misidentified the industry newsletter that first reported the development. It was Space Station News, based in Washington.

title: Men Leave But the Light Shines On
description: Its double-beamed beacon will still slice through the black of night at sea, winking its warning for 25 miles around. The horn will still issue its mournful moan through the thickest fog.

title: In Hills Above Jordan River, Jewish-Arab Hatred Grows
description: Meir Indor is a Jewish settler from the movement called Gush Emunim, or Bloc of the Faithful, and he says he does not mind if the 70,000 Jews who have settled in the West Bank have built what he called a ''bad image'' among Palestinians.

title: Budd Still on Team
description: British track and field authorities rejected pressure from the sport's international governing body and said it had decided not to withdraw Zola Budd from international competition, including the world cross-country championships in Auckland, New Zealand, on March 26. The British Amateur Athletic Board said in a statement that it had decided against pulling the South African-born runner out of the event despite the International Amateur Athletic Federation questioning of Budd's eligibility after allegations that she had run in two meets in South Africa in 1987. Rather than withdraw Budd until a meeting of the federation council on April 15 in London could determine the truth of the allegations, the British group said Budd would stay on the team until the federation determined that she had violated sanctions against participating in events in South Africa.(AP)

title: In Furnace's Hulk, Lessons on Courage
description: SINCE the birth of my children I've become a coward. In my youth, I walked out boldly into the night without the baggage of a chicken. I went to raise my voice to the moon and sniff the air and look into people's houses. I didn't bother about mortal peril. I could go skiing by myself at night in the woods, without imagining that my carcass would be discovered months later, a few bleached ribs sticking up through the spring ooze, and the headline in the local paper: ''NO ONE HEARD HER CALL.''

title: CONSERVATIVE GETS KEY BAPTIST POST
description: A theological conservative has been elected president of the divided Southeastern Baptist Theological Seminary.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ONE dish for which I had a particular liking in my post-adolescent days in France was rib steak with marrow and red-wine sauce.

title: U.S. and Costa Rica Split on Contras
description: As contra negotiators prepare to meet Sandinista officials next week for peace talks, American and Costa Rican officials remain sharply divided on policy toward Nicaragua.

title: Soviet Musicians to Play With Philharmonic
description: Two soviet performers - the conductor Gennadi Rozhdestvensky will lead the New York Philharmonic and the pianist Viktoriya Postnikova will be featured in a performance of Russian music by the New York Philharmonic on March 29 at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. The program is to include Act II from Tchaikovsky's ''Nutcracker'' and two works by Prokofiev - the Piano Concerto No. 3 and the ''Scythian Suite.''

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes gains of $5.8 million and $17.3 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from a change in accounting. c-Includes a gain of $8.5 million from discontinued operations.

title: Mookie and Mr. Bill
description: WHAT sports official once said that the best trades are often the ones you don't make? It probably wasn't Frank (Trader) Lane, who once traded baseball managers. It probably wasn't Branch Rickey, who believed in trading a player a year too soon rather than a year too late.

title: Duty on Court for Robinson
description: An old field house has a certain smell to it, a sweet mustiness that settles in over the years and becomes as fixed as the collapsible wooden bleachers, the yellowed varnish on the floor and the small concesson stand that offers little more than pop and popcorn.

title: Poll Finds Arts Attendance Has Declined
description: Attendance at concerts and other performing-arts events, as well as participation in most arts activities, has declined in this country since 1984 as leisure time has dwindled and the use of video-cassette recorders has rapidly expanded, according to a poll released yesterday by Louis Harris and Associates.

title: Advertsing; Mullen Advertising Gets New Revere Ware Lin
description: Mullen Advertising has just picked up new business from Revere Ware in Clinton, Ill. The assignment is for a new product called Micrometal Cookware, which the agency describes as the first stainless steel cookware that can be used in a microwave oven.

title: British Utility and U.S. Bank Find Good Investor Demand
description: Two corporate issues totaling $550 million were offered yesterday through Goldman, Sachs & Company at prices slightly higher than had been expected because of strong investor demand.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Chairman Rodino Retires, With Grace
description: For one who has enjoyed the power and privileges that Congressional seniority bring, leaving Capitol Hill for good isn't easy. So it was understandable that Representative Peter Rodino of New Jersey, who has spent more than half his 78 years in the House, might have had second thoughts about retiring after his current term.

title: Reciew/Film; 'Vincent,' Portrait of van Gogh in His Own Words
description: In one after another of van Gogh's self-portraits, he stares out at the viewer with intense, impenetrable eyes, eyes that seem to be floodgates holding his torrential emotions in check. ''Vincent,'' Paul Cox's study of van Gogh's life and work, matches the intense surface of those self-portraits but contains little of their underlying power. As Mr. Cox propels van Gogh's own words and art at us with increasing speed, he keeps us at a fatal distance from the film, which aims to capture the artist's innermost point of view.

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included $850,000 in writedowns and reserves for the restructuring of Ronson Metals; the year also included a gain of $499,000 from the sale of Neodymium Technology in a non-exclusive licensing agreement. The latest year net included $100,000, or 7 cents a share, related to a 1986 grant by the company of a non- exclusive licensing agreement for Neodymium Technology.

title: Heir to Family Orchard Harvests Fruit Brandy
description: LEAD: THE family of Stephen McCarthy has been in fruit since the turn of the century, when Mr. McCarthy's grandfather, a graduate of the Yale Forestry School, traveled west to Oregon. The family orchards are halfway between Mount Hood and the Columbia River, high up in the Hood River Valley at an altitude of 1,800 feet.

title: Wine Talk
description: EVERY year around this time, the wine shops begin to advertise the new crop of Beaujolais. ''Just arrived,'' they trumpet. But wait a minute, anyone with half a brain will say: didn't we go through all this business about the new Beaujolais a couple of months ago? The answer is yes.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Home Loan Banks Set 3 Issues' Rates
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks yesterday announced the interest rates for a $2.45 billion offering of one-year, two-year and five-year bonds through various dealers.

title: Hospitals Hold Nursing-Shortage Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Same-Day Registration And Voting Suggested
description: A state task force today suggested amending the New York Constitution to allow voters to register and vote on election day.

title: Meachem Clinging To His 'Future'
description: The dream still has hold of Bobby Meacham. It won't let go, not now, perhaps not ever. In his mind's eye, Meacham can still see himself playing shortstop at Yankee Stadium, picking up every ground ball, making every throw, perfectly. The picture doesn't seem to fade. Eventually, it may disappear. Meacham's hope - to be the Yankees' everyday shortstop - has already begun to slip away. Rafael Santana was acquired in a trade in December. Randy Velarde, a rookie, has looked increasingly impressive at short during the spring.

title: Vehicle Sales Up This Month
description: Early March sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 6.3 percent from a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Navy Paymaster Found Slain
description: A Navy paymaster was found beaten and strangled today aboard the destroyer U.S.S. John Hancock and $120,000 was stolen from the ship's safe, a naval spokesman said. The officer's body was found stuffed into a sea locker in another part of the ship, said Chief Petty Officer Art Riccio. Officials identified the victim as Lieut. Ratish Prasad, 24 years old, of Park Forest, Ill.

title: FALCON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Topics of The Times; Schools Left Back
