description: The educational reform movement has bypassed students in inner-city schools. That act of omission perpetuates discrimination and jeopardizes America's competitiveness and social equilibrium.

title: Dining's Double Standard: You Are Where You Eat
description: ABOUT once a month, when Roger Hahn has a craving for beef, he goes to one of the nearby bars that specialize in big, juicy hamburgers. He wouldn't dream of making one at home, even though he frequently prepares elaborate meals. ''I don't like to cook red meat,'' said Mr. Hahn, who lives in St. Louis. ''It's gross. The fat spatters all over the place.''

title: Martin Fleischman, 81, Hotel Concern Founder
description: Martin Fleischman, a founder of the Fleischman Management Company, hotel and restaurant managers, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Columbia Pictures Expects Limited Profits
description: Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. said yesterday that it would have limited profits for the next three years. The company was formed in January with Tri-Star Pictures Inc. after Columbia Pictures was spun off from the Coca-Cola Company.

title: Dow Falls by 2.66 in Lackluster Trading
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday as both blue chips and secondaries continued to meander in lackluster trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.66 points, to 2,047.41, but advances led declines by 789 to 718.

title: In Britain, Tax Overhaul and a Feud
description: Britain's annual Budget Day, always a time of suspense in the House of Commons, arrived today with an extra fillip of drama because of a feud between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her strong-willed Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson.

title: Lebanon's President Invites West to Rescue Its Hostages
description: President Amin Gemayel has said Western powers are welcome to come and rescue any of their citizens held hostage in Lebanon.

title: Senate Backs Bill on Aliens That Emphasizes Job Skills
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a major immigration bill intended to place greater emphasis on occupational skills in determining who can legally immigrate to the United States.

title: Advertsing; DDB Needham Hires Ex-Saatchi Executive
description: Robert H. Huntington, 50 years old, former chairman and chief executive of the now defunct Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Group, has joined DDB Needham Worldwide, as vice chairman, chief operating officer and member of the office of the chairman.

title: Ralph Dubin, Artist, 69
description: Ralph Dubin, an artist whose work evolved from social realist figuration into one more heavily influenced by abstract forms, died of a heart attack on March 9 at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: New Suffolk Police Official
description: The Suffolk County Legislature confirmed Daniel P. Guido, the Stamford, Conn., Police Chief, on Monday as the new County Police Commissioner. Mr. Guido, 56 years old, is to take command of Suffolk's 2,600-officer Police Department next month at a salary of $85,000 a year. He replaces James Caples Jr., who resigned. The Suffolk department has been the subject of investigations into allegations of illegal wiretapping, drug use, fabricated evidence and the mishandling of murder cases.

title: Full Ketchup Nelson
description: Professional wrestling suffers from superb television camera work. If it were not so good, the fraud would not be so distressingly obvious to the audience, and the entertainment would be better.

title: Precious Metals and Oil Rise During New York Trading
description: Precious metals and crude oil futures prices advanced yesterday in New York after meandering in narrow ranges earlier on the Asian and European markets.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
DART DRUG STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said 1987 results are restated to reflect the merger of Dart Drug Holding Inc. into Dart Drug Stores Inc. effective July 1987.

title: Exterminator Assails Audit as '100% Lies'
description: An extermination company criticized in a recent audit by the New York City Comptroller's office asserted yesterday that the audit was ''absolutely 100 percent lies.''

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: A Pair of Diverse Contenders Face Up to Separate Problems; Florida Is Attempting To Channel Its Emotion
description: If St. John's backed into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Florida, the Redmen's opponent in tomorrow night's first-round West Regional game at Salt Lake City, stumbled in headfirst.

title: Real Estate; Garages Feel Cost Squeeze In Manhattan
description: OWNERS of businesses in Manhattan that cater to motorists - auto repair shops, parking lots and car washes - say demand for their services is higher than ever. But they are being squeezed out of Manhattan by the rising cost of property, even in marginal locations, they say.

title: Culinary Student Redesigns The Chef's 'Frumpy' Uniform
description: TIMOTHY NUGENT likes almost everything about being a student at the New England Culinary Institute: the classes, the hands-on cooking experience, the teachers. But what he doesn't like - what sends a shudder through his slight frame and prompts words like ''nasty'' and ''vile'' - is the traditional chef's uniform that is required in the institute's kitchens.

title: Review/Concert; Jealous Rage in a Good Cause
description: Three scenes of confrontation and jealous rage were the dramatic anchors of the Metropolitan Opera's pension fund benefit Sunday evening, a gala concert that featured the tenor Placido Domingo, the mezzo-soprano Agnes Baltsa and the Met's chorus and orchestra directed by Nello Santi.

title: Garrison Keillor Plans '2d Annual Farewell'
description: Garrison Keillor, the humorist and writer, announced yesterday that he had had ''so much fun'' ending ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' his popular radio show, last June that he would present ''A Prairie Home Companion: The 2d Annual Farewell Performance'' at Radio City Music Hall at 8 P.M. on June 3 and 4.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament: A Pair of Diverse Contenders Face Up to Separate Problems; Fairleigh Dickinson Tests Another No. 1-Seeded Foe
description: It has been three years since Jaime Latney and Damari Riddick allowed themselves to dream like this. They were freshmen on the Fairleigh Dickinson basketball team then, preparing to face Michigan, the second-ranked team in the country, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New England Corp., Boston, named Karen E. Hurst executive vice president.

title: Restore Tax Breaks For Career Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Utility Agency Bonds
description: The Bergen County Utility Authority in New Jersey is tentatively offering $139 million of solid waste system revenue bonds with a top yield of 7.795 percent for those due in 2013 through underwriters led by J. B. Hanauer & Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Husky Oil's proposal to purchase Texaco Canada Ltd. gave an incorrect purchase price for another recent deal. Amoco Inc. is paying $4 billion (United States) for Dome Petroleum Ltd.

title: Eating Well
description: Ten years ago almost every cookbook remotely connected with nutrition was for a reducing diet. Today, the nutrition-related cookbooks are more concerned with overall health than with weight reduction.

title: Gambino Informer Slain in California
description: A key Government informer whose testimony recently helped convict the underboss of the Gambino crime family and two other mob figures in a trial in New York was found shot dead execution-style Saturday in a parking lot in Irvine, Calif. He had been shot three times in the head.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Jersey Panel Criticizes Buying Of a Lake With a Faulty Dam
description: The State Commission of Investigation today criticized state environmental officials for buying a lake in 1982 for $3.1 million without finding out that its dam needed $15 million worth of repairs.

title: The U.N. Today; General Assembly
description: DONORS TO CAMBODIAN HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE PROGRAM - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council

title: De Laurentiis Sale
description: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc. said it had sold the foreign television and video rights to its 320-picture library for $69 million to the British financier Michael W. Stevens. The proceeds will be used to pay debt and is the initial step in a planned financial restructuring of the film studio, said Stephen R. Greenwald, who became chairman and chief executive of the Beverly Hills, Calif., company in February after the company's founder, Dino De Laurentiis, resigned. Poor box-office results had led the company's lenders to restrict operations.

title: 2 Key Democrats Ask Party To Back June Front-Runner; Cuomo Says He May Stay Uncommitted Till After June
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he might not endorse a candidate in the New York Presidential primary on April 19 and hinted that he would remain uncommitted at least until June, after the last of the primaries.

title: The Case Without Brawley: A Grand Jury's Rare Role
description: Most grand juries convened in New York State are presented with neatly packaged accounts of wrongdoing. In such cases -where the prosecutor has already identified a suspect, gathered some evidence and essentially ''solved'' the crime - it usually takes only minutes or hours for the grand jury to return an indictment.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Review/Dance; Lansner and Company, Mixing Film and Motion
description: Gabrielle Lansner was most persuasive when she danced with images of her own choreographic past last Wednesday night at the Dia Art Foundation. The performance by Gabrielle Lansner and Dancers included the premiere of ''Move To,'' a new work that incorporated a film of her made in 1979, with camerawork by Erica Lansner.

title: Review/Television; 'Bonanza' Returns As a Pilot
description: A run of 14 seasons might be enough for the ordinary television concept, but then ''Bonanza'' was not your ordinary show. Starring Lorne Greene as the widower rancher Ben Cartwright and Dan Blocker, Pernell Roberts and Michael Landon as his three sons, the western soap opera become an Americana fixture on NBC Sunday nights. It was the first series to be broadcast regularly in color. Now, not leaving well enough alone, some of the folks involved with the original are trying to revive and update the series. A two-hour pilot is being tested in syndication. ''Bonanza: The Next Generation'' can be seen on Channel 11 at 9 tonight.

title: Food Notes
description: Greener Bagels

title: Stock Buyback At Cleveland
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc., a mining and oil drilling concern, announced a restructuring yesterday, including the repurchase of $170 million of common and preferred stock.

title: Democrats' Fund-Raiser Is Indicted in Finance Case
description: A major Democratic fund-raiser was indicted today on Federal charges of wire fraud and making false statements in connection with a suspected scheme to defraud a savings and loan in Iowa.

title: MICROBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Busy Cable Executive To Keep Up Fast Pace
description: Speaking to Wall Street analysts last week, Stewart D. Blair, the president and chief executive of United Artists Communications Inc. recalled that when he was named president of the company in December 1986, ''I didn't smoke, I was in good physical shape and I was one of the most eligible bachelors in Denver.''

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,930,000 from a change in accounting. The company said the fourth quarter earnings were reduced by the expenses associated with the start up of a new 310,000-square-foot regional distribution center in Charlotte, N.C.

title: About Education
description: Critics of public education have clamored for a return to ''the basics.'' In recent years, many schools have responded but without uniform success. A new study says that students may be reading more but understanding it less.

title: No Verdict Reached on Improving New York Civil Jury Selection; Dick the Butcher
description: To the Editor:

title: For Love or Money, Weddings Go Abroad
description: SOME couples go to great lengths to get their wedding plans just right, but how many will go great distances, say to Europe or the Caribbean? Quite a few, according to the State Department, which receives hundreds of inquiries each year from American couples eager to tie the knot abroad.

title: The Gideon Case 25 Years Later
description: This Friday marks the 25th anniversary of Gideon v. Wainwright, one of the most popular decisions ever handed down by the United States Supreme Court.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Blacks have a rich tradition of spirituality, but it is not a tradition which enriches the Catholic Church unfortunately. I would see my appointment as a great sign of hope to black Catholics in our country and to all people of good will. It means that the church recognizes the wealth within its own ranks, that it is a church of many significant minorities.'' - Auxilliary Bishop Eugene Antonio Marino, who is to be the first black archbishop in the United States. [ A1:4. ]

title: Teachers of the Gifted Fight Accusations of Elitism
description: In classes for the gifted, there are many shades of brightness.

title: Apartments Left Vacant As Shelters Fill
description: Last year, while 28,000 homeless people were placed each night in municipal shelters and welfare hotels, there were 72,000 empty apartments in New York City, according to a city-sponsored study released last week.

title: Review/Theater; 'Fences' and 'Les Mis': After a Year's Run, Changes and Constants
description: For the brave theatergoer contemplating a visit to a Broadway hit that has run a season or longer, only two matters can be taken more or less for granted: ticket prices will have inched upward since opening night, and some, if not all, of the original cast that thrilled critics and Tony Award voters will have fled. Will quality have declined as well? Not necessarily. It is the excitement as well as the peril of theatergoing that any production can fluctuate wildly, in any direction, over the course of a long life. It's a play that stands still, as immutable as a television rerun, that is most likely to be dead.

title: Former Chicago Mayor Loses Race for Clerk
description: Aurelia M. Pucinski beat former Mayor Jane M. Byrne today in the closely watched Democratic primary for clerk of the Cook County Circuit Court.

title: Apple Price Cuts
description: Apple Computer Inc. said that the suggested retail price of its entry-level Macintosh Plus personal computer has been reduced to $1,799 from $2,199, effective immediately. Apple also reduced prices on three hard disk drives: the HD 20 SC is reduced to $1,099 from $1,299; the HD 40SC to $1,699 from $1,999, and the HD 80SC to $2,799 from $3,199. Faced with more aggressive pricing by the International Business Machines Corporation and the makers of I.B.M.-compatible clones, Apple said the price reduction would make the Macintosh Plus more competitive at the low end of the market.

title: Leo E. Mindel, Dentist, 78
description: Dr. Leo E. Mindel, a dentist who practiced for 50 years in New Brunswick, N.J., died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Highland Park, N.J. He was 78 years old.

title: SIMON WINS ILLINOIS PRIMARY OVER JACKSON AND DUKAKIS
description: Vice President Bush soundly defeated Senator Bob Dole in the Illinois Republican Presidential primary today, stretching his already overwhelming lead in the race for the nomination.

title: Littlepage Dismissed
description: After three seasons in which his teams won 23 games and lost 63, Craig Littlepage was dismissed yesterday as basketball coach at Rutgers. Littlepage, who is 36 years old, moved to Rutgers in 1985 from Penn, his alma mater. ''We appreciate the special effort and commitment that Craig Littlepage has put into the Rutgers basketball program,'' said Fred Gruninger, the athletic director. ''The progress of the program was substantially below reasonable expectations for the time Coach Littlepage has been with the university. Where we are today is not where we want to be. And we'll have to move on.'' . . . The University of Texas, making it known that it wants a basketball team ''competitive on the national level,'' announced the dismissal of Bob Weltlich, the basketball coach for the last six years.

title: Scholar Is Named as Director Of Woodrow Wilson Center
description: Charles Blitzer, head of the National Humanities Center in North Carolina for the last five years, was named today as director of the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, one of the nation's top scholarly positions.

title: 8 Charged in Philadelphia Jail Inquiry
description: A prison guard and a cook were charged today with taking money to help a prisoner escape and six other guards were accused of viciously beating a second inmate.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: First City Rescue Plan Brings Few Supporters
description: A tender offer for bonds issued by the troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. failed yesterday to attract the number of securities needed to proceed with a complex $1.47 billion plan to rescue the banking company.

title: Article 272988 -- No Title
description: A jury in Manhattan yesterday ordered a Long Island country club to pay $1.45 million to a man who was paralyzed after being stung by a bee on club property.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., introduced a new personal computer for users of MS-DOS software. Capital Associates Inc., a computer leasing concern, said it was proposing a merger at $7 a share, or $58 million, for the financially troubled NBI Inc. of Boulder, Colo.

title: Strike Grips West Bank and Gaza As 2 More Palestinians Are Killed
description: A general strike among Palestinians protesting Israeli occupation paralyzed the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, and two Palestinians were reported killed in a continuing revolt in the occupied territories.

title: Safeway Settles Boycott Charge
description: Safeway Stores Inc. today agreed to pay $995,000 in penalties to the Commerce Department to settle charges that the company had cooperated with a longstanding Arab boycott against Israel. Paul Freedenberg, Under

title: Stevens Accepts Lesser of Two Bids
description: J. P Stevens & Company, one of the nation's oldest and largest textile producers, said it had accepted a $61.50-a-share takeover offer from Odyssey Partners, a New York investor group, instead of a $62.50-a-share offer from West Point-Pepperell Inc. because of the fear of legal difficulties raised by its outside legal counsel, the New York firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

title: First Nationwide Sets Joint Venture
description: First Nationwide Bank and the J. E. Robert Companies said they planned a new business of managing troubled savings institutions.

title: Why They're Pleading to Get Into P.S. 87
description: In the principal's office at Public School 87, parents seeking to enroll their children hovered, anxious to please.

title: 10,000, Crying 'Democracy,' March in Budapest
description: More than 10,000 people chanting ''democracy'' and demanding new freedoms marched through Budapest today in the biggest anti-Government demonstration since the 1956 uprising.

title: China and Vietnam Skirmish Over Disputed Island Chain
description: Chinese and Vietnamese ships exchanged gunfire Monday near the disputed Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, according to radio reports from both countries today.

title: U.S. Gets First Black Archbishop
description: Eugene Antonio Marino was named Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta today, becoming the first black Catholic archbishop in the United States.

title: Cabinet Role for V.A. Called No Cure
description: Experts on Government administration told Senators today that elevating the Veterans Administration to Cabinet status, as proposed by President Reagan and approved by the House, would not necessarily help the troubled agency.

title: Charles Kirkpatrick, War Hero Who Led The Naval Academy
description: Rear Adm. Charles C. Kirkpatrick, a highly decorated submarine and surface combat commander who later became Superintendent of the United States Naval Academy, died of emphysema Saturday at Sid Peterson Hospital in Kerrville, Tex. He was 80 years old and lived in Kerrville.

title: Hoyt Ammidon, Retired Chairman Of United States Trust, Dies at 78
description: Hoyt Ammidon, retired chairman of the United States Trust Company and a leader in civic, cultural and philanthropic organizations, died of cancer Sunday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Glen Head, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: New York's Homeless May Benefit From Revelry on St. Patrick's Day
description: St. Patrick's Day brings to mind Irish pride, parade litter and green beer. If Patricia McGuire Rock has her way, the city's revelers may think about the homeless as well.

title: Farmers Show Off Broadened Harvest
description: LEAD: NEW YORK strutted its gustatory stuff at an all-Empire State banquet in this tip-of-the-Finger Lakes town. The meal was the highlight of a two-day conference intended to encourage the state's farmers to broaden their product offerings. Judy Green, the coordinator of the Farming Alternatives Project at Cornell University, said that although New

title: Soviet Said to Reduce Support for Cuban Economy
description: The Soviet Union is reducing its support for the Cuban economy, according to documents of the Cuban National Bank obtained by a human rights group and made public today.

title: No Verdict Reached on Improving New York Civil Jury Selection
description: To the Editor:

title: SPELLING, AARON PRODUCIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest 6 months' results included non-recurring income of $3.5 million from American Broadcasting Co. as part of the modification and extension of the company's agreement with ABC. The year-ago 6 months' results included a charge of $750,000 for expenses related to reorganization.

title: Greek Mission to Vatican
description: Greece will open its first embassy at the Vatican, a senior Foreign Ministry official said today. The diplomat said the move had no direct connection to the easing of 900-year-old religious tensions between the Greek Orthodox and Roman Catholic Churches. Pope John Paul II met with Patriarch Dimitrios I in December.

title: Closing P.L.O. Office Strikes at Free Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Says a Pipeline Figure Tried to Bypass State Dept.
description: A Swiss businessman involved in a failed Iraqi oil pipeline plan has said in an interview with the Israeli television that a friend of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tried to bypass the State Department by trying to get Mr. Meese's help on the project.

title: ENERGY SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $68,507,000 for both the quarter and year. The company said the fourth quarter loss included losses from operations and other expenses of $2,424,000, and additional non-recurring charges against income of $9,239,000; included within the non-recurring charges are writedowns of certain assets, provisions relating to the closing of certain operations, and other items.

title: Transactions
description: MONDAY BASEBALL MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL PRODUCTIONS - Named Mike Kostel director of baseball programming; Rich Domich director of special programming, and Tim Roberts director of operations. BASKETBALL L.A. LAKERS (NBA) - Activated Michael Cooper, guard, from the disabled list. FOOTBALL WASHINGTON (NFC) - Announced that Paul Lanham, special teams' coach, will become a permanent member of the staff. HOCKEY WINNIPEG (NHL) - Recalled Eldon Reddick, goaltender, from Moncton of the American Hockey League. COLLEGE HOLY CROSS - Named Mike Sherman offensive football coordinator; Dan Allen quarterback coach, and David Ungerer strength coach. MIAMI (Fla.) - Agreed to terms with Jimmy Johnson, football coach, on a two-year contract extension through 1992.

title: New York Government: For Sale?
description: This week's hearings of the State Commission on Government Integrity dramatically erase all doubts about New York's need for campaign finance reform. The bald testimony of campaign donors who depend on favorable government action creates the clear impression that New York's officialdom is for sale. Some of the state's leading politicians and business figures seem contemptuous of the law's intent and the public's right to clean government.

title: Priest, Writing Eulogy, Recalls Woman in I.R.A.
description: It was late, the fire was fading at the rectory hearth and the priest had finished writing his eulogy for Mairead Farrell, an Irishwoman slain in the time-worn rebellion.

title:
EDUCATION;
Teacher Tests Assailed As Biased and Vague
description: LEAD: The use of standardized tests to help choose teachers, a practice that has proliferated in the last decade, has come under increasing attack. The most widely used tests are being criticized as racially biased, ambiguous and ineffective in measuring critical teaching skills.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Flowering of Capital
description: Although everything will not be coming up roses as yet, April promises early riches for flower lovers in the nation's capital.

title: Quaker State Seeks To Sell Restaurants
description: The Quaker State Corporation is trying to sell its 100 Arctic Circle restaurants in nine Western states, a company spokesman said.

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $509,989 for the quarter and $919,019 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $308,051 and $556,101 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Mauch Has Bronchitis
description: Manager Gene Mauch, who left California Angels training camp abruptly last week to undergo medical tests, has been diagnosed as suffering from a case of mild bronchitis, the club announced yesterday. Mauch, 62 years old, was released from St. Joseph's Hospital in Orange, Calif. Dr. Jules Rasinski, the club physician, conducted the tests and prescribed medication for Mauch, who returned to his home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He is expected to rejoin the team later this week.(AP)

title: LIMITS SUGGESTED AT MAJOR AIRPORTS
description: The Department of Transportation proposed yesterday that the major airports, which handle 95 percent of the nation's passengers, be required to install card systems to limit access to restricted areas.

title: Syria Held Ready to Become Net Oil Exporter
description: Syria will become a net exporter of crude oil this year, in a development that carries economic and strategic significance, oil industry experts say.

title: Grappa, Fiery Brandy of Old, Seeks an Elegant New Image
description: GRAPPA may once have been the drink of peasants, but to me it will always conjure memories of being denied the special treatment that some restaurants give to favored diners.

title: SENATE VOTES JBILL ON COVERT ACTION
description: The Senate voted, 71 to 19, today to approve a bill requiring the President to tell Congress about covert operations within 48 hours after the action begins.

title: Knicks Heighten Their 3-Point Attack
description: With Rick Pitino as its coach, Providence College was known as ''America's 3-point team'' as it made its way to the Final Four last season.

title: TRITON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included gains of $47,795,000 for the quarter and $56,692,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and extraordinary tax credits of $6,621,000 and $15,025,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included gains from discontinued operations of $421,000 for the quarter and $6,457,000 for the year, and extraordinary credits of $1,423,000 and $5,437,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago fourth quarter's revenue has been restated to reflect the sale of the company's Simplicity Pattern Co. unit in February.

title: Koch on Israeli Strife: Kick Out TV Crews
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York wrote in an Israeli newspaper today that television cameras should be barred from the occupied territories.

title: FOOTE MINERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $7,934,000 and $937,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,601,000 for the quarter and $9,082,000 for the year. Results for 1986 have been restated. The company said the latest fourth quarter and year includes a gain of $11,972,000 in connection with reversion of excess assets from certain pension plans. The company also said about $4 million of the gain is included in income from discontinued operations and the remainder in income from continuing operations.

title: Carnegie Report Urges Crusade For 'Bypassed' Urban Schools
description: Despite rising test scores and other evidence of better academic performance in general, improvements in the last five years have ''bypassed'' urban schools, the trustees of one of the country's most influential educational foundations charged yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Approves Team Shift
description: The National Football League's team owners voted reluctantly, but overwhelmingly, today to approve the St. Louis Cardinals' move to Phoenix and a stadium with 20,000 more seats.

title: Panama Troops Storm a Hospital To Quell Pay Protest by Workers
description: Panamanian military units attacked the country's largest hospital today after doctors, nurses and other medical workers who had not been paid took to the streets demanding their paychecks and the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. At least 23 workers were hit by birdshot or otherwise wounded in the three-hour skirmish, which ended when heavily armed military forces stormed the hospital.

title: A Surprise Resignation At Hanover
description: In a move that stunned the banking world, John R. Torell 3d resigned yesterday as president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. The 48-year-old executive has been with the banking company for 27 years and was widely assumed to be the heir apparent to John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive.

title: Koch Criticizes City's Legislators In Fight for More State School Aid
description: Renewing the war that began two months ago with a battle over pension increases, Mayor Koch and New York City lawmakers traded accusations today over who is to blame for the problems of the city's school system.

title: Closing P.L.O. Office Strikes at Free Speech; Take It to Court
description: To the Editor:

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Desserts That Once Eased the Hard Lives of Pioneers
description: LEAD: OLD-FASHIONED seasonal desserts are legendary here in the Ottawa Valley, and almost as familar as the local greeting, ''Gi'day, gi'day, I come from the valley.''

title: Bond Trading Drifts in Doldrums
description: Bond prices continued to drift aimlessly in very light trading yesterday as market participants were forced to scramble to drum up business.

title: Rev. John Fletcher, 87; Ministered to the Deaf
description: The Rev. John Capers Fletcher, a retired Episcopal priest who ministered to the deaf for 47 years, died of a heart attack March 3 at Alexandria, Va., Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Alexandria.

title: Economic Scene; A Demand-Side Cocaine Policy
description: ECONOMISTS who analyze the illegal drug markets offer a skeptical perspective on Washington's strategy for stopping cocaine. They acknowledge that the current $700 million interdiction effort has increased risks for smugglers. But as Peter Reuter of the Rand Corporation argues, the quantity of powder seized is a poor measure of how successful the program is.

title: Boxing Notebook; Foreign TV Bullish on Tyson
description: When Mike Tyson fought Larry Holmes in January, Bill Cayton, one of the heavyweight champion's managers, said he sold foreign television rights on the bout in 45 to 50 countries.

title: Washington Talk: The House of Representatives; A House Divided by Political Rancor
description: It is not easy being the minority party in the House of Representatives, and Republicans have had to accept that since 1955.

title: Anti-Gandhi Strike Grips Much of India
description: Thousands of opposition politicians, trade union leaders and others were arrested today during a one-day nationwide strike called to press for new elections and the resignation of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government.

title: Democrats Take Assembly Seats In 4 of 5 Races
description: Democrats, already a strong majority in the New York Assembly, held onto four seats yesterday in an unusually large number of special elections on Long Island and in the Bronx and Buffalo area.

title: LESSONS
description: Allan Bloom, perhaps America's most literate malcontent, arrived here the other day ready to defend his well-known and well-read complaint on the state of the American university. His book, ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' published by Simon & Schuster, has been both a best seller and a lightning rod.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bergman Heads for Brooklyn Stage Debut
description: Ingmar Bergman's stark, sexually explicit production of ''Hamlet'' will be presented for one week in June at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: At the Top of the Game, Bird Plots a Way to Leave It
description: LEAD: Larry Bird, at 31 years old, in his ninth and possibly finest season with the Boston Celtics, has been making the spectacular seem ordinary for so long that there is a danger of taking him for granted.

title: Market Place; Analysts Favor Bar Code Stocks
description: STOCKS related to bar code reading equipment - one of technology's niche industries - have sharply recovered from their low prices in the October market debacle. These companies continue to benefit from broadening applications and from forecasts of higher profits.

title: Atari Is Suing Micron Over Prices for Chips
description: In an action that underscores the tensions caused by the current shortage of computer memory chips, the Atari Corporation has charged Micron Technology Inc., a small memory chip manufacturer, with reneging on an agreement in an effort to obtain higher prices for its products.

title: About New York; A Matchmaker For Stories And Storytellers
description: On the 19th floor of an old office building in midtown Manhattan a woman mans a telephone the livelong day. At times, people ring her up and tell her the most astonishingly intimate stories, laying bare their lives in the hope that a book will come out of it, or a movie or at least an article. The woman, Dorothy Beach, runs Dial-A-Writer (212-398-1934).

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results are in U.S. currency and have been translated at the Dec. 31, 1987 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dkr. 6.0965. The share earnings are in American Depositary Shares. Novo Industri's consolidated 1987 sales and earnings included those of the company's 90 percent-owned Danish Ferrosan Group.

title: Gap Narrows In U.S. Trade
description: The Government's broadest measure of the United States' trade performance, the current account deficit, shrank significantly, to $38.99 billion, in the last three months of 1987, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen is on vacation. Her column is moving to The Home Section, where it will appear starting Thursday, March 24.

title: F.D.A. Faults Quality Control At Drug Plant a Second Time
description: The Food and Drug Administration has released a report that for a second time sharply criticizes quality control at LyphoMed Inc., which makes drugs to fight symptoms of AIDS and other diseases.

title: 2 Key Democrats Ask Party To Back June Front-Runner; Kirk Says the Winner Will Emerge From Current Field
description: The Democratic national chairman said today that he expected a front-runner to emerge from the current field of Presidential contenders and that he would ask the rest of the candidates to rally behind this front-runner after the final primaries in June even if he lacked an actual majority of convention delegates.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall
description: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.5902 percent, down from last week's 6.5941 percent, and $50 million of 182-day paper at 6.6250 percent, down from 6.6472 percent.

title: ALLEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued European operations of $7,000 and $2,429,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes losses from discontinued European operations of $5,169,000 for the quarter and $8,732,000 for the year. The company said the latest quarter and year include a charge of $200,000 and a gain of $1,300,000, respectively, relating to an accounting change, charges of $2,800,000 for the quarter and $3,700,000 for the year both from severance and employee termination costs and a charge of $1,900,000 for both the quarter and year from the re- evalution of certain programs within the automotive test and service business segment. Year-ago quarter and year include a charge of $11,000,000 for restructuring of the company, and the quarter also includes a charge from an accounting change of $1,200,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 16, 1988
description: COMPANIES First Republicbank asked the F.D.I.C. to prevent its failure. The largest Texas banking company, with assets of more than $33 billion, was besieged anew by negative reports in the press and depositor withdrawals. A bailout would likely be among the most costly in the history of the F.D.I.C. [ Page D1. ] First City Bancorporation's tender offer for bonds failed to attract the amount of securities the Texas banking company needed to proceed with a complex $1.47 billion rescue plan. [ D2. ] Northwest Airlines eased the advance purchase requirement to three days on a discount fare widely used by business travelers. That change took effect as airlines including Northwest raised full coach fares and ended some discount fares. [ D1. ] Manufacturers Hanover's president resigned. John R. Torell 3d was widely assumed to be the heir apparent to John F. McGillicuddy, the chairman and chief executive. [ D1. ] Columbia Pictures Entertainment expects limited profits for the next three years. [ D2. ] Federated Department Stores reported higher net income for its fourth quarter and full fiscal year. Federated is the object of a fierce takeover battle between Macy and Campeau. [ D5. ] Atari charged Micron Technology with reneging on an agreement in an effort to obtain higher prices for its chips. [ D5. ] A buyout offer for Shoney's South was raised to $14 a share, or about $95.2 million, by a management group. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The U.S. economy looks a little stronger than it seemed a few weeks ago, and the likelihood of a recession is abating, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said. [ D1. ] Early March sales of U.S. cars and light trucks rose 6.3 percent from a year ago. Ford increased its share of the market to 35 percent, up four percentage points. [ D1. ] A major Democratic fund-raiser was indicted on Federal charges of wire fraud and making false statements. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL A striking simplification of Britain's tax code was proposed by the Government. Under the plan Britons earning more than $35,700 would be taxed at 40 percent. Those earning less would be taxed at 25 percent. [ D1. ] MARKETS Investors are suing the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Options Clearing Corporation, accusing them of mispricing stock index options and failing to maintain fair and orderly markets during the October market collapse. [ D7. ] Stock prices ended mixed as both blue chips and secondary issues continued to meander in lackluster trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.66 points, to 2,047.41. [ D8. ] Bond prices continued to drift aimlessly in light trading that one trader called the quietest market in four or five years. [ D14. ] The dollar gained against most major currencies in light trading. Gold rose $4.10 an ounce in New York, to $446. [ D15. ] Precious metals and crude oil futures prices advanced in New York after meandering on Asian and European markets. [ D15. ] TECHNOLOGY A device that builds three-dimensional models of objects only minutes after they have been designed on a screen has been invented by Texas graduate student. Advances. [ D6. ] A high-tech catalogue selling custom genes to pharmaceutical companies is being offered by a small company in Oxford, England. The 19 genes range in price from about $925 to $9,250. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Economists suggest a multi-pronged approach for reducing cocaine use that they say would also reduce the costs of consumption borne by society. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Companies involved in bar-code technology have recovered from their low prices in the October market debacle, benefiting from broadening applications. Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Fed Chairman Finds Economy Is Stronger
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the economy looked a little stronger than it did a few weeks ago and that the likelihood of a recession was rapidly abating.

title: Suits Filed By Options Investors
description: Two groups of investors have filed separate lawsuits against the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the Options Clearing Corporation, accusing them of mispricing stock index options and failing to maintain fair and orderly markets during the October market collapse.

title: DIGITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10,000 for the latest quarter and $113,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: ALLIANCE IMAGING reports earnings for
News Summary
description: International A3-13 A hospital in Panama was attacked after doctors and nurses who had not been paid took to the streets demanding their paychecks and the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. At least 23 medical workers were wounded. Page A1 Soviet troops will stay in Afghanistan because the United States and Pakistan have prevented completion of an agreement to end the Afghan war, Moscow announced. The negotiations failed to produce an agreement by the deadline. A1 U.S.-Israeli talks were stalled over the Reagan Administration's proposed Middle East negotiating formula, with Prime Minister Shamir reportedly objecting to most of the ideas put forth by the Secretary of State. A6 A general strike among Palestinians protesting Israeli occupation paralyzed the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, and two Palestinians were reported killed in the revolt. At least 88 Palestinians have been killed since the uprising began. A6 Jewish settlers in the occupied lands are becoming increasingly embroiled in conflict with the Palestinians, and the sense of separate and competing destinies has become even deeper. A6 Thousands were arrested in India during a daylong nationwide strike called to press for new elections and the resignation of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Government. The strike appeared to be most effective in the major cities. A3 A vote on aid to the contras won't come this week, Democratic leaders told President Reagan. They said they were not prepared to vote and that any future package would have to resemble a Democratic plan the House rejected this month. A12 A slain Irish rebel will be buried to the words of the priest who knew her, the Rev. Raymond Murray. The woman, Mairead Farrell, was shot as she and two other rebels plotted to bomb a British parade. A10 Gorbachev offers his vision of Europe's future A3 Bordeaux journal: With glitz and a grin, Chirac gains A4 Syria, for first time, plans to export oil A9 Soviet is said to reduce support for Cuban economy A13 National A14-24 George Bush defeated Bob Dole in the Illinois Republican Presidential primary, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. Senator Paul Simon led the Rev. Jesse Jackson among Democrats in the poll and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis finished a distant third. A1 News Analysis: Can Jackson win? His race and his low support among white voters are cited by most senior Democrats, who say the answer is no. Mr. Jackson has had to depend on black voters for the considerable electoral success he has scored so far. A1 The first black Catholic archbishop in the United States, Eugene Antonio Marino, was named yesterday as the new Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta, becoming the highest ranking black Catholic clergyman in the country. A1 Schooling in urban areas has not improved despite rising test scores and other evidence of better academic performance by American schoolchildren in general, the Carnegie Foundation charged. A1 Many jobs may be disappearing as soon as soon as a recession hits, economists and executives say. Though 10 million jobs have been created in the current economic re-covery, they are temporary and highly fragile. A1 A major immigration bill was passed in the Senate that intends to place slightly greater emphasis on occupational skills in determining who can legally immigrate to the United States. The bill was approved 88 to 4. A14 Washington Talk A22 Bitter feelings intensify between two parties in House Regional B1-5 The campaign funds of state officials were examined in testimony before the State Government Integrity Commission, painting a picture of officials begging for contributions, donors disguising them and aides soliciting them. A1 Many city apartments were vacant last year, while 28,000 homeless people stayed in municipal shelters and welfare hotels, according to a city study. Officials contend landlords deliberately kept the apartments empty. B1 More students have been applying to New York City public schools than classrooms can handle, and P.S. 87 is one of them. The school is thriving in a city where the public school system has been buried in criticism. B1 News analysis: In the Brawley case, the grand jury is considering a case with unclear facts and no suspects, in which the person who claims to have been attacked is refusing to provide details. What is the grand jury doing in a case like this? B1 A key informer was found dead execution-style Saturday in a parking lot in Irvine, Calif. The victim, George Yudzevich, recently helped convict the underboss of the Gambino crime family and two other mob figures in a trial in New York. B3 Arguing over the city school system, Mayor Koch and New York City lawmakers traded accusations over who is to blame for the system's problems. Mr. Koch said lawmakers were not fighting hard enough to increase state school aid to the city. B3 A coalition of clergymen in Queens said they support a thorough effort to rid their streets of drugs, but they oppose the reinsitution of the death penalty as called for by officials after the death of Officer Edward Byrne. B3 Computers replacing men at the Ambrose Light Station B1 Country club held liable for beesting B3 Jersey panel criticizes state's purchase of a lake B4

title: Final Arguments Set In Trial of Chambers
description: Final arguments in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. are to begin today at 8:30 A.M. and will continue through ''a long day'' until completed, the judge in the case told the jury yesterday.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-After a gain of $2,413,000 from an accounting change.

title: Bordeaux Journal; Here's Chirac! With Glitz and a Grin, He Advances
description: The big convention hall throbs to the driving rhythms of a rock song called ''The Final Countdown.'' Bathed in spotlights, a long white panel proclaims Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's virtues: ''Courage, Ardor, Will.'' And: ''He brings people together, he listens, he builds.''

title: Wepner Sentenced
description: Chuck Wepner, who once fought for the heavyweight title, was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison after admitting to cocaine charges. Wepner, who lost a bid for the title in 1975 to Muhammad Ali, was arrested in Sayreville, N.J., in November 1985 as part of an undercover police investigation. Under a plea-bargain agreement, Wepner faced up to 10 years in prison, and that was the sentence handed down by Superior Court Judge Joseph F. Deegan Jr.(AP)

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
US TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-earlier fourth quarter included the provision for litigation settlement equal to 14 cents a share with respect to settlement of a labor dispute with a group of its employees. The results for the fourth quarters of 1987 and 1986 were affected by various year-end adjustments, principally wage and benefit accruals. The impact on both years' fourth quarter results was a benefit of 7 cents a share in 1987 and a loss of 1 cent a share for 1986. The company also said the latest fourth quarter results were hurt by the expiration of reversing deferred tax credits that previously had been used to offset losses in prior quarters of 1987 and 1986.

title: Food Fit for the Stars, or at Least a Mountaintop
description: Cuisine of the kind rarely found outside France's best restaurants will be on its way to the stars if three enterprising Frenchmen have their way: they plan to package fine food for space flights, long expeditions on Earth or just family outings.

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $10,228,000. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $82,000 and $794,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Terry Anderson, Devalued
description: LEAD: Since the morning of March 16, 1985, when Terry Anderson, an Associated Press correspondent, was dragged from a car in West Beirut, his whole world has been a series of damp basements and cramped rooms. His companions have been a blindfold and a chain. Fear, loneliness and doubt have kept vigil with him through the long nights.

title: GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Obstacle to Licensing Of Reactor Is Removed
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has withdrawn a key objection to New Hampshire's emergency evacuation plans for the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page last Thursday about macular degeneration, an eye disease, incorrectly described the dosage in an experimental study. Each day, the patients took 200 milligrams of zinc sulfate, which contains 80 milligrams of zinc.

title: New Settlement Limits All-Terrain Vehicles
description: A new settlement that continues the ban on three-wheel all-terrain vehicles and calls for more than $8 million in corrective advertising was disclosed Monday by the Consumer Product Safety Commission.

title: LDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Business Ethics Plan Gains
description: House conferees privately agreed today to accept a Senate-passed measure, with major modifications, that would relax ethical strictures on United States businesses abroad, but only as part of a package that resolves a House-passed measure requiring foreign investors to disclose their identities and holdings.

title: France's Cozy Election
description: Some French are complaining again at the ''Americanization'' of their campaign for president. They mean a focus on personality, with nothing much clear-cut in the way of programs or issues.

title: O'Sullivan Entered
description: Marcus O'Sullivan, who ran this year's fastest indoor mile in 3 minutes 50.94 seconds last month at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, will head a team from Ireland in the Asics Cup America's Ekiden, a 50-kilometer relay race involving nine national team through the streets of Manhattan on Saturday, April 9. The United States team will consist of Steve Scott, Pat Porter, Mark Nenow, John Gregorek and Mark Curp.

title: Hall of Famers
description: Six former star athletes - including three football players - were selected for induction into the National High School Sports Hall of Fame in Kansas City, Mo. The football players were Len Dawson of the Kansas City Chiefs, Elroy (Crazylegs) Hirsch of the Los Angeles Rams, and Jim Taylor of the Green Bay Packers. Also inducted were Cliff Hagan, a former star with the St. Louis Hawks who is the athletic director at the University of Kentucky; Randy Matson, a silver-medal winner in the shot put at the 1964 Olympics and a gold-medal winner in 1968, and Brutus Hamilton, an Olympic silver-medal winner in the decathlon in 1920.

title: Bridge
description: In the 1930's, 40's and 50's, college campuses provided constant bridge activity. In a few cases dedicated enthusiasts found that their passion for the game inhibited graduation.

title: Review/Theater; 'Juan Darien,' a Tragic Story Told Without Talk
description: In the distance on the deep St. Clement's stage, there is a tiny church, and, as we watch, the church windows crumble and the building itself seems to disintegrate. Suddenly, lush foliage descends until the stage becomes a jungle. Strange serpentine creatures slither through the vines and leaves. Lizards fly, accompanied by frenzied night sounds. A mother tiger is slain, and her cub stands forlornly in the wilderness.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS A 'EUROPE FOR ALL'
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, traveling in Yugoslavia, today proposed a beguiling vision of an integrated Europe with fewer weapons and more economic coherence.

title: Cowboy Grievance
description: The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint yesterday against Tex Schramm, the Dallas Cowboys' president and general manager, and the club management for threatening players with reprisals if they had engaged in union activities during the players' strike that began lastSept. 22. The board issued the complaint based upon these charges: Threatening Tony Dorsett, the running back, with loss of deferred compensation and forcing him into early repayment of a loan specified in his contract unless he crossed the picket line; threatening Ed Jones and Kevin Brooks, defensive linemen, with loss of deferred compensation unless they played during the strike; taking reporting bonuses from Everson Walls, cornerback, and threatening him with loss of deferred income unless he crossed the picket line; informing Karl Powe, the wide receiver, that he would have to resign from the union to obtain physical therapy at the team's facility.(AP)

title: U.S.-ISRAELI TALKS FAIL TO BEAR FRUIT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel failed today to break their impasse over the Reagan Administration's proposed Middle East negotiating formula, with Mr. Shamir reportedly objecting to most of the ideas put forth by the United States.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Evert, Seguso Advance: Chris Evert overwhelmed Alycia Moulton, 6-0, 6-0, and Robert Seguso celebrated the birth of his first child with a five-set triumph over Horacio de la Pena last night at the $2.1 million Lipton International Players championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Seguso rallied to beat de la Pena, 3-6, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-2, less than 24 hours after his wife, Carling Bassett Seguso, gave birth to a boy. Second-seeded Jimmy Connors had an easy time with Broderick Dyke, 6-2, 6-2, 6-0. But third-seeded Miloslav Mecir needed nearly three hours to beat George Bezecny, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4, 6-4. Third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini beat Helen Kelesi, 6-3, 6-1, and Hana Mandlikova defeated Vicki Nelson-Dunbar, 6-1, 6-0. Andres Gomez of Ecuador beat Dan Cassidy, 6-2, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2, and Anders Jarryd defeated Thierry Champion, 6-2, 6-1, 6-2.(AP) N.B.A. Celtics 119, Pacers 113: Larry Bird scored 17 of his 34 points in the third quarter as Boston beat Indiana in Indianapolis. Kevin McHale had 24 points and Robert Parish had 21 points and 14 rebounds for Boston (45-19). Chuck Person and Steve Stipanovich led Indiana (30-32) with 21 points apiece.(AP) Hawks 104, 76ers 90: Dominique Wilkins scored 26 points to lead Atlanta to the victory at home. The Sixers led by as many as 12 points early in the game before Atlanta (38-23) took a 59-57 lead at 10:57 of the third quarter. Charles Barkley led Philadelphia (26-36) with 22 points.(AP) Bulls 108, Cavaliers 89: Michael Jordan scored 12 of his 38 points during an 18-6 second-quarter run and Sam Vincent had a career-high 18 points and 11 assists for Chicago. Only Cleveland's Ron Harper, who had 20 points, could dent Chicago's defense, which held Brad Daugherty to 11 points and Larry Nance to 10. The Bulls (36-26) overcame a sluggish first quarter to overwhelm the Cavaliers (30-34), who lost their 10th consecutive road game. (AP) Bucks 108, Kings 97: Paul Pressey and Randy Breuer scored 17 points each as Milwaukee (35-26), using a third-quarter surge, defeated Sacramento for its 12th victory in its last 16 games. It was Sacramento's fourth straight loss. Derek Smith had 26 points for the Kings (18-45).(AP) Rockets 116, Clippers 110: Purvis Short and Akeem Olajuwon scored 30 points apiece to lead Houston (37-24) at home. It was the Clippers' eighth straight loss. The Rockets have won four of their last five games. The Clippers (12-48) have lost 24 consecutive road games. Los Angeles was led by Benoit Benjamin with 25 points and 12 rebounds.(AP) Suns 111, SuperSonics 90: Eddie Johnson scored 27 points and Phoenix (18-44) overcame an early 20-point deficit to defeat Seattle, ending a nine-game losing streak. The SuperSonics (33-20) had a three-game winning streak stopped despite 26 points from Tom Chambers.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 8, Whalers 6: Hakan Loob had his fifth three-goal game of the season and his second in as many games as Calgary outlasted Hartford to sweep a three-game season series. In the game in Hartford, Loob raised his season totals to 46 goal and 95 points. Mike Bullard added his 43d goal of the season for the Flames (42-21-8). The Whalers (29-35-7) fell into last place in the Adams Division. (AP) Nordiques 3, Maple Leafs 2: Anton Stasty scored the winning goal on a power play in the second period, and the goaltender Mario Brunetta blocked 20 shots as Quebec (31-36-4) moved into fourth place in the Adams Division. Gaetan Duchesne, with his 21st goal, and Mike Eagles also scored for Quebec. Mark Osborne and Gary Leeman scored for Toronto (20-42-10).(AP) SLED DOG RACING Butcher Takes Lead: Aiming for a third straight victory in the 1,150-mile Iditarod Trail race, Susan Butcher left the Eskimo village of Koyuk, Alaska, yesterday with a two-hour lead on Martin Buser. On the trail to Koyuk, Butcher and her 11-dog team overcame a one-hour deficit, passing Buser and building a lead of five hours by the time she reached the village, 171 miles from the finish line in Nome. Butcher rested and fed her weary dogs for more than 5 hours, leaving at 7:43 A.M. local time. Buser made up time by cutting short his stay in Koyuk. With 12 of his 20 original dogs still in harness, he followed Butcher out at 9:55 A.M. Sub-zero temperatures and biting winds still hindered the leaders, and forecasters said the wind-chill factor could sink to minus 70 degrees along the trail's final miles into Nome today. The four-time Iditarod champion, Rick Swenson, was about six hours behind Butcher in third place. Seventy-year-old Joe Redington was running sixth.(AP)

title: The Battle of the Scuds
description: By bombarding each other's capitals with missiles, Iran and Iraq have reached a new nadir in their savage seven-year war. The best hope of halting it lies in getting the United Nations to vote an embargo on arms sales to Iran. But the Soviet Union has continued to block such a resolution. The moment has come for the United States to put the resolution to a vote and let the Russians choose: Support it and incur the ire of Iran, or vote no and offend moderate Arabs and America.

title: From Screen to Solid 3-D Model In a Matter of Minutes
description: A GRADUATE student at the University of Texas has invented a device that builds three-dimensional models of objects only minutes after they have been designed on a screen using computer graphics. The inventor, Carl R. Deckard, likens the device to a three-dimensional laser printer that is capable of producing a solid object rather than a two-dimensional representation of the object.

title: SOVIET POSTPONES AFGHAN PULLOUT
description: The Soviet Union said today that it was postponing the withdrawal of its troops from Afghanistan because the United States and Pakistan had prevented completion of an agreement to end the Afghan war.

title: Rangers Get on a Roll
description: Tough guys don't dance. Every once in a while, though, they do score goals and are moved to try. Last night, Chris Nilan's choreography left something to be desired. His goal, however, showed perfect timing.

title: Topics of The Times; Romare Bearden's Adventure
description: ''You don't paint what you see; you paint what you feel.'' That was the philosophy of Romare Bearden, the master of collage art, who died Saturday at the age of 75.

title: New Musical Features Frank Loesser Works
description: ''Perfectly Frank,'' a musical featuring the works of Frank Loesser, will begin performances tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at the St. Bart's Playhouse, Park Avenue and 50th Street. More than 50 years in the composer's career are covered in the musical, which will run through March 26.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
Everyone Is Asking 'Who Is Anouska?'
description: Anouska Hempel, a tiny wraithlike figure in a black silk calf-length dress and stocking feet, did not graciously accept the compliments of those who filed backstage after her first formal fashion show Friday night. Instead, she nervously proceeded to tell them what went wrong.

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade starts tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. The parade begins at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads north on Fifth to 86th Street and then east to Third Avenue.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on disposal of assets of $1,439,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the quarter and $99,000 for the 9 months. The operating results for the latest periods included gains from the sale of property of $36,000 for the quarter and $845,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a gain of $607,000 resulting from the termination of a pension plan. A gain of $2.4 million in the latest periods from the sale of a manufacturing facility and related machinery and equipment was included in the results of discontinued operations. Included in the results of the third quarter and 9 months is an additional loss from discontinued operations of $394,000, in excess of the $551,000 provision for such losses recorded in fiscal 1987. The operating results of the previous 9 months included a gain of $1,036,000 from the disposal of assets. The year-ago sales restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: GALVESTON-HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a credit of $5,242,000 from retirement of notes and tax benefits. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $18,138,000 from discontined operations.

title: Advance Purchase Rule Cut To 3 Days by Northwest Air
description: Northwest Airlines yesterday eased the advance purchase requirement, to three days, on a discount fare widely used by business travelers.

title: LARRIZZA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $213,000 and $1,358,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from the company's 50 percent equity in the earnings of Columbus Auto Parts Co., an unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: Review/Concert; Borodin Quartet at Tully
description: The Borodin Quartet is one of the Soviet Union's pre-eminent chamber groups, and one of the world's more durable ones. Founded in 1945, it boasts its original violist and cellist, and it hasn't had a personnel change since 1976. It is an ensemble that plays with an appealing sweetness, and moves with a seemingly unshakeable unity of purpose. Yet it also plays with a kind of restraint and enforced refinement that makes its readings sound beautiful but bloodless.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Frank Vorenberg, 88, Ex-Head of Gilchrist's
description: F. Frank Vorenberg, a Boston merchant for more than half a century, died of heart disease Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88 years old. Mr. Vorenberg, who lived in Cambridge, was president of Gilchrist's, one of Boston's oldest department stores. His father, Felix Vorenberg, headed the store for many years.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Feb. 23 about the retirement plans of Lieut. Gen. William E. Odom, director of the National Security Agency, reported that his deputy, Richard Lord, had retired previously.

title: U.S. Tests Find Drug in Hogs
description: Preliminary results of intensified testing by the Agriculture Department for drug residues in pork indicate that 4 percent of the tested carcasses contained excessive traces of a food additive that has been found to cause cancer in mice.

title: Study Shows Significant Decline in Ozone Layer
description: Federal scientists reported today that atmospheric ozone over the Northern Hemisphere had declined significantly over the last two decades. The study, the most authoritative so far, reaches a conclusion similar to another reported earlier this year but adds important new details on the extent of worldwide depletion of the protective ozone shield.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Joseph J. Roberto, a former architect for New York University, omitted a survivor.

title: Johnson Taking a Look at Mets' Bench
description: Dave Johnson calls them his irregulars. They have talent but no jobs. Some of them are outplaying the regulars, and one or two may even force their way onto the squad by the end of spring training.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results for 1986 include a non-cash loss of $20,382,000 due to the writedown in the net investment in the company's oil and gas properties as required by the SEC.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $474,000 on the sale of land. The company noted that earnings for the latest 6 months benefitted by the lower effective income tax rates as provided by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Wilson Ferreira, 69, The Longtime Chief of Uruguay Liberals
description: Wilson Ferreira Aldunate, the leader of Uruguay's largest opposition party, died today after a yearlong fight against cancer, his family said. He was 69 years old.

title: General Mills' Profits Rise
description: General Mills Inc. said today that its earnings jumped 25.5 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of growth in its consumer foods division.

title: Democrats Delay a Vote on Contra Aid
description: House Democratic leaders told President Reagan today that they were not prepared to vote this week on a new aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels. They also made it clear that any package considered later would have to resemble a Democratic plan that the House rejected this month.

title: NORD RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MATEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $94,000 for the quarter and a loss of $306,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. The year-ago periods' nets from continuing operations are after net gains of $85,000 for the quarter and $209,000 for the year from the sale of assets. The latest quarter and year figures included the results of Electro Fiberoptics Corp., acquired Dec. 30, 1986.

title: Advertsing; AGB Would Play David to Nielsen Goliath
description: THIS could be called a David and Goliath story except that in such a story David wins. The results of the contest between the AGB Television Research and A.C. Nielsen ''people meters'' may well be far less heroic.

title: Donors Tell New York Panel Of Disguising Political Funds
description: Contributors and solicitors for campaign funds in New York State yesterday painted a graphic and unusually detailed portrait of the tricks of the fund-raising trade that pay for the election of public officials. They told a state integrity panel about officials begging for contributions, donors disguising their contributions and state aides soliciting campaign funds from people doing business with or regulated by the state.

title: Article 144588 -- No Title
description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has levied a total of $100,000 in fines against three Japanese companies whose ships were videotaped while apparently fishing illegally in United States waters.

title: Merc Official Re-elected
description: Zoltan (Lou) Guttman was re-elected vice chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange last night, defeating John Tafaro, a former member of the Merc's board, 283-272. Mr. Guttman will serve another two-year term. William Bradt is the chairman of the New York Merc. Exchange members also chose five new members for the Merc's board.

title: FLORIDA EXECUTES CELEBRATED KILLER
description: Willie Jasper Darden, who maintained his innocence through 14 years on death row and became the focus of an international debate over capital punishment, was executed today in Florida's electric chair.

title: Dukakis Holds a Wide Lead In Washington State Contest
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts held a wide lead over Jesse Jackson in last Tuesday's Presidential precinct caucuses in Washington state, the first stage of a process to pick 65 national convention delegates. Party officials released the first results today after gathering returns by mail.

title: It's Politics, the Old-Fashioned Way
description: By 7:30 on the morning of the Illinois Presidential primary, Michael R. Zalewski had promised to have a tree cut down, ordered a truck to haul away debris from a burned-out garage and shaken dozens of hands at a polling place in Chicago's Southwest Side, all for the 23d Ward Democratic Party Organization.

title: Review/Television; Kissinger on a New Program
description: The Council on Foreign Relations and the City University of New York are beginning a monthly program today called ''Worldview.'' The initial hourlong cable television program, with Henry A. Kissinger as the guest commentator, is worth watching if only for the 10 minutes or so in which the former Secretary of State offers his views on the current Middle East problems.

title: A Winner Loses
description: A fugitive arrested after he was recognized on the television game show ''Super Password'' pleaded guilty Monday to collecting $100,000 on a life insurance policy by falsely contending his wife had been killed. The 36-year-old fugitive, Kerry Dee Ketchem, appearing under a pseudonym on ''Super Password,'' was identified by a viewer and was arrested as he tried to pick up a record $58,600 in winnings.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Obstacles in Jackson Path: Arithmetic and Attitudes
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson managed 7 percent of the white vote in today's Illinois primary, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll of voters who had just cast their ballots, and took his anticipated 90 percent of the black vote. But, as Mr. Jackson conceded tonight, that was not enough to win the statewide popularity contest here, or enough to give him anything approaching a majority of the 173 Democratic convention delegates chosen in today's voting.

title: 3 Ex-Cards Helping Pirates
description: When the trade was made, it delivered to the St. Louis Cardinals the final segment in what they expected to be their pennant-winning plan. The Cardinals won the pennant, but Tony Pena did not help much. The Pittsburgh Pirates, on the other hand, didn't win anything, but they improved impressively with the aide of Andy Van Slyke, Mike LaValliere and Mike Dunne.

title: Singapore's Labor Tax
description: Singapore will not cut the tax that employers pay for hiring foreign workers, despite demands by some members of Parliament to do so, Labor Minister Lee Yock Suan said today. Reducing the tax could cause social, economic and political problems, he said.

title: Iraqis and Iranians Continue Their Attacks Against Cities
description: Iran and Iraq struck each other's cities with missiles, bombs and artillery today in a third straight day of attacks on cities. Communiques from both sides, monitored in Nicosia, reported scores of civilians killed or wounded.

title: Dartmouth Journal; 'AIDS Road Show' Stoking a Feud
description: On the pastoral campus of Dartmouth College, where homosexuals and intravenous drug users are about as visible as skyscrapers and taxicabs, the subject of AIDS is rousing the students as fervently as keg parties and the upcoming winter term exams.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 13
Washington Talk: Briefing; 'Scrubbed' Drug Plan
description: A Congressional subcommittee and the Reagan Administration are wrestling over access to documents describing the Administration's strategy for combating the drug crisis.

title: Societe Generale
description: Societe Generale de Belgique, the giant Belgian conglomerate at the center of a takeover battle, said it would hold an extraordinary meeting of its shareholders on April 14. The gathering promises a showdown between the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti and a rival alliance of French and Belgian companies unless the two camps can settle a two-month battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique before then.

title: Panama Orders Envoy to Leave; U.S. Refuses
description: The State Department said today that the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had ordered an American diplomat to leave Panama but that the United States would not comply.

title: Federated Net Up 3.3% as Its Tax Declines
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the target of an intensifying takeover war, reported higher net income for its fourth quarter and full fiscal year, helped by a smaller Federal income-tax bite.

title: Newborns in 30 Cities to Be Tested For Presence of AIDS Antibodies
description: Newborn babies in 30 cities will be checked for AIDS virus antibodies in tests aimed at providing an early and broader look at who is getting the disease.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,569,000 from a litigation award. The latest quarter and year included interest income relating to litigation of $398,000 and $1,515,000, respectively. The year-ago quarter and year included charges of $113,000 and $691,000, respectively, relating to litigation. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $14,341,000 on the early extinguishment of debt. The company said its latest year and fourth-quarter results included gains of $7.1 million from the sale by its Federated Stores Realty Inc. unit of interest in a shopping center. The prior year included gains of $9.5 million in the third quarter, and $9.1 million in the fourth quarter, from the unit's sale of two shopping centers. The company also said its 1986 results were hurt by a $15.7 million charge from the merger of two department store divisions in the fourth quarter, and an $8.1 million charge for a loss on the disposition of two Philadelphia department stores in the third quarter.

title: Drug Witness Is Resolute at Meeting
description: As police officers in bulletproof vests stood guard in front of his house, a Guyanese immigrant named Arjune, who is a witness in a Queens narcotics case, explained yesterday why he would not be intimidated even though his house had been firebombed twice and the young officer guarding it was slain.

title: A Nevada Offering Of Airport Bonds
description: Nevada's Clark County is offering $170 million of airport system improvement revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.53 percent for those due in 2015 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago 6 months included the proceeds from the sale of Patient Monitoring Technology.

title: Books of The Times; History as a Mix of Fact and Surreal Melodrama
description: The Surprise of Burning By Michael Doane 258 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95

title: The Latest for Asthmatics: OROS Push Pull Osmotic System
description: Later this year, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve a prescription asthma drug developed by Glaxo Inc. that uses time-release technology invented by the Alza Corporation. Although the technology has been available for most of this decade, the time required for regulatory approval has delayed its use with prescription drugs in this country. The medication is sandwiched with an osmotic agent that swells when it takes up water. The sandwich is then coated with a semipermeable membrane and a laser is used to drill a tiny hole through the membrane. In the stomach, water passes through the membrane into the pill, putting the drug into solution and causing the osmotic material to swell, which pushes the drug out of the hole. This delivers the drug to the body at a constant rate instead of all at once, as happens when a traditional pill dissolves.

title: Women and Cooking
description: To The Living Section:

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Review/Television; Family Life in a Welfare Hotel on 'The Equalizer'
description: The plight of the homeless is not the most popular subject on prime-time entertainment. Television normally prefers uplifting and inspirational situations. One of the few television movies to cope with the homeless featured a feistily cute Lucille Ball as a bag lady. Among the weekly series, the subject has been broached at least occasionally on ''Beauty and the Beast,'' which describes itself as a ''contemporary fable.'' A certain distancing is necessary.

title: Cabbies Plan Strike, Alleging Harassment
description: An organization that represents taxi drivers here intends to strike today to protest what it called harassment by city regulators.
