title: Review/Music; New Amsterdam Singers
description: The most interesting piece on Sunday's Merkin Concert Hall program by the New Amsterdam Singers was also the least well sung. Carman Moore's ''Sorrow of Love'' after the poem by Yeats was full of ambitious devices - crowd murmurs, overlapping snippets of declamation, solos and chordal and imitative textures.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Talking Deals; Borden Expands Piece by Piece
description: MORE than ever, the strategy in takeovers seems to be that bigger is better. Multibillion-dollar corporate takeovers - dollar amounts that years ago would set records - have become common. Whether it's tires or textiles, retailing or pharmaceuticals, no industry appears to have been spared.

title: SOUTH AFRICA FIRM ON HANGING OF SIX
description: President P. W. Botha has come under intense domestic and international pressure to spare the lives of six blacks who are scheduled to be hanged Friday for the killing of a black councilman by a mob in 1984. But hopes for a stay of executions faded tonight.

title: Sports People; U.S.-Soviet Wrestling
description: Bruce Baumgartner and Randy Lewis, Olympic champions, head the 10-man United States team that will meet a Soviet Union squad in the Wrestling Summit March 29 at the Felt Forum, the Metropolitan Wrestling Association Inc., announced yesterday.

title: N.F.L. Extends Instant Replay
description: Instant replay will remain another year to tantalize and taunt National Football League fans.

title: Sports People; Skier to Retire
description: After spending nine years on the World Cup skiing circuit, Laurie Graham of Canada announced yesterday that she would retire after racing next Wednesday in Sallbach, Austria, in the final World Cup downhill race of the season. The 27-year-old Graham is a six-time winner on the World Cup circuit, but she failed to win a medal in three appearances in the Winter Olympic Games.(AP)

title: Review/Recital; The Classical Guitars of the Assad Brothers
description: It is probably no accident that so many performing duos consist of siblings. Sergio and Odair Assad, who played their guitars at Merkin Hall Thursday night, are brothers and look at first glance like twins (they are four years apart). Their playing is also remarkably together, despite the free, uninhibited approach to the most complex of music. These are mysteries perhaps as much biological as musical.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Warns Union He'll Use Private Garbage Collectors
description: Two years ago, Mayor W. Wilson Goode won widespread applause when he broke an unpopular 20-day strike by a union so powerful, in the view of many Philadelphians, that it actually ran the city sanitation department - and none too well, at that.

title: Sports People; Budd Withdraws
description: After days of debate between the International Amateur Athlete Federation and British track and field officials about whether Zola Budd should be eligible for international meets because she might have competed in South Africa, she solved the problem by withdrawing from the British team at the world cross-country championships.

title: CONSUMER OUTLAYS SPURRING ECONOMY
description: The latest reports on jobs, consumer debt, production and the like are convincing many economists that the economy is a lot stronger these days than they were predicting just a few weeks ago. Today's announcement of an 8.9 percent jump in home construction last month is further evidence of the economy's surprising resilience.

title: Putting New Dresses on Old Buildings
description: ''NORMALLY, architects don't like to get compared to fashion designers,'' said Matteo Thun. But then his exhibition, ''Heavy Dress: a Manifesto of Architecture,'' blurs the line between fashion design and architecture.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included gains from the sale of idle properties of $414,000 for the quarter and $909,000 for the 9 months. c-Included a gain of $406,000 from the sale of idle properties for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Waterhouse Appointments
description: In one of his first moves since being appointed chairman of Price Waterhouse & Company last fall, Shaun F. O'Malley has named 12 partners to senior positions. Two of them, Dominic A. Tarantino and James E. Daley, have been named to the office of the chairman. Mr. Tarantino, now vice chairman of tax services, will run Price Waterhouse when Mr. O'Malley is absent and will join him in representing the firm in external affairs, human resources and professional matters. Mr. Daley will coordinate the geographic practices and professional service areas.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in December 1987.

title: House Panel Approves Rise in Minimum Wage
description: The House Education and Labor Committee voted today to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.05 an hour in several steps over the next four years.

title: C. B. King, 64, Is Dead; Rights Lawyer in South
description: C. B. King, a lawyer from Albany, Ga., who was prominent in the Southern civil rights struggles in the early 1960's, died of prostate cancer Tuesday while traveling in California. He was 64 years old.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tax Returns Aren't Speed Trials
description: The Reagan Administration deserves heaps of credit for its war on red tape. The Office of Management and Budget estimates it has sliced away 560 million hours that people used to spend filling out Federal forms each year. But stopwatch efficiency can go too far. Now the tape-cutters want every Federal tax form to carry an estimate of how long the ''average taxpayer'' should spend filling it out. That's asking for trouble. The proposed regulation is intended to focus all agencies' attention on the ''time burden'' imposed by their endless questions. The Internal Revenue Service properly objects to making taxes a time trial. Taxpayer attitudes are sensitive and personal; some people accept their civic duty while others protest. Either way, what's the point of stirring up the public with a debatable time estimate whose very presence on the form insinuates that filing is onerous?

title: Frozen Food Unit For United Biscuit
description: United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C., a leading cookie maker, which owns the Keebler Company of Elmhurst, Ill., agreed to buy a big British frozen foods business from Hanson TrustP.L.C. for $:335 million, or about $620 million. Hanson, a conglomerate with holdings in Britain and the United States, bought the frozen foods company, Ross Young's, in 1986 when it took over Imperial Group P.L.C.

title: Empire of America Begins A $191 Million Offering
description: Empire of America Federal Savings Bank yesterday began offering $191 million of asset-backed certificates due in 1993 and priced to yield 7.99 percent through the First Boston Corporation acting as sole underwriter.

title: Aide Accuses Top Doctor of Plagiarism
description: Sharply conflicting testimony in a Federal trial yesterday focused on the accusation that a prominent physician had plagiarized a medical article written by a junior colleague.

title: Industrial Production Rises 0.2%
description: The nation's industrial production edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in February as reductions in output at auto factories and coal mines offset gains in other areas.

title: Ohio State Wins in N.I.T.
description: Perry Carter scored 25 points and had 10 rebounds last night as Ohio State defeated Old Dominion, 86-73, in the first round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Bridge; At Tournament in Reno, a Pre-Emptive Bid Revealed Something Important
description: Pre-emptive bidding is a two-edged sword. It will often achieve its aim of jostling the opposition into the wrong contract, but it may also give an opposing declarer a valuable clue in the play of the hand.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen's column will appear in this space beginning next Thursday. The Hers column will move to The New York Times Magazine, where it will appear on alternate Sundays beginning March 27.

title: Publication Is Advanced On Donald Regan Book
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich said this week that it had advanced from September to May the publication date of ''For the Record: From Wall Street to Washington'' by Donald T. Regan, former White House chief of staff.

title: Met Commissions Opera By Philip Glass for 1992
description: The Metropolitan Opera has commissioned Philip Glass, the most successful American opera composer of his generation, to provide a new work entitled ''The Voyage'' for performance in October 1992. The premiere of Mr. Glass's opera will help commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America.

title: Campeau Set to Alter Its Bid for Federated
description: The Campeau Corporation, the Toronto developer, turned up the pressure on Federated Department Stores Inc. yesterday by stating that it was ready to pay $68 a share in a one-tier offer for all of Federated's stock.

title: Ortega Denies That His Troops Crossed Into Honduras
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today rejected Reagan Administration charges that Nicaraguan forces are fighting inside Honduras, and he invited foreign observers to visit the border area to verify his statement.

title: Congress Needs Administration Help on Drugs; Yes to a Coordinator
description: To the Editor:

title: CUNY's Board Hears Opposition To Arts-Degree Plan for Teachers
description: The board of trustees of the City University of New York listened yesterday to a lengthy chorus of opposition to a proposal that would require aspiring teachers to earn a bachelor's degree in liberal arts rather than in education.

title: Washington Talk: The Supreme Court; Anti-Abortion Aid Stirs Church-State Questions
description: Posing as a frightened and pregnant teen-ager, a 24-year-old banker walked into the Pregnancy Distress Center in Columbus, Ohio, six weeks ago and asked for advice. She was leaning toward having an abortion, she said, but first she wanted to make sure she understood her other options.

title: Defense of Chartreuse
description: To The Home Section:

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL

title: Where the Fern, Not the Flower, Is King
description: LEAD: TO many, ferns are simply the decorative greens that provide background for cut flowers. But to the workers and owners of Florida's ferneries, the feathery fronds often mean lumbago and sleepless nights.

title: Let's Quit the Drug War
description: LEAD: An antiwar song that helped get the Smothers Brothers thrown off network television in the 60's went this way: ''We're waist deep in the Big Muddy, and the big fool says to push on.'' Today we're waist-deep in another unwinnable war, and many political leaders want to push on. This time it's a war on drugs.

title: New York Architecture
description: To The Home Section:

title: A 'Virus' Gives Business a Chill
description: For the first time in the United States, a computer program that can secretly spread from computer to computer and potentially destroy stored data has compromised a major commercial personal computer software product.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $6,568,000 from early retirement of debt. c-Net income

title: William Porter, 73, U.S. Delegate At Vietnam Peace Talks, Is Dead
description: William J. Porter, a diplomat and former Under Secretary of State, died of cancer Tuesday at the Rose Hawthorne Lathrop Home in Fall River, Mass. He was 73 years old and lived in Westport Point, Mass.

title: Marilyn R. Menge, Lawyer, 31
description: Marilyn R. Menge, vice president of the New York State Women's Bar Association, died of ovarian cancer Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 31 years old and lived in Albany.

title: Sports People; Cooper Ineligible
description: Because of dealings with three agents after the completion of the 1987 season, George Cooper, the fullback, has lost his scholarship at Ohio State. Cooper, the father of two children, said that having used up his college eligibility and needing money, he did not believe involvement with agents would influence his grant.

title: The Great Hunt For Dog Portraits
description: FOR generations, portraits of favorite dogs have held a special place in English drawing rooms. Now it seems that paintings of the pedigreed pets are found almost as frequently on the walls of New York living rooms as their real-life counterparts are on the paths of Central Park.

title: Edmund White's Tale Of a Gay youth
description: The Beautiful Room Is Empty By Edmund White 228 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Stock Dispute In Belgium Bid
description: A new legal battle has broken out between rival groups fighting for control of Belgium's biggest company, Societe Generale de Belgique, over the ownership of a key block of 10 million new shares in the conglomerate.

title: Colombia Convoy Ambushed
description: Eight soldiers and a civilian were killed and 13 people were wounded on Tuesday during an ambush by left-wing guerrillas in the northern part of the country, a spokesman for the military said today. In the Atlantic province of Cordoba, Alfonso Cujavanta, the regional leader of the leftist Patrotic Union, became the first newly elected official to be assassinated. Mr. Cujavanta was voted into office Sunday during nationwide balloting.

title: Loyola Marymount Runs Roughshod Over Opponents
description: Paul Westhead, the head coach at Loyola Marymount University, has an unusual message for his opponents in the West Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. ''We're not upset if you get a basket,'' he said. ''Just don't take a long time to do it.''

title: Linoleum as Weapon
description: To The Home Section:

title: Israel Cuts Phone Lines to Arabs; 4 More Are Slain
description: Israel severed international telephone links to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today in what the authorities described as a new effort to put pressure on the organization of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

title: HERS
description: ON April 15, 1964, a fat envelope from Mount Holyoke College arrived at my house telling me that I had been admitted to the class of '68. I was in heaven. I had wanted to attend a Seven Sisters school since I was 13 years old.

title: Review/Film; Immigrants as Predator and Prey in 'Photograph'
description: The Greece that is seen in Nicos Papatakis's ''Photograph'' is a place of sharp contrasts, a land of majestic mountain scenery and crumbling, tacky modern construction. It is a fierce longing for this homeland that propels the story forward, and the longing takes an unusual form. A shy, decent and illiterate Greek furrier named Gerasimos Jiras has been living in Paris for many years when, in 1971, a young relative named Ilias arrives with some information and a get-rick-quick scheme. It is Ilias's idea to befriend and exploit the older man by revealing dire news about Gerasimos's stepparents, then he stumbles onto an even better plan.

title: Army Tuition Aid Drying Up Under Budget Cuts
description: Army bases around the country are running out of tuition assistance funds for soldiers because of a $30 million cut in the Army's education budget, according to college groups.

title: Rocket Maker Fined in Fatal Fire
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. has been fined $31,700 for six violations of state health and safety rules after an investigation of a fire that destroyed an MX missile assembly building and killed five workers, officials said today.

title: In Tropical New York
description: IT'S a jungle out there. At the new Banana Republic store, which is modeled after Victorian residences in Burma, this is taken literally.

title: Scripps to Sell Stock to Public
description: The E. W. Scripps Company, the privately held parent corporation of the Scripps Howard Media Group, said this week that it plans to sell some of its limited-voting common stock to the public.

title: Canadians Acquire Stake in U.S. Trust
description: The Central Capital Corporastion, a Canadian financial services concern based in Toronto, bought a 7.8 percent stake in the U.S. Trust Corporation of New York for $31.3 million.

title: U.N. Asks Iran and Iraq To End 'War of Cities'
description: The Security Council issued an informal statement today calling on Iran and Iraq to end the 16-day-old ''war of the cities.''

title: Review/Film; A Pious Hasid in the Hell of Pigalle
description: The notion must have seemed like a laugh riot: take a pure and pious Hasid and plop him onto the streets of Pigalle in the company of drug pushers, hookers and transvestites. Well, we've all seen worse; the problem here is that the heavy hand of Gerard Oury, who directed and collaborated on the script for ''Levy and Goliath,'' knocks over credibility some time before Levy knocks over Goliath.

title: Taiwan Gangster Convicted of Killing Writer
description: A Taiwanese gangster who said he had killed a Chinese-American journalist on orders from Taiwan's Government was convicted of murder today.

title: Ex-Auto Racer and Wife Are Slain in California
description: Gunmen on bicycles killed a longtime figure in auto racing and his wife in their driveway today, days after he told a friend he had received several death threats.

title: Housing, the Koch-LeFrak Way
description: A quarter-century ago, New York City acquired a splendid housing site on Grand Street on the Lower East Side. Ever since, its fate has been buffeted by arguments about which race and what income group might live there, and by changes in housing laws - and the site has remained untouched. Finally, Mayor Koch has persuaded Samuel LeFrak, the builder, to produce housing there. It's a big step forward. The Lower East Side below Houston Street was once mostly Jewish and poor. Now there's a polyglot population with dramatic differences in income and age. Poorer residents need subsidies to rent improved apartments. Better-off families need help to afford cooperatives like those put up years ago on Grand Street by the United Housing Foundation. Lacking Federal help, the Mayor relies on the willingness of 400 wealthy householders to buy future condominiums at market prices.

title: A Warning On a Pesticide
description: Consumers Union has urged the public not to use pest strips, pet flea collars and insecticide sprays containing a chemical known as diclorvos, DDVP, or vapona because of cancer risks.

title: Advertising; ABP Group in Accord To Buy Fisher, Jackson
description: Joseph F. Bartolone, chairman of the ABP Group, announced yesterday that his company had reached an agreement with Fisher, Jackson, Levy, Flaxman to acquire that agency's assets.

title: A South Korean Resigns His Opposition Post
description: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's best-known opposition leader, resigned today as president of his party in a last-minute bid to unite the nation's bitterly divided opposition before legislative elections next month.

title: AIDS Quilt to Be Shown in 20 Cities
description: A seven-ton patchwork quilt made of 3,488 hand-sewn panels, each commemorating a person who died of AIDS, will be displayed in segments in 20 cities in coming months.

title: U.S. TO SEND FORCE TO AID HONDURAS, CITING 'INCURSION'
description: President Reagan tonight ordered the deployment of four battalions of American troops, about 3,200 men, to Honduras as a sign of support for the Government there.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Lloyd H. Burke, Federal Judge, 71
description: Lloyd H. Burke, who served nearly 30 years as a Federal judge, died Tuesday. He was 71 years old.

title: Robins Merger Is Approved
description: A Federal judge today approved the A. H. Robins Company's merger pact with the American Home Products Corporation after the companies agreed to put $100 million toward quick settlement of some Dalkon Shield claims.

title: Poultry Producer to Get $162 Million for Stock
description: Lonnie A. Pilgrim, a Texas poultry producer who does his own television commercials a la Frank Perdue, will make $162 million with the sale of his stock in the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation to Tyson Foods Inc.

title: NEW SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13, D26-27 An Iran-contra indictment accused John M. Poindexter, Oliver L. North and two other men of illegally providing the Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of American weapons to Iran. Page A1 Admiral Poindexter was accused in the Iran-contra indictment of having methodically deleted from White House computer files messages that he wrote and received. D27 U.S. troops are flying to Honduras, a senior Administration official said. The White House charged that Nicaraguan troops had invaded Honduras and attacked a major base camp for Nicaraguan rebels. A1 Nicaragua denied that its forces were fighting inside Honduras and invited foreign observers to visit the border area to verify its position. A12 Civil disorders swept Panama after a failed attempt to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The strongman's regime said the uprising was led by the chief of police. A1 Three Ulster residents were killed and dozens were wounded as an assailant threw grenades into a crowd of several thousand mourners at the burial of three Irish Republican Army guerrillas. A1 American-Israeli differences were underscored as President Reagan warned after meeting unsuccessfully with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir that opponents of Washington's peace plan would have to answer for failure. A3 Pakistan says superpowers can help end Afghan deadlock A9 NATIONAL A14-29, B6-7 Economists are predicting faster growth than they had expected just a few weeks ago, amid evidence of resilience in the nation's economy, particularly among consumers. A1 The F.D.I.C. may have to pay up to $4 billion this year to solve banking problems in Texas in the largest one-year drain on the Government agency that insures deposits in the nation's banks. D1 The Senate upheld the nuclear lobby in voting 53 to 4l against imposing responsibility for accidents on the contractors that operate the Government's nuclear research and weapons program. A29 The President vetoed a civil right bill intended to clarify antidiscrimination laws that were limited by a 1984 Supreme Court decision. Mr. Reagan disregarded warnings from key Republicans of a backlash. A1 Evan Mecham, defending himself in Phoenix at the first impeachment trial of a governor in nearly 60 years, appeared relaxed, laughed frequently and wove in several self-deprecatory jokes. A14 A software 'virus,' a type of computer program that can secretly spread from computer to computer and potentially destroy stored data, has infected a commercial personal computer product. D1 POLITICS B6-7 Vice President Bush surged ahead of Bob Dole in the Republican Presidential races because of planning and organization and mistakes made by the Kansas Senator. A1 Jesse Jackson accused rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination of being too passive about South Africa. He urged that they pledge to order American companies out of South Africa unless that country holds ''fair and free elections.'' B6 The Democratic Presidential race looks murkier than ever after the Illinois primary. It seems increasingly likely that no aspirant will have a majority of convention votes by the time the primaries end June 7. B7 Ex-Mayor Byrne is beaten in race for court clerk B6 WASHINGTON TALK B6 Anti-abortion aid raises church-state issue REGIONAL B1-5 A campaign financing inquiry in New York State will include the Legislature, the State Boards of Elections and more donors seeking to influence politicians, according to state officials. B1 Promotions for future police officers to sergeant, lieutenant and captain in New York City must first complete at least two years of college, according to a new order. B1 Radiation Technology Inc., a North Jersey company that uses radiation to sterilize spices and medical equipment, pleaded guilty to submitting falsified data to the Government concerning safety at its plant in Rockaway. B1 Robert Garcia was bribed by former executives of the Wedtech Corporation, prosecutors told a Federal judge. Representative Garcia has denied any wrongdoing involving the Bronx military contractor. B3 Small employers are retrenching in New York City unlike the rest of the nation, where most new jobs have been created by small businesses, a government study said. B3 Photographs of Jennifer Levin prove that Robert E. Chambers Jr. murdered her in Central Park in 1986, according to the prosecutor's summation to the jury. B3 An inquiry into Playland was ordered by the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, amid charges of ''mismanagement and improprieties'' at the county-owned amusement park. B2 William H. Honan has been named the chief cultural correspondent of The New York Times. The paper's new cultural news editor will be Marvin Siegel, now deputy editor of The Week in Review. C29 Large families are an endangered species. But parents who have decided to preserve this vanishing way of life believe that the joy of raising a large family, even on a modest income, far outweighs the burden. C1 New York Senate minority leader labors under a cloud B1 New York Assembly tightens its rules on recording work hours B3 Correction union criticizes handling of Rikers riot B3 Koch appoints ex-aide to another post B3 Agnelli honored at Metropolitan Museum B4

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ammunition From Foes
description: Cramming a mass of data into a Congressman's briefing book is one way corporate lobbyists try to give weight to advocacy and to broaden and disguise a parochial interest. But in a departure from good research form, four pages of data distributed recently by the American Nuclear Energy Council, the lobbying arm of the nuclear power industry, were filched from its lobbying opponents.

title: Noriega Foils Coup Attempt; Civilians Take to the Streets
description: An attempt to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega failed here today, but it was followed by widespread civil disorders across Panama.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Malcolm Mace will join DDB Needham Worldwide Chicago as executive vice president and director of account management.

title: New York City Assists in Search for Day Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; In Search of Irish, Or the Greening Of the Suburbs
description: Ameruso, Biaggi, Esposito, Friedman, Manes, Myerson, Simon, Turoff, Zaccaro.

title: Lilly Rejects British Fund
description: Eli Lilly & Company rejected on Tuesday a demand by British lawmakers that the pharmaceutical giant set up a trust fund for victims of a discontinued anti-arthritis medication. The demand was made Monday by 100 British lawmakers who signed a letter to Richard D. Wood, Lilly chairman and chief executive officer.

title: FINANCIAL BENEFIT GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $422,000 on investments. c-After a gain of $1 million on investments.

title: Gooden is Satisfied He Is on Schedule
description: Dwight Gooden said it was ridiculous to panic or even to fret about it. Spring training never was his long suit, anyway, and he said he was ''right on schedule.'' He said all this immediately after the Philadelphia Phillies had raked him for 10 hits and six runs in four innings.

title: Gertrude Hill, Training Director, 58
description: Gertrude Hill, director of training for the New York City Department for the Aging, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Making Ordinary Oak Look Unordinary
description: LEAD: THE tall, narrow chest of drawers that recently set a record price for a piece of Frank Lloyd Wright furniture is an outstanding example of quarter-sawn oak. But whether a piece is museum-quality or a more mundane example, any oak can be enhanced by a good penetrating oil finish in a walnut color.

title: Advertising; Martin Agency Wins Maserati Auto Account
description: After a seven-agency race, the Martin Agency of Richmond came out the winner in the Maserati Automobiles competition. The budget is $2 million.

title: Israel's A-Arms: A Sacred Cow
description: LEAD: When India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, and Pakistan's President, Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, visit the United States, the press intensively questions them about whether their countries have or are building nuclear weapons. However, when the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzak Shamir, visits Washington, as he is now, the issue of Israel's possession of nuclear arms never seems to come up, even though Israel's nuclear capabilities are thought to be far more advanced than either India's or

title: Moscow Journal; Armenian Forsakes the Liturgy to Tend His Flock
description: For three Sundays running, the Rev. Tiran Guredzhian has been unable to conduct services at the little pink Church of the Sacred Assumption in Moscow.

title: ATOM LOBBY GAINS VICTORY IN SENATE
description: In a victory for the nuclear lobby, the Senate today voted against imposing accountability for accidents on the contractors who operate the Government's nuclear research and weapons program.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 22 about negotiations to sell The New York Post described the newspaper's longevity claim incorrectly. The Post was founded in 1801 and considers itself the oldest newspaper in the United States published continuously as a daily. The Hartford Courant, which began as a weekly in 1764, considers itself the oldest continuously published newspaper. In addition, a Letter to the Editor on Feb. 29 misstated the standing of The Alexandria (Va.) Gazette. Founded in 1784 as a weekly, The Gazette has been published with varying frequencies under a variety of names. It now appears twice a week as The Alexandria Gazette-Packet.

title: Racial Remark Creates a Furor; Ouster Is Sought
description: A high-ranking official in the Education Department has become the focus of controversy after a newspaper quoted him as saying that the student bodies of black colleges may ''contain a high level of thieves.''

title: Review/Film; 'Bell Diamond,' Beyond the Mines
description: Jon Jost's ''Bell Diamond'' is about the seven-year marriage of Jeff, a Vietnam veteran, and Cathy, who live in Butte, Mont., in a house that is enviably full of waste space and seems to have been furnished with knickknacks won at a carnival.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of American Express Co., promoted Anne M. Busquet to senior vice president and general manager of its Optima Card division.

title: Repairing Ailing Pens
description: IS your nib broken? Has your clip snapped off? Is your sack split?

title: 'Phantom' Professor Grades Work Via Computer
description: Students who skip Prof. Gerald M. Phillips's opening lecture in his course on group decision making may find themselves searching the campus in vain for any trace of him the rest of the semester.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SPRING thaws and rains often bring leaky basements with them. Unfortunately, in early spring the ground may be too hard from freezing or too muddy to let you fix basement leaks the best way: by repairing the exterior of the foundation walls or by regrading the land near the house. But several measures can be taken to remedy most problems so well that no further repairs will be necessary.

title: Military in Panama Is Accused of Abuses
description: Panama's security forces tortured, beat and arrested people who peacefully protested the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, killing one man who shouted ''Down with Noriega!'' in public, Amnesty International said today.

title: After 3 Years, Sister Keeps Hostage Vigil
description: In a basement hideaway, somewhere in the southern suburbs of Beirut, Terry A. Anderson marked a bitter anniversary today - three years as a captive of a Shiite fundamentalist group that calls itself Islamic Holy War.

title: Bush vs. Dole: Behind the Turnaround
description: History is written by the victors, and that is true even of political campaigns not yet concluded. In retrospect, the winning side's decisions invariably appear brilliant, and losers almost always look foolish.

title: MAY DEPT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The results included charges equal to 8 cents a share for the latest year and 1 cent a share for the prior year resulting from the LIFO method of inventory evaluation. The year-ago fourth quarter results included a LIFO credit equal to 2 cents a share and 1 cent a share extraordinary credit.

title: Jade Hunter to Be Retired
description: Jade Hunter, who won the Donn Handicap and the Gulfstream Park Handicap in Florida earlier this winter, fractured his right front cannon bone in a workout at Gulfstream Monday and will be retired.

title: Trip to Cuba Is Planned By Cardinal O'Connor
description: A trip to Cuba is planned soon by John Cardinal O'Connor, who would be the highest-ranking American Roman Catholic official to visit that nation since Fidel Castro took power in 1959, the Archdiocese of New York announced.

title: Advertising; Unusual Path To a Post With Esty
description: THE William Esty Company has hired a most unusual woman as its director of new business, an important job in an agency eager to return to its previous eminence.

title: House Approves Prime Site For Black Patriots' Memorial
description: The House has given final Congressional approval to legislation authorizing prime Federal parkland in Washington as a site for a national monument to the 5,000 blacks who fought the British in the American Revolution.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: Early this year, the National Cancer Institute canceled plans for a 10-year, $130 million study among 32,000 women to determine if the risk of breast cancer could be greatly reduced if women cut in half the amount of fat they eat. With one in 10 women destined to get the disease, the possibility that a relatively simple dietary change could save lives initially seemed worth investigating.

title: Housing Starts and Permits Are Up
description: Builders broke ground for new homes at an annual rate of 1,494,000 in February, an 8.9 percent increase that followed two straight declines, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $1.5 million for the quarter and $4.5 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss The results included the sales and operating performance for the acquired Fairchild Semiconductor business since October 1987.

title: Beach Resort Imports Sand
description: A Texas beach will soon change color, from brown to white, with the help of Florida sand. For years, people have complained about Galveston's murky water and brown, narrow beaches, said Ralph McPheeters, administrator of a development called Palm Beach at Moody Gardens. ''We can't do anything about the water, but we sure can do something about the sand,'' he said Tuesday. Two bargeloads of sand from pits near Orlando are expected within two weeks. Mr. McPheeters said the sand was selected not only for its color, but also for its consistency, just right for building castles.

title: Lag Cited in Small-Business Growth
description: Unlike the rest of the nation, where most new jobs have been created by small businesses, New York City's small employers have made ''a steep cutback'' in the rate of expansion, according to a government study released yesterday.

title: Waldheim Was No Mere Clerk or Bystander
description: To the Editor:

title: A Muted Trumpet
description: ''In our adversary system of justice, any person haled into court who is too poor to hire a lawyer cannot be assured a fair trial unless counsel is provided for him. . . . The right of one charged with crime to counsel may not be deemed fundamental and essential to fair trials in some countries, but it is in ours.''

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
John W. Spurdle, Investment Banker, 81
description: John W. Spurdle, an investment banker, died Sunday at his home in Monmouth Hills, N.J. He was 81 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article from Buenos Aires on Monday about the remains of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele misidentified the chief pathologist of Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency. He is Murice Rogev.

title: Linoleum Nostalgia
description: To The Home Section:

title: NEW JERSEY STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Remove the Trade-Bill Shackles
description: It's the moment of truth for the Gephardt amendment to the foreign trade bill, an ill-conceived scheme to punish countries whose exports are too popular with American consumers. House and Senate conferees must adopt, modify or kill the measure.

title: Figure in John Belushi Case Freed From California Prison
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith, who admitted giving the comedian John Belushi the heroin-cocaine mixture that killed him in 1982, was freed from prison today after serving 15 months.

title: Bonn's Debt Forgiveness
description: West Germany is ready to forgive debt worth about 2.5 billion marks, or about $1.6 billion, owed by several of the poorest developing countries, the Overseas Development Minister, Hans Klein, said today.

title: Do-It-Yourself Jobs Take On New Chic In a High-Tech Age
description: The mood was enthusiastic this week at the enormous McCormk k Place exhibition halls here, as more than 1,200 suppliers of home improvement products for the amateur displayed their wares to about 36,000 store buyers at the National Home Center Show.

title: BAMBERGER POLYMERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U. of Chicago Names Dean
description: The University of Chicago has named a 53-year-old New York cancer researcher as the new dean of its medical school. Dr. Samuel Hellman, physician in chief of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, will become dean of the Pritzker School of Medicine on Sept. 1, the university anounced Monday. Dr. Hellman will replace Dr. Donald King, whose five-year contract with the university expired Dec. 31.

title: Orrin Frink, Mathematician, 86
description: Orrin Frink, a mathematician who taught for 41 years at Pennsylvania State University and was chairman of the university's mathematics department from 1949 to 1960, died March 4 at his home in Kennebunkport, Me. He was 86 years old.

title: Harkness Grant Goes To Brooklyn Academy
description: The Harkness Ballet Foundations have awarded a $75,000 grant to the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the largest single award in the foundations' history, to help support the theater's spring dance season.

title: Surprise: Yankee Pitching Is Thriving
description: If pitching was a concern when the Yankees opened their training camp four weeks ago, it is less so today. Rick Rhoden, who will be their starting pitcher on opening day, threw six innings today against the Texas Rangers without allowing a run and extended the staff's string of scoreless innings to 21.

title: Fiat Chief Is Honored At the Met
description: At the Metropolitan Museum last night, art met commerce face to face over drinks, a thousand ''buona seras'' and silver trays brimming with sliced salmon, caviar and minced chicken in pastry boats.

title: U.S. Weighs Rebellion's Effect on Noriega's Grip on Power
description: Senior Administration officials said today that the coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega demonstrated deepening division within the Panamanian military, his principal base of support. But the officials said they were uncertain whether the failed rebellion would weaken General Noriega's hold on power.

title: Jackson Assails Foes on South Africa
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today accused his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination of being passive in their disapproval of the South African Government.

title: Judge Backs Settlement In State Farm Bias Case
description: A Federal judge has approved a settlement of a sex discrimination suit brought against the State Farm Insurance Company, which will now have to pay as much as $420,000 apiece to women who were denied jobs as insurance agents in California.

title: March: Skier's Kindest Month
description: WHILE most people see March as the end of winter, knowledgeable skiers regard it as the best month of the ski season. The weather is usually mild, the areas less crowded, and the snow still consistent and deep.

title: Former Mayor of Chicago Loses Bid for Court Clerk
description: Aurelia M. Pucinski beat former Mayor Jane M. Byrne Tuesday in the closely watched Democratic primary election for clerk of the Cook County Circuit Court.

title: Pakistan Urges Symmetry in Afghan Aid Cuts
description: Pakistan suggested today that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, could play a role in unblocking the Afghan peace talks when the two officials meet in Washington next week.

title: Publisher Is Charged
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged that the publisher of an investment newsletter in Queens took cash, stocks and stock options from at least 10 companies to support their securities.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Recital; Alexander Baillie on Cello
description: One is always embarrassed when one's perceptions conform to cliches. But the debut recital Monday night at Town Hall of Alexander Baillie, an English cellist, conformed in nearly every particular to stereotypical expectations about English music-making.

title: A Radiation Company Admits Safety Violations
description: Radiation Technology Inc., a Rockaway Township-based company that uses radiation to sterilize spices and medical equipment, pleaded guilty today to charges that it submitted falsified documents to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission concerning safety procedures at its plant in Rockaway.

title: Gorbachev Faults Stalin on Rift With Tito
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev confessed Soviet fault today for the bitter falling-out between Belgrade and Moscow in 1948, in a significant gesture toward Yugoslavia's Communist leadership.

title: Reagan Vetoes Bill That Would Widen Federal Rights Law
description: President Reagan disregarded warnings of a political backlash from Republican Congressional leaders today and vetoed a major civil rights bill.

title: Takeover Law In Ohio Upheld
description: A Federal judge rejected a claim by an Italian tire maker that Ohio's anti-takeover law is unconsitutional.

title: Advertising; Margeotes to Handle Cunard North America
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss has beaten out Young & Rubicam and Fallon McElligott for the Cunard account in North America, which has a budget of between $6 million and $7 million.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Foreign Investment
description: Foreign investment is becoming a hot topic on Capitol Hill. An investigation of foreign takeovers of United States banks is planned by Representative John D. Dingell, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee and its investigations subcommittee.

title: The Wearing of the Black
description: What should be a day of joy for the Irish, of all nationalities, turns instead into a day of mourning for the victims of yesterday's attack in a Belfast graveyard. The mourning extends to lost hopes of reconciliation in Northern Ireland: wake follows wake, coffin follows coffin, tears follow tears, in a cycle that defeats reason and obliterates decency on both sides - Northern Ireland's Protestant majority and the Catholic minority.

title: U.S. Gives Japan Deadline In Dispute on Construction
description: The Reagan Administration today set a two-week deadline for Japan to resolve the conflict over opening its construction market to American companies, a White House official reported. If Japan fails to offer a ''satisfactory solution'' to the dispute, the official said, it will face American retaliation.

title: Review/Organ; Leonard Raver In Recital
description: Alice Tully Hall now counts as New York City's only major concert facility with a built-in pipe organ. And Leonard Raver, who has been a Juilliard School faculty member since 1975 (as well as organist of the New York Philharmonic since 1977) presumably knows its character as well as anyone, since Tully Hall is in the Juilliard School building. But at his recital there Tuesday night, the organ didn't seem always ideally suited to the music he had selected.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Potted Plants Galore
description: If the legal profession gave out Academy Awards, Brendan V. Sullivan, the lawyer who represented Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North at the Iran-contra hearings last summer, would certainly have received at least a nomination for his dramatic declaration, ''I am not a potted plant.''

title: Review/Music; Reggae by Sugar Minott
description: Sugar Minott, the Jamaican singer, blew into S.O.B.'s last Thursday like a three-day hurricane. Leading his tough working band, one of those rare groups that sounds like its members play together regularly, are paid well and like each other, Mr. Minott tore the place up.

title: PETERS, J M CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
'Cosi' Mystery at Met
description: Hei-Kyung Hong, a young South Korean soprano who is quickly becoming one of the most sought-after singers on the operatic scene, was pulled out of the opening-night cast of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera last week, in an incident that has set the corridors buzzing with gossip about prima-donna jealousy.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Cruise Ship Is Crippled by Fire
description: An engine fire broke out today on the Scandinavian Star, leaving the cruise ship adrift for hours in the Gulf of Mexico with more than 700 people aboard, the authorities said.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament; West Has the Quickest Draw
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament should be fast and furious out West.

title: Health: Patients' Rights; New Safeguards Allow Many Patients to Appeal Hospital Discharges
description: As hospitals come under increasing pressure to discharge patients quickly, New York State has begun one of the nation's strictest programs to protect patients from being forced out before they are medically ready or before arrangements for further care have been made.

title: INSIDE
description: College Credits for Police

title: Westchester Begins Playland Inquiry
description: Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke ordered an inquiry into the operations of the county-owned Playland Amusement Park today amid charges of ''mismanagement and improprieties'' touching his administration.

title: Jackets Are All The Rage
description: THE name Fred Marcellino may not be a household word. But those who read Tom Wolfe's best-selling novel ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' will spend many hours with Mr. Marcellino's work.

title: Dry Cleaner Specializes in Ancient Stains
description: LEAD: The richly embroidered satin waistcoats and gold-threaded gowns displayed in museums look better today than they did on their original owners. Now they are clean.

title: Chevron, Koreans In Joint Venture
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc., the domestic operating company of the Chevron Corporation, said it had agreed to conduct a joint-venture oil exploration and development program with the Lucky-Goldstar International Corporation of Seoul, South Korea. Lucky-Goldstar will make an initial investment of about $20 million in the venture, which will begin drilling immediately at 10 onshore and offshore well sites in California, Oklahoma, Texas and the Gulf of Mexico.

title: An Iran-Contra Guide: What Happened and When
BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 17, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Advertising; Denny's New Owner Dismisses Foote, Cone
description: TW Services Inc., the new owner of the Denny's restaurant chain, has dismissed Foote, Cone & Belding, Los Angeles, from the account after a 10-year relationship, and also let go Western International Media, which had been doing the media buying.

title: ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
For Reagan, Bizarre Turn; The Options Dwindle On Central America
description: Even with the long and tortured history of the Reagan Administration's Central American policies, no one could have anticipated the bizarre convergence of events today. In the United States

title: UNITED STOCKYARDS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a gain of $844,790 of unrealized appreciation in the company's securities. c-Included a gain of $858,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change, a gain of $348,580 in unrealized appreciation in the company's securities, and a pre-tax gain of $1.68 million from the sale of real estate.

title: KEY RATES
ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax benefits of $306,000 for the quarter and $506,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Review/Dance; Phoebe Neville
description: Phoebe Neville presented two types of dances Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. There were fine examples of the exquisitely crafted pieces for small casts for which she is best known. But there was also an ensemble work for all 11 members of the Phoebe Neville Dance Company.

title: Bond Prices Fall in Light Trading
description: Bond prices slumped yesterday in light trading, as market participants sold securities following unexpectedly strong economic reports and a rebound in oil prices.

title: Maurice Linder Dies; Insurance Agent, 93
description: Maurice Linder, an insurance agent for 45 years and the oldest living member of the industry's ''Million Dollar Round Table,'' died of heart failure Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: NVRYAN LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time charge of $600,000 for consolidation of the company's United Kingdom manufacturing operations for both the quarter and year, and a gain of $500,000 from settlement of patent infringement and antitrust litigation for the quarter and the year includes a charge of $799,000 from expenses incurred during the attempted acquisition of Huntco Health Care. c-Includes a pretax gain of $663,000 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: Duluth Mayor Is Indicted
description: A grand jury has indicted Mayor John Fedo on 23 charges, including theft, falsifying expense records and attempting to obstruct the state auditor. The indictment, made public Monday after the Mayor's arraignment in State District Court, included 22 felony charges. The 37-year-old Mayor, a member of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party, called the charges a political ploy.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We beat him unmercifully.'' - George McMurray, who helped capture a gunman at a funeral in Northern Ireland. [ A1:2. ]

title: NORTH, POINDEXTER AND 2 OTHERS INDICTED ON IRAN-CONTRA FRAUD AND THEFT CHARGES
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and two other key participants in the Iran-contra affair were indicted today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the United States by illegally providing the Nicaraguan rebels with profits from the sale of American weapons to Iran.

title: Tricks to Raising Campaign Funds
description: The New York State Commission on Government Integrity, in two days of hearings, has given broad exposure to the tricks of campaign financing. Among the techniques are these:

title: Yields Move A Bit Lower
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday, continuing a downward pattern in recent weeks.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart in some editions on March 5 about rates of unemployment and employment in New York State and New Jersey gave inconsistent figures for January and February. The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics provides two kinds of figures: those adjusted for seasonal variations (shown in the chart), and those not adjusted for seasonal variations (cited in the article). In practice, the seasonally adjusted figures have been used for comparison.

title: A Dutch Auction Security Debut
description: Dutch auction securities, often used by many corporate preferred stock financings, have been introduced for the first time to the tax-exempt market by Goldman, Sachs & Company through a new instrument called ''periodic auction reset securities.''

title: Chicago Journal; In Bits and Pieces, This Is Their Vietnam
description: Joe Hertel used to keep Vietnam in his basement, hidden away in boxes and footlockers filled with old photographs and other war souvenirs. Sometimes he would show the ragged collection to other veterans, and it would bring back memories both sweet and sad.

title: Poindexter Charged With Deleting Files
description: After the Iran-contra affair erupted, John M. Poindexter, the national security adviser, methodically deleted from White House computer files all messages he wrote or received, prosecutors charged in an indictment made public today.

title: Contra Bases Called Target Of Managua
description: The Nicaraguan attack along the Honduran border appears primarily aimed at rebel supply bases in Honduras that support anti-Government operations in northern Nicaragua, according to United States military officials.

title: E.P.A. Rejects Doing a Cancer Study of Herbicide
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says it will not conduct a special study of a widely used herbicide suspected of causing cancer among farmers because other research has not confirmed the suspicion.

title: Possible Sun Bid
description: The Sun Company said that it had received notice that a tender offer for the large oil and gas company was being contemplated by an investment group led by a Dallas lawyer, Ernest M. Edsel. At today's closing, price of $58, Sun, based in Radnor, Pa., is worth $7.4 billion. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Edsel said the Malpaso Company of Dallas was studying the bid. A spokesman for Sun said the company is not for sale.

title: 2 States Get Extension on Young Bus Drivers
description: The Labor Department has agreed to let some North and South Carolina school districts continue to use 17-year-old bus drivers through the end of the school year.

title: Review/Dance; Lubovitch the Earth-Shaker Takes a Breather
description: When a choreographer is on a creative jag the way Lar Lubovitch has been for the last three years, the expectation is that he will pull a masterpiece out of every hat.

title: From Chartreuse to Gatorade in 900 Years
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Mirror Swaps Cable Units
description: The Times Mirror Company reached an agreement with a partnership of Tele-Communications Inc. and United Artists Communications Inc. to swap cable televison systems in several states. No value on the deal was announced, but analysts estimated it would be worth about $740 million, based on an average price of $2,000 per subscriber. The companies had announced tentative plans for the exchange in early October, but the details were not worked out until now, Times Mirror said. Tele-Communications owns a majority stake in United Artists.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Citibank to Phase Out Policy Against Liberal Arts Majors
description: Citibank said today that it would abandon a policy that denied credit cards to some liberal arts majors after students at the University of California at Berkeley demanded the bank's representatives be barred from campus because of the policy.

title: F.D.I.C. Faces a Texas-Size Drain
description: The banking problems in the depressed Southwest have become so acute, banking experts say, that they could create the largest one-year drain in history on the Government agency that insures deposits at the nation's banks.

title: Review/Recital; Barbara Conrad, Mezzo
description: Barbara Conrad, a mezzo-soprano who has sung with the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, made her formal recital debut Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall, offering a program that explored some unusual corners of the art-song tradition.

title: Bradley Tells State Leaders He'll Make an Endorsement
description: Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, told state Democratic leaders today that he intended to endorse one of the candidates running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, and urged them to drop plans to send an uncommitted slate to the national convention.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,026,000 and $6,518,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $173,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $1,062,000 for the quarter and $3,540,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary gains of $54,000 and $1,289,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said all periods presented have been restated for both the discontinuance of the company's apparel and fiber products segments and the reinstatement of its home furnishings operations as continuing.

title: Blinking Green Light
description: What's the first thing Yitzhak Shamir, the right-wing Prime Minister of Israel, should do when he returns to Jerusalem from his meetings in Washington?

title: 2 Editors Get New Posts At The Times
description: The appointment of William H. Honan as chief cultural correspondent of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the paper's executive editor. Mr. Honan, who has been serving as cultural news editor, will be succeeded by Marvin Siegel, now deputy editor of The Week in Review.

title: Key Sections of Conspiracy Indictment in Iran-Contra Affair
description: Following are key sections of the indictment returned by a Federal grand jury today against Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Richard V. Secord and Albert Hakim in the Iran-contra case. COUNT ONE The Conspiracy And Its Objects

title: Review/Dance; Flamenco Images of Garcia Lorca
description: It is hard to imagine flamenco being gentle, low-keyed entertainment. But that was the mood created in ''Imagenes de Garcia Lorca,'' presented by La Compania de Teatro de Albuquerque and Eva Encinias's Ritmo Flamenco on Friday at Marymount Manhattan Theater.

title: The Prado Is Chosen To House Collection Of Thyssen-Bornemisza
description: The Prado Museum in Madrid has been selected to house a part of the Thyssen-Bornemisza collection, one of the world's richest private art collections.

title: Tennstedt Cancels Concerts
description: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt has canceled his remaining series of performances with the New York Philharmonic because of an injury to his arm in a fall, the orchestra has announced. Felix Kruglikov will conduct in his place. The performances are tonight, tomorrow and Saturday at 8, and Tuesday at 7:30. The program remains unchanged.

title: Wickes Negotiates Hosiery Unit Sale
description: The Wickes Companies said it was negotiating to sell the Kayser-Roth Hosiery Group to members of the unit's management and the Narragansett Capital Corporation of Providence, R.I. The hosiery unit, based in Greensboro, N.C., is one of the world's leading manufacturers of men's and women's hosiery, including such brands as No Nonsense, Liz Claiborne, Calvin Klein, Burlington and Supp-Hose. Kayer-Roth Hosiery, which had about $500 million in sales last year, employs 9,600 workers at 16 manufacturing plants and four distribution centers in the United States and Europe.

title: Arizona Senate Hears Governor Deny Charges
description: Under attack at the polls, in criminal court and in the State Senate, Evan Mecham took the stand here today to defend himself in the first impeachment trial of a governor in almost 60 years.

title: 3 Killed by Grenades at Belfast Funeral
description: Three people were killed and dozens wounded today as an assailant threw grenades into a screaming crowd at a funeral and then fled across the graveyard from enraged mourners.

title: Putting New Faces In Family Portrait
description: When Tom Lasorda was a teen-ager in Norristown, Pa., his mother bought evaporated milk, the milk that came in the can with the picture of a cow on it.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis

title: Koppers Turns Down Bid From Beazer and Shearson
description: The Koppers Company yesterday rejected a $1.27 billion takeover bid from Beazer P.L.C. and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., saying the $45-a-share offer was inadequate.

title: Worries Over Computer as a Grant-Making Tool
description: A proposal by the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts that would emphasize greater use of computerized data in determining grants to nonprofit arts groups has provoked concern among arts administrators around the country.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: A 3-YEAR-OLD who cries out ''Mommy!

title: Correction Officers Complain Rikers Riot Was Mishandled
description: The head of the correction officers' union charged yesterday that a riot on Rikers Island last month that extensively damaged the jail was mishandled by the Correction Department.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Cellular One, a mobile phone company in Waltham, Mass., to Kelley & Wallwork, Boston.

title: Impeachment Hearing Is Urged for U.S. Judge
description: A group of judges that makes policy for the Federal courts is urging the House to consider impeaching Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon of Mississippi, who is scheduled to go to prison for perjury next Wednesday.

title: Income Up 8% At May Stores
description: The May Department Stores Company, one of the nation's largest retailers, said it had an 8 percent rise in net income in the fourth quarter, to $230 million, or $1.52 a share, from $213 million, or $1.38 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues held steady at $3.37 billion. For the fiscal year ended

title: N.F.L. Rule Changes at a Glance
description: The National Football League adopted eight rule changes at its annual meeting in Phoenix:

title: New York Shifts a Primary
description: Governor Cuomo signed legislation today that will allow New York's state primary elections to be held this year on Thursday, Sept. 15. The state primary, not to be confused with New York's April 19 Presidential primary, had been scheduled for Tuesday, Sept. 13, but that is the Jewish holiday of Rosh ha-Shanah. The September primary determines nominations for such positions as State Senate, Assembly Congressional seats.

title: Review/Pop; Lyle Lovett, Country Singer
description: Skinny as a matchstick, his vulpine features crowned by a rat's nest of dark hair, Lyle Lovett looks more like an English post-punk rocker than one of the brighter lights of American country music. True to his appearance on Monday evening at the Bottom Line, where he swung out in front of a large country band, the Texan singer and songwriter slyly and relentlessly subverted traditional country-music sentimentality.

title: Article 695088 -- No Title
description: American Standard Inc. is expected to announce today that it has agreed to sell the company for an estimated $2.6 billion, or about $79 a share, people close to the deal said last night.

title: Review/Jazz; Some Elders Offer 'Salute to Dick Hyman'
description: The eight musicians who played for a ''Salute to Dick Hyman'' at last Thursday's ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert at the Loeb Auditorium of New York University brought an unusual amount of warmth and affection to this 14th salute to a living jazz musician that has been organized by the impresario Jack Kleinsinger over the past 15 years. Mr. Hyman, who played at the first ''Highlights in Jazz'' in 1973, has been a close and frequent associate with most of the musicians who came to salute him.

title: Women's N.C.A.A.; St. John's Advances With 83-70 Victory
description: In their first trip along the route of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament, the St. John's Express eliminated Fairfield, 83-70, last night at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Review/Concert
description: The Syracuse in a Commissioned Work

title: Drawn-Out Legal Battle Is Predicted in Iran Trial
description: The 23-count indictment today against four defendants in the Iran-contra affair aims some of the standard weapons in the arsenal of Federal prosecutors at high-level officials who say they were lawfully carrying out President Reagan's national security policies.

title: CINEPLEX ODEON CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said 1986 results include a $1,381,000 special gain. Year-ago results are restated.

title: K Mart's New Unit
description: The K Mart Corporation, the big discount retailer, said it was forming a new business to sell office supplies and furniture, and business equipment in warehouse-type stores. The venture marks K Mart's entry into the field. The stores will compete with traditional office-supply houses and catalogue distributors in an industry that generates revenues of $108 billion a year. K Mart, however, plans to aim at the general public rather than businesses. The 25,000 square-foot stores will sell merchandise at discounts of 10 percent to 50 percent from list prices.

title: 2 Jersey City Men Held In Attack on an Indian
description: Two men linked to a group suspected of harassing Indians here were charged today with assaulting an Indian man in what authorities called a racially motivated attack.

title: COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 14
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $925,000 for the quarter and extraordinary income of $2,856,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $599,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Sports of The Times; The A's Designated Difference
description: WHILE the other members of the Oakland Athletics were sweating at the start of spring training, Jose Canseco remained at his Miami home to sign autographs at a baseball card show. When the 23-year-old slugger finally arrived in the clubhouse a few days late, Don Baylor held up his passport.

title: Phone Companies Plan New Services
description: The day is coming closer when a home telephone line can be an electronic pipeline to a wide variety of information services.

title: New York Assembly Stiffens Rules On Legislative Employees' Hours
description: In a move that he said would ''enhance the accountability'' of the State Assembly, the Speaker, Mel Miller, announced today that Assembly employees must now record the hours they spend each week working on legislative business.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Last Arguments Offered in Trial On Levin Death
description: The prosecutor in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. urged the jury yesterday to consider Jennifer Levin the ''most eloquent witness of all.''

title: Nets Defuse Bucks With Williams's 30
description: The game tonight was more important to the Milwaukee Bucks than it was to the Nets. The Bucks, who entered the game with a 35-26 record, are seeking a playoff spot that would give them a home-court advantage. The last-place Nets are playing out the string.

title: Tennis Notebook; Davis Cup Coach Looks Down the Road
description: Perhaps we can call this the Davis Cup version of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe may still have some good days left, and Ivan Lendl will eventually become a citizen of the United States, but Tom Gorman, the Davis Cup coach, was looking toward the future when he named Andre Agassi and Jay Berger to the team that will play in Peru April 8-10.

title: Review/Saxophone; Steve Lacy, A Jazz Expatriate
description: Steve Lacy, the expatriate soprano saxophonist who lives in Paris, usually plays with American jazz musicians when he visits New York. But through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street, he is working with his longtime Paris-based sextet. Its music is as eccentric and cluttered as a much-used messy desk - or, perhaps, an imaginary Cubist collage of sheet music, saxophone mouthpieces, a book of poetry, toys, cabaret ticket stubs and stamps from North Africa.

title: Tandy to Buy Grid Systems
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that it would acquire the closely held Grid Systems Corporation, a manufacturer of laptop personal computers based in Fremont, Calif.

title: First Chief Executive For Marks & Spencer
description: Marks & Spencer P.L.C., Britain's largest and most profitable retailing chain, has appointed Richard Greenbury to the newly created position of chief executive.

title: Reagan 'Will Not Abandon' Middle East Peace Plan
description: President Reagan pledged today that the United States would pursue its Middle East negotiating plan and warned that those who reject it would have to answer to their own people.

title: Gentle, Slow-Moving Car That Goes Moo
description: MOVE over, Detroit. Delaware's own

title: Henley to Split Itself and Buy Back Stock
description: The Henley Group Inc., created in a 1986 spinoff from Allied-Signal Inc., said today that it would split into two separate public companies. Henley also announced plans to repurchase 22 percent of its stock.

title: CALIFORNIA JOCKEY CLUB reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Senate Leader, Indicted, Perseveres
description: Six months after he was indicted on charges of using public funds to finance partisan election campaigns, the State Senate's Democratic leader, Manfred Ohrenstein, speaks in two distinct voices.

title: Olive Carey Dies at 92; Longtime Film Actress
description: Olive Carey, an actress and the wife and mother to a pair of famous Harry Careys, died Sunday at her home. She was 92 years old.

title: BETRAYAL CHARGED IN SEWER PROGRAM
description: When President Reagan took office, he made a $5 billion-a-year program for building sewage treatment plants an early target of his plan to transfer many Federal programs to the states.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In cold weather the glass and the aluminum frames of our skylights sweat so much that moisture accumulates and runs down off the low end. This water is damaging the drywall. Is there a cure? A. Apparently the skylights do not have double-pane insulating glass, and the aluminum frames do not have thermal barriers. This allows the inside of the metal and glass to get almost as cold as the outside, so moisture from the warmer inside air condenses on these cold surfaces.

title: Congress Needs Administration Help on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Needs Administration Help on Drugs; Don't Blame Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Ward Orders Some College For Top Ranks
description: The New York City Police Commissioner announced yesterday that members of the force seeking promotion to the rank of sergeant, lieutenant or captain would have to complete two to four years of college.

title: Sports People; Funds for School Meet
description: The national scholastic indoor track and field championships, whose existence was threatened earlier this month by insufficient funding, has received a flood of last-minute contributions to the Metropolitan Athletics Congress. The M.A.C., the organizer and developer of the meet, has generated more than $3 million in college scholarships since its inception in 1984.

title: Parade Today
description: The St. Patrick's Day Parade starts at 11:30 A.M. The parade begins at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, heads north on Fifth to 86th Street and then east to Third Avenue.

title: Health: Psychology; What Do Children Fear Most? Their Answers Are Surprising
description: Children have a more finely tuned sense of pride than most adults realize, recent studies indicate.

title: Pencil Promotion Scratched
description: When the Allegan County Sheriff's Department submitted a $930 bill for 5,000 pencils bearing the sheriff's name, the county commissioners drew the line. The pencils were to be distributed to students to promote the department's Youth Services Bureau, Sheriff Robert Schra said in explaining why he had submitted the bill as a school-safety expense. Commissioners saw the pencils as closer to political advertising and said they would consider paying only if the message were changed. '' 'Observe the safety rules always,' would be fine,'' said Commmissioner Flora Moore.

title: Review/Music; Javanese Puppetry and Song
description: The World Music Institute, which presents concerts of everything from third-world exotica to jazz and blues, sponsored a four-hour performance of Javanese shadow puppet theater on Saturday evening at Washington Square Church. For the occasion, the dhalang - puppetmaster, narrator and director - was Sumarsam, a master not only of his puppet arsenal, but also of conveying his art to listeners for whom its conventions are alien. He was joined by I. M. Harjito, a percussionist, and the New York Indonesian Consulate Gamelan, a skilled ensemble of young players.

title: For Sitting In Clover
description: AMERICA'S enthusiasm for the outdoors continues to fertilize the garden-furniture business. The latest offerings, to be introduced next month in High Point, N.C., are from the Winterthur Museum and Gardens, outside Wilmington, Del.

title: Sports People; Hawkins Is Best
description: Hersey Hawkins of Bradley, the nation's leading Division I scorer with an average of 36 points a game, has been voted college basketball's player of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association. Hawkins, a 6-foot-3-inch senior guard, was an easy winner over Danny Manning of Kansas.

title: CARLUCCI CONFERS WITH SOVIET AIDE
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci met for 10 hours today with the Soviet Defense Minister, Gen. Dmitri T. Yazov. American officials said the talks produced no specific agreements but opened the way for an expanded military discussion between the superpowers.

title: Investigation Of Donations Will Expand In New York
description: The New York State investigation of campaign financing will spread into the Legislature, the State Board of Elections and still more contributors seeking to influence politicians.

title: First Interstate
description: First Interstate Bancorp is offering $100 million of 8.65 percent subordinated notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.85, to yield 8.687 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The five-year notes, which are noncallable for the first three years, are priced to yield about 87-hundredths of a percentage more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said that the issue had been assigned an Aa-3 rating by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: Warner-Lambert Deal
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said this week that it was planning a $5 million joint venture with the Government of China to make chewing gum, cough drops and candies. The pharmaceutical company said that Dentyne gum, Halls cough drops and Fruitfuls candies would be produced.

title: Commuters, Arise
description: To the Editor:

title: Free Throws Sink the Knicks
description: From the minute he entered the dressing room tonight, Charles Barkley was very vocal.

title: Market Place; Pension Funds May Sell Stocks
description: AS the first quarter winds down, money managers are spending some of their cash to ''dress up'' clients' portfolios. Fearful of losing pension fund accounts, these managers want to show more stocks in their portfolios during this rising market.

title: Koch, Seeing Error, Puts Ex-Rights Chief on Women's Panel
description: Mayor Koch, conceding that he mishandled the resignation of Dr. Marcella Maxwell as head of the New York City Human Rights Commission, has named her to head his Commission on the Status of Women - the same job she held before taking over the rights panel four years ago.

title: Jacques Tiffeau, 59, Miniskirt Proponent In World of Fashion
description: Jacques Tiffeau, the French-born fashion designer who rose to the top on Seventh Avenue in the 1960's, died of lung cancer on Feb. 29 in Paris. He was 59 years old.

title: VYQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,983,000 for the quarter and $2,833,000 for the year; the quarter also included a non-recurring charge of $2,632,000 for the writeoff of intangible assets and the accrual of costs associated with the restructuring of certain operations and relocation of its principal executive offices. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $150,000 for the quarter and $445,000 for the year.

title: OPEC Decides Not to Meet on Prices
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said today that it would not hold any extraordinary meetings to deal with the recent fall of oil prices, which has taken the average price to between $13 and $14 a barrel in the last few weeks. Several oil producers outside OPEC, however, continued to meet in London today in search of a way to prop up oil prices.

title: Late Rally Sends Dow Up by 16.91
description: LEAD: A late rally spurred an otherwise dreary stock market to a strong gain yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, down much of the session, closed at 2,064.32, up 16.91 points.

title: Police Chief's Yard Yields a Body and a Puzzle
description: A body unearthed in the police chief's front yard after three days of digging has been identified as that of his wife's former husband, who disappeared nine years ago.

title: On at Least One Thing, the Democratic Candidates Can Agree: It's Wide Open Now
description: The Democratic Presidential race, clouded before the Illinois primary Tuesday, looked even murkier today as the candidates moved their campaigns into Kansas, Michigan, Wisconsin and other states that vote in the next month.

title: Calendar: A Tour, Antiques And Crafts
description: Irish Neighborhoods

title: Democrats Complain They Weren't Told
description: Democrats in Congress said tonight that they had not been told of the decision to send United States troops to Honduras and had learned of it only when they were asked about it by reporters at a Democratic fund-raising event.

title: Garcia Accepted Bribes, Wedtech Judge Is Told
description: Former executives of the Wedtech Corporation bribed Representative Robert Garcia, a prosecutor has told the judge in the Federal racketeering trial of Representative Mario Biaggi.

title: Review/Television; Putting Marianne Moore in Perspective
