description: Marianne Moore (1887-1972) is probably remembered by too many people as the slightly eccentric old poet who lived in Brooklyn, dressed dramatically, loved baseball and visited the ''Today'' show to be interviewed by Joe Garagiola. Tonight's edition of ''Voices and Visions'' on Channel 13 - shunted to midnight because of pledge-week festivities -does indeed touch on those aspects of the woman John Ashbery once called ''the Mary Poppins of poetry.'' But ''In Her Own Image,'' produced by Robert Chapman with David Schmerler, keeps the ''lovable character'' image in perspective as it explores the roots and substance of her work.

title: Review/Rock; Marti Jones's Soulful Voice
description: Marti Jones's show at the Bottom Line on Friday was full of lost possibilities. She's a startlingly immediate singer; her voice, windowpane clear, can take the most trivial ''I . . . you'' (love/hate, see/didn't see) songwriting conceit and charge it with the sort of larger meaning that can spring from a small, tactile description. And to hear her sing is to be addressed intimately, from one person to another - a listener has to pay attention.

title: First Republicbank in Bailout Talks
description: Officers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation met with executives of the First Republicbank Corporation today to prepare a temporary bailout intended to stanch a growing run on the bank company's deposits, officials close to the talks said.

title: Ranger Streak Is Ended
description: Perhaps it was too much to ask. The Rangers, who had continued to win games even as they lost players, were beaten, 8-4, by the Capitals last night at the Garden. It was discouraging, clouded by the loss of another player.

title: Sears Agrees to Buy Western Auto Supply
description: In another big step into specialty retailing, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had agreed to buy the Western Auto Supply Company, a retailer and wholesaler based in Kansas City, Mo., in a deal that values the company at $402 million.

title: A Vanishing Way of Life: The Large American Family
description: If there were a list of socially endangered species, large families would be among those at the top. Only about 2 percent of American families with children under the age of 18 have five or more children at home, according to a 1986 census report. In 1960, the figure was 8 percent.

title: In Congo, Fashion From a Suitcase
description: TO be cool in Congo is to be a ''sapeur.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cellular America Inc., Freehold, N.J., said its board had directed the company to prepare a plan of dissolution for submission to the shareholders for their approval.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Benjamin Franklin Savings, Houston, to the Hively Agency, also in Houston.

title: Shift in Alien Law Ends a Trying Journey
description: Silvia Luz Arana de Gills, a 29-year-old Argentine whose husband and two children are American citizens, will arrive in New York in six weeks.

title: Southeast Regional; Villanova Forgets Past
description: Rollie Massimino and his Villanova Wildcats seem to have developed a collective amnesia as they prepare for their eighth National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in nine years.

title: Duo Recital at Weill
description: The cellist Anner Bylsma and the fortepianist Malcolm Bilson, two highly regarded performers on authentic instruments, will play a duo recital tonight at 8 at Weill Recital Hall, in Carnegie Hall. Each of the players will be featured in solo works - Mr. Bylsma in a Bach sonata, Mr. Bilson in a sonata by Schubert - and they will collaborate on two Beethoven Sonatas for Piano and Cello (Op. 102, Nos. 1 and 2). Tickets are $12. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 1-for-10 reverse stock split in January.

title: Poland Gets U.S. Envoy
description: The United States Ambassador, John Davis, formally presented his credentials in Warsaw today, five years after Washington scaled down its diplomatic presence in Poland to protest the imposition of martial law. The post had been vacant since the United States called back Ambassador Francis Meehan in 1983, two years after martial law was imposed to suppress the Solidarity union movement. Mr. Davis, 60 years old, has been charge d'affaires since then. He has had two previous tours of duty in Warsaw in the 1960's and 70's.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Departing Official
description: Robert W. Kagan, who has been deeply involved in the Reagan Administration's policy on the rebels in Nicaragua, will be leaving the State Department next month to become a fellow at the Naval War College in Rhode Island, where he will write a book on the Central American country.

title: TECHNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $83,600 for the quarter and $290,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: The Law; For Mega-litigation, a State-of-the-Art Courtroom
description: A mothballed building on a hillside here about 20 miles south of San Francisco may seem an unlikely location for the model courtroom of the future. But here, amid the abandoned hallways and decaying buildings, a segment of the future has arrived. And it even seems to work. c The 11,000-square-foot courtroom and chambers in a former public high school auditorium were planned as a great leap forward from the 19th-century model to state-of-the-art courtroom design and trial management, with computer data bases and instant retrieval of information, laser disk document storage and electronic reproduction of the court reporters' transcript. It will be closely watched by courts and lawyers across the country and is already being emulated in Arizona.

title: Old Aspirin News
description: To the Editor:

title: Yokohama Journal; Pinball Madness: Bigger Than the Military Budget
description: By 11 A.M., barely an hour after the King Pachinko Parlor had opened, a thick gauze of cigarette smoke settled upon the losers like a shroud.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Hearty Peasant Fare

title: Legal Points Called Key to Estimate Board's Fate
description: Legal considerations, and not a popularity contest, will be responsible if the Charter Revision Commission ultimately recommends against preserving the Board of Estimate, the commission secretary, Nathan Leventhal, said yesterday.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Veterans Cheating on Pensions, G.A.O. Says
description: United States veterans are cheating the Government of tens of millions of dollars each year by lying about their incomes and thus collecting excessive benefits, a Congressional report says.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results included a loss of about $9.2 million from the sale of an unprofitable acute-care hospital and the writedown of assets of about $2.6 million.

title: Brechtian Collaboration in Experimental Theater
description: ''No Plays No Poetry but Philosophical Reflections Practical Instructions Provocative Prescriptions Opinions and Pointers From a Noted Critic and Playwright'' is not the sort of title designed to lure theatergoers into a colorful audience-participation event.

title: A Wild West Not Far From the Khyber Pass
description: Local residents tell a visitor not to worry about the repeated bursts of automatic firing heard in this isolated settlement, the administrative center of Bajaur Agency, a district on the mountainous Afghan border. ''This is our Wild West,'' one said, showing perverse pride.

title: Question of Statehood Is Dominating Puerto Rico's Party Vote
description: Puerto Rico's voters will decide Sunday whether the Democratic Party will stay in the control of statehood advocates or be turned over to those who want the island to remain a United States commonwealth.

title: Count Basie Orchestra
description: The Count Basie Orchestra will play music for dancing, presented by the New York Swing Society, on Sunday at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090). Doors open at 7 P.M.; tickets are $25.

title: Okinawan Folk Music
description: Yukito Ara, a performer on the Okinawan shamisen, a variant form of the Japanese lute, will play a concert of folk music from Okinawa at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art,Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, Manhattan, on Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 206-1050.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 18, 1988
description: COMPANIES Federal regulators will provide $1 billion in cash to First Republicbank's subsidiary banks in an effort to stop a huge outflow of deposits and a widespread loss of confidence in Texas's largest banking company. The F.D.I.C. said it would guarantee all deposits, of any amount, in the company's 73 banking subsidiaries. But the regulators stressed that the obligations of the parent company would not be guaranteed, raising the prospect that shareholders and creditors could lose their investments. [ Page A1. ] Firestone agreed to be acquired by Bridgestone for $80 a share, or $2.6 billion, a price far beyond the $58-a-share, $1.86 billion offered by Pirelli. [ D1. ] Pillsbury will sell its Godfather's Pizza chain and sell or close poor performers in its Steak and Ale and its Bennigan's chains. [ D1. ] American Standard accepted a takeover offer of $78 a share, or slightly more than $2.5 billion in cash, from the small investment house Kelso & Company. [ D1. ] Merv Griffin offered to buy Resorts International for $35 a share, or about $225 million, impeding the efforts of Donald J. Trump to take the company private. The bid was quickly rejected by Resorts' board and spurned by Mr. Trump. [ D3. ] Whirlpool increased its offer for Roper to $50 a share, topping a $45-a-share bid from G.E. [ D3. ] Apple Computer sued Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard, charging copyright infringement in software programs that mimic the look of the Macintosh screen. [ D3. ] No delay is needed in Campeau's revised tender offer for Federated Department Stores, the S.E.C. told a Federal court. [ D3. ] Ms. will change hands for the second time in six months when a group of executives buy it and Sassy. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The U.S. foreign trade deficit widened slightly in January, to $12.4 billion. But it showed significant improvement with major trading partners like Japan and the countries of Western Europe. And imports, which have remained stubbornly high, fell $2.2 billion to the lowest level since April 1987. [ A1. ] Factories, mines and utilities operated at 82.4 percent of capacity in February, the third consecutive month at that level. [ D6. ] A Senate committee has refused to provide the G.S.A. with information about its investigation into charges of corruption in the awarding of Government telephone contracts. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL Britain cut interest rates to halt the surge in the pound. The Bank of England trimmed its benchmark rate to 8.5 percent and major commercial banks followed. [ D1. ] MARKETS More changes are needed to prevent another collapse of the stock market, the S.E.C. chairman, David S. Ruder, warned. [ D1. ] Stock prices moved higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21.72 points, to close at 2,086.04, its highest level since the market crash on Oct. 19. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose, recouping most of Wednesday's losses. [ D12. ] Oil futures rose sharply in late trading, buoyed by reports that OPEC would soon take steps to bolster prices. [ D14. ] The Panama pipeline that carries Alaskan oil remained closed. But experts said a disruption of world oil markets was unlikely. [ A9. ] The dollar soared against most currencies, but the Canadian dollar traded at a four-year high against the U.S. currency. In New York, gold fell $1.60, to $443.40. [ D14. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Corporate America has become the acquisitive society par excellence. But do the mergers increase the efficiency of American corporations or the economy? Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Japanese stock prices have climbed to their highest levels since the Oct. 19 crash on Wall Street. And Japanese issues that trade in the U.S. are posting solid gains. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest periods included a pre- tax writedown of $350,000 on oil and gas assets.

title: Japanese Riding Hawaii's Real Estate Boom
description: Real estate brokers here tell stories about Genshiro Kawamoto, a 55-year-old Tokyo billionaire who in recent months has cruised Honolulu's better residential neighborhoods in a black limousine. Every so often he pointed to a house he wanted to buy.

title: Boogie-Woogie Band
description: Sammy Price, a pianist, will lead a boogie-woogie band tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., along with a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Tuna Importers Told To Cut Dolphin Deaths
description: A Federal agency today ordered foreign nations that export tuna to the United States to reduce the number of dolphins killed in fishing.

title: Ruder Sees Disagreement on Market Curbs
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that talks between the exchanges and regulators have yet to produce sufficient agreement on new measures -including coordinated trading halts, price limits and other ''circuit breakers'' - to prevent another collapse of the stock market.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Lawrence Turcic, 38, Met Museum Curator
description: Lawrence Turcic, assistant curator in the drawings department of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York. He was 38 years old.

title: Bork Signs to Write Book on American Law
description: Robert H. Bork, whose nomination to the Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate last fall, has signed with the Free Press, a division of Macmillan, to write a book tentatively titled ''Dissenting Opinion.'' Publication is planned for the spring of 1989.

title: 3,000 G.I.'s, and Questions; Is Move Good Policy Or an Overreaction?
description: President Reagan's decision to dispatch more than 3,000 troops to Honduras has generated angry debate throughout the capital.

title: RAPITECH SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Risk of the Recalcitrant Surrogate Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Math Teacher to Root For in 'Stand and Deliver'
description: Even those used to watching Edward James Olmos regularly in his ''Miami Vice'' role will have a tough time recognizing him at first in ''Stand and Deliver,'' since Mr. Olmos has transformed himself so completely. His hair has been thinned and pasted unflatteringly across his pate; he looks heavier, wears glasses and has none of the complexion-improving makeup used for his television role. Mr. Olmos has turned himself into the complete embodiment of a hard-working, knowledge-loving public school math teacher whose greatest ambition is to see his students get ahead, and he has done this to inspiringly great effect. If ever a film made its audience want to study calculus, this is the one.

title: Drummer and Quintet
description: Michael Carvin, a drummer, will lead a quintet featuring Claudio Roditi on trumpet tonight through Sunday at at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9, 10:30 P.M. and midnight and 1:15 A.M.; there is no fourth set on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament; West Regional; Late 3-Pointer Sinks Redmen
description: St. John's, a controversial choice for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, made a quick but hard-fought exit here tonight.

title: Treasury Bonds and Notes Regain Ground
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose yesterday, recouping virtually all the losses sustained in the previous trading session.

title: Carlucci Says Soviet Talks Built 'Bridge'
description: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci ended a three-day meeting with his Soviet counterpart today by declaring that ''a bridge of communication has been built.''

title: New Role for CUNY: Big Brother to Public Schools
description: At 10 public schools in New York City, many educational decisions - including setting entrance requirements, shaping the curriculum and choosing the principal -are worked out with a branch of the City University.

title: Advertising; Liberty Travel to Start TV Effort on Sunday
description: Liberty Travel, a major independent travel agency that is the largest newspaper advertiser in the travel-service business, will start a big television effort in the New York market on Sunday.

title: New Security Is Proposed
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it was asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to approve trading in a new product called Cash Index Participation contracts. The exchange said the so-called C.I.P.'s would allow investors to buy or sell an index of stocks in the same way they trade individual shares of stock.

title: Koch Administration Blocks Ex-Adviser From Civic Posts
description: A former adviser to Mayor Koch, Franklin J. Havlicek, has been rejected for two civic posts by the Koch administration in what Mr. Havlicek said was an effort by City Hall to stifle dissenting voices in government.

title: TIME MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Case Against the President
description: President Reagan is not accused of any crime in the indictment of John Poindexter, Oliver North and two weapons traders for the Iran-contra conspiracy. The very fact of the indictment accuses him of something more serious.

title: U.S. TROOPS ARRIVE AT HONDURAS BASE TO SHOW SUPPORT
description: A force of more than 3,000 United States combat troops began arriving at a Honduran air base today as a show of support for the Honduran Government.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $207,862 from an accounting change.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
2 Azerbaijani Officials Dismissed Over Rioting
description: The Communist Party chief of the Azerbaijani city of Sumgait, where at least 32 people were killed in attacks against Armenians last month, has been dismissed for ''major shortcomings'' in his work, officials said today.

title: Democracy Triumphs in a Literary Guise
description: To the Editor:

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest year results reflect a pooling of interest with Monfort of Colorado Inc., which merged with Conagra in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1987.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Panama Imposes Curbs, Recasts Military After Revolt
description: The Panamanian Government militarized public utilities today and ordered a curfew in the country's second-largest city in an effort to restore order after a coup attempt against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. It also began a shake-up of the military high command, The curbs were imposed after strikes by utility workers cut off electricity and water and blocked roads. At electrical plants and hospitals here, soldiers were on guard, and leaders of the electrical workers' union said that some employees were being forced to work at gunpoint.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
I.B.M. PS/2 Shipments
description: Shipments of the International Business Machines Corporation's new line of personal computers, introduced last April, reached 1.5 million units by the end of January, the company's senior vice president, George Conrades, said today.

title: 3 Die in Blast at a Jersey Testing Plant
description: An explosion and fire at a chemical testing plant early today killed three men and seriously injured a fourth, and officials said they were focusing their investigaton on a cylinder of possibly unstable gas.

title: Art People
description: Unstereotyped Rituals

title: Toll of 2 Cancers Is Up Among Elderly
description: A new study has found surprisingly sharp increases over 15 years in deaths from two uncommon types of cancer in elderly white Americans. They are brain cancer and multiple myeloma, a marrow cancer that can painfully destroy bone.

title: Fading Devils Lose 2-Goal Advantage
description: The Devils relinquished a two-goal lead tonight and let 2 more valuable points escape from their grasp in the race for the playoffs.

title: South Africa Delays Hanging of 6 Blacks In Killing of Official
description: Six blacks won a one-month stay of execution in a South African court today, 15 hours before they were to be hanged.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company's minority interest in Precision Target Marketing resulted in a loss of $203,000 for the latest third quarter, compared with a gain of $20,000 for the year-ago period, and a loss of $435,000 for the latest 9 months, against a gain of $84,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Raucous Pop Songs To an International Beat
description: THERE'S a great moment in the middle of ''Paid in Full,'' a slinky rap piece by Eric B. and Rakim, remixed and tarted up for dance clubs: Out of left field comes a woman's wailing voice, obviously Middle Eastern in its gentle, hilly melismas. But her voice fits in perfectly, suggesting different cultures colliding and yet having fun.

title: On Stage
description: 'Graduate' and 'Godspell'

title: Queens Murder Suspect Is Sentenced to Prison
description: One of two men who investigators suspect ordered the slaying of a rookie New York City police officer was sentenced yesterday to three and a half to seven years in a separate gun possession case.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $36,120,000. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $1.2 million for the quarter and $11,758,000 for the year. The latest year included an after- tax charge of $43.4 million for disposition, expenses and writedowns of discontinued businesses.

title: UNIGENE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Shamir Leaves Washington With U.S. Proposal in Peril
description: The four-day visit to Washington by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel ended today with the Reagan Administration's Middle East peace initiative on the brink of failure.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Two Soul Survivors

title: BAKER, J INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,596,000.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Going Private
description: Last September, a President who was looking for policies to pursue in his lame-duck year appointed a commission to explore some of his old ideas about letting private operators take over some of the Government's work and to develop some new ones he had not yet considered.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about bids for J. P. Stevens misstated Senator Strom Thurmond's position about the possibility of a takeover by West Point-Pepperell.

title: Rushing to React in Honduras
description: If Nicaragua were intent on occupying Honduran territory, that might justify President Reagan's dispatch of 3,200 U.S. troops to support an aggrieved ally. Yesterday's truculent declarations from President Daniel Ortega suggest, again, that Managua knows how to snatch defeat from the jaws of political victory.

title: Bilzerian Looks At SSMC Sale
description: The Florida corporate raider Paul A. Bilzerian, who took over the Singer Company earlier this year, said today that he might seek a buyer for SSMC Inc., the sewing machine company spun off from Singer two years ago.

title: Restaurants
description: CENTURIES before the neologism grazing was coined to describe hit-and-run eaters, the Spanish were doing just that at their tascas, convivial restaurants where a copious display of appetizers, called tapas, were lined up along the bar. So it should be no surprise to Rufino Lopez, a native of Galicia in northwestern Spain, that nomadic nibblers are flocking to his inviting new restaurant, Alcala.

title: Rome Prizes Awarded
description: Scholars, artists, architects, writers and arts patrons gathered in the State Department's elegant Diplomatic Reception Rooms this evening to mark the 94th year of the American Academy in Rome and to announce the 1988-89 winners of its prestigious Rome Prize.

title: At the Border, Nicaraguan Says Raid Is Over
description: Sandinista troops have called off a major military offensive along the northern border with Honduras after overrunning a series of contra guerrilla bases, according to local commanders.

title: Sports of The Times; Coaches Raising the Roof?
description: IT took 4.8 inches of snow followed by a heavy rain to bring down the roof of the Hartford Civic Center on Jan. 18, 1978. Who knows what the collection of Knights and Thompsons, Chaneys and Browns, will do to the reinforced girders and cement today?

title: Maurice S. Segal, Medical Researcher, 80
description: Dr. Maurice S. Segal, professor emeritus at Tufts University School of Medicine who was a prominent researcher in lung disease, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Once Again, an AIDS Furor
description: LEAD: We are being prevented by cultural habits of thought from the urgent task of measured responses to the AIDS epidemic.

title: Louis Gates, Chemical Researcher, 81, Dies
description: Louis W. Gates, a chemical researcher who played an important role in the modern development of the liquid disinfectant known as Lysol, died Monday at the Waterview Nursing Home in Cedar Grove, N.J., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: Italian Conservative to Try to Form Cabinet
description: President Francesco Cossiga has asked the leader of the Christian Democrats, Ciriaco De Mita, to form a new Government.

title: Cruise Ship Plans Refunds
description: Passengers of the fire-crippled cruise ship Scandinavian Star, under tow to Cancun on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula today, will receive refunds and tickets for another Mexican cruise, a company spokeswoman said. Jill DeChello of the Miami-based SeaEscape Ltd., which runs the Star, said the passengers would be reimbursed their fares, which range from $179 to $499 fares, and get a free cruise.

title: Lawyer for 2 in Iran Inquiry Said to Get Immunity
description: A Geneva-based lawyer and financial adviser to two arms dealers indicted in the Iran-contra affair has been granted immunity in exchange for cooperation with the special prosecutor in the case, according to people familiar with the investigation.

title: Letter Says Prosecutor Is Blackmailing Judge
description: A Colombian accused of smuggling 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States has presented a letter in court alleging that the chief prosecutor in his Federal trial is blackmailing the judge.

title: Choral Society
description: The New York Choral Society, under the direction of John Daly Goodwin, will sing Vaughan Williams's ''Serenade to Music,'' Rossini's ''Stabat Mater'' and Bruckner's ''Mass in E minor'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The soloists, in the Rossini, are Susan Neves, soprano; Antoinette Hardin, mezzo-soprano; Richard Croft, tenor, and Jan Opalach, bass. Tickets are $10 to $22. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Advertising; Ex-New Yorkers Start San Francisco Agencies
description: Out in San Francisco, two new ad agencies are on the scene, each started by creative people from New York - one by an old pro and the other by a couple of under-30 upstarts.

title: Apple Sues Microsoft And Hewlett-Packard
description: Hoping to protect a key selling point of its Macintosh, Apple Computer Inc. filed a copyright-infringement suit against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

title: N.F.L. Takes Over Indebted Patriots
description: The National Football League today virtually took the New England Patriots away from the Sullivan family.

title: Review/Film; Mastroianni in 'Mattia'
description: Marcello Mastroianni has never had any trouble convincing us that he can charm any woman who catches his eye, and any audience along with her. He's doing it again in ''The Two Lives of Mattia Pascal,'' a movie made for European television that opens today at the Carnegie Screening Room.

title: Southdown Sues
description: Southdown Inc., the Houston cement maker that has offered $420 million for Moore McCormack ResourcesInc. of Stamford, Conn., said it had sued Moore McCormack's directors over an anti-takeover provision and a possible recapitalization. Earlier this week, Moore McCormack, which also produces cement, said it was considering a financial restructuring or recapitalization that could mean paying a substantial cash dividend to its shareholders to maximize the value of its stock and avoid being acquired by Southdown.

title: Senators Deny G.S.A. Data on Phone Inquiry
description: The Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs has refused to provide the General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals with information about its investigation into charges of corruption in the awarding of Government telephone contracts, according to correspondence released yesterday by the G.S.A.

title: GREAT AMERICAN MANAGEENT & INVESTMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Ex-Police Official Acquitted In Two Puerto Rico Killings
description: A former police colonel was found not guilty early today in the murders of two young radicals almost 10 years ago, while another former policeman was found guilty in the deaths.

title: British Jobless Rate Dips
description: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in February from 9.2 percent in January, the Government said today. The figure stood at 11 percent in February 1987, the Department of Employment said.

title: I.R.A. Man Buried, in Peaceful Rites
description: A fresh grave was dug this morning at Milltown Cemetery, and another Irish Republican Army insurgent was interred, this time in peace.

title: Lilco Inquiry By Giuliani Is Reported
description: Two Suffolk County officials said today that United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani has for the last four months been investigating criminal allegations that the Long Island Lighting Company has repeatedly lied to regulatory commissions and filed false documents with the panels.

title: Mets Air Aiming to Sharpen Lineup
description: The Mets indicated today that they would end spring training in two weeks with a flurry of moves along these lines: John Gibbons will be traded, Mookie Wilson will probably not be traded, Mark Carreon and Keith Miller may make the team as rookies, and Randy Milligan will start the season in Tidewater and not in Japan.

title: Review/Film; A Look at High School In 'O.C. and Stiggs'
description: ''O. C. and Stiggs,'' made by Robert Altman in 1984, deals with what may be one of the director's least favorite subjects: all-American boys. Mr. Altman's utter lack of sympathy for this film's two schoolboy protagonists (the screenplay is based on material from National Lampoon magazine) is unmistakable, and it's also liberating, so his satirical side is given unusually free rein.

title: Deliberations Begin in Trial Of Chambers
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. began deliberating yesterday after 11 weeks of testimony, 8 hours of closing arguments by the lawyers and 90 minutes of final legal instructions by the judge.

title: Sports People; Golfer Revives Boy
description: A petition was being circulated yesterday among players in the L.P.G.A. Tucson Open seeking to exempt Mary Bea Porter from qualifying for next week's Standard Register Turquoise Classic in Phoenix, an L.P.G.A. spokeswoman said.

title: Trade Deficit a Bit Bigger Over All But Improves by 18% With Japan
description: The nation's deficit in foreign trade widened slightly in January, to $12.4 billion, a $200 million increase over December's total. But the deficit showed significant improvement with major trading partners like Japan and the countries of Western Europe, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Dow Up 21.72, to 2,086, Highest Since Crash
description: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21.72 points to close at 2,086.04, its highest level since the market crash on Oct. 19.

title: Dannie Richmond, 56, Drummer With Mingus
description: Dannie Richmond, a drummer whose long association with Charles Mingus made him one of the leading percussionists in modern jazz, died Wednesday in Harlem of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Review/Film; Relationship of 2 Brothers Explored in 'Dominick and Eugene'
description: Twelve seconds and a world of difference separate Dominick (Tom Hulce) and Eugene (Ray Liotta), fraternal twins whose mental abilities vary tremendously. Gino is a hard-working medical student, and his education is being paid for by Nicky, who is proud of being able to provide for his slightly younger brother. However, Nicky's own career is less distinguished, since he works cheerfully and at the height of his abilities as a garbage man. An accident that occurred when the twins were young has kept Nicky in a perpetually childlike state.

title: East Regional; Syracuse Gains On Late Surge
description: Before facing North Carolina A & T in the first round of the East Regional, Coach Jim Boeheim of Syracuse said, ''I always go into the tournament feeling the same: worried something bad's going to happen.''

title: LARGE TEXAS BANK TO GET $1 BILLION IN FEDERAL RESCUE
description: Federal bank regulators announced today that they would inject $1 billion in cash into the subsidiary banks of the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas in an effort to stop a huge outflow of deposits and a widespread loss of confidence in the largest banking company in Texas.

title: AMERICAN CARRIERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament; Southeast Regional; Purdue Displays Power; Auburn Rallies
description: Stan Albeck's pregame apprehension proved to be right.

title: Pipeline Used for Alaskan Oil Shut by Blackout in Panama
description: The 80-mile pipeline that carries Alaskan oil across Panama for shipment to Gulf Coast refineries in the United States was closed for a second day yesterday because a strike by utility workers caused a widespread electricity blackout.

title: Advertising; Ex-Ogilvy Officer to B.J.K.&E.
description: JAY SCHULBERG, who quit his job as the creative head of the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather to look for something different, has now become creative head of the New York office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Review/Theater; 'Great Hunger,' a Dearth of Words
description: ''The Great Hunger,'' Tom MacIntyre's adaptation of Patrick Kavanagh's poem, has been controversial both in Ireland and on its world tour - for a reason that is self-evident. The play seems to contradict the founding principles of the Abbey Theater as a home for the eloquence of such writers as Yeats, Synge and O'Casey. As directed by Patrick Mason, this is intended as a work of performance art. It substitutes gestures and visual and aural effects for text. There are some words in the play, but they are insistently and boringly repetitive.

title: Buoyant Dancers Conquer New York Stages
description: SPRING begins officially next week. This, then, might well be the last weekend suitable for holing up in theaters. And it is possible to do that in dance theaters alone, since the weekend boasts programs by an extraordinary number of major choreographers and interesting newer ones, as well as a range of dancing that incorporates almost every aspect of the art.

title: Topeka Journal; A Club Where Egos Are Kept Small
description: No one knows exactly why the founders formed the Saturday Night Literary Club, one of Topeka's most venerable organizations. For the last century the Literary Club's members have met to hear, politely, one member read an original essay, then to criticize it and its author, sometimes politely.

title: Looking to the South
description: Bob Dole probably missed his chance for the Republican Presidential nomination when he could not follow up his Iowa victory with one in New Hampshire. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts may look back upon Illinois as the state in which his hopes suffered a similar setback.

title: Sports People; Apology to Postema
description: Carrying a letter of apology from the management of the Houston Astros, Manager Hal Lanier entered the umpires' locker room in Kissimmee, Fla., on Wednesday, and offered his apologies to Pat Postema for comments made about her on Monday by Bob Knepper, the pitcher.

title:
Horse Racing Notebook;
Cordero, Vasquez and Velasquez Are Nominated to the Hall of Fame
description: LEAD: Angel Cordero Jr., Jacinto Vasquez and Jorge Velasquez have been nominated for election to the Racing Hall of Fame this year, ending more than a decade of controversy that had kept the three jockeys off the ballot.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company noted that results for the first three quarters of 1987 were restated to reflect the consolidation of certain foreign subsidiaries which previously had been accounted for by the equity method.

title: Asset Sales Sought For Media General
description: Burt Sugarman, the chairman of Barris Industries and Giant Group Ltd., disclosed today that he had held talks with several Media General Inc. shareholders in an attempt to find potential purchasers of the assets of the communications concern based in Richmond.

title: Advertising; Arvida Turns to Video To Sell Florida Project
description: Now that 53.3 percent of American households are equipped with video cassette recorders, the videotape as a promotional vehicle is definitely an attractive prospect. Once you find a way to take care of the costs, that is.

title: Scientists Fear for an Ancient Egyptian Boat
description: A 4,600-year-old wooden boat of the Pharaoh Cheops appears to be in good condition, scientists said today. But they wondered how much longer it would survive the inhospitable conditions of the pit at the base of the Great Pyramid at Giza, where it was found.

title: Market Place; Japanese Stocks Build Momentum
description: STOCK prices in Japan, bolstered by domestic buying demand, have climbed to their highest levels since the Oct. 19 crash on Wall Street. And numerous Japanese issues that trade here as American depository shares are posting solid gains on the New York Stock Exchange in response to the higher prices in Tokyo.

title: The Risk of the Recalcitrant Surrogate Mother; Brecht and Solomon
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Finds Simon-Dukakis Voters Cool on Jackson
description: In the Illinois Presidential primary, Senator Paul Simon's voters also liked Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, and the Dukakis voters liked Mr. Simon. But neither predominantly white group had much use for the Rev. Jesse Jackson or for other Democratic candidates, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Egg Rolls and Bankrolls
description: Back in the 1950's, a Muscovite weary of potatoes and cabbage could find a Chinese menu at the Pekin Restaurant.

title: Review/Film; 'Beatrice,' Medieval Tale by Tavernier
description: Bertrand Tavernier lays on plenty of medieval lifestyle in ''Beatrice,'' possibly in an effort to distract us from its Gothic plot, compliments of Krafft-Ebing. The de Cortemare castle seems to have been decorated by the same firm that did the Majestic Theater - cold stone relieved by a swatch or two of material. The lighting, by torch, does not encourage reading, not that anybody in the place can read anyhow, but it does throw dramatic shadows. The inmates, got up in tatty finery, enjoy finger-licking banquets. People and animals are constantly bustling about the farmyard and through the spooky corridors, to jagged bits of music.

title: Our Towns; With a 'Ten-Hut,' 4 Middletowns March as One
description: The band from Middletown, Del., arrived here Wednesday night at 7:30, so the band room at Middletown (N.J.) South High was twice as crammed as usual. ''You think this is bad,'' said David Harris, a band leader. ''Wait for the two other Middletowns tomorrow.''

title: West Regional; At Last, Arizona Is Respected
description: Ken Lofton, a reserve guard for Arizona, plays only 16 minutes a game, but has nearly twice as many steals as any other Wildcat. He left East Chicago, Ind., three years ago for the steamy desert of Tucson, Ariz., but found that being a Wildcat wasn't cool.

title: Corruption Witness Admits He Obstructed Justice
description: A witness in municipal corruption cases pleaded guilty yesterday to obstructing justice by withholding information about a collection company for New York City's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: A Spirited Lacroix and the Serious Japanese
description: Christian Lacroix, the designer who made couture clothes sizzle, has shown he can make relatively subdued styles as well as fanciful, exhuberant ones. Both types were represented in his first extensive ready-to-wear collection. It was presented in a courtyard tent at the Louvre late Wednesday afternoon, the first day of the fall and winter fashion openings.

title: Pope Plans an African Visit
description: Pope John Paul II will visit five countries in southern Africa in September, a Vatican representative announced here today. The Pope, who will not visit South Africa, will make brief stops in Zimbabwe, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland and Mozambique from Sept. 10 to Sept. 19. The Pope will begin his trip in Zimbabwe on Sept. 10, where he is scheduled to attend a regional meeting of Roman Catholic bishops.

title: Review/Film; 'Beanfield,' Directed By Redford
description: ''The Milagro Beanfield War,'' Robert Redford's first film as a director since ''Ordinary People,'' is a populist fable set in some beautiful New Mexican landscapes about one stubborn Chicano's battle against an uncaring system. It's as full of good intentions as a campaign to get out the vote.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * British Land of America Inc., a subsidiary of British Land Co. P.L.C., London, said John H. Weston would resume the position of executive vice chairman and chief executive.

title: Mario On Mario
description: Picking a Democratic nominee from the convention galleries, putting aside the candidates who went through the primaries, would be a terrible mistake. It would be the best way to give the election away to the Republicans. If people like Mario Cuomo wanted to be President, they should have run in the primaries.

title: Article 045388 -- No Title
description: The Federal Election Commission has certified almost $3.5 million in new Federal matching funds for 11 Presidential candidates, some of whom are no longer in the race.

title: Review/Art; The Hypnotic Canvases Of Robert Moskowitz
description: ROBERT MOSKOWITZ works and reworks a narrow repertory of images, inventing through mysterious scenes of icebergs, howling dogs, crosses and skyscrapers a world in which distinctions blur between past and present, solid and ephemeral. There is a hypnotic quality to these large-scale paintings and pastels, and they call forth elusive, subconscious emotions.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Included after-tax LIFO charges of $337,000 for the quarter and $686,000 for the year. c-Included a credit of $48,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a charge of $257,000 for the year. The company said the Abercrombie & Fitch unit, which it recently sold, had a pre-tax loss of about $2 million before corporate overhead allocations in the latest year.

title: Review/Film; Tracing an Uncommon Love
description: For a movie that starts with voyeurism, advances to acute acne and concludes with a bout of necrophilia, ''Love Is a Dog From Hell'' is a remarkably innocent romance. Dominique Deruddere, a 31-year-old Belgian director, found the idea for his first full-length feature in the stories of Charles Bukowski, an American writer with an underground reputation who did the screenplay for ''Barfly.'' The funny, tender, surprising result can be seen at the New Directors/New Films festival tonight at 8:30 and Sunday at 6 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art. (The program opens with ''A Warm Reception in L.A.,'' by Vincent Cafarelli and Candy Kugel, a zippy five-minute singing cartoon about a writer whom nobody calls back.) Mr. Deruddere, who collaborated with Marc Didden on the screenplay, first did a short movie based on Mr. Bukowski's account of a man making love to a dead woman, then worked his way back to the youth of the necrophiliac, here called Harry Voss. The interpretation of how Harry got that way is a bit pat, but the three matched sections of the final work are filled with such sympathy for his longings that they compel understanding.

title: Review/Art; Action in New Paintings By Martha Diamond
description: It is easy to walk in and out of Martha Diamond's latest exhibition at the Robert Miller Gallery and think that there's not much going on, that this painter of lush, fragrantly colored, nearly abstract skyscrapers and city views is falling apart in public. At times, this seems to be the case. Several of these paintings look unfinished, falling victim to Ms. Diamond's wide-brushed, wet-on-wet painting method. But others may be among the best paintings she has made. This exhibition has a reach to it that one had ceased to expect from Ms. Diamond. It shows her taking on new subjects (particularly an unspecified, generic still life), aligning herself more aggressively with painters of the past and present and honing the vaudevillian bravura that always characterized her work.

title: TWO U.S. SENATORS ENDORSE DUKAKIS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis came to Washington today to pick up the endorsements of two Senators and to court some others, signifying a new phase of the race for the Democratic nomination marked by intense competition for the backing of party leaders.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on Tuesday gave an incorrect decimal value for the binary number 1010101. It is 85.

title: Canadian and U.S. Dollars Advance as Pound Softens
description: The dollar soared against most major currencies yesterday, but the Canadian dollar traded at a four-year high against the American dollar.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Cockburn at Town Hall

title: Voluntary Hospitals To Add Beds to Ease Crisis in New York
description: Private hospitals have agreed to provide most of the 412 beds being added to relieve overcrowding in New York City hospitals, according to a plan issued yesterday by the State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod.

title: Standard Endorses Kelso Bid
description: After a two-month battle to preserve its independence, American Standard Inc. yesterday accepted a takeover offer of $78 a share, or slightly more than $2.5 billion in cash, from the small Manhattan investment house Kelso & Company.

title: Haydn Opera
description: The Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, near 122d Street and Broadway, Manhattan, will present a Haydn opera, ''La Fedelta Premiata'' (''Virtue Rewarded''), in an English translation by Marcie Stapp, tonight at 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. The production is the American premiere of the work, and is directed by Lou Galtero, with choreography by Francis Patrelle. The student soloists and orchestra are directed by Thomas Dunn. Tickets are $8 to $12. Information: (212) 749-2802, extension 452.

title: Senate Committee Bars Abrams From Session
description: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was barred today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee from appearing at a closed briefing for members on the fighting along the Honduran border.

title: N.C.A.A. Tournament; Midwest Regional; Purdue Displays Power; Auburn Rallies
description: The last time, three years ago, Fairleigh Dickinson University was the ignored entrant that came close to producing one of the biggest shocks in the history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Review/Art; David Salle and Rafael Ferrer: In Mainstream and Out
description: David Salle's paintings (at the Mary Boone/Michael Werner Gallery) are still naughty, sly, cool. They are less busy, less layered with images. Everything seems slow, displaced, almost under water. Objects and women appear to be waiting, preparing, making themselves available. The sources of the appropriated, vaguely familiar images are more obscure. In this finely tuned pictorial world, chaos and stillness have the same sound, and suspension of self-consciousness is impossible.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Campeau Bid Ruling By S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission advised a Federal district judge yesterday that the Campeau Corporation's revised tender offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. need not be delayed because it is an amended bid rather than a new one.

title: Managers' Group Bids for Air Wis
description: A company led by senior managers of Air Wis Services Inc. said it had offered to acquire the airline holding company for about $103.6 million in cash and bonds. The company's subsidiary, Air Wisconsin Inc., is the nation's largest regional air carrier, flying under the name United Express and providing feeder traffic from East Coast cities for connections to United Airlines flights under a marketing agreement.

title: Factory Use Rate Unchanged
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 82.4 percent of capacity in February, the third consecutive month at that level, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Washington Talk: The Executive Branch; Taking Plunge From White House to Congress
description: Dana T. Rohrabacher was a bodysurfer off the California beaches of Torrance and Long Beach before he began organizing youth support for a 1966 candidate for Governor - Ronald Reagan - and he rode the conservative wave to the White House.

title: Auctions
description: Decorative Arts Rare, offbeat decorative arts produced over the last century - an 1880's lavishly gilded chair by Antonio Gaudi, a glowing 1920's glass platter by Frederick Carder and several 1930's geometric-patterned Kodak cameras by Walter Dorwin Teague -will be auctioned tomorrow at Sotheby's and next Saturday at Christie's.

title: Sports People; Cubs-Rangers Trade
description: The Chicago Cubs traded 27-year-old Ray Hayward, a left-handed pitcher with an 8-5 record and a 3.10 earned run average with Las Vegas of the Pacific Coast League last season, to the Texas Rangers for two players who spent last year with Oklahoma City of the American Association. They are Dave Meier, 28, an outfielder, who hit .320 with 18 home runs and 86 runs batted in, and Greg Tabor, an infielder, who hit .303 with 8 home runs and 66 r.b.i.

title: Sports People; Bell Is Fined
description: George Bell of the Toronto Blue Jays was fined an unspecified amount and suspended for the rest of the day for refusing to serve as a designated hitter yesterday against the Boston Red Sox in Dunedin, Fla.

title: Resorts International Rejects Bid by Griffin
description: Merv Griffin, the entertainer and businessman, made a last-minute offer today to buy Resorts International Inc. for $35 a share, or about $225 million, impeding Donald J. Trump's plan to take the casino and hotel company private.

title: TV Weekend; 'Inherit the Wind' and 'Hot Paint'
description: Two very different made-for-television productions are being offered this Sunday, both at 9 P.M. NBC is presenting still another revival of ''Inherit the Wind,'' the sturdy warhorse that's trotted out every few years to give actors of a certain age a chance to show off. This time the stars are Jason Robards and Kirk Douglas. CBS, on the other hand, has a comedy movie starring Gregory Harrison and John Larroquette. It's called ''Hot Paint'' and has a respectable quota of funny moments.

title: RECO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Risky Role In Honduras; U.S. Show of Support Could Easily Escalate
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to send more than 3,000 troops to Honduras is so far largely a symbolic gesture of support for Honduras after a Sandinista attack on contra bases along the border, according to diplomats in the region.

title: The Law; The Circuit Bench: A Lonely Job Full of Hard Questions
description: Patricia M. Wald, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, in a speech at Yale Law School, provided these insights into the working lives of appellate judges:

title: Whirlpool Lifts Roper Offer, Tops G.E. Bid by $5 a Share
description: The Whirlpool Corporation yesterday increased its offer for the Roper Corporation to $50 a share, topping a $45-a-share bid from the General Electric Company.

title: Bridge; One National Event is Ending in Buffalo as Others Are Beginning
description: As thousands of bridge players converged on this city today to start some national championship events, another was ending.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Magee and Azinger Tied: Paul Azinger shot a five-under-par 66 yesterday to tie Andrew Magee for the first-round lead in Arnold Palmer's Hertz Bay Hill Classic in Orlando, Fla. Magee was one of five players in the field of 114 to birdie the 18th hole. Bay Hill's 18th, a 456-yard par-4 slightly uphill with the green tucked against water on the right, is one of the 10 most difficult holes on the PGA Tour. Payne Stewart, who won this tournament last year, was tied with eight others at 68. Sled Dog Racing Butcher Wins Again: Susan Butcher coasted to her third straight victory in the 1,150-mile Iditarod Trail race Wednesday night. Cold winds raked the finish line in Nome, Alaska, as the flushed and perspiring 33-year-old cruised beneath the log-arch finish. Butcher finished after 11 days 11 hours 41 minutes, a record for the race's northern route from Anchorage. Last year, her time of 11 days 2 hours set a record for the shorter southern route. (AP) Tennis Evert, Connors Gain: Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors advanced yesterday to the third round of the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Fifth-seeded Andres Gomez became the highest-seeded player eliminated. Evert beat Melissa Gurney of Asheville, N.C., 6-0, 6-2. Connors defeated Jaro Navratil of Czechoslovakia, 6-0, 6-4, 6-4. Gomez lost to Jay Berger of Plantation, Fla., for the second time here in two years, 6-4, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3. Mel Purcell of Atlanta rallied from a 4-1 deficit in the fifth set to beat 10th-seeded Joakim Nystrom of Sweden, 6-4, 4-6, 3-6, 6-0, 7-5. (AP) N.C.A.A. Wrestling Slim Lead for Iowa State: Iowa State took a slim lead over Oklahoma State and Penn State yesterday after the first round of bouts in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Ames, Iowa. Iowa State had 17.75 team points with Oklahoma State and Penn State tied at 17.25. Arizona State had 15.5 points and Iowa had 15 heading into the second round. Three of Iowa State's nine wrestlers lost in the first round: Joe Ghezzi at 142, Jeff Kelly at 158 and Andy Cope at heavyweight. Vince Silva, a second-seeded 158-pounder from Oklahoma State suffered the biggest upset of the first round, losing an 8-6 decision to unseeded Scott Schleicher of Navy. The defending 150-pound national champion, Tim Kreiger, of Iowa State, scored a 16-1 technical fall over Paul Radomski of Navy to advance.(AP) N.B.A. Pistons 102, Cavaliers 99: Adrian Dantley scored 20 points, and Vinnie Johnson added 12 of his 16 points in the final period last night to spark Detroit on the road. It was the fifth consecutive victory for Detroit and left the Pistons (43-20) a game and a half behind the Boston Celtics for the best record in the Eastern Conference. Cleveland (30-35) cut the lead to 98-96 on a hook shot by Brad Daugherty with 31 seconds left. Johnson made a pair of free throws with 19 seconds to go, and Isiah Thomas scored his only second-half points on two free throws with nine seconds left for a 102-96 lead. (AP) Pacers 99, Bullets 95: Vern Fleming scored 9 of his 22 points in the final period for Indiana (31-32), including the go-ahead basket with 48 seconds to play and 3 free throws in the final 12 seconds. Jeff Malone scored 31 points and John Williams 26 for Washington (28-35), whose lead over the Knicks and the 76ers in the race for the last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference was trimmed to one game.(AP) N.H.L. Blackhawks 4, Flyers 3: Denis Savard scored 37 seconds into overtime last night, and Chicago'sBob Mason turned away 45 shots to give the Blackhawks their first victory at the Spectrum since March 8, 1983. Savard scored his 42d goal of the season when he pushed a loose puck between the pads of the Flyers' goalie, Ron Hextall. The Flyers' Ilkka Sinisalo had tied the score on a power play when he beat Mason on a rebound from the slot at 8:59 of the final period. Chicago is 3-0 against the Flyers this season.(AP) Flames 7, Bruins 5: Joe Nieuwendyk's tiebreaking goal at 8:21 of the third period led Calgary to the victory in Boston. The Flames' sensational rookie scored his 51st goal to break a 5-5 tie and give Calgary the best overall record in the league by a point over the idle Montreal Canadiens. Joey Mullen clinched the victory for Calgary with an empty-net goal with 12 seconds remaining.(AP)

title: Review/Film; Poitier in 'Little Nikita'
description: Richard Benjamin's strategy in directing ''Little Nikita'' seems to have been to paper over the holes in the plot with routine moves from spy shows past, in hopes of making the improbable passable. Sidney Poitier, an F.B.I. agent again, gets onto a couple of K.G.B. ''sleepers'' named Richard and Elizabeth Grant, a very American couple in the southern California town of Fountain Grove, who have been waiting 20 years for the call to action from Moscow. It arrives in the form of Konstantin Karpov, who is out to get a former Soviet agent named Scuba, who has been killing off other Soviet agents in the United States as a way of blackmailing the Kremlin. ''Your moment has come,'' announces Karpov.

title: Thiokol Says Workers Killed In Blaze Had Ignored Rules
description: Morton Thiokol officials said today that five employees killed in a fire while fueling an MX missile motor had ignored company rules and entered the building during a phase of the operation that should have been handled by remote control.

title: Review/Film; 'Stars and Bars,' U.S. As Land of the Odd
description: Toward the middle of ''Stars and Bars,'' Henderson Dores (Daniel Day-Lewis), a New York art-auction-house representative, arrives in Atlanta to register at one of those multi-story theme parks that are now the fashion in hotels in this country. The room clerk, smiling, gives Henderson his key and says, ''Follow the path through the atrium, then take the scenic elevator to the 35th floor.''

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit reversal of $324,000. c-Net income and after tax credits of $130,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the 9 months.

title: Di Giorgio Stake
description: An investment group led by the Belzberg family of Canada holds a 6 percent stake in the Di Giorgio Corporation and said it might seek control of the San Francisco-based manufacturer and distributor of food products. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Fril Trading Inc., a West Indies investment concern controlled by the Belzbergs, said it had purchased its stake at an average price of $20.91 a share. Di Giorgio was unchanged at $22.625 at the close of today's trading on the New York Stock Exchange. A spokesman for Di Giorgio was unavailable for comment.

title: A Major Victory For Cable Viewers
description: Late last year, a settlement was reached in a little noticed Federal antitrust suit against the principle cable television system in Manhattan. The lawsuit, filed by New York Citizens for Cable TV, accused Manhattan Cable TV of monopolizing pay-movie programming and with failing to live up to its franchise agreement.

title: Soviet Pledges Independent Pullout From Afghanistan
description: A Soviet spokesman said today that the Soviet Union would withdraw its troops from Afghanistan independently, even if negotiators in Geneva fail to agree on conditions for ending the war.

title: CUNY Law School Faculty Group Files a Suit on Two Denied Tenure
description: The faculty of the City University of New York Law School sued the university's Chancellor yesterday in a dispute over the denial of tenure to two faculty members who were influential in developing the school's unorthodox curriculum.

title: Chief at McCormick Adds Chairman's Job
description: Charles P. McCormick Jr., grandnephew of the founder of McCormick & Company, has added the title of chairman at the maker of seasonings, flavorings and specialty foods.

title: Hanoi Seeks Talks With Beijing
description: After a flare-up of hostilities this week in the South China Sea, Vietnam appealed to China today to negotiate an end to naval attacks around a contested offshore island chain ''and all other matters of border disputes.''

title: French 'Field of Honor'
description: Jean-Pierre Denis's ''Field of Honor'' (''Champ d'Honneur'') is a wistful tale about a young farmer from Perigord who goes off to fight in the Franco-Prussian War as the paid substitute for a rich man's son.

title: Campaign Finance; The Election Panel: Friend or Foe?
description: When it met the other day, the Federal Election Commission did not act like the deliberative panel it is supposed to be. The meeting degenerated into a gripe session about flaws in how Presidential campaigns are financed.

title: Nigerian Currency Falls
description: The naira, the Nigerian currency, slid today to its lowest level in nine months: 4.32 to the United States dollar, bankers said. The level marked a 1.5 percent depreciation since the last foreign exchange auction two weeks ago, when the naira was set at 4.25 to the dollar. The currency has fallen steadily since the beginning of the year, when it stood at just over 4 to the dollar, dealers said.

title: The Law; At the Bar
description: Like millions of people in his generation, Isaac Shapiro can vividly recall that moment on Dec. 8, 1941, when he heard Pearl Harbor had been bombed. He was a 10-year-old on his way to school, and clusters of apprehensive men clogged the streets of his hometown. ''The war with America has started,'' one told him.

title: Midwest Regional; Challenging Start
description: Coaches Ben Braun of Eastern Michigan and Steve Newton of Murray State are happy to be in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional, although they are quick to add that they don't plan to be doormats for their high-powered opponents in the first round Friday.

title: Why New York City Hospitals Lose Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Delays Override Effort
description: The Senate today scheduled for Tuesday a vote on President Reagan's veto of a civil rights bill.

title: Big Victory for Owners Of Hyde Park Holdings
description: Two 1983 business school graduates successfully completed their first big tender offer yesterday.

title: Israeli Army Tries New Tactic To Break Strike by Merchants
description: The Israeli Army tried to break compliance with a Palestinian strike and bulldozed an olive grove today as part of its newest measures to curb a 14-week-old revolt in the occupied territories.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY A LIVE 'KOYAANISQATSI'

title: Review/Music; Giordano's 'Chenier' In Concert
description: Giordano's ''Andrea Chenier'' is not likely to return anytime soon to its status as a beloved potboiler in the standard repertory. The plausible candidates for its leading roles are just too few, and verismo opera does not thrive in unidiomatic performances. But it is not a good idea to give up hope; just a few years ago, it seemed as though there were not one single international-class soprano who was vocally and temperamentally right for Maddalena de Coigny, and now there is at least one, as Aprile Millo showed in a Carnegie Hall concert performance on Sunday evening.

title: Seoul Olympic Rings Include Some Made of Barbed Wire
description: Every airport has security checks for departing passengers. The one here even forces arriving visitors to walk through metal detectors after they leave the plane.

title: An Uneasy Border: Honduran-Nicaraguan Incidents
NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for 1986 and 1987 have been restated to reflect the disallowance of certain tax deductions as a result of a retroactive amendment to the income tax act of Canada.

title: Editor Joins Revlon Unit
description: Andrea Robinson, beauty editor of Vogue magazine for eight years, has resigned to become president of Ultima II, a division of Revlon Inc. Ultima II markets cosmetics treatment products and fragrances. Ms. Robinson will report to Robert A. Neilson, chairman and president of Revlon's fashion and designer group.

title: Reform Era Beefed Up Board of Estimate
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Dioxin Caused No Increase In Defects at Birth
description: An accident in 1976 in Italy that exposed the largest population ever to the chemical byproduct dioxin caused no increase in birth defects, scientists have reported.

title: Interest in Koppers
description: The Koppers Company, the building products concern that has rejected a $1.27 billion bid from Beazer P.L.C. of Britain, said others were interested in buying all or part of it. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Koppers said it had held no talks with the third parties, but might do so. It did not identify them. As previously reported, Koppers is considering several alternatives to Beazer's $45-a-share bid, including a restructuring or recapitalization. Beazer said today that it had asked for a chance to bid on Koppers's construction materials business if Koppers considers selling it.

title: Lectures in Gaelic
description: An afternoon of Irish language and song is planned tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the American Irish Historical Society, 991 Fifth Avenue, at 80th Street. Two lectures, given in Gaelic, will cover the topics ''The Short Story'' and ''An Analysis of Irish Government Attempts to Develop an International Financial Services Center in Dublin''; English translations will be available. Also featured will be a performance of traditional Irish songs by Rita Ni Fhlatharta, a resident of the Aran Islands. The event is sponsored by An Scoil Ghaelige (The Irish School). Admission is $10. Information: 288-2263.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sports People; Visa for King
description: A Japanese Foreign Ministry official who did not wish to be identified said yesterday in Tokyo that her ministry ''is preparing to issue a visa for Don King as soon as possible.''

title: Advertising; Winston Network
description: The new owners of the Winston Network Inc., the country's largest out-of-home media company, have changed its name to AMNI, derived from the American Out-of-Home Media Network. It has also had several promotions announced by Craig P. Heard, its president. They include four executive vice presidents: Berton Miller, Angelo Schifano, Donald Allman and Robert G. Neuberger.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in November.

title: Gas Tanker Attacked in Gulf
description: A Japanese-owned gas tanker was attacked today in the Persian Gulf off the United Arab Emirates, shipping authorities said.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 421 money market mutual funds decreased $492.9 million, to $279.53 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 113 institutional funds decreased $2.06 billion, to $80.11 billion. Assets of the 210 general purpose funds were up $541.7 million, to $82.02 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds increased $1.02 billion, to $117.4 billion.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
HOUSE PANEL BACKS $1 TRILLION BUDGET
description: The House Budget Committee today approved a $1.1 trillion Federal budget for the fiscal year 1989 that generally follows the budget accord reached with President Reagan but raised some of his domestic spending proposals while reducing others.

title:
About Real Estate;
New Luxury Tower Joins Manhattan Rental Market
description: LEAD: Among the Manhattan spires that Sheldon H. Solow can survey from his 45th-floor office on 57th Street are two dark residential towers - one at 265 East 66th Street that he completed in 1977, the other at 73d Street and the East River that is in the final stages of construction.

title: Correction: Ulster Trials
description: An editorial yesterday said incorrectly that there were no criminal prosecutions of Ulster policemen who killed six suspects in 1982. Four constables were tried and acquitted. On Jan. 25, Britain ruled out further prosecutions despite evidence of a conspiracy to obstruct justice.

title: Democrats Question Motive For Deploying U.S. Troops
description: Congressional Democrats today challenged President Reagan's motives for sending additional American troops to Honduras, calling the move a rash response that might jeopardize the prospects for peace in Central America.

title: KEY RATES
Ms. Magazine Is Changing Hands Again
description: Ms. magazine, which has been more successful as a philosophical statement than as a commercial venture, is changing hands for the second time in six months. A group of executives is negotiating to buy Ms. and another publication, Sassy, from the Australian publishing concern that purchased Ms. in September.

title: The Vote in Illinois
Quotation of the Day
description: ''They're not near where the fighting is taking place. But they're designed to say to the Government of Honduras that, 'We are your friend and we stand with you, and if you are invaded, you can count on the United States.' '' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ A1:2. ]

title: Study Warns of Inadequate Housing
description: The number of Americans who cannot afford adequate housing has risen sharply in the 1980's, a Harvard University study released today concluded.

title: HUMANLIKE DEFECT IS CREATED IN MICE BY USING FAULTY GENE
description: Scientists say they have created the equivalent of an inherited human disease in laboratory mice by giving mouse embryos deliberately defective genes.

title: Review/Dance; Ariel Herrera, Who Falls Upward
description: Ariel S. Herrera stood out last year in a showcase series for new choreographers, and ''Fish on Friday,'' the 40-minute work he presented Wednesday night, confirms that he is a young talent to be followed.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Spirit of Glasnost
description: In the spirit of glasnost, many Americans welcome the idea of open relations with the Soviet Union - if the Russians match their words with deeds, according to a survey of 76,000 people in five cities.

title: LVI GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax loss carryforwards of $325,000 for the quarter and $1,488,000 for the year, and losses on the early extinguishment of debt of $1,000 and $188,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After tax loss carryforwards of $492,000 for the quarter and $1,241,000 for the year, and losses on the early extinguishment of debt of $135,000 and $533,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Dining Out Guide: Great Hamburgers
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMSTERDAM'S GRAND, 454 Broadway, at Grand Street (925-6166) - * (Nov. 1, 1985) The open rotisserie grill, across from the long bar of this two-tier SoHo establishment, is faced in crisp black and white ceramic tile. A good hamburger dressed with a caper-mustard sauce is produced from the charcoal grill, accompanied by traditional french fried potatoes. Rotisserie-broiled chicken and duck are available for poultry fans. Prices: $5.95 to $10.95 at lunch, $7.95 to $15.95 at dinner. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Friday, noon to 5 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. Dinner: 5 P.M. to midnight Friday and Saturday, to 11 P.M. Sunday. ELEPHANT & CASTLE, 68 Greenwich Avenue, near Seventh Avenue (243-1400) and 183 Prince Street, between Thompson and Sullivan Streets (260-3600)- ** (Feb. 1, 1980) The original Greenwich Village location is a sliver of a restaurant finished in dark varnished wood paneling; the SoHo outpost is more romantic. Both have a congenial cafe atmosphere and serve above-average grilled hamburgers on hard rolls. Slender shoestring potatoes can be ordered as a side dish. The ultimate presentation on the list of hamburger varieties is the Elephantburger, which is served with curried sour cream, scallions, cheddar cheese and bacon. Both branches also have an extensive assortment of omelets. Hamburgers from $4.75 to $7.25. Hours: 8:30 A.M. to 1 A.M. Friday, 10 A.M. to 1 A.M. Saturday, 11 A.M. to midnight Sunday. MANHATTAN ISLAND, 482 West 43d Street (967-0533) - * (Sept. 11, 1987) Climb three flights, past exercise enthusiasts of the Manhattan Plaza Health Club, to the glass-enclosed dining rooms evoking tropical decor. From the charcoal grill, you can have a hamburger served on toasted peasant bread, accompanied by spicy onions and jalapeno potato salad. Other options include shrimp and pasta with fresh tomato salsa, or sausage bread. Prices: $6.50 to $19 at lunch and dinner. Hours: noon to 9:30 P.M. Friday and Sunday, to 11 P.M. Saturday. SAM'S RESTAURANT, 152 West 52d Street (582-8700) - * (Dec. 18, 1987) A bronze sculpture of a bison over the circular bar commands attention in the high-ceilinged, handsome room with a Western theme and casually elegant atmosphere. The hefty hamburger, among the best in town, is grilled over charcoal and paired with excellent shoestring potatoes. Recommended, too, are crab cakes and blue-cheese-and-onion pizza. Leave room for yam cinnamon custard. Prices: $9.50 to $18 at lunch, $12.50 to $23 at dinner. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. What the stars mean, page C22.

title: Economic Scene; The Merger Rise: How Beneficial?
description: CORPORATE America is becoming the acquisitive society par excellence, with everybody trying to acquire everybody else. The current merger wave, briefly slowed by the shock of the stock market plunge on Oct. 19, is again climbing to record heights. In just the first two months of this year, deals totaling nearly $50 billion were consummated - one-third more than in the corresponding period last year and double the value of deals in the first two months of 1986. A billion-dollar deal is scarcely news any more, but a dozen deals begin to add up to real money.

title: Advertising; Campaign to Begin For Contact Lenses
description: Now that consumer advertising has started in Florida and is about to start in California for Johnson & Johnson's Acuvue disposable contact lenses, Lintas: New York is letting it be known that it is the agency.

title: East Regional; Indiana Returns as a Threat
description: From the upper reaches of the Civic Center Coliseum, where the basketball players looked like specks on the court, a youngster peered at the Georgia Tech team practicing today and nudged his father. ''Are those the Celtics?'' he wanted to know.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a loss of $71,000 for the quarter and a gain of $95,946,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, an extraordinary charge of $529,000 and an extraordinary gain of $42,988,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the quarter also included an after-tax gain of $2,324,000 from retirement of debt, and the year included a charge, to cover all costs and liabililies relating to certain PVC- backed carpeting produced by the company's Collins & Aikman unit, of $11.2 million after tax benefit of $8.8 million; the year also included an after-tax gain of $4,548,000 from retirement of debt. c-Net loss and after a gain of $3,638,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $6.9 million. d-After a gain of $25,493,000 and an extraordinary gain of $9,861,000. The year-ago periods' nets from continuing operations included after- tax gains on the sale of securities of $2 million for the quarter and $19.7 million for the year. Wickes said results of Grace Home Centers West, acquired June 30, 1986, and Collins & Aikman Corp., acquired Dec. 9, 1986, have been included from the effective dates of acquisition. The share earnings for all periods reflect a 1-for-5 reverse stock split effective August 1987. The prior quarter and year results are restated to reflect the divestiture of the company's lumber and building materials businesses; its apparel and hosiery businesses; several units of its Simmons Universal subsidiary, as well as certain other smaller operations.

title: 3 Mystery Books Offer Crimes High and Low
description: The Black House By Patricia Highsmith. 258 pages. Penzler Books. $15.95. Murders & Acquisitions By Haughton Murphy. 251 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95. A Masculine Ending By Joan Smith. 186 pages. Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: Co-pilot in Crash Killing Nine Had Record of Alcohol Abuse
description: The co-pilot of a commuter airliner that crashed near Durango, Colo., on Jan. 19 had been convicted at least twice of drunken driving but had been ''doing a good job'' of abstaining in recent years as a member of Alcoholics Anonymous, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Tepid Times for Gorbachev In a Thriving Yugoslav City
description: Franc Sifkovic, the general manager of the Iskra Electronic Company here, told Mikhail S. Gorbachev today how he was being affected by perestroika, the Soviet economic restructuring.

title: Review/Film; 'D.O.A.,' Racing Death
description: ''You just gave up, Dex,'' his estranged wife tells him. ''I just quit,'' Dex tells his new girlfriend. And in case she didn't get it the first time, he explains it to her later: ''I've been dead for four years now. I forgot to appreciate life.''

title: U.S. Says Saudis Are Buying Missiles From China
description: Saudi Arabia is buying Chinese-made intermediate-range missiles, capable of hitting targets across much of the Middle East, the State Department said today. The missiles are similar to ones in the arsenal of Iran.

title: A.T.& T. Purchase
