description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had made its first acquisition of a satellite communications company with the purchase of the Tridom Corporation. The three-year-old Tridom provides satellite-based networks that distribute data from a central office to numerous branch offices simultaneously. Its customers include Days Inns and Prudential-Bache Securities. The price was not disclosed, but analysts estimated the deal was worth $25 million to $50 million. Although A.T.& T. has marketed its own satellite-based data communications system, the company has only five customers nationwide that have about 200 points receiving data. Tridom has more than 800 installed receiving points and seven customers.

title: Another Quick Exit for Fordham
description: Fordham tonight continued what has become a wrenching basketball tradition. In the school's 13th National Invitation Tournament appearance, the team lost in the first round for the 11th time, 69-61, to Houston.

title: Hauling Costs Soaring, Jerseyans Turn to Dumping Trash Illegally
description: Evidence of New Jersey's growing garbage problems is all too obvious here.

title: Bridgestone In Deal for Firestone
description: In a stunning move intended to shut out the unsolicited intentions of Pirelli S.p.A., the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company agreed last night to be acquired by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan for $80 a share, or $2.6 billion.

title: The Deaf Are Heard
description: At first, nobody listened. Students at Gallaudet University, the nation's only college for the deaf, said the new president should be someone hearing-impaired. The trustees passed over two deaf finalists and picked Elisabeth Ann Zinser, an educator of unquestioned ability who, in the students' eyes, was doubly handicapped: her hearing is fine and she doesn't know sign language.

title: The Village Lives
description: A new movie, ''The House on Carroll Street,'' is set in the Greenwich Village of 1951 - and much of it was photographed in the Greenwich Village of 1987. At the moment it's playing in Greenwich Village as well. And judging by comments overheard at a recent showing, the audience wasn't there only to follow the plot.

title: Plane With 137 Aboard Crashes In Mountainous Part of Colombia
description: A Colombian Avianca airliner with 137 people on board crashed today minutes after taking off on a domestic flight from the northeastern town of Cucuta near the Venezuelan border, the airline reported. Officials said there was no immediate sign of survivors but at least one report said there were survivors.

title: LaRouche Lawyers Introduce Three Kissinger-F.B.I. Letters
description: Lawyers for Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. introduced today three letters between Henry A. Kissinger and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and said they were evidence of a Government effort to harass Mr. LaRouche.

title: Pillsbury's Pizza Unit To Be Sold
description: Seeking to fend off a possible takeover, the Pillsbury Company announced several restructuring moves late today, including plans to sell its Godfather's Pizza chain.

title: INSIDE
description: Clampdown in Panama

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: The revenue for fiscal 1987 and the first 9 months of fiscal 1988 is restated to include previously unconsolidated finance subsidiaries in accordance with FASB Statement No. 94.

title: Ruling Is Issued Against Shaving Convict's Beard
description: New York State prison authorities were barred yesterday from shaving the beard of an Orthodox Jewish inmate by a state judge in Brooklyn.

title: At The Movies
description: The Music to Watch By Robert Redford, whose ''Milagro Beanfield War'' opens today (review on page C17), is to be on hand Tuesday night at Royce Hall on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles when his Sundance Institute, in conjunction with Ascap and B.M.I., holds a star-studded event to raise funds for its effort to preserve and foster motion-picture music.

title: Wedtech Official Points To Meese Role in Loan
description: A former lawyer for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a Wedtech executive that in 1983 Mr. Meese called another Government official in an effort to speed up a loan for the South Bronx military contractor, the Wedtech executive testified yesterday.

title: Mecham Says He Told Police Not to Help Inquiry
description: Gov. Evan Mecham charged today that his impeachment trial here was a ''miscarriage of justice,'' but acknowledged ordering the state police not to cooperate with an investigation into an alleged death threat.

title: British Cut Interest Rates To Halt Advance by Pound
description: The British Government cut interest rates today to halt the surge in the value of the pound, yielding to warnings from British companies and some Government officials that the currency's continuing advance was threatening to dent the nation's exports.

title: Blame Royalty Rates, Not Digital Audio Tape
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bear Stearns & Co. said it had raised its stake in IU International Corp. to 7.41 percent.

title: Clark Is Sidelined for 3 Weeks
description: Jack Clark had not hit a home run for the Yankees, so when he finally did against the Baltimore Orioles today, his teammates thought that maybe his slowest-motion trot round the bases was his normal home-run gait.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 More than 3,000 G.I.'s began arriving at a Honduran air base as a show of support for the Honduran Government after 10 days of border clashes between Honduran and Nicaraguan forces. Page A1 Democratic legislators challenged President Reagan's sending 3,200 more G.I.'s to Honduras because of a Nicaraguan border raid. Congressional reaction largely reflected partisan lines. A8 News analysis: Many lawmakers are concerned that President Reagan's dispatch of troops is an overreaction. The Administration says the Americans will keep far away from any battle zone. A1 News analysis: The border between Honduras and Nicaragua is highly volatile. Honduran jets bombed Government positions inside Nicaragua and heavy fighting reportedly continued inside Honduras. A8 Panama's leadership militarized public utilities in an effort to restore order after widespread protests. Strikes by utility workers had cut off electricity and water and had blocked roads. A9 Six South African blacks won a one-month stay of execution 15 hours be fore they were due to be hanged. The unexpected court ruling followed an intense international campaign for clemency. A1 Moscow will withdraw its troops from Afghanistan independently, even if the negotiators in Geneva fail to agree on conditions for ending the eight-year conflict, a Kremlin spokesman said. A12 Seoul is preoccupied with security six months in advance of the Summer Olympic Games. The streets are awash in plainclothes police officers, standing unsmiling on corners and in underground passageways. A1 Carlucci says Moscow talks built ''bridge'' A3 National A14-20, D22 Aid for a big Texas banking concern is set. Federal regulators pledged to provide $1 billion in cash for subsidiaries of the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas in an effort to halt widespread withdrawals. A1 The trade deficit widened slightly in January, to $12.4 billion, but showed significant improvement with major trading partners such as Japan and Western Europe, the Commerce Department said. A1 Stock prices spurted and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 21.72 points, to close at 2,086.04, its highest mark since the Oct. 19 selloff. D1 Firestone sought to block a bid for acquisition by Pirelli S.P.A., the Italian manufacturer, by announcing that its board had agreed to be acquired by Bridgestone of Japan for $80 a share, or $2.6 billion. D1 Pillsbury sought to block a possible takeover and bolster its sagging profits by announcing major restructuring efforts, including a plan to sell its Godfather's Pizza chain. D1 Japanese buying of Hawaii property is much more common than anywhere else in this country. A broker said Japanese multimillion-dollar buying in Honolulu's affuent residential areas was frenzied. A1 Americans unable to buy or rent adequate and affordable housing have grown sharply in the 1980's, a Harvard study found. It said ''America is increasingly becoming a nation of housing haves and have-nots.'' A14 Two uncommon types of cancer are striking elderly white Americans in unexpectedly increasing numbers, a new study showed. They are brain cancer and multiple myeloma, which can painfully destroy bone. A14 A Geneva lawyer has won immunity in exchange for cooperating with the special prosecutor in making a case against two arms dealers in the Iran-contra affair, people familiar with the inquiry said. A16 Topeka journal: A club where intellect is challenged A14 Arizona Governor says he told police not to aid inquiry A15 Veterans cheat on pension benefits, G.A.O. says A18 Politics D22 Voting law flaws worry members of the Federal Election Commission. One member said it was ''very unfortunate'' that ''our past actions have let candidates do just about what they want.'' D22 Four Democrats clash with Dole on troop move D22 Two U.S. Senators back Dukakis D22 Poll finds Simon and Dukakis voters cool on Jackson D22 Statehood question looms large in Puerto Rican vote D22 Washington Talk A16 Taking plunge from White House post to Congress Regional B1-4, B6 Jersey's growing garbage woes are evident on downtown streets, where shopkeepers find their trash bins brimming with household refuse dumped there overnight by residents. The state is pressing six northern counties to build incinerators. A1 The Chambers murder trial jury has begun deliberating after 11 weeks of testimony, 8 hours of closing arguments and 90 minutes of final legal instructions by the judge. The panel is sequestered. B1 The CUNY Law School faculty sued the university's Chancellor in a dispute over a denial of tenure to two faculty members who were influential in developing the school's unorthodox curriculum. B3 Edwin Meese 3d's ex-lawyer told a Wedtech executive that the Attorney General called another Government official in 1983 to speed up a loan for the South Bronx military contractor, the executive testified. B2 Criminal assertions that Lilco lied repeatedly to regulatory panels and filed false documents with them have been under inquiry for four months by United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani, two Long Island officials said. B1 CUNY sets up campus schools with Board of Education B1 Orthodox Jewish inmate may keep beard, judge rules B2 Three die in Jersey blast B2 Koch administration rejects an ex-adviser for civic posts B3 Panels weighs legal aspects of keeping estimate board B3 Voluntary hospitals to add beds to ease crowding B3 Ready-to-wear by Lacroix B24

title: ALESSANDRA MARC SINGS VERDI AND BRAHMS
description: There were glimpses of a Verdi soprano when Alessandra Marc sang ''Pace, pace mio Dio'' at Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night. They highlighted (more so than the absurd spotlight that followed her around the stage all evening) a voice of easy power and ringing timbre.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
LEWIS, PALMER G. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The company said the figures include Western American Forest Products Inc.'s results from its acquisition on July 1, 1986.

title: The California Initiative
description: To the Editor:

title: Sagan Is Charged in Paris
description: Francoise Sagan, who became famous at 18 for her novel ''Bonjour Tristesse,'' was indicted today for using and transporting cocaine in Lyons. Miss Sagan, a friend of President Francois Mitterrand, said the charge was politically motivated. The writer, 52 years old and the author of 19 novels and a few film scripts, was among 30 people charged.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 54.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Henley Drops Its Santa Fe Bid
description: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it was dropping its threatened proxy fight for control of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange

title: FIRST BANCSHARES OF TEXAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan's Latin Tar Baby
description: Fittingly, President Reagan sent American troops south to threaten Nicaragua on the same day Hakim, North, Poindexter and Secord were indicted for their efforts to finance the overthrow of the Nicaraguan Government.

title: On Mideast Peace, a Convergence of Candidates' Views
description: The candidates for the Presidency disagree on a number of issues, but on one thing most concur: they are in favor of peace in the Middle East. And, at least among the Democrats, they think the Reagan Administration has waited too long to do something about trying to achieve it.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., an independent natural resources company, said independent judges of shareholder votes in the consent solicitations started by Blasius Industries found that none of the Blasius proposals had received the consent of a majority of Atlas shareholders. Blasius is challenging the results in Delaware Chancery Court.

title:
Patents;
A Method to Form A Blood Substitute
description: LEAD: A method of mixing chemicals to form a blood substitute was patented this week for the Air Force. Patent 4,730,936 was granted to Philip S. Thorjusen Jr., a medical laboratory technician at Keesler Air Force Base in Mississippi.

title: A Puzzle at Border: Why the Pullback?
description: Nicaraguan troops appear to be beginning to withdraw from Honduras even though they probably could have won an even more significant victory if they had destroyed contra positions inside Honduras, senior American officials said today.

title: For Firestone Workers, Some Soothing Words
description: One day after agreeing to buy the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for $2.6 billion, top executives of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan came here to soothe the fears of workers and to underscore that they were interested in operating the American tire maker as an independent unit.

title: Taxpayer Rights Bill Advances in the Senate
description: Despite protests from the Internal Revenue Service, the Senate Finance Committee approved a ''Taxpayer Bill of Rights'' today that would give people greater protection in disputes with the I.R.S.

title: 26 Clubs for Rugby Event
description: Twenty-six rugby clubs will converge, regardless of the weather, on Downing Stadium at Randalls Island today to compete in the first Big Apple Rugby Challenge. The all-amateur tournament features entrants from local colleges and high schools, and an exhibition for players over 45 years old.

title: IDB COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
Instrument Speeds Tests On Tissue
description: LEAD: A pathologist at Pennsylvania State University's medical center in Hershey, Pa., has invented an instrument that can run simultaneous tests on 60 human tissue specimens. Stained slides are produced for diagnostic examination in much less time than manual methods currently used.

title: David Klein; Limousine Operator, 42
description: David Klein, founder of Dav-El Livery, died Wednesday in Miami. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Lost $8 Million Recovered After Arrest of 4 in Brazil
description: Almost $8 million in crisp new $100 dollar bills that disappeared six weeks ago on a flight from New York City to Buenos Aires was recovered yesterday from a small group of Brazilian thieves who apparently took it in the belief that they were stealing music cassettes.

title: STROKES IN WOMEN LINKED TO SMOKING
description: Women who smoke half a pack of cigarettes a day are twice as likely to have a stroke as women who have never smoked and those who smoke two packs a day have six times as likely, researchers say.

title: KEY RATES
Exemption for Golfer
description: A golfer who failed to qualify for a tournament after interrupting her round to revive a child who fell into a swimming pool will be allowed to enter the tournament, the Ladies Professional Golf Association announced yesterday.

title: 6 Convicted of Cocaine Smuggling
description: A former passenger agent for Pan American World Airways, accused by the Government of being the ''granddaddy'' of a drug smuggling operation, was convicted today of bringing tons of cocaine into the country over an eight-year period.

title: Correction
description: An article on Thursday about Washington's reaction to events in Panama rendered a word incorrectly in quoting Leon Kellner, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, on the case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. He said, ''I have been informed by the Department of Justice that they support the position that this man should ultimately be extradited.''

title: NORTH-WEST TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter is after a charge equal to 38 cents a share from an early retirement program, increased depreciation expense and a change in accounting.

title: Coping: With Storing Winter Clothes
description: The ritual of storing winter wear is about to begin and, as uninspiring as the job may be, the time and trouble can pay off, experts say. Cleaning and covering cold-weather clothes, storing them in cool, dry places and protecting them from household pests will extend their life. Neglect will show up as holes, stains, fading, mildew and misshapen garments.

title: Decker Raises Standard Bid
description: Unwilling to abandon its effort to acquire American Standard Inc., the Black & Decker Corporation today raised its bid to $77 a share, or about $2.5 billion, from $73 a share, or $2.3 billion.

title: Review/Dance; Plisetskaya, 62, Makes It Look Easy
description: With the arrival of Maya Plisetskaya, ''Making Music Together,'' Boston's Soviet-American festival, turns a historic introduction to contemporary Soviet music and dance into a family affair.

title: STRESS IS THE NAME, AND MANAGEMENT OF IT IS THE GAME
description: Most Americans see stress as a torturous byproduct of life in a high-speed society. But there is a growing group of entrepreneurs who are enthralled by stress, who cannot get enough of it and who are making it the latest catchword to sweep the country's vibrant self-help industry.

title: RAYTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Included a tax credit of $38,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,423,000 for the year. c-Included a tax credit of $534,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,662,000 for the year. The company said fourth-quarter net declined because of a gain of $1.6 million from the sale of undeveloped land during the fourth quarter of 1986.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss The latest third quarter share earnings is anti-dilutive after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Golden Nugget Wins $29 Million Judgment
description: The developer of the financially pressed Dunes Casino Hotel project has been ordered to pay $29 million to Golden Nugget Inc. for failing to pay for a parking lot.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Steve Lacy and Band
description: Steve Lacy, a soprano saxophonist, is leading a sextet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Rhode Island Set to Run With Syracuse
description: By now the role is familiar, despite a 27-6 record that is the best in the school's 80-year basketball history. ''We've been underdogs throughout the whole year, no matter where we went,'' said Carlton Owens, the Rhode Island guard. ''People look at the name Rhode Island, they feel there's no ballplayers there.''

title: ROADWAY MOTOR PLAZAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Judge Stalls Inquiry Into a Mercy-Killing Case
description: A judge today dismissed a grand jury subpoena demanding the name of a doctor who wrote an anonymous account of the killing of a cancer patient in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Review/Music; From Finland, Conductor With Youthful Verve
description: There are those who feel that young conductors should be apprenticed in obscure European opera houses, neither seen nor heard until they are old enough to sidestep qualms about maturity. Esa-Pekka Salonen, a Finnish conductor who is not yet 30 years old, has been making some flashy recordings for CBS these last few years, and while one might argue that he does not always reach the depths of the broad late-Romantic works that attract him, his interpretations are usually thoughtfully conceived and persuasively executed.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: Bell Back in Lineup
description: George Bell returned to the Toronto Blue Jays' lineup yesterday, one day after being suspended for refusing to play, in an ongoing dispute over his becoming the team's designated hitter.

title: MAGELLAN PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $22,724 for the quarter and $67,316 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $98,338 for the quarter and $193,193 for the 9 months. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Review/Film; When a Shark Joins the Usual Academy Gang
description: If you've seen any of the previous ''Police Academy'' movies, there are just a few things to say about ''Police Academy 5: Assignment Miami Beach'' that you don't already know.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a trial involving the Wedtech Corporation described Howard Squadron incorrectly. He is a Democrat.

title: DIVI HOTELS N V reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $537,450 on the extinguishment of debt.

title: OFFICELAND INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After a $162,644 writeoff which consists of expenses related to a potential acquisition that was not completed and to the startup of a new business venture, now discontinued. The company said certain 1986 figures have been restated to conform with classifications used in the latest year. Results for the latest year were translated into U.S. dollars at the rate of $1.31 Canadian to each U.S. $1.00. The exchange rate used for the prior year was $1.38 Canadian for each U.S. dollar.

title: About New York; Simulated Baby: The Videotape For 80's Parents
description: Babies are everywhere. Ain't it grand?

title: Builders Offer Plan to Shelter 5,000 Homeless
description: New York City's real-estate industry is drafting a plan to provide apartments to 5,000 homeless families over the next five years by renovating more than 200 privately owned vacant buildings.

title: Spread of Ballistic Missiles Troubles U.S.
description: A newly disclosed purchase of Chinese medium-range missiles by Saudi Arabia is the latest example of a troubling proliferation of ballistic missiles among the world's lesser military powers, Government officials and military analysts said today.

title: STOCKER & YALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Patents;
Vocal Sounds Improved In Voice Messaging
description: LEAD: In voice messaging systems, the voice is coded for transmission or storage and can be decoded later. An improved system, patented this week for Texas Instruments Inc. in Dallas, is directed at avoiding reproduction of vocal sounds with erroneous, squeaky, cracking, coarse or grating qualities. Sounds that seem to be whispered rather than spoken are also avoided.

title: Irving Jonathan Estrin; Doctor, 72
description: Irving Jonathan Estrin, a retired doctor who specialized in physical rehabilitation, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 72 years old.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Plant Dismisses 4 Workers
description: Four employees at the Peach Bottom nuclear plant were dismissed and seven others suspended with intent to dismiss Thursday because of drug involvement, the Philadelphia Electric Company said. The plant, in south-central Pennsylvania about 90 miles west of Philadelphia, has been closed for the past year under order of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission because control room operators were sleeping on the job.

title: INSIDE
description: Guarantee for Savings Unit

title: 4.4% Growth in Britain
description: Consumer spending helped Britain's gross domestic product grow by 4.4 percent last year, according to Government figures released today. Consumer spending grew by slightly more than 5 percent in 1987 compared with 6 percent in 1986, the figures showed. Officials said Britain's economy had not been so buoyant since gross domestic product grew 7.25 percent in 1973.

title: Divestment Plan Is Rejected
description: University of Colorado regents voted Thursday not to divest a $300,000 investment in a company doing business in South Africa. Pauline Coker, a spokeswoman for the university, said its only investment in a company doing business with South Africa is slightly more than $300,000 in Caterpillar Inc. bonds that mature in 1992.

title: Soviet Gives Security Vow as Yugoslav Visit Ends
description: The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia issued a formal document today pledging to respect the ''equal rights and equal security'' of all states regardless of their power or political structure.

title: Kaiser Steel Plans A Reorganization
description: Thirteen months after seeking protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code, the Kaiser Steel Corporation, once the nation's ninth-largest steelmaker, said it had filed a reorganization plan.

title: 6 Top Ad Agency Officers Secede
description: Angered by their loss of autonomy, six top executives yesterday walked out of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency, a subsidiary of the WPP Group, to set up their own shop.

title: Some Things That Drive Bus Riders to Fume
description: To the Editor:

title: AL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter includes the results of Barre-National Inc., acquired on Oct. 30, 1987. Year-ago fourth quarter and prior year include a $1.8 million reserve established for doubtful accounts receivable related to the company's international pharmaceutical business.

title: Secord Files $38 Million Suit In Book Dispute About Role
description: Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, a leading figure in the Iran-contra affair, has filed a $38 million suit against the author, publisher, editor and distributor of the book ''Out of Control: The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua, the Illegal Arms Pipeline, and the Contra Drug Connection,'' by Leslie Cockburn.

title: Schools in Key Games
description: St. Nicholas of Tolentine, which beat Archbishop Molloy, 70-65, for the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association city championship last Saturday, could have three more key games before closing its season.

title: Stray Bullet Kills Woman In the Bronx
description: Vernia Brown, who was 19 years old, is listed in the police homicide report as ''innocent bystander.''

title: Raise the Minimum Wage and Workers' Hopes
description: LEAD: Imagine working 40 hours a week, yet failing to get out of poverty.More than two million

title: Despairing Indians Looking to Tradition To Combat Suicides
description: Following the ghost of his younger brother, 25-year-old William Wainanwit drank himself into a stupor one day last month and then went out behind the family trailer and hanged himself.

title: Ward's Version Of Abuse Amended
description: The Police Department has corrected Commissioner Benjamin Ward's account of how they became aware of child abuse in the case of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg.

title: MAIONE-HIRSCHBERG reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Takeover Fever Cools on Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company's announcement of a larger-than-expected quarterly loss and its plans to sell its Godfather's pizza chain ended a two-day run-up in its stock price that was spurred by takeover speculation. But analysts said today that the company remained vulnerable. ''I don't think anything has really changed,'' said Craig Carver of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis.

title: For Visitors on the Wing
description: Robins are back and they will soon be joined by blackbirds, towhees, warblers and thrushes. Each day through May birds will arrive. Those already here are mating and will soon start to build nests and raise young. All this because spring will arrive tomorrow at 4:39 A.M.

title: Campaign Trail
description: Campaign Respite

title: KINGS ROAD ENTERTAINMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Edward Villella Is Back for a Visit
description: Edward Villella is a happy man. The former New York City Ballet star, now living with his family in Florida, has returned to New York with the Miami City Ballet, which he directs. The company, which presented its first performance in October, makes its New York debut tonight at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. And it is a company he is proud of. The troupe has 27 sleek young dancers, led by Yanis Pikieris, a gold medalist at the 1981 Moscow International Ballet Competition. In the year and a half since the company began rehearsals, it has become a unit, Mr. Villella said in a recent conversation. ''We're almost speaking the same language,'' he said. ''We're not quite there, but almost.''

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company attributed the sales increase to the contribution of FEI Microwave Inc., acquired in August.

title: Champion Knocked Out: Richmond Stuns Indiana
description: Keith Smart pulled up in the key, squared his shoulders and took a jump shot that probably only a handful of fans in the Civic Center Coliseum doubted would go in. It's that way when a team like Indiana is involved in a close game, especially playing against a school that still has an identity crisis. No one had to remind Richmond that it was expected to lose today, or that the last time Smart had an important shot like this it resulted in a national championship for Indiana.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $530,000 from an accounting change.

title: Gain in Dow Is Cut to 1.33 After Plunge in Bond Prices
description: LEAD: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a seesaw session marked by index-arbitrage-related program trading, a ''triple witching hour'' and heavy volume.

title: Roland Drew; Actor, 87
description: Roland Drew, an actor who quit Hollywood in the 1940's for a career in dressmaking, died Thursday at his home. He was 87 years old.

title: Jersey Rates Its Workfare Experiment a Limited Success
description: Six months into its trial, the state's program to train welfare recipients and start them working is struggling with the limits and delays of the welfare system.

title: Review/Jazz; A Sunny Murray Lesson In Free-Style Drumming
description: Sunny Murray, who emancipated jazz drumming from the beat in the 1960's, showed the discipline that free drumming takes when he brought a quintet to the Knitting Factory on Wednesday. Mr. Murray rarely chooses to play a steady beat or a repeated lick, but his rumbles and accents, his thumps and flourishes, carried the music forward unswervingly. His drumming supplies a realistic pulse - one that, like the human pulse, fluctuates with every outside stimulus - while it underlines and comments on the sounds of the soloists.

title: Strickland Tries to Have Fun
description: His face is so self-assuredly dispassionate, his style on a basketball floor so coolly efficient, that Rod Strickland of DePaul has been asked more than once if he enjoys playing this game.

title: Sabine Rejects Bid From Presidio Oil
description: The board of directors of the Sabine Corporation said it had unanimously rejected a hostile tender offer of $20 a share, or $256 million, from the Presidio Oil Company and said it was in the ''preliminary stages'' of talks with third parties about transactions to ward off the unwelcome offer.

title: Seton Hall Gets Tough to Win
description: Now that Seton Hall has had a taste of its first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and its first 20-victory season in 32 years, maybe it will keep nibbling. Seton Hall finished hungry and strong today, toppling Texas-El Paso, 80-64, in West Regional play here in Pauley Pavilion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: March 19, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 28 A 'state of urgency' in Panama was declared by the Government, putting its opponents on notice that it was prepared to suspend basic constitutional guarantees in the face of continued unrest. Page 1

title: PHOTRONIC LABS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: FITZGERALD, DEARMAN & ROBRTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credits of $219,558 and $520,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. All share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Eastern Air Penalty Planned
description: The legal problems of Eastern Air Lines and its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, mounted yesterday when a Federal judge said that he would penalize Eastern on Monday for its attempts to transfer its shuttle operation to a newly formed subsidiary of Texas Air.

title: Texas Closes In on 5th Straight Title
description: Texas raced to a United States Open, American and N.C.A.A. record in the 200-yard freestyle relay, and by the end of tonight's event the Lady Longhorns were all but assured of winning their fifth swimming and diving championship.

title: From Blizzard of '88 Diary: 'People Crossed East River on Ice'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eyes of March
description: A broom handle hovers over a base-runner's head. The broom handle is held by Dave Bristol, a Philadelphia Phillies' coach, and the runner at first base, Milt Thompson, must stay crouched, as though the sky has just been lowered, else he bump his noggin. This is a spring-training lesson in base-running maneuvers.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after a gain on the termination of a pension plan of $2,614,000 for the quarter and year; the quarter also included a loss of $3,605,000 from the reversal of a tax loss carryforward. The prior year revenue included a pre-tax gain of $5,772,000 relating to Guaranty National Corp.'s public offering of common stock.

title: Review/Concert; BONDING MUSIC OF THE AMERICAS
description: The Atlantic String Quartet, under auspices of an organization called Pan American Musical Art Research Inc., played works by Julian Orbon, Mario Davidovsky and Alexander Zemlinsky at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening. The connection between the music and Pamar's avowed mission (the promotion of understanding between the cultures of the Americas) was clear enough in the first two works: Mr. Orbon was born in Spain and lived in Cuba before settling in the United States, and his Quartet (1951) draws on Cuban dance rhythms, set in a harmonically sophisticated frame. Mr. Davidovsky was born in Argentina and has long lived in New York. His mysterious, introspective Fourth Quartet (1980) is cast in a more abstruse (but never harsh) language.

title: Nets Play Tough But Hawks Win
description: What the Nets displayed tonight does not always win basketball games. But at this stage of New Jersey's season, victories are not the most important thing.

title: Islanders Battle Back for Tie
description: A brilliant performance by Kelly Hrudey in goal inspired the Islanders to recover from a three-goal deficit and gain a 3-3 tie tonight against the Washington Capitals.

title: MICRON TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: b-Net loss

title: Curbing the Urban Blues With Plants
description: Spring will bring migratory birds, forsythia and flowering trees into the lives of the nature-starved. But for some people, the spring display will simply augment the one going on inside their apartments all year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 19, 1988
description: Companies

title:
Patents;
Power Use Is Reduced In a Cordless Telephone
description: LEAD: A computer-controlled cordless telephone that offers reduced power consumption when the handset is not in use was patented this week for A.T.&T.; Information Systems of Murray Hill, N.J.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
RIVERBEND INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Griffin Sued By Trump On Resorts
description: Donald J. Trump, the real estate developer, filed a lawsuit today against Merv Griffin and also sued a dissident shareholder of Resorts International Inc., seeking to block the former talk show host's $35-a-share bid for the casino operator.

title: A War Within the Sri Lankan War
description: A brutal struggle for demographics is under way in eastern Sri Lanka, where ethnic Tamil guerrillas are slaughtering Sinhalese villagers and the Sri Lankan Army is sending the villagers back, sometimes against their wills, when they flee.

title: Writers Guild Presents 1987 Awards
description: The Writers Guild of America announced the winners of its 40th annual awards for ''outstanding achievements in writing'' for movies, television and radio during 1987. The 9,600-member guild, which went on strike against the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers on March 7, presented awards in 15 categories last night in New York and Los Angeles.

title: ROCHESTER COMMUNITY SAVNGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,260,000.

title: PRECISION TARGET MARKETING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hilton Ruiz, Pianist
description: Hilton Ruiz, a pianist, will play a solo concert at 8 o'clock tonight at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street (662-2133). Admission is free.

title: Villanova and Pitt Advance
description: Charles Smith scored 31 points today and sparked Pitt in the second half, leading the Panthers to a 108-90 victory over Eastern Michigan in the first round of the Midwest Regional.

title: Texaco Appears Close To Ending Bankruptcy
description: Texaco appeared close yesterday to clearing away the remaining major obstacles to emerging from bankruptcy.

title: Guidepost
description: Battling Bugs The approach of warm weather brings out insects, especially in kitchens. Even if your home is bug-free, insects may hitch a ride with the groceries. You can fight them with sprays, powders, traps, even ultrasound machines. But before you shop, check your shelves: you may have the products you need, and you may see what's attracting the insects. Observe basic procedures for using hazardous chemicals, and don't use any insecticide indoors that is not labeled for such use. Avoid spraying near food. One application should suffice for the season. The insecticides listed are recommended for use by nonprofessionals. PESTS REMEDIES Ants F ind and seal entry route; clean; spray with chlorpyrifos or aprocarb. Cockroaches Spray damp areas with malathion or aprocarb or use baits. Flour beetles, Discard contaminated packages; clean; flour moths store fresh supplies in resistant containers. Silverfish Attracted to protein and starch in bookbindings and clothing. Seal entry cracks. Spray with aprocarb. (Source: Cornell Cooperative Extension Bulletin No. 74)

title: Review/Music; POULENC ORGAN CONCERTO ON THE CARNEGIE PORTABLE
description: Poulenc's Concerto for Organ, Strings and Timpani is a wonderful piece, but it depends a lot on flavor and atmosphere. Carnegie Hall is the wrong place: no organ. Portable substitutes sound and look wrong. The conductor Erich Leinsdorf is not a specialist in flavor. And the hall's rather hard acoustics do not lend warmth to a lean string tone such as the Philadelphia Orchestra employed there Tuesday night with Michael Stairs as soloist. The result was that the work itself sounded rather skimpy; a disappointment.

title: Southern Mississippi Defeats Clemson
description: Derrek Hamilton scored 18 points and Randolph Keys provided a spark in the second half tonight as Southern Mississippi opened the defense of its National Invitation Tournament championship by defeating Clemson, 74-69, in a first-round game.

title: VOWS BATTLE FOR ISLAMIC STATE
description: The leader of a powerful Afghan guerrilla party and major recipient of covert American military assistance, whose aim is a ''pure'' Islamic state, consistently accuses the United States of conspiring with the Soviet Union against Afghanistan.

title: DESPITE ELECTION DISCLOSURES, ALBANY RESISTS A CRACKDOWN
description: Despite dramatic testimony this week by some of New York City's major campaign contributors, who talked of pressure from candidates and efforts to bypass the spirit of election laws, the chances are slim that the State Legislature will crack down this year on questionable campaign financing practices.

title: Honduras Says It Asked for Troops
description: United States and Honduran officials asserted today that the request for American combat troops to be sent to Honduras this week was initiated by the Honduran Government.

title: Doctor-Assisted Euthanasia Should Be Legal
description: To the Editor:

title: AMBRIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a $303,000 loss from the early extinguishment of debt. The latest year includes a $1,985,000 pretax gain on the sale of securities. Prior year includes a pretax gain of $8,068,000 on the sale of Ambrit's investment in Sheraton Securities International PLC.

title: PHILLIES RELEASE COWLEY
description: The Phillies temporarily released Joe Cowley, delaying the comeback attempt of a pitcher who less than two years ago threw a no-hitter. Manager Lee Elia said Cowley had been given his unconditional release.

title: Defect Is Linked to Heart Attack and Stroke
description: A study using ultrasonic heart scans has found that people with an enlarged left side of the heart are two to three times as likely as individuals without the defect to have a heart attack or stroke, researchers said today.

title: Review/Music; IRISH TRADITIONAL BAND
description: The Chieftains, the sextet that many regard as the foremost Irish traditional band, celebrated two anniversaries at their Avery Fisher Hall concert on Wednesday evening. One was the thousand-year anniversary of the City of Dublin, the other their own 25th anniversary year as a group. Joining them for an evening that had the merry mood of a St. Patrick's Day Eve pageant, were the Nelson Village Dancers, a New Hampshire-based contra-dance ensemble, and the dance soloist Anne-Marie Doyle.

title: CONTINENTAL GENERAL INSURANCE COMPANY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes investment gains of $758,822 and $192,896 for the latest year and year-earlier period.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Bush's Success and Long-Term Hazards
description: Vice President Bush's vast accumulation of delegates may present him with a paradox: locking up the Republican nomination with lightning speed, but potentially harming his general election bid in the process.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Graf and Sabatini Advance Easily: Steffi Graf, seeded first, and third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini closed out victories with second-set shutouts yesterday in the third round of the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Graf recovered from a slow start to beat Rosalyn Fairbank of San Diego, 7-6, 6-0. Sabatini beat Lisa Bonder of Largo, Fla., 6-2, 6-0. Zina Garrison of Houston, seeded eighth, fell to Elna Reinach of South Africa in three sets. Top-seeded Mats Wilander of Sweden beat Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 6-7, 6-4, 6-2. Tim Mayotte of Boston swept Paul Annacone of Knoxville, Tenn., and sixth-seeded Yannick Noah of France swept Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia. Ramesh Krishnan of India eliminated eighth-seeded Martin Jaite of Argentina from the hard-court tournament in four sets. (AP) Golf Azinger Up by Four: Paul Azinger, winner of three tournaments on the PGA Tour last year, shot his second straight five-under-par 66 yesterday to take a four-shot lead after two rounds of the Hertz Bay Hill Classic in Orlando, Fla. Azinger's 10-under 132 gave him the biggest lead he has ever held. Andrew Magee, who shot a 70, and David Frost, who had a 66, were tied for second at 136 after the round, which was played through intermittent rain showers. Tom Kite, who shot 68, was tied at 137 with Dave Eichelberger, who had the day's best round of 65 on the 7,103-yard, par-71 Bay Hill course. Hot Day for Geiberger: Al Geiberger shot a course-record 63 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead after the first round of the Pointe-Del E. Webb Arizona Classic PGA Seniors tournament. Geiberger's nine-under-par 63 left him three strokes ahead of Quinton Gray and Agim Bardha, who both finished six under par at 66 in Sun City West, Ariz. (AP) Walton Leads Sheehan: In Tucson, Ariz., Robin Walton fired an eight-under-par 64 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead over Patty Sheehan after two rounds of the L.P.G.A. Tucson Open. Walton, seeking her first victory in 10 years on the Tour, birdied the 15th hole to break out of a tie for the lead with Sheehan and Laura Davies and then birdied the last two holes. She finished at 11-under 133, a two-day performance that ties the 36-hole course record set by Pat Bradley in 1986 on the 6,243-yard, par-72 Randolph North layout. (AP) N.B.A. 76ers 129, Pacers 109: Charles Barkley scored 23 of his 30 points in the first half last night, leading Philadelphia to victory at home. It was the Sixers' third straight triumph and their fourth in the last five games. Indiana suffered its 11th loss in 14 outings. The victory moved the 76ers a half-game behind Washington and a half-game ahead of the Knicks in the race for the final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference.(AP) Bulls 113, Celtics 103: In Chicago last night, Michael Jordan scored 50 points, the third time this season he has reached that total, as Chicago got its first victory over the Celtics in three seasons. The Celtics, who last lost to the Bulls on Dec. 17, 1985, cut a 21-point deficit to 86-79 early in the fourth quarter, but Jordan scored 15 points and hit seven consecutive baskets during a 20-10 run that gave Chicago a 106-89 lead with 3:24 left. (AP) Horse Racing 'Derby' by a Nose: Derby Hat won a stretch duel with Creativity to reach the wire first by a nose yesterday in the $42,000 allowance feature for 4-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Derby Hat carried highweight of 122 and Nick Santagata six furlongs on the fast track in 1:10 2/5 to record his 15th victory in 64 career starts. He earned $25,200 for Bright View Farm and returned $7.40 for $2 to win as the third choice in the field of six.

title: BUSINESS WORLD AWHIRL AGAIN AS THE BIG DEALS COME BACK
description: The surprising revival of corporate takeovers since the first of the year became a bidding frenzy this week as one major American corporation after another found itself the object of competing suitors.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My attorney, Brendan Sullivan, has informed me that the defense against these charges may require him to issue subpoenas for the testimony and records of the highest-ranking officials of our Government.

title: DUKAKIS BELIEVED AHEAD IN KANSAS
description: Michael S. Dukakis was believed holding a slight edge in the Kansas Democratic Presidential caucuses Saturday, because of a campaign organization that even his rivals concede is strong.

title: CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,853,000 from an accounting change.

title: Aliens Get Extension on Amnesty Data
description: The Government said yesterday that illegal aliens seeking amnesty would be given two more months to provide documents proving that they are eligible.

title: FOR TEEN-AGERS, JOBS BUT NOT CAREERS
description: In less than an hour, Caroline McLean, a freshman at South Bronx High School, found a job, her first, as a cashier at a fast-food restaurant in midtown Manhattan. By Easter, she said, after earning enough to buy some new clothes, she will quit.

title: Southdown Sues
description: Southdown Inc., the Houston cement maker that has offered $420 million for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. of Stamford, Conn., said it had sued Moore McCormack's directors over an anti-takeover provision and a possible recapitalization. Earlier this week, Moore McCormack, which also produces cement, said it was considering a financial restructuring or recapitalization that could mean paying a substantial cash dividend to its shareholders to maximize the value of its stock and avoid being acquired by Southdown.

title: Books of The Times; New Merwin Poetry and a Collection
description: The Rain in the Trees By W. S. Merwin 78 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95. Selected Poems By W. S. Merwin 276 pages. Atheneum. $12.95. ...Here love Must wander blind or with mistaken eyes, For dissolution walks among the light And vision is the sire of vanishing.

title: Transit Officer Shoots Man Who Leapt Subway Turnstile
description: A 20-year-old Manhattan man who leapt a subway turnstile was shot and wounded by a Transit Authority police officer yesterday morning in what the authorities described as an accidental shooting.

title: Ford Cancels Plan For Scotland Plant
description: A squabble among British unions over single-union representation at factories has led the Ford Motor Company to cancel plans for an electronics plant in Scotland. Ford said the proposed $73 million plant could not compete if its workers were represented by more than one union.

title: RYMER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $152,000 and tax loss carryforwards of $303,000.

title: U.S. Aids Financial Corp. Unit
description: In an emergency move, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that it would guarantee against loss all the depositors and general creditors of the American Savings and Loan Association.

title: Barry Honored
description: Last night, the Golden State Warriors retired Rick Barry's jersey number, 24. He retired eight years ago, after playing for the Warriors in 8 of his 14 professional seasons, including 1967, when he led the National Basketball Association in scoring, and 1975, when he helped the Warriors win the league championship. Barry, who was inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 1986, is the fourth Warrior whose number has been retired. The others are Nate Thurmond (42), Al Attles (16) and Tom Meschery (14). . . . Although he made only 2 of 10 field goals from 3-point range Thursday night in a 116-115 victory over Portland, Michael Adams of the Denver Nuggets still managed to set an N.B.A. record of 24 consecutive games with at least one 3-pointer. He broke the record of 23 set earlier this season by Danny Ainge of the Boston Celtics.(AP)

title: Accord Limits Police Searches
description: The city has agreed to restrict the police in their search for a sexual-assault suspect after the Police Department was accused in an American Civil Liberties Union suit of detaining black men without cause.

title: Clean Up Your Drug Act Yourself, Mayor Koch
description: To the Editor:

title: Rolling Truck Kills A Water Worker
description: A city employee was killed yesteday when his Water Department truck ran over him.

title:
Patents;
Four to Be Inducted Into the Hall of Fame
description: LEAD: The Patent and Trademark Office announced this week that four men will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame on March 27. The ceremony will be held in Arlington, Va.

title: Clark Hasn't Lost Sense of Humor
description: Jack Clark figures that he should take advantage of his status as the player who has endured the widest assortment of disabling injuries in recent seasons.

title: Blood Is Recalled After Mix-Up
description: Blood that preliminary tests suggested might have carried the AIDS virus was mistakenly shipped to hospitals for use in transfusions last month by Red Cross centers in Washington and Nashville , a Food and Drug Administration spokesman said tonight.

title: AIDS Virus Seen Unlikely to Cause Mental Illness
description: An international conference of medical experts announced today that it had found no evidence that people infected with the AIDS virus were likely to suffer mental disturbances before suffering from the disease itself.

title: SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforwards of $447,971. c-Net loss

title: A Macho Australian Arrives on Her Cycle
description: It is easy to find soft-headed movies that pretend to be about women's roles in society, and much harder to come across a film as good as ''Shame,'' a tough-minded Australian action story with a smart, sensitive, unsettling macho heroine. In the film's first minutes a black-clothed motorcyclist rides into a small town, takes off a helmet to reveal long, strawberry blonde curls and walks into a grimy bar asking for a room and a mechanic to fix her bike. Is she a tomboy or a femme fatale? A tourist or a drifter?

title: Sleep Aid: Little Bumps in the Night
description: For years, hospital patients have slept on foam mattress pads designed to relieve pressure on the body and prevent bedsores. Now these polyurethane cushions, made of convoluted foam about two inches thick, are becoming popular with consumers seeking more restful sleep at home.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,105,000 from a change in accounting for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Day Care Series Hailed For Highlighting Issue
description: ''Day by Day,'' the new situation comedy about day care that had its premiere with much fanfare two weeks ago on NBC, is not just a success in the Nielsen ratings. It is also a hit with the nation's day-care establishment.

title: MECHAM ADVISERS PESSIMISTIC
description: Gov. Evan Mecham acknowledged today that his senior political advisers say there is little chance he can avoid conviction in the first gubernatorial impeachment trial since 1929.

title: A Family Gathering Shows Split Over Mecham Goes Deeper Than Politics
description: When Steve Benson's in-laws planned their Thanksgiving feast last year, they invited his wife and the four young Benson children. But Mr. Benson, the cartoonist for The Arizona Republic, was pointedly excluded.

title: Panel Urges Privatizing of U.S. Services
description: A bipartisan Presidential commission recommended today that the Government begin a gradual but wholesale transfer of mail delivery, air traffic control, prison operations and scores of other services to the private sector.

title: Redmen Lose a Link to Glory
description: Now that St. John's has been eliminated, the Redmen find it difficult and sad to realize that Shelton Jones has completed his college career.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,856,000 and $2,020,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss d-After tax credits of $164,000 for the quarter and $365,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter and 6-month included a charge of $2.3 million to writeoff goodwill resulting from the merger of Atlantic Metropolitan Corp. and Umet Inc. in April 1984.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for 12mo to Feb 29
Air Canada-Airbus
description: Air Canada is near agreement with Europe's Airbus Industrie to buy 34 short-haul A320 airliners and take options on 20 more in a contract worth more than 10 billion francs, or about $1.75 billion, the newspaper Le Monde said. A spokeswoman for the European consortium declined to confirm the report, but said Airbus was in talks with Air Canada as well as with other airlines. If confirmed, this would be the first purchase of Airbus planes by Air Canada.

title: Fraternity to Close After Youth's Death
description: The Rutgers University fraternity under investigation after the death of a pledge who drank himself to death will be closed for at least a year, officials said.

title: Increase Voted in Insurance for Nuclear Accident
description: The Senate approved by voice vote today a bill that would increase from $700 million to more than $7 billion the pool of insurance available for swift disbursement to victims of a major nuclear accident.

title: Paul Kohner, Hollywood Agent And Film Producer, Is Dead at 85
description: Paul Kohner, a prominent Hollywood agent, died of heart failure Wednesday at the University of California, Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 85 years old.

title: WHIRLPOOL SUES G.E. OVER ROPER
description: The Whirlpool Corporation sued the General Electric Company yesterday, charging that G.E.'s efforts to acquire the Roper Corporation interfered illegally with Whirlpool's prior merger agreement with the appliance maker.

title: Biden Undergoes Operation To Curb Danger From Clots
description: Doctors inserted a tiny filter into one of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s major veins to intercept any additional blood clots similar to one that lodged in a lung last week, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $718,423 from termination of a pension plan.

title: The Right Call on Instant Replays
description: National Football League team owners are a conservative bunch. So it was revolutionary when, two years ago, they made instant replays part of the game, a last-resort corrective for erroneous calls. This week, happily, a majority of owners rebuffed a challenge to this welcome innovation.

title: Salant Will Buy Clothing Company
description: Manhattan Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Salant Corporation, another New York clothing company, for $100 million. Manhattan agreed to the merger after Salant raised its bid to $18.50 a share of common stock. Its initial, unsolicited offer, on Feb. 2, was $16 a share.

title: Riding the No. 1 to the Sun
description: LEAD: I've had cab drivers in New York City who have recited poems they had composed or who claimed to be on their way to Hollywood with blockbuster screenplays, but today I rode with my first creative subway conductor.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a capital loss of $542,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $165,000 for the 9 months. c-Included capital gains of $2,945,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: 10 SENATORS URGE $48 MILLION IN AID FOR THE CONTRAS
description: A bipartisan group of senators introduced a $48 million package of aid for the Nicaraguan rebels today that would also permit delivery of as much as $2.5 million worth of previously authorized arms and ammunition.

title: 'Family Values' and Good Intentions
description: Governors are suddenly turning to help constituents who cannot even vote: disadvantaged children. In Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike now flock to introduce legislation that would expand child care and early education programs. And on the primary trail, ''family values'' have become a staple of campaign oratory.

title: SCIENCE ACCESSORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Reflects litigation expenses of $51,966 for the latest first quarter and $18,870 for the year-ago period.

title: Letter: On National Service; Grass-Roots Youth Corps Are Growing
description: To the Editor:

title: Alive and Well in Brooklyn
description: New York City's central business district is finally crossing the East River to downtown Brooklyn, to the benefit of all New Yorkers. Mayor Koch and Borough President Howard Golden deserve credit for leadership, sound policies, muscle and patience.

title: A CHINESE SCROLL'S MARVELS, UNFOLDED BY AN ARTIST
description: Dressed in the crisp, bright colors of his own paintings as he explores the mysteries of a 70-foot-long Chinese scroll, David Hockney effortlessly connects the past and the present, revealing himself to be a splendid art teacher in the process. In ''A Day on the Grand Canal With the Emperor of China (or Surface Is Illusion but So Is Depth),'' he delivers an extremely clear and articulate analysis of the manner in which the 17th-century scroll has been painted. Paying particular attention to ways in which the artist and his assistants used perspective, Mr. Hockney also draws comparisons with a later scroll of similar theme, in which Western influences are much more apparent. The conventional use of perspective in a Canaletto canvas provides another point of reference.

description: b-Includes a pretax gain on the sale of Atlantic City Casino-Hotel of $169,748,000. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain of $2,001,000 on debt retirements for the quarter and the year is after a loss on debt retirements of $15,902,000. title: Ex-Puerto Rican Police Agent Guilty in Slaying of 2 Radicals
description: A former police intelligence agent was found guilty early today in the murders of two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence almost 10 years ago and a former police colonel was acquitted.

title: De Benedetti Is Selling Buitoni Pasta to Nestle
description: Carlo de Benedetti agreed today to sell his Buitoni pasta company to Nestle S.A. of Switzerland for $1.27 billion.

title: Aliens Get Extension for Amnesty Proof
description: Reagan Administration officials announced today that illegal aliens seeking amnesty would be allowed two months beyond the May 4 application deadline to provide documentation.

description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to April 30 from Oct. 31. Accordingly, results for the prior-year periods did not include comparable operations.

title:
Your Money;
Keeping Records Offers Rewards
description: LEAD: Tax preparation time provides a reminder of how keeping records complete and up to date can make life easier. That is all the more true now, when the revised tax code requires many taxpayers to keep much more elaborate records.

title: Iran Reports Advances As Gulf War Widens
description: Fighting intensified in the Iran-Iraq war today, with a series of attacks in which 41 missiles were reportedly fired into cities, 5 ships were attacked, 7 planes were downed and thousands of soldiers were killed or wounded.

title: Gorbachev's Yugoslavia Trip - a Turning Point?
description: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev hopes his visit to Yugoslavia will draw Moscow closer to the nonaligned nations and will also pre-empt any planned unrest in those countries as they mark upcoming anniversaries, including the 40th anniversary of Tito's historic break with Stalin and the 20th anniversary of the

BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Iowa Takes Lead and Places 3 in Finals
description: Iowa made a strong run tonight at regaining the N.C.A.A. wrestling title it held for nine consecutive years by placing three wrestlers in Saturday's finals.

title: Zvishavane Journal; From a Gift of Earth, Many New Dreams to Till
description: Nationalist guerrillas in the bush war that transformed white-ruled Rhodesia into black-governed Zimbabwe now work the earth at a farming cooperative called Vukuzenzele, or ''Wake Up and Help Yourself.''

title: Review/Music; GIUSEPPE SINOPOLI URBANIZES BRUCKNER
description: Giuseppe Sinopoli gave us a clever Bruckner Eighth Symphony at Carnegie Hall Thursday night. Using the Philharmonia Orchestra of London, the Italian conductor has put Bruckner on a diet, the broad cushioning string sound we know so well compressed into slender, sharply penetrating shapes.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Art Blakey Jr. Is Dead, Son of Drummer, 47
description: Art Blakey Jr. a jazz drummer like his celebrated father, died of pneumonia Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Luther Swygert, 83, U.S. Appeals Judge In Celebrated Cases
description: Luther M. Swygert, a senior Federal appeals judge who handed down important decisions on issues ranging from labor relations to civil rights, died Wednesday at the Whitehall Convalescent Home in Chicago. He was 83 years old and lived in Chicago and Dune Acres, Ind.

title: ENSERCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $3,786,000 from the reacquisition of debentures. c-Includes a gain of $8,690,000 from an accounting change.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENWEST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Redskins Get Bears' Marshall
description: Wilber Marshall, the star linebacker of the Chicago Bears, today became the first National Football League player in 11 years to change teams as a free agent.

title: WESTERN UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $152,785,000 gain on the extinguishment of debt for the quarter and year. c-Net loss The year-ago quarter included asset writedowns and related charges of $362 million associated with a program to consolidate and close down redundant switching facilities used primarily to provide Western Union Telex and private wire services and $106 million related to assets associated with the Westar Satellite System. The quarter also included a $25 million gain on the sale of the corporation's interest in Airfone Inc., and a $14.7 million gain on sales of cellular telephone interests. The prior year included net from discontinued operations of $7,173,000, a $6 million gain on the disposal of discontinued operations and a $1,940,000 extraordinary loss. The extraordinary loss included $4.1 million of expenses associated with the exchange of certain notes payable, partially offset by a $2.2 million gain from the termination of a subsidiary's pension plan during the first quarter of 1986. The latest year loss from operations included $38.3 million in gains on sales of cellular interests and an $11.4 million anticipated loss on the proposed sale of the Westar Satellite System. The prior year loss from continuing operations included charges of $18.2 million from a proposed financial restructuring program, which was terminated in September 1986, and a $6.3 million writedown of the corporation's minority investment in Vitalink Communications Corp. The year also included a $15.9 million gain on sales of cellular telephone interests.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a tax credit of $26,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Billy Butterfield, 71, Big-Band Trumpeter On Shaw's 'Stardust'
description: Billy Butterfield, a trumpeter who played with the Bob Crosby, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman bands, died of cancer yesterday at his home. He was 71 years old and lived in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Israeli Soldiers Kill Another Arab
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today and wounded dozens as a wave of protests continued.

title: Right to Publish
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Has Little Punch
description: The earthquake that shook Tokyo early yesterday may have rocked skyscrapers, spilled coffee onto tabletops and knocked books off shelves, but it had little effect on Mike Tyson and Tony Tubbs.

title: Brawley Friend Arrested With 2 On Gun Charge
description: A Wappingers Falls, N.Y., youth who is a key figure in the Tawana Brawley case has been arrested on a gun possession charge in Poughkeepsie and faces another charge in a shootout last week, the Poughkeepsie police said yesterday.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $577,000. The company said the comparable figures aren't available because the company changed its fiscal year to a calendar year.

title: Salvador Ruling Party Faces Loss of Legislative Majority
description: Senior officials of President Jose Napoleon Duarte's Christian Democratic Party acknowledge a considerable decline in public support for the party and say that it will probably lose its legislative majority in elections on Sunday.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES INC reports earnings for 12mo Feb 28
An American in Japan's 'Big River'
description: It began as a lark, Ron Richardson recalls.

title: 42d Street, in Black and White (Mostly White)
description: LEAD: The decision by New York City officials and real estate developers - partners in the 42d Street Development Project - to eliminate 10 movie houses on West 42d Street provides a small but telling explanation of why 20 years ago the Kerner Commission predicted that America was ''moving toward two societies, one black, one white - separate and equal.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split in October.

title: North Quits Marines, Suggesting Subpoenas for 'Highest' Officials
description: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North announced today that he had submitted his resignation to the Marine Corps because he might require ''testimony and records from the highest-ranking officials of our Government'' for his legal defense in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Landlord in Brooklyn Fixes 354 Violations
description: A Brooklyn landlord who was sentenced to live 15 days in the neglected apartment building he owns in the Crown Heights section, has corrected 81 percent of the housing code violations that prompted the sentence, the city said yesterday.

title: AIDS TEXT REJECTED IN NEW YORK
description: An easy-to-understand book about the threat of AIDS, intended for high school and junior high school students, has been rejected as a classroom text by the New York City Board of Education even though the book is based on a film the board commissioned and distributes to schools.

title: Villanova and Pitt Advance
description: With Villanova's two leading scorers in foul trouble and Arkansas heating up a comeback, Doug West took the game into his hands on offense and defense today.

title: Envoy Will Report to Arabs On Shamir Visit to the U.S.
description: Philip C. Habib, a former special envoy to the Middle East and Latin America, was dispatched today to the Middle East to report to Arab leaders on this week's visit to Washington by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, the State Department spokesman said today.

title: Federated's 'Poison Pill' Is Upheld
description: In a severe setback to its effort to acquire Federated Department Stores Inc., the Campeau Corporation lost a key court decision yesterday, and R. H. Macy & Company now has the upper hand in the takeover fight.

title: Bond Prices Fall in Late Selling
description: Late waves of selling slashed prices of Government, corporate and tax-exempt bonds yesterday.

title: U.S. Drops All Charges Against 2 in GTE Case
description: The Justice Department dropped all charges today against an executive and a former executive of a GTE Corporation subsidiary who were indicted two years ago on charges of illegally obtaining internal Pentagon planning documents.

title: Merchandiser Leaving Sears
description: In a suprise announcement, Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that one of its top merchandisers, Joseph H. Batogowski, 48 years old, was resigning to pursue ''outside business interests.'' Mr. Batogowski, a 22-year veteran of the nation's largest retailer, could not be reached for comment.

title: PANAMA DECLARES 'STATE OF URGENCY' IN FACE OF UNREST
description: The Panamanian Government declared a ''state of urgency'' tonight, putting its opponents on notice that it was prepared to suspend basic constitutional guarantees in the face of continued unrest.

title: Gains for Nicaragua: A Victory or a New Problem?
description: Nicaraguan troops appear to have won an important military victory by expelling contra guerrillas from some isolated Nicaraguan territory along the Honduran border. But their military victory may prove to be something of a political problem because it may kindle new sympathy for the contras in Congress.

title: Bridge; Two Martels and two Cohens take top places in Grand National Pair Championship.
description: Two married couples finished one-two in the Grand National Pair Championship, which ended here Thursday night.

title: Registration Number
description: To the Editor:

title: A TOUCH OF SHAKESPEARE WITH A ROCK SCORE
description: At first sight, on the dim stage, she might be a reincarnation of Anna Pavlova as the Dragonfly. She is then revealed as a funky ballerina-queen bee. Finally, she is Shakespeare's Titania, tenderly stroking the head of one of the reclining Bottoms who form the circle in which she sits.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day yesterday misidentified the owner of Schenley Industries of Dallas. The company was sold in October and is now a subsidiary of the United Distillers Group.

title: New Pact for Walsh
description: Bill Walsh has signed a two-year contract to remain as coach of the San Francisco 49ers, but he will yield the position of team president to the owner, Edward J. DeBartolo Jr. DeBartolo will ''increase his activities throughout the entire realm of the organization,'' especially the business side, according to a statement yesterday from the club.

title: Pro-Palestinian Ad Shows What Israel Is Truly Up Against
description: To the Editor:

title: Gen. Bruce C. Clarke Dies at 86; Ex-Army Commander in Europe
description: Gen. Bruce C. Clarke, a 44-year veteran of the Army who was its commander in Europe during the Berlin crisis of the 1960's, died Thursday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., after suffering a stroke. He was 86 years old and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Chores for the Season
description: BEGIN cleanup of the lawn; rake off winter's debris, old leaves, twigs and dead grass; add to a compost pile or fill plastic bags for dumping; apply lime if the lawn was not limed in recent years; if no fertilizer was applied late last fall, now is the time; follow rates provided on bags for both lime and fertilizer and use a calibrated spreader to make applications accurate. Spring Is Here

title: Down to the Wire on Trade
description: THE final deals have yet to be cut, but already the floor is littered with scrapped amendments bearing the names of legislative stalwarts from both houses and both parties.

title: Spring-Cleaning May Be a Little Late
description: SPRING is here, and with it, spring-cleaning. When a well-known politician said last fall that she and her husband needed a wife, it wasn't a new idea to me.

title: A Dependent Fed
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OBSERVATION TOWER
description: LEAD: YOU CAN'T help but notice him wherever you drive through New Jersey. There he stands, larger than life itself, beaming at you from billboards on parkways and turnpikes, clasping a map of New Jersey to his breast.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: One Physician's Story; Being Thorough Can Be Costly - To the Doctor
description: DR. DEVRA MARCUS, a Washington internist, left private practice to work in a prepaid health plan, but felt she had to resign after about a month. The plan, she said, ''cast decision-making in terms of finances.''

title: Winning Words
description: ''Informal'' is to ''colloquial'' as ''wrathful'' is to ''formal, annual, irate, indolent or tender.''

title: Australian Jockey Is Killed in a Fall
description: Iris Neilsen, one of Australia's leading women jockeys, was killed in a fall during a race at Lismore Racecourse this afternoon, officials said.

title: THE PROMISED LAND OF LITERATURE
description: LEAD: SIX MEMOS FOR THE NEXT MILLENNIUM By Italo Calvino. 124 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $12.95.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Finding a Cloud in a 'Little Bit of Heaven'
description: LEAD: HORSE FARMS, vineyards and large tracts of woods and fields line Route 25, a winding two-lane road that is one of Southold's two east-west arteries.

title: Iraq Attacks Iran Oil Terminal
description: Waves of Iraqi planes pounded Iran's biggest oil terminal today, leaving at least two tankers ablaze in the northern Persian Gulf. Iran said it shot down three Iraqi planes.

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Trade him to the Dodgers for Kirk Gibson, straight up. Think of it. Darryl goes back to his hometown under the nurturing wing of Tommy Lasorda. If Darryl starts to open his big mouth at the wrong times, Tommy will stuff it full of good home-cooked pasta. Gibson comes to a contending team under the watchful eye of veteran players. JOHN KARREL New York

title: The Case Against Price Tags on Art
description: In an art scene that is already in danger of being swamped with idle talk about money - the latest record set by a van Gogh, the latest sale of a Julian Schnabel or the real size of Andy Warhol's estate - nothing could have been better calculated to make this unlovely situation even worse than it is than the recent ruling by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs requiring that the prices of paintings and sculptures in New York's art galleries be ''conspicuously displayed'' for all visitors to exhibitions. Undoubtedly, the most immediate effect of this ruling will be to make money - and the consciousness of money - an even more important factor in the art world than it now is.

title: Math Stars in a Movie
description: In 1982, a high-school teacher named Jaime Escalante taught calculus to 18 lower-middle-class Hispanic students in the East Los Angeles barrio. It hardly seems a subject for a movie.

title: Democratic Fight Seems Likely to Go The Distance
description: THE 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign has become a marathon steeplechase, in which candidates run, fall, get up and start running again.

title: Ms. Meyers Plans October Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Burt R. Meyers of White Plains and West Yarmouth, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dara Lynn Meyers, to Evan M. Kingsley, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Ralph P. Kingsley of North Miami Beach, Fla., and Lenox, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: PEACE THROUGH LASERS?
description: CLAIMING THE HEAVENS The New York Times Complete Guide to the Star Wars Debate. By Philip M. Boffey, William J. Broad, Leslie H. Gelb, Charles Mohr and Holcomb B. Noble. Illustrated. 299 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: Ina W. Halperin Wed To Dr. Joseph L. Young
description: At Congregation Beth El in Bethesda, Md., Ina Weinstein Halperin, the director of career planning and placement at the Washington College of Law of American University, was married last night to Dr. Joseph L. Young, a psychologist and a program director at the National Science Foundation in Washington.

title: Marion Halberg Wed To Michael Hardiman
