description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Marion Elizabeth Georgiana Halberg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. G. Peter Halberg of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Patrick Hardiman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick L. Hardiman of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church, the senior minister at All Souls, performed the ceremony.

title: Just Because It's True, Is It Art?
description: In 1982, 18 students from a high school in East Los Angeles took the Advanced Placement exam in calculus and passed. They received college credit for their high school work. The next year, 31 students from the same school passed, and the number has climbed steadily ever since. Eighty-seven students passed the test in 1987.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL'S RECORD
description: Nothing in the article on New York Hospital by M. A. Farber and Lawrence K. Altman substantiates its damaging title, ''A Great Hospital in Crisis'' (Jan. 24).

title: OPINION: CENSORSHIP VS. STEWARDSHIP ON CAMPUS
description: The opinions, pro and con, on the Supreme Court's decision in the Hazelwood High School paper case [ ''Drawing the Line on Student Rights,'' Feb. 21 ] were interesting, yet both missed a point, i.e., reality.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 20, 1988
ODE ON A RAINBOW SLIDER
description: SEASON TICKET A Baseball Companion. By Roger Angell. 406 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE LYME DISEASE LABORATORY AT NEW YORK MEDICAL COLLEGE;
Researchers Fear Time Is Running Out
description: LEAD: IN the local offices of the medical entomology laboratory of the New York Medical College there is a big round wall clock, and next to it the words, ''Tick, tick, tick.'' The sign is a joke typical of the laboratory staff's sense of humor -ticks, specifically those that transmit Lyme disease, are the sole focus of their studies.

title: Honduran Air Force Planes Bomb Nicaragua Positions Along Border
description: Honduran Air Force jets bombed suspected Nicaraguan troop positions this afternoon in the border region where the Sandinistas have been attacking United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Is Extinction Their Future?
description: GARDENERS are going native. They are planting wildflowers and learning how to grow them.

title: Utility Selling Extra Land At Auction
description: CLIMBING values have encouraged many property owners to sell their land, and Northeast Utilities is no exception. The utility is auctioning land it says it no longer needs.

title: Bonnie Kennedy Weds
description: At the John Street United Methodist Church in New York, Bonnie Kennedy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Kennedy of Leawood, Kan., was married yesterday to Paul Cox, a son of Dorothy Godfrey of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Paul E. Cox. The Rev. Dr. Warren Danskin officiated. The bride, a graduate of Russell Sage College, is a technical resource analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities in New York. The bridegroom, a financial controller at the Chase Manhattan Bank, graduated from Villanova University.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE BEST OF DE GUSTIBUS. By Marian Burros. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Marian Burros has talked turkey in The New York Times about food, drink and much more in the kitchen cabinet or on the restaurant menu. Now, in the first collection from her De Gustibus column, which began in 1983, she offers recipes, reminiscences, letters from readers, information on ingredients and nutrition, as well as her emphatic opinions on such restaurant esoterica as dining vs. smoking, the ''waiter game'' and menu mistranslations. For dessert, the secrets of the famous August Plum Torte.

title: POSTINGS: Where Brownstones Stood; A Tall Tower
description: ''It is not an offensive building,'' said Jonathan Paskow, the developer of an almost completed, 22-story condominium at 255 West 85th Street. ''It's ugly,'' said John Kowall, chairman of Community Board 7.

title: Condo Fever In New York
description: THE philistines laughed, of course at the outrageous notion: Pay up to $29,000 for a slice of bare concrete no bigger than 8 1/2 by 18 1/2 feet?

title: THE TOUGHEST CUSTOMER
description: Four days after we were married, I gave my beloved a tie. I'd shopped for hours and paid too much, but he was worth it.

title: CREDIT WHERE IT'S DUE: LILCO TO THE RESCUE
description: Everyone dumps on Lilco. Once in a while, someone should tell the other side of the story.

title: REFLECTIONS OF A WRITER: LONG WORK, SHORT LIFE
description: LEAD: Bernard Malamud, who died two years ago last Friday, gave this talk at Bennington College on Oct. 30, 1984, as part of the Ben Belitt Lectureship Series. A longer version of his remarks was printed last year in The Michigan Quarterly.

title: OH, BABY, I LOVE YOUR LOFT
description: REAL ESTATE By Jane DeLynn. 316 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $17.95.

title: Mouse in the Castle? Off With Its Head!
description: ONCE upon a time in the kingdom of Nassau County, there lived a King and Queen (anyone who owned a home in this kingdom was considered a King and Queen). Anyway, one evening this particular royal couple went to bed. All the lights were out and the castle was very, very quiet. The couple were about to fall asleep when suddenly they heard a noise coming from another part of their domain.

title: THE MARSHALL PLAN
description: IN the commotion over the Washington Redskins' snatching Wilber Marshall, an All-Pro linebacker, from the Chicago Bears as a free agent, the popular debate is whether this is an isolated case or the start of a trend. But there's no debate over whose idea it was. There is only added evidence that Bobby Beathard, befitting the general manager of the reigning Super Bowl champions, is now the National Football League's shrewdest supplier of talent.

title: Army Sets Radon Testing
description: The Army has announced it will test buildings on its bases for the presence of the natural radioactive gas radon. ''The first structures to be tested will be day care centers, hospitals, schools and living areas,'' the Army said in a statement Friday. Radon, a natural product of decaying uranium in soil, may increase the risk of lung cancer, medical researchers say.

title: KANSAS CAUCUSES WON BY DUKAKIS
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts won the Kansas Democratic caucuses today as the Rev. Jesse Jackson used strong showings in the state's larger counties to finish second. Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee was third.

title: Merce Cunningham - Still Taking Chances
description: Chance and destiny, the possible and the impossible.

title: Unstable, Shifting Climate Defies Computer Models
description: By changing the contents of the earth's atmosphere, humans are delivering a sharp kick to a machine that scientists now believe capable of rapid and unstable responses.

title: Governor Confuses Lilco Issue
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR CUOMO'S comments that the Long Island Power Authority might be enlisted to watch over the continued existence of the company have added new confusion to the bewildering course of efforts to end the impasse over the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Teachers think that Hispanics are supposed to be preparing for low-skilled jobs, not for higher education.'' - Tomas A. Arciniega, president of, California State University, Bakersfield. [ 28:1. ]

title: Where the Frontier Spirit Lives On
description: ON Dec. 5, 1905, a man bundled in furs against the 60-degree-below temperature stepped off a sled on the frozen Yukon River, walked into the town of Eagle and asked where he could send a telegram. The message he sent (over a telegraph line constructed five years before to send military communiques) announced the discovery of the Northwest Passage; it was signed ''Roald Amundsen.'' The small white frame cabin where Amundsen lived for the next two months is still standing in Eagle, on what is now called Amundsen Avenue. Down the street, in front of the log building that serves as post office to this town of 150, gleams a two-foot-high stainless steel globe of the world, with a plaque commemorating the explorer's achievement.

title: POSTINGS: Layer-Cake Offices; A Suburban Look in Flushing
description: A condominium office building under construction in Flushing that its co-developer, Ted Schorr, said has ''a very different look from what has been built in Queens'' would fit well into any New York City suburb. The six-story structure's open surroundings and layer-cake design of alternating glass and brick are more often seen from a New Jersey Transit train than the IRT No. 7. The new building at 30-48 Linden Place, which sits in the center of a 40,000-square-foot public plaza and parking lot, offers a view of Manhattan across Flushing Bay.

title: DATA BANK: March 20, 1988
Old and New Collide on the Waterfront
description: ON THE southern edge of Claremont Channel, a grim slip on Jersey City's well-worn waterfront, a rattling conveyor belt carries the squashed remains of old automobiles up to a hopper.

title: 'HOME' TO AFRICA
description: To the Editor: My sister and I visited Senegal last summer and found it the most uplifting of all our many excursions to foreign lands. Other black Americans that we met shared our enthusiasm. True, the street hawkers were desperate in their selling tactics, yet the Senegalese that we spoke with were quiet and dignified. And proud. We have made meaningful friendships and through months of correspondence have verified our first impressions. LORETTA DABBS Manalapan, N.J.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bethel, Conn. $195,000 40 Wooster Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 59-year-old Dutch colonial; screened porch, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,366. Middletown, Conn. $140,000 27 Kent Court 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 10-year-old split level; 1-car attached garage; taxes $1,038. New Milford, Conn. $212,500 Sunset Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; stone fireplace, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,000. Chappaqua, N.Y. $400,000 2 Deborah Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, 0.9 acre; taxes $7,231. Irvington, N.Y. $540,000 6 Ardsley Terrace 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 59-year-old colonial; sun porch, den, 0.75 acre; taxes $6,294. Peekskill, N.Y. $110,000 122 Hadden Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, new furnace and roof, walk to school and stores, 0.8 acre; taxes $1,684. Rye Brook, N.Y. $325,000 5 Pine Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 38-year-old frame/masonry split level; eat-in kitchen, family room, 0.28 acre; taxes $4,019. OTHER AREAS Oradell, N.J. $274,000 307 Elm Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, pool, patio; taxes $4,242. Springfield, N.J. $250,000 14 North Derby Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; deck, 1-car garage, den, c/a; taxes $3,108. Sound Beach, L.I. $111,500 10 St. James Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath 40-year-old bungalow; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $800.

title: Jeryl L. Hilleman Wed in California
description: Jeryl Lynn Hilleman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice R. Hilleman of Lafayette Hill, Pa., was married yesterday to William Alexander Albright Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albright of Lafayette, Calif. The Rev. Richard Thayer performed the Protestant ceremony in the Stanford Memorial Church at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Taking the Time To Be Where You Don't Want to Be
description: AFTER completing a shift at the Sixth Precinct in Manhattan, Officer Michael Fandal took a train to Seaford, L.I., to attend the funeral of Edward Byrne, the 22-year-old New York City officer who was shot to death as he sat in his patrol car guarding a witness in a narcotics case.

title: PRINCE CHARLES RECASTS HIS ROLE
description: The effect of Howell Raines's article was to leave me with admiration for Prince Charles, who, against enormous pressure, seems to have made himself something better than he needs to be. Why, then, does Mr. Raines say that Charles's education was ''a noble . . . experiment that backfired''? Judging from its results, it succeeded very well. D. FOY Trenton

title: The Immortality of the Teacher
description: THERE I am in the bathroom in the early morning, and I am looking in the glass. An elderly person stares at me, and I wonder how he got in the house. A guest of my children? Or did we leave the back door open last night? He does resemble me, though. I know what you are saying, little mirror on the wall. I'm not the fairest, but the oldest teacher in my department.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Browsing Bangkok's Markets
description: LEAD: WHEN I first came to live in Bangkok, nearly 30 years ago, the city boasted a lone department store, deep in the heart of Chinatown, and not a single American-style supermarket. Shopping in those days meant going to a local market, always an adventure and often a voyage of discovery as well since it usually involved coming across an expected temptation.

title: Gene Engineering: Dispute Unresolved
description: LEAD: JOHNSON & JOHNSON, which led the fight against state oversight of genetic engineering last year, remains opposed, despite the likely alternative: scattered, sometimes more stringent, local regulation.

title: Assessing the Effects of Airline Deregulation
description: ONCE hailed as enlightened economic policy, the landmark deregulation of the airline industry 10 years ago is coming under a cloud.

title: U.S. to Take On Seagulls On Massachusetts Island
description: As the 1988 nesting season approaches for Eastern shore birds, seagulls on Monomoy Island still hold a commanding lead over the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: Putting Statues Up for Adoption
description: IT'S tough to be a monument in New York City.

title: Portobello Art Festival
description: NOTTING HILL is one of the liveliest of London's small villages.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: In the Jungle With Cinderella While telling stories around the campfire one night, Eric Hansen entertained his hosts in Borneo with a Malay version of Cinderella. This is from ''Stranger in the Forest: On Foot Across Borneo'' (Yolla Bolly/Houghton Mifflin).

title: Costa Rica
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Costa Rica's Quiet Beaches and Lush Land'' (Travel, Jan. 24), I would like to suggest that anyone going to Costa Rica should consider a three-day raft trip on the Picuare River, which flows through lush, virgin jungle. Visitors can expect to see dazzling, electric-blue Morpho butterflies, scarlet macaws and the exotic nests of the oropendula. There are natural water slides, rainbow mists and exhilarating rapids. The highly experienced guides use the most up-to-date equipment, provide excellent meals and campfire tales and provoke waterfights.

title: In the Courtroom, Expertise Is Always a Matter of Opinion
description: THE jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. began its deliberations last week caught in a crossfire between two out-of-town ''hired guns.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Deadline Set For Tickets to Seoul Games

title: Jackson and Dukakis Lead in Texas Voting
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts maintained their strength from the Southern primaries in conventions today that will affect the allocation of 64 Texas delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Susan Flynn Plans to Wed Jeremy Symington in June
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Leslie Flynn of Nanuet, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Linda Flynn to Jeremy Wadsworth Symington, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wadsworth Symington of Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: STYLISH INVESTMENTS
description: In hard times, men traditionally dress up to look affluent and successful. During the Great Depression, for example, many families put a good portion of their clothing budget into the breadwinner's suit. Although we're a long way from the 1930's, it appears that the diminishing prosperity of recent times has caused many young men to abandon casual clothes for a more conservative style.

title: Pair-of-a-Kind Shoes
description: BARBARA MUSIC has been a designer of textiles, theater costumes and bridal and evening dresses. But her latest career is trimming bridal and evening shoes with all manner of laces, beads, buckles and fabric flowers.

title: Dukakis Tells How He'd Aid Factory
description: As he travels the industrial heartland, one of Michael S. Dukakis's surest applause lines is a pledge that reflects the economic anxiety pervading this region.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Seeking High Bidders; Christie's and Brokerage Lend Cachet to an Auction
description: OVER the years, Martin Markinson and Donald Tick have rebuffed an aggressive stream of realty brokers eager to find buyers for the Helen Hayes Theater on West 44th Street, which the two men have owned for almost a decade. ''We never wanted to deal with lots of brokers and prospective buyers and all that stuff,'' said Mr. Markinson, who also produces plays.

title: Doctor Links Smoking to Cancer in Woman
description: Rejecting the assertions of tobacco companies, a cancer specialist testified this week that a longtime smoker died of lung cancer caused by cigarette smoking.

title: THROUGH THICK AND THIN
description: They hit a man where he's most vulnerable - on the gleaming dome above his forehead. Designed for thinning hair, a new crop of cosmetic solutions appeals to a man's vanity, offering all the hope and promise of youth. In fact, the name of one such lotion, from a Japanese company, translates as ''never-aging forest.''

title: Welfare Test Tries A Personal Approach
description: OFFICIALS hope an experiment in eastern Connecticut can offer clues to help remove people from the welfare rolls.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

title:
MUSIC;
Two Couples Join as a New Quartet
description: LEAD: TWO husband-and-wife duos will join forces as a new quartet Saturday night in a concert at the Jewish Community Center in Trenton.

title: Next Week Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
GARDENING;
For Some, a Rose Is a Rose Is a Salad
description: LEAD: WHEN someone says, ''I love flowers,'' he may be talking about them as food. Flowers are increasingly appearing in dishes prepared by chefs from coast to coast. They are used for hors d'oeuvres, tossed in salads, fried in batter, added to soups and used to garnish meats and desserts.

title: A Realty Broker Plans to Be Wed To Sallie Gibson
description: Sallie Hibbs Gibson's engagement to Robert Patrick Fitzgerald Jr., a son of Mr. Fitzgerald of Boston and the late Sally Shaughnessy Fitzgerald, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. Martin Gibson 3d of Corning, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Southeast Regional; OKLAHOMA ROUTS AUBURN
description: Stacey King scored 9 of his 37 points during a three-minute stretch when Oklahoma took command, and the Sooners crushed Auburn, 107-87, today in the second round of the Southeast Regional.

title: Russia, Through Rose-Colored Lenses
description: History disappears down the memory hole in ''Portrait of the Soviet Union.'' Good sense is flushed away, too. Ted Turner's three-part, seven-hour series is possessed by the same spirit that once led George Bernard Shaw to throw his dinner out the window of a Soviet train because food was redundant amid socialist milk and honey. ''Portrait of the Soviet Union'' opens with great red banners and great martial music and another great May Day in Moscow; then the actor Roy Scheider, who is the host and gee-whiz narrator, says, ''Onward into the future - the dream of the Soviet Union.'' Onward indeed; the series suggests that the future is here.

title: THE HEALTH-CARE CHAOS
description: JUST AS HISTORY teaches that war is too important to be left to generals, so recent American experience teaches that medicine is too important to be left to doctors and politicians.

title: Righetti Placed In Unusual Spot
description: The game began disconcertingly for Dave Righetti.

title: Koch Expands School-Aid Bid
description: Mayor Koch asked about 150 local politicians and education officials yesterday to help him lobby the State Legislature for increased aid for New York City's public schools.

title: And Now Military Talks
description: The meeting between Soviet and American defense ministers here produced ''no breakthrough,'' as Secretary of Defense Frank Carlucci said. Still, it was a remarkable first, not spring but a sign of changing climate that can gradually lead to a dramatically different sense of the superpower confrontation.

title: Habib in Cairo
description: An American envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today to seek the backing of the Egyptian Government for an American plan for peace in the Middle East. President Hosni Mubarak has called the American plan ''encouraging'' but suggested, without specifics, that some of its provisions be elaborated.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Prime Time
description: LEAD: Bored with ''Dynasty''? Tune in to the White Plains Common Council meetings on Channel 35, the White Plains government access cable.

title: Narita Airport
description: To the Editor: How is it possible that the country that produces Hondas and Toyotas has produced Tokyo's Narita, the Edsel of airports?

title: Practical Traveler; Flying Business Class
description: ECONOMY-CLASS travelers confess to being tortured by curiosity about what is happening on the other side of that curtain near the front that the flight attendants draw so decisively after takeoff. In moments when I have been on the other side, I have secretly hoped to spy out the truth. I never learned much except that carving beef on a little trolley looks like back-breaking work.

title: The Region's Fate Is Not In Washington's Hands
description: THE debate in Washington over what to do about Central America's problems has underscored one essential point: though the United States may strongly influence the changes now shaking the region, it cannot bring an end to the conflicts.

title: Social Events; Signs of Spring
description: Award Dinner March 22 - Lee A. Iacocca will receive the Democratic Legacy Award of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith at a black-tie dinner at the New York Hilton. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by dinner, the presentation and entertainment by Marvin Hamlisch. Tickets $500; 212-490-2525. Harbor Cruise March 25 - An 8-to-midnight cruise around New York Harbor aboard the yacht Duchess, with a New Orleans-style dinner, an open bar and dancing to the Bourbon Street Jazz Band will benefit the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts. The evening will support free concerts in Queens parks this summer. Boarding is at 7:30 at Pier 62, on the Hudson River near West 23d Street. Tickets $150; 718-463-7700. SoHo Mardi Gras March 25 - The Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center, which provides a variety of social services on the Upper East Side, is holding a Mardi Gras party at the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street (Houston Street). The benefit, from 9 P.M. to 1 A.M., will aid the center's program that delivers hot meals to 330 elderly shut-ins. Tickets $40, or $45 at the door; 212-360-7620. Exotica at the Waldorf March 26 - As is the custom, there will be exotic fare including blanched hazelnuts in sea water and honey, breaded goat-meat balls, roast boar and fingers of garlic and roast venison in hot apricot sauce. The occasion is the 84th annual Explorers Club dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, starting with cocktails at 6. The black-tie benefit will help commemorate the 100th anniversary of the National Geographic Society. Tickets $165 ($90 for members); 212-628-8383. Macy's Flower Party March 27 - Cocktails, a buffet, a raffle and a panorama of floral displays on the main floor of Macy's will benefit the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation. The black-tie evening, which starts at 7:30, will be a preview of the store's 14th annual flower show. Tickets $175; 212-986-8783. Restoring a Landmark March 27 - Founded in 1795 to serve foreign sailors whose ships were moored along the East River, the Mariners' Temple Baptist Church is one of few buildings left in the city of 18th-century architecture in the Greek style. A benefit for the restoration of the church, the city's oldest Baptist congregation, will be held at the church, 3 Henry Street (at Oliver Street on Chatham Square). A 6 P.M. concert by Lionel Hampton will be followed by a reception. Contributions of $25 are requested. Information: 212-233-0423. From Pole to Pole March 28 - For two years, Deborah Shapiro and Rolf Bjelke sailed their 40-foot ketch on a 33,000-mile voyage to the Arctic and then to the Antarctic. They will talk about their adventures and show some slides at the Equitable Center, Seventh Avenue at 51st Street. Cocktails at 6 P.M. followed by the presentation; the beneficiary is the Churchill School and Center for Learning Disabilities. Tickets $50; 212-722-0610. A Canadian View March 28 - The Americas Society is a nonprofit institution devoted to informing Americans about their hemispheric neighbors. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada is expected to address the society at a benefit dinner starting with cocktails at 6 at the Plaza. Tickets $125 for members, $160 for nonmembers; 212-249-8950. Wrestling Summit March 29 - A wrestling meet, featuring contenders for the summer Olympic Games from the United States and the Soviet Union, will be held at Madison Square Garden starting at 8 P.M. At 7:30, wrestlers from local schools, including some who are physically impaired, will hold exhibition matches. A buffet reception at the Penta Hotel across from the Garden follows. The evening will benefit the Kiwanis International ''Say No to Drugs'' Foundation, the United States Olympic wrestling team and the Metropolitan Wrestling Association, which conducts instructive and competitive programs. Tickets are $100 for choice seats at the match and the reception, $10 to $25 for the match alone, or $25 for the reception alone; 718-899-7306 or the Garden box office. Concert of Thanks March 30 - Vladimir Feltsman, the pianist, will perform a benefit concert at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68th Street, to express his appreciation to those who helped him in his seven-year struggle to leave the Soviet Union. He will be accompanied by another Soviet emigre, the violinist Alexandre Brussilovsky. A reception follows the 8 P.M. concert, which will benefit the National Conference on Soviet Jewry and the Coalition to Free Soviet Jews. Tickets $100, or $20 and $40 for the concert alone; 212-679-6122 or 212-354-1316.

title: Democrats Clash With Reagan Over Arms Treaty
description: The White House has sent a sharply worded letter to Congress rejecting a move by Senate Democrats to attach a binding condition to the new missile treaty on a key arms control issue.

title: Trickle Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Advisory for Motorists: Holland Tunnel Switch
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING is a summary of potential traffic problem areas in the state:

title: Jennifer Moore, Professor, Weds
description: Jennifer Mills Moore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Moore of Armonk, N.Y., and John W. McClure, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. McClure of Byfield, Mass., were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Cynthia Briggs Kettredge, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Harvard University Memorial Church.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Sherburne, Vt.;
A Condo Hotel On the Slopes
description: LEAD: THE developers of a new inn near the Killington ski resort believe that as skiers get older they will be looking for luxury on ski vacations, and will spend to get it. That thought has inspired the development of The Inn of the Six Mountains, which is expected to open in May.

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 22 of The Times Magazine today, under the heading ''Russia Enters the Race,'' misstates part of the Soviet Union's plan to explore Phobos, one of Mars's two moons. Both Soviet craft are to engage in laser-aided analysis of the moon and send hoppers to its surface; the tasks are not allocated to one craft apiece.

title: Concern Growing On College Costs
description: LEAD: THE cost of a college education, already high, is climbing higher, and finding ways to meet it is becoming a preoccupation for many students and their families.

title: THE 'ONE REAL IMPRESSIONIST'
description: LEAD: BERTHE MORISOT Impressionist. By Charles F. Stuckey and William P. Scott with Suzanne G. Lindsay. Illustrated. 228 pp. New York: Hudson Hills Press. $45. BERTHE MORISOT The Correspondence With Her Family and Her Friends Manet, Puvis de Chavannes, Degas, Monet, Renoir and Mallarme. Edited by Denis Rouart.

title: OPINION: CENSORSHIP VS. STEWARDSHIP ON CAMPUS
description: Bari Sue Kenyon, the former editor in chief of The Paper Lion at Farmingdale High School, presents a compelling case in support of freedom of the press for student journalists [ Feb. 21 ] .

title: Woman and Man Are Seized With 2 1/2 Pounds of Cocaine
description: A woman about to board a bus for Washington with about two and a half pounds of cocaine was arrested Friday with a companion at the Port Authority bus terminal, the authorities reported yesterday.

title: On Language; Weenies Of the World, Unite!
description: ''YOU EVER HEARD OF the pol-mil weenies?'' asked Susan F. Rasky, a colleague at The New York Times.

title: Reflections of a Writer: Long Work, Short Life
description: Bernard Malamud, who died two years ago last Friday, gave this talk at Bennington College on Oct. 30, 1984, as part of the Ben Belitt Lectureship Series. A longer version of his remarks was printed last year in The Michigan Quarterly.

title: Form 1040 Takes an Average of 18 Hours
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Portrait of a Late-Blooming Coach
description: HE played basketball for Vince Lombardi and he scouted for Bobby Knight, and now he has defeated Knight as a coach. In between, Dick Tarrant taught in high school and had ''holes in my shoes.''

title: Addiction Is a Family Problem, Too
description: One woman used to call in sick for her husband when he was too drunk to get up in the morning. Another paid her son's way out of a $15,000 debt and bailed him out of jail. A young man bought beer for his father just to keep him off the streets.

title: Miss Belna Wed To A. E. Arbenz
description: The marriage of Alison Marie Belna to Andrew Edward Arbenz took place yesterday at the Four Seasons Hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. Judge Charles E. Frisco of Superior Court in Los Angeles officiated.

title: Dowsers Lead Rural Quest for Water
description: The Y-shaped wire rod made out of an old clothes hanger quivered in Donald Spohr's outstretched hands as he walked across a hilltop hayfield here. It quickly rotated toward him and completed an 180-degree arc, pointing straight down.

title: Robert M. Garrels; Geologist, 71
description: Prof. Robert M. Garrels, a prominent geologist, died of cancer of the colon on March 8 at his home in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 71 years old.

title:
ART;
Contemporary Prints at the Whitney
description: LEAD: WITH her observation in the brochure accompanying ''American Print Renaissance, 1958-1988,'' Roni Feinstein identifies the central issue in current printmaking: ''It is the artist's vision, conceptual strength, and ability to conjure up striking, and/or beautiful images that make a print successful.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $435,000 20 South Montgomery Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 83-year-old center hall colonial; library, parlor, solarium, 2 fireplaces; taxes $6,600. Commack $180,000 40 Shinbone Lane 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old high ranch; family room, deck, skylights, 2-car garage; taxes $2,900. East Williston $405,000 121 Ludwig Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, basement, c/a, 2-car garage; taxes $5,400. East Northport $244,000 58 Gildare Drive 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath farm ranch; fireplace, 0.5 acre, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500. Fort Salonga $1.05 million 3 Seashell Lane 5-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath, 35-year-old waterfront contemporary; den, new kitchen, deck, 1 acre; taxes $11,000. Sound Beach $111,500 10 St. James Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath 40-year-old bungalow; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $800. OTHER AREAS Springfield, N.J. $250,000 14 North Derby Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; deck, 1-car attached garage, den, c/a; taxes $3,108. New Milford, Conn. $212,500 Sunset Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; stone fireplace, panoramic country views, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,000. Chappaqua, N.Y. $400,000 2 Deborah Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, frontage on pond, 0.92 acre; taxes $7,231.

title: POSTINGS: Home-Buyer's Class; Looking for Affordability
description: Can anyone who is not well-off buy a home in Westchester County these days? ''It requires an extensive search,'' said Blossom Blum, executive director of Westchester Residential Opportunities Inc., a nonprofit open-housing group. ''We help people to try to find a way to afford what's out there.''

title:
DINING OUT;
Martinsville: Old Inn, New Broom
description: LEAD: IT HAPPENS sometimes that a restaurant will close or change owners or chefs while we are in the process of reviewing it. Rarely, however, is the change as welcome as that at the Valley Cafe in Martinsville, Somerset County.

title: Pampered Look at the Wild
description: ''MOOSE!'' The cry from one excited passenger sets 59 other heads aswivel, and those of us across the aisle jump out of our plush seats and lean over fellow riders to catch a glimpse of a barn-size cow and her calf grazing by the edge of a grove of birch trees. Outside the wide, curved glass windows we see unbroken wilderness; inside, we enjoy unalloyed luxury. This mode of Alaskan travel is getting an enthusiastic reception from visitors who want to view one of the wildest landscapes in the world in relaxed elegance.

title: 2 Queens Men Guilty Of Murder and Arson
description: Two men were convicted yesterday in the 1984 slaying of a homeless man, who was never identified, in a deserted building in Far Rockaway, Queens, District Attorney John J. Santucci said.

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Callas Industry Yields More Gems
description: LEAD: It is safe to assume that audible documentation exists now of just about every occasion when Maria Callas sang within the range of a microphone.

title: Jennifer Bartlett Brings a Siberian Prison to Paris
description: Once upon a time, the French were chauvinistic, right?

title: Questions Are Raised on '86 Honduras Aid
description: Only $200,000 of $20 million in ''emergency'' American military aid sent to Honduras following a March 1986 border crossing by Nicaraguan troops was used to respond to the attack, according to a report by Congressional investigators that has not been made public.

title: 6 People File to Oppose Mecham for Governor
description: Six candidates had filed petitions to oppose Gov. Evan Mecham in a recall election May 17 as the petition deadline passed Friday.

title: SPORTSMAN'S SPRING-CLEANING
description: AN outdoorsman who suffers from the pack-rat syndrome will eventually be choked by clutter whether his digs are modest or grand. At that point, he must begin to discard certain items, not only to gain breathing room, but also to save time lost in bouts of nostalgia while poking through his hoard.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: 500,000 a Year; Fewer Teen Mothers, But More Are Unmarried
description: EVERY year, about half a million teen-agers have babies - often creating lifelong difficulties both for themselves and their children. Increasingly, experts are documenting the links between adolescent motherhood and a host of social ills that range from low birthweight to poverty to dropping out of school.

title: Nancy Susan Rose to Wed Donnell R. Dufford in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Zeldon E. Rose of West Long Branch, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Susan Rose to Donnell Robert Dufford, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin H. Dufford of El Cajon, Calif. An April 30 wedding is planned.

title: A Big Texas Bank Gets Federal Aid
description: Texas's biggest banking company got an emergency $1 billion loan from Federal regulators. First Republicbank of Dallas sought the aid in an effort to restore depositor confidence. The company, with $32.2 billion in assets, has seen some $2 billion in withdrawals this year amid concern about its financial condition. First Republicbank, burdened with bad loans from Texas's depressed economy, lost $656 million in 1987. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation provided the $1 billion and received enough stock as collateral to gain effective control of the company. The loan was termed a temporary measure until a permananent solution is devised. Analysts said a full bailout of First Republicbank could cost $3 billion, making it the costliest such Federal rescue ever.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE SCREWTAPE LETTERS, by C. S. Lewis. (Mentor/New American Library, $2.95.) When this book of epistles from the Devil to his disciple was published in 1943, our reviewer, P. W. Wilson, praised C. S. Lewis for a clever portrayal of ''the devious processes of the diabolical mischief-makers,'' adding that ''somewhere in the inferno there must be considerable annoyance.'' THE NAZI DOCTORS: Medical Killing and the Psychology of Genocide, by Robert Jay Lifton. (Basic, $12.95.) How did doctors, trained to uphold the Hippocratic oath, become involved in the gruesome experiments and killings of the Third Reich? This history of Nazi war crimes committed in the name of science shows how a program of euthanasia, carried out in mental institutions to eliminate people considered defective, eventually led to systematic genocide in concentration camps. In 1986 our reviewer, Bruno Bettelheim, said the book ''painfully revived my memories of the time I had spent in two of [ the camps ] - memories of which I am unable to free myself, as no survivor of them ever can.'' The events recounted, he said, ''are dreadful enough. That doctors perpetrated them makes reading the book particularly upsetting.'' THE LAST SONG OF MANUEL SENDERO, by Ariel Dorfman. Translated by George R. Shivers with the author. (King Penguin, $7.95.) In this political fantasy by a Chilean novelist, fetuses unite and refuse to enter a world filled with corruption. ''After the complications of plot and puzzle have done their work, the richness of the invention breaks through the gate of reality,'' Earl Shorris said here last year, ''and the reader touches congruently the soulful imagination of Ariel Dorfman.'' HOLY SMOKE, by G. Cabrera Infante. (Faber & Faber, $8.95.) John McPhee once wrote an entire book about oranges. The Cuban novelist G. Cabrera Infante has done the same with cigars. The result is a social history of one of his favorite pastimes. He ''weaves his way from one theme to another, as though in a tobacco trance, turning aside to follow an idiosyncratic fancy, gliding back to his starting point,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1986. ''Everything reminds him of something else, and everything else reminds him of a cigar.'' AFTERWORDS: Novelists on Their Novels, edited by Thomas McCormack. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) Perhaps a million tiny decisions go into the writing of a book. In one of these 14 essays, Norman Mailer compares two versions of his star-crossed novel ''The Deer Park,'' showing how the slightest change in wording can be a deliberate act with powerful artistic consequences. ''What might have been a parade of solemn, solipsistic exercises is saved by good measures of humor, rueful self-criticism, biographical digressions and intelligent insights on fictional theory,'' Robie MacAuley said here in 1969. ''The silent struggle to tell it and be heard - this is what 'Afterwords' is about.'' THE CAPITALIST REVOLUTION: Fifty Propositions About Prosperity, Equality, and Liberty, by Peter L. Berger. (Basic, $8.95.) In his celebration of capitalism, Peter L. Berger is too ready to ignore its faults, Lester C. Thurow said here in 1986. But overall, he found the sociologist's book ''a nondogmatic, rational, reasonable, never shrill, balanced argument.'' FIASCO, by Stanislaw Lem. Translated by Michael Kandel. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95.) Stanislaw Lem's story of an expedition to a planet inhabited by strange, uncommunicative aliens examines the problems that arise when ideologies clash. ''In its deeper resonances it transcends the science fiction genre and reinforces Mr. Lem's claim to be one of the major writers of our time,'' our reviewer, Paul Delany, said last year. JOE & MARILYN: A Memory of Love, by Roger Kahn. (Avon, $4.95.) The lives of Joe DiMaggio and Marilyn Monroe intersected only briefly, but during their stormy nine-month marriage they were known in the press as Mr. and Mrs. America. ''Little new ground is broken here,'' Robert Strauss said in The Book Review in 1986, ''and Mr. Kahn, one of baseball's purplest prose writers, leans more to the feats of DiMag than the traumas of Marilyn. But, in all, this is a worthy compilation of anecdotes.'' ANNE OF GREEN GABLES, by L. M. Montgomery. (Signet/New American Library, $2.50.) In 1908, when this story of an orphan growing up on Prince Edward Island was published, an anonymous Times reviewer found the ''little asylum waif'' to be ''altogether too queer.'' The novel became a classic anyway and is being released in a new edition along with its sequel, ANNE OF AVONLEA ($2.50). THE FIERY CROSS: The Ku Klux Klan in America, by Wyn Craig Wade. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) Since the Civil War, the various factions of the Ku Klux Klan have risen and fallen and carried on their campaign against blacks, Jews, Catholics - everyone, it seems, except bigoted white Protestants. Last year our reviewer, Theodore Rosengarten, called this history ''an ambitious, timely, comprehensive chronicle of America's most persistent racist organization.'' LIFE DRAWING, by Emily Arnold. (Laurel/Dell, $4.95.) In the heyday of Abstract Expressionism, a girl born to a failed scriptwriter and a frustrated would-be singer struggles to be an artist anyway. In 1986, Will Blythe said here that this novel is a ''generous portrait of an artist responding to the demands of vision in love and painting in a period when artists carried more paintings than investments in their portfolios.''

title: CRIMES OF THEIR FATHERS
description: LEAD: BORN GUILTY Children of Nazi Families. By Peter Sichrovsky. Translated by Jean Steinberg. 178 pp. New York: Basic Books. $17.95.

title: Lea A. Schoenfeld Is Married To Randall Joseph Ottinger
description: The marriage of Lea Anne Schoenfeld, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Schoenfeld of Seattle, to Randall Joseph Ottinger took place last evening at the Mission Hills Country Club in Palm Springs, Calif. Rabbi Earl S. Starr performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Richard L. Ottinger of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Dr. Betty Ann Ottinger of Washington.

title: Perspectives on the Hudson River
description: The beauty and majesty of the Hudson River have inspired artists for hundreds of years, and their interpretations have been expressed in many mediums. Opening today at the Lenoir Preserve Nature Center in Yonkers is an exhibition of nearly 75 photographs that capture a spectrum of river views, some in black and white, others in color.

title: Review/Dance FIVE REPLICATIONS IN DORIS HUMPHREY HOMMAGE
description: Though widely acknowledged as a major figure in American modern dance, Doris Humphrey created work whose measured tone and intellectual underpinnings have made it seem relatively inaccessible, and unsusceptible to revivifying personal interpretation. And so the Philadelphia Dance Theater's presentation of five Humphrey dances, on Thursday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, was very welcome. Revived by close associates of the choreographer, they are clear examples of her distinctive search for the principles of dance.

title: It's Time to Put Warnings on Alcohol
description: SPUDS MacKenzie is tending goal. It's the last shot of the game, and Spuds makes an incredible save. The skillful maneuver by Anheuser-Busch's mascot is part of an Olympian effort to convince Americans that drinking is harmless and all-American. But during the next Olympiad, the ads may have a new twist. The bottle of Bud hoisted by the Spudettes may carry a message about the risks of alcohol.

title: SERVING JUSTICE WHILE PATIENTS WAIT
description: My professional life has been severely disordered by a call to jury duty in Nassau County. Though recognizing my responsibility as a citizen to serve, and beyond that being intrigued in anticipation of a new experience, I was and am worried: as a clinical social worker in agency and private practice, my extended absence would mean that depressed, anxious, sometimes abused or otherwise disturbed clients would go unserved.

title: PANAMA WIDENING PURGE OF MILITARY
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, pushed ahead today with a military housecleaning intended to solidify his control over the Panama Defense Forces.

title: We Need Role Models, Not Labels
description: WARNING labels on alcoholic beverages could shape up as the ''Why not'' issue of 1988. And that would be a shame.

title: For Many, a Vast Wasteland Has Become a Brave New World
description: William K. Joseph, video American, does most of his banking to the glow of an electronic teller in the concourse of the World Trade Center. Upstairs, as an investment counselor for Shearson Lehman Hutton, Mr. Joseph spends 10 hours a day consulting the green screen of his Quotron, the blue monitor of his IBM XT and the green display of his Bond Brain.

title: Cher: Yes? No? (Check Only One)
description: I guess I loved Cher the most the night she showed up at the Academy Awards looking like a tarantula. The academy had, pointedly, failed to nominate her for her top-calibre work in ''Mask'' - a calculated disciplinary action that sent shivers down the spine of every former teen-age girl in the audience who had ever been called into the principal's office for yet another futile round of ''life style correction'' measures.

title: TAR HEELS STOP LOYOLA, 123-97
description: Dr. Phog Allen had a saying that he used whenever a young assistant tried to convince him that this new wrinkle or that would be great innovation for Kansas University basketball.

title: Miss Culhane Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Catherine Carroll Culhane, a daughter of Mrs. M. Carroll Culhane of Waterbury and Milford, Conn., and the late Dr. Culhane, to Peter Maximus Kennedy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Jr. of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church in Waterbury. The Rev. Thomas H. Dwyer performed the ceremony.

title: In Mexico, a Fight for the Mantle of Revolution
description: Mobilized by Mexico's governing party, tens of thousands of workers, peasants and civil servants gathered in front of the National Palace here Friday to hear President Miguel de la Madrid honor the memory of President Lazaro Cardenas, who, 50 years earlier, ordered the takeover of foreign oil companies.

title: STREETSCAPES: 312-14 East 53d Street; Twin Clapboard Rowhouses, But Just One Is Landmarked
description: AMONG the first buildings to be considered for designation by the newly formed New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1966 were two identical clapboard rowhouses at 312 and 314 East 53d Street, between Second and First Avenues, built a century earlier.

title: The Palestinian Militants: A Splintered Movement
description: PRO-ARAFAT

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BLACK AVIATORS ''Black Wings,'' an exhibition tracing the history of black American combat and stunt pilots, is on view at the New England Air Museum through April 11.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FEIFFER ON CARTOONING Jules Feiffer, the Pulitzer Prize cartoonist, Obie Award playwright and Academy Award screenwriter, will lecture, with slides, on ''The Political Cartoon and the Media'' tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Theater-in-the-Round on Seton Hall University's South Orange campus.

title: Waterfront Complex Moves Ahead
description: LEAD: A COOPERATIVE venture among a developer, the state university, a school system and an educational organization is benefiting each, as well as rehabilitating a quarter-mile of the New Haven waterfront.

title: FATHERS AND SONS ON THE WATERFRONT
description: Your article about the decline of the shipping industry noted that the local economy had undergone rapid change, but it failed to emphasize the benefits that change has brought. During the last 40 years, maritime industry has withdrawn from the Hudson waterfront, leaving much of it in a state of devastation.

title: DESTINATION: MARS
description: MARS TUGS AT THE HUMAN IMAGINATION like no other planet. With a force mightier than gravity, it attracts the eye to its shimmering red presence in a clear night sky. The mind vaults to thoughts of what might have been (if Mars were a little closer to the Sun) and of what could be (if humans were one day to plant colonies there). In another time, astronomers gazed on Mars and professed to see signs of a canal-building civilization fallen on hard times; before long, belligerent Martians escaping their desiccated planet haunted our literature. In our time, spacecraft with electronic eyes have traveled to Mars and dispelled any lingering fears, or hopes, of Martians, but discovered instead a world more dynamic than the Moon and more hospitable than Venus or any other known planet. They discovered a world beckoning to be explored.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

title: Jewish-Christian Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Elliot Davis Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Elliot Davis to John Sebastian Paolella, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Paolella of Paramus, N.J., has been announced by her father, Dr. E. William Davis Jr. of New York and Old Westbury, L.I. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: International Pianists at Polayes Contest
description: IN 1985, Jose Feghali sprang to international fame when he won the Van Cliburn Competition in Texas. Tonight, the young Brazilian pianist will be one of the judges at the Annual Marcia Polayes Competition in Sprague Hall in New Haven.

title: We're Not Out of the Deep Deficit Woods Yet; A New Approach
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Survival Plans
description: At least one Soviet player, Vyacheslav Fetisov, is reportedly on the verge of joining the National Hockey League, but in the view of the director of Soviet hockey, Vyacheslav Koloskov, Fetisov and other Soviet players with a yen for foreign climes would be better off setting their sights on Japan, Switzerland or Austria.

title: GRUMMAN'S PROBLEM: CREDIBILITY
description: ''Turbulent Times Ahead for Grumman'' [ Feb. 14 ] does not address Grumman's most serious problem, lack of credibility. In an era where it is recognized that advanced electronic systems form the backbone of aerospace systems, Grumman has failed to demonstrate the capability to manage the development of systems and software.

title: In Mideast Unrest, a Struggle for TV
description: The struggle between Israel and the Palestinians in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip is also being waged for American public opinion, and the major battleground is the nightly television news.

title: Versatile Lamb Makes Its Way Back to the Table
description: SPRING is the traditional time for lamb. A roast, scented with herbs and served with new potatoes, steamed young carrots and peas is one of the many highlights of the season.

title: Food Inspection Results
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 29 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
ART;
Exploring Creativity as Process
description: LEAD: NORTHPORT GALLERIES is the second of the Island's cooperative galleries to relocate this year, following B. J. Spoke's move from Port Washington to Sea Cliff. After several years in the old Patiky auction house on Route 25-A in Northport, the gallery now occupies an attractive shopfront on New York Avenue in Huntington, where the inaugural exhibition can be seen through next

title:
INVESTING;
New Fund Offerings Stage a Rebound
description: LEAD: NEW mutual fund offerings are on the rise again, but individual investors should basically avoid them, professionals who analyze these funds say. The number of new funds dropped sharply after the October stock collapse, but lately the number of funds in registration has been creeping back to pre-crash levels.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''SANDY HOOK pilots know a nor'west blizzard when it comes along, and every mother's son of them that got ashore yesterday with a whole skin was willing to swear by the piper that played before Moses that Monday's blow was a blow that could give Sullivan, Mitchell - or any other hard hitter - a deckload of points on the 'knocking out' business and come up smiling for an unlimited number of rounds.''

title: Gay Rights Bill Cheered in Vermont
description: The worst thing was the isolation. Howard Russell can remember vividly the tormenting suspicion that he was different from everybody else in Hinesburg, the western Vermont farming community where he grew up.

title: Gas Cylinders Removed From Blast Site in Jersey
description: The local authorities in Berkeley Heights, N.J., announced yesterday that all dangerous gas cylinders had been removed from the burning debris of a chemical plant where a cylinder exploded Thursday, killing three men and injuring a fourth.

title: Art in the Service of Commerce
description: THE business of advertising and the art of photography grew up together and share many elements in common. Both, essentially, are creations of 20th century technology. Both have played an enormous role in shaping our view of the world. And both live or die on their ability to tap into the mysterious power of image.

title: The Only Way to Go
description: EXPERTS and administrators around the world have long been troubled by the problem of procedural penalties for such matters as tardy arrival and slow play. It seems unfair, say some, for a major knockout team match to be decided by circumstances other than actual play. The counter-argument focuses on the difficulty of discouraging misdemeanors without imposing penalties with teeth.

title: Holly Stevens Married To Christopher D. Bell
description: Holly Mather Stevens, a vice president and the director of media planning at DeWitt Media in New York, and Christopher Duncan Bell, a stockbroker at Equitable Securities of New York, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley officiated.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: MOZART FESTIVAL

title: AFLEET WINS TOBOGGAN IN HIS FIRST RACE OF SEASON
description: Afleet, who may have been the nation's best miler as a 3-year-old last year, made a winning seasonal debut yesterday with an impressive victory in the $110,800 Toboggan Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: 3 Policemen Killed in Attack Near Pretoria
description: Three black policemen were killed when two black men opened fire with automatic rifles on a group of people in the yard of a township west of Pretoria, the police said today.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO CEILING BUT HEAVEN. By Mykal Mayfield Banta. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This is a first novel both violent and overwhelmingly sad. ''No Ceiling but Heaven'' is the strife-filled tale of the Midwestern Harden family, as narrated by the mentally retarded Johnny. The Hardens' difficulties center mostly on Bobby, Johnny's twin brother, who is angry and destructive, a borderline psychopath. As he is gradually presented to us, Bobby is beating up a neighbor who has mocked Johnny, dealing drugs, brawling in defense of his hopelessly inebriated father (who for years has topped off his evening with a full bottle of liquor) or generally inciting trouble. Though the author never clearly makes the link, it's obvious that one of the sources of Bobby's rage is his father's alcoholism; Bobby also feels guilty when faced with Johnny's handicap, even though it's a disability that at times seems rather slight. But despite the novel's endless bleak scenarios, a strong portrait of love somehow manages to emerge, one that is expressed through Johnny's sympathetic though matter-of-fact voice. Although the boys' mother is given short shrift, Johnny eloquently conveys the enormous devotion that links Mr. Harden and his sons, as well as the twins' love for each other. Thus, within this family's whirl of troubles, the author has managed to reveal the unbreakable bonds that connect fathers, sons and brothers. This story is a tribute to those complicated, mysterious kinds of love.

title: Program Fashions Tools To Let the Disabled Work
description: A BUMPER sticker on the back of Charles M. Malvasi Jr.'s powered wheelchair reads: ''I may be slow, but I'm ahead of you.''

title: POSTINGS: By the Sea; Hotel and Town Houses
description: In a one-time resort now being transformed into a bedroom community, Henry V. Vaccaro is hedging his bets. Along with the first hotel to be built in Ocean Grove, N.J, in 50 years, Mr. Vaccaro plans 14 town-house condominiums. The combination resort-and-conference hotel will have 168 rooms and Victorian architecture. The six-story hotel will face the ocean, but the two-and-a-half-story town houses behind it will overlook Wesley Lake. The hotel and town houses will share a pool and a solarium.

title: As Sales Drop, Builders of Boats Turn to Artworks
description: New England boat builders are diversifying, making sculptures and ornaments for buildings as well as custom-made yachts, to compensate for a flagging market.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A Crusade to Restore Sight HE downplays his credentials and speaks of his deeds in humble terms. Dr. Yale Solomon of Brightwaters is a modest man.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SOVIET SUCCESSION STRUGGLES: Kremlinology and the Russian Question From Lenin to Gorbachev. By Anthony D'Agostino. (Allen & Unwin, $45.) One school of thought sees all signs of struggle in the Kremlin as playacting, a device to gull the West into giving aid and comfort to the comparatively ''good'' Soviet leader who is at odds with supposedly ''bad'' domestic foes. Actually, according to this viewpoint, the two factions are as alike as peas in a pod. Anyone still subscribing to this theory need only read ''Soviet Succession Struggles'' by Anthony D'Agostino to be persuaded that the conflicts that have marked the Soviet regime since Lenin's time have been deadly real. (But the book does demand commitment: Mr. D'Agostino, a professor of history at San Francisco State University, is inclined to bog down in minutiae.) The author postulates two broad political orientations - a militant, ideological impulse, which he calls the ''Leningrad line,'' and a more pragmatic, liberal ''Moscow line'' - that recur like a leitmotif through Soviet history. The contest between them is endemic, he finds, to the system, and the clashes that break out into the open when a leader dies are only the climactic moments of a constant process. The prize in these succession struggles, the author holds, goes to the tactician who occupies a centrist position, alternating between the two extremes as circumstances dictate. This suggests that Mikhail Gorbachev can be expected to retreat from his reforms if the going gets tough. Mr. D'Agostino's well-researched, if controversial, argument is an interesting contribution to the debate over the nature of Soviet politics.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: WOLF WINTER. By Clare Francis. (Morrow, $19.95.) The cold war doesn't get colder anywhere than in Scandinavia's Arctic Circle, the scene for this immensely satisfying espionage melodrama by the author of the best seller ''Night Sky.'' The time is the early 1960's, when strategically located Norway finds itself the center of a secret battle between its NATO partners and the neighboring Soviet Union over the placement of American nuclear missiles on the frozen Lapp plateau.

title: Is the Secretary of Agriculture the Real 'Farmer Brown'?
description: TO MOST New Jerseyans, he is The Honorable Secretary of Agriculture, Mister Arthur Richard Brown Junior. But to most folks in this Atlantic County agricultural community (population: 3,000), he is just plain ''Farmer Brown.''

title: And the Winner Gets . . . a Radioactive Dump
description: California has chosen a site for a low-level radioactive waste dump, a decision that made many people unhappy - because they wanted it in, or at least near, their backyards.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE BUTCHER'S THEATER. By Jonathan Kellerman. (Bantam, $19.95.) Set in present-day Jerusalem, this new novel by the author of ''When the Bough Breaks'' is a traditional murder mystery with a slight deviation. Here the twist of the knife competes with the twist of international politics. Someone is kidnapping young Arab women, drugging them, mutilating them and dumping their bodies in areas already aflame with Arab-Israeli tensions, including an area in the hills of Jerusalem called the Butcher's Theater.

title: Report Says U.S. Demands on Aid May Impede Afghan Pact
description: A demand by the Reagan Administration that the Soviet Union end assistance to the Afghan Government at the same time that the United States cuts off aid to the country's guerrilla forces could prove a major obstacle to a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan, according to a staff report to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: He Gave Elegance to Manhattan's Skyline
description: The death last month of the builder and architect Irwin S. Chanin did not have any immediate impact on the shape of the city -Chanin was, after all, 96 years old, and had not put up a new building in years, even though he did manage the remarkable feat of going to his office almost daily until a couple of months ago. But the end of his life was an event of great significance nonetheless, for he was the last of the men who built the extraordinary skyline of New York in the 1920's and 1930's - and now that he is gone, so, too, is any direct link between us and that remarkable period. The great towers of the 20's and 30's have become the models to which the 1980's looks, and Chanin built many of the best of them.

title: Treaty Powerless to Stem A Growing Loss of Ozone
description: The destruction of the earth's protective ozone layer, set in motion by the release of industrial gases into the atmosphere, will continue for decades despite the best efforts of governments and industries to control it, scientists now agree.

title: 'Miss Firecracker' Is Staged in Fairfield
description: THE Boston Post Road Stage Company of Fairfield is offering a delightful account of ''The Miss Firecracker Contest,'' a funny and touching play by Beth Henley.

title: Tyson vs. Tubbs Tonight
description: Mike Tyson, who has not fought overseas since he was an amateur, defends his world heavyweight championship against Tony Tubbs tonight in Tokyo.

title:
FOCUS: Monterey;
Safeguards For a Land Of Beauty
description: LEAD: IN the late 1950's, when Bruna Odello and her family first contemplated development of part of their 284-acre artichoke farm at the mouth of the Carmel River, they envisioned 1,844 single-family homes on 134 acres. The remaining acreage would stay as farmland.

title: Drop in Pupils Forces Choices
description: FOR the last decade, public school districts throughout New York State have been forced by declining enrollment to make important decisions that will affect the future of their students, faculty and educational programs.

title: PORTUGUESE SINCE HENRY THE NAVIGATOR
description: THE dot that represents Madeira on world maps lies roughly at the level of Casablanca in the Atlantic Ocean, a half-inch or so off Morocco. Close inspection transforms the dot into a sunny, colorful little volcanic archipelago 340 miles from the African coast, composed of one main island called Madeira, high and green, another small sandier one, Porto Santo, which serves mainly as a beach resort, and several uninhabited bits of rock, the Desertas, which float attractively on Madeira's horizon and offer tourists on day cruises a chance to explore, and the more distant Selvagens.

title: The Quality of Life For the Disabled Must Be Improved
description: THOSE of us fortunate enough to live our lives without physical disability - to rush off to work, hurry home, shop, play - seldom wonder what life would be like if confined to a wheelchair, on crutches or having to cope with some other handicap.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: On Foot in a London Village
description: WHAT we call London is really composed of many separate villages whose names often indicate their origins: Covent Garden was the market garden to the Convent of Westminster Abbey, and the Knightsbridge section grew up beside a bridge that crossed the Westbourne River where Hyde Park's Albert Gate stands today. Similarly, the village of Clerkenwell, a half-square-mile area just west of the old City of London, took its name from a well, where in the 14th century the Worshipful Company of Parish Clerks, a guild of men who assisted parish priests, performed annual mystery plays.

title: TALKING: Professionals; Conversion Rights Are Confusing
description: PHYSICIANS, dentists and other professionals with offices in residential buildings in New York City are usually in an ambiguous situation when the buildings face cooperative or condominium conversion.

title: What Hath Norrington Wrought?
description: Classical music-lovers should be amply familiar by this time with the name of Roger Norrington, the English specialist in the period performance of 19th-century music. Mr. Norrington's Beethoven symphony recordings have been almost universally admired, and his recent Berlioz weekend in London's Queen Elizabeth Hall, capped by ''authentic'' accounts of the ''Symphonie Fantastique'' and ''Romeo et Juliette,'' were almost more revelatory than his Beethoven. Avid collectors of radio tapes are already exchanging copies of the BBC broadcast of the performances, and EMI has now recorded the ''Fantastique.''

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: The Mets shouldn't handle Strawberry; he should be traded to an American League team for a premier left-handed reliever and, hopefully, a young catching prospect. CARL PRINCE New York

title: For Devotees of Dumplings
description: THE Long Island Seafood Dumpling House in the Merrick Mall Plaza is a restaurant in transition. When first visited, it had a sign outside that said East West Cafe, and so did the menu. The staff answered the phone with ''Good evening, East West Cafe.'' Since December, the restaurant has been operated by the Queens Dumpling House of Rego Park. The new name, sign and menus should be in place by the end of this month.

title: McCarter: Spotlight On Freud
description: ''IS THIS going to be a war?'' the 18-year-old woman asks the psychoanalyst who is out to get at her innermost secrets and get out the truth behind her neurosis, while she challenges him every step of the way.

title: Bugs of California
description: To the Editor:

title: London Terrace
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW LENNON MYSTERY TOUR
description: When John Lennon was assassinated on Dec. 8, 1980, it seemed that a particularly vivid chapter in the history of popular music had come to an abrupt end. Of course, in the most literal sense, it had: Lennon's ''approved'' creative works - his contributions to the Beatles catalogue, his post-Beatles solo disks, the handful of songs he wrote for other performers, his two books of humorous poetry and short stories, and a number of artworks, films and video productions - would have to stand as a definitive and finite record of the material he considered ready for release.

title: Cynthia Goodwin Weds
description: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Cynthia Ann Goodwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alton B. Goodwin of Wellesley Hills, Mass., to Timothy Francis Byrnes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Byrnes of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Damian O'Connell officiated. Mrs. Byrnes is the travel and finance advertising sales manager for Vanity Fair magazine. She and her husband, a senior sales representative for the Harris Corporation, a communications products concern, are graduates of Stonehill College in North Easton, Mass.

title: THE REWARDS OF GRANDCHILDREN
description: I feel sorry for Carol Reiman. In her essay (''Baby-Sitting Grandchildren: Love Them and Leave Them,'' Opinion page, Feb. 28), she announced that she did not want to baby-sit her grandsons. Simply put, it exhausted her.

title: Review/Opera; CAST CHANGEOVER IN MET'S 'KHOVANSCHINA'
description: The cast for the Metropolitan Opera's production of Mussorgsky's ''Khovanshchina'' Thursday night included a number of singers who hadn't appeared in the season's first performance. Chief among them was Paul Plishka, singing his first Dosifei with the company.

title: Saving a Study to Save the Sound
description: MEMBERS of Congress, trying to keep a cleanup study of Long Island Sound moving at full speed, have begun fighting a Reagan Administration proposal to cut the Federal estuary program by $2.5 million in 1989.

title:
GARDENING;
For Some, a Rose Is a Rose Is a Salad
description: LEAD: WHEN someone says, ''I love flowers,'' he may be talking about them as food. Flowers are increasingly appearing in dishes prepared by chefs from coast to coast. They are used for hors d'oeuvres, tossed in salads, fried in batter, added to soups and used to garnish meats and desserts.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Knoxville, Tenn.;
Mobile Homes: No Showplace
description: LEAD: A LOCAL manufacturer is still reeling from the shock of the rejection by the Knox County Commission of its proposal to build 225 mobile homes on 50 acres, with tennis courts, a swimming pool and other amenities.

title: Talking Heads Confronts the Modern World
description: The world rushes in to the new Talking Heads album, ''Naked'' (Sire 25654 LP, cassette and CD) - and the results are marvelous. After a pair of disappointing albums and nearly two years of splinter projects, Talking Heads have regrouped for an album recorded in Paris with American, African, British, Irish and Caribbean musicians. In songs that touch on politics, commerce, utopia, sex and death - nothing trivial - Talking Heads have unveiled grooves and strategies that other bands will ponder and plunder well into the 1990's.

title: U.S. Indicts Co-Founder of an Irradiation Concern
description: The former chief executive officer and co-founder of Radiation Technology Inc., an irradiation company, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and violations of the Atomic Energy Act.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Jan. 24 with an article about Antigua, Guatemala, misstated the market days for the town of Chichicastenango. They are Thursday and Sunday. A brief accompanying report described Antigua's bus services incorrectly. The Greyhound company does not operate in Guatemala.

title: Toward a World Economy
description: 'I am very little concerned about the issue of foreign investment in the United States. On the contrary, integration of world economies is a desirable trend.

title: U.A.W. Members Back Pact At Mazda Plant in Michigan
description: Union workers at the only United States automobile assembly plant operated by the Mazda Motor Corporation have ratified a contract with the Japanese concern.

title: LONG ISLAND FOLLOW-UP
description: Castle in Court DEALING a stiff financial blow to Southampton Village, a Federal jury in Brooklyn has awarded Barry Trupin $1.9 million in damages because village officials denied his civil rights when they halted construction of his dream castle by the sea.

title: INSIDE
description: Before the Vote, Violence

title: Correction
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about a training program for generals in the United States Army misidentified a National Guard division involved in a battle simulation at Fort Leavenworth, Kan. It was the 47th Infantry Division.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: McFarlane Praised, Congress Blamed
description: LEAD: The independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh has now taken action on the Iran-contra case. A grand jury has charged Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and the former national security adviser John M. Poindexter with conspiring to defraud the Government. Their cases have yet to be adjudicated. But even before the indictments, a third former White House official, Robert C.

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Trade him to the Yankees for Dave Winfield. Boss George will revel in an unending supply of the kind of headlines he loves and the Mets will gain a multitalented gentleman with maturity, dignity and class. DIANE COFFIELD Great Neck, L.I.

title: THE LITTLE NETWORK THAT COULD
description: LEAD: WHEN THE MOVERS AND shakers at the news divisions of ABC, CBS and NBC converge on Atlanta for the Democratic National Convention in July, they will see something they are not apt to like.

title: Help From the 'Hidden Persuaders'
description: THE year was 1956. The movie was ''Picnic.'' And at a New Jersey drive-in theater, according to legend, an invisible message flashed across the silver screen every 32 seconds: ''Eat popcorn. Drink Coke.'' The concession stand reportedly filled with hungry patrons, and subliminal messages were declared a box-office success.

title: What Killed Oscar Wilde?
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Experience and Hope for U.S. Inner Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Trade Strawberry to Houston and bring Nolan Ryan back to New York. JOE LANDI New York

title: Mets' Backman Out of Position
description: Whatever happened to Wally Backman, the prize pupil, the tough little second baseman for the Mets who reminded Dave Johnson of himself as a tough little second baseman?

title: Peugeot Alive and Going Global
description: WHEN Jacques Calvet, chairman of the Peugeot automobile group, joined the company in 1982, it was in shambles. It lost $300 million that year, its market share in Europe was plummeting and many analysts said bankruptcy was just around the corner.

title: Cologne
description: To the Editor: As a repeat visitor to Cologne, I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Cologne'' by John Dornberg (Travel, Jan. 31) and learned about a few more places to visit.

title: L.I. Awaits More Reverse Commuters
description: EVERY MORNING, when the tide of commuters moves westward from Long Island to New York City, Bill Merritt catches the 7:44 at Pennsylvania Station and rides the Long Island Rail Road east to Hicksville, where he is a lawyer for Lilco.

title: The Environment
description: LEAD: WITH its latest proposal for cleaning up areas contaminated by the Lipari Landfill in Pitman, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency has finally won over local residents in that Gloucester County community.

title: New Offensive on Lyme Disease
description: HEALTH and science groups will mount a major offensive against Lyme disease over the next few weeks, in hopes of gaining some measure of control over the tiny tick that causes the trouble.

title: Gorbachev's Flexibility Abroad Buys Time Back Home
description: THE setting is Washington and the subject Soviet-American relations, but when the Soviet Foreign Minister calls on Reagan Administration officials this week the domestic political fortunes of his country's leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, will be inextricably linked to the talks.

title: Comings and Goings
description: At the age of 32, Ingemar Stenmark may not be over the hill, but when you get that old in world-class skiing, it's an understandable impulse to wait until one season is over before deciding whether to compete in the next one. Stenmark said he planned to do just that, except for one thing: ''Winning another race will make it hard for me to retire. Then I'll know I still belong among the top skiers.'' . . . Dale Mohorcic, the right-handed reliever who led the Texas Rangers with 16 saves last season, will undergo elbow surgery tomorrow and will be out about six weeks, according to the team physician, Dr. Mike Mycoskie. . . . Glenn Hubbard, the Oakland Athletics' second baseman who was hit in the face by a pitch last week, will undergo surgery to repair multiple fractures in his left cheekbone and will be sidelined three to four weeks.(AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about fast food restaurants misstated the time period for Kentucky Fried Chicken's financial turnaround. The company was financially sound by 1980, and in good shape when Pepsico bought it in 1986. No cash infusions were needed.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Let Them Use Cloth - Diapers

title: Governor's Reformist Image May Hinge on Party Dispute
description: A simmering dispute here over leadership of the state's Democratic Party is threatening to tarnish the progressive and reformist image of Gov. Ray Mabus by raising the specter of racial politics three months after he took office.

title: N. M. Beretta to Wed Donna Ann D'Onofrio
description: The engagement of Donna Ann D'Onofrio to Norman Morse Beretta, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Beretta Jr. of Jamestown, R.I., has been made known by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. D'Onofrio of Wilton, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: FOR SPRING ... KEEP IT SIMPLE, KEEP IT EASY
description: As spring rounds the corner, even the most buttoned-up dressers tend to relax, shedding their inhibitions with their heavy winter wraps. In the spring of 1988, that easygoing attitude will be embodied in loose-fitting, uncomplicated fashions that are certain to make last year's showy plumage seem as dated as a Nehru jacket.

title: Ceramics: Expression Through Color
