description: COLOR is said to be the most complex, yet the most exciting, aspect of design. In painting, color is both fact and illusion.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: REDCOAT. By Bernard Cornwell. (Viking, $18.95.) When Benjamin Franklin was asked in Paris to confirm reports that General Howe had taken Philadelphia, he murmured slyly that it would be more accurate to say Philadelphia had taken General Howe. The complaisant British commander, as portrayed in this blood-soaked costume drama by the best-selling British writer Bernard Cornwell, spends the winter of 1777-78 ensconced in the rebel capital with his

title: In Belfast, Death, Too, Is Diminished by Death
description: BEYOND the coffin, out in the churchyard, red-haired Kathleen Quinn was full of fun and flirting shamelessly for all her eight years of life. ''Mister, I'm to be on the TV tonight,'' she told a stranger, squinting up happy and prim. Kathleen had taken her brother's bike and skinned her knee bloody, all while people were praying goodbye inside the church to another rebel body in another coffin.

title: Riches Abound in 'The Woods'
description: While immersed last week in the magnificent original cast recording of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine's fairy-tale musical, ''Into the Woods'' (RCA Victor 6796-2RC; all three formats), I was reminded of how crucial a cast album can be to the future reputation of a show. If the score is first rate and the performances finely tuned, no matter what a show's short-term commercial fate, its cast album will keep the music circulating and win for it future champions who may never have seen it produced.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: L. RON HUBBARD: Messiah or Madman? By Bent Corydon and L. Ron Hubbard Jr. (Lyle Stuart, $20.) The Church of Scientology is a bizarre cult, and its founder and leader, L. Ron Hubbard, was a ''cosmic outlaw,'' in the words of L. Ron Hubbard Jr. There is little of the son in this book but a good deal of Bent Corydon, who headed one of the Scientology ''missions'' in California during the 1970's until Hubbard decided to take over these lucrative franchises, leaving their well-rewarded leaders bewildered and broke. This book, supposedly a biography of Hubbard (who died in 1986), turns out to be a series of tales about naive people who were put through abusive tests before they were allowed to pay thousands of dollars to an organization that humiliated them. Mr. Corydon does little to explain why he remained attached to a group that fed its members scraps and hurt him beyond measure. Hubbard, who gained worldwide prominence with his book ''Dianetics'' (1950), is portrayed as a greedy, vindictive man whose hidden agenda centered on hoarding vast sums of money and escaping legal accountability. In recent years, the church has agreed to pay millions of dollars to former members who claimed they had been defrauded. Mr. Corydon draws heavily on the court documents. His interviews, while offering a good deal of color, are often disjointed. The church is a strenuous litigator: the publisher says several lawsuits were undertaken to delay or suppress the distribution of the book. And L. Ron Hubbard Jr., as part of the settlement of his own claim against his father's estate, tried to have his name removed from it.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TALES OF GOLD. By Lewis H. Carlson and John J. Fogarty. (Contemporary Books, $25.) This book by Lewis H. Carlson, a professor of humanities at Western Michigan University, and John J. Fogarty, an associate professor of English at Ferris State College in Michigan, is an oral history of the last 15 Summer Olympic Games. The authors interviewed 58 American gold medal winners, whose revealing stories cover everything from training techniques to politics to the major personalities of the Olympics. Raymond Barbuti, a track star at the 1928 Amsterdam Games, remembers being ''pretty well crocked'' during a confrontation with Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the American team leader. Hours before, Barbuti had won the 400-meter dash and went out to celebrate, only to learn later that MacArthur wanted him on the 1,600-meter relay team the next day. Barbuti refused at first, because it meant replacing someone else. MacArthur, of course, prevailed, and the team won another gold. Helen Stephens, who won two gold medals in track at the 1936 Berlin Games, tells of her meeting with Adolf Hitler. He gave her ''a little Nazi salute, and I thought, 'I'm not going to salute you.' So I extended my hand and gave him a good ol' Missouri handshake.'' The athletes naturally deplore the intrusive politics that threaten the Games, and some of them have harsh words for Olympic officials. All that is forgotten, though, when they talk about the specialness of winning a gold medal.

title: Albert York Abides in His World With Grand Aloofness
description: Albert York is a strange case. This reclusive painter of deliberate, dreamlike landscapes, still lifes and portraits was born in Detroit in 1928. He went to art school in Canada and Michigan. He moved to New York City in the early 1960's and studied briefly with Raphael Soyer. He has lived for more than 20 years on the east end of Long Island, where he has witnessed more than his share of development and change. Not much more is known about him.

title: Weed-Gobbling Fish To Be Stocked in Ponds
description: THIS year, for the first time, a fish known as the Amur, or grass carp, will be permitted in some Connecticut ponds.

title: Linda Burns Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold I. Burns of Washington and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Susan Burns, to Narses Jose Colmenares, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Colmenares Azuaje of Caracas, Venezuela. The couple plan to marry in July.

title: Nunn Stops Parker
description: Michael Nunn used to be maligned as a fighter who danced. Tonight, he was a dancer who punched.

title: Rhode Island Bounces Syracuse, 97-94
description: The Running Rams of Rhode Island came into their first National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in a decade believing they could run with anybody. After a desperation 3-pointer by Earl Duncan, the Syracuse guard, bounced off the rim at the buzzer today, the East Regional's 11th-seeded team had proven it did indeed belong among the nation's elite.

title: Presidential Obsession
description: THe President who sent the Marines to Lebanon on a mission without a purpose has now sent 3,000 American soldiers to Honduras. Once again their mission is unclear. Once again professional military people are troubled.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WHITNEY MUSEUM OF ART IN STAMFORD;
Trying to Stir a Passion for Art
description: LEAD: WHEN a branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art opened in Stamford in 1981, it was the first time a major New York museum was establishing a suburban satellite.

title: BEYOND INSULIN
description: INSULIN INJECTIONS, SCIENTISTS HAVE LONG known, are merely a way to manage diabetes - not cure it. Diabetics no longer die of comas induced by excessive blood sugar. But they do die, before their time, of a range of complications directly related to the hour-to-hour fluctuations of blood sugar, or glucose, that persist even with insulin therapy. Virtually all diabetics, within 15 or 20 years of diagnosis, begin to develop complications of the circulatory and nervous system. Insulin shots can keep a diabetic's blood glucose within a normal range, but they cannot replace the lost cells of the pancreas, the beta cells, that in healthy individuals secrete the hormone insulin in precisely needed bursts.

title: More Dollars Equal Less Message
description: I HAVE been an advertising writer for 27 years. I've written ads for everything from automobiles and airlines to ham and cheese. For many of those years, I've written commercials that helped put people in public office. I've stopped, as have a number of my colleagues, even though poltical advertising is a very profitable part of our business.

title: 'Home' to Africa
description: To the Editor: Regarding Steven Barboza's article ''Going 'Home' to Africa'' (Travel, Feb. 21): His reference to Goree Island evokes a haunting, devastating experience. We -my husband and I - were there 10 or 11 years ago when visiting our daughter, then a Peace Corps volunteer in Senegal. The the slave house, the inscriptions on the walls, that flat rock from which the enslaved took their last step out of Africa are all indelibly incised in my memory. It's impossible not to be moved to tears (a hackneyed phrase but literally - and physically - apt here). This overwhelming reaction of disbelief of a tragic reality must be what overcomes visitors to Holocaust extermination camps. Human cruelty seems to have - and have had - no bounds in time or place.

title: THREE ETERNAL HOURS
description: GETTYSBURG The Second Day. By Harry W. Pfanz. Illustrated. 601 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press. $34.95.

title: A River Route To Budapest
description: FOR much of its length between West Germany's Black Forest and the Black Sea, the Danube is a waterway for sturdy freight barges. The swift flow of the river, one of the world's fastest commercial waterways, deters leisurely boating. Dams and locks help control flow and aid navigation on a river that is shallow, quirky and full of character and vitality. The Donauprinzessin, or Danube Princess, built in 1983, was especially engineered to cope with those quirks. Her equipment includes a tetrahedral rudder, bow thruster, two river radar systems and a stern as well as bow anchor, and so well insulated are the two 998-horsepower diesel engines that the ship's passage at about 14 miles an hour seems virtually silent.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: LESLIE N. COREY;
'Preserving Land Provides a Balance'
description: LEAD: AS Connecticut's landscape continues to give way to development, Leslie N. Corey, the executive director of the state chapter of the Nature Conservancy, an environonmental organization, is concerned that the effect will be a ''permanent loss of the state's character.''

title: Daphne Moore To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Daphne d'Aubigny Moore to Douglas Andrew Butler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Butler of Orange, Calif., has been announced by her parents, Kathleen Roe Moore and John C. Moore, both of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Artist Makes Quilts of Paper Squares
description: LEAD: WHILE studying for her master of fine arts degree at Pratt Institute, Mellie Cooper explored ways of abandoning old forms of expression for new ones.

title: Review/Opera; NEW 'HOFFMANN' CAST
description: There were five newcomers Wednesday night in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Contes d'Hoffmann'' cast, but the most striking was a familiar face: Placido Domingo in the title role. Hoffmann surely counts among the celebrated tenor's best parts. It suits his voice admirably, and he invests the acting with all his considerable intelligence. For him to make the ultimate poetic effect, perhaps a more carefully rehearsed production in a more intimate theater would be necessary.

title: The Extension Ladder
description: LIKE it or not, ladders are indispensable when working on a home's exterior.

title: U.S. LIMITS ITS AID TO HONDURAN ARMY
description: The Reagan Administration, wary of a possible political backlash on Capitol Hill, has rejected a proposal to use American helicopters to transport Honduran troops to the battle zone where Sandinista forces have been fighting rebels, a senior Administration official said today.

title: 'Mrs. Warren' Sparkles Anew
description: THE Long Island Stage Company has been facing severe financial problems recently.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Stakeout Starring Richard Dreyfuss, Emilio Estevez, Madeleine Stowe, Aidan Quinn. Directed by John Badham. 1987. Touchstone. 117 minutes. $89.95. Rated R.

title: Special Today; Men's Fashions/Magazine, Part 2.
description: Keep it simple, keep it easy.

title: John B. Winston Wed To Lisa Joy Lockwood
description: Lisa Joy Lockwood, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Lockwood of North Woodmere, L.I., and John Bruce Winston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Winston of Havertown, Pa., were married last evening. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Review/Jazz; TERRY WALDO'S MANY MOODS
description: Terry Waldo, a pianist and singer with a rich repertory of jazz and popular material ranging from the days of ragtime to the swing era, is at the Fortune Garden Pavilion leading a group as deeply involved in this music as he is.

title: OF A CERTAIN AGE
description: THE MERE MENTION OF A WOMAN'S AGE once sent shudders rippling through polite society. The same was true in cosmetics advertising, with copywriters delicately discussing youthfulness instead. Today, as more women boast of their advancing years, cosmetics companies are tackling the subject with vigor and enthusiasm.

title: Miss Vogliano to Wed Thomas A. Goodman
description: A June wedding is planned by Marie Jean Vogliano and Thomas Andrew Goodman, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Vogliano of New York and Eatons Neck, L.I., have announced. Mr. Goodman is the son of Reynold H. Goodman of Stuart, Fla., and Betty S. Goodman of Hartsdale, N.Y.

title: Barcelona
description: To the Editor: In response to a letter (Travel, Feb. 7), Paul Delaney said he did not recommend the Hotel Colon in Barcelona because, among other things, the linens were not changed every day. I've never understood this complaint, which I've heard many times from travelers. How many of us at home have our bed linens changed daily? I know I don't. MORTON I. MOSKOWITZ Brooklyn

title: Review/Folk; Wolfe Tones, From Ireland
description: Militant Irish nationalism kindles the music of the Wolfe Tones, who played for a boisterously adoring audience Thursday at the Ritz. Rough-hewn traditionalist songs, many with explicit pro-Irish Republican Army and anti-English lyrics, have made the group hugely popular in Ireland.

title: Tracking the Changing Landscape
description: SHELL GATHERER, high upon a hill, peered down at his fellow tribesmen setting traps and fishing in the wetlands marshes of Mamaroneck Harbor. It was the early 1600's, and life was good and game was plentiful for his fellow Siwanoy Indians, who with the Wequasgeeks had hunted much of what is now Westchester and the Bronx for 8,000 years.

title: Macy's Agrees to Sell 11 A.&S. Stores If It Succeeds in Acquiring Federated
description: Executives of R. H. Macy & Company said yesterday that they would sell 11 of the 14 Abraham & Straus stores in New York and New Jersey if their concern succeeds in acquiring the corporate parent of A.& S., Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Senate Mulls Excusing Nuclear Utilities' Debts
description: In an attempt to salvage the faltering United States uranium industry, a bill that would forgive payment of $8.8 billion owed the Government by the nuclear utility industry is expected to reach the Senate floor next week.

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Give Strawberry a break. The Mets shouldn't ''handle'' him at all; they should leave him alone. If I were managing the Mets, I'd put Strawberry in the cleanup spot, day in and day out, night after night. TIMOTHY MUSKAT Ithaca, N.Y.

title: About Men/Hers
description: Starting this week, the About Men column will alternate in this space with the Hers column, which used to appear in the Times on Thursdays.

title: A Filtered Portrait of Lincoln Comes to the Small Screen
description: On April 4, 1865 - 123 years ago, almost to the day - Abraham Lincoln visited Richmond, for the only time. The very morning after the Confederate capital fell to his Union forces, Lincoln walked, unannounced, into the heart of the city. To his surprise the newly freed black population turned out to greet him with ''wild, indescribable, ecstatic joy,'' in the words of one contemporary journalist. Some white residents, however, shut themselves inside their homes, glowering at the scene through drawn curtains, ''as if it was a disgusting sight.'' Ten days later, in Washington, a Southern sympathizer assassinated the President.

title: A Triumph Victory for Hjartarson
description: THE 25-year-old Icelandic grandmaster Johann Hjartarson achieved the triumph of his career by defeating the former Soviet - now Swiss - grandmaster Viktor Korchnoi in their preliminary world championship candidates match in Saint John, New Brunswick.

title: Hearings Continue on Plans To Raise NJ Transit Fares
description: LEAD: THE PROPOSAL by NJ Transit to raise bus and railroad fares statewide will be brought before the public this week as the agency's series of 14 public hearings continues tomorrow and Tuesday.

title: WHAT'S KILLING THE UMPS?
description: IF YOU WERE A BASEBALL PLAYER, THIS MIGHT seem like the Twilight Zone.

title: 'Miss Firecracker' in Fairfield
description: THE Boston Post Road Stage Company is offering a delightful account of ''The Miss Firecracker Contest,'' a funny and touching play by Beth Henley.

title: CLOTHES ATTACHMENTS
description: Ask a man to name his favorite article of clothing, and he probably won't mention his most expensive suit or the elegant tuxedo he wears once a year. More likely, it will be something similar to the designer Bill Blass's old L. L. Bean boots, so comfortable, he says, ''I'll probably be buried in them.'' Or Garrison Keillor's lucky red socks, which, when pulled up, once prevented an airplane from going down - or so the celebrated author believes. It might even be as prosaic as Mayor Koch's 1950's plaid sport coat, which, he says fondly, ''looks like a horse blanket.''

title: Alaska Ferries
description: To the Editor: Regarding the inquiry about Alaska ferries (Q & A, Feb. 21), let me report on my agreeable journey on the Alaska Marine Highway last summer.

title: A Season of Rebirth For the Hudson River
description: THE signs are everywhere. From the gleaming shad massing in the Hudson, to the tiny crocuses crowding Westchester lawns, spring is arriving in the county.

title: THE FIRES OF SPRING
description: JULY MAY MARK THE official beginning of barbecuing season, but those with a passion for grilled foods gladly overlook such formalities. In deep winter, these people can be found scraping the snow from their grills; in spring, they huddle under umbrellas as they cook.

title: ROUTE OF PIPELINE IS REJECTED BY U.S.
description: A proposed 399-mile natural gas pipeline in the Northeast is unacceptable because its route across the Appalachian Trail would create scenic and environmental problems, the Federal Department of the Interior said last week.

title: Bridge Players Linked In a Four-City Hookup
description: Many expert bridge players, and some not so expert, were part of an innovative international hookup at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here this afternoon.

title: CLARK'S EX-MANAGER HAD KIND WORDS
description: Listening to Whitey Herzog, one might get the idea that he misses Jack Clark, even with all of his injuries.

title: A Planner Balances Quantity and Quality
description: FEW people could live on a Long Island devoid of economic activity. More than ever before, communities across the Island, concerned about untethered development, have taken up the tools of community planning to balance economic advances with the quality of life.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NO PLACE LIKE HOUSE
description: LEAD: Philip Langdon's book AMERICAN HOUSES (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95) aims at heightening our ''understanding of today's American houses and how they're changing'' by showing examples of recent domestic architecture from across the country. It contains over 200 stunningly reproduced pictures, as well as a substantial text that provides thumbnail histories of recent trends and touches on such topics as solar energy and construction techniques.

title: Midwest Regional; Purdue Overpowers Memphis State
description: This generation of Purdue Boilermakers had spoken of an invisible but frustrating barrier that stood at the second round of the national collegiate basketball tournament.

title: EUROPE LEARNS TO SHUT THE DOOR
description: A HISTORY OF PRIVATE LIFE Philippe Aries and Georges Duby, general editors. Volume Two: Revelations of the Medieval World. Edited by Georges Duby. Translated by Arthur Goldhammer. Illustrated. 650 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $39.50.

title: Value of EKG for Students Debated
description: MARY JANE PANULLO said that ever since her son, Cary, was given an electrocardiogram last year as part of his high school pre-football physical, she has rested easier.

title: Rock Stars Help AIDS Drive
description: LEAD: KOOL and the Gang, Jellybean, Deju and Southside Johnny already have the ear of New Jersey teen-agers, but now these rock stars have a message that they hope young listeners will take to heart.

title: Teacher Role: Hire New Peers
description: IN a departure from traditional roles in education, the East Williston School District has made selecting new teachers the responsibility of the district teachers themselves.

title: Michael Bresnick Is Wed To Andrea Victoria Cohen
description: The marriage of Andrea Victoria Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cohen of Princeton, N.J., and New York, to Michael Noah Bresnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Bresnick of Riverdale, the Bronx, took place last evening at the Nassau Inn in Princeton. Rabbi Edward Feld officiated.

title: Review/Theater; Peripatetic Double Bill By En Garde Company
description: To be ''site specific'' is to go on location with a play, to take it out of the theater and stage it in a natural environment. In pursuit of that objective, the En Garde Arts company has presented plays in a vacated automobile showroom and, with the help of projections, on the facade of an apartment building.

title: Europeans Agree to Work on U.S. Space Project
description: The European Space Agency has agreed, after two years of negotiations, to take part in the United States space station project and provide a laboratory module to be permanently attached to the earth-orbiting station.

title: Review/Concert; Fischer-Dieskau Returns to New York Stage
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, who had not sung in America since 1980, returned to Carnegie Hall Friday night to sing Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder'' with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London. It was easy for him to renew his bond of communication with this public. Oboe and horn played their brief opening lament; the baritone entered with a quiet reflection that the sun would rise again as though no sorrow had befallen in the night, and instantly we were all in the world of Mahler and Ruckert (the poet) and their close examination of grief.

title: Political Memo; Momentum Eludes Democrats, One by One
description: Whatever happened to momentum?

title: Questions and Answers On Presidential Primary
description: CONNECTICUT will hold its Presidential preference primary March 29. At stake in the voting will be 35 Republican delegates and 52 Democratic delegates to the parties' national conventions this summer. Seven other at-large Democratic delegates - party and elected officials - will be chosen later. As the primary nears, there are questions about who may vote and how to register. Here are some answers prepared by the League of Women Voters in Connecticut:

title: Barbaric Splendor Suited Him
description: THE LIFE OF MY CHOICE By Wilfred Thesiger. Illustrated. 459 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: Fresh, No-Frills Dining in Danbury
description: DINNER at the New England Food Company in Danbury can be a rare gustatory experience, comparable to dining at the home of an exceptionally gifted cook who uses only the best fresh ingredients.

title: Ruling Clouds Inheritance of Rentals
description: THE appellate court decision last month invalidating succession rights in the rent-stabilization system threw into limbo the status of hundreds of thousands of New York City apartment dwellers.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The longer you go after a crash without a downturn, the less it weighs on people's minds.'' - Martin A. Regalia, National Council of Savings Institutions, on the strength in consumer spending.

title: KNICKS STRUGGLE TO SALVAGE VICTORY
description: The Knicks showed again last night that they can't handle big leads.

title: Loudness Isn't Volume
description: Many audio manufacturers conduct training seminars for their dealers to assure that their products are presented in an informed way. At a recent session of this kind, the instructor asked for an explanation of the loudness control.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: UNCOMMON WISDOM: Conversations With Remarkable People. By Fritjof Capra. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) After it was published in 1975, ''The Tao of Physics'' by Fritjof Capra inspired so many imitators that he could be said to have started a genre. By elegantly drawing parallels between the acausal, relativistic world of modern physics and the teachings of Buddhism, Mr. Capra produced an intellectual gem. What made the book so credible was that its author was trained as a physicist. But as he shows in the autobiographical ''Uncommon Wisdom,'' he was never so much a scientist as a devotee of that grab bag of countercultural magic that has come to be called new-age philosophy. It is not clear who would want to read this book, which traces the intellectual origins of Mr. Capra's thought. His tales of hitchhiking through Big Sur, smoking marijuana and discussing the novels of Hermann Hesse have a certain nostalgic charm. And his story of sharing a couple bottles of wine at breakfast with the radical psychotherapist R. D. Laing is priceless. But most of the conversations reported here - be they with Werner Heisenberg, Gregory Bateson, E. F. Schumacher or Indira Gandhi - are more tedious than enlightening. Mr. Capra's ideas are more cogently expressed in ''The Tao of Physics.'' ''Uncommon Wisdom'' reads like an acknowledgments section that wrested control from its author and grew until it took over an entire book.

title: Joan Eagan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Aloysius Eagan Jr. of Wellesley and Hyannis Port, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Eagan to James Andrew Vahey 4th, the son of Mr. Vahey 3d of Rochester, N.H., and Laraine Winders of San Francisco. Miss Eagan, an associate at Chemical Bank in New York, graduated from the University of Virginia. Her fiance graduated from Dartmouth College, where he is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at the Amos Tuck School.

title: Sleepy Hollow Is Still Just a Legend
description: A PROPOSAL to change North Tarrytown's name to Sleepy Hollow was firmly rejected by residents of that village last week by a vote of 1,322 to 794. But proponents of the switch said they were a growing minority and would probably try again.

title: Frederick Loewe Tribute
description: A musical tribute to the composer Frederick Loewe will take place on March 29 at 1 P.M. at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street. Julie Andrews, Richard Harris, Robert Goulet, Louis Jourdan, Agnes de Mille, Kitty Carlisle Hart and others will take part. Mr. Loewe died last month at the age of 86. The event is open to the public.

title: Dr. Hock Marries Dr. Bruce A. Brod
description: Dr. Jennifer Suzanne Hock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Hock of Great Neck, L.I., was married there last evening to Dr. Bruce Alan Brod, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Brod of Broomall, Pa., and Manahawkin, N.J. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Henry Weintraub, officiated at Temple Emanuel.

title: On Giving Toads A Friendly Hand
description: NOT blessed with good looks, toads generally don't have too many friends among people. The Fauna and Flora Preservation Society in London is an exception.

title: 'Rashomon' Returns, Probing Reality Anew
description: ''Rashomon - it's more than just a movie. The word has come into the language now.'' Fay Kanin, the co-author, with her husband, Michael, of a 1959 adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's film, was remarking how deep a note the movie has struck here. The very name, she said, now means any conflicting versions of the same reality.

title: Don't Cry for Argentina's Opera House - But You Might Shed a Tear For the Obelisk
description: In the city of Buenos Aires, where the arts are revered as in few places of the world, the Colon Theater is the most important cultural icon. For 80 years, Argentines have climbed the red carpet of its golden staircase to sit in its glittering splendor and be awed by the best in music, opera and dance. People seeking standing space in the upper rings -affectionately called paradise -often line up for blocks outside the imposing French Renaissance building in the center of the city.

title: Drill Team Puts Rutgers on the Map
description: IN A steamy bubble-domed enclosure on the Busch campus of Rutgers University here, 17 students marched to a rhythm without music, their cadence marked by the click of rifle butts against concrete, the slap of gloved hands against rifle stocks and the whoosh of twirling weapons.

title: Stop the 'Buying of Long Island'
description: AT a period of peak prosperity, Long Island faces many critical issues that must be solved if we are to continue as the jewel of the New York State economy.

title: Gore Campaign Becomes Hopscotch in Search of a Dramatic Showing
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. scored the victories he had hoped for on Super Tuesday, winning five states and propelling himself into the front rank of the Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: THE GUIDE
description: FINE AND FINNISH ''Art by Design: Reflections of Finland,'' an exhibition of contemporary Finnish handcrafts and industrial design, opens at the Katonah Gallery Tuesday and continues through May 15. The exhibition is in collaboration with the Finnish Society of Crafts and Design in Helsinki. Following this showing, the 50 examples of glass, ceramics, wood, brass, textiles and other items will tour museums and design centers in several American cities, celebrating the National Year of Friendship with Finland. A proclamation by President Reagan marks this year as the 350th year since the first Finns settled in the Delaware Valley.

title: Part-Timers Find a Sweet Workplace
description: Ben Strohecker is a chocolate maker with unconventional ideas about running a business.

title: U.N. Unit to Visit Nicaragua To Look Into Border Dispute
description: A United Nations team will visit Nicaragua as soon as possible to investigate the border conflict with Honduras, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sherburne, Vt.;
A Condo Hotel On the Slopes
description: LEAD: THE developers of a new inn near the Killington ski resort believe that as skiers get older they will be looking for luxury on ski vacations, and will spend to get it. That thought has inspired the development of The Inn of the Six Mountains, which is expected to open in May.

title: Animal Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Post Office Acts to Acquire Airport Site
description: LEAD: THE United States Postal Service is well on its way to acquiring the 33 acres adjacent to the Westchester County Airport on which it wants to build a $100 million mail distribution center.

title: Vivian Steir Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Vivian Esther Steir to Dr. Douglas Stuart Rabin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Rabin of West Chester, Pa., has been made known by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Berton Steir of Brookline, Mass. The couple plan to marry in September.

title: DON'T GIVE IN TO THE BAGGY GROWN-UPS
description: THE BEAUTIFUL ROOM IS EMPTY By Edmund White. 228 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Preserving a Tiffany Factory as a Condo
description: LEAD: FOR nearly a century, the Tiffany factory has been a symbol of both the New York jeweler's cachet and Newark's industrial past. Ornamental brickwork, turrets and Normandy towers grace the two-story blocklong structure, which until three years ago housed the company's silverplate manufacturing plant.

title: FATHERS AND SONS ON THE WATERFRONT
description: As administrator of the State Coastal Management Program, I have learned to appreciate the importance of cargo-handling operations to the maritime industry and the state's economy.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: FACEMAKER. By William Katz. (McGraw-Hill, $16.95.) The aristocratically handsome Dr. Andre Laval is the world's foremost cosmetic surgeon. Carly Randall is a magazine writer whose face was demolished when she volunteered to try the escape slide of a new jetliner in connection with an article she was writing.

title: FROESE PRESERVES A VICTORY FOR RANGERS
description: When he was younger, Bob Froese worried about when he would get his next start. He would study the schedule, think he had figured it out, and end up regretting the whole discouraging procedure.

title: TEXANS SEE RAYS OF HOPE IN ECONOMIC CLOUD
description: Like uninvited guests who decide to extend their stay, the headlines throughout Texas have projected a sense of dreary familiarity this week.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
A Sunny Deal For Sansom St.
description: LEAD: AFTER 22 years of debate and planning, a 160,000-square-foot retail and office complex opened last month next to the University of Pennsylvania campus.

title: PRINCE CHARLES RECASTS HIS ROLE
description: Howell Raines describes a friend of Prince Charles, Laurens van der Post, as ''an 80-year-old author and anthropologist, with a New Age mystical streak.''

title:
;
Artist-in-Residence
description: LEAD: IT appears that Noriyoshi Ishigooka, a 60-year-old Japanese artist and art collector, is ready to purchase a 23-room mansion and five-bedroom guest house on 2.65 acres in Bronxville. That means that the property, which some had believed might be bought as a diplomatic residence, will remain on the village tax rolls.

title: THE CONTINUING PASSION FOR PEARLS
description: PEARLS HAVE ALWAYS fueled a panoply of emotions. They have been lusted after and fondled in the names of both propriety and passion. Royalty has always been bedecked with ropes of them, fathers indulge their daughters with them and career women, finding them a luxury within reason, treat themselves to a modest strand or two. Pearls, more than any other kind of jewelry, instantly convey a classy look.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MARCH 20, 1988
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 4 BOUND BY DESIRE, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $4.95.) An untamed rogue pursues a maiden through the romantic spots of 19th- century Mexico, Paris, London and Spain. 3 7 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $4.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple with diverse backgrounds and ambitions. 4 2 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 5 2 TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) From the 50's to the 80's in Thalia, Tex. - a sequel to ''The Last Picture Show.'' 6 4 SANTORINI, by Alistair MacLean. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Nuclear disaster and treachery haunt the crew of a British spy ship patrolling the Aegean. 7 16 THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Bantam, $4.95.) Complex family relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City. 8 8 OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Berkley, $4.95. Tracking down a deadly disease that ophthalmologists pass on to their patients. 9 3 BROTHERS, by William Goldman. (Warner, $4.95.) A series of violent events is part of an international political conspiracy. 10 5 ARIZONA! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $4.50.) A brave band of pioneers confronts the desperadoes who rule the land west of Yuma. 11 19 WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $4.95.) A fairy tale, complete with an aged king, an evil wizard and a mouse. 13 3 GUARDIANS OF THE WEST, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) Kings, sorcerers, gods and men in a 7,000-year war. 14 34 RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $4.95.) Australia's gradual evolution from a penal colony to a flourishing nation. 3 3 THIS 'N THAT, by Bette Davis with Michael Herskowitz. (Berkley, $3.95.) The actress's memories and opinions. 4 230 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Psychological and spiritual inspiration by a psychiatrist. 5 4 THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) Three generations of the Kennedy family. 6 4 HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Fawcett, $4.95.) A White House television correspondent comments on his assignment. 7 14 ELVIS AND ME, by Priscilla Beaulieu Presley with Sandra Harmon. (Berkley, $4.50.) The rock legend as friend, lover, husband and father. 8 56 NECESSARY LOSSES, by Judith Viorst. (Fawcett, $4.95.) Life is a series of losses, the author says, and we must confront them to grow. 9 72 WEST WITH THE NIGHT, by Beryl Markham. (North Point, $12.50.) The ballerina recalls her checkered career. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 43 DIANETICS, by L. Ron Hubbard. (Bridge Publications, $4.95.) Latest edition of a handbook by the founder of Scientology. 2 * 8 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1988 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. 3 * 2 GARFIELD WORLDWIDE, by Jim Davis. (Ballantine, $6.95.) The 15th book of cartoons about a cat. 4 79 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. (Pocket, $4.95.) How to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 5 7 THE ARTHUR YOUNG TAX GUIDE 1988, edited by Peter Bernstein. (Ballantine, $10.95.) The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 retail outlets, including newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets and bookstores. These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Monk Building a Spiritual Refuge for Cambodians
description: When Oung Mean, a Buddhist monk from Cambodia, arrived in the United States in 1978, Cambodian refugees were practicing their faith in makeshift temples scattered around the country.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 94, Bullets 89: Charles Barkley scored 27 points last night in Landover, Md., to lead Philadelphia to its third consecutive victory. The 76ers are a half-game ahead of the Bullets and the Knicks in the race for the final playoff berth in the East. Washington led, 80-76, after Jeff Malone's jumper with 7:43 remaining but did not score again until John Williams hit at 3:32.(AP) Tennis Mandlikova Upset: Hana Mandlikova was upset yesterday at the Lipton International Players Championships by Sabine Auer, ranked No. 289, in a match that ended with Mandlikova angrily hitting a ball at a lineswoman. Auer, a 21-year-old West German with a stinging forehand, survived five match points in the second set to advance to the fourth round, 4-6, 7-6, 7-5. The tiebreaker score was 7-3. With the score 5-5 in the last set, the fourth-seeded Mandlikova became incensed when Dessie Samuels ruled that an Auer shot had caught the baseline. (AP) Skiing Tomba Edges American: Alberto Tomba of Italy edged Felix McGrath of Norwich, Vt., by 22-hundredths of a second in a World Cup slalom race in Are, Sweden, and took a 13-point lead in the overall standing. It was the fifth slalom triumph of the season for the Italian and his eighth World Cup victory of the Alpine ski season. Tomba was fifth after the opening 57-gate run. He had runs of 49.90 and 51.51 seconds for a combined time of 1:41.41. The 24-year-old McGrath, in his fifth season on the United States Ski Team, clocked 1:41.63. Tomba leads Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, 249-236, going into today's downhill.(AP) N.H.L. Penguins 7, Flyers 0: In Pittsburgh, Zarley Zalapski scored his first goal and had three assists, and Steve Guenette stopped 38 shots for his first shutout to help deal the Flyers their fifth straight loss. The streak is Philadelphia's longest since the Flyers lost five from Dec. 26, 1970, to Jan. 3, 1971. Pittsburgh remained 1 point behind the Rangers in the race for the final playoff spot in the Patrick Division.(AP) Bowling Fallgren Breaks Dry Spell: Palmer Fallgren captured his first Professional Bowlers Association title in eight years by beating Don Genalo in the title game in the King Louie Open in Overland Park, Kan. Fallgren earned his third career championship by beating Genalo, 226-210. Genalo had eliminated Leroy Bornhop, 234-223, in the semifinal. (AP) Curling U.S. Men's Champions Selected: Washington defeated New Jersey, 7-3, to win the United States championship and advance to the world championship in Lausanne, Switzerland. Washington, representing the Granite Curling Club of Seattle, posted a 12-1 record in the six-day tournament at the St. Paul Curling Club.(AP) Fencing American Advances in Saber: Michael Lofton of Hempstead, L.I., a four-time National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, was the only American to reach the direct elimination round of 32 yesterday in the Enterprise Press World Cup International. The Olympic preview in saber competition began at New York University's Coles Sports Center with 139 entrants from 18 countries. After preliminary rounds, the leading fencers were Bence Szabo of Hungary, Grigory Kirienko of the Soviet Union and Jean-Francois Lamour of France, the 1987 world champion. Golf Davies Ahead by 2: Laura Davies shot a three-under-par 69-206 and took advantage of Robin Walton's problems on the back nine to take a two-shot lead after yesterday's third round of the L.P.G.A. Tucson Open. Davies, a rookie from England and the first-round leader, regained the lead when Walton, the second-round leader, took a bogey-6 on the 13th hole. (AP) High School Basketball Tolentine Wins: St. Nicholas of Tolentine (28-1) defeated Holy Trinity (13-13) of Hicksville, L.I., 70-53, last night for the New York State Catholic A Championship. Tom Schneider, the Holy Trinity center, had a game-high 17 points. Malik Sealy had 16 to help Tolentine to its 20th straight victory. Tolentine will next play Friday in the state federation championships in Glens Falls, N.Y. Its opponent will be Lincoln (24-0) of Brooklyn or Adlai Stevenson (21-4) of the Bronx, which play today for the Public Schools Athletic League championship.

title: TAKING A BITE OUT OF THE BIGGEST STATE
description: At first glance, Alaska seems a bit overwhelming as a vacation site. The 49th state is a fifth the size of the continental United States, and one of its 5,000 glaciers is larger than Rhode Island. But Alaska can be toured on a cruise ship or by rail, plane and ferry. Getting There

title: Chambers Jury Revisits Scene of Levin's Death
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. secretly went to Central Park yesterday morning to visit for a second time the site of Jennifer Levin's death.

title: Precocious
description: WISH YOU WERE HERE Starring Emily Lloyd (in photo), Geoffrey Hutchins, Tom Bell, Jesse Birdsall, Heathcote Williams. Directed by David Leland. 1987. Fries Home Video. 91 minutes. $79.95. Rated R.

title: FATHERS AND SONS ON THE WATERFRONT
description: Anthony DePalma's moving article ''From Fathers to Sons on the Waterfront'' (Feb. 21), about the declining waterfront industry, presents a human dimension that has been largely invisible to the public.

title: The Incredible I.R.A. Withdrawal Game
description: THE Internal Revenue Service has an April Fool's gift for some taxpayers: new rules dictating how much must be withdrawn from individual retirement accounts by April 1 to avoid a stiff penalty.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: JULIETTE. By Michel Goeldlin. Translated by Heather Parker. (Ragweed Press, Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, $12.95.) Michel Goeldlin is a Swiss author whose novels, according to his publisher, have all been inspired by actual experiences. ''Juliette'' (the third of six, the first to be translated from French into English) is an account of a young woman's psychoanalysis.

title: Group for Women Who Know Their Business
description: LEAD: WHEN Fletcher Associates, a New Haven public relations firm, passed its five-year anniversary, its owner, Nancy Fletcher, decided to find out more about other businesses in the state owned by women.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
4th Golf Development for Westchester
description: LEAD: SPORTS enthusiasts and others seeking to live on the grounds of an active Westchester golf course are about to get a foursome in Westchester County, where there are now three such developments either in progress or planned.

title: WEE PRISONS
description: GREYHOUND FOR BREAKFAST By James Kelman. 230 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15.95.

title: Pain Lingers At City College
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Aftereffects of the Baby M Case
description: MEMBERS of the New Jersey Supreme Court are to be congratulated for the depth and comprehensive nature of their judgment in the Baby M case. However, the complexities of the issues are such that they are likely to defy resolution by a single judgment.

title: NORIEGA REBUFFS U.S. ON AN OFFER TO LEAVE PANAMA
description: Rebuffing the Reagan Administration, Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has rejected an American offer to let him leave the country without facing extradition to the United States on drug charges, senior Administration officials said today.

title: GIMMICKS PROMOTE VACCINES IN YOUNG
description: From a drawing to win a car in Chicago to discounts on hamburgers in New Orleans, public health agencies around the nation are seeking innovative ways to persuade parents to bring in their children for vaccines.

title: Cocnern On Funds for Sound
description: MEMBERS of Congress whose districts border on Long Island Sound say they will fight a Reagan Administration proposal that might dilute funding for the three-year-old Federal study of the Sound.

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Considering how the Mets played last year, perhaps the team should listen to Strawberry instead of trying to figure out how to handle him. PETER J. CALLAHAN Newark, Del.

title: For the Small Client, Architectural Flights of Fancy
description: LEAD: WHEN the congregants of St. Matthew's Church in Bedford wanted to do something special this year for their annual fund-raising antiques show, they hit upon an idea that was literally for the birds.

title: A Honeymoon Revisited, With Children
description: I FIRST visited the south of France in 1961. That is more than half my life ago, and I have returned often since. Like so many others, I find myself moved by that landscape - compelled by its long history, dazzled by its light. Some travelers are drawn to mountains, while some prefer valleys instead; for each pilgrim to the desert there is one who dreams of forests; for each lover of the lakefront there is one who wants the river. Some are happiest on oceans, some near ponds. Certain vistas move us; others fade.

title: BOY'S BOOKS: LET SPOT LIVE
description: For Christmas, a (male) friend gave Z our two young sons some pretty authentic-looking handcuffs. They were the hit of the season. I was frankly astonished to see my two little angels arresting each other and goose-stepping around the house. But my husband took it for granted. He said: ''Well, of course. They're boys.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Lake Success
description: LEAD: IT has been 43 years since the United Nations moved its temporary headquarters into the Sperry Gyroscope Company plant in Lake Success, thrusting the village into the international limelight.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland; Reversing Disinvestment
description: WHEN University Circle, a management group, initially agreed with this city in 1974 to lease five acres near Case Western Reserve University, the idea was to create interest in the property among private developers.

title: A Captain's Ideals Lead Him to Jail
description: Meir Amor, a captain in the Israeli reserve army, has just completed a 21-day jail sentence for refusing an order to serve in the occupied territories.

title: Shauna Lev Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Grantham Ballard of Mercer Island, Wash., and Honolulu, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Ballard's daughter, Shauna Marie Lehv, to Frank G. Binswanger 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Binswanger Jr. of Philadelphia. A May wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: A report last Saturday about the marriage of Pamela Lawrence Dempsey to Bruce Jay Charendoff misstated the bride's job title and misidentified the university from which she graduated. She is an assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and a graduate of Duke University.

title: Midwest Regional; UPSET LEAVES VALVANO SAD BUT NOT SURPRISED
description: Before the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Coach Jim Valvano of North Carolina State said that the first game of the postseason was always ''by far'' the most difficult to win. He was right. His Wolfpack, heavily favored to beat Murray State, became one of the biggest upset victims in this season's tournament when they lost, 78-75, in a first-round game Friday.

title: We're Not Out of the Deep Deficit Woods Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: News Companies Faulted for Lack of Blacks
description: Twenty years after the Kerner Commission chastised the press for reporting the news ''with white men's eyes and a white perspective,'' a panel of black journalists said last week that newspapers and broadcasters had failed to recruit enough blacks into the nation's newsrooms.

title: PRINCE CHARLES RECASTS HIS ROLE
description: Prince Charles's influence in matters of architecture and inner-city rehabilitation has been felt here in Brooklyn, where neighborhood preservationists quote the Prince of Wales in speeches opposing high-rise luxury condominiums planned for our beloved shore front.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Mahwah $392,500 4 Willowbrook Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old colonial; library, fireplace in family room; hardwood floors; taxes $3,316. Montville $139,900 136 Change Bridge Road 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 2-year-old town-house condominium; patio, w/w carpeting; monthly maintenance $75, taxes $1,577. Old Bridge $144,900 13 Ridge Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old Cape Cod; den, enclosed patio, carport, w/w carpeting; taxes $2,396. Oradell $274,000 307 Elm Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 38-year-old ranch; fireplace, pool, patio, dining room; taxes $4,242. Springfield $250,000 14 North Derby Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; deck, 1-car attached garage, den, c/a; taxes $3,108. West Orange $225,000 13 Burnett Terrace 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 45-year-old Tudor; fireplace, maid's room, den, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,621. OTHER AREAS New Milford, Conn. $212,500 Sunset Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 16-year-old ranch; stone fireplace, panoramic country views, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,000. Chappaqua, N.Y. $400,000 2 Deborah Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old frame colonial; eat-in kitchen, frontage on pond, 0.92 acre; taxes $7,231. Sound Beach, L.I. $111,500 10 St. James Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath 40-year-old bungalow; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $800.

title: Forgotten In the 'Madness'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: KANSAS CITY
description: Kansas City has some April surprises in store for visitors: After 20,000 or so arrive for the Final Four weekend (April 2 to 4) of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, it will turn its more urbane side to travelers.

title: Dr. Jonas Marries Fellow Physician
description: The marriage of Dr. Elizabeth Ann Jonas, a neurology resident at Yale-New Haven Hospital, and Dr. Thomas David Eisen, a fellow in renal disease at the Yale University School of Medicine, took place last evening at the Parker Meridien in New York.

title: SYSTEM PROPOSED FOR TRANSPLANTS
description: New York State plans to set up a system to coordinate the procurement and distribution of organs and tissue for transplants in an attempt to distribute them among patients fairly, the Health Commissioner has announced.

title: Charisma, Issues and Candidate Dore
description: I can't get excited about any of them. None of them have any charisma. And why won't they talk about the issues?

title: Military's Use of German Cars Is Questioned
description: A House subcommittee has asked Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci to explain reports that American military personnel in West Germany use some German-made cars and buses, contending that doing so ''undermines the American automotive industry.''

title: Clear the Exit From Afghanistan
description: If the Russians sincerely want to get out of Afghanistan, Washington should do everything reasonable to help them to the exit. Now it seems that the U.S. and Pakistan - and perhaps Moscow as well - are trying to gain marginal bargaining advantages and are losing sight of the central goal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 27 about the business of advising parents misidentified the producer and distributor of ''The Children's Journal,'' a radio program. It is produced and distributed by Livy Morris Productions in Cincinnati.

title: East Regional; High-Volume Coaching Spurs Owls and Hoyas
description: As is the case with many coaches, there are similarities in the way John Chaney of Temple and John Thompson of Georgetown go about their jobs, blending the roles of surrogate parent and drill instructor. Thompson jokingly talked today about how he called the Hoya players just about every nasty thing he could think of during the course of the regular season, reaching a point where the players thought they were probably the worst and dumbest team ever to play for him.

title: Street Fashion; A Safe Spot in the Hem Tempest
description: HEMLINES may rise and hemlines may fall, but trouser lengths stay pretty constant, stopping right there at the top of the shoe (or more and more frequently these days, tucking neatly inside a boot). Such comforting reliability may be one reason why so many women are turning to trousers to fill an ever-increasing number of sartorial bills.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Brawley Case of 1753
description: On Jan. 1, 1753, an 18-year-old Londoner named Elizabeth Canning celebrated the New Year at the home of her uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Colley. At 9 that night she left for the home of the Lyon family, where she was a housemaid. The Colleys accompanied her. When they left Elizabeth, she had less than a mile to go.

title: IRRADIATION ARTICLE CALLED MISLEADING
description: The Feb. 14 Opinion Page article by Lee Rothberg against irradiation of food was misleading and mistaken. In her zeal, she performed a disservice by attempting to overwhelm us with facts purporting to prove the process of irradiation inherently hazardous and, therefore, to be banned.

title: Dr. Amy Sherman to Marry Dr. John McCarthy in May
description: Dr. Amy Hope Sherman and Dr. John Gerard McCarthy, physicians at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, plan to marry in May, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Julius H. Sherman of Great Neck, L.I., have announced.

title: August Wedding For Mary Maher
description: The engagement of Mary Frances Maher to Edward Mullins Hawley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hawley of Los Angeles, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Maher of Greenwich, Conn. An August wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
For Some, a Rose Is a Rose Is a Salad
description: LEAD: WHEN someone says, ''I love flowers,'' he may be talking about them as food. Flowers are increasingly appearing in dishes prepared by chefs from coast to coast. They are used for hors d'oeuvres, tossed in salads, fried in batter, added to soups and used to garnish meats and desserts.

title: From Jesuits To Zimbabwe: A Gift of Land
description: In the verdant hills that rise and roll here, and in the rich valley nestled below them, the talk is of return.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Jan. 31, about the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's investigations of possible crimes, reported allegations of wrongdoing at the Joseph M. Farley nuclear power plant in Dothan, Ala. Some charges were made by former employees at the plant who said they were dismissed because they raised safety questions. The plant owner, the Alabama

title: Late Primary Keeps State Role Intact
description: EVER since Southern Democrats agreed to hold all of their Presidential primaries on March 8, political experts have debated whether New Jersey's primary on June 7 - traditionally one of the nation's best-covered elections - would still mean anything.

title: What Killed Oscar Wilde?
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne Cudlip Is Affianced
description: The engagement of Anne Simpson Cudlip to Wilfred Augustine Finnegan 3d, a son of Mrs. John G. Finnegan of Rye, N.Y., and the late Dr. Finnegan, has been announced by Nancy Clapp Cudlip of Waccabuc, N.Y., and William J. Cudlip of Grosse Pointe, Mich., parents of the future bride.

title: Residents Fight Commack Theater
description: LEAD: CITING potentially ''unbearable'' traffic congestion, two civic groups in Commack are fighting a proposal by a developer to build a nine-screen theater at the site of the former drive-in movie theater on Veterans Memorial Highway.

title:
ART;
'Expert Eye' Offers Range of Invention
description: LEAD: WHEN an institution sponsors an open-to-all juried art exhibition, it would seem to be a benign act. The local community gets an opportunity to meet a range of new artists and creative ideas through a potentially dynamic show, and deserving artists have a chance for exposure and recognition. The system even allows the question of who is deserving to be resolved fairly, since a panel of jurors screens each work submitted.

title: Sophocles With a Chorus Of Gospel
description: When ''The Gospel at Colonus'' had its first performance at P.S. 122 on the Lower East Side in 1980, it was a half-hour show with one actor, five singers, two songs by Bob Telson and just the beginnings of writer-director Lee Breuer's central idea: that the essential nature of Greek tragedy could be revealed to modern audiences by presenting Sophocles' ''Oedipus at Colonus'' in the form of a black Pentecostal church service.

title: N.C.A.A. TOURNAMENT: West Regional; SETON HALL CAN STAND ITS GROUND
description: Arizona won't push Seton Hall around on Sunday afternoon.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Princeton Show: Consistently Rewarding
description: LEAD: THE 29th annual Princeton Antiques Bhow and Sale will be held Friday through next Sunday at Princeton Day School on the Great Road. One of the state's oldest such shows, and one of the most beautifully presented, it is consistently rewarding.

title: The Rough Boyhood of the Girl on the Block
description: LAST. Always last. Despite my skills on the baseball diamond, I was mere dross as sides were drawn, unless a dork was the only other live body left.

title: Colleges Are Seeking to Remedy Lag in Their Hispanic Enrollment
description: Hispanic-Americans continue to lag behind other minority groups in entering the mainstream of higher education, a fact that seriously hinders their own economic aspirations as well as the development of the nation's future work force.

title: Bradley Faults Plans For Uncommitted Slate
description: SENATOR Bill Bradley flew up from Washington last week to tell New Jersey Democratic leaders once again that he would not be a candidate for President and to urge them to drop any plans to send an uncommitted slate of delegates to the Democratic National Convention with him as its head.

title: Rutgers Women Advance
description: A crowd of 6,021 gathered at the Rutgers Athletic Center today to bid farewell to Sue Wicks, the Lady Knights' superstar who was playing the final home game of a career unmatched by any player, male or female, in school history.

title: Saudis Deny Their Missiles Will Have Nuclear Warheads
description: Saudi Arabia confirmed Saturday that is is buying Chinese intermediate-range missiles, but said they would not be armed with nuclear warheads.

title: Vaughn Meader's Second Try
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 BRITISH SOLDIERS KILLED AT I.R.A. RITES
description: There was more macabre violence at an Irish Republican Army funeral today as two armed British soldiers in civilian clothes drove their car into a crowd of panicked mourners and were, in turn, seized, beaten and finally shot to death.

title: Defining the Limits In Reagan's Use of Presidential Power
description: ON the same day last week that two of his former top aides were formally charged as criminals for their covert efforts to carry out Administration policy in Central America, Ronald Reagan took one of the most open and public steps available to a President: He ordered American troops to foreign soil.

title: SURE TIPS FOR SHIRTS
description: Jay Gatsby, Fitzgerald's fictional dandy, was the ultimate shirt connoisseur. He had only to ring up his personal buyer, and a cornucopia of elegant linens, silks and flannels would arrive. Most American men, however, buy their dress shirts the way they buy supermarket chicken - with a hasty examination of the parts visible through the plastic wrap and an assumption that what's hidden will be fine. As for quality features, they wouldn't know a gauntlet from a gusset, much less a well-constructed example of each.

title: Coast Ruling Protects Churches in Libel Suits
description: Churches were given increased protection from libel suits when the California Supreme Court ruled against a woman who said she had been defamed by a minister who called her ''one of the enemies of God's church.''

title: THEY WON THEIR LIFE ON THE FOOTBALL POOLS
description: A FRIEND FROM ENGLAND By Anita Brookner. 205 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $15.95.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 3-D ART As contemporary as it may seem, the concept of 3-D images is actually quite ancient. It all began when for the first time an artist tried to simulate the appearance of depth on a flat surface. With ''Seeing Is Believing: The History of 3-D in Art and Popular Culture,'' the Heckscher Museum in Huntington is exploring this cross between artistic endeavor, scientific technology and popular culture. Imported from the Fort Wayne Museum of Art, the show, which the Heckscher director, Christopher Crosman, calls ''quite batty,'' is celebrated today in a special afternoon of family activities: tours of the exhibition, which runs through May 1; a chance to have a 3-D photo made, and ''Performance: The 3-D Show,'' a multimedia presentation that details 150 years of 3-D history in 40 minutes. The program, from 2 to 5 P.M., is free at the museum, on Prime Avenue. 'OUT OF BALANCE'

title: Jill A. Garber to Marry Dr. T. J. Cohen in May
description: Jill Alyssa Garber, a registered nurse at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, and Dr. Todd Jay Cohen, a resident at Mount Sinai Hospital, also in Baltimore, are planning to be married May 29, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Victor Garber of Watchung, N.J., have announced.

title: Norman Pearlstein, an Editor, to Wed Nancy Friday, a Writer, This Summer
description: Nancy Colbert Friday, a writer, and Norman Pearlstine, the managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, are planning to marry this summer, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Scott of Lewiston, N.Y., have announced.

title: Hotels Act to Meet Keener Competition
description: ROOMS, the stock in trade of the hotel industry, have to be sold every day - a feat that becomes increasingly difficult when the supply is increased and the demand reduced. There is concern now that the county's hotel market has too many rooms and too few customers.

title: Headliners; Over Alaska
description: Susan Butcher took her dogs for a run across Alaska March 5. Last Wednesday night, 11 days, 11 hours and 42 minutes after she left Anchorage, Ms. Butcher and her dog team pulled into Nome, 14 hours ahead of her nearest competitor in the 16th annual running of the 1,150-mile Iditarod Trail Dog Sled Race. It was her third consecutive victory in the grueling contest, something no one else has accomplished since the race was first run in 1973.

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: What Darryl Strawberry did in January of this year was no different from what Lee Mazzilli and Wally Backman did in July of last year, or from what Keith Hernandez did in September of 1984. When Strawberry's teammates tell the media that he quit, it's to motivate him; when Strawberry says that his teammates were unmotivated, he's mouthing off, creating distractions. Why the distinction? The Mets should handle Strawberry as they have been: by ignoring him. DAVID SIMONS Westfield, N.J.

title: Performing Arts Centers Vie for State Grants
description: DOZENS of performing arts centers, many in old theaters with leaking roofs, have begun vying for capital-improvement money that will become available in the next year or so from the State Council on the Arts.

title: Yo, Brutus! A Bard for the 80's
description: ''I am no orator, as Brutus is,'' says Al Pacino as Mark Antony, wooing the Roman mob, ''but, as you know me all, a plain blunt man.'' Indeed, prowling a stage at the Public Theater during previews of ''Julius Caesar,'' Mr. Pacino has offered a performance that is a far cry from the conventionally heroic and patrician Mark Antony of Shakespearean tradition. This is a street-wise Antony who brings to his role not only an unrelieved intensity but also the city cadences and South Bronx body language of Mr. Pacino's childhood.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I live in a condominium, and the wall I share with the next unit seems paper-thin. I inquired about having insulation blown in to keep out noise but was told this was impossible because of fire barriers in the wall. Is there a way to soundproof this wall?

title: Cuba Reportedly Gives U.S. Schedule for Angola Pullout
description: Cuba has presented the United States with a proposed timetable for the withdrawal of its nearly 40,000 troops in Angola, the Government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos says.

title: Susan Reynolds Hayum Weds Dr. Scott Haltzman
description: Susan Reynolds Hayum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Walter Hayum of New Paltz, N.Y., and Dr. Scott David Haltzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Haltzman of Emmaus, Pa., were married last evening in Hamden, Conn. Rabbi Herbert Brockman performed the ceremony at Congregation Mishkan Israel.

title:
INVESTING;
Why a Baker Tempts an Analyst
description: LEAD: BRUCE WILLIS of ''Moonlighting'' may only be Philadelphia's second-most-famous export to California. First place probably goes to Tastykake, a line of cupcakes, doughnuts and pies that have been filling Philadelphia lunchboxes since 1914.

title: GUERRILLAS IN SALVADOR STEP UP PRE-ELECTION TERRORISM
description: Stepping up their violent effort to stop national elections here on Sunday, Marxist guerrillas have killed one mayor and kidnapped two others in recent days, burned a mayor's office, exploded several bombs and burned cars, trucks and buses to paralyze road traffic.

title: AN OPPORTUNITY FOR A THIRD PARTY
description: With the campaign between Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and Attorney General Joseph I. Lieberman offering no real differences between a Democratic liberal and Republican one, the voters of Connecticut (overwhelming supporters of Ronald Reagan in both 1980 and 1986) are without a conservative or even centrist alternative.

title: THE REGION: Pro & Con: On Racial Quotas in Housing; On Discrimination in the Cause of Integration
description: ABOUT 55 percent of the 23,000 people who live in Starrett City, a Brooklyn housing complex, are white; the remaining 45 percent are black or Hispanic. The managers of the 46-building complex have kept that balance by giving preference to white applicants, who account for only about one in five on the waiting list. Along with many residents, the management contends that since the motivation is to keep the 6,000-apartment complex integrated, the practice is both ethical and legal.

title: Moscow Chief's Fall: New View of Kremlin Schism
description: During the outburst that cost him his job as Moscow party chief last October, Boris N. Yeltsin accused the No. 2 official in the Communist Party of undermining his Kremlin colleagues, according to an American scholar who has studied the Yeltsin affair.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: A SURVEY OF THE ATLANTIC BEACHES. By Don Hendrie Jr. (Crown, $13.95.) Devereux Hoopes has driven to New England from Alabama to pick up his 16-year-old son, Carl, who has just finished a year at an expensive prep school. Divorced from Carl's mother, Devereux plans to return home with his son to spend the summer with the beauteous Tessa Dixon, but not before making some stops along the way to visit a variety of friends who live on the Atlantic seaboard.

title: Hockey; MERRIMACK SAVED BY 7 STRAIGHT GOALS
description: Merrimack produced a memorable comeback tonight against Northeastern by scoring seven straight goals to defeat the Huskies, 7-3, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

title: Review/Music; Zukerman is Soloist In Bartok Viola Work
description: Deathbed works like Mozart's Requiem leave a few important questions unanswered, but Bartok's Viola Concerto is an almost insoluble bequest. In 1945 Bartok wrote to the work's commissioner, William Primrose, that his concerto was ''ready in draft, so that only the score has to be written, which a means a purely mechanical work.'' Three weeks later the composer was dead of leukemia. One can assume the music was laid out in Bartok's head, but this order translated into chaos in the papers he left behind. Tibor Serly's valiant but always questionable completed version of the Viola Concerto was played by Pinchas Zukerman and the New York Philharmonic Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall. The conductor was Felix Kruglikov. He replaced Klaus Tennstedt, who reportedly injured his arm in a fall.

title: Smoking
description: To the Editor: I concur totally with Mr. Steffens and Mr. Davis about smoking (Letters on Travel, Jan. 24), and I never hesitate to ask smokers to put their cigarettes out if they light up where smoking is prohibited.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 14 about frequent flier programs misstated Pan American World Airways' policy on the types of flights taken before March 31 that would qualify a passenger for triple mileage credits on later flights this year. Shuttle flights are considered qualifying.

title: A Place That Sums Up Alaska
description: IT'S hard to identify one particular place that spells Alaska. The Great Land is so diverse, so vast, that no one city or destination can act as a symbol. Still, after spending a few days in Seward, a frequent visitor to the state is tempted to suggest that this small town on the Kenai Peninsula is a good choice for those wishing to sample ''the real Alaska.''

title: Questioned Blood Units Found Free of AIDS
description: The Red Cross said today that units of blood that slipped through procedures tha guard against AIDS contamination were rendered harmless by processing or never actually carried the deadly virus.

title: THE WORLD: The French Election; Mitterrand Is Counting on A Continued Rift on Right
description: It is seven long and presumably uncertain weeks before the next president of France will be elected. The politician with a commanding lead in the opinion polls, President Francois Mitterrand, has not yet formally declared that he will run for a second term of office. Yet the focus of political discussion in France is not about the campaign but about who will govern with whom after the May 8 election.

title: Miss Van Norden Plans to Be Wed To Craig Wynne
description: Mr. and Mrs. Montagnie Van Norden of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Juliana Van Norden to Craig Donald Wynne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Thomas Wynne Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Vero Beach, Fla. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Tyson: Strong, Silent and Sometimes Scared
description: IN 1982, a film maker named Michael Marton began shooting a documentary on an amateur boxing program in Catskill, N.Y., run by Cus D'Amato, the septuagenerian manager and trainer.

title: Takeovers Ad Infinitum?
description: Merger activity has heated up. With the dollar at its lowest point in years, few restrictions on purchases of American stock and a liberal antitrust climate, investors are rushing to buy American companies. How long will this buying window remain open? J. TOMILSON HILL Managing director and head of mergers and acquisitions, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Cassettes
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's article on the pleasure of listening to cassettes while driving (Practical Traveler, Feb. 7) neglected mentioning an affordable reference guide to thousands of available titles. ''Words on Tape'' at $29.95 lists over 15,000 titles from 435 cassette publishers. Titles are listed by author, title and subject. ''Words on Tape'' is available from Meckler Publishing, 11 Ferry Lane West, Westport, Conn. 06880, and from local booksellers. ALAN MARSHALL MECKLER Westport, Conn.

title: Alice Quinn, Skater, Married to Dr. Craig T. Shelley
description: The marriage of Alice Jean Quinn, a figure skater, to Dr. Craig Thomas Shelley, a visiting fellow in neurology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Sulpice in Paris. Msgr. Joseph Corbineau performed the ceremony.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Designs Have Been Modified for the Olympic Coins
description: LEAD: THE two 1988 United States Olympic coins will depict the five-ring Olympic symbol. For a time, however, it appeared that they might not. In fact, the whole subject had the United States Mint going around in circles.

title: 'I Deserve to Succeed. I Deserve to Reach My Goals. I Deserve to be Rich.'
description: NAME an obsession, a bad habit, a deficiency, or just a stage of life, and chances are some company has a subliminal cassette claiming to ease you through it.

title: 'The Playmaker' Transposed
description: To the Editor:

title: Housewives and Prom Queens, 25 Years Later
description: I find my history in novels - and only after the passage of time. The feminist novel, which flourished in the 1960's and 70's, held more than met the eye of the reader (and writer in some cases) at the time. Concealed within these tales are the seeds of many conflicts that bedevil the womens' movement, and women, today, though even if we had been prescient enough to recognize them then, the issues would have remained stubborn, defiant and perhaps insoluble.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Inclusionary Zoning; New Bonuses Spur Low-Income Units
description: INCLUSIONARY zoning has come to life in Manhattan, cast in a shape that would be hard to imagine outside New York City. By offering builders the ability to generate development rights for market-rate housing, the city has induced the development of mortgage-free housing for low-income families on the Upper West and East Sides.

title: No Castanets, Please, They're Spanish
description: American audiences -and perhaps others, too -often seem to expect Spanish performers of classical music to, somehow, be Spanish, in a way that, say, German or English performers aren't expected to look or act German or English. Despite the dignity and reserved platform manner of such eminent musicians as Pablo Casals, Andres Segovia, Nicanor Zabaleta or Alicia de Larrocha, an outmoded view of Spain persists, a Spain that seems to have something to do with the extravagantly dressed, impassioned performers in ''Carmen'' who attack their instruments with gypsy gusto and abandon.

title: A Portrait of Westchester's Homeless
description: ''AT a hotel for the homeless, a child finds two pigeons. She brings them back to her hotel room. When asked what she will do with them, she says, 'I will release them, so they can find their way home again.' ''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JIMMY D., SIDEWINDER, AND ME By Otto R. Salassi. 150 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 12 and up)

title: This Newcomer Is Disposable
description: I was on my way to the Houston FotoFest, just about to board the shuttle bus to my hotel, when I ran into my friend Elaine. Instead of the Leica M4 she usually wears, she was sporting the latest compact-VHS video camcorder. She had just begun recording her own documentary of the outskirts of Houston when my nose appeared in her finder.

title: MEGA-DEALMAKER: Reginald F. Lewis; Wall Street's New Takeover Star Warms to the Spotlight
description: AT Manhattan's Harvard Club a few weeks ago, some of New York's most prominent blackbusiness leaders and politicians assembled at a fund-raiser for Democratic Presidential candidate Jesse Jackson. The purpose of the gathering was to hear Mr. Jackson discuss his economic policy. But as they sipped champagne and nibbled smoked salmon, many in the crowd of 300 - which included Earl Graves, publisher of Black Enterprise magazine; David Dinkins, Manhattan borough president, and Percy Sutton, chairman of the Inner City Broadcasting Company - seemed at least as eager to hear their host as to listen to the special guest.

title: 6-Year-Old Killed and 3 Are Hurt in Car Accident
description: A 6-year-old boy was killed and three other children were injured in Harlem yesterday when a parked car, struck by another car that had accelerated out of control, careered onto the sidewalk where a group of children were playing, the police said.

title: Outlook for Lilco: Questions Linger
description: The Long Island Lighting Company is under pressure to abandon its Shoreham nuclear power plant to avoid a takeover attempt by the Long Island Power Authority.

title: Frederick (Bun) Cook; Hockey Player, 84
description: Frederick Joseph (Bun) Cook, who starred in the National Hockey League with his brother Bill for the New York Rangers in the 1920's and 1930's, died Saturday at Providence Manor, a retirement home. He was 84 years old.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: March 20, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-19

title: SPAIN CREDITS U.S. FOR NORIEGA OFFER
