description: Spain's offer of political asylum to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama was made at the request of the United States Government, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said.

title: Headliners; Over Atlanta
description: Among the 1.3 million Roman Catholics in the United States who are black, there is now one archbishop. Pope John Paul II last week named Eugene Antonio Marino Archbishop of the Diocese of Atlanta, making him the first black American to achieve that status within the church. Bishop Marino, a 53-year-old native of Biloxi, Miss., said his appointment was ''a sign of hope to black Catholics in our country and to all people of good will.'' It means, he added, that ''the church recognizes the wealth within its own ranks, that it is a church of many minorities.'' The Rev. Bruce W. Wilkerson, head of the Atlanta archdiocese's Commission for Black Catholic Concerns, said the Pope had made ''a bold statement'' in naming Bishop Marino to head ''so visible and so significant'' an archdiocese.

title: Rules Mean More Filtering of Water
description: LEAD: NEW, more stringent water standards will require the 80 major Long Island water suppliers to treat the water from 100 supply wells that are contaminated with volatile organic chemicals.

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, the ''Pop View'' column in the Arts and Leisure section today appears with its final paragraphs omitted from page 37. The missing passage is printed in this section, on page 59.

title: Fond Memories Of a Great Miler
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: How Should The Mets Handle Strawberry?
description: Try to find three or four other players like him! The Strawman makes things happen on that team. If they must do something with him, I say send him to NASA; the guy definitely has ignition! MADELINE MORRIS New York

title: In the Running
description: When he said that God didn't intend for women to hold positions of authority, particularly behind the plate in major league baseball, Bob Knepper was just doing what he saw as his Christian duty, ''no matter what the cost.'' Now the Astros pitcher is paying the price. The Houston chapter of the National Organization for Women has nominated Knepper for its 1988 Neanderthal of the Year award.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CRY OF THE OPPRESSED: The History and Hope of the Human Rights Revolution. By Robert F. Drinan. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) The Rev. Robert F. Drinan is a law professor and a Jesuit and was a congressman from Massachusetts for 10 years. Those credentials combine to make him a passionate and persuasive spokesman for human rights throughout the world. In ''Cry of the Oppressed'' he notes that it was not until relatively recently that racism, torture, genocide and violations of ''the rules of war'' were proscribed by international law. But the United States, Father Drinan writes, ''has failed to ratify the United Nations' central human rights documents.'' The Senate's unwillingness to ratify these covenants, despite the efforts of President Carter and many influential secular and religious organizations, ''highlights the roots of America's reluctance to commit itself to binding international agreements.'' Worse, Father Drinan says, any progress made by Mr. Carter has been undermined by the Reagan Administration, which assumes that ''human rights are of value not by themselves but only if their attainment is consistent with and helpful to the containment of communism.'' While he laments the President's general record, the author does concede that the Administration has been generally mindful of violations by Communist countries. Father Drinan has a gloomy view of the present situation, but he believes the game is worth the candle: ''The United States has a daunting moral, legal, and political duty to verify and enhance the transcendence of human rights.''

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Review/Jazz; Breuker's Eclecticism
description: A description of music by the Dutch composer and saxophonist Willem Breuker is inevitably a set of lists: tangos follow be-bop, brass band music merges with snarling free jazz, and unaccompanied saxophone solos follow Hollywood versions of Arabic music. Mr. Breuker is an eclectic, and like such fellow pastiche artists as the composers Carla Bley and Henry Threadgill, his works, especially in concert, are loaded with humor - in his case, a circus esthetic rules.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending March 5 MANHATTAN Greenwwich Village $525,000 15 West 11th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; 24-hr. doorman, large windowed kitchen, 2 exposures; maintenance $1,187, 33% tax-deductible. (Broker: Wells & Gay) TriBeCa $365,000 90 Hudson Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,435-sq.-ft. prewar loft-co-op; remodeled kitchen and bath, hardwood floors, roof garden; maintenance $816; 70% tax-deductible (Broker: Joffee LaSalle) TriBeCa $415,000 55 N. Moore Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 2,500-sq.-ft. loft-co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; remodeled kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $445, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Upper East Side $345,000 315 East 65th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $873, 37% tax-deductible (Broker: Sulzberger-Rolfe) Washington Heights $53,000 360 Cabrini Boulevard 400-sq.-ft studio co-op in a recently renovated prewar building; part-time doorman, separate dressing area, windowed kitchen; maintenance $175, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Simone Song Properties) BRONX Riverdale $50,000 5730 Moshulu Avenue 400-sq.-ft. postwar studio co-op; separate windowed kitchen, new appliances; maintenance $344, 42% tax-deductible (Broker: Kahan & Kahan Realty) Wakefield $200,000 2-family, detached, frame house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; full basement, 2-car detached garage, 35- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Albert R. Bryan Real Estate) BROOKLYN Bensonhurst $268,000 2107 66th Street 2-family semi-attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; finished basement, 24- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,063 (Broker: Mcpyel Associates Inc.) Flatlands $145,000 4622 Avenue L 2-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, semi-attached, frame house; formal dining room, large kitchen, full basement, 22- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $680 (Broker: Fogarty Real Estate) Park Slope $121,000 889 Union Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. co-op in a recently renovated prewar brownstone; dining area, large kitchen, fireplace; maintenance $385, 67% tax-deductible (Broker: Noonan Associates) QUEENS Flushing $110,000 140-33 34th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,118-sq.-ft postwar co-op; dining room, wall-to-wall carpets, new windows; maintenance $330, 38% tax-deductible (Broker: Gala Realty) Whitestone $360,000 158-11 14th Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached colonial; formal dining room, large kitchen, fireplace, 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) STATEN ISLAND Huguenot $230,000 38 Yucca Drive 2-family detached, shingle and stone house; 4 bedrooms 1 1/2 baths, dining room in primary unit; 3 bedrooms, 1 bath, sun room in other; large kitchens in both; full basement, attached 1-car garage, 42- by 90-ft. lot; taxes $2,000 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency) Todt Hill $592,000 960 Todt Hill Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, single-family, detached colonial; formal dining room, large kitchen, family room, 1-car garage, 213- by 154-ft. irregular lot; taxes $3,500 (Broker: Century 21/Papp Realty)

title: Resolution 242, Crystal Clear
description: Whether they support or oppose the views of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, Americans ought to be clear about the meaning of Security Council Resolution 242 of 1967.

title: Audrey Markin to Wed
description: The engagement of Audrey Ilene Markin to Lloyd Edward Hyman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Hyman of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Markin of New City, N.Y. Miss Markin, a graduate of Harpur College of the State University of New York at Binghamton, is an assistant corporate trust officer at the Marine Midland Bank in New York. Her fiance, a graduate of Brooklyn College, is a vice president of marketing and sales at the Mar-Chelle Hosiery Company in Nanuet, N.Y.

title: Topic for Debate: Limit Rich Schools' Spending
description: LEAD: THIS year, the General Assembly is looking at ways to equalize the amount of money spent on each student in the state's public schools. While most of the attention is being focused on changes in state education aid formulas, two lawmakers are proposing a more direct approach.

title: NO TO JELLY BEANS
description: THE THIRTEENTH MAN A Reagan Cabinet Memoir. By Terrel H. Bell. 195 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

title: Q and A
description: Replacing Windows

title: Timothy Schifter Weds Helen Lee, A Fashion Writer
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan yesterday, Helen Elizabeth Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Chun-Chao Lee of Arlington, Tex., and Destin, Fla., was married to Timothy Ware Schifter, the son of Melvin Schifter of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Margaret Hoyt Schifter. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Over Budget
description: If Kenneth Keller had it to do over, he might just settle for a plain metal desk in battleship gray. Mr. Keller resigned as president of the University of Minnesota last week amid a continuing flap over the cost of renovations to his office and official residence. The bills for refurbishing the office came to $200,000, including $17,445 for a mahogany desk and credenza. The residential renovations, originally pegged at $400,000, came to $1.5 million. Criticism of these expenditures led Gov. Rudy Perpich to withdraw his request for a $23.1 million appropriation to finance a program proposed by Mr. Keller to raise standards at the university. In his resignation statement, Mr. Keller noted that recent news stories about the renovations had ''not been good ones'' and said he was ''profoundly embarrassed and profoundly sorry.''

title: THE NATION: Organized Labor; Taking the Fight to the Shareholder
description: WHEN contract negotiations stalled last fall at Echlin Inc., a Connecticut automobile parts manufacturer, union officials decided not to try a slowdown, strike or boycott. Instead, they took their case to the company's shareholders.

title: Illegal Aliens Depress Wages for Some in U.S.
description: Illegal aliens are depressing wages and worsening working conditions for legal immigrants and native Americans in low-skilled and low-paying jobs, the General Accounting Office says.

title: Mecca for the Bargain Hunter
description: HELEN ROMAN picked purposefully through the racks of black-and-white linen suits in a shop at the Norwalk Factory Outlet complex. She shook her head and headed toward another rack. There, she wrinkled her brow as she imagined herself in a pink knit dress.

title: THE BRAND NAME GUIDE TO LIFE
description: LEAD: COMPLICATIONS By Prince Charming. 247 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

title: Hospital Is New Spot for Takeout
description: LEAD: SOME people have found a new place to shop for food: Griffin Hospital in Derby. The hospital has entered the fast-food business with dinners similar to those found in the frozen-food section of grocery stores.

title: LEAGUE FIGHTS FOR GROUND
description: The playing fields were framed by slowly shifting towers of garbage kept afloat on Little Hell Gate Bay by a stately procession of barges. The beer was temporarily locked away in a rarely used cement and fluorescent bower off a dark hallway at Downing Stadium.

title: THE WIDE, WIDE WORLD OF WEALTH
description: THE NEW PALGRAVE A Dictionary of Economics. Edited by John Eatwell, Murray Milgate and Peter Newman. Four volumes. 4,103 pp. New York: Stockton Press. $650.

title: MALAYSIA LEADER TIGHTENS HIS HOLD ON THE COURTS
description: The Malaysian Government of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, whose political party was ruled illegal by the Kuala Lumpur High Court last month, used Dr. Mahathir's large parliamentary majority this week to push through legislation curbing the power of the judiciary.

title: Beaming the Basics to the Playground Crowd
description: EDUCATORS won't be happy at first, predicted Ms. VandenBoogert of Potentials Unlimited, but bookstore owners will. The researcher, a former teacher, is putting the finishing touches on an accelerated learning program for children that is based on tapes using subliminal suggestion.

title: Macabre Wit
description: PENN & TELLER'S CRUEL TRICKS FOR DEAR FRIENDS Starring Penn & Teller. 1988. Lorimar Home Video. 59 minutes. $20.

title: A Celebration for the French Comic Strips
description: A booklet of 12 stamps from France re-create the works of French comic strip artists. The set is a salute to the comic strip as a form of communication and a belated celebration of the 1987 centennial of the appearance of the first French comic strip story.

title: Review/Dance; Kinematic's Grown-Up Fairy Tale
description: Almost everyone likes fairy tales. Children like their fantastic plots. Sophisticated grown-ups like their symbolism.

title: In Africa, Stoking Stoves to Save the Trees
description: The stove police would like this village of peanut fields, dusty trees and mud-brick houses.

title: Boathouse Builder
description: A year after he retired as the Rutgers rowing coach, Bill Leavitt is back at the team boathouse, but not, it turns out, to second-guess the new coach, Steve Wagner.

title: Peaceful Coexistence in the Office
description: WE asked 10 computer users familiar with the Macintosh and the I.B.M. PC's, PS/2's and compatibles to take the standard desert island test. ''If you were stranded and could have only one computer, which would it be?'' The findings of this unscientific survey, which has a margin of error of 100 percent, reveal more about the users who inhabit the different computer universes than about the merits of the two categories of machines. for example, chose the Mac because it could run the ''MacPlaymate'' X-rated software, whereas no such software apparently exists for the other machines. Another chose the I.B.M. PC Convertible ''because its handle allows it to be used as a tool to break coconuts.''

title: Troubled Times for Investment Newsletters
description: LEAD: BOB GROSS, editor of The Professional Investor, an investment newsletter, bought a Rolls-Royce back in 1975. He recalls that several of his competitors in the newsletter business also bought Rolls-Royces at about the same time. ''That's how good business was,'' Mr. Gross said recently. ''We were all making piles of money.

title: 'Pop View' Correction: The Missing Passage
description: Because of a mechanical error, the final paragraphs of the ''Pop View'' column on page 37 of the Arts and Leisure section today were omitted. The paragraphs, discussing Bernadette Peters in the cast recording of the Stephen Sondheim musical ''Into the Woods,'' read as follows:

title: We're Not Out of the Deep Deficit Woods Yet; Tremendous Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Force Says Wives' Jobs Are Up to Them
description: The Air Force has adopted a policy holding that military wives' decisions to work outside the home are none of the service's business.

title: Final Four Makes Sense . . . and Dollars
description: To grasp the scope of the phenomenal growth and prestige of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, one needs only to listen to Jim Hull, the captain of the 1939 Ohio State University basketball team. Hull recently recalled his team's thoughts when his coach, Harold Olsen, told them they were going to play in the first N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: Spanning the Centuries
description: THE HUNDREDS OF ROPE bridges that once spanned the chasms in the Peruvian Andes were testaments to the engineering skills of the Incas. Part of the elaborate system of roadways within the vast empire known as Tahuantinsuyu, the bridges contributed to the remarkable commerce and communication that the Incas developed during the 15th and 16th centuries.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: JEANNE COGHLAN is pretty sure that kissing her is a lot like kissing barbed wire. She hasn't been told this, but she said, ''I can't imagine a guy enjoying it.''

title: Gretchen Young Is Wed to John Baxter
description: Gretchen Young, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman Young of New York, Quogue, L.I., and Miami, was married yesterday to John Andrew Baxter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ian Wright Baxter of Los Angeles. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: The Ruthless Young Crack Gangsters
description: THEY are a new breed of criminal in New York City: young members of crack-peddling gangs who murder on a whim. And though police officials say they are confident the gangs can be uprooted by methods that have worked before, other law-enforcement experts and social scientists are less optimistic.

title: BACK FROM EVERYWHERE
description: A TIME OF CHANGE A Reporter's Tale of Our Time. By Harrison E. Salisbury. 352 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: Queens Man, 85, Dies After Attack by Robber
description: An elderly Queens man who lived alone died yesterday of a beating he received during a robbery in his home Friday, the police said.

title: Andrea Smith Weds
description: Andrea Jill Smith, a writer for ABC Radio, and Richard Michael Stapleton, a producer for CBS News, were married last evening at the Warwick Hotel in Manhattan by Rabbi Martin Zion. Mrs. Stapleton, a daughter of Martin G. Smith and Jeri Smith, both of New York, graduated from the Lenox School and Syracuse University. Mr. Stapleton, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Stapleton, attended Greensboro (N.C.) College.

title: U.S. Positions Battalion 42 Miles From Nicaragua
description: The United States has sent an infantry battalion supported by artillery to a training area 42 miles from the Honduran border with Nicaragua, American military officers said today.

title: Photos of fashions and accessories (Cornelia Katchen); DO CLOTHES MAKE THE MAN?
description: Not long ago, shortly after reading Tom Wolfe's ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' and being dazzled by Michael Douglas's wardrobe in the film ''Wall Street,'' I put on a chalk-striped shirt with a white tab collar and walked around in it all day. It was a subsidized experiment; the shirt wasn't mine. The gold collar stick I wore with it was, though, a bar mitzvah gift that for 20 years I'd considered an enigmatic tie clasp.

title: High Hopes, Hair Nightmare
description: I REMEMBER William Holden telling Grace Kelly in ''The Country Girl'' that there are two kinds of women in the world: those who pay too much attention to themselves and those who don't pay enough.

title: For Palestinians, P.L.O. Is a Homeland of the Mind
description: STUDYING a few papers spread out over a barren desk with his oversized reading glasses, the ''Old Man,'' as aides call Yasir Arafat, appears serene, almost bookish, a far cry from the fearsome image of the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: New York to Require Two Years of College For New Troopers
description: New state troopers would be required to have at least two years of college under a new program intended to improve the judgment and training of members of the state police force.

title: O'Rourke Outlines Plan for Playland
description: LEAD: AFTER weeks of relative silence, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke took the offensive last week in the debate over the management of Playland, announcing a plan for the county-owned amusement area in Rye.

title:
GARDENING;
For Some, a Rose Is a Rose Is a Salad
description: LEAD: WHEN someone says, ''I love flowers,'' he may be talking about them as food. Flowers are increasingly appearing in dishes prepared by chefs from coast to coast. They are used for hors d'oeuvres, tossed in salads, fried in batter, added to soups and used to garnish meats and desserts.

title:
ART;
Works On Paper In Bronx
description: LEAD: THE five-year-long renovation of the Bronx Museum of the Arts is to be completed in August. But the museum has hardly been twiddling its thumbs during the course of building. One remembers many noteworthy shows over the last half decade, and the current main offering, ''Master Watercolors and Drawings From the Norton Gallery of Art,'' is one of the classiest as well as one of the most instructive.

title: BEST SELLERS: MARCH, 20, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week Lis t Fiction 1 16 2 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman's secret dealings with terrorists may bring him the Presidency - or death. 2 1 20 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 11 2 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrageur's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 4 1 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 5 3 17 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts creates havoc. 6 2 39 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 7 7 5 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 8 * 4 16 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga. 9 6 22 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 10 * 5 34 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 11 8 9 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $18.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 12 10 12 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. 13 9 9 THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Abrahams/Dutton, $22.95.) Turmoil and rebellion in 19th-century Ireland. 14 12 8 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) The death of a distinguished biologist leads to discoveries about medical science's mysteries. 15 1 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family on Boston's Beacon Hill. 16 * 1 EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Houghton Mifflin, $15.95.) Nine short stories about a variety of characters and situations. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 14 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the New York entrepreneur. 2 2 7 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 3 3 6 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society recalled by a woman who married into it. 4 4 19 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 5 5 45 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 6 6 5 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 7 15 4 OSCAR WILDE, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the dramatist, essayist, poet and wit. 8 8 9 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 9 9 17 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 10 13 41 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 11 12 34 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former member of the British secret service. 12 10 34 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 13 * 14 8 DETOUR, by Cheryl Crane with Cliff Jahr. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) Lana Turner's daughter recalls the circumstances under which she killed her mother's gangster boyfriend 30 years ago. 14 7 3 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 15 11 4 DONNIE BRASCO, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (New American Library, $18.95.) A former F.B.I. agent tells of his five years posing as a mobster to discover Mafia secrets. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 7 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 2 2 37 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 3 3 5 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK AND EASY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library, $17.95.) Dishes that can be prepared in less than an hour. 4 4 132 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 17 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE HEARTS AND LIVES OF MEN, by Fay Weldon. (Viking, $18.95.) In her 13th novel, Ms. Weldon has the nerve (and the skill) to pull all the stops of melodrama, moralizing, sentimentality and adventure to produce a robust novel about love and hate. UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The story (so far) of the 22-year-old Irish poet left spastic and speechless by brain damage at birth, written in heady, acrobatic language. PERFECT PITCH: A Life Story, by Nicolas Slonimsky. (Oxford University, $21.95.) A rich and various chronicle of musical life in the 20th century, by a voluble, energetic 93-year-old insider. EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS OF THE MOON: Chimpanzee Society in the African Rain Forest, by Michael P. Ghiglieri. (The Free Press, $22.50.) Chimps are not nice - they go in too much for murder and sexism - but this book by a wildlife biologist tells us a lot about them and something about us. FRYE STREET & ENVIRONS: The Collected Works of Marita Bonner, edited by Joyce Flynn and Joyce Occomy Stricklin. (Beacon, $18.95.) Terse and reportorial, the writing of Marita Bonner (1899-1971) rendered the black and immigrant American experience as one of irremediable pain, without hope or humor. PRISONER'S DILEMMA, by Richard Powers. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $19.95.) Traumatized in some unknown way by World War II, Eddie Hobson treats himself with doses of historical fantasy in this novel about a dysfunctional family. BAD ACTS AND GUILTY MINDS: Conundrums of the Criminal Law, by Leo Katz. (University of Chicago, Cloth, $45; Paper, $14.95.) A fascinating romp through the philosophical side of law.

title: Shrinking of Homeland Stirs Armenian Protests
description: To the Editor:

title: EAST TIMOR SEEKS TO OPEN ITS DOORS
description: The Governor of Indonesia's disputed province of East Timor plans to ask the Suharto Administration to lift restrictions on travel and communications that have isolated the territory since Indonesia invaded and annexed it in the 1970's.

title: 13 Hurt, 4 Americans, in a Blast in Athens
description: Thirteen people, including four Americans, were injured tonight when a bomb exploded in a suburban Athens bar frequented by servicemen from a nearby United States Air Force installation, the police reported.

title: Ensemble Recitals Entice Listeners
description: VOCAL and chamber music recitals are planned for today and next Sunday, with today's highlights including a piano program, wind and brass quintet concerts and solo appearances by several Metropolitan Opera singers.

title: Coping With the Perils of Asbestos
description: LILI ELSIS slumped on her cellar stairs and put her head in her hands. ''We just moved all this in last Thursday,'' she said with a sigh.

title: Increasingly, Life and Death Issues Become Money Matters
description: THE everyday face of medical ethics has changed, experts say, driven by a new cost consciousness in the medical and health care professions. And the change is well illustrated by the stories of two scarce procedures and how legislators reacted to appeals by patients.

title:
DINING OUT;
New England Tastes in Tarrytown
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH many hotel dining rooms are no bigger than some of the best restaurants in their town, despite the promise of ambitious-sounding menus few succeed in transcending a reputation for flat, mechanically assembled, industrial cooking. A regimented portion- and cost-control executive mentality may, by placing too much distance between concept and execution, stifle spontanaiety and creativeness at the production end.

title: About Men; Thrice-Told Tales
description: THESE ARE TWO OF the lies I tell about myself: I say that while I was at the University of Virginia in the late 1950's, I attended classes taught by William Faulkner. If anyone asks what he was like, I mention his salty language, his wonderful offhand insights and his pronounced Southern accent. I also tell people that while in the Marine Corps I was a weapons instructor at Parris Island, playing a vengeful god in the much-storied style of the Marine drill instructor.

title: Stepping Back In Time in The Caribbean
description: WHEN word got around the island of Nevis not long ago that construction of a new golf course was being contemplated, the response from most Nevisians and long-time foreign residents was predictable: why build something we already have? That the existing course has only one hole - making it the only one-hole course in the West Indies and perhaps anywhere, for that matter - was irrelevant to most residents, who felt that one hole was quite enough. Then, too, no one comes to Nevis to play golf, although a round at the Nevis Golf Club, with its one hole and nine tees, is a novel, though not particularly challenging, experience for any golfer. Nor do visitors come to play tennis, even though most of the island's eight inns have courts, few of which seem to get much use. That is especially true at inns such as the Zetland Plantation, halfway up the 3,232-foot-high Mount Nevis, where afternoon winds gusting in off the Atlantic can play havoc with a tennis ball before subsiding to gentle evening breezes.

title: Israeli Army Steps Up Effort To Block Coverage of Unrest
description: The Israeli Army effectively blocked foreign journalists from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today, apparently in an effort to reduce coverage of Palestinian protests.

title: Azinger Leads Kite by a Shot
description: The wind whipped up to more than 30 miles an hour at times across the big Bay Hill course today and took the scores up with it as only seven golfers broke par 71 in the third round of the Hertz Bay Hill Classic.

title: Foes of Plan In Greenburgh Seek to Form Own Village
description: MEMBERS of a group of Greenburgh residents who are opposed to Supervisor Anthony F. Veteran's plan to build housing for 108 homeless families near them are seeking incorporation as a village within the town, a move that would give them control over zoning.

title: Q&A
description: Park Lodges Question:We are planning to visit the Grand Canyon, Bryce Canyon and Zion National Parks in May and want to stay in the parks. What accommodations are available? - B. Y. K., White Plains Answer:At the Grand Canyon's North Rim, which some visitors say has a more spectacular view than the South Rim, the sole hotel is the Grand Canyon Lodge. Though the park is open the year round, the lodge, which has 40 motel rooms and 160 cabins, is open only from May 18 to Oct. 24. (Inquiries about reservations should be made to T.W. Services, Box 400, Cedar City, Utah 84720; 801-586-7686.) The South Rim has several lodges as well as a village with store, bank and visitors' center. Among the accommodations are El Tovar, the park's oldest lodge, the Bright Angel, Kachina and Thunderbird. There are also accommodations a mile or so outside the park boundary, like the Best Western Grand Canyon Squire Inn. Information about all of them is available by writing to the Superintendent, Grand Canyon National Park (Post Office Box 129, Grand Canyon, Ariz. 86023; 602-638-7888).

title: Prison Term for Abduction
description: A 29-year-old Branford woman was sentenced to one year in prison Friday for abducting a baby from Yale-New Haven Hospital in October 1986. The woman, Maureen Mead, was sentenced to five years in prison, suspended after one year, followed by five years' probation. Superior Court Judge John Ronan also ordered Ms. Mead to seek psychiatric treatment. Ms. Mead told the judge she did not know why she had taken the one-day-old boy from the hospital's maternity ward where she was working as a volunteer. The baby was returned to his parents unharmed.

title: PRINCE CHARLES RECASTS HIS ROLE
description: Hurrah for the Prince of Wales, who sees architecture not as an exercise in arcane esthetic principles enunciated by a professional priesthood, but as the living expression of the lives and aspirations of ordinary people (''Defying Tradition,'' by Howell Raines, Feb. 21).

title: COSTA RICA
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a two-and-a-half-week trip to Costa Rica, I enjoyed reading your article. When we told friends we were vacationing there, the response was, ''Take a gun.'' Nothing could be further from the truth. The tranquillity of this beautiful country and their people envelopes you as soon as you settle down on a Lacsa Airlines flight.

title: Shevardnadze Visit to U.S.: Afghanistan on His Mind
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, is to arrive in Washington on Sunday in search of a compromise that would ease the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan.

title: Oddities From Old Kitchens
description: Tools and utensils that kept houses humming a century ago have been dusted off and placed on view at the New-York Historical Society, in an exhibition called ''Bellows, Bobbins and Butter Churns: Keeping House in 19th-Century America.'' Most of the 190 or so items, on exhibit through Oct. 2, were used by women in their daily chores - cooking, spinning, sewing, laundering and keeping their houses heated, lighted and free of pests.

title: Miss Lobodinski Becomes a Bride
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, Jeanine Lobodinski and George Marsh Flint 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. Charles A. Amstein.

title: Covert Whispers to Workers and Customers
description: THE fact that subliminal messages have gone public does not mean covert messages have become extinct. In department stores there may be the subliminal sound of jail doors slamming or police sirens wailing to deter shoplifters. The music piped into a factory may be cautioning workers to be safe.

title: Barbaric Splendor Suited Him
description: Wilfred Thesiger has long had a reputation as a legendary traveler, in his words ''perhaps the last explorer in the tradition of the past.'' But while his courage and resourcefulness are admirable, his autobiography indicates no awareness of how much his expeditions depended on poor, tractable people in dictatorships and colonial regimes. That this type of travel is no longer possible might strike some readers as less a tragedy than a cause for relief.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Franklin, Mass.;
New Magnet For Builders
description: LEAD: FOR the last two decades, Toll Brothers Inc. has been building expensive single-family homes in the mid-Atlantic states. Now the Pennsylvania-based company has ventured into New England, choosing a site in the ''Golden Triangle'' between Worcester, Boston and Providence.

title: Project HIRE Is Termed a Success
description: NEW JERSEY is starting to phase out its sheltered workshops in favor of finding regular jobs for the severely disabled, according to Eddie C. Moore, director of the state's Division of Developmental Disabilities.

title: 'LACE OVER STEEL': THE WOMEN MAYORS OF TEXAS
description: BETTY TURNER, THE FIRST WOMAN to serve as Mayor of Corpus Christi, Tex., is munching Gulf shrimp and having a minor disagreement with her husband, Jack. She says he feels left out when she sits on the dais at major dinners. He says he doesn't mind, because for years she did the same whenever he received an award for his work as an architect. Well, she counters, he does seethe a bit when referred to as Mr. Betty Turner. Nonsense, he replies, he finds it funny.

title: Sarah Gnaedinger to Wed John Miles
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Gnaedinger of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Howe Gnaedinger, to John Arlington Miles, a son of the late George Sackett Miles of Demarest, N.J., and Warren, Conn., and the late Mrs. Melvin Loos of New York.

title: Modern Nursing Is a Task, Not a Calling
description: AS a nurse in the same geriatric ward for a few years, I've periodically been restless for a change but never acted upon my wish for it. A few weeks ago, I finally requested to switch from days to the night shift. After waiting with mixed feelings, I was notified to start on nights the day after my vacation was through.

title: Samson, Gorilla, Dies at 30
description: Samson, a 30-year-old western lowland gorilla believed the oldest breeding male gorilla in captivity, has died at the Brookfield Zoo. The 400-pound gorilla suffered a stroke and died Thursday, said a zoo spokeswoman, Linda Elbert.

title: Two Learn Honesty Pays
description: Two men who helped retrieve some of an estimated $771,000 that accidentally fell from an armored truck here March 8 have been given plaques and rewards for their honesty.

title: Bronx Is Up: Stevenson, Gompers Win
description: The Bronx put two more basketball teams into next weekend's New York State Federation championships yesterday when Adlai Stevenson defeated previously unbeaten Abraham Lincoln, 62-61, in the Public Schools Athletic League championship and Samuel Gompers, the defending champion, trounced Prospect Heights, 92-70, in the Section B title game.

title: COUNTRYWIDE TRANSPORT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
R. M. Postelnek Wed To Nancy Jo Mitchell
description: Nancy Jo Mitchell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Paul Mitchell of Shrewsbury, N.J., and Robert Mark Postelnek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Postelnek of Rumson, N.J., were married yesterday at Congregation B'nai Israel in Rumson. Rabbi Jack M. Rosoff and Cantor Daniel Green officiated.

title: Hopes for Bidders Fade For 1st Republicbank . . . As Tension Mounts At First City of Texas
description: As bank regulators searched for a bidder to take over the deeply troubled First Republicbank Corporation, many analysts said the nation's 13th-largest bank holding company is too large and too crippled by bad loans to attract any serious offers.

title: 28 Are Reported Killed During Riots in Burma
description: The worst riots in Burma since 1974 took place last week in Rangoon, according to unconfirmed reports reaching Bangkok, and as many as 28 people were reportedly killed.

title: Debtors' Forum Urged
description: Julius K. Nyerere, the former president of Tanzania, today urged the developing countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America to create a forum to discuss their common debt problems. ''There is a need among the South countries to know each other's negotiating strategy, and at times agree on a common negotiating strategy with Western creditors,'' said Mr. Nyerere, who now is the chairman of the South Commission, which promotes economic cooperation between developing countries.

title: Mamelodi Journal; Behold the Dream! South Africa Without Racism
description: Jackson and Maria Mbetha had never before been hosts to a white family in their modest but neat home in this black township outside Pretoria.

title: Unyielding Panamanian; Despite Shrinking Options, Noriega Shows Little Willingness to Give Up Grip on Power
description: Nearly a month after he forced President Eric Arturo Delvalle out of office, the Panamanian military strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is more besieged and isolated than ever. But he has shown no further willingness to end the 10-month political crisis in his country by voluntarily relinquishing power.

title: But Let's Not Oversimplify Legal Writing
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes From Armenia In Southern California
description: News of the nationalist protests in Soviet Armenia has reverberated around the world, with a resounding echo in Southern California.

title: Propriety on Trial in Lawyers' Ads
description: The television advertisements seem simple enough: three well-known lawyers touting the divorce, bankruptcy and criminal work done by firms ''like Jacoby & Meyers,'' the cut-rate legal services chain.

title: Landing Gear Failure Forces Emergency Stop by Delta Jet
description: A Delta Air Lines jet with 76 people aboard made an emergency landing this afternoon after its landing gear malfunctioned, and one wing caught fire briefly as it scraped the runway, the authorities said. No one was injured.

title: Yumiko Honda Wed To Robert A. Posner
description: Yumiko Honda and Robert A. Posner were married yesterday at the University Club in New York by Rabbi Charles Simon.

title: Shock Waves Hit Honduras: Fears Rise Over Risk of War
description: A chill wind swept through the Central Plaza this afternoon, bending the palms and the broad shade trees and tossing Lisseth Erazco's dark hair.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 In elections in El Salvador, the ruling Christian Democratic Party appeared to have suffered a major defeat, according to Christian Democratic Party officials, diplomatic observers and other unofficial party observers. Page A1

title: Market Place; Closed-End Funds Draw Investors
description: AT a time when many investors are leery of venturing into the stock market, they are flocking to buy shares of new closed-end funds that fill their portfolios with fixed-income securities.

title: Villanova Turns to a Veteran
description: Mark Plansky, the only holdover from Villanova's 1985 national championship team, sank two free throws with 4 seconds to play today as Villanova defeated Illinois, 66-63, in a second-round game of the Southeast Regional.

title: Bush Wins Puerto Rico Primary and 14 Delegates
description: Vice President Bush won Puerto Rico's Republican primary today and added another 14 national convention delegates to his tally, while the Rev. Jesse Jackson won the Democrats' non-binding balloting.

title: Fund Raising Shouldn't Be a Senator's Main Job; Imagination Grabbers
description: To the Editor:

title: FISHER TRANSPORTATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income The latest 9-month figures are adjusted to reflect the restatement of the second quarter results due to a reconstruction of the company's accounting records.

title: I.M.F. Loan To Argentina
description: The International Monetary Fund announced on Friday a $317 million loan to Argentina that will help it pay back a $500 million loan from the United States and keep up with interest payments on its $50 billion foreign debt.

title: Agency Jumps Hurdles in Rush to Award Pacts
description: It is not uncommon in the final months of a lame duck Administration for political appointees to leave their jobs at Government agencies and for the agencies to postpone important projects and decisions until a new President takes office.

title: Review/Television; 'God Bless the Child,' on the Poor
description: Evidently, it is a subject whose time has come on evening television. Poverty and hunger and homelessness are suddenly hot stuff. Witness several of the more outstanding examples: last Wednesday's episode of ''The Equalizer'' on CBS; Saturday's final documentary segment on ''West 57th Street,'' also on CBS; the hourlong drama ''A Place at the Table'' on NBC last night, and, coming up this evening at 9 on ABC, ''God Bless the Child.''

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
An Undercurrent Of Safety Questions
description: ON my first rafting trip, in cold April water on the upper Hudson River a few years back, the paddler in front of me suddenly disappeared. He came back, within 50 seconds, wet and nonplussed.

title: Review/Music; U.S. and Soviet Artists Offer Schnittke Works
description: Over the last decade, Alfred Schnittke's reputation has traveled quickly in the West, carried by Soviet emigres and touring musicians who cite him as one of the Soviet Union's most inventive composers. Performances of his music have been less plentiful than these glowing citations might suggest, but such glimpses as we've had, mostly through recordings, have shown Mr. Schnittke to be a composer who borrows freely from accrued tradition in order to synthesize an individualistic and compelling brand of new music.

title: Koppers Gets Higher Offer From Beazer
description: Beazer P.L.C., undaunted by its rejection last week, increased its bid yesterday for the Koppers Company to $56 a share, or $1.58 billion. The new offer by the British construction company is $11 a share, or about $300 million, more than a bid by Beazer and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. that the Koppers board rejected last Wednesday.

title: Jacqueline Bazel Becomes a Bride
description: At the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York, Jacqueline Sue Bazel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bazel of Washington Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark David Horowitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Phillip Horowitz of Toledo, Ohio. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky, a cousin of the bride, officiated, assisted by Rabbis David Lincoln and Abraham Feffer.

title: Pitt's Season Ends in Overtime
description: Barry Goheen's two 3-point shots in the final six seconds of regulation set up an 80-74 overtime upset of Pittsburgh by Vanderbilt today in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional second-round game.

title: Industry Acts to Save Ozone
description: Industry in the United States and abroad is moving aggressively to curb uses of chemicals believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield.

title: Hong Kong Goals Set by Stock Expert
description: Since Robert Fell, a seasoned troubleshooter, took the helm of the Hong Kong stock exchange last November, it has recovered slightly from the October tremors that led to its four-day shutdown.

title: Australian Skipper Edges Americans
description: Peter Gilmour, the 28-year-old Australian who was backup skipper on Kookaburra III in the 1987 America's Cup series, edged six American helmsmen in final racing Saturday to win the Congressional Cup series off Long Beach, Calif.

title: Police Battle Hundreds of Youths In Riot at Texas Beach Community
description: Hundreds of young people rioted on a Gulf Coast beach before police brought them under control early today using tear gas.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Downhill Title for Zurbriggen: Karl Alpiger of Switzerland won the final men's downhill of the World Cup season and Pirmin Zurbriggen clinched his second straight World Cup downhill title yesterday. Alpiger had a time of 1 minute 44.48 seconds down the course at Are, Sweden, which was shortened to 2,890 meters because of strong winds and poor visibility. Danilo Sbardelotto of Italy finished second in 1:44.97. Zurbriggen finished 12th in 1:46.17, but the Swiss star, who placed 17th in Saturday's slalom, was second in the combined and regained the World Cup overall lead from Alberto Tomba of Italy. There are four races left in the season.(AP) Speed Skating Blair Wins Final 1,500 Meters: Bonnie Blair of the United States won the 1,500-meter race in the final series of World Cup competition yesterday at Heerenveen, the Netherlands. Blair was timed in 2 minutes 5.67 seconds, well ahead of Petra Moolhuizen of the Netherlands and Erwina Rys of Poland, both of whom finished in 2:06.52. In the 5,000 meters, Grietje Mulder of the Netherlands captured first place in 7:37.70. Blair finished first in the World Cup 1,500-meter standing. (AP) Road Racing Four-Mile Run to Donoghue: Russ Donoghue won the New York Road Runners Club's Digital four-mile run in 19 minutes 36 seconds yesterday at Central Park. He qualified for the New York City team in the Eikeden International Relays to be held on April 9. John Kenney of the Central Park Track Club was second in 20:11. Ann Vasquez of Brooklyn was the women's gold medalist in 23:35. Eldon Reynoso of the Central Park Track Club captured the 29th annual Mike Hannon Memorial 20-mile run in 1:51.36. Gillian Horovitz of New York regained the women's title, which she had won in 1985, in 2:11.28. Golf Davies Captures Tucson Open: Laura Davies of Britain made a 4-foot birdie putt on the final hole of the Tucson Open yesterday to beat Robin Walton by one stroke and win her first Ladies Professional Golf Association victory. Davies shot a par 72 for a 10-under-par 278. Walton came from seven shots back to tie Davies on the 17th hole. But her second shot on No. 18 flew into a sand trap, and she finished with a par 4 for a 70 and a 279 total. (AP) Geiberger Edges Moody: Al Geiberger fired a five-under-par 67 to hold off Orville Moody and win the $225,000 Arizona Classic in Sun City West by one stroke yesterday on the Senior PGA Tour. Geiberger finished at 17-under-par 199; Moody had a total of 200.(AP) Tennis Fernandez Upsets Sabatini: Mary Joe Fernandez stunned third-seeded Gabriela Sabatini, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Lipton International Players championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. The 15th-seeded Fernandez, a 16-year-old from Miami, will play Elna Reinach of South Africa, who defeated Linda Ferrando of Italy, 6-0, 6-2. Top-seeded Steffi Graf lost the first game of her fourth-round match, but won the next 11 on her way to a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Jo Durie of Britain. She will play sixth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, a 6-1, 6-4 winner over Nathalie Tauziat. Top-seeded Mats Wilander defeated Mark Woodforte, 7-6, 6-2, 6-1, and third-seeded Miroslav Mecir routed Dan Goldie, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3. Last night, Andrei Chesnokov outlasted fourth-seeded Tim Mayotte, 6-0, 6-7, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3, and sixth-seeded Yannick Noah beat Joey Rive, 6-2, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) Auto Racing Earnhardt Ends Losing Streak: Dale Earnhardt took the lead on the second lap of the Motorcraft 500 and ran away from the field at Atlanta International Raceway yesterday to end a string of 10 straight races without a victory. For Earnhardt, who had not won a Nascar race since last September, the victory increased his point total to 628, only 4 behind Neil Bonnett, the Winston Cup leader. Bonnett finished 22d.(AP) Indoor Lacrosse Saints Win Title: The New Jersey Saints won the Major Indoor league championship yesterday by defeating the Washington Wave before a crowd of 8,215 at Landover, Md. Jeff Goldberg led the Saints with four goals. Larry Quinn had 32 saves in goal for the Saints.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $574,363 from the termination of the company's pensionn plan for both the quarter and year.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:15 A.M. and 3 P.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M.

title: The Post Studies City Incentives For Relocating
description: The new owner of The New York Post, the real-estate developer Peter S. Kalikow, has had preliminary discussions with city officials about moving part of the paper's operations to upper Manhattan or another borough.

title: Adieu, Deux Chevaux
description: Fifty years ago, France began producing the Deux Chevaux, a car that looked like a tin can masquerading as a frog, designed to ''carry two people and 100 pounds of potatoes at a top speed of 40 miles an hour,'' according to the executive who commissioned it.

title: U.S. and Soviet In Grain Talks
description: The United States and the Soviet Union on Saturday completed the first round of negotiations on a new long-term grain agreement. Alan F. Holmer, a deputy

title: Final Bow for Many Theater Area Businesses
description: With large real-estate development sweeping across the western half of midtown Manhattan, hundreds of small show business enterprises are being forced to close or move out of the nation's leading theater district.

title: TE KANAWA AND HONG IN MET'S 'COSI FAN TUTTE'
description: For whatever reason, Hei-Kyung Hong didn't sing the role of Despina at the Metropolitan Opera's first performance of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' this season, on March 7. All agree she wasn't ill. Some have said that Kiri Te Kanawa, the Fiordiligi and one of the Met's biggest stars, requested her removal from the first-night cast, either out of prima donna jealousy or from a selfless feeling that Miss Hong wasn't ready to take on the part. In any event, the Met deemed Miss Hong ready for the second performance, last Tuesday, and the South Korean-born soprano is scheduled for most of the subsequent performances, including the broadcast April 7.

title: A FRENCHWOMAN LOOKS AT LOVE IN 'JUPON ROUGE'
description: That Americans do not have a corner on the manufacture of ludicrously bad, supposedly serious movies is demonstrated with unstoppable enthusiasm by ''Le Joupon Rouge'' (titled ''Manuela's Loves'' in English), the first feature by France's Genevieve Lefebvre. The writer-director, who has worked as a production assistant for Francois Truffaut, among others, should know better.

title: Aspin Assails Plan to Put MX Missiles on Trains
description: The Midgetman nuclear missile is a good idea that can do more to improve United States nuclear deterrence than putting MX missiles aboard trains, according to a House Armed Services study made public today.

title: Ex-Wrestler Fights in a New Arena
description: There was a time in the South when the name Thunderbolt Patterson really meant something. It wasn't just that he was a champion in the idiosyncratic world of professional wrestling, a barrel-chested braggart who spent much time boasting of his feats of valor and promising his adversaries a dire fate.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1987.

title: Books of The Times; 2 Works Trace the Turbulent Life of Roy Cohn
description: Citizen Cohn By Nicholas von Hoffman Illustrated. 483 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Japan Balks At U.S. Move
description: Japanese officials said they were dismayed at Washington's decision, on the eve of new talks on the issue, to approve retaliatory steps against Japan's construction industry.

title: Review/Dance; Villella's Miami Ballet: Mix of Classic and Modern
description: To watch the Miami City Ballet make its New York debut Saturday night at Brooklyn College was to observe a company in the process of finding an artistic identity. Founded in 1986, the group is directed by Edward Villella, a former star of the New York City Ballet, and its dancing was always crisp and clear.

title: Falklands Ferry Planned
description: A group of Falklands fishing companies plans to open the first ferry service between the South Atlantic archipelago and the South American mainland since the war between Britain and Argentina in 1982. A spokesman for the consortium, which has raised $1.8 million to buy a suitable vessel, said today that it would operate a passenger and cargo service between the Falklands and Montevideo, Uruguay, and Punta Arenas, Chile.

title: Macy's Bid for Federated Has a Clear Lead
description: After two months, the $6.3 billion takeover war for Federated Department Stores Inc. has reached a critical stage, with R.H. Macy & Company taking a clear lead over rival bidder the Campeau Corporation.

title: Pier I Imports Will Try Its First Magazine Ads
description: Pier I Imports, based in Fort Worth with 400 stores nationwide, is going to become a magazine advertiser for the first time next month. This will be in addition to its newspaper advertising in 110 markets. The chain has been using newspapers since it started a quarter-century ago.

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Power Failure Delays Passengers on Amtrak
description: Railroad passengers between Boston and Washington were delayed up to two hours yesterday when a power failure shut down the Hell Gate Bridge loop, a main link in Amtrak's Northeast Corridor, a spokesman for the rail line said.

title: Western Union Reports Profit
description: A late-year restructuring plan helped the financially troubled Western Union Corporation report a $105.3 million profit for the 1987 fourth quarter on Friday, compared with a $459.9 million loss in the same period of 1986.

title: Michael Lichtenberg Wed To Lisa Antell in Stamford
description: Lisa Antell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Antell of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Stuart Lichtenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lichtenberg of Hewlett Neck, L.I. Rabbis Allan Blaine and S. Jerome Wallin officiated at Temple Beth El in Stamford, Conn.

title: 10,000 Books Found; Oscar Nominee Sought
description: The Academy Award nominee who helped write the screenplay for ''Full Metal Jacket'' was being sought by the police today for questioning after an estimated 10,000 library books were found in two storage lockers.

title: HIGH SOVIET AIDE IN U.S. FOR TALKS
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Washington today for pivotal talks that begin Tuesday on Afghanistan, the Middle East and strategic arms reductions in preparation for President Reagan's trip to Moscow in late May or early June.

title: CHICAGO DOCK & CANAL TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain from property disposition of $7,666,000.

title: 3-Way Joint Venture In Barter Syndication
description: As TV programs in barter syndication gain importance as media for important advertisers, three major forces in the field have announced a joint venture to sell advertising time.

title: Islanders Shut Out Jets
description: Billy Smith made 35 saves for his second shutout of the season, and Denis Potvin scored two third-period goals today as the Islanders beat the Winnipeg Jets, 6-0.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in October.

title: Arizona Attack Flattens Pirates
description: Once Arizona removed Seton Hall's heart, little remained but the Pirates' soul.

title: DATACOPY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes tax credits of $3,000 and $41,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: NICARAGUA TALKS RECONVENE TODAY
description: After waging war for six years, top leaders of the Sandinista Government and the United States-backed contra guerrillas will meet Monday to talk peace for the first time.

title: Timing Helps Decker Bid, Traders Say
description: Through a quirk of timing, the Black & Decker Corporation stands a fairly good chance of winning a battle to take over American Standard Inc., even though it is trailing in a bidding contest by more than $30 million, traders said yesterday.

title: AN ISRAELI SOLDIER IS SHOT TO DEATH IN THE WEST BANK
description: An Israeli soldier was shot dead as he stood guard duty here today, the first Israeli Army fatality in the current unrest.

title: U.S. Opposes Agency Funds
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it would oppose new financing for the Inter-American Development Bank until the bank agreed to changes in its lending procedures.

title: Fund Raising Shouldn't Be a Senator's Main Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodia's Nonstop Ordeal
description: LEAD: Cambodia's ordeal seems to have outlasted the attention of everyone except the victims. But the tragedy deserves to be remembered in shame and sorrow as one of the longest and cruelest, even of this violent century.

title: Wilson Still Wants Mets to Trade Him
description: Two weeks before the start of another season, his eighth in the major leagues, Mookie Wilson is in the same place he said last July he didn't want to be: still with the Mets, still platooning in center field with Lenny Dykstra. The difference is, last season he openly talked about wanting to be traded and this spring he talks about it only when asked.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain on the extinguishment of subordinated debentures of $322,927. c-Net loss

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: RAIDS MAKE IRAN IMPORT REFINED OIL PRODUCTS
description: Repeated Iraqi air raids have damaged Iran's oil refineries, causing the nation, a leading oil producer, to import between 200,000 and 300,000 barrels a day of refined products such as jet fuel, gas oil and kerosene for home consumption.

title: Chambers Trial Jurors Deliberate for 10 Hours
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. completed its fourth day of deliberations yesterday without a verdict.

title: Project Delays Found Costly For New York
description: Most of New York City's public works projects initiated five years ago are badly behind schedule, adding costs and further delays to the construction of bridges, sewers and public schools, according to a report released yesterday by a civic group that monitors the city's management.

title: New Club: Past Life And Rock
description: How does a man pick up a woman in the New Age?

title: From Watergate, Training in Ethics
description: The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, the Watergate conspirator turned minister, says his past was the perfect prologue to his new post as head of this city's Commission on Values and Ethics.

title: FIRST AMERICAN HEALTH CONEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Lippold's 'Sun' Back at Metropolitan
description: ''The Sun,'' a hanging geometrical construction wrought of golden wire by Richard Lippold, has risen on the Great Staircase of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but not everyone is warmed by its glow.

title: Greek Owner of Bombed Bar Says There Were No Threats
description: The owner of a bar where a bomb blast wounded 13 people, including five American servicemen, said today that he never received threats or warnings of an attack.

title: Town Hall Democracy Urged for China
description: Zhao Ziyang, in his first major elaboration on China's political future since his formal appointment as Communist Party chief last November, has called for the development of a type of town hall democracy throughout the country.

title: Excerpts From Integrity Panel Hearings: Searching for Campaign Funds
description: Following are excerpts from testimony last Monday and Tuesday before the New York State Commission on Government Integrity. The questioners were G. Michael Bellinger, Alexandra Lowe and Constance Cushman, lawyers for the panel, and Peter Bienstock and James L. McGavern, members of the panel. The witnesses were Joseph Bernstein, a developer; Gerald Guterman, a developer; William Stern, campaign chairman for Governor Cuomo; Lawrence Buttenwieser, chief fund-raiser for Attorney General Robert Abrams, and Robert Pressman, a business executive. Lunch With Goldin: The $25,000 Pitch MR. BELLINGER: Mr. Bernstein, isn't it a fact that in the main you attempt to avoid making political contributions whenever possible? MR. BERNSTEIN: That's correct. Q.And you would characterize yourself as apolitical in the conventional sense? A.Very definitely not political. Q.As a matter of fact, you didn't even vote in the 1985 New York City elections, is that true? A.That's correct. Q.And yet you contributed over $100,000 to various political candidates? A.Well, I haven't aggregated it, but I don't think it's impossible. Q.Mr. Bernstein, would it be fair to say that you contributed money to political campaigns to avoid possible economic retaliation or reprisal if you did not contribute? A.To characterize why I would respond to a solicitation for a contribution, I would say it's more trying to avoid a negative impact that trying to incur a positive result. So the answer is yes. Q.And, in fact, you have previously mentioned a certain intimidation factor that you felt with respect to this? A.You could call it that. Q.Mr. Bernstein, you also stated that you were personally solicited for campaign contributions from the City Comptroller, Harrison Goldin. Is that correct? A.Yes. Q.Would you describe the circumstances surrounding this solicitation? A.I believe I received a telephone call from Mr. Goldin, wanting to have lunch. Q.Have you ever phoned Mr. Goldin? A. Yes, I have. Most recently. Q.And for what purpose? A.To try to get him to vote on a project that we have before the Board of Estimate. Q.And what project was that? A.That was the rebuilding of the High School of the Performing Arts that just burnt down. Q.Did Mr. Goldin accept your call? A.Yes. Spoke to me several times, but I wasn't able to convince him. Q.Again, would you continue on with describing the personal solicitation Mr. Goldin made to you? A.He asked us to have lunch - I am sorry, I don't recall specifically. It may have been breakfast. I am not sure which, but it was at the Edwardian Room at the Plaza Hotel. Q. What happened when you arrived at the Plaza Hotel? A. I guess we ordered some food, and started talking, and he made mention a little bit about running for Mayor, and that it would be nice if we were to support him. Q. And what else did he say? A. He thought that a contribution of $50,000, $25,000 for each of two years, would be appropriate. Q. What did you feel about this request from Mr. Goldin? A. Well, I felt I didn't have a middleman between me and him. He was right in front of me, so I kind of looked at my brother, we both kind of nodded, yeah, that was it. Q. Mr. Bernstein, isn't it also a fact that you and your brother discussed the audacity of Mr. Goldin's request? A. I guess I should say it was a little bit shocking, yes. Q. Mr. Bernstein, did you comply with the City Comptroller's request? A. Yes. Q. In fact, you made a contribution of $25,000 to the Committee for a Better Government in mid-February of 1984? A. I believe that's correct. Q. Mr. Bernstein, were you aware at this particular time that that contribution was in violation of the New York State Election Law? A. I don't believe so. Q. Were you ever so informed? A. Well, what I was informed was that the check was coming back, and that I should cut five separate checks, and that's what I have also as exhibits here, the checks that were cut back. 'I Will Defer To Your Arithmetic' MS. LOWE: Mr. Guterman, would it be fair to say that in a narrow time span, running from the end of December to early - well, the end of December 1984, to early December 1985, you contributed - excuse me, from late December '84 to early January '85 -you contributed exactly $100,000 to Harrison Goldin's campaign for Comptroller? MR. GUTERMAN: I don't recall exactly. Q. What I would like to do is to look at the contributions that begin on Dec. 17, 1984. . . What I would like to do is beginning on page 8, and continuing on the next two pages, there are a series of corporations, most of whom are located at 255-55 Union Turnpike, in Glen Oaks, New York. And I would like you to scan down with me, beginning with Nelson Investors Incorporated, and go down to the bottom of the page and tell us whether each of those corporations is a corporation in which you or Hanover Companies had an interest as of Dec. 27, 1984? A. I believe they are. Q. Now, you can check my arithmetic, but when I took out my calculator and added up these 4,700, 4,800, 4,600 contributions, I came up to exactly $100,000, does that sound right to you? A. I will defer to your arithmetic. Doing Business With the Government MR. BIENSTOCK: I want to refer to the day of the primary, if I might, and ask you whether or not the nature of fund raising dramatically changed on that date? MR. STERN: Yes. . . That night he won. And there was a madhouse. Everybody came down from the Koch headquarters, and as we were going toward the stage, I was going to the stage with the Governor, people were giving me checks, people were giving me money on my way to the stage, saying, ''I have been looking for you for weeks, where have you been?'' Q. Did you form a judgment as to why the nature of the fund raising changed after the primary? A. Yes. people trying to ingratiate themselves with somebody who was to be governor. Q. And did that apply to particular industries? A. Yes. Everybody who sells things to government or is closely related to anybody in government. And therein lies the secret of the form, I think. People who are doing a lot of business with the government and who are regulated by government, are the usual suspects of the public finance debts of Wall Street, real-estate developers, public employees unions are enormous givers. Looking for Cash: A 'Bald Request' MS. CUSHMAN: Can you please describe for the commission the manner in which these $15,000 contributions were solicited by yourself or by yourself and Mr. Abrams? MR. BUTTENWIESER: Our routine was define a congenial time to meet directly with the prospective contributor. To the considerable discomfort of my diet, it was either breakfast, lunch and dinner. It would usually be three of us. We would have a very pleasant meal together. Talk about what friends talk about. Bob's career and ultimately about the possibility of a contribution to his campaign. Q. Isn't it fair to say that these breakfast meetings with yourself were expressly designed to be the setting in which a request would be made of the contributor for a $15,000 pledge for Mr. Abrams's campaign? A. It was. Q. How did - you talked about these meetings with us on prior occasions. Isn't it fair to say to describe them as almost a formula in the sense that they tended to follow over and over and over again the same overall script? A. They did have a repetitious quality at least for Bob and for me. It was hard for me to vary the script enough to keep it - but I tried. . . . I don't want you to think that it totally revolved around eating. It could be a cocktail or it could be a visit in the office without a piece of bread being broken, but it did tend to have some element of nourishment involved. Q. That makes it something of a social affair? A. We tried to do that. Q. A little bit of a framework around the bald request for money? A. A nice change we called it. Helping a Party 'To Do Good Things' MR. MAGAVERN: Mr. Pressman, referring to the January 3, 1985 contribution to the Bronx Democratic Committee, $5,000. . . In your opinion, did that contribution enhance the economic environment of New York City? MR. PRESSMAN: No. Q. Did it have any relationship to the welfare or vitality of New York City? A. Only to the extent you are helping a political party which continues in its efforts to do good things for the city. Q. Was that party under any threat? Was there any competition that required or a particular need for funding? A. That, I would not know. CAMPAIGN FUND-RAISING: IT DOESN'T END WITH THE ELECTION Citywide elections were in November 1985 and statewide elections were in November 1986. $ Citywide Offices Receipts Expenditures Edward I. Koch 1983 $1,033,000 $143,000 Mayor 1984 2,071,000 637,000 1985 3,743,000 5,981,000 1986 765,000 870,000 1987 741,000 185,000 Andrew J. Stein 1983 * * City Council President 1984 * * 1985 $3,114,000 $3,076,000 1986 367,000 390,000 1987 199,000 142,000 Harrison J. Goldin 1983 $238,000 $51,000 City Comptroller 1984 700,000 108,000 1985 1,217,000 380,000 1986 126,000 355,000 1987 81,000 210,000 Statewide Offices Receipts Expenditures Mario M. Cuomo 1983 $1,427,000 $312,000 Governor 1984 2,273,000 257,000 1985 4,875,000 1,029,000 1986 1,146,000 5,472,000 1987 261,000 331,000 Stan Lundine 1983 * * Lieutenant Governor 1984 * * 1985 * * 1986 $1,205,000 $1,157,000 1987 77,000 83,000 Edward V. Regan 1983 $285,000 $36,000 State Comptroller 1984 312,000 287,000 1985 579,000 342,000 1986 2,338,000 2,623,000 1987 863,000 737,000 Robert Abrams 1983 $249,000 $208,000 Attorney General 1984 25,000 35,000 1985 234,000 86,000 1986 1,970,000 2,101,000 1987 349,000 208,000 * Campaign for current office had not yet begun. Sources: New York State Commission on Government Integrity, New York City Board of Elections

title: Steinbrenner Panel Swings Into Action
description: The panel appointed to review policies and programs of the United States Olympic Committee, with George Steinbrenner as chairman, has begun work. Its report is due next month.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Battle on Central Front
description: Iran and Iraq reported heavy fighting on their central warfront today, and shipping officials said an Iranian gunboat had attacked a Liberian tanker in the Persian Gulf.

title: Parrot's Beak, 1988
description: If you're out to win a war against guerrillas - to crush an insurgency that is being helped from the outside - then it makes good military sense to ''clean out the sanctuaries.''

title: Advertising; An Altered Perspective In Bank Ads
description: AT Warwick Advertising the thinking is that since most people don't like banks they aren't going to believe all those smiling, obliging folks who inhabit bank commercials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 21, 1988
description: Companies

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A recent answer that underlined Lou Gehrig's proficiency for batting runs home during his career pointed out that he averaged nearly one run batted in a game for his career. In how many seasons did Gehrig average more than one r.b.i. a game? Did he do it the most times?

title: Temple Pounds Georgetown; Richmond Gains
description: There was a sharp edge to the game, a discomfort factor that made it feel as if the fans were sitting on tacks or a siren was screaming in the background the whole time. It was attributable to Georgetown's disconcerting, high-energy style, the tenacious defense played by both teams and the booming voices that the Hoyas' coach, John Thompson, and his Temple counterpart, John Chaney, exercise with regularity.

title: Virginia Plane Crash Kills 3
description: A small civilian airplane crashed today on Quantico Marine Base as it tried to fly out of a snowstorm, killing all three people on board, the authorities said. They said the single-engine Cessna 210 left Greensboro, N.C., at 8:25 A.M. and was headed for National Airport at Washington. A Marine spokesman said the plane crashed in a field between a chapel where services were in progress, and Lejeune Hall, the base headquarters. No one on the ground was hurt.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said results for the latest year include a gain of $4,716,000 from the sale of oil and gas properties.

title: President Is Named Knight-Ridder Chief
description: James K. Batten, president of Knight-Ridder Inc., will also assume the duties of the chief executive officer of the Miami-based national newspaper and broadcasting chain next month.

title: 10 INJURED AS FIRE DESTROYS 2 BUILDINGS IN WASHINGTON HGTS.
description: Ten people, including eight firefigheters, were injured late yesterday in a four-alarm fire and explosion that destroyed two tenement buildings in Washington Heights, officials said.

title: Panama's Showcase Comes to Grief
description: Gustavo Vivas, the manager of a small trading company here, glumly hefted a thick sheaf of suddenly obsolete shipping invoices and let them drop back onto his desk.

title:
FENCING;
Soviet Fencer Wins in Saber
description: LEAD: Soviet fencers dominated the Enterprise Press New York International saber tournament yesterday. Sergei Mindirgasov, a 28-year-old army lieutenant from Lvov, defeated Imre Bujdoso of Hungary in the championship bout, 10 touches to 8. His teammate, Grigory Pogosov, defeated Robert Koscielnakowski of

title: Fund Raising Shouldn't Be a Senator's Main Job; Equalize TV Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Who Quit Replaced At Sears Merchandise Unit
description: Matthew A. Howard, who has been with Sears, Roebuck & Company for 26 years, has been named senior executive vice president of merchandising for the Sears Merchandise Group.

title: Dismal Legacy on Civil Rights
description: Ronald Reagan appears determined to go down in history as a President who sought actively to set back the cause of civil rights. How else can one read his veto of the four-year, bipartisan effort to restore the reach of antidiscrimination laws narrowed by a Supreme Court ruling? Congress appears to have the votes to override the veto. Decency argues for doing so, without delay.

title: 2 Ringers Aid Homeless
description: Two of the tallest members of Congress, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey (6 feet 5 inches) and Representative Tom McMillen of Maryland (6 feet 11), both Democrats, are scheduled to reach out - or up - to the homeless Wednesday night as forwards in a benefit basketball game against a pickup team of Georgetown University law professors.

title: Overcrowding Pervades Prison Life in Connecticut
description: Deputy Warden Frank M. Crose was making his daily telephone call to the Department of Correction with the morning head count of inmates at the lone maximum-security prison in the state.

title: U.S. MOVES TROOPS CLOSER TO BORDER
description: To reinforce a demand by the Reagan Administration that Nicaraguan troops withdraw from Honduras, 700 American soldiers were deployed here today, 15 miles from the border between the two nations.

title: All-Round Jump Rope
