description: That classic of childhood games, skipping rope, has a new look and feel these days. Professional athletes have always known its value for fitness training. But most adults left their jump ropes in the toy box.

title: Weathering the Crack Storm in Queens
description: The year's first crocuses have pushed through the winter soil, and an American flag rattles in the stiff March wind at a garden on the corner of Lakewood Avenue and Inwood Street in South Jamaica, Queens.

SCS/COMPUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: Supremacists Force A.T.&T. to Set Vote on Hiring
description: Contending that blacks are intellectually inferior, a white supremacist group has forced the American Telephone and Telegraph Company into asking shareholders to vote on ending the company's minority hiring program.

title: Metro Matters; Leading Workers In Home Care Out of Poverty
description: ''I have walked up the steps; I have shopped for them,'' Martha Green said. ''I have been stuck in the elevator. I have gone into very dangerous buildings, but I also ask God to protect me because someone has to do for them. If we live to reach some of our clients' ages, we need someone to care for us.''

title: COLOROCS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Worker Dies in Arsenal Fire
description: Fire erupted Saturday night at the Radford Army Arsenal, killing one worker and injuring six. The fire started at 7 P.M. in a building where a propellant for rockets is produced and was under brought control by 8:50, said a spokeswoman, Frances Selnow.

title: Grolier's Response Expected Soon
description: Andrew J. Reinhart, president and chief operating officer of Grolier Inc., said Friday that the company's board will make a recommendation to shareholders by the middle of this week on the offer by Hachette S.A. of France.

title: Changing Times Turn Tables On a 'Saint' of the Stalin Era
description: Pavlik Morozov, the boy martyr who was glorified as a model Communist for denouncing his father to the Soviet authorities as a class enemy in 1932, is now being portrayed here as a tragic symbol of the warped morality of an earlier era.

title: Valley Falls Journal; On Ranch, Yearly Rite Of Life And Profit
description: Near a thicket down in a hollow far from the herd, a newborn calf still damp from its birthing climbed up on wobbly legs and stumbled off after his mother. She edged away a few steps, then turned. The calf nosed at her belly, and the old cow licked his flank.

title: COMP-U-CHECK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said the prior fourth quarter and year figures are restated as a result of transactions between the company and David T. Marantette 3d, the company's former chairman and chief executive.

title: Pacers Defeat Punchless Nets
description: With the National Basketball Association headed into the final month of its regular season, the Central Division, which once appeared certain to put all six of its teams into the eight-team Eastern Conference playoff field, has gone topsy-turvy.

title: More Cause to Pause on Trade
description: When Congress started work on the foreign trade bill three years ago, the trade deficit was bad and rapidly getting worse. The Senate and House are still negotiating a final bill, even as the deficit threat is finally easing. The gap between imports and exports remains serious, but the narrowing should instruct, and give pause to, members who would build new walls of protection around America's factories and farms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a provider of financing, named Nicholas R. Rasmussen executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Man Fatally Beaten By East Harlem Mob Angry at $20 Theft
description: A 41-year-old man who was accused of snatching $20 from a woman in a bakery in East Harlem was fatally beaten yesterday by more than a dozen angry people who chased and caught him about a block from the store, the police said.

title: Leiter Searches for Perfection
description: Al Leiter sat at his locker stall today and fought off the disappointment of an unsatisfactory outing. But the longer he thought about it, the less unhappy he became. Finally, the Yankee rookie shrugged, rose from his seat and began to walk away.

title: Shamir Assails His U.S. Jewish Critics
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel lashed out yesterday against American Jews who have been pressing the United States Government to force Israel to accept an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli dispute.

title: Hachette: From Zola To a $3 Billion Giant
description: Prof. Louis Hachette saw a business opportunity emerging in the early days of railroads and, in 1826, won the first newspaper concession in Paris stations.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $286,000, or 8 cents a share, for both the quarter and year from the lower tax provision on certain foreign earnings resulting from the company's decision, in the fourth quarter, to invest such earnings on a permanent basis. c-Includes a non-recurring gain of $383,000 for the quarter and a non- recurring loss of $175,000 for the year.

title: Departing Official
description: Diana Dougan, Assistant Secretary of State and Coordinator for International Communication and Information Policy, has resigned to work on George Bush's Presidential campaign.

title: Hockey in Harlem
description: He may have cut quite a figure in his 40-goal days with the Rangers, and there may be some neighborhoods where his name is a household word, but as Pat Hickey found out a while back, Harlem isn't one of them.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,659,000 and a writedown of $11,191,000 related to the company's coal operations which includes a charge of $1,924,000 from an accounting charge. The company recently changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from June 30 and year-earlier comparative figures were not available. However, for the 6 months ended Dec. 31, 1986, it said it had net from continuing operations of $1,327,000, or 4 cents a share. A loss from discontinued operations of $1,481,000 which includes a charge of $1,029,000 from an accounting change, on revenue of $12,633,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Devils' Blight Is Ended
description: Two short-handed goals a minute apart late in the game provided the margin today for the first victory in the Devils' history at Capital Centre.

title: European Bank Plan Supported
description: West Germany officially gave its support last week to the establishment of a Western European central bank that would be independent of European Community governments. Finance Minister Gerhard

title: Daniel Woolf Jr., Professor, 77
description: Dr. Daniel Woolf Jr. died of a heart attack on March 14 as he was driving near Springfield, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: John Reverand, TV Editor, Weds Leslie Joan Gersing
description: Leslie Joan Gersing, the deputy director of public information for Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York, and John Stanley Reverand, an editor and a field producer with the WPIX Independent News television network in New York, were married yesterday at La Bibliotheque, a restaurant in Manhattan. Acting Justice Richard L. Price of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: Steel Imports Increase
description: Steel imports rose in January from the previous month and were sharply higher than in January 1987, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Thursday. The increase came almost entirely from developing nations not covered by the Reagan Administration's voluntary import quotas, the institute said. The January imports were 1.81 million tons, up 7 percent from 1.69 million tons in December and up 24 percent from 1.46 million tons in January 1987.

title: Mr. Gorbachev's Peace Eraser
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has launched another disarmament proposal. He must be up to several dozen in his three-year tenure, but who's counting? In his latest, made last week in Yugoslavia, he proposes to freeze the number of Soviet and American warships in the Mediterranean and then to withdraw the fleets altogether. What could be fairer? Well, maybe extending the naval-free zone to the Black Sea would even things out a little.

title: MANATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Review/Dance; In Boston, Pliesetskaya Heads a Bolshoi Troupe
description: There is something about ''living legends'' that triumphs against all odds and counsel. One has only to cite Maya Plisetskaya's performance here in the second ballet program of what is officially billed as Making Music Together, the American-Soviet Cultural Exchange Festival.

title: Latest Study Disputes Link Of Breast Cancer to Alcohol
description: A new study of 7,000 women has found no association between alcohol consumption and breast cancer, researchers reported today.

title: Review/Film; Australian 'Toads' and 'Feathers'
description: Pet or pest? This is the question posed by ''Cane Toads: An Unnatural History,'' a short Australian documentary that's an absolute delight. It supplies the answers to every conceivable question the viewer may have about the species in question, and a few extras: What can the toad do for tourism? What sort of person goes out of his way to squash cane toads while driving? Who feeds his favorite toads cat food, or thinks they look nice in baby clothes?

title: Man Becomes Machine For Feat of Mythic Size
description: THE body as a machine will receive one of its ultimate tests in coming weeks as a group from Massachusetts Institute of Technology attempts to fly a 70-pound human-powered airplane between the Greek islands of Crete and Santorini. They hope to set a distance record for human-powered flight while re-enacting the mythical feat of Daedalus, who escaped imprisonment on Crete by building wings of feathers and wax and flying to freedom.

title: Review/Theater; 'M. Butterfly,' a Story Of a Strange Love, Conflict and Betrayal
description: It didn't require genius for David Henry Hwang to see that there were the makings of a compelling play in the 1986 newspaper story that prompted him to write ''M. Butterfly.'' Here was the incredible true-life tale of a career French foreign service officer brought to ruin - conviction for espionage - by a bizarre 20-year affair with a Beijing Opera diva. Not only had the French diplomat failed to recognize that his lover was a spy; he'd also failed to figure out that ''she'' was a he in drag. ''It was dark, and she was very modest,'' says Gallimard (John Lithgow), Mr. Hwang's fictionalized protagonist, by half-joking way of explanation. When we meet him in the prison cell where he reviews his life, Gallimard has become, according to own understatement, ''the patron saint of the socially inept.''

title: Pepsi Sets Off a Cola War in India
description: More than a decade after Coca-Cola was kicked out of India in a burst of economic nationalism, a new cola war has erupted here over a proposal to let Pepsi-Cola compete with local soft-drink producers.

title: Dream Come True
description: It's been six years since Dan Doyle, a former basketball coach at Trinity College in Hartford, founded the Irish American Sports Foundation to help make basketball a big-time sport in Ireland, and now, after a string of interim successes, one of his original dreams is about to come true.

title: HRE PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes gains on sales of properties of $145,000 for the latest quarter and $126,000 for the year-earlier quarter.

title: Fund Raising Shouldn't Be a Senator's Main Job; Contribution Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Client Outlook Unclear After Lord's Defection
description: Richard J. Lord, after leading five top executives out of a WPP Group subsidiary to start a new agency, was well aware Friday in his still bare office of the caution he must use to avoid a costly lawsuit from Martin Sorrell, chairman of the London-based WPP.

title: Campaign Finance; Mastermind of the Dukakis Success
description: Bob Farmer, mastermind of probably the most prosperous Democratic Presidential campaign in history, was on the phone again, stroking yet another ego.

title: Whittaker Chambers's Farm Is Proposed for Landmark
description: The National Park Service has proposed landmark status for the farm of Whittaker Chambers, whose allegations about Communist infiltration of the American Government created turmoil in the years of the cold war.

title: Bridge
description: Two players from the New York metropolitan region zoomed past the leaders here Saturday night to capture the men's pair title at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals. Steve Shane of White Plains and Arthur Hoffman of Maplewood, N.J., scored 64 percent in the fourth and final session, overtaking six pairs to snatch victory.

title: In Boston, It's Dine and Be Dined On
description: If he were not president of the Massachusetts Senate, William M. Bulger could always find work as a highbrow insult comic.

title: Louisiana Bank Failure
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said that First National Bank of Port Allen, La., had failed and that its deposits had been taken over by the Iberville Trust and Savings Bank of Plaquemine, La. The F.D.I.C. said that the Thursday failure was the 39th by an American bank this year.

title: OUTDOORS: STEPS TO STARGAZING
description: WHETHER from beach or mountain, meadow or city park, scanning the night skies is among summer's sweet pastimes. And with a little study a beginner will soon be able to identify many of the major constellations or their more prominent members.

title: Tribute to Wallenberg
description: A special art exhibit paying tribute to Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of people from being sent to Nazi death camps, will go on view Tuesday in the Rotunda of the House Cannon Office Building on Capitol Hill. Twenty-seven abstract collages by Alice Lok Cahana, a Houston artist whose family was seized in the Nazi takeover of Hungary, will be on display.

title: Soviet Trade Surplus in '87
description: The Soviet Union had a trade surplus with the West in 1987 for the first time in three years, according to official Soviet figures released today.

title: BATTERED CELTICS STILL CONTENDERS
description: LEAD: PLAYOFF time is on the horizon and here come the Celtics, battered, old, and winning. Yesterday's 137-107 rout of the Chicago Bulls was their seventh victory in their last eight games. Their record stands at 46-20, giving them an outside shot at another 60-victory season. And though they are locked in a close race with Detroit for the Eastern Conference title - and home-court advantage in the playoffs - there are more believers around now than at the beginning of the season, when a number of experts were predicting this year's team would not only fail to beat the

title: Not So Versatile
description: Except for such obvious mismatches as sumo wrestling and synchronized swimming, it is almost axiomatic that athletes who are good at one sport tend to be good at other sports. This is considered especially true for sports that rely on similar skills, such as tennis and golf, both of which demand a measure of hand-eye coordination.

title: Bidders' Plans For Federated
description: Several transactions involving various divisions of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores will depend on whether R.H. Macy & Company or the Campeau Corporation win Federated.

title: New Guidelines in New York Courts Aren't Just for AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dallas Museum Curator Going to San Francisco
description: The acting director and chief curator of the Dallas Museum of Art has resigned to take a position in San Francisco, museum officials have said.

title: FORUM RETIREMENT PARTNERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $76,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $90,000, both for the quarter and 9 months. c-After tax credits of $65,000 for the quarter and $301,000 for the 9 months.

title: Liverpool Streak Ends
description: Liverpool's bid to set an English League record by going unbeaten in its first 30 games of the season was ended today by a 1-0 loss to Everton, Liverpool's longtime rival.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We had foul and bloody murders committed in our parish yesterday. Our parish is seen as dripping in the blood of the murdered, and one thinks of the mob baying for the blood of Jesus.'' - The Rev. Thomas Toner in West Belfast. [ A3:1. ]

title: INSIDE
description: G.I.'s on Honduran Duty Seven hundred U.S. soldiers were deployed in a Honduran town 15 miles from the Nicaraguan border but 70 miles from the fighting. Page A9. Tyson Retains Title Mike Tyson knocked out Tony Tubbs in the second round in Toyko to retain his world heavyweight championship.

title: More Japanese Go Overseas
description: Japanese traveled abroad in record numbers last year, buoyed by the yen's appreciation against the dollar, with the United States their most popular destination. The number who went overseas in 1987 jumped by about 1,300,000, to a high of 6,829,000, according to a Justice Ministry report issued today.

title: Few Bids Are Expected For Republicbank . . . As Tension Mounts At First City of Texas
description: The battle between Wall Street arbitragers and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation over the rescue of the failing First City Bancorporation of Texas is coming to a head with the approach of the March 29 deadline for holders to tender their First City bonds.

title: Stock Offer For Sotheby's
description: The public may be able to buy shares this spring in Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the world's richest art auction house said.

title: Kohl's Party Wins State Election
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic party managed to maintain its control of West Germany's wealthiest state, Baden-Wurttemberg, in elections today.

title: Rangers Rally to Beat Whalers by 2-1
description: When Ron Meyer dropped the puck to start the third period last night, the unlikely went to war with the inevitable at Madison Square Garden.

title: Advertising; Wells, Rich Is Keeping Expanded Job for State
description: The New York State Department of Economic Development, having reviewed a field of five ad agencies, has decided to keep Wells, Rich, Greene, the shop that gave it the stunning ''I Love New York'' campaign.

title: Azinger's 7 Birdies Win Down Stretch
description: Paul Azinger broke open a two-man contest with Tom Kite when he made seven birdies in a 10-hole stretch today to win the $750,000 Hertz Bay Hill Classic by five shots. This was the widest winning margin on the PGA Tour this year.

title: LTV Plans To Cut 350
description: The LTV Corporation said Friday that it would lay off about 350 workers in its missiles and electronics group because of the expected cancellation next week of an Air Force anti-satellite weapon system.

title: PSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for the latest year included two non-recurring after-tax charges totaling $3,016,000.

title: PRESIDENT'S PARTY IS BADLY DEFEATED IN SALVADOR VOTE
description: The governing Christian Democratic Party suffered a major defeat in national municipal and legislative elections here today, according to party officials.

title: Neglect Dulls the Glory Of a Once Famous Hall
description: At the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, in an open colonnade on the highest hill in the Bronx, the bronze likenesses of 87 men and 10 women have long been suffering the ravages of time.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,202,000 for the quarter and income of $64,127,000 for the year both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $5,853,000 and $20,511,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes an extraordinary loss from the extinguishment of debt of $3,000,000. Latest fourth quarter results from discontinued operations include a $2,000,000 after-tax loss from settling litigation concerning medical insurance coverage from one of the company's former businesses. The company said income from discontinued operations in the latest year includes an after-tax gain of $87,000,000, or $3.68 a share, from selling General Host's 75 percent interest in All American Gourmet Co. and an after-tax loss of $17,000,000 from settling litigation concerning medical insurance coverage claimed by retirees of a business General Host discontinued in 1980. The company also said income from discontinued operations in the prior year includes after-tax gains totaling $16,114,000, or 62 cents a share, (after fourth quarter reductions of $4,473,000 principally for additional income taxes), from All American Gourmet's sale of one million additional shares to the public and from selling Milk Specialties Co. and the Hot Sam Cos. division. Sales of the discontinued operations, amounting to $7,423,000 and $130,922,000 in the quarter and year ended Jan. 31, 1988, and $141,904,000 and $326,889,000 in the quarter and year ended Jan. 25, 1987, are excluded from results.

title: Joffrey Ballet Names Group To Help in Founder's Illness
description: The Joffrey Ballet has announced the appointment of an advisory group to help administer the company during the illness of Robert Joffrey, the troupe's founder and artistic director.

title: CELL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WHAT IT IS WOMEN WANT
description: SEVERAL years ago a coach of amateur fighters in Arizona feared that one of his proteges might have to box the first female contestant in Golden Gloves history.

title: Rena Sterman Marries Scott Hoffman
description: At Congregation Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., Rena G. Sterman, an associate in the New York law firm of Loeb & Loeb, was married yesterday to Scott D. Hoffman, an associate in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. Rabbis Max N. Schreier and Murray Grauer performed the ceremony.

title: Livestock Killed On Road
description: A herd of beefalo, which are part-bison and part-cattle, roamed onto the Florida Turnpike early today, causing five accidents. Seven beefalo were killed, the police said, and one motorist was slightly injured. Sgt. Alvis Chinn of the Florida Highway Patrol said 75 to 100 animals from a 400-head herd broke through a hole in a fence along the Florida Turnpike Extension in northwest Dade County. Investigators believe that horse thieves had initially cut the fence.

title: Novel by Philip Roth Wins Literary Award
description: Philip Roth's new novel, ''The Counterlife,'' won in the fiction category of the Ninth Annual Present Tense/Joel H. Cavior Literary Awards, which were announced at a luncheon at the national headquarters of the American Jewish Committee.

title: Secret Advance in Nuclear Fusion Spurs a Dispute Among Scientists
description: In top-secret experiments, Federal researchers have achieved one of the nation's most costly and elusive scientific goals: to ignite a nuclear fusion reaction in tiny pellets of hydrogen, producing powerful bursts of energy.

title: New Sense of Bearish Sentiment
description: The bond market rally kindled by October's collapse in stock prices has ended, many credit market analysts contend.

title: The No. 1 Issue In '88
description: LEAD: In 1980, the Republicans capitalized on people's fears of America's vulnerability and rode a wave of military nationalism to political victory. To capture the White House in 1988, Democrats must tap the public's fear of America's economic vulnerability in a changing world marketplace.

title: 2 OLD LINEMATES ENJOY A REUNION
description: As Bobby Hull waited in the Madison Square Garden corridor for yesterday's Pro-Celebrity Hockey Challenge to begin, the Hall of Famer recalled a night when Ulf Nilsson was bruised from head to toe.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $678,000 tax credit.

title: INVENTED LEWYT VACUUM CLEANER
description: Alexander M. Lewyt, a manufacturer and inventor who developed a vacuum cleaner that bore his name, died Friday at his home in Sands Point, L.I. He was 79 years old and also lived in Manhattan and Chartres, France.

title: Cable Widens Choices Available on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Jenifer Millstone Wed To Victor S. Schonfeld
description: Jenifer Payne Millstone and Victor Simon Schonfeld, film makers, were married yesterday in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Murray Grauer performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Moses Schonfeld.

title: Robert Goralski, News correspondent, 60
description: Robert Goralski, a longtime correspondent for NBC News, died of cancer Friday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 60 years old.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary credit of $90,000.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA TECHNOLOIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COMPUTER COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
QUARTERLY SALE OF 4-YEAR NOTES SCHEDULED
description: Treasury financings scheduled for the week include today's auction of new three-month and six-month bills. The regular monthly auction of two-year notes is set for Wednesday, followed on Thursday by new four-year notes, which are sold once every quarter.

title: New Yorkers & Co.;
description: James J. Warfield tapped nervously on the computer keyboard in his office on the 57th floor of the Chrysler Building last week, tracking the price of oil while he waited for news from Panama.

title: G.E. Adds $9 to Offer For Roper
description: Two days after being sued, the General Electric Company raised its bid for the Roper Corporation by $9 a share, to $54, or $507 million, topping the latest offer of $50 a share made by the Whirlpool Corporation.

title: Review/Art; A Look at Pei's Pyramid in the Louvre Courtyard
description: Parisians love novelty, and right now they are happy to climb a scaffold in penetrating cold and damp. Once at the top, they have a grandstand view of the pyramid that I. M. Pei was asked by President Francois Mitterrand to design for the three-sided western courtyard of the Louvre.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $20,000, a gain on disposition of subsidiaries totaling $1,616,000, as well as a tax benefit of $120,000. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $81,000 and a tax benefit of $62,000. The company said that at Jan. 31 it wrote down against continuing operations its excess costs over net assets of purchased subsidiaries by $2,385,000 before taxes, as related to the original acquisition of its exercise equipment manufacturing company. The company also said that in the latest first quarter it recorded a gross gain of $2,450,000 on the previously announced sale of its structural steel subsidiary.

title: In New York, Quest for Campaign Money Never Ends
description: Faced with ever-rising campaign costs and hoping to intimidate potential challengers, top officeholders in New York State have geared up their fund-raising operations to run constantly, not just during election seasons.

title: Business and the Law; In-House Use Of Economists
description: MOST of Carolyn Brancato's colleagues at Weil, Gotshal & Manges mark their time by poring over legal briefs, writing merger agreements and putting clients into Chapter 11 bankruptcies.

title: Air Canada-Airbus Deal
description: Air Canada is near agreement with Europe's Airbus Industrie to buy 34 short-haul A320 airliners and take options on 20 more in a contract worth more than 10 billion francs, or about $1.75 billion, the newspaper Le Monde said Friday. A spokeswoman for the European consortium declined to confirm the report, but said Airbus was in talks with Air Canada as well as with other airlines. If confirmed, this would be the first purchase of Airbus planes by Air Canada.

title: Miniskirt, Maxi Blunder
description: LEAD: For many American women, the big news a couple of weeks ago was made not in the Middle East or the Super Tuesday primaries but in our own home towns, where the fashion industry is taking a major bath on the miniskirt.

title: Noriega Is Said to Store Cuban Arms
description: A Panamanian air force officer who was granted political asylum in the United States on Friday after an unsuccessful coup attempt in Panama said today that the military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, was stockpiling Cuban arms in the country.

title: Cefis Captures Tampa Bay Derby
description: If recent history repeats itself, Eddie Maple may have come out a winner when he lost the mount last week on Forty Niner, the favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 7.

title: HONEYBEE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes $733,104 after taxes of Key-Man-Insurance proceeds, net of related non-recurriing expense and the expenses of a withdrawn secondary stock offering. c-Net income d-After a loss of $215,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Liberal Arts, Tight Credit
description: College students who major in liberal arts -good for the mind but not necessarily for the purse - know they may not end up in the money. Haven't their parents been pointing out to them all this time that it's just as easy to study business as it is, say, semiotics?

title: After Trial, Homosexuals Say Justice Is Not Blind
description: Members of San Francisco's gay community contend that the authorities' response to a slaying here has demonstrated that the American judicial system often devalues the lives of homosexuals.

title: Review/Television; Olivier Portrays an Italian Patriarch
description: A company of estimable British actors is dishing out an antipasto of Italian accents tonight on Channel 9, at 8 o'clock. The occasion is Eduardo de Filippo's ''Saturday, Sunday, Monday,'' a soup opera about an extended middle-class Neapolitan family engaged in a weekend of extended expostulations.

title: Derailment Forces Residents To Flee a Town in Minnesota
description: Twenty railroad cars, including nine hauling chemicals, derailed Saturday, forcing the evacuation of a town of 1,700 people for seven hours, officials said.

title: Tyson Wastes No Time Retaining Title
description: Join to the list of fighters both obscure and reknowned the name of Tony Tubbs, who today at the Tokyo Dome became Mike Tyson's 30th knockout victim. The end came for Tubbs at 2:54 of the second round.

title: From Irish Pulpit, Sense of Revulsion
description: As priests denounced murder from parish pulpits, Irish nationalists braced today for an expected security roundup of the funeral mob that killed two British soldiers Saturday.

title: Anti-Contra Drive: Ill-Fated Shift in Rebel Tactics
description: The Sandinista offensive last week along the Nicaraguan-Honduran border succeeded in damaging the American-backed rebels because the contras violated a fundamental axiom of guerrilla war by allowing themselves to become a fixed target.

title: Sports People; Soccer Panel Chosen
description: Henry Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, has been named chairman of a 16-member advisory panel formed to help the United States secure the World Cup soccer championship in 1994. Paul Stiehl, the director of World Cup USA 1994, which is coordinating the project on behalf of the United States Soccer Federation, made the announcement yesterday in Washington and added that Drew Lewis, the former Secretary of Transportation, and Steven J. Ross, the chairman of Warner Communications, would serve as vice chairmen. With Brazil and Morocco also candidates to host the 1994 event, FIFA, soccer's world governing body, will announce its selection on July 4.(AP)

title: HEALTHSOUTH REHABILITATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $14,000 and $622,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $316,000 for the quarter and $456,000 for the year.

title: John Marin Jr., Donor Of His Father's Art, 73
description: John Marin Jr., who for more than 40 years was the caretaker of both the collection and the memory of his father, the American artist John Marin, died of cancer Saturday at his home on Cape Split in Addison, Me. He was 73 years old.

title: Standard Stock Up On Kelso Remark
description: Shares of American Standard Inc. rose 87.5 cents in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $76.75, after Kelso & Company said that it might increase its $78-a-share agreement to acquire the company. But Kelso, a Manhattan investment firm, said that it would not decide before March 31, the day before an offer of $77 a share from the Black & Decker Corporation is due to expire. Kelso's offer expires April 15.

title: Back to Corporate Payoffs Abroad?
description: LEAD: As James C. McKay, the special prosecutor, continues investigating the Iraqi pipeline affair, Congress seems poised to gut the very antibribery law Attorney General Edwin P. Meese 3d allegedly ignored.

title: TEXSTYRENE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $139,000 from extinguishment of debt and a loss of $7,184,000 from an accounting change. The company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Jan. 31. The latest year contains 12 months, while the prior fiscal year comprises 11 months.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $176,000 on sale of securities and property. c-After a gain of $858,000 on the sale of securities and property for the quarter and a gain of $1,711,000 for the 6 months.

title: Nickel Posts Record High
description: The price paid for nickel on the London Metal Exchange soared to a record high today, fueled by unexpectedly strong demand from the stainless steel industry, metal traders said.

title: New Debate About Nuclear Energy
description: After a decade with few ground-breakings for large electricity generating stations, utilities in some regions anticipate a need for new capacity and are turning toward small plants built by independent suppliers.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L Montreal Unbeaten in 14: Larry Robinson, a defenseman, scored with 7 minutes 53 seconds to play in the third period last night, enabling the Canadiens to tie the Calgary Flames, 3-3, at Montreal and extend their unbeaten streak to 14 games. The tie gave the Canadiens a 12-0-2 record in that span. The Flames, meanwhile, extended their current unbeaten streak to seven (5-0-2). The tie also left the Flames, unbeaten in their last nine road games, 1 point ahead of Montreal in the overall league standing. (AP) N.B.A. Hawks 115, Bucks 105: Kevin Willis scored 7 of his 19 points during an 18-4 third-quarter run that broke open a tight game and carried Atlanta to the home victory. The spurt covered a four-minute stretch midway through the period and left Atlanta (40-24) with an 85-73 lead over Milwaukee (36-28). Dominique Wilkins, who led all scorers with 35 points, and Antoine Carr scored 4 points apiece during that stretch.(AP) N.I.T. UConn Reaches Quarterfinal: Cliff Robinson scored 17 points and Connecticut overcame a sluggish start in the second half last night for a 65-59 victory over Louisiana Tech in a second-round game in Hartford. Louisiana Tech (22-9) took its only lead by scoring the first 9 points of the second half for a 38-36 edge. Connecticut (17-14) then went on an 8-point run, including two jump shots by Robinson. The Huskies, making their first postseason appearance since 1982, had their best shooting game of the season, making 67.5 percent from the field. (AP) Tennis Evert Wins in Straight Sets: Chris Evert, seeded second, won in straight sets yesterday at the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Evert beat Pascale Paradis of France, 6-4, 6-2, to advance to the quarterfinals. Evert will next face fifth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, who beat 12th-seeded Raffaella Reggie of Italy, 6-3, 6-0. The men who advanced were led by second-seeded Jimmy Connors, who eliminated Amos Mansdorf of Israel, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3. Like Evert, Connors has won every set he has played in the two-week hard-court tournament. In another feature match Miroslav Mecir, seeded third, started slowly but then won 11 straight games as he beat Mikael Pernfors of Sweden, 7-5, 6-0, 6-1. (AP)

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,737,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $11,000.

title: Judge Bars Shifting of Air Shuttle
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Eastern Air Lines Inc. to abandon its plans to sell or transfer its shuttle to its parent, the Texas Air Corporation.

title: How the Curtain Rose Again at Ford's Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Birnbaum, 83, Author of Books For Jewish Liturgy
description: Dr. Philip Birnbaum, a Jewish scholar and author whose translation of the synagogue liturgy has sold 300,000 copies since it was first published in 1949, died Saturday at his Manhattan home. He was 83 years old.

title: Gore Backs Israeli Peace Plan Rejection
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. today became the first Presidential candidate to express qualified support for the Israeli Prime Minister's rejection of the Reagan Administration's peace proposals for the Middle East.

title: 5 Pershing Missiles Tested; Launching Called Successful
description: Five of the Army's Pershing 2 missiles were flight-tested today at the Air Force space and missile test center range here.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2d Honda Plant in U.S.
description: Honda broke ground on Sunday for a second United States auto assembly plant. The plant is scheduled to open in August 1989, company officials said. The $380 million factory will employ 1,800 workers and have the capacity to proaduce 150,000 cars a year. Honda began manufacturing in the United States in 1979 at its motorcycle plant in Marysville, 35 miles northwest of Columbus. The auto plant at Marysville began production three years later.

title: Robert Brustein Wins Drama Criticism Award
description: Robert Brustein, theater critic for The New Republic, has won the 1987 George Jean Nathan Award for Dramatic Criticism. Mr. Brustein, who also is artistic director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and professor of English at Harvard University, won the award in 1962 and is the first person to receive it twice.

title: Corrections
description: An article Monday on alcohol and breast cancer misstated the number of subjects in a new study by the Centers for Disease Control. The study involved about 6,000 women.

title: FUNDS UP SHARPLY FOR JACKSON CAMP
description: Contributions to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign leaped dramatically in the first two months of this year as the campaign started to build a sophisticated fund-raising operation.

title: In Paris, 2 Attractive Opposites
description: Christian Lacroix and Karl Lagerfeld have clearly emerged as the pillars of the new fashion season, as the fall and winter openings hurtle along. Intriguingly, they are on opposite sides of the fashion spectrum.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10 A.M. HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company attributed the decline in revenue principally to the sale of its hospital products group in 1986.

title: Advertising; Margeotes Gains New Recognition
description: ''IT used to be,'' said George A. Fertitta, president of Margeotes/ Fertitta & Weiss, ''that when we were after an account the competition was usually our size. Now because of the mergers the big agencies are going after smaller but noncompetitive accounts.''

title: Gil Evans, a Key Jazz Composer And Orchestrator, Is Dead at 75
description: Gil Evans, one of America's great jazz composers and arrangers, died of peritonitis Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where he had gone to recover from prostate surgery. He was 75 years old.

title: Batus Takes Step To Support Offer
description: To obtain support for its takeover offer, Batus Inc. has begun to solicit proxies from the shareholders of the Farmers Group Inc. to submit them at the company's annual meeting on May 20. Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance company, has spurned a $4.4 billion tender offer from Batus. The company has held discussions with other unspecified suitors and has outlined other possible defensive moves to remain independent.

title: A Supernova Search
description: ON Thursday astronomers will begin the most detailed search ever of the Milky Way, looking for remnants of supernova stellar explosions. The search, using the world's most powerful radio telescope, will take two years.

title: Allied-Signal Cites Error
description: A processing error at Allied-Signal caused a loss of millions of dollars in an employee retirement savings plan during the stock market crash in October, company officials said. Allied said it was making up the difference to employees.

title: KEY RATES
Review Of T.W.A. Strike Set
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Trans World Airlines had acted illegally when it refused to create vacancies for returning strikers at the end of an unsuccessful strike in 1986 by laying off 1,300 nonstriking flight attendants who had less seniority.

title: Sentence Reduced On Tainted Candy
description: The former professor who sent a box of poisoned chocolates to a Federal judge has had his 40-year prison sentence cut in half, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: MEYERS, L E CO GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue represent contract revenue.

title: Retail Merchants Group Gets Its First Economist
description: For many years, the National Retail Merchants Association, the industry's largest trade group, never had an economist. But as of yesterday, it does, in the person of Rosalind Wells, who decided to stay behind when the J. C. Penney Company moved its national headquarters to Dallas from New York.

title: Another Campeau Setback
description: The Campeau Corporation yesterday suffered a new legal setback in its battle with R. H. Macy & Company to acquire Federated Department Stores Inc.

title: Topics of The Times; A Dying Tradition?
description: Factory-prepared food is well established in the American diet. Fresh food may be tastier, cheaper and healthier, but the ''heat-and-serve'' variety spares time, work and mess. Bread. Meat and potatoes. Gourmet dishes. Whole meals. What will they think of next? How about pre-colored Easter eggs?

title: Fatal Qualities Of AIDS Virus Grows Clearer
description: SCIENTISTS may be a long way from finding a cure for AIDS, but they are getting to know the AIDS virus in extraordinary detail.

title: 3 Books to Aid Users of I.B.M. PC's
description: THREE books, one a revision of a standard, one recent and one brand-new, should be of interest to users of I.B.M. machines and their clones.

title: Guidry Considers Life Without Pitching
description: He is 37 years old and trying to come back from surgery on his left shoulder. By the time the season ends, his two-year contract will have expired. When he sits around the clubhouse these days, he spends more time thinking about his Louisiana home and his three children than his pitching. Every day, Ron Guidry comes closer to a decision.

title: CUNY Relaxes Its Plan to Alter Teacher Course
description: The trustees of the City University of New York voted yesterday not to force its nine senior colleges immediately to abolish the education major for aspiring teachers.

title: A Genial Fischer-Dieskau Reflects on Life and Lieder
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's song recital at Carnegie Hall tonight will be his first in America since 1980. His long absence only serves to make him seem even more a living legend; he has been singing professionally for 41 years and has been world-famous for most of them. His art and style have virtually defined lieder singing (even when they provide a model to be reacted against) for a whole generation of singers. And he was the first artist to bring into the normal sphere of recital programming whole realms of difficult German song now performed by dozens of artists every season.

title: MCCORMICK CAPITAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Stunned Britain Vows to Act on Deaths of Soldiers
description: Denouncing the ''bestial'' gunmen of the Irish Republican Army, the Thatcher Government today promised a ''massive murder investigation'' in the slaying of two British soldiers who apparently blundered into an I.R.A. funeral for a victim of a terrorist attack last week.

title: For Chile Opposition, the Word Is No
description: After years of feuding over what tactics to use against President Augusto Pinochet, most of the Chilean opposition has united in a campaign to try to vote him out of power in the coming plebiscite.

title: Storefront Postal Services Thriving
description: Consumers may be grumbling about the new cutbacks in hours by the United States Postal Service, but some people could not be happier: those offering private mailbox and postal services.

title: Town Is Short of Food and Patience
description: The lines started forming at dawn today outside Christ the Redeemer Roman Catholic Church, and by 9 A.M. nearly 700 residents of this sprawling working-class district had gotten something resembling what they had come for: a loaf of white bread and some eggs.

title: WINSTON RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge; A Big Score is Made in Open Pair Championship Play at the Spring Nationals in Buffalo
description: A remarkable score marked the start of play in the open pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's spring nationals here Sunday. Roy Fox and Ralph Katz of Chicago began the competition with a 74.9 percent session, believed to be the biggest on such an occasion in more than two decades.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 54 Feared Dead on 2 Oil Tankers In Iraqi Attack on Iran Terminal
description: More than 50 crewmen from two Iranian supertankers were missing and presumed dead today after an Iraqi air strike Saturday on Iran's Kharg Island oil terminal, shipping officials said.

title: Review/Marimba; Percussive And Lyric Works
description: William Moersch's instrument is the marimba, and he is drawn to contemporary works that challenge his technical and interpretive skills. On Thursday evening, he brought five recent scores to Alice Tully Hall for a performance that was impressive and at times transfixing. Particularly appealing was a new concerto by Richard Rodney Bennett. Cast in Mr. Bennett's familiar blend of free atonality and glowing lyricism, the work sets the marimba against gorgeous string writing and a soloistic tapestry of winds, giving Mr. Moersch two athletic cadenzas.

title: Bond Prices Fall; Bill Rates Rise
description: Bond prices fell again yesterday as nervous traders, worried about a flare-up of inflation, responded to a drop in the dollar and a rise in commodity prices by selling fixed-income securities.

title: Lower Dollar Means Foreign Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; Lubovitch and Brahms: Exuberant Partnership
description: Lar Lubovitch can certainly invent steps. At times, he has even filled dances with so many steps as to make them look congested. But in some of his recent creations he has carefully rationed and ordered steps, and his choreography has grown more satisfying.

title: FIRST CENTRAL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUNBELT NURSERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Tubbs's Challenge Was Brief and Sad
description: Of all the sad moments in Tony Tubbs's woeful day, perhaps the saddest came when people started saying nice things about him in defeat.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 22, 1988
description: COMPANIES A Federal judge ordered Eastern to abandon its plans to sell its shuttle to its parent, Texas Air. Judge John H. Pratt of the Federal District Court in Washington, who earlier this month had found Eastern in contempt of an injunction he issued last year against the sale or transfer of its assets, said he would fine Eastern $10,000 a day starting April 5 if it continued to violate his order. The ruling was a severe setback for Frank Lorenzo, the Texas Air chairman, in his bid to force concessions from Eastern's unions. [ Page D1. ] Kansas City Southern received a takeover offer of $60 a share in cash from an investor group that holds an 11.3 percent stake. Its offer for the balance amounts to $588 million. The group is led by a New York developer, Howard Kaskel. [ D1. ] G.E. filed two suits against Whirlpool and Roper, and it formally announced its new offer of $54 a share, or $507 million, for Roper. Whirlpool had sued G.E. on Friday, charging that G.E. was interfering in its merger agreement with Roper. G.E.'s suits said the Whirlpool-Roper deal was illegal. [ D1. ] A Federal jury awarded $8 million in the death of an I.B.M. executive who was killed in a plane crash in 1985. Lawyers said the settlement in the wrongful-death case was the largest ever. [ D1. ] Campeau suffered a new setback in the battle for Federated Department Stores. Campeau again argued unsuccessfully in Federal court for the removal of Federated's ''poison pill'' plan. [ D5. ] A. H. Robins's proposed bankruptcy reorganization was approved by a judge, clearing the way for a shareholder vote. [ D5. ] TRW will buy Chilton for about $360 million from Borg-Warner, in a further move into the information-systems business. [ D5. ] Merv Griffin may raise his bid for Resorts International, from the current $35 a share. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY A Senate panel voted to double the ''gas guzzler'' excise tax on automobiles with fuel economy of less than 22.5 miles a gallon. In the 1988 model year the tax falls exclusively on luxury imports from Europe, Congressional aides said, and it is not likely to meet significant resistance as it moves through Congress. [ D2. ] The Supreme Court will decide whether T.W.A. acted illegally when it refused to create vacancies for returning strikers by laying off 1,300 nonstriking flight attendants with less seniority. [ D8. ] MARKETS Stock prices fell broadly as trading volume slowed sharply on Wall Street, except for takeover-related issues. The Dow Jones industrial fell 20.30 points, to 2,067.14. Volume shrank to 128.8 million shares, the lowest level this year. [ D10. ] Sharp increases in ''short interest'' for the month ended last Tuesday were reported by the Big Board and the Amex. [ D27. ] Bond prices fell again. Nervous traders responded to a drop in the dollar and a rise in the prices of oil and other commodities by selling fixed-income securities. [ D23. ] Crude oil futures prices closed mostly higher in wild trading. [ D24. ] The dollar fell against most major currencies. Gold rose $5.45 an ounce in New York, to $449.45. [ D24. ] INTERNATIONAL West Germany resisted a French call to increase growth. Bonn said at a meeting of a new Franco-German financial council that there was no need for additional measures. [ D23. ] The drought in India has brought on the country's worst slump in eight years but did not do as much damage as many experts had feared earlier, India's Government says. [ D16. ] The tallest building in Europe is planned by a New York developer - a 70-story office tower in Frankfurt. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS A growing number of companies have put their names as well as their dollars behind fighting AIDS, a cause that was previously considered a ''gay issue.'' Business and Health. [ D2. ] The shoe industry is providing its own brand of fireworks on Wall Street - everything from takeover rumors to record prices for some stocks. Market Place. [ D10. ]

title: VENTURIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $994,000 for a reversal of the decision to sell the company's Napco International subsidiary. c-Net loss and included a charge of $2,783,000 for the anticipated writedown of assets and costs of disposition of Napco.

title: Agency Plans AIDS Rules
description: The Government plans to announce guidelines this week for addressing AIDS in the Federal work place, a spokesman for the Office of Personnel and Management said tonight.

title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian and Close Off Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian in the occupied territories today and wounded a dozen others in the face of continued protests.

title: GATT Reports About Canada
description: Canada announced today that it would accept the recommendations of two international trade reports that have called for an end to discriminatory practices in its liquor and fishing industries. A full council meeting of the

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM Life Insurance Co., Wakefield, Mass., an affiliate of Le Group Cooperants, Montreal, elected Paul Fontaine president and chief executive.

title: Books of The Times; A Short-Story Writer With Bloomsbury Ties
description: KATHERINE MANSFIELD A Secret Life By Claire Tomalin

title: NATIONAL HMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest second quarter included a loss of $792,000 from the writeoffs of accounts receivable, writedown of assets held for sale, and a reserve for lease obligations and legal fees associated with the closed centers.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up Sharply on Exchanges
description: Both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported sharp increases in their '' short interest' ' for the month ended last Tuesday, March 15.

title: MICHAELS STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Economic Nationalism Shapes Democratic Campaign Debate
description: After six weeks of caucuses and primaries, economic issues have begun to shape the oratory of the Democratic Presidential campaign, and many of them come down to a single theme: what economists and political analysts call economic nationalism.

title: It's Politics vs. Ratings, Or So Networks Fear
description: On the night of last month's New Hampshire primary, CBS broadcast a special political campaign edition of its prime-time news program, ''48 Hours.'' It was an hour of hard politics right in the middle of prime time, and the result confirmed what many in network television already knew all too well - given a choice, most viewers won't watch politics.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If skin cells are constantly being replaced, why don't scars and stretch marks disappear? A. It is true that the epidermis, the outermost layer of skin, replaces itself approximately every four weeks.

title: Oahu Journal; The Crush On Waikiki Gives Birth To 2d City
description: The County of Honolulu, whose centerpiece city was once everyone's vision of a tropical paradise, is moving against increasing urban congestion here by creating a new municipality 20 miles from Waikiki Beach.

title: Advertising; New Agency Gets New Yorker Account
description: The newly formed Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners yesterday got its first client, The New Yorker. Yes, The New Yorker.

title: Sports People; Lighter Behind Plate
description: Eric Gregg and some other National League umpires will have a new look this season. Gregg has lost 53 pounds, the result of the league office ordering its heavier umpires to slim down. ''They demanded that we do it,'' said Gregg, who once weighed 370. Overweight umpires became the source of jokes at last year's World Series. Gregg and John McSherry, two of the bulkier National League umpires, were not out of position for any calls, but the league thought its umpires needed to streamline their appearance. Gregg said Bruce Froemming has dropped 50 pounds, McSherry has lost 33 and Harry Wendelstedt 21. ''Bruce and I are having a race,'' Gregg said. ''I'm winning so far, but we both want to keep going.'' Gregg spent the off season working with a sports trainer near his home in Philadelphia. He also went on a diet. ''I still eat three square meals a day, but no red meat,'' he said. ''Also, I don't eat within four hours of going to sleep. That might be the biggest thing.'' (AP)

title: Wife Gets Maximum In Husband Slaying: A 32-Year Sentence
description: A woman found guilty of arranging the killing of her husband was sentenced today to up to 32 years in prison, the longest term she could have received.

title: Fix, Don't Dismiss, the Shultz Plan
description: It's hard to keep score on Prime Minister Shamir's visit to the United States, to see whether he did more good or harm to Israel's standing here and to the course of Middle East peace.

title: Goodrich Order
description: The Federal Trade Commission has ruled that the B. F. Goodrich Company's acquisition of the Diamond Shamrock Plastics Corporation in 1981 breached antitrust rules and ordered Goodrich to sell a chemical plant in La Porte, Tex. The plant manufactures vinyl chloride monomer, which is used to produce such plastic goods as irrigation pipes and phonograph records. The commission ruled that the acquisition had substantially reduced competition in the production of the chemical. Goodrich, based in Akron, Ohio, said it would appeal the decision.

title: Futility in Nicaragua
description: It's understandable that some members of Congress who voted on Feb. 29 to end military aid to the contras in Nicaragua now feel betrayed by the advantage the Sandinista regime has taken of the cutoffs. Nevertheless, the propriety and necessity of the House's action have not been diminished by the intensified fighting on the Honduras-Nicaragua border.

title: Sandinistas Reported To Be Out of Honduras Special to The New York Times
description: A Honduran Government spokesman said today that the last of the Sandinista troops who had crossed into Honduras in pursuit of contras last week were believed to have returned to Nicaragua.

title: CONSECO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the results reflect the retroactive application of accounting method changes contained in FAS 96 and FAS 97 announced in December 1987; the changes cover reporting of income taxes, profits on certain insurance contracts and investment gains of insurance companies.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sports People; Female Director Named
description: Judith Davidson has been named athletic director at Central Connecticut State University, becoming only the second full-time female athletic director in Division I. The other is Eileen Livingston of Duquesne. Davidson, 43 years old, was the head field hockey coach at Iowa, where she was named Big Ten Coach of the Year three times and led her team to the national championship in 1986. She is also president of the United States Field Hockey Association. Davidson replaces Bill Detrick, who is retiring. . . . Chet Gladchuk, an associate athletic director at Syracuse for the last three years, was named athletic director at Tulane. He succeeds Mack Brown, who is now the head football coach at North Carolina.(AP)

title: Agency Grants Operating License To Texas Reactor, Saying It's Safe
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 5 to 0 today to approve a full-power operating license for the first reactor at the twin-reactor South Texas Nuclear Project.

title: Argentine Is Accused in U.S. Of a Key Role in 'Dirty War'
description: A former Argentine general was described at an extradition hearing here today as ''the essential linchpin'' in transmitting orders for the torture and disappearance of thousands of Argentine civilians under military rule.

title: Fusion Achievement
description: Scientists at the University of Rochester announced yesterday that they had achieved record densities in tiny pellets of hydrogen isotopes, using lasers to compress their mass 100 to 200 times.

title: Diagnostic Riddle: A Lesson for Doctors
description: LAST September, a woman and her two teen-age daughters came into a hospital in Montreal and collapsed. They could not focus their eyes and were seeing double. As doctors struggled to diagnose their ailment, their conditions worsened.

title: Gun Charge Added In Steinberg Case
description: A grand jury has added drug and weapons charges to the indictment against Joel Steinberg, a lawyer who has been charged with murder in the beating death of his illegally adopted daughter, Lisa, according to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: McGraw Appointment Comes as No Surprise
description: When McGraw-Hill Inc. announced yesterday that Joseph L. Dionne, its president and chief executive, would become chairman, the news came as no surprise. Mr. Dionne, 54 years old, replaces Harold W. McGraw Jr., who is retiring.

title: Dow Declines 20.23 in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in the slowest trading this year despite considerable activity in takeover-related issues.

title: SAMSON ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Lawyer for Mecham Describes the Advice Offered to Governor
description: Gov. Evan Mecham's lawyer was called today as a witness in his client's impeachment trial, and testified that the only political option advisers offered the Governor was ''to go down with the ship.''

title: New York Needs Metering to Conserve and Manage Its Water
description: To the Editor:

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
TRW Agrees to Buy Borg-Warner's Chilton
description: In a further move into the information-systems business, TRW Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Chilton Corporation, a unit of the Borg-Warner Corporation, for about $360 million.

title: Hermitage Treasures Come to Met As U.S.-Soviet Exchange Begins
description: The dagger flies from Abraham's hand, arrested by an angel as he prepares to sacrifice his son. It hangs in midair, poised against a distant landscape of trees and rocks. The theatrical scene is one of Rembrandt's most haunting biblical compositions, and - courtesy of the Metropolitan Museum - it comes to New York direct from Leningrad, in a show that opens Saturday, ''Dutch and Flemish Paintings From the Hermitage.''

title: Part of Smoking Suit Is Allowed to Continue
description: Tobacco companies can be held accountable for not having warned consumers about the hazards of smoking before passage of a law requiring warning labels on cigarette packages, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: TECH DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Puerto Rico Vote, Democrats Support Island's Status Quo
description: In a boost for pro-Commonwealth advocates, the president of the Puerto Rican Senate was elected chairman of the island's Democratic Party Sunday, overshadowing a victory by the Rev. Jesse Jackson in a nonbinding Presidential primary.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes special gains of $205,000 for the latest year and $8,107,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Careers; New Focus On Problems Of Pensions
description: WHERE three roads meet, a traffic light reduces the danger. And when three pension trends converge, leaving many people in a precarious financial situation, Congressional action might be indicated, some professionals say.

title: ENSR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter includes a one-time, non-deductible charge of $694,000 from the acquisition of Sun Environmental Inc., acquired in November and accountedj for as a pooling of interests.

title: Dominic John Dell'Aquila, Physician, 83
description: Dominic John Dell'Aquila, a retired physician, died Sunday at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Hospital in Montrose, N.Y. after a series of strokes. He was 83 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Saliva and Parasites
description: Insects that transmit infectious parasites may do more than just carry the organisms from their animal hosts to people. They may also enhance the parasite's ability to cause illness. At least that is the case for the sandflies that transmit leishmaniasis, a serious protozoal disease widespread in the tropics and subtropics.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Corrections
description: A Business People report on Feb. 29 on the new head of the Federal Asset Disposition Association incorrectly described the departure of Roslyn Payne, the former head of the agency. She resigned.

title: U.S. Medical Students Reach to the Third World
description: MOTIVATED by altruism and adventure, a growing number of American medical students are working in the rural villages, hospitals and refugee camps of the third world to gain experience unavailable at home.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $764,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Talk: Congress; Foes of Civil Rights Bill Mount 11th-Hour Drive
description: An unlikely assortment of evangelical Christians, farmers and, for a while, homebuilders has been lobbying Congress furiously to keep a civil rights bill from becoming law.

title: Offer for Koppers May Bring Protests
description: Government employees of the city of Pittsburgh and of the state of Pennsylvania may be barred from using the credit cards of the American Express Company on official business to protest the $1.58 billion hostile takeover bid for the Pittburgh-based Koppers Company by Beazer P.L.C., the British construction company. State and city officials said that they were considering such actions.

title: N.B.A. May Add A Third Referee
description: The National Basketball Association is likely to add a third referee for games next season, going back to a system that was tried briefly in the late 1970's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a Metropolitan Opera review of ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' yesterday gave an incorrect date for the production's radio broadcast. It will be heard on April 9.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Zoo Story
description: It wasn't exactly Noah's Ark, but the United States Fish and Wildlife Service shipped off to China today a pair of Alaskan musk oxen, flown nonstop from Fairbanks, Alaska, to new quarters in the Beijing zoo.

title: For King Herod, a New Mantle of Greatness
description: AFTER two decades of digging and diving, archeologists have uncovered the grandeur that was Caesarea, the monumental seaport of ancient Judea, and have reached a loftier estimate of its ambitious builder, Herod the Great.

title: Insurance Urged For Cancer Tests
description: Insurance companies should pay for early cancer detection tests , in return for slightly higher premiums, the head of the American Cancer Society says.

title: Outline By Robins Approved
description: The A. H. Robins Company's disclosure statement outlining its proposed reorganization under the bankruptcy laws was approved by a Federal judge yesterday, clearing the way for a vote on the proposal by shareholders and creditors.

title: Cabinet Shuffle in Indonesia Brings 19 New Faces to Fore
description: President Suharto announced sweeping Cabinet changes today, replacing the Defense, Foreign, Energy and Interior Ministers.

title: Griffin Weighs Resorts Move
description: After reviewing appraisals of the operations of Resorts International Inc., the entertainer Merv Griffin said today that he was considering raising his $35-a-share bid for the Atlantic City casino operator - an offer already substantially higher than a $22-share bid from the New York developer Donald J. Trump to take the company private. Some analysts believe that

title: Tyson 'Loses' I.B.F. Title
description: The International Boxing Federation has stripped Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, of his title.

title: MARCI INTERNATIONAL IMPORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a gain of $68,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: PATTERNS
description: Knowing Your Market

title: Soloman Freedman, S.E.C. Lawyer, 78
description: Soloman Freedman, a lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission for more than 30 years, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 years old. Among the posts Mr. Freeman held at the S.E.C. was that of director of the division of corporate regulation. At his death he was associated with a number of investment companies managed by Neuberger Berman Management Inc.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reyner Banham, Architectural Critic, Dies at 66
description: Reyner Banham, a British architectural historian whose work traced the rise and fall of modernism and society's attitudes toward it, died of cancer Saturday in London. He was 66 years old.

title: Noriega Offer to Quit by '89 Strongly Denounced by U.S.
description: The State Department vigorously denounced Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's offer tonight to resign by 1989 if opponents agree to talks with his regime.

title: Why National Defense Can't Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: Governors Are Emerging as a New Political Elite
description: Not so long ago, when men like Gov. James J. Blanchard of Michigan and Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey were dreaming youthful dreams of politics, the governorship in most states was considered an office of little power and less fulfillment: in some cases a refuge for second-raters, hacks and good-time Charlies; at best, a stop on the road to greater glory in Washington.

title: Newest Headache for Hanoi: A 5,000-Dong Currency Note
description: Warning that a strong black-market economy has the potential to sabotage the policies of the new Communist leadership, Vietnam has issued a new series of currency notes.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $1,806,000 and $3,838,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss d-Includes income of $15 million from the sale of real estate in New York for the quarter, and the year includes a charge of $4,090,000 from the exchange of debt for common stock. The company said the net for 1987 included a pretax charge for a joint venture loss of $3.6 million. The loss for 1986 included a $34 million pretax charge related to the restructuring of the company's Bojangles' restaurant operations.

title: Woman Struck by 4 Vehicles
description: A woman crossing a street here Sunday was struck by four vehicles and killed, the police said. The woman, Janell Bankhead, 25 years old, was first hit by a van as she walked across a street about 12:30 A.M. She tried to get up, but a pickup truck heading in the opposite direction struck her. She was then hit by two other vans.

title: MGI PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a gain of $70,000 from the sale of real estate investments and loss of $600,000 from depreciation. c-After a gain of $246,000 from the sale of real estate investments and a loss of $445,000 from depreciation.

title: Stake in Wilson
description: The Doskocil Companies has purchased an 8.57 percent stake in the Wilson Foods Corporation. Doskocil, based in South Hutchinson, Kan., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it might offer to acquire the Oklahoma City-based meat products concern, which has 10.1 million shares outstanding. Wilson declined to omment on the filing.

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSH BACKS VETO OF BILL TO EXPAND CIVIL RIGHTS LAWS
description: Vice President Bush told a group of black supporters tonight that he supported President Reagan's veto of legislation to expand the reach of Federal anti-discrimination laws. He called the measure ''imperfect'' and said the ''imperfections should be corrected.''

title: Edd J. Roush, 94, Reds Outfielder Who Captured Two Batting Titles
description: Edd Roush, who won the National League batting championship twice while playing for the Cincinnati Reds, died yesterday in Bradenton, Fla. He was 94 years old.

title: Rheumatic Fever Cases Posing Many Puzzles As Comeback Is Feared
description: ACUTE rheumatic fever is a disease that most Americans have forgotten because it virtually disappeared from the United States a generation ago. Now, health officials worry that the disease, which is triggered by streptococcal sore throats, may be making a comeback. And its scattered reappearance is as mysterious as its disappearance.

title: Appeals Court Vacates Forced-Caesarean Ruling
description: The local appeals court here today set aside a ruling by a three-judge panel that a gravely ill pregnant woman could be forced to undergo a Caesarean delivery in an attempt to save the fetus.

title: Motions Denied In Intel-NEC Case
description: A new judge assigned to the computer chip copyright dispute between the Intel Corporation and the NEC Corporation denied motions for summary judgments from both sides. Judge William P. Gray of the Federal District Court in Los Angeles inherited the case after Judge William A. Ingram of the District Court in San Jose disqualified himself in December and nullified a decision he had made. The judge never stated a reason for his disqualification, but it was believed to be because of his ownership, through an investment club, of a small amount of Intel stock.

title: Article 081988 -- No Title
description: The United States Government had a budget deficit of $23.9 billion in February, the fifth month of the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Tishman Plans Tall Tower in Europe
description: In the face of widespread opposition in Europe to the construction of skycrapers, a New York real estate developer said yesterday that he would build the tallest building in Western Europe.

title: World Bank Portfolio Plan
description: The World Bank, known for its conservative financial policies, may soon be investing part of its $21 billion cash hoard in the potentially risky area of mortgage securities, its treasurer, Don Roth, said in an interview.

title: Rally Over Capitals Lifts Devils' Hopes
description: The end of six years of futility in the Capital Centre at Landover, Md., came Sunday at a most critical time for the Devils, as they pursue their first playoff berth.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $2,400,000. Corrected from Friday, March 18, editions.

title: In Seoul, 'Things Have Collapsed' for Opposition
description: Hopes that this nation's fractured opposition would be able to unite in time for next month's legislative elections dimmed today as merger talks collapsed again.

title: Review/Dance; A Ballet Inspired by Gogol Tales
description: A new Soviet choreographer was introduced in the Making Music Together festival here with the United States premiere of ''Sketches'' - a ballet by Andrei Petrov inspired by Gogol's stories and set to music by Alfred Schnittke.

title: Bid Made for Kansas City Southern
description: An investor group led by a New York real estate developer today offered $60 a share to acquire Kansas City Southern Industries, the railroad, data-processing and financial-services concern.

title: African-Style Reggae Crosses the Atlantic
description: Born in West Africa, bounced around the United States and the Caribbean and transformed in Jamaica, reggae is now a global beat. Tonight, one of Africa's leading reggae singers, Alpha Blondy from the Ivory Coast, will make his New York debut at 9 P.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street.

title: Bonn Says No to Paris On Growth
description: At financial talks between France and West Germany, the Bonn Government today resisted a French call that it increase its economic growth.

title: Hospital Shortages Hurt Patient Care in New York
description: New York's health-care system is suffering extraordinary shortages of beds, workers and money that are curtailing access to treatment and jeopardizing the quality of patient care, according to medical experts.

title: Big Advance In Monitors
description: THE colors are brighter, the contrast is sharper, the glare is gone and the characters are bigger. Flatly stated, the Zenith FTM - for flat tension mask, or flat technology monitor, take your pick - is a dramatic advance in color monitors.

title: Dynamic Start for Syracuse Lacrosse
description: Among the early lacrosse results this season, one that stands out is Syracuse's 19-7 rout of Johns Hopkins in the season opener March 5 on the defending national champion's home field in Baltimore.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year includes the operations of E-Z Serve Inc., which was acquired Dec. 31, 1986.

title: Tyson Calls Off Pilgrim's Deal
description: Lonnie A. Pilgrim, chairman and chief executive of the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, has disclosed that Tyson Foods Inc. called off its agreement to buy his 80 percent interest in Pilgrim's Pride for $162 million. Pilgrim's Pride, of Pittsburg, Tex., is the nation's sixth-largest poultry producer. Tyson, of Springdale, Ark., is No. 1.

title: Official Says Noriega Is Willing to Quit
description: Panama's nominal President, Manuel Solis Palma, said tonight that the military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, would be willing to step down ''at an opportune time'' before presidential elections scheduled for May 1989.

title: Man Shot Dead Mob-Style By Motorcyclist in Village
description: A man sitting in the driver's seat of his stretch limousine parked on a quiet Greenwich Village street was shot to death mob-style yesterday morning by a helmeted man who sped away on a motorcycle.

title: From High Tech to Low For Centronics' Chief
description: When Robert Stein joined the Centronics Corporation as chief financial officer in 1980, the company was a major manufacturer of dot-matrix printers. Growing at 25 percent to 50 percent a year, it seemed to have a firm place in the computer industry.

title: A Shaky G.O.P. Hunts in Vain For Rival to Moynihan in Race
description: More than a dozen prominent New York Republicans have spurned suggestions that they become their party's candidate for Senator this year, reflecting both the strength of the Democratic incumbent and what many political experts say are hard times for the state G.O.P.

description: A previously unknown group has claimed responsibility for a bombing in the Greek capital that wounded 13 people, including four United States servicemen, the police said today.
