description: The Soviet national press and television opened a sharp attack today on the campaign that drew hundreds of thousands of Armenians into the streets last month, sending a clear signal that the protesters' demands will not be met.

title: Almon Traded By Mets
description: The Mets sent Bill Almon, their utility infielder, to Philadelphia today in a trade that could open a roster spot for Keith Miller.

description: The United States' plan for an Israel-Palestine solution won't work. It is too late and too much.

description: The Nationalist Republican Alliance is a political force that illustrates the polarization, but perhaps also the possibility of change, in El Salvador.

title: High Court to Decide on Liability of Local Officials in Child Abuse
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Federal courts can hold state and local officials liable for recklessly failing to protect a child against a known danger of serious abuse by his or her parents.

title: RIGHTIST WINNERS IN SALVADOR VOTE VOW TO SEEK UNITY
description: Salvadoran rightists, victorious in national elections, said today that they would seek compromise with President Jose Napoleon Duarte, but diplomats and political analysts said they were uncertain about prospects for cooperation.

title: Article 170488 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury yesterday awarded $7.95 million to the estate of an executive of the International Business Machines Corporation and his wife who were killed in a plane crash in 1985.

title: Sports People; Providence Resignation
description: Gordon Chiesa, who replaced Rick Pitino as head coach of the Providence Friars last season when Pitino left to coach the Knicks, resigned the position yesterday after his team won only 11 of 28 games and finished last in the Big East Conference with a 5-11 record. The Friars were the only team of the nine in the conference that did not participate in a postseason tournament. Under Pitino, one season earlier, Providence reached the Final Four in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament before being eliminated by Syracuse. Chiesa, a former head coach at Manhattan College, had served for two seasons as Pitino's assistant before inheriting the job. John Marinatto, the director of athletics, denied that Chiesa was, in effect, dismissed because of the Friars' poor season but said: ''Gordie was swimming against an unbelievable tide. Everyone anticipated as good a season and anything shy of that would be disappointing.'' Marinatto said that at one point during the year, a few players came to him and ''expressed discontent'' over Chiesa.(AP)

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball Tournament; Weekend Yields a Solid 16
description: Shortly before the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced its 64-team tournament field, Arnie Ferrin, the chairman of the Division I selection committee, said that 20 to 30 teams were capable of emerging as the champion.

title: Do Scientists Pose a Threat to Rare 'Fossil Fish'?
description: THE coelacanth, a rare fish that until 1938 was known only through its fossils, has become the target of collecting expeditions that some scientists fear could lead to the fish's extinction.

title: Islanders Triumph And Move Into 2d
description: Four goals in the first period and steady goaltending by Kelly Hrudey carried the Islanders past the Minnesota North Stars tonight, 5-1.

title: Three Mile Island Waste Plan
description: The operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant said today that it is spending $800,000 for a system to boil away 2.3 million gallons of water contaminated in the 1979 accident, even though the method has yet to be approved and public hearings are months away.

title: Winning Comes In Second
description: When you are a 16-year-old high school junior with a 3.8 grade-point average and you have a bubbly personality and you happen to be the world's best swimmer, you should not have many problems.

title: Rhode Island's Reliable Duo
description: Traversing the bowels of the Dean E. Smith Center in Chapel Hill between rounds of the East Regional, Mike Krzyzewsi, Duke's basketball coach, spied an old friend waiting by the elevator.

title: Chambers Jury Deliberates for a Fifth Day
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. deliberated for a fifth day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

title: Drugs Win Support As a Bulimia Treatment
description: THE use of drugs to treat bulimia is gaining increasing acceptance as an alternative to psychotherapy, according to doctors who specialize in the eating disorder.

title: F.A.A. to Add Flight Coordinator To Improve Air Safety at Chicago
description: Seeking to halt errors by air traffic controllers that have caused a disturbing number of near-collisions at O'Hare International Airport, Chicago, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would assign another full-time air traffic coordinator to the airport tower.

title: Wedtech Executive Describes Bribes
description: A former executive of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that he paid part of a $50,000 bribe to a former Bronx Borough President by treating him and his wife to trips to Atlantic City and giving them as much as $13,500 in cash for gambling and other expenses.

title: G.E. Files Suits Against Roper Pact
description: Responding to a lawsuit by the Whirlpool Corporation, the General Electric Company yesterday filed two suits and formally announced its offer of $54 a share, or $507 million, for the Roper Corporation.

title: Review/Comedy; A Whimsical Grab Bag
description: Brian O'Connor's amiable brand of character comedy cuts against the prevailing grain of humor that stalks its prey with lethal weapons concealed under a veneer of cool. In his one-man show, ''One Hour Out of Your Life,'' which opened a three-night run at the Judith Anderson Theater on Thursday, Mr. O'Connor impersonated 10 characters. Some were celebrities like Steven Wright, whose skewed mottoes he imitated with a perfect deadpan accuracy. Others were poignant, fictional losers with whom he clearly sympathized.

description: Ciriaco de Mita, a balding, voluble man who likes to play cards with his cronies after lunch, is poised to become the most powerful politician in Italy, but he is not very happy about the prospect.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Hear Plea on Contracting
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear a Reagan Administration appeal aimed at striking down a provision on competition in Government contracting on the grounds that it violates the Constitution's separation of powers.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Troops in Slow Motion
description: The 82d Airborne Division has a reputation for its ability to be dispatched anywhere in the world within hours. It took less than 10 hours for two battalions, flown from Pope Air Force Base, N.C., to arrive in Honduras last week.

description: Crude oil futures prices closed mostly higher yesterday after uncommonly wild trading.

But diplomats said they were pessimistic about the prospects for cooperation. Page A1 Sandinistas and contras meeting in Nicaragua agreed that they would stop fighting during the talks. After the day's talks ended, both sides appeared encouraged. A1 A Persian Gulf shipping raid left more than 50 crewmen from two Iranian supertankers missing and presumed dead. title: Ford-South Korea
description: The Ford Motor Company will begin exporting its Lincoln Continental and Mercury Sable models to South Korea this spring, the company said. A Ford spokeswoman, Pam Kueber, said the initial volumes would be small, in part because South Korea's import duties would raise the cars' retail prices to about three times those in America, which are about about $28,000 for the Continental and $15,000 for the Sable. South Korea first allowed automobile imports late last year, she said.

title: Service for Murray Weiss
description: A memorial service for Murray M. Weiss, a journalist and former editor of The International Herald Tribune in Paris who died March 12, will be held on Wednesday, March 30, at 4 P.M. at the Century Association, at 7 West 43d Street in Manhattan. Mr. Weiss, who was 64 years old, was a former managing editor of The New York Herald Tribune.

title: Review/Television; Overview in Guatemala: Are Old Wounds Healing?
description: Will justice triumph in Guatemala? ''Under the Gun: Democracy in Guatemala'' is skeptical. The past, it suggests, carries too much weight; the Central American country bears the legacy of military rule. An elected president, the provocative documentary says, must walk carefully around soldiers. The documentary will be seen on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight.

description: A commuter train bound for Chicago struck a truck and derailed today, injuring at least 16 people, one of them seriously, officials said.

title: South Africa Strike Recalls '60 Killings
description: More than a million black workers joined a nationwide strike today to commemorate the killings of 69 blacks here in 1960 and to protest Government moves against anti-apartheid groups.

title: Business and Health; Corporations Join Efforts on AIDS
description: AFTER KPIX-TV in San Francisco became the first television station to cover AIDS aggressively in 1983, representatives of the station discussed a nationwide television education effort with the parent company, the Westinghouse Broadcasting Corporation.

title: 'The Sun' Is Removed From Met's Staircase
description: The Metropolitan Museum has taken down ''The Sun,'' a hanging sculpture by Richard Lippold that was installed for a week's trial over its Great Staircase. ''We are in the process of mulling it over,'' a Met spokesman said. ''At some point in the next several weeks we will decide what to do with it.''

title: Knick Pressure Collapses Spurs
description: Gerald Wilkins scored 25 points as the Knicks relied on their pressure defense to rally for a 133-121 victory over the San Antonio Spurs that improved their playoff chances.

title: A New Face for Landmarks
description: The City Council should approve the nomination of Lee Weintraub to the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. Mr. Weintraub is a distinguished landscape architect eminently qualified to assist the commission in the next important stage of its development: managing existing landmarks.

title: Drought Damage to India's Economy
description: The nationwide drought in India has brought on the country's worst economic slump in eight years but did not do as much damage as many experts had feared earlier, according to the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: Freight Trains Hit Head On
description: Two Chicago & North Western freight trains collided head on today, injuring the eight workers aboard, three seriously, the police said. An eastbound train with four engines and about 130 cars and a westbound train consisting of a switch engine and a single car collided while going 20 to 30 miles an hour, the police said. Officials were investigating the cause of the accident, which occurred about noon in this town of 15,000 in north-central Illinois. CNWd

title: Sports of The Times; Joey Meyer's 582-Foot Homer
description: DURING the 1953 season, Mickey Mantle hit a home run that sailed over the center-field stands at Griffith Stadium in Washington. As soon as the ball disappeared, Arthur (Red) Patterson hurried out of the press box. Upon his return, but without any scientific evidence, the Yankees' public-relations director announced that the ball had soared 565 feet.

title: 4 Charged With Beating Man to Death
description: Four people, including a 14-year-old boy, have been charged in the fatal beating of a man who stole $20 from a woman in an East Harlem bakery on Sunday, the police said yesterday.

title: Sale By McGraw-Hill
description: A Dutch publisher, Verenigd Bezit VNU said today that its subsidiary, VNU Business Publications Inc. had purchased a McGraw-Hill Inc. magazine, Electronics, for an undisclosed sum. Electronics, aimed at management in the electronics industry, employs 35 people and has a circulation of 135,000. VNU said the magazine was a better fit in its organization than in McGraw-Hill's. VNU Business Publications is the new name for Hayden Publishing Inc., which VNU acquired in 1986.

title: Nestle to Name Volcker
description: Nestle S.A., the Swiss food products group, plans to appoint Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, to its board, the company has announced. The election by shareholders will be held at the company's general meeting on May 19, Nestle said Friday.

title: Sandinista-Contra Meeting Begins With Accord on Temporary Truce
description: Sandinista and contra leaders, meeting today for the first time, agreed that they would stop fighting during their three days of talks.

title: ADOBE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Kevin Patterson, 32, Theater Press Agent
description: Kevin Patterson, a playwright and theater press representative, died of complications from AIDS Friday at his home in New York. He was 32 years old.

title: Bonn to Sell Stake in VW
description: West Germany said today that it would sell its remaining shares in Volkswagenwerk A.G., after twice delaying its plans to privatize the Government's stake in the giant car company.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $81,000. c-Net income d-Includes a tax benefit of $511,000.

title: Panel Calls Education of Deaf Unsatisfactory
description: Efforts to place deaf students in regular public schools have backfired, leaving many with an inadequate education, a Government commission told a Senate panel today.

title: On Elements That Want to Be Alone
description: EVER since the heyday of medieval alchemy, experimenters have sought to force the supposedly nonreactive ''noble elements'' to react and form compounds. With the recent discovery that even helium may be vulnerable to chemical attack, the complete conquest of chemical ''nobility'' may finally be in sight.

title: Manchester Journal; An English Detective's Story: The Ulster Horror
description: He has come to be known simply as Stalker, a lean and wary detective who was rated one of Britain's most indomitable criminal investigators until he was dispatched to a violent provincial place where he had never been: the green killing ground of Northern Ireland.

title: Senate Panel Backs 'Gas Guzzler' Tax Rise
description: The Senate Finance Committee voted today to double the ''gas guzzler'' excise tax on automobiles with fuel economy below 22.5 miles a gallon.

title: Fund to Assist Waste Disposal Gains in Jersey
description: Amid reports of illegal midnight dumping of garbage in parts of New Jersey, the Assembly tonight narrowly passed a bill that would create a $450 million revolving loan fund to help municipalities pay their rising garbage disposal costs.

title: WINGS WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Charter Medical Corp., Macon, Ga., which owns and operates hospitals, said its board had approved definitive terms for a management buyout by WAF Acquisition Corp. for $30.25 in cash and $7 principal of a junior subordinated debenture for each class A or class B common share.

title: From Cohn's Rolodex, A Party He Would Love
description: It never seemed to matter whether they loved or loathed him. When Roy Marcus Cohn threw a party, everyone came to play. Last night, a year and a half after his death, they threw a party for the book he helped to write. Mr. Cohn would have loved the turnout.

title: First Boston Sets Pact on Jewelcor
description: A group led by Jewelcor Inc.'s president, Seymour Holtzman, has agreed to work with First Boston LBO Inc., a unit of the First Boston Corporation, on a plan to acquire Jewelcor. The group led by Mr. Holtzman, which holds or has options to buy 26.3 percent of Jewelcor's common stock, disclosed the agreement in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The wire is stretched very tautly, and we are at some significant risk it will snap from overload.'' - Bruce C. Vladeck, president of the United Hospital Fund, on hospital care in New York City. [ A1:3. ]

title: The '88 Race at Halftime
description: At halftime in the Presidential nominating race, the most significant fact is that the moderates are the winners and their more extreme brethren are the losers.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $6,027,000 on early extinguishment of debt. c-After extraordinary losses of $1,693,000 and $7,902,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on early extinguishment of debt.

title: Risk of Sex Abuse in Day Care Seen as Lower Than at Home
description: Despite several highly publicized cases of sexual abuse of children at day care centers, a new national study said today that children at such centers are at less risk of abuse than in their own homes.

title: Timely Law on Covert Action
description: While the Iran-contra grand jury prepared its first indictments last week, the Senate gave the first legislative response to that scandal. A new bill, passed by a vote of 71 to 19, would make unmistakably and laudably clear the President's obligation to notify Congress about covert actions. President Reagan utterly failed to do so in his secret deals to sell arms to Iran to gain the release of American hostages.

title: By Design; Clothes for a Business Trip
description: No matter how long or short your business trip, you should carry a wardrobe that works. Knowing that your clothes are right leaves you free to concentrate on more important things.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Sunday about a musical tribute to the composer Frederick Loewe gave an incorrect date. The event will be held next Monday, March 28, at 1 P.M. at the Shubert Theater.

title: Sports People; Phils Trade Schu
description: The Philadelphia Phillies yesterday traded Rick Schu, who had been considered the eventual successor to Mike Schmidt at third base. Schu was sent to the Baltimore Orioles in a deal for Mike Young, a switch-hitting outfielder. The Phillies also sent Jeff Stone and Keith Hughes, outfielders, to Baltimore for a player to be named.

title: WIENER ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a payment of $428,000 to the company's former president in connection with the termination of his employment contract. c-Net income

title: Topics of The Times; Top Brass, Low Key
description: Adm. William Crowe, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, deserves a medal for plain speaking.

title: Policy Shift Is Urged for Toxic Cleanup Fund
description: A Federal environmental official has proposed that the Government return to its old policy of seeking payment commitments from polluters before beginning work on cleaning up toxic waste dumps.

title: WINNERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that 1987 results included a loss of $2,950,000 from the disposition of its 11 Mrs. Winners Chicken & Biscuits Restaurants in Baton Rouge, La., and its seven Wendy's Old-Fashioned Hamburgers Restaurants in Shreveport, La.; and expenses of about $1.5 million associated with the resolution of litigation with former franchisees.

title: Twists and Turns That Meet
description: B. J. Armstrong and Steve Kerr are examples of how the high road and the low road can twist and turn and meet on the way to the Final Four.

title: 1987 Champs Defeated
description: Phil Stinnie matched his career high with 34 points and Virginia Commonwealth eliminated the defending champion, Southern Mississippi, from the National Invitation Tournament with a 93-89 victory tonight.

title: Education; Rising College Costs: What's Available to Pay the Bill
Electric Co-op Sells Certificates
description: The Rural Electric Cooperative Grantor Trust established by the Kansas Electric Power Co-op is offering $62.4 million of grantor trust certificates in two parts through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Interior Dept. Picks Chemical
description: Chemical Bank, a subsidiary of the Chemical New York Corporation, announced yesterday that it had been appointed financial adviser to the Department of the Interior. The appointment is connected to the sale of the department's loan portfolio.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHEN Manfred Esser was at the Harvard Business School, at one of those middle-management programs a few years ago, he put on a wine tasting for his classmates.

title: Bridge
description: Two New York-area experts stepped out of their usual role and captured a major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Monday night.

title: Vatican Team, but Not Pope, Will Visit Soviet
description: The Vatican has been invited to send a delegation to the Soviet Union for a major religious celebration in June, but Pope John Paul II will not attend, a senior Vatican official said today.

title: Gooden, Police File Suits
description: Charging in legal documents that the city had inadequately trained the police officers who he said punched and taunted him, Dwight Gooden of the Mets is suing the city of Tampa and three officers who arrested him after a scuffle Dec. 13, 1986.

title: Say 'I'm Sorry' Like a Man
description: LEAD: Will nobody ever again own up to his transgressions and take the punishment like a person of character, setting a much-needed example?

title: EATING WELL
description: ALTHOUGH it's not absolutely necessary to have special kitchen equipment to turn typical American meals into healthful ones, some appliances can make the job easier. Since one of the most frequently heard complaints is that nutritionally sound food takes too long to prepare, anything to make the job more efficient is a plus.

title: Review/Film; Interchangeable Families In Hi-Tech Black Comedy
description: Video cameras and monitors watch over the characters in Atom Egoyan's ''Family Viewing'' with the patience and passivity of vultures, but without the enthusiasm. The advent of this modern technology seems to have drained all vitality out of the participants in Mr. Egoyan's very peculiar black comedy, and it's their listlessness that makes them so funny and sad.

title: Mayor's Nominee Voted To the Landmarks Panel
description: Mayor Koch's nominee from Staten Island to the Landmarks Preservation Commission was approved by the City Council yesterday, ending a 14-month battle by Anthony M. Tung to hold on to the post.

title: BOTH SIDES OFFER NICARAGUAN STEPS FOR A CEASE-FIRE
description: Leaders of the Sandinista Government and Nicaraguan contras offered differing proposals today for a cease-fire when they met for their second day of talks at this southern border outpost.

title: Brazil Assembly Backs Presidential System
description: Apparently bending to pressure from President Jose Sarney and Brazil's powerful armed forces, a Constitutional Assembly voted in favor tonight of maintaining this country's presidential system of government.

title: 'Welfare Cheats' Constitute a Very Small Minority of the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Ravages North Burma City, Killing 113
description: A fire that started in a kitchen raged across Lashio, a northern Burmese city, killing 113 people and leaving 20,000 homeless, the Government radio reported tonight.

title: Southern Africa Diplomacy Seen at Impasse
description: A major diplomatic effort by the Reagan Administration involving Angola and South Africa appears at an impasse, according to several diplomats and Government officials.

title: Chief of American Unit Gets Montedison Posts
description: Alexander F. Giacco, a leading American chemical industry executive, has been named vice chairman and chief executive of Montedison S.p.A.

title: Mitterrand, Dispelling Doubts, Stands for Re-election
description: Ending months of speculation, President Francois Mitterrand, a 71-year-old Socialist, said tonight that he would seek a second seven-year presidential mandate.

title: Evans Takes Back 800 Freestyle Mark
description: Last year, when Janet Evans broke three world swimming records, she lost one of them to an East German 23 days after she set it. Today, she regained that record.

title: Sacred and Secular In Easter Celebrations; Lamb Dishes Of Old World Affirm Tradition
description: LAMB has not been high in favor in this country in recent years, and mutton, its adult counterpart, is almost entirely unknown in modern butcher shops. Once a feature of Colonial banquets, a boned leg of mutton slowly spit-roasted before a bank of embers is something few of us will have the good fortune to taste.

title: Red Smith Honor
description: A dedication ceremony for the collected newspaper columns and memorabilia of the late Red Smith will take place this afternoon in the Rare Book Room of the Hesburgh Library at the University of Notre Dame. The sportswriter's widow, Phyllis Smith of New Canaan, Conn., gave the Red Smith Collection to the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce Sports Research Collection at Notre Dame last September. Remarks will be made by Robert Miller, the director of Notre Dame's University Libraries, and Terence Smith, the son of the sportswriter, who is a White House correspondent for CBS News. Red Smith, a graduate of Notre Dame, was a columnist for The New York Times when he won a Pulitzer Prize for commentary in 1976. He died in 1982.

title: Securities 'Fingerprinted' to Halt Fraud
description: SINCE the famous paper crunch of the late 1960's, the securities industry has been searching for new ways to guard against counterfeiting of stocks and bonds. Placing special codes that a computer reads on the certificates has caused problems because computers read only the codes and cannot distinguish between bona fide certificates and good imitations. With recent advances in color copying machines, industry analysts have predicted a rise in securities counterfeiting.

title: Article 470588 -- No Title
description: The American Stores Company today offered to acquire Lucky Stores Inc., one of the largest food chains in the lucrative and highly competitive California market, for $45 a share, or $1.74 billion.

title: Robertson Is Seen as Leader In Nevada Delegate Process
description: Supporters of Pat Robertson will apparently control the Nevada Republican convention next month as a result of county conventions held last weekend, party officials say.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Another Victory for Tomba: Alberto Tomba of Italy captured his sixth World Cup slalom victory of the season yesterday, finishing just ahead of Tetsuya Okabe of Japan in Oppdal, Norway. Tomba had runs of 57.30 seconds and 55.45, for a combined time of 1 minute 52.75 seconds, 55-hundredths of a second faster than Okabe's. Okabe's time of 54.30 was fastest in the second run, and he posted the best finish of his career. It was Tomba's ninth World Cup victory of the season - he has also won three giant slalom races - and improved his chances of beating Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland for the overall title. (AP) FIGURE SKATING Gordeyeva and Grinkov Leading: Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov used verve and precision to lead a one-two-three Soviet placing after the first part of the pairs event last night at the world championships in Budapest. Gordeyeva and Grinkov, the Olympic gold medalists, were joined at the top by Yelena Valova and Oleg Vasiliev, the Olympic silver medalists, and Larisa Selezneva and Oleg Makarov. Two American teams came next. The Olympic bronze medalists, Jill Watson and Peter Oppegard, with razzle-dazzle skating to a jazzy, percussive beat, were in fourth place; Gillian Wachsman and Todd Waggoner were fifth.(AP) N.B.A. Pistons 123, Pacers 104: Isiah Thomas scored 9 of his 25 points during a 14-0 third-quarter run last night that carried Detroit to its 18th consecutive home victory in Pontiac, Mich. Adrian Dantley scored 26 points for Detroit (45-20). The Pistons trailed, 80-77, with 2 minutes 41 seconds to play in the third quarter, but the 14-0 run gave Detroit a 91-80 lead with 5 seconds left in the period. Although a 3-point basket by Scott Skiles at the end of the third quarter brought the Pacers within 8, Detroit pulled away early in the fourth quarter. Wayman Tisdale scored 27 points for Indiana (32-34). (AP) Bucks 111, Hawks 98: Randy Breuer scored 27 points and matched his season high of 17 rebounds to lead Milwaukee to the victory at home. Terry Cummings and Jack Sikma added 22 points each for the Bucks (37-28). Dominique Wilkins scored 25 points to lead the Hawks (40-25).(AP) Nuggets 136, Spurs 109: Blair Rasmussen scored 28 points as Denver coasted to the victory at home. Michael Adams, who was 2 for 4 from 3-point range and finished with 8 points, extended his league record for consecutive games scoring on a 3-point shot to 27. Jay Vincent scored 20 points for Denver (40-26). Jon Sundvold scored 24 points for San Antonio (24-41).(AP) Jazz 103, Suns 96: Karl Malone had 28 points and a career-high 21 rebounds and John Stockton had 21 assists to lead Utah at home. The victory clinched a playoff berth for Utah (37-29) and also gave a berth to Houston. Walter Davis finished with 15 points for the Suns (20-45). (AP) N.H.L. Blues 5, Capitals 3: Brian Sutter and Gino Cavallini scored two goals apiece as St. Louis rallied from a 2-0 deficit to defeat Washington at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., last night. Greg Paslawski, playing for the first time since back surgery on Dec. 31, scored his first goal of the season to end a 2-2 tie with 2 minutes 23 seconds left in the second period. St. Louis (33-34-8) never trailed after that. The Capitals are 37-30-1. (AP) Whalers 4, Jets 3: Ron Francis took a return pass from Kevin Dineen and scored with 4:22 remaining to lift Hartford to the victory at home. The goal, the fourth by the Whalers in the final 20 minutes, capped a wild offensive flurry after the Jets had carried a 1-0 lead into the final period. The victory pushed the Whalers (31-36-7) into fourth place in the Adams Divsion. The loss was the sixth in a row for Winnipeg (31-34-10).(AP) Oilers 6, Red Wings 4: Craig MacTavish's short-handed goal with 8:26 left in the game ended a 4-4 tie to give Edmonton the victory in Detroit. With Edmonton's Steve Dykstra in the penalty box, the Detroit defenseman Doug Halward mishandled the puck at the Oilers' blue line. Mark Messier carried the puck into the Detroit zone and slipped a pass to MacTavish, who bounced a shot off the Red Wings' goalie, Greg Stefan, for his 15th goal of the season. The victory extended Edmonton's unbeaten streak to five games and pulled the Oilers (43-21-10) within 5 points of idle Calgary in the race for the Smythe Division title. Detroit (39-25-9) has clinched the Norris Division crown.(AP) Bruins 3, Flyers 0: The Boston goalie Andy Moog, in his fourth start of the league season after playing with Canada's Olympic team, stopped 20 shots as the Bruins (41-28-6) handed Philadelphia (36-31-7) a record-tying seventh shutout of the season. The seven shutouts tied a Flyers record set in 1971-72. The victory was Boston's first in Philadelphia since Feb. 21, 1982. The Bruins acquired Moog from the Edmonton Oilers on March 7. After a scoreless first period, Bob Sweeney gave the Bruins a 1-0 lead when he beat the Flyers' goalie, Mark LaForest, with a shot from the crease at 13:28 of the second period. LaForest, filling in for the injured Ron Hextall, stopped 26 shots. Cam Neely made it 2-0 with his 39th goal of the season on a power play at 5:52 of the third. With 9:51 left to play, Tom McCarthy took a pass from Michael Thelven behind the net and beat LaForest with a 10-foot back-hander.(AP) TENNIS Evert Edges Sukova: The 33-year-old Chris Evert joined the teen-agers Steffi Graf of West Germany, Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami and Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif., in advancing to the semifinals of the $2.1 million Lipton International Players championships yesterday in Key Biscayne, Fla. Second-seeded Evert outlasted Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 7-5, 6-4, in a match that lasted 2 hours 28 minutes. The 16-year-old Fernandez beat Elena Reinach of South Africa, 6-2, 6-3; Rehe, 18, outlasted Barbara Potter of Woodbury, Conn., 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, and top-seeded Graf, 18, swept sixth-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, 6-3, 6-1. (AP) COLLEGE BASKETBALL Grand Canyon Wins N.A.I.A. Title: Rodney Johns sank a 15-foot shot with 3 seconds left in overtime last night to lead Grand Canyon College over Auburn-Montgomery, 88-86, in the title game of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics tournament. After a timeout, Johns intercepted Auburn-Montgomery's inbound pass as the game ended. With 1:08 left, Grand Canyon's Craig Johnson had made a foul shot to tie at 86-86. Seconds later, Bobby Harris stole a Grand Canyon pass and drove in for a layup, but Johnson blocked the shot and Grand Canyon called a timeout with 13 seconds to play to set up Johns's game-winning shot. Johns, who scored 41 points, was named the tournament's most valuable player. The Antelopes, of Phoenix, won their third N.A.I.A. title since 1975 and finished their season 37-6. Auburn-Montgomery (32-3), of Alabama, was led by Orlando Graham with 17 points. In the consolation game, the College of Charleston (S.C.) beat Waynesburg (Pa.) College, 89-61.(AP)

title: About New York
description: The classroom is in the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island, and the students, all young women, are awaiting trial or serving short sentences - almost all on charges of selling drugs.

title: NEW DOUBTS RAISED ON AGENT ORANGE
description: A new Air Force report has raised questions about some conclusions of an often-cited 1984 Government study that was supposed to be ''reassuring'' for Vietnam veterans exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Sandinista and contra leaders offered differing proposals for a cease-fire during their second day of talks at a southern border outpost. The head of the contra delegation, Adolfo Colero, said that progress had been made. Page A1 Renewed aid for the contras was called for by President Reagan as the White House worked to fashion a contra aid package that could win bipartisan support in Congress. Mr. Reagan said the request would not be delayed during the peace talks. A10

title: Joseph S. Tushinsky, 78, Inventor, Musician and First to Import Sony
description: Joseph S. Tushinsky, a former audio-industry executive, inventor and musician, died of pneumonia at his home in Encino, Calif., Monday. He was 78 years old.

title: Proxmire Fear On Bribe Law
description: Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee, today assailed a proposed compromise that he said would weaken the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

title: Standing Up for Civil Rights
description: Congress has wisely and firmly turned back one of the most important political challenges to civil rights in recent years. The vote to override President Reagan's veto of the Civil Rights Restoration Act reconfirms a solid bipartisan consensus in Congress. It also catches the Reagan Administration, once again, on the wrong side of a civil rights issue.

title: Metro Datelines; Prison Term In Fatal Crash
description: A Brooklyn man was sentenced to three to nine years in prison yesterday for a 1986 automobile crash that killed a Bronx couple on the Interborough Parkway.

title: Market Place; Big Gains Seen In Generic Drugs
description: THE generic drug business has turned stronger, reflecting several trends that could carry its $4 billion in annual sales past $11 billion by the mid-1990's.

title: ISRAEL SAYS ARABS UNDER DETENTION NOW NUMBER 3,000
description: Israel said today that it was detaining 3,000 Palestinians in connection with the protests in the occupied territories, including 700 arrested in the last week alone.

title: Education; What Parents Should Ask Before Prepaying College Tuition
description: Tuition prepayment programs allow parents to pay a flat fee now that will cover the future cost of college at a given school when their child is ready to enroll. The programs guarantee that the child's education will be paid for, regardless of tuition increases in the intervening years. * Is there a maximum annual amount that can be contributed? Will any such maximum restrict the accumulation below a realistic projection of future college costs? * Can anyone in the family or an agent of the family contribute to the plan? Are there exclusions? * Can the proceeds from the plan be transferred to another family member if educational plans change? * Are there penalties associated with not attending a specific institution or set of institutions? What are they? * Is the yield from the plan guaranteed? How? * Is the plan insured? Can the investment be recovered if the plan sponsor ceases to exist? * Does the plan cover all college costs, or just tuition? * Are there any residency requirements for eligibility? What happens if the family moves during the plan years? * Will the plan benefits be taxable, either for Federal or state taxes?

title: Dr. Patrick Steptoe Is Dead at 74; Opened Era of 'Test Tube' Babies
description: Dr. Patrick Steptoe, the obstetrician who inaugurated a new era in 1978 when one of his patients delivered a baby girl conceived in a laboratory dish, died Monday in Canterbury, England. He was 74 years old Dr. Steptoe's family said he had been suffering from cancer.

title: It's Time to Give Back the Sphinx's Beard
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Expected to Announce Pact With Micron on Chips
description: The Intel Corporation is expected to announce Wednesday an alliance with Micron Technology Inc. that will help pave the way for Micron to increase its production of computer memory chips, industry executives said today.

title: 6 MURDERS LINKED IN BELFAST COURT
description: A self-described paramilitary retribution gunman, his eyes blackened, his face puffy, was charged today with the murders of three mourners in a grenade attack here last Wednesday on an Irish Republican Army funeral.

title: From Paris, Ungaro's Way With Luxury
description: Women addicted to the tightly swathed, brilliantly colored, sexy dresses that have become Emanuel Ungaro's signature need not worry. Even though, like most other designers, he's changing his style, some things remain constant.

title: Defense of College Plan Ordered
description: A State Supreme Court Justice, acting on a petition from the police patrolmen's union, has ordered the Koch Administration to defend a new policy that would require candidates for police sergeant to complete 64 units of college credit.

title: French Concern Plans To Buy CSX Oil Unit
description: The CSX Corporation, a diversified transportation company, agreed to sell its oil and gas subsidiary, the CSX Oil and Gas Corporation, to the North American unit of a leading French energy concern, Total Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, for $612 million in cash.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a provider of financial services, named Joe D. Heusi president and chief executive of Maryland Casualty Co., Baltimore, its principal property-liability insurance company.

title: Economic Scene; Air Fare Wars Are Not Over
description: The ticket lines are endless, the planes are late and now fares are going up. Coach class jumped 10 to 40 percent last week on many popular routes, and restrictions were tightened on discounts used by many business travelers. Is airline competition dying, a victim of increased market concentration and monopoly pricing?

title: Alice Van Santvoord, An Art Benefactor, 95
description: Alice Dresel Beal Van Santvoord, a patron of artists and a contributor to theatrical and educational institutions, died of complications following surgery Friday at St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, N.Y. She was 95 years old and lived in Newburgh.

title: Hollywood Rum and Coke: Hold the Rum, Hold the Sugar
description: Hollywood has a new ''in'' drink. At cocktail parties and premieres all over the area and throughout the film industry, Perrier has given way to Diet Coke as the drink of choice.

title: Metro Datelines; Lawyer Says Official Misled the F.B.I.
description: A prosecutor accused of fabricating death threats against herself during extradition proceedings for two Sikhs charged with terrorism gave F.B.I. agents a description used to make a sketch of a suspect, a defense lawyer said yesterday.

title: Swedes Expel Palestinians
description: Four Palestinians who had sought political asylum in Sweden were ordered expelled today for undisclosed security reasons, Erik Lempert, a senior official of the Labor Ministry, said. The order was issued after Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's Government met in a special session to consider their appeal against a ruling by police and immigration authorities that they leave the country, he said. A fifth Palestinian was granted a resident's visa for humanitarian reasons, despite objections by the National Security Police, Mr. Lempert said.

title: Education; The Cost of a Degree: Counting the Factors
description: At a recent discussion of forthcoming college tuition increases, the president of Kalamazoo College in Michigan raised some eyebrows among his colleagues by declaring that he was considering writing an ''honest letter'' to parents for the first time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 23, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Metro Datelines; 4 Plead Not Guilty In Killing by Mob
description: Four East Harlem residents pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they chased down and fatally beat a fleeing theft suspect.

title: Pious Bias
description: To The Living Section:

title: Amid Some Doubts, a Tokyo Dome
description: Japan, which has outclassed the United States in the manufacture of cars, cameras and electronic goods, is now out to prove that it can make a better domed stadium, too.

title: A Tender Lamb Dish For a Passover Seder
description: LAMB has been a traditional springtime food in the Middle East since Biblical times. It is appropriate to serve lamb for Passover, but rules govern the preparation, and are subject to various interpretations.

title: Meese Lawyer Received Bribe, Witness Asserts
description: A former executive of the Wedtech Corporation testified yesterday that he paid the personal lawyer of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d about $800,000 for ''his influence with Ed Meese.''

title: Kid Wants To Play
description: GARY CARTER looks around at the talent in the Mets' training camp and he knows he had better switch to Plan B. Plan B involves him catching long enough to break Bob Boone's ongoing record for most games caught in ''oh, five years or so.'' His hamstrings have no comment.

title: Top State Negotiator Urges Delay on Lilco Takeover
description: Governor Cuomo's chief representative in talks with the Long Island Lighting Company said today that he believed a public takeover of the utility now would cost too much and that he would prefer to see the state ''sit and wait, watching the company deteriorate.''

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * The Leonard Group, Elizabeth, N.J., to Keyes Martin Gaby Linett, Springfield, N.J., for Beauty Barn and Health Fair stores, two New Jersey retail chains.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FIRST signs of spring (however blustery) in Greenwich Village, as spotted by J. Porter Reilly: cooing mourning doves near St. Vincent's Hospital, budding ailanthus twigs at Greenwich Avenue and Eighth Street, swelling crocus stalks in Washington Square and, the surest one of all, this sign in the window of the A. & P. at 12th Street and the Avenue of the Americas: NO BARE FEET ALLOWED

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL PEN, THE CONGRESSIONAL ERASER
description: President Reagan likes to warn Congress that his ''veto pen'' is ready whenever Congress is considering legislation he opposes, but the record shows that he has vetoed far fewer bills than some of his predecessors did. Following are the top Presidents for vetoes cast and those overridden by Congress, which requires a two-thirds vote by each house. VETOES CAST . . . F. D. Roosevelt 635 In office 12 years Cleveland 584 In office 8 years Truman 250 In office 8 years Eisenhower 181 In office 8 years Grant 93 In office 8 years T. Roosevelt 82 In office 8 years Ford 66 In office 3 years Reagan 63 In office 7 years

title: States and Insurance Industry Battling on Liability Coverage
description: A long dispute between several states and the insurance industry over the reduction or elimination of liability coverage for local governments reached a turning point today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about money owed to the Federal Government by the nuclear power industry misidentified sponsors of a Senate amendment to require the industry to pay $8.8 billion. They are Senators Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, and William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: TALKS BY SHULTZ AND SHEVARDNADZE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, began crucial talks today on nuclear arms reduction and other issues to set the stage for a summit meeting in Moscow this spring.

title: Not So New
description: To The Living Section:

title: The Ups and Downs Of Skiing With Kids
description: LEAD: My wife and I introduced our children to skiing this winter. Mercifully, the season has come to an end.

title: Koppers Rejects Beazer's New Bid
description: The Koppers Company, the American construction and chemicals concern being sought by a group led by Beazer P.L.C., announced that it had rejected the sweetened $1.57 billion takeover offer as inadequate. The Pittsburgh-based concern reiterated that it would consider a recapitalization plan, to pay shareholders a large dividend while letting them hold an equity stake.

title: Sator's Sabres Complete Ranger Sweep
description: A year and a half and 25 yards have amounted to a world of difference for Ted Sator.

title: Serious Crime Rises Again in New York
description: For the second year in a row, the number of serious crimes in New York City rose in 1987, with murders up 5.7 percent and aggravated assaults up 12.1 percent, according to Police Department figures released yesterday.

title: Advertising; WPP Suing Lord, Geller Ex-Officials
description: MARTIN SORRELL'S London-based WPP Group is suing the newly formed Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners, the six men who founded the agency and Young & Rubicam, which has invested in it. They are charged with conspiring to take business from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, the WPP subsidiary they quit en masse last Friday.

title: Senate Votes to Keep Japanese Atom Pact
description: The Senate has refused to cancel a new 30-year nuclear cooperation agreement with Japan that critics say could promote the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Crime Is Up in New York City
'Welfare Cheats' Constitute a Very Small Minority of the Poor; Bravo to Mayor Koch
description: To the Editor:

title: San Mateo, Calif.
description: WITH its red and white ice-cream parlor tables, pastry display case and nonstop espresso machine, Romolo's is a virtual institution in San Mateo, about a half-hour south of San Francisco. Many Italian-American clubs and Italian restaurants in the Bay Area rely on Romolo's for their desserts, and residents rely on it for respite and cappuccino during the week and for special treats at Easter.

title: Ringling Brothers Celebrates The Classic Clowning Moments
description: It's no fun inside a burning clown house, even while the audience is shrieking with laughter. Shotgun shells keep going off, black-powder smoke squibs keep detonating, and puffs of flame keep exploding alarmingly. No wonder, then, that clowns will go to almost any lengths to escape: They'll go so far as to jump into a net held by a clown fire brigade.

title: Advertising; Manager Set At Burkhardt
description: Greg Bathon, one-time president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., a unit of the WPP Group, has joined Burkhardt & Christy, an $8 million agency with 12 employees.

title: Bell-Winfield Deal Denied by Blue Jays
description: It began as a rumor, and today it ended that way. There will be no deal between the Yankees and the Toronto Blue Jays that will bring George Bell, last season's American League Most Valuable Player, to New York for Dave Winfield.

title: Boy, 3, Is Found Scalded to Death
description: The body of a 3-year-old boy who was apparently scalded to death was found yesterday by the police in a Manhattan welfare hotel, the police said.

title: Advertising; Chiat/Day Obtains Nissan Dealers Group
description: Chiat/Day of Los Angeles, San Francisco and New York, opened an office in Chicago in January to woo the Nissan Mid-West Super Group, made up of dealers in 25 markets in the Middle West who spend $5 million a year on advertising. Chiat/Day was interested since it is already serving the national Nissan account.

title: City Council Extends Laws on Rent Control
description: The New York City Council yesterday extended the municipal rent-control and rent-stabilization laws for three years, and it turned back a request from the real-estate industry to deregulate apartments renting for more than $850 a month.

title: Education; Lessons
description: In some way, the education of every college student in the country is financed from the public trough. Taxes pay tuition, taxes buy books, taxes build buildings. We provide subsidies because, as Jefferson instructed, higher education is for the common good: It trains the country's professionals, improves morals, and forms in students the ''habits of reflection and correct action, rendering them examples of virtue to others, and of happiness within themselves.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Kosher Competition The traditional thick, sweet wine for Passover has considerable competition. Dozens of dry white and red kosher wines are available, including Champagnes, Chiantis, Beaujolais, Bordeaux whites and reds, and California cabernet sauvignons.

title: 6 Artists Get Awards
description: Six American artists - Christopher Brown, James DeMartino, Susan Hauptman, Albert York, Daisy Youngblood and Susan Lichtman -have been honored for their work by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. Each artist will receive a $5,000 cash award at a ceremony in May. More than 100 works by the six artists are on view through March 27 at the academy's galleries, on Audubon Terrace between 155th and 156th streets. Hours are 1 to 4 P.M. Tuesday through Sunday; admission is free.

title: Lethargic Bonds Ignore Reports
description: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were virtually unchanged yesterday as traders shrugged off several items of economic news that on other days might have started a rally.

title: First Boston Is Penalized
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that its market surveillance committee had censured and fined the First Boston Corporation and one of its managing directors for trade-reporting violations.

title: Decker Drops Takeover Bid For Standard
description: The Black & Decker Corporation yesterday called off its takeover bid for American Standard Inc., in return for a $25 million payment from Kelso & Company, which last week agreed to buy Standard for $2.5 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Fashion page yesterday about the fall and winter showings in Paris incorrectly ascribed one of Karl Lagerfeld's collections. It is produced by the House of Karl Lagerfeld, not by Stillman.

title: INSIDE
description: F.B.I. Harassment Charged

title: Review/Theater; Some Romans and Countrymen Conspire Anew to Murder Caesar
description: The worst thing that ever happened to ''Julius Caesar'' was its adoption by teachers nationwide as the ninth-grade student's ideal introduction to Shakespeare. In countless classrooms, ''Julius Caesar'' became the play that was Good for You - a sodden launching pad for earnest discussions about the perils of democracy, despotism, mob rule and . . . Are you dozing yet?

title: George Lehr, 51, Dies; Teamsters Fund Chief
description: George Lehr, a former State Auditor in Missouri who was credited with helping to clean up the scandal-plagued Teamsters Union Central States pension fund, died at his home here Monday.

title: Advertising; French Wine Account To Lois Pitts Gershon
description: Foods and Wines of France Inc. has named Lois Pitts Gershon Ponn/ GGK as agency for its wines and spirits. It will arrange to have its cheeses and other food products promoted by agencies or freelancers working on a project basis.

title: We Already Knew
description: To The Living Section:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Mike Mason, pitcher, on waivers for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Traded Jeff Stone and Keith Hughes, outfielders, and Rick Schu, infielder, to the Baltimore Orioles for Mike Young, outfielder, and a minor-league player to be named later. METS (NL) - Traded Bill Almon, infielder, to Philadelphia for Shawn Barton and Vladimir Perez, pitchers. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Agreed to terms with Chub Feeney, president, on a contract entension through 1990. FOOTBALL HAMILTON (CFL) - Named Michael McCarthy assistant general manager. HOCKEY PITTSBURGH (NHL) - Assigned Pat Mayer, defenseman, to Muskegon of the International Hockey League. COLLEGE DETROIT - Named Ricky Byrdsong head basketball coach. KINGS POINT - Named Joe Philben offensive line coach. Named Charlie Pravata offensive coordinator. Named Tom Masella golf coach. PROVIDENCE - Announced the resignation of Gordon Chiesa, men's basketball coach. TULANE - Named Chet Gladchuck athletic director. WEST VIRGINIA - Named Desmond Robinson assistant defensive coach.

title: Senate Roll-Call To Override Veto
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today overrode President Reagan's veto of a civil rights bill: FOR THE BILL - 73 Democrats 52 Adams, Wash. Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex. Bingaman, N.M. Boren, Okla. Bradley, N.J. Breaux, La. Bumpers, Ark. Burdick, N.D. Byrd, W.Va. Chiles, Fla. Conrad, N.D. Cranston, Calif. Daschle, S.D. DeConcini, Ariz. Dixon, Ill. Dodd, Conn. Exon, Neb. Ford, Ky. Fowler, Ga. Glenn, Ohio Gore, Tenn. Graham, Fla. Harkin, Iowa Heflin, Ala. Hollings, S.C. Inouye, Hawaii Johnston, La. Kennedy, Mass. Kerry, Mass. Lautenberg, N.J. Leahy, Vt. Levin, Mich. Matsunaga, Hawaii Melcher, Mont. Metzenbaum, Ohio Mikulski, Md. Mitchell, Me. Moynihan, N.Y. Nunn, Ga. Pell, R.I. Proxmire, Wis. Pryor, Ark. Reid, Nev. Riegle, Mich. Rockefeller, W.Va. Sanford, N.C. Sarbanes, Md. Sasser, Tenn. Shelby, Ala. Simon, Ill. Wirth, Colo. Republicans - 21 Boschwitz, Minn. Chafee, R.I. Cohen, Me. D'Amato, N.Y. Domenici, N.M. Durenberger, Minn. Evans, Wash. Hatfield, Ore. Heinz, Pa. Kassebaum, Kan. Kasten, Wis. McCain, Ariz. Murkowski, Alaska Packwood, Ore. Roth, Del. Rudman, N.H. Specter, Pa. Stafford, Vt. Stevens, Alaska Weicker, Conn. Wilson, Calif. AGAINST THE BILL - 24 Democrats - 0 Republicans - 24 Armstrong, Colo. Bond, Mo. Cochran, Miss. Danforth, Mo. Garn, Utah Gramm, Tex. Grassley, Iowa Hatch, Utah Hecht, Nev. Helms, N.C. Humphrey, N.H. Karnes, Neb. Lugar, Ind. McClure, Idaho McConnell, Ky. Nickles, Okla. Pressler, S.D. Quayle, Ind. Simpson, Wyo. Symms, Idaho Thurmond, S.C. Trible, Va. Wallop, Wyo. Warner, Va. NOT VOTING Democrats - 2 Biden, Del. Stennis, Miss. Republicans - 1 Dole, Kan.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN French terminology, a dish with tomatoes, garlic, olive oil, peppers, olives and saffron is considered to come from the Mediterranean regional tradition. Such dishes are gaining in popularity, and chicken is one of the easiest and most appropriate foods to cook in Mediterranean style.

title: Griffin Raises Bid for Resorts
description: The entertainer Merv Griffin raised his bid for Atlantic City's Resorts International Inc. today by 31 percent, to $295 million, apparently trying to entice the casino company's controlling shareholder, Donald J. Trump, to sell his interest. Last Thursday, the former talk show host said he would bid $35 a share, or $225 million, for Resorts class A and B shares.

title: Real Estate; Architectural Double Role In Manhattan
description: EVEN among the high-rise structures now going up in the west midtown section of Manhattan, the 55-story residential structure nearing completion on Eighth Avenue at 57th Street is a standout.

title: U.S. Safety Inspectors to Examine Factories, Not Just Injury Records
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced a new policy today, ordering its inspectors to examine hazardous areas of factories and not just job injury and illness records.

title: Status Quo for Unhappy Mets
description: Nolan Ryan's fastball thudded into Wally Backman's right forearm today at about 93 miles an hour. Backman was miffed.

title: Nets Sink 76ers; Knicks Routed; Nets 102, 76ers 90
description: Roy Hinson did not miss a shot from the field for the Nets, and Charles Barkley missed the entire second half for Philadelphia tonight as the Nets came away with a 102-90 victory at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Lauder Prepares to Run For Congress in Suffolk
description: Ronald S. Lauder, the former Ambassador to Austria and heir to the Estee Lauder fortune, is preparing to seek the Republican nomination to challenge Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, a Democrat, in the First Congressional District of eastern Suffolk County.

title: 6th Next Wave Festival To Open With Epic Play
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music announced yesterday that its sixth annual Next Wave Festival would open on Oct. 19 with ''The Warrior Ant,'' an epic work, conceived as a Japanese Bunraku play, by Lee Breuer and Bob Telson. The play traces the life of a mythical warrior ant, using Afro-Caribbean songs, dance and puppetry.

title: Northwest Air Expected to Announce Smoking Ban on U.S. Flights
description: Northwest Airlines is expected to announce today that it will become the only major American carrier to ban smoking on all its United States flights, an industry official said last night.

title: Our Science Priorities Need More Scrutiny
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; Portrait of a Hellion In 'Tallulah Tonight'
description: Tart bons mots fly across the stage of the American Place Theater in ''Tallulah Tonight,'' Helen Gallagher's one-woman salute to Tallulah Bankhead.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Portland, Ore.
description: LEAD: UNTIL they were struck by the entrepreneurial spirit, Peter de Garmo, late of California and Boston, thought of himself as a teacher of Spanish history, and Don Oman, of Scappoose, just down river from Portland, considered himself a construction millwright.

title: The Price of Postage
description: Examples of the new rates, scheduled to take effect April 3.

title: For Young Englishmen The Languorous Look
description: IN London, young men's thoughts are turning to romantic reworkings of classic fashions.

title: Books of The Times; Half Boys' Clubhouse and Half Survivalist Bunker
description: The Ark Sakura By Kobo Abe Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. 336 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Southland Borrows From a Licensee
description: The Southland Corporation said today that it was raising $320 million for its recent leveraged buyout through a loan from its convenience-store licensee in Japan.

title: China Sells Leases on Land To Foreigners for First Time
description: In a move to encourage land reform and create a real estate market, China began accepting bids today from foreign investors who want to buy long-term leases to develop sites here. Diplomats and members of the foreign business community saw the act as historic because control of land by foreigners has been taboo since the Communist armies marched down the Bund here in 1949 and declared that all foreign property belonged to Shanghai's citizens.

title: Education; When Aid for a Student Falls Far Short of Costs
description: Students do not have to give up on attending the college of their choice even when they find a growing gap between the cost of school and their financial aid package.

title: Tar Heels Are Already Happy
description: If there is one lingering criticism of Dean Smith's basketball program at North Carolina, it is that his teams do not win championships. And on March 13, when the Tar Heels lost the title game of the Atlantic Coast Conference Tournament for the third time in four years, that talk surfaced again.

title: For Hockey Players, Call of the Kitchen
description: Hockey players, who spend half their season on the road and often have several days of free time between games, eat in restaurants almost as much as they play on the ice. It's no wonder that so many have entered the restaurant business as a sideline to their profession.

title: Fire in Bronx Kills 2 People In Crack Den
description: A fire in a Bronx crack den killed two people early yesterday and injured five others, including two people described as squatters who jumped from the roof. The authorities said that the fire in the city-owned building had been set and classified the deaths as homicides.

title: Mexico's Foreign Aid Plan
description: Mexico today announced a 10-point financial aid program for Central America, including an innovative debt-relief plan, aimed at helping the war-torn countries rebuild their economies.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Hunter College announced yesterday that Jeff Bieder resigned as basketball coach after four seasons in which his teams had a record of 58-52, including a 17-12 mark this season. Bieder has taken a job as basketball coach at Long Island City High School. . . . Bobby Dodd, the former Georgia Tech football coach, has been released from an Atlanta hospital after undergoing chemotherapy. Dodd, 79 years old, was diagnosed as having lung cancer last week. . . . Robert Lavette, Georgia Tech's career leading rusher, has signed a two-year, no-option contract with the Atlanta Falcons. Lavette, a fourth-round draft choice of Dallas in 1985, was cut last season by the Cowboys and the Eagles. . . . The Steelers have decided to pass on Tony Robinson, the former Tennessee quarterback whose career was interrupted by a knee injury and a jail term for a cocaine conviction.

title: Business Technology; Advances; Silicon Chips Are Promising A New Era for Computers
description: COMPUTER memory technology is advancing so rapidly that some engineers believe that in the next decade silicon chips will begin to replace magnetic disks as the main way of storing information in computers.

title: Inured To the Inedible
description: Burgville is a fast-food town. You come in from the east, half mad with hunger after the long drive from Washington, and suddenly it's all spread out along the highway in front of you, and you cry, ''Paradise at last!''

title: Oil Declines On Silence By OPEC
description: The president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries called off a news conference today, and his action pushed oil prices down. He had been expected to announce measures to bolster prices.

title: Campeau Raises Its Offer Again
description: Seeking a knockout blow in its battle to win Federated Department Stores, the Campeau Corporation made higher offers to both Federated's shareholders and board yesterday.

title: Eastern Appeals Shuttle Decision
description: Eastern Air Lines filed an appeal today of a Federal judge's rulings that barred the carrier from selling its East Coast air shuttle service and threatened hefty fines if the company proceeded with the deal. The airline asked United States District Judge John H. Pratt to reverse his own March 10 contempt finding against Eastern for trying to sell the shuttle, said John J. Gallagher, a lawyer for Eastern.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sunday in the Going Out Guide of the New Jersey Weekly incorrectly described admission to a lecture this Friday by Representative Patricia Schroeder at William Paterson College in Wayne. Tickets are not free; they cost $10 ($8 for students, faculty members and the elderly).

title: Stop & Shop Workers Agree to End Strike
description: A settlement was reached early today ending a one-day strike by thousands of Stop & Shop supermarket workers in Connecticut and in western Massachusetts, a company spokeswoman said.

title: Review/Film; Sepulchral Seductress And a Taoist Warrior
description: If Gene Wilder undertook an all-Oriental takeoff on ''The Night of the Living Dead,'' he might come up with something like ''A Chinese Ghost Story.'' Ching Siu-Tung's spooky spoof, which plays at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 and Friday at 8:30 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films festival, features a klutzy hero who keeps falling into pools and puddles; a supernatural seductress who slaughters her lovers on behalf of her evil master, Lord Black, who may be a woman; a fierce warrior-philosopher-mystic who demolishes opponents with magic firecrackers, and wall-to-wall off-the-wall special effects.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By putting my signature beneath the dishonest materials of the Communist Party, you have insulted me before the whole country. I am obliged to beg forgiveness not only of the Armenian people but also before all honest people of our country.'' - Yuri Arakelyan, a Pravda correspondent, to his editor. [ A1:6. ]

title: Texaco Clears Hurdles As Court Hears Plan
description: As a Federal bankruptcy judge began final hearings today on the reorganization plan of Texaco Inc., the company said two potential obstacles to ending its yearlong bankruptcy had been removed.

title: Pouches Offer Fresher Foods, But F.D.A. Warns of Risk
description: ANYONE who has ever prepared a meal with a process called sous vide, which involves putting ingredients in a plastic pouch and cooking them, raves about the wonderful tastes that result.

title: John T. De Palma; Executive, 76
description: John T. De Palma , former chairman of Republic National Bank of New York in the mid-1970's, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 76 years old and lived in Cranford, N.J.

title: Deadline on Patriots
description: Paul Fireman, the owner of the Reebok shoe company, hopes to decide by tomorrow whether to buy the New England Patriots and straighten out their financial status. ''At this time, we are continuing intense negotiations with William H. Sullivan, owner of the team, and Francis Murray,'' said Fireman in a statement released Monday. The Sullivans have been in court with Murray, the head of a Philadelphia group that purchased an option to buy the team in 1985 and has since lent the club $21 million. If the deal goes through, according to The Boston Globe, Fireman would own 51 percent of the Patriots and be chairman, and Murray would own 49 percent and be chief executive officer. The pair would assume all of the team's debt, which is estimated at $95 million.(AP)

title: Superconductor and Silicon: Promising Marriage Is Seen
description: SCIENTISTS at the General Electric Company have come a step closer to marrying the new high-temperature superconductors to silicon-based integrated circuits by depositing a superconducting thin film on a silicon wafer. Superconductivity is the ability of a substance to carry electricity without resistance.

title: Art Historian Goes on Trial In Theft of Documents
description: Charles Merrill Mount, a scholar and art historian who is charged with transporting documents stolen from the Library of Congress and National Archives, went on trial today, denying the allegations but predicting he would be convicted.

title: Japan Warned to End Beef and Citrus Curbs
description: Two Cabinet officers warned Japan today that failure to end its curbs on imports of beef and citrus products by the end of this month would provoke punitive action by the United States within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: Woman Asserts F.B.I. Tried To Force a Lie About Agent
description: A Pennsylvania woman has accused the Federal Bureau of Investigation of trying to coerce her into making false and damaging statements about a black F.B.I. agent who had brought charges of racism against the bureau.

title: T.V.A. Reactor to Be Restarted
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved the restarting of the Tennessee Valley Authority's Sequoyah Unit 2, a $2 billion reactor closed in 1985 for safety deficiencies.

title: South Africa, Invoking Curbs, Shuts Black Paper
description: The South African Government closed a leading anti-apartheid newspaper for three months today after declaring that it was bent on stimulating revolution.

title: Officials Call Border Dispute An Obstacle in Afghan Talks
description: A border dispute between Afghanistan and Pakistan has emerged as a new obstacle to a treaty ending the Afghan civil war and allowing the withdrawal of Soviet troops, according to officials close to the negotiations.

title: The Message of a Vigilante Killing
description: Mayor Koch rightly denounces the gang that pursued, beat and fatally injured an alleged thief in East Harlem. But city and community leaders dare not ignore the frustration behind the crime.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: TWO years ago Michael Tuohy left San Francisco and an enviable job running Joyce Goldstein's Caffe Quadro to open Chef's Cafe at an Atlanta location most restaurateurs would avoid: a nondescript expressway-stop motel two doors from the Tattle Tale Lounge on Piedmont Road.

title: John A. Maurer, 83, A Holder of 60 Patents
description: John A. Maurer, an inventor who developed 16- and 8-millimeter sound recording and reproduction systems, died of a heart attack Sunday at the Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Somerset, N.J.

title: Postal Rates Are Going Up; Mailing a Letter to Cost 25/
description: With a pledge of better service, the Postal Service said today that it would institute higher postage rates, including a 25-cent charge for first-class letters, beginning April 3.

title: Washington Airport Bonds Offering Yields Up to 8.20%
description: The Metropolitan Washington Airport Authority is tentatively offering $125 million of subordinated revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.20 percent for those due in 2018.

title: U.S. Files Suit Against P.L.O. to Shut U.N. Mission
description: The United States filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Manhattan today in an attempt to force the Palestine Liberation Organization to shut its observer mission to the United Nations.

title: The Pop Life
description: Ruben Blades's 'Truth'

title: Beyond Cheesesteaks
description: ''Philadelphia is not as bad as Philadelphians think it is.'' That message, seen on a billboard here not too many years ago, was meant to be complimentary.

title: Review/Television; 'The City Never Sleeps'
description: The night has a thousand eyes, but thank heavens most are friendly. In ''The City Never Sleeps,'' nighttime in New York is inviting. The WNBC-TV film, on Channel 4 at 7:30 tonight, says darkness brings an eccentric congeniality to the streets. Even if that's not all it brings, the film is amusing.

title: Small Synthetic Spheres That Can Improve a Kiss
description: IMAGINE a lipstick that moisturized every time a woman puckered up or kissed, or a foot powder that provided more antifungal relief with every step. These are two of many applications now possible with microsponges, microscopic synthetic spheres that can be ''programmed'' to release cosmetic or pharmaceutical agents in response to pressure, time or temperature.

title: With Sisyphus in Central America
description: The Central American isthmus makes life hard for headline writers.

title: Advertising; MacNamara, Clapp Gets New President
description: Keith P. Fischer, the former president of a number of agencies, has added still another agency to the list. This time it is MacNamara, Clapp & Klein, billing about $48 million.

title: Banned in Annapolis
description: James H. Webb Jr., who angrily quit last month as Secretary of the Navy, is still a popular man on campus at the Naval Academy in Annapolis. Seven years ago Mr. Webb, a 1968 graduate of the Academy, wrote a fictional novel, ''Sense of Honor,'' based on his experiences at Annapolis as a midshipman.

title: 'Welfare Cheats' Constitute a Very Small Minority of the Poor; Root Perceptions
description: To the Editor:

title: Sacred and Secular In Easter Celebrations; Family Holiday Isn't What It Used to Be
description: EASTER is the misfit among American holidays. In principle it is the most important date in the Christian calendar, but its religious significance has been its secular undoing. The country, it seems, is too religious and too Christian to ignore Easter, but also too pluralist and too secular to absorb it comfortably as a national holiday.

title: 2 Medals for Baker
description: President Reagan presented a new Presidential Medal of Freedom to the White House chief of staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., on Monday after the original was lost in a break-in at the Baker home in northwest Washington. Mr. Baker ''is probably the only person who has received two Medals of Freedom,'' a White House spokesman said.

title: Suzy Frelinghuysen, Artist, Is Dead at 76
description: Suzy Frelinghuysen, a former opera singer and a painter whose work is increasingly recognized by collectors and museums, died of a stroke on Saturday in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 76 years old, and had homes in New York City and Lenox, Mass.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Air France said it had ordered two additional Boeing 747's.

title: Sam W. Reynolds; Former Senator, 97
description: Sam W. Reynolds, a businessman who was appointed a United States Senator and served for seven months, died at home of pneumonia Sunday. He was 97 years old.

title: Fain Arrested
description: Ferris Fain, the American League batting champion in 1951 and 1952, is being held without bail in Placerville, Calif., after deputies raided his home last Thursday and arrested him when they found more than 400 marijuana plants, according to Lieut. Howard Wilson of the El Dorado County Sheriff's office. Fain was jailed on charges of cultivation of marijuana and possession for sale, the lieutenant said, and at the time of his arrest, he was on five years' probation from a 1985 marijuana conviction. ''He increased his operation incredibly since 1985,'' said Wilson. Fain, 67 years old, played with the Athletics from 1947 to 1952, two years with the Chicago White Sox and then split the 1955 season with the Detroit Tigers and Cleveland Indians. His career batting average was .290.(AP)

title: Notrees Journal; Here's a Town That Time, and Also Trees, Forgo
description: In an act of hope, determination or just plain boredom, Kim Baumguardner and her husband, Sam, are planting trees in this dusty West Texas town. Two tiny shrubs, all but hidden by barbed wire, sit in the center of a newly purchased plot next to the Baumguardner home. Mrs. Baumguardner's best friend used to live there. Recently she moved away.

title: 7th Day of Deliberation for Chambers Jury
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. begins its seventh day of deliberations today, apparently concentrating on the internal injuries medical examiners found on the body of Jennifer Dawn Levin.

title: Review/Ballet; Edward Villella Shows Off More New Miami Dancers
description: The Miami City Ballet, directed by Edward Villella, presented more of its dancers in New York debuts with the company Sunday afternoon at Whitman Hall at Brooklyn College.

title: Marrow Transplant Succeeds
description: A girl who became the first cancer patient to receive a bone marrow transplant through the services of a computerized national registry has been pronounced free of leukemia, hospital officials say.

title: A Quiet Feminist
description: To The Living Section:

title: Filling Bork's Shoes
description: There has been intense interest among judges and lawyers in the capital over who will be named to the Federal appeals court here to replace Judge Robert H. Bork, who resigned early last month.

title: Reagan Urges Contra Aid but Democrats Are Wary
description: President Reagan called again today for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels as the White House worked to fashion a contra aid package that could win bipartisan support in Congress.

title: Gaines Appeals Ban
description: Since the 1984 Olympics, when he won three gold medals in swimming, Rowdy Gaines has earned hundreds of thousands of dollars for endorsements and appearances. For two years, he also coached young swimmers on a team called the Las Vegas Gold. Now, at age 29, though he is not in gold-medal shape, Gaines wants to swim with the Gold in the 400-meter freestyle relay Friday in the Phillips 66/U.S. Swimming national indoor championships in Orlando, Fla. However, the rules do not allow him to compete unless he puts all that money into a trust fund in his name. Yesterday, United States Swimming's eligibility committee ruled him ineligible to swim. Gaines appealed, and a special board of review will hear the appeal Friday before the relay.

title: Gerhard Claas, 59, A Leader of Baptists
description: The Rev. Gerhard Claas, general secretary of the Baptist World Alliance, has died of injuries suffered in a traffic accident near Lodi, Calif., the alliance announced today.

title: Shift in Gulf Battlefronts; Widening War on the Cities and Shipping Reflects a Desire for Diplomatic Advantage
description: In sharp contrast to recent practice, the Iran-Iraq war has become focused on offensives far from the major battlefronts on land that Teheran views as decisive in determining the eventual victor.

title: The Job of Matching Jobs With the Job Seekers
description: Reaching deep into a drawer, Ruth Mitchell grabbed a fistful of job forms and splayed them across the desktop. ''Messenger, forklift operator, dental assistant,'' she said, glancing at form after form. ''This employer wants a secretary who can type 40 words per minute and speak Korean.''

title: Democratic Battle Is On For 646 Elite Delegates
description: In the battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination, there is no group comparable to the superdelegates, the 646 Governors and members of Congress and the Democratic National Committee who will automatically attend this year's Democratic convention. And the battle for their votes in now in full fury.

title: >Review/Television; A Hospital That's Run On a First-Name Basis
description: Esther Shapiro and Aaron Spelling Productions are key members of the team that brought forth ''Dynasty.'' Now, sensing that fantasies about fabulously wealthy schemers may have run their course as the Reagan years draw to a close, the producers have decided to become more reality-oriented.
