As usual in the dizzy world of entertainment, reality is a relative concept.

title: SENATORS WORRIED ABOUT ARMS PACTS
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee expressed ''grave concerns'' today about American ability to monitor Soviet compliance with a proposed treaty limiting long-range nuclear missiles.

title: Dukakis Takes New Trade Message to North and Gephardt Cries Foul
description: ''There's no change,'' Gov. Michael S. Dukakis protested as he pledged his support for tough new trade legislation.

title: Stopping the Gulf War
description: The dispatch of American and European warships to the Persian Gulf was eventually organized into an effective operation despite the sloppy start. ''It worked,'' says Adm. Pierre Lacoste, former head of France's secret service, ''and because it worked you don't hear that it is working.''

title: Advertising; Griffin Bacal Grows
description: Griffin Bacal Inc., which has proved its skill with children's advertising as the agency for Hasbro, Milton Bradley and Playskool, will next be doing advertising for the Muppet line of dental products from Gillette's Oral-B. These include the character toothbrushes as well as Kermit the Frog mild mint toothpaste and Miss Piggy bubble gum toothpaste. The previous agency was Chiat/Day, San Francisco, which lost the rest of the Oral B business to BBDO/West.

title: Timbuktu Journal; Sadly, Desert Nomads Cultivate Their Garden
description: Mohammed Ag Mahamoud, a descendant of the fierce Tuaregs once called lords of the desert, crouched behind a sand dune and weeded his carrots.

title: Nets Sink 76ers; Knicks Routed; Mavericks 124, Knicks 105
description: Roy Tarpley set a club record with 24 rebounds and scored a career-high 29 points tonight, leading the Dallas Mavericks to a 124-105 victory over the Knicks.

title: Japan Fines Toshiba Unit for Sales to Soviet
description: A Japanese court today found the Toshiba Machine Company guilty of selling militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union, but it imposed a light fine on the company and gave suspended prison terms to two former executives.

title: Mailing a Letter? Add 3/ in April
description: Rates are scheduled to change April 3. The E stamp was printed as an interim stamp before the increase was officially approved. Among the rate increases: Letters . . . 25 cents Extra ounce . . . 20 cents Post cards . . . 15 cents Article, page D26

title: National Center Set to Improve History Teaching
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced today that it was providing money to establish a research center to improve history instruction in elementary and secondary schools.

title: Pravda Writer Disavows Article on Armenia
description: An Armenian correspondent for Pravda has disavowed an article published over his signature, an article that dashed Armenian hopes for a favorable resolution of territorial demands.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE VOTE TO OVERRIDE REAGAN ON RIGHTS
description: Overriding President Reagan's veto, Congress voted by large margins today to extend the reach of Federal civil rights laws.

title: Unspeakable Truths About Unrecoverable Debts
description: To the Editor:

title: House Roll-Call Overriding Reagan's Veto of Civil Rights Bill
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 292 to 133 by which the House of Representatives today overrode President Reagan's veto off a civil rights bill. A ''yes'' vote was a vote to override the veto and enact the law. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 52 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 10 Democrats and 123 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are 2 vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Gabon Debt Rescheduled
description: The Paris Club of Western creditor nations has agreed to reschedule Gabon's foreign debt. The French Finance Ministry, acting as spokesman for club negotiations, said in a statement today that Gabon's new payments would be made over 10 years, including a five-year grace period.

title: Soviet-Bloc Energy Sales
description: The Soviet bloc's exports of energy to the West grew last year, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today. Gas deliveries rose 5.4 percent, oil 3.7 percent and coal 1.3 percent. The bloc's biggest customer, West Germany, took 22 percent of the total.

title: Boxing Notebook; HBO Puts Focus on Chavez
description: Home Box Office has a history of building its boxing programming around multifight deals with fighters it thinks will become headliners.

title: Democrats Abroad Pick Dukakis in London Vote
description: In this lonely outpost of the American political campaign, a band of Democrats trickled into a polling place in the shadow of Westminster Abbey today and helped pick Gov. Michael S. Dukakis as their choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Letter: On Foreign Affairs; Tibet's Role in U.S.-China Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: A Man's Place
description: To The Living Section:

title: Education; College Officials Defend Sharply Rising Tuition
description: The price tag for four years of college will approach $80,000 at some of the nation's campuses next September, about the cost of a modest house in many parts of the country.

title: Ransom Wilson, Flutist, Wins $10,000 Prize
description: Ransom Wilson, a flutist and conductor of the Tuscaloosa Symphony Orchestra and the chamber orchestra Solisti New York, has been awarded the first Alabama Prize by the New York Times Company Regional Newspaper Group. The award of $10,000 is given in alternate years to a visual artist or a performing artist who was born in Alabama and who lived in that state for at least seven years.

title: Taipei Halts Work on Secret Plant To Make Nuclear Bomb Ingredient
description: Under pressure from the United States, Taiwan has stopped work on a secret installation that could have been used to obtain plutonium, a main ingredient in nuclear weapons, according to Administration officials.

title: Review/Theater; New American Plays Surface in Louisville
description: In an attempt to revitalize the Humana Festival of New American Plays, Jon Jory commissioned plays from three name writers, guaranteeing them production in the 1988 festival. For ''personal reasons,'' Susan Sontag did not fulfill her commission. Marsha Norman, the only playwright of the three, felt that her play was still in a developmental phase and requested that the workshop production not be ''subject for review or literary criticism at this point.'' Jimmy Breslin wrote a play that was not up to the standard set by the author's other work. Despite the low yield of Mr. Jory's commissioning, this year's festival - a three-day marathon drawing hundreds of critics, producers, directors and others to the Actors Theater of Louisville -proved to have more positive elements than the previous two festivals.

title: Education; Manhattan College Seeks a New Kind of Student
description: For much of its 135-year history, Manhattan College was the bootstrap used by many blue-collar Irish and Italian families to achieve a better life. But as those groups continue to climb the social ladder, Manhattan College finds itself looking to to two new groups to survive and grow - children of the affluent and of the urban poor.

title: Soviet Military Doctrine Still Stresses Offense
description: To the Editor:

title: De Benedetti Lacks Majority
description: The forces of Carlo de Benedetti came up short today in their latest effort to gain majority control of Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company. Compagnies Europeennes

title: Bonn Cabinet Backs Plan for Tax Changes
description: The West German Cabinet today approved a much-debated tax-change plan that is designed to reduce the nation's net tax bill by 20.7 billion marks, or more than $12 billion, starting in 1990.

title: Park Interests Join to Protest Home for Cult
description: A new town that is the spiritual headquarters of a cult is being built just north of Yellowstone National Park, and area residents and park officials say their worst fears about it are close to being realized.

title: For Girl With a Kite, It Was Chance to Fly
description: DeAndra Anrig was flying a kite when it suddenly started to fly her, her parents say. It was just a short hop, but one that DeAndra, who is 8 years old, is not likely to forget.

title: Food: True and False
description: To The Living Section:

title: Arts Festival to Offer Works That Defy Labels By STEPHEN HOLDEN
description: Aquatic dancing in the Columbia University swimming pool, an experimental performance series at P. S. 122 that calls itself the East Village World's Fair and an acrobatic dance-theater work in the Brooklyn Bridge Anchorage are among the more than 70 events that will be presented this June and July as part of the ''multi-disciplinary program'' of the New York International Festival of the Arts.

title: Head of E.P.A. Bars Nazi Data In Study on Gas
description: The chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, alerted by a letter of protest from agency scientists, has barred from an E.P.A. report on a toxic gas any data that the Nazis acquired in experiments on concentration camp prisoners.

title: Working Profile: Jim Burnley; Transportation Chief Plots Course for Short Haul
description: When Jim Burnley climbs behind the wheel of his white Mustang V-8 convertible and slaps in a rhythm-and-blues cassette into the tape player, he might not be instantly recognizable as the nation's Secretary of Transportation.

title: HOLOCAUST WRITER CANCELS LECTURES
description: Elie Wiesel, the chronicler of the Holocaust, decided yesterday to cancel a day of lectures scheduled for tomorrow after learning that the lectures were underwritten by a conservative Michigan publisher who has been accused by the Justice Department of being an agent of the South African Government.

title: Rhode Island Savors Success
description: On Monday, students at the University of Rhode Island camped in the lobby of Keaney Gymnasium, one underclassman pitching a pup tent, others toting mattresses. Music played, there were card games, and a festive air pervaded.

title: New York's Elections Board: Portrait Of a Hobbled Agency
description: The New York State Board of Elections, under criticism recently for its apparent laxity, conducts such cursory examinations of campaign filings that violators of the state's contribution limits are almost never caught and even blatant discrepancies in campaign accounts are often not investigated.

title: Dallas
description: HARRIET and Leon Powers made a fortune selling fine linens at a discount in Louisiana, then lost it when the local economy crashed. So they moved back to their native Dallas a year ago, determined that their next line of work would involve no inventory whatever. ''I didn't want to end up stuck with millions in unsold fabric again,'' Mrs. Powers said.

title: Court Eases Bar to Embassy Protests
description: The Supreme Court, striking down key portions of a 50-year-old law, today cleared the way for protesters to conduct hostile demonstrations near foreign embassies in the District of Columbia as long as they do not disrupt embassy activities or threaten security.

title: Protesters Try to Block Brawley Case Inquiry
description: Demonstrators protesting the handling of a special grand jury investigation into the case of Tawana Brawley today blocked the main entrance to the armory where the panel meets.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Heir Apparent Made Definite at McDermott
description: LEAD: McDermott International Inc., a leading oil services company based in New Orleans, chose Robert E. Howson today as its next chairman and chief executive, succeeding James E. Cunningham, who will retire this summer at age 65.

title: The Pauses - , ; . : ? ! - That Refresh
description: The usual onward spirit at Cooper Union is punctuated these days by unmistakable signs of hesitation that give pause for thought, or at least contemplation, on the venerable school's second floor.

title: Searle Backed On IUD Data
description: There is no evidence that G. D. Searle & Company withheld information from the Food and Drug Administration in winning approval for its Copper-7 intrauterine contraceptive device, an F.D.A. spokeswoman said today.

title: KEY RATES
Southdown's Bid For McCormack
description: Southdown Inc., the Houston-based cement manufacturer, said it was willing to offer securities for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. instead of its $450 million cash offer.

title: Bonus in Tennis
description: The Men's Tennis Council has approved a bonus system designed to combat competition from lucrative exhibition events that conflict with official Grand Prix tournaments. ''We want to eliminate the confusion caused when other events clash with Grand Prix tournaments in which players are competing for world rankings,'' said Marshall Happer, administrator of the council. Bonuses will be awarded to players based on their point standings and/or computer rankings. Happer said the incentives were needed to ''provide a representative field for each tournament.''(AP)

title: Metro Datelines; Democrat Is Winner In Suffolk Recount
description: Democrat Robert Sweeney defeated Republican James Caples by 43 votes in the race for the state Assembly seat in the 11th District in Suffolk County, the Board of Elections announced yesterday after a recount of the vote.

title: Review/Orchestra; Vienna,the Israel's Way
description: The Israel Chamber Orchestra is a finely polished ensemble with a lovely string sound and winds that play firmly and precisely. Like most orchestras, it has its strengths and weaknesses in matters of repertory, and its director, Yoav Talmi, let us see some of each in a Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Stocks Mixed as Dow Slips 0.99, to 2,066.15
description: Stock prices ended mixed in light trading yesterday after moving in a narrow range for most of the day.

title: Life in the 30's
description: Anna Quindlen's column will appear regularly on page C2 in The Home Section starting tomorrow.

title: Small Study Cites Gains in Treating Lung Cancer
description: A small study has found that an experimental treatment that stimulates the immune system can double the survival rate of patients in the early stages of lung cancer, a scientist reported today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. to Keep Its Troops On Watch in Honduras
description: Even though Nicaraguan troops have been withdrawn from Honduras, American military officers said today, the United States will keep its expeditionary force of 3,500 soldiers here for 10 days more to stand watch and to train.

title: Orders for Durable Goods Declined 1.8% in February
description: Orders to the nation's factories for durable goods fell 1.8 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today. Although it was the second consecutive monthly decline, analysts said it did not shake their belief that manufacturing will be a bright spot in the economy this year.

title: Breaking the Ice
description: Jim Wright, the Speaker of the House, has had testy relations with the Republican minority since assuming office more than a year ago. Republicans have charged him with dictatorial tactics, and they openly mourn the departure of Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Mr. Wright's predecessor, who retired in 1986 after 10 years in the job.

title: China Seeks TV Loans
description: China is seeking foreign loans to help finance the production of more color television sets to meet growing domestic demand, bankers reported today. They said the state-owned Bank of China was sounding out foreign banks for loans totaling $270 million to expand production of color television tubes and glass bulbs. The loans would be used to ugrade four production lines. Official figures show China made about 19.4 million television sets in 1987, up from about 14.5 million in 1986, and about a third of them were color sets.

title: Proposal for a Food Cut Assailed
description: Members of a Senate committee today criticized the Agriculture Department for a proposed budget cut that would eliminate financing for the distribution of surplus food to the poor.

title: U.S. Discounts Noriega's Offer to Quit
description: With President Reagan calling again for the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama, Administration officials today dismissed General Noriega's offer to resign by 1989, calling it a ploy.

title: A Reputed Drug Lord Flees Colombia Troops
description: A reputed leader of the Medellin drug cartel escaped after a shootout between his bodyguards and soldiers at a country estate near here early today, the army reported.

title: Unspeakable Truths About Unrecoverable Debts; Lend to Businesses
description: To the Editor:

title: Mecham Trial Hears of Warning About Loan
description: A former top assistant to Gov. Evan Mecham testified today that she had warned that ''people could possibly go to jail'' over an $80,000 loan to the Governor's automobile dealership from a fund intended for state uses.

title: Ulster Will Send Police Back to I.R.A. Burials
description: After two deadly funeral conflicts, the police announced the end of their policy today of staying away from Irish Republican Army burials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I know they'll never find him, because it's white against black. I know if it was my son did it, wherever he was, they would find him.'' - Melanie Ferguson, a West Indian whose son was beaten in a London racial incident. [ A1:1. ]

title: One Wright Dream On Staten Island
description: THIRTY years ago Frank Lloyd Wright designed a house on Staten Island for a young Queens couple, William and Catherine Cass. Mrs. Cass, who still lives in the house, has never forgotten the experience.

title: Color of the 50's
description: To The Home Section:

title: Grolier Rejects Hachette's Offer
description: Grolier Inc., the encyclopedia and reference book company, rejected a $415 million takeover bid by Hachette S.A. of France as inadequate. Earlier this month Hachette offered to buy Grolier for $21 a share with hopes of becoming the world's third-largest publisher. Grolier closed today at $26.50, up 12.5 cents.

title: Integrity Panel Chief is Low-Key With High Goals
description: The only thing on the wall of the office of the chairman of the New York State Commission on Government Integrity is a framed prayer of St. Francis that begins, ''Make me an instrument of your peace.''

title: Parent & Child
description: A FEW years ago, a friend asked his father if he could borrow the car to go to the beach. His father thought about it, asked some questions and finally said no. He did not trust his son to make such a trip by himself.

title: Meagher Making New Commitment
description: Mary T. Meagher is, without question, the best butterfly swimmer ever, male or female. She has been a world-record holder since age 14. But now, at 23, she had struggled in trying to decide whether she wanted to keep swimming and defend her Olympic titles this fall.

title: A Fond Son Is Reviving Preston Sturges's Fame
description: During a brief time in the 1940's, Preston Sturges was the toast of Hollywood. He had already conquered Broadway; confined to bed by a ruptured appendix, Sturges decided to write a play and produced ''Strictly Dishonorable,'' which became a hit and was twice made into a film.

title: Lucky Might Try Leveraged Buyout
description: The shares of Lucky Stores Inc. climbed another $2.25, to $49, in New York Stock Exchange trading as analysts said the supermarket chain might be preparing a leveraged buyout to exceed the $45 offer from the American Stores Company. Lucky, based in Dublin, Calif., has not yet responded to American Stores' $1.74 billion bid, made Tuesday. But the company said that its certificate of incorporation limits voting powers of any stockholder to 15 percent.

title: Bank Sheds Some Loans
description: The European American Bank, Long Island, has purged itself of $880 million of questionable loans made to borrowers in more than 20 nations who have had to reschedule their debts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 16, about a New York state panel's hearing on campaign financing, incorrectly described testimony by William Stern, a fund raiser for Mario Cuomo in 1982.

title: George Lehr, 51, Dies; Teamsters' Fund Chief
description: George Lehr, a former State Auditor in Missouri who was credited with helping to clean up the scandal-plagued Teamsters Union Central States Pension Fund, died at his home here Monday.

title: Iran Charges Iraq With Gas Attack
description: NICOSIA--Iran renewed accusations today that Iraq had killed thousands of Kurdish civilians with chemical weapons on the northern battlefront.

title: Review/Flute; From Prokofiev to Doppler
description: There was much to admire in Laura Gilbert's flute playing on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Her tone is deep, smoothly rounded and alluring, and her manipulation of dynamics and timbre - detailed enough to make trifles like Doppler's virtuosic ''Hungarian Fantasy Pastorale'' sound witty rather than merely charming, and to impose an unusually compelling dramatic shape on Luciano Berio's ''Sequenza'' - gives her the capacity to surprise.

title: ALLIS-CHALMERS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $5,246,000 for the quarter and $1,734,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,150,000 and $9,961,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said the Chapter 11 costs were essentially offset by nonaccrual of $3.7 million of interest on certain debt as a result of the filing for reorganization on June 29, 1987. The latest fourth quarter loss from discontinued operations included a loss of $12.3 million on the sale of the solids processing equipment and mineral systems businesses to Boliden AB, of Sweden.

title: Currents; The Spaceship Earth
description: WESTWEEK is, ostensibly, a furniture market held each year at the Pacific Design Center in West Hollywood, Calif., at which new furniture is introduced to West Coast designers and architects. But yesterday, Joseph P. Allen, an astronaut, opened the three-day event, ''Overview: Expansion and Insight,'' with a talk about the grandest overview of them all: the view of Earth from space.

title: Since 1948, a Jewish-Arab Population Exchange; For All the Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Pop; INXS, a Package Of Rock History From Australia
description: ''All you've got is this moment,'' INXS advises in ''Need You Tonight,'' a song that helped propel the Australian band's current album, ''Kick,'' into the Top 10. INXS (pronounced, in excess), which opened a three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall on Friday, has a core following of teen-age girls, who shrieked every time the band's skinny, chestnut-maned lead singer, Michael Hutchence, moved toward the audience or kicked shoulder-high. Now, that following is broadening. INXS's adept appropriation of every stomping groove of the last 20 years - Led Zeppelin, Prince, Bruce Springsteen, Roxy Music, Duran Duran, AC/DC - and its lyrics about living for the moment offer a neatly packaged version of rock's impact and attitude.

title: Reagan Education Budget Is Said to Deprive Needy
description: Despite President Reagan's proposed increases in education spending, millions of needy students will not receive critical educational aid if the President's budget is approved, a coalition of more than 100 groups said today.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Don't Drink the Water
description: Normally, the type of contamination that worries the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is radioactive. But when the agency recently moved into its new headquarters in Maryland, it found itself concerned with another kind of contamination: lead.

title: Canada Rejects Charges Of Hyundai Dumping
description: A Canadian Government tribunal handed a major victory today to the Hyundai Motor Company of South Korea, ruling that the Canadian subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation had not been injured by Hyundai's policy of selling its cars in Canada at lower prices than it charges in South Korea.

title: AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results reflect the acquisition of the remaining stake in Welltech.

title: Galmetiyawa Journal; The Day the Men With Guns Came to the Village
description: Eleven-year-old Seelawathi Menike and her little brother were shooing birds away from their family's vegetable plot when the big men in dark uniforms emerged from the jungle and began shooting.

title: Review/Cabaret; Jamie deRoy's Sendups
description: If Joan Rivers were a Manhattan-based cabaret artist, her act might well resemble that of Jamie deRoy, a singer and comedian who appeared at Caroline's at the Seaport on Monday.

title: The Race to Save the Ozone Shield
description: The chemical threat to the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere turns out to be more serious than feared. The damage may already be three times greater than the worst future loss assumed in a pending international treaty to cap production of the destructive chemicals. Even stronger measures may soon be needed.

title: Gerhard Claas, 59, A Leader of Baptists
description: The Rev. Gerhard Claas, general secretary of the Baptist World Alliance, has died of injuries suffered in a traffic accident near Lodi, Calif., the alliance announced Tuesday.

title: Review/Ragtime; From a Trove Of Rediscovered Joplin et al.
description: In 1985, Rick Benjamin, a 20-year-old Juilliard student fascinated with ragtime music, stumbled into every enthusiast's dream - an abandoned warehouse packed with rare manuscripts and photographs. Mr. Benjamin's find was the library of Arthur Pryor, once a trombonist in the Sousa band and later a conductor, composer and arranger who led a touring band and a recording orchestra. Pryor's collection was thought to have been destroyed in the 1920's, but it turned out to contain thousands of works by many popular composers of the time, among them W. C. Handy, Scott Joplin and Pryor himself.

title: Meese Barred From Inquiry on Black F.B.I. Agent
description: A Federal judge today barred Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and the head of the Justice Department's civil rights division from any involvement in a grand jury investigation of racial harassment allegations made by a black agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: PRICE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,708,000 on the early extinguishment of debt, included a net gain of $19,374,000 on certain properties sold in 1987 and a provision for a loss anticipated on a sale in 1988. The company also noted that it has deferred an additional $50 million in gains on the sale of properties, which will be recognized as payments are received.

title: Review/Jazz; A Basie History Lesson
description: To hear a great American orchestra like the Count Basie big band play for dancers is a musical history lesson; what's usually an esthetic experience suddenly takes on a functional, more complex meaning. At the New York Swing Dance Society's weekly dance Sunday night at the Cat Club (76 East 13th Street) pounding riff after pounding riff made the dancers hop.

title: Savings Up in Japan
description: The average Japanese household in a recent survey had $82,000 in savings at the end of last year, up 14.9 percent from a year earlier, according to a Government report published today. It was the biggest annual savings increase since 1979, when the rise was 15.5 percent.

title: Gephardt, in Michigan, Makes a Do-or-Die Run
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt was wearing a bright blue United Steelworkers warm-up jacket for his midafternoon visit to Chick's Roost Lounge, where his campaign was providing free beer and hot dogs. ''This election, ladies and gentlemen,'' he told a receptive audience, ''is for all the marbles.''

title: U.N. Assembly Assails U.S. on P.L.O. Mission
description: The General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution today deploring the United States attempt to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission.

title: Livable Pensions Count in Finding and Keeping Good Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Says It Made Mass Arrests; Arab Press Reports 500 Detained
description: The Israeli Army said today that it made mass arrests in overnight raids in the occupied territories, and Arab news organizations said 500 people had been detained.

title: Pardon of North Before His Trial Opposed in Poll
description: Americans overwhelmingly oppose pardoning Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North of the Marines before he goes on trial in the Iran-contra scandal, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Defense Attacks Arrest In Transit Police Case
description: The Legal Aid Society has filed the first of what the organization said may be scores of challenges to convictions in cases stemming from arrests by transit police officers accused in an internal affairs report of making wrongful arrests in the subways.

title: KEY RATES
Health; Treatment of Early or Delayed Puberty Increases
description: As parents learn that doctors can now manipulate the hormones involved in puberty, they are increasingly seeking treatment for children experiencing this transition either abnormally early or abnormally late.

title: Kelso Chairman Holds No Love for Wall Street
description: Louis O. Kelso, whose investment banking firm emerged victorious this week in the battle for American Standard Inc., wastes no love on Wall Street. ''We have to take capital ownership out of that gambling casino,'' he says.

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court Opinions on Food Stamps
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision, written by Justice Byron R. White, upholding a Federal law that denies food stamps to strikers, and the dissent by Justice Thurgood Marshall that was joined by Justices William J. Brennan Jr. and Harry A. Blackmon. From the Opinion

title: With Rare Unity, House Approves $1.1 Trillion Budget for 1989
description: In a display of collegiality and bipartisanship rarely seen on budget matters, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly approved a $1.1 trillion budget resolution for the coming fiscal year.

title: Davis Presses His Lorimar Bid
description: Marvin Davis, growing impatient at the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation's failure to respond to his $771 million conditional offer, wrote a letter to Merv Adelson, Lorimar's chairman, threatening to take unspecified hostile actions. Company officials declined to comment.

title: Two-Hoop Circus at the Meadowlands
description: Some of the refrains are familiar by now. For instance, John Chaney, the Temple coach, and his Rhode Island counterpart, Tom Penders, talked about the lack of recognition the Atlantic 10 Conference suffers because it does not have a television contract. And Penders, who has somehow cultivated a deep tan during a winter in Kingston, R.I., was asked once again today whether he would consider another job offer.

title: Advertising; Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Buys Muhlfeld & Wolff
description: Once Harold L. Strauss appeared on the scene at the Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey agency as the third co-chairman, it was only a matter of time before that 17-year-old agency began an acquisition program. He proved that that was his thing back at HBM/Creamer.

title: New Defense for Workers' Health
description: A bill passed by the House could ease the minds and maybe lengthen the lives of thousands of American workers. It's a modest and sensible measure, threatened by a Senate filibuster.

title: WPP Makes New Charges In Dispute Over Walkout
description: The dispute over the walkout by the top executives of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency heated up yesterday.

title: Israeli Found Guilty In Atom-Secrets Case
description: An Israeli court convicted Mordechai Vanunu today of treason and esphonage for revealing secrets of his country's nuclear program to a British newspaper.

title: Assembly Panel Proposes Election Board Changes
description: Saying that the New York State Board of Elections has been poorly managed and lags behind similar agencies in other states, the State Assembly Election Committee plans to recommend that the board begin to audit randomly campaign committees and to enter all campaign contributions into a centralized computer.

title: Guggenheim Revisits Abstractions of Albers
description: LEAD: ''WE lived together for over 50 years, yet this is the first time I've been able to look over his entire life's work,'' said Anni Albers, the widow of Josef Albers, the pioneering abstract artist. ''I never saw how wide his influence was until recently.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.We recently moved into an old house that has a finished attic. The roof insulation goes right up to the peak, with a vapor barrier under the insulation, then gypsum board covering this. This gypsum board is covered with mildew.

title: Jewish Moderate Urges Believers to Take Stand
description: Ultra-orthodox Jews, including the Hasidim, have set the religious agenda for too long in both the United States and Israel, the president of Yeshiva University said Tuesday, calling on moderate Orthodox elements to reassert themselves.

title: Cocaine Trial Is Interrupted, With No Explanation Given
description: Attorneys and the judge met in two closed sessions today at the cocaine smuggling trial of Carlos Lehder Rivas, and the jurors were then sent home without explanation.

title: >Brawley's Texts Found At School
description: In a puzzling new twist in the Tawana Brawley mystery, school books the teen-ager was believed to have been carrying on the day she disappeared in November turned up last week in her former high school in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., according to people familiar with the investigation.

title: Saint Laurent: Successes In a Quiet Key
description: If fashion is indeed embarking on a sober, straight and narrow path for fall, Yves Saint Laurent will lead the way. The master of the classic mode, introducing his collection as usual on the last day of the Paris showings, offered wearable clothes on his own terms. Except for square-crowned and three-tiered hats, they were not propped up with zany accessories. Except for pants and some evening clothes, skirts were always short, stopping three to five inches above the knee. There was an occasional flash of searing color, but most of the tones were muted.

title: Doctor Wins Award With $50,000 Prize For Cancer Research
description: Dr. George W. Santos of Johns Hopkins University, one of the pioneers in the development of bone marrow transplantation, was named yesterday as winner of the Bristol-Myers Award for distinguished achievement in cancer research. The $50,000 award will be presented at a luncheon in New York May 4.

title: Report to Green Faults Training Given Teachers
description: The training of new teachers by the New York City Board of Education is ''notoriously ineffective,'' and the least experienced teachers are often sent to the city's most troubled schools, according to a report prepared for the new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green.

title: Review/Theater; A Samurai And Death: 4 Versions
description: Going into the woods, as Broadway instructs us this season, can be an unsettling experience. That lesson is now being offered Off Broadway, too, in the famous Japanese tale of the samurai, the bandit and the woman. It's ''Rashomon,'' of course, the 1959 play by Fay and Michael Kanin based on Akira Kurosawa's memorable 1951 movie, which was taken from the 1915 stories of Ryunosuke Akutagawa.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-15 President Reagan will visit Moscow from May 29 to June 2, but it seems uncertain that he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will sign a treaty reducing long-range nuclear arms. Page A1 Nicaragua and contra conferees signed an agreement on a cease-fire that was described as historic by both sides. Under the agreement a 60-day cease-fire will be declared April 1. A1 G.I.'s will start leaving Honduras on Monday, according to the Reagan Administration. It also said it was negotiating with Congressional leaders about a package of new aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. A6 Poll finds Americans wary about sending troops to Honduras A6 China, in an anti-Western move, plans a drastic reduction in the number of its students permitted to go abroad, especially to the United States, according to Chinese students and Beijing press reports. A1 London assaults on blacks and Asians are increasing. Many Asians and blacks believe the police force, 98 per cent white, is slow to investigate whites for attacks on minority citizens, but quick to act on behalf of whites. A1 Hyundai car sales at lower prices than are charged in South Korea do no injury to Canadian subsidiaries of the Ford Motor Company and General Motors, a Canadian Government tribunal ruled. D1 Pakistanis fear Afghans will stay A3 Tuning in the news beyond Noriega's reach A6 Israel is reported to arrest 500 in occupied territories A10 National A16-32 A 1981 law denying food stamps to striking workers and their families unless they were poor enough to qualify for them before going on strike was upheld by the Supreme Court, 5-to-3. A1 Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North should not be pardoned before his trial in the Iran-contra scandal, but Americans are evenly split on whether he should be pardoned if he is convicted, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. A1 The Consumer Price Index rose only two-tenths of 1 percent last month as all seven of its main categories posted smaller increases or bigger declines than in January, the Labor Department reported. D1 Ultra-Orthodox Jews have set the religious agenda for too long in both the United States and Israel and moderate Orthodox elements must reassert themselves, the president of Yeshiva University said. A16 A child's rescuers are battling for the television rights after her rescue last October from a narrow well in Midland, Tex. Two competing groups are vying for support from the parents of the girl, Jessica McClure. A1 Smoking on Northwest Airlines flights in North America will be banned beginning April 23. The rule goes beyond a Federal smoking ban on all domestic flights of two hours or less that takes effect that day. A20 Bostonians split over needle swap to combat AIDS A16 Honda to pay $6 million in rights accord A18 John Hopkins doctor wins $50,000 award for cancer research A21 Women's college faces court test on admitting men A25 Mecham trial hears of warning on loan A27 Politics A30 Richard Gephardt wooed unionists in Detroit with free beer and hot dogs. Michigan polls show the Missouri Congressman running well behind Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. A30 Jesse Jackson is challenging as unfair the Democratic Party's plan to send hundreds of governors, members of Congress and party officials to the convention to vote their choices for a Presidential nominee. A30 Democratic aspirants have rejected the legacy of Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy, believing that America ''must not be too forceful'' in foreign policy, Senator Bob Dole charged. A30 Washington Talk A32 Gone are the rowdy days of the National Press Club Regional A33, B1-5 Books that Tawana Brawley carried when she disappeared in what she indicated was an abduction-rape have been found in her Wappingers Falls, N.Y., school in good condition, with no sign of having been in the woods where she said she was attacked. B1 The number of housing units produced by New York State since Governor Cuomo took office in 1983 has been overstated by his administration by 500 percent, or more than 100,000, data it released said. B1 Prison blood tests have shown that more than 15 percent of the inmates entering the state system from New York City tested positive for the Aids-related virus, according to the State Health Department. A33 The least experienced teachers are often sent to the most troubled schools, and the training of new teachers is ineffective, according to a report prepared for New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Dr. Richard R. Green. B3 Challenges to convictions in arrests by transit police officers accused in internal affairs reports of making false arrests will be made by the Legal Aid Society. B3 A deliberately set fire extensively damaged a seven-story apartment building in Harlem, leaving 40 people homeless, and residents said the flat where the blaze began was a crack den. B4 Metro Matters: Preaching the gospel of change B1 Teaching is emphasized at DNA museum on L.I. B1 The Board of Estimate's long nights at New York's City Hall B1 Six police commanders get top posts in New York City B3

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,591,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary loss of $10,247,000 for the year from the extinguishment of debt; the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,213,000 and a gain of $796,000 on the termination of a pension plan. c-Net loss and after net from discontinued operations of $9,259,000, a $6,487,000 loss from the extinguishment of debt, and a gain of $4,002,000 from the termination of a pension plan. d-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $2,550,000, a loss of $13,470,000 on the extinguishment of debt and a gain of $4,002,000 on the termination of a pension plan. The company's year-ago quarter loss from continuing operations included a $12.4 million writedown of an investment. The prior year results included a pre-tax gain of $37.2 million from the sale of Genmar Industries common stock.

title: Bostonians Split On Mayor's Idea Of Needle Swap
description: Controlling the spread of AIDS has become a hot political and social issue in Boston, spurred by a proposal by Mayor Raymond L. Flynn to give sterile needles to intravenous drug users in exchange for dirty ones.

title: Resorts Spurns New Griffin Offer
description: International Inc., the hotel-casino concern with operations in New Jersey and the Bahamas, said its board had rejected a sweetened $295 million takeover bid by Merv Griffin, the entertainer-turned-businessman.

title: Review/Recital; Contemporary Works for the Flute
description: Patricia Spencer, a flutist long active in New York uptown new-music concerts, offered a recital Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall that contained four world premieres and one American premiere.

title: Southern Responds
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said a letter it had received from the New York investor Howard Kaskel to buy the railroad and data processing company for $60 a share, or $588 million, ''appears to be an effort to stimulate trading in Kansas City Southern stock.'' Mr. Kaskel leads a group of investors who control 11.3 percent of the common shares. Landon H. Rowland, Kansas City Southern's president, said Mr. Kaskel's attempts to stop the company from pursuing the purchase of the Southern Pacific Railroad from the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation were ''inconsistent with the best interests of the company and its stockholders.''

title: Dole Assails 'Failure' in Democrats' Foreign Policy
description: Senator Bob Dole said today that the Democratic Presidential candidates had rejected the legacy of Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy in the belief that the United States ''must not be too forceful'' and ''must mistrust its own power.''

title: Teen-Ager Is Sentenced In Killing of a Minister
description: A homeless teen-ager who pleaded guilty to killing a Brooklyn minister who had befriended him was sentenced yesterday to the maximum term of 8Y to 25 years in prison.

title: Stockman Leaving Salomon
description: In a stunning coup, the Blackstone Group has lured David A. Stockman away from Salomon Brothers, where he has been a managing director since he left the White House in 1985.

title: No Chambers Verdict Is Reached in 7th Day
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. retired last night without a verdict after its seventh day of deliberations.

title: Islanders Rise to The Top
description: The Islanders who began a five-game road trip in third place, ended it tonight in first place. New York routed the Los Angeles Kings, 6-2, helped by two goals from Bryan Trottier, and moved past the Washington Capitals to the top of the Patrick Division.

title: Governor Dukakis Takes a Wrong Turn
description: Conventional punditry has Gov. Michael Dukakis typed as not very exciting. But hark! Having repeatedly skewered one of his main rivals in the Presidential primaries for preaching protectionism on foreign trade, he now veers in that direction himself. And in the grand tradition of Presidential candidates - and Presidents - he denies any shift in his position.

title: McCormack's Defense Plan
description: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. today announced a recapitalization plan and said it was considering the sale of the company to try to fend off a $35-a-share bid by Southdown Inc., which has been trying to buy Moore McCormick since January.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 24, 1988
description: COMPANIES Texaco's bankruptcy plan was approved by a Federal judge. The giant oil company will now emerge from the court's protection and pay Pennzoil $3 billion to settle the legal dispute that has entangled the companies for four years. [ Page D1. ] The dispute over the walkout at Lord, Geller heated up. WPP, which owns the ad agency, charged that the top executives who left to start their own shop had conspired ''to sabotage the business of the agency.'' Richard L. Lord, the former chairman, called the charges absurd. [ D1. ] Blackstone has lured David A. Stockman away from Salomon, where he has been a managing director since leaving the White House in 1985. [ D1. ] Microsoft and Apple made public a 1985 agreement that gives Microsoft the right to certain visual displays. The companies disagree on the limits of the agreement, and Apple has sued both Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard. [ D5. ] Federated's board will meet to discuss Campeau's latest offer of $6.6 billion. Macy has not yet countered the bid. [ D2. ] Brierley Investments offered $1.2 billion for Calmat, a major cement supplier in the West. [ D5. ] Lotus shares plunged $3.50, to $25.25, on the news that it would delay shipment of the latest version of its 1-2-3 spreadsheet. [ D24. ] Intel will sell Micron memory chips under the Intel label. Intel also has a warrant to buy a 2 percent stake in Micron. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The Consumer Price Index climbed 0.2 percent last month, and many analysts said that indicated inflation would probably remain in check. And the fourth-quarter G.N.P. was revised upward, to 4.8 percent. [ D1. ] Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area fell 0.2 percent, the first drop in 15 months. [ D7. ] Banks would receive only modest new underwriting powers under legislation proposed in the House. [ D13. ] Sales of U.S.-made cars and light trucks rose 0.7 percent in mid-March from the year-ago period. [ D5. ] Treasury Under Secretary Gould will direct the panel that will produce proposals on avoiding another market crash. [ D13. ] INTERNATIONAL A Canadian Government tribunal ruled that Hyundai Motor had not injured Ford and G.M.'s Canadian subsidiaries with its discount pricing. The case has been watched closely in the U.S., where a ruling against Hyundai might have led to similar filings. [ D1. ] Bonn's 4.8 million Volkswagen shares are likely to be bought quickly when the Government holding goes on sale today. [ D2. ] MARKETS Oil prices rose after OPEC's president said the organization's pricing committee would meet in two weeks. Brent crude oil rose in London by 20 cents, to $15.20 a barrel, while in New York the May contract for West Texas Intermediate crude oil rose 49 cents, to $16.86 a barrel. [ D18. ] Blue-chip stocks posted a small gain as Wall Street concentrated on takeover-related issues. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.49 points, to 2,067.64. [ D8. ] Bond prices continued to erode in another sluggish session. As on Tuesday, traders overlooked encouraging economic news from Washington. [ D16. ] Yields slipped again on C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds. [ D9. ] The dollar finished lower in dull domestic dealings, failing to react to the latest data on the U.S. economy. Gold rose $2.50 an ounce in New York, to $451.15. [ D18. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Bargain-rate bank loans for film producers are available under an innovative plan in Los Angeles County. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Will Black & Decker's retreat from the battle for American Standard, in return for $25 million, be emulated in other corporate takeovers? Market Place. [ D8. ]

title: Review/Music; Blues, Indiana Style
description: The Kinsey Report, a blues band consisting of a trio of brothers originally from Gary, Ind., plus a friend, have figured out how to make the three blues chords mean something. Each instrument takes a different sawtooth rhythm, and together, like a bunch of dancers tearing up the floor to independent versions of one beat, they put on a show.

title: Farm Banks Ask for Help
description: Three banks in the troubled Farm Credit System have requested Federal assistance to offset losses caused by weakness in the farm economy in the early 1980's.

title: Advertising; Arnell/Bickford Adds New Donna Karan Line
description: Arnell/Bickford Associates has apparently been doing a superb job for its client Donna Karan over the last four years, since the apparel maker has now awarded the agency its new DKNY ready-to-wear line. The budget for the first year is expected to come to $2 million, bringing the Donna Karan business to $4.5 million in billings.

title: Northwest Airlines Bans Smoking on Most Flights
description: In a marketing gamble, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would ban smoking on all its North American flights. It is the only smoking ban by a major American airline.

title: Home Improvement
description: EVEN if you do only indoor chores around the house, sooner or later you will probably need a ladder. If you take on outdoor tasks as well, you may wonder how to get along with less than two.

title: Gun Charge for Merchant
description: A candy store owner in Elizabeth, N.J., who admitted to fatally shooting one of two men who he said robbed his store on Tuesday, was charged yesterday with purchasing his gun without a permit. The merchant, Mohamed Taha, 47 years old, was not charged in the shooting, the police said. The dead man was shot once in the chest in the store and was found 100 yards away with loot. The second suspect, John Payne, 29, of Newark, turned himself in and was charged with robbery.

title: Cavaliers Catch Nets
description: Dell Curry came off the bench to score 10 of his 22 points during a 21-2 fourth-quarter rally as the Cleveland Cavaliers came back from a 17-point deficit to defeat the New Jersey Nets tonight, 105-96.

title: Books of The Times; One Man's Struggle to Accommodate Feminism
description: One of the Guys The Wising Up of an American Man By Harry Stein 269 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: A Charge Against John Zaccaro Jr. Dropped
description: A Vermont district judge has dismissed one of two drug charges against John Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine Farraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: Costs in New York Region Down 0.2%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. It was the region's first decline in 15 months.

title: Jim Jacobs, Tyson's Co-Manager And Handball Titlist, Dies at 58
description: Jim Jacobs, a boxing historian and a co-manager of Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. He was 58 years old.

title: Harlem Fire Linked to Crack Leaves 40 Homeless
description: A fire classified as arson extensively damaged a seven-story apartment building in Harlem yesterday, leaving 40 people homeless. Residents said the apartment where the fire began was a crack den.

title: Pill Bottles Even Grown-Ups Can Open
description: New designs for child-resistant pill containers were shown to safety experts Monday, at the beginning of this year's National Poison Prevention Week.

title: Life in the 30's
description: PERHAPS we all have the same memory of the first boy-girl party we attended. The floors were waxed, the music loud, the air thick with the smell of cologne. The boys stood on one side of the room and the girls on the other, each affecting a nonchalance belied by the shuffling male loafers and the occasional high birdlike sound of a female giggle.

title: Review/Symphony; Pulitzer Winner's Violin Concerto
description: Stephen Albert, who won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1985, is often cited as an example of the ''neo-Romantic'' movement. In the program notes for his violin concerto called ''In Concordiam,'' played Sunday afternoon at the 92nd Street Y, he objects to the appellation and points out that the Romantic strain has never really suffered interruption in the 20th century. Puccini, Rachmaninoff and Strauss - still composing in the 1920's, 30's and 40's respectively - are cited. And Mr. Albert's work, true enough, sounds more like a continuation of that tradition as it has been further handed down through, say, Samuel Barber and Dominick Argento than like a message-bearing, statement-making return to the past.

title: Poll Finds Wariness on G.I.'s
description: Americans oppose President Reagan's decision to send troops to Honduras and continue to be against aid to the Nicaraguan contras, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Yields Move Lower Again
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds slipped again in the week ended yesterday.

title: Dukakis Now Supports Ban On Furloughs for Murderers
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has agreed to support a ban on furloughs for first-degree murderers after public pressure stemming from the release of a murderer who raped a Maryland woman.

title: Market Place; Why Kelso Paid Black & Decker
description: REIMBURSE us for our expenses and we will withdraw from the field of battle. Our bill is $25 million. In return, you can pursue the takeover target.

title: Court Lifts Last Hurdle For Texaco
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in White Plains yesterday approved Texaco Inc.'s plan to emerge from bankruptcy and pay the Pennzoil Company $3 billion to settle the bitter legal dispute that has entangled the two companies for four years.

title: Man Freed in Judge's Death
description: Joe Chagra, a former lawyer who spent nearly six years in prison for plotting the assassination of a Federal judge, has been released on parole. Mr. Chagra, 41 years old, pleaded guilty in 1982 to conspiring to kill Federal District Judge John H. Wood Jr., who had been scheduled to preside over the drug trial of Mr. Chagra's older brother, Jimmy. He was released from a Federal prison in Stafford, Ariz., on Friday. Jimmy Chagra, who along with Joe Chagra was accused of hiring Charles Harrelson to kill the judge, was acquitted on a murder conspiracy charge and is imprisoned on a drug conviction. Mr. Harrelson was sentenced to two life terms.

title: Richmond Is Spinning: Spiders Are Winning
description: Inside the auxiliary gym, the drum-laden pep band is blasting out modern-day collegiate battle standards like ''Soul Man'' and the theme from ''Rocky.'' The University of Richmond's sprightly cheerleaders, the Spiderettes, brandish their pompons while the grinning members of the Spider basketball team, on the eve of their departure to take on top-ranked Temple at the Meadowlands, are doing an impromptu victory dance.

title: MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago periods' results were affected as there was a 2-for-1 stock split, payable Jan. 15, 1988, to shareholders of record, Jan. 6, 1988, and the number of shares is adjusted to reflect a weighted average of 3,263,380 shares outstanding at Jan. 31, 1988.

title: OUTLOOK ON ARMS UNCLEAR
description: President Reagan said today that he would visit Moscow from May 29 to June 2 for his fourth meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Review/Concert; Choral Society Covers a Century
description: The program John Daly Goodwin and the New York Choral Society presented at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night spanned a century of music, from Rossini's Stabat Mater (1831) to Vaughan Williams's ''Serenade to Music'' (1938), via Bruckner's Mass in E minor (1866).

title: Even Victors Are Stunned In El Salvador
description: Leaders of the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance say they are astonished by the wide margin of their victory over the ruling party in elections Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the continuation of an article on the Long Island Lighting Company was missing from page B5 in some editions yesterday, and a duplicate version of an article elsewhere about crack appeared under its headline. Readers wishing copies of the correct article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: First Ladies Were Never in the Shadows
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Soothing a Wound
description: When former Chancellor Willy Brandt came to Washington as head of the West German opposition Social Democratic Party in May 1985, President Reagan, who gets along swimmingly with the conservative Christian Democratic Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, declined to see the opposition leader.

title: INSIDE
description: Brawley Books Found

title: Placement of Ethnic Ads Is Criticized By JAMES BARRON
description: A New York State Assemblyman said today that all the ethnic advertising for the ''I [ love ] New York'' campaign in the last two years has been placed in black and Hispanic newspapers, ignoring other ethnic papers that reach more readers.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Wilander and Connors Gain: Mats Wilander and Jimmy Connors, the top-seeded players, easily advanced yesterday to the semifinals of the Lipton International Players Championships, and Yannick Noah joined them by beating Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union in straight sets at Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: Vehicle Sales Up in Mid-March
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks exceeded last year's level by seven-tenths of a percent in the March 11 to 20 period, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Navy Secretary Is Approved
description: The Senate on a voice vote today approved the nomination of William Ball III to be Secretary of the Nay, replacing James H. Webb. Mr. Ball, a former Reagan Administration lobbyist, was appointed by President Reagan after Mr. Webb resigned in a budget dispute with Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci.

title: Current; A New England Look for Norman Rockwell
description: OVER the last several years, it became clear to the directors of the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., that the old white building that housed the museum was both too small for the collection of 600 Rockwell drawings and paintings, and too fragile for the 120,000 people who trooped through annually.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 29
Dawson Asks Hold on '86 Case
description: NOW that the briefs have been filed in baseball's 1986 collusion case, the arbitrator, George Nicolau, has indicated that he could have a decision within the next 30 to 60 days. If he were to rule against the clubowners, as Thomas Roberts did in the 1985 collusion case, it's conceivable that Andre Dawson, Tim Raines and Jack Morris, among others, might be declared free agents before the end of the approaching season.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,000 and $511,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After a loss of $294,000 for the quarter and net of $279,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: School, Ready for Men, Awaits Court Ruling
description: Wheaton College will send acceptances to its first prospective male students on April 1. But the future of men at New England's oldest women's college may depend on a judge or jury.

title: Honda to Pay $6 Million in Rights Settlement
description: About 370 blacks and women who were turned down for jobs by Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. will receive a total of $6 million from the automobile maker in a settlement of a Federal discrimination case, the Government and Honda announced today.

title: Feminist Scholarship
description: To The Home Section:

title: U.S. Embassy to Colombia Is Attacked With Grenades
description: Two attackers thought to be leftist guerrillas fired rocket-propelled grenades at the United States Embassy here Wednesday night. An embassy spokesman said no one was hurt.

title: S.&P. Cuts Rating Of a Texas Utility
description: The rating of the Texas Utilities Electric Company's $6.3 billion of debt was lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Kate McLeod Is Wed To Jerry Flint, Editor
description: Kate McLeod, the president of Delano, McLeod & Strausser, a New York company specializing in sales development for magazines, and Jerry Flint, a senior editor at Forbes magazine in New York, were married yesterday in Kohala, Hawaii. The Rev. Carlton Buboltz officiated at a nondenominational service at the Mauna Kea resort.

title: Advertising; Heileman to Doner
description: Another beneficiary of the largesse of an existing client is W. B. Doner & Company of Baltimore, which has now been tapped by G. Heileman Brewing Company to promote Schmidt beer in Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. The budget is $3 million and the theme is, ''Honest to Minnesota.''

title: Consumer Price Index Up Only 0.2%
description: In a reassuring report on inflation, the Labor Department announced today that the Consumer Price Index climbed just two-tenths of 1 percent last month as all seven of its main categories posted smaller price increases or bigger declines than in January.

title: Grove City's Finances Survive Rights Battle
description: The passage of a civil rights bill over a veto by President Reagan may have hurt Grove City College's pride but not its pocketbook.

title: Armenians Are Warned Not to Protest
description: The Soviet Government called on the police and local governments today to ''take every necessary measure'' to prevent further disturbances in two southern republics that have been shaken by ethnic protests.

title: Lost Opportunity
description: To The Home Section:

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESTRS INC reports earnings for As of Jan 31
description: Assets and net income represent net assets and net investment income, respectively.

title: Law Students Protest
description: Twenty-eight students at the University of California's Boalt Hall Law School were arrested Tuesday for occupying the dean's office most of the day. The sit-in was called to protest a lack of women and members of minority groups among tenured faculty. The protesters said white males accounted for 91 percent of Boalt's 43.5 tenured faculty positions, a percentage exceeded only by the University of Chicago among the nation's leading law schools.

title: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX
description: Index Pct. Pct. for chng. from chng. from Feb. '88 Jan. '88 Feb. '87 Revised ALL ITEMS U.S. 116.0 0.2* 3.9 N.Y. 121.1 -0.2 5.0 FOOD AND BEVERAGE U.S. 115.3* -0.2* 2.9 N.Y. 122.7 0.2 5.3 HOUSING U.S. 116.8* 0.3* 3.7 N.Y. 122.8 -0.3 6.2 TRANSPORTATION U.S. 107.1* -0.2* 3.6 N.Y. 111.3 0.0 5.3 APPAREL U.S. 112.0* -0.3* 3.8 N.Y. 100.2 -1.8 -5.2 MEDICAL CARE U.S. 135.4* 0.6* 6.4 N.Y. 141.3 1.1 6.3 ENTERTAINMENT U.S. 118.3* 0.2* 4.2 N.Y. 122.0 0.0 4.7 *Seasonally adjusted; 1982-84-100 (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Gardening; Nandinas, a Favorite of the 50's, Make a Comeback
description: THE longer I garden, the more I appreciate plants that really earn their keep, those that are of interest in more than a single season. I am also increasingly fond of plants that have a place in my childhood memories.

title: New York Police Fill 6 Top Posts
description: New York City's Police Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, announced plans yesterday to promote six senior commanders to top positions in the Police Department's patrol force and administrative bureaus.

title: The Surest Way to Put Out the Drug Flames
description: To the Editor:

title: New Book of Letters Shows Young Twain In His Own Words
description: Letters written by Mark Twain in his formative years - nearly half of them never before published and many of them appearing in full for the first time rather than excerpted - will enable scholars and readers to trace the origins of some of the writer's major novels and stories.

title: Democrats' Race Spotlights 52 Delegates in Connecticut
description: Less than two months ago, when the Presidential candidates were focusing on the Iowa caucuses, the New Hampshire primary and the multiple contests of Super Tuesday, the Connecticut Presidential primary of March 29 was merely a speck on the maps of most campaign strategists.

title: Bill in House Would Limit Banks' Underwriting Power
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee today released a draft of his proposed legislation that would give the nation's banks only modest new securities underwriting powers. The proposal contrasts sharply with a bill in the Senate that would give broad new powers to banks.

title: Brooklyn Youth, 17, Shot in a High School
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was shot in the back during an argument with another student yesterday morning at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Cuomo Overstated Figures for New Housing by 500%
description: The Cuomo administration has been overstating by 500 percent, or more than 100,000, the number of housing units produced by the state since Governor Cuomo took office five years ago, according to records released by the administration today.

title: Oil Prices Rise After OPEC Sets a Committee Meeting
description: The pricing committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna in early April to review its audit of oil production, OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman, said today.

title: And Now, the Tiger of Europe
description: LEAD: Looming on the trade horizon is a new competitor far more formidable in its potential to outproduce the United States than Japan or the ''four tigers'' of Asia - South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong. That competitor is the 12 nations that make up the European Economic Community, which has embarked upon a plan to dismantle all intra-community trade barriers by 1992.

title: IRAN CHARGES IRAQ WITH GAS ATTACK
description: Iran renewed accusations today that Iraq had killed thousands of Kurdish civilians with chemical weapons on the northern battlefront.

title: Fouts May Retire
description: Dan Fouts, the San Diego Chargers' quarterback, has called a news conference for today at which the 15-year veteran and record-setting passer will reportedly announce his retirement. Team officials declined to elaborate on the news conference, saying only that it is to allow Fouts to make an announcement about his plans.

title: Now Bringing Up Baby Can Start With a Power Shower
description: SIXTEEN years ago, just before Luz Erdmann-Tobenkin had her first child, Erika, her friends gave her a simple, traditional weekday afternoon baby shower. ''We were a small group of women,'' she recalled. ''We practiced changing diapers, played games and wore little paper hats. We had a lot of laughs and I got a lot of layettes.''

title: Another Office Machine Goes Home
description: Yet another piece of electronic equipment once found only in large business offices is taking up residence in American homes alongside computers and copiers. Facsimile machines, which transmit typed or handwritten letters, graphic designs and photographs over telephone lines in seconds, are being purchased by the owners of home businesses. And with mass merchants like K-Mart considering marketing economy models, general home use is expected to follow.

title: Since 1948, a Jewish-Arab Population Exchange
description: To the Editor:

title: Massimino At Home In Final 16
description: He is pacing near midcourt, running his left hand through his silver-gray hair, his diamond-filled championship ring sparkling, his players round him executing his commands.

title: Bond Prices Continue to Decline
description: Bond prices continued to erode yesterday in another sluggish session that had traders searching for business.

title: Metro Matters; In East Brooklyn, Churches Preach Gospel of Change
description: By the busload they came, beckoned by the white fluorescent cross that shimmered through the sleet.

title: LEADER IN SENATE WARNS ON TREATY
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, served notice today that Democrats would insist on clarifying a dispute with the Reagan Administration over treaty interpretation before approving a new nuclear arms pact.

title: Times Names Editor of Child
description: The New York Times Company Magazine Group has named Kate White editor in chief of its Child magazine, which began publication in 1986 and now has a circulation of 250,000.

title: What to Do With $3 Billion
description: J. Hugh Liedtke, the chairman of the Pennzoil Company, now faces a task others envy -spending the spoils of a settlement unprecedented in size.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a one-time after-tax credit of $324,191, or 9 cents a share, as a result of the implementation of FASB 96. c-Net loss

title: Court Lifts Last Hurdle For Texaco; A Four-Year Battle Ends
description: Following are the highlights of the dispute between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company over Texaco's merger with the Getty Oil Company. Jan. 3, 1984: Pennzoil's board endorses an agreement to buy 43 percent of Getty Oil, including one billion barrels of crude oil reserves, for $5.3 billion. Pennzoil says this agreement was a binding contract. Jan. 5, 1984: Texaco's board agrees to pursue a $10.1 billion offer for Getty, and Getty accepts it. Feb. 8, 1984: Pennzoil sues Texaco in Houston, charging interference in its pact with Getty. Nov. 19, 1985: After a four-and-a-half month trial, a jury in Houston rules in favor of Pennzoil with the largest damage award in history - $10.53 billion, plus interest. April 12, 1987: Texaco, unable to post a bond for the amount of the judgment and having failed to win protection in the courts, files for Chapter 11 reorganization. Nov. 2, 1987: The Texas Supreme Court rejects Texaco's request for a review of the case. Dec. 11, 1987: A plan is proposed for a settlement of $3 billion to Pennzoil. March 23, 1988: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Howard Schwartzberg rules that Texaco may emerge from bankruptcy.

title: OHIO MATTRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
KEVLIN MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a $180,000 non-recurring writeoff of obsolete inventory.

title: Jefferies Is Sent Down By Mets
description: ''Hey, rook, you get a hit?'' Keith Hernandez shouted over to Gregg Jefferies.

title: Running Team Named
description: Dan Schlesinger, third in the 1981 New York City Marathon, and Ross Donoghue, the silver medalist in the 1,500 meters at the 1983 Pan Am Games, will head the New York City team for the Asics Cup America's Ekiden, the organizers announced yesterday.

title: Jackson Is Challenging Democrats on Fairness of Delegate System
description: In public statements and private lobbying, the Rev. Jesse Jackson is challenging as potentially unfair the Democratic Party's plan to send hundreds of Congressmen, Governors and party officials to the national convention to vote freely for a Presidential nominee.

title: Currents; It's Got More Than Steam Heat
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago Egon Runte, a Swiss engineer, started to manufacture a new kind of radiator that perhaps ranks with the cuckoo clock and the numbered bank account as among Switzerland's significant contributions to Western culture.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
BOGEN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company, previously Memory Protection Devices, said its results prior to its acquisition of Bogen on Dec. 31, 1986, are insignificant; it attributed its 1987 loss to non-recurring expenses and costs associated with the Bogen acquisition.

title: The ABC's of DNA: Students Explore Genes and 'Glops'
description: Two dozen high school students working at laboratory tables in an old elementary school in this former whaling village gave new meaning today to the familiar shout, ''Guess what I made in school today?''

title: Night Must Fall
description: The white Government of South Africa has turned the screw of repression down ever harder in the last month. It shut down the country's main anti-apartheid organizations. It silenced individual leaders. Now it has banned for three months a leading newspaper opposed to the racial system, The New Nation.

title: Carl Hildebrand, Steel Executive, 91
description: Carl Hildebrand, former president of Sandvik Steel Inc. of Fairlawn, N.J., died at his Manhattan home Monday after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

title: Karl Quits Warriors
description: George Karl, who coached the Golden State Warriors into the playoffs last season, his first with the team, announced his resignation yesterday. Ed Gregory, an assistant coach, was appointed to take over as the interim coach.

title: Sedric Toney Added
description: Sedric Toney, the 6-foot-1-inch guard, has been impressive enough for the Knicks to sign him yesterday for the remainder of the season rather than to another 10-game contract. The move also enabled the Knicks to retain the rights to Toney, who had been out of the N.B.A. since the 1985-86 season.

title: New Study Questions an Operation to Bar Strokes
description: Ten percent of the elderly Americans who undergo a common operation intended to prevent strokes either die or suffer strokes as a direct result of the surgery, a new study shows.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Track Group Bars Budd From Racing
description: Zola Budd, the South African-born runner who is a British citizen, was suspended from international competition yesterday by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, pending a review next month of charges that she competed last year in South Africa.

title: Marketing Frank Lloyd Wright
description: Frank Lloyd Wright, a legend during most of his long life, has emerged as a growth industry in the last five years. A commercial, artistic and academic habitat of conferences, exhibitions, books and objects has recently grown up around the architect - a habitat that is expanding rapidly in unusual ways.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The share earnings adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1987.

title: Review/Opera; Rysanek's Final Sieglinde At the Met
description: Leonie Rysanek's final Sieglinde at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday afternoon was the occasion for a warm outpouring of thanks to a soulful, beloved artist, and the good will that flowed all around served to keep at bay the depression ordinarily attendant on an inadequate performance of ''Die Walkure.''

title: George Gilbert, Hotel Owner, 66
description: George Gilbert, co-owner of the Raleigh Hotel in South Fallsburgh, N.Y., died of liver cancer Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in South Nyack, N.Y.

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $53,000 gain from the restructuring of debt and a $384,000 tax credit. c-Net loss and includes a $124,000 gain from the restructuring of debt.

title: Calmat, a Cement Maker, Gets a Bid From Brierley
description: The Calmat Company, a major cement supplier in the fast-growing Western markets, said today that it had received an unsolicited buyout proposal of $40 a share, or $1.2 billion, from Brierley Investments Ltd.

title: Review/Pop; Updated Israeli Folk Songs
description: Ofra Haza, a leading Israeli pop singer, made her New York debut at Hunter College auditorium on Saturday, performing Western-style pop songs and updated Israeli folk songs with hints, now and then, of older Middle Eastern traditions. Miss Haza is a Yemenite Israeli, and her first American album release, ''Fifty Gates of Wisdom,'' sets Yemenite songs to a mixture of ancient and modern instruments. But most of her concert looked to the West, using Hebrew lyrics in pop arrangements that borrowed from disco, reggae, Motown and Broadway. Miss Haza seems to be an Israeli equivalent of Linda Ronstadt, with a clear, adaptable voice and a beaming stage presence. When her songs invoke old dance rhythms, she's also light on her feet.

title: Talking Deals; A Bargain Loan For Film Maker
description: THE Tokai Bank of California, the United States subsidiary of the Tokai Bank Ltd. of Japan, wanted to enter the field of lending to Hollywood film producers. Prudential-Bache Capital Funding was looking for new public financing techniques after tax-law changes severely restricted the use of tax-free industrial development bonds. Los Angeles County was seeking ways to keep entertainment industry jobs in the region.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some editions, an article yesterday about superdelegates to the Demcoratic National Convention misstated the number of House and Senate members whose office entitles them to be delegates. The total is 253, not 53.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Medalist Gets Bid From Riverway
description: A Houston investment firm, the Riverway Securities Company, has offered to purchase all the shares of Medalist Industries of Mequon, Wis., that it does not already own for $20 a share, or $41 million.

title: Baby Jessica's Rescuers Fighting Over TV Rights
description: Last October, as the rest of the world watched, hundreds of strangers here worked for three days and two nights to rescue young Jessica McClure from the bottom of a narrow well. Now those same people are quarreling over the television rights.

title: MONY REAL ESTATE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
