description: b-After gains from sales of investments of $695,000 for the quarter and 9 months, and a provision of $500,000 for possible losses for the both periods. c-After gains of $1,461,000 from sales of investments for the quarter and 9 months, and a provision for possible loan losses of $750,000 for both periods.

title: Federated Case Judge Takes Scholarly View
description: Federal District Judge Leonard B. Sand, who has twice ruled that the ''poison pill'' plan adopted by Federated Department Stores is legal, has other issues to sort out in the bitter takeover fight by the Campeau Corporation, which is vying with R.H. Macy & Company for Federated. Those issues have been put on hold while Federated's board sorts through Campeau's latest offer of $6.6 billion.

title: 15% of New Inmates Test Positive for AIDS Virus
description: More than 15 percent of the inmates entering the state prison system from New York City who underwent blood tests recently tested positive for the AIDS virus, a spokesman for the State Health Department said today.

title: Curb Sought in Hawaii On Foreign Investment
description: Mayor Frank Fasi has proposed legislation that would stop foreign investors from purchasing some kinds of property in Hawaii, saying the measure would put an end to soaring housing and real estate costs.

title: What I'll Tell Little Christopher
description: LEAD: Three attractive bachelors live together in a fancy Manhattan penthouse. Two of them throw a gala birthday party for the third, cramming their apartment full of beautiful, sexy people who laugh and dance the night away. At last the cake is cut and the guests depart, leaving behind an especially luscious young woman to spend the night with one of the hosts.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 19
STRIKE IN PANAMA HAS WIDE EFFECT
description: Commerce remained at a standstill in much of Panama today on the third day of a strike called to protest the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Review/Television; Horace Rumpole Is Back, Fighting With His Wife
description: Horace Rumpole is back. Despite periodic public protestations from John Mortimer, the writer, and Leo McKern, the actor, that the barrister is just about played out, the grumpy old darling is once again shuttling between legal chambers and Pomeroy's pub, where it is his pleasure to quaff the house wine, sometimes referred to as Chateau Thames Embankment. It's a living, evidently, for all concerned.

title: Advertising; Fruehauf Plans to Move
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, a Detroit-based truck-trailer manufacturer, and its agency, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/Bloomfield Hills, have agreed to end their 15-year relationship. Both said the $1 million account would be better off at a smaller shop. According to D.M.B.&B., a full-service agency with $2.5 billion in billings, the client's shift in advertising in recent years required few of the services offered by the agency. As a result, Fruehauf is now looking at three small local shops, and plans to make its selection in the next two to three weeks.

title: China Plans to Let Fewer Students Go Abroad, Especially to the U.S.
description: China plans a drastic reduction in the number of its students abroad, especially in the United States, according to Chinese students and Beijing press reports. The effort comes at a time of growing concern in Beijing that too many young scholars may stay overseas or become too Westernized.

title: Satan Worshiper Rebuffed
description: A Federal magistrate has denied a prisoner's request for materials to worship Satan, ruling that Satanism is not a religion and that the knitting needles the prisoner wanted for bloodletting would pose a security risk. The Satan worshiper, Charles McCorkle, serving a 40-year sentence at the maximum-security Holman Prison for three burglary convictions, had filed a lawsuit in which he sought access to the knitting needles and to books on the occult.

title: INTERSPEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a tax benefit of $253,000.

title: Intel to Market Micron's Chips
description: As expected, the Intel Corporation and Micron Technology Inc. today announced an agreement under which Intel would sell Micron's computer memory chips under the Intel label.

title: Ted Koppel To Produce His Program
description: ABC News and Ted Koppel, anchor of the late-night program ''Nightline,'' have agreed on an unusual long-term arrangement to keep Mr. Koppel at the network by making him producer of his own prime-time programs, several ABC executives said yesterday.

title: A Playwright Tells Why Men Will Be Boys
description: ''The basic dynamics between the sexes are essentially unchanged,'' said Howard Korder, the writer of ''Boys' Life,'' a stinging play that has just been extended through June at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: ALTERNATIVE SEEN IN CANCER THERAPY
description: Cancer patients whose bone marrow had been destroyed by therapy regained marrow after receiving injections of their own blood cells, suggesting an alternative to marrow transplants, according to a study issued here today.

title: House Panel Rebukes Colleague For Loans From Campaign Funds
description: The House ethics committee today sharply rebuked Reprentntative Charlie Rose, Democrat of North Carolina, teter concludi t that he had ivoroperly borrowed funds from his campaign and then failed to publicly report the transactions.

title: Accountants' Risk Limited
description: In a decision that could affect accountants nationwide, New York State's highest court this week issued an opinion that will greatly restrict the ability of banks, finance companies, suppliers and other corporate outsiders that rely on financial statements to sue accountants.

title: Botha Under Fire for Exonerating Soldiers Accused of Killing Black
description: Lawyers and opposition politicians criticized President P. W. Botha today for intervening to prevent the trial of six soldiers charged with murdering a prominent black nationalist in South-West Africa, the South African-run territory also known as Namibia.

title: INTEK DIVERSIFIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $16,995 for the quarter and $21,974 for the year. The year-ago results restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Happy Parents Toast In-Vitro Births
description: Yesterday was a fine day for baby-sightings in Central Park. They arrived in carriages, strollers and backpacks, in cars, taxicabs and stretch limousines, 54 state-of-the-art babies going to brunch at Tavern on the Green.

title: Stock-Fall Study Gets Chairman
description: The Under Secretary of the Treasury for Finance, George D. Gould, has been named head of the President's interagency committee that seeks to produce a unified series of White House recommendations on how to avoid another stock market crash.

title: MLX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of $2.5 million from the termination of an acquisition and consolidation of manufacturing facilities. The increase in its latest year revenue reflects the acquisition of S.K. Wellman Corp., a unit of Brush-Wellman Inc., and MLX Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Group.

title: Gore Camp Firm on Loan Stand
description: The Presidential campaign of Senator Albert Gore Jr. today defended its refusal to disclose details of an estimated $1.3 million in bank loans. It said ''no one is more scrupulous'' in following Federal election laws.

title: ESSEX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $32,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $636,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Review/Reggae; One World Is the Message
description: Africans, Jamaicans and Americans of all colors jammed the Ritz for Alpha Blondy's sold-out debut New York performance on Tuesday. Mr. Blondy, who is from the Ivory Coast, came through for them all: singing in English, French and several different African languages, and playing the by now universal rhythms of reggae, he put on a solid, even-paced show.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a $644,000 gain from the termination of a pension plan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Where to Find All the Designs
description: ORIGINALrr Frank Lloyd Wright designs, from $300 wallpaper fragments to a $1 million dining room suite, can be purchased from dealers across the country. Reproductions, books and novelties are also available at more affordable prices.

title: Review/Film; Universality In Story By African
description: When a red Mack truck drives into a parched West African village bringing sacks of grain, we are prepared for an important and perhaps sadly familiar tale of tradition versus industrializaton in drought-stricken Africa. But there is nothing familiar about ''The Choice,'' a beautifully composed, emotionally triumphant film from Burkina Faso that will be shown as part of the New Directors/ New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 8:30 and tomorrow night at 6.

title: Fishing Gear Is Bringing Fancy Prices
description: THE possibility of a Haskell Minnow's being in the clutter of old fishing lures that grandfather left in a box in the attic is exceedingly remote, but if one was there and you chose to part with it you would have more than enough money for a new car.

title: Review/Recital; Fischer-Dieskau: The Return of a Meistersinger
description: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau probably did not come out of the egg singing ''Die Schone Mullerin'' or ''Dichterliebe,'' but hardly a man alive remembers when the German baritone was anything less than a fully formed master of the song literature. His career, now 40 years along, has defied tradition in rejecting the stereotype of the lieder artist as a great singer in decline. From the beginning, much of Mr. Fischer-Dieskau's success was based on the twin pillars of superior voice and overwhelming intelligence. It was never necessary, as in many song recitals, for the listener's ear to take on faith what the singer's instrument was unable to demonstrate.

title: Dow Rises 1.49; Focus on Takeover Stocks
description: As Wall Street's attention focused mostly on takeover-related stocks, blue-chip issues ended with a small gain yesterday.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said net assets at Feb. 29 were $90,636,000, or $14.21 a share, for the latest first quarter, compared with $95,854,000, or $15.03 a share, for the year-ago period.

title: Stormy Style for Bergeron
description: At one point in the Rangers' 3-2 loss to the Sabres Tuesday night, Michel Bergeron stood on his bench, screaming into a hushed and humbled Madison Square Garden and swinging a stick against the boards. At another point, he prowled the corridor underneath the stands, berating Bob Hall, the referee, and shaking his fists in disgust.

title: Currents; Right Out Of Chapter On Squares
description: IT'S the newest Italian restaurant on a block of Italian restaurants and the latest designed in Manhattan by the architect Charles Gwathmey. Due, a small, casual restaurant with light Italian fare, opened in February at 1396 Third Avenue (79th Street).

title: CHARTER-CRELLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Health; Personal Health
description: If you were among the unfortunate victims of the latest strain of influenza or the mysterious virus that has been prostrating people for up to seven days, you may have considered yourself recovered when the virus retreated, enabling you to return to your usual activities. But in addition to the expected setbacks of a debilitating illness, your body must now also recover from the effects of the treatment: bed rest.

title: Review/Rock; High-Volume Country
description: Fish and Roses and Volcano Suns, two entirely different rock groups who played at CBGB's on Saturday, are both obssessed with musical duration. Fish and Roses, a trio of bass, drums and keyboards, exudes a Lower East Side, populist intellectuality. It makes everything short: the songs seem as if they stop and start every 15 seconds, vocals are fragmented and used as just another formal element, the same as the next staggering, collapsing riff. The group will grind through a funk section only to dart off seconds later, chasing a carnival-like keyboard line.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS LEAD TO AN ACCORD FOR A 60-DAY TRUCE
description: Leaders of the Sandinista Government and the contra guerrillas signed a cease-fire agreement tonight that both sides described as historic.

title: Pakistanis Fear Afghans Will Stay
description: Impervious to the present, ageless caravans of nomads are leading their camels across the barren plateau around this dusty garrison town in the desert, heading toward summer pasture even higher than Quetta's 5,500 feet above the distant sea. They hardly seem to notice the new nomads, who have - temporarily, perhaps - taken possession of much of the land.

title: In One-Party Kenya, Election Is Questioned
description: After weeks of boisterous campaigning, this one-party state has held its first parliamentary elections since 1983 amid questions over whether ordinary citizens really hold the ruling power in a nation that declares itself a democracy.

title: HARDING ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
CENTURI INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 3
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $495,000 and a tax credit of $600,000. c-Net loss and after a loss of $6,975,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Health; Red Wine Is Linked To Migraine
description: Migraine sufferers have often told skeptical physicians that red wine, but not other alcoholic drinks, brought on their headaches. Now researchers in London say they may be right, although the reasons remain unclear.

title: Omaha Journal; The Mayor Fights His Toughest Foe
description: In the dimly lighted basement of Duffy's Tavern, Mayor Bernie Simon was being toasted by a boisterous gathering.

title: Lotus Stock Plunges After Latest 1-2-3 Is Delayed
description: Shares of the Lotus Development Corporation plunged today on the announcement that the company would delay shipment of 1-2-3 Release 3, the new version of its mainstay accounting spreadsheet program.

title: Brazil Assembly Hints It Will Prolong the President's Term
description: After months of uncertainty marked by acute economic problems and even coup rumors, an assembly drafting a new constitution has signaled that it will allow President Jose Sarney to complete a five-year term.

title: Volvo to Lift Prices 2.8%
description: Volvo Cars of North America said today that it would raise the retail prices of cars delivered to dealers after March 31 by 2.8 percent, or about $604. New prices will range from $17,250, for the 244 DL, to $39,880, for the 780 coupe.

title: Review/Pop; Ruth Brown Before Rock
description: The initials R and B, Ruth Brown points out at the beginning of her nightclub act, don't stand for just rhythm-and-blues. They are also her initials. And although Miss Rhythm, as she has been nicknamed, doesn't come right out and say it, as much as any female singer of the early 1950's she stamped her signature on the broad-based black style that immediately preceded rock-and-roll.

title: London Police Faulted as Racial Attacks Soar
description: The dispute over how Trevor Ferguson lost the sight in his left eye is of a type familiar to blacks, Asians and the Metropolitan Police here.

title: Egypt Wins Right to Export Arms to the U.S.
description: The United States has agreed to give Egypt more access to sell its military goods in the American market, conferring a status previously granted to Israel, the Defense Department said today.

title: Since 1948, a Jewish-Arab Population Exchange; No Apathy to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Still Too Many Lawyers
description: In a recent letter to the editor, Maryann Saccomando Freedman, president of the New York State Bar Association, took issue with an Editorial Notebook about the frustrations of jury service. The notebook asserted that one reason for interminable court delays was that most legislators were lawyers loath to vote any court efficiencies that would reduce legal fees. Ms. Freedman pointed out that the percentage of lawyers in the Legislature had now dropped below 40 percent.

title: Calendar: Orchids and Ceramic Vessels
description: Orchid Sale

title: Review/Music; The Alexandria Quintet
description: There cannot be a great deal of original music for the combination of flute, violin, viola, cello and harp -the disposition of the Alexandria Quintet, which was presented on Town Hall's Select Debut Series Monday evening. But what with a few items (mostly French) for the full complement, a few arrangements and adaptations, and a sampling of works for three or four of the five members, the ensemble is able to put together attractive programs, and the one offered Monday was attractively played as well.

title: Currents; Are You Bored With Biedermeier?
description: AN exhibition of urban design studies by the avant-garde Viennese design firm Coop Himmelblau opens tonight at the Storefront for Art and Architecture (97 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette Street, in SoHo). This is the first solo show for the architectural firm in the United States, and one of the first exhibitions here of what has been called Deconstructivist design.

title: Webb to Sell Gaming Unit
description: In a long-expected restructuring, the Del E. Webb Corporation said today that it would quit the gaming business this year and sell its three hotel-casinos, which analysts said could raise about $160 million.

title: HONDURAS PULLOUT SCHEDULED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that American forces would start leaving Honduras on Monday, about 10 days after they were deployed in response to a Nicaraguan offensive against base camps of the contra rebels.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes tax credits of $244,000 in the latest quarter and $142,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Health: Medical Paradox; Asthma Doctors Puzzled As the Death Rate Rises Despite Improved Drugs
description: Despite a growing arsenal of powerful drugs to relieve asthma and a deeper understanding of asthma attacks, more people are dying from the ailment than ever.

title: German Enthusiasm Builds For Volkswagen Stock Sale
description: All of the West German Government's 4.8 million shares of Volkswagen A.G., which go on sale Thursday, are likely to be bought quickly, analysts predicted today.

title: Topics of The Times; 'Housekeeping' Shift
description: A loophole in New York State's campaign contributions law exempts from public reporting the tens of thousands of dollars in operating funds that supposedly pay for political parties' staff, rents and other routine expenses. Investigations suggest that ''housekeeping'' funds are often diverted to pay party officials' campaign or personal expenses.

title: Air Wis Shake-Up
description: Air Wis Services Inc. has removed its chairman, Arthur G. Hailand Jr., and declared that the company is not for sale. Mr. Hailand and John J. Louis Jr., another director, had submitted an unsolicited bid for Air Wis, the parent of Air Wisconsin Inc. Mr. Hailand and Mr. Louis together own about 334,000 shares, or 4.5 percent of the 7.4 million Air Wis shares.

title: Transportation Chief Says F.A.A. Resists Move to Improve Air Safety
description: Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley testified at a Senate hearing today that he was dismayed at what he said was the Federal Aviation Administration's resistance to improved safety rules.

title: Hard Times Not Over For Texas Real Estate
description: Anyone who thinks that the two-year-old financial crisis in Texas could not get much worse needs to take another look at the real estate markets in the state's biggest cities.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTARE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax benefit for the quarter and a tax benefit of $288,000 for the year.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Rebuffed in Fight for $209
description: Criticizing the Government for spending thousands of dollars on the case, a Federal magistrate has ruled that a man who has Parkinson's disease can keep $209.56 that the Social Security Administration said it overpaid him.

title: Board of Estimate: A Tale of Realpolitik
description: It is 3:20 A.M. and the New York City Board of Estimate is voting on a developer's plan to build a midtown office tower using air rights from a school next door. It is a plan whose passage was all but assured 16 hours and 50 minutes ago when this meeting began in City Hall.

title: Controversy on Golf Tour
description: What used to be the Tournament Players Championship is now just the Players Championship, but by any name a tournament is not a major championship unless it is the Masters, the United States Open, the British Open or the P.G.A. Championship, at least according to Payne Stewart.

title: COURT RULES U.S. CAN DENY STRIKERS FOOD STAMP HELP
description: Over a bitter dissent, the Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law denying food stamps to striking workers and their households unless they are poor enough to qualify before going on strike.

title: Woman, 26, Is Killed In Gift Shop She Owned
description: A 26-year-old Brooklyn woman was stabbed to death yesterday in a gift shop she owned in the Canarsie section by an attacker who escaped in her car, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * B.A.T. Industries, Britain, a tobacco-based conglomerate, said it believes it can satisfy United States regulatory requirements in its bid to take over Farmers Group Inc.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included $211,206,000, or $2.21 a share, from equity in unremitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. in the latest year, compared with $169,057,000, or $1.78 a share, in the prior year.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,390,000 from an accounting change.

title: Apple and Microsoft Disclose a 1985 Pact
description: The Microsoft Corporation and Apple Computer Inc. today made public a previously confidential 1985 agreement that gives Microsoft the right to use certain visual displays available on Macintosh personal computers. But the companies disagree on the limits of the agreement.

title: Review/Books; How Movers Move and Shakers Shake
description: The Power Game How Washington Works By Hedrick Smith 793 pages. Random House. $22.50.

title: Health; Walks That Are Long Steps on the Road Back
description: Many elderly residents in a Connecticut nursing home have a new lease on life, thanks to a nurse who decided to get them up and walking twice a day.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American National Can Co., Chicago, elected Roland H. Meyer chief operating officer. It also named Louis F. Umsted vice chairman, corporate marketing, to replace Mr. Meyer.

title: Hester R. McCullough, Accuser of 2 Artists, 71
description: Hester R. McCullough, whose denunciation of two entertainers as Communist supporters became a nationwide political issue in the late 1940's, died of renal cancer Sunday at her home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. She was 71 years old.

title: CONTINENTAL HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $410,000 from the early repayment of debt for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Hambletonian Bid
description: Du Quoin, Ill., which from 1957 to 1980 was the home of the Hambletonian, the famous mile race for 3-year-old trotting horses, will make an attempt Saturday to regain race from the Meadowlands race track in East Rutherford, N.J. The race has been at the Meadowlands since 1981.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Federated Sets Meeting On New Campeau Offer
description: The board of Federated Department Stores is due to meet in New York this morning to discuss a sweetened $6.6 billion takeover bid from the Campeau Corporation.

title: POLORON PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Tuning In to the News Beyond Noriega's Grip
description: Since early February the Panamanian Government has shut three newspapers, three radio networks and a television station. But one news outlet here remains tantalizingly beyond the reach of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his censors.

title: HYCOR BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Bridge
description: Three high-ranked teams lost in the early rounds of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here Tuesday at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. in London Gets Internation Film Job
description: Young & Rubicam's London office will be coordinating the international advertising efforts of United International Pictures, which distributes pictures for Paramount, Universal and MGM/UA in 25 nations outside the Western Hemisphere.

title: Washington Talk: The National Press Club; Club's Rowdy, Irreverent Days Give Way to Age of the Yuppie
description: The old days of round-the-clock drinking, swearing and poker are gone. In their place, there are now saunas, rowing machines and computers.

title: Sculptures Straight From a Fairy Tale
description: They stand like a miniature forest, as if transported straight out of a book of children's fairy tales. But Lee Schuette's colorfully painted tree and plant sculptures - including palm, oak, pine, spruce, cedar, lilac and cactus - have hidden agendas. The ''trees'' are actually tilt-top tables, classic Chippendale or Federal designs with a twist.

title: WEDTECH WITNESS CONCEDES A POINT
description: A former Wedtech Corporation executive, testifying under cross-examination yesterday, appeared to contradict his earlier testimony that the company gave a $10,000 raise to the brother-in-law of former Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx after Mr. Simon requested the increase.

title: Review/Theater; The Legendary Search for a Scarlett
description: The quest for an actress to play Scarlett O'Hara created pandemonium in America, and especially in Hollywood. Women from around the country flocked to David O. Selznick's office pleading for a chance to choose between Ashley Wilkes and Rhett Butler, and to vow, ''I'll never be hungry again.''

title: Since 1948, a Jewish-Arab Population Exchange; Crush Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Gas Company Gives Warning Of an Unstable Contaminant
description: Additional cylinders of silane gas may have been contaminated in the same way as one that exploded at a chemical plant here and killed three people last Thursday, a gas distribution company has warned its customers across the country.

title: A Decorator Designs a Line of Furniture
description: Mark Hampton and his wife, Duane, gave a small and elegant cocktail party Tuesday night at their Upper East Side apartment to celebrate his first foray into furniture design. Mr. Hampton, an interior decorator, has created a 30-piece collection of reproductions for Hickory Chair, a division of the Lane Company, a mass-market manufacturer of traditional residential furniture.

title: Ford Motor Credit Offers 8 5/8% Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, is offering $200 million of 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Derailing 'Day One'
description: Here is how our State Department's secret agreement to sell out the Afghan freedom fighters was stopped by the light and heat of pitiless publicity.

title: Pictures Hung to Stay
description: ''I'VE seen people with a Degas that has a clunky clothesline on the back to hang it,'' said Chris Gallagher, a partner in Picture Hanging Specialists, a concern that will hang your artwork for you.

title: CONTROL RESOURCE INDUSRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $2,147,000. The company changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31. The year ended March 31, 1986 had a net loss of $3,037,000 (included a one- time gain of $4,454,031 from the sale of the company's minority interests in three Connecticut partnerships) on revenue of $6,138,000.

title: American Classics, Made in Indonesia
description: IN the sweltering heat of Central Java, almost halfway around the world from the stately homes of England, Eastern and Western traditions are combining to re-create the great furniture classics of 18th-century Europe and early America.

title: Phil Friedman, Stage Manager, 66
description: Phil Friedman, a Broadway stage manager, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan on Monday, according to the police. He was 66 years old.

title: Hit Where She Doesn't Live, She Fights
description: When a Washington lawyer, Myrna E. Friedman, moved from northern Virginia across the Potomac River to live in Maryland, Virginia did not feel quite the same about her.

title: Free George Bell
description: WANT to know why Johnny can't run? Want to know why Joanie can't jump? Want to know why people are plodding and lumbering all around you on the sidewalk as you walk to work?

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $4,917,000 for the quarter and an after-tax gain of $12,932,000 for the year both from discontinued operations; a charge of $6,250,000 relating to certain of the costs associated with the integration of the Electronics distribution businesses acquired from Ducommun Inc. in January 1988, and inventory valuation adjustments of about $5 million, principally related to computer products for both the quarter and year, and the year also includes a pretax gain of $13.4 million from sales of non- operating real estate holdings. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $3,302,000 for the quarter and $3,259,000 for the year, and the year also includes an extraordinary charge of $3,632,000.

title: Review/Art; Dutch Masterworks From the Hermitage
description: As everyone knows, Peter the Great, Czar of Russia from 1682 to 1725, had some of the happiest times of his life in Amsterdam. A big city with lots of water in it was his idea of paradise, and from his point of view the best day's work he ever did was when he turned his back on Moscow and high-tailed it to the marshlands - then famously inhospitable - that bordered on the Baltic Sea.

title: BIRD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $580,000 from reduction in utilization of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income

title: Changes in Tennis Open
description: The United States Open will begin on a Monday this year rather than the traditional Tuesday, the United States Tennis Association announced yesterday.

title: Devils Continue Late Surge
description: John MacLean, Joe Cirella and Aaron Broten each scored twice, including a penalty shot for Broten, to lead the Devils to an 8-2 victory tonight over the St. Louis Blues.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arthur Andersen & co., Chicago, ap-pointed James P. O'Halloran, a partner in the Boston office, as director of the firm's worldwide small business practice division.

title: Elliott Estes, 72, Dies in Chicago; Was G.M. Head
description: Elliott M. Estes, former president of General Motors Corporation, died of a heart attack yesterday while on a business trip to Chicago. He was 72 years old and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan.

title: FRONTIER TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes net from of $139,197 for the quarter and a loss of $1,189,208 for the year both from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FAS No. 96 Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: Rockets Trounce Knicks
description: Purvis Short matched his season high by scoring 33 points tonight as the Houston Rockets led from the opening tip in a 134-117 victory over the Knicks.

title: Post Office Calls a Foul
description: It had all the earmarks of a scam, getting the Postal Service to deliver thousands of envelopes without paying the proper postage. But according to box-office officials at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, who did just that, the mass mailing was just a misunderstanding.

title: Pepperell Tops Rival Bid for Stevens
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. returned with a higher offer for J. P. Stevens & Company yesterday, topping a bid that has already been approved by the directors of Stevens.

title: Review/Film; Alan Alda and Ann-Margret, In and Out of Love in 'New Life'
description: Alan Alda is an actor, a film maker and a person, of course, but he's also a state of mind. He's the urge, when one is riding in a gondola, to get up and start singing with the gondolier. He's the impulse to talk over an important personal problem with an entire roomful of concerned friends. He's the determination to keep looking up, no matter how many pigeons may be flying overhead. Mr. Alda's ideals may not be everyone's, but never let it be said that he doesn't make them crystal clear.

title: Alexander Athanassiades, 58, Industrialist
description: Alexander J. Athanassiades, director of the Bodossaki Athanassiades Foundation and president of a major Greek industrial and mining company, was shot and killed on March 1 by terrorists while driving to his office in Athens. He was 58 years old.

title: Albany Report Cites Quotas And Inspectors' Low Morale
description: The New York City restaurant inspection system, which was shaken yesterday by the arrest of 28 current and former inspectors on extortion charges, is characterized by low salaries, strict performance quotas and high job turnover, according to a recent evaluation completed by the State Health Department.

title: PROTEST LEADERS SEIZED, ISRAEL SAYS
description: Israel's Police Minister asserted today that underground leaders of the 15-week-old Palestinian protest had been seized in a sweep that included hundreds of arrests.

title: Bronx Teams in Tourney
description: The Yankees haven't opened yet, but this will be another big weekend for the Bronx. Four of the borough's nine teams - including three of the four Section A squads - will travel to Glens Falls, N.Y., for the State Federation High School tournament.

title: Hats On
description: A reader of this newspaper recently stayed her pursuit of world affairs to peruse an advertisement for hats, among them ''an elegant forward skimmer,'' a roller and a big-brimmed number with ''a bustle of blooms.'' A hat, she realized, was something she hadn't worn since Nov. 17, 1962, the day of her best friend's wedding.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Mark Lawrence Jr., Investment Banker, 33
description: Mark Lawrence Jr., an investment banker and a vice president of Goldman Sachs Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday while visiting Bangkok, Thailand. He was 33 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: CHALONE INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AARON BROTHERS ART MARTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EXCLAMATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: We Need Both Single-Sex and Coed Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for year-ago periods are restated to reflect a change to FIFO from LIFO for inventory valuation.

title: Review/Film; Film: Simon's 'Biloxi Blues,' Coming of Age in the Army
description: WHEN first seen in ''Biloxi Blues,'' the movie, Eugene Morris Jerome is not, technically speaking, actually seen. He's an indistinct figure in the window of a World War II troop train. With more purpose than hurry, the train chugs across a broad, verdant American landscape, shimmering in the golden light of memory, as well as in the kind of humid, midsummer heat in which even leaves sweat. On the soundtrack: ''How High the Moon.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We cannot say that this has been a victory for either side, but we can say that it has created prospects of peace and freedom for the Nicaraguan people.'' - Adolfo Calero, senior Nicaraguan insurgent leader.

title: U.S. Demand on Afghan Arms Aid Seen as Last Big Obstacle to Pact
description: The disagreement between the United States and the Soviet Union over the Reagan Administration's demand for a halt in Soviet weapon supplies to the Afghan Government has emerged as the only important obstacle to an accord on a Soviet troop withdrawal, American officials and Asian diplomats said today.

title: Our Towns; Bitter Neighbors, Guarded Homes For Mentally Ill
description: Seven nights a week Mario Chacon, a guard for Satellite Security Systems, sits in the empty two-story ranch house at 9 Highland Road and listens. He never hears anything much. Sometimes he sits with all the lights on. Sometimes he sits in the dark. As carefully as he listens, the most he hears are the nighttime sounds of a suburban street: A car passing. Someone walking a dog. Rain on the window. The oil burner in the basement clicking on. The refrigerator humming.

title: Biden Leaves the Hospital After He Is Treated for Clot
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, left the hospital today, smiling, joking and saying he feels better than he looks.

title: To Thwart Iran, Saudis Limit Mecca Pilgrims
description: In a move clearly aimed at Iran, the Saudi Foreign Minister has announced that his country will limit the number of foreign pilgrims to Mecca this summer.

title: Economic Scene; Slow Growth, Little Inflation
description: THE United States economy is looking stronger than most economists had expected after the stock market crash last October. Indeed, the highly sensitive bond market has started to worry that the expansion is so rapid as to generate an outbreak of inflation and a steeper rise in interest rates.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: MOTO PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $40 million provision for lease termination for the quarter; the year is after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,180,000 and a loss of $6,188,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included a net loss from discontinued operations of $907,000 and $1,217,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a net of $888,000 from disposal of discontinued operations. The company said the results for 1987 reflect a $47.3 million provision for lease termination expense and writeoff of leasehold improvements related to the company's headquarters building in Tulsa. The company also said that asset sales in 1987 resulted in losses totaling $16.2 million and petroleum properties were written down by $10 million in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission guidelines. In addition, a writedown in the value of a stacked rig and a provision for uncollectible notes receivable resulted in a further charge against earnings of $10.9 million.

title: Pop/Jazz; Two Singers Who Shun The Routine
description: True jazz singing demands a rare personality. Where most singers, popular and classical, find it difficult enough to project a song in just one way, carefully selecting and honing each phrase, jazz singers stake their careers on spontaneity.

title: INSIDE
description: New Life for Ancient Turtle

title: Corruption Scandal Widens in Seoul
description: A widening corruption scandal implicating former President Chun Doo Hwan's younger brother is riveting the nation with allegations of influence-peddling and abuse of power during Mr. Chun's administration.

title: Dr. Leon Ginzburg, 89, Surgeon and Professor
description: Dr. Leon Ginzburg, a surgeon, teacher and expert in gastrointestinal diseases, died of cardiac and renal failure Saturday at the Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Delay for 'Chess'
description: Preview performances of the musical ''Chess'' will begin on April 11 at the Imperial Theater, one week later than previously announced. A spokesman for the show, Bill Evans, said yesterday that the delay was caused by the installation of electronic lighting equipment in the floor of the stage. Tickets purchased for April 4 to 10 may be exchanged at the box office.

title: Du Pont to Halt Chemicals That Peril Ozone
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the world's largest producer of chlorofluorocarbons, announced plans today to phase out all production of the chemicals that scientists say are contributing to the destruction of the earth's ozone shield.

title: Checks That Self-Destruct
description: Checks treated with a chemical that causes them to disintegrate into confetti shortly after being deposited have shown up in at least two states, costing banks nearly $70,000 since the beginning of the year, police said today.

title: COASTAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,986,000 from the repurchase of subordinated notes. c-After a charge of $228,000. The company said the latest year ended Jan. 31; prior year ended Dec. 31.

title: Auctions
description: Posters - advertising events, resorts, stage personalities, films, travel and products - continue to appeal to collectors seeking bold graphics at relatively moderate prices. A wealth of posters with values ranging from $100 to $45,000 each will be offered at two auctions, one this weekend, the other on May 1.

title: Can a Cease-Fire Become Peace?
description: Suddenly and seasonably, peace and hope bloom in Nicaragua. On Wednesday the Sandinistas and contras backed away from avowed demands and signed a 60-day cease-fire, beginning April 1. On the crucial question of outside aid during this period, the contras agreed to seek only clothes and food, and get it from a neutral agency, not the C.I.A. The Sandinistas agreed to let the rebels keep their arms. And this deal was cut by supposed hard-liners, the contra leader Adolfo Calero and the Sandinista Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega.

title: On Stage
description: Send in the Clowns

title: Baseball's Disappeared
description: To the Editor:

title: Fouts Retires
description: As expected, Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers, who set several passing records during his National Football League career, announced his retirement yesterday. ''It's just that after 15 years, this body has taken about as many hits as it can,'' the 36-year-old Fouts said. ''I feel fortunate that I have my health intact, that I have all my teeth and that I have a few yet unscrambled brain cells.'' At no time was he pressured into leaving, he added.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Up 1.6% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the over-the-counter market's ''short interest'' position -the number of shares sold short and not yet covered -edged up in the month ended March 15 by 2.2 million shares, or 1.6 percent.

title: TELEQUEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter included revenue of $1,520,000 from liquidated products, a loss on sale of discontinued product of $1,662,000, inventory writedowns of $3,444,000, bad debt expense of $571,000, and an obsolete tooling writeoff of $802,000.

title: Books of The Times; Words That Can Come In Handy, but Not Often
description: They Have a Word for It A Lighthearted Lexicon of Untranslatable Words and Phrases By Howard Rheingold 224 pages. Illustrated. Jeremy P. Tarcher Inc. (Distributed by St. Martin's Press.) Paperback. $7.95.

title: Abortion, Intimidation and RU 486
description: Before this year is out, women in France, China, Sweden, Britain and the Netherlands will have a safe, nonsurgical way to end a pregnancy in the first three months. Thanks to a noisy minority, however, that option may well remain closed to American women. Unless, that is, some pharmaceutical comapny is willing to brave the boos and threatened boycotts of anti-abortion activists and apply for Government approval to market a drug called RU 486 in the United States.

title: GREAT COUNTRY BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes net gains on the sale of securities of $85,187 for the quarter and $517,742 for the year. c-Includes net gains on the sale of securities of $1,190,867 and $2,532,068 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Ex-Syracuse Mayor Draws 10-Year Term in Scheme
description: Lee Alexander, who became a spokesman for the nation's cities in the 1970's as mayor of this city, was sentenced to 10 years in prison today for his role in a $1.5 million extortion and kickback scheme.

title: State's High Court Says Some Tenants May Sue for Rent Refunds
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that New York City tenants who contend they have been overcharged for major capital improvements to their apartments may return to the lower courts to seek refunds from landlords.

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $26,000,000.

Federated Looks to Macy To Counter Campeau Offer
description: Two days after receiving a new $6.6 billion takeover bid from the Campeau Corporation, Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into talks with R. H. Macy & Company on a possible higher offer.

title: WILLIAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said that for the latest 6 months it broke even.

title: Review/Theater; A Musical of Sophocles and Pentecostalism
description: If you need an intellectual justification for listening to thrilling gospel music, you'll find enough to fill a doctoral dissertation at ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' the musical adaptation of ''Oedipus at Colonus'' at the Lunt-Fontanne.

title: Restaurateurs Tell How Bribes Were Solicited
description: Saying that he had twice been forced to pay off city inspectors who threatened to fine him for fabricated violations, the owner of an Italian restaurant yesterday called the inspections by the City Department of Health ''terrorism.''

title: BIOMET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said the results include the contribution of its recently acquired subsidiary, Electro-Biology Inc.

title: HAMILTON OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Second Wind Magazine Aims at 45-to-69 Group
description: Some old publishing pros in Connecticut are about to put out a magazine for the older crowd called Second Wind.

title: Armenian Leaders Call Off Rally Planned for Saturday
description: Organizers of the protests that brought a sea of people into Yerevan's streets last month have called off plans to resume protests Saturday in the Armenian capital, according to a Yerevan resident reached by telephone tonight.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company noted that on Feb. 29 it acquired the assets of Microtex Corp. and its affiliate, Microtex Service Corp.

title: Fighting Back on New York School Aid
description: Albany's annual battle over the New York State education budget has annually slighted New York City. This year, Mayor Koch is fighting back. And legislators from the city who are his targets resent his aggressive rhetoric as much as their upstate counterparts do. The dust of that battle ought not to obscure the basic point: New York City's schoolchildren aren't being treated fairly.

title: The Voice of an Ancient Bronx Turtle
description: Through uncountable hundreds of years, invisible to thousands of undiscerning eyes, a little carved turtle gazed inscrutably toward the Bronx River from its granite perch in a grove of hemlocks and beeches. The rediscovery and relocation of this rare Indian petroglyph were revealed yesterday by city officials.

title: Police Kill Armed Man After Hostage Is Freed
description: A man who had held his mother hostage for several hours in Far Rockaway, Queens, and then set their apartment on fire was killed yesterday after he advanced on police officers with a rifle, the authorities said.

title: Restaurants; A return to prewar times.
description: I HAD an eerie flash of deja vu upon entering the renascent Rainbow Room for the first time, sort of like seeing a newly colored version of a favorite movie from the 1930's. My memories of this glamorous setting, gleaned from photographs and films, project in black and white, yet here it is, as they say, in living color.

title: TURNER EQUITY INVESTORS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Absent New York Assemblyman's Votes Recorded
description: The routine passage of a dozen bills on Wednesday has prompted a call for changes in voting procedures after it was reported that an Assemblyman who had supposedly voted on the measures was 150 miles away at the time.

title: PENN TREATY AMERICAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago figures are adjusted to reflect a greater number of shares outstanding to the company's initial public offering in September 1987.

title: Dukakis Machine Hums in Michigan
description: Curtis Van Meter is 25 years old, a cheerful improviser from Iowa, an expert on the politics of agriculture - and the mainstay of the Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts here in Michigan's Eighth Congressional District.

title: Advertising; No U.N. Site For 'One Show'
description: ''The One Show,'' at which advertising copywriters and art directors are honored for outstanding work, has canceled its plans to use the United Nations building for its reception and presentation on June 9.

title: MARTEN TRANSPORT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dining Out Guide: Table for One
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Restaurants reviewed in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHINA GRILL, 60 West 53d Street (333-7788) - **(Nov. 27, 1987) This is a visually exciting, animated restaurant featuring a cross-pollination of Eastern and Western cuisines. Single diners will find camaraderie at the expansive eating and drinking bar in front of the open kitchen. Winning starters include Beijing oysters and tempura. Grilled sea scallops and lamb in peppery garlic sauce are also recommended. Prices (lunch and dinner): appetizers $7.50 to $14, main courses $11.50 to $25.50. Hours: Fridays noon to 2 P.M. for lunch; dinner 5:45 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays 5:45 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays 6 to 10 P.M. INAGIKU, 111 East 49th Street (355-0440) - *(Nov. 13, 1987) In the center of the opulent, red-carpeted restaurant, the solo diner can be seated at a lively circular wooden bar and choose from a variety of tempura. Within the bar, chefs turn out sizzling shrimp, lobster, beef and vegetable tempuras with a dipping sauce. One might also order the recommended hot platter of appetizers at lunch. Prices at lunch, $6.50 to $10 for appetizers, main courses $17.50 to $25; at dinner, appetizers $6.50 to $10, main courses $19.50 to $28. Open Fridays for lunch from noon to 2:30 P.M., 5:30 to 10 P.M. for dinner. Dinner only on Saturdays and Sundays, 5:30 to 10 P.M. THE RITZ CAFE, 2 Park Avenue, at 32d Street (684-2122) - *(Jan. 3, 1986) This handsome Art Deco seafood and Cajun restaurant features two long mahogany eating and drinking bars across the front of the room. Individual places at the bar are set with linen and silver during lunch, when this restaurant is at its busiest. For starters, choose scallion-flavored crab cakes or select from the shellfish bar. Drunken shrimp, cioppino, and the hot chicken salad (a lunch special) are some other options. Lunch and dinner: appetizers are $3.95 to $8.95, main courses $8.95 to $20.50. Open Fridays from 11:30 A.M. to 11 P.M.; Saturdays 5 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. HAMBURGER HARRY'S, 157 Chambers Street (267-4446) and 145 West 45th Street (840-0566) - Diner's Journal (Nov. 21, 1986) The curved eating bars with a view of the grill are comfortable places to sit in these sleek, violet-walled grillrooms. Thick hamburgers served on sesame-seed rolls are cooked on the charcoal-mesquite grill, set a few steps above the dining room. Variations on the basic burger include one with caviar and sour cream, and another under chili, cheddar, onion, guacamole and pico de gallo hot sauce. Prices: $3.85 to 6.50 for hamburgers. Hours: Fridays 11:30 A.M. to 12:30 A.M.; Saturdays noon to midnight; Sundays noon to 10 P.M. MEZZOGIORNO, 195 Spring Street (334-2112) - (Diner's Journal, Dec. 25, 1987) This bright addition to SoHo features a trattoria-style menu. Among the offerings are excellent carpaccios; individual, unusual brick-oven pizzas; pastas, and salads. If dining alone, one can choose to order at the long marble-topped bar. Prices: $8.50 to $12. Open Fridays noon to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to 1 A.M.; Saturday and Sundays noon to 1 A.M. What the stars mean, page C26.

title: Residency Has No Bearing on Police and Firefighter Dedication
description: To the Editor:

WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday SOUTH OF THE EQUATOR

title: At the Movies
description: Hallstrom's 'Peter Pan'

title: Bonds End Mixed After Early Fall
description: Bond prices ended mixed yesterday after a sharp early slide. as market participants reacted nervously to a sharp drop in stock prices, a weaker dollar and a small additional rise in oil prices.

title: In Punjab, Sikh Turns Against Sikh
description: A new kind of violence is on the rise in Punjab State. Entire Sikh families are being attacked by Sikh militants armed with increasingly advanced weapons and a determination to terrorize or eliminate those of their own people who will not cooperate with their separatist cause.

title: Art People
description: John Hejduk, the architect, practices his craft as a playwright might: he imagines a community, designs its buildings and its public places, then imagines its characters and writes elaborate stage instructions for them - poems about their hopes, their jobs, their lives.

title: Court Ruling Clears Way for Hearings on Dr. Gross
description: New York State's top court ruled today that autopsies were medical procedures, clearing the way for disciplinary hearings against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the former Chief Medical Examiner of New York City.

title: Midwest Regional; Purdue Enjoying Its Path
description: The discussion had to do with various routes to Kansas City, Mo., a popular topic this month among college basketball teams. The topic is also a strange one.

description: Charles H. Pistor, one of the top three executives at the troubled First Republicbank Corporation and the president of the American Bankers Association, said today that he plans to resign from the banking company on April 15. He is the third top official to quit recently.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1988
description: Markets

title: Advertising; Magazine Ad Growth
description: The Publishers Information Bureau reported that its member magazines were up 10.3 percent in ad pages, to 13,772, in February, compared with the same month last year, while revenues gained 19.9 percent, to $486.5 million.

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said the prior year period's sales and earnings reflect reported results for periods ended Sept. 27, 1986, for Bridge Communications Inc. and Feb. 28, 1987 for 3Com.

The year-ago periods' nets are after non-recurring charges of $2.8 million associated with settlement of litigation and a writedown of the company's investment in an affiliated company.

title: Jittery on Inflation, Poland Warns Managers
description: Measures to overhaul Poland's faltering economy, announced with fanfare last autumn, have been followed by scattered worker protests and the threat of runaway inflation.

title: Not Fit to Import?
description: The Japanese videotape begins with the words: ''Our tables are overflowing with imported foods. Are they really safe?'' The tape shows inspectors examining imported foodstuffs at Yokohama. A narrator explains that many of the imports have been treated with chemical preservatives and then left unattended in warehouses for years. The narrator asks if these imports are safe for human consumption.

title: Jackson Rift With Black Mayor Persists
description: Coleman Young, the powerful and opinionated Mayor of this city, thinks it is a good idea for the Rev. Jesse Jackson to run for office. He just thinks that Mr. Jackson has chosen the wrong office.

title: Deliberations On Chambers Slowed Again
description: The jury in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., which has deliberated for eight days with no sign of a verdict, yesterday asked the judge for an extensive re-reading of medical and scientific testimony that could take as long as two more days.

title: WICHITA RIVER OIL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $196,000.

description: b-Includes a $623,000 extraordinary loss for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,910,000 for the year. The company said prior year results are restated to reflect a change in the method of income recognition for long term contracts.

title: Boesky Enters Federal Prison in California
description: His posh offices have been rented to others, the high-tech furnishings have been auctioned for a fraction of their original cost, his employees have been dismissed and yesterday Ivan F. Boesky entered Federal prison in Lompoc, Calif.

title: 23 Arrested in 8 Gambling Raids
description: Twenty-one men and two women were arrested last night and charged with operating a $75 million a year illegal sports betting operation at eight separate locations in the Bronx, Queens and Manhattan, the police said.

title: Bridge
description: Two stunning upsets marked Vanderbilt Knockout Team play here Wednesday as the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League continued.

title: Corruption Inquiry Brings Hope to 'Bloody Mingo'
description: If there are more corrupt places in the United States than Williamson and surrounding Mingo County, the embarrassed and stunned residents of this achingly poor coal community will gladly surrender their notoriety.

title: About Real Estate; Brooklyn School Converted to Housing
description: Two years ago, when Norman Kirscher, a Brooklyn developer and president of Blanner Realty, was shown Cathedral Prep School, an ornate stone and brick cluster of buildings in the Clinton-Fort Greene section, he saw immediately that it fit his formula for producing middle-class housing.

title: Women's N.C.A.A.; Virginia Eliminates Rutgers
description: The tale seemed to be told in the first 15 minutes of the game when Virginia, after merely creeping ahead of an unassertive Rutgers team, began to run away from the stunned Lady Knights.

title: Horse Racing Notebook; State Board Rejects Ferriola's Appeal
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday ordered Peter Ferriola to begin a 120-day suspension on Wednesday for violating New York's ban on Lasix.

title: Advertising; Job for Shaw & Landy
description: Shaw & Landy, already an agency for the Hearst Corporation, has been tapped by the magazine division to do promotional advertising for Popular Mechanics magazine. The former agency is Baron & Zaretsky. The account is expected to bill $1 million.

title: PRICE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 13
FIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit reversal of $295,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $217,000 for the year, and the quarter is also after an additional provision of $524,000 to cover future litigation expense and operational close-out costs. c-After a tax credit reversal of $259,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $8,635,000 for the year. The company said the prior year included a gain of $26 million from the sale of Fidata's businesses.

title: Auction Fails to Sell Helen Hayes Theater
description: Bidding on the Helen Hayes Theater, the centerpiece of an auction of six real estate parcels, failed yesterday to reach an undisclosed minimum placed by the owners on the 499-seat theater.

title: Provocative Photography, From Midtown to SoHo
description: WITHOUT so much as walking into a gallery or museum, it is possible to spend the entire weekend gazing at pictures. Photographic images, it seems, are all around us, on subway walls, construction sites, magazine kiosks and the sides of buses. They grasp for our attention, urging us to buy new clothes, see the latest movie, visit a casino and drive home in a fancy car.

title: Temple Breezes Past Richmond
description: His tie was loosened and what was once a neatly pressed white shirt was now wrinkled and in need of laundering. John Chaney, the Temple coach, had a disheveled look, as if he had just completed a particularly tough day at the office. Appearances, however, can be deceiving as Chaney and his team proved tonight.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Net income c-Included unrealized and realized pretax gains of about $3.1 million from foreign currency transactions.

title: Review/Film; Spies, Lovers and Deceit
description: Whatever the ineffable quality that makes born movie actors of some people, it is entirely missing from the two dull leads who appear in ''Le Caviar Rouge,'' which opens today at the Festival. This dreadfully solemn spy film, which is entirely without surprises, stars Robert Hossein (who also directed the film) and Candice Patou (Mr. Hossein's wife) as former lovers who once worked together as K.G.B. agents and have been brought together at an abandoned estate outside Geneva. ''Geneva,'' a voice says as the film begins. ''Subtle . . . cold . . . haunting . . . cruel as a seagull.'' There you have it, in a nutshell. It turns out that the K.G.B. has constructed an elaborate trap for these wily ex-partners. It arranges to isolate them in this gloomy old villa (from which the camera almost never escapes), apparently an abandoned Soviet consulate, and wait for them to betray each other. The spies are so crafty that it takes most of the film for one of them to spot a video camera, part of the surveillance equipment being manned by a large squad of K.G.B. operatives elsewhere in the building.

title: Dollar Hits 125.60 Yen In Selloff
description: The dollar was battered on world foreign exchange markets yesterday, falling to its lowest level in two months against the Japanese yen and the West German mark.

title: Review/Art; Condo Creates a Future With Layers of Nostalgia
description: George Condo is one of several prodigously talented young painters who sailed into the 1980's in the wake of Julian Schnabel. As with artists like Donald Baechler and James Brown, the question is what is going to be made of all this talent. The answer, in Mr. Condo's case, is quite a bit, but not nearly as much as one could imagine.

title: CJI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,051,000 and $15,300,000, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-After an after-tax extraordinary gain of $1,069,000 for both the quarter and year from termination of a pension plan. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income for the latest year and for 1986. Both latest periods included an after-tax writedown of $10.9 million associated with the issuer of a debt security in CJI's portfolio of marketable securities which defaulted in the payment of interest. Both year-earlier periods' net from operations included non-recurring after-tax gains of $3 million from the settlement of valuation cases and condemnation matters.

title: AT WHITE HOUSE, SOME 'DISCOMFORT'
description: The Reagan Administration, caught by surprise by the terms of the cease-fire accord reached by the contras and Sandinistas, reacted ambivalently today.

title: SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Review/Film; Corruption on Campus, In 'Johnny Be Good'
description: If you wince when you hear that Chuck Berry's earthy ''Johnny B. Goode'' has been straightened out and reduced to the movie title ''Johnny Be Good,'' wait till you hear the title character's full name. It's Johnny Walker, though his wholesome Mom and kindly Gramps don't seem like the sort of folks who would name a boy after a bottle of Scotch. Johnny, in fact, is All-America, a high school football star who is the object of a fierce recruitment battle. Colleges will offer him anything -money, clothes, the coach's wife - to lure him to their team.

title: Policy on Student Loan Defaults Defended in Black College Forum
description: A top-ranking Education Department official today defended the Government's effort to reduce student loan defaults in a tense discussion with officials of the nation's black colleges.

title: Advertising; Young & Rubicam Adds Area by Buying Krown
description: Young & Rubicam, the world's largest individual agency, prides itself on the diversity of its services and has added yet another one: expertise in buying a product's way into a feature film or television production.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Indianapolis Airport Authority is tentatively offering $69 million of airport revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.494 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: American Stores Head A Reclusive Bidder
description: Leonard Samuel Skaggs Jr., chairman of the American Stores Company, may run the nation's third-largest supermarket and drugstore chain, but few know him outside his industry.

title: Russian Church Leader Is Urged to Step Down
description: A group of Soviet Christians called today on Patriarch Pimen, the ailing 77-year-old spiritual head of the Russian Orthodox Church, to step down and make way for a younger, dynamic leader.

title: A Slap for Reagan
description: The Reagan Administration, reeling from its latest veto loss, is about to be handed another well-deserved embarrassment - a Senate reservation designed to make sure that Administration witnesses are telling the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth about the latest arms-control treaty.

title: Advertising; Court Order To Defectors At L.G.F.E.
description: THE defectors from Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, as well as Young & Rubicam, which provided financial assistance in the establishment of Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners, were ordered yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice to show cause why they should not be enjoined from operating as Lord, Einstein, O'Neill or from soliciting employees or clients of Lord, Geller.

title: Cruz, At 40, Swings Hot Bat
description: In the first inning, Jose Cruz sent a curveball from Bert Blyleven deep to right field for a two-run triple. In the fourth, he saw a fastball and lined it inside the bag at third for a single. In the fifth, a change-up was lofted easily into center for another single.

title: Review/Film; A Comedy On Island Of Rhodes
description: When people of wit and refined sensibilities try to work in a form that, somehow, seems beneath them, the result is likely to be as embarrassing as when a no-talent, stand-up comedian attempts Restoration comedy. This is the sense of ''High Season,'' which pretends to be a romantic comedy with any number of quite serious subtexts.

title: Impose a Sales Tax With a Tax Rebate
description: To the Editor:
