description: b-Net loss After preferred stock dividends in the latest quarter, share earnings are less than one cent.

title: Gritty Side of Vintage Hollywood
description: She was bright, beautiful, and ruthlessly ambitious. And she needed her first break.

title: SOMERSET SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank converted from mutual to stock form in July 1986.

title: Pactel Assets Sold
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will acquire the technical and operational assets of Pactel Spectrum Services, a division of the Pactel Communications Companies, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group. I.B.M. will purchase Pactel Spectrum's assets for cash. The price was not disclosed, and the offer is expected to be completed in 30 days.

title: Irving Stock Rises $6.625
description: The price of the Irving Bank Corporation's stock surged $6.625 in yesterday's trading, to $66.25 a share, after Irving indicated it might be holding talks with a potential friendly suitor to avoid being acquired by the Bank of New York.

title: Review/Film; Reporter and the Robot
description: A lovely young woman named Friendship shows up in Jordan one day and tells a British journalist that she is an extraterrestrial peace envoy, a robot who took a wrong turn en route to M.I.T. The writer and director Peter Wollen might have created a fanciful backdrop for this science-fiction tale, but he chose a disturbingly real one. ''Friendship's Death'' is set in Amman in September 1970, when battles between Palestinian guerrillas and the Jordanian army were daily events, when several planes were highjacked to the Middle East and later bombed. But Mr. Wollen, who wrote the study ''Signs and Meaning in the Cinema,'' is less concerned with these events than with how we remember them and invest them with meaning.

title: Biondi Is Learning To Set His Pace
description: When Matt Biondi won a gold medal in the 1984 Summer Olympics, he was an 18-year-old novice in big-time swimming. When he broke world records, won a world championship and dominated freestyle sprinting in 1985, 1986 and 1987, he was shy and unsure about how to deal with everyone's expectations for him.

title: Sacred Music In Celebration Of Holy Week; Other Musical Offerings
description: Palm Sunday CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. William Byrd's Mass in Four Voices and works by Tomas Victoria, Weelkes and Hassler, at 11 A.M. Bach's ''Cantatas of Penitence and Passion,'' at 3:30 P.M. Tickets, $8. Bryd's ''Passion of Our Lord''; Dorothy Papadakos, organist, at 7 P.M. Information: 316-7540. CHURCH OF ST. MARY THE VIRGIN (Episcopal), 145 West 46th Street. Ned Rorem's ''Missa Brevis'' and Pablo Casals' ''O Vos Omnes''; Christopher Babcock, music director and organist. At 11 A.M. Information: 869-5830. CHURCH OF THE INTERCESSION (Episcopal), Broadway at 155th Street. ''Passion According to St. Mark''; chorales by Bach; selections from Stainer's ''Crucifixion''; Faure's ''Palms''; Walter Hicks Dance Troupe; W. Randolph Jr., music director and organist. At 10:30 A.M. Information: 283-6200. ST. GEORGE'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, 16th Street at Second Avenue. Dramatic presentation of the ''St. Mark Passion,'' with palm procession around Stuyvesant Park; Lloyd Larson's ''All Glory Laud and Honor''; ''Cry Hosanna,'' arranged by Marc Antonio Consoli; St. George Singers and Eroica Brass Quintet; Douglas Hatt, guitarist; Robert Opatrny, bass guitarist; Shoji Mizumoto and Kathy Masters, flutists; Randy Max, timpani; Leslie Gigio, mezzo-soprano; Lisa Fitzgerald, choreographer. At 11 A.M. Information: 475-0830. Monday ST. THOMAS CHURCH (Episcopal), One West 53d Street. Early 14th-century anonymous English mass and music by Thomas Tallis. At 12:10 P.M. Also Tuesday at 12:10 P.M. Information: 757-7013. Wednesday CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Tenebrae service, with ''Lamentations of Jeremiah'' in plainsong and settings by Tallis, Byrd and Anerio; Paul Halley, conductor. At 8 P.M. Information: 315-7540. CHURCH OF THE HOLY APOSTLES (Episcopal), 296 Ninth Avenue, at 28th Street. Tenebrae service with music by Zoilo, Palestrina, Tomas Victoria, Bull and Comes, to benefit AIDS research; John Santo, music director. At 8 P.M. Information: 807-6799. Thursday CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Dance meditation: ''The Passion of Mary''; Omega Liturgical Dance Company; Carla Desola, director. At 10 P.M. Information: 316-7540. RIVERSIDE CHURCH (Interdenominational), Riverside Drive at 122d Street. Tenebrae service, with music by Bach, Kuhnau, Lotti, Vulpius, Mozart and Sowerby; Roverside Motet Choir; John Morrison, tenor; John Walker, music director. At 8 P.M. Information: 222-5900, extension 218. ST. JOSEPH'S CHURCH IN GREENWICH VILLAGE (Roman Catholic), 371 Avenue of the Americas, at Washington Place. Walton's ''Litany'' and Durufle's ''Ubi Caritas''; Michael L. Miller, music director and organist. At 8 P.M. Information: 741-1274. Good Friday CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. ''Planctus Mariae,'' a staged medieval drama; Mary Ann Hart, Virgin Mary; Rachel Rosales, Mary Magdalen; Lori Corrsin, Mary Jacobi; David Smith, John. Paul Halley, music director; Bruce Fifer, stage director. At noon. Staged production of Bach's ''Passion According to St. John''; Thomas Bogdan, Evangelist; Wilbur Pauley, Jesus; Glenn Billingsley, Pilate; David Smith, Peter. Paul Halley, conductor; Ralph Lee, stage director. At 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $12 and $18. Information: 662-2133. ST. GEORGE'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, 16th Street at Second Avenue. Dramatic presentation of the Passion, with dance and a cappella choir and music by Victoria, Lotti and others; Lisa Fitzgerald, Vicky Vadala, Randy James and Wendy Joseph, dancers; Leslie Giglio, mezzo-soprano; George Mims, music director. At noon. Information: 475-0830. TRINITY CHURCH (Episcopal), Broadway and Wall Street. Three works by Poulenc: ''Tristis Est Anima Mea,'' Venea Mea Electa'' and ''Tenebrae Factae Sunt''; Trinity Church Choir; Larry King, organist and music director. At noon. Information: 602-0800. April 2 MADISON AVENUE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH, #921 Madison Avenue, at 73d Street. Paschal Vigil, with drama, dance and music; Oliver Goodenough; John Weaver, music director. At 10:15 P.M. Information: 243-5637. ST. GEORGE'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, #16th Street at Second Avenue. Dramatic presentation with mime, dance and music of the ''Mighty Acts of God''; with music by Betty Pulkingham and Natalie Sleeth; Leslie Mims, pianist; Douglas Hatt, guitarist; Robert Opatrny, bass guitarist; Shoji Mizumoto and Kathy Masters, flutists; Leslie Giglio, mezzo-soprano; St. George Dancers; Lisa Fitzgerald, choreographer. At 6 P.M. Information: 475-0830. Easter Sunday CHURCH OF THE HOLY TRINITY (Episcopal), 316 East 88th Street. ''The Heroic Mr. Handel''; New York Brass Ensemble; Edward Carroll, music director. At 5 P.M. Tickets, $7. Information: 289-4100. PARK AVENUE CHRISTIAN CHURCH, (Disciples of Christ),#1010 Park Avenue at 85th Street. ''Spice She Brought,'' sacred dance; Jan Connolly-Ford, choreography; McNeil Robinson, music director. At 11 A.M. Information: 288-3246. RIVERSIDE CHURCH (Interdenominational) Riverside Drive at 122d Street. Vaughan Williams's ''Five Mystical Songs''; Weinberger's ''Way to Emmaus'' and anthems by Schubert and Luening; Cynthia Madison, soprano; Michael Orzechowski, baritone; John Walker and J. David Williams, organists. At 4 P.M. Information: 222-5900, extension 218. ST. CLEMENT'S CHURCH (Episcopal), 423 West 46th Street. Violin works by Bach; Robert Deitch, violinist. At noon. Information: 246-7277. ST. GEORGE'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH, #16th Street at Second Avenue. Dramatic discovery of the empty tomb, with dance and a cappella singing; music by Randall Thompson, Benjamin Britten and others; Leslie Mims, pianist; Douglas Hatt, guitarist; Robert Opatrny, bass guitarist; Shoji Mizumoto and Kathy Masters, flutists; Leslie Giglio, mezzo-soprano; Lisa Fitzgerald, choreographer. At 11 A.M. Information: 475-0830. ST. THOMAS CHURCH (Episcopal), One West 53d Street. Britten's ''Festival Te Deum'' and ''Rejoice in the Lamb''; Quentin Lane, music director. At 3 P.M. Information: 757-7013.

title: GATT Faults Chip Actions
description: A world trade panel has found that a 1986 computer-chip agreement between the United States and Japan is consistent with international trade rules, but the panel has criticized the way it is being put into effect, American trade officials said today.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its loss before taxes in the latest year included a charge of $1,650,000 for certain future manufacturing contracts that have been entered into with less than normal gross profit margins. The company also said the loss before taxes in 1987 included the effect of charging about $2,800,000 to operations for costs incurred for preacquisition activities which were previously capitalized as a deferred charge in prior quarters.

title: Beazer Chief's Global Ambitions
description: Brian Beazer, the 53-year-old chairman of Beazer P.L.C., which has made a bid for the Koppers Company, is renowned for the exhaustive research he does on companies he wants to buy. Typically, according to one of his financial advisers, Mr. Beazer will show up at an acquired concern's headquarters at 7 A.M. shortly after the deal with a detailed game plan, including who goes and who stays.

title: Clear Lake Journal; Congregation Dismisses Its Minister Over Trip
description: In their modest way, members of the Congregational Church here are proud of their 118-year-old place of worship.

title: A Drug Charge Is Dismissed In Case of John Zaccaro Jr.
description: A Vermont district judge has dismissed one of two drug charges against John Zaccaro Jr., the son of Geraldine Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: New Face: Bradd Wong; Blending Genders in 'M. Butterfly'
description: The wardrobe hanging in the dressing room is that of a beautiful woman: gorgeously embroidered kimonos in white and gold, lush pink satin robes, black lace lingerie - the boudoir clothes of an adoring mistress. And indeed, Butterfly is the quintessential Oriental woman of stereotype, submissive and accommodating, serving her lover's every whim.

title: Demise of Weekly Lists
description: The suspension of restaurant inspections means that the Health Department will no longer supply, at least for a time, its weekly list of health code violators. Three New York daily newspapers -The New York Times, The Daily News and New York Newsday -have been printing the list. The Times has been printing the list intermittently since December 1971. All three papers have said they will not publish the current list. The threat of appearing as a violator in a newspaper was a major part of the extortion racket since publication could harm business, officials said. Publication did not follow the first citation. A restaurant owner who was charged by an inspector had a right to a hearing, and a follow-up inspection was mandatory. If the inspector claimed the violation after the second visit, the owner could again ask for a hearing and after that the restaurant's name appeared on the Health Department list that was sent to newspapers.

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said the year-ago first quarter includes $1,271,000, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of an 80 percent subsidiary, Communications & Cable Inc.

title: In Nicaragua, Another Independent Daily
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Congressman Is Critical After Heart Attack
description: Representative James J. Howard of New Jersey, chairman of the powerful House Public Works and Transportation Committee, was hospitalized in very critical condition today after suffering a heart attack while golfing, officials said.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: James (Blood) Ulmer

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $408,000 and $194,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively.

title: No Decision
description: In baseball, where decisions by umpires often stir arguments, a decision on an umpire is stirring one. Responding to several newspaper reports, Bart Giamatti, president of the National League, denied yesterday that he had ruled out a promotion for Pam Postema, who has been hoping to become the first woman umpire in major league baseball by working in the National League this season.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
KANEB ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of $4,517,000 for the quarter and $5,270,000 for the year on oil and gas properties. c-Net loss and the year included a charge of $124,779,000 for the writedown of oil and gas properties.

title: SANDINISTA-CONTRA CEASE-FIRE OPENS WAY TO A DURABLE PEACE, RIVAL NICARAGUAN FACTIONS SAY
description: Having recognized each other as authentic political forces for the first time, Government officials and contra leaders said today that the cease-fire agreement they signed Wednesday night held out the promise of a durable political settlement.

title: McCumber Leads With Eagle on 18th
description: Mark McCumber, who lives three miles from the Tournament Players Club here, gave his family and friends a big thrill today when he holed out a 112-yard sand-wedge shot from the fairway for an eagle 3 on his 18th hole. He also gave himself a one-shot lead after the first round of the Players Championship.

title: 23 Die as Missiles Hit Iraq and Iran Capitals
description: Iran and Iraq fired missiles into each other's capital today, and Teheran warned it would deploy chemical bombs if the United Nations did not punish Iraq for using such weapons.

title: Paris Journal; The Giscard Best Seller: Is It 'Run, Valery, Run'?
description: The words of the best-selling author sounded like those of a tormented poet or an introspective novelist. ''There are sentences that it took me three days to write,'' he confided. ''My criterion was not, 'Should I say it or not?' But rather: 'Did I feel it?' ''

title: Record Loss for Savings Industry
description: A third of the nation's 3,147 savings and loan associations lost money last year, giving the industry a record net loss of $6.8 billion, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.

title: Brisk Trading in VW
description: The West German Government today offered the public its 16 percent stake in Volkswagenwerk A.G., Europe's largest auto maker, and demand was brisk. The 4.8 million shares were priced at 238 marks, or about $141, each. The sale will bring the Government about $674 million before expenses of $32.5 million. Bonn needs the money to ease its growing budget deficit. The sale, part of a broad privatization program, had been postponed twice - first by a currency trading scandal at VW and then by the stock market crash.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf and Evert in Final: Top-seeded Steffi Graf won a battle of 18-year-olds yesterday, and second-seeded Chris Evert, 33 years old, beat a player about half her age to advance to the women's final of the Lipton International Players Championships in Key Biscayne, Fla. Graf, the defending champion, swept past unseeded Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif., 6-3, 6-1. Evert beat 16-year-old Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami, 6-2, 6-1. (AP) FIGURE SKATING Soviet Ice Dancers Win: Natalya Bestemianova and Andrei Bukin of the Soviet Union capped their brilliant amateur careers with a fourth world ice dancing title yesterday at the world championships in Budapest. Another Soviet duo, Marina Klimova and Sergei Ponomarenko, won the silver medal and Tracy Wilson and Rob McCall of Canada took the bronze.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Wednesday about a controversy between states and the insurance industry appeared in some copies with part of a paragraph placed erroneously at the end of the last column. The affected passage should have appeared near the bottom of the previous column. Readers wishing copies of the corrected article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N... 10036.

title: GOTTSCHALKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $689,000 from cumulative effect of a change in accounting for both the quarter and year.

title: Horse Is Rescued From Ice
description: A horse stranded on frozen Lake Champlain for at least two days was rescued in good condition today by state troopers and environmental officers. Officials theorized that the horse, Mr. Ed, whose owners were vacationing in Acapulco, had been forced onto the ice by dogs, wandered five miles and then was too scared to walk back to shore.

title: N.C.A.A. BASKETBALL: Villanova Surprised Kentucky; Duke Squeaks By; Villanova 80, Kentucky 74
description: Villanova did it again tonight.

title: KEY RATES
Rangers Come Alive to Flatten Oilers
description: Lucien DeBlois sat at his locker, his right knee wound with protective tape. Walt Poddubny stood several feet away, a towel over his shoulder, a scoresheet in front of his eyes. Brian Leetch, his head a wet, bright red mop of hair, rocked backward and laughed out loud.

title: Saving Southwestern Banks
description: LEAD: The dramatic announcement by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation of a billion dollar loan to First Republicbank, the largest banking organization in Texas, underscores the need for a Federal plan to alleviate a deepening financial crisis among commercial banks and savings and loans in the Southwest.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $5,494,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Net loss and includes a charge of $2,600,000 from extinguishtment of debt. The company said sales for both the year-earlier periods include results of certain stores that have since been closed.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on the Education page on Wednesday, about college tuition costs, misidentified a Pennsylvania college official and misspelled his name and the name of his institution. The official, Peter J. Balcziunas, is assistant to the president of Dickinson College in Pennsylvania, not the president.

title: Advertising; Two at Time Magazine Join Crosby Vandenburg
description: John J. Crowley Jr., who has been associate publisher of Time magazine, and Bruce Journey, who has been New York ad manager, are leaving to join the Crosby Vandenburg Group of Boston.

title: AMERICAN NETWORK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and includes a $9 million gain from settlement of litigation. The latest year revenue included the operations of Starnet Corp., acquired in September 1986.

title: Fatal Train Crash in China
description: Two passenger trains collided head on today in a suburb of Shanghai, killing 12 people and injuring more than 40, the state-run New China News Agency said. A second report said seven people had died. The crash was China's fourth fatal train accident in three months. The Japanese Embassy said that a 193-member tour group from a Japanese high school was on one of the trains and that two Japanese students were killed and 29 were injured.

title: 3 Men Attack Officer in Brooklyn
description: An undercover police officer trying to make a drug arrest was attacked in the hallway of a Brooklyn tenement yesterday by three men who the police believe were trying to rob him.

title: AT THE BAR
description: Only a few subway stops separate Columbia and New York Universities. But in legal academia, at least, the gulf between Morningside Heights and Washington Square was long considered unbridgeable. Whether competing for faculty, students or stature, Columbia Law School could pretty much ignore N.Y.U. - and usually did.

title: Nettles Goes to Expos
description: The Atlanta Braves sold the reserve third baseman Graig Nettles to the Montreal Expos yesterday. Nettles, 43 years old, a former Yankee, led the National League with 23 pinch-hit runs batted in last year in reserve duty with the Braves. He was in the Atlanta camp as a nonroster player with a minor-league contract. ''We didn't want to stand in his way,'' said General Manager Bobby Cox of Atlanta. ''I was happy here, but I want to play,'' Nettles said. (AP)

title: Drugs And Politics
description: On the desk is a whole pile of position papers on drugs from all the Democratic candidates. There are some good ideas in them and sharp words about the Reagan Administration's failure on drugs.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $22,000 from discontinued operations.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $33,900,000 on repurchase of debt and a gain of $50,700,000 from a change in accounting. The latest quarter and 6-month results included a gain of $20.4 million from the sale of a 35 percent interest in AMI Healthcare Plc, the company's U.K. subsidiary, offset by a provision for reserves of $20 million for the disposition and sale of several hospital facilities.

title: Leasing Official Regains A Company He Started
description: Martin Tuchman founded a shipping-container leasing company in 1968, took it public, sold it and now, 20 years later, has bought it back.

title: N.C.A.A. BASKETBALL: Villanova Surprised Kentucky; Duke Squeaks By; Duke 73, Rhode Island 72
description: John Evans stared at the scoreboard, hoping perhaps for a re-count or a few previously undetected seconds to appear. Rhode Island had not come this far just to show it belonged among the final 16, but to continue what started as an improbable journey to the East Regional final. As intently as Evans stared, however, the scoreboard would not be intimidated. Rhode Island would have to be content with giving it the old college try.

title: Maxicare in Talks on Bank Loans
description: Maxicare Health Plans Inc., the nation's largest health maintenance organization, is renegotiating its $175 million revolving credit line with its banks, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 422 money market mutual funds decreased by $730.4 million, to $278.78 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 114 institutional funds decreased by $1.22 billion, to $78.89 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $226.2 million, to $82.23 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds increased $266.2 million, to $117.66 billion.

title: Letter Critical of Israel Stirs Political Fallout
description: A letter signed by 30 Senators that accused the Israeli Government of taking an inflexible negotiating position has ignited a fierce controversy among Jews and produced threats of political retribution against some lawmakers.

title: Resorts Inc. Court Fight
description: The two largest shareholders in Resorts International Inc. today delivered opposing letters to the Delaware Chancery Court about Donald J. Trump's plan to take the company private. Tweedy, Browne Company

title: Sale by Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will sell a stake in its Colombian interests to Repsol, Spain's national oil company, for $272 million. The proposed transaction includes an interest in the Cano Limon and the Redondo fields, which currently produce 215,000 barrels of oil a day. Occidental, based in Los Angeles, said it would continue to operate the properties. Occidental's stake in the fields would be lowered to 18.75 percent, giving Repsol a 6.25 percent in-terest.

title: Review/Circus; Send in the Clowns! Ringling Spectacle Returns
description: The cotton candy is in full bloom now on Seventh Avenue, and this is the surest sign of spring for city people who do not mark the seasons by looking for robins or new greenery on the streets. Cotton candy means the circus is in town, as it usually is near the breakout of the soft season each year.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: We Need Both Single-Sex and Coed Schools; Barriers Still Exist
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Rumors Bolster Cement Stocks
description: CONSISTENTLY profitable companies are something of a rarity in the cement industry, but takeover bids and takeover rumors are lighting a fire under the group. In Wednesday's trading, three of the 18 common stocks setting 52-week highs were cement producers.

title: S.E.C. Hints At Big Cases
description: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that his agency's staff might be required to litigate ''large fraud cases'' this year and might need more money than the agency sought in its fiscal year 1989 budget request.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Motorola to Pay $16 Million For Overcharging the Navy
description: Motorola Inc. has agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges of overcharging on military contracts and to repay $16 million to the Pentagon, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Stake in Hoffmann To Be Sold by ICN
description: ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. said that it would sell its 8.6 percent stake in the Swiss drug maker Hoffmann-La Roche & Company to an unidentified buyer for $209 million. In September, when ICN disclosed its holdings, analysts had speculated that in acquiring its stake, ICN was trying to draw potential suitors for the Swiss company or hoping to obtain a worldwide marketing network for its anti-viral drug, Ribavarin. But in January, Hoffman-LaRoche made a hostile bid for Sterling Drug Inc., which was acquired by the Eastman Kodak Company for $5.1 billion last month.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $136,000 and an extraordinary gain of $3,468,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and includes a loss of $971,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $587,000.

title: Dow Plunges 43.77 Points, To 2,023.87
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in a broad decline that analysts linked to various factors, including a sharp drop in the dollar's value and worry over interest rates.

title: Smoking Out Noriega
description: Reporters covering the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign have long admired his mastery of metaphors. The other day, he coined a new one. Referring to the suffering in Panama because of the economic and financial sanctions put in place by the United States, Mr. Jackson appealed to Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to leave the country. ''The whole forest is being set afire to smoke you out,'' Mr. Jackson said.

title: Cup Challenger Hits the Water
description: The yacht New Zealand, the America's Cup challenger, made its first appearance sailing in Auckland Harbor today, three days before it is due to be launched officially.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about a plan to rescue the First City Bancorporation of Texas described the involvement of Bear, Stearns & Company inaccurately.

title: Facing the Charges
description: Lloyd Bloom, the sports agent facing extradition from California in connection with misdemeanor charges concerning his dealings with two former University of Alabama basketball players, has agreed to surrender to Alabama authorities. Bloom will surrender because, according to his attorney, Mike Trope, ''he does not want a fugitive status hanging over his head.''

title: West Regional; No Cinderellas as Clock Ticks
description: The West Regional semifinal round Friday night at the Kingdome has a field that could easily be a Final Four: Arizona (33-2) will play Iowa (24-9) and North Carolina (26-6) will face Michigan (26-7).

title: Brokerage Is Censured
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. said today that it had censured Morgan Stanley & Company and fined it $50,000 for misusing the Small Order Execution System, which is designed to facilitate the execution of orders.

title: Text of Nicaraguan Agreement on a Cease-Fire
description: Following is the text, as translated by The New York Times, of the cease-fire agreement signed here Wednesday night by leaders of the Sandinista Government and the Nicaraguan rebels: The Constitutional Government of Nicaragua and the Nicaraguan Resistance, meeting in Sapoa, Nicaragua on March 21, 22 and 23 with the aim of contributing to national reconciliation in the framework of the Esquipulas II Accord, and in the presence of witnesses His Eminence Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, president of the Nicaraguan Episcopal Conference, and His Excellency Ambassador Joao Clemente Baena Soares, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, have reached the following agreement.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,957,000 and a tax credit of $82,000.

title: Advertising; Medical Economics Set To Start New Quarterly
description: The Medical Economics Company, a major force in health-care publishing, has plans to bring out the first issue of a quarterly named Healthy Heart in June. It will be sent to 10,000 physicians to be used for counseling patients with heart disease.

title: Calfed Sets Merger With Florida Unit
description: To solidify its market share in Florida, Calfed Inc. said that it would merge with the Duval Federal Savings and Loan Association, an unprofitable savings institution in Jacksonville, Fla., with $1.3 billion in assets and 36 branches. The terms are to be disclosed after regulatory approval is obtained, a Calfed spokesman said.

title: SmithKline Bids for I.C.L.
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation has offered $32 a share, or about $340 million, for International Clinical Laboratories Inc., which is $6 more a share than in an agreement reached recently with Corning Glass Works.

title: North and 3 Co-defendants Plead Not Guilty in Iran-Contra Affair
description: Vowing to win acquittals, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter and two arms dealers pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiracy, theft and fraud in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Israel Finds Nuclear Technician Guilty of Treason and Espionage
description: An Israeli nuclear technician who told a British newspaper that Israel was making atomic bombs was found guilty of treason and espionage today.

title: LaRouche to Receive Matching U.S. Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission said today that its staff had found irregularities in the fund-raising practices of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. But the commission voted nevertheless to grant $100,000 in matching funds to his Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Colorful Chita

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the increased sales were a direct result of its April 1, 1987, acquisition of its franchisor, Sisters International Inc., in a $14.5 million buy-out.

title: Irish Traditional Music
description: Cathal Hayden, an all-Ireland fiddle competition winner, and Brian McGrath on banjo are to play Irish traditional music tomorrow at the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). Sets are at 9 and 10:30 P.M.; tickets are $5.

title: Reagan Asserts U.S. Won't Invade Panama
description: President Reagan said today that the United States will not use military force to push Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega out of power in Panama.

title: Sooners Too Much
description: Two fat cats can't rule the same alley, and two nasty birds can't rule the same roost. So Oklahoma showed Louisville who's better at playing basketball the new-fangled, high-powered way they both enjoy.

title: SPACE COMMERCE IN FLORIDA'S PLANS
description: The state of Florida, a pioneer host to the space industry, now wants a piece of the action: a commercial spaceport.

title: Judge Dismisses Theft Charges In Transit Case
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has dismissed theft charges against a man arrested by the transit police decoy squad. It is the fourth time the once elite unit has lost in court since entrapment allegations were raised late last year, defense attorneys said.

title: Non-Seabrook Assets Sought
description: A second New England utility has begun talks with the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which was driven to file under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code by its investment in the Seabrook nuclear plant, for the possible purchase of the company's non-Seabrook assets.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $16,133,000 on early retirement of debt and a gain of $16,214,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Bush Continues to Offer Mixed Message on Veto
description: Vice President Bush said today that the civil rights bill Congress passed over President Reagan's veto this week should be ''fully enforced,'' and though he continued to cite flaws in the measure he would not say whether he would have vetoed the bill himself.

title: Southdown Offer
description: Southdown Inc. said it would raise its bid for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. a second time, by adding $5 a share worth of Southdown bonds to its $35-a-share offer. The revised offer is valued at $512 million, up from $450 million. Moore, a cement maker based in Stamford, Conn., has been resisting the overtures of Southdown, a cement maker based in Houston.

title: Seagate Shares Up
description: The stock of Seagate Technology Inc. was the most heavily traded over-the-counter issue today after it was disclosed that Seagate had been chosen by the International Business Machines Corporation as the first outside supplier of the 3 1/2-inch disk drives for its new personal computers. Terms were not disclosed. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., is the largest customer for Seagate's 5 1/4-inch disk drives, but it has had to produce the 3 1/2-inch drives for its Personal System/2 microcomputers. The shares of Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., closed today at $22.50, up 50 cents, with more than 3.3 million shares changing hands.

title: TV Weekend; New 'David Copperfield'
description: Long-suffering ''David Copperfield'' has been pushed in front of the cameras again, this time for a five-part BBC series that begins Sunday, on Channels 13 and 49 at 9 P.M., as a ''Masterpiece Theater'' presentation. In the mid-1930's, George Cukor directed a David O. Selznik production of the Dickens novel. It starred W. C. Fields as Micawber and, with good reason, has become a film classic. Just to show that tackling ''David Copperfield'' isn't a cinch, a 1970 television version fizzled despite the participation of such luminaries as Laurence Olivier, Ralph Richardson, Wendy Hiller, Emlyn Williams and Edith Evans.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Detroit Tigers, who already had Billy Bean on their roster, have acquired Billy Beane from the Minnesota Twins. Beane, an outfielder formerly with the Mets, hit .174 in 10 exhibition games with the Twins this spring. Billy Bean is hitting .211 in spring training as the Tigers experiment with using the outfielder at first base. . . . Mario Soto allowed just one hit over six innings yesterday, facing the minimum 18 batters, in Cincinnati's 3-1 exhibition victory over the Houston Astros. Soto is 3-0 in five exhibition starts. . . . Bill Almon, who was traded from the Mets to Philadelphia Monday, went 5 for 6 in the Phillies' 16-7 victory over the Cardinals yesterday.

title: Cuomo Administration Calls Housing Data 'Honest Error'
description: The Cuomo administration said today that it made a mistake when it declared earlier this year that 145,000 housing units had been produced by the state during Mr. Cuomo's five years in office. But it said the figure had been arrived at through ''honest error'' and ''there was no plot to deceive the general voting public.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 A Nicaragua cease-fire accord signed late Wednesday holds the promise of a durable political settlement, according to Government officials and rebel leaders. Talks will continue under a truce extending through May. Page A1

title: Review/Film; Climbing Out of Rio Slums
description: ''Subway to the Stars'' makes stops at the slums and shanties, the dives and dumps of Rio de Janeiro. Yet when young Vinicius, the hero of Carlos Diegues's new crumbs-of-life movie, plays his saxophone, he can touch the stars. Not a novel notion, but Guilherme Fontes, with his soft, somewhat girlish face, brings such sweetness to the part of Vinicius, the invincibly hopeful musician, that the familiar character takes on a fresh and lovable spirit.

title: Personal Income Gains; Consumer Outlays Rise
description: Americans' personal incomes rose in February at the fastest pace in four months while consumer spending was propelled upward by a rebound in car sales.

title: East and West
description: Craig Harris, a trombonist, is to lead a trio that plays Eastern and Western instruments - including didjeridu and Andean flutes - on Sunday at 9 P.M. at Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street, in TriBeCa (219-8242). Tickets are $5.

title: Wedtech Figure Testifies He Hid Aid to D'Amato
description: A former Wedtech Corporation executive testified yesterday that he gave Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato more than $30,000 in illegal campaign contributions while the Senator was helping Wedtech win Government contracts.

title: Laborites Head for a Leadership Battle
description: Leaders of the Labor Party are preparing for a bruising leadership fight that seems certain to weaken both its popular support and its standing against the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: U.S. Schizophrenia On Drug Runners
description: Federal Government officials have been aware of Gen. Manuel Noriega's involvement in drug trafficking for more than 10 years. Their failure to act reflects a persistent schizophrenia in the Government that has long hampered our efforts to stem the flow of drugs from Latin America into this country.

title: Lira Notes Offered in U.S. By European Community
description: The European Community began offering 100 billion lire, or about $80 million, of seven-year notes in the United States bond market yesterday through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: BRAE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $10 million pretax provision for restructuring, and also includes as income $2,350,000 related to an expired option agreement to sell a subsidiary to an unrelated company. c-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $190,000. There are no comparable figures for the year ended Dec. 31, 1986 because during 1986 the company changed to a calendar year.

title: Reversal on 'Star Wars'; U.S. Adopts Moscow's View That the Issue Cannot Be Ignored in Strategic Arms Talks
description: The United States is taking a new approach to strategic arms talks that stems from a worry that a new treaty could otherwise be a disturbing source of misunderstanding.

title: Robert P. McCarney, Politician, 76
description: Robert P. McCarney, a conservative Republican who led several successful drives to cut state taxes, died Wednesday of pneumonia and heart failure. He was 76 years old.

title: Horne and Lakes
description: The mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne and the tenor Gary Lakes will be the soloists in a performance of Mahler's ''Das lied von der Erde'' with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Jesus Lopez-Cobos at Carnegie Hall at 8 o'clock tonight. The program also includes a Schubert symphonic fragment (D.936a), a three-movement work left incomplete at the composer's death. Tickets are $12.50 to $20. Information: 247-7800.

title: I. L. Kenen, Founder Of a Lobby for Israel In U.S., Dead at 83
description: I. L. Kenen, founder of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the largest pro-Israel lobby in the United States, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $19.5 million, which included $12,990,000 representing discount of indebtedness and a tax loss carryforward of $6,510,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary income of $935,000. The net from continuing operations for 1987 included gains of $11,174,000 from sales of CATV Systems.

title: Charles Kramer, 72, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Charles Kramer, a medical malpractice lawyer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Review/Art; Albers Retrospective: Journey Into the Austere
description: Not long ago, Nicholas Fox Weber, the executive director of the Josef Albers Foundation, was poking through Albers's attic in Connecticut and came upon several drawings from the artist's early years - portraits, landscapes and, significantly, several nudes from the 1910's. As a master at the Bauhaus before its dissolution by the Nazis in 1933, and then as a teacher at Black Mountain College in North Carolina and at Yale University, Albers did not think his students should draw from live models.

title: INSPECTORS SEIZED IN WIDE EXTORTION FROM RESTAURANTS
description: Twenty-eight current and former New York City health inspectors and supervisors were charged yesterday with extorting hundreds of thousands of dollars from restaurants by threatening to close them or cite them for sanitation violations.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ISOETEC COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that about 41 percent of the 71 percent increase in its fourth quarter revenue was due to the acquisition of Jarvis Group Inc., effective Dec. 31, 1986.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., has completed the acquisition of the olive, cherry and caper businesses of Reckitt & Colman North America Inc. for an undisclosed sum.

title: New Sentencing System: Rational Chaos?
description: An extensive, three-year effort to make Federal criminal sentences more consistent and rational has brought an entire criminal justice system to the verge of chaos.

title: Democrats Close In On Bush Nationally, Latest Survey Shows
description: After months of having their Presidential candidates regarded as inferior to Republican counterparts, the Democrats have emerged as highly competitive with the Republicans in the 1988 Presidential election, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
James J. Comerford, 87, Leader Of the St. Patrick's Day Parade
description: James J. Comerford, a former Criminal Court judge who served as the chairman of the New York City St. Patrick's Day parade for 19 years, died of complications from diabetes yesterday at Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago fourth quarter and full- year losses are after writedowns of oil and gas properties of $800,000 and $2,600,000, respectively.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Prior year results have been restated because the company changed from a fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain from an accounting change of $82,000.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Five Plus Four

title: Sacred Music In Celebration Of Holy Week
description: EASTER may be the most ccomplex of holidays, for while it is a celebration of Christ, its roots are even more ancient.

title: HOLLY FARMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Early Trades For Futures
description: Having provided investors in the Far East a futures trading arena with its evening session, the Chicago Board of Trade may soon seek to overlap with part of the European trading day.

title: Residency Has No Bearing on Police and Firefighter Dedication; Chicago's Experience
description: To the Editor:

HOLIDAY RV SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: Louis Grossman, 86, Professor and Expert On Dental Therapy
description: Dr. Louis I. Grossman, a longtime professor of dentistry at the University of Pennsylvania and an authority on root canal therapy, died Thursday at Pennswood Village, a retirement home in Newtown, Pa. He was 86 years old.

title: SAND TECHNOLOGY SYSTEMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The company said the decrease in sales in the latest second quarter was caused by the transfer of its Canadian hardware business to NAS Canada Inc., which is Sand Technology's joint venture with National Semiconductor Corp., and a decrease in U.S. sales. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: VANDERBILT BEATEN AS MANNING STARS
description: Frank Kornet, a junior forward from Vanderbilt, had sounded as if he were looking forward to this night. Kornet had volunteered for his assignment in the Midwest Regional semifinal against Kansas. He was supposed to help stop Danny Manning.

title: Louis Newman; Lawyer, 79
description: Louis Newman, a lawyer, died Thursday at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: SAN JUAN FIBERGLASS POOLS reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Artists Give Thanks for a Haven
description: Since 1926, when the former estate of Spencer and Katrina Trask in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., began a new life as the Yaddo artists' colony, more than 2,500 writers, musicians and visual artists have found refuge from the distractions of the world and created some of America's greatest novels, sonatas and sculptures amid the forests and lakes of this 440-acre retreat.

title: Dole Says Nomination Of Bush Is 'Foregone'
description: Senator Bob Dole said today that it was a ''foregone conclusion'' that Vice President Bush would win the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: WESTERN ENERGY RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said a significant portion of the 1987 loss was due to a writedown of an investment in a privately held oil and gas company which amounted to $163,124. An additional $40,260 was charged off in the latest year by releasing certain expired offshore lease interests.

title: VODAVI TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The prior year included a $4.5 million pre-tax charge for certain writedowns and writeoffs of unproductive assets.

title: Special Radio Broadcast To Help the Homeless
description: A special four-hour radio broadcast on March 29 will feature the American premiere of a new recording and requests for funds to help the homeless.

title: Coping: With Summer Rentals
description: If you're planning to rent a summer home, the time is now.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said comparable figures are not available; beginning with this reporting period, the company changed to a calendar year from a fiscal year ended Feb. 28.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Andrews Group Inc., formerly Compact Video Inc., said it had signed a definitive agreement for the sale of its Brooks Drug Inc. subsidiary to Hook-Superx for $80 million in cash.

title: EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $85,000 for the quarter and $530,000 for the year. c-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $3,000 and $563,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and a reversal of tax liability of $400,000 for both the quarter and year.

title:
Patents;
Applicator Sends Medicine Through Skin
description: LEAD: Dan Sibalis, president of Drug Delivery Systems Inc. of New York, received his sixth patent for the company this week on the manufacture of its transdermal applicator, and the trademark is Powerpach. The applicator sends medication through the skin to the blood stream.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign organization in Michigan included a scrambled sentence. Referring to Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Presidential rival, and Curtis Van Meter, a Dukakis worker, it should have read, ''Mr. Gephardt, as it happens, looks like Mr. Dukakis's (and therefore Mr. Van Meter's) main problem in the Eighth District.''

title: Swedish Forestry Group Takeover
description: A consortium of the power company Aga A.B. and the forestry groups MO och Domsjo A.B. (Modo) and Svenska Cellulosa A.B. said they had won backing for a takeover bid of about $950 million for the power and forestry company Graningeverken A.B. from its largest shareholder, Skanska A.B.

title: Review/Dance; Clown-and-Ballerina Tale, With Juggling Tossed In
description: A would-be ballerina forced to work as a waitress leaves her job to go into partnership with a clown. Together, they devise a pas de deux that amazes the world.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: DELBANCOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company, formerly known as Saxton Industries Ltd., does not have comparative figures because of a change in fiscal year.

title: CHEMCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax benefits of $81,000 and $50,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After tax benefits of $96,000 and $388,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also includes a gain of $704,000 from early extinguishment of debt. The company said 1987 results were hurt by several factors, including $600,000 in costs related to the inadvertent receipt of a quantity of waste not compatible with the company's treatment process.

title: Bessie Heard; Philanthropist, 101
description: Bessie Heard, who endowed her hometown of McKinney with a wildlife sanctuary and natural science museum, died Tuesday night, a museum spokesman said Wednesday. She was 101 years old.

title: Arizona Flattens Another Opponent
description: Top-seeded Arizona, which has cruised through the N.C.A.A. tournament with routs of Cornell and Seton Hall, continued its joy ride in pummeling Iowa, 99-79, tonight in a West Regional semifinal.

title: NEW YORK REVISING INSPECTION SYSTEM TO PREVENT GRAFT
description: In the wake of large-scale corruption charges against restaurant inspectors, the Koch administration will reorganize the way more than 3,000 New York City employees inspect and license many commercial activities, a senior official said yesterday.

title: Poison Gas: Iraq's Crime
description: Again, Iraq stands credibly accused of resorting to chemical weapons in its seven-year war with Iran. More than 100 Kurds - women, children and elderly people - were killed last week in the Iranian-occupied city of Halabja. The instrument of their death arrived in a single warplane, almost certainly Iraqi, whose bombs dispersed a yellow-white cloud through the Kurdish Iraqi city.

title: 2 Police Officers Held in Assault on Brooklyn Man
description: A Brooklyn grand jury has indicted two New York City police officers on charges of assaulting a 26-year-old cabinetmaker with ''kicks, punches and a night stick'' after he refused to obey their order to leave the lobby of the building where he lived.

title:
Your Money;
Takeovers Pose A Tough Choice
description: LEAD: With the latest wave of corporate takeovers, many shareholders face a difficult choice: should they sell their stock when a takeover bid is announced or hold on for a chance at bigger gains?

title: 44.92 Drop Puts Dow At 1,978.95
description: Stock prices fell sharply again yesterday in a broad selloff that hit blue chips particularly hard and pushed the Dow Jones industrial average below the 2,000 level for the first time in 25 sessions.

title: Kansas St. Stuns Top-Seeded Purdue; Kansas Rolls
description: The Purdue Boilermakers had seen these purple shirts this season, but they had not seen the same team. After acknowledging what was considered a relatively easy road to the Final Four, Purdue's trip came to a sudden and surprising end tonight in a 73-70 loss to Kansas State in a Midwest Regional semifinal game.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Arafat Aide Dies in Lebanon
description: A top Palestinian official loyal to Yasir Arafat was killed in clashes between Palestinians at a refugee center near this southern Lebanese town today, Palestinians said.

title: Computer Trade Curb Cheers Some Investors
description: For the fifth time since early February, stock prices yesterday came close to setting off the automatic ban on computerized stock trading at the New York Stock Exchange. But once again the computers were left alone as program traders backed off voluntarily.

title: FALCON CABLE SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a one-time charge of $8,770,000 from the retirement of high- yield debentures for both the quarter and year.

title: What It Takes to Attract Talented People to Public Service
description: To the Editor:

title: New School Finds Way To Save Orozco Fresco
description: Jose Clemente Orozco's spectacular five-wall fresco depicting the turbulent social, scientific and political upheavals of the early 20th century has narrowly been saved from destruction or possible removal from its home at the New School for Social Research by a joint effort of the Mayor's office and the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 26, 1988
description: The Economy

title: CAMERA ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-Net income

title: DAVOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $133,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $262,000 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes a tax credit of $125,000 for both the quarter and the year.

title: K Mart Sells Unit
description: The K Mart Corporation said it had sold its Lone Star Life Insurance Corporation unit to the LSL Financial Corporation, which was formed by two members of Lone Star's management. The purchase price was not disclosed. K Mart said sale of Lone Star completed its plan to dispose of most of its insurance operations. LSL Financial is owned by Royce Hunter and Jack Wahquist, who are both executives at Lone Star. Lone Star is the largest unit in K Mart's domestic insurance subsidiary, based in Dallas. Lone Star specializes in individual health-care coverage.

title: Review/Concert; The Early and Late Mahler Presented by James Conlon
description: James Conlon began his current visit to the New York Philharmonic with a program that looked at the beginning and end of Gustav Mahler's compositional life, and Friday afternoon's performance showed the young conductor to be entirely at ease with the intricacies - musical and emotional - of Mahler's scoring.

title: Bridge; Vanderbilt competitors, in remarkable recovery, make up 60 match points in 16 deals
description: One of the most remarkable comeback performances in bridge history marked Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here Thursday night.

title: INFINITE GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Glenfed to Acquire Bank in Seattle
description: Glenfed Inc., seeking its first foothold in Washington state, said it would acquire University Savings Bank of Seattle for $25 a share, or $75 million. University has $680 million in assets and 22 branches. The proposal is the latest in a series of recent bank and thrift institution mergers in Washington. University, the state's eighth-largest savings institution, is conservatively managed and well capitalized, said Gerald S. Haims, an analyst with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles.

title: J. B. Tietz Dead at 87; Draft Resisters' Lawyer
description: J. B. Tietz, a Los Angeles attorney who specialized in selective service law, died of a heart attack March 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.

title: Gore, in Reversal, Releases Data On Funds Borrowed by Campaign
description: Senator Albert Gore Jr. has released details of bank loans estimated at $1.45 million that were taken out by his Democratic Presidential campaign. For about two weeks the candidate had refused to disclose the information.

title: WOOLWORTH HOLDINGS PLC reports earnings for Year to Jan 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $28.1 million. The results have been converted from pound sterling into U.S. dollars at an exchange rate of 1.7585 equals U.S. $1.00 on Feb. 1, 1988.

title: A New Moscow, but Not That New
description: LEAD: Often during a recent visit to Moscow we found ourselves looking around in wonder. For years, we had been denied visas and castigated in the press for criticisms of human rights practices. Now we were privileged guests, invited by the Government to discuss our concerns.

title: A Quadruple Jump on Ice
description: Kurt Browning of Canada achieved the first quadruple jump in competition during his free-skating program at the world figure skating championships today, upstaging another gold-medal effort by Brian Boitano of the United States. Browning landed the jump on one foot and got credit for the quadruple from Josef Dedic, vice president of the International Skating Union.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-5, 32 News analysis: The Sandinistas have made dramatic reversals about the contras for varied reasons. The country faces an economic crisis and an insurgency that saps its resources so that social progress is impossible. Page 1 News analysis: Contra officials say they felt they had no choice but to try to reach a preliminary accord with the Sandinistas and that they believe they signed the best agreement they could get. 1 In the weeks leading to the cease-fire between the contras and the Nicaraguan Government, rebel leaders defied the Administration and opened a private channel of communication with the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, and other Democrats. 5 A Soviet cooperative seeks a profit by offering higher-quality goods and better service. Its program illustrates the trend of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic policies. 1 China's parliament opened with the acting prime minister, Li Peng, issuing a call to continue the economic and political initiatives that have dramatically affected the lives of the nation's one billion people. 3 Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir objected to a plan by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to meet with two Palestinian-American professors as part of his Middle East peace effort. 3 The Administration urged Israel to refrain from military action against Saudi Arabia's newly acquired medium-range Chinese ballistic missiles. ''Naturally, we would be totally opposed to any such thing,'' President Reagan said. 3 Santiago journal: Dark tales of dread doings 4 Paychecks are delayed for Panama's military 5 Sinhalese extremists add to Sri Lanka's turmoil 32 NATIONAL 6-8, 37-38 Seeking to combat foreign takeovers, Administration officials and House and Senate negotiators have agreed on a measure that would give the President the authority to block such deals if he believed they endangered national security. 1 I.B.M. offered to sell chip technology to its arch-rival, the Digital Equipment Corporation, rather than see Digital become increasingly dependent on Japanese suppliers, according to a new book. 1 The President considers Oliver North a hero and Mr. Reagan said that he had difficulty viewing the Iran-contra affair as a scandal. Mr. Reagan declined to say whether he would issue pardons in the affair. 6 Roman Catholic bishops refused to set aside the controversial policy statement on AIDS that they issued last December but voted instead to hold a broad discussion of the AIDS issue next June. 6 Planting fever has returned for small farmers, the largest segment of American agriculture. And out of the more aggressive members of the group are likely to come some of the big farmers of the future. 6 A nominee to a Federal court, Bernard H. Siegan, has been told by Reagan Administration officials that he should consider withdrawing his name. The nomination has been blocked in the Senate Judiciary Committee for 14 months. 6 Two military contractor employees were charged with falsifying tests on a hand-held mine detector for the Army. The company, Cubic Corporation, agreed to pay $7.25 million to the Government to settle claims that it defrauded the Army.#8 Survey finds more Americans discuss AIDS with children 8 Teachers see scant progress 8 POLITICS 37 Michigan Democrats will vote in Presidential caucuses Saturday, with Michael S. Dukakis striving to establish himself as the favorite of industrial states and Richard A. Gephardt trying to avoid elimination from the race. 37 Senator Bob Dole conceded that Vice President Bush was virtually assured the Republican Presidential nomination. ''I can read the numbers and I probably know what's happening,'' he said. 37 Senator Gore released details of bank loans estimated at $1.45 million taken by his Presidential campaign. For two weeks he had refused to disclose the information. 37 Fading influence of the U.A.W. 37 REGIONAL 33-36 Inspections of businesses by New York City employees will be reorganized by the Koch administration following corruption charges against restaurant inspectors, a senior official said. 1 Robert Chambers pleaded guilty while the jury was still deliberating a lesser charge of first-degree manslaughter. He had proclaimed his innocence in the killing of Jennifer Levin through 13 weeks of the murder trial. 1 News analysis: Chambers' decision to bargain 36 Chambers jurors tell of shifts in opinion 36 An armored truck was robbed in Brooklyn. While two guards were eating breakfast, a holdup team handcuffed a third guard in the truck, drove it several blocks to a waiting van and escaped with more than $1.2 million in cash. 33 New York City agreed to buy a house owned by Arjune, the drug-case witness from Queens. But because of the objections of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, the city paid $13,500 less than it originally offered for the house. 3 In talks on New York State's budget, officials prepared to spend the weekend trying to resolve outstanding issues in the $44 billion spending plan. 34 A boy found scalded to death in a Manhattan welfare hotel Tuesday had been returned to his parents' custody last June after the dismissal of a child abuse complaint by the city, a lawyer who represented him said. 35 A Mafia boss used fear to obtain 50 percent of a major concrete contractor in the construction industry of New York City, a defense lawyer has suggested in a summation in a racketeering trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan. 35 Everyone was at the party ... oh no they weren't 33 Dismissed Jersey official is apparently a suicide 34

title: COMPOSER'S NEW WORK
description: David First, a composer, is to present a new work for large ensemble at 9 o'clock tonight at Routette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street, in TriBeCa (219-8242). Tickets are $5.

title: Pagliarulo Rests, Reluctantly
description: Mike Pagliarulo did not want the night off. He had been hitting too well this spring to consider watching a game from the bench. But then he thought about his right elbow.

title: Pacific Enterprises Makes Offer to Sabine
description: Pacific Enterprises said today that it had agreed to pay $24 a share, or a total of $339 million, for the Sabine Corporation, topping a competing bid for the independent Dallas oil and gas concern from the Presidio Oil Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday, with an article about an Indian petroglyph found at the New York Botanical Garden, misidentified the woman at the center. She was Beth M. Henriques of the Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The company said all periods' results reflect a 2 percent stock dividend paid in April of both years.

title: UNIFORCE TEMPORARY PERONNEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 split of common shares effective May 15, 1987.

title: Review/Recital; PIANIST STRESSES MUSICAL CONTRASTS
description: In the seven years since he won a silver medal at the Van Cliburn competition, Santiago Rodriguez has established himself as a pianist fond of stressing the contrasts in the music he plays, often in the service of unusual interpretive notions. There was some of that in his recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday evening, but to this listener, who has heard Mr. Rodriguez before, the pianist seemed off form.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29

Patents;
A Cord to Prevent Accidental Electrocution
description: LEAD: Frank Martucci of Fort Lee, N.J., a retired foreman of mechanics at the New York City Health and Hospital Corporation, was granted patent 4,732,566 this week for a line and extension cord designed to prevent accidental electrocution from wiring errors. He says that thousands of such electrocutions occur each year, many of them described as heart attacks.

title: BILL WOULD CURB FOREIGN COMPANIES IN U.S TAKEOVERS
description: A measure that authorizes the President to block foreign takeovers of American companies if the deals are believed to endanger national security was approved Thursday evening by Administration officials and House and Senate negotiators.

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $125,000. c-Includes tax credits of $372,000 for the quarter and $643,000 for the 9 months.

title: Reginald Lourie Dies; Child Psychiatrist, 79
description: Dr. Reginald S. Lourie, director of the psychiatry department at the Children's Hospital in Washington for 26 years, died of a heart attack last Sunday at George Washington University Hospital in the capital. He was 79 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: PLM INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The income figures for 1987 and 1986 and the share earnings for 1987 are based on pro forma assumptions about estimated income taxes and weighted average shares outstanding for the 1987 period.

title: Devils Can't Make a Point After 2-0 Lead
description: The Devils lost a valuable point in their race for the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division tonight by playing to a 2-2 tie against the Sabres.

title: DATAMAG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Hearing Aids, Less Is Not Necessarily More
description: To the Editor:

title: Touche Ross Purchase
description: Touche Ross & Company, the Big Eight accounting firm, said Thursday that it was acquiring Meahl, McNamara & Company, a Boston-based accounting firm. The merger means that Touche Ross will have nearly 500 people in Boston. Founded in 1932, Meahl, McNamara serves mostly New England clients. Its specialty is financial-services companies.

title: Legend Buying Fund Manager
description: Legend Capital L.P., a private investment partnership, agreed this week to acquire the Delaware Management Company, a closely held money-management firm in Philadelphia with $18 billion in assets under management. The price is more than $200 million.

title: Catholic Bishops Refuse To Rescind AIDS Policy
description: Elected representatives of the United States Catholic bishops have refused to set aside the policy statement on AIDS that they issued last December, but have voted to hold a broad discussion of the AIDS issue when all the bishops meet next June.

title: FIRST NOVEL SKETCHES EVIL WITH WHAT'S NOT SAID
description: Night Over Day Over Night By Paul Watkins 294 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: BETHEL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company went public in August 1987.

title: De Laurentiis Closings
description: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group Inc., struggling to recover from heavy losses caused by a string of failures at the box office, said this week that it would close its five regional film-distribution offices, eliminating 28 jobs, or about 15 percent of its 200 workers. The company said Thursday that its future sales would be handled out of its corporate office but that the company would ''continue to explore various distribution alternatives.'' The offices to be closed are in Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas, Atlanta and New York.

title: VTX ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings have been restated to give retroactive effect to the 5-for-4 stock split declared March 17, 1987. These results are audited, VTX previously reported unaudited figures of a loss of $424,000 for the latest fourth quarter and a net of $175,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year.

title: DATA MEASUREMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CIRCUIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $35,000 and $107,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss includes a one-time charge of $507,000 for the closing of the interest in a plant and its consolidation into another facility.

title: Michigan Stopped By North Carolina
description: Sure, steady North Carolina, led by J. R. Reid and sparked by a ferocious half-court defense, defeated Michigan, 78-69, tonight to advance to the West Regional final in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: CHINESE OFFICIAL URGES MODERATION
description: China's acting Prime Minister, Li Peng, opened the annual session of parliament today with a call to continue the economic and political initiatives that have dramatically affected the lives of the nation's one billion people.

title: Going Co-op: At the Soviet Economic Frontier
description: On a rutted back road of this Russian town, two building supply companies have coexisted for years. Both offered prices fixed by the state, limited selection, indifferent service. Who cared? The state made sure everyone was paid.

title: Invitation for Blind Renter
description: A condominium association that refused to let a blind man rent an apartment has reversed itself after he filed a discrimination complaint. ''We're hoping he's going to move in and be a neighbor,'' said Morris Barnett, director of the condominium association at Century Village here. The blind man, Larry Tomecek, who is 35 years old, said Thursday he did not know if would accept the offer. If he does, his discrimination claim would be dropped, his lawyer said.

title: Review/Recital; Gutierrez Plays Schumann
description: Robert Schumann, in his music critic's mind, fancied a band of Davids eager to take on the Goliaths of musical philistinism, and crystallized their high spirits and his own kaleidoscopic moods in the ''Davidsbundlertanze'' for solo piano. Horacio Gutierrez played the cycle as the centerpiece of his Avery Fisher Hall recital Sunday evening, but one thought afresh of the underlying spirit mostly to wish he had caught it more vividly. The interpretation was something of a disappointment, inasmuch as Mr. Gutierrez is one of the best pianists around. He does not bang, he conceives of virtuoso technique as meaning something more than just playing very fast with accuracy, his tone is lovely and he is able to shape a phrase.

title: Ford Belgian Expansion
description: The Ford Motor Company's Belgian manufacturing plant expects to expand its work force after strong demand for its cars and vans, a spokesman for the Ford Fabrieken Genk works said today. The spokesman said that the plant, which employs around 11,200, expected to employ an extra 1,700 this year to help increase output. Ford Fabrieken Genk is a wholly owned manufacturing unit of West Germany's Ford-Werke A.G., which is itself 100 percent owned by the Ford Motor Company of the United States.

title: Behind Du Pont's Shift On Loss of Ozone Layer
description: On March 4, Richard E. Heckert, chairman of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, wrote the kind of combative letter Du Pont executives have been writing for years. Answering three Senators who had sharply criticized the company, he said there was no reason for Du Pont to stop making chlorofluorocarbons, the useful compound that critics say destroys the earth's protective layer of ozone.

title: COMP-U-CHECK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Year-earlier results have been restated.

title: BOND PRICES ADVANCE MODERATELY
description: Bond prices moved moderately higher in subdued trading yesterday as investors turned from a declining stock market to the relative stability of Government securities.

title: KEY RATES
Two Charged With Murdering British Soldiers at I.R.A. Rite
description: Two men have been charged with murder in the mob killing of two British soldiers during an Irish Republican Army funeral in Belfast, the police said today.

title: 2 Employees of Military Concern Are Accused of Defrauding Army
description: Two employees of a military contractor in San Diego were charged today with falsifying test results of a hand-held mine detector for the Army.

title: With Fewer Volunteers, Greenwich Firefighters Face a Test
description: For years, elected officials here tried not to rile the volunteer firefighters, a proud political force known to engineer the defeat of first selectmen they did not like.

title: For Managua, Economic Woe
description: When the Nicaraguan guerrillas announced one of their first directorates five years ago, the Sandinista newspaper Barricada ran photos of each contra leader beneath a huge headline that declared, ''These Beasts Will Never Return.''

title: Genisco Faces Fraud Charges
description: A California military contractor, the Genisco Technology Corporation, has been accused of conspiracy to defraud the Government on Navy contracts to build parts for strategic weapons systems, Justice Department officials said today.

title: James Howard, Congressman, Is Dead at 60
description: Representative James J. Howard, a New Jersey Democrat who served more than two decades in Congress, died this afternoon at the Washington Hospital Center, a day after suffering a heart attack. He was 60 years old.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $9,903,000, or $1.23 a share, on a real estate sale. Sales results are restated for reclassification of the Metal Products Group to discontinued operations.

title: ANSWWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 17.

title: How Manhattan Cable Agreed to Pick Up Bravo
description: As Gary Kaskel sees it, ''the consumers won.''

title: Guidepost
description: Planning a Move

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 5
description: b-Net income The company said the latest third quarter loss was caused by pre-tax charges of $24,165,000, related to decisions to restructure or curtail certain businesses, the previously announced decision to reduce employment and certain asset writedowns.

title: Ordinaires at Siberia
description: The Ordinaires, an instrumental rock band, is to perform tonight at 11:30 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. at Siberia, 804 Washington Street (463-8521). Admission is $5 before 11 P.M., $10 after.

title: About New York; Thrill of Gluttony Beats the Agony Of Indigestion
description: Carl Herkowitz, a coin collector from Detroit who was in town this week for a convention of numismatists, stopped by the Carnegie Deli for a bite Wednesday night and heard while he was dining that there would be a knish-eating contest in the place the next day. Once, long ago and far away, Mr. Herkowitz finished with the overachievers in a submarine, or hero sandwich, group gorge, but he had nearly put away the sweet memory of that challenge successfully met in youth. Now his blood was up again.

title: PANAMA'S MILITARY GOES WITHOUT PAY
description: With the Government strapped for cash because of economic sanctions imposed by the United States, the distribution of checks to the 15,000-member armed forces was put off today for a week.

title: By All Means, Destroy Fissionable Material
description: To the Editor:

title: CALL IT CINEMA VILLAGE
description: LEAD: The other day, I awoke to find it had snowed. Only the snow hadn't drifted down in light, airy flakes. Clumps of cotton had been arranged on my window sill by two men who waved cheerfully before descending to the street in a cherry picker. Shakespeare was almost right when he wrote, ''All the world's a stage.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gains on asset sales of $4,285,000 and $9,111,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes gains on asset sales of $9,699,000 for the quarter and $9,955,000 for the 9 months.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $11,000.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
RESUTLS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Pacers 101, Nets 100: Steve Stipanovich's 3-point shot with two seconds remaining lifted Indiana to a victory last night over the Nets in Indianapolis. Stipanovich, who scored only 9 points, caught Vern Fleming's pass before it bounced over his head to sink the winning basket from in front of the Net bench.

title: Home Resales Increase 3.8%
description: Sales of existing homes increased 3.8 percent in February, after declining for three straight months, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Robert Joffrey, 57, Founder Of the Ballet Troupe, Is Dead
description: Robert Joffrey, the founder and artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, a company renowned for its wide-ranging repertory and exuberant young performers, died yesterday morning at the New York University Medical Center University Hospital in New York City. He was 57 years old.

title: SEEKING PROFITS IN CONSUMER COMPLAINTS
description: America has developed a service-based economy, but many people don't think much of the service they're getting.

title: Islamic Nations End Meeting With Denunciations of Iran
description: Moslem countries ended a conference today by denouncing Iran for riots in Mecca last July and for refusing to sign a cease-fire in its war with Iraq.

title: Strike Voted at Jaguar
description: Workers at Jaguar P.L.C.'s Coventry plant in central England have voted to go on strike over plans to increase production, a union spokesman said today.
