Members of the Transport and General Workers Union and the Amalgamated Engineering Union voted by a 2-to-1 ratio to go on strike after Easter in the British luxury car maker's first important dispute in three years, a transport union spokesman said. ''We are striking over management's attempts to increase production without increasing payments,'' he said. There was no immediate comment from Jaguar.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan's Hero: North

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Includes tax credits of $2,220,000 for the quarter and $4,460,000 for the year. In 1987, preferred stock dividends exceeded net income. Results include the operations of Heritage Federal from its merger on July 31, 1986.

title: Letter: On Central America; The Freedoms That Salvadorans Enjoy
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutors Get What They Want And the Defense Reduces Its Risks
description: After nine days of nervously awaiting a jury's decision on his fate, Robert E. Chambers Jr. apparently recognized that he stood a good chance of being convicted of the most serious offense in New York State: second-degree murder.

title: 2 World Records Fall at Swim Meet
description: Tom Jager of Collinsville, Ill., and Artur Wojdat of Poland broke world records tonight in the Phillips 66/U.S. Swimming national indoor championships. Dara Torres of Beverly Hills, Calif., broke two American records, in the morning and at night.

title:
Patents;
Fees Not Paid, 150 Patents Expire
description: LEAD: This week's Official Gazette of the Patent and Trademark Office includes a list of 150 patents that expired on Jan. 3 because maintenance fees were not paid.

title: GUINNESS PLC reports earnings for 12mo to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $116 million. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $66 million. Results are in U.S. dollars; results for both periods have been translated at Dec. 31, 1987 exchange rate of 1.8785 pound sterling equals one U.S. dollar. Results for 1986 are on a pro-forma basis.

title: MANFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Reagan Nominee for Judgeship Urged to Withdraw
description: High-level officials in the Reagan Administration have told Bernard H. Siegan, whose nomination to the Federal appeals court in California has been blocked in the Senate Judiciary Committee for 14 months, that he should consider withdrawing his name.

title: Review/Film; A Dickens Adaptation In Novelistic Detail
description: In this time of fast food for the mind as well as the body, the novels of Charles Dickens remain glorious anachronisms. No spare, slim stories they, padded out to novel-length by single lines of cryptic dialogue and a graphic designer's mutely beautiful, very wide margins.

title: AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary charges of $111,254 and $1,688,746 for the quarter and year, respectively, and realized investment losses of $4,144 for the quarter and realized investment gains of $2,578,365 for the year. c-Net income d-Includes realized investment gains of $571,919 and $2,070,116 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for all periods reflect adjustments required to conform with generally accepted accounting principles.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax credit of $15,000. c-Net income d-Includes a loss of $78,000 on the disposal of a business segment for both the quarter and 6 months; a reversal of a tax credit of $17,000 for the quarter and a tax loss carryforward of $17,000 for the 6 months, and the 6-month also includes net from operations of a business disposed of $182,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I just have to believe that they're going to be found innocent because I don't think they were guilty of any lawbreaking or any crime.'' - President Reagan, referring to Lieut. Col.

title: I.M.F. Report On Seoul Effort
description: The International Monetary Fund today praised South Korea's economic success but urged Seoul to increase imports and to continue revaluing its currency, the won. A report prepared by an

title: Stumbling Toward Day Care
description: In 1971, when President Nixon vetoed Senator Walter Mondale's bill to establish a comprehensive national day care system, he voiced a fear shared by millions:

title: Company Owner Described As Fearful of Rejecting Mob
description: A defense lawyer has suggested in a summation that a Mafia boss used fear to obtain 50 percent of a major concrete contractor in New York City.

title: Gossip Column Becomes Target For the Gossips
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art gave a gala Monday night. A lot of swells were there, according to Suzy's column in The New York Post on Tuesday. No, they were not, said James Revson's column in New York Newsday on Thursday.

title: Favorites Emerge in the Final
description: There was an occasional heart-thumping close game to add to the suspense, and the emergence of a surprise team - make that two - to stimulate interest. But now that the East Regional has been sorted out and the could-have-beens have gone home, the final between Temple and Duke at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Saturday is a matchup the tournament committee envisioned three weeks ago when the field of 64 was selected.

title: Britain Cuts Trade Deficit
description: Britain's merchandise trade deficit narrowed 8 percent in February, while the country's annual inflation rate was unchanged at 3.3 percent, the Government said today.

title: After a Year, Knopf Shows the Impact of Its New Publisher
description: Sonny Mehta visited the United States often while he was running Pan Books in London. But during his first few months running Alfred A. Knopf he had to contend with culture shock, separation from his family and the language barrier - not the British-American language barrier that so amused Mark Twain, but the one that distinguishes hard-cover book publishers (Knopf) from paperback publishers (Pan).

title: Review/Music; Debut of a Choral Group Mixes the New and the Old
description: Choral singing is a recreation as well as an art - hence New York's large, dues-paying, often lumbering groups that command our attention in concerts several times a year. The other side of the coin offers the smaller, tighter, wholly professional choruses that rise above dilettantism. An addition to the latter is the New York Concert Singers, organized and directed by Judith Clurman. Miss Clurman's 16-member mixed ensemble made its debut at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night in a program of the new and the old.

title: Review/Dance; Choreography Combines Poetry and Speed
description: They call themselves That Was Fast. And fast they are. Karen Pearlman, an American dancer, and Richard Allen, an Australian dancer and poet, have teamed up as That Was Fast. Offering works that blended choreography with poetry, they hurtled across the stage Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center. One never knew what might come next.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article Thursday about Chinese plans to cut back on foreign study misidentified the source of reports that only 3,000 students a year would be allowed to go abroad. That number was cited by Chinese students who had spoken with Chinese consular officials in the United States; it was not based on official Chinese or American figures.

title: Upshaw Joins Indians
description: The Cleveland Indians, unwilling to start the season with the recently acquired Terry Francona as their first baseman, bought the contract of Willie Upshaw yesterday from the Toronto Blue Jays. The Blue Jays had deemed Upshaw expendable because they want to have Cecil Fielder and Fred McGriff share first base.

title:
Patents;
Method for Performing Laser Eye Surgery
description: LEAD: A New York eye surgeon, Dr. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr., was awarded a patent this week for his method of performing ophthalmic laser surgery. Patent 4,732,148 is related to one he was granted on March 8 for the apparatus that is used.

title: SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 58.

title: Michigan Race: High Risks for 2 Rivals
description: Michigan's Democrats make their Presidential choices on Saturday, with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts striving to establish himself as the favorite of the big Northern industrial states after his setback last week in Illinois, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri struggling to avoid elimination from the contest.

title: ZENTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $249,000 from reversal of a tax credit for the quarter; the year included a tax credit of $140,000 and a gain of $240,000 from a change in accounting. c-Net income d-Included tax credits of $513,000 and $1,607,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: A Sharp-Eyed Owner Halts Theft of His House
description: Frank Calabro glanced out the window of his real-estate office this week and saw a house heading north on the William Floyd Parkway.

title: Francis McCarter, 70, Retired Lawyer, Dies
description: Francis E. P. McCarter, senior partner of the law firm of McCarter & English, died of cancer on March 17 at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: SHOWCASE COSMETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: NICHOLS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
I.N.S. Ruling Benefits Illegal Immigrant Children
description: Undocumented immigrant children who are or have been in foster care will no longer be disqualified from becoming legal residents of the United States, according to a modification of immigration policy.

title: Armored Car Robbed of $1.2 Million While Guards Eat
description: While two armored truck guards were eating breakfast in a restaurant in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn yesterday, a holdup team handcuffed a third guard in the truck, drove it several blocks to a waiting van and escaped with more than $1.2 million in cash.

title: Antiquity, Quickly
description: How about not polishing something this spring? If you like the patina of antiquity, the kind that takes a millenium or two, you can now just brush it on. How? With Patina Green, a solution in a 16-ounce container, brush included, that's being offered for $18 in Pottery Barn's new catalogue.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter loss is after a nonrecurring charge of $223,000 from writeoff of items the company had been depreciating and amortizing, and an increase in inventory reserves.

title: SPORTING LIFE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Federated's Stock Off 25/
description: The common stock of Federated Department Stores slipped 25 cents yesterday, closing at $69, as another day went by without a new offer from R.H. Macy & Company. The Campeau Corporation on

title: DELEGATE TALLY
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules and delegates' public statements. DEMOCRATS Dukakis 531 Gephardt 147 Gore 364 Jackson 518 Simon 164 Uncommitted 385 *2*Total delegate votes: 4,163 *2*Chosen so far: 2,109 *2*Needed to nominate: 2,082 REPUBLICANS Bush 788 Dole 178 Robertson 17 Uncommitted 72 Total delegate votes: 2,277 Chosen so far: 1,055 Needed to nominate: 1,139

title: B.P. Plans Name Change
description: The British Petroleum Company plans to change its name by midyear to reflect its trans-Atlantic operations, a senior executive said today. E. John P. Browne, executive vice president of B.P.'s Cleveland-based BP America Inc. unit, did not say what the new name would be. The company's name has been changed several times since incorporation in 1909 as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company. The names of units of the London-based B.P. include Standard, Sohio and BP Alaska.

title: SHONEY'S SOUTH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The net in 1987 included a gain of $2,160,000, or 30 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S. Seizes 17 and Businesses In an Atlanta Narcotics Case
description: In an effort to break up what the United States Attorney here calls a major network of drug distribution and money laundering, Federal agents have arrested 17 people and seized 16 businesses and 40 buildings owned by them.

title: The Misery Hour
description: Evening. The cocktail hour they used to call it. We used to drink martinis and listen to the great Erroll Garner on the phonograph. Well, they used to call it the phonograph. It played records. Records were big, circular . . . Well, never mind. Anyhow, they used to call them records.

title: Report of Boycott
description: Regardless of the outcome of an investigation into whether Zola Budd raced in her native South Africa last year, some black African countries may boycott the Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, if Budd is chosen to compete there by the British Olympic team, according to a report in The Times of London.

title: New Soviet Income Tax: A Bite Up to 90%
description: Soviet citizens engaged in private business will face a progressive income tax beginning April 1, with rates ranging up to 90 percent, according to an official of the Soviet Finance Ministry.

title: Reagan Urges Israeli Restraint on Saudi Missiles
description: The Reagan Administration today publicly urged Israel to refrain from any military action against the medium-range ballistic missiles that Saudi Arabia recently purchased from China.

title: INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter includes a capital loss of $2,669,112 and a charge of $433,844 connected with an abandoned merger. The company said in the third quarter of 1987, charges related to the merger were $551,730, bringing total 1987 charges related to the merger to $985,574.

title: Judith Somogi, 47, a Conductor; Among First Women on Podium
description: Judith Somogi, one of the first women to become a conductor, died at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I., Wednesday morning. She was 47 years old and had suffered from cancer for four years.

title: Bruno's Expands
description: Bruno's Inc., Alabama's largest grocery chain, has agreed to buy 82 Piggly Wiggly stores in Georgia for $30 million in stock, company officials said. Bruno's, a Birmingham-based company, already has 123 supermarkets. Under the agreement, Bruno's will buy Piggly Wiggly Southern, a Vidalia, Ga., holding company that owns stores in central and southern Georgia. The purchase includes a 585,000-square-foot warehouse in Vidalia that serves all 82 stores. Bruno's operates supermarkets under the names of Bruno's, Food World, Foodmax and Consumer Warehouse Foods in Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and Florida.

title: Chambers, With Jury at Impasse, Admits 1st-Degree Manslaughter
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., who insisted through 13 weeks of an agonized murder trial that Jennifer Levin had died accidentally, yesterday reluctantly said he had lied, that he had meant to hurt her, and he abruptly pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter.

title: People Express: Gone but Not Forgotten
description: LEAD: The report that Texas Air suffered a record loss of $466 million in 1987 may come as a blow to its shareholders and management, but at our house it was the best news in years.

title: Report Says Lilco Takeover Would Result in Savings of 10%
description: A long-awaited study for the Long Island Power Authority has found that electric costs on the Island would be about 10 percent lower over the next 15 years if the Long Island Lighting Company were publicly owned, officials said today.

title: Budget Talks in Albany Spill Into the Weekend
description: A waiting-room atmosphere settled on the State Capitol today as officials prepared to spend the weekend trying to resolve outstanding issues in the state's proposed $44 billion budget.

title: Review/Dance; 2 Works by Lar Lubovitch, Divided by 5 Years' Growth
description: ''Cavalcade'' was created toward the start of Lar Lubovitch's recent hedonistic period of choreography, epitomized in the lush, exuberant sweep and flow of ''A Brahms Symphony.'' ''Cavalcade,'' choreographed in 1980, rolls and roils gently along with its score by Steve Reich. But the seams show in ways they don't in the Brahms piece, which was performed, with ''Cavalcade,'' by the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company on Tuesday at City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Mr. Lubovitch has clearly perfected the style in the five years between the creation of the two pieces.

title: Trump Seeking $600 Million
description: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Resorts International Inc., said he was trying to arrange $600 million in bond financing that could be used to complete the Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City. The money could also help Mr. Trump meet the costs of buying out the stockholders.

title: MEDAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter results are after adjustments of $958,000 which pertain to interim periods prior to the fourth quarter. The company changed its fiscal year to a calendar year from a March 31 year-end in 1986. The year-ago ''year'' period is for the 9 months ended Dec. 31, 1986.

title: WHARF RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the results for the latest fourth quarter and year were hurt by unusual expenses of $3.1 million, including $1.3 million from redemption of stock options and severance payments to resigning officers and directors; the results for the year also included an extraordinary charge of $235,000.

title: Sinhalese Extremists Add to Sri Lanka's Strife
description: One Sunday earlier this month, a man on a bicycle rode up to a village official not far outside the capital, fired several shots at him and pedaled off into traffic.

title: Whirlpool Urges Roper Acceptance
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said it had asked the Roper Corporation to recommend that its shareholders accept Whirlpool's $50-a-share tender offer for the company, rather than the $45-a-share offer made by the General Electric Company. Neither G.E. nor Roper would comment on Whirlpool's request. Roper's stock price closed unchanged at $55 a share today, indicating that traders expected further bidding.

title: Shamir Assails Shultz Plan to Meet 2 U.S. Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir sharply objected today to a plan by Secretary of State George P. Shultz to meet with two Palestinian-Americans as part of his Middle East peace effort.

title: As Truce Chances Developed, Contras Built Private Channel to Democrats
description: In the weeks leading to the cease-fire agreement between the contras and the Nicaraguan Government, rebel leaders defied the Reagan Administration and opened a private channel of communication with the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, and a handful of Democrats.

title: Review/Theater; A Brechtian Curiosity Set in 1930's Spain
description: Brecht himself described ''Senora Carrar's Rifles'' as a ''large step backward'' in his dramatic development, and 50 years after its first performance here it is hard to disagree with his judgment. Essentially it is a 75-minute tract, and not all the energies of the cast in the current production at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater nor the addition of music and songs can turn it into compelling theater. It remains a Brechtian curiosity seldom staged and for good reasons.

title: No U.S. Blank Check for Israel
description: LEAD: Assume that in the general elections to be held later this year Israeli public opinion rallies behind Prime Minister Yitzak Shamir's repeated assertions that national security requires Israel to maintain unquestioned sovereignty in the occupied territories. Given the importance of American financial, military and diplomatic support for Israel, any such decision by Jerusalem automatically engages

title: TWO BRONX SCHOOLS REACH FINALS
description: Malik Sealy, the 6-foot-7-inch all-America senior center, scored 14 of his game-high 38 points in the third quarter to set a Section A record and lead St. Nicholas of Tolentine to an 85-54 victory over Adlai Stevenson in the New York State Federation Championship semifinal here tonight.

title: S.&P. Index Futures Get New Limits
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it would impose a new system of adjustable daily price limits on its Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts.

title: France Frees Bomb Suspect, But Denies Deal for Hostages
description: A man suspected of organizing a bombing campaign in Paris that killed 13 people and wounded more than 200 others in 1986 was released from detention today.

title: Sooners Don't Plan to Pause
description: Billy Tubbs was asked today at a news conference whether any Big Eight Conference basketball team reminded him of Villanova.

title: I.B.M. SAID TO OFFER CHIP DATA TO RIVAL TO THWART JAPANESE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has offered to supply vital computer chip technology to its arch-rival, the Digital Equipment Corporation, rather than see Digital become increasingly dependent on Japanese suppliers, according to a new book and sources in the industry.

title: Review/Dance; The Ancient Odissi Style Steps Off an Indian Frieze
description: Odissi dance lives on in the ancient temple sculptures and friezes of the State of Orissa on the eastern coast of India. Neglected in this century, it has been less well known and less practiced than Bharata Natyam. But in Sanjukta Panigrahi, who performed Saturday night at the Asia Society, Odissi has a distinguished and dynamic interpreter.

title: TELE-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $100,000. c-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Grier, a field judge and back judge in the National Football League for seven years, has been chosen by Art McNally, the supervisor of officials, to become the league's first black referee, replacing Bob Frederick, who retired. Of 107 officials in the league, 11 are black. . . . Jerry Hairston, the team's career pinch-hitting leader, was among three players waived by the White Sox yesterday. . . . Julie Krone was fined $500 by the Aqueduct stewards yesterday for failing to exercise appropriate judgment by not riding out her mount in a close finish at Aqueduct Thursday. It was the second such fine this year for Krone, the leading female rider in racing history. . . . Rowdy Gaines, who retired after he won three gold medals in swimming at the 1984 Summer Olympics, was planning a one-race comeback today in a relay in the national indoor championships in Orlando, Fla. It was a favor to three young swimmers he once coached. But he said the furor over whether he had amateur standing surprised him, and he withdrew last night ''because I could probably cause a big problem.''

title: More Than 'Shazam!'
description: Howie Evans's attitude about Mark Macon was: ''You're so good? Prove it to me.''

title: Beyond the Restaurant Payoffs
description: Add the New York City Department of Health to the long list of city agencies tainted by corruption charges. News that health inspectors have been accused of shaking down restaurants provides dramatic evidence that the city needs to overhaul its system for policing its 15,000 eating places.

title: U.S. Offering Medals To P.O.W.'s Since '17
description: About 142,200 individuals or their families will be eligible for a military medal honoring American prisoners of war, the Defense Department said today.

title: Teachers' Union Is Disappointed By Progress of Education Reform
description: Five years after a landmark report that declared the nation imperiled by ''a rising tide of mediocrity'' in education, American schools have shown little improvement because of a lack of Federal aid, the National Education Association said today.

title: GAIN IN AWARENESS OF IMMUNE DISEASE
description: More Americans are learning about how AIDS is transmitted and discussing it with their children, according to a new Federal report.

title: Goldin Blocks Higher Price For Drug Witness's House
description: After weeks of turmoil, something nice finally happened to Arjune, the drug-case witness whose house in Queens was firebombed: New York City agreed to buy the house.

title: Black Family Survival
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Panel Can Lead Us Out of Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: XOMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $32 million non-recurring, non-cash charge for acquisition of the technology and rights of an affiliated research and development partnership.

title: Colombia Volcano Rumbles
description: A volcano that killed 20,000 people in 1985 rumbled and began spewing a thick column of ash and steam today, and an immediate evacuation of the area was ordered, officials said. A quarter-inch blanket of ash covered Manizales, a town 20 miles northwest of the Nevado del Ruiz volcano, a radio station there reported.

title: UConn Advances To Semifinals, 72-61
description: Phil Gamble scored 7 of his 18 points on free throws in the final 6 minutes, and Cliff Robinson added 17 points as Connecticut beat Virginia Commonwealth, 72-61, tonight in the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament The Huskies (18-14) broke out of a 51-51 tie by outscoring the Rams, 21-10, over the final 6 minutes 53 seconds. Gamble made 6 foul shots and Jeff King, who finished with 14 points, also added 6 during a 14-5 run as Connecticut moved into the semifinals for the first time in seven tournament appearances.

title: Stewart Up by One After Eagle at 18th
description: A day after Mark McCumber took the first-round lead in the Players Championship with an eagle at his 18th hole, Payne Stewart eagled the same hole to take the second-round lead by a stroke over McCumber and Mike Reid.

title: Advocate of Independence Wins in Gibraltar
description: Joe Bossano, leader of the Gibraltar Socialist Labor Party and an advocate of independence for this British colony, was declared the victor today in local elections.

title:
Patents;
New System For Avoiding Air Collisions
description: LEAD: A new system to avoid aircraft collisions was patented this week by George B. Litchford and Burton L. Hulland. They assigned patent 4,733,241 to the Litchstreet Company of Northport, L.I. They are partners in the concern.

title: Bush Drops Half of Paid Campaign Staff
description: Vice President Bush's Presidential campaign laid off almost 50 percent of its paid staff after the 17 Republican primaries and caucuses of March 8, campaign officials said today.

title: Reagan Asserts Iran-Contra Defendants Are Not Guilty
description: President Reagan declared today that he did not believe Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North and his three co-defendants in the Iran-contra affair were guilty.

title: Track Inquiry Ends
description: After a three-month investigation, the Italian Olympic Committee announced yesterday that Italian officials had falsified the long-jump results at the world track and field championships in Rome last September to insure that Giovanni Evangelisti of Italy would win the bronze medal. The committee said that disciplinary measures would be taken against eight officials of the Italian track and field federation, including the federation's secretary general, Luciano Barra, and the technical director of the national track team, Enzo Rossi.

title: Jurors Describe 'Wild' Shifts of Opinion
description: With their marathon deliberations abruptly ended by a surprise plea bargain, jurors in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. spoke with reporters for the first time yesterday, describing what one called ''wild'' shifts of opinion and emotion during the nine days they spent trying to reach a verdict.

title: Dismissed Jersey Official Found Dead
description: A New Jersey education official who was dismissed in January amid a corruption investigation was found dead yesterday in the garage of his home, according to the police.

title: Santiago Journal; At a Chilean 'Utopia,' Dark Tales of Dread Doings
description: More than a quarter century ago, they followed a traveling preacher from Germany to a place of sunny skies and crisp air in the foothills of the Andes.

title: Dollar's Decline Continues
description: The dollar continued to fall against the Japanese yen and other major foreign currencies yesterday, even though the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan apparently moved to bolster its value.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pretax gain from the sale of properties of $274,000.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,565,000 on the sale of real estate for the quarter and year.

title: The Palm Frond Industry St for Annual Observance
description: As Jesus entered Jerusalem he was greeted by people bearing palm fronds plucked from the trees above them, the New Testament says. But tomorrow, on Palm Sunday, the annual celebration of this event will depend on modern commerce.

title: James Gould, 79, Dies; Ex-Chief of Radio City
description: James F. Gould, the former president of Radio City Music Hall, died of heart failure Thursday at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla. He was 79 years old.

title: Fading Influence for Divided U.A.W.
description: The United Automobile Workers is unaccustomed to neutrality in a hard-fought Presidential campaign.

title: Bobby Hutcherson
description: Bobby Hutcherson, a vibraphonist, is to lead a quartet - with Kenny Barron on piano, Buster Williams on bass and Tony Reedus on drums - tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Review/Jazz; A Drummer Who Goads The Soloists
description: Tony Williams's drumming fills all the requirements of modern jazz. It propels and punctuates the ensembles, goads and comments on every solo; it swings with furious precision. Yet in the first set by Mr. Williams and his quintet on Wednesday at the Village Gate (Bleecker and Thompson Streets), where the band is performing through tonight, his jazz technique evoked elemental forces: gale winds, avalanches, tsunamis. Even at relatively calm tempos, he generated a fierce subterranean pressure.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: b-Net income The latest periods' results were affected by a special restructuring charge of $7.5 million.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Comparable figures were not available; the company changed its fiscal year-end from late May to Dec. 31.

title: Thailand Has Done Its Share for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $178,000 and $689,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $55,000 and $299,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and tax credits of $131,000 for the quarter and $395,000 for the year.

title: For Contras, 'No Help Left'
description: Senior contra officials say that they felt they had no choice but to try to reach a preliminary accord with Sandinista representatives and that they believe they signed the best agreement they could get.

title: Gooden Turns Back Clock and Twins
description: Dwight Gooden found his old rhythm today and turned in a sparkling six-inning, two-hit performance, striking out six Twins. Roger McDowell pitched two scoreless innings and Randy Myers finished up in the ninth as the Mets shut out Minnesota, 4-0, for their eighth straight victory.

title: Senta Driver Dancers
description: Senta Driver and her dance company, Harry, are to make their only New York appearance this season in performances at 8 o'clock tonight and at 3 and 8 P.M. tomorrow at the Emanu-El Midtown Y Dance Center, 344 East 14th Street. The program is to include Ms. Driver's new ''Overruns,'' featuring Larry Hahn, a guest artist, and ''Specialty,'' ''Memorandum'' and ''Avner, Rena, Bud and Roxie, Lillian and Sam.'' Tickets are $8; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Tickets are also available for a benefit dinner and the performance tomorrow. Information: 344-1910.

title: Eastern Pilots Weigh Bid for Texas Air
description: The pilots' union of Eastern Airlines has been exploring a possible takeover of the troubled airline's parent company, the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Review/Pop; A Jazzy Side Of Cleo Laine
description: Few singers come better equipped to perform the music of Stephen Sondheim than the English pop-jazz contralto Cleo Laine. Besides an immaculate vocal tone, the qualities that Miss Laine brings to Sondheim are an aura of unflappable worldliness and a theatrical perspective that has noticeably sharpened since her appearance on Broadway in the musical ''Drood.''

title: It Takes More Than Sun To Make a Car Shine
description: The bright days of spring show up the drabness that winter left behind, and one of the more visible reminders is an automobile covered with the residue of snow, sleet and neglect - a car that's crying for a wash and wax.

title: Kennedy to Face Republican But Not Party's First Choice
description: The chairman of the State Republican Party, Ray Shamie, said Thursday that he would not challenge Senator Edward M. Kennedy this year. But a longtime aide to Mr. Shamie, Joseph Malone, will run against Mr. Kennedy.

title: U.N. to Study Poison-Gas Charge
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar agreed this evening to an Iranian demand that he send a team of experts to investigate accusations that Iraq used chemical weapons against civilians, the United Nations said.

title: Burglars Strike Apartment Of Bronx District Attorney
description: The Bronx District Attorney, Paul T. Gentile, became a crime victim Wednesday night when burglars looted his residence, making off with two handguns, a stereo and other valuables, the police said yesterday.

title: COOPER COS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $3,146,000. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $17,900,000.

title: Part-Time Farmers Learn It Is Full-Time Work
description: Looking restive and showing no sign that he had worked through the night at a nearby power plant, Chris Cogan took a last sip of coffee as he rose from the breakfast table. Sleep could come later. The land lay waiting.

title: Victim of Scalding Was Known to the Authorities
description: A lawyer who represented a 3-year-old boy found scalded to death in a Manhattan welfare hotel said yesterday that the child had been returned to his parents' custody in June after the dismissal of a child abuse complaint by the city.

title: Tese's Arguments Against Immediate Takeover
description: VINCENT TESE, the president of the State Urban Development Corporation, holds a crucial role on the Long Island Power Authority. As Governor Cuomo's Director of Economic Development, Mr. Tese has served as the chief representative for the Governor to the negotiations with the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Fancy Leaves to Brighten Corners in the Shade
description: INDOORS separate annual and vegetable seedlings and pot them individually; keep hairlike roots covered to prevent them from drying out; water carefully and put in a shaded location for a day or two until the roots are settled; then provide full sun and use water-soluble fertilizer diluted to half-rate. Caladiums

title: Suffolk G.O.P. Digs Out
description: JUST elected leader of what could be, but is not, one of the strongest Republican organizations in the state, Assemblyman John C. Cochrane of Brightwaters last week tackled one of the decisions that will help determine whether he can lead a comeback of the Suffolk Republican Party.

title: Alexandra Meigs Meredith Is Married To Ward Shaffer Taggart in Princeton
description: Alexandra Meigs Meredith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Meredith of Pennington, N.J., was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Ward Shaffer Taggart, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Taggart of Dallas.

title: High-Flying Haiku
description: IN JAPAN,'' SAYS JAPAN Air Lines in a series of radio ads, ''most everyone writes a haiku now and then, even busy executives.'' Now J.A.L. is urging busy American executives and other listeners to follow suit - with the chance of winning two first-class, round-trip tickets to Tokyo and $1,000 in spending money. Why the emphasis on business people? ''Because sometimes they should have a chance to look at nature,'' says Tadao Fujimatsu, the airline's vice president for public relations, based in New York. ''Haiku is a kind of tranquilizer.''

title: At Chambers Trial, Two Dramas End
description: By midday Friday, after eight and a half days of jury deliberations in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr., two separate dramas were nearing their final acts.

title: Winners Circle Series At Bushnell in Hartford
description: THE Fischoff and Coleman competitions are among the most prestigious in the world, and the Ridge String Quartet - formed only five years ago - has won both.

title: Cross Burning in Baltimore
description: A black woman who moved to a predominantly white neighborhood two weeks ago found a burning cross in a nearby park and racial ephitets on a window of her house, officials said Friday. Lieut. Larry Leeson said police officers investigating the burning of a 3-foot cross also found ''KKK'' painted in shaving cream on the windshield of a car owned by the woman, Carrie Venable. ''I'm here to stay so they might as well get used to it,'' she said.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Commercial Growth; Activity Along the Spine of Kingsbridge
description: IN the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx, a commercial and residential revival has uprooted the bingo players of Upper Broadway.

title: Miss Dann Weds Harvey S. Friedman
description: Anita Dann, a casting director for film and television in New York and Los Angeles, and Harvey Stuart Friedman, who owns the Sky Development Corporation, a real-estate developer in Passaic, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Shelton J. Donnell performed the ceremony at the Hillcrest Country Club in Los Angeles.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
Comparing the Prices Of Art and Coins
description: LEAD: ARE rare coins too cheap? The question may seem irrelevant to long-time collectors. But coin prices have risen dramatically in the last 15 years, and today's market levels make those of bygone decades seem almost Lilliputian.

title:
STAGE VIEW;
The Latest From Stoppard: A Quark-and-Dagger Thriller
description: LEAD: No, it's not necessary to be familiar with quantum theory, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, Kant's philosophy and the novels of John le Carre in order to enjoy Tom Stoppard's ''Hapgood.'' Yes, it would certainly help to have a passing acquaintance with some of them. Mr. Stoppard once said that his aim as a dramatist was to ''dislocate an audience's assumptions.

title: The Capital Press Pool Has Its Little Fish Too
description: Alan Emory, a Washington reporter for The Watertown (N.Y.) Daily Times since 1951, is the dean of New York's press corps. And, as in all bureaucratic endeavors, rank has its privileges.

title: Dr. Maher Weds Dr. A. S. Borcich
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York, Dr. Elizabeth Anne Maher, an ophthalmology resident at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony Steven Borcich, a fellow in gastroenterology at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. The Rev. Salvatore Matarazzo performed the ceremony.

title: Tax-Exempt in New York: $4.3 Billion
description: Property-tax exemptions totaling $4.3 billion were granted to more than a million New Yorkers in 1986, according to a state report issued this week.

title: A Desperate Spring on the Edge
description: On a sunny, late-winter afternoon in Yuma, Ariz., in an otherwise forgettable intrasquad game at the remote training camp of the San Diego Padres, Dickie Thon doubled, and members of both teams joined the small crowd in its cheers.

title: 5 More Die as Palestinians Battle in Lebanon
description: Rival Palestinian guerrilla factions were fighting each other today in a refugee center in southern Lebanon where a military commander for the Palestine Liberation Organization was killed on Friday.

title: TV VIEW
description: 'Lincoln'- A Giant Seen As a Man

title: Oil Leasing Plan Off Florida Keys Is Blocked
description: A proposal to allow oil and gas exploration off the Florida Keys has been dropped from the Federal Government's five-year leasing plan after state officials agreed to withdraw legal challenges to it.

title: Should a Principal Have Been a Teacher?
description: New Jersey's school principals and many of its superintendents are up in arms over the proposed new requirements for certifying principals. Elimination of the current requirement that principal candidates have three years of teaching experience is ostensibly at the core of this dissent.

title: 18 Die in Philippine Clashes
description: Fifteen Communist guerrillas and three soldiers died in gun battles in the northern and central Philippines, the military said today. A spokesman said 10 rebels and a soldier were killed in a one-hour battle in Albay Province, south of Manila, on Friday, and 5 rebels, 2 soldiers and a civilian were killed in a 13-hour battle in northern guerrillas attacked an army detachment in a remote village.

title: Review/Dance; THE FOOTPATH COMPANY
description: Alice Rubinstein is a choreographer whose gaze is turned outward at the world around her, to judge by a program presented by her Footpath Dance Company on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. And the dancers of Footpath, which is based in Cleveland, move well and are good-looking and very likable. The productions are professionally crafted. But Ms. Rubinstein's vision is not always transferred clearly to the stage.

title: STAYING AWAKE AFTER THE CURTAIN RISES
description: In her March 6 essay (''To Sit, to Sleep, Perchance to Clap,'' Opinion page), Caren S. Goldberg wrote of her difficulty in staying awake in regional theater.

title: Unscheduled Flight
description: DeAndra Anrig was flying a kite near her home in Mountain View, Calif., last weekend when something stronger than the first breeze of spring caught hold of it.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
A CHILD OF ONE'S OWN
description: LEAD: THE BABY MAKERS By Diana Frank and Marta Vogel. 298 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf. $18.95.

title: 'Doubles': Locker Room Comedy
description: ''DOUBLES,'' a mean-spirited comedy by David Wiltse, has just opened at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst. Its subject is male bonding and how men of a certain class relate to one another.

title: A Championship of Smelly Sneakers
description: The contestants entered the old red brick recreation center here, picked up their numbered bibs and sat down on the wooden benches lined up across the gym floor.

title: Sri Lanka Fishermen Killed
description: Six Moslem fishermen were shot and killed off Sri Lanka and nine of their companions were missing and feared dead, a Sri Lankan military official said today. A news agency blamed the attack on Tamil separatists.

title: Carol Anne Schmertz Weds Frederic B. Katz
description: The marriage of Carol Anne Schmertz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Schmertz of North Bellmore, L.I., to Frederic B. Katz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Katz of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., took place last evening at the Suburban Temple in Wantagh, L.I. Rabbi Robert A. Raab and Cantor Bernie Barr officiated.

title: Providing Sanctuary for Birds of Prey
description: WITHOUT warning, the snowy owl flew up in the face of the woman who cared for it, the strong flight feathers brushing her blond hair. The woman remained calm.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Sausalito, Calif.;
Houseboats Under Siege
description: LEAD: AT a bargain price, Nick and Suzanne Cooke control a nice piece of real estate. As they sit in their living room, they have views of this city's waterfront marinas and San Francisco Bay just east of the Golden Gate Bridge.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: John T. Schwarzlose, executive director of the Betty Ford Center, advises drug addicts who wish to join A.A. ''. . . to say they are both alcoholics and drug abusers.'' I believe Mr. Schwarzlose is missing the most important and, perhaps most difficult, tenet of A.A. - honesty. How can anyone expect to recover in a program based on honesty if he is there on the basis of a lie? FRANCES SKINNER Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: A Veteran Wordsmith Faces the Music
description: I have roamed the writing landscape, going from novels to biographies to short stories to television dramas to ballets to Broadway plays -but despite all that variety, for as long as I can remember I have coveted what I secretly considered the ultimate but elusive spice - writing a musical comedy. I don't know why. It defies explanation but there is for me no feeling to compare with the rush of euphoria I experience when I go to a musical and, on entering the theater, hear the orchestra warming up. Just the sound of the saxophone player tooting a few riffs or the drummer testing his skins and I am filled with a peculiar mix of elation and envy.

title: MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: DON'T DIET. By Dale M. Atrens. (Morrow, $16.95.) With the fervor of a roadside revival preacher, Dale M. Atrens exhorts us to embrace adiposity and live. A professor of psychobiology at the University of Sydney, Australia, Mr. Atrens believes it is our fixation on fat, not the fat itself, that gets us into trouble. He zealously hacks his way through a thicket of what he considers to be popular misconceptions about the demon pudginess, and if, in the end, his passion is more convincing than his rather sparse empirical backup, it is still refreshing to hear someone say enough is enough. Mr. Atrens's basic argument is that it's physiologically almost impossible for many people to lose weight, as evidenced by a high recidivism rate and the unflagging profitability of diet paraphernalia, from liquid concoctions to surgeons' staples. In doggedly seeking slimness, we open ourselves up to two serious health threats - the stress of constantly regarding food as the enemy, and the despair of feeling like a failure. And, he asserts, we don't really insure ourselves against heart trouble or cancer; he blames those mostly on saturated fats, not body weight. It would be nice if he were right. Unfortunately, Mr. Atrens's prose, which can be as dense as a Dobos torte, does not offer much in terms of sustenance. A lot of what he says makes sense - in particular, a vitriolic attack on the woman-as-scarecrow esthetic -but too much of it is infuriatingly vague. He dismisses the notion of tables of appropriate weight and then differentiates between the grossly obese (who need to lose weight) and the pleasingly plump (who don't), without giving readers a clue as to how he defines his categories.

title: NEW YORK UNIONS NEARING DEADLINE
description: With contracts covering 195,000 workers expiring this week, New York State is negotiating with bargaining units representing everyone from prison guards to chemists who test blood samples for AIDS.

title: Fliers Spend Weekend to Pay for a Bargain
description: Americans will do anything for a bargain. And they spent a lot of money to prove it this weekend.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 6 about cultural events in Europe this spring and summer described this year's Venice Biennale incorrectly. This Biennale will be the 43d.

title: First-Class Biking in Baja California
description: IT was one of those moments that instantly made clear why we'd flown all the way down to the tip of Baja California to go bicycle riding. The 26 Americans, happily tired after another day of biking and stuffed from a spectacular lobster dinner, strolled into the town plaza of tiny Todos Santos. It was Saturday, the second night of the New Year, and a brilliant full moon bathed the tree-lined square.

title: Sponsoring the Arts: Good Business
description: Anyone raising money for the arts, myself included, gets a twinge of discomfort when causes like the homeless, the hungry, the elderly and the sick are mentioned as needing bigger pieces of the philanthropic pie. I often find myself groping for an appropriate ''yes, but . . .'' response. But in fact, the answer is not that elusive.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Lesson in Repentance From Ogden Nash
description: To the Editor:

title: World Weary
description: THE LIVING DAYLIGHTS Starring Timothy Dalton (in photo), Maryam d'Abo, Jeroen Krabbe, Joe Don Baker, John Rhys-Davies, Art Malik, Andreas Wisniewski, Thomas Wheatley, Robert Brown. Directed by John Glen. 1987. CBS/Fox Video. 130 minutes. $89.98. Rated PG. Some brief nudity.

title: A Man of Many wOrds, 1,000 at a Time
description: LEAD: WHEN Norman W. Schur told a group of people some years ago that he was a lexicographer, ''only two of the seven knew what that was,'' he said.

title: Rail Museum to Displace A Furniture Company
description: LEAD: A ONE-STORY brick building, 20 by 110 feet, at the Greenport terminus of the Long Island Rail Road tracks is the prize in a year-old battle between the Village of Greenport and a local family-owned furniture company. It is a battle that, last week, the village appeared to have won.

title: Judge Orders Mistrial Over a Prankter's Note
description: The juror's friend thought it would be funny to leave a little note the other day. The joke prompted a mistrial.

title: POSTINGS: 1690 Mill as a Centerpiece; 7 for Harrison
description: Down by the old mill stream, Burton Handelsman is building colonial-style homes and mending a colonial mill. His seven-house project in Harrison, N.Y., at a bend in the Mamaroneck River will include the restoration of a 17th-century grist mill. Built in 1690, the stone-and-wood structure is the oldest mill in Westchester County, said Michael Cassarella, Harrison town historian. The mill, which fell into disrepair after it stopped producing flour in 1918, will be restored as the result of a deal between Mr. Handelsman's company, Love Realty, and the town. The deal allows some of the building lots on the eight-acre site to be less than the one acre required by zoning law.

title: Does It Pay to File Separate Returns?
description: THE Tax Reform Act of 1986 is creating a new trend: his and her tax returns. Before, almost all married couples saved money by filing joint tax returns. Couples who filed separately faced higher tax rates. More important, they lost valuable tax benefits like the ''two earner'' deduction, which was equal to 10 percent of the salary of the lower-earning partner, up to $3,000.

title: HOME VIDEO/NEW RELEASES
description: Near Dark Starring Adrian Pasdar, Jenny Wright, Lance Henriksen, Bill Paxton, Jenette Goldstein, Joshua Miller, Tim Thomerson, Marcie Leeds. Directed by Kathryn Bigelow. 1987. HBO Home Video. 95 minutes. $79.99. Rated R.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some days we really suffered, but that's war. What we really want is to live in peace. I believe we can stop hating each other.'' - Daniel Verona, 18, after two years in the Nicaraguan Army. [ 19:1. ]

title: L.I. Sound Gains A Title and Funds
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND will be designated an ''estuary of national significance,'' in ceremonies tomorrow, guaranteeing Federal financing for the Long Island Sound Study until at least 1991.

title: Small Corner, Large Following
description: THEY swept into Elmont's Petite Corner restaurant: the Gold Coasters, with ankle-length white coats, furs, fashionable dresses and the unmistakable aura of people in the know. Now their secret is out. This is a gem of a restaurant, well worth a trip to Elmont.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: OVEREXPOSED: Treating Sexual Perversion in America. By Sylvere Lotringer. (Pantheon, Cloth, $16.95; Paper, $9.95.) Had Sylvere Lotringer's intent been simply to describe a method of treating sexual deviance in which the offender is flooded with the stimuli that arouse him until they become boring, his book would be reasonably successful.

title: COMFORTING TRADITIONS
description: MORE THAN ANY OTHER JEWISH holiday, Passover is unwavering in its traditions. Even the most inventive chef is likely to turn to his mother's recipes, perhaps with just a bit of fine-tuning, for the festive feast.

title: Ghost Train
description: To the Editor: ''Riding the Ghost Train'' (Travel, Jan. 31) confirmed my own experiences with Amtrak. They sell you a ticket on the grandiloquently titled Silver Star, Sarasota to New York. Unless you are a skillful timetable reader, you don't know till you get to the Sarasota Amtrak station that the first several hours will be spent on a bus from Sarasota to Tampa where the rail trip starts. R. C. SCHNITZER Key West, Fla.

title: The Perfect Tool for Killing
description: GENE WARS Military Control Over the New Genetic Technologies. By Charles Piller and Keith R. Yamamoto. 302 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/ William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A WASHINGTON-based organization that opposes garbage incineration has received a grant to conduct an analysis of waste-disposal alternatives in Union and Atlantic Counties.

title: Mimi Ellis, a Lawyer, To Marry C. M. Storey
description: The engagement of Marie-Armide Longer Ellis to Charles Mills Storey has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Elizabeth Watson Blanchard of Needham, Mass.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FOCUS: CENTRAL AMERICA

title: Palestinians Turn Ire on Collaborators
description: Bicharra Qumsaya kneaded the black worry beads in his right hand as he scanned the faces of his neighbors crowded into the Greek Orthodox Church. He wore a well-tailored dark suit and the traditional white Arab headdress, held in place with a double black band.

title: The Alfredo Kraus Secret For Triumphing Over Time
description: Alfredo Kraus is a tenor of many distinctions, and one among them on which all observers would have to agree is the really unusual preservation of his voice. We have at the moment a fair number of opera singers clustered around the age of 60 who have lasted impressively well, but Mr. Kraus, who was born in 1927, has conceded less to time than any of them.

title: Sylvia Plath's Biographers
description: To the Editor:

title:
TO START WITH . . .;
Double Indemnity
description: LEAD: ONE DAY LAST month, in Manhattan, Matthew Kornreich, a 63-year-old insurance broker, made a presentation to a potential client in the real estate business. Later the same day, his identical twin, Morton, who helps him run the New York-based Kornreich Organization, repeated the sales pitch to a representative of the company in Los

title: BEST SELLERS: MARCH 27, 1988
description: Weeks This Last On Week Wee k Fiction 1 1 3 THE ICARUS AGENDA, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $19.95.) A congressman has secret dealings with terrorists. 2 2 21 THE BONFIRE OF THE VANITIES, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.95.) A bond trader caught in the jungles of New York. 3 3 3 HOT MONEY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) Which member of a gold arbitrageur's family was responsible for the murder of his fifth wife? 4 4 2 TREASURE, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) Dirk Pitt leads a global pursuit of hijackers of an ancient Egyptian literary trove. 5 6 40 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians. 6 5 18 THE TOMMYKNOCKERS, by Stephen King. (Putnam, $19.95.) Two writers' zealous attempt to unearth mysterious artifacts causes havoc. 7 15 2 INHERITANCE, by Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $18.95.) A woman finds herself enmeshed in the jealousies and conspiracies of a wealthy family. 8 7 6 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 9 10 35 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 10 8 17 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $17.95.) Continuing the space saga begun in ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 11 * 9 23 KALEIDOSCOPE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Three sisters, separated by fate, and the lawyer whose mission is to find and reunite them. 12 13 10 THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Abrahams/Dutton, $22.95.) Turmoil and rebellion in 19th-century Ireland, observed through the eyes and voices of many witnesses. 13 1 S., by John Updike. (Knopf, $17.95.) A New England woman, in search of a new life, joins a religious commune in Arizona. 14 * 14 9 MORTAL FEAR, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) The death of a distinguished biologist leads to discoveries about medical science's mysteries. 15 * 11 10 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $18.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 16 * 12 13 WINTERS' TALES, by Jonathan Winters. (Random House, $13.95.) Unusual short stories by the comedian and television personality. Weeks This Last On Week Week Nonfiction 1 1 15 TRUMP: The Art of the Deal, by Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. (Random House, $19.95.) The career and business style of the entrepreneur. 2 2 8 THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS, by Paul Kennedy. (Random House, $24.95.) How economic and military forces affected the fortunes of great nations in the past 500 years. 3 4 20 THRIVING ON CHAOS, by Tom Peters. (Knopf, $19.95.) The author discusses how companies can survive in today's and tomorrow's turbulent world. 4 * 3 7 THE PRIZE PULITZER, by Roxanne Pulitzer with Kathleen Maxa. (Villard, $17.95.) Life in Palm Beach's steamy rich society recalled by a woman who married into it. 5 5 46 LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions. 6 6 6 KEEPING SECRETS, by Suzanne Somers. (Warner, $17.95.) The actress recalls her experience as the daughter of an alcoholic. 7 8 10 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a fast-developing new science that involves disorder, arrhythmia and the bizarre and the random in nature. 8 14 4 BATTLE CRY OF FREEDOM, by James M. McPherson. (Oxford University, $30.) A history of the American Civil War era. 9 * 7 5 OSCAR WILDE, by Richard Ellmann. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the dramatist, essayist, poet and wit. 10 13 9 DETOUR, by Cheryl Crane with Cliff Jahr. (Arbor House/Morrow, $18.95.) Lana Turner's daughter recalls the circumstances under which she killed her mother's gangster boyfriend 30 years ago. 11 12 35 THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade. 12 * 10 42 THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years. 13 9 18 THE CAT WHO CAME FOR CHRISTMAS, by Cleveland Amory. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) A self- styled curmudgeon's memoir of a cat. 14 11 35 SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service. 15 15 5 DONNIE BRASCO, by Joseph D. Pistone with Richard Woodley. (New American Library, $18.95.) A former F.B.I. agent tells of his five years posing as a mobster to discover Mafia secrets. Weeks This Last On Week Week Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 38 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level without drugs. 2 1 8 ELIZABETH TAKES OFF, by Elizabeth Taylor. (Putnam, $17.95.) The film star relates her experiences in gaining and losing weight. 3 3 6 WEIGHT WATCHERS QUICK AND EASY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library, $17.95.) Dishes that can be prepared in less than an hour. 4 4 133 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $14.95.) A standard reference work in a 1983 revision. 5 5 18 THE FRUGAL GOURMET COOKS AMERICAN, by Jeff Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) New recipes and techniques for preparing many regional dishes. The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States, statistically adjusted to represent sales in all bookstores. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) SIX MEMOS FOR THE NEXT MILLENNIUM, by Italo Calvino. (Harvard University, $12.95.) Five (the sixth was unwritten) highly personal meditations on the art of writing by the Italian wizard of short prose narrative who died in 1985, these were to have been the 1985-86 Charles Eliot Norton Lectures at Harvard. THE BEAUTIFUL ROOM IS EMPTY, by Edmund White. (Knopf, $17.95.) The second of what Mr. White hopes will be four autobiographical novels, this transparent, artfully unreflective account takes its narrator from entry into the gay life to the creation of gay political consciousness at the end of the 60's. SEASON TICKET: A Baseball Companion, by Roger Angell. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) Casual, long, lyrical, indispensable essays published in The New Yorker between 1983 and 1987. A FRIEND FROM ENGLAND, by Anita Brookner. (Pantheon, $15.95.) A delicate portrait of a woman who tries by social and imaginative stratagems to inhabit the lost world of the European bourgeoisie, until the real world inevitably irrupts. THE HEARTS AND LIVES OF MEN, by Fay Weldon. (Viking, $18.95.) In her 13th novel, Ms. Weldon has the nerve (and the skill) to pull all the stops of melodrama, moralizing, sentimentality and adventure to produce a robust novel about love and hate. UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The story (so far) of the 22-year-old Irish poet left spastic and speechless by brain damage at birth, written in heady, acrobatic language. PERFECT PITCH: A Life Story, by Nicolas Slonimsky. (Oxford University, $21.95.) A rich and various chronicle of musical life in the 20th century, by a voluble, energetic 93-year-old insider.

title: Review/Pop; Trio Recalls Big Band Era
description: The Swing Now Trio, three versatile musicians who have been kindling memories of the Swing Era, including the big bands and the jitterbugs, every Wednesday night for more than a year at the North River Bar in Tribeca (145 Hudson Street), brought their music but not their dancers uptown to the garment district Thursday evening to play at Terranova, a restaurant at 18 West 38th Street.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: WE DON'T DIE: George Anderson's Conversations With the Other Side. By Joel Martin and Patricia Romanowski. (Putnam, $17.95.) A 35-year-old Long Islander, George Anderson, is a psychic medium - if we are to accept the claims of this book - whose accuracy with strangers approaches ''85 to 95%.'' ''To use a crude metaphor,'' the authors of ''We Don't Die'' write, ''George seems to act as a radio receiver through which the spirits communicate on an energy frequency most of us are not consciously attuned to.

title: Alexandria P. George To Wed Park Mauck
description: Mrs. F. Whitney Clark of Bedford, N.Y., and William D. George 3d of Sewickley, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter Alexandria Pinkerton George to Park Gilbert Mauck, a son of Louise G. Crimmins of Somers, N.Y., and Ward L. Mauck of New York. An October wedding is planned.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Absolutely not. Just this once, why don't we leave some decision making to a human being? Besides, isn't arguing with an umpire a right guaranteed by the Constitution? ROBERT E. SHEA Rumson, N.J.

title: NUCLER ARMS AND NEW JOBS CLASH IN IDAHO
description: A plan to build the first new atomic weapons plant in a quarter of a century has ignited a major political struggle in the Northwest over jobs and nuclear disarmament.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23 The Noriega Government in Panama moved swiftly to try to force an end to the economic paralysis that has gripped the country for weeks, using a combination of military muscle and threats of legal action. Page 1

title: Review/Opera; Catherine Malfitano As the Met's 'Lulu'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Lulu,'' in the complete three-act version, has been a jewel in the company's crown ever since its premiere in 1980. If anything, it has improved in many details over the years. The season's first performance of Berg's masterly drama on Friday evening went off with special verve, thanks to a largely experienced cast and the stylish conducting of James Levine.

title: THE WHY OF A HICCUP, THE SPEED OF A SNEEZE
description: THE BODY IN TIME By Kenneth Jon Rose. Illustrated. 237 pp. New York: John Wiley & Sons. $19.95.

title: Debuts; SIX INSTRUMENTALISTS AND A SOPRANO GIVE RECITALS
description: Scott St. John

title: Officials Act to Speed Holiday Flow on Toll Plazas
description: LEAD: THE New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway will accommodate Easter holiday traffic by eliminating lane closings at the end of the week.

title: HAVE YOU HEARD THE ONE ABOUT THE MICROPIG?
description: THE MAN WITH NO ENDORPHINS And Other Reflections on Science. By James Gorman. 174 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: The Developer's Art
description: TWONG! THAT'S A sound no one wants to hear this spring as golfers tee off at Willowbend Golf Club in Wichita, Kan. The brainchild of entrepreneur George J. Ablah, Willowbend boasts an original sculpture at every tee. The 21 pieces include ''Lumberjack'' by Red Grooms, ''Hand'' by Fernando Botero, ''The Juggler'' by Chaim Gross and, alongside the first tee, Bruno Lucchesi's life-size bronze, ''After Shopping,'' seen above.

title: Searching for a Friendly Interface
description: AS they build computers that are easier to use, computer makers have been making hardware and software that is more complex and more expensive. The Macintosh has long been cited as a friendly computer, but it is expensive. Efforts to bring Macintosh-like features to the PC have focused on Microsoft Windows, or OS/2 With Presentation Manager. But those alternatives are also costly, and learning to use them is not easy. Nor do these approaches help the estimated 18 million users of plain old I.B.M. PC's and compatibles.

title: Anne Redmond Brophy Plans to Wed Standish Heminway O'Grady in August
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Brophy of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Anne Redmond Brophy, to Standish Heminway O'Grady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. O'Grady of Princeton, N.J. The couple plan to marry in August.

title: Grandfather Faults Tactics In Park Trial
description: Saying that the family has ''kept a gag on for a year and seven months,'' Jennifer Levin's grandfather had harsh words yesterday for Robert E. Chambers Jr.'s defense and for the judicial system.

title: CRAZY THOUGHTS, PANIC ATTACKS, LOVE
description: MIND MATTERS How Mind and Brain Interact to Create Our Conscious Lives. By Michael S. Gazzaniga. 255 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $17.95.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Essex
description: LEAD: MAIN STREET in Essex runs from the top of a gentle hill through a row of tightly packed and meticulously groomed houses and shops before it reaches a wide, grassy park along the Connecticut River. The quiet street epitomizes the graceful blend of the town itself. White clapboard and weathered brick homes dating to the Colonial era stand in harmony with businesses whose exteriors subtly tell of the commercial enterprises within.

title: The Scientist as Ignoramus and Hero
description: THE STATUE WITHIN An Autobiography. By Francois Jacob. Translated by Franklin Philip. 326 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Water Leak at Atom Plant
description: About 8,400 gallons of slightly radioactive water leaked into the Hudson River from the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant, the plant's operator said today. The water was discovered missing from a 345,000-gallon storage tank outside the containment structure, said a spokeswoman for Con Edison, Bea Meltzer. The problem was discovered this morning at the plant, 25 miles north of New York City, but officials were unsure how long the water had been leaking. A spokesman for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Carl Abraham, said the leak posed no health hazard.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Mirage of Secure Borders
description: Writing in Foreign Affairs magazine, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir maintains that Israel's frontiers were ''virtually indefensible'' until the conquests of 1967. So he resists withdrawal from the West Bank, whose heights dominate Israel's ''population centers, main industrial zones, rail and road arteries and international airport.''

title: DEMOCRACY IS TALKED ABOUT, BUT PINOCHET'S STILL IN CHARGE
description: ON International Women's Day earlier this month, the Chilean military Government outlawed public gatherings and sent army troops in battle gear into busy city streets and crowded shopping malls. The action was not a reflection of the Government's policy toward women but rather of its fear that the occasion would provide an excuse for anti-Government protests. Those who attempted to demonstrate were carried off to jail for a few hours or sent fleeing by bursts of tear gas.

title: Homosexual Ban In Child Care
description: AFTER becoming the first state to adopt a law banning homosexuals as foster or adoptive parents, New Hampshire began to question parents in its child-care program on their sexual orientation.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: Nan Robertson quotes a rabbi, who states, ''There are no Jewish alcoholics.'' I hope that readers do not get the impression from this that knowledgeable rabbis are not fully aware of the extent of alcoholism among Jews.

title: An Intrastate Rivalry Gains a National Flair
description: The sight was as hard to believe as the notion of a top-seeded team being removed from the national collegiate basketball tournament. On one night, hundreds of miles from home, there they were: Kansas State fans, in their purple and white, rooting for the University of Kansas, and Jayhawk fans, dressed in crimson and blue, cheering for the Wildcats.

title: At Bangladesh University, Studies in Despair
description: Amid the poverty, political turmoil and violence of Bangladesh, there is no sadder place than the University of Dhaka.

title: Reinventing A Company Town
description: AROUND town, they talk about different things. They talk about the nasty ice storm a few weeks ago that knocked out power for so many. They talk about their high school basketball team toppling Shakamak in the playoffs. They talk about who's turning 40 next and at whose house they will have the next Turning 40 party.

title: FIVE RICH ROTTERS
description: THE ICARUS AGENDA By Robert Ludlum. 677 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Rods Are Becoming as Feathery Light as the Flies They Cast
description: When the Orvis company of Manchester, Vt., introduced a 2-weight fly-fishing outfit four years ago, it seemed, to this observer at least, that the firm had gone as far as anyone could or should in creating a lightweight and delicate ensemble for wooing trout.

title: The Sound Gains a Title And U.S. Study Funds
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND will be designated an ''estuary of national significance,'' in ceremonies tomorrow, guaranteeing Federal financing for the Long Island Sound Study until at least 1991.

title: Cash In Hand, State Lags on Buying Parkland
description: LEAD: EIGHTEEN months after voters approved a $250 million bond act to buy open land and expand or improve parks, New York State has yet to make a single land acquisition on Long Island.

title: Old Gags and Pure Ham
description: THE ROAD TO RIO Starring Bob Hope (in photo, right), Bing Crosby (in photo, left), Dorothy Lamour, Gale Sondergaard and the Andrews Sisters. Songs by Johnny Burke and James Van Heusen. 1947. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 101 minutes. $69.95.

title: 700 Just Out of Sandinista Army Are More Than Ready for Peace
description: With more than 700 soldiers being discharged from military service at the Sandinista Army base here today, it was natural that the air be filled with cheers and enthusiasm.

title: Carol Maytag Plans to Wed
description: Mrs. Kerryn King of New York and Winterpark, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Carol Ann Maytag of London, to Capt. Richard Reginald Madeley of the Royal Marines, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. B. Madeley of Salisbury, Wiltshire, England. A May wedding is planned.

title: Bali
description: To the Editor: Hotel management, architects, construction engineers and builders so often conspire, seemingly, to annoy hotel guests. The Bali Sol, from which I am writing, is a magnificent example of a complete lack of understanding of a guest's needs. Beautifully landscaped, the hotel fronts on the sea. The reception atrium is gigantic, rooms large, nicely designed and decorated. The restaurants, pools and other services are extremely well operated. A guest is awed by this hotel until - and what a shocking event - a toilet is flushed.

title: A Pizza Magnate And His Mansion
description: RUNNING the length of the original wing of Stapleford Park, a stately home near this Leiscestershire village, is an inscription that reads: ''William Lord Sherard, Baron of Letrym, Repayred this Building, Anno Domini 1633.''

title: From City Bustle To Goat Farming
description: CAN a successful Manhattan leather-goods manufacturer move upstate and make out as a goat farmer?

title: There Are Plenty More Noriegas Where This One Came From
description: To the Editor:

title: Peete Returns to the Ranks of Leaders
description: There are enough bad backs on the PGA Tour to fill a hospital's orthopedic ward. The latest man to feel those aches and pains is Hal Sutton, who failed to make the cut Friday in the Players Championship.

title: REAGAN STRESSES DIFFICULTY OF SUMMIT ISSUES
description: President Reagan said today that pre-summit conference talks have ''made clear how difficult the issues are between the United States and the Soviet Union'' and that it remains to be seen how much good the sessions in Moscow this spring will do.

title: With Rights Bill Override, Reagan's Limp Begins to Show
description: THE morning of the votes that, as expected, overrode his veto of a major civil rights measure, President Reagan traveled to Capitol Hill to deliver a pep talk to Republicans.

title: Dropping Of Budgets From School Votes Sought
description: LEAD: IF THE New Jersey School Boards Association is successful, the school elections on April 5 could be the last in which voter approval is needed for school budgets that do not exceed state-mandated budget caps.

title: Elizabeth Silver Married to Laurence Wankowski
description: The marriage of Susan Elizabeth Silver, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Silver of White Plains, to Laurence Z. Wankowski, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Janislaw Wankowski of Stourbridge, England, took place yesterday at the Surrey Registry Office in Sutton, England. The registrar, John R. S. Turner, officiated.

title: Molehills Can Be Mountains, Too
description: The 50-odd piano pieces that Mendelssohn called ''Songs Without Words'' have been largely forgotten. They are small and unprepossessing, while the symphonies of Mahler are large and unavoidable. I suspect that every time Beethoven's Ninth takes a walk through our imagination, a miniature or two gets crushed underfoot. Things that occupy a lot of space naturally get in the way of our attention. Little things get lost.

title: Sooner Defense on Display in 78-59 Victory
description: In the first half, Oklahoma tried to play the game Villanova's way, and lost. In the second half, Oklahoma tried much the same thing, and won.

title: The Anatomy of a Co-op Conversion
description: AARON ZIEGELMAN, one of New York City's biggest co-op converters, bought the seven-story apartment building at 97th Street and Broadway almost as an afterthought. He had just bought another building on Central Park West and the sellers said, well, as long as he was buying, why not look at this one too?

title:
FOCUS: Fairfax, Va.;
Attracting Corporate Investors
description: LEAD: WHEN Mobil, the nation's fifth largest corporation, moves its headquarters from midtown Manhattan in the summer of 1990 to this fast-growing region it will join several other major companies that have decided to cut costs, gain cachet and convenience or, in some cases, do all three.

title: Extending the Concepts of Fiber
description: THE EVOLUTION within each medium is a fascinating aspect of contemporary craft. In fiber, for example, many artists push their limitations by applying textile concepts and processes to nonfibrous material.

title: C. W. Post's Life in Metaphor
description: HOW does a small, bearded writer who looks like a Talmudic scholar, who grew up speaking Yiddish in a house ''just like the shtetl,'' find his way to writing about the sacred cows of American food and popular culture? In Max Apple's books, food packages come alive in the capers of characters called Birdseye and C. W. Post, whose name graces one of Long Island's universities, the site of one of the Post family homes.

title: HUTCH TRIES TO GET HIS, AND DOES
description: DREAMING By Herbert Gold. 271 pp. New York: Donald I. Fine. $17.95.

title: THE MASCULINE MYSTIQUE
description: ONE OF THE GUYS The Wising Up of an American Man. By Harry Stein. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: Levity and Politics Mesh As Mayors Push Agenda
description: It's not that Charley Royer and Bill Hudnut do not like and respect each other. Quite the opposite. It is just that they cannot resist the fun of flinging verbal darts at each other.

title: General Strike Fails to Take Hold in Armenia
description: Yerevan was peaceful today, with no sign of the confrontation feared by authorities or the mass stay-at-home strike called by protest leaders, according to residents of the Armenian capital reached by telephone.

title: EAT YOUR FOOD - BUT DON'T ENJOY IT
description: REVOLUTION AT THE TABLE The Transformation of the American Diet. By Harvey A. Levenstein. Illustrated. 275 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $21.95.

title: Fewer Bursts, Less Bursting
