description: THE CBS CORRESPONDENT Bob Schieffer, reporting election returns on one of the primary nights, wondered aloud whether a percentage figure he was giving should be described as less or fewer. The grammarian on the spot immediately pronounced judgment: when a percentage is used to indicate an amount or quantity, it takes less; when used to describe a number, it takes fewer. Thus, you say, ''His Florida percentage in 1988 was less than it was in 1984,'' and ''Fewer voters went for him this year.''

title: Stockbroker Wed To Miss Mallory
description: Suzanne Gardner Mallory, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Mallory of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Scott Manning, the son of Billie M. Manning and Lee N. Manning, both of Littleton, Colo.

title: Socialist's Victory on Gibraltar Favors Britain
description: In elections with broad implications for relations between Spain and Britain, Gibraltar voters have chosen a Socialist government opposed to negotiations between the two countries over the status of the territory.

title: 503 Fifth Avenue
description: To the Editor:

title: In Music by Minors, Romance Triumphs Over Lust
description: Somewhere in suburban Long Island, a teen-age girl is up in her room, chatting on the telephone while her television set flickers with the sound off. She's talking about her parents and sisters, her friends at high school and her piano lessons. But mid-sentence she giggles and says, ''Wait a minute, I have to tape this. I'm on MTV.''

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT WAS almost as if the bird had emerged from the sand. One moment, there was nothing but a winter-scoured beach pocked with flotsam. The very next, there was this bird.

title: THE POLITICS OF CUOMO'S COLLEGE AID PLAN
description: WITH audience after audience in recent months, Governor Cuomo has wasted little time getting to one of his favorite topics: Liberty Scholarships. ''It can catch on all over the U.S.,'' Mr. Cuomo said in a speech to 350 Hispanic leaders earlier this month, ''and everywhere I talk about it, I have people say to me on the way out of the room, 'Mario, stay with it.' ''

title: Governors in Northeast Share Ideas on Waste
description: Recycling programs could make the Northeast a major producer of natural resources, but finding markets for the trash could be a major headache, according to officials at a governors' conference here.

title: Bach Chamber Soloists Offer a Birthday Salute
description: PIANO recitals and offbeat chamber programs help bring March to an intriguing musical close, starting today at 3 P.M., when the Bach Chamber Soloists offer a slightly late 303d birthday salute to their namesake composer. On the program at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers are the G major Flute Sonata, two sinfonias, and the C major Trio Sonata of Bach, along with a Sonata for flute, violin and continuo by Bach's son, Carl Philipp Emanuel.

title: POSTINGS: SoHo Project; Blending New and Old
description: The Broida Museum was to house the Broida collection before Edward R. Broida took his Susan Rothenbergs and went home to Los Angeles. But before leaving town in May 1986, Mr. Broida, a California developer, sold the 60-year-old, SoHo shell where the contemporary artworks were to be displayed to a long-time associate, Richard Talmadge, for $5.6 million.

title: Detentions at a Baltic Rally Confirmed by Soviet Press
description: The Soviet press agency Tass confirmed reports today that a number of people had been detained at rallies in the Soviet Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia on Friday.

title: Robust Italian Fare in Stamford
description: IN Italian, il mulino means the mill, and that has little connection to the shopping center Il Mulino is part of. But never mind. This small new storefront restaurant in the Springdale section of Stamford is prettier inside than outside, with gray wood walls and partitions counterpointed by greenery, pink tablecloths and red Leatherette booths.

title: THE CRUELEST ASSIGNMENT
description: THE MOSCOW CORRESPONDENTS Reporting on Russia From the Revolution to Glasnost. By Whitman Bassow. Illustrated. 385 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: TAKING LIFE THREE SECONDS AT A TIME
description: MINDWORKS Time and Conscious Experience. By Ernst Poppel. Translated by Tom Artin. Illustrated. 224 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Evening Fashion; Maximum From a Minimum
description: THE big news in fashion lately has been the rejection by many women of the miniskirt. Be that as it may, there is still a segment of the population, mostly young and obviously in excellent shape, that has embraced the shorter styles - or rather, let the styles embrace them. For these women the mini, especially the mini evening dress, is standard attire.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Challenge for a New Proprietor
description: LEAD: WHEN Dennis Foy's popular Chatham restaurant, The Tarragon Tree, closed its doors on New Year's Day, it was disappointing news indeed for area diners. It seems that Mr. Foy plans to fulfill a long-time dream of entering the Manhattan restaurant fray by launching Park Place on East 59th Street next month.

title: Sweet Corn to Grow In the Home Garden
description: LEAD: CORN on the cob is sweeter these days. Seed growers continue to offer more and more of the sugary hybrids with names like Staysweet, Sweet Sue, Xtra Sweet and Kandy Corn.

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: If there are any readers remaining who will venture a Nepal trek after reading Marcia R. Lieberman's article, may I add one additional caveat.

title: Review/Dance; Students From Juilliard Present a Mixed Bill
description: The Juilliard School Dance Division's annual performances are a time-honored tradition in New York. But this spring's program, seen Friday night at the Juilliard Theater, did not live up to that tradition. Most of the dances were familiar works and offered little sense of any potential professionals in the Juilliard Dance Ensemble, which is made up of advanced Juilliard dance students.

title: Debate Continues on Alien Deadline Extension
description: LEAD: AS THE Federal Government alien-amnesty program enters its last month, debate continues in New Jersey and throughout the nation over whether to extend the deadline.

title: Dr. Laurie E. Ellman Wed To Dr. Matthew Garfinkel
description: Dr. Laurie Ellen Ellman, a dentist in Brooklyn Heights, and Dr. Matthew Jan Garfinkel, a resident in orthopedic surgery at the Montefiore Medical Center, were married last evening. Rabbi David E. Fass officiated at Singer's restaurant in Spring Valley, N.Y.

title: Mets Send Milligan to Pirates and Get Reserve Catcher
description: The Mets made one of those moves today that will tantalize fans who will wonder: just what does it all mean?

title: Bronx Showdown In Basketball Final
description: Malik Sealy, a dominating 6-foot-7-inch center from Tolentine High School, and Danny Tirado, a gutsy 5-7 point guard from Our Saviour Lutheran, turned in record-setting performances Friday night in leading their Bronx schools to the final of the New York State Federation basketball tournament at the Civic Center.

title: Soviet Rehabilitates 20 Executed by Stalin
description: More than 20 people executed by Stalin have been posthumously reconfirmed as Communist Party members with unblemished records, the Tass news agency said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After leading Florida Southern to the N.C.A.A. basketball semifinals, Jerry Johnson has been named the 1987-88 Division II player of the year. . . . Dan Jansen, the speed skater who fell twice during the Olympic Winter Games in Calgary, Alberta, has been asked to throw out one of the two first balls at the Milwaukee Brewers' home opener April 15. The other one will be thrown out by Audrey Kuenn, widow of the former Milwaukee manager Harvey Kuenn. . . . Jim Spivey and Dick Beardsley will be among the runners for the 50 state teams at the first American Ekiden, the five-stage relay road race through the streets of Manhattan on April 9.

title: West Side Landmark to Become a Hostel
description: A CENTURY-OLD Manhattan landmark is being converted from neighborhood eyesore to New York's biggest youth hostel. The project is a rare collaborative effort involving a West Side community group, a midtown developer, an international foundation, two Wall Street securities firms, seven government agencies and 300 profit-seeking investors in 30 states.

description: THE CIRCLE TOUR By William Wiser. 388 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: Question of the Week: Next Week; How Will The Mets And Yanks Do in '88?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Officials are pPressed to Appeal; YONKERS RACIAL SUIT SETTLED IN COURT, NOT IN COMMUNITY
description: LAWYERS for the city were moving in two directions as Yonkers responded uncertainly last week to a Federal judge's longstanding order to build low-income housing in predominantly white neighborhoods as a remedy for four decades of racial discrimination against nonwhites, who account for about 18 percent of the population.

title: Nobel Laureate Invited to Meet the King
description: WHEN King Karl Gustav XVI of Sweden visits New Jersey next month to mark, at a ceremony in nearby Bridgeton, the 350th anniversary of the landing of Swedes in the New World, he is expected to digress briefly to greet a local man he befriended in Stockholm last November.

title: Lisa Gail Shaw Is Married To Lon J. Goldstein on L.I.
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., Lisa Gail Shaw, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs J. Stanley Shaw of Bayside, Queens, was married last evening to Lon Jay Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goldstein of East Norwich, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans officiated. The bride, a sales assistant for Shearson Lehman Hutton, graduated from Syracuse University. Her father, a senior partner of the law firm of Shaw, Licitra, Eisenberg, Esernio & Schwartz in Garden City, L.I., was the chairman of the Queens Liberal Party from 1968 to 1974.

description: American residents of the former Canal Zone say the Panamanian Government is harassing and intimidating American civilians and military personnel here.

description: The critical problems facing Mississippi's Gov. Ray Mabus are reminiscent of the problems that were successfully attacked in Vermont in the 1960's.

title: Ellen Reichman Plans To Marry Shaul Cohen
description: Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Reichman of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ellen Miller Reichman to Shaul Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Cohen of Safed, Israel. A June wedding is planned.

title: Hospital: Clinic Speeds Head-Injury Recovery
description: LEAD: PATIENTS with mild head injuries who receive follow-up care return to work 50 percent sooner than patients who do not, therapists at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center in Hartford have found.

title: A Business Climate Without Smoke
description: BEGINNING Friday, many workplaces in Connecticut will have something they did not have before: smoke-free areas. The task of setting up those areas has many employers posting signs, circulating memos and holding meetings with their workers to discuss the new rules.

title: DATA BANK: March 27, 1988
Review/Concert; HARMONIE WIND ENSEMBLE
description: Some listeners may regard the bright, vigorous sound of a wind ensemble as so seductive that the quality of the literature it plays doesn't matter. But listening to the Harmonie Ensemble's concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening, one had the impression that the greatest dilemma facing the director of such a group is finding literature worth hearing. Steven Richman, who directs these players, was about half successful this time.

title: RIGHTS AND CHOICES
description: Relationships are indeed complicated, but ''. . . a baby on the way . . .'' is no way to ''. . . help us banish . . . more stubborn doubts.''

title: FRESH FROM THE BOOMY, BUMPY WOMB
description: THE WORLD OF THE NEWBORN By Daphne Maurer and Charles Maurer. Illustrated. 293 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.95.

title: 40 Wounded in Bangladesh
description: At least 40 people, including six children, were wounded when were bombs set off by robbers at a rural fair, the police said today. More than 20 bombs went off Friday during a fair in the village of Kaliakandipara in Sirajganj district, about 50 miles northwest of Dhaka, according to police officials. A 7-year-old boy and five adults were critically injured, they said. Officers said many stalls set up by traders were robbed, but the amount of money and goods taken was not known. The robbers escaped, they said.

title: The Next Superpower Summit May Be Unrehearsed
description: SUPERPOWER summitry is part pageant, part process, part concrete deal-making, and a certain balance among all the elements is needed for a meeting to be considered a success. By that standard, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are 1 for 3 at the moment, having failed in Geneva in 1985 to do much more than get acquainted, having sown confusion in the arms negotiations in Reykjavik in 1986, and having succeeded in Washington last December by creating an amicable atmosphere and signing the first treaty to eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons.

title: No Headline
description: The National Metaphor Baseball is the national metaphor as well as the national pastime, and nobody has a better batting average with a pen than Roger Angell. This is from ''Season Ticket: A Baseball Companion,'' (Houghton Mifflin).

description: To the Editor:

description: LEAD: This is how the mission usually began, that summer of 1984...

title: Plaza Hotel Is Sold To Donald Trump For $390 Million
description: Donald J. Trump disclosed yesterday that he had bought the Plaza Hotel for $390 million and would upgrade it into ''the most luxurious hotel in the world.''

title: JACKSON WINS EASILY IN MICHIGAN IN SURPRISING SETBACK TO DUKAKIS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson dealt a blow to the Presidential candidacy of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today, trouncing him in the popular vote in Michigan's Democratic caucuses and denying him the momentum he had sought in this big industrial state.

title: The Sudden Rise of the Red-Bag Business
description: LAST June in Indianapolis, children were found playing with vials of blood they took from a dumpster near several doctors' offices. Two of the vials were infected with the deadly AIDS virus. In July several homeowners in Manchester, N. H. woke up to find their backyards littered with assorted operating-room waste. Heavy rains had dislodged the garbage from a nearby hospital's landfill.

title: Take It Easy On Strawberry
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Reliving Days of Scouting
description: IN honor of cookie month, the window display at the drugstore on the main street of Danbury is devoted to the Girl Scouts.

title: MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: THE NEW AGE: Notes of a Fringe-Watcher. By Martin Gardner. (Prometheus, $19.95.) Martin Gardner preaches to the unbeliever. He seeks not only to explain seemingly unexplainable phenomena, but to put them into context. Half of this book, which will be in stores in late April, is composed of Gardner columns called ''Notes of a Fringe-Watcher,'' written for the Buffalo journal Skeptical Inquirer. The remainder includes articles and reviews written for a variety of publications. The result is a sometimes lively, often repetitious, collection that manages to say too much and too little. On Shirley MacLaine, for example, Mr. Gardner can't write enough. Yet the uninitiated unbeliever may stumble over unexplained references, such as ''CSICOP'' (Committee for Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal). When explaining why scientists need to know magic, Mr. Gardner is often entertaining and informative. Many pieces should be of great interest to general readers. Unfortunately, the format -all pieces are in the order in which they were published and are accompanied by many author notes and letters to the editor - clutters the book and draws attention away from the articles. To his credit, Mr. Gardner always maintains a firm grasp of the subject, and a tone that is skeptical without being snide, whether he is writing about numerology, 19th-century spiritualists or what he calls ''prime-time preachers.'' At his best, he effectively explores the mixture of sincere belief and crafty deception that is ''conspicuous by its prevalence in the history of bogus science.''

title: JONATHAN DEMME'S OFFBEAT AMERICA
description: IN A DIM ROOM HIGH ABOVE the controlled chaos of Times Square, Jonathan Demme is watching a movie.

title: Regatta Is for Yacht Clubs to Enter
description: A different kind of regatta has surfaced on the West Coast. The event downplays the superstars of the sport in favor of the yacht clubs that have produced them.

title: 2 New York Players Take a Bridge Title At Spring Nationals
description: Bridge players from the New York metropolitan region were successful on two fronts Friday, winning one national title and putting themselves in a good situation to win another.

title: Unacceptable Image
description: Those Soviet parents who have had mixed feelings about the glorification of Pavlik Morozov may be resting easier these days. The authorities are toning down the hero image of Pavlik Morozov, who had been held up as a model of Communism since 1932, when, as a 13-year-old, he denounced his father as a class enemy and was subsequently murdered as an informer. For more than a decade, editions of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia have carried increasingly shorter references to the boy. In the last 15 months, a movie debunking the myth has attracted 20 million viewers. And an article in this month's issue of the journal Yunost declares that Morozov ''is not a symbol of steadfastness and class consciousness, but of legalized and romanticized treachery.''

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: A few additional words on health and Himalayan travel: I became badly ill in Ladakh in 1985. At Srinagar I was given Mexoform, an antibiotic. This and the similar Enteroviaform are sold over the counter all over India. I learned that they are extremely dangerous - possible side effects include blindness - and are not sold here.

title: Czechoslovak Police Disperse Catholics at a Rally
description: Riot policemen backed by water cannon beat and arrested hundreds of Roman Catholics in western Czechoslovakia on Friday night when they demonstrated for religious freedom, Western reporters said today.

title: Social Events; Festivities for Many Tastes
description: 'Phantom' Party March 30 - The Joffrey Ballet is holding a theater benefit at ''The Phantom of the Opera.'' The evening will begin with cocktails at 6:30 at Sardi's. Tickets, $250 each or $1,000 for a pair, limousine service and an original cast recording, from 212-265-7300. Singles' Seder April 1 - A religious and social celebration will be combined at the 12th annual singles-only Passover seder at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street. The seder is sponsored by Havurah, the synagogue's singles organization, which will be the evening's beneficiary. Rabbi David B. Kahne will recite the Haggadah, and Cantor Dov Keren will chant the seder melodies before the traditional dinner. Tickets for the 6:30 P.M. benefit, $55, from 212-593-3300. Open Doors to Reading April 4 - Through its free tutoring programs, Literacy Volunteers of New York City served 700 adults last year. The group is holding a cocktail party from 6:30 to 8:30 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, and the benefit will include a preview of works to be auctioned: Chinese art, porcelains and Old Master paintings. Tickets, $50, from 212-475-5757. Double Performance April 5 - With ''Esplande,'' ''Runes'' and the premiere of ''Brandenburgs,'' the Paul Taylor Dance Company will open its monthlong season at the City Center with a black-tie benefit. Following the performance at 7, there will be supper at the University Club, 1 West 54th Street; afterward, Michael Feinstein will perform. Tickets, $350, from 212-431-5562. Lecture and Cocktails April 5 - Rosamond Bernier will reminisce about Picasso, Matisse and Henry Moore, all of whom she knew in the 1940's as the feature editor of Vogue and later as the founder of L'Oeil, an art publication. The 6:30 P.M. lecture at Christie's will be followed by a reception to benefit the Sarah Lawrence Art Gallery. Tickets, $100, from 914-337-0700, extension 205. At Bloomingdale's April 5 - Bloomingdale's will open its doors at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue at 8 P.M. for a black-tie cocktail party, followed by dinner and entertainment by Barbara Cook and the High Heeled Women, a cabaret act. Peter Duchin will provide the music for dancing. The evening, ''Hooray for Hollywood,'' will benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Tickets, $350, from 212-874-4098 or 212-705-2441. New Theater in Town April 6 - A new performing-arts building is about to open on the Upper East Side: the Florence Gould Hall at 55 East 59th Street, adjoining the French Institute/Alliance Francaise, which raised the money to build it. The new structure will open with a benefit for the institute, and the evening will include a presentation of Jean Cocteau's 1921 work, ''Les Maries de la Tour Eiffel.'' The 7:45 P.M. performance will be followed by dinner just down the block at Regine's. Black tie. Tickets, $500, from 212-355-6100. An Evening of Dance April 6 - The Dance Theater Workshop, for 23 years a leader in producing experimental dance, is holding a benefit cocktail party, performance, buffet and dance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, starting at 7 P.M. John Kelley will star in the premiere of his work ''Find My Way Home,'' a retelling of the Orpheus and Eurydice legend, set in the Depression. Tickets, $100, from 212-691-6500. Celebration on the River April 6 - The American Cancer Society is now 75 years old, and to celebrate, a black-tie fund-raising celebration will be held at Pier 88, on the Hudson River near 48th Street. In addition to cocktails at 7, followed by dinner, dancing and entertainment by Peter Allen, the evening will offer a preview of Moda Italia, a two-week fashion and cultural exhibition sponsored by the Italian Trade Commission. The show will be open to the public April 7 through 17. Benefit tickets, $350, $500 and $1,000, from 212-586-8700, extension 390. Tickets for cocktails and dancing at 10 for those age 40 or younger are $125. 'What's Up, Doc?' April 9 - For 15 years, the Children's Museum of Manhattan has taken art and science programs to potential high-school dropouts and youngsters at welfare hotels. Its annual spring benefit starts at 10:30 A.M. at Loews Astor Plaza, Broadway at 44th Street, with a show of top American and foreign cartoons. There will then be a Bugs Bunny Parade along Broadway to the Marriott Marquis a block away for what the museum is calling the First Character Lunch, to be attended by more than 100 cartoon characters, clowns, mimes, musicians and magicians, including Sylvester, Babar, Paddington Bear, Superman, Wonder Woman and Sci-Fi the Robot. Tickets, $60 for children, $125 for adults or $275 for two adults and one child, from 212-765-5905.

title:
GARDENING;
Growing Plants in Poorly Drained Soil
description: LEAD: WHEN a gardener complains of having wet soil or poor drainage, a professional horticulturalist will almost instinctively suggest that it be drained. Seldom is the alternative suggested: Use plants that thrive in poorly drained soil.

title: Laura Hood Marries
description: Laura Ann Hood, a dancer with the American Ballet Theater, and Robert Martin Hupp, the managing director of the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater, were married yesterday at the Society of Friends Meeting House in Manhattan. Bishop Anthony Fennimore of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Dr. Peter Hood of Santa Rosa, Calif., and Audrey Hood Weitzman of New York. Mr. Hupp's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hupp of Laurel, Del.

title: MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: THE COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH COMPLETE GUIDE TO HEALTH AND WELL-BEING AFTER 50. Edited by Robert J. Weiss and Genell J. Subak-Sharpe. (Times Books, $24.95.) Old age is a shipwreck, de Gaulle used to complain, but Dr. Robert J. Weiss and Genell J. Subak-Sharpe insist that it is never too late to turn it into something more like a Caribbean cruise. Dr. Weiss, a former dean of the Columbia University School of Public Health, and his co-editor offer tips for staying well, shaping up and looking on the bright side. Healthiness, they say, is often the close companion of positive thinking, while depression can be bad for the body as well as mind. It is never too late to start over, to exercise, eat with care and lose weight. And it is never too late to stop smoking; after 10 or 15 years of abstinence, former smokers may be as fit as if they had never inhaled in the first place. There are also stern admonitions and useful telephone numbers to call for help with overdrinking. For those unready to look their age, there are descriptions and diagrams of cosmetic surgery on the nose, chin, breast and pate. Dr. Weiss and Ms. Subak-Sharpe canvassed the faculty at the School of Public Health and they have summed up the consensus on such major problems as heart disease, cancer and Alzheimer's. The resulting plain talk might make useful reading while trying to get past the busy signal when calling the doctor's office. Clearly the guide's best advice is to consult a physician - whether the reader is about to try a new exercise video, a megavitamin diet or a trip abroad. Despite the title, the ''Complete Guide'' is not really complete, and much of the message will be familiar to faithful readers of newspaper health columns. But it does provide useful ammunition to people trying to talk themselves and friends into taking care.

title: Deserving Students Promised Jobs
description: BUSINESS, church and community groups and educators have banded together in a consortium that will create job incentives designed to help students complete their high school education.

description: To the Editor: Having just returned from the same trek, I would urge anyone interested in going to talk to people who have trekked recently. That trail is a difficult one; mud slides wiped out some of the paths two years ago. The new ones are often harrowing.

description: HUMAN GENE THERAPY By Eve K. Nichols. Illustrated. 251 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $9.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: HYPOCHONDRIA: Woeful Imaginations. By Susan Baur. (University of California, $19.95.) An ancient and honorable disease, hypochondria received the solemn attention of authorities from Hippocrates to Freud. Distinguished victims, like Kant, Samuel Johnson, Darwin and Tennyson, suffered publicly with no loss of dignity.

title: HOW MAGNATES PICK PARTNERS
description: OVER THE DIN AT THE OYSTER Bar, the cavernous subterranean restaurant in New York's Grand Central Terminal, Philip F. Anschutz, the Denver oil baron, was being fed a proposal for a leveraged buyout of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Jerry M. Seslowe, one of his financial advisers, laid the figure of $6.5 billion on the table, a chilling amount even for a billionaire who had recently pocketed $500 million in cash from the sale of some energy properties.

title: THE DANGEROUS MARQUIS DE SADE
description: My wife is neither prudish nor anti-intellectual. Nevertheless, upon reading one of the works of the Marquis de Sade, she reacted in a way that has come to be regarded as typical of the complacent bourgeois mentality: without saying a word, and having gone through about one-third of the book, she flung the slim volume into the trash can and went straight to the bookshelves to look for a substitute - the apposite word might be antidote - for her interrupted reading.

title: Coney I. Opens Today Amid Hope of Revival
description: For Walter Williams, a former Marine sergeant who is now chief carpenter for the Cyclone at Coney Island in Brooklyn, this was the moment that could tell whether a winter's worth of carpentry, steel track repair and other maintenance on this 60-year-old roller coaster would pass the safety test.

title: Princeton Sweeps
description: The Princeton Tigers had more than a fair amount of success in foul weather today as they swept all their rowing races against Navy on the Severn River.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I had the outside of my house covered with light green aluminum siding 20 years ago. This color has faded and now looks dull and ugly, so now I want to paint this siding. Can it be painted and if so, is there a special process I must use? Will the siding have to be repainted regularly?

description: LEAD: OVER his last four seasons as director of Pepsico Summerfare, Christopher Hunt has put on numerous dramas. Briefly last month, he was also featured in one, a performance Mr. Hunt said he would rather not repeat.

description: MOST players think of suit combinations as kid stuff. They are indeed the basic building blocks of play, with more varieties, perhaps, than there are bridge players in the world to play them. But some of the combinations are quite deceptive, and difficult to analyze.

title: Catherine Du Bois To Marry in June
description: Catherine Jay Du Bois and Harold Augustus O'Callaghan 3d, a son of Mrs. and Mrs. O'Callaghan Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Adrienne Allen Du Bois of Rye, N.Y., and Dr. John Jay Du Bois of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced.

title: Bimonthly Is Distant Early Warning of the Far-Out
description: What the world didn't need, Eric Utne realized, was another magazine. So he founded the Utne Reader - a publication probably best described as the Swiss Army knife of New Age counterculture for people too busy to read magazines.

title: Karen Joachim Wed To David A. Sobotka

Joachim of Massapequa, L.I., was married in New York last evening to David Allen Sobotka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Sobotka of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi William Cohen officiated at the Plaza.

title: The Tug of War Ends in a Sudden Collapse
description: OF the preliminary world championship candidates matches in Saint John, New Brunswick, the one that most resembled a tug of war was that contested by the 36-year-old Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman and the 23-year-old Soviet grandmaster Valery Salov. Throughout the first five games of the six-game series, one player or the other seemed to have the upper hand, yet neither succeeded in capitalizing on anything.

title: Miss Stambolis Is Wed
description: The marriage of Maria Anastasia Stambolis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Takis Stambolis of New York, to Adam Prival Scher, the son of Jack O. Scher of Faber, Va., and Gloria Prival of New York, took place yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York. Judge George F. Roberts of the New York State Court of Claims performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. Mr. Scher is a photographer and a guitarist.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: Despite its lack of regimentation, A.A. works. More than three years ago, I learned that there is no single ''correct'' way to become, and to remain, sober. Some spend their days going from one meeting to another, others attend only one or two a month. At the meetings, some share their histories and their daily lives; some sit quietly and listen to the others.

description: AMERICAN officials are learning a basic history lesson from the mounting political and economic crisis in Panama: that just being on what they perceive as the right side of an issue is not enough to change the course of events.

title: New Hampshire Wary Of Offshore Sand Mines
description: Sand and gravel used in concrete, for roadway fill and to stem beach erosion is a resource Federal officials now regard as scarce.

title: Graf Beats Evert For Lipton Title
description: Forget the tentative Steffi Graf who was beaten by Gabriela Sabatini two weeks ago in Boca Raton and lost more points off her vaunted forehand than she won with it. Forget the up-and-down 18-year-old West German player who struggled with her game here in the early rounds of the $2.1 million, two-week Lipton International Players Championships.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ENERGY POLICY;
The U.S. Needs a New Strategy Now
