title: Fiction Fuels the Documentary
description: In Orson Welles's ''Citizen Kane,'' a journalist searches for the motivating force in the life of Charles Foster Kane, the newspaper tycoon. The result is a portentous ''March of Time'' type of documentary that, finally, misses the point. In Woody Allen's ''Zelig,'' which poses as a documentary about the life and times of the notorious ''Chameleon Man,'' the unmistakable figure of Mr. Allen (in the title role) is seen in old newsreel clip, peeking around Hitler to wave to a friend in the audience at a Nazi rally.

title: MAINE WINS SERIES TO GAIN FINAL FOUR
description: Mario Thyer, a freshman, scored the game-winner and Maine displayed strong defense in a 4-3 quarterfinal victory over Bowling Green.

title: Tennessee Advances to Final Four
description: Tennessee's 15-point halftime lead was cut to a point today before it beat Virginia, 84-76, in the East Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: THE YUPPIES OF MISSISSIPPI
description: As one who left the ''Great and Sovereign State of Mississippi'' following a number of painful experiences in 1964, I found little cause for joy in Peter J. Boyer's article ''The Yuppies of Mississippi'' (Feb. 28). Mississippi seems to have replaced rebel-flag-waving bigotry with the self-serving desire to achieve ''drastic change.''

title: 2 Charged With Murder of 5 In Supermarket in St. Louis
description: Two men have been charged with the murder of 5 supermarket employees in a robbery Sept. 4 in which 4 of the victims were shot in the back of the head after being ordered to lie on the floor.

title: Iona Football Plan Upsets Neighbors
description: THE greatest sound in the world to Peter Jensen, Iona quarterback, would be wild cheers from fans at a home game in New Rochelle. Right now, that is impossible.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: In football, instant replay has made the officials timid and has reduced their ability to control the game. It would be even less practical in baseball, giving managers another excuse to attack the umpire's authority. BRADLEY FINKELSTEIN Far Rockaway, Queens

title: 'Red Horizons'
description: To the Editor:

title: Salamander Tunnels Flunk First Test in Massachusetts
description: An attempt by townspeople to protect mating salamanders from being killed by cars has been thwarted - all but one of the amphibians has ignored tunnels installed for them beneath a busy street.

title: New Products to Prevent Accidental Needle Sticks
description: EXCEPT for the switch to disposable plastics, the design of the hypodermic syringe remains much as it was when Charles Pravaz, a French physician, invented it in 1853. Soon that will change.

title: POSTINGS: South Bronx Renovation; Mixed Rentals
description: A renovation of four adjacent city-owned buildings under way in the rubble-strewn South Bronx offers a mix of market and low-income rents and has drawn 1,000 applications for its 110 apartments, according to its developers. The large number of requests reflects not only the quality of the project but also the shortage of livable buildings in the area, said Brien O'Toole, executive director of the Mount Hope Housing Company, the nonprofit sponsor with FGK Development, a private company. ''It's much more sad than reassuring,'' he said.

title: Four Zoo Employees Test Positive for TB
description: Four San Diego Zoo employees tested positive for tuberculosis after they were exposed to infected monkeys.

title: Robinson Ready for Next Step
description: Bill Robinson is a black man who wants to be a baseball manager. He is serious enough about gaining experience that he managed in Latin America over the winter, picking up a roaring case of malaria as a souvenir.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ALL STRINGS

title: Machines That Cut the Mess to a Manageable Size
description: A NEW industry has been developed over the last few years by companies offering to handle infectious waste ''from cradle to grave,'' transporting the red-bag garbage in special plastic boxes and burning it in incinerators or autoclaving. Red-bag waste is estimated to account for 10 percent of a hospital's garbage, but it can account for more than half of the disposal budget.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Gatwick Gets New Terminal Nearly 30 years after opening the South Terminal at Gatwick Airport, Queen Elizabeth dedicated the new North Terminal there on March 18, and passengers were due to begin using the building last week.

title: On Seeking a Site For a 'City of God'
description: THE concept was big: a 300- or 400-acre walled ''City of God,'' with temples, canals, elephants and other beasts of burden.

title: IN AFGHANISTAN, THE OPPORTUNITIES FOR WAR ARE ENDLESS
description: CERTAINTIES are hard to come by here or in Peshawar, the unofficial capital of the 10 Afghan political groupings eager to seize control as soon as the Soviet Army leaves their country.

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: I had the wonderful experience of trekking in the Nepal Himalayas last fall. ''Preparing for Nepal's Rugged Reality'' by Marcia R. Lieberman (Travel, Feb. 21) was well done but omitted one important bit of advice for anyone about to embark on an experience of a lifetime. I discovered the most important item in my duffle bag was a Katadyn water filter. I stayed healthy during the entire trek to 16,000 feet and credit that to drinking lots of purified water. The filters are available for $200 postpaid from R.E.I. Recreational Equipment Inc., Post Office Box 88126, Seattle, Wash. 98138. JOY TIMKEN Canton, Ohio

title: Language and the Bible
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN FEAR CONQUERS
description: In his article ''When Fear Conquers'' (Feb. 28), Douglas Shenson has, in large measure, figured out the key to educating the nation about the dreaded disease AIDS. He has done so by asking us to reflect on our past behavior as we worked our way through the fear that accompanied another dreaded disease, leprosy. That's the kind of clear thinking that we have come to associate with heroes in this country. I hope we continue to hear from this young man. JEANNE FLOYD, R.N. Stewartstown, Pa.

title: Arms Cuts Need Thought
description: There isn't likely to be another arms reduction treaty ready for Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev to sign in Moscow in nine weeks.

title: STREETSCAPES: General Tire Building; 'Gas Station' Style: An Overlooked Gem of the 1930's
description: FOR the last several years, only an architectural detective would have noticed the building. Since the early 80's it has been boarded up, completely concealed under a uniform coat of white paint. But in the last year or so, the paint has peeled off, revealing a minor masterpiece of the 1930's, the Art Deco General Tire Building at 602 West 57th Street.

title: CHAOS WAS HIS OPPORTUNITY
description: WALDHEIM The Missing Years. By Robert Edwin Herzstein. Illustrated. 303 pp. New York: Arbor House/William Morrow & Company. $18.95.

title: Rousing Ride Via Computer
description: It is a car buff's dream. Here I am at the foot of a twisting-turn hill with five world-class automobiles at my disposal, and the object is to hop into one of them and get to the top as quickly as possible - without hurting myself or bending the machinery.

title: Belgians Get Look at Wartime Fascist Leader
description: Belgian television viewers were confronted recently with one of the darkest figures in the country's recent history, the Fascist leader Leon Degrelle.

title: Designing a Decent Alternative for the Homeless
description: A decade ago, when the number of homeless people in the City of New York was roughly a fifth of what the city estimates it to be today, this problem could not be seen in terms of architecture. It was more a matter of management, of helping people find what housing existed and getting them the money to pay for it. Now, things are entirely different - the combination of a vast increase in the number of homeless people and the continued loss through abandonment of older housing units has made the plight of the homeless a crisis that management alone cannot solve. The city desperately needs more housing units, and it must obtain them quickly.

title: Review/Concert; Cincinnati Symphony
description: With a history dating to 1895, the Cincinnati Symphony is the fifth-oldest orchestra in the country, and it has certainly had its share of conductorial glamour, with the likes of Stokowski and Reiner among its former directors. Yet its great conductors were always on their way to greater things, and in nearly a century, the Cincinnati has remained something of a steppingstone.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: I would like to share with your readers an experience I had in Zabreb. My wife and I were traveling through Yugoslavia last fall. In a hotel in Zagreb, at approximately 11 P.M., I started to shake and tremble. I became frightened and thought I had a heart attack. My wife called the desk and we were given a number to call for first aid. My wife called this number, and she was advised that there would be someone to see me within half an hour.

title: Correction
description: The caption under ''Riddle,'' by Bill Jensen, which accompanied an article about art prices in this section last week, failed to indicate that only part of the painting was reproduced. The full work is shown above.

title: Alla S. Wright, Banker, to Wed John Crowther
description: The engagement of Alla Steffen Wright to John Ernest Crowther, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Crowther of Menston, Yorkshire, England, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Willard M. Wright Jr. of Wynnewood, Pa.

title: Delay on Smoking Risk Research Is Faulted
description: The tobacco industry failed to exercise its moral responsibility to research the risks of smoking after independent studies in the 1930's began to link lung cancer to cigarettes, an epidemiologist testified in Federal District Court here this week.

title: Aladar Szegedy-Maszak, 84, Dies; Former-Hungarian Envoy to U.S.
description: Aladar Szegedy-Maszak, a Hungarian diplomat who resigned as Ambassador to Washington in 1947 in a rejection of Communist rule in his country, died Friday at his home in Washington after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Dance; Pieces by Burnside and McLaughlin
description: The program that Chris Burnside shared with Mickey McLaughlin and Dancers on Friday night at St. Mark's Church contained dances jammed with steps. Yet the most effective work was a monologue in which clever lines were heightened with a few well-chosen movements.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Pittsfield, Mass.;
The Cluster Alternatives
description: LEAD: TWO clustered housing developments went on the market recently in this city of 50,000, reflecting an emerging interest in alternatives to the neighborhoods of detached single-family homes that dominate the housing scene here.

title: Losing to Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ALLIGATOR CLOSES HER EYES
description: THE DANCE OF LIFE Courtship in the Animal Kingdom. By mark jerome Walters. Illustrated. 198 pp. New York: Arbor House/William Morrow & Company.

title: Simon Rattle Is On a Roll, and London Is Shaking
description: The growing reputa-tion of Simon Rattle as a leading young conductor in England has spread around the world, and it has given the industrial midland city of Birmingham a newly high profile abroad. But his success as principal conductor of the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra has also had a major impact on the orchestral scene in England itself.

title: The Peninsula by Car; Tijuana to Nopolo
description: TRAVEL in Baja California has eased considerably since the first Jesuits ventured up the peninsula by horse and mule in the 17th century founding missions, but several logistical details must still figure into exploring the Baja.

title:
GARDENING;
Growing Plants in Poorly Drained Soil
description: LEAD: WHEN a gardener complains of having wet soil or poor drainage, a professional horticulturalist will almost instinctively suggest that it be drained. Seldom is the alternative suggested: Use plants that thrive in poorly drained soil.

title: Stanley of Red Sox On Disabled List
description: Bob Stanley, the right-handed pitcher, and Ellis Burks, a center fielder, were placed on the disabled list today by the Boston Red Sox.

title: Eating in France
description: To the Editor: On a recent stay in Paris we revisited both Chez Albert and Le Petit Zinc and were not disappointed in either spot. However, we would like to inform readers that the telephone number for Le Petit Zinc, which appeared in an article about Paris restaurants (Travel, Oct. 25), which we saved, is no longer in service. The new number is 46.33.51.66. Readers should also be advised that reservations are suggested.

title: A Pyramid in Paris
description: THE CONTROVERSY HIT LONG before the first bulldozers. In 1983, President Francois Mitterrand of France used his authority to engage the Chinese-born American I.M. Pei as architect for the much-needed renovation of the Louvre; and when Pei's sleekly contemporary design emerged, it generated public outrage on both political and cultural grounds.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CELEBRATION OF O'NEILL Eugene O'Neill's centennial is being observed by the Yale Repertory Theater and a stellar company of performers, directors and designers.

title: 200 POLITICIANS DEAL FOR ONE TRADE BILL
description: REPRESENTATIVE John D. Dingell emerged from a recent closed-door meeting with his arm draped around the shoulders of Representative John Bryant. Moments later, he warmly greeted Treasury Secretary James Baker in a Capitol corridor, and the door of Mr. Dingell's office closed behind the two.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: PSEUDO-SCIENCE AND SOCIETY IN NINETEENTH-CENTURY AMERICA. Edited by Arthur Wrobel. (University Press of Kentucky, $24.) It isn't easy to find good things to say about pseudo-science, but Arthur Wrobel and the contributors to this volume manage to. The authors suggest that much of what we ridicule as pseudoscience was closely allied with major cultural movements of the 19th century and provided impetus for a revolution in scientific methodology.

title: Baker Sees No Pardon Before the North Trial
description: The White House chief of staff, in an interview broadcast today, said he thought it was ''highly unlikely'' that President Reagan would issue a pretrial pardon for former aides indicted in the Iran-contra scandal.

title: A Playland Commission Gains Ground
description: LEAD: AS the recent charges of mismanagement at Playland are investigated, many county leaders are saying they want a revaluation of the Playland Commission, the five-member citizens group that for years ran the county-owned amusement park in Rye.

title: English Trifle: Serious Dessert
description: HEDGEHOG pudding, fruit creams, tansies, syllabubs, flummeries, junkets, trifles: not just one, but all of these fancifully named sweets would have adorned an English banquet table in the 18th century. The English still love their desserts, even in this era of heightened calorie and cholesterol consciousness. But the only survivor of that banquet table is the rich cold pudding known as trifle. A layered melange of sponge cake soaked in drink (sherry, brandy or both), covered with jam, custard and cream, it is the quintessential English dessert.

title: The Music of Easter Abounds
description: SINCE 1960, the Presbyterian Church of Bedford has conducted a 7 A.M. Easter service on the village green in front of the church, as it will do this year. ''It's a simple, quiet service, celebrating first light, surrounded by historic churches and an ancient cemetery where English settlers are buried; listening to Scripture readings and guitar music, and singing together,'' said Timothy Wagner, lay assistant to the minister and organizer of the event.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: The score is tied at 3-3, it's the last half of the ninth, runner on second base. Here comes the pitch: a hit to centerfield . . . runner is on the way home . . . the throw from center field . . . batter slides . . . the umpire calls the batter out. Extra innings. Wait. The home-team manager asks for instant replay. Analysts say the batter was safe. Score, 4-3. Game over. Visiting team's fans start a riot. Bottles are thrown toward the replay booth, etc.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Is Minimum-Floor-Area Zoning Legal?
description: DEPENDING upon how the residential land is zoned, how many bedrooms are planned, the lot size and various local regulations in 115 of Connecticut's 169 towns, the minimum size of a house may vary from 600 to 1,800 square feet.

title: Elizabeth Kline to Wed John H. Mullan in June
description: Elizabeth Chapman Kline, an associate in the New York law firm of Emmet, Marvin & Martin, and John Hugh Mullan, the deputy general counsel of the Grumman Corporation in Bethpage, L.I., plan to marry June 19.

title: Missile Raid on Teheran Resumes 'War of Cities'
description: Iraq said it fired two long-range missiles into Teheran today, and Iran said its fighter-bombers attacked Iraqi troops in a battle for a strategic region in northeastern Iraq.

title: L.I. Sound Gains Title And Funds
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND will be designated an ''estuary of national significance'' in ceremonies tomorrow, guaranteeing Federal financing for the Long Island Sound Study until at least 1991.

title: Albany Notes; Cuomo Orders Housing Figures Inquiry
description: Governor Cuomo, whose administration was found this week to have overstated by 500 percent the number of housing units created by the state during his five years in office, has ordered an inquiry into the accuracy of his housing division's figures and into the way it compiles them.

title: Righting English
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
Do-It-Yourself Guide to a Nursery
description: LEAD: AS an owner of a large Connecticut retail nursery until my recent retirement, I watched uninitiated homeowners shop. Sometimes they were intimidated or bewildered by the maze of botanical lingo they heard and the often confusing array of seedlings and plants, which they found for sale.

title: Amy Lessler Engaged To C. W. Freeman 3d
description: Amy Lynne Lessler, a market analyst at the Polaroid Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., and Charles Wellman Freeman 3d, the controls coordinator for Paine Webber Properties in Boston, plan to be married in July. Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Lessler of Fairfield, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Jr. of Washington.

title: The Airlines Tackle Pilot Error
description: JOHN K. LAUBER SLIPS A CASSETTE INTO THE video cassette recorder and fiddles with the controls. ''Now, watch this,'' he says, stepping back, excitement in his voice. Dr. Lauber, a psychologist and a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, has shown this tape before. But the intensity that comes over him as the green image of a Boeing 747 swims up on the screen is striking.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lisbon, Me.; New Vitality By the River
description: ABOUT $80 million in public and private money has been invested in the last five years in new manufacturing plants, businesses, homes and public works in this town of 13,000 people nestled beside the Androscoggin River.

title: The Focal Point of Duke's Journey to the Final Four
description: Out on the court, Danny Ferry had helped slice the net from the orange rim, and now he was searching the faces of Duke fans in a corner of Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THE GOSPEL ACCORING TO JOY
description: WHEN BILL JOY WAS GROWING up in Farmington, Mich., his father taught him the rudiments of chess. Young Bill then read every book he could find on the subject and developed a powerful game, yet his father and younger brother, Bob, could sometimes still defeat him. ''He played 20 moves ahead to our two or three,'' Bob Joy recalls, ''and analyzed our moves far too deeply.''

title: Macon Has Company in His Misery
description: It wasn't easy for Howard Evans to watch. Mark Macon, his friend and backcourt partner for Temple, was living out a nightmare of air balls as the Owls' hopes of a trip to the Final Four were deflated by Duke, 63-53, in the East Regional final today.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Learning About Federal Furniture
description: LEAD: FEDERAL furniture is a confusing nomenclature, referring more broadly to a time than to a specific style. Nevertheless, there are sufficient stylistic characteristics attached to the period from 1780 to 1820 to make the study of Federal furniture a viable enterprise.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: ''Objective'' explanations of the A.A. program are informative. But ''gritty'' facts cannot communicate the essential truth of the program. Bill Wilson and Bob Smith changed the world, not only for alcoholics, but for families and friends of alcoholics - Al-Anon and ACOA (Adult Children of Alcoholics) -gamblers (Gamblers Anonymous), drug addicts (Narcotics Anonymous), people with eating disorders (Overeaters Anonymous) and scores of others who find they need a program of recovery. CAROLE P. Wilton, Conn. NOTE: Members of Alcoholics Anonymous are generally identified by their first name and last initial.

title: What of the Canal?
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislative Process: The Name Is the Game
description: THE legislative process is always interesting to watch when the two houses are controlled by different political parties, but bickering last week between the leadership of the State Senate and Assembly almost stopped the process dead in its tracks.

title: SHULTZ WILL MAKE NEW MIDEAST TRIP
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will visit the Middle East beginning April 3 in a new attempt to persuade Israeli and Arab leaders to accept his plan for a peace settlement, the State Department said today.

title: For Holy Week - Celebrations in Music
description: LEAD: HOLY WEEK - the eight days from today, Palm Sunday, through Easter - is the most significant time on the Christian calendar, as well as a time that has inspired some of the most creative and passionate musical compositions.

title: INDIAN POLITICIAN KILLED IN CAROLINA
description: A Lumbee Indian who was a candidate for Superior Court judge in racially troubled Robeson County was found shot to death today at his home, officials said.

title: REGIME IN PANAMA SEIZES FLOUR MILLS AND CANAL DOCKS
description: The Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, combining military muscle and threats of legal action, moved swiftly today to force an end to the economic paralysis that has gripped Panama for weeks.

title: Dukakis and Bush; WHY THE CANDIDATES LOVE TO BE ENDORSED
description: THE conventional wisdom of Presidential politics is that flowery endorsements from fellow politicians don't mean much.

title: Habitats, Not Cages; ZOOS TRY CONJURING SOME DISAPPEARING BITS OF WILDERNESS
description: ZOOS have come a long way since they housed their pitiful inmates in bare cells.

title: What Happened to the Revolving Door
description: THE CLOSING BELL AT the New York Stock Exchange had not even sounded on Black Monday before Wall Street was blaming the Reagan Administration and Congress for provoking the crash with out-of-control budgets and deliberate debasement of the dollar. Washington, meanwhile, was accusing the investment banking crowd, with its megabillion-dollar mergers and exotic trading techniques, of turning our capital markets into one gigantic casino. At a time of crisis, it seemed as if the level of constructive talk between the country's political and financial power brokers had sunk to a new low.

title: WHO'S MINDING THE STORE
description: For more than 30 years my father worked in Filene's, the Boston department store. As I look back, it seems important that he worked ''in'' Filene's, or ''with'' Filene's. I don't think I ever heard him say he worked ''for'' Filene's. There was a spirit of identification - a sense of family, to risk sounding maudlin - that the store's employees seemed to share.

title: Yankees Are Settling on a Team Amid Relative Calm
description: The first 37 days of Billy Martin's latest comeback have been eerily quiet, as if this were any other spring camp with any other team. The fact that it is the Yankees - with their volatile owner and unpredictable manager - makes it unusual, as if this serene feeling simply cannot last.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Corporate Relocation; Bright Lights, Big City: More Firms Staying Put
description: OVER the past year New York City has been rattled by the corporate exodus of such giants as J. C. Penney & Company and the threatened defections of such companies as NBC and Integrated Resources.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: One day a world championship will be determined by a wrong call. Why not make the change before that happens? CHARLES A. KROLOFF Westfield, N.J.

title: Muskrat Hunting Issue Is Polarizing Delaware
description: Every Wednesday during the season is muskrat night at the Wagon Wheel restaurant along U.S. 13, the main highway through this town.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: BEFORE FREUD: Neurasthenia and the American Medical Community, 1870-1910. By F. G. Gosling. (University of Illinois, $22.95.) No one was nervous before the late 18th century - the appropriate temperament had not yet been invented - but 100 years later just about everyone's nerves were exhausted.

title:
GARDENING;
Growing Plants in Poorly Drained Soil
description: LEAD: When a gardener complains of having wet soil or poor drainage, a professional horticulturalist will almost instinctively suggest that it be drained. Seldom is the alternative suggested: Use plants that thrive in poorly drained soil.

title: Q&A
description: Hungary Question:I have heard conflicting accounts from friends about the amount of Hungarian currency that must be purchased by visitors to Hungary. Can you enlighten me? What is the time involved in getting a visa? Is a visa required for Austria as well? -R. R., Buffalo Answer:Hungarian officials say there is no requirement to purchase a specified amount of Hungarian currency. There used to be, but it was discontinued in 1978. A spokesman for the government's Hungarian Travel Bureau said visitors may take a maximum of 100 forints a person - about $2 - in coins, not bills, into Hungary, and must leave all forints behind when they leave. Dollars and traveler's checks may be converted into Hungarian money at border crossings, international airports, banks, hotels and state tourist offices. It is not recommended that travelers buy forints ahead of time, the bureau spokesman said.

title: The Shapes of Things to Come
description: DESPITE the vast changes that have taken place within 35-millimeter cameras in the last 10 years, including a dramatic shift from mechanical to electronic controls, the outsides have stayed pretty much the same. The typical camera body is still a pudgy rectangle about the size of a deli ham sandwich with a lens stuck in the middle.

title: 2 Children and 4 Adults Die In a Fire at a Newark House
description: In one of the worst fires in recent Newark history, six people were killed and six others were injured early yesterday when flames swept through a three-story frame house in the Central Ward, fire officials said.

title: Opulence Yields to Stethoscopes
description: To the casual observer, the scene being filmed would appear to be nothing special. Yet, something surprising is happening.

title: Concerns That Decide the Price Is Right
description: HOW much is it worth? When it comes to real estate, the value often is not determined by the seller or the buyer but by the mortgage lender. Banks, which once relied upon their own officers to inspect properties and set a fair-market value before granting mortgages, now pay fees to real-estate appraisal companies to perform the service.

title: A Small Primary Becomes a Main Event
description: THE long and crowded race to the White House makes an important stop in Connecticut on Tuesday, when the state holds what will be the only presidential preference primary in the nation this week.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Add instant replay and all you do is add more time for televised beer commercials. MICHAEL J. VITUCCI Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Judge Rules Couple Can't Keep Tiger
description: A Darien couple will not be allowed to keep a partially blind, epileptic tiger in their home, a Federal judge ruled this week.

title: New York Needs More Facilities
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
A Beneficiary of Tax Revision
description: LEAD: TO H & R Block, the cries of anguish echoing across the land as April 15 approaches are like a heavenly choir. The largest preparer of individual Federal income tax returns - 10 percent of the nation's 105 million filers are expected to troop into one of Block's 7,500 offices - expects another year of rising profits.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: REPRESENTATIVES James A. Courter, Republican of Hackettstown, and Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Hackensack, will debate ''Trade and Economic Growth'' tomorrow at the headquarters of Silver Burdett & Ginn Inc., a publishing company, 250 James Street, Morristown.

title: SCHOOL FOR HANDICAPPED WORKS MIRACLES OF HOPE
description: The Feb. 21 article about the Little Village School did a pretty good job of portraying all handicapped children as being helpless and without any hope for a normal life. While it started out as sounding positive with the title ''Here, Small Steps of Hope,'' by the time one was finished reading it, it seemed like a hopeless tale of woe.

title: Three Crows Cause a Neighbor to Take Flights of Fancy
description: They've been there all winter, cackling from their favorite tree-top turret. I've usually ignored their presence, regarding the ubiquitous trio as a comforting sign that all is well in Larchmont, musing on the shrill diatribe hurled in my direction once they spy my plodding through the icy slush every morning.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE OPEN DOOR;
COMMUNITY HEALTH CLINIC KEEPS GROWING IN OSSINING
description: LEAD: THE Open Door Family Health Center is opening another door. The 16-year-old medical organization is housed in an ornate, 19th-century building at 165 Main Street here. This month, the center bought the neighboring Ross Building - a quaint-looking structure, faced in clapboard and adorned with the date ''1868'' - for $260,000.

title: Ronald D. Sernau Is Wed To Stephanie Anne Wiley
description: Stephanie Anne Wiley and Ronald David Sernau, graduates of the Cornell University Law School, were married last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y., by Rabbi Sandy Bogin.

title: Miss Lacey to Wed Pedro de Azambuja
description: The engagement of Michelle Diane Lacey to Pedro Castrioto de Azambuja, a son of Malu Futscher Pereira of Lisbon and Marcos C. de Azambuja of Geneva and Rio de Janeiro, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Paule R. Jensen of Seattle and Brussels and Gerald A. Lacey of Lexington, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: Review/Recital; FISCHER-DIESKAU SINGS MAHLER PROGRAM
description: The second solo recital in Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau's Carnegie Hall engagement found the baritone in tremendous form Thursday, careening through the colorfully populated landscapes of ''Des Knaben Wunderhorn'' with a zest and command that made for an unforgettable evening.

title: INSIDE
description: Striking the Chambers Deal

title: Venture Capital
description: When Congress eliminated the favorable treatment of capital gains in 1986, many thought it would hurt venture capital companies' ability to raise money. The Oct. 19 stock market collapse also caused alarm. But venture capital funds have more money than ever. What is the outlook for this industry? CHET BORGIDA Director of capital markets group, Grant Thornton.

title: DATA UPDATE: March 27, 1988
Jackson Campaign, Up From Chaos, Gets the Most Out of Fewest Dollars
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign has won more delegates for less money than any of his competitors. It has done so by merging the passion of a political movement with some of the modern techniques of campaign management.

title: TAKING A LEAP INTO OLD AGE
description: AFTER THE STROKE A Journal. By May Sarton. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95.

title: New York vs. London
description: To the Editor:

title: Colleges Fighting Growth in Prejudice
description: BIGOTRY has been reported on the rise on New Jersey college campuses, and school leaders from across the state are beginning to do something about it.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: MESSENGERS OF PARADISE. Opiates and the Brain: The Struggle Over Pain, Rage, Uncertainty, and Addiction. By Charles F. Levinthal. (Anchor/Doubleday, $17.95.) There are chemicals in the brain that send messages that cause us to feel joy. Other substances, like morphine, happen to resemble these chemicals, which is why they are addictive.

title: Beate G. Kessler and Charles N. McDermott Weds
description: Beate Gertraud Kessler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Siegfried A. Kessler of New York and Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married at St. Paul's German Lutheran Church in New York yesterday to Charles Neil McDermott, a son of Mrs. Charles H. McDermott of Worcester, Mass., and the late Mr. McDermott. The Rev. Soenke Schmidt-Lange, the pastor of the church, and the Rev. Joachim von Kerssenbrock, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORK LEADERS FAULT BILL ON BIAS
description: A range of top New York City officials has criticized a proposal to create a special crime category for bias-related incidents, calling the measure too narrow and difficult to enforce.

title: Icons From an Era When Screens Were Silver And Silents Were Golden
description: The cinema is an art that thrives on legend, but it took time for it to develop legends of its own. In the beginning it borrowed themes and motifs from the other popular arts, from well-established traditions in fiction, the theater, vaudeville, genre painting; and if early movies seemed thrillingly modern when they first appeared, with the passage of time one of their most interesting aspects has become the way in which they frequently preserve the spirit of the 19th century.

title: WHEN FEAR CONQUERS
description: I lived in Louisiana in the mid-1970's and had the opportunity to visit Carville on one occasion. I was struck by three things about the place - a sort of decaying beauty, an ethereal quiet and an overwhelming sense of isolation. At the time, I felt that Carville was in decline and that there would never be a need for another place like it again.

title: Great Is Great, Old or New
description: It must seem sometimes to lovers of classi-cal music that all the old verities are crumbling under their feet. Critics pontificate about the fate of classical music, suggesting that it may not have a future in this age of pop and electronics and cultural upheaval. Composers freight concert programs with unlistenable exercises in modernist rigor or cheesy crossover pastiches. Early-music performers nibble forward into the core repertory like eager mice.

title: Nicole Sinek Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Herbert Sinek of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Irene Sinek, to Leo Peter Arnaboldi 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnaboldi Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to be May 28.

title: SCHOOL FOR THE HANDICAPPED WORKS MIRACLES OF HOPE
description: I was deeply touched by the article ''Here, Small Steps of Hope.'' As a parent of a child who attends the Little Village School, I have nothing but praise for this wonderful place.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: No. No. No. Can no sport be left as originally played? There is enough analysis of every pitch, every swing of the bat, every move of the players. ALICE SCHREIBER Stamford, Conn.

title:
ART;
Paper: Medium With a Message
description: LEAD: THE uniform, mass-produced newsprint on which these words are written is a far cry from the idiosyncratic, handmade material featured in ''Paper/Process,'' the current exhibition at the Anthony Giordano Gallery at Dowling College in Oakdale. In the hands of the five artists selected by Catherine Valenza, a Dowling graduate and the show's guest curator, paper is exploited for its sculptural and expressive qualities, becoming more than just a neutral vehicle for applied imagery.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, the telephone number for the state's AIDS hot line was incorrect in an article last week on AIDS education campaigns. The number is 1-800-624-2377.

title: THAT'S MY LINE
description: THE FIRST COMMERCIAL TELEPHONE RESEMBLED A clunky box camera. Designed in 1877 by Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Watson, it cost what was then a princely sum: $20 a year in two advance installments. In relative terms, telephones can now be just as pricey, but they also do much more. Many function as secretaries, having built-in answering machines and memories that record the time of a call or automatically dial a series of preprogrammed numbers. Still others come with facsimile machines that double as home copiers. But regardless of its many capabilities, the telephone also has become a sophisticated design object. ''Twenty-three million telephones are now sold in America a year,'' says Paul I. Becker, president of Becker Inc., a company that represents several telephone manufacturers. ''And many of them are not just technologically sophisticated, they're also esthetically appealing.'' Available in a host of models, colors and materials, and created by well-known architects and designers, these telephones often transcend home or business necessity; they have become telling expressions of decorative taste.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: 'JESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR' ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' the Andrew LLoyd Webber-Tim Rice musical that depicts the last days of Jesus, will open Wednesday at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn.

title: New York's Urban League, Riddled by Debt, Searches for Aid
description: The New York Urban League, hobbled by debts, is seeking contributions from corporations, foundations and individuals to help the 69-year-old social service agency survive and continue to assist the city's disadvantaged.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about development of the New Haven waterfront quoted a word incorrectly in a comment from Pamela Wuerth, director of Schooner Inc., the environmental education organization. She said, ''And beginning this spring, Schooner's sailing research vessel, the J. N. Carter, will be able to dock in front of our building for the first time in five years.''

title: AUGUST WILSON'S VOICES FROM THE PAST
description: There was a time when Au-gust Wilson - a playwright whose reputation is built on his facility for capturing the poetic richness of the language of ordinary black America - did not know how to get his characters to speak.

title: Where The Cactus Meets the Sea
description: ONE of the first things I noticed as we landed in Los Cabos, the airport at the southernmost tip of the Baja California peninsula, was the cloud of vultures darkening the sky at the end of the runway. The opportunity for metaphor, or message, was obvious.

title: Beth L. Winnick, A Student, Weds
description: Beth Lara Winnick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Winnick of Woodbridge, Conn., was married last evening to Michael Louis Falcone, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Falcone of Baltimore. Rabbi Steven Mason and Nicholas Feurer, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Woodbridge Country Club.

title: Marymount Presents a Show on the Ins and Outs of Weaving
description: LEAD: A resurgence of interest in weaving is reflected in the growth of the Handweavers Guild of Westchester, which was begun in 1963 by eight weavers who wanted to share their expertise. The guild now has about 100 members, including weavers from Rockland County and Connecticut as well as Westchester.

title: Kathleen Carney, Medical Student, To Wed in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stephen P. Carney of Easton, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Kathleen Carney, to Dr. Frederick A. Godley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Godley Jr. of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and New Canaan, Conn.

title: Cries of 'Murderer' in the Rain
description: As protesters, neighbors, reporters and the curious looked on in a soft, steady rain, Robert E. Chambers Jr. left his home yesterday, stepped into a black Cadillac and headed off to jail.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: MOTHERS AND MEDICINE: A Social History of Infant Feeding, 1890-1950. By Rima D. Apple. (University of Wisconsin, Cloth, $39.50; Paper, $16.25.) A 1907 advertisement for Mellin's Food for the Baby tells much of the story. In it a baby on the left, which has been nursed at the breast, is at best a third of the size of its twin on the right, ''raised on Mellin's Food.

title: Bullets' Reserves Topple Nets
description: Frank Johnson and Mark Alarie, both reserves, combined for 25 points tonight to help the Washington Bullets to a 99-88 victory over the Nets.

title: Endgame With Moscow
description: It would be surprising if White House strategists weren't looking hard at the last months of the Administration. Most likely, they are talking about final moves with Moscow - on Afghanistan, strategic nuclear arms and Nicaragua. And all this in the context of President Reagan's role in history and the upcoming Presidential election.

title: Anthony Murphy Wed To Susan Strothmann
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Susan Jean Strothmann, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Derek Strothmann of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony John Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Murphy of Craftsbury Common, Vt. The Rev. Stanley Moseley performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
Growing Plants in Poorly Drained Soil
description: LEAD: WHEN a gardener complains of having wet soil or poor drainage, a professional horticulturalist will almost instinctively suggest that it be drained. Seldom is the alternative suggested: Use plants that thrive in poorly drained soil.

title: Do Iowa Presidential Caucuses Go On When Television Lights Are Off?
description: Iowa answered the age-old question about the tree falling in the deserted forest today. Even without the national press, the network crews, the out-of-town pundits and the pollsters, Iowans gathered once again to voice their Presidential preferences in a second round of caucuses.

title: Spring's Green Fuse Ignites the Garden
description: I THINK of the seasonal changes as subtle and incremental over long periods of time, like the color of the marsh grass on the harbor meadows, just now showing a tentative touch of green.

title: Jane L. Fishman Weds Executive
description: Jane Leslie Fishman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Fishman of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., was married last evening to Efraim Grinberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gedalio Grinberg of New York. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe, assisted by Cantor Isaac Wall, performed the ceremony at Har Zion Temple in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: 'JUST PLAIN SCARED'
description: LEAD: IN MAY 16, 1944, I TURNED 35. I WAS president of the Pepsodent Company in Chicago. Sitting across from my desk that day was Frederick M. Peyser, Sr., a partner of the old New York investment banking firm of Hallgarten & Company.

title: How Many Terms Is One Too Many?
description: IN a recent interview with David Frost, President Reagan indicated that on leaving office he intends to lobby for repeal of the 22nd Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: OVERPOWERING THE SCENT MARKET
description: EVERY NIGHT WHEN CARL SCHAAB RETURNS FROM WORK to his New Jersey home, his wife gives him a kiss - and a sniff. If her husband smells as though he has been romping with several women, each wearing a different fragrance, then all is well. Wanda Schaab can be sure he spent the day at work.

title: Program Gives Support To Alzheimer's Victims
description: Eight elderly men and women sat quietly in a semicircle, chopping vegetables for the borscht they were to eat for lunch, when one of them struck up a Yiddish tune made popular by the Andrews Sisters in the 1930's.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Garden City Victorian Being Relocated
description: LEAD: ONE of Garden City's grand old houses is about to be moved for the second time in 116 years and start a new life as a museum and community center. In its new role, the house will continue to be a reminder of the legacy of the village's founder, Alexander T. Stewart.

title: Mary Rutherford Engaged To Jared Tobin Finkelstein
description: Mary Elizabeth Rutherford and Jared Tobin Finkelstein plan to be married in May, the future bride's parents, Patricia J. Rutherford of Albuquerque, N.M., and William I. Rutherford of St. Louis, have announced. Mr. Finkelstein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Finkelstein of New York.

title: Ghost Train
description: To the Editor: It's too bad the confused passengers on the Ambus missed their meal at the Polka Dot Cafe around the corner from the railroad station in White River Junction. We had breakfast there after spending the night across the street at the Hotel Coolidge. After gorging ourselves on muffins and the bottomless cups of coffee, we purchased a bagful to fortify us on our journey. JUNE OLIANSKY Brooklyn

title: New Suffolk Ponders 'Progress'
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT pressures on New Suffolk, in the Town of Southold on the North Fork, could in the next few weeks determine the tiny hamlet's future. The hamlet is so small that the town does not keep records on the number of residents; the combined year-round population of Cutchogue-New Suffolk is 2,864.

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: DORIS LILLY answered her telephone recently and was, as she put it, ''paralyzed with disbelief.'' A disembodied voice announced that it was the billing department of a major hospital, requested that she hold the line and assured her that a representative would be with her in a minute. She's almost certain the pronouncement was followed by music, but she wouldn't swear to it because she was still in a small state of shock about being called by a message machine.

title: For Surgeons, Gloves of Brass Chain Mail
description: AMONG those who fear infectious diseases the most are surgeons who can be exposed to large amounts of blood while operating. ''A small minority of surgeons refuse to operate on AIDS patients,'' said Dr. Edward Quebbeman of Milwaukee, a member of the Committee on the Operating Room Environment of the American College of Surgeons. ''Some surgeons have a pathological fear and take exaggerated preventative measures.'' He said he heard of surgeons taking AZT, a drug used to treat AIDS, before before operating, adding, ''Of course, it has no benefit.''

title: A Veiled Threat
description: TWELVE-FOOT-HIGH walls. Steel gates. Dogs and armed guards. Inside, cool, high-ceilinged old houses, oases of green lawns, servants slipping noiselessly about - and women. For six weeks last spring I went from one feudal family compound to another in Pakistan. And always it was the same. Glasses of pomegranate juice. Trollies bearing chilies and curries. The men in the family coming in and out of the compounds. The women staying inside.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: MARCH 27, 1988
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Dell, $4.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of the 60's on his way to the 80's. 2 5 BOUND BY DESIRE, by Rosemary Rogers. (Avon, $4.95.) An untamed rogue pursues a maiden in the 19th century. 3 3 OVER THE EDGE, by Jonathan Kellerman. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) A psychologist-detective solves a string of vicious murders. 4 8 DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $4.95.) A couple's 30-year romance. 5 3 TEXASVILLE, by Larry McMurtry. (Pocket, $4.95.) These figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Rangers Rally On 4 Late Goals
description: Phil Esposito, the general manager of the Rangers, was halfway out the door of the jubilant locker room before he turned, and began to try and address his team.

title: Iranians' Strike Isn't the Feared Winter Offensive
description: Iran's attack into northeastern Iraq last week was a tactical success, but is of little strategic importance, according to both American and Iraqi military experts.

title: Robert Plant: White Bread Or Visionary?
description: ''White, clean and neat'' - that's the way Robert Plant recalls his childhood in the mid-50's, in the song of the same name that concludes his new album, ''Now and Then'' (Esparanza/Atlantic 790863 LP, cassette and compact disk). He remembers Pat Boone singing mellifluous bromides to ''Take Daddy's Blues Away,'' and Debbie Reynolds, and Johnny Ray, all ''sugar, sugar white clean and neat.''

title: Review/Dance; The Rhythms of Spain By Del Conte Company
description: Because some of its forms make use of castanets and stampings, Spanish dance can be an art of sound as well as sight. But sounds and sights were occasionally blurred in the program that Andrea Del Conte and the American Spanish Dance Theater gave Thursday night at the Triplex Theater of Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: 'Rose Tattoo' Gets an Extended Run
description: As popular music changed in the 1950's, with rock 'n' roll evolving from such traditional black forms as rhythm and blues, black musicians went on composing and playing in the old and new styles.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: No. The players aren't perfect so why should the umpires be? HEATHER BROWN New York

title: AN ANGLER'S RITES OF SPRING
description: IT WAS A WEEKLY TUESDAY LUNCH AT Cafe 43 in Manhattan, the home of the esteemed Theodore Gordon Flyfishers. And as surely as the mayflies hatch on the hallowed surface of the Beaverkill River in the third week of April, thoughts turned - as they invariably do among fishermen sounding the depths of winter - to spring.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I had the outside of my house covered with light green aluminum siding 20 years ago. This color has faded and now looks dull and ugly, so now I want to paint this siding. Can it be painted and if so, is there a special process I must use? Will the siding have to be repainted regularly?

title: Unseemly Behavior
description: The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, the former White House aide who spent seven months in jail for his part in the Watergate scandal, just kind of naturally perks up when talk turns to ethics. So Mr. Magruder, who was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1981, seemed delighted when civic leaders in Columbus, Ohio, recently asked him to head a Commission on Values and Ethics. The commission was an outgrowth of meetings among Columbus leaders who were appalled last October by the spectacle of hundreds of people scooping up about $1 million in cash that had fallen from an armored car. Mr. Magruder said his ministerial studies helped qualify him to head the panel. ''I took on as kind of my issue - because of Watergate, I'm sure - the issue of ethics,'' he said.

title: U.S. Policy Is Assailed By Mexican President
description: President Miguel de la Madrid has charged the Reagan Administration with emphasizing might over diplomacy in its Central American policy, at a high cost in death and destruction.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: CRIME
description: About two years ago Irving Weinman, in his first novel, ''Tailor's Dummy,'' introduced Detective Inspector Lenny Schwartz of the New York Police Department. Schwartz had some unusual things going for him. He was a Harvard graduate. He was literate. He was smart. He was likable. He also at one time had taken a bribe in order to send his son through college, and that was something always at the nasty end of his subconscious - and his conscious, for that matter.

title:
DINING OUT;
American Cuisine in Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: Open four months, The Good Life not only shows promise but brings to the area light new American cooking that just escapes being trendy. While this newcomer is most welcome, one has the impression that the place should be and, with a little more practice, could be better than it is. The items on the small menu indicate that the kitchen has the imagination to venture beyond currently fashionable preprations to more ambitious renditions; however, at this time, good as they are, dishes manage to be successful only in part.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Selinsgrove, Pa.;
Home Projects In a Rural Area
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has started at a home development called Breezewood Forest just west of this Susquehanna River town in central Pennsylvania. The first major subdivision to be approved in the area since 1985, it will have 44 single-family houses and 110 town houses.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Food Drive's Results
description: LEAD: The Spring Harvest Food Drive is over, but its yield is just beginning to benefit the hungry. Since mid-March 58,700 cans of food have been collected from 81 schools countywide, sorted by members of five Junior Leagues and distributed to 38 soup kitchens and food pantries throughout Westchester, according to Sherrie Jossen, communications coordinator for the Junior League of Central

title: Sandinistas and Contras, Wearied By Their War, Make Their Own Peace
description: WHEN negotiations between the Nicaraguan Government and rebel leaders opened Monday morning at the southern border outpost of Sapoa, a group of visiting Americans was on hand to offer moral support to the Sandinistas, none quite believing that this was really happening. As the contras touched Nicaraguan soil legally for the first time in years, one of the visitors called out, ''The North American people want a cease-fire.'' Aristides Sanchez, a member of the contra directorate, turned and replied, ''So do we, believe me.''

title: A Failure of Communications
description: HOUSE OF DREAMS The Bingham Family of Louisville. By Marie Brenner. Illustrated. 452 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Article 082388 -- No Title
description: AT 9:30 A.M. LAST OCT. 19, CLIFTON R. WHARTON JR. ENTERED the ornate ballroom of the Westgate Hotel in San Diego where he proposed to deliver a brief talk. Only a few minutes earlier, he had learned of the tumult in New York: The stock market had dropped by more than 170 points and was heading south. Before the day was done, the Dow Jones Industrial Average would plunge by more than 500 points and the value of the securities traded on the New York Stock Exchange would shrink by more than $500 billion.

title: Easter Music, With New Notes
description: LEAD: WITH the start of Holy Week today, the Island's churches will be alive with the sound of music for the next week. And while, as expected, Handel's ''Hallelujah Chorus'' from ''The Messiah'' and Faure's ''Palms'' dominate the scene, there are a few surprises in the offing.

title: Wrestling Meet For U.S., Cuba
description: A United States team led by the former world champion Bruce Baumgartner and two-time National Collegiate Athletic Association champion Royce Alger will meet the Cuba national wrestling team in a dual meet Thursday at Edinboro University.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart on March 6 about the dollar's reach abroad carried obsolete information about a Viennese restaurant. The establishment, Restaurant Mattes, closed last July.

title: Plisetskaya - Ballerina in Search of Choreography
description: Sarah Caldwell has called her extraordinary American-Soviet festival in Boston ''Making Music Together,'' but as any anthropologist will tell you, man moved before he sang. And so it is only natural that dance is also - through Maya Plisetskaya's participation - a major component of this festival.

title: EXECUTIVE BACK
description: LEAD: ''I WAS ON THE PHONE, SCREAMING AT A client, a bank president, who was throwing his weight around,'' says Stephen L. Pino, president of S.L. Pino and Company, a New York custom furniture design and installation company. ''By the time I got off, I was walking funny, one shoulder higher than the other, and pain was radiating from my back.

title: Jill Allison Barlow Marries Eric Mark Sussman on L.I.
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jill Allison Barlow, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clive Barlow of Woodsburgh, L.I., was married last evening to Eric Mark Sussman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sussman of Meadowbrook, Pa. Rabbis Joel Zion and Aaron Landis and Cantor David Benedict officiated.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Peekskill, N.Y. $227,000 Eagle Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new frame colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 0.39 acre, not yet assessed. Pleasantville, N.Y. $253,000 24 Brentwood Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old frame ranch; rec room, workshop, patio, 1-car garage, 0.4 acre; taxes $4,700. Tarrytown, N.Y. $295,000 Ichabod Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 42-year-old frame colonial; den, alarm system, walk to station, 0.25 acre; taxes $3,885. Norwalk, Conn. $360,000 55 Crooked Trail 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; alarm system, outdoor garden lighting, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,673. Trumbull, Conn. $319,000 105 Lazybrook Road 4-bedroom, 2 bath, 6-year-old colonial; facing golf course, cathedral ceilings, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,900. Wilton, Conn. $365,000 26 Partrick Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old colonial; private pond, spacious rooms, 2 acres; taxes $2,410. OTHER AREAS Massapequa, L.I. $163,000 12 Pompano Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Northport, L.I. $204,000 8 Vine Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,800. Wayne, N.J. $222,500 25 Archung Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; family room, fireplace, c/a; taxes $2,832.

title: Should A Principal Have Been A Teacher?
description: Only a few years ago, school administrators hailed alternate certification for teachers as one of the quantum leaps in education since Socrates, that recalcitrant Greek stonecutter, asked questions in the agora.

title: Leslie A. Yancey Wed in Brooklyn
description: At the Congregational Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn Heights, Leslie Anne Yancey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Yancey of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Roger Hedrick Westerman, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon E. Westerman of Detroit. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin, the minister of the church, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Harry H. Kreuner, the retired minister.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: ENERGY POLICY;
JAPAN IS SPENDING HEAVILY TO AVOID OIL
description: LEAD: OVER the past several years, in tandem with its steadily rising prosperity, Japan has emerged as the paragon of an efficient industrialized nation. While there are similarities between the Japanese and American economies, one area that is profoundly different is energy policy: Japan has one, the United

title: Nancy Kadner Is Engaged
description: Nancy Beth Kadner, the promotion director at Rolling Stone magazine in New York, and John Harry Feingold, a director of mortgage trading at Salomon Brothers in New York, plan to be married May 15. Ms. Kadner is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kadner of Los Angeles. Her fiance is the son of Raymond Feingold and Natalie Gittelson, both of New York.

title: Austria Adopts New Plan for Payments to Victims of Nazis
description: Parliament has passed a law to pay up to $416 each to people victimized by the Nazis when Austria was under German rule during World War II.

title: RIGHTS AND CHOICES
description: Don Bredes's disappointment must be painful (About Men: ''Rights and Choices,'' Feb. 21.) But he makes it hard for us to sympathize with him. He writes of injustice and a man's rights, rather than telling the story of a risky human adventure that failed for very understandable reasons. He casts himself as victim, rather than as a participant who needs to wonder how he may have contributed to an impulsive and, possibly, mistaken decision, and to the unhappy outcome. JAMES E. DITTES New Haven

title: Camping Out In West Africa
description: LONG after the sun has set, two fires cast a flickering light on the people of Elen-kine, a small coastal village in Senegal's Casamance River region.

title: Deirdre Finney To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Deirdre Finney and James Richard Boylan has been announced by Mrs. Thomas Dunn Finney of Idabel, Okla., a grandmother of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title:
TELEVISION;
'Star Trek' Sails Boldly On
description: LEAD: Last fall, while America continued to ground its manned space flights, a different mission into the farthest reaches of the galaxy was launched. Paramount Studio unveiled ''Star Trek: The Next Generation,'' a syndicated sequel to the cultishly popular science-fiction series that was originally broadcast on NBC in 1966.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
STARVING AGAIN
description: LEAD: Dennis's ex-wife had fallen in love with a man she said was like out of a book.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Kansas City, Mo.; Luster Returns To a Boulevard
description: REDEVELOPMENT has begun to restore Armour Boulevard, one of Kansas City's major east-west thoroughfares, which had been tarnished by years of neglect.

title: SOME OF HER CLOSEST FRIENDS
description: LEAD: ELEPHANT MEMORIES Thirteen Years in the Life of an Elephant Family. By Cynthia Moss. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: HAWAIIANS' PATIENCE FOR IMPROVEMENTS IS WEARING THIN
description: ONLY a few hundred people live in this hamlet on the southeastern coast of what Hawaiians call the Big Island. Rural and slow-moving, with old wooden buildings where the local people trade gossip and buy fruit-flavored cones of shaved ice, the village recalls Hawaii at the turn of the century, before its landscape and lifestyle were forever changed by huge military bases and glittering beachfront resorts.

title: OFFICIAL BELFAST BUSIES ITSELF WITH THE SIDE ISSUES OF STRIFE
description: THE burial of the dead inevitably is followed by the resurrection of politics in the ceaseless Irish-Anglo agony. But a striking quality in the latest episode of violence and despair, the worst in more than a decade, is how much of the post-mortem debate remains focused on surface points of conflict.

title: More to Some Books Than Their Covers
description: AN astronomy book from 1474 has two wheels that turn to show the movements of the moon. An 1850 work on obstetrics has 50 flaps that lift to reveal anatomical details. A 1977 artist's book contains a real tortilla sealed in Mylar. A book about Georgia is shaped like Georgia, and Poemobiles have poems popping up from flat surfaces.

title: RTESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Zurbriggen Retains Title: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland retained his World Cup overall title yesterday with two aggressive, risky runs in the season's last slalom in Saalbach, Austria. Alberto Tomba of Italy fell in the second run, but by then the battle for the title was decided. Zurbriggen assured himself of a finish in the top five with a 48.42-second clocking in the difficult second run on the Schattberg course. The Swiss ace needed to finish at least seventh in the season's final event to claim the title. He finished fourth with an overall time of 1:40.73. The winner was Paul Frommelt of Liechtenstein with a combined time of 1:39.65. With Michela Figini winning the women's overall title, Switzerland swept the top honors for the second straight year.(AP) Austrian Triumphs: Klaus Sulzenbacher of Austria, who already had wrapped up the overall title a week ago at Holmenkollen, Norway, won the World Cup season finale yesterday in the Nordic combined in Rovaniemi, Finland. Sulzenbacher won four of the season's eight World Cup competitions, collecting 160 points. Torbjorn Lokken of Norway was second with 118 points and Andreas Schaad of Switzerland third with 80 points. Jukka Ylipulli of Finland was second in the final competition and Andrei Dundukov of the Soviet Union finished third. No Americans or Canadians entered the meet.(AP) Cross-Country Kristiansen Wins Again: Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway completed a remarkable double yesterday, winning her second world title in six days. Kristiansen, 32 years old, romped to victory in the World Cross-Country Championships at Ellerslie race course outside of Auckland, New Zealand. John Ngugi of Kenya won the men's title for the third straight year as Kenyan men filled eight of the first nine places. Last weekend, Kristiansen easily took the world 15-kilometer road-race title in Adelaide, Australia, winning by two minutes. The Norwegian's margin of victory yesterday was 19 seconds as she clocked 19 minutes 4 seconds for the 3.72-mile course. Ngugi, a 25-year-old soldier and part-time farmer, clocked 34 minutes and 32 seconds over the 7.5-mile course and won by 22 seconds over his teammate Paul Kipkoech.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Tops Wimbledon: John Aldridge returned after a four-match absence because of an injury and sparked Liverpool to a 2-1 victory over Wimbledon yesterday. Aldridge's goal after 34 minutes was his 22d of the English League season. Liverpool maintained its 14-point lead in the First Division with 76 points in 31 matches. Manchester United scored twice in the last eight minutes to beat West Ham, 3-1, and hold on to second place in the standings with 62 points. Everton, the defending champion, moved into third place with 59 points after a 2-1 victory at Watford.(AP) Bowling Voss Wins Second Title: Brian Voss won his second Professional Bowlers Association title in two weeks yesterday when he captured the $150,000 True Value Open in Peoria, Ill. In winning his sixth Tour crown, Voss beat top-seeded Dave Ferraro, 278-244, in a title match that featured 19 of 24 possible strikes. The victory by Voss makes him the first bowler this year to win two events.(AP) Golf South Korean Ahead by 2 Strokes: Ok-Hee Ku of South Korea took the lead with a birdie on the first hole and went on to shoot a three-under-par 70 for a two-stroke lead after yesterday's third round of the $350,000 L.P.G.A. Turquoise Classic in Phoenix, Ariz. Ku, who has won 16 tournaments in Korea but is seeking her first L.P.G.A. Tour victory, was at 10-under 209 through 54 holes. Rosie Jones and the second-round co-leaders Amy Alcott and Colleen Walker were next at 211. Jones shot a 70 yesterday on the 6,404-yard Moon Valley Golf Course while Alcott and Walker carded ever-par 73s.(AP) Boxing Bassa Retains Title: Fidel Bassa of Colombia withstood a late rally by Dave McAuley last night to score a unanimous 12-round decision and retain his World Boxing Association flyweight title. Bassa knocked McAuley out in the same King's Hall ring in Belfast, Northern Ireland, 11 months ago.(AP) Road Racing Drach Wins 100-Kilometer: Dave Drach of Westport, Ky., overtook Don Lookingbill of York, Pa., after 20 miles and went on to win the Metropolitan Athletic Congress 100-kilometer road race in 8 hours 32 minutes 27 seconds at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. Lookingbill failed to finish the 62.1-mile race that attracted a field of 16, including three women. Christiane Avin of the Millrose Athletic Association was the women's winner in 9:46.43. Horse Racing Creme Fraiche Triumphs: Creme Fraiche beat heavily favored Cryptoclearance by a nose yesterday to win the $219,600 Tropical Park Handicap at Calder as both horses smashed the track record of 2:07 for a mile and quarter. The winning time was 2:05 4/5 for Creme Fraiche, who was ridden by Angel Cordero Jr. and trained by Woody Stephens. He paid $7.60 for $2 to win. The $131,760 winner's purse raised Creme Fraiche's career earnings to $3.77 million and once again made him the leading money-winning horse in training. All Sincerity finished third in the field of eight. (AP)

title: Ms. Chisolm Plans to Marry Peter Holger Hansen in June
description: The engagement of Allison Chisolm to Peter Holger Hansen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Holger Hansen of Swarthmore, Pa., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. William A. Chisolm of New York. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Romare Bearden: Epic Emotion, Intimate Scale
description: Even though he was 75 and ill for some time, Romare Bearden's death earlier this month was a shock. It was clear from his work that he loved everything about art. He trusted materials, trusted the creative process, trusted the people who spoke to him in and across his paper. His art grew freer, wiser, more poignant in a way that is rare in postwar American art, where the demand for newness and change has pressured artists into defining personal evolution as continually re-creating themselves from scratch.

title: Life Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Practical Traveler; Mixed Signals On Lost Tickets
description: LOSING an airplane ticket can be worse than losing your passport. United States Embassies can rapidly replace a lost or stolen passport, but you may never get a penny back if your ticket is stolen, or it could take 18 months to recover what you have to spend to get a new one. There are some bright spots. A lost ticket for an overseas flight can sometimes be replaced on the spot at no charge.

title: The Incredible Hulks
description: In the afternoon, the gray station wagon left parked on a residential block in Manhattan's Chelsea district still looked like a station wagon. After dark, the scavengers arrived and removed some of the engine and the rear wheels. Then, finding nothing else of value, they smashed all the windows, showering broken glass and leaving behind another in the rising tide of abandoned hulks that deface American streets. How many neighborhoods must be trashed before city governments get serious about fighting the tide?

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: COMMERCIALIZING SUPERCONDUCTORS;
If We Lose the Race, Blame Industry
description: LEAD: BUSINESS executives like to complain about government inaction when it comes to international competition. So along come a far-reaching scientific advance making possible supereconductivity at economically feasible high temperatures - what W. Bruce Merrifield, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Productivity, Technology, and Innovation, calls ''one of the most significant commercial developments ever'' - and what happens?

title: No Need to Make Calamity of So Long Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Bird Gets 31 in Rout By Celtics
description: After the Boston Celtics blew a 30-point third-quarter lead in their loss to the Philadelphia 76ers on Friday night, the Knicks had reason to fear that they would pay for that loss. Their fears were well-founded. With Larry Bird scoring 31 points, including a Madison Square Garden-record four 3-point field goals, the Celtics battered the Knicks last night, 118-106.

title: Man, 64, Is Beaten to Death In Apartment in Co-op City
description: A 64-year-old Bronx man was found beaten to death Friday night in his ransacked apartment in Co-op City, the police said yesterday.

title: IS YOUR LIFE SOMEONE ELSE'S PORNO MOVIE?
description: WOMEN AND CHILDREN FIRST By Francine Prose. 229 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: DUKE KNOCKS OFF TEMPLE TO GAIN FINAL 4
description: For Temple, it was worse than having a kid brother tag along to the playground for a pickup basketball game, stepping on your toes along the way. The only place the Owls could find sanctuary from Duke today was in their huddle, and most of those sessions with their coach, John Chaney, were not at all pleasant.

title: Golden Days for Arbitrage
description: A WALL STREET trader interrupted a telephone interview last week to check on the status of the takeover battle for Federated Department Stores. The news was good. Campeau had raised its bid to $73 a share from $68. ''And I bought in late, two weeks ago, at 66,'' he reported. ''Not a bad gain.'' On Wall Street, the talk of big deals and easy money is back. And risk arbitragers, the traders who specialize in betting on takeovers, are riding the market again, trying to capitalize on the fact that takeover plays represent one of the few clear-cut opportunities in today's stock market. The hardy firms that survived October's dark days and the tribulations of the insider-trading investigations now find themselves in a charmed world: There seems to be a new deal every day, and there are fewer arbitragers in the race, which means their profits can be greater. And many of today's buyers are blue-chip companies, which are more likely to close the deals than the rowdy raiders who dominated the takeover world before the market collapsed.

title: Poor Management Laid To Turtle Back Zoo
description: THE consulting veterinarian for Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange, Dr. Barry M. Adler, charged last week that poor management, zoo maintenance and animal care had contributed to the deaths of at least 13 animals since January and were to blame for other problems in recent years.

title: Saving the Chapels of Wales
description: INTRODUCED to Christianity through their native Celtic Church, absorbed into Roman Catholicism and transmuted through diktat to Anglicanism by King Henry VIII, the Welsh waited until the coming of the ironworks, coal mines and slate quarries late in the 18th century and throughout the 19th before molding Nonconformist denominations according to their own image and emerging with dramatic oratory and four-part harmony onto the religious center stage. Brushing aside the Anglican Church, which did not even deign to provide them with Welsh-speaking bishops, the agricultural and industrial laboring classes of Wales embarked on an extraordinary and costly building campaign. Between 1811 and 1914 they erected some 5,000 unrendered stone or stucco chapels for Baptist, Congregationalist (or Independent) and Methodist worship. These developed from simple adaptations of farm buildings into massive auditoriums with facades embodying a diversity of Greek, Romanesque, Gothic and other styles as well as late Victorian eccentricities.

title: Fight to the Finish
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GOOD CLEAN FUN OF DREAMING
description: THE DREAMING BRAIN By J. Allan Hobson. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Basic Books. $22.95.

title: Miss Druger, Dietitian, To Wed B. A. Jamieson
description: Prof. and Mrs. Marvin Druger of Syracuse have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jane Druger, to Brian Andrew Jamieson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Graham Jamieson of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is to be in September.

title: County Gains Music Festival
description: LEAD: CHAMBER MUSIC lovers in the county may discover another opportunity to pursue their passion on June 5, when the Dobbs Ferry Chamber Music Festival makes its debut on the Masters School campus.

title: ALONG U.S BORDER, A THIRD WORLD IS REBORN
description: When he received the report almost four years ago about the high incidence of children with diarrhea and mysterious skin rashes, Dr. Laurance Nickey wondered if he was really reading about the United States.

title: Atheletes and Esthetes
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Today:; The Business World/Magazine, Part 2
description: Special reports in this issue include:

title: Bridge Repairs Tie Up Commuters
description: LEAD: BEFORE one of three eastbound lanes of Interstate 80 was closed on Feb. 26, it took Theresa Radler 25 to 30 minutes to get from her home in Hopatcong to her job in Pine Brook on Route 46.

title: 'WOMEN IN CHARGE': PHOTOGRAPHY BY CONNECTICUT WOMEN
description: THE connection between New Haven's 350th anniversary and International Women's Day is tenuous, to say the least. Nevertheless, the two events are being celebrated together by numerous shows in and around the city this March.

title: Freud's Vienna Begins at Berggasse 19
description: WHEN a Nazi commando raided a second-floor apartment in Vienna's Berggasse one spring day 50 years ago, a sign on the building reading ''Prof. Dr. Freud/3-4'' had already been removed and a swastika flag had been draped over the doorway.

title: Anne N. Emmons And James Mason To Marry in June
description: Anne Neal Emmons and James Stephenson Mason, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Mason of Parkersburg, W.Va., and Kennebunkport, Me., plan to marry in June, the parents of the future bride, Diane Neal Emmons of Manchester, Mass., and Robert W. Emmons Jr. of Annisquam, Mass., have announced.

title: Review/Cabaret; An Accordion Summit
description: At P.S. 122 on Thursday night, Danny Mydlack, a performance artist and accordionist, announced, ''I saw that in the future, everybody was walking around playing accordions,'' and for one night it was true. Billy Swindler and Zeena Parkins (a.k.a. the B.Z. Squeezies) presented a variety show of accordion music from all over, their fourth Accordion Summit since 1984. On one side of the stage rested a half-dozen stacked, graduated accordions, a keyboard Machu Picchu.

title: Gambling on Life
description: LAST DECEMBER A major clinical trial to determine whether aspirin could reduce the risk of heart attack in men was suddenly halted. Every other day for five years each of the 22,000 healthy doctors who had agreed to take part in the experiment had taken a white pill; half took an aspirin, half a placebo, and none knew what he was getting. The project was abruptly stopped because the data had become statistically unequivocal. Among those taking aspirin, 104 had suffered heart attacks, among those taking the placebo, 189 had.

title: Waterston Brings Real Life to Life
description: WITH his appearances in the title role of ''Gore Vidal's Lincoln'' tonight and tomorrow night on NBC-TV and his current performance as an arms negotiator - a character loosely based on the American career diplomat Paul H. Nitze - in the play ''A Walk in the Woods'' on Broadway, Sam Waterston is adding two more characters to his ever-growing gallery of nonfictional heroes.

title: 'Litter Is a Behavioral Problem'
description: ROGER W. POWERS is the president of Keep America Beautiful, a private, nonprofit organization based in Stamford and ''dedicated to building a national cleanliness ethic.''

title: Eritrean Rebels Claim Big Victory Over Ethiopia
description: Eritrean rebels fighting the Ethiopian authorities say they killed or captured 18,000 Government soldiers and seized three Soviet military advisers in an offensive that they said had ''broken the backbone of the Ethiopian Army'' in Eritrea.

title: Early Polls Suggest a Close Contest in Chile Vote on Pinochet
