description: Myriad research groups, consultants and others are polling Chileans about their attitudes toward the coming presidential plebiscite, and it is common wisdom that every organization shapes the questions according to its own biases.

title: THE QUARRELSOME KOREANS
description: ON THE DAY BEFORE HIS inauguration as President of South Korea on Feb. 25, Roh Tae Woo posed in front of his party headquarters to be photographed with giggling cleaning ladies in overalls.

title: O'Connor Faults Parts of Yonkers Bias Agreement
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, John Cardinal O'Connor, has announced his opposition to elements of a bitterly disputed agreement to desegregate housing in Yonkers, saying they present ''potential problems.''

title: Another Look At Hook Shot
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TOGETHER APART
description: IT IS, WITHOUT A DOUBT, THE GRANDEST birdhouse in Virginia Beach, Va. A Victorian mansion in miniature, it was produced by William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation, and his wife, Sue Ling Gin, a Chicago entrepreneur, during weekends at their oceanfront retreat in the coastal city. As one might expect of a hard-driving couple accustomed to thinking big, this simple addition to their spare, modern house became an extravaganza.

title: Kathleen Lamb Wed to Dr. Daniel Ts'o
description: St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathleen Elaine Lamb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Philip Lamb of Hingham, Mass., and Dr. Daniel Y. Ts'o, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul O. P. Ts'o of Ellicott City, Md. The Rev. Samuel Matarazzo performed the ceremony.

title: Day-Care Services Growing at Schools
description: LEAD: BROOKE SHUSTER, a second-grade pupil, remains in the Chapman School in Cheshire long after other children her age have gone home.

title: WINNOWING OUR WARHEADS
description: THERE IS A HIGH RISK for the United States in the current strategic arms reduction talks, known as START, that call for a 50 percent reduction in strategic nuclear warheads. The risk is less in what we negotiate with the Russians than in how we divide up the 50 percent we would be allowed to retain. The prospect of a START agreement offers us an important opportunity to reassess our nuclear arsenal and the assumptions on which we have built it.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I had the outside of my house covered with light green aluminum siding 20 years ago. This color has faded and now looks dull and ugly, so now I want to paint this siding. Can it be painted and if so, is there a special process I must use? Will the siding have to be repainted regularly?

title: Democrats Urge Changes In Budget Process
description: DEMOCRATS on the Board of Legislators called last week for major changes in the county government's budget process, ones that they said could help replace yearly tax-levy increases of 12 to 16 percent with ''modest'' rises roughly equivalent to the growth in the cost of living.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Instant replay? How about a dome over Wrigley Field? MARC GRIGOROV Cortland, N.Y.

title: U.S. DEUSTS OFF AN OLD LAW
description: LEAD: IN what legal experts say is the most aggressive use of seditious conspiracy laws in recent years, the Reagan Administration has charged a number of radical organizations on the left and right of the political spectrum with plotting to overthrow the Government.

title: Martha Beale Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Beale of Geneseo, N.Y., have annonced the engagement of their daughter Martha Kimberley Beale to Frederick E. Nicholson, a son of William A. Nicholson of Palm City, Fla., and the late Gladys Marie Nicholson. Miss Beale is an assistant head nurse in the operating room at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Her fiance is a surety bond underwriter with the Seaboard Surety Company in New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: Ms. Liu to Marry Dr. E. L. Trimble
description: The engagement of Cornelia Liu to Dr. Edward Lloyd Trimble, a son of Mrs. I. Ridgeway Trimble of Baltimore and the late Dr. Trimble, has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Darrell T. Liu of Bethesda, Md. The couple plan to marry May 7.

title: Honduran Cooperation With Washington in Support of Contras Is Cooling
description: Roberto Castillo, a 40-year-old Honduran legislator and real estate developer, stood in a passageway in the National Assembly, quietly talking about the thousands of Nicaraguan rebels who have been camping in his country for the last seven years.

title: Cynthia R. Leder And Jeffrey Glekel To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Leder of Margate, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Ruth Leder to Jeffrey Glekel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Newton Glekel of Manhattan. A June wedding is planned.

title: Questions Are Posed About Halfway House
description: In a Westchester Opinion article [ ''Halfway Houses: What Goes On Inside,'' Feb. 28 ] , Alan Menikoff of Search for Change categorizes the widespread community opposition to the proposed operation of a halfway house by Search for Change in Larchmont as ''predictably similar'' to that appearing in other communities, dismissing out of hand the numerous valid questions raised by town officials, community groups and mental-health professionals. He is clearly wrong. The Search for Change halfway house proposed for Larchmont is an experiment, not a norm. Mr. Menikoff and Search for Change have continuously failed to address the unique and serious questions raised in connection with the proposal, presumably because they have no answers. Because Search for Change and Mr. Menikoff have shown no inclination to be forthright on the facts, we feel compelled to do so in their place.

title: TALKING: Co-op Rentals; Suburban Owners At Risk
description: PROSPECTIVE buyers, investors and owners of cooperative and condominium apartments in Westchester, Nassau and Rockland Counties should be aware of possible problems in renting out their units for even a brief time.

title: MIND OVER DISEASE: CAN HAPPY THOUGHTS HEAL?
description: Leave a pendulum to its own devices and it most assuredly will swing the other way. So it has been lately with a theory of health and healing that treats the mind as a weapon at least as powerful as the best of modern medicaments. After nearly a century stuck on the side of the body, the pendulum has recently cut a wide arc toward the mind.

title: Reagan Just Loves to Send Troops
description: LEAD: Early in the Civil War, the Confederate Government contracted with the Laird shipbuilders of Liverpool to build ironclad rams - powerful warships - for delivery in 1863. If they were allowed to slip out of Liverpool harbor, the cost to Union warships and merchantmen would be catastrophic. As the Navy Secretary Gustavis Fox said, ''It is a question of life and death.

title: Arizona, Carolina Maneuver
description: Top-seeded Arizona and surprising North Carolina, scheduled to meet in the West Regional final Sunday, engaged in a subtle campaign of psychological maneuvering this afternoon.

title: Islanders Regain First
description: Pat LaFontaine negotiates an ice rink the way a water beetle negotiates a pond. He skitters across it, preferring a series of zig-zags to the more conventional route. Even mobile defensemen are left twirling in place from the effort of trying to imitate his path. Goaltenders, trying to anticipate his every move, see only a darting blur instead of a straightforward forward.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I had the outside of my house covered with light green aluminum siding 20 years ago. This color has faded and now looks dull and ugly, so now I want to paint this siding. Can it be painted and if so, is there a special process I must use? Will the siding have to be repainted regularly?

title: Seeking the Deeper Meanings of Pop Culture
description: More than 3,000 people have gathered here to ponder soap operas, nursery rhymes, hair styles and other attributes of American popular culture.

title: Curing What Ails Them
description: MEDICINE ON TRIAL The Appalling Story of Ineptitude, Malfeasance, Neglect, and Arrogance. By Charles B. Inlander, Lowell S. Levin and Ed Weiner. 304 pp. New York: Prentice Hall Press. $18.95.

title: Yankee Independence, Yankee Zoning
description: I AM not a native New Englander. I was born and grew up in the Middle West. In elementary school, we learned about the group of small states in the Northeast corner of our country where the first settlers battled harsh winters and farmed land that was more rock than soil. New Englanders, we were told, were fiercely protective of their own way of doing things, a characteristic that time has not erased. It is known as Yankee independence.

title: What's Doing In Washington
description: If anything can distract Washington from its preoccupation with front-runners, public opinion polls and primaries this year, it is the arrival of spring. For with spring the capital once again becomes a gracious Southern city, with garden tours, lunchtime strolls and outdoor festivals.

title: Texaco to Emerge From Bankruptcy
description: The way was cleared for Texaco to emerge from bankruptcy and pay the $3 billion to Pennzoil that will settle their four-year-old legal battle. A Federal bankruptcy judge approved Texaco's plan for ending the bankruptcy protection that it sought almost a year ago; at that time, it was beset by problems caused by the $10.5 billion award that Pennzoil had won in a Texas court. Texaco could be out of bankruptcy as soon as early April. Carl C. Icahn, Texaco's largest shareholder, objected to some parts of the plan but he voted for it. It was Texaco's acquisition of Getty Oil in 1984 that led to the dispute with Pennzoil. Now Texaco will have to sell some sizable assets to pay Pennzoil.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BABETTE'S FEAST: And Other Anecdotes of Destiny, by Isak Dinesen. (Vintage, $4.95.) In the title piece of this collection of five short stories, a French political refugee who arrives in a small Danish fishing village turns out to be a Parisian chef who astounds the ascetic Lutheran locals with a sumptuous meal. ''What other hands might have made the most venal kitsch . . . Isak Dinesen has transformed, by imagination, by wit, by savoir-faire, above all by belief, into genuine if anachronistic art,'' Gerald Sykes said here in 1958. FAITH, SEX, MYSTERY: A Memoir, by Richard Gilman. (Penguin, $7.95.) At the age of 27, the drama critic Richard Gilman, who considered himself a Jewish atheist, had a moment of epiphany at the public library. A year later he converted to Catholicism, but eventually he felt so intellectually constrained that he lost his faith. Last year, our reviewer, Mary Gordon, said that in this intellectual autobiography ''the pleasures of the prose are great.'' ''In recounting this history, [ he ] presents us with a work deserving of all honor for its dark honesty, its fierce, reflective intellectuality, the lambent constancy of both its vision and its style.'' WATCHERS, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) Last year, our reviewer, Katharine Weber, said that the richest character in this thriller is a genetically engineered golden retriever named Einstein, who is being stalked by a mutant killer. ''Despite some pedestrian writing, the suspense holds to the end. Displaying a little more depth and a lot more humor than Stephen King, Dean R. Koontz has really hit his stride.'' TALES OF A NEW AMERICA: The Anxious Liberal's Guide to the Future, by Robert B. Reich. (Vintage, $8.95.) The liberals can rise again, Robert B. Reich believes, if they develop new myths in which traditional rivalries - between capitalism and communism, the United States and Japan, labor and management - are seen not as zero sum games but as symbiotic relationships. Last year, Nicholas Lehmann said here that the book was ''ambitiously and intellectually honest,'' but sometimes ''maddeningly vague.'' A SPORT OF NATURE, by Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $7.95.) A white woman raised in South Africa marries a black revolutionary and inherits his cause when he is assassinated. Last year, our reviewer, Maureen Howard, called the book ''a powerful novel of awakening, emergence, and, in so far as fiction can make it possible, a call for a new order.'' BLUES, by John Hersey. Illustrated by James Baker. (Vintage, $6.95.) Cast as a dialogue between a stranger and a fisherman, John Hersey's book about angling for bluefish off Martha's Vineyard is a philosophical meditation on one of mankind's first sports. ''Almost no one has answered 'why fish?' better than Mr. Hersey,'' Verlyn Klinkenborg said here last year. ''What Mr. Hersey does best of all is evoke wonder.'' BERLIN WILD, by Elly Welt. (Onyx/New American Library, $4.50.) During World War II, Josef Bernhardt, a teen-aged Jewish mathematician, hides out with other fugitive geniuses at a neurological institute in Berlin. Last year, our reviewer, Julia Markus, found the novel ''overly clever'' but admired its ''descriptive ability and intelligence.'' HOLD ON, MR. PRESIDENT! by Sam Donaldson. (Fawcett Crest, $4.95.) So far, Sam Donaldson has spent more than a decade covering the White House for ABC News. Last year, The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt criticized Mr. Donaldson for being rather self-absorbed, but he liked the book's ''sharp snapshots'' of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan. ''Without ever waxing solemn or punditlike, he shrewdly weighs and illustrates the respective jobs they've done.'' THE HOLLOW WOMAN, by Simon Ritchie. (Signet/ New American Library, $3.50.) This mystery novel about a one-armed Canadian private eye named John Kenneth Galbraith Jantarro begins with a botched kidnapping case, in which a mother and child are killed. ''The ending is scary,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review in 1987. ''Hitchcock would have loved it.'' SERPENT IN THE SKY: The High Wisdom of Ancient Egypt, by John Anthony West. (Julian/Crown, $12.95.) John Anthony West is one of the latest of a long line of maverick scholars who argue that ancient Egyptian knowledge was actually imported from the lost civilization of Atlantis. In 1979 one reviewer said the book ''reads like a Rosicrucian primer, discussing the concepts of cosmic harmony . . . Pythagorean harmonics, hieroglyphics and symbolism, and mathematics.'' THE RUG MERCHANT, by Phillip Lopate. (Penguin, $6.95.) An Iranian rug seller who would rather be an art historian tries to save his business, situated on the Upper West Side's rapidly gentrifying Amsterdam Avenue, from landlords who want to triple his rent. Last year, our reviewer, Jerome Charyn, called the novel ''a sad, tight, lyrical song among the glittering ruins of Manhattan. . . . a quiet descent into an urban hell.'' HARDBALL: The Education of a Baseball Commissioner, by Bowie Kuhn. (McGraw-Hill, $5.95.) The former baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn was so unpopular among fans that our reviewer, Daniel Okrent, wondered who would want to read his life story. In fact, he discovered, the book ''is a much worthier, more interesting and better-written book than the autobiographies we're used to getting from baseball's usual memoirists, the players. . . . It is in many ways a remarkable book, by a man who deserved better than the hand that most baseball writers - myself included - dealt to [ him ] during his tenure.''

title: Independent Fed
description: To the Editor:

title: Westport Surveys Historic Architecture
description: WITH camera and clipboard in hand, Mary McCahon has been driving along every street, avenue and byway in Westport, taking pictures of buildings of historic interest.

title: EAST-WEST PARLEY SNAGS OVER RIGHTS
description: A 16-month-old conference in Vienna on security and humanitarian issues has recessed with progress reported toward new negotiations on conventional arms, but little movement on human rights.

title: AUTO MOTIVES
description: NOT LONG AGO, DURING a country-house weekend, I was puzzled to see a successful businessman I know who looks like a wispier Woody Allen climb into a new Porsche 911. When he drove off, my experienced ear told me he knew very little about the sports car, its engine or gearbox. ''What's he doing in that Porsche?'' I asked my host. ''That's his new car.'' ''But he doesn't know how to drive it,'' I said. ''Drive it?'' said my host. ''Are you kidding? He doesn't drive it. He wears it. He puts it on like a new blazer and struts it around.''

title: Review/Music; 3 Soviet Composers Are Focus of Festival
description: In the haphazardly organized, passionately performed and poorly marketed pot-pourri that is Sarah Caldwell's Soviet-American music and dance festival Making Music Together, three composers stand out, and all three had programs devoted to their music on Friday.

title: Kyoto's Canvas Bags Suited for All Needs
description: THE storefront of Ichizawa Hanpu Kogyo (Ichizawa Sailcloth Enterprises) in Kyoto is so modest it's very easy to pass it by. The many-paned window of the shop is not markedly different from that of the other old offices and shops on Higashioji-dori, and the earthy colors of the bags visible through the glass blend in with the dark wood, gray roof tiles and copper rain pipes of the shop's exterior and that of other buildings on the street.

title: Yale Enriches Its Silver Trove
description: The American silver collection at Yale University, long acknowledged as pre-eminent in Colonial holdings, is now described by Patricia R. Kane, Yale's curator of decorative arts, as second to none through the mid-19th century. The impressive expansion is the result of a comprehensive gift of 18th- and 19th-century silver - about 4,400 pieces - made by Carl R. Kossack, a Yale alumnus, and his family. A representative selection of 235 items is on view in ''American Silver from the Kossack Collection'' at the Yale University Art Gallery through June 12.

title: Split Widens On Lilco Takeover
description: AS it enters what could be a decisive week, the Long Island Power Authority is badly divided, an agency split between four directors who want to move to assume control of the Long Island Lighting Company as soon as possible and others who hope to delay any takeover attempt.

title: Witt Wins Title For Fourth Time
description: In her final competition as an amateur, Katarina Witt of East Germany tonight won the World Figure Skating Championship for the fourth time.

title:
ART;
An Early American 'Face Painter'
description: LEAD: ''FACE PAINTER'' is a novel term used to characterize Gustavus Hesselius (1692-1755), who is recognized as America's first professionally trained portrait painter.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: You're a Bad Boy, Spuds MacKenzie

title: An Office Casualty: My Right to Smoke
description: I AM looking through the help-wanted ads in my local newspaper because I am thinking of going back to work. Limited by the narrow choice of offerings in the East End's primarily blue-collar work force, I scan each job description carefully.

title: Cakes for Easter or for Passover, Two Holidays That Coincide
description: THE weekend of Easter observances and the beginning of Passover coincide this year. Home cooks will be busy preparing Passover seders on Friday and Saturday evenings or putting together Easter Sunday dinners.

title: DOWNWARD MOBILITY
description: LEAD: THE DIVE BOAT TELITA ROCKS GENTLY AT ANCHOR on a lonely stretch of the Bismarck Sea off Papua New Guinea. Toward sunrise eight scuba divers slip quietly out of their cabins for a look at coral formations that grow jungle-like atop an undersea wall.

title: Chomsky and the Khmer Rouge
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Franklin Lakes $250,000 541 Shirley Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 19-year-old contemporary; patio, dining room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,108. Maplewood $196,000 14 Carleton Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 1-car garage, deck; taxes $3,726. North Plainfield $169,900 358 West End Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 49-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, living-room fireplace, patio; taxes $2,178. Orange $195,000 787 East Clarke Place 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 51-year-old colonial; family room, library, 2 fireplaces, 2-car detached garage; taxes $3,365. Short Hills $601,000 35 Cayuga Way 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old expanded ranch; 2-zone heating, c/a, den, 3 fireplaces; taxes $8,398. Wayne $222,500 25 Archung Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; family room, fireplace, c/a; taxes $2,832. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. $227,000 Eagle Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new frame colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 0.39 acre, not yet assessed. Trumbull, Conn. $319,000 105 Lazybrook Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; facing golf course, cathedral ceilings, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,900. Massapequa, L.I. $163,000 12 Pompano Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800.

title: When White Water Isn't Enough
description: I AM shooting down the Colorado River in gray rubber raft No. 612 with a mountainy boatman, a headphoned Upper West Sider and a Midwestern couple protected from the spray in see-through rain slickers, like potatoes in a Baggie. The Upper West Sider is listening to the ''Ride of the Valkyries'' on a Walkman supplied by one of the guides on our 13-day, 235-mile voyage through the Grand Canyon; modern rivermen don't quite trust the crashing river to hold the interest of tourists with contemporary attention spans. With its monumental rock formations and stomach-wrenching rapids, the canyon may be the pre-eminent white water experience in America. But wired into Wagner, the Upper West Sider is as placid as a boater on Central Park Lake.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Backward Runs the Racer STAN WUNDERLICH'S hobby has become a pain in the neck. The Woodbury resident likes to run backward, ''and in a long race,'' he said, ''your neck can definitely hurt.''

title: QUESTIONING THE ETHICS OF DUAL-ROLE CONSULTANTS
description: IN an era when influencing government is a big business, the New York State Commission on Government Integrity is focusing on a new type of power broker - the public relations consultant representing private interests who doubles as a fund-raiser for politicians who often control the fate of those same interests.

title: BETWEEN LIBYA AND CHAD, TRUCE BACKED BY MIGHT
description: Six months after a cease-fire halted the Libya-Chad war, 10,000 Chadian troops face 12,000 Libyans in the dispute over the Aozou Strip, a 100-mile-wide slice of the Sahara claimed by both countries.

title: Computer Centers Help Teachers Keep Learning
description: WHEN Carol Anselmo, a fourth-grade teacher, wanted to take a ''hands on'' science workshop, she signed up for ''Science Alive'' at M-Tract.

title: Dukakis Wins Polling In N. Dakota Caucuses
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis overcame a strong showing by the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the final weekend of Democratic caucuses to win North Dakota's Presidential preference poll today.

title: MAN TO MICROBE: DO A JOB, DROP DEAD
description: IN response to concerns about releasing living, gene-altered microbes into the environment, scientists have learned to program bacteria to destroy themselves when their work is done.

title: Ranchers Fret as Drought Hangs Over the West
description: A second consecutive year of low rainfall is causing drought conditions in much of the West and threatening to force water rationing in many communities.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: In breaking her anonymity, Nan Robertson has done a disservice to herself, to Alcoholics Anonymous and to the alcoholic who still suffers.

title:
IN SHORT;
MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: LEAD: RETURN OF THE RISHI: A Doctor's Search for the Ultimate Healer. By Deepak Chopra. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) This is the story of an Indian-born, American-trained physician who rediscovers an ancient healing tradition. We first encounter him as an untried intern, who, transported from India straight into the wards of a New Jersey hospital, must cope with his first ''expiration'' (hospitalese for death) amid the incomprehensible high-tech rituals of defibrillators and codes blue: ''My first American patient had been a dead man.

title: Perfect Spy Rallies to Win the Bay Shore
description: Perfect Spy, the Candian gelding who upset Forty Niner in Florida last month, knocked off another prominent Kentucky Derby hopeful yesterday when he ran down Success Express in deep stretch to win the $164,100 Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Despite Criticism, Fetal Monitors Are Likely to Remain in Wide Use
description: Electronic fetal monitors have been under attack for more than a decade by some women's groups and parts of the medical community. But despite research showing that using monitors does not produce healthier babies, most obstetricians say that a complicated interplay of legal and economic pressures makes it almost impossible to stop using them.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A Buyer's Market in Morristown Offices
description: LEAD: EARLIER this month the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, with headquarters in Basking Ridge, announced plans to consolidate some of its scattered operations in Westchester and New Jersey into one location in downtown Morristown.

title: Porter Is Out
description: Abandoning her game to save a child's life won her a special exemption to play in the Turquoise Classic, but becoming a hero hardly helped Mary Bea Porter's golf game. Plagued by what she described as flashback images of the unconscious child's ashen face as she gave a 2-year-old boy mouth-to-mouth resuscitation March 16, Porter failed to make the cut, and the Turquoise continued without her yesterday at the Moon Valley Country Club in Phoenix, Ariz.

title: The Need to Consider Pathological Gamblers
description: The article, ''Legislators Weigh Raceway Proposal'' [ March 6 ] , outlines many of the ramifications of establishing betting parlors in our county. One overlooked consequence of legitimizing and facilitating easy access to horse race betting is the possible increase in the number of pathological gamblers.

title: When Schooling Gets in Learning's Way
description: MY son Shane is a discipline problem at school. When I confront him, he tells me he wants to drop out; since he knows I'll never permit it, he's hoping to be expelled for misbehavior.

title: Recycling, Long Neglected, Is Now Seen as Vital to New York
description: Recycling - long a neglected element of municipal garbage handling -is now viewed as vital to New York City's efforts to dispose of ever-increasing amounts of waste.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsfield, Mass.;
Cluster Houses Meet a Need
description: LEAD: TWO clustered housing developments went on the market recently in this city of 50,000, reflecting an emerging interest in alternatives to the neighborhoods of detached single-family homes that dominate the housing scene here.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: As a member of A.A., I read your article with interest. I was distressed to read that the General Service Office of A.A. would not allow recovering alcoholics to handle its finances. I am the controller of an investment-banking firm in New York City, and wonder what the management of my firm will think when they read that the management of A.A., which knows alcoholics better than anyone, will not trust a recovering alcoholic to handle its finances. I feel that this tradition is no longer appropriate. JOHN B. Sunnyside, Queens NOTE: Members of Alcoholics Anonymous are generally identified by their first name and last initial.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
Nice Place to Visit but You Wouldn't Want to Live There
description: LEAD: RECENTLY I underwent minor surgery at a major institution. It was the kind of place where a chef in a tall white hat served samples of a new alcohol-free wine they're introducing with dinner.

title: Why the Analysts Are Poles Apart
description: PROBABLY the most time-honored investment axiom is this: When everybody starts pushing the same products, or starts predicting the same things, do just the opposite.

title: Q and A
description: Mortgage Insurance

title: TEEN-AGE SUICIDE AND THE FAMILY
description: I applaud the passion with which Gilbert W. Cass wrote ''Strategies for Dealing With Teen-Age Suicide'' (Opinion page, March 6). I strongly believe that everyone needs to know more about how to deal with and prevent the tragic waste of our adolescents who use suicide as a solution to the problems in their lives that appear to be insoluble.

title:
FILM;
Roman Polanski: 54 and 'Frantic'
description: LEAD: In Roman Polanski's new film, ''Frantic,'' a woman steps out of the frame - her Paris hotel room - and disappears. Her husband settles down for a nap, only slightly puzzled; she will be back. ''That's an obsession I have whenever I'm waiting for somebody who is late,'' said Mr. Polanski the other day over lunch in a bistro near the Champs-Elysees.

title: 11 Held in S.I. Gambling Raids
description: Eleven people were arrested yesterday in raids on four Staten Island houses that the police said were used to take sports bets over toll-free telephone numbers.

title: The Music of Easter Fills Churches
description: THE story of Holy Week is being told in music around the state this week as churches present the seasonal works of composers from medieval to modern times.

title: Eight Artists Explore Concept of 'Outsiders'
description: ''CONVERGENCES/CONVERGENCIAS,'' at the Lehman College Art Gallery, appears to be yet another tribute to democracy. All save one of its eight participants are Latin American by birth or descent (the exception comes from Portugal) and all are living and working in the United States. What makes the show different from others of its type is the essay that comes with it.

title: Deborah Weiss, Student, Is Wed
description: The marriage of Deborah Marion Weiss, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey J. Weiss of Haworth, N.J., to James Whitman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Whitman of New York and South Salem, N.Y., took place yesterday at the New Haven Lawn Club. Judge Ralph K. Winter of the Federal Court of Appeals in New York officiated.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I don't know how to invest that kind of money without acquiring something.'' - J. Hugh Liedtke, Pennzoil's chairman, on how to spend $3 billion.

title: POSTINGS: Subsidized by the Sea; Coney Island Town Houses
description: To make the 112 moderate- to middle-income homes of Seaside Gardens Townhouses possible, more had to be brought together than just the modular walls and roofs by DeLuxe Homes of Berwick, Pa., and the concrete foundations by Julius Meherberg, a builder. Prior to the start of construction next month in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, the $13.8 million project needed a financial-aid package.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Absolutely. For that matter, why not use electronic strike zones and foul lines. We won't need instant replays or umpires. How about automatic pitching machines? . . . WILLIAM W. AMBROSE Cambridge, Mass.

title: Attaching Wood to Concrete Floor
description: A surprisingly frequent, though unusual, home-improvement task is attaching wood to concrete. Two instances where this is necessary are covering a concrete slab by building a wood or wood-supported floor over it, and installing a partition wall in a basement containing a concrete floor.

title: SUDDENLY, IT'S CHICAGO
description: IF DANTE HAD SEEN THE TREASURY BOND PIT AT the Chicago Board of Trade, he would have added another circle to his vision of hell. Imagine a ring of steps around an octagonal floor, about 35 feet in diameter on the top step, occupying the northwest corner of a wood-paneled trading room the width of a city block. Some 600 men and women stand jammed together in this pit, shouting and gesticulating, sometimes swaying in unison like tulips in the wind, from 8 o'clock in the morning when trading begins until 2 o'clock in the afternoon. Nobody goes to lunch, and few will risk losing their places by visiting the bathroom. Such abstinence is possible because almost everyone is under 35. (''Don't be confused by those gray heads you see,'' said the Virgil showing a visitor around. ''They're 28 years old, too.'') The Treasury bond pit works by open outcry, which means that each bid and offer is good only for the instant of utterance and must be incessantly repeated. The noise is devastating.

title: Verbatim; No Work, No Pay
description: 'Exercising the right to strike inevitably risks economic hardship, but we are not inclined to hold that the right of association requires the Government to minimize that result by qualifying the striker for food stamps.' - Justice Byron R. White, writing for the majority in the Supreme Court's decision upholding a law that makes any household with a member on strike ineligible for food stamps.

title: Walker in the Wings
description: Take away Herschel Walker's helmet, his shoulder pads, his hip pads, his thigh pads and his football cleats, and what do you have? A running back in tights and ballet slippers, of course.

title: 2 Belfast Men Appear in Court in Killing of Soldiers
description: Two men appeared in court today on charges that they murdered two British soldiers during a funeral for an Irish Republican Army member in which the soldiers were beaten, stripped and then shot.

title: No Room at Docks As Boats Fill Sound
description: FOR years, John and Gloria Howley kept their 28-foot sailboat at a marina in Norwalk. But when they returned last September from a two-year trip to Florida and the Bahamas, they were unable to get their old docking berth or find one elsewhere in the area.

title: Clean Drinking Water Is a Necessity
description: IN A NICE middle-class neighborhood less than 10 miles from the beach, hundreds of families say they are being held hostage. Not, however, by drug dealers or terrorists; their kitchen faucets have made these families' lives a nightmare.

title: THE KNOTS AND LOOPS OF LITERATURE
description: THE ESSAYS OF VIRGINIA WOOLF Volume Two: 1912-1918. Edited by Andrew McNeillie. 381 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95.

title: Steven M. Beck Weds Carol Beth Berkowitz
description: Carol Beth Berkowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Berkowitz of Great Neck, L.I., and Boynton Beach, Fla., was married last evening to Steven M. Beck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Beck of Tamarac, Fla. Rabbi Robert Widom officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, L.I.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Computer Network
description: LEAD: SINCE early February, sixth-grade students in Beverly Tarpley's class at the White Plains Intermediate School have been talking, with Apple II GS computers and modems, to their peers in 200 schools in this country and abroad as part of a telecommunications-based science program, the National Geographic Kids Network.

title: A 350th Anniversary Celebration Is Shared
description: ON Tuesday, Finland, Sweden and the United States will celebrate the 350th anniversary of the first landing made by Swedes and Finns in North America. The colony located in what is now Delaware was named New Sweden, after its founder, the New Sweden Company. At the time, Peter Minuit was the company's director.

title: A Bouquet of Fashion Whimsy
description: SOMETHING new has been added to Macy's annual spring flower show, which opens today in all its fragrant glory at the Herald Square store. The main attraction is on the street floor: thousands of fresh flowers, shrubs and trees, from native cactuses and dogwood to African amaryllis and Australian orchids.

title: Passing in the Night
description: The current American effort to find a way to peace in the Middle East faces a frustrating irony. Israel and the Arabs have to a degree exchanged the position they held for many years.

title: Some Japanese (One) Urge Plain Speaking
description: Nearly two decades later, the words of Eisaku Sato still glisten in the annals of Japanese verbal befuddlement.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $305,000 16 Braham Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; fireplace, decks, 60-foot bulkhead on water; taxes $4,400. Bay Shore $665,000 121 South Awixa Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, sun porch, 1 acre with boatslip, 2-car garage; taxes $6,700. Massapequa $163,000 12 Pompano Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; basement, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,800. Northport $204,000 8 Vine Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,800. Wading River $145,000 28 Maple Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old high ranch; family room, dining room, deck; taxes $2,000. Williston Park $240,000 69 Dartmouth Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; dining room, den, attic; taxes $2,100. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. $227,000 Eagle Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new frame colonial; family room, eat-in kitchen, 0.39 acre, not yet assessed. Trumbull, Conn. $319,000 105 Lazybrook Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 6-year-old colonial; facing golf course, cathedral ceilings, 0.75 acre; taxes $2,900. Maplewood, N.J. $196,000 14 Carleton Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 42-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, 1-car garage, deck; taxes $3,726.

title: Stark Visions of Life From the Lands of Kafka
description: ''Espressiv: central Euro-pean Art Since 1960'' - an exhibition hunkered down in the basement of the Hirshhorn Museum through April 17 -brings together a sobering dose of grim, gritty art from five countries: Yugoslavia, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Austria. For the artists represented in the show, the focus is squarely on the human figure, twisted into anguished, grotesque, defiant, occasionally amusing shapes.

title: ORGANIZATION MAN: Victor E. Millar; Why Saatchi Chose a Stodgy Ad Chief
description: MADISON AVENUE was alive with drama last week, as top executives at Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein defected from the shop's British parent, WPP Group P.L.C., and set up their own firm.

title: Louisiana Governor Given Broad Power To Curb the Budget
description: The Legislature today approved a bill giving Gov. Charles E. (Buddy) Roemer extraordinary power to deal with Louisiana's fiscal crisis by slashing government spending.

title: 14-Year-Old Charged in Fatal Mob Beating
description: A 14-year-old boy was charged yesterday in the fatal beating of a theft suspect by a mob in East Harlem last Sunday, the police said.

title: Housing Rights Advocate in Boston Wins Her Own Battle Over Dismissal
description: Kathy B. Gannett has won a battle against a formidable former boss, the Federal Government. In the process she also hopes she has furthered the cause of civil rights in Boston.

title: TAKING RISKS
description: IN HIS MOST RECENT SHOWING OF MEN'S fashions in Milan, Franco Moschino gave tradition a vigorous tweak. Staging his show in a makeshift supper club, rather than in a conventional auditorium, he decked out his models in waiters' coats, and sent real waiters milling about arrayed in his new winter wares. For some, Moschino's deliberate upending of convention was no more than Italian irreverence carried to comic extremes. But it typified the unruly spirit invading some collections this year, as Italy's foremost men's-wear designers sought to revive their reputations as risk takers and rule breakers.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
Constitutional Debate
description: LEAD: Putting a new twist on an old maxim, Susan C. Swanson, the County Historian, says that people who remember the past should have the opportunity to repeat it. And this year, they will - at least in this state.

title: The Peach Bottom Syndrome
description: THEY came to work in jeans and T-shirts, and passed the hours with magazines, video games and rubber band fights. Often, they took turns sleeping, and sometimes everyone on the shift was dozing.

title: ALCOHOLICS ANONYMOUS
description: As a recovering alcoholic, I was pleased to read Nan Robertson's article ''The Changing World of Alcoholics Anonymous'' (Feb. 21). Her style reflects our slogans -straightforward; no hype. As Ms. Robertson points out, ''It is in the intimacy of neighborhood meetings that . . an inkling of the reasons for A.A.'s success can be grasped.''

title: Mauch Retires
description: It was just a mild case of bronchitis that led him to take a couple of weeks off as manager of the California Angels, but the layoff gave Gene Mauch a chance to reflect. Yesterday, after reviewing his 26 years as a major league manager, the 62-year-old Mauch announced that he was stepping down and turning the Angels over to Cookie Rojas, the former major league infielder and Angels scout who had been serving as interim manager.

title: Judith Place To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Bassett Moore Place of San Francisco and Portola Valley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Judith Gauntlett Place to Harold Dean McMillan Jr., a son of Mr. McMillan of Astoria, Ill., and Rachel Mitzbacher of Woodside, Queens. An October wedding is planned.

title: Should Baseball Use The Instant Replay?
description: Any proven technological methods deployed to increase the accuracy of any judgmental decision, I am definitely in favor of for any sport. LEO FONTANELLA Hillside, N.J.

title: Stepping In To Serve as Grandparents
description: No matter how cold the morning, 84-year old Julia Dubin of Port Chester is up early and ready to take the bus to St. Agnes Hospital in White plains. There, at the Children's Rehabilitation Center, she spends four hours a day, five days a week, feeding and fussing over the children she calls her ''babies.'' Everyone at the center calls Miss Dubin ''Grandma,'' and although she has no children of her own the robust native of Costa Rica has earned the title - as a longtime participant in the Foster Grandparent Program of the White Plains-based Westchester Community Opportunity Program.

title: An Olympic Farm System?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Survivor's Duty Is Not to Forget
description: ''MY name is Ruth Minsky Sender. I am a Holocaust survivor.''

title: Steinbrenner Strikes Back
description: George Steinbrenner's prolonged cold war with Dave Winfield advanced to a new front today. The Yankee owner said Winfield's recently published autobiography would disrupt team unity, and he suggested that the player's physical attributes might be diminishing.

title: Parents in Baby M Case Clash on Visiting Rights
description: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould and William Stern, the parents at the heart of the bitter Baby M surrogacy and custody dispute, have taken sharply differing views on the amount of time Mrs. Whitehead Gould should be allowed to see their daughter, Melissa Stern.

title: Wilander and Heat Topple Connors
description: A 35-year-old pitcher may keep going for 10 more years. A 35-year-old defensive end may rush the passer all game without tiring. But 35-year-old tennis players are not meant to play for 3 hours 39 minutes when the temperature is 83 degres in the stands and more than 120 on the cement court and the humidity is 63 degrees and draining.

title: U.C.L.A. Rules the '50th' Poll
description: IT originated in 1939, when it was won by the University of Oregon's basketball team, the Tall Firs as they were known. That first tournament was sponsored by the National Associaton of Basketball Coaches, but when it lost $2,531, the National Collegiate Athletic Association had a suggestion: If the N.C.A.A. could sponsor the tournament in the future, it would write a check to pay the coaches' debts.

title: Review/Pop; 2 Singers at Beacon
description: Regina Belle and Peabo Bryson slid cleanly through a moderately inspired pop concert at the Beacon Theater on Saturday night.

title: India's Spirits Are Being Appeased but Not Expelled by Economic Progress
description: Reports of evil spirits haunting trees and swooping down to possess innocent villagers have shown a marked reduction here in recent years.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In Panama's Cash Crisis, Gambling Spirit Wanes
description: Presidents come and presidents go, but one thing has always remained constant here. For Panamanians, the National Lottery could always be counted on to stay immune to the vicissitudes of politics and daily life.

title: Banned English Paper Reopens in Malaysia
description: Malaysia's liveliest English-language newspaper, The Star, has resumed publication after a five-month ban.

title: Review/Recital; Baritone And Oboe Offer Heine
description: In Heine's ''Doch die Kastraten Klagen,'' a poet and singer derides the castratos, with their pure tones and crystal trills, for objecting to the roughness of his own song. A new setting of the poem, by David Blake, was heard at Weill Recital Hall Friday night in the course of a joint recital by the baritone John Shirley-Quirk and the oboist Sara Watkins. Mr. Blake represents the castratos with an oboe line of bel canto trilling and melodiousness, while the baritone comments ironically from the poet's ''rough'' point of view; both soloists responded with apt characterization.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Washington Talk: The Washington Press Corps; Reagans Join in an Evening of Deflating the High and Mighty
description: President Reagan's farewell appearance at the Gridiron Club dinner transformed the Washington press corps' annual tribal rite in white-tie-and-tails into an evening likely to be remembered for its sentimentality as much as for the pungency of its political one-liners.

title: The Toes Are Tapping and the Bag Stays Packed
description: When Harold Nicholas walks down New York streets, stopping occasionally to watch a little break-dancing, he is likely to be greeted by cries of ''Hey, Little Seymour!'' But the man who played that role in the 1974 film ''Uptown Saturday Night'' is also an internationally known acrobatic tap-dancer. He and his older brother, Fayard, performed as the Nicholas Brothers, starring at the Cotton Club in Harlem, on Broadway and in hit movie musicals. And Harold Nicholas is still dancing, singing and stealing the show at 64.

title: Its Bonus Checks Inviolate, Alaska Nears a Crisis
description: In 1983, Gov. William J. Sheffield urged the Alaska Legislature to end the year-old program giving Alaskans a personal slice of the state's oil wealth, which meant an annual check of several hundred dollars for each resident.

title: In the Dance of the Two Dollars, Canada Seems to Be Taking the Lead
description: After 12 years of trading their currency at a discount to the United States dollar, Canadians have watched recently with a mixture of satisfaction and concern as the Canadian unit has bumped progressively upward, passing the 80-cent (United States) level last recorded in February 1984.

title: Prices of Base Metals Climb
description: Strong demand for stainless steel has sharply increased the prices for base metals and is likely to keep them high through 1988, according to market analysts and metals traders.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; To Lead or Not to Lead
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat, implied last year that he would not seek another term as Senate majority leader. But Mr. Byrd's advisers now say he has not decided what he will do. Rivals are not waiting for the final word.

title: RONNE MANDELKE WED TO A LAWYER
description: Ronne G. Mandelker, the daughter of Evelyn Ostow Mandelker of New York and the late Benjamin Mandelker, and Andrew Halfin Braiterman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Hirsh Braiterman of Baltimore, were married yesterday. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun in Manhattan.

title: Youths Revel on Spring Break
description: Tens of thousands of young people jammed the streets of this desert resort Saturday for traditional spring break revelry watched closely by a reinforced police presence.

title: Move to End Belgian Crisis
description: Jean-Luc Dehaene, a Flemish Christian Democrat, was asked by King Baudouin today to form a government and haul the country out of a five-month crisis. Mr. Dehaene was appointed the King's mediator two months ago to sound out the parties' positions on a new coalition, but abandoned the mission on Thursday after talks failed to bridge differences over the language problem that toppled the Government of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens in October. Political analysts said Mr. Dehaene would have more leverage in negotiations if chosen to form the government rather than acting as mediator.

title: Article 996388 -- No Title
description: Treasury financings scheduled this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's $12.8 billion auction of new three-month and six-month bills.

title: Israeli Given 18 Years In Atomic Secrets Case
description: A Jerusalem district court today sentenced a former nuclear technician, Mordechai Vanunu, to 18 years in prison for telling a London newspaper that Israel was secretly manufacturing atomic bombs in an underground factory.

title: Metro Datelines; Police Rescue Man On Brooklyn Bridge
description: A man who climbed to the top of the Brooklyn Bridge in despondency over family problems surrendered Saturday to the police, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We parents will take our own hang-ups to the grave, but there's no reason for our kids to continue them.'' - Cindy Brannigan of Belfast, Northern Ireland. [ A10:2. ]

title: MILAN GANIK IS MARRIED TO DR. ADDIE SHERBANY
description: Dr. Addie Sherbany, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Sherbany of Manhasset Hills, L.I., and Milan Ganik, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vojtech Ganik of Phoenix, were married yesterday at the Water Club in Manhattan by Rabbi M. Asher Murciano.

title: 'Coach' for Forgetful Swimmers
description: Counting laps as one swims can be tedious, especially when the numbers approach three digits. Now, there is a computer designed to do the task.

title: Topics of The Times; Money in the Hole
description: Last October a little girl named Jessica McClure fell into a well hole in Midland, Tex. Four hundred people - public employees and volunteers - worked for three days and two nights to get her out.

title: 'Jurors Will Disregard' Is Often Not Regarded
description: Even if they try, jurors usually are unable to follow a judge's instructions to disregard inadmissible testimony introduced in trials, says a Northwestern University researcher who studied cases involving illegal searches.

title: Derby Picture Offers No Sure Bet
description: The 114th Kentucky Derby is just 40 days off, but it is as difficult to find anyone with a strong opinion about the race as it is to find a colt who looks like a good bet to win it.

title: Marriage for Thomas
description: Debi Thomas, the United States figure skating champion and Olympic bronze medalist, announced today that she was married to a University of Colorado student just before the world figure skating championships that ended here Saturday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Butterick Co., a consumer products company specializing in home sewing patterns, fashion publications and greeting cards, set up a new division called Butterick Sales Co. and named Allan Feller its president.

title: JONATHAN HERVEY FRANCIS MARRIED TO ROBERTA WOHL
description: The marriage of Roberta Wohl, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Wohl of Queens Village, Queens, to Jonathan Hervey Francis, a son of Mrs. Jonathan B. Francis of Victoria, British Columbia, took place yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Charles Lippman officiated.

title: Armenians and Glasnost; Soviet Press Debate on Regional Discord Underlines Party Split on Democratization
description: From the chaos of mass protest, strikes and ethnic violence that have rocked two southern Soviet republics, a sharp new debate has begun to emerge about what ''democracy'' means in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union.

title: Review/Theater; Panoramic History Of Blacks in America In Wilson's 'Joe Turner'
description: August Wilson continues to rewrite the history of the American theater by bringing the history of black America - and with it the history of white America - to the stage. In ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Mr. Wilson's third play to reach New York, that history unfolds with the same panoramic sweep that marked ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' and ''Fences.'' As the new play's characters hang out in the kitchen and parlor of a black boardinghouse in the Pittsburgh of 1911, they retrace their long hard roads of migration from the sharecropping South to the industrialized North, and those tales again hum with the spellbinding verbal poetry of the blues. Whether a lost young woman is remembering how her mother died laboring in the peach orchards or a bitter man named Herald Loomis (Delroy Lindo) is recounting his seven years of illegal bondage to the Mississippi bounty hunter Joe Turner, Mr. Wilson gives haunting voice to the souls of the American dispossessed.

title: Hebron Has a History of Jewish Expulsion; Bitter Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Cabaret; Mary Haran's Pre-Rock American Pop
description: Although Mary Cleere Haran has appeared on and off Broadway in shows like ''The 1940's Radio Hour,'' ''The Heebie Jeebies,'' and ''Hollywood Opera,'' her stage work barely suggested the superbly supple and witty cabaret singer she has become.

title: Panama's Plan to Sell Seized Flour Provokes Anger
description: Outrage over the seizure by troops of thousands of sacks of flour from the country's two largest mills deepened today after the military Government announced that it planned to sell all 1.3 million pounds to the baking industry.

title: 4 Slain as Rebels in Turkey
description: The security forces shot and killed four people accused of being Kurdish guerrillas in southeastern Turkey today, the Anatolia news agency reported. The agency said the four, who were discovered in a cave, opened fire on Government troops searching the area near Bahce, a village in Adiyaman Province. Most guerrillas in the region are affiliated with the Kurdish Labor Party, which seeks to establish an independent state in southeastern and eastern Turkey.

title: Review/Television; Testimonies to Injustice In 'Moyers: Facing Evil'
description: It's hard to explore ideas on television; the medium moves too fast. Moreover, if it slows down, we grow bored. No matter how thoughtful television tries to be, it doesn't work unless it commands our attention. ''Moyers: Facing Evil'' is thoughtful; it commands our attention as well. In the least likely places, it is full of exhilaration.

title: ROBIN RUSKIN MARRIES BRIAN LINDER, LAWYER
description: Robin Ruskin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Ronald Ruskin of New York and Menands, N.Y., and Brian David Linder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Linder of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Stanley Davids, assisted by Cantor David Benedict, performed the ceremony.

title: American Cold Shoulder for Belfast School
description: There is indeed an unsensational, nonviolent story to be told about the troubled Irish of Belfast. It is about a fragile integrated school started by Protestant and Roman Catholic parents sick of what the sectarian divide has done to the minds of children.

title: Leading the U.S. Assault For a French Clothier
description: As part of a big push to make a name for itself in the United States, the French clothing chain Rodier has named Max J. Garelick president and chief executive of Rodier U.S.A.

title: Review/Television; 2 Views of Relations Between the Sexes: Cynical and Wary
description: Take your choice: relations between men and women these days are generally a matter of (a) cynical hustling or (b) wary truce. Depends on which television channel you stumble into. For the hustler theory, tune in at 9 P.M. tonight to ''Addicted to His Love,'' an ABC television movie starring Barry Bostwick as a modern Lothario on the prowl. The wariness scenario is explored, with wisecracks to spare, on this evening's episode of ''Designing Women,'' on CBS at 8:30.

title: Inside the Courts: A Look at Four Plea Bargains
description: Behind the dry statistics of drug-case prosecutions that help to choke New York City's court dockets are episodes that illustrate typical arrests and typical plea bargains.

title: Metro Datelines; Pipe Bomb Found Near Mayor's House
description: A man walking along a footpath in Carl Schurz Park on the Upper East Side of Manhattan yesterday afternoon found a pipe bomb about 200 feet south of Gracie Mansion, the residence of Mayor Koch, the police said.

title: Oloitokitok Journal; The Lionhearted Masai: Besieged by Modern Life
description: Warriors of the Masai tribe, imposing symbols of a nomadic culture that has journeyed doggedly through the centuries, are caught between tradition and modernity in this rickety outpost nestled against Mount Kilimanjaro.

title: The Genscher Line
description: On April 15, 1986, when U.S. bombers gave a permanent headache to Libya's Muammar el-Qaddafi, Bill Casey brought a group of non-C.I.A. economists in to see the President. As bombs fell on Tripoli, statistics about the Soviet economy rained on Ronald Reagan.

title: Metro Matters; Campaign '88: What's in It For the Bronx?
description: ''What would I ask them?'' Maggie Rodriguez repeated. ''About the drug problem, the crack problem, that's the biggest problem around here.'' ''Holdups, robberies,'' Carmen Velez said. ''Now that we have the new houses here it's going to get worse,'' Mrs. Rodriguez predicted. ''The more new houses we have, the more customers, the more people are going to try crack. I can't even allow the kids to go to the park,'' she said, shrugging a shoulder toward Crotona Park across the street, which, at 8:30 A.M., was deserted except for a jogger in a red running suit, a man walking five dogs and some young men sprawled languidly on boulders.

title: Chile's Growing Trans-Pacific Ties
description: A new cartoon character has shown up in Chilean newspapers in the past year: a cowboy-hatted kangaroo, its pouch stuffed with dollars, telephones and the documents of complicated financial deals.

title: 5 Die in Philadelphia Fire
description: A fire apparently started by a kerosene heater spread through four row houses early Sunday, killing five people and forcing 17 others to flee, officials said.

title: U.S. Official Says New Pressures Against Noriega Are Considered
description: The Reagan Administration has miscalculated the ability of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withstand American economic pressure aimed at forcing his ouster and is now considering further moves against him, a senior State Department official said today.

title: History at Hampton
description: The Hampton University women's basketball team traveled to North Dakota this past weekend, looking to win its first National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship.

title: Other Parties Are Talking To Koppers
description: The Koppers Company said yesterday that it had begun discussions with at least one other company over its sale, although it declined to name possible suitors.

title: Darling Gives It Less Thought
description: Ron Darling, the thinking man's pitcher, is thinking less and winning more these days. And he gave another rave performance for the Mets today when he buzzed seven innings of one-hit shutout ball against the Houston Astros.

title: Iranian Gunboats Attack 2 Tankers in Gulf
description: Iranian gunboats attacked and set fire to the Danish supertanker Karama Maersk in the southern Gulf today, regional shipping sources said. The attack came a day after a smaller Indian tanker was set afire by Iranian gunboats near the Strait of Hormuz.

title: Korean Growth at 12%
description: South Korea's gross national product grew 12 percent last year, down from a growth rate of 12.3 percent in 1986, the Bank of Korea announced Friday. Bank officials said exports accounted for 46.1 percent of the G.N.P. last year, reaching a record total of $47.2 billion, up 36.2 percent from a year earlier.

title: Digging Up Tourney's Roots
description: JOHN DICK was a junior at Oregon in 1939 when the Ducks defeated Ohio State in the first National Collegiate Athletic Association national championship basketball game.

title: A Key Pickens Aide Sets Out on His Own
description: When the definitive history of Wall Street is written, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is assured a place as the house that built the junk bond. But had it not been for David H. Batchelder, adviser to the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens, the age of the junk bond might well have arrived much later.

title: Officials to Meet on Swaggart
description: The highest governing body of the Assemblies of God church is expected to meet Monday to resolve a dispute over discliplinary action against the Rev. Jimmy Swaggart for his admitted moral lapses.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Killed by Train In Apparent Suicide
description: A Long Island man died after throwing himself in front of a Metro-North train yesterday afternoon in what officials described as an apparent suicide.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did Billy Martin ever manage in the minor leagues?

title: An American 'Tai-pan' For Jardine Matheson
description: Brian M. Powers, an American from Massapequa, L.I., became one of the most powerful people in Hong Kong by being named ''tai-pan,'' or ''big boss,'' of Jardine Matheson & Company, the big trading concern.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1988
description: THE ECONOMY Interest rates seem unlikely to move much from recent levels, although the credit markets may be stimulated in the short term by the drop in stock prices. There is little evidence that either the economy or inflation will shoot up, analysts say. They predict that yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond are likely to remain within a range of 8.50 percent to 8.75 percent for a few weeks. [ Page D1. ] Orders for U.S.-made machine tools rose last month, in part because of a surge in exports. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Stock prices rose today in Tokyo, with the Nikkei index rising 270.78, or 1.07 percent, by midday. [ D5. ] The World Bank may lose some of its strongest allies in a Congressional showdown over the lender's need for new capital. [ D1. ] A surge in the value of Canada's dollar is raising concern that continued gains against the U.S. dollar could reduce Canadian exports and choke off Canada's impressive economic growth. [ D10. ] Chile's fast-growing economy is drawing a flood of investments from Asia, Australia and New Zealand. [ D10. ] COMPANIES Koppers said it had begun discussions about a sale with at least one other company, in an effort to thwart Beazer's $1.85 billion bid. The Pittsburgh-based maker of building materials said it was also considering a recapitalization. [ D1. ] Attacks on the Beazer takeover offer by Pennsylvania state officials have been unusally harsh, analysts say. The officials have been especially critical of the role played by Shearson Lehman Hutton. [ D1. ] A Pennsylvania steel mill has been revived with the help of an innovative economic ''swat team'' for industry. [ Page A14. ] WPP Group will go to court today, challenging an agency formed by executives from its Lord, Geller unit, amid signs of growing resentment over British control of U.S. agencies. [ D2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The dean of retail display art has taken a minimalist approach to this year's Easter displays in the famous windows of Tiffany & Company. New Yorkers & Co. [ D1. ] Taxpayers are making the same old mistakes. Of the 10 most frequent errors this year, only three are related to changes in the tax code, the I.R.S. says. Tax Watch. [ D2. ] Bondholders now control the economy, a prominent economist contends. As a result of their prudence, he says, recessions may be a thing of the past. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Review/Dance; Theatrical Look at Love In a Pastoral Setting
description: Mimi Gross created magic in ''Matches,'' a new theater-dance piece choreographed by Douglas Dunn and performed by Douglas Dunn and Dancers on Saturday night at the Kitchen. All the wit and exuberance of Ms. Gross's paintings inform the set and costumes she designed for this full-evening work, which must be the first theatrical event to list ''volunteer leaf painters'' in its credits.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Taking a Fresh Look at Eggs After 34 Easters at Tiffany
description: Gene Moore is leaning back in his chair this morning in his seventh-floor office at Tiffany & Company dreaming about Easter 1989. ''Eggs,'' he is thinking, as he has every Easter for the 53 years since he began to dress windows in the stores along Fifth Avenue. ''What can I do with eggs that I haven't done before?''

title: More Grain Sold to Soviet
description: Federally subsidized sales of 475,000 metric tons of hard red winter wheat to the Soviet Union have been arranged by five private exporters, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The Foreign Agriculture

title: Queens Gets Court to Speed Drug Cases
description: After nearly a year of delays, a court unit devoted exclusively to narcotics cases will begin operating in Queens today in an effort to speed the prosecution of dealers arrested in the borough's drug-plagued neighborhoods.

title: Alcatraz Journal; Rock May Be a Hard Place for Casino
description: Suppose you had a beautiful city by the bay with a projected budget deficit of $172 million. Suppose that bay had a 12-acre rock sitting in it, formerly the home of an infamous Federal prison and now a tourist attraction that draws nearly 800,000 people each year.

title: Exercise Gains Support As a Key Ingredient In a Weight-Loss Plan
description: ALTHOUGH the national obsession with fitness is now more than a decade old (some would argue more than two decades old), beginning a serious exercise program for the first time can still generate excitement and turn a person's life around.

title: Review/Dance; Solo for Senta Driver Is a Cerebral Walk
description: Senta Driver once called her dances portraits of herself thinking. She certainly was a thinking choreographer on Saturday night when her company, Harry, came to the Emanu-El Midtown Y. Ms. Driver revived ''Memorandum,'' a cerebral and astonishing solo dating from 1975 in which she simply trudged while reciting names of famous ballet dancers. Occasionally, she raised or lowered her arms. Otherwise, all she did was trudge. If one could not tell what she thought about those dancers, the weight of her steps implied that she had much on her mind.

title: Economic Swat Team Saves Jobs in Pennsylvania
description: Last summer, in yet another setback for American industry, the bankrupt LTV Corporation closed down J & L Structural Inc., one of the last functioning mills in LTV's vast steel-making complex along the Ohio River near here. Gene Gormley, the mill operator, scratched the date on his control console as if it were an epitaph: 8-14-87.

title: Hebron Has a History of Jewish Expulsion
description: To the Editor:

title: Lynne Whitman, Engineer, Wed to D. S. Solender
description: Lynne Barbara Whitman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira L. Whitman of East Brunswick, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Solomon Solender, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Solender of Manhattan. Rabbi Eric Milgrim officiated at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins 6, Nordiques 3: Mario Lemieux scored two short-handed goals yesterday as Pittsburgh, playing on the road, beat Quebec and moved into a fourth-place tie in the Patrick Division with the Rangers. Lemieux, the league's leading scorer with 65 goals, has figured in 13 the last 14 goals scored by the Penguins. Lemieux's second short-handed goal at 2 minutes 18 seconds of the third period gave the Penguins a 4-1 lead. He stole the puck from Marc Fortier at the Quebec blue line and virtually carried the Nordiques' player on his back for 30 feet before scoring.(AP) Whalers Close to Clinching: In Hartford, the Whalers scored three goals in the final period last night, two by Carey Wilson, as they drew within 2 points of clinching the final playoff berth in the Adams Division with a 4-2 victory over Montreal. Ron Francis and Wilson scored during a 54-second span early in the period, and Wilson added his 26th goal of the season with 6:46 left. The Whalers have a 7-point lead over the Quebec Nordiques. To make the playoffs, the Nordiques would have to win all four of their remaining games while the Whalers failed to get 2 points.(AP) Red Wings 5, Sabres 3: Adam Oates had two goals and two assists last night to lead Detroit to victory in Buffalo. Dave Barr, Petr Klima and Joey Kocur got the other goals for the Red Wings, who have already clinched the Norris Division title. The Sabres clinched their first playoff berth in three seasons when Quebec lost to Boston Saturday. (AP) AUTO RACING First-Time Nascar Winner: Lake Speed came up with the victory that had eluded him for nine years, driving away from the field yesterday in the TranSouth 500 Nascar stock car race at Darlington (S.C.) International Raceway. The 40-year-old driver from Jackson, Miss., beat Alan Kulwicki to the finish line by 19 seconds. The victory came in the 164th race of Speed's Nascar career, dating back to 1980. Speed, who started his team in 1986, drove an Oldsmobile to the victory, averaging 131.284 miles per hour in the race, which was slowed by eight caution flags, three in the first 31 laps. He won $49,435, giving him career earnings of $1,037,300. Davey Allison wound up a distant third, the only other competitor on the lead lap at the end. Most of the favorites were slowed by accidents or mechanical problems.(AP) GOLF South Korean Woman Wins: Ok Hee Ku of South Korea made a 12-foot uphill putt to save par on the 18th hole yesterday and won the Turquoise Classic, her first Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament victory in three years on the tour. She had a four-round total of 11-under-par 281 and shot a one-under-par 72 yesterday. Her best previous finish was third in the 1986 Boston Classic. Tied for second, one shot behind, were Ayako Okamoto of Japan and Dottie Mochrie. Colleen Walker and Amy Alcott, co-leaders after two rounds, finished three shots back on the 6,404-yard par-73 Moon Valley Country Club course in Phoenix.(AP) HORSE SHOW Matz Wins in Florida: Michael Matz of Collegeville, Pa., won his 35th career Grand Prix riding Bon Retour to victory yesterday in the Cadillac Grand Prix of Florida at the Bob Thomas Equestrian Center in Tampa. Matz was one of five entries to reach a timed jumpoff by turning in two penalty-free rides. The event was the final one to qualify United States show jumpers for next month's World Cup finals in Gothenburg, Sweden. The 10 riders in the finals are Katie Prudent of Middleburg, Va.; Michaela Murphy of Far Hills, N.J.; Joe Fargis of Southampton, N.Y.; George Morris of Pittstown, N.J.; Chris Kappler of St. Charles, Ill.; Greg Best of Flemington, N.J.; Norman Dello Joio of South Salem, N.Y.; Rodney Jenkins of Montpelier Station, Va.; Peter Leone of Franklin Lakes, N.J.; and Jay Land of Atlanta. ROAD RACING Staten Island Runner First: Frank McConville of Staten Island, third last year, won the New York Road Runners Club's Haworth 10-kilometer run yesterday in 30 minutes 18 seconds at Central Park. A field of 2,412 competed in the 6.2-mile race. The 24-year-old McConville finished 280 yards ahead of Mike Feurtado of the Warren Street A.C. Gordon Bakoulis of the Atalanta Track Club won the women's title in 34:31. DOG SHOW Sheepdog Takes Top Honors: An Old English sheepdog, Ch. Aphrodite Snow Jubilee, owned by Toni Lett and Arlene Pietrocola, was gaited by Bill Trainor to the top honors yesterday at the Twin Brooks Kennel Club show in the Dunn Sports Center in Elizabeth, N.J. It was only the third ring appearance since she had a litter of seven puppies 16 weeks ago. ''She had all the aspects of a good show dog, for she was in there to win,'' said Joseph Dainty, the judge. ''Then she has a magnificent coat and a beautiful head.''

title: Collective Effort Lifts Kansas; Arizona Stops North Carolina; Kansas State Falls, 71-58
description: Injuries, suspensions and academic problems could easily have ruined their season, but the Kansas Jayhawks seemed to survive with the brilliance of Danny Manning and a hard-working, complementary mix. The Jayhawks appear to be lifted by Manning not unlike the way Larry Bird's gifts raised an otherwise ordinary Indiana State team all the way to the 1979 championship game.

title: Elections Offer Only an Illusion of Participation
description: To the Editor:

title: Devils Keep Hopes Alive
description: After their 7-2 triumph over the Rangers here this afternoon, the Devils have come a step closer to believing the last playoff spot in the Patrick Division is within their grasp.

title: For Edward Said, Shultz Session Proved Collegial and Constructive
description: Even before Edward W. Said visited Washington Saturday to discuss the Middle East with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel complained that the meeting violated a United States commitment not to meet with members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Kemp to Back Bush
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp is expected to endorse Vice President Bush on Monday. Officials with knowledge of the endorsement said today that the Congressman from upstate New York had agreed to support Mr. Bush after conversations with the Vice President and his campaign. Mr. Kemp is scheduled to campaign with Mr. Bush in Wisconsin. Mr. Kemp dropped out of the Presidential race earlier this month.

title: No Clear Verdict on Various Tournament Formats
description: The issue of how best to run an elimination tournament in college hockey came into focus again over the weekend, and it was hard to say which of two formats was fairer for athletes and spectators, total goals or the mini-game.

title: Advertising; Revision at Doremus
description: The Omnicom Group has split Doremus Porter Novelli back into its previous components, with Doremus Public Relations handling financial and investor relations, and Porter Novelli doing general public relations and serving as the worldwide coordinator of the Omnicom PR Network. Both units are part of Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services division.

title: Army Rethinks Plan for a Utah Test Site
description: The Army has decided to reconsider its plan to build a laboratory in Utah for testing defenses against biological weapons. The decision came after a week marked by increasingly intense local opposition.

title: Don't Exaggerate Its Effect
description: LEAD: Would the exclusion of foreign journalists help Israel quell the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza? Probably not.

title: The Wizard Surveys His Changing Game
description: IN the next room, the framed pictures of his U.C.L.A. championship teams have been hung on a wall. Each of the 10 frames holds the young faces of Bruins - Lew Alcindor, Bill Walton, and champions that came before, between and after - with the backdrop of the arena that housed the national semifinals and finals.

title: Books of The Times; Brinkley Recalls How Washington Went to War
description: Washington Goes to War By David Brinkley Illustrated. 286 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Proposal to Curb Busing in Seattle Seeks to Attract Whites to Schools
description: In an effort to lure white students back into the Seattle public schools, Superintendent William M. Kendrick is proposing to halve the number of children bused for racial integration.

title: OPEC Unity Called Crucial
description: A prominent Arab oil expert, describing the oil market as ''very weak,'' warned today that the failure of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to abide by their output quotas could bring a collapse of oil prices.

title: Top-Ranked Logo
description: Whenever the phone used to ring at the Temple University bookstore, it was usually a personal call for one of the employees or a wrong number. Occasionally, it was a faithful alumnus seeking a sweatshirt for his grandson.

title: Advertising; A Mammoth Spoof by Keye/Donna
description: KEYE/DONNA/PEARLSTEIN of Los Angeles will reveal itself tomorrow as the cunning collective brain behind the mysterious print advertisements for Mammoth Pervasive and Bland Inc., a nonexistent agency.

title: The Dumb Pursuit of a Smart Weapon
description: The Defense Department spends billions in developing high-tech weapons to offset the Soviet edge in numbers. To understand how perversely this vital agenda is pursued, consider the death of the Aquila, a pilotless plane that the Army has been developing for 14 years. It is one of the few new weapons canceled in the new defense budget.

title: FOUR MORE ARABS KILLED BY ISRAELIS
description: Israeli soldiers shot dead four more Palestinians today as the army pressed a campaign that the Government says has led to the arrest of nearly 2,000 people in a week and a half.

title: Chinese Plan For Investment
description: China plans to set up five companies to supervise investment in such areas of the economy as energy and transportation, the Deputy Prime Minister Yao Yilin said today.

title: Outdoors: As March Ends, the Trout Season Begins
description: ALONG with snowdrops blooming in secluded places, pussy willow catkins swelling and the first orange-red nodules of rhubarb emerging from last year's mulch, another sure sign of spring in New York State is the opening of the trout season April 1.

title: Musher's Memories
description: Susan Butcher had the sniffles, which seemed natural enough for someone who recently spent 11 days 11 hours 42 minutes shivering through some the worst weather Alaska has to offer while chasing a dog sled over 1,158 miles of some of the state's most forbidding terrain.

title: Supporters Link Death Of Indian to Candidacy
description: A rarity in racially troubled Robeson County, Julian Pierce was respected by blacks, Indians and whites, but many of his supporters say he was slain because someone did not want a Lumbee Indian to be a judge.

title: WPP-Lord Dispute Focuses on Autonomy
description: WPP Group of Britain will go to court today in an effort to ward off the potential collapse of its Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein subsidiary. But the company's actions may help make its chairman, Martin Sorrell, the target of anti-British feelings that have surfaced in the advertising business.

title: Stock Dip May Keep Bonds Up
description: The recent sharp drop in stock prices may provide a short-term stimulant to the fixed-income markets, but most analysts say that interest rates are likely to remain mired in the narrow range they have occupied for the past several weeks.

title: Gymnastics; The Fiery Karolyi Lands on His Feet
