description: HERE and there on the north side of town, large billboards suggest how passersby might help the United States cause later this year in Seoul, South Korea. They show Bela Karolyi, the renowned gymnastics coach, standing with three potential Olympians who are ''going for the gold'' and ''can use your help.'' Karolyi has a large training center nearby.

title: Metro Datelines; Three Are Killed In Head-on Car Crash
description: A 10-year-old boy and two adults were killed, and two girls were injured in a head-on crash Saturday night, the state police said yesterday.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday New-Home Sales Feb. Prices of New Homes Feb. Leading Indicators Feb. Wednesday Factory Orders Feb. Thursday Farm Prices March Friday Unemployment March Construction Spending Feb.

title: Review/Pop; An Irish Songwriter Shows Her Volatility
description: Passion is volatile in Sinead O'Connor's songs; within a verse, it can become love, anger, lust, vulnerability, defiance or religious fervor. The songs on her debut album, ''The Lion and the Cobra,'' carefully channel those raw emotions, shifting unpredictably from plea to accusation or from meditation to rock stomp; her voice can be sweet or lacerating, delivering endearments in a bitter rasp or breaking into wordless ululation. On Saturday, with ''The Lion and the Cobra'' now in the Top 50, the Irish songwriter gave her first New York City concert at the World, which sold out weeks in advance.

title: Honi Coles to Receive Capezio Dance Award
description: Charles (Honi) Coles is to receive the 37th annual Capezio Dance Award. W. McNeil Lowry, a former vice president of the Ford Foundation, is to receive a special tribute at the award presentation in a private ceremony on April 18 at the Joyce Theater. Alvin Ailey is to serve as the master of ceremonies and Agnes de Mille is to present Mr. Coles with the $5,000 prize.

title: A Rave Review for Navy
description: In rare praise for a nuclear weapons program, the House Armed Services Committee said today that the Navy's program to build an improved Trident submarine-launched missile appears to be on time and under budget. ''The other programs we've looked at had a variety of problems, so this is kind of a man-bites-dog story,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and the panel's chairman.

title: 2 Savings Units Acquired
description: Two failed Oklahoma savings and loan associations with assets totaling $168 million were taken over by Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association of Minneapolis, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said Friday. The action is expected to cost the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation $76 million, the bank board said. Investors Savings and Loan Association, based in El Reno, was in receivership, with its capital about $27 million below minimum requirements. The other institution, United Federal Savings and Loan Association of Durant, had negative net worth of $21 million, the bank board said.

title: Topics of The Times; Witness for a Special Prosecutor
description: All accused persons are presumed innocent until proved guilty, but few enjoy that presumption as fully as the indicted Iran-contra defendants. President Reagan, the highest law officer in the land, the man for whom the attorney general works, said of them last week: ''I just have to believe that they're going to be found innocent because I don't believe they're guilty of lawbreaking of any kind.''

title: Bearden Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Romare Bearden, the painter and collagist who died March 11, is to be held at noon April 6 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Derek Walcott, the poet, Ralph Ellison, the novelist, and Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, the city's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs and an authority on Mr. Bearden's work, are to speak at the service, which is being organized by June Kelly, Mr. Bearden's manager, and Richard Clarke, an art collector.

title: Anxious Times for Rangers
description: There were more than five minutes left in the third period today when Michel Bergeron of the Rangers pulled his goaltender. For the Rangers, who lost to the Devils, 7-2, to complete a disappointing weekend, time is running out and desperation may be setting in.

title: More Whites in South Africa Resisting the Draft
description: Ivan Toms, a 35-year-old physician, chose to go to jail for 21 months rather than continue serving as a reserve lieutenant in the South African Defense Force.

title: Jubilant Jackson Stresses His Record in Connecticut
description: A jubilant Jesse Jackson, fresh from a stunning victory in the Michigan Democratic caucuses Saturday, brought his campaign to Connecticut today, telling cheering supporters that he has a better record of service here than any of his opponents in the Connecticut primary Tuesday.

title: U.S. Places Car Theft Losses At $29 Billion Over 13 Years
description: More than 12.3 million cars, trucks, vans and motorcycles valued at $52 billion were stolen over a 13-year period, the Federal Government said today.

title: Market Place; New Power Seen For Bondholders
description: THROUGHOUT the economic expansion of the 1980's the economist Edward A. Hyman warned time and again that the longer it continued the greater grew the risk of a 1930's-type depression.

title: The Evolution That's Sought At The Post
description: Peter S. Kalikow and Peter O. Price, the new owner and publisher of The New York Post, have begun what they describe as ''evolutionary changes'' intended to highlight the newspaper's ties to Manhattan and make it ''the in-flight magazine of the New York City commuter.''

title: South Africa Rail Offering
description: South Africa has started an ambitious privatization program with the stock flotation of a railway company that includes the Banana Express, a line carrying tourists on a scenic stretch of the Indian Ocean coast.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Pillow Fellows
description: In Washington, social functions can make strange bedfellows, or in this case, pillow-fellows.

title: Fundamentalism, Too, Is Part of Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Joan Harris Blum, Counseling Director, 63
description: Joan Harris Blum, director of a drug and alcohol counseling program in Millbrook, N.Y., died of cancer today at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Millbrook.

title: Should TV Be Barred? Tyrannies Say Yes
description: LEAD: ''Sticks and stones may break my bones but television can really hurt me.'' That seems to be the modern version of the old nursery rhyme now being mouthed by everyone from a realpolitiker like Henry A. Kissinger to a local warrior like Mayor Koch of New York City.

title: Advertising; Equimark, in Search, Names Four Finalists
description: The Equimark Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based financial holding company, has not only announced it is searching for a new agency but also the names of the four finalists, all in New York.

title: NICARAGUA FREES 100 FROM PRISON UNDER CEASE-FIRE
description: One hundred Nicaraguan prisoners walked through a wire gate to freedom today, the first direct beneficiaries of the new cease-fire accord.

title: Charter Panel To Hear Plan From Its Chief
description: The Charter Revision Commission will hear its chairman's proposal for revamping the New York City government today, at a meeting bound to irritate further the frayed tempers of elected officials who favor the status quo.

title: Tax Watch; Leading Mistakes Of Taxpayers
description: DESPITE the numerous tax law changes that were incorporated in the 1987 income tax returns, the most common errors cropping up this season are mainly the kind that taxpayers have made in years past: sloppy math and putting numbers in the wrong places on the tax forms.

title: I.M.F. Sees Faster Growth
description: The economies of the seven leading industrial democracies are expected to grow by 2.6 percent this year and by 2.8 percent in 1989, according to economists at the International Monetary Fund.

title: Lee Guber, 67; Theater Producer And Entertainment Official, Dies
description: Lee Guber, who helped produce nearly a dozen shows on Broadway and was part of an entertainment chain that brought such performers as Judy Garland, Jack Benny, Sammy Davis Jr., Perry Como and Liberace to suburban theaters and concert halls around the country, died of brain cancer yesterday at his home on the East Side of Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: Advertising; Publishers' Award To Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather has once again won the richest purse in advertising, the $100,000 award bestowed by the Magazine Publishers of America for the best magazine advertising of the year.

title: Supporters Push for New >Library for Handicapped
description: A small brick building in lower Manhattan has been the focus in the past year of a barrage of letters, petitions and telephone pleas that is intensifying as the state's budget negotiations draw to a close.

title: Advertising; Three Trade Groups Form Freedom Council
description: Against a background of agitation in various Federal and state quarters to regulate advertising, the three mightiest organizations in that industry have banned together to fight further incursions into the freedom of commercial speech.

title: World Bank Friends Talk of Bolting
description: Some of the strongest backers of the World Bank, which has never had a lot of friends in Congress, may turn against it this year in an election-year showdown over the need for additional capital.

title: Bradley Works to Recapture 1986 Pace
description: Richard and Kathleen Bradley of Westford, Mass., have a tradition: they ring a Swiss cowbell on the front porch of their colonial house every time their daughter wins a golf tournament.

title: Campaign in New York Beginning As Party Weighs Jackson's Role
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign comes to New York State in earnest this week with three candidates debating at Fordham University tonight and New York politicians trying to assess the Rev. Jesse Jackson's stunning victory Saturday in Michigan.

title: Amy Knoblauch Wed to David Dubin
description: At Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, Amy Gail Knoblauch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Knoblauch of Reading, Pa., and James David Dubin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Dubin of State College, Pa., were married yesterday by Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg.

title: Stock Prices Rise in Tokyo, Fall Sharply in Hong Kong
description: Stock prices jumped here today in active midday trading. Brokers said that the activity reflected the beginning of the new stock market fiscal year, ignoring a faltering dollar and a weaker trend overseas.

title: Street Life: Keeping 'Beloved Places'
description: It is four days until Passover, but by yesterday afternoon the air inside Schapiro's had the sweet, sticky smell of the seder table after the fourth glass of wine. Small wonder. Since 1899, Schapiro's has been making what it calls ''the wine you can almost cut with a knife,'' storing it in cellars on the Lower East Side and dispensing it at Passover in gallon jugs.

title: Panoramic History of Blacks in America in Wilson's 'Joe Turner'
description: August Wilson continues to rewrite the history of the American theater by bringing the history of black America - and with it the history of white America - to the stage. In ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' Mr. Wilson's third play to reach New York, that history unfolds with the same panoramic sweep that marked ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom'' and ''Fences.''

title: Markets to Close Friday
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed April 1 in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign stock exchanges will be closed. Banks will be open, as will most businesses and Government offices. The Labor Department is scheduled to report on the nation's unemployment rate for March, and the Commerce Department is scheduled to report on construction spending for February.

title:
ON YOUR OWN: TENNIS;
Finding the Nerve To Enforce Rule On Foot-Faulting
description: LEAD: IT'S unlikely that many club tennis players would describe themselves as cheaters. But it's quite probable that, technically, they often are. That's because so many of them violate Rule 8 of the Rules of Tennis. Rule 8 is the foot-fault rule, one of the game's most misunderstood and, in recreational matches, difficult to enforce.

title: Early Gainsborough Found
description: The British Museum said today that it was buying an early self-portrait of Thomas Gainsborough that has recently come to light in London and is believed to be the only finished drawing of the 18th-century English painter known to exist. Dated 1754 to 1759, when Gainsborough was between 27 and 31 years old, the drawing is being bought from a dealer who acquired it in the United States, a museum spokesman said. He declined to give the price, saying ''The deal is not yet complete.'' Art experts have long thought that the portrait existed, because of a lithograph based on it made in the 1820's.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Dawson Prefers Two-Year Pact
description: Andre Dawson said in a report published today that he would stay with the Chicago Cubs, regardless of his possible free-agent status, if he could sign an acceptable two-year contract with the club.

title: Jersey Official's Death Is Suicide
description: The authorities here have confirmed that suicide was the cause of death of a New Jersey education official who had been dismissed amid a criminal investigation of his office.

title: Elections Offer Only an Illusion of Participation; Making of a Primary
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Two Foursomes Face Each Other in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Final at the Spring Nationals
description: Two tough foursomes, liberally supplied with both skill and stamina, fought here this afternoon in the final of the Vanderbilt knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13 Nicaragua freed 100 prisoners under the cease-fire agreement signed by the Government and rebels. The prisoners released represent a cross-section of those being held for violating the public security law. Page A1 Flour seized by Panamanian troops will be sold to the baking industry. The Government confiscated flour from two private mills where it was being stored for distribution by a relief organization, provoking outrage. A3 Panama's lottery has lost customers as the country's cash shortage worsens. Panamanians, hoarding food and money, doubt the Government's ability to pay the winners. No one wants to buy the tickets. A3 Washington miscalculated the ability of the Panamanian leader, Gen. Manuel Noriega, to withstand efforts to force him from office and will have to re-evaluate the situation next week if he is still in power, a U.S. official said. A6 News analysis: Protests in Armenia and Azerbaijan have touched off debate in the Soviet Union over what democratization means under Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Some want more discipline. Others want more responsive government. A1 An integrated school in Belfast, started by Catholics and Protestants, found on a trip to raise money that the school held less interest for some Irish-Americans than the Troubles. A1 White resistance to the draft is growing in South Africa, where military service is compulsory.A white doctor who went to prison rather than serve has become a symbol for consciensious objectors. A13 Four more Palestinians were killed by Israeli soldiers as Israel pressed a campaign that the Government says has led to the arrest of nearly 2,000 people in a week and half. The protests continue despite the arrests. A12 Two Palestinian-Americans who met Secretary of State George P. Shultz Saturday said the meeting was an informal exchange of ideas. Israel complained that the meeting violated a U.S. promise not to meet members of the P.L.O. A12 Kenya's Masai yielding to change A4 Evil spirits in an Indian village A8 National A14-19, B6 A higher minimum wage may win Congress's approval, setting the stage for a possible a Presidential veto. Supporters say the bill would help the poor. The Administration says employers would hire fewer people. A1 A Pennsylvania economic office that has ready access to the Governor has worked with private entrepreneurs and state agencies to quickly right faltering companies and to attract out-of-state industries. A14 Testing biological weapon defenses in Utah is being opposed by leading politicians and is being reconsidered by the Army. Opponents include Senator Orrin G. Hatch and the Governor. A14 Busing to desegregate schools in Seattle may be used less under a proposal by the superintendent to lure white students back into the public schools. The city voluntarily agreed to bus students 10 years ago. A17 Alcatraz Journal: Rock may be a hard place for a casino A14 Indian's candidacy for judgeship linked to slaying A15 Its bonus checks inviolate, Alaska nears a crisis A19 Politics B6 Jesse Jackson's victory in Michigan astonished Democratic Party leaders. Party professionals have begun contemplating the possibility that Mr. Jackson could win more delegates than anyone else. A1 The campaign in New York has begun. Three Democratic Presidential candidates will debate at Fordham University tonight. Against that background, New York politicians are assessing Jesse Jackson's victory in Michigan. A1 A victory for Michael S. Dukakis in Connecticut's Democratic Presidential primary on Tuesday would give him a sweep of New England states. But the size of the victory will be important for his campaign. B6 Jubilant Jackson stresses his record in Connecticut B6 Washington Talk A18 Reagans join in evening of deflating the high and mighty Regional B1-4 A court for narcotics cases in Queens begins operation after nearly a year of delays. The new unit is intended to help speed the prosecution of drug dealers arrested in a campaign to stem the cocaine trade in Queens. B1 St. Patrick's Cathedral at Easter is busier than any other time in the year. Choirs are rehearsing every night, extra priests are hearing confessions and all the seats for the 10:15 A.M. Easter Mass have been given out. B1 New York's first Fitness Expo for aerobic exercising took place at the Palladium. San Francisco and Los Angeles, more with-it aerobically, have been holding FitnessExpos for five years. B1 Plans for The New York Post call for evolutionary change to highlight the newspaper's ties to Manhattan. Peter S. Kalikow and Peter O. Price, the new owner and publisher, want to make it the paper for New York City commuters. B1 Folklore on the Lower East Side is being catalogued by two researchers as part of a project to document neighborhood institutions on film and tape before they disappear. B3 A library for the handicapped on the Avenue of the Americas has been the focus of a barrage of letters, petitions and telephone pleas. Supporters want New York state officials to spend $16 million for a new building. B3 Visiting rights in the Baby M case are at issue. The parents have different views over how much time Mary Beth Whitehead Gould, the mother, should be allowed to see the child, Melissa Stern. Mrs. Whitehead Gould seeks more time. B3 The Charter Review Commission is expected to hear a proposal today that the Board of Estimate be disbanded and its powers be distributed among the City Council, a land-use panel, the mayoralty and the borough presidents. B3 Plea bargains dispose of typical minor drug cases B4

title: Fred Jacobson, Lyricist, 73
description: Fred Jacobson, a former United States Foreign Service officer and a lyricist, died of a heart attack at Greenwich Hospital today. He was 73 years old and lived in Greenwich, Manhattan and Florence.

title: New York Prisons Need More Spanish-Speaking Employees
description: To the Editor:

title: EXEMPTIONS LIKELY IN DRIVING PERMITS
description: The Transportation Department says it is taking steps that could exempt farmers and firefighters from new Federal rules that force all truck drivers to obtain commercial licenses.

title: Real Estate a Lure in Takeovers
description: Corporate raiders used to look at one thing in picking an acquisition target: the value of a company's businesses in relation to its stock price.

title: Ford's Units Report a Profit
description: The Ford Motor Company's non-automotive subsidiaries together earned a $62 million profit in 1987, their first money-making year since 1979, the auto maker said in its annual report.

title: McCumber Wins With Record Score
description: Mark McCumber, who gave up the landscaping business for the pro golf tour 10 years ago, completed a record score of 15-under-par 273 on the Tournament Players Club course today to easily win the Players Championship.

title: Mayor and de Montebello Go Voice to Voice
description: An intense rivalry is shaping up between two star vocalists, Edward I. Koch, the Mayor of New York, and Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum, on the sonic battlefield of cassette tapes.

title: Bills to Raise Minimum Wage Advance in a Ready Congress
description: If the advocates are correct, raising the minimum wage, now $3.35 an hour, would have few noticeable adverse effects on business or employment and could stimulate the economy by increasing the purchasing power of the 4.7 million Americans who earn it.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 27, 1988: MONDAY Amer Express Sierra Pacific Resources BellSouth Corp Unocal Corp Pep Boys-Manny Moe TUESDAY UGI Corp WEDNESDAY Cascade Nat Gas Iowa Resources Donaldson Co Washington DC Gas Lt GenCorp Inc THURSDAY Norton Co FRIDAY Ennis Business Forms US West Nevada Pwr

title: Tool Orders Up in February For Second Straight Month
description: Bolstered by substantial increases in exports, orders for American-made machine tools remained strong for the second straight month, increasing by two-tenths of 1 percent in February from the previous month, to $298 million, the industry's trade association said.

title: Man Missing in River After Saving Son's Life
description: A man gave up his life preserver to save his son after a boating accident near here and was missing and presumed drowned today in the Sandy River.

title: Collective Effort Lifts Kansas; Arizona Stops North Carolina; Wildcats Coast To 70-52 Victory
description: When Arizona began its season with victories over Syracuse, Michigan and Iowa, skeptics said that Lute Olson's Wildcats were playing too well too early and predicted burnout by February.

title: E.T.A. Blamed in a Bombing And Killing of an Ex-General
description: A retired Spanish Air Force general was shot to death and a bomb exploded in central Madrid today, wounding two people. The police blamed the Basque separatist group E.T.A. for both attacks.

title: Review/Dance; Maya Plisetskaya Stars As Doomed Karenina
description: Maya Plisetskaya as diva - that is the image to retain of the Bolshoi Ballet's superstar in the title role of ''Anna Karenina.''

title: Further Drop In Gas Prices
description: The average retail price of gasoline fell again during the past two weeks, to less than 95 cents a gallon, according to a nationwide survey.

title: 'Neat' Is Finito
description: LEAD: That's it, finito. Neat's gone, worn-out, beyond repair. ''Neat'' - meaning nifty, meaning something I admired, meaning what 100,000 Valley Girls used to mean when they declared something ''totally awesome.'' Though it was long one of my favorite words, I just can't bring myself to use it anymore.

title: Review/Opera; Cast Changes In Cosi Fan Tutte At the Met
description: Three new cast members assembled in ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday evening. Douglas Ahlstedt, as Ferrando, came closer than he has in other seasons to fulfilling the promise he showed when he came on the scene in the 1970's. His tenor rang out bright and true in the first scenes, he acted with spirit, and though he is not a model of elegant phrasing, he did quite capable work in the lyrical movements.

title: Pennsylvania Takes On Wall St.
description: As Beazer P.L.C. of Britain made its sweetened bid for the Koppers Company official last week, executives of the Pittsburgh-based company stepped up their campaign to ward off the takeover through a publicity campaign that has mobilized state and local officials.

title: Nicaraguan Team Unlikely
description: The cease-fire agreement that was signed on Wednesday in Nicaragua by the Sandinista Government and the contras, aimed at ending a long internal conflict, will have no apparent effect on that country's decision to skip the Summer Olympics this year in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Clark Uncertain When He'll Return
description: Jack Clark limped from the trainer's room to his locker to the whirpool and back. It was obvious he still felt some of the pain from the torn muscle in his left calf, but as he spoke about it today, his voice carried distinct shades of optimism.

title: A Backdoor Bailout for Banks
description: Twenty Texas savings and loans lost more than $4 billion last year. Now insolvency is consuming the commercial banks as well. Texas Commerce Bancshares and First City Bancorporation of Houston are belly up, and last week the giant First RepublicBank of Dallas took the first formal steps toward oblivion. Is the entire Texas banking system about to disappear down some bottomless black hole of debt?

title: Patrons at Bar Turn Tables on Gunmen
description: Regulars at JD's Circle In weren't about to stand by idly when armed robbers burst into the bar and demanded money from the owner, Donna Hannum.

title: School Basketball; Tolentine Savors Its Finish
description: A couple of nights ago, somebody asked John Sarandrea, the coach at St. Nicholas of Tolentine, one of the top-rated high-school basketball teams in the nation, what it had been like to coach under the scrutiny and pressure his Wildcats saw this season.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Plans on Panama

title: New York, Huff, Seeks Aerobics Parity
description: Deborah Khazei, who does aerobics for a living and is currently one of the Crystal Light national mixed-pairs champions, made a celebrity appearance yesterday at the first New York Sports Expo, downtown at the Palladium.

title: The Talk of St. Patrick's; Sacred and Secular Meet at St. Patrick's
description: Worshipers bearing palm branches and tourists bearing cameras walked by as Norma Valdez stood silently in the rear of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday with her 1-month-old daughter, Angelica, all rosy and pink, swaddled in her arms.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jim Scalfone has joined the William Esty Company, a part of Saatchi & Saatchi, as senior vice president, executive art director.

title: George W. Cornell, 91, Lawyer and Legislator
description: George W. Cornell, a New York lawyer and former Republican state senator, died last Thursday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla.. He was 91 years old and formerly lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: DUKAKIS ON STUMP TO SWEEP REGION
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts brought his Presidential campaign home to New England today to ask Connecticut voters to salve the wound of his defeat in Michigan.

title: Jet Evacuated at Detroit
description: A Northwest Airlines jet was evacuated tonight at Detroit Metropolitan Airport here when residual fuel vapors briefly ignited, causing what witnesses thought to be a fire, officials said. Four passengers were injured slightly while evacuating the Boeing 727 shortly after it landed at 8:20 P.M., and the incident forced the airport to close for about 20 minutes.

title: JACKSON TRIUMPH CHANGES OUTLOOK OF TOP DEMOCRATS
description: Democratic Party leaders expressed astonishment today at the Rev. Jesse Jackson's landslide victory in the Michigan caucuses Saturday and confessed that they found it hard, after weeks of surprises, to predict how or when the party's Presidential race would be decided.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
100th Assist For Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky will not win the scoring title or score 50 goals for the first time in nine seasons in the National Hockey Leauge, but tonight he established a milestone by reaching the 100-assist mark for the eighth straight season.

title: A Pornographer Given 10 Years By a U.S. Judge
description: A private computer teacher in Great Neck, L.I., received a maximum sentence yesterday - 10 years in Federal prison and a fine of $250,000 - for sending child pornography material through the mail.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Dec. 4.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; White House Eyesore
description: After 241 American servicemen were killed in a terrorist truck bomb attack in Beirut in 1983, a wall of concrete barriers was hurriedly erected around the White House.

title: WERNER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
E. S. Gandrud, Inventor, 85
description: E. S. (Gandy) Gandrud, inventor of a land-measuring wheel that provided the accuracy needed to carry out New Deal farm programs, died Friday at the age of 85.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; High Court to Rule on Property Tax System
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a local property tax system under which properties that have recently changed hands are taxed at much higher levels than other properties of comparable value.

title: DEVCON INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Legal Arguments End in Jersey Child-Abuse Trial
description: Legal arguments in the nine-month trial of a day-care teacher accused of sexually abusing 20 children at a center in Maplewood ended here today.

title: Broadway Is Offering Black Theatergoers More Reasons to Go
description: Four major shows - three of them new, one beginning the second year of its run - are drawing a segment of the audience to Broadway that has gone there in the past only occasionally in great numbers. With two dramas, ''Fences'' and ''Joe Turner's Come and Gone,'' and two musicals, ''Sarafina!'' and ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' Broadway has more offerings for black theatergoers than at any other time in memory.

title: Morrison Parker, District Leader, 81
description: Morrison Parker, a stockbroker and a Republican district leader, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: 2,810 Accidents Cited At U.S. Nuclear Plants
description: The nation's commercial nuclear power plants reported 2,810 accidents in 1987, about the same number as for a slightly smaller number of plants the previous year, a group critical of the industry said today.

title: Dollar Continues To Decline
description: The dollar continued to lose ground to the Japanese yen and other major currencies yesterday, although the Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve reportedly moved again to support it.

title: Special Sort of Saturday Night
description: SATURDAY night used to be the loneliest night of the week if you were trying to lure sports fans to their televisions. But something has been happening lately that has gone against the odds, although it is unlikely to mean a change in viewing habits.

title: Carnival Fall Kills Youth
description: A 15-year-old fell 20 feet to his death after he climbed up from under the safety bar on a carnival ride, an official said Sunday. The youth, Demetrick Welch of Lauderhill, fell from the Orbiter ride when he either tried to get out of his seat or change seats with his sister.

title: Missile Treaty May Allow Exotic Arms
description: The Soviet-American treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles may allow each side to field futuristic versions of the weapons, the Senate Armed Services Committee said in a report today.

title: Nets Are Caught at the Finish by Celtics
description: The green freight train that the Nets derailed in Boston Garden about a month ago didn't begin to roll tonight until midway through the third quarter. And when it began moving, it was 17 points behind.

title: Martin Supports Owner on Book
description: The boiling feud between Dave Winfield and George Steinbrenner did not cool today. In fact, battle lines seemed to be drawn.

title: BRAD RAGAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $599,000 from sale of a commercial location. c-Net loss and includes costs of $275,000 after tax incurred for moving the coporate office.

title: Bernard Kalb to Be Host of PBS Series
description: Bernard Kalb, a former foreign correspondent for CBS, NBC and The New York Times, has been named the host of ''Global Rivals,'' a four-part series scheduled to begin next fall on the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 28
description: b-Net income and includes net from discontinued operations of $2,169,000. Year-ago results are restated for an accounting change. There were 15 weeks in the year-ago quarter.

title: British Group's Hopeful View
description: Britain's trade deficit will widen this year, unemployment will increase slightly and investment in manufacturing will rise by 10 percent, the Confederation of British Industry forecast today.

title: Nevada Governor to Run
description: Gov. Dick Bryan of Nevada, a Democrat, announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for the United States Senate and criticized the Republican incumbent, Senator Chic Hecht. ''If he was the kind of Senator Nevada deserves, I would not have made that decision'' to run, said Mr. Bryan, who is in the middle of his second four-year term. The 50-year-old former attorney general has held a wide margin over Mr. Hecht in polls taken over the last year.

title: U.S. Studies Seoul's Ban
description: In the first step toward possible trade retaliation, the United States today began a formal investigation of charges that South Korea's ban on United States meat imports is illegal. The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said in a statement that the Reagan Administration had accepted a petition filed last month by the American Meat Institute that cntended that South Korea's ban on high-quality American beef and veal was unjustifiable and unreasonable.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Chicago Proposes Bias Settlement
description: The city of Chicago has agreed to pay $9.2 million in back pay to settle a discrimination case involving 729 black, Hispanic and female police officers, the Justice Department said today.

title: HMG-COURTLAND PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that in February, H.C. Investment Assocaites, a 51 percent owned joint venture, completed the sale of Florida property.

title: CHEMFIX TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income

title: Coney I. Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 62-year-old Brooklyn woman died in a fire in her Coney Island apartment last night, the police reported. The victim, Mollie Weisberg, was found by firefighters in her smoked-filed apartment at 3130 Brighton 6th Street. The fire, which was reported at 9:30 P.M., was confined to the fifth-floor apartment where the woman lived alone. The blaze was quickly extinguished. The victim was taken to Coney Island Hospital where she was declared dead on arrival. The police said that the fire the fire was under investigation but that it did not appear to be suspicious.

title: Facts About Fat
description: New Federal dietary guidelines advise Americans who need to limit cholesterol to avoid foods containing highly saturated palm, palm kernel or coconut oils. Pending legislation would make it far easier to follow that advice by requiring package labels to specify the presence of these cheaper tropical oils in processed foods.

title: HAMPTON HEALTHCARE reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,470,000.

title: By Design; The 1960's Redux
description: Are you old enough to remember the Age of Aquarius? If so, you are lucky: now is the time to haul out your old beads, stone necklaces, cuff bracelets, outsize brooches and belts with filigree buckles. While you are at it, resurrect the rest of your hippie regalia, including the caftans and tunics of crushed velvet, embroidered or tie-dyed fabrics.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a gain of $9,733,000 from an accounting change and a $6,309,000 gain from a tax change related to a change in accounting.

title: INSIDE
description: Pact May Allow Exotic Arms The treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles may allow each side to field futuristic arms, a Senate report says. Page A3. Israel Agrees on Inquiry The Israeli Government, ending a year of negotiations, says it will cooperate with the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair. Page A16. China to Pare Bureaucracy China announced that 20 percent of its bureaucratic force would be slashed to encourage efficiency and better decision-making. Page A3.

title: Mother Held in 2d Abuse Case
description: Three months after she was accused of breaking her 3-year-old son's arm, a Bronx woman was arrested again yesterday, along with her mother, and charged with breaking the boy's leg in a new assault, the police said.

title: Young & Rubicam Discloses Lengthy Talks on Lord Deal
description: Soon after WPP Group acquired Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein last July, Richard J. Lord, the agency's chairman and chief executive, approached Young & Rubicam about buying his firm or providing financing so that its managers could buy it, according to papers filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: At Bell Labs, Research and Development Are Alive and Well
description: To the Editor:

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dr. Arthur Vineberg, 84, Surgeon
description: Dr. Arthur Martin Vineberg, who developed artery transplants at McGill University in Montreal, died early Saturday of pneumonia at the university's Royal Victoria Hospital, where he worked for 55 years. He was 84 years old.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Douglas Gluck and Marian Monsen have been elected senior vice presidents at SSC&B Lintas:New York.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Friendly Debate By 3 Democrats; Dukakis Absent
description: Three of the Democratic Presidential candidates disagreed on handgun legislation but on little else last night in a debate in the Bronx that was marked by the absence of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1,216,000 for the latest quarter and $2,003,000 for the year-earlier period. c-After a $964,000 gain from insurance claim proceeds.

title: Poe Rarity to Be Auctioned
description: A rare first edition of Edgar Allan Poe's ''Tamerlane,'' bought for $15 in a New Hampshire antiques shop on Feb. 29, is to be auctioned in June.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Colt Industries, a maker of specialty metals, machine tools and engines, which is the target of a $17-a-share tender offer by a company organized by Morgan Stanley Leveraged Equity Fund II L.P., said Mason Best, a merchant banking firm that was said to be interested in acquiring Colt, had determined that it would not be making an offer.

title: Panama Troops Storm a Hotel To Arrest Foes
description: Panamanian troops and plainclothesmen swept into a luxury hotel in the capital tonight, seizing opposition supporters and more than a dozen journalists, five of them Americans.

title: RJR Nabisco to Buy Shares
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday announced plans to make a tender offer for up to 20 million shares of its stock for a minimum of $52 a share, or $1.04 billion.

title: Metro Datelines; 2 More Held in Death Of a Suspected Thief
description: Two more people were arrested yesterday and charged in the death of a man who was beaten by bystanders who suspected him of stealing $20 in a East Harlem bakery last week, the police said.

title: F.D.I.C. Faces First Loss Ever
description: The Federal fund that insures deposits in commercial banks could suffer a loss in 1988 for the first time in its 54-year history, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's chairman, L. William Seidman, said today.

title: A.&P. Insider Case Is Settled
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged an executive secretary at the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company and her husband with illegal insider trading in the stock of Waldbaum Inc. before the public announcement of a merger agreement between the two companies in 1986.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Wednesday from The Associated Press about four people charged in the fatal beating of a man in Harlem incorrectly described statements made by their lawyers, based on information supplied by the Manhattan District Attorney's office. The defendants did not admit participating in the assault.

title: Review/Television; Rommel, Brilliant General and Naif
description: Erwin Rommel may be the only German general whose reputation survived World War II; certainly he became the best known of Hitler's soldiers. ''Rommel,'' at 8 o'clock tonight on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, sifts through his life. It suggests he is entitled to posthumous glory.

title: Wicks Law Blocks New York State Construction
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADVIEW SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said all periods reflect the elimination of the deduction of undeclared and unpaid preferred dividends from net loss as a result of the merger of Broadview Financial Corp. into its subsidiary, Broadview Savings & Loan. Such dividends amounted to about $1,050,000 a quarter.

title: Desert Partners Extends USG Bid
description: Desert Partners L.P. extended its $42-a-share tender offer for 21.5 million shares of the USG Corporation. The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight today. A Desert Partners spokesman said that a nominal number of shares had been tendered through last Friday and that the offer is now scheduled to expire at 5 P.M., Eastern time, on April 8.

title: Books of The Times; 'Paris Fashion,' Clothes as Extension of Culture
description: Paris Fashion A Cultural History By Valerie Steele Illustrated. 317 pages. Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Flyers Regroup
description: For the first time in a month, the Philadelphia Flyers, the Patrick Division's third-place team and losers of 10 of their last 13 games, have fewer than eight regulars out of the lineup.

title: Japan Keeps Beef and Citrus Quotas
description: Japanese leaders today rejected United States demands that they remove all quotas on beef and citrus imports, but they left the door open for possible concessions as negotiations with Washington reached a conclusive phase.

title: V.A. Cabinet Bill Advances as a Dispute Is Averted
description: The elevation of the Veterans Administration to Cabinet status was virtually assured today as a Senate committee chairman agreed to drop a proposed amendment that had threatened the change.

title: Drug Halts Graft Rejection in Burn Victims
description: A DRUG that has become indispensable in organ transplants now shows promise in the treatment of burn victims, according to doctors at the Southern California Burn Center of Sherman Oaks Community Hospital.

title: Dukakis Is Widely Favored In Connecticut Race Today
description: The three leading candidates in the increasingly muddled race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Albert Gore Jr., made last-minute campaign stops in Connecticut today on the eve of the state's primary Tuesday.

title: Sandinistas and Rebels Discuss Cease-Fire Details
description: A delegation of contra commanders entered Nicaragua today to begin detailed talks about the size and location of cease-fire zones into which they are expected to withdraw.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Shot by Gunmen At a Massage Parlor
description: Four men who were asked to leave a Manhattan massage parlor early yesterday are suspected of returning and shooting three people, critically wounding two of them, the police said.

title: Qaddafi Announces Pullback Of Troops on Egypt's Border
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today that he would withdraw Libyan troops from the Egyptian border.

title: Stop Stalling on Home Care
description: A recent article in The Times painted a grim picture of New York State's hospital system. Emergency rooms, Bruce Lambert reported, are jammed with patients waiting for beds. Ambulances containing emergency cases are routinely diverted from one overloaded hospital to another. The emotionally disturbed, brought into crowded psychiatric wards, sometimes spend the night strapped to stretchers.

title: Rampal Recital
description: The flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal is to give his only New York recital at 8 P.M. April 6 at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Rampal will perform the New York premiere of David Diamond's Sonata for Flute and Piano as well as works by Czerny, Franck and Bartok. Appearing with Mr. Rampal will be John Steele Ritter at the piano. Tickets are $10, $15 and $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $288,912 and $380,736 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes gains on the sale of discontinued operations of $16,261 for the quarter and $10,643 for the year.

title: Florida Hospital Revenue Bonds
description: The Hospital Board of Directors of Lee County, Fla., is tentatively offering $80 million in hospital revenue-refunding bonds for a project for Lee Memorial Hospital. The financing offers a maximum yield of 8.065 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Keeping the Price Right
description: Real estate appraisal is a tricky business. Sometimes appraisers are overoptimistic, and sometimes they yield to pressures or collude fraudulently to overvalue properties.

title: KEY RATES
PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1987 results included a loss of $2,308,000 from legal settlements and a charge of $730,000 from a change in pension accounting, and are after a gain of $300,000 from a reversal of a previous writeoff of an investment in a joint venture. The 1987 results also included the sale of Golding Industries, acquired late in the third quarter.

title: COLONIAL COMMERICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and in both the quarter and year preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Review/Theater; A Dropout Tries to Restore His Faith
description: Dropping out of Harvard graduate school and turning his back on the 1960's counterculture that has nurtured him, Paulie Bindel comes home to Brooklyn and tries to restore his faith in Judaic tradition. Paulie is the searching protagonist of Robert Greenfield's novel ''Temple'' and of the play of the same name at the American Jewish Theater. There is enough material in Mr. Greenfield's adaptation - and in what he has chosen to omit from his acclaimed novel - for an evening teeming with life and with ritual. However, in common with its leading character, the play has its own problem of identity.

title: Charles Willeford, 69, Author of Crime Novels
description: Charles R. Willeford 3d, a writer of crime novels featuring Hoke Moseley, a fictional Miami homicide detective, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in South Miami. He was 69 years old.

title: Amiens Journal; On the Far Right Is Le Pen, Talking of the Deluge
description: Like the stand-up comic he sometimes resembles, Jean-Marie Le Pen, attired in a double-breasted blue blazer and gray slacks, strode the stage, a microphone pinned to his lapel. For two hours, without notes, he announced the apocalypse that awaits France if it does not reverse an ''invasion'' of third-world immigrants.

title: DEALER MUST PAY TO TREAT ADDICTS
description: In an unusual application of state law, a Brooklyn judge yesterday ordered a convicted heroin dealer dealer to pay more than $2 million in restitution, with the money to be used to support drug rehabilitation programs in New York City.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Forschner Group Inc., Shelton, Conn., a maker of cutlery, pocket knives and wicker baskets, announced that John B. Balson, chairman and chief executive, would leave the company, a subsidiary of the Prospect Group Inc., as chairman, chief executive and a director to join Stendig Industries as president and chief executive in early April.

title: From George to Winnie to Willie
description: THE news out of Fort Lauderdale is that Steinbrenner said that Winfield said that Randolph said that Winfield said that Steinbrenner said that Randolph said that - well, so forth and so on.

title: Fetuses Treated Through Umbilical Cords
description: A PROMISING new technique is allowing doctors to evaluate, treat and even give blood transfusions to fetuses while they are still in the womb.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Temperature For World Rises Sharply In the 1980's
description: Average global temperatures in the 1980's are the highest measured since reliable records were first kept over 130 years ago, according to reports now coming in from scientists around the world.

title: Talking Business; with Cooney of the N.A.M.; Takeover Curbs On Foreigners
description: As part of a sweeping trade bill expected to be concluded this week, Congressional and Administration negotiators have agreed to give the President authority to block foreign acquisitions of American companies if national security is believed to be threatened.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $44,000 and $89,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income d-Includes tax credits of $665,000 for the quarter and $745,000 for the 6 months.

title: Bridge; Team Wins Vanderbilt Knockout Championship in an Exciting End to the Spring Nationals
description: One of the most exciting Vanderbilt knockout team championships ever played ended here Sunday night in a victory for a foursome led by Eddie Kantar of Los Angeles. Teamed with Alan Sontag, Roger Bates and John Mohan, all of Manhattan, he trailed by 9 imps into the final quarter of 16 deals but finished strongly to win by 25.

title: Talks on Budget Stall in Albany On Allocations
description: State budget talks, which were said to be on the verge of conclusion late Sunday night, stalled today, apparently because of disagreements over apportioning money for housing, transportation and education.

title: Market Place; Analysts Cautious On Utility Choices
description: UNCERTAINTY over profit prospects and the path of interest rates has made investment firms quite selective in recommending electric utility stocks.

title: Pick Up Trash Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Honeywell Begins Offering Of Australian-Dollar Notes
description: Honeywell Inc. began offering $85 million in notes denominated in Australian dollars yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, as the United States dollar again declined in foreign-exchange trading yesterday.

title: KENTUCKY MEDICAL INSURNCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Cable Operator's High-Yield Notes
description: The Adams-Russell Company, an owner and operator of cable television systems based in Waltham, Mass., is offering $273.5 million in senior subordinated deferred-interest notes due in 1997 at $492.89 per $1,000 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Gephardt Drops Race for Democratic Nomination
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, who was unable to sustain his early success in the Iowa caucuses, dropped out of the 1988 Democratic Presidential competition today and prepared instead to run again for his St. Louis seat in the House of Representatives.

title: San Diego Journal; Tiny Airport Is a Giant Issue, Again
description: For 20 years now they have been arguing about what to do about the airport here. But the day of reckoning may finally have arrived.

title: A Bearing Without Friction
description: Using a small chunk of a new superconducting material, engineers at Cornell University have designed a high-speed, virtually frictionless bearing that spins at more than 1,000 revolutions per second.

title: Control Data Stake In Silicon Graphics
description: The Control Data Corporation will buy a 20 percent stake in Silicon Graphics Inc., a maker of computer work stations, the two companies announced. Under the agreement, Control Data will pay $22.50 a share for newly issued shares of Silicon Graphics, with a total price of $68.9 million.

title: Fashion; Paris Sets the Pace With New Directions
description: If fashion is indeed progressing to a more serious, grown-up stage, French designers will lead the way. In the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings in Europe, the French, as a group, displayed both imagination and confidence as they struck out in new directions.

title: Scientists Identify Fiber Struck First By Dystrophy
description: SCIENTISTS have pinpointed one type of muscle fiber that appears to be destroyed first in the crippling progression of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

title: Officials Oppose U.S. Cuts In Aid to Homeless Families
description: City and state officials from around the country, testifying yesterday at a new homeless shelter in Brooklyn, urged Congress to overturn a Reagan Administration plan to cut emergency Federal aid for homeless families.

title: Postema Not Picked
description: The National League named two new umpires yesterday, but Pam Postema, who was seeking to become the first female umpire in major league history, was not among them. Postema, who had been given only an outside chance of being selected, will work this year in the American Association.

title: On Afghan Peace
description: LEAD: America may well have lost the opportunity to negotiate a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan by making unrealistic, last-minute demands for changes in the pending United Nations peace accord.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Feared Sting of Insurance Lobby Haunts Capitol
description: In the national capital, crowded with high-paid lobbyists, some are respected. Others are feared. By most accounts, the Independent Insurance Agents of America, boasting a grass-roots membership of more than 126,000, which with a phone call can bring the insurance hordes into Washington, belongs to the category of the feared.

title: Police Feared Chambers Escape
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr. was considered an escape risk on his last night of freedom, and extra police officers were posted at New York City airports and bus terminals in the event he tried to flee, a senior law-enforcement official said yesterday.

title: SOVIET EMIGRANTS ARRESTED BY BONN
description: West Germany today announced the arrest of six suspected Soviet spies, including four Soviet emigrants and an engineer who it said may have passed information about two jet-fighter projects.

title: China to Pare Its Bureaucracy by 20%
description: China announced today that its central Government would be drastically reorganized and 20 percent of its bureaucratic force slashed in an effort to encourage efficiency and better decision-making.

title: Athens Unmoved by Protest
description: The Greek Government will continue its freeze on construction work at American bases in Greece despite a protest from the United States, a Government spokesman said today. Greece first announced the freeze last year when negotiations started on the future of the four major bases and 21 smaller military installations operated by the United States. The current agreement expires in December.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: South Africa Delays Release Of the Movie 'Cry Freedom'
description: The release in South Africa of ''Cry Freedom,'' Sir Richard Attenborough's apartheid film, has been 'postponed indefinitely,'' the distributors said tonight.

title: A White Teen-Ager Is Acquitted Of Assaulting 2 Hispanic Youths
description: A white teen-ager was acquitted yesterday of assault charges stemming from what the police said was a bias-related attack by a group of white men on two Hispanic teen-agers in Queens. He was the second of two young whites charged in the case to be acquitted.

title: PETROMARK RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Fever Pitch Just Isn't Duke's Style
description: Several strands of white toilet tissue were draped across bare branches on the quadrangle, the remnants of a raucous victory rally Saturday in which more than 2,000 students burned benches and trash, citing tradition as their motive. The campus book store did a brisk business in T-shirts, especially those celebrating Duke's East Regional championship, and the triple crown, three victories against archrival North Carolina this season.

title: Review/Violin; An Exemplar Of Musical Absorption
description: Gidon Kremer is probably the most interesting violinist playing today. Not always the most satisfying, since his tone can be dry, his formidible technique can turn rough, and his musicality itself can take on a harsh edge. But he has a capacity for intense absorption and musical thought that leaves our more glamorous violinists very far behind. He knows how to let his curiousity and love for a piece speak through the details and the large span of his playing.

title: GENCOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lucky May Get Higher Offer
description: The American Stores Company said today that it was prepared to raise its takeover offer for Lucky Stores Inc. to $50 a share, or $1.93 billion, from its current $45-a-share tender offer. American Stores said the increased bid was conditioned on an ''expeditious completion'' of a deal. Earlier in the day, Lucky

title: 'Unfinished Job'
description: One-third of all baseball job openings in the last year were filled by members of minority groups, the baseball commissioner's office announced yesterday. But baseball still does not have a black manager or general manager one year after the Los Angeles Dodgers executive, Al Campanis, caused a furor by saying that blacks lack ''some of the necessities'' for those jobs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 Attempts to aid the contras broke down in the House of Representatives. Republicans demanded an early vote on renewed military assistance for the Nicaraguan rebels if peace talks fail. Page A1 A delegation of contra commanders entered Nicaragua to begin talks about the cease-fire. The presence of top combat commanders in the delegation was taken as a sign that contra units support the cease-fire. A12 Panamanian troops stormed a hotel and arrested dozens of opposition leaders who had earlier led a protest march. It marked the first time Gen. Manuel Noriega's regime had detained opposition members in such numbers. A1 Israel will seal off the West Bank and Gaza Strip in anticipation of an Arab demonstration on Wednesday. The action bars journalists from the territories and prohibits Palestinians from entering or leaving. A1

title: Cracks in the Williamsburg Bridge Shut 2 Lanes
description: The two outer Brooklyn-bound lanes of the ailing Williamsburg Bridge were closed to vehicular traffic yesterday afternoon when inspectors found cracks and a large hole in a main cross beam near the Manhattan side.

title: Price of Nickel Soars Again
description: Nickel prices soared to record levels again today as the London Metal Exchange reported that its warehouse stocks fell to the lowest level in five and a half years. The price of nickel for immediate delivery jumped $1,400 a metric ton, to $23,900.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD HOME reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Promise or Disaster?
description: Jesse Jackson's nearly 2-to-1 victory in Michigan has thrown a lot of Democratic Party leaders, most of them anonymous, into an orgy of weeping, wailing and gnashing of teeth. Having finally perceived the truth of what they had been only pretending to believe - that Mr. Jackson is a real candidate, winning a lot of delegates - these nameless leaders now tell reporters that their party faces a terrible dilemma:

title: Abraham W. Rosenthal, Y.M.H.A. Director, 91
description: Abraham W. Rosenthal, the former executive director of the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. and the former chairman of the Council of Social Agencies, both in the Bronx, died Thursday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif., after a short illness. He was 91 years old.

title: RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $452,000 for the quarter and $630,000 for the 6 months. The company said its 43 percent ownership of Delta Woodside Industries accounted for about $2,439,000 of net, or 33 cents a share, for the latest quarter and about $4,820,000, or 64 cents a share, for the 6 months. This compared with the year-ago figures of about $2,363,000, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and about $3,878,000, or 51 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: 2 Held in Killing of Candidate
description: Investigators have taken two suspects into custody in the shotgun slaying of Julian Pierce, an Indian who was running in the May 3 primary for Superior Court judge, the county sheriff said early today.

title: TAYLOR DEVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Israel Now Says It Will Give Data for Iran-Contra Inquiry
description: The Israeli Government announced today that it would cooperate with the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair, Lawrence E. Walsh, ending a year of negotiation.

title: Reagan Asks Changes In Congress Trade Bill
description: President Reagan strongly pressed Congress today to make major changes in a trade bill reaching the final stages of deliberation on Capitol Hill.

title: New Support for Stronger GATT
description: An international consensus is emerging in favor of strengthening the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, giving the organization that regulates world trade new authority to review national trade policies.

title: Gotti Jury Selection Begins in Secret
description: News reporters and the public were barred yesterday as a Federal judge began questioning prospective jurors in chambers for the new racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and two co-defendants.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * National Geographic Traveler, a four-year-old quarterly with a circulation rate base of 775,000, is changing to six-a-year frequency next January.

title: Advertising; Hill & Knowlton Wins Three Silver Anvils
description: The Public Relations Society of America has announced the winners of its Silver Anvil Awards, the most respected prize in the field.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Arabs of Israel won't come to their senses, reality will be harder and laden with impending disaster. I am not afraid. A test of strength between us and them is like a contest between an elephant and a fly.'' - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. [ A6:6. ]

title: Dedmon Traded
description: The Atlanta Braves yesterday traded Jeff Dedmon, a relief pitcher, to the Cleveland Indians for a player to be named. Dedmon, a 28-year-old right-hander, had been suffering shoulder problems. He was 3-4 last season. (AP)

title: ALTERNATIVE HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wilander Withdraws
description: Mats Wilander, citing an injury he suffered in the fourth set of his victory Sunday in the Lipton International Players Championship final, has withdrawn from the $680,000 World Championship Tennis finals in Dallas.

title: Rig Count Dips in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States fell by eight last week, to a total of 935, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. A year ago, the count was 748. The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil, not the number of rigs producing it.

title: Outbreaks of 2 Diseases in Coral Prompt Assessment of Caribbean's Reefs
description: ALARMED by outbreaks of two diseases in coral, researchers are beginning ambitious programs to evaluate the condition of reefs throughout the Caribbean and neighboring waters.

title: Devils Enjoying Playoff Race
description: The Devils have never played games of such significance so late in a season, and they are enjoying themselves immensely.

title: MECHAM COMPLAINS OF INSULT AT TRIAL
description: Gov. Evan Mecham complained at his impeachment trial today that he was ''insulted'' that a prosecutor had compared the Governor's use of a protocol fund with embezzlement.

title: Play Your Cards Right
description: I'VE never met a computer program that could play a decent game of poker, but Card Sharks will give you a pretty good run for your money. What it lacks in depth of play, it makes up for in entertainment value and a certain crazy charm.

title: Review/Recital; Duo in Beethoven and Mendelssohn
description: The Rudiakov Duo consists of the cousins Michael Rudiakov, a cellist, and Shoshana Rudiakov, a pianist. The two appeared last Tuesday night in a program at Weill Recital Hall that failed to compensate in competence for its overriding aura of placid stolidity.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Is it true that bulimia and anorexia nervosa affect women exclusively? A. ''No, not exclusively, but yes, predominantly,'' said Dr. Diane W. Mickley, who has done research on the diseases as founder and director of the Wilkins Center for Eating Disorders in Greenwich, Conn. She said most studies show that 90 to 95 percent of the victims are women.

title: Hyundai Dealers Busy
description: For the second consecutive year, Hyundai dealers led their competitors in the number of cars sold per dealership in 1987, the trade publication Automotive News said today. Dealers of the South Korean-made models sold 1,368 cars per dealership last year.

title: Federated Moves to End Bidding War
description: As the takeover war for Federated Department Stores Inc. entered its 10th week, the retailer's directors moved yesterday to bring the bidding contest between the Campeau Corporation and R.H. Macy & Company to an end by tomorrow.

title: The Way to Deflate Insurance Rates
description: LEAD: Last week, nine states accused four big insurance companies of conspiring to restrict competition in commercial liability coverage. While this action is welcome and long overdue, both the states and Congress should go a step further and bring competition to the coverage that affects most Americans more than any other -automobile insurance.

title: 5 Are Charged With Deception In Bus Scheme
description: Three former Woodbridge Township school officials and two bus company owners have been charged with bilking taxpayers out of more than $1 million in student transportation costs, law-enforcement officials announced today.

title: DEADLOCK PERSISTS AT AFGHAN PARLEY
description: The Afghan peace talks remained deadlocked today, with the Soviet Union refusing to reopen negotiations with the United States on terms for a suspension of military aid, officials and diplomats involved in the discussion said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 29, 1988
description: Markets

title: Kemp, in Call for Unity, Endorses Vice President
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp, declaring that the time had come for Republicans to unite behind Vice President Bush, endorsed him today for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: Metro Datelines;
description: Long Island Sound was designated yesterday as an ''estuary of national significance,'' guaranteeing $1 million a year in Federal financing for an ecological study of the waterway.

title: Jackson Rivals Confront Problem Of How to Campaign Against Him
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination were grappling today with a problem they never expected to face: How to deal with Mr. Jackson not as a power broker, but as a formidable opponent, and how to do so while avoiding attacks on Mr. Jackson that could tear their party apart.

title: AMERICAN CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $9,035,000 for the quarter and $2,076,000 for the year from the early repayment of debt, and the year also includes a gain of $3,075,000 from an accounting change. c-After losses from the early repayment of debt of $3,783,000 for the quarter and $6,600,000 for the year, and the quarter also includes a loss of $1,089,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Lambs of Big East Roaring in N.I.T.
description: Two teams that were among the least of the Big East during the regular season have become the last conference survivors in postseason play.

title: First U.S. Units Leave Honduras
description: A battalion of 700 American paratroopers returned from Honduras today as the United States began to withdraw a 3,500-man contingent sent in a show of force against Nicaragua.

title: Boron Said to Be Crucial to Bone Formation
description: BORON, an element best known for its use as an eye wash and a roach killer, plays a critical role in the body's ability to use calcium to form bone, new research indicates.

title: Cutting Social Security Won't Reduce the Deficit; An Insurance Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Return to Vietnam
description: Two decades after serving in Indochina as an Army officer, Senator Larry Pressler will return to Vietnam on a ''humanitarian mission'' to improve relations between Washington and Hanoi.

title: Review/Dance; Boston Message to Plisetskaya: 'Bravissima!'
description: In Czarist times, one of the most spectacular of Russian ballet traditions took the form of special evenings in tribute to a dancer or choreographer. These programs were called ''benefits,'' meaning that a ballerina's admirers were expected to ply her with diamonds and rubies, at the least.

title: JETBORNE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Cities Named
description: The United States Olympic Committee said yesterday it expected to choose Atlanta or Minneapolis-St. Paul as the bid city for the 1996 Olympic Summer Games.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Net loss Year-ago fourth quarter includes unspecified gains from sales of interest in certain cellular partnerships. The company said the latest year includes unspecified gains from sales of cellular partnership interests and from the sale of an investment. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split payable April 12.

title: Charter Panel Debates Proposal on Shifting Power
description: The chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, Richard Ravitch, yesterday presented his plan for a radical restructuring of New York City's government, setting off a substantive discussion among commission members.

title: Bombing Is Reported In the Afghan Capital
description: A car bomb exploded in Kabul on Sunday killing four Soviet advisers and another person, Western diplomatic sources in Islamabad said today.

title: Birmingham Orchestra
description: The City of Birmingham Orchestra, conducted by Simon Rattle, is to make its New York premiere on April 13 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Appearing with the orchestra is to be the pianist Alfred Brendel, featured in Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 4. The program also features the New York premiere of Robin Holloway's ''Seascape and Harvest'' and Sibelius's Symphony No. 5. The orchestra, which gave its first performance in 1920, has appeared at British music festivals and other concerts in Europe. Tickets are $12.50, $16 and $18. Information: 247-7800.

title: Our Towns; Ordinary People: Retarded Adults Move Next Door
description: When group homes first came to Long Island, they were mainly in the middle of the Island and the South Shore, where housing was less expensive. Had this continued, it could have led to a ghetto of group homes. So four years ago, the Association for Children with Learning Disabilities - a nonprofit agency with 15 community residences - planned its first home for retarded adults on the Gold Coast of the North Shore, at 312 Melbourne Road in Great Neck's Russell Gardens section.

title: Milwaukee Mayor Outlives Problems And Politicians in His 28-Year Reign
description: As a boy growing up in the 1920's Henry W. Maier followed his grandparents to every political meeting for miles around: Democratic, Republican, Socialist, Communist. His grandparents urged the bright young man to shoot for elective office himself someday. Years later, when Mr. Maier had become the Mayor of Milwaukee, he went back to visit his 103-year-old grandmother.

title: British Find the Past Enriching
description: Anthony Gaynor stands at the forefront of one of Britain's most promising industries of the future - the past.

title: Construction Talks Advance
description: Negotiators from the United States and Japan have made substantial progress in resolving a dispute over access for American construction companies to $60 billion worth of Japanese construction projects, an American negotiator said today.

title: MIPS Computer
description: MIPS Computer Systems Inc., which makes high-speed microprocessors and computers, announced a new microprocessor and the formation of a software company to acquire and distribute programs for its computers. MIPS, which is privately held and based in Sunnyvale, Calif., pioneered in making high-speed microprocessors using a design philosophy known as reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. The new product can execute 20 million instructions a second.

title: MERRILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Iran Says It Repelled Iraqi Attack
description: Iran said that its Revolutionary Guards beat back an Iraqi counterattack in Kurdistan today and that Teheran holds 540 square miles of the strategic region in northeast Iraq.

title: Mexico to Extend Controls
description: With the agreement of business and labor, the Government today extended through May the wage and price controls it had placed in effect in December.

title: Bamboo and Pyramids
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS have long puzzled over the means Egyptian pyramid builders used to raise and move immense blocks of stone without the help of wheels, pulleys or domestic animals. A new study suggests that the basic stone-raising tool along the Nile 5,000 years ago was the simple bamboo pole.

title: Armenian Area in Azerbaijan Is on Strike, Moscow Reports
description: Armenian protesters have shut factories and schools and halted rail cargo in the capital of the region that is the focus of a territorial dispute involving two southern republics, Soviet newspapers reported today.

title: Complex Whistles Found to Play Key Roles in Inca and Maya Life
description: EXPERTS are teasing thousand-year-old secrets from the clay whistles, ocarinas and flutes of the ancient Americas, discovering that these old musical instruments are surprisingly advanced in their construction and tonal qualities.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about the Supreme Court's decision to review a case involving Trans World Airlines misstated the number of striking flight attendants who were told by T.W.A. that their jobs had been filled or abolished after they offered to return to work in May 1986. The correct number is about 5,000.

title: Dollar Uncertainty Weakens Stock Prices
description: Amid uncertainty about the dollar, stock prices closed mostly lower after sharp declines in the previous two sessions.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Amoskeag Bank Shares Names New Chairman
description: The directors of Amoskeag Bank Shares Inc. elected Milton Machinist, 72 years old, as chairman and chief executive yesterday, succeeding William S. Bushnell, 57, who resigned abruptly last Wednesday after seven years at the New Hampshire banking company.

title: Fine-Tuning Benefits Knicks
description: In the final minutes of the 69th game of the season, Rick Pitino came up with a new lineup, and it brought the Knicks a 114-106 victory over the Dallas Mavericks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gulf Canada Resources To Acquire Asamera
description: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, said today that it had agreed to buy Asamera Inc., an oil, natural gas and gold producer, for $512 million (Canadian), or about $413 million (United States).

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Man Dies Saving Children
description: A 76-year-old man was struck and killed yesterday when he pushed two children out of the way of a truck that collided with a school bus in the Bronx, the police said.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $47,059,000 and a gain of $3,712,000 from an accounting change.

title: An Ill Wind From China to Arabia
description: Many countries produce intermediate-range missiles capable of carrying nuclear warheads; none have sold them to third-world nations - until now. The Soviet Union is reported to have sold its 500-mile-range SS-12 missile to Iraq, which is using the weapon with a conventional warhead to murder civilians in Teheran. Equally disastrous is China's decision to sell its 2,200-mile-range East Wind missile to Saudi Arabia. The United States needs to do all it can to dissuade China from delivering these missiles.

title: I.B.M. Is Gaining a Foothold In the Minicomputer Market
description: With the 9370 minicomputer introduced last year, the International Business Machines Corporation is gaining a foothold in medium-priced computer systems after a slow start, company executives said here today.

title: U.S. AGENCIES ISSUE BOOK ON LITERACY
description: Responding to a study showing a significant degree of illiteracy in the workplace, the secretaries of Commerce, Education, and Labor today released a book aimed at helping employers identify and address literacy problems among their workers.

title: Billions in U.S. Aid Urged for Low-Income Homes Special to The New York Times
description: A private panel studying the nation's housing problems called on the Federal Government today to replenish the country's supply of low-income housing.

title: A Rave Review for Navy
description: In rare praise for a nuclear weapons program, the House Armed Services Committee said Sunday that the Navy's program to build an improved Trident submarine-launched missile appears to be on time and under budget.
