''The other programs we've looked at had a variety of problems, so this is kind of a man-bites-dog story,'' said Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, the panel's chairman. The Trident II is to be put aboard submarines starting next year at a cost of at least $36 billion, depending on the number of Trident submarines the Navy builds.

title: Study of Normal Mourning Process Illuminates Grief Gone Awry
description: MOURNING a loved one is always painful, but some people find the process more difficult than others, either becoming too distraught or holding too much emotion in. In studying these extreme reactions, researchers are coming to a sharper understanding of the normal course of mourning, and of the signs that it has gone awry.

title: Court Allows Photo Merger
description: A merger between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Colorcraft Corporation is not an effort to force other companies out of the photo-finishing industry, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

title: Chess; A Quiet Victory for Seirawan, Winner of the Second International Open in New Brunswick
description: Yasser Seirawan won first prize, $10,000 (Canadian), in the International Open Tournament 2 in Saint John, New Brunswick. The 27-year-old Seattle grandmaster scored 7-2 in the nine-round Swiss-system competition.

title: Delays Plague Middle-Income Condominium Plan in New York
description: Two years after a coalition of developers offered to build at no profit 3,000 condominium units for middle-income New Yorkers, the group is still awaiting city sites on which to build more than a third of the apartments.

title: Corrections
description: An Executive Changes report in Business Day last Tuesday inaccurately described promotions at the AM Life Insurance Company and the Guardian Financial Corporation.

title: Trains End Bronx Stop: Who Cares And Why
description: A protest is being mounted to save a Metro-North rail station in the South Bronx from closing this week, but the noise is not coming from local residents, many of whom say they have no idea the train even stops in their neighborhood.

title: Stieglitz at the Dawn of Photojournalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Plan By Britain
description: The British Government said today that it would urge American contractors to invest in nuclear power stations in Britain when that country sells off its state-run electricity industry.

title: Major Gains In Graphics
description: PERHAPS nowhere else is the rapid advance of personal computers so clearly visible as in the realm of computer graphics. The aisles at the National Computer Graphics Association's annual meeting here last week were filled with demonstrations of flashy computer graphics that until just a couple of years ago were the exclusive domain of supercomputers and mainframes costing hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of dollars.

title: No Polls Of Michigan Voters
description: There is no reliable information on what kinds of voters supported which candidate in the Michigan Democratic caucuses Saturday because no polls of voters were conducted. Such exit polls are often conducted in primary and general elections.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL NATIONAL LEAGUE - Named Gary Darling and Mark Hirschbeck umpires. ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Jeff Dedmon, pitcher, to Cleveland for a player to be named later. BOSTON (AL) - Assigned Pat Dodson, first baseman; Danny Sheaffer, catcher; and Rob Woodward, John Leister and Zach Crouch, pitchers, to its minor league camp. CHICAGO (AL) - Assigned Joel Davis, pitcher, to Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. DETROIT (AL) - Acquired Don Schulze, pitcher, from Minnesota for Karl Best, pitcher. Released Tim Lollar, pitcher. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Assigned Larry Owen, catcher, to Omaha of the American Association. Placed Ed Hearn, catcher, on the disabled list. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Assigned Ronn Reynolds, catcher, to its minor league complex. SEATTLE (AL) - Released Mike Trujillo, pitcher. Placed Scott Bankhead, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Assigned Phil Oullette, catcher; Brick Smith, first baseman, and Donnell Nixon and Dave Hengel, outfielders, to Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. Assigned Rod Scurry, pitcher, and Nelson Simmons, outfielder, to its minor league camp. TORONTO (AL) - Assigned Glenallen Hill, outfielder, to Syracuse of the International League. Assigned Eric Yelding, shortstop, to Knoxville of the Southern League. BASKETBALL LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS (NBA) -Signed Claude Gregory, forward, for the remainder of the season and Steve Burtt, guard, to a 10-day contract. COLLEGES CARNEGIE MELLON - Named Richard Scheines men's tennis coach. HOFSTRA - Announced the retirement of Richard Berg, men's basketball coach. MISSOURI - Named Frank Novack running backs coach, Carl Reese defensive secondary coach and Charlie Coe linebackers coach. FOOTBALL KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Signed Ron Monaco, Dan MacDonald and Kurt Norman, linebackers; Pat Thetford, tight end; Kuivan Jenkins, running back, and Bob Standifer, defensive tackle. HOCKEY HARTFORD (NHL) - Signed Jody Hull, forward, and Adam Burt, defenseman, to multiyear contracts. Signed Marc LaForge, defenseman. Agreed to terms with Peter Sidorkiewicz, goaltender.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. 76ers 108, Rockets 98: Mike Gminski scored 23 points and Cliff Robinson and Charles Barkley each added 22 last night as the 76ers defeated the Rockets in Philadelphia. Houston played without its leading scorer and rebounder, Akeem Olajuwon, who suffered a bruised knee against Portland on Saturday night. Olajuwon had started 129 straight games for the Rockets, who have clinched a Western Conference playoff berth. The victory enabled the 76ers to tie Cleveland for seventh place in the Eastern Conference standings. The 76ers took over undisputed possession of second place in the Atlantic Division, half a game ahead of Washington and one in front of the Knicks. The 76ers never trailed after Robinson's free throw put them ahead, 23-22, with 2:25 left in the first quarter. Gminski scored 20 points as they took a 56-45 halftime lead.(AP) N.H.L.

title: Allied Fills Presidency, A Job Vacant Since '85
description: Alan Belzer, an executive vice president of Allied-Signal Inc. and president of the company's engineered materials sector, was named president of the huge technology company yesterday.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12mo Feb 29
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $21,683,000. The gain resulted from the June 1986 sale of the company's Virginia Service Territory to Virginia Power.

The company said it changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from March 31 and accordingly, the results reported for the 9-month ended Dec. 31, 1987 represent its results for the 1987 fiscal year.

description: The Israeli Army announced tonight that it was sealing off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in anticipation of planned Arab demonstrations on Wednesday.

CATO CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 30

title: Cooper Is Selling Lens Solution Unit
description: The Cooper Companies, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its United States contact lens care solutions business to Wesley-Jessen Inc., a subsidiary of the Schering-Plough Corporation, for about $63 million in cash. The transaction is subject to the completion of Cooper's previously announced agreement to sell its worldwide contact lens business to Wesley-Jessen, too, for about $150 million in cash.

title: Press's Right to View Esposito Records Is Backed
description: The Supreme Court let stand today a Federal appellate ruling that news organizations had a right to see court records including partial transcripts of court-ordered wiretaps on the telephones of Meade H. Esposito, the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, and others.

title: ROCKINGHAM BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The per share earnings for the year- ago periods were not available because the company went public in July 1987.

COMPUTER MICROFILM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Strawberry Back In Touch With Mets
description: The poster is still there on the bulletin board in the Mets' locker room with the huge photo, some scrawled graffiti and the printed inscription: ''Wanted, dead or alive, Darryl Strawberry.''

title: Cutting Social Security Won't Reduce the Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers; Fordham Betting on Wall St. Site
description: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY is seeking classroom space in the Wall Street area for its graduate school of business, now based in the Lincoln Center area.

title: Correction: On a Houston Bank
description: An editorial yesterday erroneously characterized the condition of Texas Commerce Bancshares of Houston. The bank's solvency is not in question. Its position was strengthened last year following acquisition by Chemical Bank. We regret the error.

title: Russians' Visit to Cape Evokes Kennedy Era
description: Karen Khachaturian, a prominent Soviet composer, paused today in front of a photograph of John F. Kennedy and sobbed. The 68-year-old Mr. Khachaturian bowed several times before the picture, which hung on the wall of Rose Kennedy's memento-filled home. ''It's not fair,'' he said softly. The Kennedy family and its Hyannis Port complex on Cape Cod have always held a special place in the hearts of many Americans. But it seemed today that this scenic retreat overlooking Nantucket Sound has also captured the imagination and emotion of the Soviet people.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILITES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $89,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $207,000.

title: Review/Television; 2 Shows for Young Viewers About Homelessness
description: Will younger viewers pull themselves away from music videos long enough to consider the subject of the homeless? Two series aimed at young audiences are giving the possibility a shot this week. This afternoon at 4 o'clock, CBS's ''Schoolbreak Special'' series is presenting ''Home Sweet Homeless,'' and tomorrow at 4 P.M., ABC's ''Afterschool Special'' offers a repeat broadcast of ''Are You My Mother?''

title: Advertising; Several Shifts In Accounts
description: A number of advertisers found new agencies last week. Cuisinarts Inc., went to

title: Reagans Sign Lease On California Estate
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, have signed a three-year lease on a $2.5 million estate in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles to live in after they leave the White House, the White House said today.

title: 2 Shot at Texas Church
description: A man demanding the return of his adopted daughter fired into a group of people getting out of a church school van Sunday, hitting the girl's biological mother and seriously wounding her cousin. The Fort Worth Police Department issued a warrant for the arrest of Ollie Thomas, 74, on two counts of attempted murder, spokesman Tom Wayne said.

title: STROBER ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1986 results are on a pro forma basis to reflect its reoganization prior to its initial public offering Nov. 7, 1986 and the implementation of a compensation plan effective July 1, 1986.

title: Lester Rawlins, 63, Stage TV Actor; Won Tony for 'Da'
description: Lester Rawlins, a stage and television actor who won a Tony and three Obie Awards, died of cardiac arrest last Tuesday in his home on West End Avenue in Manhattan. He was 63 years old.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
An Edelman Plan That Went Awry
description: Asher B. Edelman, the corporate takeover entrepreneur, rarely walks away from a deal without making money. Yet when faced recently with the need to put up more capital to buttress Ponderosa, the steakhouse chain he owned, he chose to sell at no profit, walking away from a potentially lucrative deal.

title: Hofstra Coach Resigns
description: Dick Berg has resigned as Hofstra's basketball coach after eight seasons. His team recently finished 6-21.

title: South Africans Strike Botswana
description: South African troops killed four people early today in a raid on a house in Gaborone, the capital of neighboring Botswana, the Government said.

title: BIPARTISAN TALKS ON AID TO CONTRAS COLLAPSE IN HOUSE
description: Efforts by House Democratic and Republican leaders to fashion an aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels broke down tonight over Republican demands for an early vote on renewed military aid for the contras if the current truce collapses.

title: Prescott Huntington, 82, Ex-Assemblyman
description: Prescott B. Huntington, a retired lawyer and New York State Assemblyman, died Thursday at his home in St. James, L.I., after a short illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Prosecutor's Messenger Is Robbed at Bank
description: A messenger from the Manhattan District Attorney's office was robbed of $4,900 yesterday by two men and a woman in a bank in lower Manhattan, the police said.

title: VITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $3,000 and $95,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: The Debate Over Style at Death's Door
description: Here amid the tombstones of historic Kensico Cemetery, a quiet war is raging over a subject as old as civilization: the desire of men and women to leave behind some mark of their existence.

title: Bravo, Jesse
description: That night, Gov. Mario Cuomo was making a witty speech.

title: Bonds Tumble After Dollar Drops
description: Bond prices tumbled in light trading yesterday, as the dollar continued to decline against other currencies.

description: b-Included a pre-tax charge of $417,000 for revaluation of assets for the quarter and year; the year also was after a $758,329 gain from the extinguishment of debt and tax credits and included a pre-tax gain of $2.5 million from the sale of a product line. c-Net loss

title: TSENG LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: All the Dresses She Can Buy
description: It's not uncommon for a woman, or a man, to put her salary on her back. What's uncommon about a woman named Ivana Trump is that she'll get her new salary only by putting it on her back.

title: Cutting Social Security Won't Reduce the Deficit; Helps Fill the Coffers
description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Campaign Sidesteps the 'O' Word
description: It's not every corporation that would put together a multimillion-dollar Olympic promotion and then assign it a 10-word name in which the word ''Olympic'' does not appear.

title: Stars Perform in Memorial Tribute To Composer Frederick Loewe
description: Hundreds of people lined up outside the Shubert Theater yesterday to bid farewell to the composer Frederick (Fritz) Loewe, who died on Feb. 14 at the age of 86. Drawn by stars - among them Julie Andrews and Richard Kiley - and the promise of a free ticket, they began gathering outside the theater before 9 A.M.; by the time the doors opened at 12:45, the line wound west on 44th Street to Eighth Avenue and then north to 45th Street.

title: John J. Bookman, 76, an Internist And Specialist in Diabetes, Dies
description: Dr. John Jacob Bookman, an internist specializing in diabetes, died in an auto accident in East Fishkill, N.Y., Sunday while driving back to Manhattan, where he lived and maintained his medical practice. He was 76 years old.

title: Hachette-Grolier
description: Hachette S.A. of France said that its vice chairman, Yves Sabouret, had told Robert J. Clarke, chairman of Grolier Inc., that the company was still interested in acquiring Grolier ''on a friendly basis.'' Grolier has already rejected a $21-a-share, or $415 million, offer by Hachette. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hachette said that it believed its offer was ''a full and fair price'' for the encyclopedia concern, based in Danbury, Conn. Hatchette told the S.E.C. that a meeting has been scheduled for Tuesday so that Hatchette could continue its review of Grolier's financial data.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Deficit Cutter
description: The National Economic Commission, a bipartisan group that will make recommendations to the next President on ways to cut the budget deficit, has chosen David G. Mathiasen to be executive director.

title: SHL SYSTEMHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Du Pont Sends a Message on Ozone
description: The Du Pont Company has pledged to phase out all production of CFC's, the chemicals that erode the life-protecting ozone layer in the high atmosphere. Du Pont, the world's largest producer of CFC's, with sales of $600 million a year, set no specific timetable. But it said a ''reasonable goal'' would be to cut output by 95 percent by the year 2000 - nearly double the goal set by an international protocol last year.

title: Found: A Rare Tape Of 'Krapp's Last Tape'
description: It could be called a case of ''Krapp's Lost Tape'' - and the rediscovery of that tape shows Jack MacGowran in an unfamiliar but form-fitting role.

title: The Afghan End Game: When Millions Move
description: In many capitals and in the headquarters of international organizations throughout the Western world, planning has begun for what may become one of the greatest movements of people in modern times - the return of Afghan refugees to their country.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dartmouth President Faults Right-Wing Student Journal
description: The president of Dartmouth College, James O. Freedman, today sharply criticized a right-wing student publication whose views on women, minorities and homosexuals have often roiled the campus in its eight-year history.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included a charge of $44.5 million for the writedown of oil and gas assets. The share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: A Worthy Quartet Reaches the End
description: From the first tipoff last November until the final shot in last Sunday's regional finals, the college basketball season has been like a furious storm with no discernible center. It has raged and swept in no particular pattern.

title: Advertising; Account
description: * Travel Agents International, Tampa, Fla., a travel franchise, to McFarland & Drier Advertising, Miami.

title: Advertising; Marschalk Seeks Impact For Olympus
description: WHEN it introduces its Infinity Superzoom 300 camera, the Olympus Optical Company of Japan will be supported by the kind of high-quality creative work that one expects from Lowe Marschalk, as well as some creative thinking from the agency's media department.

title: Gone, One Tax Loophole: Being Abroad on April 15
description: Irked by an airline advertisement touting a way for Americans to delay paying their Federal income taxes, the Internal Revenue Service today closed a longstanding loophole in the law that gave taxpayers who managed to be out of the country on April 15 an extra two months to pay.

title: Fermat's Theorem Solved? Not This Time
description: THE most notorious unsolved problem of mathematics, Fermat's Last Theorem, appears to have defeated yet another attack, put forward this month by a Japanese number theorist.

title: TOPPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
description: b-After a $2,638,000 tax credit.

Kansas Bars Batus Proxies
description: Insurance regulators in Kansas ordered an immediate halt today to Batus Inc.'s campaign to obtain shareholder backing for its proposed takeover of Farmers Group Inc.

title: Gains in Governments' Pay Equity Reported
description: State and local governments increasingly are moving to pay men and women the same for jobs that are different but are deemed to be of similar value to an employer, according to a private study released today.

title: New Round of Higher Bids for I.C.L.
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation raised its tender offer for International Clinical Laboratories Inc. to $37 a share today, or about $400 million, just hours after Corning Glass Works made a sweetened $35-a-share offer.

title: CLARCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
At the Baby M Visitation Hearing, Bitter and Anguished Testimony
description: In a day of angry and anguished testimony, William and Elizabeth Stern appealed today for Mary Beth Whitehead Gould to be barred for the near future from seeing Melissa Stern, the 2-year-old at the heart of the Baby M surrogacy and custody dispute.

title: Judge Accepts Witness Despite 1975 Hypnosis
description: A Federal judge indicated yesterday that he would permit the prosecution in a Mafia trial to present a witness who had been hypnotized to help her remember an abduction she had seen.

title: Talking Econo-Military
description: The phrase ''politico-military'' entered the strategists' jargon about a generation ago. It was a handy way of reminding diplomats and military men, who tend to go their own ways, that their concerns are tightly linked. Clausewitz observed that war and politics have shared goals, but he made it sound as though they were alternatives when in fact there are constant interconnections.

title: Court Rejects State Claim on Inmates' Benefits
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may not take Social Security benefits received by their prisoners to pay for their support.

title: Troops at Roadblocks Close Off Occupied Territories
description: Israeli soldiers manned roadblocks along major highways today to keep Palestinians out of Israel and journalists out of the occupied territories.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Mayor Henry W. Maier of Milwaukee misstated the date of the election to choose his successor. It is April 5.

title: Let All Young People Join National Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; International Classical Meets Brazilian Modern
description: There are two shows onstage at the City Center where Fernando Bujones and Yoko Morishita opened last night with Cisne Negro, a company from Brazil that is making a weeklong United States debut.

title: For Syria, a Pivotal Role in Mideast
description: As it celebrates the 25th anniversary of Baath Party rule this month, Syria appears to have recovered its ability to influence the Arab political agenda.

title: PATLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 2d Grolier Rebuff
description: Grolier Inc. has again rejected a $415 million bid by the French publisher Hachette S.A. as inadequate. Grolier, an encyclopedia and reference book company based in Danbury, last week rejected the $21-a-share offer made earlier this month. Amory Hall, a Hatchette spokesman, called his company's offer fair. Grolier, whose mainstays include Encylopedia Americana, added that it was still exploring all alternatives for maximizing value for its stockholders.

title: Letting Actors Strut Their Stuff
description: One moment she is a pregnant housewife in her 20's, the next moment a stolid middle-aged bureaucrat, the next a 60-ish translator whose physical charms are described as resembling a ''bulldog in a housecoat'' and whose ferocious personality mellows only after swilling a great deal of vodka, when she becomes alarmingly seductive.

title: Upbeat Tone for Hernandez
description: To all those people who wonder if he's lost a step, and to all those rookies on the Mets waiting to take his job, Keith Hernandez had a message today: he expects to play first base every day for the next three years and as often as possible for three years beyond that.

title: Heart Attack Deaths Reduced
description: A two-year study of more than 17,000 heart patients showed that aspirin and the seldom-used drug streptokinase, taken together after the onset of chest pains, reduce deaths among heart attack victims, researchers said today.

title: Wartime Trauma Cited in Death Penalty Reversal
description: The California Supreme Court has invalidated the death sentence of a Vietnam veteran because the sentencing trial excluded testimony that the man might have killed two young girls in response to wartime trauma.

title: Alumnae Back School Sex Barriers
description: A new round of battles has broken out in the effort to save women's colleges from extinction.

title: Two Soldiers Sentenced In Live Burial Incident
description: Two Israeli soldiers who admitted beating and burying alive four Arabs were sentenced to jail terms that were stiffer than those requested by prosecutors, Israeli radio reported today.

title: Corrections
description: A story in Science Times yesterday on treating fetuses using the umbilical cord incorrectly identified a hospital at which Dr. Stuart Weiner performed such procedures. It is Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-15 A new U.S.-Japanese agreement will allow American construction companies to work with Japanese contractors in building large public works projects in Japan. The agreement ended a politically sensitive trade dispute. Page A1 Panama's Roman Catholic bishops asked Gen. Manuel Noriega to resign as soon as possible and end the nation's political crisis. General Noriega's hand-picked civilian President, Manuel Solis Palma, rejected the request. A1 Outrage over violence in Panama was expressed by a White House spokesman, who said that the Reagan Administration's patience is limited. He was discussing assaults on American reporters and opponents of Gen. Manuel Noriega. A8 Agreement in principle on contra aid was reached by House Democratic and Republican leaders. They will meet today to approve a final draft of the $50 million package for the Nicaraguan rebels. A7 Five cease-fire zones in Nicaragua were agreed to by senior Nicaraguan military officers and contra commanders. Negotiators did not resolve all questions related to the zones, into which contra forces must withdraw. A6 Israeli soldiers manned roadblocks along major highways to keep Palestinians out of Israel and journalists out of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel has ordered the occupied territories closed for three days. A12 Syria's influnce over Arab politics is recovering as President Hafez al-Assad's Baath Party celebrates 25 years of rule. Syria is using ties with Iran in dealings with the oil-producing Arab countries of the Persian Gulf. A13 News analysis: France's campaign for the presidency tends to polarize around two candidates early in the race. President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac emerged quickly as frontrunners. A3 A small circle of Soviet leaders made the decision to move troops into Afghanistan. Even the Soviet Ambassador to Washington did not know in advance about the intervention, which may have raised doubts and opposition from the start. A11 An opponent of apartheid is shot to death in Paris A3 National A16-25 The No. 2 Justice Department official and five other top officials resigned because of growing concern over Attorney General Edwin Meese's legal problems and leadership, department officials said. A1 Jimmy Swaggart may not preach from the pulpit or on his television show for at least a year, the leaders of his church ordered. The Assemblies of God elders said Mr. Swaggart must be rehabilitated from ''moral failure.'' A1 Freezing part of the eye can reduce by half the risk of blindness or vision loss in some premature infants, Federal officials said. A nationwide trial proved so successful that doctors cut it short. A16 New house sales in February increased after 3 straight months of decline. The jump was the largest in almost 2 years. But analysts were cautious about prospects since the drop in January was so severe. D1 Must cemetery give ground to airport? A16 High Court rejects state claim on inmates' benefits A22 Politics A18-19 Bob Dole left the race for President and said he would work to help elect Vice President Bush. Senator Dole's withdrawal all but insured that Mr. Bush would receive the Republican nomination. A1 Governor Michael S. Dukakis won the Connecticut Democratic Presidential primary, solidly defeating the Rev. Jesse Jackson. George Bush won the Republican primary as Senator Bob Dole withdrew from the race. A1 Michael Dukakis's loss in Michigan to Jesse Jackson came as many Democrats began to consider him the likely Presidential nominee. Even his win in the Connecticut primary may not ease the wounds, political observers said. A18 Albert Gore assailed Jesse Jackson for his views on foreign policy. In the strongest attack by a Democratic Presidential candidate on Mr. Jackson, Senator Gore criticized Mr. Jackon's positions on the Middle East. A18 Cuomo says nominee should be most favored in primaries A18 Washington Talk A22 Dispute over raises for Congressional staff Regional A21, B1-3, B6, B28 An offer to buy Lilco for $7.45 billion was voted unanimously by the directors of the Long Island Power Authority. If the takeover succeeds, the public authority must abandon the Shoreham nuclear power plant. A1 A crackdown on bribes to inspectors in New York City was announced by the Koch administration, which warned businesses and landlords for the first time that they face criminal prosecution if they offer or pay bribes. B1 A Brooklyn movie palace closed after 60 years. The Walker Theater had a far shorter run as a landmark. Demolition crews are converting the building to discount clothing stores. But its Wurlitzer will be preserved. B1 Suspending restaurant inspections means that diners must consider whether they can assess conditions in restaurants until inspections resume. Diners can see some signs of proper food handling. C1 Protections broadened for news material sought in court cases A21 Encounters of homeless and commuters at Penn Station B1 Minority and gay groups vie for same government AIDS funds B2 Debate over scholarship plan delays budget talks B2 Stun-gun defendants sentenced B3 Regan says vocational schools reduce dropout rates B6

title: Scalpers Warned On $2,000 Ticket
description: Tickets for the Final Four this weekend could sell for $2,000 each, some speculators have said. And the police thought it was a good time to remind residents that ticket scalping in Kansas City is against the law.

title: Reagan Approves Legislation For Black Patriots' Memorial
description: President Reagan has approved a bill placing a $4 million memorial to blacks who fought against the British in the Revolutionary War in Washington's main tourist district.

title: Advertising; Calet, Hirsch & Spector Wins Duette Window
description: Calet, Hirsch & Spector, a New York subsidiary of the Ross Roy Group of Detroit, has won the Duette Window Fashions account over two other New York shops. The budget is $3 million.

title: Clemson Reveals Tests
description: Clemson University said that since it began mandatory drug testing in 1985, a total of 37 athletes had tested positive, some of them more than once. In a report that gave few details, the school said that 2,171 athletes had been tested, producing 56 positive results by 37 athletes, some of whom were suspended. The report did not identify the athletes or their sports. Although the test results indicated that only 1.7 percent of the athletes had used drugs, Byron Harder, a team doctor, said he was dissatisfied with the rate. ''We would like it to be zero,'' he said.(AP)

title: Books of the Times; Family Relations, Society and a Monstrous Baby
description: The Fifth Child By Doris Lessing 133 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Portrait Of a Chef: Pastry Arts Refined
description: LEAD: SURELY a large part of the life force of Albert Kumin, pastry chef, is contained in his hands.

title: Spanish Airline
description: Spantax S.A., Spain's largest charter airline, said it was ceasing activities because of debts totaling $90 million. A company spokesman said that Spantax had canceled all flights, effective immediately, affecting about 20,000 passengers. Last year, Spantax, based in Madrid, carried 1.35 million passengers to the United States, Latin America and several European destinations, as well as to domestic locations. The airline had a loss last year of about $5.4 million, on revenues of $160 million.

title: Noriega Is Urged by Bishops To Quit 'as Soon as Possible'
description: Panama's Roman Catholic bishops called on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today to help end the country's political crisis by relinquishing power ''as soon as possible.''

title: Goetz Appeals Weapons Conviction
description: Lawyers for Bernhard H. Goetz appealed his conviction on weapons possession yesterday, arguing that he should have been sentenced to a year in prison instead of six months.

title: Colombian Attorney General Is Said to Quit
description: The Attorney General of Colombia, Alfredo Gutierrez Marquez, resigned Monday after a report that cocaine traffickers used an airfield at his brother's ranch, a person at the President's office said.

title: 120,000 Blacks Saved From Homeland Status
description: South Africa's highest court today struck down a 1985 decision by the Government to forcibly incorporate a black community of 120,000 people into KwaNdebele, a tribal homeland.

title: Investor Demand Is Strong For Triple-A Georgia Bonds
description: The State of Georgia, one of few states that still has a rating of triple-A, priced $277.6 million of general obligation bonds in competitive bidding yesterday. Because there have been only a few issues of significant size with high-quality ratings priced this year, investor demand is strong.

title: Dealer Finds a Haggadah Is Not So Rare
description: For a while, Aharon Berger, a Brooklyn dealer in antique Judaica, thought he had acquired a genuine edition of the first printed Passover Haggadah, dating from 1482. That would have given Mr. Berger only the second known copy of the Guadalajara Haggadah, printed in Guadalajara, Spain.

title: A Highflier's One Final Gamble
description: Since the early 1980's, a new sort of entrepreneur has shaken up the electric utility industry.

title: States Agree to Turkey Deal
description: The State of Connecticut has sold 53 wild turkeys to Maine, fetching $143.40 per turkey. But the money will be going back to Maine when Connecticut seeks to buy fishers, a carnivore once common as far south as North Carolina but now limited to northern New England. Dale May, a Connecticut wildlife biologist, said officials hope to hasten the animal's return by transplanting a population to the state's northwestern hills.

title: ALL AMERICAN SEMICONDUCTOR reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the increase in the number of shares outstanding is due to the completion of the company's initial public offering of 1,150,000 shares in August 1987.

title: Advertising; Ayer to Handle Corian For Du Pont in Europe
description: N.W. Ayer, the agency for Du Pont's Corian in the United States since 1982, will now handle it in Europe, taking over from Young & Rubicam. Ayer has been a Du Pont agency since 1956.

title: Greek Cypriot Chief's 'Peace Offensive' Fades
description: Since assuming office a month ago, President George Vassiliou has promised a ''peace offensive'' to end the 14-year crisis between Greek and Turkish Cypriots.

title: America, a Wholly Owned Subsidiary of. . .
description: How the mighty keep falling! Three of the seven largest American advertising agencies, including J. Walter Thompson, now belong to the British. Doubleday is part of a German publishing company. Firestone is going Japanese. Brooks Brothers, epitome of the Establishment, could soon belong to Marks & Spencer, the British merchandiser. Even J. Press, which clothed generations of affluent Yale and Harvard undergraduates, belongs to a Japanese firm.

title: 3 People Are Killed During Police Chase
description: An elderly couple in their and the teen-age driver of a stolen car all died when their cars collided head on during a high-speed police chase, the authorities said yesterday.

title: MAXXAM GROUP inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $8,120,000. c-Net loss The latest year included a pre-tax gain of $133,363,000 from the sale of Maxxam's cutting and welding products operations, and a pre-tax gain of $18,355,000 from the termination of a pension plan. The latest year also included investment and other income of $9,437,000, compared to $53,877,000 in 1986.

title: Wine Talk
description: SOMEONE once asked a newspaper columnist about the response to a particularly fiery polemic of his. ''Just what I expected,'' he replied. ''A half a dozen letters poured in.''

title: Sandinistas and Rebels Agree To Set Up 5 Cease-Fire Zones
description: Senior Nicaraguan military officers and contra commanders agreed today to create five cease-fire zones into which contra forces will withdraw.

title: Passengers Evacuate Plane In Apparent Panic at a Flash
description: Passengers apparently panicked at the sight of flames on the wing of a Northwest Airlines jet and evacuated the plane without waiting for instructions from the crew, officials said Monday.

title: Jackson in Action: Running Hard, Running Late
description: Since his surprising landslide victory in the Michigan caucuses this weekend, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has loomed large on the front pages of newspapers, the news shows of the television networks and the minds of Democratic Party professionals.

title: Test Shows Freezing Is Best Treatment for Infant Eye Disease
description: Freezing part of the eye can reduce by half the risk of blindness or vision loss in certain premature infants, Federal health officials said today.

title: Judge Orders Eastern To Halt Pilot Training
description: A Federal judge ordered Eastern Air Lines Inc. yesterday to stop training nonunion pilots on Eastern aircraft that it has leased to a North Carolina cargo airline.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Waived Guy Hoffman, pitcher. CLEVELAND (AL) - Released Frank Wills, pitcher, and John Moses, outfielder. Reassigned Don Gordon, pitcher; Terry Francona, first baseman, and John Stefero, catcher. DETROIT (AL) - Waived John Wetteland pitcher. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Reclaimed John Wetteland pitcher. OAKLAND (AL) - Placed Glenn Hubbard, second baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Put Steve Bedrosian, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Released Bill Dawley, free agent, and George Vukovich, outfielder. SEATTLE (AL) - Released Ken Dixon, pitcher. TEXAS (AL) - Released Ed Vande Berg, pitcher. Optioned Ray Hayward and Gary Mielke, pitchers, and James Steels, outfielder, to Oklahoma City. Assigned Dwayne Henry, pitcher, and Jeff Kunkel and Tom O'Malley, infielders, to Oklahoma City. Returned Craig McMurtry, pitcher, to their minor-league camp. Placed Brad Arnsberg, pitcher, on the 60-day disabled list. YANKEES (AL) - Waived Pete Filson, pitcher. BASKETBALL NATIONAL BASKETBALL ASSOCIATION - Fined Utah Coach Frank Layden an undisclosed amount for making critical remarks about officials March 14. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed Kevin Henderson, guard. NETS (NBA) - Signed Duane Washington, guard, to a 10-day contract extension. FOOTBALL KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Traded Todd Blackledge, quarterback, to the Steelers for a fourth-round draft choice. NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - igned Steve Pontiakos and Eric Riley, tight ends. NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Daren Gilbert, lineman, to a one-year contract; Chuck Commiskey, lineman, to a two-year contract; and Derek Holloway, wide receiver, and Garland Jean Baptiste, fullback. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Traded Clarence Verdin, wide receiver-kick returner, to the Colts for a draft pick. HOCKEY PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Sent Wendell Young, goaltender, Brian Dobbin, right wing, and Magnus Roupe, left wing to Hershey. RANGERS (NHL) - Signed Darren Turcotte, center; Robb Graham, right wing, and Jeff Bloemberg, defenseman, and assigned them to Colorado. Announced that Colorado signed Mark Janssens, center. MONDAY BASEBALL NATIONAL LEAGUE - Named Gary Darling and Mark Hirschbeck umpires. ATLANTA (NL) - Traded Jeff Dedmon, pitcher, to Cleveland for a player to be named later. BOSTON (AL) - Assigned Pat Dodson, first baseman; Danny Sheaffer, catcher; and Rob Woodward, John Leister and Zach Crouch, pitchers, to its minor league camp.

title: Stocks Rebound; Dow Up 18.57, to 1,998.34
description: Stocks rebounded broadly yesterday, posting their first advance in four days.

title: For French Voters, Old Faces of '88
description: The campaign for the French presidency has swiftly designated its two front-runners: President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, the leader of the conservative neo-Gaullist movement.

title: Nevada Governor to Run
description: Gov. Dick Bryan of Nevada, a Democrat, announced Monday that he would be a candidate for the United States Senate and criticized the Republican incumbent, Senator Chic Hecht. ''If he was the kind of Senator Nevada deserves, I would not have made that decision'' to run, said Mr. Bryan, who is in the middle of his second four-year term.

title: First City Suitors Alter Terms of Bid
description: Embroiled with Wall Street arbitragers who continue to balk at its terms, the group bidding to acquire the ailing First City Bancorporation of Texas Inc. today reduced the percentage of bondholders who must approve its $1.5 billion offer to 70 percent, from 90 percent.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Let Them Have Credit
description: The scene: the corner of 17th Street and L Street Northwest, prime territory for the expense account set.

title: Ex-Engineer Gets 5 Years in Fatal Amtrak Crash
description: A former Conrail engineer was sentenced today to the maximum term of five years in prison and fined $1,000 for causing 16 deaths in Amtrak's worst train accident.

title: Judge Assails 4 Ex-Policemen in Sentencing in Queens Torture Case
description: Declaring that for the police ''to viciously assault'' criminals illegally is to embrace ''anarchy,'' a judge yesterday sentenced a former police officer to prison for helping to torture a Queens marijuana dealer with an electronic stun gun.

title: Data Reflect Aging Population
description: The percentage of elderly people confined to nursing homes is remaining stable as the population ages, according to a Federal report issued today.

title: TRANSCISCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $3,260,000 for the latest year and $2,162,000 for 1986.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Capitals 2, Red Wings 2: Dale Hunter scored a power-play goal 1 minute 14 seconds into the third period last night, lifting Washington into a 2-2 tie with Detroit at Landover, Md. Hunter, left alone in front of the Detroit net, took a centering pass from Bengt Gustafsson and slipped a backhand shot past the goalie Greg Stefan for his 20th goal of the season. The Wings, the leading penalty-killers in the National Hockey League, had allowed one goal in 27 short-handed situations before giving up two power-play scores to the Capitals. Detroit took a 2-1 lead on a goal by Adam Oates with 2:20 left in the second period. Washington had tied the game at 1-1 on Dave Christian's power-play goal wih 7:28 to play in the period. Dave Barr put a rebound into an open net 1:14 into the game for Detroit's 1-0 lead.(AP) Sabres 3, Nordiques 1: Mark Napier scored two goals and Darren Puppa made 46 saves as Buffalo defeated last night in Quebec, clinching third place in the Adams Division and eliminating the Nordiques. The Nordiques scored only once on 12 power-play chances in the game as they lost their fifth straight. (AP) N.B.A. Hawks 120, Mavericks 106: Dominique Wilkins scored 40 points, including 6 in a second-quarter run that gave Atlanta control of the game, and the Hawks defeated Dallas at the Omni last night. Wilkins scored his 6 key points and Antoine Carr added 6 as Atlanta outscored Dallas by 20-7 to turn a 31-28 lead with 10:36 remaining in the second period into a 51-35 lead late in the period. The Mavericks never got closer than 7 points the rest of the way. It was the 14th time this season Wilkins scored 40 or more points. It had been 131 games, the longest such streak in the National Basketball Association, since an opponent scored 40 or more against the Mavericks. The last to do it was Sleepy Floyd, then with Golden State, who scored 41 points on Dec. 6, 1986. The Mavericks' coach, John MacLeod, was ejected in the second period after getting his second technical.(AP) BOXING Honeyghan Knocks Out Vaca: Lloyd Honeyghan pinned Jorge Vaca to the ropes in the third round and knocked him out with a barrage of punches at 2 minutes 58 seconds to regain the World Boxing Council welterweight title last night at Wembley, England. Honeyghan, who lost his title to the Mexican 11 months ago, dominated the scheduled 12-round rematch. Honeyghan became only the second fighter from England to regain a title, at any weight.(AP) HORSE RACING Hibernation 4-Length Winner: Hibernation took the lead from the pacesetting Pentelicus after entering the stretch and went on to a four-length victory in the $33,000 allowance feature yesterday at Aqueduct. Pentelicus was the runner-up in the eight-horse field. The victory was the fourth in eight career starts for Hibernation, who went six furlongs in 1:10 2/5 to earn $19,800 for his owner, Alfred G. Vanderbilt. Hibernation paid $5.40 for $2 to win as the favorite.

title: DUKAKIS REBOUNDS, DEFEATING JACKSON IN CONNECTICUT BID
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts easily defeated the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Connecticut Democratic primary yesterday, winning the lift he had sought to reinvigorate his campaign.

title: AMERICAN BUILDERS WIN PARTICIPATION IN JAPAN PROJECTS
description: Ending one of their most contentious trade disputes, the United States and Japan completed an agreement today that would permit American construction companies to participate with Japanese contractors in building airport terminals, bridges, ports and other large public works projects in Japan.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Add Condition to Missile Treaty
description: In a development that may portend a major fight on the Senate floor, the Foreign Relations Committee voted today to attach to the new missile accord a binding condition that the White House finds unacceptable.

title: Foe of Apartheid Is Shot Dead in Paris
description: The Paris representative of the African National Congress was shot and killed today as she arrived at her office.

title: Gay and Minority Groups Compete for AIDS Money
description: With the number of AIDS victims increasing faster than the money available to help them, some minority and gay groups serving neighborhoods hit by the disease now find themselves battling for the same government dollars.

title: Yankees Offering Winfield
description: Dave Winfield has told friends that he has no intention of approving a trade this season, but it apparently hasn't stopped George Steinbrenner, with whom Winfield is feuding, from shopping his right fielder to other teams.

title: Manning Honored
description: Danny Manning, the standout forward for Kansas, has been named the 18th winner of the Joe Lapchick Award, sponsored by St. John's in honor of the Redmen's late coach, and the 14th winner of the Eastman Award as the top male collegiate basketball player, voted by the National Association of Basketball Coaches. The Lapchick award, to the nation's outstanding senior collegiate basketball player, will be presented to Manning as part of the Basketball Hall of Fame's enshrinement events May 3 in Springfield, Mass.

title: Icarus Fell; U.S. Team Hopes to Do Better
description: On the island of Crete, sometime in the next few days, Greek mythology is heading for an American update. Stand back, Daedalus, with your wings of wax and feathers; make way for New Aviator, with graphite spars and polyester film and the backing of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Democratic Voters Storm the Bastille
description: LEAD: ''Is it a revolt?'' Louis XVI asked, upon hearing the news that the Bastille had fallen. ''No, sire,'' his minister replied, ''it is a revolution.''

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper yesterday. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million of the 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.6483 percent, up from 6.6192 percent last week.

title: Cuomo Remains Unflustered at Jackson Gains
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the Democratic Presidential nominee should be the person who receives the most votes in the primaries. ''If that's Jesse Jackson, wonderful,'' he declared.

title: Arthur M. Vineberg, Surgeon, 84
description: Dr. Arthur Martin Vineberg, who developed artery transplants at McGill University in Montreal, died of pneumonia Saturday at the university's Royal Victoria Hospital, where he worked for 55 years. He was 84 years old.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Tulane Fight Over Merger Leaves Scars
description: For Newcomb College, the battle appears to be over. But questions and scars of distrust remain in the aftermath of a fight over Tulane University's decision to merge the faculty of Newcomb, its coordinate women's school, with that of the university's College of Arts and Sciences.

title: 2 Executives Are Given Garbage Duty by Judge
description: Two garbage company executives will gain a new perspective of their industry because a Federal District Court judge has sentenced them to work as garbagemen for their guilty pleas to bid-rigging charges.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; Who Do You Thank When the Staff Gets a Raise?
description: People on Capitol Hill have a choice phrase to describe legislation that contains nonessential, often costly, riders that are added to benefit special interests. Such legislative packages are called ''Christmas tree bills.'' Last Christmas, a new Yuletide figure came into being here: the mystery Santa Claus.

title: Advertising; Justamere Gets Account
description: Justamere Advertising Agency of Hopatcong, N.J. has announced that it has become agency for the City Federal Services Bank, which, Justamere said, bills some $4 million. It was formerly handled in-house. City Federal, based in Bedminster, N.J., has 113 branches throughout the state and in Florida, where its parent company, Citifed Financial Corporation has its headquarters in Palm Beach.

title: Tempest in a Soup Dish: Light Matzoh Balls, or Heavy?
description: FRIDAY night, as soon as the soup course is served at many Passover seders throughout the country, an age-old debate will ensue: light, airy matzoh balls in the chicken broth versus heavy matzoh balls.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Transplant Candidate
description: Representative Floyd Spence is on a national organ donor list awaiting a double lung transplant. The South Carolina Republican, who will turn 60 next month, suffers from chronic obstructive lung disease, a condition that impairs breathing.

title: HADSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The one thing you learn how to do pretty well in our business is to count. You come to trust your instincts to tell you it's over. In my heart I know that time is now.'' - Senator Bob Dole. [ A19:1. ]

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Food Notes
description: Edible Easter Bonnets

title: The Pop Life
description: Musical Collages

title: World Bank Seeks New Agent Firms
description: The World Bank announced it is inviting 14 United States regional securities firms and three Toronto-based firms to become agents for its program of continously offered longer-term securities, known as Colts.

title: Sundstrand Filing
description: The Sundstrand Corporation, an aerospace contractor, has said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expects to be fined heavily by the Government because of an investigation into reported overcharges. Last July, the Defense Department said that Sundstrand, based in Rockford, Ill., had overbilled the United States over two years by more than $100 million on military contracts. The company is being investigated by Federal grand juries in Illinois and Washington state.

title: AUDIO-VIDEO AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest year includes a pretax gain of $1,032,000 on the sale of Cyclops Corp. common stock.

title: Olympian Returns To Familiar Task
description: It almost seems like a cruel trick. Four years ago, Randy Lewis had to survive three matches, a protest, a rematch and an arbitration decision to defeat Lee Roy Smith for the right to represent the United States in the Olympic wrestling tournament at 136 1/2 pounds. With all that behind him, he breezed through the Olympic field to win the gold medal.

title: Fantasy of the Bride-to-Be: A $100 Gown
description: THE thrill of a good buy drew more than 100 brides-to-be, attended by mothers, fiances and friends, to stand in line on a spring morning outside Second Time Around, a thrift shop in Manhattan.

title: Federated To Proceed On Bid Plan
description: Preparing for a crucial board meeting today, Federated Department Stores Inc. gave guidelines for final offers to its two bidders yesterday, leaving its ''poison pill'' shareholder-rights plan in place.

title: Keep the Number, Cheo
description: IT started as a whim, the suggestion of his 13-year-old son, Cheito.

title: Rough Justice in the Chambers Case
description: After 13 weeks in court, including nine days of fruitless jury debate, the murder case of the People of New York v. Robert Chambers Jr. ended in a compromise plea to manslaughter. The public heard in intimate detail Mr. Chambers's bizarre defense that his killing of Jennifer Levin in Central Park two summers ago was an accident that grew out of violent sex. Then, abruptly, he admitted in open court that he had intended harm, though not murder. The sudden denouement after so long a drama left a wake of questions:

title: Regan Urges New York City to Add More Vocational High Schools
description: New York City's vocational high schools have much lower dropout rates than other high schools, but there are too few of them to meet the demand, according to an audit by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: Some Arms Cheating May Not Matter
description: For seven years, the Administration has angrily decried Soviet cheating on arms accords. Now it finds itself in the same position as its predecessors, of urging the Senate to ratify a treaty with verification provisions that are adequate but not airtight. After two months of hearings, the treaty on Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces is scheduled for a Senate Foreign Relations Committee vote today. The senators can confidently give this pact the benefit of the doubt.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Phylicia Rashad Joining Cast of 'Into the Woods'
description: Phylicia Rashad is to replace Bernadette Peters in the role of the Witch in the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: Food Safety: More Than Meets The Eye
description: WHEN a fifth of New York City's 110 restaurant inspectors were arrested last week on charges of bribery, the safety of every establishment was suddenly open to question. With inspections temporarily suspended and no agency providing dependable, regular oversight, consumers are forced to consider whether they can assess the hazards presented by eating in restaurants.

title: HAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: M. W. Patterson, 91, Social Service Leader
description: Margaret Winchester Patterson, a volunteer in social service organizations, died of heart failure Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: Devils Gain in Playoff Bid
description: With Sean Burke shining brightly in their goal, the Devils reduced Mario Lemieux to mortality tonight and scored a 4-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: We Need to Encourage Nursing as a Career
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Prices Up in Light Trading
description: Bond prices moved higher in light trading yesterday, responding to a rise in the dollar's value on foreign exchange markets.

title: Baby M Visitation Hearing Focuses on Publicity
description: Mary Beth Whitehead Gould today scoffed at the notion that she would take 2-year-old Melissa Stern on cross-country book promotion tours if she received immediate visitation rights to the child she bore under a surrogate-mother contract.

title: PASSPORT TRAVEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Congress Seeks Trade Bill Soon
description: Striving to find compromises that will enable Congress to pass a trade bill this week, leaders of the House and the Senate began a major effort today to sort out their differences.

title: Dollar Up, Halting Its Sharp Fall
description: The dollar rebounded against most major foreign currencies yesterday as the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve reportedly moved to bolster its value.

title: The Cats Who Let Us Live With Them
description: WE have always lived with animals. Goldfish. A guinea pig. And cats. Mostly we have had cats.

title: Ted Kluszewski, 63, a Leading Home Run Hitter
description: Ted Kluszewski, the slugging first baseman who led the major leagues in home runs in 1954 with 49, died tonight after apparently suffering a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: HOWE RICHARDSON reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $550,000 on the termination of pension plans. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary gain of $3,092,000.

title: ADMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed about $5.4 million of the latest third quarter loss primarily to costs related to inventory adjustments and fixed asset writeoffs reflecting a change in marketing strategy.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: HAPPY EASTER

title: Review/Theater; Brazilian Pageant of Music and Dance
description: ''Oba Oba,'' the glitzy Brazilian music-and-dance extravaganza that has settled in at the Ambassador Theater for a limited run, is a circusy nightclub pageant whose attractive, scantily clad performers never stop smiling as they scamper about the stage and parade through the aisles. ''Exotic,'' ''torrid,'' and ''scintillating'' - adjectives that have a slightly quaint 50's ring - are among the words that spring to mind in trying to evoke the mood of a festive revue whose performers include voluptuous, bare-breasted women, well-muscled acrobats doing running handstands, and an adoring tribute to Carmen Miranda in which several pounds of wax fruit and flowers adorn the performers' heads.

title: Authority Votes $7 Billion Offer In Bid for Lilco
description: The directors of the Long Island Power Authority voted unanimously today to make a $7.45 billion offer to buy the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: About Education
description: In a recent interview with a campus reporter, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of Yale University, criticized fraternities for ''exclusionary policies'' and alcohol abuse. Mr. Schmidt, a 1962 Yale graduate, was himself a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon, but said that if he were to do it all over again, he would not join a fraternity.

title: LENNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Rangers' Options Are Suddenly Simpler
description: Walt Poddubny's swollen right hand has made it difficult for him to execute the simplest of chores. Today, finished with practice, preparing for the Rangers' flight to Chicago, Poddubny picked up the morning newspaper. Painful as that was, it hurt far more to open the pages and fully absorb what he read.

title: Indian Held in Candidate's Death' Sheriff Rules Out Political Motive
description: A young man was charged today with killing an Indian judicial candidate last weekend, and a person believed to be an accomplice was found dead, apparently having committed suicide.

title: Review/Film; Ghosts And Extra Eyeballs
description: Anyone whose idea of high wit can be achieved with bizarre latex facial makeup and extra eyeballs in unexpected places will at least admire ''Beetlejuice'' for its ingenuity. Tim Burton, who also directed ''Pee-Wee's Big Adventure,'' shows a keen grasp of preadolescent tastes in special effects (the weirder the better), pacing (illogical but busy) and comic constructs (only something incongruous, like people breaking into the ''Banana Boat'' song (''Day-O'') for no reason, is funnier than something rude).

title: Dallas Ballet to Reopen With New Budget Plan
description: The Dallas Ballet, which canceled its spring season because of financial problems, is to stage a reduced season in October, company officials said today.

title: CVN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss Results for the 1987 period have been restated to the company's new fiscal reporting period. The company's annual financial reporting period was changed from a Dec. 31 calendar year to an Aug. 31 fiscal year effective Aug. 31, 1987.

title: Hollywood's Cluster Syndrome
description: Sometimes movie themes seem like mushrooms. Overnight, a peculiar and unexpected cluster springs up.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RAILROAD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Low Dropout Rate at Catholic Schools Linked to Social Ties
description: James S. Coleman, the University of Chicago sociologist, has new research showing that the high school dropout rate in Roman Catholic schools is much lower than in other private schools or in public schools.

title: LURIA, L & SON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $608,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Advertising; A Campaign For Squirt Soft Drink
description: PERHAPS the best way to describe the planned national advertising campaign by A&W Brands for its recently acquired Squirt soft drink is with the brand name itself.

title: STRATEGIC PLANNING ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Detroit Journal; Must Cemetery Yield to Airport?
description: These days, other than the oak trees on the hillside, there is nothing serene about the Serenity lot or any other lot at Detroit's Gethsemane Cemetery.

title: Boxing Notebook; Leonard Comeback Rumored
description: Rumors are mounting that Sugar Ray Leonard will return to the ring before the year is out.

title: Advertising; The Hall of Fame Salutes 3 New Members
description: The 39th annual Advertising Hall of Fame induction luncheon was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, with Edward N. Ney, Eugene H. Kummel and the late Vance L. Stickell the honorees. That brought the list of inductees to 106.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 30, 1988
description: INTERNATIONAL A U.S.-Japan pact to assist American companies seeking construction contracts in Japan was reached in talks in Washington, a day before a deadline set by the President's Economic Policy Council. The two-year-old dispute was one of the most contentious trade disputes, and the council had recommended sanctions if Japan did not yield. The Administration hailed the accord as proof that negotiations, rather than retaliation, could bring change. [ Page A1. ] House and Senate negotiators grappled with other trade issues, trying to sort out their differences before the Easter recess. [ D9. ] THE ECONOMY Sales of new homes rebounded smartly in February after three straight declines. The 20.3 percent jump last month was somewhat more than expected and the biggest in nearly two years. But analysts remained cautious about the outlook. [ D1. ] The index of leading indicators rose 0.9 percent in February, providing further evidence that a recession is unlikely this year. [ D4. ] MARKETS The dollar advanced against major foreign currencies, as the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve reportedly moved to bolster its value. In late dealings in New York, the dollar was trading at 125.20 Japanese yen, up sharply from 123.80 yen on Monday. Gold rose 15 cents in New York, to $455.25 an ounce. [ D1. ] Stocks rebounded broadly, posting their first advance in four days. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.57 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,998.34, and advancing stocks outnumbered declining issues 1,024 to 478. Analysts attributed the gain to the dollar's modest recovery and to takeover activity. [ D12. ] Bond prices moved higher in light trading, responding to a rise in the dollar. The improvement took place in spite of a rise in equity prices and stronger-than-expected economic reports. [ D19. ] Platinum futures prices surged $7 an ounce on news of U.S. economic gains and racial unrest in South Africa. [ D20. ] COMPANIES Kohlberg, Kravis became the fourth investor in Texaco to seek U.S. permission to buy up to 15 percent, renewing speculation that the nation's third-largest oil company is headed for the auction block. Texaco cautiously welcomed the move. [ D1. ] Roper's directors changed horses and endorsed G.E.'s $504 million takeover bid, withdrawing the support it had given to Whirlpool's bid two weeks ago. [ D1. ] Federated gave guidelines for final offers to its two bidders, leaving its ''poison pill'' shareholder-rights plan in place. Campeau said it would not abide by the guidelines but failed to have the bidding procedure halted by the courts. [ D1. ] A Federal judge blocked a plan by Eastern Air Lines Inc. to train nonunion pilots on its aircraft that it has leased to a North Carolina cargo carrier. [ D2. ] A group seeking First City Bancorp of Texas reduced the percentage of bondholders who must approve its $1.5 billion offer. [ D2. ] An investigator for WPP found files missing from Lord, Geller after its top executives defected, according to court papers. [ D6. ] Odyssey raised its bid for J. P. Stevens to $64 a share, or $1.14 billion, topping an offer from West Point-Pepperell. [ D5. ] The British Government will sell the Rover Group to British Aerospace for about $279 million. [ D5. ] TECHNOLOGY Solar electricity may be far cheaper by the mid-1990's as photovoltaic cells become much more efficient. [ D10. ] Some of Silicon Valley's most advanced fabrication techniques are being used by the auto industry to produce a new generation of ''smart sensors.'' Advances. [ D10. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Eastern Airlines and its machinists union offer a test of the ability of labor and management to find common ground in a rapidly changing industry. Peter Passell. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The restaurant industry has many problems, but several companies are getting strong recommendations. Market Place. [ D12. ]

title: Bilzerian, Taking Over, Fills No. 2 Singer Post
description: Joseph J. Campanella was named president and chief operating officer of the Singer Company yesterday as William F. Schmied resigned the posts. Mr. Schmied also stepped down as co-chairman, co-chief executive and a member of the board.

title: Fadeout for Movie Palace in Brooklyn
description: With one final C chord on its mighty Wurlitzer, the Walker Theater in Brooklyn ended a 60-year run yesterday, distinguished as one of the most enduring neighborhood movie palaces in New York and one of the city's most briefly lived landmarks.

title: Gore Assails Jackson on View of Israel
description: In the strongest attack yet by a Democratic Presidential candidate on the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Albert Gore Jr. assailed Mr. Jackson's foreign policy views yesterday and said he was ''dismayed'' by Mr. Jackson's ''embrace of Arafat and Castro.''

title: At Penn Station, an Oasis for Homeless
description: In the cavernous waiting areas and flourescent-lighted passages of Pennsylvania Station dozens of New York City's homeless, weary and disheveled, encounter fleetingly the rail commuters in business suits who each day head to and from Long Island, New Jersey and points beyond.

title: John J. Bookman, 76, a Specialist in Diabetes, Dies
description: Dr. John Jacob Bookman, an internist specializing in diabetes, died in an auto accident in East Fishkill, N.Y., Sunday while driving back to Manhattan, where he lived and maintained his medical practice. He was 76 years old.

title: L.I. Officials React Cautiously To Offer to Take Over Lilco
description: Long Island business leaders and elected officials today reacted cautiously to the Long Island Power Authority's offer to take over the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: BILL IS REJECTED ON TOXIN WARNINGS
description: The Senate effectively rejected legislation today that would have required warnings to workers that they risk cancer and other diseases from on-the-job exposure to toxic chemicals.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Business Technology page on March 9 about women in engineering misstated the source of a quotation by Sandra K. Bidwell of Tucson, Ariz. The quotation about sex discrimination in the engineering profession was from an article written by Karen Fitzgerald in The Institute, a newsletter published by the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers.

title: In Bangladesh, a Pale Imitation of Red Tape
description: It is in the Second Nine-Story Building at the Government's central Secretariat that much of life in this nation of 100 million people slows to a standstill.

title: Bond Index Market Ends
description: The Chicago Board of Trade has suspended trading in its five-month-old Corporate Bond Index futures contract because of a lack of volume. The contract is based on an index of bonds issued by 100 United States corporations. The Commodities Futures Trading Commission has approved ''dormant status'' for the contract, so the exchange could revive it later.

title: Rediscovery for Sooner Fans
description: The last time the University of Oklahoma basketball team made it to the Final Four, Harry Truman was President, Joe Louis was heavyweight champion and James Cagney was starring in ''13 Rue Madeleine'' at the Mayfair, only a few blocks from Madison Square Garden, where the Sooners lost the title game to Holy Cross, 58-47.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday on the International Business Machines Corporation misidentified the source for estimated sales of I.B.M.'s 9370 minicomputer. The estimates were provided by Myron Kerstetter, an analyst with the Gartner Group.

title: Reagan Clarifies His Remark About North Being a Hero
description: President Reagan today hedged his assertion that Lieut Col. Oliver L. North was a hero, with the President confining his continuing praise to the indicted marine's combat record.

title: Review/Television; Violence From Sex Bias
description: Is violence against gay men and lesbians rising? The panelists on ''Metroline'' aren't sure, but they agree that violence is a serious problem. They also seem to suggest, however, that society shows increasing acceptance of, and tolerance for, gay men and lesbians. The program, ''The Most Frequent Victim,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 tonight.

title: Bridge
description: Duplicate players look hopefully for a top score on a single deal, proving that they have beaten their rivals in the short run, and for a top score in a session, demonstrating long-run victory. They are not, in general, concerned with the score in a round of play against one pair of opponents.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a gain of $5,696,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income d-After an extraordinary loss of $2,396,000 from redemption of debt. Manor Care said the loss in the latest quarter was caused principally by its previously announced writedown of its investment in the common stock of Beverly Enterprises. The company said the previously reported writedown in its latest third quarter was $22.1 million.

description: EASTERN AIRLINES and its largest union, District 100 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, seem locked on a collision course that could destroy the airline, the union local or both.

BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1987 losses resulted from high marketing expenses, along with realized and unrealized losses on investments, particularly during the October stock market crash.

Ex-Clerk Charged in Thefts
description: A former court clerk was accused today of stealing more than $100,000 from the city's Parking Violations Bureau, the Westchester County District Attorney said.

description: b-Includes a reversal of a tax loss carryforward of $245,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $130,000 for the year. c-Net loss d-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $1,218,000 for both the quarter and year, and tax credits of $295,000 and $405,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company, in a preliminary report, said it had a 1987 fourth quarter loss of $245,000 and net income for the year of $702,000, or 54 cents a share. The company also said that its audited figures for 1987 reflect an addition to the company's policyholder reserves at year-end of $500,000.
