description: To the Editor:

title: An Idea Man at NBC Receiving Polk Award
description: As his friend Art Buchwald, the humorist, sees it, Gordon Manning, a staff consultant to NBC News, is ''the man in the middle no one knows'' who ''arranges for things to happen.''

title: ALLWASTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ORACLE SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: In accordance with FAS No. 86, $185,000 of software production costs have been capitalized in the latest quarter and $1,482,000 for the 9 months, compared with the year-ago periods of $1,295,000 for the quarter and $3,701,000 for the 9 months. The share earnings were adjusted for the company's recent 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: The University of New Orleans has dismissed the basketball coach, Art Tolis, for ''just cause,'' apparently intending to avoid buying out the remaining two years of his contract. Tolis, who said he did not like the implication that he did anything wrong and will go to court to fight the dismissal, was promoted from assistant coach last spring when Benny Dees left to take the job at Wyoming. After a 5-5 start, Tolis, 53 years old, led the Privateers to a 21-11 record and a berth in the National Invitation Tournament this year. His base salary was $58,000 a year, meaning the school would have to pay $116,000 to buy him out. However, dismissal for cause would relieve the school of that burden.

title: Bush Nomination Seems Assured As Dole Leaves Republican Race
description: Vice President Bush all but officially became the Republican nominee for President today when Senator Bob Dole, his chief rival, ended his campaign.

title: KEY RATES
NODAWAY VALLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a loss of $250,000 on the disposition of subsidiaries. c-Included a gain of $250,000 on the sale of a leased plant. The figures are restated for an accounting change.

title: Small 'Intelligent' Sensors That Are Affordable in Cars
description: THE American automobile industry is adopting some of Silicon Valley's most advanced fabrication techniques to produce a new generation of ''smart sensors'' that will cut the cost of the computer-controlled features with which it hopes to tempt car buyers in the 1990's.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Springtime Can Be a Season for Skiing
description: SPRING rains plus freezing plus sunshine equal corn snow, one of the most delightful surfaces for skiing. The term corn derives from the size of ice particles as they melt and refreeze, growing from granules to kernels.

title: USAir Is Offering Trust Certificates
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc. and USAir Inc., both subsidiaries of USAir Group Inc., are offering a total of $137.4 million in equipment trust certificates through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. Underlying security for the certificates are seven Boeing 737-300 airplanes.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writedown of $12,087,000 on the company's oil and gas properties since the net capitalized cost as Dec. 31, 1986 exceeded the present value of estimated future net revenue. The total writedowns for oil and gas reserves for 1986 were $18,970,000.

title: About New York; Inside Lazer Tag And the Scoop On Boggle Bowl
description: Scott Marley was saying, in response to a dumb question from a man who is completely witless when it comes to games: ''Checkers is problematic. At this point it is completely analyzed. Becoming good at checkers is mostly a matter of memorizing openings. They just have draw after draw.''

title: LESSONS
description: There are no lectures, no tests, no classes per se. There are only the immortals - Plato and Aristotle, St. Augustine and Montaigne, Spinoza, Swift, Melville, Moliere, more than 130 of The Great Books, as they are called at St. John's College, in what is still, after 50 academic seasons, an experiment in the liberal arts.

title: For Workers, More Paths to Degree
description: In classrooms from lower Manhattan to Los Angeles, automobile assemblers and prison guards, taxi drivers and postal carriers are taking such college courses as ''The Latin American Novel,'' and ''The Abnormal Personality,'' all with the encouragement of their unions.

title: New-Home Sales Jump By 20.3%
description: Sales of new homes rebounded smartly in February after three straight declines that seemed to be bearing out fears that housing would drag down the nation's economy.

title: Gotti Jury Selection Opened to Reporter
description: A Federal judge yesterday lifted much of the secrecy surrounding the questioning of prospective jurors in the new racketeering and drug trial of Gene Gotti and two co-defendants.

title: No Nominee Wins Largest Novelists' Prize
description: For the first time, not one of the nominees for the $50,000 Ritz Hemingway Award, the largest prize for novelists, received enough votes to win.

title: Insider Case Settlement
description: Andrew Solomon, a former arbitrage analyst with Marcus Schloss & Company and a member of the insider trading ring that became known as the ''Yuppie Five,'' has settled Federal charges that he had received material non-public information about takeovers and gave it to his superiors at the firm, who used the information to make illegal trades. The Securities and Exchange

title: A Leap in Efficiency for Cells Tapping the Sun
description: MAKING electricity from sunlight may become as cheap as making it from coal or oil in some regions by the mid-1990's because of a development in the efficiency of photovoltaic cells, according to a group of researchers.

title: Blackledge a Steeler
description: After finishing last season with the worst-rated starting quarterback in the National Football League, the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday acquired a possible replacement, who, they think, may have been the best quarterback in the league to spend most of the season on the bench. In exchange for a fourth-round draft pick next month, the Steelers got Todd Blackledge from the Kansas City Chiefs. The 27-year-old Blackledge, who won the Chiefs' starting job in training camp last fall, was replaced two weeks into the season by Bill Kenney. But if Blackledge, who led Penn State to the final No. 1 ranking for the 1982 season, emerges as a star with the Steelers, he will lend more luster to the acclaimed crop of quarterbacks drafted in 1983. In addition to Blackledge, who was the second quarterback selected, the crop included John Elway, the No. 1 pick; Jim Kelly, Tony Eason, Ken O'Brien and Dan Marino. First, however, Blackledge must win the Steeler starting job. He will be competing with Mark Malone, who managed only one touchdown pass while throwing 11 interceptions in the last seven games of the season; Buddy Brister, a third-year pro, and Steve Bono, a former backup for the Minnesota Vikings.(AP)

title: Britain to Sell Rover Group
description: The British Government announced today that it was selling the Rover Group P.L.C., the ailing car maker, to British Aerospace P.L.C. for $:150 million, or about $279 million - well below the price that analysts had expected.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Forbidden Fruit
description: Members of the Senate Agriculture Committee are to be subjected today to the temptation of forbidden fruit - apples, oranges and strawberries that may have been exposed to untested pesticides.

title: CONTRA AID TALKS REACH AN ACCORD
description: House Democratic and Republican leaders said tonight that they had agreed in principle on a package of about $50 million to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a $250,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the quarter and year. c-Net loss

title: Islanders Continue To Roll
description: The Islanders, whose coach has found no better a one-word description for his team than ''unpredictable,'' have done the unexpected now for the past two weeks. They have been reliable, hard-working and consistent, and this type of monotony has enabled them to construct a six-game unbeaten streak. The players haven't given him much to criticize, and Coach Terry Simpson, basking in tonight's 5-3 defeat of the Flyers, has found himself in the position of having little to mold.

title: Leading Indicators Advance 0.9%
description: The Commerce Department reported today that its main economic forecasting gauge rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in February.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, and Premark International Inc., Northbrook, Ill., said Amoco Performance Products Inc., an Amoco Chemical unit, had purchased the commercial plastics operations of Premark's Datco Manufacturing unit in Augusta, Ga. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Meese's 3 Years in Office A Calendar of Troubles
description: Since his confirmation as Attorney General in 1985, Edwin Meese 3d has been investigated by three special prosecutors and the Office of Government Ethics. Questions have been raised not only about the propriety of his personal finances, but about what role he may have played in the Iran-contra affair, the awarding of a Government contract for the Wedtech Corporation and a plan to construct an Iraqi oil pipeline close to Israel. Following is a summary of the areas in which the Attorney General is or has been under scrutiny: Personal Finances

title: Real Estate; Costs Forcing Printers Out Of Manhattan
description: AFTER two years of searching for affordable relocation space in Manhattan, Stan Roth, who has run a printing business in New York City for 31 years, is leaving.

Little clues can tell diners what restaurants are safe to eat in. Page C1. Ban on Murdoch Overturned A Federal appeals court declared unconstitutional an amendment that barred Rupert Murdoch from media cross-ownership. Page A21.

description: Arnold I. Burns, 57 years old, who had served as Deputy Attorney General since July 24, 1986, was not viewed as an ideological conservative at the Justice Department.

title: Stockholm Cathedral Choir
description: Works by contemporary Swedish composers, as well as music by Bach, Brahms and Strauss, will be performed by the Stockholm Cathedral Choir next Monday at 2 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. The concert, which is free, is the choir's first stop on a tour of the United States.

title: Eating Well
description: THOSE who observe Passover, the holiday that marks the ancient Hebrews' deliverance from bondage in Egypt, are unlikely to view it as an occasion fraught with nutritional dangers. But for people who are concerned about eating carefully, the abundance of eggs, fat and salt in the foods served during the eight-day celebration, which begins on Friday, poses a problem and a puzzle.

title: CALLON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said its board adopted an accounting ''quasi-reorganization'' effective Dec. 31. It said that as part of the reorganization, the gains attributable to its financial restructuring transactions, about $41.9 million, have been excluded from its 1987 results of operations.

description: b-Includes a charge of $541,000 from a product discontinuance and a writeoff of $105,000 from other deferred development costs.

title: Are Babies Welcome to Dine? Yes, if They're Well Behaved
description: SMALL children and tiny infants can be seen - and heard - on occasion at Le Cirque, one of New York's most glittery restaurants, and most of the time no one minds.

title: HIGH JUSTICE AIDES QUIT AMID CONCERN OVER MEESE'S ROLE
description: The Deputy Attorney General and the head of the Justice Department's criminal division resigned today, along with four of their top aides. Department officials said the six quit because of their mounting concern over the legal problems and leadership of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d.

description: b-Net loss

description: The Williams Companies is offering $200 million of notes in two parts through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Scholarship Plan Slows Albany Talks
description: With Governor Cuomo and the Legislature close to agreement on most major issues, budget talks appeared to break down late this afternoon because of a disagreement over Mr. Cuomo's proposed Liberty Scholarship program. Mr. Cuomo has made the program his top priority during budget talks.

title: Citicorp Official Gets Key Post at Bank Leumi
description: The Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York said yesterday that it had named Richard C. Kane, a Citicorp senior vice president who is in charge of Diners Club International, as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: Large-Scale Immigration Also Hurts Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Chase Foresees Lift for Earnings
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation expects its earnings to be bolstered this year by between $500 million and $600 million because of special factors, its president, Thomas G. Labrecque, said. A large part of the total is expected to come from the sale of 1 New York Plaza, a large building in the Wall Street area where Chase conducts its back-office activities.

title: The Cuisine Gang
description: So for years New York City health inspectors drove up the cost of restaurant meals with a shakedown racket. I for one, possibly the only one, am sore at the Health Department about this. I want the Health Department to send me back my money.

title: 60-Minute Groumet
description: WHEN I am asked to name the one food that responds best to quick and easy cookery, I am always tempted to say mussels. You simply toss well-scrubbed mussels into a kettle, cover tightly and cook until the mussels open.

title: Filipino Rebel Chief and 2 Associates Seized
description: The military announced today that three top Communist leaders had been seized Tuesday as security forces continued a series of arrests of leading figures in the underground party.

title: Balbina Journal; On Amazon Noah's Ark, All Aboard (Even Wasps)
description: With the warming sun lifting the morning mists off the jungle, a group of men strapped on inflated jackets and headed for another day of saving lives.

description: b-Net loss

title: Wayward Tiger Is Cut Down
description: Forestry workers killed a Bengal tiger after it attacked and killed a woodcutter, who was believed to be its 17th human victim in five months, the police said today.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Holds 4.9% of Texaco's Shares
description: The investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company yesterday became the fourth party to seek Federal permission to buy up to 15 percent of Texaco Inc., renewing speculation that the nation's third-largest oil company is headed for the auction block.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a gain of $90,000 from a change in accounting for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income d-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $270,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PARTERS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the 1986 loss was primarily caused by a non-cash property-impairment writedown from the oil price decline in the first quarter.

title: Ohio State and UConn in Final
description: The last four games have changed the season for Connecticut. The Huskies have gone from a last-place team to the championship game of the 51st annual National Invitation Tournament.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Identity Problem
description: When Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel was visiting the United States recently, a group of Jewish lawmakers met privately with him to discuss American policy in the Middle East. As the senior Jewish member of Congress, Representative Sidney R. Yates presided, calling on members to speak.

title: 'Limits to Our Patience,' U.S. Cautions Noriega
description: A White House spokesman expressed outrage today over the violence against opposition figures and American reporters in Panama, and he warned that ''there are limits to our patience.''

title: Medicare to Deny Aid for Treatment
description: The Federal Government will not provide supplemental payments to hospitals that use the anti-clotting drug T.P.A. on Medicare patients who have suffered a heart attack, a spokesman for the Health Care Financing Administration, which operates Medicare, said. The drug, whose full name is tissue plasminogen activator, is made by Genentech Inc., a biotechnology company based in San Francisco.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morris Township, N.J., the high-technology concern, named Frederic M. Poses president of its engineered materials sector. He is also expected to be elected a corporate executive vice president.

title: Advertising; Saatchi Gets Homestar
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/San Francisco, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.(London), has been picked to handle the introduction of Homestar International's new line of household products. The promotion budget, estimated at $5 million for the remainder of the year, will cover everything from packaging to all aspects of a national advertising. The products will be introduced at the end of the year.

title: Bid for Stevens Raised By Odyssey Partners
description: The price to take over one of the nation's biggest textile producers, J. P. Stevens & Company, continued to rise yesterday amid Wall Street speculation that stockholders may yet see further increases in the bidding.

title: CBS Sweetens A Pension Plan
description: CBS Inc., which has made a string of moves to cut back the size and scope of the company, said yesterday that it would offer increased pension benefits to about 11 percent of its employees if they elect to retire within the next four months.

title: The Best Supporting Baker?
description: GOING Hollywood was never Gilberto Godoy's dream.

title: Roper Endorses G.E. Bid; Whirlpool Weighs Action
description: Directors of the Roper Corporation recommended yesterday that shareholders tender their shares to the General Electric Company, withdrawing the company's endorsement of a bid by the Whirlpool Corporation.

title: Canada Puts Neo-Nazi's Ideas on Trial, Again
description: For weeks now, a district courtroom here has resounded with testimony about Nazi vans in Belgrade, the installations at Auschwitz and mass executions in the German-occupied Crimea as witnesses have taken the stand in to examine in minute detail the fate of European Jews during World War II.

title: Bribe Givers Face Penalties In Crackdown
description: Seeking new strategies to deter corruption, the Koch administration said yesterday that it would crack down on businesses that offer or pay bribes to municipal inspectors.

title: Market Place; Analysts' Choices In Restaurants
description: THE restaurant industry - that smorgasbord of fast-food chains, coffee shops, family-style outlets, cafeterias, dinner house operations and casual theme units - has been experiencing more than its share of problems for some time. Nonetheless, several companies are getting strong recommendations from Wall Street analysts.

title: Review/Film; Sleaze and Sentiment In Canadian 'Night Zoo'
description: When first met, a young convict named Marcel (Gilles Maheu), sometimes called Stick, is being raped in his cell by his ''birthday present,'' another convict acting on the orders of Marcel's associates in a drug operation gone sour. Marcel, it seems, double-crossed his associates, who are still on the outside and to whom he owes $200,000.

title: Hospitals' Handling of Uninsured Patients Faulted
description: Thousands of emergency room patients are annually put at risk of permanent damage or even death when they are transferred from private to public hospitals because they lack insurance, a Congressional report said today. It blamed the Administration for not enforcing a law prohibiting such transfers.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a credit of $73,600 related to a reduction in accrued merger expenses resulting from a failure to consummate a planned merger for the quarter and included a charge of $226,400 related to merger expenses for the year. c-Included a charge of $75,000 related to merger expenses for the quarter and year.

title: As the Computer Fiddles, Users Burn
description: Anyone who has used a personal computer has been forced to wait while the machine completed some task. A University of Texas at Arlington researcher has found that such waiting can produce anxiety and theorizes that such anxiety reduces productivity.

title: Neil Williams, Painter On Shaped Canvas, 53
description: Neil Williams, an artist who pioneered in the use of the shaped canvas, died of a heart attack while visiting a friend in New York last Friday. He was 53 years old, and had recently been living in Brazil.

title: New Baby Boom? No, Just a Dim Echo
description: Look, people exclaimed last week: A new baby boom! That's surely what the new data from the National Center for Health Statistics seemed to show. Births in 1987 rose almost 3 percent over 1986. The total, 3,829,000, is the largest number reported since 1964. The one-year rise of almost 100,000 births can't be denied, but fears of another unsettling population bomb are premature. An echo of the post-1945 baby boom can now be heard, but it is remarkably dim.

title: Knicks Fail to Complete Rally
description: At the hotel, in the dining room over lunch, and on the bus trip from Cleveland to the Richfield Coliseum, the Knicks emphasized the importance of tonight's game against the Cavaliers. Trent Tucker, their 3-point specialist, said, ''We have to play this game as though it were a home game.''

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and both the quarter and year include a pre-tax gain of $1,063,000 on the sale of a subsidiary.

title: Don't Let Medicaid Promote Poverty
description: Like other states, New York struggles with the problem of opening its Medicaid program to the working poor. Though the Assembly has approved a sensible measure that would do so, the State Senate continues to sit on the proposed Family Access to Health Care Act. Proponents now worry that the bill may be deferred another year or more. That would be a tragedy, not just for the beneficiary families but also for the cause of welfare reform.

title: A Haggadah Born of Paradox
description: THE people who loved her are quietly dreading the seder this week because Rachel Anne Rabinowicz will not be there, effervescent and enlightening, the perfect Passover celebrant. But many other seders will be enriched, because her scholarship and devotion to Jewish tradition will shine from the pages of the Haggadah she edited.

title: El Salvador Seizes Reporters Returning From Rebel Zone
description: The Salvadoran military detained 15 reporters returning Monday from a rebel-controlled zone, seized their belongings and equipment and made a veiled threat against one of them. The journalists were released after several hours and their possessions - expect for several videocassettes - were returned to them.

title: Court Backs Murdoch In Battle on F.C.C. Ban
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Congress had unconstitutionally singled out Rupert Murdoch with a law that sought to prevent his ownership of a newspaper and television station in the same market.

title: Suffolk Votes A Bill to Ban Plastic Bags
description: The Suffolk County Legislature approved a bill today to outlaw the use of plastic grocery bags and other plastic food containers, starting in July 1989.

title: House Panel Cuts $800 Million From Request for 'Star Wars'
description: The House Armed Services Committee voted today to cut $800 million from the Reagan Administration's program of space-based missile defenses.

title: Fewer Frills for Children at Easter
description: ONCE upon a time, little girls woke up on Easter morning and ran to the window. If the sun was shining, they could dress up in their new spring coats and bonnets and patent leather shoes. If it was raining - or even worse, snowing - they would have to plead with their mothers to be allowed to wear their good clothes.

title: Review/Recital; Schubert Piano Dialogue With Levine and Noda
description: Schubert's music for piano duet, written with parlor performance in mind, is rarely played in public. However, many of his compositions in the four-hands genre push far beyond the casual dilettantism such a constraint might imply, deserving the best preparation and execution that professional pianists can bring to them. So prospects were bright for Monday evening's all-Schubert program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art by the team of James Levine and Ken Noda.

title: Ruling Broadens Reporter Protections
description: New York State's highest court broadened protection for reporters yesterday by ruling that, with few exceptions, journalists do not have to turn over news material to the courts, even when it was gathered from nonconfidential sources.

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. Increases Refugee Quota
description: Citing an increase in the number of Armenians trying to leave the Soviet Union, the Reagan Administration said today that it will propose a substantial increase in the number of those refugees admitted to the United States.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Temple's Mark Macon, who led his class in scoring with a 20.6 average, and Loyola of Chicago's Kenny Miller, who led the nation in rebounding with a 13.6 average, head The Associated Press all-freshman team. Livingston Chatman of Florida, Jay Edwards of Indiana and Dennis Scott of Georgia Tech were also named to the team, which was selected by a nationwide panel of sportswriters and broadcasters. . . . Coach Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz has been fined an undisclosed amount by the National Basketball Association for making critical remarks about officials after a game March 14 against Denver in which Layden and Karl Malone, a forward, were ejected in the first quarter. Layden said the officiating was ''an absolute disgrace'' and said the referees were ''cheating the fans.'' . . . Sam Bowie underwent surgery on his broken right leg in what the oft-injured center said was his final attempt to salvage his professional basketball career. Bowie, who has played in only five games the past two seasons, has suffered a broken leg four times since 1981. The surgery yesterday was his fourth bone-graft operation. . . . Pat Day became the 19th jockey in the history of thoroughbred racing to win 4,000 races when Ann's Bid won the $22,000 allowance feature yesterday at Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark. The 34-year-old native of Brush, Colo., has been the nation's leading jockey on four times and has been awarded the Eclipse Award three times.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Simon Marlow has rejoined Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, New York, as executive vice president, senior management representative.

title: DEAN FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Soviet Afghan Drive Called Decision of a Few
description: Not long ago, Georgi A. Arbatov, a member of the Communist Party Central Committee, described the day in December 1979 when he learned that Soviet forces had swept into Afghanistan.

title: New York City Bridges Should Be Repaired With State Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: DUKAKIS OUTLOOK REMAINS TROUBLED
description: Despite his victory in yesterday's Connecticut primary, Michael S. Dukakis's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination is a troubled candidacy.

title: Disney Buys Stake
description: The Walt Disney Company has paid $85.2 million for a 50 percent interest in the Wrather Corporation that was held by the New Zealand financier Ronald A. Brierley. Last year, Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., a La Jolla, Calif., company controlled by Mr. Brierley, acquired 28 percent of Wrather, a hotel operator based in Beverly Hills. Industrial Equity has offered $986.6 million, or $40 a share, for the Calmat Company, a Los Angeles cement concern. It already owns 19 percent of Calmat's shares.

title: President of Forschner Adding Title of Chief
description: James W. Kennedy has been an ace seller of Swiss Army knives, and for his reward he was named yesterday to the added post of chief executive of the Forschner Group, which distributes the leading brand of those knives in the United States.

title: Missing Files Reported in Lord Case
description: A private investigator working for the WPP Group found that files belonging to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein were missing after the advertising agency's top executives defected and started their own shop, according to court papers filed by WPP lawyers on Monday.

title: Store Near School Raided for Cocaine
description: The authorities have seized three kilograms of cocaine, $16,000 and a small arsenal in a raid on a Brooklyn candy store, law-enforcement officials said. Ten men, including the store owner, believed by the authorities to be members of a Colombian cocaine ring, were arrested at 10 P.M. Monday after an undercover agent had negotiated to buy five pounds of cocaine.

title: Out-of-Work Michiganders No Longer Out of Luck
description: When Tim Robb was laid off last summer from his job assembling truck frames at a General Motors plant here, his fate seemed all too familiar a story for Michigan, whose automobile industry has lost 130,000 blue-collar jobs in the last decade.

title: Kenneth W. Tucker, Public Relations Executive, 41
description: Kenneth W. Tucker, senior vice president and general manager of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Public Relations of New York, died of cancer Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: New Macy Offer for Federated
description: R. H. Macy & Company says its latest bid for Federated Department Stores has a sharply higher value than Wall Street's estimates on the non-cash part of its offer, according to people close to its takeover battle with the Campeau Corporation.

title: Rumors Persisting On Winfield Trade
description: Dave Winfield was the Yankees' quiet man today, but controversy continued to swirl around the right fielder. Rumors of a trade - this time to Baltimore for Fred Lynn - were coupled with talk that sounded as if it were coming from an unsettled clubhouse.

title: Providing 'Guardian Angels' For Aged
description: Thousands of meter readers, cashiers and other utility employees are looking out for the welfare of many of the 1.8 million elderly people in Illinois by volunteering for the state's Gatekeeper program.

title: Mentor to Acquire Tektronix Division Special to The New York Times
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said it would acquire the computer-aided engineering and computer-aided software engineering business of Tektronix Inc. for $5 million in cash, a small fraction of the price Tektronix paid for the company two years ago. The two companies, both based in Beaverton, Ore., also said they would form a strategic alliance to link Mentor's electronic design business with Tektronix's test-equipment business.

title: Virginia County Marketing Bonds
description: Virginia's Fairfax County, in the Washington area, is offering $99.8 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: Metro Datelines; Inspections Resume For Restaurants
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday resumed inspections of restaurants after they were suspended last week when 28 current and former city inspectors were charged with extorting payments from restaurants.

title: Results Plus
description: Tennis Noah Eliminates Mayotte: Yannick Noah, off to the best start of his eight-year pro career, improved his record to 19-3 this year by eliminating Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3, last night in the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis Finals at Dallas. Noah advanced to tomorrow's semifinals where he'll face the winner of last night's second quarterfinal between top-seeded Stefan Edberg and Martin Jaite. Noah, France's top player, dominated last night's match, taking control in the first set when he got the only service break in the 10th game, cracking a backhand pass down the line. Mayotte, ranked No. 9 in the world, was broken again in the fourth game of the second set after fighting off 2 break points. Noah, ranked No. 8, wrapped up the second set with a drop volley. Mayotte got his first service break in the sixth game of the third set, but by then it was too late. (AP) Evert and Maleeva Advance: Top-seeded Chris Evert and second-seeded Manuela Maleeva advanced to the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Eckerd Open with straight-set victories yesterday at Largo, Fla. Evert, of Boca Raton, defeated an unseeded qualifier, Federica Bonsignori of Italy, 6-2, 6-4, and Maleeva, of Bulgaria, beat Kathleen Horvath of Largo, 6-2, 7-5. (AP) Horse Racing Prospector's Halo Wins: Prospector's Halo, the favorite, finished fast on the far outside to win by a head in the feature race yesterday at Aqueduct. Jazzing Around was second in the field of seven. The victory was the fifth in 12 career starts for Prospector's Halo, who went seven furlongs on the fast track in 1:23 to earn $25,200. Prospector's Halo paid $5 for $2 to win.

title: Murdoch Gains Time On Boston Situation
description: Rupert Murdoch will have another chance to persuade the Federal Communications Commission to let him keep both The Boston Herald and a Boston television station a little longer, as a result of a Federal appeals court ruling on Tuesday.

title: Mexican Growth at 1.4%
description: The Government has announced that the Mexican economy grew by a small 1.4 percent last year, recovering from a steep recession that caused a 4 percent contraction in 1986. In a report delivered late Tuesday to the legislature, the office of President Miguel de la Madrid said that non-oil exports soared by 24 percent, giving the nation a surplus of $4.2 billion in the 1987 current account. Mexico had a deficit of $1.3 billion in 1986.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, a holding company involved in investment programs, said Edward J. Hall had joined the company as executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: A New Depression? Entirely Possible
description: LEAD: Is history repeating itself? Will the October stock market crash be followed by aftershocks that will bring on another depression? The danger is very much alive in the reaction of foreign investors to the trade bill now before Congress.

title: 'Hi. This is . . .'
description: Without the telephone and the computer, modern American life would be impossible. But combine them, and the result can seem diabolical.

title: New Life for Old Leather
description: ''WE don't do clothing or motorcycle seats,'' said Michele Costello, the apprentice at Robert Falotico Studios, a leather repair business. Robert Falotico, the owner, echoed his assistant: ''Clothing, handbags, luggage we do not do.''

title: Talking Deals; For Sale or Not? The Courts' View
description: ONE of the first things executives say when they come under takeover attack is that they want to remain independent.

title: Night Trading Widened
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange will expand its night session trading list on April 14 with the addition of futures and options on the British pound and the Swiss franc. Night trading at the exchange, which runs from 7 to 11 o'clock Sunday through Thursday, began on Sept. 16 with the options on Australian dollars, Deutsche marks and Japanese yen. The exchange averages 5,000 contracts a night.

title: For Jackson Backers, Connecticut Was More Than a 2d Place Finish
description: Supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that his second-place finish Tuesday in the Connecticut Democratic Presidential primary really constituted a victory.

title: Health: Clinical Advances; Major Surgery for Kidney Stones Yields to Innovative Techniques
description: Dramatic advances in the treatment of kidney stones have eliminated the need for major surgery in all but a relatively few patients, a panel of experts concluded today.

title: Short Story Prize Awarded
description: Donald Barthelme is to receive the third annual Rea Award for the Short Story. The $25,000 award is given by the Dungannon Foundation to honor living American writers who have made ''a significant contribution to short-story writing.'' Mr. Barthelme, whose works have included ''Forty Stories,'' ''Overnight to Many Distant Cities,'' ''City Life'' and ''Unspeakable Practices, Unnatural Acts,'' was selected by a jury that included Cynthia Ozick, Benjamin DeMott and Bill Henderson. The award is named for Michael Rea, the president of the Dungannon Foundation, and is to be presented on April 6.

title: 5 Are Charged In Theft Scheme At TV Station
description: Three former executives of WNYW-TV, Channel 5 in New York, and two associates were indicted yesterday on charges of selling advertising time and keeping the proceeds.

title: Judges Weigh Assets Freeze In Drug Cases
description: All 12 active judges on a Federal appeals court held a hearing yesterday on whether the Government could prevent defendants from hiring the lawyers of their choice by freezing the defendants' assets, including the money they intended to use for legal fees.

title: Arauquita Journal; Oil Bonanza Has a Drawback: Bombs and Bullets
description: In this once-forgotten border town on the banks of the River Arauca, where tranquillity was long the solitary reward for living in poverty, the discovery of oil nearby five years ago is no longer remembered as the moment when things began to get better.

title: Sports of The Times; Oklahoma's Stack Of Blue Chips
description: EACH of the other three teams in the Final Four has a glamorous all-American name: Danny Manning of Kansas, Sean Elliott of Arizona, and Danny Ferry of Duke, blue-chip National Basketball Association prospects either this year or next. But the University of Oklahoma has a stack of blue chips, three immediate or eventual first-round N.B.A. choices: Stacey King, Harvey Grant and Mookie Blaylock, plus a likely second-round choice in Ricky Grace.

title: Review/Recital; Debut for Piano Team
description: Ralph Markham and Kenneth Broadway have performed as a piano duo since 1979, but they didn't get around to making their New York debut until Monday evening. For the occasion, they came to Town Hall with a program that ran the gamut from salon works to blockbusters, with the New York premiere of a shimmering work composed for them in 1981 by Alexina Louie as the evening's centerpiece.

title: Pearl E. Joseph, Advertising Executive, 47
description: Pearl E. Joseph, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam Inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at her home in Carmel, N.Y. She was 47 years old.

title: Magical Powers?
description: Clayton Yeutter, the United States Trade Representative, had an almost mystical experience while attending a House-Senate conference on the trade bill the other day.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there was proven wrongdoing, it would be devastating to the Administration and to Republicans this fall. But Mr. Meese deserves the presumption of innocence to which all Americans are entitled, even if he's the Attorney General.'' - Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. [ B10:3. ]

title: A Nazi Victim's Diary In Reading by Lindfors
description: Excerpts from the diary of Etty Hillesum, a victim of the Auschwitz concentration camp, are to be read by the actress Viveca Lindfors on April 17 at 7:30 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The excerpts are from the book ''An Interrupted Life,'' which was published by Pantheon Books in 1981. The book is an account of Miss Hillesum's life from 1940 to her death in 1943 at the age of 29.

title: Matzoh Handmade In Old Way Is Scarce
description: In Jewish communities all around New York, where preparations for tomorrow night's Passover seder have reached a fever pitch, everybody is talking about the Great Shmura Matzoh Shortage of '88.

title: Navy Secretary Is Sworn In
description: William Ball was sworn in Wednesday as Secretary of the Navy, replacing James Webb, who resigned last month to protest Pentagon plans to postpone completion of a 600-ship navy. Mr. Ball, 39 years old, is a former State Department official.

title: Los Angeles Mob Figure and 6 Others Plead Guilty
description: The reputed leader of the Mafia in Southern California and six associates have pleaded guilty to extortion or racketeering charges, but they denied being members of an organized crime syndicate.

title: New Orleans Journal; Where Vice Has Seen Palmier Days
description: Prostitution has enjoyed a joyously lurid history in this fun-loving old city, where tourists once ogled the palaces in the red-light district near the French Quarter.

title: Yields Mostly Unchanged
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

title: Metro Datelines; Who Put Asbestos In Lincoln Tunnel?
description: Federal and state agencies were investigating yesterday whether 40 bags of asbestos found in a tube of the Lincoln Tunnel had been dumped there deliberately.

title: Seasonal Slipcovers Amid the Cuisine
description: ORIGINALLY slipcovers, or loose covers as they were called in Europe centuries ago, were used to protect good furniture from dust and summer sun. In light cottons or muslins, they gave a room an informal, fresh feeling.

title: Drug Witness to Get Reward
description: The New York City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, who last week forced the Board of Estimate to cut $13,500 from the price it would pay for the house of a drug-case witness, said yesterday that he had arranged for two private donors to give the witness a $25,000 reward.

title: Former E-II Official To Work for Himself
description: Roger T. Briggs, who participated in more than 60 acquisitions and divestitures over the years as the top lieutenant of Donald P. Kelly, said yesterday that he was parting with the Chicago deal maker to manage his own portfolio.

title: Review/Dance; Tribute to Early Modern and Beauty
description: They wanted beauty. Indeed, they hungered for beauty. That America's early modern dancers sought to bring beauty to the world was demonstrated Monday night at Playhouse 46 at St. Clement's Church when the Center Dance Collective presented works created between 1906 and 1926 by Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn, two pioneers of modern dance. The program also included a solo choreographed in 1919 by one of their greatest pupils, Doris Humphrey. It, too, preached a gospel of beauty.

title: Jackson Acting to Build Ties With Party Elders
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, seeking to ''raise the comfort level'' toward his Presidential campaign and quell talk of a stop-Jackson movement, today convened a get-acquainted breakfast of Democratic Party elders.

title: Metro Datelines; Lead in Paint Leads To Closing of School
description: More than 470 children were sent home when the city's Health Director closed their elementary school yesterday after finding high levels of lead in paint and air samples, officials said.

title: More Cigarette Exports Seen
description: Cigarette exports are expected to rise sharply this year, largely because of growing demand in some Asian countries, according to an Agriculture Department analysis.

title: Herman Burman, 89, Otolaryngologist, Dies
description: Dr. Herman J. Burman, a former professor and otolaryngologist, died of a heart ailment yesterday in the Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in Hallandale, Fla., and Manhattan.

title: Metro Matters; A Whistleblower And His Ex-Boss Coexist, Barely
description: The hand-lettered signs in the lobby of Bellevue Hospital Center proclaim March as Social Work Month. But on the 19th floor prison ward, where even the steel bars are painted white, one social worker doesn't feel very welcome.

title: Bond Prices Dip in Quiet Trading
description: Bond prices dipped slightly in very quiet trading yesterday as market partcipants began to close out positions in advance of a long holiday weekend.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1988
description: The Economy

title: Arizona Senate Drops a Key Impeachment Charge
description: The Arizona Senate today dismissed the most serious of three impeachment charges against Gov. Evan Mecham and moved toward considering a verdict on the two charges that have already been heard.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption Monday with a picture supplied by the Associated Press showing the West Regional Championship basketball game between North Carolina and Arizona misidentifed a player. He was Tom Tolbert of Arizona, not Steve Kerr.

title: New John Cage Opera To Have U.S. Premiere
description: ''Europeras I and II,'' a new opera by John Cage, is to have its American premiere as the centerpiece of the 1988 Pepsico Summerfare. The work, commissioned by the Frankfurt Opera and presented in that city last December, is to be performed by the German company on July 14, 16 and 17, partly in celebration of the composer's 75th birthday.

title: Review/Dance; Belgrade Folk Troupe
description: An accordion player strolled along with some young people behind him. His music prompted them to burst into song and then start dancing. They could have been on a picnic in the country. They could just as easily have been in a village square. Instead, they were on stage, for they were members of the Belgrade State Folk Ensemble ready to start their program Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx.

title: Chairs With Souls for the Computer Age
description: LEAD: WHEN Peter Danko began designing ''a wooden chair for the computer age,'' he pulled people off the street into his studio in Alexandria, Va., and sat them down on the molded shapes he was coaxing from 10 layers of laminated wood.

title: Wife of Sir Rudolph Bing Is Arrested
description: The wife of Sir Rudolph Bing, who last year spirited her disoriented husband overseas in violation of a court order, was arrested yesterday in Manhattan after an executive of Columbia Artists Management complained of harassment.

title: Intoxicated Democrats
description: Some Democrats took the pledge in 1972, after a third of their party's voters defected, enlarging the Nixon landslide. Some more took the pledge after the 1980 Reagan landslide. After the 1984 Reagan landslide, sobriety seized almost all Democrats. ''If we're going to win,'' they said to one another, ''we have to contain our lust for liberalism. We must move to the center and reclaim the votes of traditional, disaffected Democrats.''

title: Easter Stopover
description: Rome at Easter - the first tourist invasion of the season, when tens of thousands of pilgrims converge at St. Peter's for mass and a glimpse of Pope John Paul II, and among them will be Secretary of State George P. Shultz and his wife.

title: European Prices Rice
description: Consumer prices in the 12-nation European Community rose three-tenths of a percent in February from January, and 3 percent from February 1987, the European Community reported today. The 3 percent rate remained unchanged from January. That compares with inflation rates of nine-tenths of 1 percent in Japan and 3.9 percent in the United States.

title: Th  D p tme t of  J st ce
description: The wrong people are leaving the Department of Justice. Edwin Meese, the Attorney General, having forfeited the confidence of everyone but President Reagan, clings to his job. Unable to make the White House see the chaos at Justice, two competent and concerned top officials have jointly resigned, widening the gaps in the department's leadership. How long will Mr. Meese continue to impose upon his President's misplaced trust?

title: Spinks Jokingly Slips a Few Questions
description: The subject was fear at the formal news conference at the Plaza Hotel yesterday announcing the June 27 Mike Tyson-Michael Spinks heavyweight title fight in Atlantic City.

title: Who Lives Here, a Go-Getter or Grouch?
description: TO neighbors and passers-by, the exterior of a house speaks volumes about the people living in it, according to a survey by researchers in city and regional planning at Ohio State University.

title: 300 Years of Quilts on Display in Hartford
description: A modest but pleasing exhibition at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford offers a sampling of quilting techniques and patterns covering almost 300 years. Most of the 35 quilts are American, drawn from the museum's collection and augmented by works from collectors from the Hartford area. The show is entitled, ''Drunken Paths and Ladders to the Stars,'' after traditional quilt patterns.

title: No Trade of Wilson in Sight
description: The Mets pursued talks with the Baltimore Orioles and half a dozen other teams today about trading Mookie Wilson. But they said later that nothing seemed imminent, and predicted the odds were 70-30 that Wilson would still be a member of the Mets when the season opened next week.

title: Kuwait Reports Skirmish With Iran
description: Three Iranian gunboats opened fire today on a Kuwaiti island outpost in the Persian Gulf, wounding two Kuwaiti soldiers and drawing return fire, the Kuwaiti Defense Ministry said.

title: Review/Music; Urgent Sounds of Rap
description: Ecstatic pandemonium reigned at the Apollo Theater last Friday night, the sort that comes from a show mixing humor, pride in achievement and the healing qualities of dance music.

title: Fire Halts Metro-North
description: Metro-North commuter rail service between New Haven and Stamford was interrupted for three hours early this morning by a fire at a lumberyard here, officials said. Service was halted while firefighters stretched hoses across the tracks at about 4:30 A.M. to fight the fire, which destroyed one building at Ring's End Lumber. Trains ran between New Haven and South Norwalk, with buses replacing some trains between South Norwalk and Stamford. Full service resumed at 7:30 A.M. after the fire was out.

title: France Said to Be Negotiating With Iran on Hostages' Fate
description: Evidence is growing that France is negotiating with Iran to gain the release of the three French hostages held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. The developments are surrounded by intrigue and electoral maneuvering by both Iranian and French politicians.

title: Review/Dance; Light-Footed Fusillade School of Tap
description: When Harold Nicholas sidles out onto the stage of the Joyce Theater, where he and the Jazz Tap Ensemble of Los Angeles are performing through Sunday, every inch and atom of his body seem to be primed for entertainment. A little avuncular, a bit of a lover, he dedicates steps to various sections of the audience. He croons silkily, belts out and dances to a medley of favorite songs like '' 'S Wonderful,'' ''It Don't Mean a Thing'' and ''It Could Happen to You.'' He feathers the stage with his tap-dancing, which is of the light-footed fusillade school. And yes, the 64-year-old Mr. Nicholas does one of those quick splits that made him and his brother, Fayard, famous as the Nicholas Brothers, at the Cotton Club, on Broadway and in film musicals of the 1940's.

title: Market Place; Analysts Contrast 1988 With 1930
description: EVER since the stock market collapsed on Oct. 19, investors familiar with history have been waiting for the other shoe to drop. The bull market of the 1980's was so similar to the one in the 1920's, they believed, that as in 1929-30 the collapse would have to follow the 1930's script and end with another market drop six months later, leading to a depression.

title: Calmat Rejects Brierley's Offer
description: The Calmat Company, the big West Coast cement maker sought by New Zealand's most ambitious corporate raider, Sir Ron Brierley, said that its board of directors had rejected Brierley Investments Ltd.'s unsolicited $980 million bid as inadequate.

title: Israel Reported to Raid A Village in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops and their Lebanese Christian militia allies stormed a Shiite Moslem village in southern Lebanon today and fought with pro-Iranian guerrillas, reports said.

title: House Candidates Are Chosen in Mississippi
description: Voters in two southern Mississippi Congressional districts have selected nominees for seats that Representatives Trent Lott and Wayne Dowdy are giving up to run for the Senate.

title: Review/Art; In Vienna, the Old-Time Russian Avant-Garde
description: It is almost on the sly that the best exhibition of Russian avant-garde art that has ever been allowed out of the Soviet Union has arrived here at the Museum for the Applied Arts, where it can be seen through May 15.

title: Bank of New York Offered Irving Data
description: The Irving Bank Corporation yesterday offered to provide the Bank of New York with the same financial information that it is providing other potential acquirers on the condition that the Bank of New York give up its hostile takeover attempt. Irving's offer was in response to a March 28 letter from J. Carter Bacot, chairman of the Bank of New York, to Joseph A. Rice, chairman of Irving, asking for the same information Irving is giving other potential acquirers.

title: 4 Palestinians Die in Day of Protest Against Israel
description: Four Palestinians were shot to death by Israeli forces in the occupied territories today as Arabs staged a widespread protest strike despite heightened security.

title: Albany Near Accord on Road Funds
description: Key legislators said tonight that they were ready to agree on a $3 billion transportation bond issue that would pay for road and bridge repairs over the next four years. The bond issue would be the largest in the state's history.

title: Power Struggles Leave Budget Agency Paralyzed
description: For more than a year the Congressional Budget Office has been without a permanent director as a result of a deadlock between House and Senate leaders over one candidate. And the chances of a quick resolution appear slim.

title: What Makes an Antique Truly Antique?
description: BROCK JOBE can examine a pine chest of drawers and know it was made sometime between 1754 and 1770 by craftsmen from Boston or Salem, Mass.

title: Review/Theater; 'No Plays No Poetry,' But Brecht's Theories
description: As director, Anne Bogart has had the ingenious notion of staging Bertolt Brecht's theories rather than one of his plays. In collaboration with members of three experimental troupes, Otrabanda, the Talking Band and Ms. Bogart's own Via Theater, she is presenting a collective performance piece with a self-descriptive title: ''No Plays No Poetry but Philosophical Reflections Practical Instructions Provocative Prescriptions Opinions and Pointers From a Noted Critic and Playwright.''

title: Now the Yard Has A Focal Point
description: MANY of the things that every garden should have, according to the theoreticians of horticultural design, are notably absent in my own suburban plot. Gardens ought to have vistas, but there's not a trace of a vista in mine, just a whole lot of plants crammed into every spare inch.

title: Edgar Faure, 79, Dies in France; Twice a Postwar Prime Minister
description: Edgar Faure, one of the best-known French postwar politicians, died today, hospital officials said. He was 79 years old.

title: Race for Substitutes To Help Save Ozone
description: The race is on in the chemical industry for what is envisioned as a multibillion-dollar market for substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, the widely used compounds suspected of destroying the earth's ozone shield.

title: Montana Sapphires And Jersey Rubies
description: A TREASURY of Tiffany jewelry, much of it made with gems found in the United States, is on exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History through June 5.

title: Fact and Fantasy in the Air
description: It seems obvious that air travel has become less safe since deregulation, as cost-conscious airlines look to younger, less experienced pilots to fly through ever more crowded skies. Obvious, and wrong. According to a recent study for the Brookings Institution by Steven Morrison and Clifford Winston, it simply isn't true.

title: Bridge; At a Desperate Moment in the Vanderbilt Final, the Bidding Looked More Like Poker
description: At the highest levels bridge is a highly disciplined game, with players striving for accuracy and avoiding anything that might lead their partners astray.

title: Review/Film; High School Antics in 'Invisible Kid'
description: Grover is a teen-age nerd, but will he stay nerdy for long? Of course not. He is the hero of ''The Invisible Kid,'' a movie that proves you can cull every known cliche from successful teen adventure films and still come up with a bomb.

title: Sports People; Bedford in Treatment
description: William Bedford, the Detroit Pistons' reserve center, has entered a rehabilitation program to be treated for chemical dependency, the team announced yesterday. Bedford, 24 years old, was to begin treatment yesterday at the Adult Substance Abuse Program based in Van Nuys, Calif., according to a Pistons spokesman, Matt Dobek. Bedford will be suspended with pay while he is being treated for narcotics addiction, Dobek said. Bedford appeared in 38 games this season, averaging 2.6 points and 1.7 rebounds a game. Bedford was named in April 1987 in an indictment that charged he either witnessed or knew of drug transactions by players for the Phoenix Suns, who drafted him in the first round of the 1986 draft. No criminal charges were filed against Bedford, and he was reportedly granted immunity from prosecution for his testimony before the grand jury investigating the case. He testified to using cocaine once while with the Suns, when he attended a party in Phoenix.

title: Brother of Korea's Ex-President Arrested
description: Chun Kyung Hwan, the younger brother of former President Chun Doo Hwan, was arrested early today on charges of embezzlement and influence peddling.

title: U.P.I. to Cut 150 Jobs And Expand Services
description: United Press International announced a plan today to expand into new areas and eliminate 150 jobs in a move to end its financial problems.

title: Samuel J. Gedalowitz, Rabbi, 59
description: Rabbi Samuel J. Gedalowitz of the Civic Center Synagogue in lower Manhattan died of cancer today at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 59 years old and lived in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

title: Nicaraguan Leader Is Calling For Economic Aid From U.S.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has made several public pleas in recent days for American economic help and a diplomatic thaw, suggesting that a desire to rebuild relations with Washington was his main reason for approving a cease-fire agreement.

title: F.A.A. Hastens Program to Prevent Collisions
description: In a major policy change, the Federal Aviation Administration has sharply accelerated its program for preventing midair collisions near busy airports, agency officials said yesterday.

title: Prices Paid To Farmers Unchanged
description: The prices farmers received for raw products this month averaged the same as they did in February but were 7.4 percent above the level of March 1987, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Boost for Winfield Book
description: The official publication date isn't until April 18, and bookstores have barely had time to unpack their advance orders. Spurred by some stinging free publicity from the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, however, copies of ''Dave Winfield: A Player's Life'' have been fairly flying off the shelves, according to W. W. Norton & Company. Norton is publishing the semiautobiography of the Yankees' high-paid right fielder.

title: Dow, in Last-Minute Selloff, Drops by 20.22
description: Stocks dropped sharply in the last few minutes of trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended down 20.22 points, or 1 percent, at 1,978.12. Broader measures than the Dow were also lower and declining stocks outnumbered those that rose by 917 to 571.

title: Sports People; Hazzard Dismissed
description: Walt Hazzard was dismissed yesterday after four seasons as head basketball coach at U.C.L.A. Hazzard guided the Bruins to a 16-14 record this season, well below expectations for a team coming off a Pacific-10 Conference championship. The Bruins finished in a tie for second in the Pac-10 this season, but were upset by Washington State in a first-round game of the conference tournament. Hazzard, the Pacific-10 coach of the year last season, received a two-year extension on his contract last summer, through the 1989-90 season. U.C.L.A. was 21-12 in 1984-85, Hazzard's first season; 15-14 the following year and 25-7 in 1986-87. Hazzard was U.C.L.A.'s fifth head coach since John Wooden retired after the 1974-75 season. He was not immediately available for comment.

title: Hospitals Fault Limit On Heart Drug Funds
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to deny Medicare payments for use of a heart attack drug that costs more than $2,000 a treatment is a form of health-care rationing, industry spokesmen asserted yesterday.

title: Prosecutor in Howard Beach Trial No Precedent for Brawley Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Asked to Uphold Aid to Religious Counselors
description: Solicitor General Charles Fried today urged the Supreme Court to uphold a 1981 Federal law that grants money to religious groups, and others, to counsel teen-agers on premarital sex.

title: Computer Edges Doctors in Heart Cases
description: A computer program was somewhat more reliable than physicians in predicting whether patients who arrived at emergency rooms with chest pain were having heart attacks, according to a new study.

title: Hutton Plans a Guilty Plea
description: E. F. Hutton Group Inc. will plead guilty to criminal charges that it laundered money for unidentified clients who have previously been reported to be organized crime figures.

title: Goalie Wins Top Prize
description: Robb Stauber, the University of Minnesota goalie who has some unfinished business ahead of him, was named today as the winner of the Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's outstanding player. The award is named for Princeton's fabled athlete of the World War I era.

title: The New-Boy Network
description: Just as the old order changeth, yielding place to the new, so does the old-boy network change, making way for the new-boy network.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I want to build a brick walkway without using cement or mortar. Can I just set the bricks into the soil, or should I put down a bed of sand first? A. It is best to put down a sand base first; otherwise, the bricks will sink into the soil. Dig out the soil to a depth of at least four inches; then spread a two-inch layer of sand on the bottom as a base for the bricks. It is easiest to set up form boards along each side of the excavation, just as you would for pouring concrete. Then spread the sand over the bottom, and level it by dragging a board across the surface.

title: Life Images In Sandra Bernhard's Solo Show
description: Both the title and the advertising campaign for Sandra Bernhard's one-woman show, ''Without You I'm Nothing,'' toy ambiguously with romantic imagery. If the title suggests a sudsy love story, the ads and the show, which opens today at the Orpheum Theater (126 Second Avenue, at Eighth Street), juxtapose photos of Ms. Bernhard dreamily contemplating her own face.

title: Ruth Crosby Noble, Author, 91
description: Ruth Crosby Noble, an author, died March 15 at the Allendale (N.J.) Nursing Home, where she lived. She was 91 years old.

title: Books of The Times; Letters From Havel in a Czech Prison to His Wife
description: Letters to Olga June 1979 - September 1982 By Vaclav Havel Translated by Paul Wilson 397 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: More Justice Aides Expected to Resign
description: Justice Department officials, describing disarray at the department after the resignation of two senior aides to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, said today that there might soon be other resignations protesting Mr. Meese's continuing presence at the department.

title: S.&S. Unit Has Fancy New Home
description: WHEN the 1,350 employees of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton show up for work next Tuesday after a long weekend, they may not have the Art Deco spire of the Chrysler Building towering majestically over their heads, but they will have a fully equipped health club and running track in their penthouse. Less for the soul, more for the body. Long an East Side racket, the advertising game has become more and more distanced from its epithet, Madison Avenue. In 750,000 square feet at 375 Hudson Street, off West Houston Street, the S.&S. unit will have the most westerly location of any major New York ad agency.

title: New Audi Models Designed for U.S.
description: The West German car maker Audi A.G., in a bid to improve its United States business, is planning two new models designed for the American market, its chairman, Ferdinand Piech, said today. Audi, which is 99 percent owned by Volkswagen A.G., has been hit by a sharp drop in United States sales since incidents were reported of acceleration problems in its automatic Audi 5000 model. Mr. Piech, giving his first news conference since taking over the chairmanship in January, said the new models that Audi plans to introduce into the United States would be ready within three years. Audi is VW's luxury car branch.

title: 76ers Win and Stay in Race
description: Charles Barkley scored 33 points and grabbed 14 rebounds and four other 76ers scored in double figures tonight as Philadelphia downed the Milwaukee Bucks, 134-109.

title: Milner Out for Drug Use
description: Eddie Milner, a Cincinnati Reds outfielder, was suspended from baseball for one year without pay today by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for using cocaine as a repeat offender.

title: Winter Hideaway, Gem From the Past
description: HOW exclusive is a beach house when it is flanked to the north by a towering Holiday Inn and to the south by an orange-roofed Howard Johnson, particularly when thousands of college students on spring break cruise past at all hours of the day and night?

title: Rangers Stay in the Race
description: There was, to be sure, little art to the deal. In order to make the playoffs, the Rangers, lacking leverage, agreed they had to win all three of their remaining games just to fulfill their end of an uncertain bargain.

title: Ex-Justice Aide Deeply Troubled By Meese Role
description: William F. Weld, who resigned Tuesday as Assistant Attorney General, had become so concerned about the legal troubles of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d over the last few months that, if he had been prosecuting the case, ''he would have to seriously consider indicting Meese,'' according to a close aide.

title: Review/Rock; The Kinks, Ever Young
description: Most rock bands that have been around as long as the Kinks, who emerged in 1964, are oldies acts. The Kinks have staved off that fate for so long that they can take it lightly; at a sold-out Beacon Theater concert Tuesday, they dipped into their catalogue of hits but weren't confined to it.

title: Goldwater Describes Jackson As Best in Democratic Field
description: Former Senator Barry Goldwater said today that the Rev. Jesse Jackson was the most intelligent Democratic Presidential candidate in the 1988 race.

title: U.S. Asking China's Help on Burmese Drugs
description: The United States has asked China for help in curbing opium and heroin production in Burma, where the Communist Party is now thought to be the major supplier of narcotics, according to a group of Western officials briefing reporters here today.

title: Legislators Seek A Wider Choice In Charter Vote
description: Two state legislators submitted bills today to let New York City residents vote on more than just the recommendations of a charter revision commission appointed by Mayor Koch.

title: Among the Multitude of Ayes, Nays in the Chinese Congress
description: There, on page 3 of People's Daily, organ of the Communist Party, was a postcard-sized photograph of three men in China's Parliament sitting with their hands in their laps while around them hands fluttered aloft. It was an extraordinary display of official discord.

title: Of Koch and Kidnapping
description: Mayor Koch, whose political credo seems to be ''Take no prisoners,'' revealed yesterday that he had given equally strong orders for handling anyone who might take him captive: ''Pay no ransom.''

title: Trump Withdraws Proposal To Take Resorts Private
description: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Resorts International Inc., said today that because of confusion created by a competing offer he was withdrawing his $22-a-share, $123 million proposal to take the Atlantic City casino operator private.

title: Downhill Roller
description: ''Spratt Decries 21% Drop in Bearing Work Force,'' read the headline on a press release from the office of Representative John M. Spratt Jr., Democrat of South Carolina.

title: MORE QUESTIONS ABOUT MORE POLLS
description: More news organizations are conducting public opinion polls than in any other Presidential election year, and the Democratic caucuses in Michigan have once again raised questions about the role of opinion surveys in covering campaigns.

title: Debt-Relief Plan Opposed
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told Congress today that he strongly disagreed with proposals to forgive some of the third world's debt, now more than $1 trillion.

title: A Skyline Of Carved Chairs
description: SIX years ago, just after he arrived in New York from Poland, the architect and stage designer Jan Jakub Gontarczyk saw an office chair on the street. It had a swivel base and a beautiful Art Nouveau back. He renovated it and gave it to a friend.

title: INSIDE
description: Swaggart Defies Order

title: Sports People; Bruce to Be No. 1
description: The Atlanta Falcons said yesterday that they would make Aundray Bruce, a linebacker from Auburn, the first player to be picked in the National Football League draft on April 24. Coach Marion Campbell reported that the Falcons would immediately begin trying to negotiate a contract and have Bruce signed before draft day. Bruce and his agent, Richard Woods of Mobile, Ala., had a meeting with Falcon officials at the team's training complex at Suwanee, Ga., on Tuesday. The Falcons drew the No. 1 spot in this year's draft by virtue of last year's 3-12 record, worst in the N.F.L. The 6-foot-5-inch, 231-pound Bruce was an All-Southeastern Conference performer at Auburn.

title: Manila Captures 2 Top Communist Leaders
description: President Corazon C. Aquino and military officials claimed a major victory over Communist rebels today after the capture of the rebel army's leader and the Communist Party's No. 2 man.

title: Right Wins a South Africa Vote
description: The far right-wing Conservative Party strongly won a by-election today for a seat in Parliament from the Randfontein voting district in Transvaal Province in South Africa.

title: Tour Is Different With Davies
description: Laura Davies wound up and let fly with one of the longest drives ever seen in women's competition early this month. She paced it off with her brother, Tony, who is also her caddie, and said the ball went 341 yards.

title: Renault Assistance
description: The European Community's executive body has approved French Government aid to the giant auto maker Renault but has set certain conditions on the assistance. The European Community commission approved aid to Renault of 20 billion French francs, or $3.54 billion. The decision marked the end of a two-year investigation into Government assistance to Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, a state agency.

title: Graduate Students Become Tax Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Zarzuela in a More Spacious Setting
description: With its tightly made, small-scaled zarzuela productions, Repertorio Espanol has manufactured virtue from necessity in recent years - the necessity being the company's tiny, if appealingly decrepit, theater on East 27th Street. There has been some spreading out this spring: roughly a third of the showings are moving to new basement premises in the Equitable Tower on Seventh Avenue. This included Sunday afternoon's performance of ''La Corte de Faraon.''

title: Chairman Raises Bid for Flexi-Van
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation said that its chairman and chief executive officer, David H. Murdock, had sweetened his offer to acquire the 68 percent of Flexi-Van's common stock that he does not already own. Mr. Murdock is offering $38.50 a share, or a total of $144 million for the shares. Mr. Murdock had offered a $35 a share in his initial proposal, which was announced last month. Shares of the cargo container leasing company rose $2.625 today, to $38, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Taking a 'Normal' Step, Squibb Names Officers
description: The Squibb Corporation made two major executive appointments yesterday, naming Jan Leschly president and chief operating officer and Dr. Charles A. Sanders vice chairman.

title: Knicks' 3-Pointers Off Mark (and on It)
description: Several times Tuesday night the Cleveland Cavaliers offered the Knicks a victory that would enhance their playoff chances.

title: No Surprise Here: Men Prefer the Mini
description: IF women were dressing to please men, the mini might have made it.

title: Calendar: City Tours, Egg Motifs And Crafts
description: Neighborhood Tours

title: High, HighER, HighEST Fashion
description: MANY of the chicquest models on runways from New York to Paris are donning quirky, sometimes comical glasses. The designs are the brainchild of Alain Mikli, who has garnered a reputation for haute-couture glasses.

title: Japan Dumping of Trucks Charged
description: The Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association charged today that Japanese companies are dumping compact trucks on the American market.

title: Brazil Begins Debt Auction
description: The developing world's most indebted nation began an experimental program this week to swap a small portion of its $112.7 billion foreign debt for equity interests in Brazilian enterprises.

title: Hilton Hotel Chairman Wins Ruling on Stock
description: The California Court of Appeal has ruled in favor of Barron Hilton in his long battle to obtain control of a 27.4 percent block of stock in the Hilton Hotel Corporation that was left by his father, Conrad Hilton.

title: Throwing Out Social Lifelines In Suburbia
description: IN the five months that Shirley Angus has called Stamford, Conn., home, she has made more friends than in the five years she lived in England. ''When I moved to England from South Africa,'' she recalled, ''there was no way to meet people unless you took the bull by the horns and introduced yourself to strangers.''

title: U Conn Beats Ohio St. For Title
description: Steve Pikiell does not look like the type of player who could beat a team as talented as Ohio State. The 6-foot-2-inch guard is a reserve for Connecticut and he enters the game when Coach Jim Calhoun wants to settle the team down.

title: The Size of Museums
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs report on March 15 misstated the stake that the General Electric Capital Corporation holds in the FGIC Corporation. General Electric Capital owns 37.5 percent of FGIC's common stock.

title: General Dynamics Selling Debentures
description: The General Dynamics Corporation is offering $100 million of 9.95 percent debentures due in 2018 at a price of 98.95 to yield 10.061 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: It's a Rosy Night as Mildred Turns 90
description: The thing about Mildred Hilson is that men are mad about her. Not long ago, 21 socially prominent men gave a dinner at ''21'' to honor Mrs. Hilson, grande dame of the diamond brigade. ''It was just Mildred and her men,'' Angier Biddle Duke was saying. ''We wore 'I Love Mildred' T-shirts.''

title: Harcourt Brace Appointments
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said yesterday that Ralph D. Caulo, an executive vice president, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: South Bronx Fire Kills Infant Girl
description: A baby girl was killed and four people, including two firefighters, were seriously injured in a fire early yesterday in the South Bronx that investigators said was apparently caused by careless use of candles in an apartment without electricity.

title: David Tyler Paul, Publisher, 53
description: David Tyler Paul, an editor and publisher of educational books and video programming, died of lung cancer Monday at Abington Memorial Hospital, Willow Grove, Pa. He was 53 years old and lived in Chestnut Hill, Pa.

title: KEY RATES
A Trick Of the Eye
description: AS the popularity of folk art soars, the number of fake paintings and decorative objects on the market has multiplied.

title: Church Embroiled in Yonkers Bias Case
description: ''Look at those marks,'' said Rita Dushock, pointing to two freshly painted orange stripes, 500 feet apart, along the unbroken curb of Valentine Street that forms the southern border of St. Joseph's Seminary. ''That's where the housing will go.''

title: Health: Psychology; The Children of Divorce: Joint Custody Is Found To Offer Little Benefit
description: Flying in the face of the growing movement to give divorced parents joint custody of their children, a new study has found that such arrangements do not necessarily benefit the children and in some cases may even be detrimental.

title: Farm Credit Bank Offering Is Made
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks began offering $2.91 billion of three-month and six-month bonds at par yesterday through various dealers.

title: Meese Inquiry Likely to Be Prolonged
description: The cloud cast over the Justice Department by the investigation of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d will not dissipate any time soon, Mr. Meese's lawyer and others close to the inquiry said today.

title: NASA Considers Big Raise in Shuttle Cargo Rates
description: The Government is considering charging space shuttle customers up to $245 million a flight, nearly three times the current maximum, for carrying cargo into space, a Congressional panel was told Tuesday. There were indications that the idea was meeting stiff resistance.

title: Special Night for Potvin
description: Ever since September, when he relinquished his Islander captaincy and announced his plan to retire this spring, the season has been one long going-away party for 34-year-old Denis Potvin, the most decorated defenseman in the National Hockey League.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Gerald E. Murray has been named executive vice presiden tand assistant general manager of the Chicago office of Porter Novelli, public relations, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group.

title: Devils Are Clicking At the Right Time
