description: Everything is working with the precision of a Swiss watch for the Devils, at the most crucial part of the season.

title: Review/Television; Wallace Stevens: A Poet's Double Life
description: One of the more intriguing aspects of watching ''Voices and Visions,'' public television's 13-part series on American poets, is the discovery of certain patterns and motifs. There is, for instance, the curious phenomenon of the ''double life.'' William Carlos Williams was a world-renowned poet and a practicing pediatrician in a small New Jersey town. Now, tonight at 10 on Channel 13, we have Wallace Stevens (1879-1955), who explored exotic verbal worlds in his poetry while working as a claims lawyer for the Hartford Insurance Group. Produced by Jill Janows and directed by Richard P. Rodgers, ''Wallace Stevens: Man Made out of Words'' is still another splendid addition to a fine series.

title: Eight Keys for Unlocking Title Door
description: Joe B. Hall knows how to win the national championship. And Joe B. Hall knows how to lose it.

title: Soviet Papers Say Armenians Threaten to Continue Strike
description: Armenians threatened to continue a general strike paralyzing the main city of a disputed southern region until the Government agreed to make the region part of Armenia, newspapers reported today.

title: Boy, 14, Is Fatally Shot by His Cousin, 17, in Their Queens Home
description: A 14-year-old boy was shot once in the head and killed by a 17-year-old cousin early yesterday, according to the police, who confiscated a .38-caliber revolver and a full vial of crack in the bedroom the youths shared in their home in South Jamaica, Queens.

title: Hong Kong: A City Bent on Erasing Its Past
description: The only synagogue in Hong Kong - a turn-of-the-century Sephardic building with creamy white walls, marble pillars and graceful buttresses - is facing demolition as developers prepare to build two high-rise apartment towers.

title: The Final Four: Kansas; Jayhawk Fans Are Living in a State of Delirium
description: The Road Trip, like any truly worthwhile college road trip, was planned and executed within hours. Robert (Knobby) Farha, a senior at the University of Kansas and a manager at The Wagon Wheel Cafe, and Shawn Archer, a senior who works downstairs at Pyramid Pizza, were determined to follow their Jayhawks to the Midwest Regional championship. An all-nighter on the road was not going to get in their way.

title: Russian Chess Player Wins At Tournament in New York
description: Vassily Ivanchuk, an 18-year-old international master from Russia, had a clear victory yesterday in the New York International chess tournament at the Penta Hotel.

title: The Jackson Reality
description: The romance of Jesse Jackson's candidacy is running so strong now that it seems ungenerous to point to reality. Here is a black outsider rousing voters, black and white, with a message of hope in change. Here is a candidate with little money running a superb campaign.

title: Big Board Weighs Curbs
description: The New York Stock Exchange is considering new rules to halt trading if the market rises or falls more than a certain amount in one day, John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's chairman, said.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WISHING that someone sleep like a baby may be more of a curse than a benediction. The brain of a sleeping child works differently from the brain of an adult. There is a link between the 3-year-old who sleeps so soundly that he does not wake up when you carry him from the car to the house and get him undressed for bed, and the toddler who frightens the whole family with his screams of terror a few hours after he goes to sleep.

title: Chance for G.O.P. Mischief in Wisconsin Vote Arises
description: Senator Bob Dole's announcement on Tuesday that he was abandoning the Presidential race gave Wisconsin Republicans an opportunity for mischief and Wisconsin Democrats an opportunity for righteous outrage. Neither rose above the temptation. After Mr. Dole's news conference, the state's Republican Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, called The Milwaukee Sentinel to offer his comments. He volunteered a denial that he had ever encouraged Republicans to cross over and vote in the Democratic primary next Tuesday, now that the Bush-Dole race was over. Republicans, he said, should stay in their own party and vote for Vice President Bush. Democrats Suspect a Plot

title: HE VOWS TO STAY
description: The resignations of top Justice Department officials prompted demands from Democrats today that Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d resign, and Republicans expressed concern that Mr. Meese's legal troubles could damage the party's prospects in the fall elections.

title: Alcoa Chairman To Alter Strategy
description: The Aluminium Company of America will concentrate on the business that its name reflects, said Paul O'Neill, the chairman of the company. He said in a letter to shareholders with the company's 1987 annual report that the company would shun the diversification strategy touted by his predecessor.

title: John Clellon Holmes, 62, Novelist And Poet of the Beat Generation
description: John Clellon Holmes, a writer and a poet who was regarded as a spokesman for the Beat Generation, died of cancer yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Competition for Contracts Trims Costs for Pentagon
description: Since 1985, when the Navy ended the General Dynamics Corporation's monopoly on producing the Tomahawk cruise missile and encouraged competition from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the missile's average price has fallen to $653,000, from slightly more than $1 million.

title: Soviet Hints It Might Compromise On Arms Aid to Afghan Guerrillas
description: The Soviet Union has indicated it will consider allowing military aid to continue to reach the Afghan guerrillas after the cutoff date set in a peace accord now being negotiated, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Sports People; Discipline for Layden
description: The Utah Jazz will reprimand Frank Layden after the National Basketball Association's decision to fine the franchise $10,000 for remarks made by the coach. The N.B.A. announced the fine Tuesday for Layden's criticism of the officiating in a Jazz-Nuggets game in Denver earlier this month. David Checketts, president of the Jazz, s said, meanwhile, that he was writing Commissioner David Stern about the incident and would likely appeal the fine.

title: Stainless Steel Surcharge Seen
description: The British Steel Corporation and West Germany's Krupp enterprise plan to introduce a surcharge on stainless steel to reflect higher prices they are paying for nickel, a component of stainless steel, industry sources said today.

title: Dukakis and Jackson Strategies Rest On Differing View of Two-Man Race
description: Recharged by a solid victory in Connecticut, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis looked ahead to Wisconsin and New York primaries, where the outcomes may hinge on whether the Massachusetts Governor can quickly get the race focused as a two-man contest with the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Study on European Borders
description: The 12-nation European Community loses at least $250 billion a year in extra costs and lost economic opportunities by staying divided along national borders, a two-year study has concluded.

title: Metro Datelines; 23 More Lose Jobs In Medical 'Sickout'
description: The city discharged 23 more provisional Emergency Medical Service workers yesterday for taking part in a ''sickout'' early this month to protest work conditions and wages.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Representatives were bipartisan in overwhelmingly approving a $47.9 million aid package for the Nicaraguan insurgents. The vote was 345 to 70. Page A1

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly HUMAN RIGHTS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON NEW AND RENEWABLE SOURCES OF ENERGY - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Peace Corps Is Widening Its Role in Africa
description: At 24, Lori Leonard is younger than most of her students at Chad University.

title: Sanctions On Toshiba Face Veto
description: The Reagan Administration extended its veto threat today to another contentious section of the trade bill that House and Senate conferees are rushing to complete before the Easter recess.

title: NORIEGA APPEARS TO BE PREVAILING IN GENERAL STRIKE
description: The Panamanian Government appeared today to have all but broken protest strikes by middle-class businessmen and public employees.

title: A War for the Hearts and Minds of Our Children; Improve the Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Sri Lanka Chronicle Gets Gingerly Updating
description: Even as armed fighters continue an age-old battle for dominance in Sri Lanka, a team of monks and scholars is updating a 1,400-year-old chronicle that records the origins of the conflict.

title: Old Horse Aqueduct's Hero
description: The King of Aqueduct is old and cranky. It can take him a leisurely 20 minutes to walk the 100 yards from his home in Barn 11 to the track, and he won't stand for being hurried along.

title: Of Cabbages And Kings
description: IN early 19th-century Germany, the architect Friedrich Weinbrenner designed urban palaces and gardens for the ruling family of Baden, in the southwestern part of what is now West Germany. He also devised elaborate schemes to make farming a scientific endeavor. And in the city of Karlsruhe, the capital of Baden, Weinbrenner built neo-classical row houses for the middle class, along with government buildings, theaters, casinos and schools.

title: Tax Savings Seen as Lowering L.I. Electric Rates
description: The Long Island Power Authority would be able to provide electricity more cheaply than the Long Island Lighting Company largely because it would not be required to pay income taxes on its earnings, according to the authority's consultants.

title: Schlesinger to Present Nancy Hanks Lecture
description: Dr. Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian, will give the first Nancy Hanks lecture on Arts and Public Policy on April 13 at 7 P.M. at the National Academy of Sciences, 2101 Constitution Avenue, N.W., Washington.

title: Health; Personal Health
description: For the Zuni Indians of New Mexico, the modern rallying cry is ''Ho Chikwa: Weykkya Hanukwa.'' It means, ''I outran diabetes.'' The popular saying reflects the fact that running and other modes of exercise have become central to the lives of the Zuni, 40 percent of whom develop diabetes by the age of 45.

title: Factory Orders Fall By 0.8%
description: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in February, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent was not a cause for alarm.

title: Sports People; Action Against Patriots
description: A complaint alleging that they violated Federal labor laws during negotiations with the National Football League Players Association last year has been issued against Billy Sullivan, the New England Patriots' president, and against the team itself by the National Labor Relations Board. Sullivan and the Patriots are charged with unlawful union discrimination for waiving the union vice president, Brian Holloway, the day after he appeared on national television and criticized club owners for their bargaining stance. Complaints have previously been filed against all the N.F.L. clubs and against the Dallas Cowboys individually. Hearings on all of the complaints will begin on May 9. . . . Despite negotiating snags, the Sullivan family yesterday appeared close to selling the team to Paul Fireman, head of Reebok International. Lawyers hoped a deal could be signed today.

title: Court of Appeals Sets Aside A Bar to Army's Drug Testing
description: A preliminary injunction barring random drug testing of 9,400 civilian Army employees was set aside by a Federal appellate court Tuesday while it considers the Justice Department's appeal of a lower court order.

title: Swaggart Defies Church Leaders On Suspension
description: The Rev. Jimmy Swaggart will return to the pulpit on May 22, his lawyer said today, defying national Assemblies of God church officials who had suspended him for a year.

title: Advertising; President is Chosen At Times Mirror Unit
description: Francis P. Pandolfi, who began his magazine publishing career while still an M.B.A. candidate at Harvard, is going to join Times Mirror Magazines as president.

title: House Panel Rebuffs Staff on Animal Patents
description: In an unexpected move, a House Judiciary subcommittee today refused to accept a report written by its staff that concluded that Congress should allow the Government to approve patents for new kinds of animals, including those that have been altered through genetic engineering.

title: Experts and Lawyers Differ Over Visits in Baby M Case
description: The visitation hearing in the Baby M dispute ended today, with opposing lawyers and mental health experts sharply divided on the role Mary Beth Whitehead Gould should play in the life of 2-year-old Melissa Stern.

title: Time Reportedly Weighs Unit's Sale
description: Time Inc. is believed to be considering the sale of Scott Foresman & Company, its textbook publishing unit, Wall Street sources said. The company refused to comment. Time bought the company two years ago for $520 million.

title: DELEGATE TALLY
description: Current breakdown of Presidential preference of delegates to national political conventions, compiled by The New York Times. Preferences are based on state laws, party rules, delegates' public statements and projections from early results in caucus states.

title: Got a Question? Just Ask Miss Hall
description: BECAUSE she has just celebrated her 90th birthday, the normally active Elizabeth Cornelia Hall has been even more active than usual.

title: Texaco Said to Examine a Buyout
description: Top executives of Texaco Inc. have taken a close look at a management-led buyout as one way to protect the company's independence, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Nova Is Proposing Polysar Takeover
description: The Nova Corporation of Alberta, frustrated by its inability to take over the Polysar Energy and Chemical Corporation through other means, has made a bid of $1.17 billion (Canadian), or about $994.5 million (American), for the Ontario petrochemical giant. The offer would give Polysar shareholders the equivalent of $22.50 a share.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Business Day on Saturday about the British Petroleum Company inaccurately described a plan to change the name of the Standard Oil Production Company, a subsidiary. Standard Oil Production will be renamed but the new name has not been disclosed. British Petroleum will not be renamed.

A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the aid; a ''no'' was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 179 Democrats and 166 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 65 Democrats and 5 Republicans. title: Cut South Korea's Umbilical Cord
description: LEAD: Although South Korea has been shaken by allegations of financial misconduct by the brother of former President Chun Doo Hwan, the nation's transition to democracy is proving to be smoother than many people expected. Key opposition leaders have reconciled themselves to the ruling party victory in the presidential election late last year.

title: By Vote of 17-2, Panel Urges Senate to Approve Arms Pact
description: By a vote of 17 to 2, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today that the Senate approve the Soviet-American accord banning medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.

title: Leona Maricle, Actress, 81
description: Leona Maricle, a stage and film actress for 40 years, was found dead, apparently of a heart attack, in her Manhattan apartment last Friday. She was 81 years old.

title: Sports People; Schlichter's Woes
description: Art Schlichter, the former Indianapolis Colts quarterback who was suspended by the National Football League in 1983 for gambling, has filed for bankruptcy protection, a television station reported yesterday. Schlichter, who is Ohio State's career passing leader, filed a bankruptcy petition in United States Bankruptcy Court in Columbus, Ohio, listing his debts at about $1 million and his assets at $1,800, station WBNS reported.

title: Review/Theater; Exploring the Travail of South Africa
description: Yes, ''Lost in the Stars'' is painfully dated. The gentle hope of ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' Alan Paton's novel on which the Kurt Weill-Maxwell Anderson ''musical tragedy'' was based, has been crushed by the events in South Africa. Almost 40 years after the play opened on Broadway, the glimmer of reconciliation with which it ends flickers like a liberal pipe dream. Despite all that, however, or partly because of it, the work, even in the uneven production at the York Theater, remains remarkably moving.

title: Review/Recital; Taiwanese Pianist In New York Debut
description: Chiu-tze Lin, a Taiwan-born pianist whose career has been centered in the American Midwest, drew a full house for her debut at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. In works of Mozart, Prokofiev, Schumann and Bach she displayed a strong but not foolproof technique and a hearty tone that sounded - even after allowing for the amplifying effect of this auditorium - big and unforced.

title: Review/Theater; A Fantasy Of Political Violence
description: How should a playwright confront the assassinations and conspiracies that have scarred American life since the 1960's and avoid sounding a trite one-note lament? In her play ''June 8, 1968,'' Anna Theresa Cascio, a dramatist of considerable promise, recasts an event trivialized long ago by television into her own grotesque, funny-sad pop fantasy of what might have happened.

title: Advertising; New Chairman Brings Name Change to Kobs
description: Howard Draft, 34, has been promoted to chairman and chief executive of Kobs and Brady Advertising, which is his honor changed its name to Kobs & Draft.

title: A War for the Hearts and Minds of Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Piano; Sonatas and Songs
description: Maria Meirelles, a Brazilian-born pianist now based in Michigan, returned Monday night to Weill Recital Hall, the scene of her New York debut several seasons ago. On that occasion she offered, in seven concerts, all the Beethoven sonatas. So by comparison, her enormous program Monday night - big sonatas by Schumann and Prokofiev, Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue, short pieces by Villa-Lobos and the whole of Ravel's ''Gaspard de la Nuit'' - might be considered modest.

title: KEY BANKING BILL PASSED BY SENATE
description: The Senate approved landmark legislation today that would radically weaken the 55-year-old law that separates the banking and securities industries.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SLUGGISH drains in sinks and tubs rank high among household annoyances. However, remedies for drain woes are usually simple. If the problem is addressed early, restoring a sluggish drain to full effectiveness or even clearing a drain that has become completely clogged seldom require much skill or effort, and may require only a few tools.

title: Israeli Resigns His U.N. Post To Enter the Political Battle
description: Israel's representative at the United Nations, Benjamin Netanyahu, said today that he had resigned to enter politics.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Tomorrow is Good Friday, Saturday is the first day of Passover and Sunday is Easter. Following are holiday schedules. NEW YORK

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Morristown, N.J., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., said it had completed the consolidation of its Bendix and Garrett units and would sell three divisions with combined annual sales of $200 million to sharpen its focus as a major supplier of aircraft systems.

title: Senate Panel Approves a Budget That Doesn't Eliminate Programs
description: The Senate Budget Committee overwhelmingly approved a $1.1 trillion spending plan for 1989 today in line with many of President Reagan's priorities.

title: Corrections
description: An Associated Press picture in some copies Tuesday accompanying an article on the racketeering trial of Gene Gotti and two co-defendants was published in error. The photographer, who thought he was taking a picture of Angelo Ruggiero, a defendant, photographed a man whose identity could not be learned.

title: Advertising; Account Shifts in Shoes, Cigarettes and Soda
description: There was a bit of account action of interest to those of covetous bent.

title: Review/Cabaret; Steve Ross, Elegant Anachronism
description: The most striking quality about Steve Ross, the singer and pianist who began an extended engagement at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday, is his physical resemblance to Cole Porter.

title: Pirelli Cancels Loan Facility For Aborted Firestone Bid
description: Pirelli S.p.A. has canceled the $2.3 billion loan facility that it had arranged to finance an acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the Swiss Bank Corporation International said today. Pirelli's effort to buy Firestone has been abandoned.

title: A War for the Hearts and Minds of Our Children; Government Subsiized
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MANY years ago I fell in love with a boy who was the sort that didn't so much want to date you as to brand his initials in your forehead with a red-hot iron. He had the hair of Robert Redford and the eyes of Rasputin, and for roughly a year I was completely in his thrall. Then, rather abruptly, the enchantment ended and I came to my senses.

title: Texas Commerce Bancshares Alive and Thriving
description: To the Editor:

title: House Approves the Rehiring Of Dismissed Air Controllers
description: The House approved legislation today that would require the Federal Aviation Administration to rehire 1,000 air traffic controllers who were dismissed after an illegal strike nearly seven years ago.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $47 MILLION TO AID NICARAGUA REBELS
description: House Democrats and Republicans joined forces today and approved a $47.9 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels. The vote was 345 to 70.
